title: ITALY DENOUNCES ARGENTINA ON PURGE REPORT
description: President Sandro Pertini has denounced Argentina's military Government for its statement that thousands of people who disappeared in the 1970's should be considered dead.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES TO DELAY BOTTLE LAW 3 MONTHS
description: Consumers would not pay deposits on beer and soda cans until Oct. 1 under a bill passed this week by the State Assembly.

title: MOZART WORK MAY BE PREMIERED
description: MOZART was the quintessential wonder child. Before he was out of the 18th-century equivalent of rompers, he had been taken by his father, Leopold, through England and most of Europe, where he was feted in the capitals and courts for his virtuosity, his uncanny ability to sight-read and improvise and - to a lesser extent - for his compositions.

title: SETTING RULES ON HOMES AS WORKPLACES
description: EARLY in March, James F. Gillespie, who has lived in Westport, C onn., for 20 years, dashed off an irate letter to the local n ewspaper. He was furious, he said, because town zoning regulations p ermit psychiatrists to operate out of their homes but do not offer t he same privilege to psychologists like himself. Why should he be d enied equal economic opportunity?, he asked.

title: COCKTAILS ON THE TERRACE
description: For those lucky enough to have a terrace in the city, it is a perfect place to entertain friends in warm weather.

title: FIVE ACRES & INDEPENDENCE
description: Prospective buyers who visit the Cape Cod-styled model house at U.S. Home Corporation's Beckett, N.J., development, should be as concerned about the area's soil conditions and rainfall as they are about local schools and mortgage rates. The homes planned for this unusual housing development will not be on standard lots but will sit on 98 minifarms ranging in size from 1.6 to 18 acres.

title: Karen Simonson Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Joy Simonson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Simonson of Washington, was married yesterday to Barton Chase Phelps, son of Julian O. Phelps of Westfield, N.J., and Milton, Vt., and the late Elizabeth Faulk Phelps. Judge Oscar H. Davis of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit performed the ceremony at the Textile Museum in Washington.

title: JAZZ ORGAN: DICK HYMAN
description: Since a Baldwin console organ has been installed in the Market Place at Citicorp Center this week for a series of classical and jazz performances, it was almost inevitable that Dick Hyman, a jazz organist of unusual versatility, should be one of the performers. He gave an early evening concert on Tuesday that showed his relationship to two distinctive jazz organists, Fats Waller and Count Basie, and allowed him to indulge his own fancy for fugues on an eminently appropriate instrument.

title: Cockpit Entrepreneur: Allen E. Paulson
description: BY LANDING GULFSTREAM ON WALLSTREET, THE COMPANY'S CHIEF CASHES IN By AGIS SALPUKAS FOR most of his 61 years, Allen E. Paulson used his hands to earn his keep. When he was younger, he c leaned rooms in a hotel, hawked papers and milked cows. After World W ar II he fixed cars and refurbished old planes.

title: Old and New Meet in Boston
description: At the oldest house in Boston, there's something new. The oldest house is the three-story oak-frame structure built in 1680 that was home to Paul Revere from 1770 to 1800 and is now a museum.

title: ASSORTED MURDERS
description: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST, By Ed McBain. 231 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $13.50. ICE By Ed McBain. 317 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.50. DANCING BEAR By James Crumley. 228 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: JAZZ FOR PICKNICKERS
description: It would be hard to drive past Montclair High School on Park Street without noting the rustic charm of its amphitheater: level after level of rock-slab seats sunk into a grassy hillside.

title: POLISH RIOT POLICE GIRD FOR PROTESTS
description: Workmen put the finishing touches today on reviewing stands for the Government's annual May Day celebrations Sunday, while riot policemen gathered to prevent demonstrations called by the Solidarity underground.

title: Libya Probe Claims a Victim
description: Yet another of Tripoli's tentacles came to the surface in Washington last week. A Federal grand jury indicted Waldo H. Dubberstein, a former Defense Department intelligence officer, charging him with passing military secrets to Edwin P. Wilson, the renegade Central Intelligence Agency operative, and to other agents of the Libyan government.

title: ATLANTIC CITY: SHIPSHAPE MALL
description: ATLANTIC CITY OCEAN ONE, a shopping and restaurant mall shaped like an ocean liner, opened on the Million Dollar Pier here last week. One of those at the opening ceremonies, State Senator William L. Gormley, Republican of Atlantic City, said he hoped the mall would ''demonstrate that businesses can thrive here without gambling and will prompt the construction of other noncasino projects, including hotels.''

title: STAGE: 'DANTON'S DEATH' BY BUCHNER
description: The Classical Stage Company's venturesome appetite for difficult classics of dramatic literature has now led the company to Buchner's ''Danton's Death,'' a seminal work of modern theater.

title: BEIRUT EMBASSY BLAST PROMPTS U.N. SECURITY REVIEW
description: Jack W. Santarelli, the chief of the United Nations' security force, guards what may be the world's most vulnerable diplomatic complex.

title: Claire Van Hanswyk and Robert Hoffman Married
description: Claire Van Hanswyk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Van Hanswyk of Camillus, N.Y., and Robert J. Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Hoffman of East Williston, L.I., were married yesterday at the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church in New York. The Rev. James G. Amos performed the ceremony.

title: A SIGN OF SPRING: THE SHAD RUN
description: EACH spring the blooming forsythia signals the return, not only of the shad but also of the shad fishermen, to the Hudson River. It is a springtime event dating to the Indians.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is always the question, can the octopus so enmesh you that there will always be an arm around you, tugging you from the direction you want to go.

title: SHULTZ IS WILLING TO GO TO DAMASCUS FOR PULLOUT TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was prepared to go to Damascus to discuss a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: CORRUPTION CITED IN WASTE BUSINESS
description: A leading New York-area waste contractor has gone on trial here in one of a series of criminal cases that has put on the public record extensive new accounts of corruption and organized-crime influence in the region's garbage carting industry.

title: Empty Airplanes
description: To The Business Editor: Professor Frederick Thayer's letter of April 17 represents a triumph of theory - his theory - over fact. Competition in the airline industry, he says, not recessions, causes empty seats.

title: Pentagon Official Describes Lie Detectors as Unreliable
description: The Pentagon's chief health official, challenging the reliability of lie detectors, has told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that such devices can only detect stress that ''may result from severe emotional causes other than guilt.''

title: PRESIDENT'S ANTIDRUG TASK FORCES ARE LAGGING BEHIND IN ORGANIZING
description: The plan for 12 special narcotics task forces that President Reagan announced in October, saying, ''The time has come to cripple the power of the mob in America,'' is behind schedule.

title: A TEACHER WEIGHS ROLE IN U.S. SURVEY
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE morning after he returned from the White House, Jay M. Sommer, who speaks 10 languages and teaches four, was talking about science. ''Take, for example, the amount of science that students study at New Rochelle High School, at Scarsdale High School, at Rye, Eastchester,'' he said. ''The programs are rich. If I am comparing, for example, Westchester schools to Atlanta schools or to Cincinnati or to almost any part of the country, except for some schools in the San Francisco area, which are excellent, we are doing very well. But we still need improvement.''

title: Miss Woods, J.E. Mueller Are Married
description: Shauna Colton Woods, daughter of Rear Adm. Mark William Woods, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Woods of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday on Governors Island to John Edward Mueller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond John Mueller of Prairie Village, Kan. Comdr.

title: NUCLEAR REGULATION: THE COURT CHANGED NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: A SELF-HELP GUIDE FOR MANAGERS OUT OF A JOB
description: BACK around the turn of the century, the Park Row Building was M anhattan's loftiest office tower. Now it is a low-budget address fore xecutives with no jobs to go to. No jobs, but an office.

title: FRENCH MUSIC WORKS ITS PLENTIFUL CHARMS
description: The symphonic repertory as we know it is fundamentally Germanic, but no symphony orchestra in the world would find musical life tolerable without the chance to revel now and then in the colors and atmospheres of some choice French scores. Could anyone really get along without Debussy and Ravel?

title: GEORGE BALANCHINE, 79, DIES IN NEW YORK
description: George Balanchine, one of the greatest choreographers in the history of ballet and the co-founder and artistic director of the New York City Ballet, died yesterday.

title: SAYING 'I DO' AND THINKING 'WHO ONE?'
description: IKNOW I don't deserve your sympathy. It's entirely my own fault. P erhaps, though, by unburdening myself, I can save someone else c omparable heartache and anxiety.

title: DERBY MONEY ISSUE HAS A SECOND SIDE
description: The rule restricting the Kentucky Derby to the 20 3-year-olds with the highest career earnings has been widely criticized for keeping lightly raced and late-blooming colts out of the race. It is now apparent that the rule has a converse flaw: keeping rich but wilting horses in the field long past their prime.

title: Alva Gimbel Is Dead; Active Philanthropist
description: Alva Bernheimer Gimbel, an active philanthropist and the wife of the late Bernard F. Gimbel, the board chairman of Gimbel Brothers, died yesterday at her estate in Greenwich, Conn. She was 90 years old.

title: 20,000 VISIT BOTANIC GARDEN AS CHERRY BLOSSOMS BLOOM
description: There was something a bit sad about the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's cherry blossom festival yesterday: Many of the cherry blossoms had not yet bloomed. The harsh April rains had delayed them.

title: Wadkins Leads by 1 After 68
description: Lanny Wadkins, the PGA Tour's leading money winner this season, overcame an early stumble today and shot a three-under-par 68 that gave him a one-stroke lead over Hal Sutton Tom Purtzer going into the final round of the Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: Sports of the Times; Strikeout Arms and the Men
description: HIS number assures Nolan Ryan of being a baseball treasure. His number of strikeouts now is 3,509 and climbing. Whatever the eventual number, it deserves to be carved in marble with 755 (Henry Aaron's homers), 4,191 (Ty Cobb's hits), and 511 (Cy Young's victories).

title: THIS FABLE TURNS INTO A MUDDLE
description: Right at the top, we know that ''V,'' the two-part miniseries beginning at 9 tonight on NBC, isn't just another fling at science fiction. ''To the heroism of the resistance fighters - past, present and future - this work is respectfully dedicated,'' the prologue says. Then ''V'' goes on to nothing less than a retelling of history - the rise of the Nazis, done as a cautionary science-fiction fable. For television, this is probably a first. It is also an ideological muddle.

title: BERGEN BUILDS OWN 'AFFORDABLE' HOUSING
description: WITH a median family income of $27,000 and 70 mostly suburban, residential communities, Bergen C ounty is one of the richest counties in the United States. It also i s one of the toughest areas for families with moderate incomes who a re seeking homes they can afford.

title: SCHOOLS CHIEF VOWS AID FOR CITY PUPILS
description: NEW HAVEN WHILE the nation last week read of a report by a Federal commission that strongly criticized the quality of American education, the newly named State Education Commissioner pledged that Connecticut schools with poor student performances and high drop-out rates will now get priority for state attention and assistance.

title: NEW LIFE FOR JAIL
description: THOUGH it was almost a half-century ago, John F. Green of Danbury vividly recalls life at the old city jail on Main Street. He spent four years there, not as an inmate, but as one of four children of the jailer, the late Martin A. Green.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN MURDER TRIAL OF 4 OFFICERS
description: The prosecution rested its case Friday in the three-week old murder trial of four police officers from nearby Everett.

title: TWINS TOP BREWERS ON 4 IN 9TH
description: Tom Brunansky hit a two-out two-run homer to cap a four-run ninth inning today as the Minnesota Twins scored a 9-7 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: A STORY ASSIGNED BY FATE
description: ELENI, By Nicholas Gage. 470 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: ROCHESTER, ATOP BOOM IN TECHNOLOGY, SEARCHES FOR AN IMAGE
description: The talk here is of money - lots of it. A convention center, $40 million. A Stouffer's motel, $14 million. Two office buildings, $20 million. A huge suburban shopping center, $50 million.

title: Kathryn Corrigan Marries R.A. Woods
description: Kathryn Corrigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Corrigan of New York and Saltaire, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Allen Woods, son of Mr. and Mrs. William David Woods of Encino, Calif. The ceremony was performed at St. James Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, assisted by the Rev. Julian Miller, Roman Catholic chaplain of University Hospital, Stonybrook, L.I.

title: Lucy Yun Shen Wed To C.M. McDermott
description: Lucy Yun Shen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Chung Shen of Howard Beach, Queens, was married yesterday to Christopher Manning McDermott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Manning McDermott of Madison, Conn. Msgr. Thomas J. Gradilone performed the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Last September, Roger Rudnick's nostalgic ''40's in the 80's'' concert series at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack presented a piling of nostalgia on nostalgia that might be considered the ultimate nostalgia extravaganza for those whose nostalgia buttons are triggered by the 40's and 50's. The cast was made up of Peggy Lee, Betty Hutton, Keely Smith, Ella Mae Morse, Margaret Whiting, Johnny Johnston, Gordon MacRae, Andy Russell, the Pied Pipers and Nelson Riddle.

title: Peter Eric Feinberg Wed To Margery Anne Gering
description: Margery Anne Gering, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gering of Livingston, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter Eric Feinberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Feinberg of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbis Alexander Shapiro and Samuel Cohen performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Abraham.

title: A CALL FOR THE U.S. TO CATCH UP IN SPORTS DIPLOMACY
description: A recent newspaper article reported that the United States Government is sending $10,000 worth of basketballs, hoops and nets to the African nation of Burundi. It was just a brief item, hardly big news. But it illustrates how far the United States has fallen behind other countries in making friends through sports.

title: DIVISIVENESS PLAGUES RESORT
description: ATLANTIC CITY RACIAL divisiveness in City Hall, residents and officials say, is blocking progress toward meeting the same basic needs of housing, improved convention facilities and transportation that troubled this resort city even before the gambling casinos arrived in 1978.

title: THE REGION
description: Republicans have long held sway in the New York State Senate, but last week they had things locked up. On orders from Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson, members were rounded up and confined to the chamber for several sessions.

title: AGED-HOME SNAG
description: JEWISH groups will meet this week in an effort to bolster shaky plans to construct Suffolk County's first kosher nursing home. What was to be a $23 million, 300-bed nursing home on the 40-acre campus of the Suffolk Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Commack has been on the drawing board for more than two years. The area's Jewish community felt it had successfully wooed and won the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center of Brooklyn as sponsor and operator of the facility.

title: MAKING MONEY IN 'WHOOPS' BONDS
description: LOS ANGELES GARY J. LUNDGREN'S small Seattle brokerage firm has made more than $3 million before taxes in the last two years by trading exclusively in ''Whoops'' bonds, the tax-exempt securities of the troubled Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: Instructor and Student Die in L.I. Plane Crash
description: A flight instructor and student were killed this morning when their single-engine plane crashed into an open field a mile beyond the runway at Republic Airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: 63 Die in Bangladesh Storms
description: Sixty-three people were killed and more than 500 injured in fierce storms that swept several Bangladesh towns in the last week, according to a Government report issued today.

title: WHERE CARNEGIES RUSTICATED
description: Let it rain and I used to dream as children do of a deep whispering forest where the flowers grew giant-size and the birds spoke in tongues and the vines were so fat they could carry me from a tree to a pony's wild silky back.

title: FORGETFULNESS; The Birds of War
description: Few creatures evoke such reflexive horror as the vulture, sinister in shape and repellent in diet. Joan Didion's mordant book, ''Salvador,'' tells of vultures grown stout on human car-rion.

title: A Quick Viking
description: Joey Browner, the first-round draft choice of the Minnesota Vikings, has signed three one-year contracts. The defensive back from Southern California thus became the earliest a top choice has signed in Viking history -three days after the draft. He is the brother of Ross Browner of the Cincinnati Bengals. ... The knee injury that Georgia's quarterback, John Lastinger, suffered in an intrasquad game a week ago is more serious than was thought and may not be healed in time for the the opening game next fall.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DOUBLE FUTURE FOR GOLD AND SILVER COINS
description: The news out of Washington has been alternately good and bad for those hard-money advocates who are hoping for the issuance of bullion-type United States gold and silver coins. There was good news April 15 when legislation to authorize such coins got strong support at a Senate hearing. However, four days later an influential congressman threw up a major roadblock that seemed to chill chances for early action.

title: A Slow Shuttle To Agreement In Lebanon
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said before arriving in the Middle East last week he would stay as long as necessary to get agreement for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. Later, Mr. Shultz was reporting progress by the ''inch'' or even less. At that rate...

title: ENVIRONEWS: PESTICIDE FIGHT
description: A Pesticide suspected of causing cancer in humans, and believed to be harmful to birds and other wildlife, has been approved for use on 4,375 acres in Burlington and Ocean Counties as part of the state's program for controlling gypsy moths.

title:
DINING OUT;
ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DELAWARE
description: AVISIT to Bucks County, Pa., in late spring can be downright addictive. Riding or cycling down country lanes and over covered bridges, it is hard to believe that such a sylvan setting is just 65 miles from Manhattan. The pleasantest way to savor the area is to stay at one of the little inns along the road skirting the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River.

title: THE ETERNAL BEACH
description: RICHARD HALLORAN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

title: CLASSICS HEAD FOR A MASS MARKET
description: Is there a new recorded classical music boom, one with real mass market potential? The innovative marketing techniques (innovative for classical music, anyway) that have been employed to sell classical cassettes show signs of continued rapid growth, and the latest development is one of the most telling of recent months: classical cassettes, at budget prices, can now be found in dozens of F.W. Woolworth stores in the East. Woolworth, a symbol for years of the mass market, has been convinced by a distributor to stock the cassettes, along with the usual pop music that has been a staple in Woolworth stores for some years.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM Two series of Japanese films begin this week, one featuring the works of a veteran actress and her filmmaker husband, the other honoring two of Japan's most highly esteemed directors. Films featuring Hideko Takamine, who as a child actress was known as ''the Shirley Temple of Japan,'' will be shown at the Japan Society beginning Wednesday.

title: SHIPPING NUCLEAR WASTE IS EVERYBODY'S BUSINESS
description: BY EARLY summer, the United States Court of Appeals is expected to decide a case that will have important implications for the people of New Jersey.

title: SHATTERING MORE THAN GLASS
description: IAM thankful that the Long Island Expressway was not very crowded the other night. If it had been, it is possible, even likely, that I would not be alive today.

title: Argentines Sail for Falklands In Hope of Seeing War Graves
description: Fifty relatives of Argentines killed in the Falkland War set sail today with hopes that Britain would let them visit the graves of Argentines buried on the islands.

title: Alice Comins, Lawyer, Weds James A. Brennan Jr.
description: Alice Louise Comins, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Comins of Ilion, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Andrew Brennan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brennan of Old Westbury, L.I. The ceremony was performed at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Westbury by the Rev. Harry Boyle and Canon Stephen Applegate, an Episcopal priest.

title: ALVARADO PLEDGES SWEEPING CHANGES FOR CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the next Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he intended to make sweeping changes in the way the school system is run -changes that he said would cost some officials their jobs and put a stronger emphasis on students and teachers.

title: IS A 'MAGNIFICENT MOMENT' SLIPPING BY?
description: In a modest suburban living room last week, underground representatives of two leftist parties said recent leadership changes in the Salvadoran Army and the guerrilla movement make this ''a magnificent moment'' for talks among El Salvador's warring factions.

title: Miriam Gill Wed to James R. Stirn
description: Miriam Wellington Gill, daughter of Mrs. William R. Goss of Chicago and the late James William Gill, was married yesterday to James Reid Stirn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles van Syckel Stirn of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, and Snug Harbor, Quebec. The Rev. Bliss Browne and the Rev. James Flemming performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: YET BEING SOMEONE OTHER By Laurens van der Post. 352 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95.

title: NO LAYOFFS, BUT . . .
description: To The Business Editor: I am one of more than 100 employees who were not ''laid off'' from Materials Research Corporation, but who lost their job anyway (''Lifetime Employment, U.S. Style,'' April 17). During the period that the company's sales fell to $60.1 million from $71.6 million, the official word was that no one would be laid off.

title: PASSAIC RECALL IS AUTHORIZED
description: PASSAIC TWO years ago, Robert C. Hare, the incumbent and a former firefighter, defeated Joseph Lipari, a meat broker, by 800 votes in a bid for a second term as Mayor of Passaic.

title: East Harlem to Livingston St.
description: Anthony J. Alvarado preaches an educational philosophy based on the ''expectation of success,'' but he doesn't always practice it. A month ago, he did not believe he had the slightest chance to become New York City's next Schools Chancellor. Two weeks ago, he was congratulating Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. on getting the $85,000-a-year post. But last week, following Mr. Wagner's surprise rejection by the State Education Commissioner and several tumultuous meetings of the Board of Education, Mr. Alvarado found himself succeeding Frank J. Macchiarola as head of the nation's largest school system.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: Mary Louise Montgomery Is Married
description: Mary Louise Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Montgomery of Washington, was married yesterday to Robert John O'Connor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connor of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Howard J. Hansen performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: I must take exception to the statement that ''new recruits are of uneven quality.'' In my 12 years in the Foreign Service, the quality of recruit judged by his or her background has never been higher.

title: WRITING OUT OF THE POLISH AGONY
description: THE WITNESS OF POETRY, By Czeslaw Milosz. 121 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $8.95.

title: THE HUMAN CYCLE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH TV PROGRAMS TO BE SHOWN
description: To many Americans, British television means the exquisitely produced period dramas on the Public Broadcasting Service, such as ''Upstairs Downstairs'' and ''Brideshead Revisited.'' Other viewers associate programming from Britain with the bawdiness of Benny Hill or the zaniness of Monty Python.

title: A CRITICAL TIME FOR FARMERS
description: ''WELL,'' said Paul Young, who owns a tree and plant nursery in Wilton, ''we certainly haven't had to water anything.'' That was a positive attitude for a Connecticut farmer to take toward the wettest of Aprils. From the dairy farmers of Litchfield County to the vegetable growers around New Haven to the nursery owners whose trees, shrubs and plants ultimately grace homes statewide, almost every part of the $303 million-a-year industry suffered under the record rainfall.

title: LILCO AND BOKUM ARGUE IN COURT
description: This article is based on reporting by Dede Feldman and Denise Tessier. It was written by Mrs. Feldman.

title: ALVARADO NOW MATRICULATES IN A TOUGH SCHOOL OF POLITICS
description: The New York City Board of Education listed the attributes it considered important for a new Chancellor in an advertisement in The New York Times on Jan. 30, under ''Careers in Education.'' ''Proven capacity for exercising program leadership including supervising the development of curricula, personnel and management programs,'' it read. ''Sensitivity to community needs.''

title: Cornell Wins, 16-7
description: Kevin Cook scored 5 goals, and Bruce Bruno had 6 assists to help Cornell to a 16-7 lacrosse victory over Princeton today. Cornell, 8-1 over all and 5-0 in the Ivy League, clinched a tie for its 10th consecutive Ivy title.

title: Pastora's Rebels Clash With Nicaragua Forces
description: A Nicaraguan officer said today that army troops had clashed for the first time with guerrilla units under the command of Eden Pastora Gomez, a hero of the Nicaraguan revolution who later broke with the Sandinists.

title: China Tries to Lure Scientists To Remote Parts of Country
description: China is offering better pay and other benefits to attract urgently needed scientists to its remote areas and strategic border regions, two leading newspapers reported today.

title: CONSUMER RATES
JERSEY SCHOOL SETS RECORD
description: Carl Lewis won the invitation 100-meter dash at the Penn Relays today, but he was more excited over the second championship victory by his alma mater, Willingboro High School of New Jersey. He took a victory lap round the Franklin Field track with Willingboro's winning 3,200-meter relay foursome.

title: MAJOR CRIMES FALL 9.9% IN COUNTY IN '82
description: THE number of major criminal offenses reported in the county dropped by 9.9 percent last year, to 39,233 from the 43,558 reported in 1981, according to preliminary figures released by the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services. Violent crimes - murder and negligent manslaughter, rape, robbery and assault - declined by 2.5 percent, to 3,177 in 1982 from 3,259 the year before. It was the first decrease in that category since 1979. The 1981 figure was a record for violent crime in the county since the early 1970's.

title: Miss Foxen, a Banker, Weds Frederic J. Dunn
description: Elizabeth A. Foxen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Foxen of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Frederic J. Dunn, son of Family Court Judge John J. Dunn and Mrs. Dunn of West Islip, L.I. The Rev. Stephen O. Babos of Fordham University performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Gone But Not Forgotten
description: As a Senate committee was preparing for this week's confirmation sessions with William D. Ruckelshaus, nominated to head the Environmental Protection Agency, a House panel took steps to force a former agency official to testify.

title: PLEASURE AND DAZZLEMENT
description: SEASONAL RIGHTS By Daniel Halpern. 69 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $12.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95. THRONE/FALCON/EYE By Hugh Seidman. 67 pp. New York: Random House. $10. ON TOUR WITH RITA By Nicholas Christopher. 110 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: Alliene Johnson Is Wed
description: Alliene Claire Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Davis Johnson of Port Jefferson, L.I., was married yesterday to Timothy Francis Klimczyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark J. Klimczyk of Olean, N.Y. The Rev. Stanley Larson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Port Jefferson, assisted by the Rev. Donald Le Clerc, a Roman Catholic priest of Port Jefferson.

title: VILLANOVA'S REIGN ENDED BY ARKANSAS
description: For years, the Penn Relays had been a showcase for Villanova's runners. The Wildcats from Philadelphia's suburban Main Line often won three, four or five of the eight championship relays for men.

title: 'Age of Vulnerability' On The Job
description: Ruth Farabaugh's article, ''It's an Age of Vulnerability'' (Opinion Page, April 3), moved me deeply. She reports that she is an idealist, who gives her job, and her life, everything she has; does everything according to the rules, but has been passed over for a promotion, and denied the recognition she knows she has earned.

title: A FAMILY'S HISTORY IS ENCAPSULATED BY ITS RECEIPTS
description: THIS is silly, I thought to myself, as I looked at the boxes of receipts and copies of every transaction ever made since my marriage many years ago. As I dragged the boxes to the better light of the attic window, I mentally blamed my mother for the ''don't-throw-anything-out-you-may-need-it-someday'' syndrome that I inherited.

title: TESTING THE WATERS AS BOAT CARPENTERS
description: THE Suffolk County Department of Labor and the Coecles Harbor Marina of Shelter Island have donated an 18-foot flat-bottomed wooden skiff to the Town of Shelter Island and a similar boat to the Mashomack Preserve on Shelter Island. The boats are products of a job training program sponsored by the Labor Department in which seven unemployed men acquired skills in boat carpentry and repair, which are in demand on the East End.

title: Not an 'Us' And Not a 'Them'
description: Regarding ''Us and Them, But Not Invariably,'' by Zoe Kamitses (Opinion Page, April 17), I'm a happy customer - the baggy Levi size 7. but I'm not a ''them'' and I'm not an ''us.''

title: INDUSTRY SEES THE DARK SIDE OF REGULATION
description: ''Is excessive government regulation strangulating your business?'' a Chamber of Commerce brochure once asked its members. ''If Federal 'red tape' has your hands tied, we can help.'' Indeed, the chamber was among the leaders in the effort to ''get the government off the backs of the people,'' and applauded President Reagan's deregulatory efforts.

title: Formula to Pick Derby Starters
description: To the Sports Editor: I am a great fan of horse racing and the Kentucky Derby.

title: Liverpool Bows But Wins Title
description: Liverpool clinched the English soccer championship title Saturday for the sixth time in eight seasons despite losing, 2-0, at Tottenham.

title: EIGHT YEARS OF A 'PAINTERLY' PHOTOGRAPHER
description: AN ace at a trade sometimes gains a double definition, such as a painter's painter. Jan Groover's definition doesn't exactly match, for she might be a painter's photographer. In an essay about her work for the catalogue of her eight-year retrospective at the Neu Neuberger Museum in Purchase (through June 12), Alan Trachtenberg discloses that Miss Groover welcomes being termed a ''formalist'' and ''painterly.''

title: A CRISIS OF IDENTITY
description: JUST when I had begun to feel comfortable with my role as a freelance writer, secure in my creative output, the crisis over my true identity erupted.

title: Rita Patrice Campanile Weds Thomas McCaffrey
description: Rita Patrice Campanile, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Pasquale S. Campanile of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Thomas M. McCaffrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McCaffrey of Wilbraham, Mass. Archbishop Giovanni Cheli, Papal Nuncio and head of the Holy See's observer mission to the United Nations, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTE DUE ON TAX-CREDIT BILL
description: AN INNOVATIVE bill that would offer tax credit as an incentive for corporations in the state to invest in work by New Jersey artists is expected to reach the Assembly floor for a vote this month.

title: TRYING TO SAVE ZILCHBURG
description: THE TRUTH ABOUT THE NEUTRON BOMB, The Inventor of the Bomb Speaks Out. By Sam Cohen. 226 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.50. THE NEW HIGH GROUND, Systems and Weapons of Space Age War. By Thomas Karas. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: SCHOOL GARBAGE PLAN STUDIED
description: OFFICIALS of the Shoreham-Wading River School District have proposed building a resource-recovery facility on school property that would convert about 100 tons of garbage daily to electricity and heat for the district's high school and public library.

title: 'PORGY AND BESS' FINDS ITS SHOWCASE AT RADIO CITY
description: Porgy, the luckless but eternally game hero of ''Porgy and Bess,'' may feel that the life stretching out before him is a long, lonesome road. As I stared about me at Radio City Music Hall, though, I had the pronounced feeling that Porgy's road was getting less lonesome all the time. This trip around (fourth version I've seen), the George and Ira Gershwin opera is being raptly attended by more people per performance than can have been packed into any auditorium since that all-embracing arena at Epidaurus shut up shop a few thousand years ago (only to reopen a little while back, which is the way things go with the theater).

title: CUBAN TIES BOATLIFT TO DRUG TRADE
description: The Cuban Government used the 1980 Mariel boatlift to send as many as 7,000 spies to the United States, some of whom were ordered to help drug smugglers ''flood'' this country with illegal narcotics, one such spy said today.

title: FEW CLUES IN MARCH SLAYING OF OWNER OF 'VILLAGE' CLOTHES SHOP
description: Shortly after noon on March 11, Roberta Kaplan, the owner of Arabella, a Greenwich Village boutique, was stabbed to death during an apparent robbery in her shop at 135 West Third Street. She had been stabbed in the chest and hands. The cuts on her hands indicated that she may have struggled with her killer.

title: Conquering Cambridge
description: It may have been 20 years since Betty Friedan made her mark as a feminist, but she proved more than equal to the task of defending her creed against the ''foppish humor'' of Cambridge students. Members of the Cambridge Union Society irritated Mrs. Friedan, who wrote ''The Feminine Mystique'' two decades ago, with sexist jokes and whimsical treatment of the subject of their debate, the question of whether feminism is good for men. Though she put them in their places right enough, she thought she had lost the contest until the vote was recounted last weekend and she emerged an overwhelming winner, 123 to 56.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at Shea Stadium, 126th Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:30 P.M. Tom Seaver will pitch for the Mets on Bat Day. (SportsChannel and WTBS 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. (Television - Channel 11, 3 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 3 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 3:30 P.M. Game 4 of Eastern Conference semifinal series. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M., WNEW 1130 3:30 P.M.) Bucks vs. Boston Celtics, at Milwaukee. The Bucks hold a 2-0 edge. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Boxing Alex Ramos vs. J.B. Williamson, 10 rounds. middleweights, and Johnny Verderosa vs. Reyes Cruz, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Edwin Rosario vs. Jose Luis Ramirez, 12 rounds, lightweight championship, San Juan, P.R. Rosario (17-0) and Ramirez (64-3) are fighting for the W.B.C. title vacated by Alexis Arguello. (Television - Channel 7, 4:45 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Gold, at Denver. (Television - Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.. Radio - WOR-AM, 710; 1:30 P.M.).

title: Cost Overrun Predicted For Seabrook Plant
description: The troubled Seabrook nuclear power plant will cost at least $8 billion, nearly $3 billion more than the builder estimates, the State Public Utilities Commission predicted Friday.

title: CELTICS FADE BADLY
description: There was no better way to describe what happened to the Celtics at Boston Garden Friday night than the comment by Charlie Criss, the substitute guard of the Milwaukee Bucks:

title: OPERA: 'EURIDICE' PERFORMED BY MANNES CAMERATA
description: The Mannes Camerata gave us the second annual installment of its promised series of early operas Friday night at Park Avenue's Christ Church. Last year's offering was Gagliano's ''Dafne'' and scheduled for 1984 is ''La Galatea'' by Vittori. But Friday the Mannes group, under the direction of Paul Echols, went back to opera's ultimate beginnings - ''Euridice'' by Jacopo Peri.

title: A Path Out of the Secret War
description: Taken at his word, President Reagan has given Congress the advice it needs when it reviews America's involvement in a secret war against Nicaragua. In his definition of Central American policies last week, the President didn't deny the undeniable. He insisted the operations were lawful and limited to the objective of interdicting any arms traffic from Nicaragua to guerrillas in El Salvador and elsewhere.

title:
GARDENING;
3 POPULAR HEDGES: PRIVET, YEW, HEMLOCK
description: THE three most commonly used hedging plants in this region are privet, yew and hemlock. All three are satisfactory for both the formally clipped and the informally natural hedges.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The Dow Jones average raced past the 1,200 mark for the first time ever as investors barreled into the market in full force. Oil stocks - buoyed by Soviet and Egyptian price increases - led a one-day, 22-point advance that carried the Dow to 1,209.46. It climbed still further on the strength of technology and blue-chip stocks and closed the week at 1,226.20, up 29 points. It has been a rousing time for the stock market - the Dow is nearly 60 percent higher than its August 1982 low - and one that many believe will continue as retirement account money and still-large cash holdings flow into Wall Street. Says Greg Smith of Prudential-Bache: ''The stock market only needs prospects of a recovery, lower bond rates and cash from I.R.A.'s to keep it happy.''

title: REDISCOVERING THE ERA OF WOODEN BOATS
description: TERENCE SMITH is editor of the Washington Talk page of The New York Times.

title: Reagan a Frat Man
description: A 6-foot-1-inch pledge was inducted yesterday into Phi Slama Jama, the University of Houston's slam-dunking basketball fraternity, but only after making sure there would be no bizarre initiation rites.

title: Philippine Journalist Released After 18 Days
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ordered the release under house arrest of Antonio Nieva, a journalist who had been held 18 days in a military stockade for purported Communist ties.

title: WHEN MOTHERS GIVE UP CUSTODY
description: ''ICOULDN'T go past a Little League ball game without crying,'' the woman told a group of 14 mothers who, like herself, live apart from their children. ''In a social sense, I couldn't relate to anyone. I was like a wounded animal.''

title: BEING YOUR OWN BOSS - WITH BENEFITS
description: ''F REEDOM,'' ''self-fulfillment'' and even ''off the books'' are all familiar lyrics from the siren song of self-employment, but ''fringe benefits'' generally is not. Indeed, many of those eager to be their own boss only belatedly ask how they can replace the benefits that come with being someone's employee.

title: NEW U.S. JOBS ACT GEARS UP FOR OCT. 1
description: ''WE'VE been off and rolling since we first heard about it,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week, discussing the county's efforts to implement the new federally financed Job Training Partnership Act, which replaces the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act. ''Some people have said it's like son of CETA and downplayed it. But I have great hopes for it.''

title: A STATE'S ESTIMATE OF HEALTH'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: WAITER'S JOB IN PALESTINE WAS 'DREAM' OF KAFKA'S
description: Franz Kafka would have been 100 years old on July 3, and publishers in the United States, Western Europe and Israel are not going to let the centennial of the enduring Czechoslovak novelist -whom Herman Hesse in 1920 called ''the uncrowned king of German prose'' - go unnoticed.

title: Jay Teagle and Alastair Keith, Banker, Are Married in Church in Palm Beach
description: Jayne Will Teagle, daughter of Mrs. Page W. Smith of Palm Beach, Fla. and the late Walter C. Teagle Jr., of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Alastair James Keith, son of Lord Keith of Castleacre, Norfolk, and Lady Ariel Keith of London. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph Warren Jr. at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach.

title: Joe Berardi Captures Firestone Bowling Final
description: Fourth-seeded Joe Berardi of Brooklyn won four straight matches today, averaging 216 to capture the third major bowling title of his career, the $200,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions.

title:
CAMERA;
A PRIMER ON VIEWFINDERS AND FOCUSING SCREENS

HOME DESIGN;
LIVING IN GRANDEUR
description: The clothes closets are in the dining room. The kitchen used to be a spare bedroom. In the small salon, which doubles as the apartment's only bedroom, one pair of double doors leads to a shallow shoe closet and another leads to a blank wall.

title:
GARDENING;
3 POPULAR HEDGES: PRIVET, YEW, HEMLOCK
description: THE three most commonly used hedging plants in this region are privet, yew and hemlock. All three are satisfactory for both the formally clipped and the informally natural hedges.

title: EDITOR PURCHASES OAKLAND TRIBUNE
description: Robert C. Maynard announced today that he had completed his purchase from the Gannett Company of The Oakland Tribune, where he has been editor since 1979 and publisher since 1981.

title: FIVE ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS SUING TO BAR COMPLEX IN MEADOWLANDS
description: The National Audubon Society and four other environmental groups filed suit in Federal Court here today seeking to halt a multimillion-dollar construction project in the Hackensack Meadowlands by the Hartz Mountain Development Corporation.

title: One Basket for Foreign Trade?
description: In the matter of the United States' import-export difficulties, the Reagan Administration last week did a classic bureaucratic turn: It reorganized its organization chart.

title: JUST WHO OWNS FEDERAL COAL ANYWAY?
description: The Reagan Administration has provided a rich vein of benefits to the nation's coal industry, if not quite the bonanza for which the operators were hoping. But to a growing number of critics, the vein has been too rich by far.

title: SWEET DESSERTS
description: Fresh, ripe fruit - whether simply garnished or elaborately turned out in a delicate pastry - enhances summer meals. olor is what summer desserts are all about, the luscious, vivid colors of summer: golden and ruby raspberries, purple-black figs, apricots, pink peaches, pale green melons and brilliant red strawberries. For decorating there are bright flowers such as bachelor buttons, delphiniums, roses or lilies, and greens with beautiful shapes, such as ivy or nasturtium leaves.

title: A 'BIRTHDAY BASH' FOR BRAHMS
description: THIS is the year the music world is celebrating the 150th anniversary of Johannes Brahms's birth. And while the composer didn't have any Long Island roots, the Sea Cliff Chamber Players do. So on Saturday, his actual birth date, the Players, complete with official Nassau County proclamation, will stage a ''Brahms Birthday Bash,'' a four-hour marathon concert at the C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater in Brookville.

title: TEACHERS LOBBYING FOR BARGAINING BILL
description: TRENTON Several hundred members of the New Jersey Education Association will meet with their Assemblymen here Thursday in an effort to win passage of a bill that would significantly broaden the scope of public-employee negotiations.

title: IN A NERVOUS WORLD ECONOMY, POLAND IS ACUTELY DEPRESSED
description: In Poland last week, everything seemed scarce except tension as May Day and the threat by underground Solidarity leaders of fresh demonstrations drew near.

title: A VIRTUOUS WOMAN'S SLIDE FROM GRACE
description: OCCASION OF SIN, By Rachel Billington. 315 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95.

title: MISSILES SET OFF MILD DEBATE IN SICILY
description: This serene center of a prosperous agricultural district has all the trappings of a city in southern Italy: churches more numerous and imposing than one would expect in a community of 28,000, a central piazza around a modest fountain dominated by a stately town hall, a variety of clubs whose storefront quarters serve as social centers for men, and a sense of prevalent conservatism - even though 42 percent of its population voted for the Communist Party in the last election.

title: FROM FRENCH, MANHATTAN REGIONS
description: THERE are restaurants that justly provoke anger, and they do so for various reasons. It might result from the contempt some managements show for their clientele, a superciliousness intended to intimidate, to make diners feel that they are there by special privelege. At such places, humbled guests are buffaloed into grateful acceptance of often carelessly prepared or defrosted food.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: CHARLEY is one of those people I have known for years, but in the way that you know neighborhood people with whom you are friendly but whose interests common to yours remain yet undiscovered. So Charley and I have reduced our conversation to the lowest common denominator of all human discourse: the weather. I've talked weather with Charley for years, and rarely has this led to disagreement or heightening of suspicion on either side. It is well known that weather is indisputably there and not necessarily cause for debate.

title: THE SUMMER SUIT
description: Above: Blazer, $300, and slim skirt, $125, both in linen, by Donna Karan and Louis Dell'Olio for Anne Klein & Company. At Bloomingdale's.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: MIGRATIONS OF THE HEART By Marita Golden. 234 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: No OTB Bets For the Derby
description: Anyone who wants to place a legal bet on the Kentucky Derby next Saturday will have to do it through the parimutuel windows here. The board of directors at Churchill Downs announced today that there would be no offtrack or other-track wagering on the 109th Derby.

title: Reagan Selects an Envoy
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Robert Keating, a consultant to the general counsel's office at the Navy Department, to be Ambassador to Madagascar and the Comoro Islands.

title: HOST NATIONS TRADE BONES FOR BENEFITS
description: In the animal kingdom, the instinct to stake out real estate and defend it against intruders is called the territorial imperative. No creature is more territorial, it seems, than that suborder of the human species, paleontologist. Where they dig becomes the center of a professional universe. It is with good reason that the acreage is guarded jealously and, on rare occasions violently, as in the socalled Dinosaur Wars of the late 19th century, when the crews of Edward D. Cope and Othniel C. March fought over dig sites in Wyoming and Colorado.

title: John Abernethy Wed To Tracey Anne Smith
description: Tracey Anne Smith, daughter of Mrs. Joseph E. Smith of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Mr. Smith, was married yesterday to John Abernethy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Abernethy of Kingston, N.Y. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: SPLASH FOR THE WEEKEND BRUNCH
description: BRUNCH, an all purpose weekend excuse for a late breakfast or lunch, has only two requirements. First, some wine or spirits must be hidden in a glass of tomato, orange or grapefruit juice and second, you must serve eggs. The only permissible exception to the egg rule is a platter of bagels, cream cheese and smoked salmon.

title: UNION CHIEF TELLS PUBLISHERS HOW TO RUN THEIR BUSINESSES
description: The publishers of the nation's 1,710 daily newspapers, meeting last week in New York City, were told that they should be delivering a free weekly paper to every home in their city because such ''shoppers'' are wonderful vehicles for advertising.

title: PEACE DESERVES A TRY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction
description: The Perspectives column on brownstone assessments last Sunday incorrectly reported the financial situation at the 10-unit building in the West 80's purchased by Eric Witkin, a lawyer, and his wife, Regina.

title: HEART-DIET COURSES
description: NO SALT tomato paste, low-fat cheese, low-cholesterol bologna. These and other products new to supermarket shelves are a response to demands from a growing number of consumers who are changing their diets to lessen the chance of heart disease.

title: WINDUPS, OPENERS AND A RARE RECITAL
description: MAY is farewell time in the concert world, and this week marks the last chance to hear some of Connecticut's finest ensembles before the summer break.

title: IS A HOUSE ON A BARGE PRACTICAL?
description: AVIEW of the New York area's beautiful harbors and coastline is a h ighly prized feature of any house or apartment. But moving right o nto the water, given the area's blustery winters, is a way of life m ost people dismiss as too difficult.

title: T.W. Wilson Jr.  Weds Miss Lynn
description: Marjorie Lynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Lynn of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Thomas Winfield Wilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson, also of Bethesda. The Rev. Orville E. Chadsey performed the ceremony at the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church.

title: A Banker Married To Chris Caldwell
description: Carol Christopher Caldwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Caldwell of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., was married yesterday to Michael Russell Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Conrad Zimmerman of Summerville, S.C. The Rev. George W. Long Jr. performed the ceremony at the Lookout Mountain Presbyterian Church.

title: Iron Bars, Iron Beds
description: The nation's prisons are bursting at the seams, but states can at least shuffle inmates around in search of an unoccupied cot. This is one possible conclusion to be drawn from a Justice Department report last week that the prison population reached an all-time high in 1982 and a Supreme Court decision that states can transfer prisoners to other states even if the move cuts family ties.

title: A MOVIE AND ITS SOUNDTRACK AREN'T ALWAYS IN HARMONY
description: Even in this age of record-business recession, the presence of a commercially viable soundtrack LP can bolster the financial fortunes of a film. Partly for this reason, and partly from a renewed interest by directors and producers in the musical as a cinematic form, we have been deluged recently with film soundtrack albums. Three examples for the past couple of months help illuminate the shifting relationships between musical films and their aural documentation.

title: Siren's Song of Spring
description: It used to be said that birds sing in the spring from hearts flooded with joy, but lately scientists claim that birds are virtual mechanisms singing only as a territorial device. (We are inclined to split the difference and suggest that they sing from the joy of territoriality.)

title: BISHOPS TO FINISH ATOM ARMS LETTER
description: The country's Roman Catholic bishops are set to conclude their arduous, sometimes stormy formulation of a pastoral letter that is sharply critical of nuclear arms.

title: NEW LOOK AT NEWPORT
description: The Rhode Island resort city of Newport is far from being short on ways to orient the visitor. There are tours by bus and tours by boat, rail tours and walking tours. Yet, during the last year or so, two new entries have joined the ''getting-to-know-Newport'' race. One is a dramatic, 90-minute tape you can rent, along with a tape deck, for touring about town in your own car. The other is an elaborate, 25-minute slide show called ''Here's Newport,'' with Douglas Fairbanks Jr. as the voice-over host.

title: Mailbox; Martin Sours Longtime Fan
description: To the Sports Editor: My personal thanks for Ira Berkow's fine column on Billy Martin (''Martin Is Yankee Symbol,'' The New York Times, April 7). It surely articulated the feelings of many longtime Yankee fans who are finding it harder and harder to stay Yankee fans.

title: DEBUT OF JOFFREY BALLET HAS LOS ANGELES AGOG
description: New York's Joffrey Ballet is opening its first season as a resident dance company in Los Angeles, becoming the first major dance company with home bases in two cities.

title:
SEASONAL SETTINGS;
The bright colors of the season are an attractive complement to the food.
description: Much of the appeal of summer fare has to do with where and how it is eaten. A lobster, for instance, served at a table on a cold winter's day, cannot compare to one eaten at a clambake by the sea. So, too, with the tableware of summer, which, like the gear for a clambake shown here, should be as festive and informal as the occasion itself.

title: VARIATIONS ON THE BARBECUE
description: Barbecues are distinguished from both grilled and spit-turned foods and, although associated with this country, are, in fact, international. In certain sections of this country, the word barbecue is used to imply almost any meat, poultry, game or fish that is cooked over charcoal or on a spit.

title: Free Press, Fair Trial (Con't.)
description: No news isn't always good news, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled last week. In fact, ''an atmosphere of secrecy...undermines the public trust,'' the state's highest judicial tribunal concluded in ordering pretrial proceedings in criminal cases open to reporters except in what lawyers described as extraordinary circumstances.

title: AUTO INSPECTION BILL FACING OPPOSITION
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the State Senate last week passed, 23 to 5, a bill giving motorists the option of having their cars inspected at private garages and paying $10 to $12 for the privilege, the measure may have tough going in the Assembly.

title: REPORT SAYS FEDERAL WIRETAPS ROSE 23% IN '82
description: Federal prosecutors increased their use of court-approved telephone wiretaps and other eavesdropping devices by nearly one-fourth last year, according to an annual report on electronic surveillance published by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.

title: Yarborough Gets Pole For the Winston 500
description: Cale Yarborough, the fastest driver, will head the fastest field in the history of stock car racing when it takes the green flag Sunday at Alabama International Motor Speedway for the Winston 500 Grand National race.

title: Frances Marie Phelan Marries David M. Walton
description: Frances Marie Phelan, daughter of Frances M. Phelan of Port Washington, L.I., and the late John R. Phelan, was married yesterday in New York to David Munson Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Walton 3d of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: GILBERT, SULLIVAN AID THEATER
description: IN its first appearance in the county, one of the nation's leading amateur Gilbert and Sullivan companies will present ''Princess Ida'' at the Irvington Town Hall Theater on Saturday. The benefit performance by the Blue Hill Troupe will aid in the renovation of the historic theater, which is modeled after Ford's Theater in Washington and occupies the third floor of the Town Hall.

title: MUSCOOT MAY DAY
description: A host of bucolic activities in celebration of May Day have been scheduled for the opening of Muscoot Farm at 10 A.M. today. The 28-room manor house and turn-of-the-century farm owned and operated by the county's Recreation Department will welcome visitors for free to special programs from noon to 4 P.M.

title: DANCE: THE RUSH COMPANY
description: The members of Patrice M. Regnier's Rush Dance Company did a lot of well-disciplined rushing about Wednesday night in the Space at City Center. But their rushings seldom had much point or impact.

title: Beckenbauer Is Set For Cosmos Opener
description: Franz Beckenbauer was skiing in Switzerland last February when the Cosmos were training in the Bahamas for the North American Soccer League season. Today, Beckenbauer will be playing soccer at Giants Stadium when the Cosmos play their home opener against the Montreal Manic. How well he will play in his first league game with the Cosmos in nearly three years is a question not even Beckenbauer can answer yet.

title: Resisting Cancer
description: Richard A. Bloch, a co-founder of H. & R. Block - the tax preparation chain that spells the family name phonetically - was 52 years old when a doctor told him he had lung cancer and would die. Mr. Bloch rejected the death sentence, sought the best medical advice possible and had the upper lobe of his right lung removed. That was in 1978.

title: Rare Camel Born in St. Louis
description: A healthy twin-humped Bactrian camel has been born at the St. Louis Zoo. Only about 200 of the camels exist in the wild. The camel, weighing 80 pounds. was born to a zoo inhabitant April 11.

title: Effects of Education on Prejudice
description: It was perfect timing that Denis E. Dillon's article, ''Prejudice Is No Prank'' (Opinion Page, March 27), appeared just a few days after a conference, ''Reducing Prejudice: A Matter of Education,'' was held for educators and youth group leaders in Suffolk County.

title: CHICAGO'S ACTIVIST CARDINAL
description: WHEN the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States convene in Chicago tomorrow to vote on a pastoral letter on nuclear warfare, their action will climax a two-year battle led by Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, principal architect of the controversial declaration, who has fought for it as head of the bishops' committee that has seen it through three drafts. On that front, another and longer campaign is just beginning: The Cardinal sees the document, which will be distributed to parishes later this year, as a platform for continuing instruction and debate among the nation's 50 million Catholics. His long-term objective is the transformation of the Catholic Church in the United States into a ''peace church,'' and his public pursuit of that objective has brought him into conflict with some of his ecclesiastical colleagues and under severe criticism from the Reagan Administration.

title: ASKING FOR MONEY GRACEFULLY
description: WHEN I turned 29, I made a list of everything I was still afraid of doing. At 30 I began doing them. I wrote a novel, learned to dance and sing and attempted to duplicate my mother's rice pudding. But it took until I was 31 to volunteer to ask people for money.

title: Ellen O'Hare Is a Bride
description: Ellen O'Hare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James O'Hare of West Lebanon, N.H., was married yesterday in West Hartford, Conn., to Robert Hoskins Rogers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers of Fairfield, Conn.

title: PORTISCH'S BLUNDER
description: The most disheartening, most disastrous blunder of the quarterfinal matches for world championship contenders was Lajos Portisch's 52d move of his fourth game with Viktor Korchnoi in Bad Kissingen, West Germany.

title: The Perils Of Progress
description: At Boston's Brigham and Women's Hospital, technology may have made doctors too clever by half. Research published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week found that physicians misdiagnosed nearly a quarter of the studied cases of patients who died there, thanks partly to fancy new techniques.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE Tricentennial Ball was the kind of affair people talk about long after the band has played ''The Party's Over.'' Held last weekend at the Rye Town Hilton, it was a 300th birthday bash for the county that, in the words of one guest, ''was without a doubt a capital H 'happening.' '' There was a room decorated in red, white and blue and one in shiny space-age silver; there was a fife and drum corps and a remote-control robot, and there were 750 guests ranging from local merchants to Rodman C. Rockefeller, son of the late Governor of New York.

title: BOLAND IS CENTER STAGE, LIKE IT OR NOT
description: As President Reagan was walking down the center aisle of the House Wednesday night, Representative Dan Rostenkowski threw his arm around Representative Edward P. Boland and, catching the President's eye, pointed playfully at the Massachusetts Democrat. Mr. Boland squirmed uncomfortably at all the attention as his colleagues laughed.

title: The Art of Decorating Eggs
description: It was with much interest that I read the article on Polish egg decorating done by Stephanie Kostecki Costanzo (''Decorating Eggs: A Folk Art Updated,'' April 3).

title: OLD SALES OF INDIAN LAND DECLARED FINAL
description: Once sovereigns of the continent, American Indians have become plaintiffs in the courts of their conquerors. Their numbers and power diminished and largely beyond the reach of litigation, the tribes have sought the return of ancestral lands or payment for their losses. The going has never been easy. It is going to get harder, for President Reagan's veto last month of a Congressional settlement with the Pequot tribe in Connecticut has thrown in doubt the accepted method for resolving the claims. An attempt to override may take place this week.

title: CONTINENTAL (THAT INCLUDES ASIA)
description: JACOB'S in Baldwin is a modest new Continental restaurant with an atmosphere that is warm and friendly enough to make it appealing despite a somewhat austere setting, and a menu that is diversified enough to make it interesting. Cooking is far from flawless, but efforts are made so that it has a certain originality. After its two and a half months of operation, a regular clientele seems to be developing - encouraged, it would seem, by the menu's moderate righthand column.

title: LABOR PARTY FINDS AN ELECTION ISSUE IN BRITISH RAIL
description: It's been a century and a half since the world's first public passenger rail service was introduced on 38 miles of track between Stockton and Darlington. These days, the British rail system has 11,000 miles of track, but it also has mounting deficits, labor disputes, worsening service and shaky revenues.

title:
STAMPS;
TWO NATIONS PAY TRIBUTE TO OUR GERMAN SETTLERS
description: A commemorative for the 300th anniversary of the arrival of the first German settlers in America has been issued jointly by the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany. The stamps continue a pattern of joint issues that in the past 12 months has found the Netherlands and Sweden joining the United States to commemorate common historic moments.

title: Nobody Here But Us Fish
description: The Soviet navy, submarine division, has been showing extraordinary curiosity about Nordic waters at least since 1981, so last week, having had enough, the Swedes dropped a diplomatic depth charge and yesterday the Norwegians were dropping real ones.

title: THESE BRITISH DRAWINGS ARE A ROYAL FEAST FOR THE EYES
description: It is no longer novel to travel to SoHo to see architectural drawings - indeed, the steady growth in the popularity of architectural drawings as collectible works of art was fanned in part by exhibitions of the work of contemporary architects at the Leo Castelli Gallery on West Broadway. What is novel, however, is to step off a SoHo street and see drawings by Andrea Palladio, Inigo Jones, Christopher Wren and John Soane - not figures one would consider staples of the downtown art scene.

title: Socialists Win In Lisbon, Vienna
description: Europe's Socialists won two national elections last week but one of their stars, Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, resigned anyway. The Socialists came in first in Austria and Portugal where Mario Soares will return as Prime Minister after five years in opposition.

title: POP: EDDIE DAVIS SOLOS
description: When Eddie (Lockjaw) Davis was a member of Count Basie's orchestra, he often projected a combination of swagger and cool. Stepping out of the saxophone section to take a solo, he approached the microphone with a macho stride as he casually swung his tenor saxophone into blowing position, as though what he was about to do was scarcely worthy of his attention.

title: James S. McNider 3d Wed To Anna Mary Van Buren
description: Anna Mary Van Buren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ralph Van Buren Jr. of Hampton, Va., was married there yesterday to James Small McNider 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McNider Jr. of Lynchburg, Va. Bishop John C. Bentley, retired, of the Episcopal Diocese of Alaska performed the ceremony at St. John's Church.

title: Princeton Triumphs
description: The lightweight crews of Princeton, Harvard and Yale raced in their annual triangular meeting today for the Goldthwait Cup, with Princeton capturing the varsity race in a new Lake Carnegie course record for lightweight crews.

title: THE DANCE: MISS LEVINE IN TAP REVUE
description: ''Constant Play,'' a tap-dance revue, clattered its way into the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Thursday night. Produced and choreographed by Andrea Levine, it also starred Miss Levine, who was ably abetted by Heather Cornell, Shelley Oliver, Marcos Dinerstein, Roy Lavitt and Jessie Hentoff.

title:
ANTIQUES;
IT'S TIME FOR OUTDOOR SHOWS AGAIN
description: THE deluges of recent weekends apparently have not dampened the spirits of the various organizations that sponsor outdoor antiques shows.

title: WELCOME ADDITION TO THE GALLERY SCENE
description: THE Lakewood Gallery in Glen Cove's Village Square, until recently a frame shop that also boasted attractive exhibition space, has now become the headquarters of the Hempstead Harbor Artists. With minimal redecoration and an ambitious program of shows by members and invited guests, the gallery is a welcome addition to the scene in an area where exhibition facilities are scarce.

title: PRINCETON: VIEWS OF AN IDYLLIC AMERICA
description: PRINCETON SOME prints have difficult personalities. They cling aloofly to the walls on which they are displayed, waiting for us to come to them. They seem to be aware of their worth, and, if we are to get to know them, it is up to us to take the first step. Usually, the acquaintanceship that develops warrants the effort.

title: A THATCHER RIFT WITH PYM WIDENS
description: During a crucial council of war five days before Britain invaded the Falkland Islands last year, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher denounced the members of a delegation from the Foreign Office, telling them they were incapable of advising her adequately.

title: PRIME TORY SCORECARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Shocking Loss for the Knicks
description: ALL week long, Bernard King took electronic treatment for his injured right ankle. That's medicine. Yesterday, Moses Malone and Franklin Edwards cruelly turned up the wattage on three electrifying plays late in the game. That's murder.

title: Sweet Smell of Success
description: Where there's smoke, a special team of transit police officers has been swinging into action. Officials last week said a monthlong crackdown on subway smoking has resulted in 2,143 summonses, nearly a third for marijuana use.

title: HAPPINESS IS A FAST PIGEON
description: WITH a polite ''excuse me,'' John A. Pennella sprang from a lawn chair, dashed across his Greenwich backyard, grabbed a long-handled net, scooped up a bird that had landed on the garage roof, pushed it through the door of a shed and punched a nearby clock - thereby demonstrating what one of the more esoteric sports, pigeon racing, is all about.

title: CHANCE SIGHTING OF A TIRE LED TO SLAYING SUSPECT
description: The arrest of a suspect in the abduction and slaying of a 25-year-old Morris County woman last Dec. 5 hinged on a detective's chance sighting of an automobile tire that matched a tire impression found at the scene of her seizure, according to a court transcript unsealed here this week.

title: THE STRAINS OF FRASER'S DUAL ROLE
description: DETROIT BARRING the unexpected, Douglas A. Fraser, the president of the United Automobile Workers Union, will be re-elected to another oneyear term as a director of the Chrysler Corporation this week, continuing his unprecedented role as the only labor representative on the board of a major American corporation.

title: Romantic Reading for Men
description: The female American reader nowadays has an insatiable appetite for romance novels. That, at any rate, appears to be a popular working hypothesis for publishers and booksellers, as habitues of paperback racks must have noticed. It's less obvious but perhaps no less interesting that the male American reader also buys millions of romantic novels.

title: THE WEEKEND BREAKFAST
description: The breakfast hour on a long summer weekend can stretch through the entire morning.

title: YACHT TEAMS MATCH TACTICS
description: The two dinghies on the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club team squeezed along either side of the lead boat of the Dutch team, carrying him off course.

title: Rail Strike Seen As Exploitation
description: The conductors' and trainmen's strike highlighted their outrageous salaries and the attendant social costs. Judged by The Times's account, their excessive pay costs rail commuters an additional $12 million a year, or $170 per commuter, a figure assuming the $36,000 average salary, or more than double the generously estimated $16,000 annual pay that their job would draw in a free market.

title: BARNARD AWARD FOR MRS. KIRKPATRICK FOUGHT
description: Hundreds of Barnard College students and faculty members have mounted a campaign to have the trustees of the college withdraw a commencement award to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: CUOMO SEEKS EXTENSION OF INVESTIGATION PANEL
description: The State Commission of Investigation technically expires at midnight tonight, but Governor Cuomo has asked the Legislature to extend the commission's life for a year.

title: Chicago Mayor to Return 20% of His Salary to City
description: Mayor Harold Washington said today he would return 20 percent of his annual salary to the city and would move to dismiss up to 540 employees hired in the waning days of Mayor Jane M. Byrne's administration.

title: A NOVEL RECYCLING
description: When the Village of Freeport was considering sites for much-needed office space for its Department of Public Works, the project's architect, Siegmund Spiegel, cast an eye upon the town's abandoned sewage treatment plant. Mr. Spiegel's suggestion that the treatment plant be turned into offices and that the department's old building be sold was accepted after the village saw his blueprints. ''We only built one completely new building,'' said Mr. Spiegel.

title: A REFRESHING MIX
description: The lightest drinks - and the most refreshing - are those that contain the most water. But the most memorable are flavored by where, when and with whom they are shared. n summer days of yore, when Times Square shimmered like Dar es Salaam in the August sun and air-conditioning was still an East Side conceit, the only place to be was in the cool dark bar of The Blue Ribbon and the only thing to drink was Berliner Weisse.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA'S SECRET ISLES
description: GEORGE McMILLAN lives on the South Carolina coast in Frogmore and is writing a book for Random House on the planned 1945 invasion of Japan.

title: No Headline
description: Celebrating the Brooklyn Bridge As an old Brooklynite, I want you to know how much I enjoyed David McCullough's article ''The Great Bridge and the American Imagination'' (March 27).

title: A LIVELY REVIEW OF THE FUTURIST EXPERIENCE; NEW HAVEN
description: Futurism, the noisy and tumultuous art movement founded by the Italian poet-ideologue Filippo Tomasso Marinetti (1876-1944) nearly 75 years ago, has established its assertive presence on the campus of Yale University. Since Yale's Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library acquired the Marinetti archives in 1977, scholars have been sifting the many pounds of Marinetti wordage about his movement, Italy's most significant contribution to 20th-century modernism, in the form of letters, diaries, notes, publications and memorabilia.

title: 18 SEIZED IN WESTCHESTER WAR ON DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: The Westchester County police arrested 18 people in their roadblock campaign against drunken drivers this weekend and said future roadblocks would not be announced in advance.

title: Recent Sales
A CLOSE-UP LOOK AT THE FRAUD THAT RUINED O.P.M.
description: The study, two years in the making, is 600 pages long. It provides a rare glimpse into the workings of American industry, finance, investment banking, accounting and lawyering. And it finds fault with some of the nation's most prestigious business institutions.

title: 54 WHO CAME HOME AND 6 WHO DIDN'T
description: CHARLIE COMPANY, What Vietnam Did To Us. By Peter Goldman and Tony Fuller. With Richard Manning, Stryker McGuire, Wally McNamee and Vern E. Smith. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: A Newsweek Book/William Morrow & Co. $15.95.

title: Arlen's Music at Michael's
description: The music of Harold Arlen will be performed by Marian McPartland and Brian Torff during a three-week engagement at Michael's Pub, 230 West 55th Street, beginning May 10.

title: FOR GERMAN SCHOLARS, HITLER 'DIARIES' ARE LATEST TRIBULATION
description: The case of papers found in an East German hayloft that the magazine Der Stern claims are Hitler's diaries is a treasure of sensation as long as controversy continues over their authenticity. For German historians it is a Pandora's box, but there is wide disagreement about whether it has loosed on the world a swarm of destructive furies or a cloud of gnats.

title: FABULOUS TRAVELER
description: Italo Calvino, the Italian master of allegorical fantasy, was visiting and lecturing in Manhattan recently. ''New York is a fabled city, a fabulous city,'' he said. ''I feel that it's one of my cities - like San Remo, where I grew up, or Rome, where I now live, or Paris, where my wife and I keep a small apartment. I felt that way almost from my first visit here more than 20 years ago.''

title: Karen Schwefel, M.J. Butler Wed
description: Karen L. Schwefel, daughter of Mrs. Edward J. Martin of Islip, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Capt. William G. Schwefel, U.S.M.C., was married yesterday to Michael J. Butler, son of William F. Butler Jr. of Hyannis Port, Mass., and the late Dawn Ludington Butler. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew J.W. Mullins in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: THE EXPLOSION IN BANK DEPOSITS
description: CONTINENTAL BANK has a long history of turning up its nose at consumer banking, preferring to concentrate on commercial and industrial loans and relying heavily on borrowed money, rather than consumer deposits, to fund its loans. In recent years, that was just as well. Consumers, seduced by money market funds offering higher rates, abandoned not only commercial banks like Continental but also the nation's savings and loans.

title: Tracing Some Consequences Of Social Policy
description: In the two years since Congress acted on what it took to be the Reagan mandate for limited Government and a less dependent people, there has been intense debate about how the poor could cope under the cutting edge of the Reagan budget. Last week came some hard data on the effect of legislative, economic and social changes - not all but mostly the result of the Reagan program. Predictably, it provoked as much argument as it provided conclusions.

title: No Headline
description: Marketing America Abroad While I fully support Richard N. Gardner's thesis that public diplomacy is a ''vital element in America's foreign policy,'' there has been no weakening of our public diplomacy under the current Administration (''Selling America in the Marketplace of Ideas,'' March 20). In fact, it has been significantly enhanced.

title: WINDOW ON THE FUTURE
description: JOHN BRANNON ALBRIGHT is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section.

title: ABUNDANT NATURAL GAS AWAITING DECONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Insurance Article Is Called Misleading
description: The March 27 Opinion Page article by State Senator H.James Saxton about New Jersey's ''no fault'' automobile insurance was biased and misleading. It presented a lopsided view of the problem without regard to the cogent, well-documented position presented by the State Bar Association to the Legislature and the press.

title: REPORT CARD ON THATCHERISM
description: Steven Rattner, an investment banker, was formerly a Times correspondent in London.

title: State School Aid And Poor Districts
description: In the article on the survival of ''save harmless'' operating aid in education (''Save Harmless School Formula Survives Anew,'' April 3) there is the implicit feeling, shared by the Governor's office, the State Department of Education, the Board of Regents and many educational finance reformers that the termination of save harmless aid would be a significant reform in helping poor districts.

title: PERIL POINTS
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan foreign policy is running out of time.
