With less than a year remaining before the distractions of the Presidential primaries, there seems no escape from the question: Is the Administration moving to the threshold of real acomplishments or is it on the verge of serious failures? The political turmoil of a Presidential year does not mix well with the sustained diplomatic initiatives usually necessary for success. From Central America to the Middle East, East-West relations, Western Europe, Africa and China, events have reached the point where they might get somewhat better or much worse, or just sit there festering until they may explode.

title: MARTIN SUSPENDED FOR 3 GAMES
description: Billy Martin, who only last week was fined $5,000 for his behavior toward umpires, was suspended today for three games for kicking dirt on an umpire in the Yankees' game with Texas Friday night. Martin, however, immediately appealed the suspension and was on hand to direct the Yankees to a 6-3 loss to the Rangers tonight.

title: Topics; Forgetfulness; Mnemonic
description: Soon after taking office, every President insists that he will practice consensus-style cabinet government. It never happens; no sooner do White House interests conflict with those of the departments than Presidents forget the Cabinet.

title: 'WOMEN IN HUMOR' CONFER: IS IT A MAN'S WORLD?
description: ''Take what you do seriously, but don't take yourself seriously,'' said Anne Meara. ''Think of yourself as a working woman not as a star,'' said Marilyn Sokol. ''Think, 'I'm here to make a living and to enjoy myself.' ''

title: CRIME
description: For almost 10 years Robert B. Parker has been writing his privateeye novels about Spenser, who operates out of Boston, and the 11th in the series, THE WIDENING GYRE (Delacorte, $12.95), adheres pretty much to the successful formula established with ''The Godwulf Manuscript'' in 1974. By now Spenser has a wide following, to the point where Dell is reissuing paperbacks of the entire series this spring.

title: Heil History
description: You're a West German magazine publisher, on the trail of the scoop of the decade: a Hitler diary that no one even knew existed. You fear a hoax but you smell a killing. You pay a lot to look and, finding the volumes plausible, a lot more to keep them. Now you own the ''real Hitler'' that no one ever knew, a daily anatomy of evil. What do you do?

title: DALLAS MAYOR-ELECT SAYS HE WILL CHART AN INTERNATIONAL COURSE FOR HIS CITY
description: Mayor-elect A. Starke Taylor Jr., a wealthy cotton exporter who was the businessmen's choice for Mayor of this exploding Sun Belt city, based his successful election campaign on a pledge to make Dallas an international city. But on a clear Texas day, his view is intergalactic.

title: NAZI ACCUSATIONS TURN LIFE INTO A NIGHTMARE
description: In January 1977, the Government turned Frank Walus's American dream into a nightmare when it falsely accused him of Nazi war crimes, including murder, and convicted him of lying to cover a Gestapo past. In November 1980, the Government told Mr. Walus it had all been a mistake and to forget it.

title:
Energy Conservation and Budget Relief;
A CALL FOR A TARRIFF ON U.S. OIL IMPORTS
description: THE time is right for a tariff on imported oil. The Organization of P etroleum Exporting Countries has been losing control over the world o il market, and a tariff would add to the cartel's problems and help b ring about a further drop in oil prices. Moreover, it would protect o ur economy from any oil price shocks that might occur in the future a nd provide much-needed government revenues during a time of growing b udget deficits.

title: Data Bank
AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALL AMERICAN MUSIC, by John Rockwell. (Alfred A. Knopf, $15.95.) A s tudy of contemporary American music, popular and highbrow.

title: NORWEGIAN SHIP ATTACKS SUSPECTED SUB
description: A Norwegian warship twice attacked today what appeared to be an unidentified submarine near here, a naval spokesman said.

title: NIXON LIBRARY TO BE BUILT IN SAN CLEMENTE
description: The Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library has found a home in the city where the former President had his Western office overlooking the Pacific.

title: ISLANDER FEVER IS SWEEPING THE ISLAND
description: THERE are very few things that most Long Islanders have in common with one another - certainly few pleasant things. The average guy on the North Shore thinks the Southern State Parkway is in Virginia. The average guy in East Hampton thinks that heading west, after Southampton, you come to Manhattan and then California.

title: Make Way for The Money Train
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may not get much credit from passengers, but it has received more than it expected from investors. Because a higher-than-anticipated bond rating made the agency's recent offering more popular than planned, it raised an extra $356 million.

title: MANY OF SPRING'S PRETTIEST AZALEAS ARE WILD SPECIES; BY G. DAVID LEWIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- G. David Lewis is professor of plant pathology, Rutgers University.

title: 4 Die in Car Crash Ending a Police Chase
description: Four people were killed today in a high-speed head-on collision between a car carrying three teen-agers and an automobile that was trying to outrun pursuing police officers.

title: WHO AMONG US?
description: On Nov. 3, 1969, President Nixon spoke to ''the great silent majority of my fellow Americans'' about Vietnam. He warned that ''defeat and humiliation'' there would destroy U.S. credibility. ''A nation cannot remain great,'' he said, ''if it betrays its allies and lets down its friends.'' Rejecting American withdrawal, he said we would stop the Communists by building up South Vietnamese forces.

title: REPAIRING NUCLERA PLANTS' EMERGENCY PLANS
description: AS an emergency drill unfolded on March 9 at the Indian Point nuclear power station, officials at the plant and those in the New York State emergency center in Albany were drawing opposite conclusions about the usefulness of the exercise. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is to debate possible deficiencies in Indian Point's emergency plans this week.

title: JEWISH MOTHERS AND DAUGHTERS ENJOYING TIES
description: The chattering, gossiping yenta -an intrusive woman lampooned mercilessly by Jewish comedians and scorned in the novels of some of the best-known Jewish writers - is a stereotype that probably ought to be retired, according to Dr. Eleanor Mallach Bromberg, assistant professor of social work at Hunter College.

title: Pattern of Rejecton
description: Not all those accused of Nazi war crimes are wanted men.

title: Nakasone Starts Tour Of 5 East Asian Lands
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left here today on a 10-day, 5-nation tour of Southeast Asia during which he is expected to shore up confidence in the region with offers of economic aid.

title: PROGRESSIVE OR NOT, BRAHMS STILL FASCINATES
description: Poor Brahms. Of all the great composers he is the one whom many listeners find easiest to condescend to, if not actually dislike. We can't really pity him, however, because audiences do not tire of hearing his works and musicians pay him tribute in the best way possible, by incessantly performing his music. It would be hard to find a musician who would deny his importance. And yet, though this week marks the 150th anniversary of his birth, there remains something about Brahms that can breed antagonism. I remember once, in my infancy as a critic, suggesting to a famous violinist that perhaps Brahms was a minor composer who owed his status to the early publicity efforts in his behalf by Schumann and Joachim. The only response I received was a blank stare. This was also a period when I was convinced that ''Tosca'' and ''La Boheme'' would one day drop out of the opera repertory never to be heard from again. For me, you see, oldtimers such as Brahms and Puccini lay like logs across the road, taking up space on programs and blocking public acceptance of modern composers.

title: BERGEN COMMUNITY MUSEUM: A MAJOR NAKIAN SHOW; PARAMUS
description: THE odds against a major exhibition by an artist of world renown at the Bergen Community Museum would seem longer than those against finding more mastodons in the county.

title: FIXING A FAULTY KITCHEN SINK SPRAY CAN BE A SIMPLE MATTER
description: A GREAT many kitchen sinks are equipped with faucets that have separate spray attachments connected to the base of the faucet under the sink. These are designed so that pushing down on a lever or valve on the spray head diverts water from the regular spout to the spray head, which is attached to a flexible hose so it can be pulled out and moved around inside the sink.

title: ISLANDERS TOP BRUINS
description: Clarke Gillies came back to the Islanders' lineup tonight and helped to restore the scoring prowess of his linemates, Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy.

title: LOTS OF DOORS, BUT NOT MANY THRILLS
description: A QUICK glance through the program of ''But She Won't Lie Down,'' the comedy-thriller being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, will not turn up any note on its author, Peter Yeldham. Although the plot leaves much unexplained, ''the case of the shy playwright'' is the only mystery connected with this production. The rest of the evening is as mysterious as popcorn.

title: SALEM GETS THE GO-AHEAD ON RESTARTING REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON WHILE emergency planning was the hot topic at Indian Point and Shoreham, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was still coping last week with an actual emergency at the Salem 1 plant, in Lower Alloways Creek, N.J. In February, the plant suffered a complete failure of its automatic shutdown system - an unprecedented event - when two circuit breakers failed.

title: TRADING TRASH FOR PARKLAND
description: For the past few years the residents of Guilford, Conn., have been turning the town's old cans, glass and newspapers into acres of recreational land. Conservation-minded citizens have been performing this magic through a trash recycling project that helps finance the land purchase program of the Guilford Land Conservation Trust.

title: TASTY FORAYS INTO DELAWARE AND BEYOND
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The New York Times.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BRIARCLIFF MANOR
description: ''P EOPLE who live here wouldn't think of living anyplace else,'' a real estate agent said of Briarcliff Manor as she gestured over the tops of chimneys, each bespeaking several hundred thousand dollars of dwelling, toward the Hudson River down the hill.

title: Future Events; A Mixed Bag
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Royal Occasion May 3 - Prince and Princess Michael of Kent will be the guests of honor at the opening night of the London Contemporary Dance Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and at a black-tie supper afterward in the academy's Lepercq Space, with steak and kidney pie the piece de resistance. The evening, part of the ''Britain Salutes New York'' arts festival, will benefit the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation and help establish an exchange program between the United Kingdom and the United States for student dancers, choreographers and contemporary dance companies. Tickets, $125, from 636-4138. Spring Fete May 4 - When members of the Musica Sacra chorus and orchestra file offstage after their final concert of the season at Avery Fisher Hall, a good portion of the audience will join Richard Westenburg, the conductor, and soloists at a supper party in the main gallery of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. There will be a buffet with many flambe dishes, and dancing to a Peter Duchin orchestra. Supper tickets $100, concert tickets $13, from 874-7104. Proceeds will help Musica Sacra in future New York seasons.

title: Engine Fails, Plane Is Safe
description: A Piedmont Airlines jet that had just taken off with 39 people aboard turned around and made an emergency landing at Kanawha Airport today after an engine failed. No one was injured, said Piedmont spokesman Dave Lewis. He said the Boeing 737, bound from Charleston to Washington, D.C., had been in the air about ''10 or 15 minutes'' and had already leveled off.

title: Amy Dickinson, Sales Manager, Marries in Ohio
description: Amy Bostick Dickinson, daughter of Mrs. Lanford Barrows of Cincinnati and Philemon R. Dickinson of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to David Stanly Beckwith, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Ruffin Beckwith Jr. of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Paul Long, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Indian Hill Church in Cincinnati, assisted by the Rev. Pierce W. Klemmt of the Trinity Episcopal Church of Troy, Ohio.

title: Leonard Kirschen Dies at 74; Reporter Jailed by Rumanians
description: Leonard Kirschen, a correspondent for The Associated Press who spent 10 years in jail in his native Rumania, died today at the Royal Northern Hospital in London. He was 74 years old.

title: GANDHI'S THOUGHTS RECALLED IN NOTES
description: AMONG those watching as the movie ''Gandhi'' gathered eight Academy Awards last month was Mary Messner of New Rochelle. But she had a special link with the man and the events depicted in the film; she had only to turn from the television set and glance at the wall of her dining room to see five framed sheets of paper bearing the words and signature of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

title: An election for Turkey
description: Turkey's military rulers last week promised to hold elections on Nov. 6 to restore civilian government. Gen. Kenan Evren, who heads the regime that seized power in 1980 and suppressed rampaging violence, called for new broad-based parties that could command a stable majority in the new Parliament. Despite a ban on political activity by 100 former party leaders, many would-be candidates were visiting them to seek support. In Washington, the State Department welcomed ''substantial progress on the road to establishment of full democratic government in Turkey.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''MOST New Jerseyans probably don't realize that, even in good times, hundreds of thousands of New Jersey children live at or below poverty level,'' said Ciro A. Scalera, executive director of the Newark-based Association for Children of New Jersey, a childadvocacy group. ''When economic conditions deteriorate and Federal budget cuts and regulatory changes reduce or restrict services, children and their families suffer even more.''

title: A SEARCH FOR OLD WALLPAPER
description: NAN WILLIAMS is looking for wallpaper. Not just any wallpaper. Very, very old wallpaper. Mrs. Williams, who is curator of the Gen. William Hart House in Old Saybrook, has organized a search for 18thand 19th-century wallpaper - on the walls or off them.

title: Jews of Arab Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Gadfly
description: As the owner of one share of stock in the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in New Jersey, 29-year-old David Brook takes his capitalist responsibilities seriously. A year ago he used his stock to get an antinuclear proposal onto the utility's yearly proxy statement.

title: SEEKING CLUES TO MEMORY LOSS
description: ''EVEN my wife doesn't know what to tell people when they ask her: 'What does your husband do?' '' The speaker is Walter B. Essman of Glen Cove, and it is not difficult to understand why such a question cannot be dealt with succinctly by his wife, Shirley.

title: No Headline
description: As the ''last'' Assistant Secretary of State for Educational and Cultural Affairs, I find Ambassador Gardner right on the mark in his provocative essay. Having developed a superb instrument to promote international dialogue, the United States now funds it inadequately, handicaps its effectiveness and, perhaps most shortsightedly, subjects these programs to communicating the views of one Administration.

title: Study Time: Where to Find It
description: To the Sports Editor: Congratulations to Dr. Jerome Vogel; his discussion of the baseball ''klutz'' (April 17) was enlightening. Further embarrassment of the subaverage or only average athlete occurs in the school.

title: Happily, In Limbo
description: Pioneer 10 is an overachiever. The satellite was launched March 3, 1972 from Cape Canaveral, Fla.; its mission, to scan Jupiter.

title: ...AS APARTMENTS NEAR FINISH
description: NEARLY a decade ago, residents of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, seeking to rebuild the area's d evastated housing stock, won Federal and New York City approval of t heir plan to renovate 450 apartments in a block of Howard Avenue forl ow- and moderate-income residents.

title: CORRECTION
description: A heading on page 25 of The Times Magazine today omits a word from a quotation by the playwright Marsha Norman. It should read: ''We are soldiers, marching, and we must not step on the mines. We are trying to clear the path, to tell you what's out there.''

title: Interns Agree on 2-Year Pact
description: The Committee of Interns and Residents, which represents 2,100 physicians in training at municipal hospitals in the city, announced Friday night that it had agreed on a new two-year contract with the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation. The committee said its physicians would receive salary increases of 8 percent the first year and 7 percent the second year. Last Monday, the committee, which carried out a weeklong strike at the hospitals two years ago, had accused the city of refusing to bargain in good faith.

title: SHANKER URGES TEACHERS TO AID SCHOOL REFORM
description: The president of the American Federation of Teachers, Albert Shanker, said today that teachers and their unions should cooperate in reforming the country's educational system, even if this meant agreeing to longer school days, longer school years or other changes that teachers have resisted in the past.

title: AFGHAN WAR ISN'T OVER BUT SOVIETS SEEM TO BE WINNING
description: The snow is melting in the high passes through which refugees flee to Pakistan and arms shipments filter in the starlight to the waiting insurgents. Around Kabul and provincial towns, Soviet troops gas their vehicles, load heavy ammunition and prepare for the fourth summer of the occupation campaign in Afghanistan.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: DIM SUM, the inviting teahouse canapes of China, have inspired two recent cookbooks by New Jersey residents well versed on the subject. Jean Yueh of Summit, a skillful writer and a teacher of Chinese cuisine, has written ''Dim Sum & Chinese One-Dish Meals'' (Irena Chalmers Cookbooks, P.O. Box 988, Denton, N.C., $6.95, plus $1 postage).

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FROM Fairleigh Dickinson University in Teaneck to Stockton State College in Pomona, students in the next few weeks will earn degrees in subjects ranging from archeology to zoology. Along with those degrees, honorary ones will be awarded to those who have made their marks on society.

title: Freer Trade
description: To the Business Editor: A strict reciprocal policy must be established with our major trading partners (''Peeling Away Japan's Trade Barriers,'' April 17).

title: IN APPRECIATION OF WHITE WINE
description: Long maligned in the hierarchy of the grape, white wine not only can age well and acquire character, it has a range that takes it from aperitif to dessert. e are white wine drinkers, we Americans, and all the Beaujolais and Lambrusco in the world aren't going to change that. Not for a while, anyway.

title: HUGHEY TURNS DOWN COLLEGE
description: TRENTON IF ROBERT E. HUGHEY had accepted the job as president of Stockton State College in Pomona, he would have served as Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection for 15 months.

title: SUN CAN'T DO IT ALL, EVEN IN DRY GARDEN
description: LAST week's sunny days helped to dry out drenched garden soil. But they did not shorten the gardener's long list of catch-up chores. At the top of the list is replanting vegetable seeds. Traditionally, spinach, peas, lettuce, turnips, radish, onion sets - the hardy, cool weather vegetables - are planted at the first chance in spring as soon as ground can be worked.

title: BALLET: ELLIOT FELD, SOUTH OF THE BORDER
description: In ''Danzon Cubano'' and ''La Vida,'' performed Thursday in the Joyce Theater by the Feld Ballet, Eliot Feld takes us to that fabled territory called ''south of the border'' -the land of toucans and siestas, with a shake of Carmen Miranda's hips thrown in. Brief bright flashes amid the palms, the two are companion dances that find Mr. Feld in an amusingly throwaway mood.

title: PICNIC IN A VINEYARD
description: Probably nothing is as pleasurable in warm weather as a country picnic. This one is classic Americana, but it has a style and spirit all its own.

title: NEW YORK URGED TO ALLOCATE HYDROPOWER TO 4 MORE STATES
description: A hearing examiner has recommended that four states - New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island - be permitted to buy some of the inexpensive hydropower generated in New York at Niagara Falls and on the St. Lawrence River.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Greenspan Fed?

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? HISTORY
description: IF you ever have wondered what was in an old New England name, the answer is, probably an ancestral trade or skill. Several centuries ago, when it became necessary to tell people apart -usually for local tax reasons - by giving them surnames, those second names had one of three common bases: a physical attribute, the work one did or the place where one lived. Thus, three men from the same village, each of whom was named William, might be told apart in local records by the first being called William Black, commemorating the man's dark complexion; the second William might be called William Carpenter because that was his trade; and the third became William Ford because he lived where the local stream was most easily crossed.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE RITES OF SPRING FOR BOATERS
description: OTHER places have other spring rituals. In Connecticut coastal towns, spring comes when the boats go back to the water. At the hardware store in the village, Stan is checking invoices for marine bottom paint, and out in the harbor, McDonald is laying moorings from his gray flatboat, the Mudhen.

title:
GARDENING;
3 POPULAR HEDGES: PRIVET, YEW, HEMLOCK
description: THE three most commonly used hedging plants in this region are privet, yew and hemlock. All three are satisfactory for both the formally clipped and the informally natural hedges.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Do you know of any places with a focus on seashell collecting? I would like to start off in Florida or in the West Indies region. - W.R., Stamford, Conn. Answer:Captiva and Sanibel, barrier islands off the Gulf coast of Florida, have beaches that draw collectors of seashells. Major airlines serve Fort Myers, Fla., about 20 miles from the islands. At the Fort Myers airport you can rent a car to get around the area; on the islands there are bicycle paths and taxi service. At the entrance to Sanibel Island, the Chamber of Commerce (Post Office Box 166, Sanibel Island, Fla. 33957; 813-472-1080) maintains a visitor information center. You can also write to the chamber for accommodations information. Reservations are necessary during the peak season, from Christmas through Easter; lodgings are less expensive and easier to get, except on holiday weekends, the rest of the year.

title: Ellin Dixon Is to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Eugene Dixon Jr. of Lafayette Hill, Pa., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Edith Eleanor Dixon, to Donald P. Rosendale of New York and Millbrook, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: I'd like to add a sidelight about the Brooklyn Bridge that involved the St. Patrick's Day parade. It's a coincidence that the recent controversy over the Grand Marshal occurred on the bridge's centennial, but this was almost trivial compared with what transpired as a result of the bridge's opening in 1883.

title: A DIFFERENT CLAMBAKE
description: An inventive twist on the traditional clambake works even in places where the ocean is miles away. cratch the beach anywhere from Greenwich to Bar Harbor at this time of year and chances are one will uncover a clambake cognoscente. This festive, labor-intensive New England tradition of the clambake seems to have as many variations as the country two-step. It seems that every local expert has his own foolproof method - placing ingredients in a 50-gallon oil drum, in aluminum trash cans or in sealed barbecue grills - and each one, according to its adherents, leaves the food juicier and more flavorful than the next. The old-fashioned technique borrowed from coastal Indians, which requires digging a deep pit in the sand and lining it with rocks, is performed nowadays only by historically dogmatic types. And, besides requiring backwrenching labor, this method presents the hazard of gritty food if not performed properly.

title: Louise Kaufman Married
description: Louise Ann Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kaufman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Ithaca, N.Y., to Daniel Riddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Riddell of Randolph, N.Y. Rabbi Laurence Edwards performed the ceremony at the Anabel Taylor Chapel of Cornell University.

title: LET THE ELDERLY STOP RUNAWAY SOCIAL SECURITY By Bob Cary
description: Probably only we, the elderly, can untangle what is usually termed ''the Social Security mess.'' Even though the system has been given a temporary reprieve, no President, no Congress, no politically appointed commission can deal realististically with this matter because, frankly, they are afraid of us. We are organized, articulate, well-financed, and we vote. Indeed, we now receive a gratuity exceeding $160 billion every year - reason enough to vote. Thus, it should surprise no one that Washington's response to this disaster-aimed mechanism has been to tinker with the transmission, and change the oil - praying that today's crop of elected and appointed officials will be long retired when the cylinder head explodes.

title: Little Hobart Big in Lacrosse
description: A winning lacrosse team is a tradition at Hobart College. The Statesmen, from Geneva, N.Y., are seeking their fourth straight National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship, and their sixth since the N.C.A.A. began tournament play in 1973. Hobart has not had a losing season since 1959 and has been ranked first in the weekly lacrosse coaches' poll all spring.

title: Correction
description: A photograph of John F. Kennedy that appeared in the issue of April 17 was incorrectly dated. The correct date is 1963.

title: COOL GREEN TASTES FOR WARM DAYS
description: In its natural form, this coolest of colors is as refreshing to the eye as it is to the palate. Warm hospitality is the sort guests usually respond to, but when midsummer temperatures soar, cool hospitality seems much more to the point. From June through mid-September, what dinner guests appreciate most is surcease from withering heat and humidity, and not even airconditioning may be quite enough to obliterate the sense of outdoor steaminess.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Two crossed radishes proclaimed a shop as a greengrocer's; a dramatic carving of a devil indicated a pharmacy that sold a special brand of stomach medicine; a geisha house announced itself with a painting of a coy fat cat. Signmakers in old Japan could find a way of advertising anything, using the traditional arts of calligraphy, lacquer painting, wood carving and carpentry to make lively emblems for shops that indicated their wares and services.

title: COMPUTER PROGRAMS EASE TEST-TAKING
description: NOW that high school seniors have acceptances and rejections from colleges in hand, a new group of students in the county is beginning the process of applying to college.

title: THE CASE AGAINST TV IN THE COURTROOM
description: TELEVISION is a business, and its success is measured in ratings. Greater and greater emphasis is being placed on television news programs to get high ratings. What gets higher ratings than real-life drama with ingredients such as violence, perhaps sex, money?

title: RAIN HITS POCKETBOOK, TOO
description: NEARLY 12 inches of rainfall, almost three times the average for April, fell on Long Island last month, costing farmers tens of thousands of dollars, a loss that will also be suffered by consumers in the form of higher prices when farm produce reaches the market later this year.

title: Other, Not Outer
description: To the Editor:

title: GIRLS OF SCARSDALE DOMINATE LEAGUE
description: THE short, shrill blast of a whistle pierces the cool of a waning spring afternoon. ''Hold it!'' screams Art Resnick, arms flailing as he scrambles to follow the play. Twenty-three girls and two assistant coaches freeze in their tracks on the soccer field as Head Coach Resnick darts to their center and the ball.

title: Reagan Gets a Scathing Report On Education
description: ''We have been committing an act of unthinking, unilateral educational disarmament,'' the National Commission on Excellence in Education reported last week. But while the two-fisted prose assailed the deterioration of school curriculums, teacher training and student preparedness, and then catalogued remedies, the commission may have been rhetorically more clever than clear about who should lead the rearmament -the Federal Government or states and localities.

title: THE BISHOPS' LETTER
description: The results of the two world wars of this century, representing setbacks for European civilization, already began to draw a veil of doubt over the validity, in this modern age, of most of the theoretical principles worked out in earlier centuries to relate the use of the armed power of the state to politics and morals. But the development of the nuclear weapon, bringing the power of existing arsenals to a point that made their use in warfare suicidal and threatening to the very intactness of civilization, heightened the significance of these questions many times over, presenting dilemmas to which the wisdom of the past provided no sure answers, and raising the demand for a fundamental rethinking of the role of armed force in the strategy and the moral philosophy of the modern state.

title: Cosby the Dropout
description: He couldn't run but he could hide, so Bill Cosby did the logical thing yesterday. The 45-year-old comedian dropped out of the Masters 1,600-meter event at the Penn Relays.

title: WHY BE A TEACHER? REWARDS DO EXIST
description: WHAT ambitious American boy (and now what ambitious American girl) ever said he wanted to be a teacher? Teachers are poorly paid, do not advance and are not given status. They do not invent anything, produce anything, sell anything. In a hustling, competitive, scientific, technological world, teachers have no tangible signs of achievement and thus are given no honorary degrees and little recognition. Anyone can become a teacher, and there is no career ladder. One does not become a senior partner with increased responsibility and the accompanying deference. In short, teaching is not a glamorous profession. In obscurity, one labors for a pittance.

title: Information Offered on Alcoholism Group
description: There was an article on March 20 on the family dynamics in an alcoholic home and the destructive effects on the children raised in such a home (''Now Alcoholic's Family Is Treated, Too''). For those readers who identified with the article, I would like them to know that if they wish to learn where meetings of Adult Children of Alcoholics are held on the eastern end of Long Island, they may call the Long Island Council on Alcoholism in Westhampton Beach for that information.

title: Auto Arbitration: Not the Last Word
description: General Motors has not only had a grim time selling cars recently, but a tough problem making ones that are free of defects. Last week the Federal Trade Commission struck a deal with the company on consumer complaints that looked almost as ambiguous as gas mileage ratings.

title: 76ERS BEAT KNICKS BY 108-105 IN LAST :002 FOR 3-0 LEAD
description: A 10-foot banked shot by Franklin Edwards with 2 seconds remaining yesterday gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 107-105 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden and moved New York a step closer to playoff elimination.

title: SEPTEMBER 17
description: My defenseless country will admit you invader where Jas and little Mary went walking to school the path won't be split into an abyssRivers are too lazy not quick to flood knights sleeping in the mountains will continue to sleep so you will enter easily uninvited guestBut sons of the earth will gather at night funny carbonari plotters of freedom they will clean old-fashioned weapons will swear on a bird on two colorsAnd then as always - glows and explosions boys like children sleepless commanders knapsacks filled with defeat crimson fields of glory the strengthening knowledge - we are aloneMy defenseless country will admit you invader and give you a plot of earth under a willow - and peace so those who come after us will learn again the most difficult art - the forgiveness of sins

title: 35 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 35 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named one that was allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: SMUGGLING OF ALIENS BY CANADIAN ROUTE TO U.S. IS INCREASING
description: The number of illegal aliens being smuggled across New York's border with Canada has increased significantly in the last year, according to American immigration officials, government prosecutors and lawyers who defend the aliens and smugglers.

title: WOMAN PUSHES SUIT ON PRINCETON CLUBS
description: TRENTON PRINCETON UNIVERSITY'S three all-male eating clubs face a court challenge here Tuesday when a graduate of the Class of 1980 continues a five-year effort to bring the clubs under the jurisdiction of state antidiscrimination laws.

title: OLD DIVISIONS EVIDENT IN BROOKLYN SCHOOL RACE
description: Ten years after a school boycott that divided the Canarsie-East Flatbush school district on racial and geographic lines, those divisions are still evident in Tuesday's school board elections.

title: 200 TUFTS STUDENTS END THEIR SIT-IN PROTESTING TENURE DENIAL
description: Students emerged early this morning from the Tufts University administration building, ending a three-day protest against the denying of tenure to a sociology teacher and against the tenure promotion procedure in general.

title: Driver Killed in Crash At Alabama Speedway
description: One driver was killed and another badly burned in separate crashes during the ARCA 500-Kilometers stock car race today at Alabama International Motor Speedway.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ATTACK ON HONDURAN BORDER
description: Guerrillas launched coordinated attacks here and at nearby Santa Rosa de Lima Friday, killing at least 28 people and destroying four bridges and 13 large trucks, according to witnesses.

title: SIHANOUK'S CAMBODIAN COALITION IS GIVEN RECOGNITION BY 5 ENVOYS
description: In a ceremony that he said underscored the diplomatic strength of his government in exile, Prince Norodom Sihanouk and other members of his insurgent coalition gathered here today to accept the credentials of five ambassadors whose governments recognize the Prince as Cambodia's legal president.

title: A 'CROWN' LOST, A 'PORGY' GAINED
description: WHEN he was growing up in the Union County community of Cranford, Jonathan Sprague's parents took him to see the Christmas show at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: CELEBRATING IN A TENT
description: More and more people are choosing to hold large gatherings at home, and one way to handle a host of guests elegantly is in a gaily appointed tent. Recent years have seen a trend toward holding weddings and receptions at home. It is seen as more personal, and, at this time of year, this notion has great appeal.The freshness and openness of an outdoor party can be ideal in late spring and early summer. A wedding reception in a tent, such as this one held on the grounds of a home in Harrison, N.Y., can combine the fluidity and informality of an outdoor party with the elegance of an indoor sitdown dinner.

title: RECITAL: BERGMAN, PIANIST
description: Borah Bergman, a strikingly original pianist, concluded Dance Theater Workshop's ''Out on the Keys'' series with a solo concert on Wednesday.

title: YOKNAPATAWPHA COUNTY OF THE MIND
description: THE TENNIS HANDSOME, By Barry Hannah. 166 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Wendy Ann Moss Marries M.A. Lasher in New York
description: Wendy Ann Moss, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David W. Moss of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' home to Martin Aaron Lasher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron J. Lasher of Heuvelton, N.Y. Dr. Robert Berson of the New York Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony.

title: U. N. Session Criticizes The West on Namibia
description: A weeklong United Nations conference here on South-West Africa has ended with the issuance of a strong statement against United States insistence on linking the area's independence with the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Johansson's Prediction
description: Weight lifters are getting stronger, runners are getting faster and boxers are getting better. They are so much better in boxing that the sport is in jeopardy, says Ingemar Johansson, the former heavyweight champion.

title: BY NED ROREM
description: Ned Rorem, the composer and writer whose Third Piano Concerto will be given its first New York performance this afternoon by the American Symphony Orchestra with Rita Bouloubibi as soloist, will be 60 years old in October. The following are some of his reflections as he approaches that anniversary.

title: ON THE HUNT FOR DECOYS
description: ZACK TAYLOR is boats and travel editor of ''Sports Afield'' and lives in Easton, Md.

title: IN BROWNSVILLE, CHURCHES JOINING TO BUILD HOMES . . .
description: THE Old Testament tells the story of the prophet Nehemiah, who was s ent by the King of Persia to Jerusalem in 420 B.C. to help rebuild t he city after the Babylonian captivity.

title: ROOMMATE AGENTS ARE MATCHERS OF PEOPLE
description: UNTIL recently the sharing of living quarters by two or more unrelated men and women was generally regarded by society as a result of moral or financial deprivation, or both.

title: REAGAN BLAMES FEDERAL ROLE FOR MEDIOCRE SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan, commenting on a bipartisan Federal commission's warning about educational mediocrity, said today that the solution lay with parents and local officials, not the Federal Government.

title: SOCIETY MAKES NO-INTEREST LOANS TO NEW YORK'S IMMIGRANTS
description: On a December evening in 1892, 11 men met at the Wilner Synagogue on Henry Street in Manhattan and pooled their savings - $95 - to establish a free loan society similar to those they had known in their native eastern European countries.

title: CITY BALLET: THE KOZLOVS MAKE DEBUT
description: Valentina Kozlova and Leonid Kozlov, who were dancers in the Bolshoi Ballet, defected from the Soviet company while it was in Los Angeles in 1979 several weeks after Alexander Godunov did the same in New York.

title: Betty Wallace and Andrew Corty Wed
description: Edith Laughlin Wallace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Wallace of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married there yesterday to Andrew Pisko Corty, son of Dr. and Mrs. Claude Corty of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Caroline Fenderson performed the ceremony at the Unitarian-Universalist Church.

title: 1 KILLED AS CAR HITS 34TH ST. SHOP
description: A car, hurtling past crowds of startled shoppers, crashed into a clothing shop on West 34th Street yesterday afternoon and killed 1 woman and injured at least 27 other people, including 6 children, authorities said. Fifteen of the victims were reported seriously injured.

title: MURPH HOMERS TOP METS, 6-1
description: When Dale Murphy hit a two-run home run in the ninth inning Friday night at Shea Stadium, it wasn't enough for Atlanta to beat the Mets, who won the game, 6-5. When Murphy hit a two-run homer in the ninth yesterday afternoon at Shea, it was more than enough for the Braves to beat the Mets, 6-1.

title: TREASURES IN SILVER
description: Collecting English silver is an American obsession. Indeed, the majority of antique silver enthusiasts in this country seem to view English wares as the only kind to collect, a feeling that is not shared by Americans who accumulate such other period wares as furniture, porcelains, books, glass or needlework. In silver, it seems, Britannia still rules America.

title: BREYTEN PRAYS FOR HIMSELF
description: There is no need for Pain Lord We could live well enough without It A flower has no teeth It is true we are only fulfilled in death But let our flesh stay new as fresh cabbage Make us firm as a fish's pink body Let us spellbind each other with eyes deep butterflies Pardon our mouths our guts our brains Let us regularly taste the sweet evening air Swim in tepid seas, be allowed to sleep with the sun Ride peacefully on bicycles through bright SundaysAnd gradually we will rot like old ships or trees But keep Pain far from Me o Lord That others may bear it Be taken into custody, ShatteredStonedHangedLashedUsedTorturedCrucifiedInterrogatedPlaced under house arrestMade to slave their guts out Banished to obscure islands till the end of their days Wasting in damp pits down to slimy green imploring bones Worms in their stomachs heads full of nails But not Me Never give us Pain or complain

title: TRENTON
description: THE Kean administration and the State Legislature are at odds over money again. This time, the argument - about the amount spent by New Jersey to educate handicapped students in private schools - has aroused emotions on both sides.

title: Hussein Criticizes U.S.  On End of P.L.O. Talks
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that the United States was partly responsible for the collapse of his talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization on President Reagan's peace plan.

title: Joann Daly Weds John Stuart Gray
description: Joann Marie Daly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Daly of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday to John Stuart Gray, son of Mrs. William Steele Gray Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Gray. The Rev. Richard Van Wely of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony in St. John's Chapel at the Groton School in Groton, Mass., from which the bridegroom graduated.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Tie and a Tiepin

title: RARE VIRUS MAY HAVE LINK WITH IMMUNOLOGICAL ILLNESS
description: Evidence of an unusual virus has been found in up to one-third of blood samples from some victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrone, or AIDS, an immunological disorder that has killed about half of the 1,352 people known to have acquired it, according to the Federal scientist in charge of investigating the epidemic.

title: CROWDED BANGKOK IS SINKING UNDER WEIGHT OF ITS OWN GROWTH
description: It's been uncommonly dry here, and a good thing, too, everyone says. Soon enough, the rainy season will begin and once again much of this city will come sloshing to a halt.

title: UNDER THE RED STAR
description: INSIDE THE SOVIET ARMY, By Viktor Suvorov. 296 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $15.95.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: CRUISES CLOSE TO HOME
description: T hink of a cruise, and chances are you conjure up visions of long stretches of ocean and exotic distant ports. But some interesting cruises this year are very close to home. For many Northeasterners, it's an easy trip to the point of departure and return, and you can spend three days to two weeks exploring the Atlantic Seaboard or its inland waterways.

title: SOME THOUGHTS ON DISRESPECT
description: RECENTLY, a man in Alabama alerted the police and the press that he was about to attempt suicide. He set himself afire in front of cameras, and for several minutes two youngish cameramen filmed the incident until one finally decided to intevenne.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 1, 1983
description: International A visit to Damascus to discuss a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon is being considered by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He said he was prepared to interrupt his diplomatic shuttle between Jerusalem and Beirut to make the trip, which, he said, could take place as soon as he was satisfied that that ''genuine progress'' was made toward an agreement on an Israeli pullout. (Page 1, Column 6.) Bangkok is sinking so fast that engineers warn that the entire city, the capital of Thailand, is in danger of falling below sea level by the end of the century. (1:4.)

title: DICKSON MOVING UP, AND FAST
description: While some pro tennis players talk of trimming their tournament commitments, Mark Dickson is playing anywhere and everywhere he can. ''All these other guys like (John) McEnroe and (Ivan) Lendl played a lot of big tournaments at a younger age,'''the 23-year-old Dickson said thu other day. ''The only way I can consistantly move up and establish myself is to play a much as I can.''

title: TEMPLES OF TRIUMPHANT MATERIALISM
description: Architecture has seldom been more seductively deceptive than in the great 19th-century arcades that look like temples of exuberant frivolity and not mere monuments to the triumphant materialism of the industrial age. Long rows of elegant shops and offices in the Burlington Arcade in London suggest aristocrats promenading under glass skylights on tesserated indoor streets where windows are filled with silver, leather and silk.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE State University of New York at Purchase has been on a winning streak recently. Dr. Sally Banes, assistant professor of dance history, John Cohen, associate professor of visual arts, and Mel Wong, lecturer in dance, have all received Guggenheim Fellowships. In addition, Judith Pfaff, a sculptor who taught last semester in the visual-arts division, also received the award.

title: Babette E. Krolik, City Official, Wed
description: Babette Ellen Krolik, general counsel of the New York City Housing Development Corporation, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Rafsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Rafsky of Philadelphia. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Krolik of West Bloomfield, Mich.

title:
THE REGION;
Lottery Chairman Gets Unlucky
description: Among the losers of last week's New Jersey Lottery was its chairman, Reese Palley. He was indicted on charges that he falsified documents related to a conflict of interest investigation involving his dealings with companies doing business with the lottery, prompting Governor Kean to call for his resignation.

title: CUSTOM FLY RODS AID ANGLERS
description: FIVE salmon occasionally dimpled the stream's surface. Ed Roberts, a custom rodmaker, watched as a vacationing sportsman tried over and over again to land his fly where the fish were feeding. Then he tried it himself. ''I took all five in about 10 casts,'' Mr. Roberts said.

title: Women's League And Innovation
description: To the Sports Editor: After reading Nancy Lieberman's article on women's basketball (''Nancy Lieberman's Revive-a-League Campaign,'' The New York Times, April 17) one can appreciate her dogged determination to regenerate the defunct Women's Pro Basketball League.

title: FINE TAPE DECKS FOR LESS
description: When H.G. Wells wrote ''The Time Machine'' - the famous novel that established the idea of time travel - the shifting of experience in time was science fiction. Fiction has become science since. Experience can be pushed about in time with no trouble at all. Whenever anything is recorded in sound or image, the event is whisked through time and space to be experienced elsewhere some other time. Every recording is such a miracle, and the owners of cassette decks - seen in this light - are habitual miracle workers.

title: Greece and Turkey Seek To Improve Relations
description: The Foreign Ministers of Greece and Turkey met for more than two hours on Thursday in an effort to improve relations.

title: A LETTER NEVER SENT
description: WHEN I last wrote you I had had one miscarriage. You answered, ''Not to worry, the gleam in your eye will be a baby soon.'' Well, now I've had three miscarriages, the last one twins in my fourth month. That gleam in my eye seems to be a falling star.

title: CLASSICS IN SEARCH OF CLASSICAL ACTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: REDISTRICTING PLAN'S EFFECT ON BOARD
description: A NEW set of district lines for the Board of Legislators has finally emerged from months of hearings, political maneuvering and, finally, mapmaking. The changes may lead to a fresh production for the Board: New Faces of 1984.

title: THE PICNIC
description: Eating in a faraway spot generally means transporting a weighty assortment of food, drink and tableware, so probably the most important piece of picnic equipment is a good sturdy hamper.

title: WHY NOT A SUMMIT?
description: The U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms talks in Geneva have reached an impasse, which is likely to develop into a crisis before the end of the year unless both sides make some strenuous new effort to avoid it.

title: FOES SAY DEFENSE BUDGET MAY DISARM ECONOMY
description: To a Marxist, it must seem paradoxical. America's industrial sector is reeling from recession. As last week's report that the index of leading economic indicators rose 1.5 percent in March demonstrated, a recovery has begun, but its vigor and staying power are uncertain. There is pervasive slack - in steel, shipbuilding, aircraft production, mining, construction. Unemployment exceeds 10 percent and may be close to that level when the voters elect a President and new Congress 18 months from now. And yet the 98th Congress is refusing to give President Reagan all the money he seeks for national defense, money that presumably would help move the economy towards full employment.

title: The Secret's Out
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER 22 YEARS, ISLIP PLAN SET
description: ISLIP Town officials have won what they are calling a Pyrrhic victory: a State Department of Environmental Conservation decision to give the town complete authority over a project that has been on a back burner for 22 years.

title: Eileen F. Hoey Is Married To Matthew C. Albanese
description: Eileen Frances Hoey, daughter of Josephine Ann Hoey of New Springville, Staten Island, and Raymond N. Hoey of Suffield, Conn., was married yesterday to Matthew Charles Albanese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Albanese of Jericho, L.I. The Rev. Arthur Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Glen Head, L.I.

title: VENTING SMITHEREENS
description: Not long ago, I had a few moments free from worrying about money and didn't know what to do with them, so I bought a copy of the best-selling book ''What to Worry About and How to Do It,'' hoping to get some ideas.

title: FROM THE FRESHMEN COME CALLS FOR HELP
description: THIS is the season of the envelopes, the thick ones that say ''Yes'' and the thin ones that don't. It is early spring and all over the country another group of high school seniors is waiting for envelopes. For some, even the thick ones don't guarantee success, for in the fine print of the letter are sentences that say there is scholarship money or that there isn't, and that, too, can decide whether the school of choice will be the college of attendance.

title: COLLEGE IN BRIDGEPORT SEEKS A NEW HOME
description: conditioner in his office on a cool spring day.

title: 300 Flee Opry House Area
description: About 300 people living near the Grand Ole Opry House were evacuated today after a railroad tank car derailed and began leaking explosive methanol, officials said.

title: TALKS WITH THE GODS WHO LURE CHILDREN
description: PIPERS AT THE GATES OF DAWN, The Wisdom of Children's Literature. By Jonathan Cott. Illustrated. 327 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: CLASSROOM ZOO IN BRONX ENLIVENS SCIENCE STUDY
description: The odor in Room 201 at Whalen Junior High School in the Bronx may not be the most pleasant, but the students do not mind. In fact, their teachers say, they seem to enjoy going to class since a minizoo was installed this school year.

title: CAVEAT WINNER IN DERBY TRIAL BY NOSE OVER TOTAL DEPARTURE
description: - Until today, a sleek bay colt named Caveat had made a career of closing like a whirlwind only to finish second or third behind good horses. Today, he finally beat some. Though far behind at the top of the stretch, Caveat caught Total Departure in the final stride to win the $60,850 Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs.

title: Janet Laib, a Consultant, Wed to Edward Gottlieb
description: Janet Laib and Edward Gottlieb, public-relations consultants in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride. Associate Justice Bentley Kassal of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: PASTS THAT STAY PRESENT
description: POINTS OF DEPARTURE, By Dan Pagis. Translated by Stephen Mitchell. Introduction by Robert Alter. 123 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.95. AUSTERITIES By Charles Simic. 61 pp. New York: George Braziller. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $4.95. RECKLESS WEDDING By Maria Flook. 65 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95.

title: Beatles Museum Aided
description: The Beatles, considered antiestablishment 20 years ago, won official Government recognition today with a $62,800 grant to help build a Beatles Museum in Liverpool, the Beatles's native city. The $628,000 museum will exhibit Beatles artifacts, including a guitar used by John Lennon, a piano played by Paul McCartney and suits the Beatles wore on stage.

title: A RENEWAL PLUS
description: The rejuvenation of Christopher Street, which is being spurred by the rehabilitation of the landmark Federal Archives Building in the West Village, will get an additional boost this summer with the completion of a retail complex of six shops and a restaurant on the block between West and Washington Streets. The complex is being developed in the ground floor of a four-story building at 162-174 Christopher Street, which used to be a parking garage and actually has two identities.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK CRITICAL OF DODD
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Senator Christopher J. Dodd was ''demagogic'' and ''irresponsible'' in his response on behalf of Congressional Democrats to President Reagan's address Wednesday on Central America.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PROVINCETOWN
description: GREGORY KATZ, formerly on the staff of The Provincetown Advocate, is a reporter with USA Today..

title: Slugger Misses Mark
description: Mike Alfano, a sophomore third baseman for C.W. Post, hit home runs his last three times up Friday in a 16-13 victory over Lehman.

title: THE PLEASURES OF SUMMER
description: Tolstoy's Levin in "Anna Karenina" offers his guest a meal of cucumbers, fresh honey and coarse black bread, and serves it in the protective shade of a beekeeper's cottage. In ''Women in Love,'' D.H. Lawrence describes an equally romantic picnic, but hints at a repast much more boisterous, sensual and opulent.

title: CHILEAN EXILE'S POLITICAL WORK
description: Miguel Littin's ''Alsino and the Condor,'' which opens today at the Cinema 3 Theater, is a politically angry film with the manner of a mournful fable - a very odd but haunting mix. It can't quite bring itself to say what's on its mind, but instead, like a child who is shy, it points at things with furious if silent disapproval.

title: MOLIERE REDUCED TO FARCICAL ANTICS
description: ALMOST as if in overreaction to Broadway's recent staid staging of ''The Misanthrope,'' which closed at the Circle in the Square last month, the Hartford Stage Company production really gets down to another extreme, overloading Moliere's many-layered masterpiece with a sense of farce that is as persistent as the type of characters' nagging insistence on purity and perfection.

title: Eleanor Schrumm Weds K. N. Davis Jr.
description: The marriage of Eleanor M. Schrumm to Kenneth N. Davis Jr. took place yesterday at the Community Church in Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Monkman performed the Methodist ceremony

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. DEBT CUT BY PRUDENTI
description: ANTHONY J. PRUDENTI has not been able to end the internecine warfare that has marked Suffolk Republican politics for the last five years, but the Republican county chairman has apparently resolved the fiscal problems that plagued the Suffolk Republicans for even longer.

title: 14 FEARED DEAD IN FLORIDA CRASH OF NAVY PLANE
description: A Navy airplane carrying 15 people crashed into the St. Johns River today after one of its engines caught fire and exploded five minutes after takeoff from Jacksonville Naval Air Station.

title: Balanchine Rites to Be At Russian Cathedral
description: Requiem services for George Balanchine will be held at the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 93d Street and Park Avenue, tonight at 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 2 P.M.

title: Deborah Packer and L.W. Mumm, Lawyers, Wed
description: Deborah Packer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Avery Packer Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Lawrence William Mumm, son of Mrs. Lawrence George Mumm of East Williston, L.I., and the late Mr. Mumm. The ceremony was performed in the Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit by the Rev. William H. Strain, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Hartman, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: FOR THE SUMMER, REALTY INTERNSHIPS
description: STUDENTS will be watching eviction proceedings in New York City H ousing Court and excavating an Indian burial ground in Rhode Island a s part of internship programs in real estate management and p reservation being offered for the first time this summer.

title: HOW I'LL OUTWIT MOTHER NATURE
description: SPRING makes one feel a whole new resurgence of life - or at least it's supposed to. My intentions of capturing the quintessence of the season abound as I leap down the old porch steps, ready to give my all in making nature an integral part of my life. Wrong.

title: Miss Hays Plans Wedding for June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Hays 2d of Asharoken, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Wakefield Hays, to Douglas Andrew Sloan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sloan of New York and Roxbury, Conn. The wedding is to be in late June.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Military Analysis
description: United States intelligence analysts say that in the course of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's talks in the Middle East, Israel is likely to press for a revival of a 1981 memorandum of strategic understanding. The memorandum, which was suspended by Washington three weeks after it was signed, calls for extensive Israeli cooperation in the deployment of American forces in the Middle East to counter Soviet military threats to the region.

title: A SEAFOOD MOTIF IN SOUTH NORWALK
description: ANEW restaurant, Becket's Landing, has come to the corner of Washington and Water Streets in the revitalized area of South Norwalk. Not only does it look like the previous occupant of the premises, 50 Water Street, it is still using the former restaurant's matches and paper place mats. Exposed brick walls, hanging plants, New Orleans posters and tables close together evoke familiar memories.

title: OBSOLETE ORGANIZATIONS AND THEORIES
description: The Next American Frontier. By Robert B. Reich. Times Books. 324 pages. $16.60. Dangerous Currents. By Lester Thurow. Random House. 239 pages. $16.95.

title: SHOATE OF GERNERALS FINDS REJUVENATION
description: Rod Shoate, the 6-foot-1-inch, 215-pound linebacker for the New Jersey Generals, sat at his locker before practice the other afternoon chuckling at the ironies of his football career.

title: THE NATION
description: To no one's surprise, and by the tally to the disappointment of a very few, San Franciso's Mayor last week won a special election on which there was a lone ballot question: ''Shall Dianne Feinstein be recalled from the office of mayor?'' Of the 158,789 votes cast, 80 percent were ''No's.''

title: Gillies Was Eager To Get a Quick Hit
description: What Clark Gillies wanted upon his return to action for the Islanders tonight was to get hit almost immediately after he stepped onto the ice at Nassau Coliseum.

title: ANSWERING THE CHALLENGE OF EVEREST
description: foot high pass, where colored Buddhist prayer flags flap, our battered green trucks halt, and the American climbers, huddled together for warmth in the back, rouse themselves to look at the objective.

title: TESTS FIND WATER UNAFFECTED BY POCONO MOUNTAINS DUMP
description: Initial tests show no contamination of drinking water by toxic chemicals found recently at a toxic waste dump in the Pocono Mountains, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources has reported.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: The Bloopie Awards

title: INTERPRETERS BRING COUNTY'S PAST TO LIFE
description: AS newborn lambs walk beside their mothers outside the barn and a miller grinds wheat into flour, the aroma of a midday meal being prepared over an open hearth permeates the kitchen. The scene could easily be set in the 18th century, but is, in fact, a recent morning at Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown. The cook, miller and farm workers, dressed in copies of 18th-century farm clothing, are ''interpreters,'' whose task it is to help 20th-century visitors span the centuries and understand the history and life of the people who lived on this once-thriving Dutch farm and trading center.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JUST ANOTHER LOVE STORY By R.R. Knudson. 201 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: 2 Soviet Fishermen Die
description: The police began an investigation today into the deaths from methyl alcohol poisoning of two Soviet fishermen aboard a Soviet trawler south of Singapore, officials said. Five other fishermen aboard the vessel were also taken ill. Two were treated and released, and the other three remained hospitalized in critical condition, the police said.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WOMENFOLKS Growing Up Down South. By Shirley Abbott. 210 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $13.95.

title: WESTCHESTER LAWMAKERS PICK SITES FOR TWO GARBAGE PLANTS
description: In an often noisy session, Westchester County legislators this week designated sites here and in Elmsford for the construction of two disputed garbage-transfer stations. At the same time, they gave surrounding communities until June 1 to propose alternative plans.

title: SCHOOL BOARD ELECTION NEARS IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE ON Tuesday, voters here will go to the polls and, for the first time in 83 years, elect a member to the school board. Until last year, when voters by a 3-to-1 margin approved a referendum calling for an elected school board, all board members were appointed by the mayor. New Rochelle was one of two cities in the state - the other is Rensselaer - with appointed school boards. Under the referendum, incumbent members remain on the board until their terms expire.

title: BARYSHNIKOV PUTS HIS STAMP ON BALLET THEATER
description: When American Ballet Theater opens an unusually long season - 11 weeks - tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it will be the third year the company will be seen in New York with Mikhail Baryshnikov at the helm. As Ballet Theater's artistic director since Sept. 1, 1980, Mr. Baryshnikov - to keep the nautical image - is still adamantly steering the course he first predicted. And yet he is, perhaps surprisingly, also willing to trim his sails.

title: THE COCKTAIL PARTY
description: One of the great pleasures of summer is the light that lingers long after sundown, making the outdoors - whether on a city terrace or a country field - one of the finest places to be.

title: PROPHECY FULFILLED
description: The world of bridge does not have a Nostrodamus, but there is one remarkable prediction which may be on the way to fulfilment. ''I saw in my mind's eye,'' said a famous authority, ''a giant electric board where every bid and play would be followed by the audience as clearly as though they were sitting in the room around the players. I can foresee the day when such a board will be automatically connected by wire with hundreds of similar boards so that every bid will be heard around the world.''

title: Official Under Investigation Quits Environmental Agency
description: Richard Funkhauser, director of international affairs for the Environmental Protection Agency, resigned Friday, the 14th appointee to leave there in two months.

title: POINTS WEST AND SOUTH
description: RUNNING TIME, By Gavin Lambert. 406 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $15.95.SAVANNAH By Eugenia Price. 595 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: AGAIN, WARTIME EVENTS STIR GERMANY
description: Annette Eberly Dumbach and Jud Newborn are writers living in Munich and collaborating on a book about The White Rose to be published by Little, Brown.MUNICH ''Ididn't want to impose myself on the story,'' said the German director Michael Verhoeven. ''I wanted it to be honest, decent and restrained. And I wanted it to be the story of human beings - not the story of icons to be solemnly revered once a year at special services.''

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE name of the Greenwich Philharmonia has been hitting some sour notes with many of its musicians and members of the public of late, and as a result, the name will be changed to the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra beginning in June.

title: A NEW LOOK AT THE 'CRADLE' THAT ROCKED BROADWAY
VENEZUELA STARTS CAMPAIGN FOR DEC. 4 ELECTION
description: Campaigning has begun for the presidential election Dec. 4, and there is some expectation here that, with the economy in a slump, the campaign may turn on specific issues rather than personalities.

title: Susan Bren Is Married To Lewis H. Wirshba
description: Susan Bren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bren of Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to Lewis Howard Wirshba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wirshba of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz, assisted by Cantor Erno Gross, performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND: CANADA'S PLACE APART
description: SONDRA GOTLIEB, whose most recent novel, ''A Woman of Consequence,'' is to be published this month by St. Martin's, is a Canadian who lives in Washington.

title: NEW BISHOP SAYS CHURCH IN NEWARK MUST REACH OUT TO SPANISH-SPEAKING
description: NEWARK FOR the last three weeks, Bishop David Arias, New Jersey's first Hispanic bishop, has been been busy answering congratulatory letters, meeting with leaders of Spanish-speaking societies in the Archdiocese of Newark and tieing up loose ends left over from his ordination.

title: Carol M. Wallace, A Writer, Is Wed To F.W. Hamlin
description: Carol McDonald Wallace, daughter of Carol Gardner Wallace of Fairfield, Conn., and William Noble Wallace of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Frederick Wright Hamlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Huntington Hamlin of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Frederick Hill, assisted by the Rev. Jeffrey Gill and the Rev. Patrick Thyne, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Angels at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: ONE HOME'S TRASH IS ANOTHER'S TREASURE
description: FOR small boys, antiques collectors, furniture refinishers, junk pickers, fireplace lovers, toy repairmen, book collectors, appliance fixers, string savers and scrap-metal dealers, this is the best month of the year.

title: A NEW ORCHESTRA TAKES SHAPE
description: THE stage was empty except for the barest outline of a double bass that could be seen peeking out from behind the left-hand curtain. Protected thus from prying eyes, the musician played, his bow intermittently gliding into view.

title: EVERYONE RIDES KOCH'S ROLLER COASTER
description: The budget was set. The arguments had been settled over which new taxes to propose and how many police officers, teachers and firefighters to hire. All that remained was to write the press release, four pages that were hardly a match for the bulky books containing more than a thousand pages that made up the actual spending plan, but which nevertheless would be Mayor Koch's definitive statement on New York City's fiscal health. But in spite of the decidedly good news to be conveyed last week, there was disagreement among Mr. Koch's top aides over how his statement should convey it.

title: THE OUTER BANKS: DOWN HOME
description: GERALD GOLD is an editor on The New York Times Magazine.

title: INFORMANT IDENTIFIES 5 AT BRINK'S TRIAL
description: An informant has identified the main defendants in a Manhattan trial involving charges that a radical group carried out several robberies and four murders.

title: Barbecue Stew
description: Can red meat be steamed and still be considered barbecued? The Federal Department of Agriculture invited public comment on the question in the spring of 1982, and by June it had received hundreds of angry letters from citizens who thought Big Brother was trying to hop over their backyard fences and tell them how to barbecue the chops.

title: Royal Couple End Tour
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales ended a six-week tour today when they left for a vacation in the Bahamas. They boarded a flight to Los Angeles, from where they will go on for a 10-day vacation on the Bahamas island of Windemere. Their 10-month-old son, Prince William, will return to England.

title: O'NEILL AT YALE
description: Eugene O'Neill's ''Touch of the Poet'' will be the final production of the Yale Repertory season, opening Friday and running through May 21 at the theater, at York and Chapel Streets, New Haven.

title:
GARDENING;
3 POPULAR HEDGES: PRIVET, YEW, HEMLOCK
description: THE three most commonly used hedging plants in this region are privet, yew and hemlock. All three are satisfactory for both the formally clipped and the informally natural hedges.

title: Thai Prime Minister Is Reappointed
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda was reappointed to a new four-year term today after reversing his decision to leave office, the Thai radio said.

title: Giants Are Looking To Marshall at Defensive End
description: The best defensive lineman in a United States college was not drafted on the first round, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants contends.

title: BILL BRADLEY USES OLD LESSONS IN A NEW ARENA
description: WASHINGTON I N Senator Bill Bradley's large new white office with high ceilings and high windows, there is an echo. ''Listen,'' he says. And the sound of the word is faintly reheard. The Democratic United States Senator from New Jersey is standing near the center of the room, a yellow pencil behind his ear, a blue lightweight suit casually worn, his vaulted left eyebrow raised, and he laughs in his throaty manner at the sound. That, too, reverberates lightly. There are other echoes in the room, these silent. They depict what the Senator, with characteristic irony, refers to as his ''past life.''

title: P. P. Grace to Marry Miss McMenamin
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Robert McMenamin of South Orange, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Patricia McMenamin, to Patrick Peyton Grace, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Grace of Manhasset, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
WHEN TRADITIONAL IS RADICAL
description: No two present-day still-life photographers could differ more in their work than Lilo Raymond and Stanley Wulc. The only thing they really have in common is the way that they both stand apart from contemporary trends. Yet each in a different way is producing work of great beauty and expressiveness that is sure to give many viewers much satisfaction.

title: A DANCE COMPANY BRINGS ITS ENSEMBLE SPIRIT FROM LONDON
description: A repertory company for modern dance, geared to year-round work and wih none of the dancers trained in New York, should be something different for New York audiences, believes Brooklyn-born Robert Cohan, whose London Contemporary Dance Theater will perform at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from May 3 through May 8. As Mr. Cohan recently said, ''We're bringing a European-type framework for a dance style that once had American roots, but which is now distinctively different.''

title: Older and Wiser
description: When Bobby Rush raised his hand last week, it wasn't in the clenched fist salute of his days as a Black Panther leader, but to take the oath of office as a Chicago alderman. Mr. Rush, who was defense minister of the party when two of its other leaders were killed in a police raid in 1969, said he still believes ''militancy is an important part of maturation.'' Now 36 years old, he said that blacks would achieve their greatest gains through the exercise of ''black power in the truest sense - political.'' He said he realized politicians ''had the kind of power the Panthers never would.''

title: SOVIET IS WOOING MOSLEMS TO EAST
description: The Soviet Government, in an effort to populate a Siberian region initially intended as a homeland for Jews but shunned by most of them, is now offering inducements to other would-be settlers, these from Moslem Central Asia.

title:
Energy Conservation and Budget Relief;
IT MIGHT WORK IN A DREAM WORLD
description: ONCE again, as has happened so often in the past, those concerned w ith raising revenues for the Federal Government are casting covetouse yes on petroleum as a source of funds.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: A baritone and a string quartet were the most interesting of last week's debut performers. Donald Collup's program in Town Hall Wednesday swung back and forth between lieder and the French song tradition but also offered Handel's familiar ''Ombra mai fu'' from ''Serse'' and a world premiere - Ned Rorem's ''Three Calamus Poems,'' after Whitman. They were commissioned by Mr. Collup.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: A Salute to Israel parade begins at noon, moving up Fifth Ave- nue from 57th Street to 86th Street, then turning east to Third Avenue.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN POET ON HIS IMPRISONMENT
description: IN 1975, at the height of his literary acclaim, South Africa's leading poet in the Afrikaans language, the 36-year-old Breyten Breytenbach, was imprisoned by the Government of his fellow Afrikaners for clandestine activities against their apartheid system of racial laws. Released last December and now back in his Paris home with his wife, Yolande, Mr. Breytenbach is still numbed by his seven years in prison and the shock of reentry into freedom. But he consented to talk about how he came to ''invade'' his own country to campaign against apartheid, how he was caught, and how his jailers treated him before sending him into exile.

title: Reagan Draws The Line but Debate Continues
description: President Reagan warned Congress last week it would be jeopardizing ''the national security of all the Americas'' if it clipped his wings in El Salvador and Nicaragua. The unusual Presidential address to a joint session of Congress achieved a short-term (and perhaps temporary) gain; two committees delayed until this week potentially damaging votes on military aid to San Salvador and clandestine operations, no longer very secret, against the Sandinist regime. Members of Congress normally duck rather than challenge Presidential judgment on security matters.

title: AN ECONOMIST IN THE HOUSE
description: HOW WE LIVE, By Victor R. Fuchs. 293 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: HIGHER EDUCATION'S NEW ECONOMICS
description: Edward B. Fiske is education editor of The Times. MORGAN L. Leach is a 21-year-old native of Dillon, S.C., whose recently widowed mother earns $8,000 a year trimming carpets in a local factory. By putting together a combination of Federal grants and loans, his own summer earnings and a loan from a relative, Leach managed to make it through three years at St. Augustine College, a black institution in Raleigh, N.C. He was hoping to graduate this June and become a physical therapist.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Dedicated Women The Radio City Music Hall Rockettes -36 women dancers from 5-feet-5-and-a-half-inches to 5-feet-8-and-a-half-inches tall - are, according to Gwen Verdon, ''a different breed of woman.'' Miss Verdon herself, of course, is also unique. The nation's preeminent Broadway musical star has won four Tony Awards - for ''Can Can,'' ''Damn Yankees,'' ''New Girl in Town'' and ''Redhead.'' She also starred in ''Sweet Charity,'' ''Chicago'' and the movie version of ''Damn Yankees.'' Her knowledge of the Rockettes grows out of her recent role in ''Legs,'' a made-for-television movie - the first such film to be shot in the Music Hall. In ''Legs,'' a story of life backstage with the famous chorus line, Miss Verdon portrays the Rockettes' choreographer. It will be broadcast Monday on ABC at 9 P.M.

title:
Instruction for U.S. Management;
JAPANESE COMPETITION CAN BE HEALTHY
description: IN the hand to hand combat between the United States and Japan in h igh technology, the industry and labor leaders who incessantly c omplain that Japanese corporate gangsters use treacherous economic k arate are merely afraid of fair fight. If you listen closely, you'llh ear them demand that Japanese companies be required to fight a ccording to American boxing rules of the 1930's.

title: WOMEN PLAYWRIGHTS: NEW VOICES IN THE THEATER
description: Marsha Norman's '' 'Night, Mother,'' an aging woman lives with her adult daughter in an ordinary house on a lonely country road. Minutes after the play begins, the daughter announces that she is planning to kill herself. '' 'Night, Mother'' becomes the heart-rending battle for the daughter's life. The horrified mother tries every possible method of dissuasion while the daughter calmly puts their house in order. By the end of the evening - 90 minutes without intermission - the audience has shared a catharsis of grief and pain.

title: TOUGHNESS IS REASON FOR THATCHER'S HIGH RATING
