description: Since the end of the post-war boom in 1973, there has emerged in the West a pattern of defeat for incumbents. During that period, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter have lost in the United States, James Callaghan in Britain, Valery Giscard d'Estaing in France, Helmut Schmidt in Germany and others in Spain, Sweden, Greece and so on. Some countries have moved left, some right, but few have stayed put.

title: African Beliefs a Danger, Pope Tells Zaire Bishops
description: Pope John Paul II told seven bishops from Zaire today that they should guard against allowing African beliefs to interfere with Roman Catholic doctrine.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IT'S not all fun and games when the people responsible for the education of Long Island's children go conventioneering. Some 200 of them were in San Francisco over the weekend attending the National School Boards Association annual convention.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD Retold and Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 6) LITTLE RED CAP By the Brothers Grimm. Translated by Elizabeth D. Crawford. Illustrated by Lisbeth Zwerger. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Co. $9.50. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: DENNY'S 2-HITTER STOPS ASTROS
description: Pete Rose hit a triple to highlight a two-run sixth inning, and John Denny pitched a two-hitter for his third straight complete game to lead the Phillies to an 8-0 victory today over the Houston Astros.

title: The Kind of People in the Nuclear Debate
description: In his article ''Tactics in the Debate on Shoreham'' (Opinion Page, April 3), Herbert Jaffe portrays antinuclear activists as demagogues who are more interested in frightening their fellow citizens than in coming to grips with the realities of nuclear power. He views public hearings as forums for ''untutored laymen'' to engage in ''a campaign of obstruction and deception.''

title: A Peaceful Klan Rally Is Held in Connecticut
description: Surrounded by tight police security, about 30 members of the Ku Klux Klan staged a noisy but peaceful rally today on the front steps of City Hall in this central Connecticut industrial city.

title: 'Wilderness' Opens May 5
description: ''The Wilderness of Shur,'' a play about the civil rights of Southern Jews and blacks after the Civil War, will begin performances on May 5 at the New Federal Theater at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street.

title: Lendl and McEnroe in Final
description: Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, overcame a loss of concentration and defeated the hometown favorite, Bill Scanlon, 6-1, 6-7, 6-3, 6-3, in the semifinals of the $300,000 World Championship Tennis Finals.

title: THE CREATION OF A FEMINIST THEOLOGY
CINEMA CHIC CATCHES THE EYE BUT MISSES THE MIND
description: In ''The Hunger,'' a new film directed to the nines by Tony Scott, Catherine Deneuve and David Bowie play the achingly chic Miriam and John, who live in an East Side Manhattan palazzo more grand than most embassies, surrounded by several millennia of art objects, without any visible means of support and not even any visible domestic help.

title: Kathleen Benner to Wed
description: The engagement of Kathleen Diane Benner to Christopher Haskell Duble, son of Nancy S. Duble of North Haven, Conn., and Peter W. Duble of Hamden, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Benner of Gibsonia, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. A September wedding is planned.

title: A Different View Of 'Democracy'
description: Joan Fallon, in her defense of the Minute of Silence Law (Opinion Page, April 3), suggests that ''democracy means comprise, without either side giving up rights.''

title: REVUE: TRIO IN 'TRUST US' AT WEST BANK
description: ''In l983, it's not enough to live your life, you must survive it,'' proclaim the cabaret trio Weeden, Finkle & Fay in their comic revue, ''Trust Us,'' at the West Bank Cafe. Billed as ''a musical therapy,'' the show - which plays through tonight and returns May 6 - pitches a self-help program to the audience in a mixture of patter songs, video sequences and exhortatory speeches.

title: THE DOLLARS CASTRO ONCE WANTED-BUT NEVER ASKED FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Human Cycle'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Foster Wed To James Smith
description: Laura B. Foster, director of development of the Youth Counseling League of New York, was married yesterday to James S. Smith of New York and Narragansett, R. I., a partner in Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, New York. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Alanson Houghton.

title: MYSTIC AQUARIUM FIGHTS A FATAL INFECTION
description: STAFF members at the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium, the largest tourist attraction in Connecticut, were fighting last week to control a bacterial infection that apparently led to the deaths of two dolphins within five days.

title: Co-op as a Family Affair?
description: Question: Can the board of directors of my cooperative deny me permission to make my daughter either a co-owner or owner of my apartment? I would like to assure that she can live here without having to bear estate taxes. ... M.G., Bronx Answer: Under the standard form of a proprietary lease, the board has the right to deny permission while the owner is alive. Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, says that he advises boards not to allow this to happen because of family disputes that sometimes arise.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Marking a New Line With Markdowns

title: Martha M. Robinson Marries
description: Martha Marie Robinson, daughter of Bishop Harold Barrett Robinson and Mrs. Robinson of Buffalo, was married yesterday to James Henry Higgins 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Higgins of Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: HIGH-TECH WON'T PROVIDE MOST NEW JOBS
description: FROM what we read and discuss with others, it is obvious that we are in a period of uncertain employment and our economy is on the verge of transforming itself from a manufacturing work environment to a service, or what some will label, a technology work environment. In fact, Connecticut is second only to California in the number of persons employed in high-technology enterprises.

title: BRAZILIANS HOPEFUL OF AN ACCORD ON LIBYAN PLANES
description: Officials said today that they were hopeful of an agreement soon to end a diplomatic impasse over the presence of four Libyan planes detained here while carrying arms to Nicaragua. The Brazilians are insisting that the Libyans leave without the arms, and the Libyans say they will not depart without them.

title: BY PETER COWIE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Cowie is a British critic and film historian. His latest book is ''Ingmar Bergman: A Critical Biography'' (Scribner's). LONDON Tethered horses, awaiting their cue, champ nervously on straw. ''Sir's coming,'' whispers a technician. Red lights on four mobile cameras wink on and off, and a clapperboy stands ready. It is 2:30 P.M. in the Granada Television studios in Manchester, and ''Sir'' is the affectionate, respectful greeting accorded Sir Laurence (now actually Lord) Olivier, about to make his first appearance of the day on set as King Lear.

title: PAPERBACKS NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE AUTO ALBUM. By Tad Burness. (Houghton Mifflin, $6.95.) Tad Burness, who has written several books about cars, culled the pictures and text for this trade paperback original from his syndicated newspaper column. ''The Auto Album'' depicts and comments on dozens of models dating from the 1890's to the 1970's, including a ''most unusual Duesenberg'' with a ''modernized'' front end (see above). Aficionados of advertising as well as of cars may be interested in ''IS THE BUG DEAD?'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $9.95) which will be published later this month. It's a compilation of Doyle Dane Bernbach ads for the Volkswagen Beetle.

title: THE RELIEF MAY BE BRIEF FOR SMALL FARMS
description: As the Reagan Administration's new payment in kind and acreage reduction programs are edging into place in the rain-sodden South and Middle West, a wide-ranging debate is getting under way. It involves questions about which types of farmers will ultimately be helped the most, how much the farm supply merchants will be hurt, and what, if anything, the nonplanting of so much grain and cotton land will do to retail food supplies.

title: A Report Bombs In Argentina
description: As a fiasco, it may not rank with the Falklands invasion. Nevertheless, the report issued last week by the Argentine military on its role in extirpating leftist subversion during the 1970's angered a lot of people who had counted on more frank detail on how thousands of Argentinians had disappeared than the armed forces were willing to admit.

title: Spain Imposes Civilian Justice
description: Spain's generals and admirals last week lost their venerable claim to separate and often lenient justice. In a bold assertion of civilian ascendancy, the Supreme Court in Madrid sharply increased the prison sentences military judges had given 22 officers who botched a 1981 attempt to overthrow the Government.

title: PERFORMANCE PAYS TRIBUTE TO BALANCHINE
description: Lincoln Kirstein stepped in front of the curtain a few minutes before the New York City Ballet's matinee began yesterday at the New York State Theater.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT: WHAT HAPPENS NEXT?
description: For the last several months the future of the Shoreham nuclear power plant has been uncertain. Its possible operation has been stalled by a dispute between Suffolk County officials and executives from the Long Island Lighting Company, which owns the $3.2 billion nuclear plant. Following are questions and answers that highlight recent developments in what has become the case of the nation's most expensive nuclear reactor:

title: ASSEMBLY TO WEIGH SMOKING ISSUES
description: AFTER listening for months to the arguments of health organizations and representatives of tobacco manufacturers, Connecticut lawmakers are preparing to vote on a bill that would require some employers to provide nonsmoking areas in the work place.

title: U.S. ACCUSES LABORATORY OF BOTCHING CANCER TESTS
description: A former technician in one of the nation's largest research laboratories has testified in Federal court that hundreds of mice died or were lost through negligence in pesticide and herbicide studies for cancer-causing agents.

title: Epistolary Offensive
description: The Soviet Union widened the Washington-Moscow missive gap last week when the Kremlin made public a letter Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, had personally fired off to Samantha Smith, a fifthgrader in Maine.

title: L.I.'S ALGER WINNER
description: HENRY VISCARDI JR., who for many years has been a leader in the field of education for the disabled, will be among this year's recipients of the Horatio Alger Award for Distinguished Americans.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA GOVERNOR CALLS STORES TO ASK BOOK'S REMOVAL
description: Gov. William J. Janklow said Friday that he was trying to call all book store owners in South Dakota to ask them to remove ''In the Spirit of Crazy Horse'' from their shelves because he believes it libels him.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: HOW 'MY ONE AND ONLY' CAME TO BROADWAY
description: When the production of ''My One and Only'' was first announced a little over a year ago, it was supposed to be the occasion for three gala events. It was to be a revival of the 1927 George and Ira Gershwin musical ''Funny Face,'' with a new book but still featuring such classic songs as '' 'S Wonderful'' and ''How Long Has This Been Goin' On?'' The show was to mark the return to tap shoes of Tommy Tune, the acclaimed director and choreographer (''Nine,'' ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine''), who hasn't performed on Broadway since 1974, when he won a Tony Award for his show-stopping performance in ''Seesaw.'' And it was to herald the Broadway debut of Twiggy, the former English fashion model turned actress and singer.

title: MUDDY WATERS, BLUES PERFORMER, DIES
description: Muddy Waters, who played a key role in the development of electric blues and rock-and-roll and was the greatest contemporary exponent of the influential Mississippi Delta blues style, died in his sleep early yesterday at his home near Chicago. The singer and guitarist was pronounced dead at Chicago's Good Samaritan Hospital, reportedly of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: MORE THAN JUST THE LEADERS OF THE RACE
description: DICTIONARY OF AMERICAN NEGRO BIOGRAPHY, Edited by Rayford W. Logan and Michael R. Winston. 680 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $50.

title: Miss Goldman Is the Bride Of David Stephen Mathias
description: Lynn Gale Goldman, an assistant attorney general of the State of Maryland, and David Stephen Mathias, an associate with the Washington office of the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: ART OF THE MAMLUKS ON VIEW IN HARTFORD
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum's installation of ''Art of the Mamluks'' is handsome -one of the best ever at this museum. Designed by Charles Froom, it is a sequence of softly lighted rooms with ogee-arched doorways and walls painted raw umber and beige.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 7 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 4 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high-school set. 3 3 4 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 4 4 5 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 5 5 5 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 6 6 5 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.) London bankers gamble on the ability of a horse breeder to produce a star race horse. 7 7 8 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, 5.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 8 15 2 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer.

title: I.B.M. SITE DEBATED IN NEW CASTLE
description: A PROPOSED International Business Machines laboratory in New Castle has won a tentative welcome from town officials for the taxes it will contribute - but not from some of the neighbors, who say they would be sandwiched between the new laboratory complex and the existing I.B.M. Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown, one and a half miles to the north.

title: Maine Moose Hunt Vote Set
description: The Maine Supreme Court gave its approval Friday for a November referendum on outlawing the state's moose hunt. Upholding a lower court decision, the court ruled 6 to 1 that a group called Smoosa, for Save Maine's Only Official State Animal, had collected enough petition signatures to force a referendum. The referendum will have no effect on this year's moose season, set for Sept. 19-24.

title: No Headline
description: Real-Life Dressing I've been trying to figure out what it is that makes Bill Cunningham's pictures of Michaela McElroy so intriguing (''Real-Life Dressing,'' March 27). Miss McElroy's selection of clothes - smart, understated, self-confident -is not unusual, nor are her not inconsiderable good looks.

title: Miss Burchenal Becomes Bride
description: Barbara Fahys Burchenal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Holland Burchenal of Noroton, Conn., was married yesterday to Bradford Worth Landers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Worth Landers of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Miss Ross Is Wed To C. W. Kiersted In Bernardsville
description: Parthenia Ross, daughter of Mr. a nd Mrs. Edmund Burke Ross of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher William Kiersted, son of Mrs. William Cole Miller Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Lieut. Comdr. Wynkoop Kiersted 3d, U.S.N. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Alfred Niesa Jr.

title: NEW BOOK SAYS MAO ORDERED LIN BIAO KILLED
description: A book to be published this month asserts that Lin Biao, a former Chinese Defense Minister, was ordered assassinated 12 years ago by Mao Zedong and that many important elements of the case have been covered up in official Chinese accounts.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOLLY, McCULLOUGH, & TOM THE ROGUE By Kathleen Stevens. Illustrated by Margot Zemach. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $10.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: Commodities; '17-Hour Option' For Metals
description: BECAUSE their markets operate around the clock for most of the week, sleep has always been a precious commodity for metals traders. To protect their clients' futures or cash positions in these commodities, many brokerage houses keep their metals departments staffed throughout the night in case some important development affects the platinum, gold, silver or copper markets.

title: Advertising; Sears Shift To Ogilvy, Needham
description: largest national advertiser, on Friday consolidated much of the advertising of its Sears Merchandise Group from five agencies to two.

title: A WOMEN'S RIGHTS HANDBOOK
description: A revised handbook on women's rights has been published by the American Civil Liberties Union. Entitled ''The Rights of Women,'' it first appeared 10 years ago and has been completely revised by its authors, Susan Deller Ross, special counsel for sex-discrimination litigation in the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, and Ann Barcher, a lawyer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: OLD BLUES TAKE OARS TO HARLEM RIVER
description: In thin-skinned craft, needle-narrow and minnow-quick, a gentlemanly assemblage of former oarsmen from the Oxford and Cambridge University crews took to the water yesterday as waves, not of the Thames but the Harlem River, slapped against the sides of their boats.

title: California Building Panel Says Shoddy Work Rises
description: Many new buildings in earthquake-prone California are unsafe because the construction industry is cutting corners, state officials said today.

title: REAGAN, FLUTTERING
description: Lie detectors do not detect lies or determine truth; they merely indicate when you are relaxed or tense about giving an answer. A smooth or psychopathic liar can beat the machine; a truthteller, intimidated or nervous about being hooked up to the machine, can often be branded a liar.

title: BURNS BACK PLAYING THE PALACE
description: GEORGE BURNS, who is 87 years old, has written another book, his fifth since becoming an elder jokesman, but the point to be made here is that tonight he is going to play the Palace, which is celebrating only its 70th birthday this year.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CUT BENEFIT TO DYING IN HOSPICE CARE
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted rules that would reduce the value of a new Medicare benefit for the terminally ill to about 60 percent of the level envisioned by Congress.

title: FULL STORES AND EMPTY POCKETS TELL CHILE'S STORY
description: It was a Sunday, and the 80 people who trudged through the church-supported soup kitchen in a backyard in this poor suburb of Santiago shared spaghetti and beans, with turnips on the side.

title: RYAN'S STRUGGLE TO GLORY
description: LOOKING back, as one is often asked to do after reaching a milestone, Nolan Ryan finds it easier now to be philosophical about the early days of his baseball career. He has accomplished a great deal in 16 seasons and there have been no lingering side-effects from those four uncomfortable years among the masses in New York.

title: Frevold Captures Drake Marathon
description: Keith Frevold of Des Moines, battling stomach cramps, rain and a strong wind, took the lead in the final mile and won the Drake Relays marathon today. Frevold was timed in 2 hours 34 minutes 40 seconds.

title: CHARLES MCCABE
description: Charles McCabe, a veteran columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle, was found dead today, apparently of natural causes, in his home on Telegraph Hill.

title: TV: 'LEGS,' A STORY ABOUT BEING A ROCKETTE
description: THE script is hardly inspired, and the production can get noticeably chintzy at times, but there is something charming about ''Legs,'' the television movie on Channel 7 at 9 tonight. This is another of those ''making it in show-business'' tales, but with a slight twist. Instead of the young dancer's being plucked from the chorus to become an overnight star (''Go out there and wow them, kid''), ''Legs'' offers three young women simply trying to get a job on the chorus line. The line in this case happens to be the Radio City Music Hall's Rockettes.

title: Loop-Run Record
description: Mary Decker set an American record today of 31 minutes 51.2 seconds in the women's 10,000-meter loop run. Her effort broke the record of 32:04 held by Jan Merrill. A loop run is a road race that begins and ends in the same place.

title: UNKNOWN QUANTITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolina Governor Bids Reagan Act on Schools
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. of North Carolina urged President Reagan today to call a conference of governors to improve the nation's schools.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FEUD. By Thomas Berger. 265 pages. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95.

title: Cruz Posts Upset Over Verderosa
description: Undefeated Reyes Cruz, fighting outside the Dominican Republic for the first time, upset Johnny Verderosa today with a 10-round unanimous decision in a junior-welterweight bout.

title:
RELATIONSHIPS;
NEW LOOK AT FEARS OF CHILDREN
description: SOME fears transcend time; they occur in every generation of c hildren: The toddler who clings to his mother on the first day of n ursery school. The child who cannot sleep in the dark. The y oungster who trembles at the sight of snakes in the zoo.

title: Bridge:
description: There was excitement in this quiet city on the Derwent River Friday as the Tasmanian team inflicted the first substantial defeat on Kathie Wei's Precision quartet of touring New York experts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Promoting the Vote

title: OUTLAYS UP
description: Two months after securing a multibillion-dollar rescue package through international financing, Brazil, the world's largest debtor nation, is seeking to borrow more money.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A May Day Mass For the 'Black Madonna'

title: Mary-Jane Moskowitz Is Married to a C.P.A.
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I., yesterday Mary-Jane Moskowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Moskowitz of Port Washington, L.I., was married to Henry M. Dachowitz, son of Rabbi Pincus Dachowitz of Brooklyn and the late Seyma Sacksner Dachowitz. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony.

title: Damage in Missouri Tornado That Killed 2 Put at $5 Million
description: Volunteers helped their neighbors clean up damage today from a tornado that killed two people and caused at least $5 million in damage.

title: OPPOSE SANDINISTS OPENLY
description: United States support for the democratic rebellion against the Nicaraguan Government is right and necessary, but because the Reagan Administration is doing it the wrong way and not presenting its case effectively, it stands a good chance of failing in Congress and on the ground. President Reagan's speech to Congress last Wednesday was a good start, but he should go further, making a bold and open case for supporting the democratic rebels.

title: Arthur Hirsch, Lawyer, Marries Janice Turner
description: Janice Warren Turner, daughter of Gus C. Turner Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va., and Mrs. Warren Jones Semel of San Diego, was married yesterday in New York, to Arthur I. Hirsch, son of Estelle Hirsch of New York and the late Joseph A. Hirsch. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony at Windows on the World.

title: CHINA JAILS 4 PRIESTS FOR NOT SEVERING VATICAN TIES
description: Four elderly Catholic priests in Shanghai have been sent back to prison for up to 15 years for offenses that included maintaining ties with the Vatican and sending abroad information about Catholics in China.

title: 10 REVIVE THE PONY EXPRESS WHERE TRUCKS DARE NOT GO
description: High in the pine-covered red foothills of the Sierras, a group of men have brought to life a symbol of romance and adventure in the Old West.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING CASE AND A SHATTERED FAMILY
description: They had come to Manhattan hoping to see the circus at Madison Square Garden Saturday afternoon, but there was no matinee. So Anita Karpowich, her sister, Margaret, and their three nephews and a niece visited the Empire State Building and then strolled about Manhattan.

title: L.I. COMMUNITY AIDING DOCTOR ILL WITH LEUKEMIA
description: About two years ago, Dr. Edgar Frenkel, a 34-year-old psychiatrist from Oceanside, L.I., found that his tennis game tired him more than usual.

title: A HUMBLING OBLIGATION
description: President Reagan's endorsement of the Scowcroft Commission's report on strategic forces brings some good news at last. The report contains several important breakthroughs in the approach to the nuclear arms race.

title: BRIEFING
description: A 'Roast' for Udall

title: RAIDERS MAY SEEK FURTHER LITIGATION
description: Three weeks after the Los Angeles Raiders' antitrust lawsuit against the National Football League ended, there are indications that the Raiders are considering additional litigation.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Costa Rica Frees Ship With Nicaragua Cargo
description: Costa Rica has released a freighter loaded with 200 tons of explosives for Nicaragua after determining the cargo was intended for geological research, Attorney General Francisco Villalobos announced.

title: Mrs. Thatcher to Get Award
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain will be given an award by the Winston Churchill Foundation of the United States at a dinner at the British Embassy May 27 during her visit to Washington.

title: TWO-WAY CABLE TV NETWORK STARTS
description: Beginning tonight, a novel two-way cable television network will allow 180,000 viewers in six cities to register instant opinions about programs and advertising they see on their home screens.

title: Chinese Steel Output
description: Chinese steel production in 1982 rose 4.4 percent, to 37.16 million metric tons, compared with 1981, the State Statistical Bureau said in its annual report. Last May, China said it planned a 4 percent cut in steel output, to 34 million tons, in 1982.

title: STAGE: 'MY ONE AND ONLY,' 'NEW' GERSHWIN SHOW
description: CAPT. BILLY BUCK CHANDLER (Tommy Tune), the derring-do 1920's hero of the musical ''My One and Only,'' dreams of being ''the first man in history to fly nonstop to Paris.'' It's giving away nothing to say that Billy at last takes flight in Act II, and, as he does, so does the entertainment that contains him. The second half of the handsome show at the St. James levitates with some of the most inspired choreography Broadway has seen in several seasons - all set to the celestial music of George Gershwin and danced to kill by a company glittering in Art Deco swank.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday about Gov. John Y. Brown of Kentucky incorrectly identified the state's former Transportation Secretary. He is Frank Metts.

title: News Analysis
description: The Senate, deeply divided over how to shrink Federal budget deficits, begins debate Monday on a Congressional budget resolution for 1984.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO BACK PLAN TO CUT COST OF MEDICAID
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch have agreed on a program that would require Medicaid recipients in East Harlem to receive all their health care from designated hospitals and physicians.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEF
description: Richard Petty avoided a multi-car crash at mid-race and went on to win the Winston 500 race today - the only Grand National stock car event he had not won.

title: ROCKETS LAND NEAR BEIRUT BUILDING HOUSING SHULTZ
description: Two artillery rockets were fired directly over the roof of the United States Ambassador's residence here early today as Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other key officials slept inside.

title: Radio News Programs Suffer in Deregulation
description: The Radio Television News Directors Association has released a survey that shows the deregulation of the radio industry has prompted some stations to cut back on their news and public affairs programs.

title: ROCK: MARTHA AND MUFFINS
description: LIKE the Talking Heads, their most obvious prototype, Martha and the Muffins, the Toronto-based rock quartet that has attracted critical attention in recent years, was founded by art school students. And like the Talking Heads, their Canadian cousins specialize in subtly colored musical collages that blend penetrating lyrics about the confusions of urban life with a jerky pogo beat and funk guitar and bass figuration.

title: LATE BLOOMERS MAKING A CHARGE
description: IT rained so much here yesterday morning that it was 5-2 against getting a car out of the stable gate at Churchill Downs. Several horsemen who bucked the odds were stranded in the windshield-deep lake that used to be Longwood Avenue. This was not just an ordinary downpour. It was an almost-Biblical deluge, the type that usually blows itself empty after 15 minutes or so.

title: Post-Civil War Drama
description: The 1983 Ethnic Heritage Series will open at Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater at 466 Grand Street on Thursday with Nicholas Biel's play ''The Wilderness of Shur.'' Mr. Biel's drama, which runs through May 29, is about relationships between black and Jewish Americans from 1865 to 1869. Mr. Biel, a dairy farmer and playwright, wrote ''Winners and Losers,'' about the military government in Germany after World War II. For information: 598-0400.

title: WHEN MOSCOW CHEATS ON ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: VIETNAM CONSEQUENCE: QUIET FROM THE MILITARY
description: In the widening and increasingly intense debate over the Reagan Administration's policy on Central America, one voice has been noticeably quiet. The nation's senior military officers have had little to say in public.

title: Key to a City Council That Represents All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paula Roland Married In Upper Nyack, N.Y.
description: Paula Elise Roland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Roland of Teaneck, N.J., and Paul Charles Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marcus of Riverdale, the Bronx, were married yesterday by Rabbi George Stern at Temple Beth Torah in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

title: NIGERIA FACES DEBT PROBLEMS
description: Not long ago, Nigeria was every banker's favorite African country. Abundant oil reserves, a large population, a free market economy and solidly Western orientation were among the attributes that made Nigeria the kind of customer that inspires confidence in those who make it their business to lend money.

title: MCENROE TOPPLES LENDL IN FIVE SETS
description: John McEnroe ran off 7 straight points in a fifth-set tiebreaker to beat Ivan Lendl and win a record third World Championship Tennis Finals today. The scores were 6-2, 4-6, 6-3, 6-7, 7-6, with the last tiebreaker ending at 7-0.

title: BUSINESS PLANNERS LOOK TO TELECOMMUNICATIONS
description: Cities and towns have historically sprung up and grown along major transportation routes such as rivers, railroads and highway interchanges. But the next ''crossroads'' could well be those places with access to modern electronic communications, according to urban development officials, planners and real estate developers.

title: QUIET COVE IS SCENE OF FAMILY FISHING RITUAL
description: NEARLY 50 years ago, in the springtime of my days and of the year, I had first pulled white perch from the upper reaches of Town Cove on Tisbury Great Pond and since then had taken each of my children-Stephen, Jeffrey, Mary, Alison - to the spot.

title: ISLANDERS NOW WARY OF BRUINS
description: The Islanders know the fear factor in the playoffs. They met it head-on in the first round last year, narrowly escaping elimination by the Pittsburgh Penguins. This year, while pursuing their fourth consecutive National Hockey League championship, they have felt an occasional tremble. Their four-of-seven-game series with the Rangers was tied after four games, the Rangers taking control with consecutive victories at Madison Square Garden.

title: TAYLOR LAW: NOT FOR RAIL DISPUTES
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens. 7:35 P.M. First meeting of the season, and opener of a three-game series against the Astros, making their first visit to Shea this season. Despite a 1-9 record on the road, the Mets are playing over .500 ball at home. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Royals at Kansas City, 8:35 P.M. Yankees' Manager Billy Martin has appealed the three-game suspension he was assessed Saturday for a run-in with an umpire, so he will be directing the team pending resolution of the appeal. A hearing is set for May 9. (Television - Cablevision, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8:30 P.M.) Basketball Bucks vs. Boston Celtics at Milwaukee, 8 P.M. Game 4 of Eastern Conference semifinal series. Celtics were stunned in the first three games of this series, losing the first two games of a playoff in Boston for the first time in their history. The Bucks can sweep today. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.). Nuggets vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Denver, 9:30 P.M. Fourth game of Western Conference semifinal series. Johnny Moore, San Antonio point guard, who previously set a playoff record with 20 assists, scored all 9 San Antonio points in overtime for a career-high 39 in the last meeting to give the Spurs a commanding 3-0 lead in this series, which they are looking to sweep tonight.

title: Rosario Captures Lightweight Title
description: Edwin Rosario captured the vacated World Boxing Council lighweight title today by winning a unanimous decision over Mexico's Jose-Luis Ramirez.

title: MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983; International
description: Brazil, which owes an estimated $88 billion abroad, says it needs more aid despite its recent huge borrowings from international lending agencies, governments and private banks. Officials say they need more time for economic measures to work. (Page D1.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Madrid Marathon As a Manhattan Fantasy

title: Skiing at 82
description: Charlie Nebel didn't intend to complete 1 million vertical feet of recorded skiing on the day before his 82d birthday, it just happened that way. When asked about his achievement, he dismissed it, saying, ''Oh, that. I got a nice belt buckle.''

title: PERILOUS LATIN POLICY
description: President Reagan's speech to Congress last Wednesday signals his determination to pursue the course - based on a disastrous self-fulfilling prophecy - he has followed in Central America since coming to office. Instead of trying to contain unrest in Nicaragua and El Salvador, the Administration is apparently going to continue to spread upheaval throughout the region.

title: TILLING FIGHTS BTR TAKEOVER
description: It was never a secret that BTR, a giant British industrial conglomerate, wanted to expand further into energy-related activities, particularly in the United States. Nonetheless, the City of London, Britain's Wall Street, found BTR's bid on April 11 for Thomas Tilling, valued at about $900 million, something of an eyeopener: both the offer and its backing by City underwriters were among the largest in Britain's corporate history.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ISOLATE BORDER AREA
description: A series of bridge bombings and coordinated attacks by Salvadoran guerrillas along the Honduran border constituted one of the most destructive rebel strikes in months, according to officials and residents of the area.

title: RUNDOWN CITY BUILDINGS CALLED HOUSING RESOURCE
description: Residential buildings that New York City owns through tax foreclosures were viewed last week at state hearings as a ''housing resource for the future,'' but one that would require considerable subsidies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECALL

title: Chen of Taiwan Wins Golf Playoff
description: The Taiwan pro Chen Tze-ming overcame drizzling rains and high winds in a playoff to win the $294,000 Chunichi-Crowns golf tournament today in Nagoya.

title: YANKEES' OFFENSE EXCELS IN VICTORY
description: Crammed into Billy Martin's sauna-like office, the Yankees sat through 39 minutes of meetings today - 18 minutes with George Steinbrenner, 21 minutes with Martin. Then they burst out into the fresh air at Arlington Stadium and made what the owner and manager hoped was a fresh start to the rest of their season.

title: OILERS BEAT HAWKS FOR 3-0 SERIES LEAD
description: Glenn Anderson's goal at 13 minutes 5 seconds of the third period tonight gave the Edmonton Oilers a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks and a 3-0 lead in the Campbell Conference championship playoffs.

title: Two Die in Accidents on L.I.; Drunken Driving Is Charged
description: Two Nassau County residents were killed in traffic accidents on Long Island early Sunday and the drivers of cars involved have both been charged with driving while intoxicated, according to Suffolk and Nassau County police.

title: TIMBER INDUSTRY HOPEFUL AND SKEPTICAL OF REBOUND
description: On the lush slopes of the Cascade Mountains, the snowpack is melting, and lumberjacks are returning to the forests to help fill the nation's strongest demand for lumber in more than two years.

title: U.S. SEEKS DATA ON BABY DEATHS IN CONNECTICUT
description: The deaths in Connecticut hospitals of newborn infants with severe birth defects have led to a dispute between the state and the Federal Government.

title: OPERA: 'JEREMIAH' IS REVIVED
description: In 1962, Binghamton's Tri-Cities Opera Company presented the world premiere of Myron Fink's ''Jeremiah.'' The work received several performances, an enthusiastic press and then, like many other worthy American operas, disappeared. Last week, Tri-Cities Opera remounted ''Jeremiah'' at the Forum, a beautifully restored one-time vaudeville house in downtown Binghamton. Saturday night's performance proved that ''Jeremiah,'' 21 years after its premiere, remains compelling.

title: CHICAGO POLICE FOUND TO DISMISS CASES ERRONEOUSLY
description: For decades detectives here have dismissed a large number of serious criminal cases by classifying them ''unfounded,'' an internal Police Department audit concluded last week.

title: HOW TO RAISE THE COST OF HOSPITAL STAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: VICTORY TO SMITH'S TWOSOME
description: Geoff Smith, a Providence College student from England, and his partner, Margaret Groos of Eugene, Ore., won the Trevira Twosome, a 10-mile race for couples at Central Park yesterday. Smith finished ahead of all the male runners and Miss Gross the women.

title: California Doctor Is Charged In 11 Drug Overdose Deaths
description: A doctor who operates a detoxification center for drug addicts has been charged in a new complaint with 11 counts of involuntary manslaughter in the drug overdose deaths of patients.

title: Francis Heads for Whalers
description: Emile Francis, who has been president and general manager of the St. Louis Blues since 1976, is expected to be named the Hartford Whalers' president today.

title: Timerman's Son Is Sentenced For Refusing Lebanon Service
description: Daniel Timerman, son of the Argentine human rights activist Jacobo Timerman, was sentenced today to 35 days in jail for refusing to serve with the Israeli Army in Lebanon, the military command said.

title: OFFICIAL TIES CUBA TO U.S. DRUG TRAFFIC
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, asserted today that he ''would find it very difficult to believe that the Cuban Government itself is not involved'' in drug trafficking in the United States.

title: Tambay's Ferrari Takes Grand Prix
description: Patrick Tambay of France, driving a Ferrari, fought off a spirited closing challenge from the Brabham of Riccardo Patrese of Italy today to win the San Marino Formula One Grand Prix.

title: Jovan Selects Zwiren, Cunningham
description: The search by Jovan Inc. for a new agency, which so excited the Chicago advertising community, has come to an end with not one but two agencies moving into the winner's circle. Zwiren & Wagner, Chicago, is getting all of the Jovan business, while Cunningham & Walsh out there will be getting most of the other brands from under the Beecham Cosmetics umbrella.

title: Credibility Gap in School
description: The National Commission on Excellence in Education may dwell too obviously on the link between national security and good schools. And it may have unfairly ignored many good things the nation's educators are doing. But who can deny that public education's lost credibility creates a crisis for too many American communities - or that efforts to remedy the problem are nowhere in sight?

title: Pamela Ann Davis Wed to Gary Stephen Schpero
description: Pamela Ann Davis, a vice president in the investment banking department of E.F. Hutton & Company, was married yesterday to Gary Stephen Schpero, an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. The nondenominational ceremony was performed jointly by the Rev. Michael Trainor, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: WALKER GAINS 172 IN GENERALS' VICTORY
description: The New Jersey Generals, who had played well in portions of some of their first eight games, put together four quarters of power football today and defeated the Denver Gold, 34-29, before 47,940 at Mile High Stadium.

title: SEX DIFFERENTIALS IN INSURANCE
description: Sex discrimination has long been a fundamental, and accepted, way for insurers to set rates. But proposed legislation would strike at the heart of the industry by eliminating different treatment for men and women in all kinds of insurance.

title: Union Reaches Accord With Walt Disney World
description: Walt Disney World reached a tentative contract settlement today with a union representing 8,000 park workers, including those who perform as Mickey Mouse and other cartoon characters.

title: Chattanooga Bank Sold
description: A Louisiana banker has purchased Chattanooga's United American Bank, one of five banks that had been controlled by Jake Butcher before his banking empire dissolved.

title: West Germany Wins In Hockey
description: West Germany defeated East Germany, 7-3, today in a physical match in the world hockey championships and secured a berth in next year's Canada Cup.

title: Alaska Tops U.S. Income List
description: Mineral-rich Alaska topped the nation in per capita income again last year, with its residents averaging $15,200, compared with $11,056 for Americans in general, Government figures indicated today.

title: THEATER: 'JUNIPER TREE,' A BALLADLIKE MUSICAL
description: WENDY KESSELMAN has taken ''The Juniper Tree,'' the Brothers Grimm story, and turned it into a haunting little musical in the shape of a ballad. The 70-minute play, in a Music-Theater Group-Lenox Arts Center production at St. Clement's, is further enhanced by the presence on stage of the playwright-composer as balladeer. Sitting on a stool and playing a guitar, Miss Kesselman sings in a reedy voice, leading us though a world that is both dreamlike and nightmarish.

title: NICARAGUA LISTS U.S. 'VIOLATIONS' IN BITTER REPLY TO REAGAN SPEECH
description: The Nicaraguan Government, making what it said was its formal response to President Reagan's speech on Central America last week, provided today for the first time a detailed list of what it called violations of its territory by the United States during the past two years.

title: News Analysis
description: There used to be a saying among Israeli foreign affairs experts, ''We don't know which Arab country will be the first to sign a peace treaty with us, but we know which will be the second: Lebanon.''

title: Suzanne Heller, Neal Haber Wed
description: Suzanne Marie Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Heller of White Plains, was married yesterday to Neal David Haber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Haber of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: NAVY IS CRITICIZED ON COST OF PLANE
description: The Defense Department's watchdog office has accused the Navy of misleading Congress on the cost of the FA-18 fighter-bomber program by using questionable accounting practices.

title: I.R.S. CRACKS DOWN ON DONATIONS OF ART
description: For years America's museum collections have grown at the taxpayer's expense. That much the Government intended. But the Internal Revenue Service says art donors have abused the tax system - to the tune of millions of dollars - by claiming greater write-offs than they are entitled to.

title: Barbara Schlesinger Marries Dr. Michael Amdurer
description: Barbara Wynne Schlesinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Schlesinger of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Amdurer, son of Dr. Stanley Amdurer of Portals Nous, Majorca, and the late Frieda Neugebauer Amdurer of Capetown, South Africa. Rabbi Simkha Weintraub performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center in Paramus, N.J.

title: Iran and Iraq Exchange Prisoners in Turkey
description: Iran and Iraq completed an exchange of prisoners of war in Turkey today when 32 Iranians flew home after negotiations that stretched well into Saturday night, the Turkish state radio reported.

title: A Good Impression
description: Maybe it was the Oneonta factor. That, at least, could help explain last week's bizarre turn of events in which John Elway, professional football's top collegiate prospect, said that he would pursue a career in professional baseball with the Yankees rather than accept a contract with the Baltimore Colts.

title: KISSINGER AND VANCE UNITE FOR SAKE OF SOCCER
description: Henry A. Kissinger has faced many challenges in top-level international diplomacy. So has Cyrus R. Vance. Now the two former Secretaries of State are allied in a new diplomatic venture, with the Federation Internationale de Football Association, as they try to overturn a decision that is almost certain to be upheld.

title: Sweetening the Pot
description: In 1946, major league baseball owners were upset because Jorge Pasquel, the Mexican League's multimillionaire owner, was enticing the rank and file of the major leagues with satchels of cash.

title: CRENSHAW RALLIES FOR A ONE-SHOT TRIUMPH
description: Ben Crenshaw, whose slump last year caused him to leave the tour for two weeks, staged a comeback today with a five-under-par 66 that brought him from three strokes back to a one-stroke victory in the $400,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 2, 1983
description: International Unauthorized May Day marches in Poland were broken up by the police. Thousands of demonstrators had turned out on behalf of the banned Solidarity trade union. The state television said that there had disturbances in 20 localities. (Page A1, Column 6.) Nicaragua listed in detail its charges of United States violations of its territory in the last two years. The list was provided in a response to President Reagan's Central American speech last week. (A1:3.)

title: PHILLIES TROUNCE ASTROS
description: The end of a 19-year major league career with Cincinnati, Montreal and Boston, in which he had nine times cracked 20 or more home runs and seven times driven in more than 100 runs, seemed imminent for 40-year-old Tony Perez on Nov.1 when he was released by the Red Sox. In the 1982 season, Perez had batted .260 with six homers and only 31 runs batted in while playing 69 games as a first baseman and designated hitter.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT MANIC
description: The Cosmos displayed a few glimpses of the past today and trounced the Montreal Manic, 6-0, in their home opener in sunny Giants Stadium before a crowd of 41,946.

title: The U.N. Today; May 2, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: RACQUETS PROBLEM FOR PROS
description: Racquet switching may help some tennis players improve their strokes, but Larry Stefanki and Van Winitsky say they have learned their lessons.

title: MUSIC: AN 'ISRAEL IN EGYPT' FROM BRITAIN
description: THE Monteverdi Choir and the English Baroque Soloists, both founded and directed by John Eliot Gardiner, have been making appearances in New York, and Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, they assembled for a performance of Handel's great oratorio ''Israel in Egypt.''

title: Regulators Split on Sale Of Banks to Brokerages
description: Proposals to prohibit securities firms and insurance companies from crossing traditional industry barriers into the banking business are sharply dividing the Federal Government's key regulators, some of whom disagree on the wisdom of slowing the pace of bank deregulation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People who drive drunk should see the devastation they can bring to a family, my family.

title: DEFICIENT MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CENTRAL PRESIDENT
description: Alfred E. Perlman, a railroad trouble-shooter who was president of the New York Central Railroad and other major lines, died in San Francisco Saturday after a short illness. He was 80 years old and had lived in Hillsborough, Calif., for 12 years.

title: Curfews Set in West Bank
description: Israeli troops imposed curfews on three areas in the occupied West Bank of Jordan today after Palestinian youths stoned Israeli vehicles, the military command said. Under the restrictions, Palestinian residents are not allowed to leave their homes without permission from military authorities.

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Quasar Petroleum Co. filed for an offering of $50 million of subordinated debentures due 1993, through Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: SINGLE MOTHERS BY CHOICE: PERILS AND JOYS
description: Jane Mattes, a Manhattan psychotherapist, realized when she was 36 years old that perhaps Mr. Right wasn't going to come along after all. So she decided to have a child outside of marriage.

title: CONCERT: LUKAS FOSS, PIANIST AND COMPOSER
description: LUKAS FOSS is one of the few modern-day musicians who has managed to maintain an identity as a composer while pursuing a successful career as a performer. Until our own century, such a dual career was so common that no one would have thought to mention it, but the tradition has been allowed to wither away, if not quite die. If only for that reason, the appearance of Lukas Foss the pianist playing a new work by Lukas Foss the composer deserves attention. He turned up last evening at Alice Tully Hall as pianist in his ''Solo Observed,'' as well as in two other pieces on the season's final program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: SLM Puts Its Chairman Back in Movie Industry
description: The major film studios, for the first time, are going outside for the financing of their films and one of the major movers behind that trend is Irving H. Levin.

title: MUBARAK, DISPUTING REAGAN, URGES A P.L.O. ROLE IN TALKS
description: President Hosni Mubarak, taking issue with President Reagan, said today that it would be a ''serious mistake'' not to include the Palestine Liberation Organization in the early stages of the Middle East peace process.

title: Washington Watch; Power Plant Fight Grows
description: WASHINGTON BATTLE lines are now clearly drawn for a showdown over whether the nation's privately built hydroelectric projects should remain in the hands of investor-owned utilities or whether they should be turned over to local governments.

title: 8 Men Might Be Charged In Paris Over Bombings
description: Eight men detained after Friday's wave of bombings in the capital by Corsican separatist guerrillas will probably face charges, police officials said today. A total of 22 people were reported detained in France and Corsica.

title: TREASURY ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE
description: Treasury financing dominates this week's calendar of new debt issues, with auctions of three- and six-month bills today, threeyear notes on Tuesday, 10-year notes on Wednesday and 10 3/8 percent bonds on Thursday.

title: WEST SIDE RESIDENTS TRY TO FIND A SOLUTION TO PROSTITUTION PROBLEM
description: For one week last summer the police drew the line in the battle against prostitution around the construction site of New York City's new Convention Center.

title: A Fox for the Juvenile Justice Coop
description: An atmosphere of steamy gossip surrounds President Reagan's appointment of Alfred Regnery to head the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention. Opponents spread tales of how in a political campaign, the nominee misrepresented and exploited his wife's private troubles and how his behavior after the birth of his child moved a pediatrician to denounce him as ''a danger to the health needs of our children.'' There are more important reasons to oppose his confirmation.

title: Blazers Avert Sweep
description: The Portland Trail Blazers stayed alive in the National Basketball Association playoffs today with a 108-95 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: POINT MAN SPEAKS OUT ABOUT CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Nestor D. Sanchez, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Inter-American Affairs, comes as close as anyone can to being the soul of the Reagan Administration's policy toward Central America.

title: Boy, 15, Reported Killed In Aruba Voting Violence
description: A 15-year-old boy was reported shot to death and two other people were wounded in election-day violence in Aruba over the weekend, the police said.

title: People
description: * Peter H. Hurley is joining Stern & Ingalls as executive vice president. * Leo Brandstatter has been elected a senior vice president of Needham, Harper & Steers/USA Inc. * Neil Costa and Eugene H. Tashoff have been appointed senior vice presidents of Campbell-Ewald, New York.

title: What Won't Change in Austria
description: During Bruno Kreisky's 13 years as Austria's Chancellor, his small country has stood for more than lederhosen and chamber music. Neutral by treaty, it has been a haven and transit for exiles from the East, and its economy has prospered impressively through productive links with the West. None of this will change with the Chancellor's resignation, and it is useful to remember why.

title: A VOYAGE THROUGH KAFKA'S AMBIGUITIES
description: The subject was Franz Kafka, the author of ''The Trial,'' ''The Metamorphosis'' and other works that have fascinated and disturbed millions of readers around the world for decades.

title: Market Place; The Pattern Of the Rally
description: FOR investors, it was like watching their favorite movie all over again. For the third time in as many weeks, stock market indicators finished Friday at record highs.

title: U.S. Assures Seoul on Aid
description: The United States has assured Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk of South Korea of a continuing United States military presence and continued military aid, a State Department official said over the weekend. Mr. Lee is to visit President Reagan at the White House Tuesday and has met with Congressional leaders and State and Defense Department officials about American security aid, the official said.

title: 12 BODIES RECOVERED FROM FLORIDA RIVER IN NAVY PLANE CRASH
description: Divers pulled eight bodies from the St. Johns River today, bringing to 12 the number of known dead after a Navy transport plane with 15 aboard crashed into the water and burst into flames.

title: Disaster Aid Offered to Utah
description: President Reagan has declared three Utah counties a major disaster area since landslides and flooding last month left 40 people homeless and hundreds economically stranded. The action Saturday made Federal money available to supplement state and local recovery efforts, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said. Landslides blocked the Spanish Fork River, creating a lake and submerging the town of Thistle.

title: Martha Wright Millard Wed to J.L. Van Cleef
description: Martha Wright Millard, a literary agent, was married yesterday, to Jabez Lindsey Van Cleef, a writer, at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Millard of Newtown, Pa. Federal Judge John P. Fullam of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania performed the ceremony.

title: Norway Sights Oil Slick Where It Fired at Sub
description: The Norwegian Navy said today that it had spotted an oil slick in an estuary where an unidentified submarine was believed to be located and that a frigate had fired another barrage of antisubmarine missiles at ''an underwater object'' located by sonar.

title: BRETT OUT, ROYALS BOW AGAIN
description: While George Brett was hitting safely in his first 16 games of the American League season, the Kansas City Royals were a winning team. His league-leading .460 batting average and 18 runs batted in helped the Royals to victories in 10 of the first 16.

title: FEARING ILLNESS, 15 SUE TO BAR SPRAYING OF DIOXIN
description: A small group of residents who fear for their future health were preparing to go to court Monday to block the planned spraying of herbicides containing dioxin on the forests of Nova Scotia.

title: 1,000 ATTEND BALANCHINE REQUIEM
description: More than 1,000 dancers, friends and acquaintances crowded into the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign yesterday evening for the first of two requiem services for George Balanchine, the choreographer, co-founder and artistic director of the New York City Ballet who died Saturday.

title: 2D-BEST, HE WINS ANYWAY
description: Though he was not the first man to cross the finish line, 22-year-old Donald Bossardet of Huntington Station, L.I., won the 11th annual Long Island Marathon today. Bossardet was timed in 2 hours 25 minutes 11 seconds, nearly two minutes behind Ira Meyers of Bellmore, L.I., an unofficial participant.

title: REAGAN MAKES HIS FIRST VISIT TO VIETNAM MEMORIAL ON MALL
description: President Reagan paid his first visit to the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial today, placing a bouquet between the granite walls bearing the names of 57,939 dead and missing soldiers.

title: SOLIDARITY RALLIES TURN INTO CLASHES WITH POLISH POLICE
description: Despite efforts by the Government to show that the outlawed Solidarity union was finished, tens of thousands of pro-Solidarity, anti-Government demonstrators turned out today for unauthorized May Day rallies in 20 Polish cities and towns.

title: Ellen Anikstein Is Bride Of Frederic Baumgarten
description: Ellen M. Anikstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Anikstein of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday in New York to Frederic H. Baumgarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Baumgarten of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Black Leaders Consider Tactics for 1984 Choice
description: Prominent black political leaders, meeting in a private session this weekend, vowed to ''accelerate'' efforts to increase black impact on the selection of a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1984.

title: MALONE SHOWS KNICKS' NEED
description: WHEN the clock stopped with 5 seconds remaining, the Knicks were 6 points behind the Philadelphia 76ers in the game they would lose yesterday, 105-102, but at their bench, Hubie Brown was yelling, ''Time out, time out.'' Now, as the Knick players surrounded their coach, the ovation began. For only a moment, it was scattered and slow, but soon virtually all of those in the assembling of 15,457 spectators were on their feet and clapping. And the noise was washing down over Hubie Brown and his team, a waterfall of appreciation.

title: BRAVES SET BACK METS AND SEAVER, 2-1
description: Dale Murphy didn't hit any home runs yesterday, as he had in the two previous games, but he drove in one run and scored the other as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Mets, 2-1, at Shea Stadium.

title: Saudis Cite Oil Recovery
description: Saudi Arabian oil output remains below four million barrels a day but the international crude oil market is showing the first signs of recovery from the recession, the head of the state oil company, Petromin, said today.

title: SEX-RELATED SHOPS ARE FEWER
description: The number of massage parlors, peep shows, topless bars and other sex-related businesses operating in the Times Square area has been cut almost in half since 1976, according to a report released yesterday.

title: BANKS SEE RELIEF IN A TAX DELAY
description: The Scranton National Bank has spent about $25,000 and much of the last few months preparing for a withholding tax on interest and dividend income, scheduled to take effect July 1. New computer software had to be purchased by the small Pennsylvania bank, exemption forms filed for its many elderly customers and bank personnel trained.

title: JOHN SAMUELSON, GAIL KORMAN WED
description: Gail Korman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sinclair Korman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Crawford Samuelson, son of Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of Belmont, Mass., and the late Marion Crawford Samuelson. Rabbi Maurice Davis of White Plains performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Ellen Wiener Marries Jonathan Golden
description: The marriage of Ellen Jean Wiener and Jonathan Kross Golden, New York lawyers, took place yesterday at the Scanticon-Princeton Executive Conference Center and Hotel in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Mel Gottlieb officiated.

title: ACTUARIAL 'DECREPITUDE'
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTERS TO CHOOSE BOARD MEMBERS FOR CITY SCHOOLS
description: With the long dispute over the selection of a citywide Schools Chancellor resolved, voters will complete the selection of the city's public school leadership tomorrow by electing members of 32 local school boards.

title: 76ERS COMPLETE SWEEP OF KNICKS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers acquired Moses Malone during the offseason to take them to the National Basketball Association championship. The 76ers took a big step in that direction yesterday, and in doing so ended the Knicks' season. Malone completed an awesome performance as the 76ers defeated the Knicks, 105-102, at Madison Square Garden to sweep the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal series. The 76ers, who have made it to the conference final for the fourth straight season, will oppose the winner of the series between the Milwaukee Bucks and Boston Celtics. The Bucks lead that series, 3-0.

title: RULING INTENSIFIES CONFLICT ON EXCEPTION TO RENT CURB
description: When Susan and Seymour Slaven moved to East 62d Street in 1973, they assumed that their $650-a-month one-bedroom apartment was rent stabilized. The lease said so, a rent-stabilization notice hung in the lobby, and nearly every apartment in the city was covered.

title: MAGAZINES BATTLE OVER THE '500' LISTS
description: Fortune and Forbes, the business biweeklies, have spent months compiling their annual ''500'' surveys of America's largest companies. Now, as each publication sets about the task of trying to persuade business readers that its list is the best, the sparks are flying.

title: 'DIARIES' OF HITLER IN THE WEST SINCE '45, LONDON PAPER SAYS
description: The documents purported to be the secret diaries of Hitler are now said to have been in the West for nearly 40 years, The Sunday Times of London reported today.

title: DR. SPOCK, AT 80, STILL GIVING ADVICE
description: Dr. Benjamin Spock, the nation's baby doctor in spite of everything, will be 80 years old Monday. He will celebrate at his solar-heated home in the Ozarks, where he and his wife, Mary Morgan, who is 39, have lived since 1976. If the weather is decent, the white-haired, barrel-chested old athlete will hurl his 6-foot, 4-inch body into a boat on nearby Beaver Lake and row his customary eight miles. Maybe, because it will be his birthday, he will stop fretting about the future of the world for a few minutes and let his memory drift - say, to 1924, when his crew from Yale won the Paris Olympics.

title: BUCKS SET BACK CELTICS
description: The cries of ''sweep, sweep, sweep'' that echoed throughout the sold-out Mecca here on this cold and windy afternoon might soon be answered. With Milwaukee's 107-95 triumph today over the Boston Celtics, the Bucks took a 3-0 lead in this four-of-sevengame game Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: JOFFREY OPENS ON COAST
description: The Joffrey Ballet became the newest pearl in the performing-arts cluster of the Los Angeles Music Center last night, and the opening setting was as lavish as any created by the fantasy makers who gave this city its fame.

title: 17 CREWMAN STRANDED ON SHIP SEIZED AT SOUTH BROOKLYN PIER
description: Federal officials have seized a rusting oil tanker at the Columbia Street pier in South Brooklyn, and 17 foreign crewmen are stranded on board with no pay and meager supplies of rice and potatoes.

title: A FARM FAMILY'S STRUGGLE IN THE LAND OF TOO MANY KANGAROOS
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIAL REVOKES $2 MILLION IN PROMISED COMMUNITY AID
description: New York State's new Housing Commissioner has denied financing to eight community groups that were promised grants by her predecessor. She has also reduced awards promised to four other groups.

title: Entrepreneur Sees Success on Games
description: William F. von Meister, founder of the computerized information retrieval service known as the Source, has had a career of innovative ideas that do not always turn into business successes.

title: Travel Agents Going From In-House to Ogilvy
description: The American Society of Travel Agents, whose membership will be facing competitive pressures from outside their fold for the first time, has selected Ogilvy & Mather, New York, to do a $5 million image campaign.

title: Pilot Killed and 2 Hurt In a Plane Crash on L.I.
description: A small, single-engine aircraft crashed in the Suffolk County community of Coram yesterday afternoon, killing the pilot and slightly injuring two children, the only other occupants, the county police reported.

title: M.T.A. EYES BOSTON'S USE OF FARE CARDS
description: Every day, thousands of people here ride the subways without so much as touching a token. Instead, they slip a plastic card through an electronic device, pass through the turnstile and head for their train.

title: Western Air Chief Quits; Lawyer Named to Post
description: In a move that elicited little surprise in the airline industry, Neil G. Bergt, 47-year-old chairman and chief executive officer at Western Airlines, announced on Friday that he had resigned. His departure from the nation's 10th-largest carrier had been expected since October, when his plan to acquire control of the company's stock fell through.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*8.82 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*11.50 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: PLACING AN APPETIZING ORDER
description: NOTHING personal against the Chicago Black Hawks and the Boston Bruins, but when I get back from the Derby, I want to see Gretzky and Bossy. No surprises. I want to see The Fastest Gun in the West take on The Fastest Gun in the East. Edmonton against the Islanders in hockey. They must play each other in the Stanley Cup finals because it is inevitable, one of those matchups you can smell before the season even begins: the three-time champions from the East, no longer kids, against the fresh new team from the oilfields of western Canada.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a professional basketball game, a defensive player slaps the ball away from his opponent, and it rolls toward the center line. Another offensive player touches the ball in the forecourt, but he does not have control until he crosses the center line to the backcourt. Is this a violation?

title: SHULTZ IN ISRAEL FOR MORE TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz traveled here from Beirut today to present Israeli leaders with the results of nearly 18 hours of negotiations with Lebanese leaders on a revised draft agreement on an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: FURTHER RATE DROPS EXPECTED
description: The modest decline in interest rates last week in the face of this week's heavy schedule of new Treasury issues is being seen as a strong sign that rates will head still lower in the future.

title: LORIMAR'S RETREAT FROM FILMS
description: When Lorimar Productions, the television company that made the Ewings and the Waltons household names, turned its hand to movie-making several years ago, success seemed as predictable as the high ratings of ''Dallas'' and the devilry of J.R. But after 20 movies, including ''Being There,'' ''The Postman Always Rings Twice'' and ''S.O.B.,'' and $21 million in write-offs, Lorimar has retreated from the big screen.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sailing up the Avenue AChinese junk seemed to be moving up Sixth Avenue in Saturday's s unshine, a window shade sail of bamboo and rice paper at its tallestm ast. But baffled onlookers also saw beat-up umbrellas open like s pinnakers and a red flag signaling from the stern.

title: More Than a Local School Fight
description: New York City's local school board elections are usually local, important to parents in the district and few others. But tomorrow's election in the Sixth District, on Manhattan's Upper West Side, holds wider interest.

title: JOINED U. OF CALIFORNIA IN 1913
description: Joel H. Hildebrand, one of the most venerated faculty members ever to teach at the University of California, where more than 40,000 students passed through his freshman chemistry class, died Saturday night at his home in Kensington, an adjoining town. He was 101 years old.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $7,133,000 and a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $250,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $196,000 and a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $500,000. d-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $4,106,000 and net from disposal of discontinued operations of $40,225,000.

title: KEMPER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including gains on the sale of investments of $8,721,000 for the latest first quarter and $3,291,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ALATENN RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TUESDAY, MAY 3, 1983; Companies
description: The American Motors Corporation and China are close to signing an agreement to jointly produce Jeeps in Peking. The accord, which would be the first joint venture by an American auto maker in China, calls for the production of 40,000 vehicles a year for sale throughout the Far East. (Page A1.)

title: GEORGE DELUCA, 93, EX-JUDGE AND 50'S LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
description: George B. DeLuca, a former Lieutenant Governor of New York, died yesterday at the North Central Bronx Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Offensive Splurge
description: Tony Muser, the manager of the El Paso Diablos, was not as amazed as most of the other baseball fans in the country when his team beat the Beaumont Golden Gators, 35-21, on Saturday night in a Texas League game. Having managed in El Paso for three seasons, he was not totally unprepared for the offensive splurge that broke Texas League records for runs, hits and runs batted in. He has reasons for calling his home field The House of Horrors or The Deadly Dome.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Hung Jury Reunites

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Pitcher Pays Price
description: Jack McKeon, the San Diego Padres' general manager, says he fully supports Manager Dick Williams's decision to drop the pitcher Chris Welsh because of insubordination. Welsh, 8-8 last year, had a shutout going in his first start of the season Saturday, when he disobeyed an order from Williams in the third inning of the second game of a doubleheader with the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

title: Man in Crash Held In $250,000 Bail
description: The driver of a car that crashed into a dress shop on 34th Street Saturday, killing one woman and injuring at least 26 other people, was ordered held in $250,000 bail yesterday.

title: 1,500 Vietnamese Troops Begin Leaving Cambodia
description: About 1,500 Vietnamese troops accompanied by tanks and artillery today left Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, for home.

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: Business Group Seeks To Aid Gifted Children
description: A private group today announced a drive to develop the nation's ''most valuable'' and often neglected resource, gifted youngsters, into future Thomas Edisons and Albert Einsteins.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
E.P.A. FAILED TO AID TOWN PLAGUED BY ASBESTOS, HOUSE PANEL TOLD
description: An official of the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday that Rita M. Lavelle, who was dismissed as the agency's assistant administrator in charge of the toxic waste cleanup program in February, made at least four announcements on hazardous waste sites based on political expediency and may have let politics block the cleanup of cancer-causing asbestos at an Arizona mobile home community.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a gain from the effect on years prior to 1982 of an accounting change of $5.9 million.

title: HIGH COURT BARS A TAX SHELTER
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in favor of the Internal Revenue Service and shut the door on a much disputed tax shelter.

title: ELWAY TRADED TO BRONCOS BY COLTS
description: John Elway, the Stanford University quarterback who insisted he would not play for the Baltimore Colts when they made him the first pick in the National Football League draft last week, was traded last night to the Denver Broncos.

title: 2 AGENCIES EXPAND A COOPERATIVE EFFORT TO INVESTIGATE ARSON
description: About 50 additional detectives will be assigned to a special Police and Fire Department task force now being set up to mount a new citywide attack on arson, officials said yesterday.

title: PAYCO AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The share earnings in 1982 restated to reflect 200 percent stock dividend declared in April.

title: BUILDING A ROBOT: THE CRASH COURSE
description: THE robots are coming. Nobody doubts it. And they raise important questions as they approach. How can they best serve mankind? What can they really do? Why are the Japanese so far ahead in robotics? Will robots be practical in the home? What are their drawbacks? But the answers often seem clouded in razzle-dazzle and the frivolities of science fiction. To glean some truths about the impending revolution in robotics, I set about building my own mechanical man. Heathkit has produced a much publicized $2,500 robot named Hero that anybody can buy ready-made to roll around the house. For $1,500, you can buy a kit and build Hero from scratch. All it takes is two weeks of hard work.

title: DANCE: HUBBARD STREET
description: THE HUBBARD STREET DANCE COMPANY is one of the success stories of dance today. Five years ago, several dancers got together under the aegis of their teacher, Lou Conte, to entertain the elderly in neighborhood centers in Chicago, where the company is based. Today, Hubbard Street is a highly respected, spunky little jazz-dance company with some big festival credits and an eye on continental and European tours.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,186,000, or 81 cents a share, due to an increase in investment valuation of a portfolio security owned by a subsidiary.

title: ELECTRO-BIOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $55,000 for the latest first quarter and $413,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 31, 1983.

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: COURT OVERTURNS LIBEL VERDICT AGAINST THE WASHINGTON POST
description: A Federal judge overturned a libel verdict against The Washington Post Company today and threw out a jury award of $2.05 million to William P. Tavoulareas, the president of the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,201,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DIARRHEA PERSISTS AS SCOURGE OF THIRD WORLD
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh THE man staggered as he walked in and would have collapsed on the floor had a friend not been holding him up. Soon he was stretched out on a cot in a long, spotless, wardlike room that held perhaps 125 similarly stricken people, more than half of them children who appeared to be less than 5 years old.

title: ARGENTINA REPORTS THE KILLING OF TERRORIST LEADER
description: A man described as a leading terrorist was killed Saturday in a gun battle at a farmhouse outside the provincial capital of Cordoba, Argentine officials say.

title: U.S. FIGHTS RULING ON DETROIT POLICE
description: The Justice Department today asked a Federal appeals court to reconsider its opinion upholding the Detroit Police Department's promotion plan that provides for an equal number of blacks and whites to be promoted to lieutenants. The department criticized the plan as ''reverse discrimination.''

title: WESTON, GEORGE, LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal, and Vancouver stock exchanges. b-Includes a tax credit of $1,000,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,600,000.

title: DEBATE ON DEVELOPMENT DIVIDES EAST HAMPTON
description: At a recent Town Board meeting here, after the Democrats and Republicans had spent hours calling each other liars, after the youngest Democrat and oldest Republican had quarreled over where they should sit, after countless split votes, Carol Morrison, private citizen, stood up from the audience and leveled what might have been the angriest charge of the day against the Town Supervisor, Ronald Greenbaum.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
