description: President Reagan gave a qualified endorsement today to an emerging Senate Republican budget for 1984 that would require only minor tax increases this year and could reportedly contain a deficit of more than $190 billion.

title: MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Sweden Begins Search For Another Submarine
description: Warships and helicopters searched Sweden's east coast today for a suspected foreign submarine, but the navy called off a similar hunt on the west coast.

title: FIVE REPORTED HURT
description: Four patrons and a waiter in a Chinatown restaurant were injured yesterday when part of the floor collapsed into the basement. A section of floor in the dining area of the Hong Wah restaurant, at 8 Bowery, lowered ''like an elevator,'' according to a witness, Detective Sgt. Martin Stiastny of the Major Case Unit. At least three patrons and one waiter were on the section that collapsed at 1:41 P.M., according to witnesses.

title: MERRY LAND & INVESTMENT reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated for 5 percent stock dividends issued March and September 1982 and March 1983.

description: THE SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET, affiliated with the New York City Ballet, gave one of its best annual workshop performance series in recent years at the Juilliard Theater on Monday and over the preceding weekend.

title: CACI GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: NOT surprisingly, I have clung to a great liking for the traditional and regional dishes of my native Burgundy, so a good deal of my cooking stems from my recollections of childhood.

description: The Police Department yesterday suspended Lawrence Gillott, a 35-year-old officer formerly assigned to the 10th Precinct in Manhattan, after he applied for a disability retirement.

description: JUST at the time a national survey indicated severe educational lacks in mathematics and communications skills at the high school level, some embattled professors from college humanities departments met for three days in Princeton, N.J. title: A BROOKLYN HIGH CHESS TEAM IS KING
description: Simon Yelsky, 17 years old, started playing chess in his native Kiev when he was 6. ''I played four hours a day, six days a week,'' he said. ''I liked chess much better than school.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. As a child I used to love licorice. I believe it was made from an herb or spice called licorice, but a friend tells me it is made from anise. He also says it should be spelled liquorice rather licorice. Can you settle this argument?

title: MCI Up 57.1% as Sales Double
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter rose 57.1 percent, to $53.1 million, or 48 cents a share, from $33.8 million, or 35 cents a share, in the coresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues more than doubled, to $331.4 million, from $164.7 million.

title: HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The 1982 figures have been restated for pooling of interest with Dutchland Laboratories Inc.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid June 8.

title: E.E.C. Production Data
description: The European Economic Community's industrial production index, with a 1975 base and seasonally adjusted, was unchanged at 111.2 in February from January, the community's statistics office said today. It said the figures appear to confirm a halt in the decline of industrial output, which reached a low point at the end of 1982. In February 1982 the index stood at 114.9.

title: WILLIAM W. HEER
description: William W. Heer, former president of the Concord Watch Corporation, died on April 24 at a hospital in Keene, N.H., after a short illness.

title: 2 Choose N.B.A.
description: Two top juniors in the Big Ten, Derek Harper of Illinois and Russell Cross of Purdue, today became the first underclassmen to announce that they give up their remaining college eligibility to join the National Basketball Association.

description: The figures in the year-earlier periods have been restated for effects of a rate order on Dec. 30, 1982 and results for the latest year reflect a nrecurring gain of $7,897,000, or 80 cents a share, from accounting method on unbilled revenues.

title: WINE TALK
description: SAN FRANCISCO NOT too long ago the very best wineries in California boasted that their output was good because it was unblended. Many a label said ''100 percent cabernet sauvignon.'' Dark tales were told of unscrupulous makers who cut their cabernet with everything but beet juice while brazenly using the cabernet name.

title: Denial by AM Ex-Chief
description: Roy L. Ash, the former chief executive officer of AM International, today denied any involvement in the reportedly fraudulent accounting practices that led the company into bankruptcy proceedings.

title: NO DEAL TO OBSTRUCT
description: F or all practical purposes, the National Football League is now composed of only 27 teams. What was once its 28th team, the Los Angeles-Oakland Raiders, appears more concerned with litigation than with linebackers.

title: VIETNAM RAID: NUMBERS IN DOUBT
description: The number of Cambodian civilians killed early last month when Vietnamese troops shelled their camp, reportedly herded some of them into bunkers and then threw grenades at them has been placed by Cambodian refugees at between 20 and 40.

title: KERO-SUN'S SHARP SETBACK
description: For seven years William S. Litwin lived an entrepreneur's dream. Starting with an idea and a clapboard country store in a small Connecticut town in 1975, Mr. Litwin built a $100 million-a-year company and a nationally known product. His idea -selling Japanese kerosene heaters to American homeowners with high heating bills - spawned an $800 million-a-year industry.

title: JWT GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,569,000 from foreign currency translations. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,143,000 from foreign currency translations. Revenue for the latest period includes Simmons Market Research Burearu Inc. figures.

title: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding give retroactive effect to a 20 percent stock dividend declared in August 1982.

title: Professor's Study Finds Entrepreneurship Rise
description: Entrepreneurship is on the increase, says Karl H. Vesper, a professor at the University of Washington who makes a study of such things. Mr. Vesper says the statement is hard to prove but cites such signs as rising self-employment and new magazines on the subject. ''The general level of prosperity is really pretty high,'' he said, ''and that gives some freeboard to individuals who want to go out and start enterprises.''

title: Far West in Suit To Thwart Jacobs
description: The Far West Financial Corporation has filed a $100 million lawsuit to stop Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, from proceeding with his plan to buy the Bekins Company.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: The ''Hers'' column was particularly apt for me, as the third anniversary of my mother's death was April 22.  When my mother died letters poured in from every city in which she had ever lived. They expresed the anger and sorrow that accompanied the shock of her death. Each one highlighted a facet of her personality, and the diverse people she had known and touched in her life.
description: I will keep those letters just as I will keep the letters she wrote to me.

title: Ex-Princeton Aide Guilty of Theft
description: A former Princeton University official has pleaded guilty to misappropriating $127,500 in university funds.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $180,000. c-Net loss.

title: SALVADOR FAULTED BY U.S. IN KILLINGS
description: The State Department, worried about Congressional opposition to aid for El Salvador, issued an unusually blunt criticism of the Salvadoran Government today for its handling of a case involving the murders of two Americans working for the A.F.L.- C.I.O. and a Salvadoran union leader who headed a land redistribution effort.

title: WHEN TEAK FURNITURE NEEDS A FACE LIFT
description: TEAK is one of the truly great woods of the world. It is strong for its weight and naturally durable. On land the termites leave it alone, and afloat marine borers pass it by. No wonder it is in such demand for furniture as well as for boat decks and fittings.

title: CONCERT: WEISGALL WORKS
description: HUGO WEISGALL, the composer, is 70 years old this year, and in June he retires from teaching at Queens College. Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall the school offered an evening of his music in celebration. The Queens College Choir under Paul Maynard sang six choruses.

title: 3 ANTIQUE SHOWS FOR MOTHER'S DAY
description: Three antiques shows should help satisfy the urge to browse and buy this Mother's Day weekend. In New York, the 96th White Plains Antiques Show at the County Center on the Bronx River Parkway begins today and continues through Sunday.

title: New York Bell Rating Lowered
description: Duff & Phelps, a Chicago-based bond rating company, has lowered the rating of the New York Telephone Company's outstanding refunding mortgage bonds, debentures and notes to D& P-2, High Double-A, from D& P-1, Triple-A.

title: YANKS AND RAWLEY TURN BACK ROYALS
description: Fortunately for the Yankees, the won-lost pattern that they have followed this season worked for them again tonight. They had won the last game of each of their first eight series, and they made it nine-for-nine with an 8-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals behind the pitching of Shane Rawley.

title: Connecticut Panel Votes Tax Plans
description: The Legislature's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee today approved and sent to the General Assembly two alternative tax packages to raise about $280 million and balance a $3.5 billion budget for Connecticut's fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANAGERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a net realized gain on investments of $20,286. The company went public Jan. 28,1983. Results include the operations of Warwick Insurance Co., a subsidiary which began operations during 1982.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think the E.P.A. is crippled, I think it is in trouble.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a semiattached two-family house and live on the first floor. The apartment on the second floor has a lot of condensation on the inside of the outer walls (the walls that are not attached) and on the windowsills. The windows are wet and foggy all winter, the sills have turned black (probably mildew) and the walls are starting to turn black, from the bottom up. I had the outside of the brick and stucco completely redone last year but this didn't help. The contractors and roofers I called in blamed the roof, so this year I had the roof recoated, but the problem seems to be no better. Any ideas?

title: SENATE REJECTS 3 BUDGET PLANS TO CUT DEFICIT
description: The Senate today decisively rejected three proposed budgets for the Government that their sponsors said would shrink future deficits below the high levels projected by President Reagan and by the Senate Republican leadership.

title: Newsprint Price Rises Reported
description: Two more newsprint manufacturers, Bowater North American and the St. Regis Paper Company, have notified their American customers of intended price increases, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Christo Drapes Miami Isles in Pink
description: MIAMI, May 4  The color of dawn, breaking over Biscayne Bay this morning, found its match in masses of shiny pink fabric as hundreds of workers began to release the first of the voluminous skirts that will surround 11 tiny islands in a two-week, $3.1 million extravaganza by the artist Christo.

title: Anatoly Lyapidevsky, Soviet Flier, Dies at 75
description: Anatoly V. Lyapidevsky, an Arctic flier and the first Russian to win the title of Hero of the Soviet Union, died last week, according to dispatches from Moscow. He was 75 years old.

title: Hindus and Sikhs Said to Clash for 3d Day
description: Rival mobs of Hindus and Sikhs armed with swords, daggers and stones fought in the streets of the northwestern city of Patiala for a third straight day today, according to reports from the area.

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Finns in Agreement On Cabinet Posts
description: Four leading political parties reached agreement today on a division of Cabinet posts in Finland's new center-left coalition. The Government will be sworn in Friday.

title: Ford Diesels From Britain
description: The Ford Motor Company Ltd.'s engine plant at Dagenham has been modified to manufacture diesel engines for cars, it was disclosed today.

title: Tilling Profit Forecast
description: Thomas Tilling P.L.C. issued a forecast today that its pretax profits would more than double this year, to about $150 million. Tilling, a building, energy and industrial equipment company, is fighting a takeover bid by BTR P.L.C.

title: G.M. Challenges U.S.  On Axle Defect Recall
description: The General Motors Corporation today challenged the Government's determination to recall up to 5.3 million of its 1978, 1979 and 1980 mid-size automobiles and pickup trucks that have what a safety agency says are defective axles.

title: AFTER THE 1915 MASSACRES OF ARMENIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS HIRE CHIEF OFFICER
description: Lew Schaffel, a former general manager of two other teams in the National Basketball Association, has been hired by the Nets to run their day-to-day operation, the club announced yesterday.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: DESIGN SYMPOSIUM
description: Design Symposium, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, 212-860- 6868.

title: G.O.P. HAILS LEHRMAN FUND AID
description: Lewis E. Lehrman held a fund-raising dinner last night for one of the organizations he has formed to take over some of the traditional functions of the Republican Party in New York State.

title: News Analysis
description: The vote by the House Select Committee on Intelligence Tuesday to cut off American support for anti-Government forces in Nicaragua demonstrates the problem of using covert intelligence operations to promote contested foreign policy goals.

title: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIRLINES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Dr. Herman E. Pearse, Atom Burn Researcher
description: Dr. Herman E. Pearse, a retired professor of surgery who did some of the original research on atomic radiation burns in World War II, died Monday at the age of 83 at his home in Harwich Port, Mass. He also had homes at Man-of-War Cay in the Bahamas and Vinalhaven, an island in Penobscot Bay, Maine.

title: Imitation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Your article, ''Architectural Imitation: Is It Plagiarism?'' (March 12), fails to distinguish between two separate issues: plagiarism and simultaneous invention.

title: Beltran Unit Faces Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Beltran Corporation said an involuntary petition for Chapter 11 reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act had been filed against its Acton Foodservices Corporation subsidiary in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Massachusetts.

title: Congressmen Attacked Over El Salvador Stand
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, was quoted today as saying that some members of Congress would like to see a Marxist administration in El Salvador. She did not name them.

title: GRAFFITI PROBLEM ON THE INCREASE ON CITY'S BUSES
description: Graffiti, long the bane of the subway system, are becoming an increasing problem on New York City buses, transit officials say. ''Everybody senses we're losing the battle,'' said Howard H. Roberts Jr., the new chief of the city's fleet of 4,160 buses. The driver of a No. 10 bus heading south on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan yesterday agreed. ''You can just stop at a light,'' he said, ''and they mark up the bus. There is nothing you can do.''

title: Bribery Trial Opens For Philadelphia Officers
description: Five police officers, including the inspector in charge of a police district, systematically took protection money from people engaged in vice activities, the prosecution charged today in opening arguments of a police corruption trial.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Seeking Recognition

title: Reader's Digest Taps Sullivan & Brugnatelli
description: Sullivan & Brugnatelli has been retained by Reader's Digest for a job that is a bit unusual for an ad agency. It will be doing field research to find out which of six articles in each issue of the Digest has greatest consumer appeal and then designing a special cover for the magazine featuring it.

title: HEALTH CARE FUND INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., announced that, within its newly formed chemical sector, A. Clark Johnson Jr. had been named group vice president and president of the industrial chemicals division; R. Thomas Cummings had been named president of the fibers division, and Robert F. Traflet had been named president of the plastics and functional chemicals division.

title: Saga Plans to Buy Grandy's of Dallas
description: The Saga Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Grandy's Inc., a Dallas concern that operates 62 family restaurants specializing in chicken.

title: EARLY MUSIC: MONTEVERDI CHOIR CONCERT
description: JOHN ELIOT GARDINER'S Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists presented the third of their four concerts here Monday night at Town Hall, part of the ''Britain Salutes New York'' series. Once again they affirmed their status as one of our - ''our'' meaning the international musical community's - finest large-scale early-music groups.

title: USF & G reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Solisti Concert May 24
description: Solisti New York, a chamber orchestra founded and directed by the flutist Ransom Wilson, will perform on May 24 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center.

title: WARSAW SECRET POLICE SAID TO BREAK INTO A CONVENT
description: Roman Catholic Church sources said today that the security police broke into a convent on Tuesday and beat up workers for a church group helping the families of jailed Solidarity activists.

title: GAF Requests A Court Delay
description: The GAF Corporation has asked the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to delay the certification of the April 28 vote in the proxy fight between GAF and Samuel J. Heyman, a dissident shareholder.

title: Library Director at Florida U.  Shot 5 Times by Ex-Employee
description: A former employee of the University of Florida library barged past secretaries today and shot the library director, university officials said.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After benefits of extraordinary credits.

title: News Analysis
description: Nearly six months after a leadership change in the Kremlin that raised wide expectations, the new Communist Party chief, Yuri V. Andropov, appears unwilling or unable to adopt the bold initiatives that might break the economic immobility besetting the Soviet Union.

title: Angels 16, Orioles 8
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Doug DeCinces drove in three runs with two homers, and Rod Carew raised his batting average to .489 with four hits. Carew, Bobby Clark, Bob Boone and Brian Downing drove in two runs apiece.

title: BROCK CAUTIOUSLY BACKS TRADE UNIT
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said today that a single Federal Department of Trade could be helpful in streamlining decision-making but cautioned that it could present a hazard if taken over by forces of protectionism.

title: BISHOPS, GRATIFIED, PREPARE TO TEACH LETTER ON PEACE
description: As the nation's Roman Catholic bishops filed out of the meeting hall Tuesday just after they approved a historic pastoral letter denouncing nuclear war, they were warmly applauded by a group of peace demonstrators. One bishop, misty-eyed and with his voice choked, turned to another and said, ''It's a great day for the church.''

title: BELTRAN ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. The year-ago 6 months results are pro forma. Beltran was spun off from Acton Corp. in January 1982.

title: Earl Hines Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for the jazz pianist Earl Hines, who died last month at the age of 77, will be held today at 2 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Fellow jazz musicians including Billy Taylor, Milt Hinton, Art Blakey, Maxine Sullivan, Dorothy Donegan, Jackie Byard and Eddie Locke will play during the service. Eulogies will be delivered by Stanley Dance and John Hammond.

title: Floods in Soviet Far East
description: Roads and bridges have been destroyed and hundreds of houses flooded in the Soviet Far East in the worst rain storms there this century, a Moscow newspaper reported today.

title: Bridge:; Happy; Australians Watch; Visiting New Yorkers Lose
description: The final exhibition match of the Precision tour of Australia here Tuesday night provided excitement for more than 200 spectators watching on the Bridgerama demonstration board, thanks to a hurried decision made away from the table.

title: New Raider Suit Is Officially Filed
description: The Los Angeles Raiders officially filed a new lawsuit against the National Football League in Federal court here today, asking $57 million in additional damages from the league.

title: Best Deal Sought
description: Dick Lynn, the attorney representing Chris Hinton, met yesterday with Bruce Allen, the general manager of the Chicago Blitz, to discuss a contract for Hinton.

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE REAGAN ADMINISTRATION DOSEN'T FEEL THOSE HUNGER PANGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Elway's Pay
description: When the quarterback John Elway signed a contract Monday in the private plane of Edgar F. Kaiser Jr., the owner of the Denver Broncos, he became the highest-paid player in the National Football League.

title: GEORGE B. COSTIGAN SR.
description: George B. Costigan Sr., who represented Long Beach, L.I., on the Nassau County Board of Supervisors for 14 years, died Saturday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lived in retirement for several years.

title: Pitcher Is Out, On Principle
description: Chris Welsh sat at home in San Diego yesterday, waiting for the telephone to ring. The 28-year-old left-handed pitcher had defied an order from Dick Williams, the manager of the Padres, on Saturday in Pittsburgh and was prepared to start paying the consequences.

title: GTE Settlement By Justice Dept.
description: The Justice Department negotiated a settlement with the GTE Corporation, allowing GTE to purchase Southern Pacific Communications, because it doubted it could block the deal in court, a top Government official said today. ''I think that one has to recognize the realities of litigation in a case of this kind,'' Ronald G. Carr, a deputy assistant attorney general for antitrust, told reporters today.

title: OPTEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $622,000.

title: FOR HARD-TO-FIND APPLIANCE REPAIRS
description: IF your French-made food processor or your electric mixer is broken, you may not get any sympathy from the shop where you bought it; stores that sell the latest in kitchen gadgets often are unable to repair them.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEASONING

title: THEATER: THOMAS BABE'S 'BURIED INSIDE EXTRA'
description: THOMAS BABE'S ''Buried Inside Extra,'' now at the Public's Martinson Hall, is the production Joseph Papp will send to London's Royal Court Theater this summer in exchange for its gift of ''Top Girls.'' To say that New York got the best of this bargain is an understatement. ''Buried Inside Extra'' is a murky play that shows off neither the New York Shakespeare Festival, Mr. Babe nor an estimable cast to worthwhile advantage. There is, at least, a first-rate set.

title: JOSEPH RUTTENBERG, WINNER OF 4 OSCARS AS CINEMATOGRAPHER
description: Joseph Ruttenberg, a cinematographer who won Oscars for ''The Great Waltz'' (1938), ''Mrs. Miniver'' (1942), ''Somebody Up There Likes Me,'' (1956) and ''Gigi'' (1959), died Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 93 years old.

title: BRINK'S WITNESS TELLS OF ROBBERY IN BRONX IN 1981
description: An armored-car robbery and shootout in the Bronx were described in detail yesterday by an informant testifying in a Federal trial involving the Brink's robbery in Rockland County.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $85,700 for the latest first quarter and $126,400 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: METS LOSE FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: The Mets' feeble attempts to mount an attack showed in the statistics of their erstwhile big hitters last night. Dave Kingman, who did not attend an optional batting practice earlier yesterday, and George Foster, who did attend, remained ineffective as the New Yorkers made only six hits and lost, 4-3, to the Houston Astros.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in July 1982.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a White House transcript of President Reagan's interview today by George Condon of Copley News Service, Bruce Drake of The New York Daily News, Sara Fritz of U.S. News and World Report, Carl Leubsdorf of The Dallas Morning News, Chris Wallace of NBC News and Steven R. Weisman of The New York Times: Bishops' Stand on Arms

title: EVANS REAPPOINTMENT TO S.E.C. IS CLOUDED
description: John R. Evans, a conservative Republican member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and enthusiastic cheerleader for the free-market system, would seem an ideal Reagan Administration ally.

title: Marietta to Sell Unit to Litton
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced it had agreed in principle to sell its International Laser Systems Inc. subsidiary to Litton Industries for $46 million in cash.

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan on Doomsday

title: Ontario's Premier Withdraws From Tories' Leadership Race
description: Premier William Davis of Ontario today ruled himself out as a possible candidate for Prime Minister, saying he would not run for leader of the Progessive Conservative Party.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Backbone of Health

title: BONN SAYS IT SEEKS SOVIET EXCHANGES
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he hoped to set up regular top-level contacts with Moscow, but he warned Soviet leaders against using military power to threaten their Western neighbors.

title: BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend last December.

title: A NEW BREED OF SOCIAL SECRETARY
description: NOT too long ago they were called social secretaries. They worked for wealthy, social women and they dealt almost exclusively with notes, invitations, appointments and place cards. Many of them, brought up in the milieu in which they ended up working, were daughters of genteel families that had fallen on hard times. Their handwriting was usually impeccable and their typing and shorthand were frequently pathetic.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $1,170,000 representing a provision for loss on the company's commitments to Kesser Electronics International Inc. due to severe operating problems'' of Kesser in recent quarters.

title: Peking Says the U.S. Creates Central American Turbulence
description: China's leading newspaper said today that United States ''interventionist policy is a grave factor causing turbulence in Central America.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Expanding Kingdom

title: Pan American Dispute
description: This year's Pan American Games are in serious danger of being called off, after a new clash between the Venezuelan Olympic Committee and the Government.

title: LONDON GARDEN OF RARE PLANTS IS FINALLY OPENED TO THE PUBLIC
description: After 310 years, one of London's best-kept secrets has just been revealed to the public. Located in a fashionable residential area, the Chelsea Physic Garden, a 3.8-acre enclave of rare plants and culinary and medicinal herbs, has been hidden behind the high brick walls just off the Thames River since its founding in 1673 by the Worshipful Society of Apothecaries.

title:
ISSUE AND DEBATE;
SOUTH AFRICA BOYCOTT PUSHED
description: Political pressure is increasing for state and local pension funds to boycott investments in companies doing business in South Africa. A handful of states and cities has already passed laws requiring boycotts of this kind. Bills seeking divestiture of such securities are pending in roughly half of all state legislatures.

title: PROFESSOR OF HISTORY AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Minna R. Falk, the first woman to become a full professor of history at New York University, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings do not reflect a 3-for- 2 stock split declared May 4.

title: AFGHANS FIND ASYLUM GOAL HARD TO GAIN
description: Forty Afghans who are being held in a former Navy jail in Brooklyn - some for as long as 15 months - face an uncertain future in their efforts to gain asylum in the United States.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Owner of Oilers Burglary Victim
description: A burglar took jewelry worth an estimated $400,000 and $2,000 in cash early Tuesday from a hotel room occupied by Peter Pocklington, the owner of the Edmonton Oilers, the police said.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 5, 1983; The Economy
description: Opponents of tax withholding won a round in their efforts to force a House vote on a repeal measure this month. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee had refused to report a repeal bill to the floor, but a petition to discharge the bill received the required 218 signatures. The move raises the prospect that the House will adopt a Senate plan that would postpone withholding from interest and dividend payments until at least 1987. (Page D1.)

title: Parliament Dissolved, Vote to Be Set in Italy
description: President Sandro Pertini dissolved Parliament today, clearing the way for early general elections in June as demanded by Italy's Socialist Party. Political leaders will meet Thursday to negotiate the date.

title: Teamsters Set to Settle Suit, U.S. Sources Say
description: Trustees of two International Brotherhood of Teamsters benefit plans have agreed to repay more than $6 million to settle a Government lawsuit over what the Government charged was the abuse of union assets, Reagan Administration sources said tonight.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES PRETORIA CURBS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee has voted to apply new economic sanctions against the white minority Government of South Africa for its apartheid policy and against United States corporations that fail to offer equal opportunity to nonwhite employees in that country.

title: NEW YORK STATE EXTENDS DISABILITY AID TO ALL FULL-TIME DOMESTIC WORKERS
description: Governor Cuomo signed into law today a bill requiring employers of all full-time domestic workers to provide salary insurance for disabilities suffered by the employees off the job. Under a previous law, only employers of four or more domestic helpers were affected.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report on April 10 about a 20 percent increase in college tuition misidentified the affected schools. They are Southern Connecticut State University, Eastern Connecticut State University, Central Connecticut State University and Western Connecticut State University.

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DEMOCRATIC DEATH WISH
description: As it proved in 1972 with George McGovern, the Democratic Party would rather be left than President. In the last week, Democratic Party leaders have given the 1984 Republican nominee the greatest political boon in their power to bestow: strident, partisan, isolationist opposition to a Presidential call for the defense of our closest neighbors.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
A SLIDING MECHANISM FOR STORING TELEVISION
description: WITH television sets as omnipresent in American households as refrigerators and ranges, you may want to store a set out of sight when it is not being watched. The easiest way is to conceal it in a cabinet.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: Customs Service agents seized 20 cardboard boxes containing more than $4 million in United States currency from a plane preparing for takeoff today for Panama.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook The Deepening Mystery of Yellow Rain

title: DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
G.P.U. Optimism
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, whose Three Mile Island nuclear plant was shut down four years ago, today expressed optimism that its troubles were now history.

title: WALKER, HIRAM, RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Horses From Italy Restricted
description: The Agriculture Department has reimposed restrictions on the importation of horses from Italy because of a contagious venereal disease called equine metritis. A department official said Tuesday that Italian officials reported a new finding of the disease in three mares. The restrictions will affect only mares and stallions of breeding age.

title: HANNAFORD BROS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago per share figures reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 28, 1983.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: Craig Settles Suit
description: Jim Craig, the hockey goalie, has settled a negligence suit stemming from the death of a young woman in a two-car collision. Craig, who had been driving one of the cars, was acquitted last September of a charge of vehicular homicide stemming from the same incident, which occurred in Mattapoisett, Mass., last May 29.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CORRECTION
description: An article April 11 on the wounding of Cambodian civilians incorrectly attributed several statements to Pierre Pont, a representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross at a Cambodian hospital. The statements were made by another member of the hospital's staff.

title: AN OLD-WORLD VIEW
description: I ke Herschkopf was talking recently about his father, Wolf, who loved playing soccer as a youth in Poland but who has had certain problems with the peculiarities of sports in America.

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Top Manager At Cox Cable Rejoins G.E.
description: For the third time in his career, Robert C. Wright is signing on with the General Electric Company. After leaving in 1979 to head Cox Cable Communications, Mr. Wright is returning to G.E. as vice president and general manager of its housewares and audio business division.

title: BOMARKO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $253,000 for the quarter and $559,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $59,000 for the quarter and $44,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $166,000 for the quarter and $346,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled Mike B oddicker, pitcher, from Rochester. BOSTON (AL) - Carl Yastrzemski was r eleased from University of Massachu- s etts Medical Center, where he had been u ndergoing treatment for lower back s pasms. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Optioned Doug C orbett, pitcher, to Edmonton of Pacific C oast League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Multimedia, Inc., a communications company, acquired a l imited partnership interest in the Reds. DETROIT (AL) - Recalled Dave Ruck- e r, pitcher, from Evansville of American A ssociation; sold Bob James, pitcher, to M ontreal Expos' Wichita farm club of A merican Association. HOUSTON (NL) - Placed Nolan Ryan, p itcher, on 21-day disabled list. Recalled L uis Pujols, catcher, from Tucson of Pa- c ific Coast League; optioned John Mizer- o ck, catcher, to Tucson; Reactivated Mike S cott, pitcher. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Placed Derrell T homas, infielder, on 21-day disabled list. METS (NL) - Called up Darryl Straw- b erry, outfielder, and Tucker Ashford, s econd baseman, from Tidewater; placed M ike Bishop, catcher, on waivers. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Optioned M ike Chris, pitcher, to Phoenix of Pacific C oast League. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Sold Chris Welsh, p itcher, to Montreal for an undisclosed a mount of cash. YANKEES (AL) - Brought up Bert C ampaneris, infielder, from Columbus a nd sent Don Mattingly, first baseman- o utfielder, to Columbus.

title: Profits Up 9% At Ciba-Geigy
description: Ciba-Geigy, Switzerland's largest chemical company, said today that 1982 profits rose 9 percent from a year earlier on slightly higher sales.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRITISH BLOCK SOTHEBY TAKEOVER BID
description: The British Government temporarily blocked today the attempt by two American financiers, Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen C. Swid, to take over Sotheby Parke Bernet, the money-losing international auction house.

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MORE HISTORIANS TO EXAMINE HITLER'S 'DIARIES'
description: Stern magazine announced today that it would allow historians from West Germany, Switzerland and the United States to examine the diaries it says are those of Adolf Hitler. But it would not name the historians or say when they would begin work.

title: Trainer Stakes Career on Colt
description: In a Kentucky Derby in which most trainers admit they are taking a chance with horses who have yet to prove their quality, there is one trainer who is quietly but firmly saying that his colt is destined for greatness. David Cross says that Sunny's Halo will win the roses here Saturday, and has staked his career on the colt.

title: MOSLEY IS NAMED CHAIRMAN OF THE PHILHARMONIC'S BOARD
description: Carlos du Pre Moseley, the former president and managing director of the New York Philharmonic, was elected chairman of the orchestra's board at its meeting yesterday afternoon. Mr. Moseley succeeds Amyas Ames, who has been chairman since 1970 and who announced his retirement earlier this year.

title: Doctors Use Interferon To Fight Rare Disease
description: Large doses of genetically engineered interferon, an infection-fighting protein, may be useful in fighting a rare skin cancer that afflicts homosexual men with a deadly immune system deficiency, doctors reported today.

title: Arkansas Panel To Help Baldwin
description: A committee of state insurance commissioners was formed yesterday to work with the Baldwin-United Corporation to develop solutions to its financial problems.

title: MONEY MARKET RATES DOWN AT MAJOR BANKS
description: Interest rates on bank money market accounts declined for the third consecutive week in the period ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: Technology; Dry Painting's Pros and Cons
description: PAINTING is usually a messy process, and in many industrial jobs, the mess involves both noxious fumes and toxic sludges. ''Powder coating,'' or ''dry painting,'' as it is sometimes known, may be a better approach to the process of coating appliances, electrical equipment and other products to protect them from corrosion and improve their looks.

title: OSMONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CONSUMERS WATER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Ted Bates Names New York Head
description: After a long and tireless search, Robert E. Jacoby, president and chief executive of Ted Bates Worldwide, has decided to fill the job of president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York, his largest division, with indigenous talent -Donald M. Zuckert, advertising man and lawyer.

title: LOSER IN GARY PRIMARY WEIGHING LEGAL ACTION
description: Thomas J. Crump Jr., the apparent loser in Tuesday's bitterly contested Democratic mayoral primary, is weighing the possibility of legal action, including a recount, to overturn the results.

title: 3-STATE HOUSE VOTE ON FREEZE CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON. May 4 (AP) - Following were the positions of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today approved, 221 to 203, an amendment that would revoke a nuclear arms freeze if it was not followed by negotiated reductions ''within a reasonable, specific period of time.''

title: 3 U.S. STUDIES AIM TO FOSTER ADVANCES IN 'SUPERCOMPUTERS'
description: The White House today announced a threepronged effort to encourage the development and use of new ''supercomputers'' that would be the fastest and most powerful in the world.

title: STRIKERS AT THE AMSTERDAM NEWS SEEKING TO BUY OUT PAPER'S STOCK
description: Employees of The New York Amsterdam News who have been on strike since Feb. 1 decided yesterday to attempt to purchase the stock of the newspaper through an employee stock-ownership trust.

title: STUDY SAYS WEAKNESSES OF SCHOOLS POSE AN ECONOMIC THREAT TO U.S.
description: A group of 41 governors, corporate leaders and other prominent figures asserted here today that the poor quality of American public schools was threatening the military, economic and social well-being of the country.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WHAT EXALTED MANAGERS HAVE WROUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: The Roll-Call
description: Following is the breakdown of the 9-to-5 vote of the House Select Committee on Intelligence on Tuesday to bar covert assistance for anti-Sandinist rebels in Nicaragua:

title: 2 Police Officers Accused of Theft
description: Two police officers assigned to the 76th Precinct in Brooklyn were arrested yesterday on charges they had stolen two car batteries, authorities said. The officers - Joseph Valentine, 39 years old, and Walter Neville, 38 -were suspended without pay.

title: Treasury Bond Futures Rise to Contract Highs
description: All Treasury bond futures prices soared to life-of-contract highs yesterday, reflecting the extraordinary demand in the cash market for the record $15 billion of Treasury refunding issues being auctioned this week.

title: SALVADOR VOTES AMNESTY FOR PRISONERS AND REBELS
description: The Constituent Assembly today unanimously approved an amnesty law that could lead to freedom for hundreds of political prisoners.

title: I.R.S., OFFER AN AMNESTY
description: The Internal Revenue Service should begin tunneling into the underground economy. A sensible approach would be announcement of an amnesty of limited duration.

title: HEAD OF PSYCHOANALYTIC GROUP
description: Dr. Victor J. Teichner, who was inaugurated last Sunday as president of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and was a past president of the New York County branch of the American Psychiatric Association, died Tuesday of complications after surgery at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: HOUSE PANEL STUDIES UNDERTAKER REGULATIONS
description: With a Congressional deadline approaching, a House subcommittee held a hearing today on a Federal Trade Commission proposal that would make undertakers disclose funeral price information.

title: SAGE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
Kennecott Raises Prices
description: The Kennecott Corporation said today that it was raising its base price for copper by a cent a pound, to 83 cents, effective immediately. Several other copper manufacturers have raised prices recently.

title: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $391,000 from operations of the discontinued glass container division and a provision of $29.9 million for loss on disposition of the glass container division. c-Including income of $535,000 from operations of the discontinued glass container division. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Phillies 9, Reds 4
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Mike Schmidt drove in four runs for the second straight game, Bo Diaz and Garry Maddox hit home runs and Steve Carlton got his 289th career victory.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
XEBEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company went public March 1.

title: NEW SAN DIEGO MAYOR TAKES CONCILIATORY STANCE
description: Roger Hedgecock, the newly elected Mayor of San Diego, adopted a low-key stance from the start today in listing his priorities in office. He said he would ''assemble the best staff I can'' at City Hall and promote the city's economic development.

title: Douglas Hudson Dead at 77; Ex-State Senator in New York
description: Douglas Hudson, a former New York State Senator and Assemblyman, died Monday at Memorial Hospital in Albany. He was 77 years old and lived in Castleton, N.Y.

title: STOCKMAN DEFENDS FAIRNESS OF REAGAN POLICY
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, defended the fairness of President Reagan's policies today, saying they had increased the purchasing power of many poor people by controlling inflation and reducing tax rates.

title: AN OVERDONE CRITIQUE OF EDUCATION IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Refinery Plan
description: Esso S.A.F., a subsidiary of the New York-based Exxon Corporation, said today that it would probably shut down its refinery next year at Bordeaux in southwest France. The company told the French authorities it planned to close the refinery because of overcapacity. The Bordeaux refinery is capable of handling three million tons of crude annually.

title: DEMOCRATS REPORT TENTATIVE TRUCE TO END 4-WEEK SENATE SLOWDOWN
description: Democrats in the State Senate have tentatively agreed to end the four-week slowdown they mounted to protest their treatment by the Republican majority, senators and staff members said today.

title: Argentina, Irked, Calls Envoy Back From Italy
description: Argentina today recalled its envoy from Italy after Italian criticism of an Argentine report on the disappearance of thousands of people in the 1970's.

title: Fast Patron Visits A Fast-Food Spot
description: A McDonald's restaurant got an unexpected customer Tuesday when a pilot landed a helicopter, bought a sack full of fast food, then flew off.

title: COOLIDGE'S LATIN FOLLY: BUT IT DID 'WORK'
description: To the Editor:

title: AVIATION GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $305,000 for the quarter and $634,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $276,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: GRUMMAN NET INCOME UP SHARPLY
description: The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter nearly tripled to $22.6 million, or $1.60 a share, from $7.6 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, which was restated for discontinued operations and a change in the method of accounting for investment tax credits.

title: Hard to Check
description: When the Rangers decided last November to organize an alumni association, the initial steps seemed deceptively easy. ''We didn't think at the beginning that contacting all the former players would be difficult,'' said John Halligan, the business manager and public-relations director, who with Bill Chadwick and Steve Vickers were named by Jack Krumpe, the Ranger president, to administer the association.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CASTLE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CANADIAN NATIONAL RY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Federation Cool To House Action
description: The resolution by the United States House of Representatives supporting the American effort to acquire the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament failed to impress the Federation Internationale de Football Association today.

title: MUSIC: CLEVELANDERS
description: THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA is in a state of suspension this season, caught between, so to speak, crossed international plane flights. Its music director of a decade, Lorin Maazel, has already left to head the Vienna State Opera, but Christoph von Dohnanyi has not yet left the Hamburg State Opera to begin his four-year term as music director of the Clevelanders next season.

title: CONCERT: BRAHAMS SERIES
description: SOME of the Brahms ''celebrations'' this spring hardly vary from normal programming policy, since Brahms is, after all, central to the repertory. But the seven-concert survey of the composer's chamber music that began Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y has more to recommend it. This is a real overview of a genre that was central to Brahms's creative imagination. And to judge from Tuesday's performances, it will be a well-performed survey, as well.

title: DANCE: AILEY 'STACK-UP'
description: AQUARTER of a century is just about an entire lifetime in terms of dance companies. But the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater looked as young and gutsy as ever, dancing up a storm as it opened its 25th anniversary season Tuesday at City Center, in a performance dedicated ''with gratitude and love'' to the memory of George Balanchine.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HOUSE ARMS FREEZE MEASURE
description: Following are the key clauses in the nuclear weapons freeze resolution passed tonight by the House of Representatives:

title: Manager Slain
description: Douglas Tatting, the 48-year-old manager of the boxers Andy Ganigan, Kenneth Ganigan and James Johnson, was fatally stabbed Tuesday night during the first fight card of the year in Hawaii. A suspect is in custody, but the police would give no details.

title: CHINA SEEKS BETTER EAST EUROPEAN TIES
description: After two rounds of talks with the Soviet Union on improving their relations, China has opened a broader drive to improve relations with other Communist nations in Eastern Europe.

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INVESTIGATORS SCRUTINIZE DENVER E.P.A. OFFICE
description: The regional office of the Environmental Protection Agency here is under scrutiny by a team of investigators sent by the agency's inspector general's office in Washington.

title: 35 RUBELLA CASES ARE REPORTED BY BANK
description: Thirty-five cases of rubella have been reported at a lower Manhattan office of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, and the City Health Department began emergency immunizations of 5,000 bank employees yesterday.

title: WILLIAMS, A L, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There were no comparable year- ago results.

title: PETROTECH NV reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: BANK-RULE CHANGES PROPOSED IN FRANCE
description: Two job-support proposals floated in recent days by France's Socialist Government are being viewed by bankers here as thinly disguised measures to bring the country's remaining private banks, most of which are foreign owned, under state control.

title: AMERICAN APPRAISAL ASSOCIATION INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the quarter and $410,000 for the year and net gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $2,174,000 for the quarter and $1,989,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $216,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including income of $75,000 from discontinued operations and a net gain of $250,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: MIDWESTERN FUEL SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New RCA Models
description: The RCA Corporation introduced five new models of its videodisk player, including a random access model that will allow the user to play any particular segment of the disk and to display still pictures from specially prepared disks.

title: 13 ARE INJURED IN FRENCH CLASHES
description: Policemen using clubs and tear gas injured at least 13 students today while breaking up demonstrations around the country. The demonstrators were protesting a Government plan to toughen university entrance requirements and take more control over courses.

title: PLAYSAlex Yannis
description: E xcellent defensive plays usually go unnoticed in a hockey game decided by the margin of five goals, but one by Denis Potvin was among the prime topics of conversation after the Islanders' 8-3 playoff victory over the Boston Bruins in Nassau Coliseum Tuesday night.

title: MONDALE WANTS IMPORTS TO CONTAIN U.S. PARTS
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, who has wide support among organized labor in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, told union leaders today that he strongly favored a bill requiring that many foreign-made products imported into the United States have some American-made parts.

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED ANEW ON WEAPONS
description: A month ago, White House officials felt President Reagan had deflected pressures for more flexibility on arms control by modifying his position in the medium-range missile talks and discreetly encouraging the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to ease their criticism of Administration arms policy.

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $1,100,000 due to an increase in the value of employee stock appreciation rights during the quarter.

title: GETTING LOUISIANA LAND VOTES
description: Carl H. Lindner of Cincinnati, one of the wealthiest men in America, will convene with his advisers tomorrow to decide which of two feuding factions he wants to back in the proxy fight for control of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: The earnings are adjusted for 3-for-2 split payable May 18.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES ADVANCE BY 10.5%
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that new car sales rose 10.5 percent in the last 10 days of April, and some analysts argued that demand for cars seemed to be slowly rising.

title: Summer Jobs Set For 59,000 Youths
description: There will be 44,800 federally supported summer jobs open to New York City's young people this year, and a private consortium hopes to provide 15,000 more, according to testimony yesterday at a City Council hearing.

title: A. MILTON RUNYON
description: A. Milton Runyon, a former executive vice president of Doubleday & Company, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Money Is the Lure
description: Ray Pinney says there is a simple reason why four former members of the Pittsburgh Steelers have jumped to the United States Football League. Pinney, an offensive tackle, says it's money.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of McCorkell, Sidaway & Wright, a London based direct response agency, acquired as of Jan. 1, 1983.

title: The U.N. Today; May 5, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Pogo Sells Preferred Stock
description: The Pogo Producing Company, a Houston-based oil and gas exploration company that is trying to prevent a takeover, said yesterday that it had sold in a private placement 1.1 million shares of a new series of preferred stock for $111 million in cash.

title: HOUSE APPROVES ALTERED VERSION OF ARMS FREEZE
description: The President faces renewed pressure for more flexibility on arms control, page A13. Roman Catholic bishops overwhelmingly oppose nuclear arms, page B17. Excerpts from the bishops' pastoral letter, page B16.

title: DANCE: 'FOLLOW THE FEET' AT A.B.T.
description: ''FOLLOW THE FEET,'' urged the title of the new work by John McFall that American Ballet Theater presented on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Since the feet involved in this male duet were those of Mikhail Baryshnikov and Robert La Fosse, that sounded like good advice. But once those feet got going, they never really went anywhere.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $87.4 million associated with an optional retirement and separation program.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago sales figure includes revenue of $148,000 from real estate.

title: Article 144621 -- No Title
description: President Reagan asked Congress Tuesday for $141,000 to paint and patch up the exterior of the home provided by the Government to Vice President Bush.

title: 400 Former Polish Internees Reported to Resettle in U.S.
description: The State Department said today that as many as 400 Poles interned after the crackdown on the Solidarity union had left Poland and had been resettled in the United States.

title: Iran Reduces Japan Oil Fee
description: Japan's commerce chief said today that Iran had granted his country a discount of $2 a barrel off the official $28 Iranian oil price on a new contract.

title: RUCKELSHAUS GIVES PLEDGE TO ENFORCE ENVIRONMENT LAWS
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, President Reagan's nominee to head the beleaguered Environmental Protection Agency, said today that there had been an ''abuse of process'' at the agency and pledged to enforce environmental laws ''as written by Congress.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Ins and Outs
description: The San Diego Sockers have been the most successful of the outdoor-turned-indoor soccer teams, and yet they may suffer for their success.

title: HUNDREDS OF BIRDS INVADE HOME IN CALIFORNIA
description: Hundreds of birds swirled ''like a tornado'' down the chimney of a home twice in one week, creating a fluttering mass invasion reminiscent of the Alfred Hitchcock movie ''The Birds,'' the home's owners said today.

title: Henry S. McNeil Dies; Headed Drug Concern
description: Henry Slack McNeil, a former president of McNeil Laboratories Inc. who was a patron of the arts, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in Plymouth Meeting, Pa. He was 66 years old.

title: SWEDEN SETS OFF MINES IN SEARCH FOR SUBMARINES NORTH OF CAPITAL
description: Naval forces hunting an alien submarine detonated two mines late today in a channel where spotters saw the periscope of a small submarine that was trying to escape, the search command said.

title: CHURCH ON COAST LOSES TAX STATUS
description: The State Board of Equalization has removed the tax-exempt status of the Rev. Robert H. Schuller's opulent Crystal Cathedral, which holds concerts priced at up to $150 a seat.

title: Novosti Assails Swiss On Closing of Bureau
description: The Soviet press agency Novosti today rejected charges that it had been involved in subversive activities in Switzerland and said the closure of its Bern office would damage relations.

title: COMMODORE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $125,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $57,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REPORT TELLS OF ILLEGAL PESTICIDE SALES
description: EXTERMINATION companies in New York City are selling consumers highly concentrated pesticides that are designated for use by professional exterminators, according to a report prepared by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The department charged that such sales and the use by consumers are sometimes illegal and pose serious health hazards to those who apply the chemicals in their homes.

title: AFFILIATED BANK CORP OF WYOMING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SPURS ELMINATE NUGGETS, 145-105
description: George Gervin's 26 points led seven Spurs in double figures as San Antonio routed the Denver Nuggets, 145-105, tonight to win their Western Conference semifinal series in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: REHAB HOSPITAL SERVICES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COLLEGES AS LOBBYISTS: FAST LEARNERS
description: Before the Senate began debate on a Congressional budget resolution this week, hundreds of college presidents around the country had received a message alerting them to the issues at stake.

title: News session transcript, page D22.
description: President Reagan said today that insurgent groups in Nicaragua receiving covert aid from the Central Intelligence Agency were ''freedom fighters'' opposing a Government that had betrayed its revolutionary principles.

title: News Analysis
description: A Federal district judge's ruling Monday throwing out a jury's $2.05 million libel verdict against The Washington Post followed a pattern in which libel defendants have fared much better with judges than with juries.

title: Legislature Votes Bill On Red Light Runners
description: The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a measure that would toughen penalties for drivers who run red lights.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for year to March 31.
AMEDCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Johnny Puleo, an Entertainer; Played in Harmonica Groups
description: Johnny Puleo, the little man with the giant harmonica who entertained kings, presidents and millions in movie, television and nightclub audiences, died Tuesday at the age of 74.

title: Failures Up In Houston
description: Battered both by the continued slump in oil and gas prices and by the slow economic recovery, Houston-area businesses lined up in bankruptcy court in sharply increasing numbers in the first quarter of this year.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE SECRECY MUDDLE
description: On March 11, President Reagan signed a National Security Decision Directive to tighten secrecy in Government. The order has come under growing criticism in Congress and the press. Now it has problems in the Government itself.

title: Strawberry to Join Mets
description: The Mets have decided to bring the heralded outfielder Darryl Stawberry up from the minor leagues in time for Friday night's game against Cincinnati at Shea Stadium. He will start in right field.

title: EGYPT EXPECTED TO RESTORE TIES TO SOVIET SOON
description: Egyptian officials and foreign diplomats here expect Egypt to restore diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union soon. Ties were severed by President Anwar el-Sadat in September 1981.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Comings and Goings
description: Ron Tabb, Benji Durden and Ed Mendoza, who finished second through fourth, respectively, in last month's Boston Marathon, will represent the United States in the marathon at the world track and field championships this summer in Helsinki. Greg Meyer, the winner, will attempt to qualify for the 10,000-meter run. ... Ron Friest, who plays right wing for the Minnesota North Stars, will undergo spinal fusion surgery Monday at the Mayo Clinic and is expected to miss all of next season. ... Don Nelson, coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, has been fined $1,000 by the National Basketball Association for remarks in which he called Danny Ainge, a Boston Celtic guard, ''a cheapshot artist.'' ... Carl Yastrzemski, the Boston Red Sox slugger, was released from the University of Massachusetts Medical Center after a week of treatments for lower back spasms.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $348,000 and a tax credit of $1.5 million. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.1 million, extraordinary credits of $4.9 million and a pretax gain of approximately $7.2 million on the sale of certain assets of the discontinued real estate financing operation. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective April 6.

title: TRIBUNE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REPEAL BID ON INTEREST LAW GAINS
description: Opponents of tax withholding on interest and dividend payments prevailed today in their effort to force the House of Representatives to vote on a repeal measure this month.

title: Stocks Rise in Heavy Trading
description: With more than 100 million shares trading hands, the stock market registered a broad advance yesterday, fueled by the impressive performance of the transportation issues and a drop in interest rates in the credit markets.

title: Kodak, Off 72.8%, Blames Labor Cuts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, a traditional Wall Street favorite that has fallen on hard times in recent months, yesterday reported sharply lower earnings for the first quarter, primarily because of the cost of an employment reduction program.

title: Boat With Argentine Families Of Falkland Dead Turns Back
description: Fifty relatives of Argentines killed in the Falkland war last year gave up trying to visit graves on the islands today and began to return home.

title: 3 Bodies in 2 Barrels Found in Coast Park
description: The bodies of a man and two women were found today inside two cement-sealed steel drums that had been left in Golden Gate Park, the police said.

title: DOW SAYS U.S. KNEW DIOXIN PERIL OF AGENT ORANGE
description: The Dow Chemical Company maintains that at least two years before the United States halted the use of Agent Orange in Vietnam in 1971, both the Defense Department and the company were aware of evidence indicating that dioxin, a contaminant in the herbicide, might cause birth defects in the children of women exposed to the defoliant.

title: TRUDEAU CALLS SOVIET PLAN ON MISSILES HELPFUL STEP
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the willingness of the Soviet Union to consider the numbers of European-based warheads as well as missiles in establishing schedules for nuclear arms reduction was ''a step in the right direction.'' He also said he had urged President Reagan to meet with the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO MODIFY FARM MARKETING ORDERS
description: President Reagan, in an action that could lead to lower consumer prices for various fruits, nuts and other products, has directed the Agriculture Department to remove or modify some federally sanctioned protections for growers who agree among themselves to restrict output or allocate production.

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. AIDES CONFIDENT OF AN ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that he would call a meeting of his Cabinet soon to decide whether to accept the Lebanese-Israeli draft agreement worked out by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Spain-Africa Pipeline
description: Spain's Industry and Energy Minister, Carlos Solchaga, will propose construction of a gas pipeline linking North Africa to Spain at an International Energy Agency meeting in Paris this weekend, an industry ministry spokesman said today.

title: Venezuelan Seeks Big Flagship Stake
description: A Venezuelan businessman has offered to buy the one million shares that Flagship Banks Inc. of Florida filed a registration statement for on Tuesday.

title: BOSSY GIVEN A SPECIAL HONOR
description: The huge black sombrero, with its decorations of silver and orange and red and yellow, was placed on the bottom of Mike Bossy's locker, and a baseball hat was stuffed inside it. The dark blue sombrero, with silver trim, rested on top of the pile. Bossy had scored playoff hat tricks for the Islanders before Tuesday night, but during Game 4 of the Stanley Cup semifinal series against the Boston Bruins, Bossy's three goals inspired a moment that he could not remember happening in a remarkable six-year career: A two-sombrero night.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $839,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $1,570,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $518,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $487,000 for the quarter and $1,299,000 for the 9 months, and a pre-tax charge of $9,867,000 for the writedown of certain assets for the quarter. The year-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Chief Executive Named For ACLI Commodities
description: George D.F. Lamborn, whose family name is well known in the sugar trade, has been named president and chief executive of ACLI International Commodity Services Inc.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WITH more and more people doing their own maintenance work around the house, it is not surprising that manufacturers and distributors who cater to them are continually introducing new products. Here are some interesting ones: Automatic Sprinklers

title: PSYCHIATRIC CONVENTION IS JUMPING WITH ADVICE
description: It is a bustling event in which men and women wearing name tags ride elevators and duck into doorways marked with such titles as ''New Dimensions of Anxiety,'' ''Cults and Mass Hysteria'' and ''One Hour of Bright Light Reduces Depression.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. BISHOP'S PASTORAL LETTER ON WAR AND PEACE
description: Following are excerpts from ''The Challenge of Peace: God's Promise and Our Response,'' the pastoral letter of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops that was approved Tuesday in Chicago. The excerpts have been provided by The Associated Press, which worked from a copyrighted, published third draft of the document produced by the conference, and inserted amendments that were approved at this week's meeting. The conference's official version of the letter will be published later. Introduction

title: HOLLYWOOD REPORTER 50 YEARS
description: Sidney Skolsky, the Broadway and Hollywood reporter whose column of vignettes called ''Tintypes'' appeared in New York and national newspapers for more than 50 years, died after a long illness at his home in Los Angeles Tuesday. He was 78 years old.

title: CERAMICS MADE TO DO A JOB
description: FIVE years ago she took a course, and her new interest in ceramics became a full-time occupation.

title: FIBAK UPSET
description: Vitas Gerulaitis eliminated Eddie Dibbs, and John McEnroe advanced without hitting a ball, but sixth-seeded Wojtek Fibak was upset by an obscure 25-year-old Californian, Scott McCain, at the Mercedes Tournament of Champions yesterday.

title: An Indictment In Rohm Theft
description: A former manager of the Rohm & Haas Company has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of stealing in 1978 the company's secret formula for QM663, an adhesive promoter used in $100 million worth of products, and selling the formula to an Austrailan manufacturer.

title: SERVED NEW YORK IN CONGRESS
description: Katharine St. George, a conservative Republican who served as a United States Representative from New York for 18 years until being defeated in 1964, died Monday at her home in Tuxedo Park in Orange County. She was 86 years old.

title: WISCONSIN PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a foreign currency translation gain of $246,000 and a charge of $2,865,000 representing the cost of a 9-week shutdown. c-Net income including a foreign currency translation gain of $2,181,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: PIONEER GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Paterson Notches 19-Run 2d Inning
description: Harry Shoucair and Mark Geimke each hit two home runs in a 19-run second inning today as William Paterson set one National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III record and tied another in a 24-1 victory over Scranton.

title: HECTOR, JET ROOKIE, HAD ROUGH START
description: Johnny Hector's route to professional football has been traveled many times before. It is a road of uncertainty with a happy ending only for those who win jobs and hold them against strong competition.

title: Air Controllers Held Up to Par
description: The rebuilt air traffic control system can now safely handle 100 percent of the traffic it directed before the President Reagan dismissed 11,400 striking controllers in 1981, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole said today.

title: TRANS-CANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: THE PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: EVER at the mercy of the elements, gardeners in both city and country were grateful this rainy spring that they were not farmers with livelihoods at stake. The wettest weekends in memory washed away garden activities, destroying seeds, soil and roots, and dampening dreams of colorful summer harvests. ''Better late than never'' rarely succeeds in the garden, but this May it's the only game in town. Spring Cleaning

title: RELIABLE INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ARCHITECT AND CLIENTS: A LASTING MARRIAGE
description: IN July 1971, Mara and Donald Kurtz had just moved into a new rental apartment on the East Side. The architect they asked to redesign the place refused, saying it was too small a project. But he did recommend a friend, Paul Segal.

description: Award to Mrs. Reagan From Phoenix House

title: BankAmerica Seafirst Bid
description: The BankAmerica Corporation filed an application Tuesday with the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco to acquire the Seattle-based Seafirst Corporation.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Ramsey Is Promoted After nine games as the backup quarterback for the Los Angeles Express, Tom Ramsey, the former U.C.L.A. star, is being promoted to the starting lineup, replacing Mike Rae. ''We've felt all along that Tom would be our quarterback of the future, and we wanted to see how he reacts in a starting role,'' said Coach Hugh Campbell in explaining the decision to start Ramsey against the Boston Breakers Saturday. Ramsey and the 31-year-old Rae, the oldest player on the Express roster, have divided quarterbacking duties fairly evenly throughout the season.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $99,476, or 3 cents a share. c-After a realized investment loss of $22,703.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 5, 1983
description: International Nicaraguan recipients of covert aid from the Central Intelligence Agency were ''freedom fighters'' opposing a Government that had betrayed its revolutionary principles, President Reagan said. He also said, in an interview at the White House, that it would be ''all right with me'' if Congress wanted to require that assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels be ''overt instead of covert.'' However, there would have to be no further restrictions imposed on the rebels' activities, Mr. Reagan said. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Israel's Cabinet will soon meet to decide whether to accept the Lebanese-Israeli draft agreement worked out by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said. A senior Cabinet official said the meeting would probably take place in time to allow Mr. Shultz to meet his unofficial target of concluding the accord by the end of this week. (A1:3.)

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
UTAH SLIDE CUTS COAL AND RAIL OPERATIONS
description: A landslide in a deep canyon 60 miles southeast of Salt Lake City that buried one of the main railroad routes between Denver and Salt Lake City is causing substantial operating and financial disruptions to the coal and railroad industries in Utah and Colorado.

description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include a gain of $1.7 million from the exchange of common stock for convertible debentures. Year-ago quarter and 6 months results include a gain of $1.5 million from the sale of textile rental operations in Detroit.

description: Nazareth College turned a dormitory into apartments for the elderly and brought its campus a new way of looking at life.

description: b-Net income

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

Tax Exemptions Can Be Prudent
description: New York State's Constitution exempts religious, educational and charitable institutions from real estate taxes, a concept the courts have been interpreting generously. But there has been a sudden, unwelcome reversal. An appellate court has ruled the city correct in taking away the exemption of Asia House, a not-for-profit agency devoted to exhibiting and explaining Asian art and culture.

title: RTC TRANSPORTATION CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain from sales of equipment and a tax benefit transfer compensation aggregating $326,000. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $128,000 from sales of equipment.

title: Time for an Incomes Policy
description: Eastern Airlines, near default on bank loans, nonetheless agrees to raise machinists' wages by 32 percent over three years ... Caterpillar Tractor, threatened in world markets by a lower-cost Japanese producer, nonetheless ends a long strike with a 20 percent, three-year pact.

title: Merrill Group to Offer Mortgage-Backed Bonds
description: The Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group yesterday announced a program to buy mortgage-collateralized bonds from home builders and repackage them for sale to investors.

title: ISLANDERS PEAK FOR BRUINS
description: The Islanders play tonight in Boston, where the rink is smaller, the fans are foreign to them and the Bruins are on the verge of being eliminated from the playoffs for the 11th consecutive season.

title: Bereavement
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: It so happens that bereavement is an experience that all living people must encounter if they live long enough (''Hers,'' April 21).
