When I was a graduate student at Columbia the late Prof. Willard Woller, who was a sociologist, learned that I was a rabbinical student.

title: A CITY CLEANUP BEGINS
description: ''What we are attempting to do,'' said Jane Kalmus, ''is call everyone's attention to the fact that we can help, and we are doing this in cooperation with the city. We are talking about the people of New York who want to do something about the litter in the city in which we work and play. We want to get everyone involved.''

title: FLORIDA IS UPHELD ON DIPLOMA DENIAL
description: Florida may deny high school diplomas to seniors who fail the state's functional literacy test, a Federal district judge declared today in ruling against black students who asserted the examination was discriminatory.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Golf William D. Richardson Memorial, at the Seawane Club, Hewlett Harbor, L.I., 7:15 A.M. More than 100 golfers are entered for the first day of stroke play in one of the metropolitan area's most important amateur tournaments. George Zahringer of Sands Point, L.I., is the defending champion.

title: WEINBERGER CRITICIZES REJECTION OF PLAN TO STRENGTHEN ARMED FORCES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger criticized the House Armed Services Committee today for voting to reject the Reagan Administration's plan to add 37,000 people to the armed forces next year.

title: Advertising; New Ad Approach For CNA
description: ADVERTISERS of tires and insurance are burdened with the knowledge that folks are not really interested in what they have to say. Interest in the general subjects is mighty low.

title: BOSTON MAINTAINS CLAMP ON PARKING AS ONE METHOD TO EASE TRAFFIC WOES
description: In downtown Boston every curbside space sprouts a pole that bears either a parking meter or a sign saying ''No Parking.'' Both kinds of spaces fill up each day with cars, some of which are then blocked in by additional cars that are double parked.

title: Market Place; Capitalizing on Misperceptions
description: MOST investors felt they had missed the play in Merrill Lynch's stock after it began to soar last summer from a low of 21. But in November, when the price hit 70, the BMI Capital Corporation began aggressively buying the stock and has continued as a buyer ever since.

title: CHRISTO DRAPES MIAMI ISLES IN PINK
description: The color of dawn, breaking over Biscayne Bay this morning, found its match in masses of shiny pink fabric as hundreds of workers began to release the first of the voluminous skirts that will surround 11 tiny islands in a two-week, $3.1 million extravaganza by the artist Christo.

title: Piedmont President Takes Over as Chief
description: William R. Howard was elected chief executive of Piedmont Airlines yesterday as the line's founder, Thomas H. Davis, stepped down at age 65.

title: Catholics Should Defy Orders To Trigger Bomb, Bishop Says
description: Roman Catholics serving in the armed forces should refuse any order to detonate a nuclear weapon, Archbishop John R. Quinn said today, comparing them to soldiers in Nazi Germany ordered to participate in war crimes.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Cosmos Beaten, 4-1
description: Roger Davies, who signed with the Fort Lauderdale Strikers on Tuesday, scored a goal and helped Teofilo Cubillas score two others tonight in a surprising 4-1 victory over the Cosmos.

title: BETTE DAVIS JOINS ABC'S FALL LINEUP
description: Next fall's prime-time schedule on ABC will bring Bette Davis to the home screen each week as the owner of a glamorous hotel, while ''Laverne and Shirley'' will leave after seven and a half years of service for the network.

title: BRAZIL TO SHIP ARMS BACK TO LIBYA
description: Brazil will return a shipment of Libyan arms intercepted here en route to Nicaragua by sea after attempts to arrange air transport failed, a Brazilian Air Ministry spokesman said today.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AN OVERDONE CRITIQUE OF EDUCATION IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results were restated to more appropriately reflect year- end adjustments for worker's compensation insurance and capitalized interest.

title: INDIA'S MOSLEMS SEE IN GAINS A BRIGHTER TOMORROW
description: On the south side of New Delhi is a cluttered urban village of narrow, twisting alleyways, tantalizing sights, sounds and smells, hole-in-the-wall shops and dusty Asian bustle that could have served well as the set for many a biblical movie. It is called Nizamuddin, and for generations it has been an island of Islam in the Hindu sea that is India.

title: ALVARADO WANTS ALL-DAY CLASSES IN KINDERGARTEN
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the new Schools Chancellor, yesterday proposed closing some troubled high schools by September and finding the money to make all-day kindergarten classes the norm throughout New York City.

title: BAILING OUT MEDICARE
description: All evidence suggests that until incentives are devised to restrain physicians' economic behavior, Medicare's coming fiscal crisis will not be resolved. So far, neither the Administration nor Congress has confronted this politically sensitive issue.

title: THE MARKET'S LITTLE WINNERS
description: When the stock market began climbing last August like an inspired mountain goat, Carol A. Ruth didn't rush right out and buy something. In fact, she waited until April before making her choices.

title: County Grand Jury Indicts Biegenwald
description: A Monmouth County grand jury indicted Richard F. Biegenwald today on a charge of murder in the killing of an 18-year-old Camden girl, the County Prosecutor said.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,879,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: PENN VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CUBIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Books Of The Times
description: ON BECOMING A NOVELIST. By John Gardner. Foreword by Raymond Carv- er. 150 pages. Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE GRANTED $200 MILLION INCREASE IN RATES
description: Customers of the New York Telephone Company will soon pay slightly more for monthly service, but the cost of a call from a pay phone will stay at a dime, the Public Service Commission decided yesterday.

title: Partnership Sales Hit High in March
description: Sales of publicly registered, limited partnership investments reached $994 million in March, the highest monthly total in the industry's history, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a leading tax-shelter research concern based in Fair Haven, N.J. First-quarter sales of $1.7 billion were up more than 53 percent from 1982 and point to a $7 billion-plus year, Mr. Stanger said.

title: CITING VANDALISM, ISLIP PROPOSES SELLING 25 OF ITS SMALL PARKS
description: Officials here have proposed selling 25 of the town's public parks to builders, saying vandalism is so severe that the parks are too costly to maintain.

title: Larry Brown Sued by Nets
description: The Nets have filed suit against Larry Brown, their former coach, seeking repayment of $125,000 that the club said it had advanced him under the four-year contract that he broke last month to become head coach at Kansas.

title: No Headline
description: The Boston Celtics will keep Kevin McHale and Larry Bird and will otherwise forgo wholesale changes after being eliminated from the playoffs in four straight games by the Milwaukee Bucks, General Manager Red Auerbach said today.

title: Johan J. Smertenko, 86, Dies; Author and Activist for Israel
description: Johan J. Smertenko, an author, professor and an activist in the establishment of the state of Israel, died last Friday at the River Glen Continuing Care Center in Southbury, Conn. He was 86 years old and had lived in Woodbury, Conn.

title: Devils to Lose Levo
description: Tapio Levo, the New Jersey Devils' defenseman who led the team in assists with 40, will not return to the National Hockey League next season. The 26-year-old Levo informed Coach Billy MacMillan that he will play in his native Finland.

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $14,238,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $5.4 million on the disposal of discontinued operations and income of $7,103,000 from cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: Union Is Accepted In Columbia Vote
description: Clerical workers at Columbia University voted yesterday, 468 to 442, to accept representation by District 65 of the United Auto Workers.

title: OLIVIER AND HIS GENIUS, AN EXPANSE OF CLASSICS
description: THE gala celebration of Laurence Olivier, sponsored last week by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, necessarily emphasized the actor's movie career. However, in the selection of clips from his films, it was impossible not to be aware of his brilliant performances on stage. Except for obligatory scenes from such classics as ''Wuthering Heights,'' the outstanding moments were from movie versions of roles he had first played in the theater -Archie Rice in ''The Entertainer,'' and, especially, his three great Shakespearean incarnations, ''Hamlet,'' ''Henry V'' and ''Richard III.''

title: HERS
description: THROUGHOUT human history, acts of violence that would be considered crimes on the part of strangers have been placed in an entirely different category if committed by one family member against another. In both the literal and the metaphoric senses, they have been beyond the law.

title: INTEREST RATE DROP CONTINUES
description: Interest rates continued to decline yesterday as investors and speculators readily absorbed a large new issue of 10-year Treasury notes, and seemed eager to buy long-term Treasury bonds scheduled for sale today.

title: Explosives Found In Bronx Home
description: A suitcase removed from the apartment of a Bronx man who was being evicted by city marshals was found to contain plastic explosives, blasting caps, an M-1 rifle and ammunition, the police reported.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Children were pulled out of school to stack sandbags beside the rising Mississippi today as chest-deep water rushed along roads south of St. Louis and forced hundreds to flee their homes.

title: DANCE: LONDON COMPANY IN BROOKLYN
description: THERE are three things to stress about the program the London Contemporary Dance Theater presented last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -the second of two programs in its New York debut season, which runs through Sunday afternoon.

title: Pregnant Teen-Agers In State Get Hot Line
description: With more than 60,000 teen-agers in the state getting pregnant each year, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, today announced a new hot line and referral service.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BITCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FRIONA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
KFC Expansion
description: The KFC Corporation, a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries, announced plans for a major expansion of its Kentucky Fried Chicken stores over the next five years. Richard Mayer, the unit's chairman, said Reynolds had committed $100 million for the expansion, which is expected to produce 50 percent growth by 1988 in the United States, as well as ''substantial expansion'' overseas. Kentucky Fried Chicken currently has 3,500 franchised stores and 900 company-owned stores in the United States, and 1,400 in 54 other countries.

title: MATCHING CONGRESSMEN AND EXECUTIVES, FOR A PRICE
description: For Senators and Representatives, the seminars that Ernest Wittenberg runs to bring them together with corporate executives are an easy way to pick up a $2,000 honorarium. For the executives, it is a way to get inside information on what's happening on Capitol Hill. And for Mr. Wittenberg's public relations company, which is the matchmaker, it is good public relations.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A COUNCIL PANEL SEEKS TO PROTECT S.R.O. TENANTS
description: Single-room-occupancy dwellings where landlords have illegally tried to force out tenants could not be turned into higher-grade apartments under a bill passed yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: STATE IS ACCUSED OF BACKING OUT ON LAYOFF DEAL
description: The head of the state's largest Civil Service union accused the Cuomo administration yesterday of reneging on a deal that would have prevented layoffs of state employees.

title: Money Market Fund Assets Off $1.7 Billion
description: Money market fund assets fell $1.7 billion for the week ended Wednesday, to $171.6 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The drop during the previous week was $1.9 billion.

title: FOUNDER OF 'TALL SHIPS' GROUP
description: Barclay H. Warburton 3d, founder of the American Sail Training Association, which was the host for the 'tall ships' visit to New York in 1976 in honor of the nation's bicentennial celebration died Sunday at his home in Newport, R.I. He was 61 years old.

title: Murder Count Reinstated Against 2 Coast Doctors
description: Murder charges were reinstated today against two doctors who disconnected life-support systems and cut off food and water to a brain-damaged patient who later died.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the year-ago quarter include the January 1982 operations of the 12 properties included in the company's plan of disposition.

title: SASCO COSMETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $273,737 from discontinued operations and a tax benefit of $57,100.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
West German Inflation
description: West Germany's rate of inflation in April climbed two-tenths of 1 percent from March and 3.3 percent from April 1982, the federal Statistics Office said today. The office's cost-of-living index, using a 1976 base of 100, rose to 133.2 in April. The 3.3 percent year-to-year increase narrowed, however, from a year-to-year gain of 3.5 percent in March and 3.7 percent in February.

title: 4 Escape Prison In Adirondacks
description: Four inmates escaped from a mediumsecurity Federal prison here today, and the state police said tonight that they were concentrating their search in the area surrounding this town in the northern Adirondacks.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. c-After an extraordinary charge of $68,323 for the quarter and $284,557 for the year, and an accounting adjustment gain of $9,116 for the quarter. Revenue figures for the year-ago quarter and year are restated.

title: Index; International
description: Thirsty Soviet's grand design: tap Arctic waters A2 Soviet assails Iran's crackdown on Communists A3 Demonstrators in Paris skirmish with the police A4 Around the World A5 Socialist International's stand on Puerto Rico angers U.S. A6 Close Senate vote seen on aid to anti-Sandinists A7 Proposed new constitution is in- troduced in South Africa A9 Hussein-Arafat talks reported at ''a final end'' A10 A Reporter's Notebook: The wait for an Israeli-Lebanese accord A12 Government/Politics Ruckelshaus plans few major policy changes A15 Three Democrats bid for trade unions' Presidential support A16 U.S. to reduce number of high- ways for double-trailer trucks A18 Jersey Assembly passes bill on teacher contracts B2 Top New York court limits sub- poenas of physicians' records B3 Senate votes $1.8 billion for health insurance for jobless B6 Washington Talk Pentagon: Chief of Naval Opera- tions on morality and weapons A32 Competing for the capital's lux- ury hotel market A32 Briefing A32 Religion Eastern Orthodox Christians pre- pare to observe Easter D15 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of Eastern Orthodox Good Friday, alternate-side parking is sus- pended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Rhinebeck, a village that time passed by C1 New arts flourish in new spaces C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: BIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Former Morgan Officer In Waterhouse Venture
description: Alexander M. Vagliano left the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in 1981 as head of its international banking division. Since then, among other things, he has been testing the feasibility of raising sheep commercially in New England.

title: CHRISTO VISION UNFOLDS
description: The biggest water sport in Miami today was boating around the ''Surrounded Islands,'' the string of 11 islands in Biscayne Bay whose shapes are being contoured, by the artist Christo, with 200-foot-wide ''skirts'' of pink fabric.

title: 'THE WHITE ROSE,' STUDENTS AGAINST NAZIS
description: LIKE the young German martyrs whose World War II story it tells, Michael Verhoeven's ''White Rose'' is resoundingly decent and sincere. The intrinsically stirring story of these dissidents, who risked their lives to disseminate anti-Nazi literature in the Munich of 1942 and 1943, is enough to give this film an almost automatic emotional power.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about the decline of sex-related businesses and felony crime complaints in midtown Manhattan incorrectly described the affected area. It extends from 30th to 50th Street and from the East River to the Hudson.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE CITY;
description: Two men, one dressed in a police officer's uniform and carrying a walkie-talkie, held up a Brooklyn jewelry manufacturer yesterday and escaped with more than $50,000 worth of jewelry, the police said.

title: New Crisis in Bolivia As 3 Quit Cabinet
description: The resignation of three Cabinet ministers has plunged Bolivia's left-wing Government into its second political crisis since it ended nearly 17 years of military rule seven months ago.

title: IT'S NOT CHICAGO, PHILADELPHIA DEMOCRATS SAY OF THEIR PRIMARY
description: ''Philadelphia is not Chicago'' has become the catch phrase of the Democratic mayoral primary here. By repeating it, the rival factions suggest a shared intention to avoid the racial animosities of the election for Mayor in Chicago last month.

title: SENATE ADDS 1.8 BILLION IN HEALTH INSURANCE FOR JOBLESS TO BUDGET
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to add $1.8 billion to the 1984 budget to pay for health insurance for the unemployed, but the action left the Republican leadership still short of the votes it needs to pass its budget proposal.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $5,028,000 for partial reversal of an income tax provision incurred in relation to a gain on a debenture exchange in 1977, a gain of $532,000 from property sales, and a tax benefit of $437,000. c-After a gain of $8,602,000 from the sales of hotel properties, a gain of $1,505,000 from the sale of tax benefits, and a tax benefit of $4,094,000.

title: TRANSPORT ISSUES LEAD STOCK RISE
description: The transportation issues led the stock market to its second consecutive broad advance yesterday in continued heavy trading. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange soared to 107.9 million shares from 101.7 million shares the day before with many of the secondary issues attracting most of the buyers' attention.

title: TONECRAFT REALTY INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
THE COST OF A SHUTDOWN: AN UNCLEAR BOTTOM LINE
description: What would happen if the two reactors at Indian Point were shut down because of yesterday's ruling by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission? The plant operators - the Consolidated Edison Company for Indian Point 2 and the New York Power Authority for Unit 3 - disagree sharply with opponents of the plants. Following are some questions and answers about the issues:

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S RULING PARTY FACING A CHALLENGE FROM THE FAR RIGHT
description: The governing National Party is trying to fight off a right-wing challenge in two rural districts on the Zimbabwe border, where white voters are at least as resistant to the idea of racial change as anywhere in the country.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 16.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THEATER: 'PROVOKED WIFE,' A COMEDY
description: ALMOST three centuries after it was written, Sir John Vanbrugh's ''Provoked Wife,'' still speaks wittily about marriage, infidelity and the suppression of women by men. One of the pleasures of the Actors Touring Company of London's production of the Restoration comedy is its timeless impertinence.

title: E.P.A. Backing Is Seen For Waste-Disposal Ship
description: An official of the Environmental Protection Agency says that, on the basis of final test results, the agency is likely to urge approval of a permit for a waste disposal concern to burn liquid chemicals aboard its incineration ship.

title: WALCO NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After income of $75,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Includes income of $157,000 from discontinued operations.

title: The U.N. Today; May 6, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dennis Eckersley, a Boston Red Sox right-hander, may miss a couple of starting assignments with tendinitis in his pitching arm. ... Pat Hallacy, a 27-year-old welterweight, was found guilty of aggravated battery for breaking a man's jaw in a private club in Wichita. ... Craig Perrett, a jockey involved in a two-horse spill Tuesday at Monmouth Park, was suspended a week for ''careless riding.'' ... Larry Ferguson, a 42-year-old former all-Big Ten running back with Iowa, was sentenced to six months in Federal prison for embezzling $40,000.

title: COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SUPERIOR OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES Qtr to March 31 1983 reports earnings for Revenue.
Economic Scene; Profit-Sharing Bid in Sweden
description: TWO major events are perturbing the Swedes these days. One is the stepped-up espionage of Soviet submarines in Swedish harbors. ''The situation is extremely dangerous,'' a Government spokesman says. But other Swedes in the foreign office are saying that the heightened submarine activity ''doesn't fit'' with the peace offensive and bid for greater East-West trade by Yuri V. Andropov, the new Communist Party chief, and confess their confusion.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Baby Sitter Is Convicted In Death of Girl, 3
description: A live-in baby sitter who prosecutors say systematically beat a 3-year-old girl over a 10-month period was convicted today of murdering the child.

title: Indians 7, Twins 5
description: Andre Thornton drove in two runs and extended his hitting streak to 10 games as Cleveland completed a sweep of the three-game series.

title: U.S. SEES OIL PRICE DROP OF $5 A BARREL BY 1985
description: World oil prices will decline another $5 a barrel by 1985 despite the increased demand that will accompany economic recovery, the Department of Energy predicted today in its annual survey.

title: Qualified Report For Cincinnati Gas
description: The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company's outside auditors, Arthur Andersen & Company, placed a qualification on the previously unqualified report on its financial statements.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 6, 1983
description: Companies

title: ARNOLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Analysis
description: For months the House of Representatives was awash with contention over the nuclear freeze resolution, and now that the floor fight is over and an agreement has been adopted, the debate over which side prevailed and over the implications of the resolution has just begun.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES $188 BILLION BUDGET FOR ARMED FORCES
description: The House Armed Services Committee today approved a $188 billion military authorization bill for the 1984 fiscal year, giving President Reagan all the major weapons programs he sought while reducing his budget request by $10.5 billion.

title: Murdoch Satellite Deal
description: A company owned by Rupert Murdoch, the American and Australian publisher, has signed an agreement to use a communications satellite for a direct-broadcast televison service to start as early as September.

title: WISE USE OF FEDERAL LAND
description: Scarcely a week passes in which the Interior Department's controversial Secretary, James Watt, is not castigated by environmentalists and others for what is seen as opposition to all that is virtuous, just and good for the nation. The media have led us to believe that truth is on the side of the environmentalists. To others, however, Mr. Watt's policies are reasonable, and are consistent with a different set of values.

title: Pan Am Doubles Size of Offering
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday announced a public offering of 100,000 units made up of $100 million of 13 1/2 percent senior debentures due May 1, 2003, and warrants to buy 10 million shares of Pan Am stock.

title: MEDEX IN. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: Kissinger to Lead World Cup Group
description: The United States World Cup Organizing Committee, seeking a ''fair hearing'' in an effort to stage the 1986 soccer tournament, said yesterday that it would dispatch a 10-man delegation headed by Henry A. Kissinger to Stockholm.

title: John F. Ahearne
description: Former chairman of the commission ... 49 years old ... five-year term as member expires on June 30 ... deputy assistant secretary for resource applications, Department of Energy ... staff member White House Energy Policy and Planning Office ... deputy assistant secretary of defense for general purpose programs ... principal deputy assistant secretary of defense for manpower and reserve affairs ... officer, United States Air Force, 1959 to 1970 ... associate professor of physics, Air Force Academy ... adjunct professor, University of Colorado Extension ... staff member, Air Defense Division, office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis ... director, Tactical Air Directorate Office, 1970 to 1972 ... bachelor of science and master of science degrees, Cornell University ... M.A. and Ph.D. in physics, Princeton University ... married, five children. James K. Asselstine

title: School to Be Shut; Asbestos Cited
description: Westchester County's Health Commissioner, Dr. Anita S. Curran, today ordered the Walt Whitman Middle School in Yonkers closed by next Thursday because asbestos is ''hanging like slender threads from the ceilings.''

title: JETLINER'S ENGINES FAIL OFF FLORIDA, BUT CREW PREVENTS A SEA 'DITCHING'
description: An Eastern Airlines jumbo jet lost power in all three engines yesterday and narrowly missed having to ''ditch'' off Florida. The plane, with 162 passengers and 10 crew members, fell below 4,000 feet before the crew could finally restart one engine and reach Miami International Airport safely.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MARITIME TELEGRAPH & TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $12 million from discontinued operations.

title: EASTERN ORTHODOX CHURCHES TO MARK EASTER IN OLD RITES
description: Eastern Orthodox Christians celebrate Easter this Sunday in rites recalling not only the spiritual power of Jesus' Resurrection, but also their churches' cherished role as guardians of the doctrine of an undivided Christendom.

title: HADDAD RULES OUT ANY COMPROMISE ON HIS ROLE IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Maj. Saad Haddad, the former Lebanese Army officer who operates his own militia in southern Lebanon, said today that he would not accept any compromise on his demand to be appointed overall commander of Lebanese security forces in the south.

title: CUOMO SEEKS TO WIDEN INVESTMENTS BY INSURERS
description: Governor Cuomo submitted a bill today that would permit sweeping liberalization of investment rules for life insurance companies licensed to operate in New York State.

title: 2-Party Group Backing A Bill on Housing Bias
description: A bipartisan Congressional group, confident it can override a Senate filibuster, today introduced a bill aimed at eliminating discrimination in housing.

title: G.A.O. Cites Oil Fund Misuse
description: The Reagan Administration has improperly impounded $800 million that was to have been spent this year to fill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $407,500. c-Includes tax credits of $250,000 for the quarter and $1,050,000 for the 9 months.

title: Grace School Fair
description: The 28th May Fair of the Grace Church School, Fourth Avenue and 10th Street, will go on tomorrow, rain or shine. The blocklong event offers food, crafts, toys and entertainment. Admission is $1; proceeds benefit programs at the elementary school.

title: END OF DELAY-CAUSING INSPECTIONS ON NEW HAVEN LINE IS DUE JUNE 1
description: The wheel inspections that have delayed thousands of Metro-North commuters daily on the New Haven line over the last six months are expected to end by June 1, the president of the railroad said yesterday.

title: The Bishops and the Bomb
description: The two-year quest of the Catholic bishops for an answer to the nuclear dilemma is as important as the result. In composing their 150-page pastoral letter, they heard scores of experts and weighed hundreds of nuances. The key bishops and their assistants now know as much about the issues as laymen can.

title: A WEST BANK VIEW'S UNHELPFUL EXTREMISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Forsch Sues Agent
description: Bob Forsch, the St. Louis Cardinal pitcher, has filed a damage suit charging that his former agent, LaRue Harcourt, had invested $281,500 in ''speculative and unsafe'' ventures that benefited Harcourt's family, cost Forsch dearly and entangled him with the Internal Revenue Service. Some of the money, Forsch said, had been used to buy a tavern for Harcourt's wife and some had been used to buy a house for Harcourt's lawyer.

title: PANEL ASKS STRESS ON ENGLISH STUDIES
description: A group of educators said yesterday that Federal money now going to bilingual-education programs should be used to promote proficiency in English, not to teach other academic subjects in a foreign language.

title: D'Arcy Aide to Handle Business Development
description: Hal Bay, chairman and chief executive of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, announced yesterday that, just as he promised he would, he is moving the first international executive into New York headquarters to strengthen that office.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,680,000 from vessel sales and an unrealized foreign currency gain of $2,471,000, or 10 cents a share. c-Includes an unrealized foreign currency gain of $4,232,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HAZARDOUS LEAKS NEED A PLUG MADE IN ALBANY
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Miller, 51, an Actor; Died on Location for TV Film
description: Michael Miller, an actor who appeared on Broadway, on television and in the movies, died Wednesday of a heart ailment while on location in Harpers Ferry, W. Va., during the filming of a public television production of ''Pudd'nhead Wilson.''

title: REISCHAUSER IN A BOSTON HOSPITAL
description: Edwin O. Reischauer, former United States Ambassador to Japan and a noted Asia scholar, was taken from Tokyo to a hospital here Wednesday. He was reported in stable condition today with gastritis, an inflammation of the stomach lining.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
9 KILLED AS FIRE SWEEPS APARTMENTS IN CHINATOWN
description: Nine people died in a three-alarm fire in a Chinatown apartment building early this morning, the Fire Department said. The victims, none of whom were immediately identified, died during blaze that lasted more than an hour and destroyed the interior of the five-story brick building at 40 East Broadway, according to a department spokesman.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Walker's Calling
description: Goals are often placed before Herschel Walker, the Heisman Trophy winner from Georgia, and another one looms. The National Football League record for consecutive games in which a runner gained 100 yards or more is seven.

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
description: b-Net loss.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an investment gain of $45,679 and a tax credit of $15,000. c-Includes a gain of $7,231 from investments and a tax credit of $3,000.

title: WIVES OF LAWYERS AID HARLEM YOUTHS
description: They are all the wives of lawyers, well educated and well placed in the black community. They consider themselves fortunate and they also consider that they have a responsibility to those around them who have not had their advantages. Fifteen years ago, they banded together to organize a New York chapter of an organization called National Barristers' Wives Inc.

title: Three women and their road to directing
description: FOUR years ago, the American-born Joyce Bunuel wrote and directed her first movie, ''Dirty Dishes,'' in Paris. Last week, it opened in New York at the Carnegie Hall Cinema. Mrs. Bunuel says it's hard for her to think about it now, because she was a different person when she made the picture. ''But it's honest,'' she says. ''And it mirrored the confusion of a lot of women I knew. We couldn't win. Staying home was a drag. Going to work was hard. Being married was a pain. Not being married was lonely. If you had kids, you had headaches. If you didn't have kids, you felt you weren't a woman.

title: Bright Continental; Italian pub-tavern
description: VIRTUALLY a private luncheon club with members drawn from the neighboring art galleries, auction houses and museums, Les Pleiades, on 76th Street, just west of Madison Avenue, is, in fact, a public restaurant, and a fairly attractive one at that. Bright red walls provide a cheerful backdrop for comfortable banquettes and tables, which are, however, a little too close together in some areas. Nevertheless, the room is inviting, if dated, and conducive to intimate conversation. At night, when the pace slows, it is even quieter and more enjoyable.

title: Life After Sports
description: Gary Fencik, an outstanding strong safety for the Chicago Bears since he was graduated from Yale in 1976, is healthy and still enjoys Sunday afternoons during the season. But since he suffered serious injuries to his left knee and ankle in 1979, he has begun preparing himself for life after the National Football League.

title: News Analysis
description: When the Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted after the Three Mile Island accident to require extensive emergency preparations around every reactor in the country, opponents of nuclear power immediately thought of Indian Point. ''From the standpoint of common sense, emergency planning has always been the Achilles heel at Indian Point,'' said Ellyn R. Weiss, a lawyer who represented the Union of Concerned Scientists before the commission in an action to close the plants. ''But the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had no rules that looked at these questions until after Three Mile Island.''

title: MOUNTAIN FUEL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Plight of the Libraries
description: New York City bibliophiles ought to be ashamed of themselves, according to Andrew J. Stein, the Manhattan Borough President. He was one of a panel at a news conference yesterday at the main library, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, to urge an increase in the city's library budget.

title: IRVINE SENSORS reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Net income

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CLOSE SENATE VOTE SEEN ON AID TO ANTI-SANDINISTS
description: The Senate intelligence committee is closely divided on whether to follow its House counterpart and vote Friday to ban covert support for anti-Government forces in Nicaragua, according to two committee members.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a capital gain of $1,540,000, or 14 cents a share. c-Includes a capital gain of $664,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: EUBIE BLAKE MUSICAL TRIBUTE ON PBS
description: BEING packaged as part of public television's ''Kennedy Center Tonight'' series, ''Eubie Blake: A Century of Music'' will be broadcast on Channel 13 tomorrow night at 9. This 90-minute program was taped in January at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The event was designed as a tribute to the 100th birthday of the composer and ragtime piano player, whose parents had been slaves.

title: Pridi Phanomyong Dies at 82; Led 'Free Thai' Forces in War
description: Pridi Phanomyong, a former Prime Minister of Siam who led the pro-Allied underground movement in World War II in what is now Thailand, died Monday of a heart attack, the Thai Embassy said. He was 82 years old.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PHOTO-CONTROL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TOP-SEEDED LENDL UPSET BY LECONTE
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, who said two days earlier that he doubted that John McEnroe could reach the final of the Mercedes Tournament of Champions, was eliminated yesterday in the third round, 6-2, 6-3, by Henri Leconte of France.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. CUTS BACK HIGHWAYS FOR OVERSIZE TRUCKS
description: The Transportation Department agreed today to reduce the number of highways to be opened to double-trailer trucks in eight states and it made changes in the Federal truck route map in three other states.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CLIMB TO THE SUMMIT
description: The climb to the Williamsburg seven-nation summit meeting at the end of May is going so badly that last-minute emergency efforts are needed to avert disaster.

title: OZARK AIR LINES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MISCHER COR. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BOSSY SHADOWED AND STYMIED
description: Mike Bossy had not been accustomed to such attention. But then, the circumstances surrounding the fifth game of the Stanley Cup semifinal series between the Islanders and Boston Bruins were also unusual.

title: SFM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Z & Z FASHIONS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $55,143. c-Includes a tax credit of $10,000. Shares outstanding figures are based upon stock purchase of 169,312 shares on Feb. 7.

title: Peddlers, Then and Now
description: Some people still have ''fond and colorful memories of the pushcarts,'' said Jacob Tuchman, who sells fish and chips on the sidewalks of New York. ''We are all that remains of that day.''

title: Vote of Confidence
description: Many pro football players had spoken out against the way he handled last year's strike, but when the matter came to a vote before the board of player representatives yesterday, Ed Garvey retained his position as executive director of the National Football League Players Association.

title: Chinese Leader in Bucharest
description: Hu Yaobang, China's Communist Party leader, arrived in Bucharest today on the first stop of a tour that will also include Yugoslavia. Mr. Hu is making his first trip outside China since he became party leader two years ago.

title: INSURANCE ACCORD SET BY BALDWIN
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to closer supervision of its insurance subsidiaries by insurance commissioners of the states where the units have their headquarters.

title: Lear Siegler Buys Unit of Tigerair
description: Lear Siegler Inc. and Tigerair Inc., a subsidiary of Tiger International Inc., said that Lear Siegler had purchased Tigerair's Aviquipo Inc. subsidiary for cash. The price was not disclosed, but Tiger said it would realize a gain on the sale.

title: P.S. 186 to Ph.D. to B.A.
description: Mortimer J. Adler, philosopher, author and tireless educator of the masses, received a Ph.D. in 1928 from Columbia University - without ever earning a B.A.

title: Chernenko Absence in Soviet Is Now Linked to Pneumonia
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the 71-year-old Politburo member who is believed to be Yuri V. Andropov's rival for power, has been ill with pneumonia, his office said today.

title: WEBB, DEL E, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes equity of $501,000 in the earnings of an unconsolidated subsidiary. c-Includes equity of $1,578,000 in the earnings of an unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALEWIVES EXCITING ON LIGHTER TACKLE
description: Eclipsed by his larger cousin the American shad, the alewife gets scant attention from anglers, which is a pity, for it is exciting to catch on ultralight spinning tackle or a small fly rod, frequently leaping from the water in its quest for freedom.

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHNIQUES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,000.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: 'THE SANDGLASS'
description: THERE is an amazing fluidity to Wojciech Has's ''The Sandglass,'' a 1973 adaptation of a story by the Polish writer Bruno Schulz. There's also a good deal of obscurity, since each scene in this dreamlike fantasy film leads into its successor with no apparent logic or urgency. ''The Sandglass,'' which is gracefully directed and only marginally exasperating, opens today at the Thalia.

title: Superior Off 72%
description: The Superior Oil Company reported that net income in the first quarter plunged 72 percent, while revenues dropped 13.8 percent. The Houston-based company said that net income in the latest three months fell to $23.7 million, or 19 cents a share, from $83.4 million, or 66 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Firstquarter revenues dropped to $457.6 million, from $530.7 million in the period a year earlier.

title: Sears Trade Unit And First Chicago
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that the First Chicago Corporation would become a partner in Sears World Trade Inc., an international trading company recently formed by the retailing giant.

title: Yields Raised Slightly On M.T.A. Bond Issue
description: Yields have been increased slightly for a $271 million bond issue of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, according to underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: 31 Are Killed in Crash Of Thai Military Plane
description: A Royal Thai Air Force C-123 transport plane crashed today while landing at a base north of Bangkok, killing all 31 military personnel aboard, an air force spokesman said.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ART: 15 YEARS OF KEITH SONNIER AT P.S.1
description: KEITH SONNIER, an artist who resists typecasting, has gone off in all directions since he first started showing in New York in the mid 1960's. Neons, videotapes, pieces concerned with sound amplification, large-scale drawings and, lately, even sculpture that looks like sculpture occur in his rambling body of work. His sprawling - and very uneven -show at P.S. 1, 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens, organized by Alanna Heiss, executive director of the Institute for Art and Urban Resources, which administers P.S. 1, covers four Sonnier categories: video, sculpture, drawing and film.

title: Thousand Fans Attend Rites for Muddy Waters
description: About 1,000 musicians, friends and fans paid their final respects to Muddy Waters at a service on Chicago's South Side Wednesday.

title: NEW HOTELS EMPHASIZE THE AMENITIES
description: One day last week a smartly dressed crowd turned out for a ribbon-cutting ceremony at which Alejandro Orfila, the Secretary General of the Organization of American States, wielded what was described as ''an historic dress sword from the War of 1812.''

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $525,000 to operations.

title: Ex-Official Gets Suspended Term
description: Arthur B. Powers, a former State Transportation Commissioner, was sentenced today to a one-year suspended jail term, two years' probation and a total fine of $1,500 on charges relating to a corruption investigation in the Transportation Department.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RLI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a realized gain of $4,310 from investments.

title: THEATER: 'CAINE MUTINY' BACK AT CIRCLE IN SQUARE
description: IF you are hungering to see a revival of ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,'' then hop to the one that has arrived, by way of Stamford's Hartman Theater, at the Circle in the Square. Graced with crackling, intelligently conceived performances by John Rubinstein, Michael Moriarty and most of a large supporting cast, Arthur Sherman's staging gets every ounce of juice there is to be had from Herman Wouk's 1954 Broadway hit - and then some.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BIG DISAPPOINTMENT FOR A 'LITTLE GUY'
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. J oe Taibbi went to bed Wednesday night thinking he had a horse in the Kentucky Derby. He didn't need any other dreams. ''The chance of a lifetime,'' he said, recalling the years of running Taibbi's Arco Service Station on Water Street in Wakefield, Mass., and dreaming of owning a horse.

title: PUBLISHING: A GOLD MINE FOR TECHNICAL WRITERS
description: SUCCESSFUL writers have sometimes provided financial help to struggling younger writers and scholars. The Ernest Hemingway estate, for instance, provides an award for the best first work of fiction by an American author, James Michener contributes to young American writers and William H. Crouse is endowing New York with the William H. and Gwynne K. Crouse Library for Publishing Arts, which will be dedicated next Tuesday at the Graduate Center Library of the City University.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
description: b-Including a credit of $123,000 for the termination of a lease.

title: YANKEE 'BIG BATS' PRESSING AND MISSING
description: The Yankees knew before the season began that they would need run production from Dave Winfield, Steve Kemp and Don Baylor if they were to win the American League East championship. One month into the season, the Yankees have learned precisely how dependent they are on those three.

title: Two Tied For Lead With 66's
description: David Graham birdied six of the final nine holes, and Jim Nelford had a consistent round sprinkled with five birdies as both shot five-under-par 66's today to share the firstround lead in the $400,000 Houston Coca Cola Open golf tournament.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ONE-ACT MARTHON ON

title: PRESIDENT, IN TEXAS, STRESSES CENTRAL AMERICA
description: President Reagan, seeking political support among Mexican-Americans, drew vigorous applause today as he defended his military and economic aid program for Central America.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $229,000 on the repurchase of debentures and a nonrecurring gain of $820,000, or 32 cents a share, from the sale of a manufacturing facility. c-Including income of $179,000 from spun-off operations.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SUDDENLY, the party pace has quickened. It's May, the last chance toa ssemble large groups of the ''right'' people before summer. As one h ectic partygoer observed: ''If you want to give a big party, it has t o be in October or May. That's when everyone's in town.''

title: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: 76er Ailments
description: Several Philadelphia 76er players have been on the sick list this week, but all are expected to be ready by Sunday when the team meets the Milwaukee Bucks for the opening game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship series.

title: BRIEFING
description: An Attack on the Debt

title: Convicts Put on Display
description: Thirty-two prisoners spent a day on display in an abandoned automobile showroom as a sheriff protested overcrowded jail conditions and were then transferred to less public quarters in five counties. ''I think we have awakened the public to the overcrowding of our jails, and I think the state and the courts will move now to correct the situation,'' the Morgan County Sheriff, Buford Burgess, said Wednesday after the last of prisoners were moved to other jails.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: It cost the Government $30 million to design, develop and build what was once the world's biggest and most expensive experimental power-generating windmill. But on the auction block today, the best offer for the failed experiment was $51,600.

title: 2 COLTS WITHDRAWEN; FIELD LIMIT OF 20
description: The 109th running of the Kentucky Derby here Saturday drew a maximum field of 20 today, but only after Churchill Downs officials persuaded the owners of two horses to withdraw their runners in order to generate more money for the track.

title: Bethlehem Chief Critical of Rival
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's top executive defended his company's use of foreign technology and investment capital while condemning the United States Steel Corporation's plan to import unfinished steel slabs from the British Steel Corporation.

title: Arum's Federal Plan
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, was trying to promote a Federal boxing commission in Congress yesterday. Criticizing the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association as not meeting the needs of Americans, Arum said the sport is ''essentially an American business run by people out of the country who are accountable to no one.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 'OLD' GAS CONTROLS WORTH KEEPING
description: To the Editor:

title: Herzog Inaugurated As President of Israel
description: Chaim Herzog, a former director of military intelligence and prominent member of the opposition Labor Party, was sworn in today as Israel's sixth President. He succeeds Yitzhak Navon, also from the Labor Party, who ended his five-year term.

title: Bridge: The Cavendish Invitational Is Keeping Up Its Tradition
description: For the past nine years the annual Cavendish Club invitational tournament has attracted experts from many parts of the world, as well as some of the best players in North America. This year's event, starting tomorrow and ending Sunday, is no exception.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHULTZ WAITS FOR LABORS TO PAY OFF
description: Shortly before 11 o'clock tonight, during a break in final discussions with American officials on a Lebanese-Israeli draft agreement on troop withdrawals, a senior Israeli Foreign Ministry official wandered down to the coffee shop in the King David Hotel here.

title: Talks Continue In GAF Contest
description: Lawyers for the GAF Corporation and a dissident shareholder, Samuel J. Heyman, are continuing negotiations daily in an effort to resolve a bitter proxy dispute.

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income includes a tax benefit of $15,000.

title: Divers Find Body Of Missing Boy
description: Six scuba divers combing the bed of Tuthill Creek on Long Island today recovered the body of a 6-year-old boy who tumbled into the water last Monday while playing with a friend.

title: 10 Killed in Java Accident
description: Ten people were killed and 43 others were severely injured today in a traffic accident in Java involving a military truck, two buses and a motorbike. A police spokesman said the driver of a truck with 38 soldiers aboard lost control while driving on a narrow road near Semarang, 225 miles east of Jakarta. The truck hit two buses and a motorbike before overturning.

title: Advertising; 2 Cigarette Accounts Are Shifted
description: IN an exciting chain of events yesterday, the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation announced that it was moving its Barclay cigarette brand from McCann-Erickson to Ogilvy & Mather, and within an hour the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company announced that it was assigning its Camel brand to McCann, both domestically and in 20 foreign countries.

title: CONSUMERS GLASS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,606,000 on the sale of 45 percent equity interest in an Australian affiliate.

title: WHERE TO CELEBRATE BRAHMS DAY
description: The Mayor has proclaimed tomorrow Brahms Day, in honor of the composer, who was born 150 years ago, on May 7, 1833. Some commemorations planned this weekend by music groups around the metropolitan area follow: Today

title: GULF RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $228,000 from discontinued operations.

title: OGILVY & MATHER INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Kingman Affected By Move
description: Darryl Strawberry's call-up late Wednesday was the highlight of a couple of moves that have already affected some other Met players and will likely have an effect on more, including Dave Kingman, the National League's home-run champion last year.

title: UNIONS' PRESIDENTIAL SUPPORT SOUGHT BY THREE DEMOCRATS
description: With varying degrees of enthusiasm and hope, three Democratic Presidential candidates presented their case for trade union support to representatives of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Industrial Union Department today.

title: CONCERT: CATHEDRAL IS SETTING FOR CHOIR
description: ANY performers brave enough to stage a concert within the vast confines of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine must come to some kind of understanding with its resonant accoustics. On Tuesday night, the Monteverdi Choir and the English Baroque Soloists, under the direction of John Eliot Gardiner, roamed through the man-made cavern in search of a balance, seeing music by Gesualdo, Gabrieli, Schutz, Monteverdi, Purcell and Bruckner from different vantage points.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $380,000 from foreign currency translations. c-After a loss of $65,000 from foreign currency translations.

title: POLAND ACTIVISTS ARE SAID TO FACE PRESSURE TO LEAVE
description: The Polish authorities are encouraging thousands of people they regard as potential political troublemakers to leave the country under an unspoken arrangement with more than half a dozen Western countries, Western diplomats here say.

title: FRENCH STOREKEEPERS ADD PROTESTS TO PARIS STUDENT DEMONSTRATIONS
description: The police here skirmished with students and shopkeepers today after separate anti-Government demonstrations brought 10,000 shopkeepers into the streets.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Palme Meets Russian As Sub Hunt Continues
description: The Swedish Prime Minister, Olof Palme, met in Stockholm with the Soviet Ambassador, Boris D. Pankin, today while the navy stepped up its hunt for a suspected midget foreign submarine in a bay off Sweden's east coast.

title: ALBERTA ENERGY CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes $21.1 million special gain on oil sands agreement. The revenue figures represent revenue net of royalties.

title: DIASPORA AND MOROCCO
description: ''ROUTES OF EXILE: A MOROCCAN JEWISH ODYSSEY,'' which yesterday opened an engagement through next Thursday at the 72d Street East Theater, is a fascinating film about the oldest of Jewish experiences, the Diaspora, told in terms of the once-thriving Jewish community of Morocco.

title: WADELL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $122,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $3,000. c-Including income of $348,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $478,000.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 22, 1982.

title: HORSZOWSKI, THE SOUND OF A LEGEND
description: In Vienna at the age of 7, he studied piano with Theodor Leschetizky, the teacher of Paderewski, Gabrilowitsch and Schnabel. When he was 11, he began a lifelong friendship with an admiring Arthur Rubinstein. At his New York debut, when he was 14, he was compared to the child genius Mozart. He played throughout Europe with Maurice Ravel and Josef Szigeti, and at Marlboro, Vt., in company with the pianist Rudolf Serkin. He and the cellist Pablo Casals played at Prades, Spain, and in Puerto Rico and for President John F. Kennedy at the White House. He will be 91 years old next month, and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 6 P.M. he will play the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 27 in B flat major (K. 595) with the Musica Aeterna Orchestra at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: BROKERAGE IS CENSURED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Prudential-Bache Securities for failing to supervise properly a stockbroker who was reportedly involved in a scheme to manipulate the stock of the Intercontinental Diamond Corporation.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY PASSES TEACHERS' BARGAINING BILL
description: The New Jersey Assembly today passed a bill that would broaden the bargaining rights of teachers and other public employees.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DANCE: BALLET THEATER OFFERS ROBBINS'S 'N.Y. EXPORT: JAZZ'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER presented a dream of a program on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The provocative assortment ranged from August Bournonville to Merce Cunningham. And, as one audience member murmured, the dancers looked so pretty and danced so well.

title: Taiwan Lifts Auto Ban
description: Taiwan has lifted its ban on imports of European cars powered by engines bigger than 3,000 cubic centimeters, the Board of Foreign Trade said today. The ban was imposed in August 1980 to conserve fuel, and did not apply to American cars. Today's decision is aimed at increasing trade with Europe, which fell to a total of $4.71 billion last year from $4.84 billion in 1981, the board said. Car imports from Europe totaled 7,400 units in 1982.

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS' APPEAL FADES
description: The Great Plains Coal Gasification Project, a huge synthetic fuels plant rising from a mile-square patch of coal-laden prairie here, has been held up by many as an example of the kind of technology needed to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil.

title: CONVERSIONS: THE RESERVE FUND ISSUE
description: Two weeks ago Justice Eugene R. Wolin in Manhattan State Supreme Court upheld the authority of the New York City Council to enact a law requiring sponsors of cooperative and condominium conversions to establish a reserve fund for new tenant-owners.

title: Stroh, Pabst To Swap Plants
description: The Pabst Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company announced an agreement to exchange plants in St. Paul and Tampa, Fla., in an even trade with no financial outlays involved.

title: SHIFT OF STRATEGY ON MISSILE ATTACK HINTED BY WEINBERGER AND VESSEY
description: The Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledging that MX missiles in existing silos would be vulnerable, raised the possibility today of edging United States policy toward a strategy known as launching under attack.

title: MUSIC: NEWTON LEADS JAZZ SEXTET
description: WITH a front line of flute, violin and vibraphone, the James Newton Sextet -appearing through tomorrow at Sweet Basil - seems primed for sweetly tinkling chamber jazz. But Mr. Newton's pieces in a late set earlier this week were of much stronger stuff.

title: SOUTHLAND AND OFFICER INDICTED
description: The Southland Corporation, which runs the nationwide 7-Eleven convenience store chain, and one of its vice presidents were charged by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday with conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the chain.

title: Artists to Hold Sale
description: Works by Ademola Olugebefola, Bob Blackburn, James Van Der Zee, Dinga McCannon, Tom Feelings, Otto Neals, Abdul Rahman, Pat Davis and other artists will be on sale this weekend at the second ''$100 & Under'' spring sale of the New York State chapter of the National Conference of Artists. The sale is a benefit for the conference and the Benin Gallery, 240 West 140th Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards, where it will be held. Hours are from 6 to 10 P.M. today and 2 to 7 P.M. tomorrow.

title: A.M.C. AND CHINA SIGN JEEP PLANT PACT
description: The American Motors Corporation formally signed a contract today for a joint venture with the Chinese to manufacture a Jeep for use in China and for export in the Far East in competition with four-wheel drive Japanese vehicles that now dominate the Asian market.

title: Ryan's Secret: An Active Arm
description: Most of Nolan Ryan's injury problems during his major league career have not involved his pitching arm, which is an oddity for a pitcher, especially one who throws a baseball at 100 miles per hour. Ryan, who broke Walter Johnson's career strikeout record last week, said that he has never pampered his arm, not even during the offseason when he works on his cattle ranch in Alvin, Tex.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Fair, and Foul, on the Street
description: Mayor Koch signed a peddling law yesterday that should, in time, make life on the sidewalks of New York a little more agreeable. That's no small achievement, and it's one worthy of the first award in a series we intend to make in this brand-new corner of comment.

title: Long-Term Interest Rates Up; 30-Year Bond Brings 10.29%
description: Long-term interest rates, which had declined steadily during the past week, rose slightly yesterday as investors and securities dealers faced nearly $1.5 billion of new corporate issues, as well as a $3.75 billion auction of new Treasury bonds.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,406,286 for the quarter and $1,437,020 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $259,039 for the quarter and $619,862 for the 9 months.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Home Products Corp. named Robert G. Blount senior vice president-finance.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 6, 1983
description: International

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't think accidents are likely but where they are, the results could be severe.'' - John F. Ahearne of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. (A1:6.)

title: ACCORD REACHED ON 2 UNION FUNDS
description: The Labor Department today settled a longstanding case against the frequently troubled Teamsters' Central States pension and welfare funds, with the current trustees to replace $6.5 million that the department had contended was improperly used.

title: VOTING DOWN IDEAS
description: Where, if not on the college campus, should ideas be openly and freely heard and debated? Who, more than students and faculty, should uphold that ideal of the campus as an open forum for all views?

title: PHILHARMONIC: MEMBERS-ONLY NIGHT
description: ONCE a season the New York Philharmonic, like most other symphony orchestras, puts on a members-only night. Principals and other leading players from the Philharmonic ranks are brought forward to display their talents and augment their incomes by appearing in concertos and other pieces calling for virtuosic soloists. It was time again last night for this annual event, under the guidance of Zubin Mehta. Perhaps out of special respect for their fellow musicians, Mr. Mehta and the orchestra were on the alert all evening, with generally precise and sonorous results.

title: THIRSTY SOVIET'S GRAND DESIGN: TAP ARCTIC WATERS
description: Muddy and swollen with melting snow, the Vologda River takes a sharp bend under the high cupolas and ancient walls of the city whose name it shares, then straightens out for the 24-mile run to the Sukhona River.

title: STRAPHANGERS RATE QUALITY OF THEIR RIDES
description: For all those subway riders who compare horror stories, a new survey might settle some arguments about who had the worse trip. The BMT's J and M trains are the ''worst'' subway lines, the study found, and the IND's B, D and F lines are the ''best.''

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Marfa, Gato del Sol: Similarities Abound
description: When Marfa drew post 18 for the Derby yesterday morning, it was the capstone to a series of uncannny similarities between him and Gato del Sol, who won last year's Derby after breaking from post 18.

title: ISRAELIS QUESTION U.S. ON DRAFT
description: Israeli leaders pressed United States officials for clarifications today on certain points in the Lebanese-Israeli draft accord worked out by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on his nine-day diplomatic mission.

title: LIFE AS A NON SEQUITUR WITH CHICAGO CITY LIMITS
description: It is the Phil Donahue Show, and ''Mr. Donahue,'' teased white hair folded over his forehead, is wandering through the audience with a microphone talking about his topic for the day, which happens to be, he says, the imminent destabilization of Rome by POPE, an acronym for People Organized for Papal Extermination.

title: Japan Denies Iran Price Cut
description: Japanese oil industry executives opened talks in Teheran today on new contracts for Iranian oil, sources here said.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HOUSE UNIT WOULD CURB I.M.F. LOANS TO PRETORIA
description: A House banking subcommittee acted today to bar the United States from supporting loans made by the International Monetary Fund to South Africa because of that country's racial policies.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BIGGEST GAME IN TOWN. By A. Alvarez. 185 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95. MAYBE it isn't fair to tax A. Alvarez for having written a merely interesting book on the world of professional poker. After all, in ''The Biggest Game in Town,'' which first appeared in slightly different form in The New Yorker, Mr. Alvarez tells us most of what we want to know about Las Vegas's increasingly famous World Series of Poker - its background, history, setting and leading characters, along with a typical denouement, in this case the final rounds of the 1981 event.

title: Grains and Soybeans Show Little Change
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures continued to meander within a narrow range yesterday in the absence of any significant market news. In fact, prices of these key farm crops have been relatively steady since farmers overwhelmingly agreed a month ago to participate in various Federal programs aimed at idling vast amounts of acreage.

title: O.& M. and D.D.B.  Increase Net Income
description: Ogilvy & Mather International put out its first-quarter statement yesterday and it was up, just as Doyle Dane Bernbach's was the day before.

title: BLAME THE C.I.A, BUT ALSO BLAME THE SANDINISTS
description: The activities of the Central Intelligence Agency in Nicaragua are clearly wrong and misconceived. The concern of the American people and Congress about the scope of these activities is justified. However, I believe that it is a mistake to argue that if the covert activities against Nicaragua were to cease, there would be peace and political stability in my country. This argument is as simplistic as the Reagan Administration's argument about El Salvador: It ignores the social and political realities of Nicaragua.

title: A Break for the Disabled
description: Some of the 105 job applicants appeared in wheelchairs; some had crutches or braces. Guides steered the blind amid the rows of interviewers' desks, labeled with the names of 32 prospective employers, and sign-language interpreters were on hand.

title: Rising Prices For Gasoline
description: The largest United States gasoline marketers have raised wholesale prices by up to 3.3 cents a gallon this week in a trend that is expected to continue until the oil industry recoups its losses from recent price wars.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ BY LONDONERS
description: BERLIOZ wrote that his ''Symphonie Fantastique'' was the tale of a ''young musician of morbidly sensitive temperament and fiery imagination.'' But as the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Claudio Abbado, played it in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, it seemed more like the tale of a musician with very few passions and lots of technique pretending to be morbidly sensitive.

title: ART ROCK: 6 GROUPS PLAY
description: WHITE COLUMNS, a gallery and performance space at 325 Spring Street, has been host to several festivals of downtown art rock in the last few years, and on Wednesday night another such series got under way. This one is called ''Speed Trials,'' and it offers several groups a night (on Wednesday, six groups in four hours, which is speedy indeed on the rock circuit) through Sunday, with a final ''celebration'' Tuesday at Studio 54.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRUINS TROUNCE ISLANDERS AND CUT SERIES LEAD TO 3-2
description: The Islanders, their air-travel itinerary to Edmonton already charted, found themselves grounded tonight by a Boston storm of forechecking and backchecking.

title: Reactors for China
description: France and China were to sign a memorandum of understanding tonight expected to lead to the sale of four 900-megawatt nuclear reactors to the Chinese, President Francois Mitterrand of France told a news conference today.

title: RATES DECLINE ON MORTGAGES
description: The average interest rate charged for new home mortgages fell in April to 13.13 percent, the lowest level since August 1980, the Government reported today.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: RUCKELSHAUS PLANNING FEW MAJOR POLICY CHANGES
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, President Reagan's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency, indicated today that he planned substantial changes in management style but few major departures from the Reagan Administration's basic environmental policies.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss There were no share earnings for the latest quarter because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: ART: A 2-CENTURY SHOW FROM ROYAL ACADEMY
description: THIRTY and some years ago, under the presidency of Sir Alfred Munnings, the Royal Academy of Arts in London had sunk to a very low ebb. Notorious, above all, for having said in a broadcast speech at the academy's annual dinner that he would like nothing better than to give Picasso a running kick from behind, Munnings was a coarse brute who managed in no time at all to alienate every shade of educated opinion.

title: Italy Sets June 26 and 27 For General Election
description: Italians will vote June 26-27 in a general election, one year ahead of schedule. The Government of the departing Prime Minister, Amintore Fanfani, set the voting dates today.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A Ranger-to-Be?
description: The Rangers are on the verge of signing one of the best collegiate goaltenders in the country, sources familiar with the situation confirmed yesterday. He is Ron Scott, a two-time all-American from Michigan State and an undrafted free agent.

title: BOBBY SCOTT'S LIVING TRIBUTE TO NAT (KING) COLE
description: THE music of Nat (King) Cole - the warm, rounded, intimate sound of his voice, the brilliant piano playing that foretold an important jazz career before the singing took precedence - is still as alive and vital today in many minds and memories as it was before Cole died in 1965 at the age of 48.

title: BRAVES' ROOKIE DOWNS ASTROS
description: Craig McMurtry yielded only four hits in six innings, and Dale Murphy hit his eighth home run as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Houston Astros, 6-3, tonight.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation reported that earnings in the first quarter of 1983 more than doubled. The St. Louis-based company, which produces military aircraft, submarines, missiles, gun systems and tanks, said that net income in the latest three months advanced to $56.8 million, or $1.03 a share, from $28.3 million, or 51 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. First-quarter sales jumped 50 percent, to $1.8 billion, from $1.2 billion.

title: Nuclear Weapon Is Tested
description: A nuclear weapon 1,280 feet below the surface with a force below the equivalent of 20,000 tons of TNT was detonated here today at the bottom of a vertical shaft in the Nevada Test Site.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a special gain of $373,000. c-After a special charge of $4,816,000.

title: Hussein-Arafat Talks Reported at 'Final End'
description: Negotiations between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat on a common strategy to take part in President Reagan's Middle East plan have come to ''a final end,'' a Jordanian official said today.

title: 7 DIE IN NEW LEBANON BATTLES
description: Artillery and rocket duels raged around Beirut's Christian and Moslem suburbs today in the worst wave of violence since the Israeli invasion last summer.

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including investment gains of $10,120,000. c-After investment losses of $3,426,000.

title: NUCLEAR COMMISSION WARNS INDIAN POINT MAY BE CLOSED UNLESS RESCUE PLAN IMPROVES
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission threatened today to shut down the two nuclear power plants at Indian Point, 35 miles north of New York City, unless steps were taken to eliminate ''significant deficiencies'' in emergency plans.

title: TITLE IS RETAINED
description: Hard-hitting Santos Laciar of Argentina knocked out Shuichi Hozumi of Japan today and retained the World Boxing Association's flyweight title. The knockout came at 2 minutes 52 seconds of the second round, after Laciar had landed a series of blows to Hozumi's body and face.

title: POWER-SHARING BILL INTRODUCED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's proposed new constitution was formally introduced today in Parliament in Cape Town. The main feature of the highly complex charter is that a colored, or mixed-race, House of Representatives, with 85 members, and an Asian House of Deputies, with 45 members, will be set up alongside the present white House of Assembly, which has 178 members.

title: SELAS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Miss Hearst's Kidnapper Is Freed on Parole
description: William Harris, who pleaded guilty in 1978 to the kidnapping in 1974 of Patricia Hearst, has been paroled from prison and is working as a legal aide, his lawyer says.

title: FUTILE WAIT IN CALIFORNIA FOR END OF MARS SILENCE
description: The antenna out in the Mojave Desert of California, at Goldstone, listened in on Mars yesterday, with its attendants hoping against hope to hear something from Chryse Planitia. There, on the cold, rusty-red plain, the Plain of Gold, sat the Viking 1 lander where it had put down in July 1976 and had regularly transmitted photographs and weather reports until last November, when inexplicably it went silent.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $869,000 from discontinued operations. Results for the latest first quarter include a gain of $1,078,000 from a refund of prior years' utility charges.

title: 'ALL BY MYSELF,' ABOUT EARTHA KITT
description: EARTHA KITT'S sheer force of personality is enough to make ''All By Myself'' an attention-getting documentary, even if it reflects Miss Kitt's abrasiveness as memorably as her prodigious energy. Christian Blackwood, who produced and directed this profile, clearly intends it admiringly. But he has captured Miss Kitt's stagy, disingenuous side just as surely as he's conveyed her strength. The woman seen here is most memorable for her willfully eccentric singing style, her inch-long eyelashes and her very short fuse.

title: Kathy Horvath Posts an Upset
description: Kathy Horvath, a 17-year-old American who is recovering from a back injury, upset top-seeded Virginia Ruzici, 7-5, 6-1, today in the third round of the Italian Open tennis tournament.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $6,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $19,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: LED COAST MUSEUM
description: James Henry Breasted Jr., an art historian and former director of the Los Angeles County Museum, died Wednesday after an illness of several months at the Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia, N.H. He was 74 years old and lived in Tamworth, N.H.

title: RHINEBECK, A VILLAGE THAT TIME PASSED BY
description: THE coat of arms of Rhinebeck displays the British and Dutch flags, representing its discoverers; the shield of the Rhineland-Palatinate, for the religious refugees who found Rhinebeck a haven; a gristmill, for one of the village's earliest industries, and violets, reflecting the not-too-distant time when Rhinebeck was ''the violet capital of the world.''

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
VIETNAM'S WITHDRAWAL IS THE KEY TO THE CAMBODIAN SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE JET IS HIJACKED TO SOUTH KOREA
description: Two crew members of a Chinese domestic airliner were shot in midair Thursday and their plane, with 105 people aboard, was hijacked to South Korea, Government officials said.

title: THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.
