title: CHRYSLER TO REPAY LOAN EARLY
description: The Chrysler Corporation will repay $400 million of its $1.2 billion in Government-guaranteed loans by the end of next month, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said today.

title: METS'S GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: For much of the last three years, Darryl Strawberry has been able to think of little but his his major league debut, which takes place at Shea Stadium tonight when the Mets play the Cincinnati Reds.

title: LONG-DISTANCE CALLS WILL PAY THEIR SHARE
description: To the Editor:

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. c-Cushman Electronics broke even in the year-ago 6 months period.

title: Curtiss-Wright Settles With G.E.
description: Curtiss-Wright has received $15.28 million from the General Electric Company in settlement of all outstanding disputes between them, the two companies said in a statement.

title: Concert to Mark Birth Of Mary Lou Williams
description: Two programs Sunday will commemorate the birthday of the jazz pianist Mary Lou Williams, who died in 1980. The Mary Lou Williams Foundation will sponsor a concert at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, at 2:30 P.M., with the pianist Amina Claudine Myers in solos; the be-bop pianist Chris Anderson with a trio, and an all-star sextet - George Coleman on tenor saxophone, Woody Shaw on trumpet, Hilton Ruiz on piano, Major Holley on bass, Walter Perkins on drums and the singer Carmen Lundy.

title: SCHERER, R P, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $675,000 incurred in connection with an unsolicited tender offer. The year-ago results are restated for the adoption of a change in accounting for foreign currency translations.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The Head of Contel Relinquishes a Post
description: Charles Wohlstetter, a founder and head of Continental Telecom Inc., the nation's third-largest independent phone company, relinquished the post of chief executive yesterday.

title: Jazz and World Music
description: Two groups that mix jazz and world music, the Art Ensemble of Chicago and Codona, will share a double bill tonight and tomorrow at Swing Plaza, 17 Irving Place at 15th Street (477-3728). Shows begin at 9:30 and 12:30; tickets are $10.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a foreign currency translation loss of $73,000. c-Net income.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS A U.N. MEETING
description: Nicaragua asked today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to consider measures to stem what it termed a United States-backed invasion of Nicaraguan territory from Honduras.

title: LAWYER FOR BRINK'S DEFENDANT EMPHASIZES ISSUES OF POLITICS
description: A defense lawyer stressed political points yesterday in crossexamining a key informant in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan. The lawyer, Chokwe Lumumba, questioned the informant, Tyrone Rison, about ''the black liberation movement.'' Mr. Rison acknowledged that the movement sometimes referred to the black community as ''the family,'' a term he had used earlier to describe a group of radical robbers.

title: SOCIALISTS' STAND ON PUERTO RICO ANGERS U.S.
description: The Socialist International, the consultative body of the world's Socialist Parties, has angered the United States with the passage of a resolution stating its support for the independence of Puerto Rico.

title: KENTUCKY DERBY FIELD
description: No. Post Horse Jockey Trainer Prob. Pos. Odds 4 1 Slew o'Gold Angel Cordero Sidney Watters Jr. 6-1 5 2 Play Fellow Jean Cruguet Harvey L. Vanier 4-1 1 3 a-Balboa Sandy Hawley D. title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENTS ON THE N.R.C. DECISION ON THE INDIAN POINT PLANTS
description: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission; its chairman, Nunzio J. Palladino; a commissioner, John F. Ahearne; Consolidated Edison; the New York Power Authority; the chairman of the Rockland County Legislature, Herbert Reisman, and the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke: By the Commission

title: CARTIER: ART DECO FOR THE 80'S
description: It's called Black, White and Deco. And the name pretty much tells what it's all about. Cartier has produced a collection of jewelry, crystal and table-top objects that are basically black and white and in the mood of the Art Deco period.

title: NEWLY FOUND SHELL IN JERSEY TIED TO CBS MURDERS
description: While the murder trial of the man accused of killing four people in a Hudson River parking lot was going on in Manhattan last week, more potential evidence against the defendant was uncovered in New Jersey, two detectives testified yesterday.

title: A RARE APPEARANCE FOR STAN FREBERG
description: IRREVERENT parody has always been a flourishing subcategory in pop music but never more so than in the 1950's, when the charts were dominated by inane novelties and sappy love songs. The overriding silliness of pop in those days inspired a golden age of pop satire when humorists like Stan Freberg, Spike Jones and the country and western duo Homer and Jethro wickedly spoofed the hits and crazes of the moment.

title: JAZZ: PASS PLAYING AT FAT TUESDAY'S
description: WHEN Joe Pass plays solo guitar, as he is doing through tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, he thinks like a full band. He weights every note precisely, letting his thumb carry bass lines while his fingers deal out chords or wide-ranging melodic lines or three-way repartee.

title: Dealers honor art historian
description: LAST night at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the Art Dealer's Association of America presented its annual outstanding-lifetimeachievement award to John Rewald, the 71-year-old German-born art historian.

title: NEW ARTS FLOURISH IN NEW SPACES
description: THERE was once a time when you went to galleries for paintings, to theaters for plays and to concert halls for music. But now it's possible to find all of those under one roof in the multimedia arts centers that have sprung up around New York over the last decade or so in abandoned schools and industrial sites.

title: SECOND THOUGHTS IN THE LAND OF FREE SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP COURT LIMITS SUBPOENAS OF DOCTORS' DATA
description: The New York Court of Appeals today placed new restrictions on the state's authority to issue subpoenas to investigate misconduct by physicians.

title: AYKROYD IN 'DOCTOR DETROIT'
description: ''DOCTOR DETROIT,'' which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is an entertainingly slapdash variation on the comedy about the mild-mannered professor who, through a series of improbable coincidences, finds himself up to his ears in the high life outside academe and enjoys every minute of it.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,000 from the sale of assets.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $134,000 for the quarter and $2,072,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $3.4 million.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Fair, and Foul, on the Street; The Species Slob
description: ''Shame,'' Dr. Willard Gaylin has written, ''is the sister of guilt. ... They serve the same purposes: to facilitate the socially acceptable behavior required for group living.'' And both are missing from the makeup of those who insist on using the sidewalks of New York as a lavatory.

title: P.& G. Wins Top Job Case
description: It certainly will not be remembered like Brown v. Board of Education, but it was a decision by the highest court in the land, as far as advertising is concerned.

title: LASER PRECISION reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income The year-ago share earnings figure adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in February 1983.

title: East River Boat Race
description: A crew race between American alumni of Oxford and Cambridge Universities will be held, rain or shine, Sunday in the East River. The race, called the Watneys Challenge and based on the annual event in England, will begin at 12:15 P.M. at 89th Street; good viewing can be found in Carl Schurz Park. The race is expected to end about an hour later at 23d Street.

title: BILTRITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Postwar art in 3 sales
description: WILLEM DE KOONING'S ''Two Women,'' a voluptuous oil and charcoal on canvas painted in the mid-1950's, is expected to be the star of the bidding in three sales of post-World War II art to be held next week at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. The Abstract Expressionist work, which will be offered Tuesday at 7 P.M., is in warm flesh tones, green, blue, pink, orange and yellow. It is the only large picture from the artist's much-admired 1950's ''women'' series (he did about 10 oil paintings on the theme) that has remained in private hands. Martha Baer, Christie's contemporary-art specialist, expects that the painting may sell for as much as $800,000, which would be a record for a de Kooning and for an Abstract Expressionist work.

title: AT INDIAN PT., A HISTORY OF NUCLEAR POWER, PROBLEMS AND CONTROVERSY
description: More than 30 years ago, in 1952, the Consolidated Edison Company began to study the possibility of using atomic energy to generate electricity. It became the first company to announce plans to build a commercial-sized atomic power plant without government subsidy. Oct. 8, 1954. Con Edison announces the purchase of a 250-acre site in Buchanan, N.Y., on the east bank of the Hudson River 35 miles north of midtown Manhattan, to construct its atomic power plant. It says the plant, to be built in an area known as Indian Point, will cost $50 million to build. May 4, 1956. The Atomic Energy Commission, the predecessor of today's Nuclear Regulatory Commission, grants Con Edison a construction permit. Major work on the plant, whose cost has risen to $121 million, starts in 1958. The plant - with a capacity of 275 megawatts, 59 percent from the heat of the reactor and 41 percent from a supplementary oil-fired superheater - is expected to provide enough power to fill the needs of a million homes.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $209,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $870,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,075,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: A NEW COMET TO APPROACH CLOSE TO EARTH
description: A newly discovered comet is speeding toward a ''close'' encounter with the Earth next Wednesday. The small, fast-moving object, now a faint light in the distant sky, is expected to approach within 2.9 million miles of the Earth, the closest a comet is known to have come in two centuries and much closer than the celebrated Halley's comet has ever come.

title: Market Place; A Way to Play Biotechnology
description: THE way to play the biotechnology game on Wall Street, according to John R. Groome, a senior vice president of the United States Trust Company, is to buy a package of stocks and hope for some ultimate payoff in the market.

title: ELECROHOME LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago revenues have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS IRAN ON PARTY CRACKDOWN
description: The Soviet Union today assailed Iran's crackdown on the Communist Party and said the Islamic authorities were adopting the repressive measures of the former Shah and contributing to an American-inspired anti-Soviet campaign.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,040,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a tax credit of $431,000. c-Net income. Results for the year-ago quarter include the operations of Diamond Tool & Horseshoe Co. since its acquisition on March 18, 1982.

title: JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Cardinals 4, Padres 3
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Ken Oberkfell got four hits and drove in two runs, including the game-winner, with a two-out single in the ninth inning.

title: APARTMENTS IN LIMBO
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY'S CHIEF DISCUSSES MORALITY AND WEAPONS
description: After Adm. James D. Watkins, the Chief of Naval Operations, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters at Marymount College in Arlington, Va., last summer, he turned to the audience to accept and said, ''I am a moral man.''

title: MARINE TRANSPORT LINES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax gain of $139,000 from the disposal of two vessels. The year-ago results were restated to reflect the recognition of $2,160,000 of revenue and $1,166,000 of net income related to the sale of tax benefits during the quarter.

title: NATIONAL SECURITIES & RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BROTHER INDUSTRIES' NEW LOOK
description: Brother Industries, Japan's leading producer of sewing machines and typewriters, is entering the office automation field, not so much by choice but by necessity.

title: POP JAZZ
description: IN 1958, a fledgling vocal group called the Impressions sang a soulful entreaty, ''For Your Precious Love,'' with Jerry Butler's satiny baritone taking the lead. By the mid-60's, Mr. Butler was a solo star, and with Curtis Mayfield's impassioned high tenor out front, the Impressions charted the progress, the aspirations and the determination of black Americans in songs like ''Keep on Pushing,'' ''Amen,'' ''People Get Ready'' and ''We're a Winner.''

title: A BLACK CHURCHMAN SAYS HE WAS BEATEN BY 2 POLICE OFFICERS
description: Flanked by church and community leaders, a Baptist minister yesterday accused two New York City police officers of beating him and jailing him and a companion after stopping them on a Harlem street for questioning about a traffic violation.

title: Homequity and Fantus Get New Presidents
description: Homequity Inc., a pioneer in the business of relocating corporate employees, has named John J. Gottsman as president. Mr. Gottsman, 40, succeeds Robert D. Kunisch, 41, who moves to Homequity's parent, the PHH Group, as one of three executive vice presidents. Mr. Kunisch will be in charge of personnel-related services at PHH and Mr. Gottsman will report to him.

title: Family Contact Studied In Transmitting AIDS
description: A study of eight families in Newark, N.J., shows that some children may have contracted a deadly disease of the immune system from ''routine close contact'' with their families, a researcher says.

title: PHILLIPS CABLES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New Harold Prince musical, as usual, will be unusual
description: HAROLD PRINCE, who has brought to Broadway the stories of a fascist dictator and his wife (''Evita'') and a bloodthirsty barber (''Sweeney Todd''), is enhancing his reputation for the unconventional. His next musical will tell the story of a love affair between a black stripper and an Irishman in Chicago in 1933. This new project, which is set in and around a burlesque house, began about three months ago, when the playwright Fay Kanin brought the idea to Mr. Prince in his bustling midtown office.

title: The Real Politics of Guns
description: President Reagan this evening addresses a meeting of the National Rifle Association in Phoenix. Since he was a victim of handgun violence, his views on the subject of gun control will carry special meaning. Indeed, the speech presents an opportunity to rise above ideology and move the handgun control debate a few steps forward.

title: Sale by Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its Martinsburg, W.Va., cement plant and terminals in Baltimore and Washington to the Riverton Corporation for more than $20 million. Privately owned Riverton sells masonry cements, portland cement, lime and stone throughout the East. Martin Marietta has been divesting itself of some of its operations to ease the burden of the debt it acquired last summer in its unsuccessful takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation.

title: Ganigan Bout On
description: Less than two days after his manager, Douglas Tatting, was stabbed to death at a ringside incident in Honolulu Tuesday night, Andy Ganigan said he would go ahead with his scheduled bout against Jimmy Paul for the United States Boxing Association's lightweight championship in Reno June 26. Tatting, who let his fighters keep 80 percent of their purses rather than the 60 percent most managers give, had dreamed of seeing Ganigan win the championship, the fighter recalled.

title: Verdi Opera at Hunter
description: The Bronx Opera Company will perform Verdi's early opera ''Un Giorno di Regno'' tonight and tomorrow night at the Hunter College Playhouse, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: RAYMOND IN TALKS ON A BUYOUT PLAN
description: Raymond International Inc., a big international construction and engineering company based in Houston, said yesterday that it was considering a leveraged buyout by its management and employees.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
4 Drug Suspects Seized in Shootout
description: Two kilograms of cocaine were seized, four suspects were arrested and two more were being sought today after a shootout Wednesday outside a West Orange skating rink in which three detectives were slightly wounded, authorities said.

title: Field of 20 Lacks A Strong Favorite
description: Little has happened here this week to change the prospect that at least half of the 20 horses who will be loaded into the Churchill Downs starting gates Saturday have a legitimate chance to win the 109th Kentucky Derby.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Sports Pages yesterday listing the field for the Kentucky Derby incorrectly listed the network that will broadcast the race on radio today. It is ABC.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHNIQUES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $76,000. c-Net loss. Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: The Brooklyn Bridge
description: THE GREAT EAST RIVER BRIDGE 1883-1983. Preface by Williard C. Butcher. Foreword by Michael Botwinick and Linda S. Ferber. Essays by Deborah Nevins, Barbara Head Millstein, David McCullough, Albert Fein, Lewis Kachur, Steven S. Ross. 180 Pages. Published by the Brooklyn Museum and Harry N. Abrams. $35. ''O harp and altar, of the fury fused.'' ''Terrific threshold of the prophet's pledge.'' ''Unfractioned idiom, immaculate sigh of stars.'' This is how Hart Crane saw the Brooklyn Bridge in 1930, 47 years after it was finished. It also inspired paintings by George Stella, John Marin, Albert Gleizes, Max Weber, George Grosz, Georgia O'Keeffe, Ellsworth Kelly and Robert Indiana. For Joseph Stella, the bridge was ''a weird metallic apparition'' ''traced for the conjunction of WORLDS.''

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After income of $289,000 from discontinued ons.

title: Princess Rooney Winner in Oaks
description: Princess Rooney won her 10th race without a defeat with an unimpressive 1 1/4-length victory today in the $179,950 Kentucky Oaks for 3-year-old fillies at Churchill Downs.

title: A WATER STEWARD IN DINERS' FUTURE?
description: Considering the status bottled waters now enjoy, we can probably expect that soon a new brand of connoisseurship will develop and vintage waters may not be far away.

title: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Net income.

title: DEFENDING MARFA
description: They came with vigilante zeal, like the mob in the western movies, demanding that the sheriff do something about the town bully. Every morning the crowd grew bigger outside the stall of Marfa, the boisterous gray favorite in today's Kentucky Derby.

title: MORROW EXPECTED TO BE PLAYING TONIGHT
description: The Islanders dressed quickly, happy to leave Boston Garden Thursday night. Clean shaven and hair blown dry, they grabbed their bags and sauntered toward the old building's East Lobby. But they did not go unnoticed.

title: TV: THE PRESIDENT'S IMPRESSIVE USE OF THE CAMERA
description: There is nothing a media consultant can do for President Reagan. Media consultants are the stage managers, voice coaches and lighting directors of American politics, taking in a pleat here, a tuck there, making their candidates presentable for television. Mr. Reagan, however, does it all himself. He is awesome in his use of the tube.

title: CITY PURSUES A NEW BREED OF SCOFFLAW
description: Charged with saving New Yorkers from too much noise, too much smoke and too much garbage, litter and filth, the city's Environmental Control Board is seeking expanded power to deal with its No. 1 problem: too many scofflaws.

title: Canal Board Backs Stockyards Spinoff
description: The board of the Canal-Randolph Corporation authorized the formulation of a plan to spin off the United Stockyards Corporation, Canal-Randolph's largest subsidiary, to the Canal-Randolph shareholders.

title: SOVIET VISITORS IN VERMONT ENCOUUNTER THE ECHO OF A DISSENTER
description: Two Soviet citizens visiting New England schools on an exchange program had an unexpected encounter Thursday with a blond boy, younger than his classmates, who showed surprising skill at the Russian language.

title: Boy Strangles in Towel Roll
description: Two roller-towel dispensers have been removed from a school here after a first grader became entangled in one and died. Classmates found Jeff Hansen, 7, in a Lakeview Elementary School restroom, hanging by his neck in the machine's towel. Officials believe that he may have been swinging on the towel and that his death was accidental.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $180,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Carew at .500
description: Rod Carew had three hits tonight to raise his league-leading batting average to .500 and help the California Angels to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: LYON METAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including securities gains of $1,513,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,613,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: STAGE: 'MARATHON '83' BEGINS
description: The mental and emotional collapse of a high-flying ace of advertising is the satiric subject of Percy Granger's ''Dolphin Position,'' the high point of the opening round of the Ensemble Studio Theater's ''Marathon 1983.'' The six-week festival of one-act plays is an annual event for this enterprising community of writers, actors and directors.

title: A BUDGET VICTIM: G.O.P. SENATE COALITION UNRAVELS
description: ''The budget document is just a political document,'' said Senator Paul Laxalt. ''As soon as we adopt one, it's quickly forgotten.''

title: The Small Print
description: As part of the trade in which they got John Elway, the Denver Broncos have agreed to play the Baltimore Colts in one exhibition game in 1984 and another in 1985. The Colts have had trouble scheduling exhibition opponents in recent years because of the poor crowds that the team draws.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the fiscal year- end from Aug. 31 to June 30.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Mississippi U. Declines To Ban 'Dixie' Song
description: The University of Mississippi, which banned the official use of the Confederate flag after black students called it a sign of racism, refused today to agree to other demands by the black students. These included a ban on the song ''Dixie'' and the school's use of a Colonel Rebel mascot.

title: Olin Dutra, Golf Star in 30's; Won the United States Open
description: Olin Dutra, one of the top touring golfers of the 1930's and the winner of the United States Open in 1934, died Thursday at his home here after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: INSTACOM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BUSH DOESN'T COUNT ON GAIN IN BLACK G.O.P. VOTE IN 1984
description: Vice President George Bush, in town to address a national convention of black Masonic leaders, said today that although the Reagan Administration was courting the black vote, he was not sure it would do any good.

title: DEVON APPAREL DIVISION reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
An Eye (Reagan's) on Age
description: Much Washington punditry these days involves whether President Reagan, who is 72 years old, will consider himself young enough, or too old, to run for a second term. And the President seems to be airing his thoughts on his age with increasing frequency.

title: POLAROID SLIDE SETUP AIMED AT BUSINESSES
description: The Polaroid Corporation has come to market with a system that it hopes will do for slides what the Land camera did for photographs. Last week the Autoprocess system, which develops and processes slides in three minutes, went on sale in Boston-area camera stores and professional supply houses. The response has been enthusiastic. At Crimson Camera Technical Sales, a Cambridge company that deals exclusively with commercial customers, Don Perrin, general manager, said, ''We can't wait to get more in stock.''

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Ability to Contain Nuclear Accident Tested
description: Workers wearing protective gear picked through desert brush today, cleaning up radioactive debris strewn over a mock seaport in an elaborate drill to test the Government's ability to contain a nuclear accident.

title: CAYMAN RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,682,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,322,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Bulova Watch is 95 percent owned by Loews Corp.

title: AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including capital gains of $281,674, or 7 cents a share.

title: Thompson Seeks Help
description: David Thompson of the Seattle SuperSonics, who was named an allstar despite erratic play this season, has entered a voluntary treatment program in Denver in an effort to overcome a problem with drugs and alcohol, club officials said yesterday. ''I'm very happy he's taken care of this,'' said Seattle's coach, Lenny Wilkens, who disclosed that he had urged Thompson to seek treatment after the 28-year-old player acknowledged his problem just three games before the end of the season. Thompson is a free agent, and Wilkens said the club would not make a decision on whether to offer him a new contract until he had completed his treatment.

title: STRAWBERRY ARRIVES AT SHEA
description: Behind home plate, at the backstop where the ground crew enters the playing field and catchers chase pop fouls and passed balls, a podium marked the spot where Darryl Strawberry would address reporters at 4 P.M. yesterday. But now, with 30 minutes remaining to call his very own, Strawberry jogged to the warning track in right field and sprinted back and forth, covering the ground that is expected to become his backyard for at least a dozen years.

title: Richard L. Bowditch, 53, Dies; W.R. Grace & Co. Executive
description: Richard L. Bowditch, treasurer and senior vice president of W.R. Grace & Company, choked to death Wednesday at a dinner for the Committee for National Security in Washington. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: From the London Line
description: Heads swiveled on Central Park West and joggers stopped in their tracks as a big red doubledecker London bus lumbered downtown from the West Side. New Yorkers waved, city bus drivers saluted and a pedestrian crashed into a lamppost as he was throwing kisses.

title: Zahringer Advances
description: George Zahringer 3d of Sands Point, L.I., the defending champion, was penalized for arriving late for his morning match yesterday but recovered to win two matches and advance to the semifinals of the William D. Richardson Memorial Golf Tournament at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Zahringer will face Dick Stanley of Island Hills in the semifinals tomorrow. The other semifinal matches Brian Brown of Southward Ho against Peter Nisselson of Hampshire.

title: Honduras Expels Reporter
description: The Honduran authorities have expelled a freelance correspondent for United Press International for writing articles that they asserted were ''tendentious or false, with the object of disparaging'' the country. The correspondent, John Lantigua, 35 years old, of San Francisco, was picked up by immigration agents at his apartment in the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa and placed on a flight to Miami.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR'S SMOLDERING BID TO CONTROL CITY COUNCIL FLARES UP
description: The smoldering power struggle to control Chicago's City Council broke into the open again today with strong words on several sides and an indication that the final resolution would come from the courts.

title: Who Should Veto Nuclear Power?
description: Suddenly, there's a surprising threat to the two nuclear power plants at Indian Point, N.Y. - from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. It says they must shut down unless a better emergency evacuation plan can be devised by June 9.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for year to Feb 27.
description: The year-ago share earnings reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split effective Nov. 9, 1982.

title: UNITED-OVERTON CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: A Judge Puts His Qualities To Good Use at the Table
description: Just as poor judgment in a lower court can sometimes be put right on appeal, so a misjudgment in the bidding can be corrected by a combination of skill and luck in the play. Who should know this better than a judge, and one was supervising, quite judicially, the proceedings on the deal shown in the diagram.

title: JOBLESS RATE STEADY, BUT OFFICIAL DECLARES SITUATION IMPROVED
description: The rate of unemployment in April, remainedat the March level of 10.1 percent of the labor force, but the nation's employment situation ''improved considerably,'' the Labor Department said today.

title: TORSTAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $178,000 from discontinued operations.

title: THE SHADOW FOLLOWING BOSSY
description: The Shadow stood in a bright light, smiling and shaking his head in wonder. Luc Dufour, a 20-year-old rookie with the Boston Bruins, smiled because the television interviewer with the microphone was asking questions in English. Dufour's English had been limited to weekly lessons during his days with the Chicoutimi Sagueneens, his junior league team back in Quebec. The lessons were supplemented this season by his exposure to the dialect that is shouted from the balcony of Boston Garden, where a novice student of English can learn many new words and phrases.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the settlement of a claim of $807,340. c-Net loss

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Revenue figures represent commissions.

title: U.S. Court Overturns Faculty Quota System
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down a racial quota system for faculty in the Kalamazoo, Mich., public school system that voided seniority rights for some white teachers.

title: U.S. Ordered to Justify Afghans' Confinement
description: A Federal judge yesterday gave the Government 20 days to file papers supporting its position that it is acting legally in confining 40 Afghan aliens in a detention center in Brooklyn.

title: Your Money; Cost Averaging In Reverse
description: THE resurgence of equity mutual funds, a result of the soaring bull market that began last August, has again stimulated interest in techniques of investing in these open-end investment companies. But withdrawals from a fund can also be handled in many different ways, and specialists have devised a variety of methods.

title: Noles Sued Again
description: Dickie Noles, the Chicago Cubs pitcher who was arrested last month after a barroom brawl in Cincinnati, has been hit with a second damage suit growing out of the incident.

title: JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO 9.2% IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City's unemployment rate fell from 11 percent in March to 9.2 percent in April, while the rate for New York State as a whole was unchanged at 9.3 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 3 CHARGED WITH CONSPIRING TO FORCE OUT TENANTS
description: Three men have been indicted on charges of conspiring to force tenants out of an apartment building on West 57th Street in a scheme that included attacks on tenants and threats of murder.

title: WALL STREET PENNIES PER SHARE FOR CITY SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net income

title: Covering the Chancellor
description: The executive director of the United Federation of Teachers, paying her first visit to Anthony J. Alvarado since he took over as Schools Chancellor this week, decided a gift was in order.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $581,000 for the quarter and $3.5 million for the year. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $653,000.

title: N.R.C. FINES OWNER OF SALEM A-PLANT IN JERSEY $850,000
description: The operator of the Salem nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey was fined $850,000 by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today for violations of Federal nuclear safety regulations.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: AUSTRALIA IS SAID TO SPY ON ALLIES
description: The High Court ordered The National Times today to stop publishing classified documents that assert that Australia spied on Asian allies and was cut off from United States information on China's invasion of Vietnam in 1979.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHILDREN
description: Ezra Jack Keats, an illustrator and writer of children's books who won many awards, died of a heart attack early yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: June 6. Israel invades southern Lebanon to destroy Palestine Liberation Organization bases. In the next few weeks the Israelis battle Syrian forces in eastern Lebanon and surround West Beirut.

title: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
SOCAL STUDIES SALE OF EUROPEAN UNITS
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it is discussing with unnamed parties the sale of all or part of its refining and marketing operations in Europe.

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PACIFIC POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Cabinet decided to approve in principle the proposed agreement between Lebanon and Israel. With regard to certain political and security issues, the Government will seek additional clarifications.'' - Dan Meridor, Israeli Cabinet Secretary. (4:3.)

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a loss of $591,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $233,000 for the quarter and $2,243,000 for the 6 months, and a special gain of $51,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: DOW RISES BY 12.87, TO 1,232.59
description: Stock prices advanced smartly yesterday in the heaviest trading since early January, as more and more smaller investors joined in buying stocks in the belief that the market would continue to rise.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (TUCSON, ARIZ reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: WHY LOCAL PHONE SERVICE MUST DO WITHOUT TOLL-CALL SUBSIDY
description: To the Editor:

title: GAIN FOR CITY'S RETAILERS
description: Sales of New York City's seven largest department stores rose 5.4 percent in April compared with April last year, the smallest monthly gain in three months, a spot check showed yesterday.

title: MONOSIL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: In April, Monosil merged with Citel Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif. and the combined companies carry the name Citel.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Tommaso Morlino Dies at 57; Was Italian Senate President
description: Tommaso Morlino, the President of the Italian Senate, died today after a heart attack, the Senate announced.

title: Philadelphia's Exchange Shut
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange was shut down today by a minor fire that blacked out parts of the building and sent more than 1,000 people into the streets, authorities said.

title: Gibraltar Savings
description: The Gibraltar Savings Association, with $4.8 billion in assets, and a subsidiary of the First Texas Savings Association will merge under an agreement worth $249 million approved by the two boards.

title: Freedom Through Verse
description: Giggling and fidgeting in their seats at Aaron Davis Hall at City College, some 150 schoolchildren quickly fell into a respectful silence yesterday as their classmates began to read.

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to April 3.

Patents;
Strobe for Coronary Disease
description: THE Cardiac Strobe, as it is trademarked, was patented this week by Robert E. Wernikoff, a scientist at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, who describes it as effective in the detection of coronary artery disease, a major cause of death in the United States.

title: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-After a loss of $382,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Tennessee Bank Closed
description: The Smith County Bank was closed Thursday by Federal officials - the seventh Tennessee bank to fail since 1979. State Banking Commissioner W.C. Adams said the bank, with assets of $32.98 million in 1982, would reopen Monday under new ownership.

title: ISRAEL VOTES LEBANON PACT IN PRINCIPLE, BUT A PULLOUT AWAITS TALKS WITH SYRIANS
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted today to accept in principle a draft agreement with Lebanon on border security and mutual relations. The accord is intended as a basis for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon, provided the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Syrian Army also leave. Security in Southern Lebanon

title: MORE BUSINESSES JOINING PROGRAMS TO AID SCHOOLS
description: A growing trend in American education - the direct involvement of business and industry in public schools - is already well-developed in New York City, and Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado said yesterday that he wanted even greater involvement.

title: EASTERN MECHANICS' MISTAKE LED TO JET STALL, INVESTIGATORS REPORT
description: It was mistakes by two mechanics that caused all three engines of an Eastern Airlines jumbo jet to stall, dropping the aircraft perilously close to the Atlantic Ocean, Federal investigators said today.

title: CASE SETTLED, A JUROR FINDS IT GUILTY OF 21 MONTHS' BOREDOM
description: The day after the judge announced an out-of-court settlement in a 21-month-old antitrust trial, Tom Black, a juror, got on his bicycle and rode from his home in Clairemont to San Diego and back, 50 miles, hard and fast, until he could ride no more.

title: State Fund May Buy Seafirst
description: The Washington State Investment Board will decide Monday whether to invest state employee pension funds in a bid to buy the troubled Seafirst Corporation.

title: Article 150290 -- No Title
description: The sale at auction of a Manhattan woman's $200,000 East Side cooperative apartment for $15,000 to satisfy a $350 debt must be honored, a judge has ruled.

title: 3 DEAD AND 10 HURT IN BLAZE OVER CHINATOWN RESTAURANT
description: Three people were killed and 10 others, including four firefighters, were injured yesterday morning in an accidental fire that swept through two Chinatown buildings, the Fire Department said.

title: NOVA, AN ALBERTA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Player Is Held On Sex Charge
description: Julio Valdez, a reserve infielder for the Red Sox, was taken from the dugout during tonight's game with Seattle and arrested on a statutory rape charge, the police reported.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.4 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose $1.4 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said late yesterday. The increase was unexpected by most market analysts and dashed hopes for a swift decline in interest rates. Heavy selling of longer-term United States Government debt issues followed the announcement, pushing interest rates up.

title: PROVIDENT LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
No Lament at te E.P.A.
description: As warm weather is followed by people putting their feelings on their T-shirts, some employees of the Environmental Protection Agency now have the words ACID REIGN on their backs.

title: A NEW SURGE OF INTEREST IN SECONDHAND AIRCRAFT
description: Dick Funk, manager of a storage lot for used commercial aircraft awaiting buyers, remembers not too long ago when only one plane a month would leave his facility, the Evergreen Air Center 30 miles north of Tucson. Last month, though, in a strong sign that better times may have returned in the depressed market for used jetliners, a dozen aircraft moved off the Evergreen field.

title: The Talk of Phnom Penh
description: Even though this country has seen a long war, a famine and then an invasion by Vietnam, this capital seems surprisingly cheerful. There are cars on the streets, food in the markets and more smiles than a visitor might expect.

title: Midway Behind Ads on Airline
description: The mystery of who is asking newspaper and magazine readers to ''create'' their own airline has been solved. It is Midway Airlines, the upstart Chicago-based carrier, which has begun a nationwide advertising campaign aimed at finding out what people in business want in the airline subsidiary that the carrier plans to start late in June.

title: Soviet Is Said to Free 5 Held for 13 Months
description: Five men who were arrested 13 months ago after publishing underground criticisms of the Soviet system have been released from jail without standing trial, associates of the five men reported today.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BALLET: 'GALLOPING GOTTSCHALK'
description: Every dance company needs a crowd-pleaser from time to time, and the American Ballet Theater's ''Great Galloping Gottschalk,'' performed Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera, is certainly that.

title: COUNTIES REJECT NEW STEPS TO BAR A-PLANT CLOSING
description: County officials in the area around the Indian Point reactors said yesterday that they did not plan to take any additional steps in response to the threat made by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to shut the nuclear plants.

title: BENGUET CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results have been translated at the rate of 9.74 Philippine pesos equal $1 for the latest first quarter and 9.17 Philippine pesos equal $1 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: Playbill Executives Marry
description: Arthur T. Birsh, publisher of Playbill, and Joan Alleman, editor in chief of the magazine, were married yesterday at their home in Greenwich Village. State Supreme Court Justice Michael J. Dontzin performed the ceremony. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: Hitch in Fouts's Pact
description: The night before the National Football League draft, Gene Klein, the owner of the San Diego Chargers, announced that he and Dan Fouts had reached a ''verbal agreement'' on a contract that would enable the star quarterback to finish his career with the Chargers.

title: LONDON PAPER ABANDONS DEAL
description: The Sunday Times said today that it had accepted the conclusion of West German experts that the documents offered as diaries of Hitler were forgeries and had canceled plans to publish excerpts.

title: OIL PRODUCERS VIE FOR EXPLORATION FUNDS
description: When the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to drop their benchmark price for crude by $5 a barrel in March, a prolonged spate of infighting appeared to come to an end and oil prices stabilized.

title: GLAXO SAYS ULCER DRUG HAS APPROVAL OF F.D.A.
description: Glaxo Holdings Ltd. said today that it had received provisional approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration for a popular anti-ulcer drug that would compete with the hugely successful Tagamet on the American market.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: TRADE DEFICIT NARROWER
description: A rare gain in American exports helped chop the nation's merchandise trade deficit by nearly one-third in the first quarter of 1983, the Government said today. A big drop in oil imports contributed to the improvement.

title: HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $5.5 million. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,408,960.

title: HOW BRITONS REACTED TO A METRIC CONVERSION
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYMOND INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHINA'S BUSINESS WOES IN U.S.
description: They seem to have the ingredients of success: elegant showrooms in choice New York locations, carefully displayed merchandise and lots of money. All that the 30 companies set up by China in the United States lack is familiarity with the capitalist way of doing business.

title: A NEW CLASS OF LANDLORD
description: The landlord is always wrong, goes the tenant's litany. But what about when the tenant becomes a landlord and starts doing the very kinds of shady things he perennially accuses landlords of?

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SINCLAIR VENEZUELAN OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Excludes a loss of $2,911,000 from the devaluation of the Venezuelan Bolivar. Sinclair Venezuelan Oil is a 97 percent-owned subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Co.

title: FUND DRIVE FOR CANCER IS STUDIED
description: NEW YORK'S Attorney General is looking into a Washington-based c ancer research organization that has been soliciting contributions i n the state. State officials say the organization has not complied w ith all of New York's regulations on charitable organizations.

title: FROM KAMALI, ARTFUL HATS
description: Norma Kamali's art lies in unerringly transforming traditional staples of American dress into fashion items of high fun and some zing at, most important, the right price. Take, for example, her successful handling of sweatshirt clothes, given new scale and humor by dint of shoulder pads. Or her recent collection of shoes with variations on every generic style of American shoe, including highheeled sneakers.

title: Why Try the Jurors?
description: A committee of the New York Assembly has just killed a bill to reform the jury selection process - and thus given overwhelming evidence that its members have lost touch with reality. They should be required to do jury duty.

title: English-Language China Daily To Publish in North America
description: The official English-language China Daily is to publish a North American edition starting June 1, the newspaper said today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Each year the College Scholarship Fund of the United Federation of Teachers gives 300 scholarships to outstanding public-school seniors in great financial need.

title: 4,600 NASSAU REPUBLICANS TURN OUT IN A TRIBUTE TO MARGIOTTA
description: More than 4,600 Nassau County Republicans rose to their feet, cheering and applauding for Joseph M. Margiotta. There seemed to be more red, white and blue balloons than people, and as Mr. Margiotta walked into the hall Thursday night, the band struck up the tune ''Wonderful Guy.'' The tumult reached its height as Mr. Margiotta - in the eyes of party members a victim of a miscarriage of justice -took his seat at the three-tiered dais.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INTEGRITY ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: A CLEVEPAK OFFER FOR INTERPACE SEEN
description: Trading in the stock of the Interpace Corporation was halted yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as reports circulated of a new offer for the company. The stock was at 31 1/4, up 1/4, when trading was halted at 11 A.M.

title: 500 AT HARVARD LAW SCHOOL PROTEST NEW GRADING POLICY
description: More than 500 students at the Harvard Law School demonstrated for the second day today to protest a policy to take effect next fall that permits professors to count a student's classroom participation in grading.

title: Westhead Job Shaky
description: He has three years left on a four-year contract, but his first season was something of a disappointment, and, as a result, Coach Paul Westhead's future with the Chicago Bulls is far from certain. That was the word from the general manager, Rod Thorn, who said that Westhead's status would be discussed at a meeting of the club's executive committee next week.

title: COSTA RICA ASKS THE O.A.S TO POLICE NICARAGUA BORDER
description: Costa Rica has asked the Organization of American States to create an international force to police its border with Nicaragua, and O.A.S. officials said today that the request is scheduled to be taken up next week.

title: ABC-TV Drops Film About Elizabeth Taylor
description: TV has dropped its plans to broadcast a film based on the life of Elizabeth Taylor, a network spokesman said.

title: JOHN JAY HOMETOWNS
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAHAM MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MORE CHEECH AND CHONG
description: With ''Still Smokin','' Cheech Marin and Tommy Chong are scraping the bottom of their barrel and finding only bits and pieces of the characters and comedy routines that were so successful in their earlier films, including ''Up in Smoke,'' ''Nice Dreams'' and ''Cheech and Chong's Next Movie.''

title: BONN SAYS TESTS SHOW DIARIES AREN'T HITLER'S
description: The Interior Ministry said today that examination by state archivists and tests by police laboratories had determined that volumes purporting to be Hitler's secret diaries were forgeries.

title: Lebanese Fighting Increases; Shells Hit Beirut for a 2d Day
description: Fighting between Christian and Druse militias in the hills overlooking Beirut increased sharply tonight.

title: ROCHESTER AND PITTSBURGH COAL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Giant Tug-of-War
description: As part of the Glenfiddich Games in Central Park next Saturday and Sunday, the New York Giants will stage a tug-of-war between active and retired players.

title: Officer and a Suspect Wounded in Shootout
description: A police officer was shot in a knee and his assailant was critically wounded in an exchange of gunfire last night in a Bronx apartment house, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in some editions yesterday with a picture of Greek Orthodox worship services misidentified the church. It was the Chapel of St. Paul in the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America.

title: MOTHER'S DAY
description: Millions of mothers around the world look forward to Mother's Day as an occasion for joy and flowers, a day set aside to celebrate the life they have given others. For a handful of mothers, however, in some countries where it is on the calendar, this day is a reminder not of how central motherhood is to existence but of how precarious it can become.

title: SERVED IN NEW JERSEY AS ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: Grover C. Richman Jr., New Jersey Attorney General from 1954 to 1958 and a former United States Attorney for New Jersey, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Westchester division of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in White Plains. He was 71 years old and lived in Edgewater Park, N.J.

title: CINCINNATI AREA HUB OF HOUSING FIGHT
description: To the south, the city's prosperous business district crowds the muddy Ohio. To the north, Liberty Hill's tastefully restored brick mansions hold the high ground. In between stretches a jumbled stew of old brick row houses called Over-the-Rhine, and there is a fight going on here over what should be done there.

title: PHYSICISTS' ARMS STAND CRITICIZED
description: The White House science adviser, George A. Keyworth 2d, today criticized the American Physical Society, one of the nation's leading scientific organizations, for what he called its ''arrogant action'' in seeming to challenge President Reagan's arms control policies.

title: TUITION POLICY AT STATE U. SAID TO AID THE AFFLUENT
description: The chairman of the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities said yesterday that the state was providing heavy subsidies for affluent students to attend the State University of New York through its current tuition policy. He said the policy should be changed to insure fairer competition between the public and private sectors of higher education.

title: DRUNKEN-DRIVING EFFORT TERMED LAGGING IN CITY
description: New York City's 10-month-old program to combat drunken driving was sharply criticized yesterday by specialists in alcoholism treatment and by the chairman of the State Assembly's subcommittee overseeing the program.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Seeking the TV Spotlight
description: Not every Republican member of Congress can be interviewed by Jane Pauley on NBC's ''Today'' show. But Representative Thomas J. Bliley of Virginia made it two weeks ago.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 7, 1983
description: International

title: Trenton's Latest Lottery Troubles
description: The New Jersey Lottery Commission hoped for praise when it announced it had created 100 millionaires, but the news was elbowed aside by the indictment of a commissioner, Reese Palley. He is charged with falsifying documents to thwart an investigation of several allegedly improper transactions he had with the commission's vendors.

title: Midwife Looks Back At Thousands of Births
description: Having assisted in the births of more than 3,000 babies in India and more than 5,000 since she left the country in 1955, Asoka Roy retired recently as director of midwifery at the Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: From the Pulpit To the Proscenium
description: The pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem for the last 16 years, the Rev. Dr. Wyatt Tee Walker, is also a gospel-music scholar and singer. So he feels ''entirely comfortable,'' he said yesterday, about playing a singing minister in ''Mama, I Want to Sing,'' a concert-musical at the Heckscher Theater, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street.

title: E.P.A. NOMINEE GAINS IN SENATE
description: A Senate committee today unanimously approved William D. Ruckelshaus to head the Environmental Protection Agency, with the panel's chairman calling the vote ''the first important step'' in restoring confidence in the troubled agency.

title: PITTSBURGH-DES MOINES STEEL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
CAMPANERIS SPARKS YANKS TO 8-4 VICTORY
description: The Yankees generally enjoyed their first 1983 visit to the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome tonight, but it was Bert Campaneris who enjoyed it the most. Campaneris celebrated the start of his second life in the major leagues by stroking four hits, stealing a base and figuring in four double plays.

title: TRUST COMPANY OF NEW JERSEY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST MATAGORDA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Justice Promotion Asked
description: President Reagan announced Thursday that he would nominate D. Lowell Jensen, who heads the Justice Department's criminal division, to be Associate Attorney General, the department's No. 3 post. Mr. Jensen, 54 years old, a former California District Attorney, would succeed Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has resigned to become the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

title: PHILHARMONIC: MEMBERS ONLY
description: Once a season the New York Philharmonic, like most other symphony orchestras, puts on a members-only night. Principals and other leading players from the Philharmonic ranks are brought forward to display their talents and augment their incomes by appearing in concertos and other pieces calling for virtuosic soloists. It was time again Thursday night for this annual event, under the guidance of Zubin Mehta. Perhaps out of special respect for their fellow musicians, Mr. Mehta and the orchestra were on the alert all evening, with generally precise and sonorous results.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES POWER TO CUT OFF COVERT AID MONEY
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence approved a measure today that would enable Congress to cut off future financing for covert operations in Central America.

title: THE FOCUS OF EVIL
description: When Ronald Reagan described the Soviet Union as the focus of evil in the world, at a gathering of the National Association of Evangelicals, in Florida, European hackles tended to rise. We were perhaps, neither sufficiently naive nor sophisticated to conceal our surprise when American friends attempted to placate us by saying: ''You've got to realize, he was talking to a bunch of preachers.''

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HARSCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REAGAN CALLS THE MIDEAST ACCORD 'A SIGNIFICANT STEP FORWARD'
description: President Reagan, pleased with what he called the ''good news'' of the Israeli agreement in principle with Lebanon, said today that ''we have crossed an important threshold in the path to peace'' in the Middle East.

title: REAGAN BUDGET ALLY IN SENATE SAYS RECOVERY CAN'T TAKE BIG TAX RISE
description: Pete V. Domenici, Senate floor manager for a budget resolution for 1984 supported by the Reagan Administration, said today that the economic recovery was too weak to permit tax increases of a size recommended by Democrats.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATL GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

PATENTS;
Implantable Heart Uses Two Hydraulic Pumps
description: The third in a series of patents on a totally implantable artificial heart, with a pair of hydraulically actuated blood pumps, was received this week by Foxcroft Associates of San Antonio, Tex., sponsors of the project.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After capital transactions.

title: MOSCOW'S STAKE IN MIDEAST NEGOTIATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Herman G. Klein, 66, Is Dead; Guttenberg Mayor 28 Years
description: Herman G. Klein, the Mayor of Guttenberg, N.J., for 28 years, died Wednesday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J., of complications after surgery. He was 66 years old.

title: Eastern Airlines' Pilots Agree on Concessions
description: Pilots for Eastern Airlines will fly more and take less vacation under a tentative agreement announced today by the carrier and the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: Upsetting Odds Have Good Effect
description: The last two times Laz Barrera trained a colt for the Kentucky Derby, his horse was the second-favorite but ended up winning the race with the favorite finishing second. Barrera sent out Bold Forbes to upset Honest Pleasure in 1976 and did it again with Affirmed, who beat Alydar in 1978.

title: Creeping On at Petty Pace
description: Here is something fresh to worry about: procrastination. Do you put off until tomorrow what you can do today? If so, you are a procrastinator practicing procrastination and, according to psychologists who talked to The New York Times, you should change your ways immediately. Not tomorrow. Today.

title: ADVANCED SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS INT NV reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-This is the initial first quarter report issued by the company and so there are no comparable year-ago results. Results were translated at the rate of 2.735 Dutch guilders equal $1.

title: WESTERN CASUALTY & SURETY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an investment gain of $286,426. c-Includes an investment gain of $134,587.

title: EMORY TELLS HOW PHYSICIAN FAKED MUCH RESEARCH
description: Officials at Emory University have disclosed the details of an investigation that found a heart researcher faked eight scientific papers and 43 research abstracts while at the university here.

title: ROCKLAND CHIEF CITES CONCERN OVER INDIAN PT.
description: ''If it's a question of money or lives,'' the chairman of the Rockland County Legislature said, ''we place lives - the safety of people - in a higher priority.''

title: Turkey Decrees Laws Curbing Role of Unions
description: Turkey's ruling military announced new laws today that forbid unions from engaging in political activity, make them put their money in state-controlled banks and limit strikes to 60 days.

title: BALANCHINE
description: Politics may make strange bedfellows, but the needs of art can make even stranger. When Mayor John V. Lindsay and the Ford Foundation, then the nation's leading arts patron, together conspired to have me elected pro bono chairman of the New York City Ballet, I insisted on meeting the company's real masters, George Balanchine, and his lifelong mentor Lincoln Kirstein, before I accepted.

title: Robert F. Mackle Dies; A Developer in Florida
description: Robert F. Mackle, whose family pioneered the development of major Florida communities, died Wednesday night in Miami. He was 71.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOWN EAST

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
Elizabeth Lynch Is Wed To Karl Kuechenmeister
description: At St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn., yesterday Elizabeth Lynch, coordinator, radio network news, for NBC News in New York, was married to Karl Kuechenmeister, vice president, media sales, for the Telepictures Corporation in New York.

title: Index; International
description: The Talk of Phnom Penh: Dig- ging stops and healing starts 2 French officials fear unrest may spread to factories 3 Chinese official to go to South Korea over hijacking 3 Around the World 5 Costa Rica asks O.A.S. to police Nicaragua border 5 Reagan calls Israeli move ''sig- nificant step forward'' 5 U.S. considers options in case of radio jamming by Cuba 5 Search for source of ''diaries'' leads to ex-Nazis 6 The Sunday Times of London can- cels Hitler's alleged diaries 6 Government/Politics Chicago's smoldering political fire flares anew 9 Reagan tells N.R.A. he will help repeal firearms curbs 12 Hispanic Democratic leaders look to 1984 12 Reagan aide assails Physical Society's arms control stand 17 City Environmental Control Board seeks new powers 25 Debtor sale of $200,000 apartment for $15,000 is upheld 27 Washington Talk Briefing 7 Congress: Budget fight splits Re- publican coalition 7 General Around the Nation 8 Debate rises over historic desig- nation for Cincinnati area 8 Soviet visitors in Vermont en- counter the echo of a dissenter 9 For a juror, 21 patient months, then an out-of-court pact 9 U.S. report ties mechanics' er- rors to near-crash of jet 10 Jury gets case of four policemen in murder case 24 City's drunken-driving program assailed at hearing 26 Arts/Entertainment Miller directing his ''Death of a Salesman'' in China 13 Ballet Theater on Indian Point 26 Education/Welfare Emory tells how physician faked research 8 Industry getting increasingly in- volved in public schools 27 Obituaries Ezra Jack Keats, illustrator and author of children's books 10 Grover C. Richman Jr., former New Jersey Attorney General 10 Sports Pages Mets win on Foster's homer in 13th; Strawberry makes debut 19 McEnroe makes stormy advance to semifinals 19 Kentucky Derby field of 20 lacks strong favorite 19 George Vecsey on defending Marfa 19 Morrow of Islanders is expected to play after knee surgery 20 Campaneris's four hits, fielding help Yanks beat Twins, 8-4 20 Players: Bruins rookie who shad- owed Bossy in Game 5 20 Scouting: Barrera is upset by Kentucky Derby odds 20 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 14 Saturday News Quiz 17 Sports People 21 New York Day by Day 26 About New York 27 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: LOTTERY OFFICIAL MAY BE BARRED FROM A MEETING
description: Governor Kean said today that he would seek to prevent Reese Palley, the former chairman of the New Jersey Lottery Commission, from taking part in the commission's next meeting, on May 25. Mr. Palley was indicted last week on charges of trying to impede an ethics investigation.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BELL CERTIFIES PLAN ON TREATING RIVALS
description: The 22 Bell System companies met a courtimposed deadline today for certifying they will treat competitors equally in states where regulators authorize intrastate long-distance competition.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Italy Eases Money Curb
description: The Italian Government announced today that it was easing currency export restrictions on Italian tourists traveling abroad. Italians may now export up to 1.6 million lire, or $1,100, worth of foreign currency each year, as well as up to 200,000 lire, or $140, worth of Italian banknotes each trip. Previously, tourists were allowed to export only $750, worth of currency, including Italian banknotes.

title: British Local Elections Give Unclear Message
description: The British electorate appears to have sent Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher an ambiguous message about her chances of winning a second term if she chooses to call national elections next month.

title: U.S. LISTS 'OPTIONS' ON CUBAN JAMMING
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials have indicated to commercial broadcasters that they are considering a list of 40 options for retaliating against Cuba, including ''surgical removal'' of the transmitting antennas, if the Havana Government begins regular jamming of American radio stations, according to Congressional and broadcasting officials.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: The Hazards of Libel
description: In setting aside a highly publicized $2 million libel judgment against The Washington Post, Federal Judge Gasch of the District of Columbia extended an odd trend. Juries are awarding high damages for libel, but judges are overturning their verdicts and sharply reducing the awards.

title: Bill to Bar Users
description: Rep. J. Michael Ruane, a five-term Democrat from Salem, Mass., has achieved what he considers a minor victory in the state House of Representatives. He is not optimistic, however, that his bill regarding drug usage by athletes will become law.

title: HISPANIC DEMOCRATIC LEADERS DISCUSS STRATEGY FOR '84
description: A group of Hispanic Democratic leaders, buoyed by what they regard as a growing number of contests in which Hispanic voters have turned defeat into victory for the party, met here today to organize a vehicle that would carry that influence into the 1984 Presidential race.

title: JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Including a net realized investment gain of $10,120,000. c-After a net realized investment loss of $3,426,000.

title: METS WIN ON FOSTER HOMER IN 13TH
description: The Mets greeted the arrival of Darryl Strawberry last night with the kind of fireworks rarely seen at Shea Stadium. They hit four home runs, the final one a three-run blast by George Foster in the 13th inning, to beat the Cincinnati Reds by 7-4 and end a five-game losing streak.

title: ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
32 Michigan Families Move Back to Waste Site
description: Thirty-two families began moving back today to homes they were forced to leave two weeks ago when a judge ordered immediate cleanup of Michigan's worst toxic waste site.

title: HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: MCENROE BEATS SMID IN FIERY TWO SETS
description: John McEnroe reached the semifinals of the Mercedes Tournament of Champions yesterday but not before he and Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia took some crisp verbal and tennis shots at each other.

title: Xerox to Start Telecopier Option
description: The Xerox Corporation said it will start installation in June of a telecopier with an option allowing it to communicate with computers and office automation networks.

title: Kodak to Cut 1,600 Jobs
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would lay off 1,600 employees from its apparatus division near Rochester bringing to 2,700 the total number of workers idled by the company this year.

title: South Africa Imposes Rules on Border Farmers
description: The South African Government published regulations this week to require owners of border farms to occupy their property in an effort to ward off guerrilla incursions from neighboring countries.

title: Breaks Are Even
description: Teams in the United States Football League have played nine games this season. The National Football League, you may recall, logged only nine games in its most recent season, due to the 57-day players' strike that eliminated seven weekends of games from the schedule.

title: GUARDIAN DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $407,000. c-Net income.

title: Harvester Gets Louisville Bid
description: A group of Louisville business executives has signed a ''letter of intent'' to purchase the International Harvester Company's Louisville plant for about $26 million.

title: A MACHINE EMPLOYED TO ABUSE WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Device Collects Samples Of Airborne Pollutants
description: A sample collector for atmospheric pollutants has been developed at the Environmental Protection Agency's laboratory in Research Triangle Park, N.C. John P. Bell of the laboratory staff got Patent 4,381,681 for the device, which accumulates particles that may be hazardous.

title: CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $4,000 for the quarter and income of $1,258,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $451,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $601,000 for the quarter and $11.4 million for the 40 weeks. c-Including extraordinary credits of $2.4 million for the quarter and $37.2 million for the 40 weeks. The company is listed on the Boston, Philadelphia and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: CHRYSLER ASKING THE U.S. TO FORGO PROFIT IT COULD MAKE ON LOAN AID
description: The Government could make more than $220 million on Chrysler Corporation stock by exercising a right to purchase the stock at less than half the current market price. But company and Government officials said today that Chrysler now wants to cancel the arrangement.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. WILL LIFT BAN ON F-16'S SALE TO ISRAEL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the agreement for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon was ''a significant step,'' and that President Reagan would lift the embargo he imposed last summer on the sale to Israel of 75 additional F-16 fighter planes.

title: Stanley Benjamin Dies at 57; Architect and Builder on L.I.
description: Stanley Richard Benjamin, an architect and builder who worked on Long Island for many years, died of cancer Monday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 57 years old.

title: SOUTHERN MINERALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JURY GETS CASE OF OFFICERS ACCUSED IN MOTEL DEATH
description: Jurors began deliberations today in the trial of four Everett, Mass., police officers accused of beating a man to death in a brawl in a motel room last July.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report in the Finance column of Business Day on Thursday in correctly stated the debt rating by Moody's Investors Service for the Northern Trust Corporation's commercial paper. It was lowered to Prime-2 from Prime-1.

title: PRESIDENT TELLS RIFLE ASSOCIATION HE'S FOR REPEAL OF SOME GUN CURBS
description: President Reagan, declaring that he had always felt a special bond with the National Rifle Association, promised at the association's convention today that he would help seek to repeal firearms restrictions that he said ''needlessly interfere with the rights of legitimate gun owners like yourselves.''

title:
PATENTS;
Lead Content of Blood Analyzed by Instrument
description: Chia-Gee Wang, a physicist in Millwood, N.Y., has invented an X-ray biomedical instrument that makes nonintrusive reading of the lead content of blood.

title: CHINESE AIDE FLIES TO SOUTH KOREA OVER HIJACKING
description: China, embarrassed by the first successful hijacking of one of its civil airliners, today dispatched an official delegation for discussions with authorities in South Korea on the return of the hijackers as well as the plane, its crew and passengers.

title: WILLY LOMAN GETS CHINA TERRITORY
description: The salesman shuffled onstage into the exposed skeleton of his small house and wearily handed his hat to his solicitous wife, who cast about for some place to put it.

title: Generals Cut Hall
description: The Generals have cut Leamon Hall, the former star passer for Army who was installed on New Jersey's developmental squad after he had failed to win a position with the Arizona Wranglers. As a replacement on the developmental squad, the Generals signed Jeff Knapple, who was the Denver Gold's starting quarterback earlier this season but who was waived later. ... Among the 13 free agents signed by the Giants yesterday was Mike Teeuws, a Stanford center who is the son of a former National Football League lineman, Len Teeuws.

title:
PATENTS;
Sludge Robot Cleans Sediment from Tanks
description: Tord Svensson of Jonkoping, Sweden, has been granted Patent 4,381,237 for a sludge robot that cleans sediment from the bottom of a tank and gets rid of it outside.

title: Field's Chairman Quits
description: George P. Kelly, chairman and chief executive of Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago department store, has resigned, effective June 1, the company announced yesterday.

title: Bad News on Booze
description: For the reporters, photographers, commentators, camera operators, sound and light technicians, producers, assistant producers, unit managers and others who are assigned to cover national political candidates, no booze is bad news. So when a group of news people realized recently that they were in a bus in Ohio following a candidate to a dry town, they began to grumble and gripe, recalling the alcohol-free days of bivouac in Plains, Ga., the home of Jimmy Carter.

title: FRENCH OFFICIALS FEAR UNREST MAY GROW
description: An adviser to President Francois Mitterrand said today that the Government believed that the street clashes and unrest of the last two weeks might not have reached their high point, and that the protests by students, doctors, farmers and shopkeepers could spread to factories next month.

title: GEMAYEL VOWS NOT TO BE DETERRED
description: Senior Lebanese officials said today that Syria had informed them that Damascus objects to virtually every major clause of the withdrawal agreement worked out between Israel and Lebanon by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: TRAIL OF HITLER 'DIARIES' LEADS TO FORMER NAZIS
description: The disclosure today that the purported Hitler diaries are fakes has left the source of the 60 volumes unclear, but investigations so far have led to former Nazi officials in West Germany and elsewhere.

title: SAVING ON COSTS OF LONG-DISTANCE CALLS
description: Once the only way to save money on long-distance calls was to play by Ma Bell's rules. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company urged that calls be made at night or on weekends and dialed directly, and, if all else failed, that they be as brief as possible.

title: Claudia Marianne Townsend Marries Paul West
description: Claudia Marianne Townsend, city editor of The Washington Post, was married in Atlanta yesterday to Paul West, Washington bureau chief of The Dallas Times Herald.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 7, 1983
description: Companies

title: SHULTZ'S REMARKS ON THE AGREEMENT
description: Following is the text of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's comments in Jerusalem on the Israeli agreement in principle to his proposals for withdrawing foreign troops from Lebanon, as issued by the State Department:

title: Outdoor Sculpture Show
description: ''On the Bridge,'' an outdoor sculpture exhibition, will open tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Delancey Street entrance to the promenade of the Williamsburg Bridge. Sponsored by ABC NoRio and Collaborative Projects, nonprofit arts organizations, the show features works in steel, wood and cement, and will be there all this month.

title: PENSION UNIT ISSUES POLICY ON SUICIDES
description: The Reagan Administration has devised new procedures to deal with people who threaten to kill themselves after being told they may lose their Social Security disability benefits.

title: WEDDING SET FOR SUMMER BY MISS DOW
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Tsung-I Dow of Boca Raton, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah M. Dow, to Glenn H. Hutchins, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Hutchins Jr. of Chapel Hill and Kitty Hawk, N.C.

title: MANEUVERING FOR PATRONAGE
description: who is also the mentor of the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan - back on the public payroll.

title: LET TEACHERS TEACH BUT NOT EXAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CERONE'S HOME RUN HELPS YANKS WIN
