description: Rick Cerone, unhappy with his platooned catching status and struggling offensively, finally injected some fun into his dismal season tonight. Batting .209 with no runs batted in, Cerone swatted a three-run home run in the eighth inning that put the Yankees ahead of Minnesota, 7-5.

title: WHY DOES OPERA LURE FILMMAKERS?
description: Film, as an inherently contemporary medium, might appear far removed from the stately anachronisms of opera. But a surprising number of present-day film directors seem to have become actively involved with opera, to the point of benign obsession.

title: No Headline
description: Equity in Education And the Democrats Assemblyman John Behan's letter to the editor on April 10 is an open reproach to Democrats, especially to those Democrats who vie with Republicans for ''credit'' for Governor Cuomo's retreat from his determination to use state aid to achieve equity in educational opportunity throughout the state.

title: A GOOD EGG: WHAT TO DO WITH IT AFTER FINDING IT
description: FOR Sunday brunch or a light lunch any day of the week, you can't go wrong with eggs. The best eggs I ever tasted I used to buy from a Chamula woman who sold them at the market in San Cristobal in southern Mexico. They came with thick filthy shells and were carefully wrapped in her woolen shawl to be put one by one - they were sold by the piece - into your basket. They had yolks of the deepest orange I have ever seen. The omlettes you could make with these eggs were so full of flavor that I kept them quite simple, cooked in a nutty brown butter, plain or with nothing more than a few fresh herbs.

title: FUGAZY CAR SERVICE EXPANDS
description: and-driver service introduced last year to the streets of New York City by the Fugazy International Corporation, is expanding its operations to include Westchester and Connecticut.

title: SOME HELPFUL GARDENING HINTS FOR SUBURBAN TRANSPLANTS
description: BEFORE I moved to the suburbs, the only clinging vines I knew were long-fingernailed girls at fraternity parties. Before I moved to the suburbs, snails were served in six-sectioned dishes by snooty French waiters -they didn't squish under my feet after a rainstorm.

title: LEADING TRUMP
description: Veteran players who evince nostalgia for the ''good old days'' can indeed point to evidence that the game is not what it used to be. Most would agree that standards of play have risen, but also that standards of behavior and dress have declined.

title: PRESIDENT CHURCHILL
description: In 1935, Winston Churchill spoke these words: ''Want of foresight, unwillingness to act when action would be simple and effective, lack of clear thinking, confusion of counsel until the emergency comes, until self-preservation strikes its jarring gong, these are the features which constitute the endless repetition of history.'' With these words, Churchill attempted to warn his countrymen of the danger posed by a rearming Germany and of the urgent need for Britain to act. His observations on the inability to learn from history are relevant today. Just like British attitudes in this earlier era, prevailing attitudes in America today have permitted a deteriorated military posture.

title: For Mothers and Others
description: Back in 1964, when Lynn Moen was launching a Book Center for the International Childbirth Education Association, she had a hard time finding materials for expectant and new parents and the various professional people who work with them. On Mother's Day 1983, however, she's in a position to be choosy. Mrs. Moen, who now owns and runs the mail-order Birth & Life Bookstore in Seattle, says it stocks roughly 600 titles and estimates that she turns down a good three-quarters of the available books on her subject.

title: Mailbox; Walter Johnson Had It Tougher
description: To the Sports Editor: In Dave Anderson's column that compares the strikeout records and careers of Nolan Ryan and Walter Johnson (''Strikeout Arms and the Men,'' The New York Times, May 1), he wrote that old-timers grumble that Hank Aaron on his way to his home-run record required almost 2,900 more times at bat to tie Babe Ruth at 714. They should stop grumbling, he asserts, because the modern day Nolan Ryan achieved his career strikeout record of 3,509, one more than Johnson's old mark, in only 3,345 innings, whereas Johnson required 5,923 innings.

title: INDIAN LORE AND MORE
description: On May 5, 1703, Chief Katonah and Chief Wackaname, on behalf of the Munsee Indians who inhabited parts of the county at the time, sold their lands to Zachariah Roberts of Bedford for two gallons of rum, four pounds of gunpowder, four hatchets, five coats, two blankets, six shirts and 10 pieces of eight, or Spanish pesos.

title: Holdup Man in Jersey Gets 40-Year Sentence
description: A 21-year-old New York City man has been sentenced to 40 years in state prison for his part in a New Jersey supermarket holdup in which two hostages were taken, authorities said.

title: COLORADO CONDOMINIUMS: A DOWNHILL RUN
description: STEPPING out of the sales office at Beaver Creek, a resort communityi n the Rocky Mountains 110 miles west of Denver, Abraham Shames, who h ad been inquiring about buying a condominium, looked dazed.

title: No Headline
description: Holocaust Studies At Lawrence High We wonder where the writer of ''Teachers Learn to Teach the Holocaust'' (April 10) got the listing of schools on Long Island that teach the Holocaust. At Lawrence High School we were pioneers in offering a course in Holocaust studies.

title: CHOOSING AN AUTO CLUB
description: It's a chilly evening in Wilmington, N.C. Homeward bound from Florida, two New Yorkers drive off the main highway to see the historic business district. Rounding a corner, their car comes to an abrupt halt in front of the post office. Lights, ignition, everything electrical stops. All fuses check out. The short circuit is obviously in the wiring, but where? For now the only thing to do is call a tow truck.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WILD APPALOOSA Written and illustrated by Glen Rounds. New York: 79 pp. Holiday House. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 11)

title: STERN EDITORS RESIGN OVER HITLER SCANDAL
description: The two chief editors of Stern magazine announced today that they were resigning after a statement by the Interior Ministry Friday that documents the magazine presented as lost diaries of Hitler were forgeries.

title: FRESH AIR FUND WILL OPEN 107TH APPEAL TOMORROW
description: The Fresh Air Fund, which for more than a century has sent underprivileged children from New York City on summer vacations in the country, will open its 107th appeal tomorrow faced with rising costs and an increased need for its programs.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Fear Of Recession Is Easing
description: In spite of indications of an economic recovery, 54 percent of Americans feel that unemployment and recession together form ''the most important problem facing this country today,'' according to the latest Gallup Poll. However, this was a decline of 8 percentage points from last October.

title: MISS STONE TO MARRY ARMAND DE TORRES
description: Mrs. Herbert S. Stone 3d of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Hilles Stone, to Armand de Torres, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Torres of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Banning Barriers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE THINGS THAT CHANGE AND THE THINGS THAT DON'T
description: AT the ripe old age of 13, I discovered with sudden certainly that my suspicions were true. My mother and I had nothing in common except for the fact of my birth.

title: SHE AND FIANCE LAWYERS
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Pollaro of Bayside, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Pollaro, to Marc Pergament, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Pergament of Brooklyn.

title: FOR MOTHER'S DAY, SUNNY SIDE IN BED
description: LIKE the Cowardly Lion, I lack courage. When asked, ''What would you like for Mother's Day?'' I can't say, ''Please, no breakfast in bed.''

title: WILL PRIVACY BE SACRIFICED TO TECHNOLOGY?
description: THE wealthy purchase it, the middle-class strives for it and the poor sacrifice it. And what is the fate of privacy in today's sophisticated electronic marketplace?

title: PRESIDENT CHAMBERLAIN
description: The Administration and its supporters love to invoke the Anglo-French appeasement policies of the 1930's to beat down critics of their defense program. Anyone who dares criticize the huge military buildup is drowned in cries of ''Munich'' and likened to Neville Chamberlain. This is a political hard sell that seeks to substitute emotional symbols for informed debate. Indeed, the symbolism is particularly inappropriate, for the real lessons of the 1930's run counter to Ronald Reagan's case.

title: SAVORING POULE AU POT IN FRANCE
description: ANN BARRY is on the staff of the Arts and Leisure section of The Times.

title: SOME TRIED AND OFTEN TRUE WAYS OF REMOVING STUCK SCREWS
description: ANYONE who has ever taken apart an old cabinet or an old piece of furniture, and anyone who has ever tried to remove a rusty screw from wood, metal or plastic, soon discovers that screws don't always come out as easily as they originally went in. All too often the screw just won't budge, no matter how much pressure you apply to the screwdriver - the screw seems to be almost welded in place.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article April 24 on enforcement of the Surface Mining and Reclamation Act incorrectly identified H. Alma Hepner. She is director of Congressional and public relations in the office of the special counsel, United States Merit Systems Protection Board.

title: CRIME
description: Apparently there is a demand for Robert Barnard's mysteries, as well there should be. The man is one of the deftest stylists in the field (and out). His second mystery, A LITTLE LOCAL MURDER (Scribners, $11.95), which was published in England in 1976, has just been issued in America. His first, ''Death of an Old Goat,'' came out in 1974, and perhaps we shall be getting that one of these days.

title: Correction
description: In the About Books and Authors column of April 17, a letter Ernest Hemingway wrote about ''West With the Night'' by Beryl Markham was said to have been addressed to Malcolm Cowley. This information, which was supplied by the book's publisher, was incorrect. The letter was addressed to Maxwell Perkins.

title: ANNE K. WILCOX, TEACHER, IS WED TO P.D. RAYMOND
description: Anne Keating Willcox, daughter of Mrs. Francis A. Lewis of Malvern, Pa., and Mt. Desert, Me., and the late John K. Willcox, also of Malvern, was married yesterday to Peter Dana Raymond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Merriam Raymond of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Richard W. Hess performed the ceremony at Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: Maura H. Oz to Wed Ens. John Nankervis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sermi N. Oz of New York and Istanbul, Turkey, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maura Helene Oz, to Ens. John Thomas Nankervis Jr., U.S.N., son of Comdr.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FAITHFUL BEAN, FROM PLOT TO POT
description: IT has long been my theory that simple foods are often the best, and that heavily seasoned dishes originated as a means of covering up for rancidness or poor quality. Having recently received as a gift a plastic bag containing two cupfuls of dried beans, I had a chance to test this theory.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article from New Delhi on March 13 incorrectly described Vanuatu's position on the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. In 1981, the South Pacific island nation supported a United Nations General Assembly resolution calling for the withdrawal of foreign troops. In 1982, it was absent from the vote on a similar resolution, but subsequently announced support for it.

title: PRESSURES BUILD FOR ARMS CONTROL PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON IN the chess play of arms negotiations, Soviet leader Yuri V. Andropov tried last week to one-up President Reagan by offering to limit not only nuclear missiles and bombers in the European theater but also the number of warheads.

title: Richard Einhorn Weds Miss Sachs
description: Carolyn Sachs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan M. Sachs of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard L. Einhorn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Einhorn of Livingston, N.J. Acting Village Justice Herbert Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Sachs home.

title: Killanin Critical of U.S.
description: Lord Killanin, former president of the International Olympic Committee, says in his memoirs that the United States showed ''arrogance'' in its decision to boycott the 1980 Summer Games in Moscow because of the Soviet move into Afghanistan.

title: No Headline
description: Never has an article touched me as did the story about Eleni.

title: Education Article Held Ill-Founded
description: Prof. Jackson Toby's Opinion Page thoughts (April 3) on reducing the age of compulsory attendance to 15, especially for the violenceprone student, have some merits.

title: New York Times Magazine May 8, 1983
description: William Safire 10 On Language Pseudo Salestalk Russell Baker 16 Sunday Observer The Hardest Word Marie Winn 18 The Loss of Childhood The Age of Protection, in which children were to be treated as innocents, is a memory for most families today. Joseph Lelyveld 32 Oppenheimer of South Africa Archcapitalist and would-be reformer, Harry Oppenheimer strives for ''constructive engagement'' between apartheid and the blacks.

title: TRENTON WEIGHING ENTERPRISE ZONES
description: TRENTON ''WE WILL neglect our cities to our peril,'' President John F. Kennedy told Congress in 1962, ''for in neglecting them we neglect the nation.''

title: L.I. VILLAGE ACTS TO KEEP ITS WATERFRONT CLEAR OF HOUSEBOATS
description: When Robert Ciano's crews began building big houseboats at dockside in this old factory village, some people worried that he was transforming their community into ''Hong Kong on the Patchogue River.''

title: BOSSY'S 4 LEAD ISLANDERS INTO FINAL
description: The Islanders, their regular season sometimes good, occasionally bad and often indifferent, rolled into their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup final tonight with an impressive 8-4 victory over the Boston Bruins before a crowd of 15,317 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mason's 204 Leads Golf; Ballesteros 3 Shots Back
description: Britain's Carl Mason shot a twounder-par 70 today in the $70,000 French Open golf tournament and took a three-stroke lead after three rounds.

title: BY BARBARA GERBASI
description: AS I stand by the open door, the chill of the predawn air causes me to wrap my robe a bit tighter. The haze of sleep still hovers as I watch my daughter pack her car. She comes in to say goodbye. ''Drive carefully,'' I caution, ''and don't forget to call when you get there.''

title: IN SEARCH OF PUERTO RICAN SANTOS
description: LOUIS UCHITELLE is an assistant business and financial editor of The New York Times.

title: MISS KINNEY IS MARRIED
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan yesterday Deirdre Kinney was married to David Brian Brennan by the Rev. Peter Dillon. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Kinney and Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Brennan, all of Bronxville, N.Y. The bridegroom's father is senior executive vice president of Bloomingdale's.

title: NEEDED: A BETTER JOBS BILL
description: Six former Secretaries of Labor - three who served under Republicans, three under Democrats - recently wrote to President Reagan to express deep concern about the unemployment situation and its consequences. We think our letter's points and suggestions merit a wide audience, especially in view of its bipartisan sponsorship.

title: OLD FERRYBOAT IN A NEW ROLE
description: EDGEWATER ON APRIL 3, 1905, the ferryboat Binghamton started shuttling between Hoboken and Barclay Street, in lower Manhattan. Today, the old steam double-ender is still afloat and moored in Edgewater. However, she is now a restaurant - in fact, two restaurtants - and moves only when tides and currents nudge her.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC The week in music will celebrate the old and the new. Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House, Edward Aldwell plays the third and last of his Bach piano recitals this season. Mr. Aldwell's Bach is an unusually effective blend of heart and mind (he is a musicologist and theorist as well as a performer), and Sunday night's program features two of Bach's most formidable works - The Goldberg Variations and the French Overture.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The violinist Mihaela Martin, 24 years old and a native of Bucharest, won the 1982 International Violin Competition of Indianapolis. The judges chose well: Miss Martin combines the technical perfection our musical Zeitgeist demands with a distinct artistic personality in the grand tradition. Her performance last Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, with the worthy pianist Paul Ostrovsky, must be counted as one of the most exciting debut concerts of the year.

title: FLORIO AND STAFF PURSUE E.P.A. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON THE headlines have shrunk and the whirlwind of activity has subsided to a steady breeze, but Representative James J.Florio and his staff continue to look into the workings of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: PLANT GIVING WAY TO SHOPPING CENTER
description: For years, Bernard J. Rosenshein, a New Rochelle, N.Y., developer who specializes in shopping centers, drove past the huge Reynolds Aluminum plant at 47 Longbrook Avenue in Stratford, Conn., and wondered how he could acquire the property. He believed it was was ideal for commercial redevelopment because of its proximity to growing residential communities in Fairfield County.

title: Turkish President Warns Voting Could Be Delayed
description: Turkey's military President, apparently trying to discourage activities by former political leaders, warned today that elections scheduled for next November might be delayed.

title: DAMASCUS APPEARS TO REBUFF SHULTZ ON PULLOUT PLAN
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today appeared to rebuff efforts by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to win Syria's consent for an early withdrawal of its troops from Lebanon along with those of Israel.

title: Jews and Business
description: To the Business Editor: The article ''Jews in the Corporate Establishment'' (April 24) confirms the research of the American Jewish Committee, which has been a pioneer in efforts to identify and eradicate discrimination against Jews in the corporate world.

title: BRITAIN IS SLOWLY IMPROVING ITS AGING U.S.-BACKED FORCE
description: LONDON THE core of Britain's nuclear strike force is four nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarines, all built in the late 1960's and christened with vigorously martial names: Resolution, Repulse, Renown and Revenge.

title: A NEWCOMER IN CHARGE OF THE C.F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON FOR a brief period last year, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission celebrated a small milestone. The agency, long under fire for its administrative woes and inefficiencies, actually had a full complement of five commissioners, something that had occurred only once before, at its founding seven years ago.

title: ITALIAN GLOOMY OVER MIDEAST PEACE PROSPECTS
description: Italy's Foreign Minister, returning from a tour of the Middle East, has painted a gloomy picture of the outlook for peace in both the Arab-Israeli conflict and in the war between Iran and Iraq.

title:
ANTIQUES;
AN ENGLISH ACCENT IN SUSSEX
description: ANDOVER WITH more than a dozen dealers on hand, this Sussex County town offers a wide variety of antiques, from American country and formal furnishings to jewelry, dolls, clocks and folk art.

title: IMMIGRANT HELD FOR 31 YEARS AS MENTALLY ILL GETS $400,000
description: A Federal jury has awarded $400,000 to a 53-year-old Chinese immigrant who contended he was locked in state mental hospitals for three decades without being treated by anyone who spoke his language.

title: BROOKLYN, BOROUGH OF WRITERS
description: For writers, Brooklyn has never been primarily the borough of the Bridge. Borough of churches, borough of nostalgia, borough of hope (for Dodgers fans), it is above all a piece of geography or, if you prefer, a considerable piece of real estate. Literary visitors have found it an urban alternative to Manhattan's desperate pursuit of the present. Djuna Barnes found work here contributing to The Brooklyn Eagle. Edmund Wilson discovered the erotic life of the working class in Brighton Beach. James Agee saw Brooklyn as a vast domestic spectacle. To Thomas Wolfe it was a mystery that only the dead truly knew.

title: BARBARA MARTIN WEDS FREDERICK H. TAYLOR JR.
description: Barbara Carol Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester N. Martin of Baltimore was married yesterday to Frederick Harvey Taylor Jr., son of Dr. Frederick H. Taylor and Rita G. Taylor, both of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. James P. Farmer Jr. performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Baltimore.

title: THE MANY TRAPS IN HIGH-TECH
description: WHEN the Columbia space shuttle lifted off its launching pad last N ovember to put into orbit a communications satellite, the spirits of5 0 employees at the Orrox Corporation shot up, too. After toiling in t he lab for two years, they were ready to produce earth stations thatw ould pick up television programming beamed by the satellite.

title: A PLACE FOR SOCCER'S WORLD CUP
description: ACCUSATIONS fly between continents, carried in the newsprint of m any languages. International figures hiss at one another in public a nd political cartoonists gleefully parody everyone involved.

title: COUNTY STUDENTS VISIT CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON DAVIDA HOROWITZ had a busy day in Washington on Tuesday. At 9:30 A.M. she had an appointment at the White House. Two hours later she met with her Congressman on the floor of the House of Representatives to talk about plans for construction of a museum on the Mall to commemorate the Holocaust. After an impromptu photo session outside the Capitol, she made a brief stop at the Supreme Court, hurried across town to meet with a lobbyist, visited the Vietnam Memorial, and then, just to prove that she's not all work and no fun, Davida took in a show at the Ford Theater.

title: WHERE THE CHEERS ARE ONLY SEEN
description: WHITE PLAINS WITH two outs and a runner on third, Janice Bryan knows she must not let another run score if her softball team from the New York School for the Deaf is to have a chance of winning. On her next pitch, the batter hits a hard line drive that seems destined for center field, but Miss Bryan picks the ball out of midair to end the inning.

title: Express Defeats Breakers
description: Mike Rae connected with Kris Haines for a 6-yard touchdown pass with 18 seconds left to give the Los Angeles Express a 23-20 United States Football League victory over the Boston Breakers tonight.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FAITHFUL BEAN, FROM PLOT TO POT
description: IT has long been my theory that simple foods are often the best, and that heavily seasoned dishes originated as a means of covering up for rancidness or poor quality. Having recently received as a gift a plastic bag containing two cupfuls of dried beans, I had a chance to test this theory.

title: 'OTHER VIC' TAKES DRAMA ON THE ROAD
description: WHEN Alana Caraccio and Frank Scoblete hit upon the name ''The Other Vic Theater Company'' for the troupe they founded 18 months ago, they did it more with tongue in cheek than eye on lofty ideal.

title: KAREN HONEY ASNIN WED TO PAUL WHITBY, A LAWYER
description: Karen Honey Asnin and Paul G. Whitby were married yesterday in Le Club in New York by Rabbi Charles D. Lippman.

title: RURAL VOTE LOOMS LARGE FOR AFRIKANERS
description: It seemed the kind of boast that a big-shot politician tries out on his small-town constituents when he senses they may not be as impressed with him as they used to be. But even in the remote reaches of the northern Transvaal, where white South African politics have a rough-hewn quality reminiscent of west Texas, the note struck by a Cabinet minister in computerized letters to his voters sounded forced. ''The eyes of the world,'' he wrote, ''are on Soutpansberg! Let no man or woman stand idly aside.''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF anyone has a good idea about what to do with a 143-year-old, 19-room mansion that is sitting vacant on North Main Street in Wallingford, an advisory committee appointed by the Wallingford Town Council would like to hear it.

title: WHEN MUSICIANS OF RIDGEFIELD UNITE
description: WHO says they can't go on meeting this way? For 11 years now, the professionals of the Ridgefield Orchestra and the high schoolers of the Ridgefield Youth Orchestra have been joining in happy spring conclave, their May 15 concert preceded by a day of intensive rehearsals, and followed by a dinner tendered by the musicians' parents.

title: THE COLLEGE SPORT CRISIS
description: WITH all the ''crises'' plaguing intercollegiate athletics, it is particularly important to recognize what is a true crisis demanding our attention, and what isn't.

title: DISCREET CHARM IN DECORATION
description: The news in le beau monde that one within its ranks has put his house into Mark Hampton's hands is apt to be received with approving nods and subtle sighs of relief. Hampton, a prominent practitioner of the somewhat suspect profession of interior decorating, is a man who inspires confidence. One can be certain that with him, there will be no embarrassing surprises, no outlandish departures from received good taste. The results will be stylish, very probably even stimulating, but always discreet.

title: CARRIE SHAW DOREMUS WEDS JOHN LINDSAY KEATING
description: Carrie Shaw Doremus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clinton Doremus of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to John Lindsay Keating, son of Mrs. Joseph M. White of Little Silver, N.J., and James M. Keating of Sea Girt, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson by the Rev. Daniel Degnan, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by the Rev. Ronald P. Jaynes, an Episcopal priest.

title: STUDY TELLS HOW 14 STATES RESPONDED TO AID CUTS
description: After the Reagan Administration pushed through deep cuts in Federal domestic programs for 1982, many states reacted by making cuts of their own, according to the first detailed national study of the effect of the budget changes.

title: TELEPORT PROJECT HITS A LEGAL SNAG
description: A $225 million satellite communications center on Staten Island, described by Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper as one of the biggest proposed economic development projects in New York, is being subjected to a legal dispute.

title: HOW TO GET A PROPER APPRAISAL
description: FEW decisions connected with the selling of a home cause more a nxiety and uncertainty than the setting of an asking price. Aim too h igh, brokers and appraisers warn, and you may price yourself out of t he market. If you set the price too low and make a quick sale, you m ay be left with a nagging suspicion that you could have obtained t housands of dollars more.

title: ADDICT-DOCTORS GET AID UNDER GEORGIA PROGRAM
description: He was a 41-year-old drug addict and alcoholic who nervously twirled his mustache and rubbed his hand up and down his leg as he talked about his attempts to get treated. He told of month-long detoxification programs that were more like being locked up than being treated, and of being shown films on how you could die from abusing alcohol and drugs.

title: VARIETY SPICES THESE NEW SYMPHONIC RELEASES
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Willy Loman Is a Hit On the Peking Stage
description: Thirty-four years after he first appeared on Broadway, Willy Loman dragged his suitcase full of dreams across a Chinese stage today and moved an audience to tears in the Peking premiere of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman.''

title: THE PICTURE ON THE WALL AND MEMORIES OF JOE LOUIS
description: APICTURE on the wall in George Steinbrenner's office at Yankee S tadium started a few chains of thought, and these started a bit of r ooting through the record books: Joe Louis's birthday was May 13, 1 914, which means he would have been 69 years old on Friday if he h ad lived. This takes qualification. When the Brown Bomber was k nocking people down, it was widely held in actuarial circles that a ctually, he had been born a year earlier. The time warp would make h im 70 on May 13.

title: FESTIVAL OF FLOWERS TO HELP CHURCHES
description: ''IF of thy mortal goods thou art bereft,'' wrote Moslih Saadi, a 13th-century Persian poet, ''and from thy slender store, two loaves alone to thee are left, sell one and with the dole buy hyacinth to feed thy soul.''

title: HOW DRG BILLING WORKS
description: New Jersey is the first state to use the Diagnosis Related Groups - or DRG - billing system in all acute-care hospitals. Although many hospital administrators and doctors decry it, state Department of Health officials say it offers a chance to slow the increase in hospital costs.

title: Biscayne Bay in Full Bloom; With Christo's Giant 'Lilies'
description: The artist Christo's giant ''lilies'' of shocking pink plastic, environmental art on a grand scale, reached full bloom today in a lazy channel of Biscayne Bay between Miami and Miami Beach.

title: Chicago Council Again Meets Without the Mayor's Consent
description: Mayor Harold Washington avoided a face-toface confrontation with a dissident City Council faction today by refusing to open a special session, but his opponents stayed and conducted business.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) International intrigue and secret negotiations between England and Russia on the eve of World War I: fiction. 2 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Stell. (Dell, $3.95.) A Korean War widow makes it as a career woman, a celebrity and a mother: fiction. 3 MY SWEET AUDRINA, by V.C. Andres. (Pocket, $3.95.) A young girl entrapped by the fears of her over-protective family: fiction. 4 THE THORN BIRDS, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) The saga of a 19th-century Australian family: basis of the television miniseries. 5 SO SPEAK THE HEART, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.). A beautiful noblewoman falls into the hands of a powerful and passionate knight: fiction. 6 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.50.)

title: Greenwich Publisher Named
description: Steven L. Isenberg has been appointed publisher of Greenwich Time and The Advocate, succeeding Jay A. Shaw. Mr. Shaw has been named a special assistant for national sales development for the newspapers' parent concern, the Times Mirror Company. Mr. Isenberg, a 42-year-old lawyer who served in the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay in New York, joined Newsday in January 1982 and had been assistant publisher. The appointments take effect May 30.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, 126th Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:30 P.M. (Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Minneapolis. The Yankees have won the final game of all nine series they have played this year. (Television - SportsChannel, 2:15 P.M. live and 8 P.M. tape. Radio -WABC, 770; 2:15 P.M.) Astros vs. Atlanta Braves at Houston (Television - WTBS 2 P.M.).

title: DR. ANNE ALLAN TO WED DR. S.N. WILSON
description: Dr. and Mrs. A. J. Gordon Allan of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Anne Elizabeth Allan, to Dr. Scott Numo Wilson, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Philip Wilson of New York.

title: BIG PICTURES THAT SAY LITTLE
description: With the exhibition ''Big Pictures,'' the Museum of Modern Art for the first time publicly takes notice of the state of photography in the 1980's. In the process it directly acknowledges, also for the first time, the profound effect that contemporary painting and sculpture have had on the medium since the mid-70's. The selection of 33 large-scale pictures by as many artists includes work by David Hockney, Sol LeWitt, Robert Rauschenberg, Kenneth Snelson and William Wegman - figures who have helped legitimize photography in the eyes of the art world by making it an adjunct of their oeuvres, but who have remained until now peripheral to the museum's account of the medium.

title: KETHERINE E. HAZLET WED TO
description: WILLIAM C. SCHMIDT 2D rine Ellen Hazlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hagerty Hazlett Jr., of Saunderstown, R.I., and Dorado Beach, P.R., was married yesterday to William Charles Schmidt 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilson Schmidt of Wayland, Mass. The Rev. John Hall performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Old Narragansett Church in Wickford, R.I.

title: EDUCATOR ASSERTS IMMIGRANTS DO NOT THREATEN JOB MARKET
description: New immigrants to New York City do not take employment away from native workers, but rather help keep certain kinds of businesses alive, according to a paper presented at New York University.

title: 'Hitler Diaries' Flunk Tests
description: The magazine Stern had the reddest face in the business and somebody somewhere was laughing all the way to the bank. These were the closest things to certainty last week after the West German Interior Ministry declared the recently ballyhooed ''Hitler diaries'' to be fakes.

title: THE TWILIGHT OF SMOKESTACK AMERICA
description: IT is quiet in Buffalo. No shoppers to speak of, no noon-hour rush to lunch, no bursts of traffic accelerating from stoplights, no movement on the Erie Canal, the artery that turned Buffalo from just another town to a thriving port. Buffalo is a fading steel city, a fading flour-milling city, a fading automobile-rubber-chemicalsbuilding supplies-machinery city.

title: BALLET: BOSTONIANS ON HOME GROUND
description: There are times when glamour and knock-'em-dead pyrotechnics take a back seat to sheer charm and the pleasures of intimacy. A performance on Thursday by the Boston Ballet at the Colonial Theater here was one of those times.

title: PAROLE BOARD ASKED FOR TRANTINO DATA
description: THE state's Parole Board, which turned down Thomas Trantino last November, has been ordered to explain why the convicted murderer should not be considered for release for at least nine years.

title: PRICE OF OIL IS A KEY TO COSTS OF MILLSTONE 3
description: THE General Assembly acted last month to limit the future cost to consumers of the Millstone 3 nuclear plant, now almost 80 percent completed in Waterford. But factors largely beyond the lawmakers' control - falling oil prices and past inflation - mean that the reactor's completion will raise the bills of most electric users in Connecticut sharply, despite the new law.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: EDGAR SNOW'S CHINA: A Personal Account of the Chinese Revolution Compiled from the Writings of Edgar Snow. By Lois Wheeler Snow. (Vintage, $11.95.) Edgar Snow's widow has selected excerpts from the books, diaries, letters and articles he wrote in and about China between 1928 and 1949 and combined them with several hundred photographs (most of them from the same period) ''to provide some first-hand insight on the why and how of the birth of the People's Republic of China.'' The smiling face above belongs to Mao Zedong, who was snapped while attending an exhibition of agricultural and industrial products.

title: SYMPATHY IS NEEDED
description: ''THERE isn't a day that goes by that something doesn't trigger off a tear or two,'' Kathy says. ''There are days that are a lot worse than others.''

title: 'PANIC' IN SUFFOLK? THAT'S AN INSULT
description: AS if we Long Islanders didn't have enough supposed shortcomings to reckon with, now we're being put down as a hysterical mob, particularly those who live in the East End. It wouldn't be so bad if we could attribute the slurs to the jealousy of weekenders, but when they come from our country leaders (and I use the word loosely), we'd better blow the whistle.

title: On the Other Side
description: William Harris, the self-styled revolutionary who went to prison after pleading guilty to the 1974 kidnapping of Patricia Hearst, is working within the system these days. His lawyer said last week that Mr. Harris had been released on parole in April and was living and working as a legal aide somewhere in Alameda County, Calif. Mr. Harris and his wife, Emily, were members of a group called the Symbionese Liberation Army. Mrs. Harris also pleaded guilty to the kidnapping, and both were sentenced to from 10 years and eight months to life. She was expected to be released on parole later this month.

title: FOR MORE INFORMATION ON BIRTHPARENTS GROUP
description: We found the April 10 About Westchester column, "Hello, I'm Your Mother," to be an excellent description of how the mutual-aid group Concerned United Brithparents is helping parents who surrendered a child for adoption find support. We would like to note that the C.U.B. group is available to any parent who has surrendered a child for adoption and is interested in hearing from anyone wishing to become a member. More information can be obtained by calling the Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse at 347-3620, Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: AS PLAYLAND REOPENS, COUNTY PONDERS ITS OPTIONS
description: acre amusement and recreation park on Long Island Sound, is scheduled to open officially on Saturday for the start of its 56th year - one the county's budget refers to as a year of transition.

title: CONSUMER RATES
GARMENT WORKERS PUSH FOR CHANGES
description: MOUNT VERNON BETWEEN them, they represent 71 years of service in the garment industry in the county. Pasqualina Barbara, a diminutive, gray-haired woman with matching gray eyes, started working as a dressmaker in a Mount Vernon factory in 1933, at the age of 14. Judite Tavares, a soft-spoken Portuguese native, immigrated to America with her parents in 1961 at the age of 21, and began working as a floor girl in a textile factory a year later.

title: ANGELA INGRAO, A CHEF, MARRIES JEFFREY POWERS
description: Angela Marie Ingrao, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Ingrao of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Reid Powers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Powers of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Johns Island, Fla. The ceremony was performed at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral by Auxiliary Bishop Patrick V. Ahern of Staten Island and the Rev. James S. Conlan, director of the Parish Mission Team of New York.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: An Ultimatum For Indian Point

title: SUSAN BURGOYNE ALLEN WEDS STEPHEN HINTON
description: Susan Burgoyne Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Burford Allen of Houston and Rehoboth Beach, Del., was married to Stephen Fitts Hinton, son of Mrs. William Addison Rank of Waialua, Oahu, Hawaii, and Colonel John Hinton Jr., U.S.A., retired, of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Howard B. Kishpaugh performed the ceremony in the chapel of the St. Alban's School, of which the bridegroom is an alumnus, in Washington, assisted by the Rev. Elwyn Brown.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP/JAZZ John Martyn appeared on the British folk scene of the 1960's with a burry, smoky voice, atmospheric songs and an acoustic guitar style that interwove British folk tunes and ragtime's percussiveness. Then he began investigating the electric guitar, which could be plugged into an echo machine to create ricocheting rhythms, or fed through distortion devices to sound like a giant set of bagpipes.

title: Expos Set Back Phillies, 3-2
description: Tim Raines hit a single to score Doug Flynn, a pinch-runner, with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning today to give the Montreal Expos a 3-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The loss ended a three-game winning streak by the Phillies.

title: PETER O'TOOLE RISES FROM THE ASHES
description: Peter O'Toole is sitting in a Plaza Hotel suite, chain-smoking Gauloise cigarettes in a jaunty black holder, sipping tea and talking about his ''second coming.'' The words have a dual meaning, because they refer both to his controversial 1972 film, ''The Ruling Class,'' which has been re-released by Embassy Pictures and is now playing at Loews New York Twin, and to his own life as well.

title: BERLIOZ'S JINXED 'CELLINI' GETS ANOTHER CHANCE
description: The word fiasco, indispensable though it is to the hard-pressed critic, has been cheapened by overuse. Operatic history is littered with examples of famous flops, but there have been only a handful of genuine fiascos, failures so stunning that only the stubbornest of composers could recover from them. The first Paris performance of ''Tannhauser'' in 1861 was such a temporarily crushing blow for Wagner. Nearly as daunting for Puccini was the jeering of ''Madama Butterfly'' in 1904. The hooting reception awarded to ''Guntram'' in 1894 left permanent scars on the psyche of Richard Strauss. To rank as a genuine fiasco, an opera must be more than a passing scandal. It must divert, if only temporarily, the course of genius.

title: Cows, Instead of Broken Glass
description: ''I remember that it was meeting you and your family that changed a lot of things in my life. It gave me drive.''

title: WHY VIOLENCE PERVADES HIS BOOKS
description: WHEN he was in his early teens, the novelist Eric Van Lustbader witnessed a man brutally beaten on the streets of lower Manhattan. ''I'll never forget that scene,'' he said. ''I felt horrified. I was outraged at not being able to do more than call the police.'' The fact that acts of violence figure strongly in Mr. Lustbader's novels -often in the form of ritualistic murder - may seem surprising from one who professes a deep aversion to them.

title: Q & A WITH THE NEW BUILDING CHIEF
description: Robert A. Esnard has been the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Buildings for a month. Prior to that he was vice president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, deputy borough president of the Bronx and director of the city planning office in that borough. In an interview, he discussed his assessment of the tasks ahead of him.

title: No Headline
description: Shoreham Plant: 'Why All the Fuss?' I live four miles from the Shoreham nuclear plant. I lived here 15 years ago when building began.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE BOOK OF PIGERICKS Pig Limericks. Written and illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 48 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (Ages 5 and Up)The talented Arnold Lobel Personifies pigs very well, Has wit, a good ear, And reveres Mr. Lear.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.Source: HSH Associates

title: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE FOOTLIGHTS
description: MARIAN SELDES, an actress and writer, is the author of ''The Bright Lights: A Theater Life'' and a novel, ''Time Together,'' both published by Houghton Mifflin.

title: WASHINGTON PUTS INDIAN POINT ON NOTICE
description: When the nuclear power industry started, things were much simpler. Washington would grant the permits to build the plants, and keep an eye on operators to assure safety. The states would regulate the utilities that owned the plants, setting rates for the power they produced. And localities would sit back and collect the taxes.

title: BUT LET'S LIMIT THE BREAK
description: WHILE I agree with both the Keynesian and supply-side economists that the scheduled tax cut is n eeded to sustain the recovery, I believe that a modest adjustment c an be made that will make it both more effective and more equitable.L et's place an upper limit of $500 on the size of the tax cut, so t hat people with very high incomes will not get inordinate tax r eductions, while those at middle or lower income levels will get thef ull 10 percent reduction.

title: SUSAN POOR, HOSPICE AIDE, AND RICHARD S. SPEAR WED
description: Susan Poor and Richard Steven Spear were married yesterday by the Rev. Ann Tyndall, a Unitarian minister, at Stillwater Cover Ranch, an inn in Jenner, Calif.

title: Model Student
description: Apparently all 1,100 members of Princeton University's class of 1987 will be given movie roles, modeling contracts and lucrative television commercials.

title: DEBATE ON HAMPTONS AIRPORT: IS IT JUST FOR THE WEATHLY FEW?
description: FROM time to time, in the course of its 47-year history, the small East Hampton Town Airport has inspired the expansion-minded to come up with plans for a more elaborate facility. The idea has, in fact, been considered and rejected by four previous Town Boards. Though disappointing to backers, the defeats may not have been particularly surprising; the costs of expansion, both in dollars and in potential harm to the environment, were bound to present obstacles.

title: S.V. SARLE WEDS MISS DANNENBERG
description: Linda Jane Dannenberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eli Mercer Dannenberg of New Seabury, Mass., was married in Manhattan last evening to Steven Vaughan Sarle, son of Sherwood Vaughan Sarle of Whitesboro, N.Y., and the late Doris Fairchild Sarle. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel and the Rev. Scott Metheny, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

title: WHAT BRINGS OUT THE CROWD? EVERYTHING
description: AT Bloomingdale's in Garden City on a wet and blustery day, a small legion of well-dressed women camped outside the store at 8:30 A.M., awaiting the arrival of a television anchorwoman who was to give a talk.

title: THE RIFT OVER PROTECTING THE CONSUMER
description: WASHINGTON ''M R. S. lost his job and was unable to keep up the loan payments,'' begins a case history from the Legal Aid Society. ''The creditor is now seizing the car and household furnishings. They are taking the furniture several pieces at a time on different days. Essentially, they appear to be doing this to force Mr. S. to make payments on the loan.''

title: THE HARDEST WORD
description: One of the worst mistakes I ever made was throwing away a brochure from an agent - I think he was based in Wisconsin - who was trying to establish himself in a unique business. If you retained his services, he would say, ''No,'' for you. That's all he did to earn his fee - he said, ''No.''

title: METS FAIL, AFTER 6-0 DEFICIT
description: The Mets rallied from a 6-0 deficit in the last two innings last night but fell short and lost, 7-5, to the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium.

title: FLYING LUXURY FOODS TO TABLES IN U.S.
description: A year and a half ago, Walter Martin and his partners Paul Moriates and Andrew Udelson arranged for a Dutch supplier to send 22 pounds of fresh Dover sole by air to New York. The fish arrived within 24 hours after it was caught, they sold it to Andre Soltner at Lutece and their fledgling company, Flying Foods, was in business.

title: 2 Rookie Generals Grateful
description: When it comes to vocations anticipated and vocations achieved not often does a child of suburbia, like a Steve Hammond or a John Joyce, wind up as a pro football linebacker. There are too many obstacles and options along the way, but Hammond and Joyce persisted against considerable odds, and they have opened careers for themselves with the New Jersey Generals.

title: U. (ULTIMATE) F. (FRISBEE) O. (OUTING)
description: THE smell of Ben Gay hung heavily over the playing field of the State University of New York at Purchase last weekend, and more than a few athletes limped away from the first Eastern Collegiate Ultimate championship. When the last disk had been thrown, the University of Massachusetts had defeated a team from Glassboro State College, 11-8. Thus ''Zoo Disk,'' as the Amherst team is known, became the Eastern Collegiate champion, after playoffs involving 14 colleges.

title: Close Call for Gary's Mayor
description: Convincing voters that City Hall has little control over their economic woes - or in the case of Gary, Ind., over competition from foreign steel mills - is sometimes no easy matter.

title: WHY THE WRITING HAD TO STOP
description: HAMMETT, A Life at the Edge. By William F. Nolan. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $16.95.

title: PARTICIPATORY NOVELS
description: When involved in a particularly vexing mystery, Sherlock Holmes would shoot a revolver into a wall, play his violin or take drugs. Hercule Poirot would drink hot chocolate and wax his mustache. Lord Peter Wimsey had his bottle of port and his attentive manservant.

title: HOSPITALS SHOULD SUPPORT THE HEALTHY
description: THE word ''hospital'' evokes many images and many emotions in the minds of all of us. I daresay few have an identical set of images. To some, the word ''hospital'' means high technology - CAT scanners, complicated computerized diagnostic equipment, operating rooms and beeping heart monitors. To others, the word conjures images of ambulances and rushing people in white uniforms handling crowded emergency-room situations. To still others, it means the security of a clean, quiet hospital bed, with warm food, a caring physician in attendance, and a skilled, reassuring nurse watching over one, day and night.

title: Decision '88
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GORGE RISES
description: What should this country do to try to change the system of racial discrimination in South Africa? That issue of politics and conscience is boiling up again: on the campuses, in state houses and city halls, in Congress. For the Reagan Administration, it is awkward news.

title: Correction
description: The photograph of Nora Ephron that appeared in the issue of April 24 was taken by Jill Krementz.

title: BEYOND GRETZKY, THE OILERS' LINEUP IS 19 MEN DEEP
description: AT first glance it seemed a familiar post-game locker room scene. Nineteen Edmonton Oilers showered and dressed without fanfare while the press swarmed about a 20th, who patiently answered all questions. So in demand was this star, that he did not even have a chance to get out of his sweat-drenched uniform. But it soon became clear that something was different. The young man who sat exhausted in his cubicle was not Wayne Gretzky, the National Hockey League's most valuable player in each of his three seasons, but a goalie named Andy Moog.

title: Jurors Clear General Motors In '78 Crash in Which 6 Died
description: A jury has cleared the General Motors Corporation of responsibility for an automobile crash five years ago in which five members of a family and a truck drive were killed.

title: Texan Is Yachting Long Shot
description: One way to catch John Kolius's attention is to tell him there is something he can't do. The quiet, slender sailor with the Texas twang seems to find a way of overcoming the impossible.

title: John Williams Is Dead at 80; Stage, Screen and TV Actor
description: John Williams, a British-born actor who played the consummate gentleman in a half-century of roles on stage, screen and television, is dead at the age of 80.

title: RATE FORMULA COST COUNTY $4 MILLION
description: DESPITE its population declines during the last decade, the county as a whole would have gained more than $4 million in state revenuesharing funds this fiscal year if 1980 census figures, rather than the 1970 figures, had been used to calculate the disbursement.

title: COZY AMBIENCE IN RIDGEFIELD
description: IT has been three years since our last visit to The Elms, a restaurant with five cozy dining rooms in an 18th-century white clapboard house on Ridgefield's main street. We approached this time with a certain anxiety. Our previous two meals had been unforgettable -not for their culinary distinction but for the snailpaced, careless service. Memories of an unfortunate Mother's Day when dinner took an interminable three and a half hours were still painfully vivid.

title: TB RECORDS A RISE, WITH 67 CASES IN '82
description: consumption, a disease that during the 19th century killed up to 20 percent of the population before the age of 50. The disease is now called tuberculosis and has become a highly curable condition when treated with powerful drugs for nine to 18 months.

title:
LEISURE;
SOMETIMES ELEGANT WISTERIA MUST BE COAXED TO FLOWER
description: Eric Rosenthal is a freelance writer.

title:
IF FRANCE'S ATOMIC ARSENAL IS A JOKE, IT'S GROWING LESS FUNNY ALL THE TIME;
PARIS
description: IN the calculations of cataclysm, the French nuclear forces have always been a small joke, but the humor is basically misguided. Having a means of nuclear deterrence not only gives the French the theoretical possibility of wiping out 30 Soviet cities. Every Government since Charles de Gaulle introduced the force de frappe in the 1960's has also understood that an independent French atomic arsenal means a French say, or at least the necessity to take France into account, when people talk about how the world is going to be run.

title: No Headline
description: This past summer, I visted my pappou's village of Elatohori. There, I listened to my relatives' accounts of their experiences during World War II and the subsequent Civil War.

title: REPUBLICANS THINK BETTER OF TANGLING WITH DEFICITS
description: As the White House and Congress grappled with the 1984 Federal Budget last week, something remarkable became clear. The crisis atmosphere that had surrounded all the deliberations for months had somehow lifted. Few in the Reagan Administration or in the Republican Congressional leadership were talking anymore about the need for drastic action to close deficits projected as extending indefinitely in the future.

title: DEATHS OF TWO CHIEFS EXPOSE RIFTS AMONG SALVADOR REBELS
description: Events surrounding the deaths of two Salvadoran guerrilla leaders here last month offer rare glimpses into the intense differences within the Marxist guerrilla movement and its sometimes difficult dealings with Nicaragua's leftist Government.

title: AND ZEBRA STRIPES AND CHOCOLATE BARS
description: HEN'S TEETH AND HORSE'S TOES, By Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $15.50.

title: Complaints in Receivership
description: Question: For years I have been the tenant in a rent-controlled apartment. Last year the building was placed in receivership. There is severe rain damage to my apartment and the ceiling has fallen in. What recourse do I have? ... J.R., Manhattan Answer: Harry Michelson, general counsel of the Rent Control Division, points out that a receiver is a court appointee. He believes you should address complaints to the court that appointed the receiver, and that this may require hiring a lawyer. You can also file a complaint with your District Rent Office at 2 Lafayette Street, phone 566-7970.

title: Insider's Tale At Brink's Trial
description: After a violent underground odyssey that included several armed robberies and a prison break, Tyrone Rison surfaced last week as the chief prosecution witness in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan. In several days of testimony, he described a group that called itself ''the Family,'' maintained ''safe houses,'' was heavily armed and, he said, ''felt like doing robberies and turning the money over to the black people.''

title: The Right to Walk Around
description: Edward Lawson contended that California police had no right to treat him like a nobody just because he refused to say who he was.

title: BOSSY STILL GETS THRILL FROM GOALS
description: He is not a machine, even though his goal-production rate might make it look that way. Mike Bossy scored four goals for the Islanders in their 8-4 playoff victory over the Boston Bruins tonight, and someone asked him afterward if such feats still excited him.

title: Girl Becomes 4th to Die From Chinatown Blaze
description: A 9-year-old girl died yesterday morning at Bellevue Hospital, the fourth victim of a fire that swept two buildings in Chinatown Friday. The Fire Department said the girl, Fiorita Fernandez Leung, was probably asleep on the third floor of the building at 38 East Broadway when the fire began at about 12:45 A.M.

title: CUOMO ASSUMES ACTIVE ROLE AS PARTY LEADER
description: Governor Cuomo, who won the gubernatorial nomination over the opposition of the state's Democratic organization, is now taking an active role in the party leadership and using his son Andrew as his chief link to the party.

title: MATTHEW KOVNER AND MISS CHESLER TO MARY JULY 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Chesler of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Aimee Chesler, to Matthew Robert Kovner, son of Albert Kovner of West Roxbury, Mass., and Ruth M. Kovner of New York.

title: Lewis Winner in 10.06
description: Carl Lewis ran the 100 meters in 10.06 seconds tonight at the Houston invitation track meet, the fastest time this year.

title: FOR DODD, GAIN IN A COUNTERPOINT
description: SENATOR Christopher J. Dodd flushed noticeably last week when asked whether he had any ambitions to run for Vice President, now that national attention has focused on him following his televised rebuttal to President Reagan's recent address on Central America.

title: KEEP CHURCH AND STATE APART
description: THE FACT that Thomas Jefferson's birthday (April 13 was his 240th) is not celebrated with sales at used-car lots and discount houses - the way we honor Washington and Lincoln -would not, I think, perturb our third President.

title: AT AGE 27, A DREAM OF ADOLESCENCE COME TRUE
description: BASEBALL is an American sport and it is the stuff of the American Dream, the rise from sandlot to stadium. Dan Lovallo is living a variation of that fantasy.

title: SPACE NEED PINCHES COLLEGES
description: AT the end of the current semester, the Adelphi School of Social Work will have to vacate the quarters it has rented for seven years from Hofstra University. The facility, called The Mods, was originally built as a 200-bed dormitory, and Hofstra's present need for this space points to the success of the school's aggressive recruiting campaign for out-of-town students.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL TO SEEK WIDELY EDUCATED STUDENTS
description: A new admissions program to encourage future physicians to pursue a broader undergraduate education is to be announced tomorrow by the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, one of the country's most prestigious medical schools.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: AN OFFICER at the Naval Air Engineering Center in Lakehurst has informed the state's Department of Environmental Protection that 36 drums of carbon tetrachloride, a cancer-causing chemical, may be buried beneath what is now a Little League field next to the center.

title: AS MAMA LAY DYING: REMEMBRANCES OF THINGS PAST
description: I SIT by her bed and watch my mother dying. "It's just a matter of hours," they say. My sisters will be here soon. I look at her face. It's remarkably uncreased. Peaceful. Almost like a child's.

title: JEWS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: I find the article on ''Jews in the Corporate Establishment'' most disturbing, in particular the tasteless anecdote related by Laurence Tisch equating Judaism with a hunchback's hump.

title: TWO OFFICES DEBATE CAR INSURANCE STUDY AWAITED BY CUOMO
description: A review ordered by Governor Cuomo in January of two state insurance regulations has not been done, and both the Insurance Department and the Governor's office say the other should have conducted it.

title: MUSIC: ENGLISH CONCERT
description: Last weekend New York had a chance to hear John Eliot Gardiner's Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists; and Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum, Britain presented us with another of its early music groups - the English Concert directed by Trevor Pinnock.

title: GAIL P. GIBSON MARRIES DANIEL GEORGE CIABURRI
description: Gail Patricia Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson Jr., of New York and Bogota, Colombia, was married yesterday to Daniel George Ciaburri, son of Marie A. Ciaburri of Middletown, Conn., and Daniel Hurley Ciaburri of Haddam, Conn. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Saint Thomas More Church in Manhattan.

title: JEWS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: The article might have asked why Jews - and for that matter blacks, Hispanics, women, and most 'hyphenated-Americans'' - seldom make their way up those slippery rungs of corporate success. I think that the bottom line remains the same as in the mid-1960's when H. Rap Brown remarked, ''Discrimination is as American as cherry pie.'' STEPHEN L. SLAVIN Associate Economics Professor Union County College Cranford, N.J., April 30

title: Upset in Richardson Golf
description: Brian Brown of Southward Ho in Bay Shore, L.I., upset the defending champion, George Zahringer 3d of Sands Point, on the 19th hole today to win the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament at the Seawane Club.

title: TIDE OF REFUGEES, AND SUFFERING, RISES ACROSS SALVADOR
description: Sitting in the dust that surrounds her makeshift hut in Chalatenango and staring blankly into space, Maria Alvarenga spoke quietly to a visitor recently about her forced flight from her village six weeks earlier.

title: THE HOLE IN ANDROPOV'S SPACE-WEAPONS TREATY
description: T o the Editor: I noted with interest your recent news article (April 28) about Yuri V. Andropov's letter to a group of American space and military specialists who favor banning a race in space weaponry. I believe it is important to take a critical look at what the Soviet leader has offered.

title: A ROMANTIC SOUTH PACIFIC
description: A SONG FOR SATAWAL By Kenneth Brower. 218 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: CONSERVATIONISTS NOW HELPING DEVELOPERS
description: SINCE 1964, the New Jersey Conservation Foundation has been one of t he most ardent protectors of the state's dwindling open spaces. It h as used its treasury to buy land threatened by development and hold i t until the state or a municipality raises the funds to secure it p ermanently as protected green space.

title: GEORGE SCHWOLSKY
description: George Schwolsky, a lawyer, former State Representative and judge, died Friday at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: When Michael Flannery was named grand marshal for New York City's St. Patrick's Day Parade last month, the Government of Ireland boycotted the parade, as did some American officials.

title: A TALK WITH ALBERTO MORAVIA
I.R.A. Victim's Body Found
description: The body of a man killed for reportedly informing to security forces was found today near the border of the Irish Republic, the police said. The Irish National Liberation Army, a leftist offshoot of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, said it shot the man for informing.

title: MARY ELLEN TOBIN AND WALLACE R. BAKER ARE WED
description: Mary Ellen Tobin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Tobin of New York and Saugerties, N.Y., was married yesterday to Wallace R. Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Boyce Baker of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Tenants Harbor, Me.

title:
TV VIEW;
THE RISE OF 'THE A-TEAM' GUARANTEES MORE VIOLENCE
description: The prevailing mood in the executive suites of NBC-TV these days is likely to be one of nervous jubilation. Providing cause for celebration, the network, running a poor third to ABC and CBS in the audience ratings for several years, has finally come up with the kind of big program hit that could signify a boost for the entire schedule.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR THE 100TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: A commemorative for the 100th anniversary of the completion of the Brooklyn Bridge, which is still one of the most picturesque of all the bridges that bind the greater New York area into a world metropolis, is being issued on May 17 in New York City.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The 'Nonpolitical' Mann

title: A TRIP TO THE DARK SIDE OF SPRING
description: ITHINK I have springitis and it's not the good kind. No romantic y earnings. No head-in-the-clouds fancy turning to love. For the m oment, at least, my head is turned to the dark side of spring and t his shadow, cast across the sunshine of the daffodils, is in my own b ackyard.

title: LONDON
description: Throughout his life, Noel Coward had his ups and downs in the stockmarket of public taste - on one occasion he was actually spat at by disappointed theatergoers in the London streets -and the arrival of John Osborne and kitchen-sink realism in 1956 sent his reputation plummeting lower than ever before. At a time when playwrights were expected to be socially responsible, morally rigorous and, in short, as puritanical as possible, he seemed to embody all the rudest words in the critical vocabulary: shallow, trivial, escapist.

title: Miss Olney Plans A June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Olney of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Forbes Olney, to James Atwood Knight, son of Richard B. Knight of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Atwood Knight of Providence, R.I.

title: SUNDAY, MAY 8, 1983
description: International Syria's President appeared to rebuff efforts by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to win Syria's consent for an early withdrawal of its troops from Lebanon. After a four-hour meeting in Damascus with President Hafez al-Assad, Mr. Shultz said that the Syrians ''are hardly enthusiastic about the agreement'' that Israel accepted in principle on Friday. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: CENSUS BUREAU FINDS WOMEN ARE PLANNING FEWER CHILDREN
description: Women are planning fewer children and gaining confidence in their ability to turn those plans into reality, according to a new Census Bureau report.

title: The Ayatollah's Other Satan
description: One of the West's biggest fears about Iran has been that the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's hatred for the United States might give the Soviet Union an opportunity it never had with the Shah. But last week, Moscow's effort to move in on the revolution collapsed with the ouster of 18 Soviet diplomats from Teheran and the outlawing of the Communist Tudeh Party.

title: 'MAYERLING' IS AN UNEXPECTED SUCCESS
description: In January, 1889, Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria-Hungary, son of the Emperor Franz Josef, is presumed to have shot dead Mary Vetsera, his 17-year-old mistress, and then committed suicide. These events took place at a Hapsburg hunting lodge at Mayerling, a name familiar from more than one film about the subject and also the title of Kenneth MacMillan's ballet about one of history's most celebrated trysts.

title: THE FROSTS, FAMILY AND FRIENDS AT MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR AN ART collector acting as the curator of a show is not unprecedented, but it's sufficiently unorthodox to be worth remarking about.

title: ALL THE INSURANCE YOU'LL EVER NEED
description: AT first glance they may seem like insurance policies worth buying. F or just $16.80 a month, your banker may say, you can be sure your m ortgage will be taken care of in case you die. For $3, says an ad t hat arrives in the mail, you can have a policy that gives you $ 250,000 in coverage every time you fly. Even your veterinarian may s uggest a policy, saying that for just $19 you can be insured againste xpensive medical treatment that your pet may need.

title: RENAISSANCE GLIMPSES IN URBINO
description: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, is a writer who lives in Europe.

title: Sour U.S. Loans
description: The United States Attorney's office in Philadelphia tried a new tack last September in the Government's drive to collect from former collegians who have defaulted on student loans: It began to seize their automobiles. Among the cars impounded were a Lincoln and a Porsche.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: FINALE'S A START, A $5 TICKET'S FREE
description: HOW can the finale be a beginning? How can a $5 ticket be free? David Gitelson, a member of the Community Concert Association of Mount Kisco, explains: ''As an exceptional bonus, anyone subscribing to our 1983-84 season before the final offering this year - the Joffrey II Dancers - can attend that performance as our guest.''

title: STATE'S FIRST IN VITRO CLINIC OPENS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE state's first in vitro fertilization clinic, which had been in the planning stages for a year, has opened at Middlesex General-University Hospital here. The program, affiliated with the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, had its first patient on April 30, and about 100 women with missing, blocked or damaged fallopian tubes - which keep them from conceiving -have applied for the program. About 80 percent live in the state.

title: DIVERSITY MARKS A DEBUT IN DRAWINGS
description: IT should not be surprising that artists find so much pleasure in drawing. The testing of ideas through line and form often leads to great personal satisfaction and, at times, even great exhilaration.

title: JODY REDLING IS MARRIED
description: Jody Anne Redling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frank Redling of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday in Caldwell, N.J., to Michael Anthony Guariglia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dante Guargiglia of Passaic, N.J. The Rev. Robert Stagg performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Mother Joseph Chapel on the campus of Caldwell College. The bride is assistant advertising manager with Prentice-Hall, publishers, in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Mr. Guariglia is an associate with the Newark law firm of McCarter & English.

title: Rate on U.S. Home Loan Lowered to 11.5 Percent
description: About 800,000 more Americans should be able to qualify for home loans under lower interest rates being put into effect next week by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration.

title: SCHOOLS GUIDE
description: In looking for a new home the bottom line for many families is the quality of the schools.

title: ALAN JAY LERNER BREWS A POLITICAL LOVE STORY
description: In 1936 Robert Sherwood won a Pulitzer Prize for his play, ''Idiot's Delight,'' which starred Alfred Lunt as a third-rate hoofer who encounters a long-lost love in the cocktail lounge of a hotel in the Italian Alps, where they are being detained by the Italian government as the hostilities preceding World War II escalate. Played by Lynn Fontanne, the long-lost love - a former Cockney showgirl who is now the mistress of a wealthy munitions manufacturer - is sporting an exotic blond wig instead of her own red hair, and posing as an elegant Romanoff whose family fled Russia during the revolution.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WANT a piece of the old Katonah railroad station as a keepsake? The Country Children's Center, a day-care facility in the hamlet, would like to sell you some of the old beams - or, more specifically, pieces of old beams - to raise money.

title: IMPERFECT UNESCO: CONDUCTOR OF THE 'BUSINESS OF ALL OF US'
description: To the Editor:

title: LAURENCE BILLET WEDS MISS DYAL
description: Debra Jeanette Dyal, a financial analyst in the corporate planning department of Pan American World Airways in New York, was married yesterday to Laurence Kenneth Billett, director of corporate financing for Pan Am. Capt. James W. Robinson, a minister of the Universal Life Church, performed the ceremony aboard the yacht Papagallo II in San Francisco Harbor.

title: 42 Die and 50 Are Injured In Istanbul Hotel Blaze
description: A fire gutted a hotel filled with foreign tourists today, killing 42 people and injuring at least 50, witnesses and officials said.

title: PRIMARIES SEEN AS REFERENDUM ON KEAN RECORD
description: TRENTON TOMORROW is the deadline for registering to vote in the June 7 primary elections. Although there is no statewide contest to hold broad interest, the elections to choose candidates for 120 seats in the State Legislature could greatly affect the performance of the Kean administration over the next two years.

title: Tide of Bitterness For Mitterrand
description: Francois Mitterrand's popularity plummeted last week as demonstrations and strikes by French doctors, farmers, students and shopkeepers tied up traffic in Paris and provincial cities. Opinion polls showed the Socialist President with lower personal approval after two years in office than any of his Fifth Republic predecessors.

title:
DINING OUT;
DUAL ROLE FOR A FERRYBOAT OF OLD
description: THE difference between a weeknight and a weekend visit to the same restaurant can be so marked that one could almost be in two different establishments. This is was illustrated recently during three visits to the former ferryboat Binghamton, which is now moored on the Hudson River in Edgewater. The craft houses two restaurants, The Engine Room, which is below deck, and The Galley, which is on the upper deck.

title: IT'S NECESSARY FOR SHORT-TERM GROWTH
description: AFOOLISH consistency, Emerson told us, is the hobgoblin of little m inds. But we are wary of politicians who would have us do one thing t oday and the opposite tomorrow.

title: Recent Sales
STATE FEARS BEING LEFT HIGH AND DRY
description: At Lake Havusu, on the border with California, giant pumps lift water from the Colorado River up an 800-foot mountainside and into the first stretch of a concrete aqueduct that unfolds across the remote reaches of Arizona's high desert. When it is finished, the aqueduct will travel 300 miles, an unbroken ribbon of concrete and pipe designed to transport billions of gallons of Colorado River water to thirsty Phoenix and Tucson.

title: QUESTION OF NEW RACE BY WHITE IS DOMINATING BOSTON POLITICS
description: Wherever former City Councilman Lawrence S. DiCara goes to campaign for next fall's mayoral election, he hears the same question.

title: Acknowledging Damage at E.P.A.
description: Just how far the Environmental Protection Agency sank in recent months was indicated last week by the promises made to Congress by the man nominated to be its new Administrator. ''There will be no hit lists, there will be no big 'P' political decisions, there will be no sweetheart deals,'' William D. Ruckelshaus told the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, which confirmed him unanimously.

title: MISS FRANKLIN PLANNING HER WEDDING FOR JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. William D. Franklin, of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Franklin, to Robert Michael Opotzner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Opotzner, of Shelton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CARROLL GARDENS
description: IT WAS, said Salvadore Scotto, a surprise. In the early 1960's, the b rownstoners began to trickle in, first into Cobble Hill, across A tlantic Avenue from Brooklyn Heights, and then farther south into h is neighborhood, an Italian enclave that had its own identity but n ot a name, a place that some called South Brooklyn and others simply' 'the neighborhood.''

title: SIX DAYS ON THE PEKING-MOSCOW EXPRESS
description: JOHN POMFRET 2d is a student at Stanford University who recently returned from 19 months of study in China.

title: POP FROM DOWN UNDER
description: This year's music business success story has been Men at Work, who came out of nowhere - also known as Australia - to sell millions of copies of their debut album, ''Business as Usual.'' They certainly weren't the first Australians to have hits worldwide, but unlike most of their predecessors with an eye on the international audience, Men at Work didn't play down their out-of-town origins. Just the opposite: A song proclaimed ''I come from the land down under'' and bandied about Australian slang.

title: SOUTH AFRICA JAILS BLACK OVER A BANNED BOOK
description: A prominent black journalist recently drew an unusually heavy prison sentence of two and a half years for possession of a single banned book. The sentence was a result of plea bargaining that suddenly cut short the trial of nine people charged with being underground activists of the outlawed Pan Africanist Congress.

title: BALDNESS AT THE TOP
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Cut, Shaped and Refocused

title: 'VALLEY GIRL': ROOTS IN L.I., FERRR SURRRE
description: HOW did the rage begin for real? No one knows for sure - or, to state it as resonantly as it is supposed to sound, ''ferrr surrre.'' But the emergence of the Valley Girl, otherwise known as a ''Val,'' and her male counterpart, the ''Val dude,'' who are symptomatic of a contemporary suburban teen-age life style - in language, in dress and in vacuous values - has made a mark on youngsters from California to Cedarhurst.

title: THE MET WILL PRESENT THE PRIVATE HENRY MOORE
description: As Henry Moore is a great many people's favorite Englishman, it might seem that nothing much could go wrong with the major retrospective exhibition of his sculptures and drawings that will open to the public next Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum. The address could not be more august. The shaping hand is that of William S. Lieberman, who is in charge of 20th-century art at the Met and an old friend and champion of Moore. Not since the enormous exhibition in Florence in 1972 will Moore's work have been seen in such strength outside his own country.

title: ISRAELI HANDICAPPED GET BACKING FOR TRIP TO SPECIAL OLYMPICS
description: A gathering of New Yorkers raised $17,000 last week to help finance the participation of a team of mentally handicapped Israeli youngsters at the 1983 International Summer Special Olympic Games, which will be held in July in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Marching Feet Mark the Years Of Living History
description: Poles by the tens of thousands marked anniversaries last week by defying the Government with pro-Solidarity marches in at least 20 cities. The demonstrations began on May Day and continued through the anniversary of the 1791 democratic constitution and Roman Catholic festival of Mary, Queen of Poland, on May 3.

title: Romance Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICAN JOURNEY: THE BLUE TRAIN
description: JOSEPH LELYVELD is the chief of The Times bureau in Johannesburg.

title: New York's New Chancellor Holds His FIrst Class
description: To Anthony J Alvarado, the solutions to some New York City educational problems are open-and-shut. Or, more precisely, shut-and-open. Attending his first Board of Education meeting since his selection as head of the nation's largest school system, Chancellor Alvarado last week proposed closing high schools that ''don't work'' and reorganizing their staffs and curricula.

title: ELAINE A. WEBER ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Weber of Scottsdale, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Anne Weber, to Robert Michael McGoldrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGoldrick of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Paying Back The Teamsters
