description: It has taken nearly a decade of investigations and litigation, but the Teamsters Central States pension and health and welfare funds have been gradually losing their reputation as handy reservoirs for the mob. Last week, in another rehabilitative step, the Labor Department announced a settlement that calls for the union funds' trustees to replace $6.5 million that the agency says was improperly spent.

title: JEWS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: A more erroneous picture would be hard to paint if one is considering New York as the No.1 Financial Center and one of the top social centers.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FAITHFUL BEAN, FROM PLOT TO POT
description: IT has long been my theory that simple foods are often the best, and that heavily seasoned dishes originated as a means of covering up for rancidness or poor quality. Having recently received as a gift a plastic bag containing two cupfuls of dried beans, I had a chance to test this theory.

title: Jury Resumes Deliberations
description: A jury met for six hours today in its second day of deliberations in the trial of four Everett policemen charged with murder in a melee at a motel.

title: DANCE: 'SALKA VALKA' BY RAATIKKO
description: Dance Theater Raatikko, an interesting, if sometimes perplexing, modern-dance troupe from Finland, brought ''Salka Valka,'' a threeact narrative work by Marjo Kuusela, to the Theater of the Riverside Church on Friday night.

title: 4 Americans Climb Everest
description: Four Americans and a Nepalese sherpa radioed today that they had reached the 29,028-foot summit of Mount Everest from the southeast ridge.

title: PSEUDO SALESTALK
description: ''It's nice to have your own money to spend, isn't it?'' Sounds like an innocuous observation; in reality, those words are a sneaky salesman's way of asking a young person: ''Tell me, now, if there's somebody else you have to consult before buying.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SEATTLE
description: MOIRA FARROW is a reporter for The Vancouver Sun.

title: Headliners; It's You, Miami
description: Miamians who avoided Biscayne Bay for fear of being embarrassed by the sight of stark naked islands had their anxieties assuaged last week.

title: MARY SHELLEY INGRAM IS WED
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Mary Shelley Ingram, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Ingram 2d of Pasadena, Calif., was married to William Hunter deButts 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. deButts Jr. of Marshall, Va. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the ceremony.

title: MARKET RECOVERS HEALTH
description: TWO major shows held in Connecticut last month ''turned the antiques market around'' in this region, according to several dealers. Most of the exhibitors reported excellent buyer response.

title: A SCHOOL FOR NANNIES IS PLANNED
description: DR. HENRY L. HARRIS was conducting a seminar in Stamford for working mothers with young children when he heard a statement that caused the women to giggle like their 3-year-olds at playtime.

title: KATHRYN B. SMITH WED TO THERAPIST
description: Kathryn Ballard Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jennings Talbot Smith of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Edward Davis Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Baltimore. The Rev. John Deason performed the ceremony at the Hugenot Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: Presidential Candor on Aid To Nicaraguans
description: President Reagan came close last week to advocating the overthrow of the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua. As 1,500 American-assisted Nicaraguan rebels reportedly launched a new drive across the Honduran border, the President condemned a fresh Congressional move to bar covert aid to what he called ''freedom fighters'' and questioned the right to exist of ''a Government out of a barrel of a gun.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The profile of the police officer has changed - it's not a male bastion any more, and your ethnic Irish, Italian, with a sprinking of Jewish, cop has given way to a new mix.

title: Wrong Address
description: To the Editor:

title: ONCE UPON A TIME, AN ACTRESS TURNED INTO A PRODUCER
description: Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. LOS ANGELES ''Actors are always telling you pipe dreams,'' notes Academy Awardwinner Mary Steenburgen. ''They talk about projects they'd like to do, but they never get around to doing them. So, I was skeptical when Shelley Duvall first mentioned 'Faerie Tale Theater' to me. But it turned out to be more than a pipe dream.''

title: RETRIAL IS SOUGHT IN '76 MURDER
description: BRIDGETON APUBLIC DEFENDER here contends that his client was inaccurately identified and convicted of murder as the third person at the scene of a shooting in 1976. He has asked the Appellate Division of State Superior Court for a new trial for Leonard Williams, who was 17 at the time of the murder and has been in prison ever since.

title: MISGUIDED SOCCER FANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Soviet Diplomats Leave Iran Amid Jeers
description: Fifteen of the 18 Soviet diplomats ordered to leave Iran left here today amid chants of ''Death to the Soviets!'' and ''God is great!'' from militants at the airport.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 8 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 5 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high-school set. 3 3 5 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 4 4 6 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 5 5 6 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 6 6 6 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.) London bankers gamble on the ability of a horse breeder to produce a star race horse. 7 8 3 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 8 7 9 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh.

title: Human Torch
description: Cecil Andrews of Jacksonville, Ala., called a nearby television station last March 4 and said he had some real news. He was tired of being unemployed, he said; he planned to set himself on fire in the town square. When two cameramen arrived, the 37-year-old roofer doused himself with lighter fluid and struck a match.

title: No Headline
description: Nicholas Gage's article brought back memories of fear and shame from a terrible period of my native country's past. I, too, remember the daily terror of that time, the talk of torture, killings and disappearances our elders spoke of in subdued voices.

title: Brown Upsets Cornell
description: Brown upset fifth-ranked Cornell, 13-7, in lacrosse today for the Bruins' first victory over the Big Red since 1973.

title: SUNNY'S HALO CAPTURES 109TH KENTUCKY DERBY
description: Six months ago, Sunny's Halo was a crippled and sour colt who had no supporters except the trainer who had staked his career on him. Today, he won the 109th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: FIBER ARTISTS DEVISE NEW FORMS
description: WOVEN tapestries, once created to insulate the cold stone walls of drafty castles, have now become popular decorations in the more modest domestic setting of contemporary homes. They are also frequently found adorning the lobbies and hallways of office and apartment blocks and softening the harshness of modern interiors. Now that tapestries are valued more for beauty than utility, fiber artists are inventing new, experimental forms that have little to do with traditional woven hangings.

title: SUSAN ROSENFELD PLANS TO WED A PSYCHIATRIST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Rosenfeld of Albany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Margot Rosenfeld, to Dr. Stuart Wachter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Wachter of Flushing, Queens.

title: POP: SLY WITHOUT THE FAMILY
description: Because the bill at the Red Parrot on Wednesday announced Sly and the Family Stone, one had hopes of seeing some vestige of the colorful Bay Area family agglomeration that revolutionized soul music in the late 60's and early 70's.

title: STEPHEN I. STRICKER MARRIES MISS COLE, FINANCE ANALYST
description: Barbara S. Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Cole of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Stephen I. Stricker, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Stricker of Rockville Center, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Daniel Syme at the Helmsley Palace in New York.

title: ALBANY PREPARING TO TIGHTEN CONTROLS ON CAPITAL SPENDING
description: With the state considering a $1.25 billion bond issue for transportation, the Legislature is seeking ways of keeping a closer eye on construction projects.

title: HIGH ASSOCIATE OF HOWARD HUGHES
description: Chester C. Davis, a New York lawyer who was one of the most influential aides of Howard Hughes, the reclusive billionaire industrialist, died Thursday at his thoroughbred-horse farm in Unadilla, N.Y. Mr. Davis, who also maintained an apartment in New York, was 72 years old.

title: GOVERNOR'S HOUSE IS POLITICAL PAWN
description: After standing empty for the eight years Edmund G. Brown Jr. held office, the never-used $1.4 million Governor's Mansion remains vacant as a pawn in quarrels between Gov. George Deukmejian and Democrats in the State Senate.

title: AT COLLEGES, A SEASON OF CHANGE
description: These are times of change for many of the Island's colleges. With graduation ceremonies scheduled for the coming weeks, the institutions are already focusing on the next academic year.

title: MY MOTHER ELENI
description: My Mother Eleni

title: THE CENTRAL QUESTIONS
description: Secretary of State George Shultz has made some progress in the Middle East. He has persuaded the Israeli Government ''in principle'' to withdraw its troops from Lebanon, but he's still concentrating on the fringes of world problems.

title: ALL AT ONCE EVERYONE IS WORRIED ABOUT SCHOOLS
description: People interested in education and old enough to remember Sputnik may sense something familiar in the air these days: evidence that the quality of education in this country is once again becoming a national issue.

title: Meaning and Object
description: To the Editor:

title: POP SONGS: A DEBUT
description: Perhaps Maria Martha Serra Lima sings better in a recording studio than she did on Thursday at Carnegie Hall. That would explain why she has hit albums in her native Argentina.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
CHRYSLER'S BIG CARS LEAD AUTO'S RALLY
description: Auto sales made solid gains in the last 10 days of April as Americans rekindled their old love affair with the big car. The nation's leading auto companies said new-car deliveries, paced by sales of such old gas-guzzling standbys as the Delta 88, the Caprice Classic and the LeSabre, climbed 10.5 percent in the period. Chrysler's sales, spurred by its high-priced New Yorker, surged 63.6 percent as the No. 3 auto maker captured an impressive 15 percent of the market. ''We can't get enough of that car,'' said one ecstatic dealer. And an equally exuberant Lee Iacocca announced that Chrysler - eager to prove its problems are over - would repay one-third of its $1.2 billion in Federal loan guarantees seven years ahead head of schedule and renegotiate the rest.

title: AT LAST, A HURRAH FOR MARGIOTTA?
description: The United States Supreme Court last week did what no rival politician could: It forced Joseph M. Margiotta to retire. The decision not to hear the Nassau Republican chairman's appeal ended 17 months of legal and political maneuvering to stave off a two-year jail term and retain control of the machine he made into one of the nation's most powerful. Mr. Margiotta is expected to enter prison soon.

title: Peace March in Hungary
description: An unofficial peace group marched for the first time through Budapest today bearing banners with messages directed at both Moscow and Washington. Witnesses said about 450 demonstrators joined the end of a much larger, official march. Some of their banners read, ''All nuclear missiles out of Europe now.''

title: MISS REDDIN WILL WED V.W. PLOUGH 3D
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. George V. Reddin of Raleigh, N.C., formerly of Cedar Grove, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Annamarie Reddin, to Vernon Watson Pugh 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Pugh Jr., also of Raleigh.

title: MOTIVE NEXT STEP FOR CBS TRIAL JURY
description: Evidence about how a purported plot to silence witnesses in a fraud investigation culminated in four murders on a West Side pier will be presented to a jury in Manhattan this week, according to the prosecutor.

title: On Saccharin
description: To the Business Editor: It is unfortunate that The Times continues the fiction that groups such as the Center for Science in the Public Interest should be classified as ''consumer groups.'' The irony of this is highlighted in ''Keeping Saccharin on the Shelves'' (April 24). For the third time, Congress, acting under enormous pressure from consumers, has permitted continued use of saccharin, in direct opposition to the views of so-called consumer groups that do not derive their direction from consumers. MURRAY BERDICK

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE There's something special for dance tastes of all kinds this week. ''Giselle'' fans will have a field day at the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater is presenting five performances of that classic with four different casts.

title: BROOKE DOCKAR-DRYSDALE WED ABROAD
description: Marian Brooke Dockar-Drysdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Dockar-Drysdale of Radley Village near Abingdon, Oxfordshire, England, was married yesterday to Neil David Samuels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Samuels of New York. The Rev. Daniel Pope performed the ceremony at St. James the Great Anglican Cnurch in Radley.

title: Data Bank; May 8, 1983
Orioles Are Riding Singleton's Hot Bat
description: Ken Singleton hasn't hit a home run righthanded since 1981, but Baltimore's switch-hitting designated hitter feels his power is back.

title: 'Flightseeing' French Style
description: When it comes to the high life, literally speaking, what can compare with a flying tour of France? Flightseeing is the name given to a series of six-day airplane tours, available into October, that are built around zipping from Paris to the Channel coast to Bordeaux, the Cote d'Azur and the French Alps with overnight stops at deluxe hotels, among them the Normandy in Deauville, La Reserve in Bordeaux and the Mas d'Artigny near Nice. The restaurants include that operated by Paul Bocuse, the celebrated chef, near Lyons, and the Domaine d'Auriac near Carcassonne.

title: No Headline
description: Changing Face Of Japan Robert C. Christopher's article ''Changing Face of Japan'' (March 27) was one of most balanced and realistic articles on that land I've seen in some time. It reinforced many of my own impressions from having taught English in Tokyo during 1974-75.

title: A GUEST ARTIST BRINGS A DANCE TO THE AILEY
description: Marcia Pally is a freelance writer.

title: STAGE: 'GOODBYE GOODBYE' A GAME
description: There is a game that involves the cast of ''Goodbye Goodbye,'' an earnest and short play of the experimental sort offered by Teatron, a new company, at La Mama, and the winner of it is the person who is willing to go furthest in self-degradation.

title: Red Sox Restrict Valdez
description: He has been released on bail pending arraignment tomorrow in Roxbury District Court, but Julio Valdez, the Red Sox utility infielder who was arrested on a charge of statutory rape Friday night, will not suit up ''until further notice,'' the club said yesterday. The announcement came hours after the 26-year-old Valdez was arrested at Boston's Fenway Park during the seventh inning of Friday night's game against the Seattle Mariners.

title: BARBARA B. STORCH IS WED
description: Barbara B. Storch of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday at Christ Church to Arthur E. French Jr., son of Mrs. French of Springfield, N.J., and the late Mr. French. The Rev. Allen Tinker performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of William J. Buckalewof Venice, Fla., and the late Mrs. Buckalew, was previously married and divorced, as was Mr. French.

title: A PIANIST WHO TAKES ON BEETHOVEN WHOLE
description: Nicholas Kenyon is a music critic for The Times of London. LONDON Virgil Thomson once wrote a famous sentence about the intelligentsia of musical New York not being found at Philharmonic concerts. Ask people in musical London where the intelligentsia have been this season, and the answer will not be Covent Garden, or the ballet, or the symphony orchestras, but Alfred Brendel's Beethoven sonata cycle. During each of the seven recitals, which were spaced over several months, starting in October and finishing in April, the Elizabeth Hall on the South Bank has been packed, and queues turned away.

title: A New Sports Car In the Family Size
description: THERE appears to be a growing market for sport sedans, resulting no doubt from the tide of imports and a burgeoning awareness of what a car can be. The imports have no lock on the practical-but-fun category, of course, and Detroit has scurried to come up with some offerings of its own, packing technology and good handling into family-sized packages.

title: IN HONG KONG, SOME DEBTORS STILL GO TO JAIL
description: Not many places still put people in prison for owing money, but then not many places take money as seriously as does this outpost of unbridled capitalism.

title: DANCE: AILEY TROUPE IN 'RESEARCH'
description: Sometimes choreographers can make the oddest things happen in their dances. And Gary DeLoatch made quite a few odd things happen in his ''Research,'' which received its New York premiere at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's performance on Wednesday night at the City Center.

title: THE REGION
description: One hundred years to the day after legislation creating New York State's civil service system was enacted, the Cuomo administration made it slightly smaller last week. It issued pink slips to the first state workers whose jobs are to be sacrificed in the name of a balanced budget.

title: CHANGING FACE OF JAPAN
description: Robert Christopher's article rests upon the premise that Japanese culture is only now beginning to reflect ''values'' long prevalent in this country and others. His evidence, however, suggests that the cultures have been more similar than different all along.

title: SUSAN V. MULLIGAN MARRIED IN JERSEY
description: Susan Valier Mulligan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Mulligan of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Douglas Pribor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugo C. Pribor of Nashville. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Hegg at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J., assisted by Rev. John Corr of the Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J., and the Rev. Bernard Siegle of the St. Francis Roman Catholic Monastery in Loretto, Pa.

title: KAI WINDING, 60, TROMBONIST AND A LEADER OF JAZZ GROUPS
description: Kai Winding, the Danish-born jazz trombonist, died Friday after suffering a coronary attack in St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. Mr. Winding, who had been hospitalized for the treatment of a brain tumor, was 60 years old and had been living in Spain.

title: Susan Schelpert Wed to Kent Murray in Bronxville
description: Susan Appleyard Schelpert, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John William Schelpert 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kent Lachlan Murray, son of Fay Stickney Murray of Ardmore, Pa., and Donald Lenford Murray of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Bronxville.

title: FAIRFIELD COUNTY'S CB 'BUDDIES' MEET FACE TO FACE
description: GRAY Fox was there, as were Mermaid, Hubcap, Blackbeard and Country Bumpkin. ''Hey, Handlebar, how are you?'' cried Skeezix as she ran a snow-pea pod through the anchovy and sour cream dip.

title: JEWS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: I must take exception to the opinions extolled by Mr. Tisch with regard to ''Jews in the non-Jewish world.'' The inference here - further supported by Mr. Tisch's analogy between hunchbacks and Jewish heritage - is that Jews are somehow innately or inherently different from other human beings, and that, like the hunchback, they are inextricably bound to their condition of ''Jewishness.''

title: FROM ANCIENT ART TO A PEEK AT FUTURE
description: ''ANCIENT art,'' said Norma Kershaw of Great Neck, ''only comes out of the ground because of archeology, which is a technique. Through the study of the art, we can begin to understand the nature of the people who created it, and the more we study, the more we see that these people are just like ourselves, although we are separated by a gulf of time, thousands of years.

title: IN NEW PRODUCTS, SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL
description: JAPAN'S electronics industry, after two years of declines, has s tepped up its efforts to lure buyers. Its annual spring ritual of p roduct introductions shows an even greater dependence on its s uccessful ''small is beautiful'' formula: Its products are more c ompact, lighter and more functional while prices are about the same o r lower than last year.

title: Reagan Links His Policy To Help for the Family
description: President Reagan said today that his policies were aimed at restoring the American family to ''its rightful place,'' in part by easing pressure on the average family's household budget.

title: CONCERT: A REUNION FOR IMPRESSIONS
description: The Impressions's Silver Anniversary Tour, with the current fourman group plus Curtis Mayfield and Jerry Butler - founding members who have since enjoyed successful solo careers - arrived at the Beacon Theater on Friday night. Though the present Impressions includes two more founders, Fred Cash and Sam Gooden, and achieves a rich, silky vocal blend, for the most part its routines are standard harmony-group fare.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE BOOK OF ROYAL LISTS By Craig Brown and Lesley Cunliffe. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Summit Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: DANA WORTH IS BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Worth of Easton, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dana D. Worth, to Robert Kent M. Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Peterson of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned. Miss Worth and her fiance graduated from Ohio Wesleyan University.

title: Helping Out the Afghan Rebels
description: On the murky heaths of covert military action, it's often not so much what you do as who you do it to. That was the gist of a report in The New York Times last week that some of the same members of Congressional intelligence committees who have vigorously opposed the Administration's not-so-covert aid to anti-Sandinist guerrillas in Nicaragua have been perfectly willing to approve increased American military aid to Islamic insurgents in Afghanistan.

title: CITY PLANS TO CURB SOME ABATEMENTS OF PROPERTY TAXES
description: The Koch administration plans to make major changes in a troubled program that gives property-tax incentives to developers, according to Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SIGN OF THE BEAVER By Elizabeth George Speare. 135 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $8.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: THE LURE AND LORE OF BAMBOO
description: Chinese bamboo craftsmen, from the 16th century on, enriched scholars' desks with sculptures, writing tools, brush holders, wrist rests and other objects. Some excellent examples survive, as can be seen in ''Bamboo Carving of China,'' an exhibition of 85 selections at China House Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, on view through May 29. The show is believed to be the first in this country devoted to the craft.

title: WHO WAS THAT MASKED CAPITALIST?
description: THE EMPIRE'S OLD CLOTHES, What the Lone Ranger, Babar, and Other Innocent Heroes Do to Our Minds. By Ariel Dorfman. With translations by Clark Hansen. 225 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: EAST GERMANY FINALLY EMBRACES LUTHER
description: A few years ago, in the land of his birth, Martin Luther was a prophet without honor, regarded by Marxist historians and Communist propagandists as a lackey of reactionary 16th-century princes and an enemy of peasant rebels.

title: Driver Escapes Injury In Crash on Indy Track
description: Rich Vogler, among 22 rookie drivers hoping to qualify for the Indianapolis 500 auto race May 29, crashed into the third-turn wall today in practice at the Motor Speedway.

title: MUSIC: 'WILD GARDENS OF THE LOUP GAROU'
description: ''Wild Gardens of the Loup Garou,'' composer Carman Moore's music drama based on 25 poems by Ishmael Reed and Colleen McElroy, takes its central image from voodoo folklore. The Loup Garou, explains the program note, is a spirit of restlessness that takes the forms of dogs and birds; it both drives people crazy and makes them able to love.

title: REINVENTING MOSLEM CIVILIZATION
description: RECOGNIZING ISLAM, Religion and Society in the Modern Arab World. By Michael Gilsenan. 287 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $7.95.

title: HOSPITALS TO OFFER WEEK OF SEMINARS
description: MANY Connecticut hospitals will celebrate National Hospital Week this week with a wide range of health and safety seminars open to the public. The scheduled topics include sports medicine, nursing practices, Medicare changes and child care.

title: MISS DOUDNA, A WRITER, WEDS RICHARD GRAND-JEAN
description: Christine Doudna, a free-lance editor and writer in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Grand-Jean, a managing director of Salomon Brothers Inc., an investment banking firm in New York. The Methodist ceremony was performed in their house in New York by the bride's father, the Rev. Dr. John Charles Doudna of Baldwin City, Kansas.

title: SOVIET SAID TO TEST SUBS OFF SWEDEN
description: Sightings of submarines off Norway and Sweden in the last eight months have led intelligence sources from NATO and neutral countries to conclude that, despite denials from Moscow, Soviet submarines have been making forays in the area.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FROM ALEXANDER TO CLEOPATRA The Hellenistic World. By Michael Grant. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: SENATOR BILL BRADLEY will receive the Distinguished Public Service Award of the New Jersey Society of Fellows of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at the Aspen Hotel in Parsippany tomorrow. Governor Kean, the keynote speaker, will sign a proclamation noting the league's 70th anniversary.

title: NAME-DROPPING IS PART OF MENU
description: THE Country House in Stony Brook looks as if it has been transplanted from a Southampton summer colony. Several fireplaces and the exposed beams in a couple of areas suggest the origin of this attractive Colonial building turned restaurant. But most of it has been redecorated in shades of lime green and pink, with hanging plants, white trellises and tiny winking lights strung about. The menu currently in effect is called the Spring Collection from Palm Beach, another location that is in keeping with the decor.

title: JUDITH LESAGE BECOMES BRIDE
description: The marriage of Judith Hussey LeSage to Edward Anthony Grassi took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Gerald Parker performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Bernard Russell Le Sage of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Le Sage. Mr. Grassi is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ettore Howard Anthony Grassi of Chestertown, Md.

title: Cosmos in 'Must' Game Today
description: The Cosmos are experiencing a period of uneasiness as a result of two losses in their first three games and with several of their players negotiating contracts.

title: RIDING WITH A STIFF UPPER LIP
description: QUENTIN CRISP was born in England and now lives in the United States. His most recent books are ''Doing It With Style'' (Franklin Watts), written with Donald Carroll, and ''How to Become a Virgin'' (St. Martin's).

title:
CAMERA;
USE FLASH-FILL FOR OUTDOOR SHADOWS
Correction
description: A caption in an article last Sunday on the O.P.M. Leasing fraud incorrectly identified the company's owners in pictures taken after they were sentenced. Myron S. Goodman was shown shielding his face, and Mordecai Weissman was shown stepping out of the courthouse.

title: Future Events; Lunch, Tea and Dinner
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Familiar Models May 12 - Gala luncheon and fashion show of the New York Women's Division of State of Israel Bonds in the Sheraton Centre's Imperial Ballroom celebrates the 35th anniversary of the state of Israel. Clothes by top Israeli designers from swimsuits to evening wear will be modeled by celebrities like Dr. Joyce Brothers, Anne Jackson, Carmen de Lavallade, Robert Merrill and Harold Reed. Moriah Blum, wife of Yehuda Z. Blum, chief Israeli delegate to the United Nations, and Matilda Cuomo, wife of Governor Cuomo, will be special guests. Admission, minimum purchase of a $1,000 bond plus couvert, $35. Reservations from 212-677-9650, extension 359.

title: FIRST STEP TO STARDOM
description: IN his second go-round during batting practice Friday night, Darryl Strawberry dutifully bunted twice and then settled into his lean, almost languid, left-handed stance. Easily, naturally, with no apparent effort, the Mets' new 21-year-old right fielder kept swinging his big brown bat, lashing line drives onto the outfield grass and crashing a few towering shots that soared over the fence beyond where he should be playing for the next decade or two.

title: THE LOSS OF CHILDHOOD
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, AND NOT SO LONG AGO, the second Sunday in May celebrated a very different image of women and motherhood from the one that prevails today. When today's parents were children, Mother's Day still honored a domesticated little woman waiting with milk and cookies after school, a mother as unlikely to become a single parent during the course of her children's childhood as to become a coal miner.

title: DR. FREDERICKS TO WED IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Fredericks of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Rose E. Fredericks, to Dr. Kenneth A. La Bresch, son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. La Bresh of Bloomington, Minn.

title: BRITAIN'S SYMPHONY OF FESTIVALS
description: NICHOLAS KENYON is a music critic for The Times of London.

title: VIRGINIA STANIFORD ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell Simpson Staniford of Old Saybrook, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Bulkelely Staniford, to Francis J. Reid, Jr, son of Mrs. Reid of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Mr. Reid.

title: A DRAMA OF LIFE STYLES AND NEEDS
description: AVOIDING the problems that the sexual revolution has created would be as successful as pretending it never rains. Newspapers, magazines, television and radio devote much time and space to current life styles and the manner in which people cope with modern living. The theater, too, has addressed itself to the myriad questions tumbling out of unorthodox love nests.

title: Stanky to Retire
description: After six years as the baseball coach at the University of South Alabama in Mobile, Eddie Stanky, the 65-year-old former major league player and manager, was scheduled to retire last night following a game against Miami. Stanky, an infielder who played for the Chicago Cubs, Brooklyn Dodgers, Boston Braves, New York Giants and St, Louis Cardinals in an 11-year career, later managed the Cardinals, the White Sox and, for one day in 1977, the Texas Rangers.

title: Kentucky Derby Chart Copyright 1983 by Daily Racing Form, Inc.
description: The Kentucky Derby, $531,000, 3YOs, 1 1/4M. Start good, won driving. Off, 5:40. Winner, b.c. by HaloMostly Sunny, by Sunny. Trainer, David C. Cross. Value to winner, $426,000; second, $60,000; third, $30,000; fourth, $15,000. Times - 23 4/5, 47 1/5, 1:11 4/5, 1:36 4/5, 2:02 1/5.

title: The Worst Is Yet to Come
description: Californians received a word to the wise from the earthquake gods last week when a strong temblor devastated the rural town of Coalinga. Within 30 seconds after the ground heaved at a magnitude of about 6.5 on the Richter scale, Coalinga's commercial district was destroyed, gas line fires raged, electric power went dead and hundreds of residents were homeless.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: IN DEFENSE OF THE FAMILY Raising Children in America Today. By Rita Kramer. 263 pp. New York: Basic Books. $15.50.

title: MARGARET D. MONROE WEDS DAVID ZELLINGER
description: Margaret Dickinson Monroe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Perrine Monroe of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to David A. Zellinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome P. Zellinger of Ballwin, Mo. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Libbie Deverich Stoddard, a Unitarian minister, at the Slayter Center for the Performing Arts, Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind.

title: 'SHOWBOAT' YIELDS SOME REFRESHING SURPRISES
description: When you go to a revival of a musical like ''Showboat,'' you certainly don't go to see what's new. But, precisely speaking, neither do you go to see what's old. What are you doing, then? Well, you're sort of making the trip to see what's new in what's old.

title: A GOOD DEFINITION MIGHT HELP
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission has declared war on insider trading. It has submitted t o Congress a bill - the Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1983 - d esigned to help win what has been called an ''unwinnable war.'' But,u nless the strategy is modified, it may create worse problems than e xist even now.

title: CHICAGO HAS A NEW PROFILE; CHICAGO
description: For the last 30 years, the crisp, austere forms of the International Style have been the hallmark of this city's skyline. So one's first reaction to the latest crop of Chicago skyscrapers is that they don't belong here - that there has been some mistake, that they must have been intended for some other city.

title: CHANGES FOR MOSTLY MOZART
description: Gerard Schwarz, the music director of the Y Chamber Symphony, was appointed as music adviser to the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center before last season, and this summer is the first which will fully reflect his influence. Several changes will be evident in the festival as a result. For the first time, there will be performances on authentic instruments, to take place in the traditional 7 P.M. pre-concert recitals, preceding the main recitals at 8 in Avery Fisher Hall. Each of the 28 different programs, some which will be repeated in the 42 concerts scheduled from July 11 to Aug. 27, will also include at least one work new to the festival. And there will be a thematic emphasis to much of the programming, which will, in Mr. Schwarz's words, focus on ''composers who greatly influenced Mozart and composers Mozart greatly influenced.''

title: No Headline
description: Lasers and a Child To the Editor: I have done a Science Fair project in which I took first place on the subject of lasers. You failed to note in your otherwise wellwritten article ''Corporate Push for Space Lasers'' (April 24), that the energy intensity of a laser could be reduced to steam when passing through atmospheric moisture such as rain, snow and clouds.

title: AUSTRIA'S SERENADE TO SCHUBERT
description: BERNARD LEVIN is a columnist for The Times of London and the author of several books, including ''Conducted Tour,'' a book of musical travels (published in London by Cape).

title: CONGRESS JOCKEYS TOWARD A BUDGET COMPROMISE
description: W ASHINGTON OSTENSIBLY, the issues dividing the United States Senate last week in five days of inconclusive debate on the 1984 budget were taxes and deficits: Which poses a greater threat to economic recovery?

title: CLEARING CONFUSION ABOUT HOME LOANS
description: LIFE was relatively simple for the home buyer selecting a mortgage i n the era of stable interest rates. In the metropolitan area the b uyer had few choices to make. Most lenders were offering essentiallyt he same loan - a fixed-rate, long-term mortgage at an interest rate t hat hardly varied from one institution to another.

title: 2 GERMANYS IN NEW PHASE OF LOVE-HATE RELATIONSHIP
description: One of the most intricate and contradictory diplomatic relationships in the world - the many ties that bind East Germany to West Germany - is going through what looks like a bad patch. Last week, the two Germanys were having a noisy spat.

title: HOME FOLKS AT ANOTHER'S THROAT
description: THE FEUD By Thomas Berger. 265 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte Press. $13.95.

title: VIRGINIA RUSSO AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Clark of Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Clark's daughter, Virginia Marshall Russo, to Andrew James Bachman, son of Mr. and Mts.

title: PATRICIA MURRAY TO MARRY PETER B. DERR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Caanan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Bradley Murray, to Peter Bilkeley Derr, son of the Rev. Virginia Bush Drr of Rochester and Rev. Dr. Thomas Sieger Derr of Northampton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: HARRISON DANCE lessons on Monday, piano on Tuesday, painting on Wednesday - a full after-school schedule is de rigueur for many suburban youngsters. But the popular stereotype of mom piling the children in the car and ferrying them to their extracurricular activities often does not work out so smoothly. Brother must be taken to one end of town, sister to another; extra classes and programs cost extra money.

title: RIGHTS UNIT CITES GUATEMALA
description: An international group that monitors human rights has accused the Guatemalan Army of systematically murdering Indians, and it called for the immediate suspension of United States military sales and the withholding of military aid to Guatemala.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY In 1927, the German photographer Albert Renger-Patzsch wrote, ''Let us leave art to the artists, and let us try - with photographic means - to create photographs which can stand alone because of their photographic character - without borrowing from art.'' If the theme sounds familiar, it is because Alfred Stieglitz, Paul Strand and Edward Weston were all saying the same thing at about the same time.

title: DRIVING 'MUSICAL' AT THEATER OF UNIVERSAL IMAGES
description: face) are among the mostly nameless street types who saunter through ''Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death,'' Melvin Van Peebles's shrill tone poem about survival in a black ghetto.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Red Sox slugger who has been plagued with a series of ailments since suffering a near-fatal heart attack more than a year ago, is scheduled to undergo surgery tomorrow in an effort to clear up some persistent respiratory problems. ... Dewey Selmon, a linebacker acquired by the San Diego Chargers from Tampa Bay last year, has retired. ... Ten years after he lost a decision to Joe Frazier, then the heavyweight champion, in a nontitle bout in London, Joe Bugner, the 33-year-old former British and European champion, will face Frazier's 22-year-old son, Marvis, in Atlantic City June 4. ... Grete Waitz and Joan Benoit, who finished first and second in last year's 10,000-meter L'eggs Minimarathon in Central Park, have entered this year's event, which is expected to attract 6,000 runners May 28.

title: ODD EARLY SPRING BATTERED FARMERS
description: One of the odder springs in memory, which brought torrential rains and late freezes to many parts of the country, has already cost fruit and vegetable growers and beef cattle raisers millions of dollars.

title: WHAT MOTHERS DO BEST-LECTURE
description: IHAVE just finished delivering Motherhood Lecture No. 101. It is the speech about no one, besides t he mother, doing anything in the way of work around the house. There were several stirring references to the countless number of t hings that mother does for everyone, from laundry and ironing, c ooking and cleaning to chauffeuring, and to the appalling dearth of r eciprocal effort. My audience of four children seemed suitably i mpressed with my message and duly chagrined at their failures.

title: Perfectly Clear On Racial Quotas
description: William Bradford Reynolds's speech to Amherst College undergraduates 10 days ago was a forceful reaffirmation of Administration policy on racial quotas in employment and education. That the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights called quotas ''morally wrong'' and described their use as having created a ''racial spoils system'' in America was not needed to make the policies plain.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AT the age of 69, after 13 years as a member of the theater arts faculty of the State University at Stony Brook, Richard Dyer-Bennet, the folk singer, is retiring this month.

title: VCRS BREAK A SOUND BARRIER
description: Sales of Video Cassette Recorders - VCRs for short - have doubled yearly for years and about five million of them are currently whirring away in this country. They all have one thing in common: Their sound is awful, muffled and marred by tape noise.

title: SALVADORAN SLAYING CARRIES MESSAGE FOR POLITICIANS
description: In El Salvador, death threats often come by telephone. Friday night the message was more direct. The body of a young man who had apparently been strangled and then shot in the head was found in a hotel parking lot with a warning for a Salvadoran politician.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN WE live by routines, schedules and deadlines. To get away from all that, we take vacations. But once on vacation we find ourselves following routines, schedules and deadlines as if we'd never left home. ''Everybody out for a nice swim!'' Bah.

title: Talks on Salmon Scheduled
description: THE newly-formed Atlantic Salmon Federation, a joining of the two largest and most active groups working on behalf of the fish in this country and Canada, is sponsoring a New England Atlantic Salmon Management Conference in West Springfield, Mass., next Friday and Saturday.

title: HOW DO WE CAPTURE A STAR'S GENIUS?
description: The Lincoln Center Film Society's tribute to Laurence Olivier April 25 was chockablock with people who are famous, recently famous or would-be famous. Never have my feet been stepped on by so many well-known actors, actresses, writers, directors and dressmakers. To paraphrase a line from Neil Simon's book for ''Sweet Charity,'' Avery Fisher Hall was so stuffed with celebrities that I was about the only person there I'd never heard of.

title: THE MUD MADE LOSING TOUGHER
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. The mud did not become the elegant white high heels or the bright green slacks as the owners of 19 horses sloshed to the barns. ''It's hard enough to lose in the sunshine,'' Wayne Lukas said, ''let alone in the rain.''

title: NEW DEACONS ARE FILLING MANY NEEDS
description: ridden husband, the other about an executive making the best of a job demotion.

title: 26 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 26 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and six that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: BILL TO PHASE IN RATE INCREASE BY UTILITIES GAINS IN HARTFORD
description: Legislation aimed at softening a sudden increase in electricity rates that Connecticut consumers could face with the completion of two major nuclear power plants was approved this week by the State House of Representatives.

title: Italy to Return To the Polls
description: Italy's Socialist Party, possibly encouraged by the good fortune of brother parties in France, Spain, Portugal and Greece, has been spoiling for an election. Last week it got its wish.

title: CLARE SHAFER TO MARRY GORDON JONES 3D IN FALL
description: The engagement of Claire Lynne Shafer to Gordon Lee Jones 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Bruce Shafer of Belvedere, Calif., parents of the future bride.

title: BETH E. ROCHFORD WEDS SALES AIDE
description: Beth Ellen Rochford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Rochford of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to John Bates Blankinship 3d, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Stanford Blankinship of Barnet Center, Vt. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly by the Rev. John Croneberger and the bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister in Barnet Center, Vt.

title: Article 150737 -- No Title
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been given more than half a million dollars by the Starr Foundation, the largest single gift in the fund's 71-year history.

title: Topics; Bursts of Color; Splat!
description: Bank robbery was once the stuff of bloody romance. Bonnie and Clyde, Depression folk heroes, stormed into banks, terrorized customers and made daring getaways under fusillades of police gunfire.

title: Blossom Hotline
description: Each spring, along with reporting all the usual weather, Japan's national meteorological agency keeps the Japanese posted on the advance of the cherry blossom, the national flower. Early forecasts are based on the weighing, dissecting and analyzing of buds cut from trees at a certain Tokyo shrine in March.

title: 2 WIN TOP PRESS CLUB AWARDS
description: Coverage of events in the Middle East dominated the 44th annual awards given last week by the Overseas Press Club. Two reporters won top awards for coverage of the Beirut massacre and two news organizations won for their coverage of the Middle East.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NURSING COST: CHANGES SOUGHT
description: SUMMIT AN 81-year-old woman suffering from a host of physical problems lay quietly in a medical-surgical unit at Overlook Hospital here last week. Incontinent and disoriented, unable to get out of bed or feed herself, she required intensive nursing care.

title: SUSANNAH D. CHRISTY WED TO M.P. MCCOY
description: Susannah Damon Christy, a daughter of Mrs. Priscilla Meek Christy of Potomac, Md., and Dr. Francis T. Christy Jr., of Rome, was married yesterday to Michael Patrick McCoy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Pierpont McCoy at Pacheo, Calif. The Rev. Dr. John Wesley Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: No Longer Barefoot
description: John Goodson, the Pittsburgh Steelers' barefoot punter who averaged 40.4 yards as a rookie last year, says he has discovered a way to improve his performance - wearing a shoe on his kicking foot. ''It does work incredibly better; the spirals are just unbelievable,'' he said.

title: JIDDA
description: AFTER four months of inconclusive negotiations and 12 days of grueling shuttle diplomacy by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Israel and Lebanon agreed last week on terms for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon. Mr. Shultz, who received grudging Israeli assent to his compromise plan in Jerusalem, proclaimed ''a milestone'' on the road to stabilization in Lebanon and a welcome lift for American Middle East diplomacy.

title: GERMAN PROVOCATEUR
description: SCENES FROM THE LIFE OF A FAUN, By Arno Schmidt. Translated by John E. Woods. 159 pp. New York: Marion Boyars. $13.95.

title: MARY MARS TO BE WED TO A RECTOR
description: The engagement of Mary Charlotte Mars of New York to the Rev. Franklin Andrew Mahlau, rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Hyde Park, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Mars of Sidney, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Reynold J. Mahlau of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Mahlau.

title: It's Party Time at the Downs
description: When he was preparing for last year's Kentucky Derby, the trainer Wayne Lukas says, a reporter not overly familiar with racing asked him: ''If your horse doesn't win this year, will you try again next year?''

title: THE DELIGHTS OF NESSELRODE
description: ne of the pleasures of writing about food is the seemingly unending delights in learning the origins and ramifications of food names. We have always been fascinated by the idea that the names of various celebrities have been perpetuated more for having a dish named after them than for their exploits.

title: CHINESE CUISINE, SLEEK DECOR
description: IT seems that these days the county's Chinese restaurants vary decor as much as cuisines. Nowhere is this divergence with red flocking and lacquer figurines better seen than in the sleek, ultramodern Pagoda restaurant. Perforated metal ceiling tiles, shiny enough to reflect the action beneath, recessed lights; and shoji-like walls surround a raised pagoda-shaped gazebo, which seats six to eight at a round table, and can be reserved in advance.

title: Force Ties Soccer Series By Defeating Blast, 6-3
description: Vic Davidson scored three goals and George Nanchoff two as the Cleveland Force defeated the Baltimore Blast, 6-3, in a Major Indoor Soccer League playoff game today, tying the Eastern Division championship series at two games each.

title: SOVIET MAY ADD SITES FOR MISSILES DIRECTED AT ASIA
description: The Soviet Union is making preparations that could lead to the virtual doubling of its SS-20 medium-range missiles targeted on Asia, Administration officials and intelligence experts said today.

title: JEWS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Business Editor: As a professional who mixes professionally and socially with Jews and non-Jews, your article has particular meaning to me. I am occasionally asked by non-Jewish co-workers: Do you consider yourself an American first or a Jew first? My answer is always the same: As long as there are country clubs that exclude me because I am Jewish, I don't have to make that choice. It has been made for me. JUDITH R. FIELDS

title: Q & A
description: Question:How can travelers find out about charter flights, especially those to Europe, from airports other than New York City's? - J.L., Miami, Fla. Answer:A monthly publication called Jax Fax Travel Marketing Magazine contains listings of charter flights; the May 1983 issue has, according to its cover, ''over 3,000 specific listings of 1983 flights & tours with dates and prices to more than 80 destinations.'' Jax Fax, which is subscribed to by travel agents around the country, is also available to individuals. (For a year's subscription, send a check for $12 to Jet Airtransport Exchange, Inc., 280 Tokeneke Road, Darien, Conn. 06820.)

title: Trickle-Down Theory Revisited And Explained
description: The Reagan Administration's social welfare policies have been widely criticized as unfairly harsh on the poor. But in Congressional testimony last week, budget director David A. Stockman maintained that parsimony was paying off - and making life less dreary for those who receive Government aid.

title: CONCERT: CZERNY WORK
description: Imaginations are often stirred by the prospect of forgotten music -pieces once played with regularity, even celebrated, but now ignored. But works like Czerny's Second Symphony - which was resuscitated by the Jupiter Symphony at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night - tend to throw cold water on our fantasies. Like so many unplayed artifacts from the past, it was a lot more interesting to think about than to hear.

title: BASKETBALL FANS PURSUE FIGHT
description: An specialist in market research, David E. Labson, took an informal survey two years ago, and its results convinced him that no one in Darien would oppose his plan to raise $35,000 to build a lighted outdoor basketball court.

title: No Headline
description: Having a Choice About a Job I'm sorry that Anne Dagosto (in ''Replies to 'Tomorrow, a Job': Choices or No Choice at All,'' Opinion Page, April 10) misunderstood the thrust of my article. What she labeled the ''murmuring of all the reasons why she can't look for a job'' was a litany of the feelings and concerns, not to mention the responsibilities, of a suburban mother and housewife considering re-entering the job market.

title: IS THE PASTORAL LETTER ON NUCLEAR WARFARE ONLY A BEGINNING?
description: AFTER nearly two years of study and debate, America's Roman Catholic bishops last week put the finishing touches on a pastoral letter on nuclear weapons. The document has blazed new trails in the church's teachings on social justice. The process of forging it has spotlighted the United States church hierarchy as perhaps no other issue in its history.

title: MCENROE TO MEET GERULAITIS IN FINAL
description: Swirling winds and John McEnroe's patience and touch blew away Guillermo Vilas's normally unflappable clay-court game yesterday, 6-1, 6-1, in the semifinals of the Mercedes Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills.

title: Stalemate in Hartford
description: ''Everything is a possibility, and nothing is a probability,'' a Connecticut legislator observed last week. That seemed a succinct assessment of a fiscal standoff in which the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee approved two alternative tax plans to close a $280 million deficit in the state's $3.5 billion budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: BUS LINES EVALUATE EFFECTS OF RAIL STRIKE
description: YONKERS OVERTIME for bus drivers has dwindled. Mechanics in the big Liberty Lines garage here are no longer asked to fill in as drivers at the end of their shifts. Vice presidents have stopped riding around in cars to keep an eye on bus stops.

title: BUOY TO BUOY AND BAR TO BAR, SAILORS CLEAR THE MISSISSIPPI
description: First, the black night sky grows gray over Illinois, dimming the stars and the caged lightbulbs on the deck of the aging ship tethered along the muddy riverbank that marks the edge of Iowa.

title: OPPENHEIMER OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: IN AN ORACULAR VEIN, AN academic named Chester A. Crocker once said of South Africa: ''That country is by its nature a part of the West. It is an integral and important element of the Western global, economic system.'' Mr. Crocker, who has since become the State Department's top Africa hand and author of the Reagan Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement'' with South Africa's white minority Government, was openly embracing a premise found in both South African propaganda and the arguments of Marxist analysts: that the West's formal condemnations of apartheid mask an enormous stake in the outcome of the shadowy struggle between the races there. ''Historically,'' he acknowledged, ''South Africa is by its nature a part of us.''

title: TV ROCKS WITH MUSIC
description: To a strong musical beat, melted cherry ice cream drips onto a woman sunning herself on a beach. A young man in a bathing suit sings about a woman who boards his yacht, her body painted orange, blue and green. Nearby, on an oceangoing raft, another man plays a saxophone.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Whistle While You Work

title: PLACIDITY IN STAMFORD, CLARITY IN GREENWICH
description: WHEN the call for art objects goes out far and wide, through city, countryside and hamlet, the resultant juried exhibition is bound to have a motley look. Such is the case with the Connecticut Painters and Sculptors Annual at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, through May 29.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF FACING TEST OF POWER
description: NASSAU COUNTY Republicans are expected to rally around Hempstead Town Councilman Joseph N. Mondello when they hold their special convention Thursday night at Hofstra University to formally complete the selection of a new party chairman.

title:
MUSIC ABROAD 1983;
A COMPENDIUM OF MUSICAL OFFERINGS
description: Vernon Kidd is a New York actor, singer and writer.

title: POLICE DEPT. GETTING MORE YOUTHFUL AURA AS ITS ROLLS INCREASE
description: The New York City Police Department will soon have a force that is the youngest in its history, with more women and members of minority groups.

title: Writers And Business
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN MASTERS, 68, WHO WROTE OF THE ROLE OF BRITISH IN INDIA
description: John Masters, whose tales of British Empire on the Indian subcontinent included ''Bhowani Junction,'' ''Nightrunners of Bengal'' and ''Coromandel,'' died Friday in Albuquerque, N.M., of complications after a heart-bypass operation. He was 68 years old, and resided in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Tewell Posts 65-206 For One-Shot Lead
description: Doug Tewell sank seven birdies en route to a 65 today and moved a stroke in front of Lee Trevino with 206 in the $400,000 Houston Open golf tournament.

title: CONCERT: WESTENBURG'S MUSICA SACRA
description: Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra can be counted on for eminently satisfying performances of the great (and, sometimes, refreshingly obscure) choral literature. Those performances are not always brilliant or challenging or boldly innovative from a stylistic standpoint.

title: Jill Owesny Plans To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Owesny of Spring Hill, Fla., formerly of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Allison Owesny, to James Ricketts Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Lawrence of Mount Kisco, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: A TRICKY LINE BETWEEN LAPSE AND LIBEL
description: What if the press wins its battles for laws protecting it from multimillion-dollar libel verdicts, but loses the war for the trust of a skeptical public? Journalists have worried about this for years.

title: Stahr Wins Relay for Carmel
description: Mike Stahr anchored his Carmel (N.Y.) High School team to victory in the distance medley relay at the New York Relays yesterday after receiving the baton in third place, 30 yards behind the leader.

title: 6TH GRADERS GET HARD LESSON FROM STATE: CLOSE DOWN
description: A group of students and a teacher who started a bank at school were learning a lot about high finance when the state decided to teach them a lesson about the law - by shutting them down.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FAITHFUL BEAN, FROM PLOT TO POT
description: IT has long been my theory that simple foods are often the best, and that heavily seasoned dishes originated as a means of covering up for rancidness or poor quality. Having recently received as a gift a plastic bag containing two cupfuls of dried beans, I had a chance to test this theory.

title: Only Legal Wars Are Worthy Wars
description: We are back to arguing not just about the wisdom of waging war but who decides.

title: MISS WHITE IS BETROTHED
description: The engagement of Nancy Carolyn White to George Frank Bryant Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bryant of Rye, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. White of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Grand Deception
description: William Cohn of Miami flew Pan American World Airways to faraway places for two years - London, Honolulu, Johannesburg, Hong Kong - and saved at least $40,000 in air fares. The 31-year-old operator of a novelty shop masqueraded as a flight attendant.

title: U.S. STUDY GIVES SOVIET HEALTH SYSTEM LOW MARKS
description: A report by the Joint Economic Committee of Congress concludes that the health-care system of the Soviet Union is responsible for a decreased life expectancy, decreased fertility and increased infant mortality.

title: STUDY ASSAILS PENTAGON ARGUMENT FOR EXPANDING CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The Defense Department's argument that the United States should produce new nerve gas weapons to offset Soviet advances in chemical warfare is seriously flawed, according to a study sent to Congress by the General Accounting Office.

title: TGV: LE TRAIN A GRANDE VITESSE
description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: Stepmothers
description: Sentiment retouches our mental snapshot of the American family with its beaming mom and dad and 2.3 children in their Sunday best. Look past the supposed prototype and you may see someone else in the picture, a woman with an anxious expression and a tight smile. Hers is the hardest role in a changing family. No songs canonize her virtues. No greeting cards lavish their bad verse on her. Florists ignore her claim to filial tribute. She is the anomalous extra: the stepmother.

title: HAVE CURRENCIES FLOATED TOO LONG?
description: IN the world of foreign currencies, yesterday's solution has become today's problem. The system of ''floating'' exchange rates devised 10 years ago to avoid the crunching and often humiliating devaluations of the postwar period, has produced an equally troublesome era of currency volatility that many believe now threatens the world's emerging recovery.

title: Pony Express Rides Again
description: When the Pony Express went back into business for the first time in 122 years, Byron Clark, for one, couldn't have been happier. Mr. Clark, a 51-year-old feed store keeper from Carson City, Nev. is one of 10 volunteers who are carrying mail by horseback along a 40-mile route temporarily blocked to vehicles by a rock slide.

title: NEW TACK TAKEN ON CHILD ABUSE
description: NEWARK WITH the incidence of child abuse increasing, partly because of the straitened economy, state officials have obtained funds for a program designed to help families cope with stress and other problems before the parents take out their frustrations on their children.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: Size: Seven to nine and half inches.

title: U.S. JEWISH STUDENTS PROTEST ISRAELI POLICY IN A LETTER TO BEGIN
description: Jewish students at three leading American law schools, in a letter to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, have protested Israel's invasion of Lebanon and its treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories.

title: AT COLLEGES, A SEASON OF CHANGES
description: These are times of change for many of the Island's colleges. With graduation ceremonies scheduled for the coming weeks, the institutions are already focusing on the next academic year.

title: No Headline
description: Correction: In Home Design Part 2 of April 17, the photograph on page 57 was incorrectly identified. It is a model of an early design for Trump Plaza at 167 East 61st Street.

title: ART ON THE MARCH
description: Charles Grabareck, a 28-year-old Hartford artist, received his doctorate in painting in 1979 from the University of Massachusetts, where he studied with John Grillo. Currently a member of Artworks Gallery, the Asylum Hill Artists' Cooperative in Hartford, he has become somewhat impatient with the pace of his career:

title: U.S. SAYS STATE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR EVACUATION PLAN
description: A top official of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, disputing a position taken by Governor Cuomo, said today that the Governor had the ultimate ''legal responsibility'' in developing an evacuation plan to be used in the event of a nuclear accident in New York State.

title: LUCY CAROL ARONSON TO MARRY JACOB A. GREENBURG
description: Dr. and Mrs. Allan R. Aronson of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Carol Aronson, to Jacob A. Greenburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Greenburg of Oceanside, L.I.

title: ONE-FAMILY PROJECT
description: Last fall, as most summer people were leaving for the season, Peggy Stanton of Quogue, L.I., her 26-year-old son, David, and her daughter, Sarah, 22, bought a disheveled but sturdy clapboard house in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: SHELLEY THARAUD MARRIES DENIS DANIELS ON COAST
description: Shelley Mace Tharaud, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Poincare Tharaud of San Francisco and formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Tharaud, was married yesterday to Dennis Daniels, son of Mrs. Worth W. Daniels of San Mateo, Calif., and the late Mr. Daniels. The Rev. Richard C. Fowler of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in San Francisco. performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: YES, HUNGRY CHILDREN RIGHT HERE ON L.I.
description: AT the Mill Pond in Stony Brook, where children try to entice overfed ducks with freshly purchased bread, it is difficult to believe that, not 10 miles away, there are children who are poor and hungry. It seems impossible that some children know real need nearby, while the children and even the ducks at the Mill Pond know only plenty.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ACORPS of judges past the mandatory retirement age, but still eager to adjudicate, have come out of retirement to help the state clear some of its judicial backlog. In doing so, they have saved the state and 17 counties thousands of dollars.

title: LEONARD SIEGEL
description: Leonard Siegel, vice president and director of special situations research at the New York stock brokerage of Josephthal & Company, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 48 years old.

title: Another Pothole For Westway
description: Like many a West Side motorist, Westway has run into delay after delay. Last week it hit another bump when an adviser to Governor Cuomo released a report calling it ''a luxury the city and state probably cannot afford.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
U.S. MINT IS CRITICIZED FOR ITS FALSE ECONOMICS
description: The United States Mint has come under fire from critics in Congress and members of the coin collecting hobby for what they consider excessive penny-pinching. The critics contend that the Mint, one of the Federal government's most profitable agencies, has been cutting too many corners in its budget - and, in some instances, reaping false economies.

title: SPURS' COACH SEES A DIFFERENT RESULT
description: Stan Albeck, the San Antonio Spurs' coach, knows that the Los Angeles Lakers beat his team soundly last year en route to the National Basketball Association championship, but this time things will be different.

title: 'SHOOTING FROM THE LIP' ENFORCES NO ARMS BAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran and Iraq Join Parley On Controlling Oil Slick
description: Iran and Iraq joined other Persian Gulf countries today at talks here on controlling a giant oil slick threatening their coasts, according to officials of the conference.

title: CLAIRE MCG. DIBBLE WEDS
description: The marriage of Claire McGuire Dibble of East Hampton, L.I., widow of Willis A. Dibble, to Harold J. White of Upper Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Daniel E. Fagan performed the ceremony. Mr. White, whose first wife died, is president of the I.J. White Corporation, metal fabricators in Farmingdale, L.I.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALL AMERICAN MUSIC, by John Rockwell. (Alfred A. Knopf, $15.95.) A study of contemporary American music, popular and highbrow.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A LULL IN ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD THIS normally would be the beginning of the annual legislative season known as the adjournment rush. The General Assembly is just over four weeks away from its constitutional adjournment date of June 8, and a lot of work is still to be done.

title: GUN LOBBY LEADER BEATS A CHALLENGER
description: A challenge to the leadership of the National Rifle Association by a militant faction was decisively rejected today.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Handmade Selections At Up to 50% Off Handmade Gifts in Hartsdale Village stocks wares of American artisans and craftsmen, usually at full retail prices, but this month there are 20 to 50 percent reductions on selected categories. The markdowns precede the Circus Day sidewalk sale May 14 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. During that villagewide promotion, free parking is available on the top level of the municipal lot; at other times, parking is metered.

title: WALESA IS PICKED UP BY POLICE
description: Lech Walesa was picked up by the police after a meeting in Warsaw Friday night and driven back to his home in Gdansk by security agents before dawn, it was learned today.

title: THE LOSING TRIBES
description: NOW THAT THE BUFFALO'S GONE A Study of Today's American Indians. By Alvin M. Josephy Jr. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.THE SPIRTUAL LEGACY OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN By Joseph Epes Brown. 135 pp. New York: Crossroad $10.95.

title: SPRING SHOWCASE IN WEST ORANGE
description: WEST ORANGE COLLECTORS of ceramics, glass and jewelry who have not yet discovered the Towne Gallery here might find a selection of works assembled for a ''spring showcase'' a good reason to search it out.

title: WATERMELON FROM SEED
description: Each summer, with a clear conscience, I grow dozens of watermelons in New England. Midget varieties which mature in 65 to 75 days include Yellow Baby; You Sweet Thing; Northern Sweet; Park's Whopper and Sugar Baby.

title: No Headline
description: Ideas for New York City I agree with Andrew J. Stein's premise in ''Wanted: Ideas for New York City'' (March 20) that ''we must evolve specific new programs that nurture our business community, particularly the service industries.'' In presenting his recommendations for developing service industries, Mr. Stein fails to provide an immediate and logical solution to increase employment and stimulate economic recovery in New York City.

title: SHOULD CHANCE DECIDE THE OUTCOME OF A MATCH?
description: A roulette ball dropping into a red slot of the wheel gave Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union his victory in his quarterfinal world championship candidates match with Robert Hubner of West Germany. To have such a contest decided by chance is undesirable, but so far FIDE (the International Chess Federation) has no better solution.

title: MY MOTHER ELENI
description: The beautiful story of Eleni's love and sacrifice was engrossing. I could feel Nicholas Gage's pain as he journeyed to Greece to seek out his mother's executioners.

title: DEMAND STRAINING SOFTBALL FACILITIES
description: IN towns across Westchester, the silence of twilight in the suburbs is being punctuated by the crack of bats and the pounding of mitts, the bellows of umpires and the cheers of spectators. Spawned by the warm air and longer days of spring, softball fever has the county in its grasp and probably won't break until well into September.

title: SHOULD ISRAEL RECOGNIZE THE P.L.O.?
description: A PALESTINIAN STATE, The Implications for Israel. By Mark A. Heller. 190 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $16.

title: TROUBLES FOR THE CENTURY ON CENTRAL PARK
description: FROM its construction in 1930, with its Art Deco facade reaching 32 stories on twin towers, the Century a partment building has been one of the most imposing structures on C entral Park West.

title: A Different View Of Baldwin Sportsnite
description: Some 20-odd years ago, I was a participant in several of Baldwin High School's supergala Sportsnites, but my memories of them as a participant are quite different from Fred McMorrow's view of them as an observer (''About Long Island,'' April 24).

title: MY DAYS IN HOLLYWOOD
description: Irene Mayer Selznick, daughter of Louis B. Mayer and wife of David O. Selznick, grew up in Hollywood during its golden age, in the 1920's and early 1930's, when movies not only set the style for everything from women's hair fashions to men's undershirts but also gave America its largest vision of itself. The triumphs and follies of the stars were the folk tales of America, and fan magazines were required reading for millions. Hollywood was at the top of the scale in American popular culture, and Irene Mayer Selznick's father and then her husband sat atop that town. Louis B. Mayer, as head of production for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, was the most important film maker of his time, producing dozens of popular hits - with ''more stars than there are in heaven,'' including Greta Garbo, Joan Crawford and Clark Gable. David O. Selznick reached the apex of his career with ''Gone With the Wind,'' released in 1939, which for years remained the most popular and most profitable of all Hollywood movies. After her Hollywood days, Irene Mayer Selznick came into her own - not just as daughter and wife - but as a leading Broadway producer, most notably of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' ''Bell, Book and Candle'' and ''The Chalk Garden.'' Her memoirs, ''A Private View,'' from which this article is adapted, will be published by Knopf later this month. HAVE no idea exactly when David first proposed, but I had been startled by very early intimations from him.

title: Gas Decontrol
description: To the Business Editor: I read with interest and disbelief Prof. Herman Schwartz's letter (April 17) on natural gas deregulation. I am a small producer of natural gas who gets $1.85 per thousand cubic feet before payment of state insurance taxes. You bet I want total deregulation. Why should others get $10, $5, or whatever for the same product? What other commodity market operates in a similar manner? MACCALLUM RIENHOFF

title: MALONE-LANIER IS KEY MATCHUP IN SERIES
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have the excitement of Julius Erving, the explosiveness of Andrew Toney and the playmaking of Maurice Cheeks. The Milwaukee Bucks have the scoring ability of Marques Johnson, the all-round play of Sidney Moncrief and a roster whose versatility only the Los Angeles Lakers can match.

title: REFORM IS NEEDED ON CON ED RATES
description: IF one lives in Westchester County, three things are certain: death, taxes and the highest utility rates in the country. The situation will not change unless our county and state lawmakers adopt some significant reforms in the area of utility-rate setting.

title: CARRIAGE ADDS TO A WEDDING
description: STEWART G. THOMSON and his wife, Sara, of Easton spend more time in carriages on weekends than most folks do in cars. This means of transportation has become a source of delight for them and for the dozens of brides they drive to the church and to reception ceremonies each year by a horse-pulled antique carriage.

title: New Findings Add to Mystery Of Heart Disease
description: From the medical experts who thought diet, high blood pressure and cigarette smoking play a role in the risk of heart attack, but who couldn't say what role, comes another enticing research result: Men who suffer heart attacks have more of the female sex hormone estradiol than other men.

title: 5 More Die in Fighting In Hills Around Beirut
description: Christian and Druse militamen clashed in the hills overlooking Beirut in the night, leaving 5 more dead and raising the three-day toll to 23 killed and 70 wounded, the police said today. The shelling tapered off at dawn.

title: ARGENTINE GENERALS PAVE PERONISTS' PATH TO POWER
description: The Government's recent report on terrorism said little about what happened to thousands of Argentines who disappeared, evidently while in the hands of state security forces, in the 1970's. But it said a great deal about the changing political aims of the country's military rulers.

title: EBAN GETS APOLOGY FROM U.S. GROUP
description: A new American Jewish organization has sent an apology to Abba Eban, former Foreign Minister of Israel, for distributing statements by Mr. Eban in a direct-mail fund-raising effort that went to 60,000 American Jews.

title: GOOD BUYS IN THE THRIFT BUSINESS
description: LOS ANGELES ALTHOUGH stock prices for many savings and loan associations have tripled in the last year with the drop in interest rates and rising mortgage demand, some analysts still see pockets of opportunity for investors in the thrift business.

title: DESPERATE REMEDIES
description: 1934 By Alberto Moravia. Translated by William Weaver. 297 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.50.

title: 3 BROWNSTONES IN THE REMAKING
description: A glimpse inside three Harlem brownstones in various stages of renovation will be part of a daylong workshop and tour next Sunday that is designed to inspire and inform people who are interested in the rebirth of this upper Manhattan neighborhood.

title: ROBERTA BELLER TO MARRY
description: Betty S. Beller of Woodmere, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Roberta D. Beller, to Dr. Robert Andrew Frankenthaler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Frankenthaler of New York.

title: INDIAN POINT IS NOT ALONE IN LACK OF AN APPROVED EMERGENCY PLAN
description: None of the five sites with operating nuclear power plants in New York and New Jersey have federally approved emergency evacuation plans, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: SMALL TOUCHES MEAN SO MUCH
description: THE art of ''muruwwa'' is disappearing from the world. ''Muruwwa'' is the Bedouin code of the desert. If a stranger arrives at your tent seeking shelter and food, you must give him a place to sleep and your last piece of bread, if necessary. This hospitality and graciousness at times seems to be lacking in the world today.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HISTORIC HOUSE TOURS
description: It may be Mother's Day today, but it's also the start of Historic Preservation Week, and the Huntington Historical Society has come up with a way to mark both occasions: a tour of the Old Town Green Historic District. A collection of buildings from the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries that have been preserved by private individuals, the neighborhood, society spokesmen say, truly exemplifies the theme of this year's national celebration, ''Preservation Is Housing America.''

title: No Headline
description: The Public and Organ Transplants Congratulations on Harry Schwartz's article ''Toward the Conquest of Heart Disease'' (March 27). I must comment on one issue, however, and that is the general public's negative attitude toward donation.

title: FREEZE-OUT IN GLITTER GULCH
description: THE BIGGEST GAME IN TOWN, By A. Alvarez. 185 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: Youths Pelt Miami Police With Stones and Bottles
description: Small bands of youths pelted the police with stones and bottles and looted two stores over three hours early today after officers broke up a noisy street party in the Overtown section, the authorities said.

title: JANE U. RIPPETEAU TO BECOME BRIDE OF KEVIN HEFFRON
description: Mr. and Mrs. Darrel D. Rippeteau of Watertown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane U. Rippeteau of New York to Kevin L. Heffron, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Heffron of Upper Saddle River, N.J.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WAR COMES TO WILLY FREEMAN By James Lincoln Collier and Christopher Collier. 178 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $12.95. (Ages 11 to 15)

title: OPERA: BERLIOZ'S 'CELLINI' IN CONCERT AT CARNEGIE
description: THE French taste in opera has long run in two opposite and seemingly unreconcilable directions. On one hand, there is the concentration, almost amounting to obsession, with grandeur, mythic deeds, heroic striving and all that. But, running against this current, there also is a French taste for prosaic comedy.
