It is typical of the French that they institutionalized this personality split in the 19th century by establishing one opera house where only works considered grand could be performed and another where the repertory was restricted to what we might now call music theater.

title: U.S. BANKS IRKED BY FRANCE
description: Strains have been developing in the relationships between the major American banks and the French Government, mainly as a result of France's severe economic problems and the growing politicization of the French banking system, according to American bankers in Paris.

title: IN HILLS OF EAST INDIA, A CHRISTIAN VISION SURVIVES
description: In the 19th century Christian missionaries from the West traveled to India's northeast region seeking converts among the tough hill tribes.

title: I.M.F. Easing Chile Loan
description: Chile, suffering from a deep recession, has failed to meet terms of a loan set by the International Monetary Fund in January and easier terms are being arranged, according to financial sources.

title: PROBLEMS MOUNT FOR UTILITIES
description: The nuclear power industry, already reeling from stagnant demand for electricity, huge cost overruns for new construction and mounting environmental opposition, has been dealt a devastating blow by the Federal Government in recent actions, several of the nation's biggest utilities said over the weekend.

title: Braves 4, Astros 3
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Rick Behenna combined with three relievers on a six-hitter and Bob Horner singled home the tie-breaking run in the fifth.

title: 7 Israelis Hurt in Lebanon
description: A bomb blast wounded seven Israeli soldiers, most of them slightly, south of Beirut today, the Israeli military command said.

title: EX-AIDE IN LABORATORY SAYS DATA ON SOAP INGREDIENT WERE FALSIFIED
description: A former technician of a large research laboratory has testified in Federal District Court that scientists falsified data in studies of a substance that was cleared for use in bath soaps and other products.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SOLOISTS SHINE IN TRIBUTE TO BRAHMS
description: BRAHMS'S Double Concerto for Violin and Cello could almost be considered an instrumental trio with the orchestra playing a third solo part. But Saturday night, as Johannes Brahms was honored by Zubin Mehta conducting the New York Philharmonic in its pension-fund benefit in Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestral role was overshadowed by the accomplishments of the soloists. The cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the violinist Gidon Kremer, playing exactly 150 years after the composer's birth on May 7, 1833, and substituting for the indisposed Rudolf Serkin, put the emphasis not on late Romantic autumnal melancholy or thickly textured outbursts, but on a contemporary, stringent, lyrical urgency.

title: Market Place; Ignoring Calls For Correction
description: THE stock market shrugged off a sinking spell last Monday, then regrouped its forces and, amid a surge of trading volume, finished Friday at record highs for the fourth week in a row. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange swelled to 515.5 million shares, marking the busiest week of this year.

title: FILENE'S OF BOSTON ENTERS NEW YORK WITH QUEENS STORE
description: The Filene's chain of Boston, which a year ago chose Long Island as the site of its first expansion outside New England and now operates three stores there, has opened its first New York City store, in Queens.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I grew up in a tough neighborhood in Rhode Island. If someone took a swing at me, being a good Irishman, I would say swing back.

title: Ayer Resigns At Blue Cross
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shields Associations, based in Chicago, confirmed Friday that N.W. Ayer's office out there had resigned the business after a seven-year relationship.

title: DENVER'S MAYOR IS ISSUE AFTER TENURE OF 14 YEARS
description: The downtown is a forest of construction cranes and sleek new office towers of glass and steel. The suburbs sprawl onto the surrounding plains and lap against the nearby mountains, absorbing an average of 100 new residents each day.

title: Nicaragua to Seek U.N. Peacekeeping Force
description: Nicaragua will ask the Security Council on Monday for a United Nations peacekeeping force to patrol border areas, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: SHULTZ IS CHEERED BY SAUDI REACTION TO PULLOUT PLAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was very encouraged by Saudi Arabia's reaction to the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement and to his efforts to bring about a pullout of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

title: COSMOS DOWN STRIKERS IN OVERTIME, 3-2
description: The Cosmos rallied from a two-goal deficit and defeated the Fort Lauderdale Strikers, 3-2, in suddendeath overtime today before a crowd of 25,134 at Giants Stadium.

title: HOLLYWOOD PAYS COURT TO FRANK YABLANS, THE NEW BOSS AT M-G-M/U.A.
description: Frank Yablans's eggs are getting cold. It is three months into his new job as vice chairman and chief operating officer of M-G-M/U.A., and he manages, at most, two bites of toast between handshakes.

title: Miss Coles Wins by 6
description: Janet Coles shot a steady three-under-par 69 today and was never seriously challenged as she won the $150,000 Lady Michelob golf tournament by six strokes.

title: COUNCIL OF CHURCHES, MEETING THIS WEEK, IS FACING DISCORD
description: The National Council of Churches, the largest ecumenical organization in the United States, will confront some of the most difficult issues in its history when it meets in San Francisco this week.

title: Debt Issues
description: * The Republic of Finland filed for an offering of up to $400,000,000 in notes and/or bonds; underwriters have not been determined.

title: NAZI MEMENTO MARKET FULL OF FRAUD
description: The volumes that Stern magazine presented as lost Hitler diaries are only the most recent forgeries to emerge from a market for Nazi memorabilia that crosses geographical and ideological borders.

title: SON OF MOB INFORMER TESTIFIES OF FEARS IF HE IS RETURNED TO MOTHER
description: The 13-year-old son of a Government informer testified Saturday in Federal District Court that he feared retribution by organized crime here if he was returned to his mother's custody.

title: MISSING ARGENTINES: FAMILIES' HOPES BETRAYED
description: On Thursday Susana Martinez Duran's hopes were high. After quickly arranging things at home in the southern city of Neuquen, she flew 700 miles to the capital.

title: COMPUTER LENDING GROWS AT PUBLIC LIBRARIES
description: When librarians at the Connetquot Public Library in Bohemia, L.I., announced in a recent newsletter that the library would soon have three personal computers that could be checked out and taken home, they were nearly overwhelmed by the response.

title: A $1 CABLE FEE FOR TV HOOKUP UPHELD BY STATE
description: Most landlords will continue to be paid a $1 fee for each building by companies installing cable television wires along the walls and roofs of their apartment houses, according to officials of the State Commission on Cable Television.

title: GRAHAM CARDS A 64 FOR 5-SHOT VICTORY
description: David Graham rallied from five strokes off the lead and shot a 64 today to win the $400,000 Houston Open golf tournament by five strokes.

title: GIVE TUITION CREDITS
description: President Reagan has again submitted to Congress his proposal to give tax credits to parents who send their children to private schools. Echoing Teddy Roosevelt at San Juan, he said he would ''charge up that Hill until we get a victory.'' The President deserves support. Despite assertions that tax credits are somehow illiberal, they are in fact profoundly democratic.

title: Volume Down Sharply In This Week's Issues
description: This week's volume of corporate and Treasury financing is expected to fall off sharply from last week, although record amounts of new issues are expected in coming months.

title: Washington Watch; Oil Company Tax Measures
description: WASHINGTON DESPITE their enormous size - or perhaps partly because of it - the large integrated oil companies have in recent years been most unsuccessful in resisting political pressures to make them pay higher taxes.

title: BRETT EXTENDS HIT STREAK TO 19
description: George Brett hit a two-run home run in the top of the fifth inning yesterday, extending his consecutive game hitting streak to 19 and helping the Royals defeat the Blue Jays, 6-1, at Toronto.

title: French Skipper Expected to Win
description: Philippe Jeantot, sailing the 56-foot cutter Credit Agricole, is expected to be the first across the finish line Monday in the BOC Challenge, the single-handed race around the world.

title: STUDIES FOCUS ON DECAY IN U.S. PHYSICAL FACILITIES
description: Efforts to repair the country's decaying physical facilities are under way at all levels of government and among private institutions.

title: Girl in Valdez Case Said to Have Lied
description: The 14-year-old girl the police say had sexual relations with Julio Valdez of the Boston Red Sox says she lied to him about her age and hopes he will not get into ''a lot of trouble,'' according to a published report today.

title: McEnroe Lobs Way to Title
description: The lob, almost forgotten in the serve-and-volley world of men's tennis, became John McEnroe's most effective weapon yesterday in his 6-3, 7-5 victory over Vitas Gerulaitis for the $100,000 first prize in the Mercedes Tournament of Champions.

title: Mubarak Briefed by U.S.
description: The United States Ambassador, Alfred L. Atherton Jr., briefed President Hosni Mubarak and Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali today on the efforts of Secretary of State George P. Shultz in the Middle East.

title: Vermont Faces Record Deficit
description: With Vermont facing a major budget deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30, Gov. Richard A. Snelling says he may call the Legislature back for a special session in the fall unless revenue increases significantly.

title: JANE COHLER ROSS
description: Jane Cohler Ross, vice president for public relations and communications for the auction house of Christie, Manson & Woods International Inc., died of cancer Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: Killings in Peru Put at 866
description: Peru's Interior Minister has told the country's Senate that 866 people have died in guerrilla violence in the central Andes since the end of 1980, local newspapers reported today. In a confidential report to a defense committee on Thursday, the minister, Luis Percovich, said also that 2,400 suspected members of the Shining Path guerrilla group had been arrested, the newspapers said.

title: A WORLD WAR II INTERNMENT OPPOSED BY BIDDLE
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: I GUILLARI DI PIAZZA
description: TALKING animals, fairies, ogresses and evil spirits cavorted in colorful style on Saturday at the New York University Theater, where I Giullari di Piazza, the Italian folk-music theater, handsomely recreated an evening of early Neapolitan theater. Featuring six actor-singers playing multiple roles, and an instrumental ensemble directed by John La Barbera, the program offered two interrelated folk tales in the court style of Neapolitan commedia dell'arte.

title: Advertising; Ally Wins Big Again In Awards
description: ALLY & Gargano once again scored the best at The One Show, the season's first important presentation of advertising awards, although it didn't quite overwhelm the event as it did last year.

title: Libya Frees 4 West Germans As Part of Prisoner Exchange
description: Libya today freed four West Germans serving long prison terms after West Germany deported a Libyan jailed for life for the killing of a former Libyan diplomat, a Government spokesman said.

title: Dr. Teresa McKinley Wed In Long Island Ceremony
description: At Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday Dr. Teresa McKinley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. McKinley of San Diego, was married to Dr. David Schaer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Schaer of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Posner.

title: Blitz 31, Federals 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Tim Spencer and Kevin Long scored two touchdowns each to lead the Blitz. The victory, Chicago's second over the Federals this season, lifted Chicago to a 7-3 record.

title: CUT IN INCOME TAX LIKELY TO SURVIVE
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee, said today he did not think there was any chance President Reagan's 10 percent income tax cut, scheduled to take effect July 1, would be repealed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Education and Religion

title: Don't Tinker With the Hospice Program
description: A few months before his death from bone cancer, Father Vincent Pulicano, who founded Manhattan's Cabrini Hospice, spoke of the dying. ''They want their own bed,'' he said, ''the bed they have been sleeping in for 30, 40, 45 years; the same pictures on the walls; to hear the same noises of children on the street, to see their loved ones.'' Yet for 75 percent of Americans, the final exit is preceded by a cruel departure from their own small world of home and family.

title: A TOUCH OF ORANGE
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. THE first thing to know about Patty Cross is that she likes Mexican food so much that she opened a Mexican restaurant in Ontario to be able to get her hands on an enchilada when she needed one.

title: ECONOMIC PARLEY IN PARIS WILL SEEK TO SETTLE DISPUTES
description: Major negotiations will begin here today aimed at keeping the incipient global economic recovery on course and resolving the Reagan Administration's dispute with its West European allies over trading with the Soviet bloc.

title: FOSTER'S HOMER PACES MET VICTORY
description: Even Casey Stengel would have called it amazin'. The 1983 variety of his old New York Mets team came back from a 5-0 deficit and beat the Cincinnati Reds by 10-5 yesterday with the help of a three-run homer by George Foster in the seventh inning.

title: IF GUERRILLAS WON'T PLAY
description: What does the United States do if the Salvadoran guerrillas don't want free elections?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Principle on Park Ave.

title: A New 4-Party Coalition Announced in Thailand
description: A four-party coalition and 44-member Cabinet have been formed after nearly three weeks of talks among winners of general elections held April 18, the Thai radio announced.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On Desegregation In School, Separate Is Still Unequal To the Editor: Your April 22 editorial ''The Good News About Busing,'' discussing its workability and successes, is on the mark precisely because it has become socially acceptable to be openly opposed to desegregation of the public schools.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 293 COMPANIES;
description: (Loss) *not applicable, loss in 1982 period. (1) Three months to Jan. 31. (2) Three months to Feb. 28. (3) Three months to April 30.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Astros at Houston, 8:35 P.M. The Mets, who have won only one game on the road this season, start a seven-game trip, opening with three in the Astrodome.

title: A NEW CHAPTER FOR PILOT PEN
description: For the Pilot Pen Company, Japan's largest pen maker, such lines of business as computer software, building materials and office automation seem far afield indeed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Cemetery Sale

title: Newfoundland Is Named Best
description: The biggest animal in the ring, a 155-pound Newfoundland, Ch. Seward's Blackbeard, tonight was named best of 2,848 dogs at the 54th all-breed show of the Trenton Kennel Club at Mercer County Park.

title: REAGAN'S GRAND PLAN TO PAY INDIAN CLAIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, has elected Camron Cooper, William M. Fischbach, Howard H. Ockelmann and Dwaine H. Smith vice presidents.

title: Giants 12, Pirates 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Darrell Evans drove in five runs with two homers, and Jack Clark had a two-run homer as the Giants won their fifth straight.

title: Rutherford in Indy-Practice Mishap
description: Johnny Rutherford, a three-time winner here, severely damaged his race car today but escaped serious injury when he smashed his new Wildcat racer into the wall of the first turn at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway during practice for the May 29 Indianapolis 500.

title: Berenter Wins Account For Italian Sports Cars
description: Last week was a good one for Berenter, Greenhouse, Elgort. It won International Automobile Importers, which will be selling the Pininfarina and Bertone Italian sports cars. I.A.I. is run by Malcolm Bricklin, the man that brought the Subaru to America.

title: FLY FISHING FOR STRIPERS
description: AS one who has struggled for more than 30 years to become dedicated to the endeavor, I feel qualified to offer advice to those who would become accomplished saltwater fly fishermen, particularly for the much-esteemed striped bass.

title: Nevada Bill on Pornography
description: The Nevada Legislature passed a bill Saturday making it a crime to possess child pornography. The penalty for conviction would be six months in jail and $1,000 fine.

title: 2 Aliens Killed in Crash Of Truck in Texas Chase
description: A truck carrying illegal aliens flipped over and burst into flames Saturday.

title: MONDAY, MAY 9, 1983; International
description: Economic ministers meet in Paris today in a bid to further a global economic recovery and to try to resolve the Reagan Administration's opposition to trading with Soviet bloc nations. The outcome of the two-day meeting, the largest ever assembled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, is viewed as critical to the success of this month's scheduled economic summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va. (Page A1.)

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 9, 1983
description: International Saudi Arabia's reaction to the Israeli-Lebanon withdrawal agreement and to efforts to bring about a Syrian pullout from Lebanon was very encouraging, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said after talks with King Fahd and Prince Saud of Saudi Arabia. From Saudi Arabia, Mr. Shultz went to Israel and then to Lebanon for an unexpected meeting with Lebanese leaders that was aimed at bolstering their morale in the face of stepped-up Syrian pressure to renounce the agreement. (Page A1, Column 6.) A major economic meeting in Paris that is to start today will attempt to keep the world economy on course for recovery and to resolve the Reagan Administration's bitter dispute with its European allies over trading with the Soviet bloc. It will bring together the trade, finance and foreign affairs ministers from Western countries in the largest meeting ever called by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The outcome is likely to have a decisive influence on the economic summit of the seven major industrial nations at Williamsburg, Va., this month. (A1:2.)

title: Alexandra Mezey Wed To C.T. Stites, Editor
description: Alexandra Mezey, daughter of Margaret M. Fitzgerald of Sykesville, Md., and the late Alexander Mezey, was married yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls to C. Thomas Stites. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: F.C.C. BUDGET HEARINGS STIR BROADCAST BATTLE
description: A seemingly routine bill to provide the Federal Communications Commission with its yearly budget has become the focal point of a bitter backroom fight between the National Association of Broadcasters and Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, chairman of the telecommunications subcommittee, the most influential House member on communications matters. A vote is tentatively scheduled for Tuesday.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Alice Allison Dunnigan, 77, A Journalist and U.S. Official
description: Alice Allison Dunnigan, a retired Government official who had been chief of the Washington bureau of the old Associated Negro Press from 1947 to 1961, died Friday of abdominal anemia in Providence Hospital in Washington. She was 77 years old.

title: TV: TWAIN'S 'INNOCENTS ABROAD'
description: MARK TWAIN continues to exhibit considerable resistance to being dramatized. This time it is ''The Innocents Abroad,'' adapted by Dan Wakefield, that falls disconcertingly flat. The production, being broadcast on Channel 13 at 9 this evening, kicks off a ''Mark Twain Festival,'' which will continue for three more Mondays on ''Great Performances'' with repeat showings of ''Life on the Mississippi,'' ''The Mysterious Stranger'' and ''The Private History of a Campaign That Failed.''

title: 76ERS WIN IN OPENER, 111-109
description: Clint Richardson, noted more for his defense than his offense, scored all 7 of the Philadelphia 76ers' points in overtime today to help them to a 111-109 playoff victory over the Milwaukee Bucks at the Spectrum.

title: 'The Dresser' to Be a Film
description: Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay will star in the film version of ''The Dresser,'' Ronald Harwood's two-caracter theatrical comedy. Shooting will begin in London later this month. Mr. Courtenay, who played Norman, the dresser, in the London and Broadway productions, will recreate the role for the movie. Peter Yates is the director and producer; Mr. Harwood wrote the screenplay.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*8.78 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*11.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: FAMILIES AS VICTIMS OF STROKE
description: AGED couple is having a leisurely Sunday breakfast in a d iner when, suddenly, the man explodes in a torrent of obscenities. L eaning across the table, his wife sings softly into his ear, ' 'Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you.'' The man falls s ilent.

title: BONN SEEKS VILLAIN IN THE HITLER HOAX
description: The West German Interior Ministry has opened an investigation to uncover the sources of the ''diaries'' of Adolf Hitler, which Government experts determined Friday were forgeries, a senior ministry official said today.

title: JAPANESE EXPRESS CONCERN OVER REPORT SOVIET MAY INCREASE MISSILES
description: Japanese Government officials expressed concern today over a report from Washington that the Soviet Union is making preparations that could lead to a virtual doubling of its SS-20 medium-range missiles targeted on Asia.

title: JUSTICES URGE SIGNIFICANT SHIFTS IN U.S. TRIAL RULES
description: The Supreme Court has formally adopted and sent to Congress new rules of procedure for the Federal courts that could substantially change the way many Federal trials are conducted.

title: MANY IN BUCHANAN HOPE INDIAN POINT STAYS OPEN
description: Richard Suessenbach can see the nuclear power plants from his back porch only in winter, after the leaves from the dogwood and oak trees are down.

title: Books Of The Times
description: PRESENT HISTORY. By Theodore Draper. 467 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: 2 Strong Aftershocks Jolt Devastated Coast Town
description: Two strong aftershocks jolted this San Joaquin Valley community tonight, six days after a major earthquake seriously injured 47 people and destroyed or damaged most of the town's 2,700 homes.

title: WILLY LOMAN IN PEKING
description: Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' directed by the author and starring Stephen Ying, who translated the play into Chinese, opened in Peking last week.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Old York to New

title: CRANSTON, 68, SEEKS TO 'WEAR DOWN' COMPETITORS
description: Senator Alan Cranston has had one day off since January, and most nights find him in hotels far from home. When it rains he takes his habitual morning run in the corridors, confident that someday he will have a spectacular, blind-corner collision with a waiter from room service.

title: WAS THE FIRST SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE
description: H. Lee Dennison, Suffolk County's first Executive, died Friday after he apparently suffered a heart attack while working in the backyard of his home in in Belleair Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and had moved to Florida two years after his retirement.

title: SCOTT'S TIME HAS COME AND IT'S STARTING TIME
description: IT was always next year for Bobby Scott -well, possibly next year. Then this spring, after 12 seasons as a backup quarterback with the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League, he joined the New Jersey Generals of the new United States Football League, and, it seemed, his time, at long last, had come.

title: DODGERS WIN 5TH IN A ROW, 6-4
description: Dusty Baker and Greg Brock hit home runs as the Los Angeles Dodgers held off the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, today for their fifth straight victory.

title: AFTER THE RECORD RAINFALL, A SEASON FOR SNEEZING AND SCRATCHING
description: The record rains that have swamped the New York area after a long dry spell are causing more wheezing and sneezing than usual this spring. They are also likely to produce one of the worst spring mosquito crops in recent memory.

title: Chicago Mayor Appeals To Aldermen in Split
description: Mayor Harold Washington sent telegrams to the city aldermen today asking that representatives from two sharply divided factions of the City Council get together to talk before a meeting scheduled for Wednesday.

title: JERRY LEWIS IS THE KING AT CANNES FILM FESTIVAL
description: The 36th Cannes International Film Festival opened here this weekend in the sprawling new movie palace, with a tribute to stars and a new episode in the long-running love affair between France and Jerry Lewis.

title: SUB WORKERS, AFTER MASS, REFLECT ON BISHOPS' LETTER
description: Five days a week, many of the people who live among these hills build submarines that carry nuclear weapons; on Sundays, they come to mass at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church here. Today they came and talked about those weapons and of the American Roman Catholic bishops' stand against them.

title: PUMPING THE DELAWARE STIRS A DEBATE
description: Swollen by spring rains, the Delaware River now rushes in white-capped torrents past old homes that nudge the shoulders of a narrow road winding along its wooded banks.

title: Miss Feder Wed In White Plains
description: The marriage of Judith Feder to Tapani Tapanainen took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Feder, in White Plains. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony.

title: Benefit 'Pal Joey' May 22
description: A special performance of Rodgers and Hart's ''Pal Joey,'' featuring Michael Callan and Tammy Grimes, will be presented May 22 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: U.S. DIPLOMAT IS ORDERED OUT BY AFGHANS
description: The State Department said today that a senior diplomat at the United States Embassy in Afghanistan had been ordered to leave the country by the Soviet-backed Government.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRIDGEWORK

title: Stars Top Gold, 6-3, For Ninth Triumph
description: David Trout kicked field goals of 53 and 18 yards to lead the Philadelphia Stars to a 6-3 victory over the Denver Gold in the United States Football League today.

title: OWNER TO SELL 49% SHARE OF SUNNY'S HALO
description: When Sunny's Halo won the 109th Kentucky Derby Saturday, his camp was rewarded for its faith in the colt, and at higher odds than the 5-2 mutuel payoff.

title: Mr. Margiotta's Faith, and Power
description: ''I still have faith in the criminal justice system,'' Joseph Margiotta said after the Supreme Court refused to review his conviction for extortion and mail fraud. So do we. Federal justice has prevailed over one of New York's most powerful politicians and brought him to account for abuse of office, the chairmanship of Nassau County's Republican Party.

title: STAGE VAN ITALLIE'S 'EARLY WARNINGS'
description: IN ''Early Warnings,'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, Jean-Claude van Itallie transmits radar messages from a theatrical DEW line. The evening's three one-act plays are auguries of impending doom, as perceived through the author's vivid imagination.

title: Swedes Hold Soviet Ship Amid Submarine Search
description: The Swedish Navy detained a Soviet tanker for more than three hours today while helicopters and patrol boats continued to search for two submarines believed to be trapped in nearby waters.

title: YANKS ARE BEATEN, 6-5, AS TWINS END A 6-GAME SLIDE
description: The Yankees of 1983 can't expect to be able to run because they apparently have not yet learned how to walk. Or put another way, the Yankees can't expect to win the American League East title if they can't push their record past the .500 mark.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Confers On British Election Date
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met today with top advisers for eight hours, but there was no indication afterward concerning the date of the next general election.

title: THE ROAR OF THE RACE
description: The green flag was dropped and they were off, 25 drivers stomping on it hard, roaring down the short straightaway in a thunder of virile engines, hellbent for beating the rest of the pack into the first turn. An ill wind of dust, asphalt particles and gas fumes bathed the spectators, a few of whom turned away when the drivers hurtled their cars at the first corner.

title: Wildcats Capture Title
description: Carlton Young captured the 400-meter dash in meet-record time and also anchored Villanova's winning 1,600-meter relay team today to lead the Wildcats to the men's team title in the Big East track and field championships.

title: Bridge: Canadian and Oklahoman Lead at the Cavendish Club
description: A young Canadian-American pair who are burning up the tournament trail took a substantial lead in the Cavendish invitational pairs when play reached the halfway mark early yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: When you have 408 dilapidated subway stations and enough money to repair only 28 of them, how do you choose? That is the question facing the New York City Transit Authority as it prepares to spend $264 million on rebuilding subway stations over the next three years. For 28 stations, the money will bring new lighting, new tiles, architectural improvements and noise- reduction features.

title: LEADER IN LEGAL CLINIC FIELD
description: What Joel Hyatt wants is to be the H & R Block of the legal profession. In a literal sense, Mr. Hyatt's chain of 117 legal clinics has already achieved that goal. Under an agreement signed with the big tax preparation service three years ago, H & R Block provides administrative services - and in most areas, shared office space - to Hyatt Legal Services. Mr. Hyatt himself, an engaging 32-year-old, has moved from Cleveland, where he began the clinics, into the Kansas City, Mo., office of Henry Bloch, the founder of the tax chain.

title: SOURCE OF DIOXIN IN HUDSON RIVER FISH INVESTIGATED
description: With the striped bass returning for the start of a new spawning season, a five-state investigation has begun to trace the sources of the dioxin that has contaminated the fish in the Hudson River.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: A golfer selects a club and approaches his ball in a deep bunker. He loses his footing on the way down and his wedge accidentally strikes the sand as he tries to right himself. Is there a penalty?

title: NEW YORK AS THE PREMIER 'INFORMATION UTILITY'
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICE UNION CONFIDENT OF VICTORY AT COLUMBIA
description: The results of the collective-bargaining election are being contested, but leaders of District 65 of the United Automobile Workers say they are pleased with the recent voting by clerical workers at Columbia University.

title: Bandits 17, Invaders 10
description: The quarterback Jimmy Jordan threw a pair of touchdown passes to lead Tampa Bay to a 17-0 advantage and then the Bandits' defense held off the Invaders.

title: COTTAGE GIVES NEW HOPE TO INMATES
description: More than two decades ago, officials of the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, the state's only maximumsecurity prison for women, would isolate their most difficult prisoners in a large brick building at the edge of the compound in this wooded Westchester County suburb. It was called Fiske Cottage.

title: AMNESTY RUMOR IN ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's military Government plans to grant amnesty to members of the security forces for any crimes they might have committed in antiguerrilla operations, the pro-Government daily La Nacion said today.

title: THEATER: 'PRIVATE LIVES,' BURTON AND MISS TAYLOR
description: THE tone of the Richard Burton-Elizabeth Taylor ''Private Lives'' is established right off. When Mr. Burton makes his first entrance on to the attractive Deauville hotel terrace designed by David Mitchell, he looks anything but happy. His face is a taut mask, frozen in an expression of less-than-exquisite pain, and there's no bounce as he walks about on his stacked boots. He's not Noel Coward's flippant hero Elyot Chase - he doesn't even seem to be an actor. In his immaculate Savile Row business suit, Mr. Burton mostly resembles a retired millionaire steeling himself for an obligatory annual visit to the accountant. He's bored out of his mind but grimly determined to clip the coupons and sign the papers that will allow him to maintain his cash flow for the next year.

title: U.S. TRADE THAT GOES BEYOND COMMERCE
description: To the Editor:

title: RIDERSHIP DOWN ON METRO-NORTH AND JERSEY LINE
description: Not all the commuters who rode Metro-North and N.J. Transit trains before the recent strikes have returned, estimates show, but railroad officials said yesterday that it was too early to tell what permanent effect, if any, there would be.

title: Maine Power Seabrook Sale
description: The Central Maine Power Company has announced that it will put up for sale most of its ownership in the beleaguered Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant as part of ''a major effort'' to reduce capital spending and improve earnings.

title: U.S. POLITICS FROM AFAR
description: Europeans are beginning to ask about coming U.S. Presidential politics. This is unseasonal, because usually they only get around to noticing challengers and issues in the last stages of the campaign.

title: LAKERS DEFEAT SPURS, 119-107
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Norm Nixon scored 30 points each today to pace the Los Angeles Lakers to a 119-107 victory over the San Antonio Spurs in the opening game of the Western Conference four-of-seven-game championship series.

title: WEINBERGER TO MEET SAUDI DEFENSE MINISTER IN PARIS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger will meet in Paris this week with the Saudi Defense Minister to discuss the Middle East, according to American and French officials.

title: Commodities; 'Wild Card Option' In Bonds
description: ONE of the major reasons Treasury bond futures have long been the most actively traded contracts in the commodity market is that traders who sell futures short could use what is known as the ''sellers put,'' or ''wild card option,'' when bond cash and futures prices were falling.

title: El Paso Dividend
description: The El Paso Company, a major producer of natural gas, has announced that it has lowered its quarterly dividend to 17 cents a share, from 37 cents a share, because of the state of its balance sheet. Travis H. Petty, El Paso's chairman, said the cut in the dividend, which is payable June 30 to stockholders of record May 20, was made because of the continuing weakness in natural gas markets and because of current earnings. El Paso, which was acquired by the Burlington Northern Corporation in January, reported net income of $14.3 million, or 27 cents a share, in the first quarter, down from $21.2 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago.

title: Andrea Temesvari Wins Italian Open
description: Andrea Temesvari of Hungary used her driving topspin to rout Bonnie Gadusek of Largo, Fla., 6-1, 6-0, in the final of the $150,000 women's Italian Open tennis tournament today.

title: 'THE CHILD-CUSTODY SYSTEM DOES NOT WORK'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poor Start for the Summit
description: Will the leaders of the industrial democracies meet at the end of the month as the chieftains of seven autonomous powers or will they begin to address common problems by truly coordinating their power? The first pass was not encouraging.

title: NELSON COACHES THE AVERAGE TO WINNING PERCENTAGE
description: DON NELSON was talking recently about superstar basketball players. Not that he is such a great authority on them. He wasn't one himself. Not even close.

title: 'SAVAGE REVENGE' IS NOT PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Wins
description: The United States Coast Guard Academy rowing team won four events, including the varsity and junior varsity men's eights races, in the ninth annual New England championship regatta on Lake Quinsigamond today. The varsity won by four lengths in 6:42.8 from Massachusetts and the junior varsity won by 10.3 seconds in 7:03.7 from Holy Cross. Connecticut College dominated the women's eights by winning both the varsity and junior varsity races.

title: BALLET: NUREYEV OFFERS HIS 'MANFRED' IN CAPITAL
description: For some years, Rudolf Nureyev has sought to bring to the United States ''Manfred,'' a ballet he choreographed in 1979 about Lord Byron's life and poetry and which is set to Tchaikovsky's ''Manfred Symphony.''

title: NOVA SCOTIA AWAITS GAS FIELD'S BENEFITS
description: This year, the gentle salt breezes of spring are carrying the unaccustomed scent of success to this province, one of Canada's poorest. Evidence is mounting that a natural gas field discovered 110 miles off Nova Scotia will become the first commercial petroleum development off the East Coast of North America.

title: FIVE KILLINGS: A FEARFUL SILENCE IS BROKEN
description: For five months, Anna Olesiewicz's parents waited. Their 18-yearold daughter had disappeared from the boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J., last August, but it was not until the morning of Jan. 14 that two boys, building a fort in dense underbrush behind a fast-food restaurant in Ocean Township, stumbled upon her body. Miss Olesiewicz had been shot to death.

title: PERFECT PLOT FOR THE CUP
description: SELDOM, if ever, has the Stanley Cup final had a more theatrically perfect plot. Even before the playoffs began, script writers were hoping it would boil down to this the New York Islanders, arguably the best team in National Hockey League history, trying to extend their championship reign through four years against the challenge of the Edmonton Oilers with the Great Gretzky himself, arguably the best player in history.

title: ISAAC W. CARPENTER Jr.
description: Isaac W. Carpenter Jr., who served as an assistant secretary and comptroller in the State Department in the Eisenhower Administration, died Friday at Clarkson Hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS MADE GAINS IN STATE SENATE WRANGLE
description: The agreement in the New York State Senate that ended four weeks of debate and procedural wrangling, the first major slowdown of Senate business in memory, is one that few senators are willing to discuss openly.

title: SURVIVING DEDUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann D. Agatson Is Married To Philip L. Glazer on L.I.
description: Ann D. Agatston, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Agatston of Atlantis, Fla., was married yesterday to Philip L. Glazer, son of Abraham Glazer of Mount Washington, Mass., and Rose Glazer of Springfield, Mass.

title: STEPS TO DEPORT NAZI BACKERS CAUSE LEGAL CONCERN
description: The Justice Department's efforts to deport one or more former Nazi sympathizers to Israel, where they would face prosecution for crimes against Jews in World War II, raise troublesome legal and moral questions, several legal experts said in interviews recently.

title: PURCHASING MANAGERS FIND GAINS
description: Purchasing managers of the nation's major corporations reported yesterday that the economy continued to improve in April but that the rate of gain had not accelerated.

title: Love Triumphs
description: When Jim Campbell came down to earth in May 1981, after flying higher (21,210 feet) than anyone had ever flown before in an ultralight aircraft, he was so cold and stiff the ground crew virtually had to pry him out of the tiny plane - a delicate, lightweight craft that is little more than a motorized hang glider.

title: QUARTER'S PROFITS IMPROVE
description: Continued weakness in the nation's heavy industries - steel, chemicals and oil - marred what otherwise was an improvement in corporate profitability during the first quarter.

title: Team America Now 2-0
description: Perhaps America's team has not caught America's fancy just yet. But the crowd of 14,211 soccer fans who braved a cold rain to watch Team America's first home game at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium here today saw the troupe of United States citizens and citizens-to-be work hard to capture at least their local crowd's favor.

title: Islanders Clear Away Doubts After Their Mediocre Season
description: And now the Islanders, after enduring the doubts that surrounded their mediocre regular season, are but four victories from their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup championship.

title: Marcie Gold Udell Weds George Creed, Publisher
description: Marcie Gold Udell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Udell of Sands Point, L.I., was married in Manhattan yesterday to George Louis Creed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Creed of Philadelphia. Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: BLACK POPULATION ROSE 17.3%
description: The number of blacks in the United States is increasing faster than the population as a whole, with the proportion of blacks rising in all areas except the South.

title: French Aide to Visit Arabs
description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France is scheduled to arrive here Monday for two days of talks expected to focus on French arms sales to the United Arab Emirates. Official sources said the two sides would discuss the possible sale of French Mirage 2000 jet fighters. The United Arab Emirates said last week that it was planning to expand its navy.

title: Walesa Says He May Join Solidarity Underground
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the now outlawed Solidarity labor union, said today that he would join the Solidarity underground if police do not stop their campaign of harassment against him.

title: CHINA TO LET SEOUL TRY HIJACKERS IN RETURN FOR JET AND PASSENGERS
description: China agreed today to let South Korea try six hijackers who seized a Chinese passenger plane last week and forced it to fly to South Korea, an official announcement said.

title: CONTINUING DECLINE SEEN FOR RATES
description: The credit markets set aside fears of higher interest rates last week and readily absorbed $2.4 billion of new corporate and foreign offerings at the same time as the Treasury sold $15 billion of new notes and bonds, a record combination of financing for one week.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report Thursday on the ''Surrounded Islands'' project in Miami by the artist Christo incorrectly described Jan van der Marck's association with Miami's 1982 New World Festival of the Arts. Mr. van der Marck served with the festival as cosponsor of Christo's project.

title: Yugoslavia Takes Table Tennis Title
description: Yugoslavia regained the men's double title from China today at the 37th world table tennis championships. Dragutin Surbek and Zoran Kalinic defeated China's Xie Saike and Jiang Jialiang, 21-15, 19-21, 20-22, 21-17, 22-20.

title: Bandag Will Not Name Successor to President
description: After a special directors meeting Friday, Bandag Inc. issued a two-sentence announcement that Charles E. Edwards, the company's 54-year-old president, was resigning. Martin G. Carver, chairman of Bandag and the son of the company's late founder, said that ''having a president is not necessary.''

title: The U.N. Today; May 9, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaints by Nicaragua at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Vagrancy Taken By Broom Dance
description: Christiana Stables' Broom Dance held off a charging Syrianna to post a half-length victory in the 33d running of the $55,800 Vagrancy Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: HELP FOR THE NURSING MOTHER WHO WORKS
description: There appears to be only one problem with nurturing a baby on mother's milk: mother must be there. That would rule out breast-feeding for women who cannot take their babies into the workplace or classroom.

title: Sneaker Scoop
description: The Cavalier Daily, the student newspaper at the University of Virginia, raised a few eyebrows on the campus at Charlottesville, Va., last Wednesday when its lead story revealed that Terry Holland, the basketball coach, had an agreement with Adidas, the shoe company, whereby Adidas supplied basketball sneakers for the whole team and paid Holland $15,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: An Occupational Hazard

title: Jersey Man Held in Slayings Of Two Asbury Park Women
description: An 18-year-old Neptune man was being held in bail of more than $1 million today charged with the slayings of two Asbury Park women last month.

title: STORING AREA OF MIAMI AIRPORT IS A THIEVES' SHOPPING CENTER
description: To the casual passer-by, ''corrosion corner'' at Miami International Airport is a crowded, messy place where old planes are cannibalized for parts, newer ones are stored and serviced, and cargo carriers come and go.

title: NEIGHBORS MAKE MUSIC A WEDNESDAY TRADITION
description: To Rita Schwartz there seemed nothing strange about leaving a city-sponsored meeting to dash off to a morning musicale in a Brooklyn Heights home.

title: Sterling Bank Chief Planning Expansion
description: At age 79, Theodore H. Silbert is making plans to expand the Sterling National Bank, the centerpiece of the financial and factoring business he began during the Depression with $1,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Golden Nugget Inc. said it completed the acquisition of 15 acres in the Marina area of Atlantic City, from MGM Grand Hotels Inc., as a site for a hotel-casino complex; the purchase price was earlier said by Golden Nug- get to be $25 million.

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS WIN CITY ELECTIONS
description: The Socialist Party swept to victory in most towns and cities in municipal elections today, consolidating on a local level the national power it won in general elections last October.

title: HUNTER COLLEGE OFFICIALS MOVING INTO NEW TOWER
description: After so many delays and so many promises, Sheila Hirschman found it all a little hard to believe. ''I just never thought it would come to be,'' she said, sitting within freshly painted walls and among boxes of files in her new office at the Hunter College C tower at 68th Street and Lexington Avenue. ''It's a dream come true.''

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GULF ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Chamber-Music Festival
description: The Chamber Music Associates, a nonprofit organization of amateur musicians, will present its spring festival next Sunday at 2 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street.

title: Support for LeFlore
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association said it would file a grievance against the Chicago White Sox on behalf of Ron LeFlore, the outfielder who was released April 2 with one year left on his fouryear contract. The club had said that LeFlore would not receive his salary for the season, $735,000, because he had breached his contract by failing to live up to clauses of the the standard major league contract that govern the conduct of a player and his condition for play.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Star at the Barre

title: U.S., in Countermove, Ousts Afghan Diplomat
description: The State Department today ordered an Afghan diplomat out of the United States in what seemed to be a reply to the expulsion of an American diplomat from Kabul.

title: ASTROS' RALLY BEATS METS
description: The Mets found a new way to lose tonight. They were coasting along with a four-run lead in the fifth inning when the Houston Astros scored five runs. But the run that hurt most, the deciding one in Houston's 6-4 victory, sneaked home as the Mets were arguing about a close call at first base.

title: Atlanta Airport
description: A $85.9 million issue of Baa-1/ A-rated Atlanta airport revenue bonds was tentatively priced by the MerrillLynch White Weld Capital Markets Group with 9 3/8 percent bonds due 2010 at a price of 99 1/4 to yield 9.45 percent. The issue also includes bonds with yields from 6.5 percent in 1987 to 9 percent in 1997 and 9.25 percent in 2003.

title: TRANSPLANTATION OF FETAL CURES POINTS TOWARD DIABETES CELL
description: SCIENTISTS in California and Australia have eliminated diabetes in some laboratory animals by giving them pancreas glands transplanted from fetuses of the same species. The research represents one of several dramatically new modes of attack on human diabetes, a widespread disease that still, despite decades of research, can be neither prevented nor cured but only alleviated, and even with the best medical management continues to cause blindness, loss of limbs and premature death in some patients.

title: COMET'S ENVELOPE OF DUST AND GAS APPEARS HUGE
description: AS the comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock approaches its close passage of the Earth tomorrow, its envelope of glowing gas and dust is growing and now covers an area of the sky that appears more than twice the size of the Moon. But the gas and dust cloud are dim and should be viewed through binoculars.

title: Texas Big Guns
description: Unlikely happenings continued last week in the Texas League in the wake of a recent five-game series in El Paso between the Diablos and the Beaumont Golden Gators that produced 149 runs, 171 hits and 25 home runs. The Diablos, who had defeated Beaumont, 35-21, 10 days ago, continued slugging on Thursday in Midland where they edged the Cubs, 20-19.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXPLODING A MYTH
description: ''As fear of crime has become epidemic in America,'' I wrote in a recent article, ''the myth has spread that streams of criminals are going free because the exclusionary rule prevents the evidence against them from being used in court.''

title: Happy Switch
description: On Jan. 20, the date that Team America was officially launched, Jeff Durgan of the Cosmos was openly skeptical about the idea. Then he went to the February tryout camp for Team America, which is both the United States national team-in-training and a North American Soccer League franchise based in Washington.

title: Lacrosse Playoff Is Led by Hobart
description: Hobart College was named yesterday the top-seeded team for the National Collegiate Athletic Assocation's Division III postseason lacrosse tournament.

title: No Headline
description: Charlotte Curtis Some Literati Tour China

title: FRENCHMAN SETS SOLO RECORD FOR GLOBAL SAILING
description: Philippe Jeantot of France swept across the finish line in his 56-foot black cutter Credit Agricole early today to win the BOC Challenge, the first organized single-handed race around the world.

title: Heating Oil Futures Off; Technical Factors Cited
description: All actively traded heating oil futures contracts dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a gallon yesterday, except the unrestricted spot June delivery, which plunged 2.71 cents, to 75.06 cents.

title: WEINBERGER AND SAUDI TO MEET
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger was scheduled to leave here for Paris tonight to urge Saudi Arabian leaders to help persuade Syria to withdraw its military forces from Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

title: MEDICINE MAY LEARN FROM THE TRAGEDY OF AIDS
description: MODERN medical practice is based partly on what has been learned from enormous tragedy: the common plagues and rare disorders that scientists would never dream of creating in experiments but that nature thrusts on us as part of life.

title: PORTLAND GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GERMAN PUBLISHER SUING HIS REPORTER OVER THE HITLER HOAX
description: The publisher of Stern, the West German magazine that bought bogus Hitler diaries for $3.3 million, filed fraud charges today against the reporter who said he had discovered them.

title: CHADWICK-MILLER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Q&A
description: Q. I read somewhere that fish have a protective coating, or slime, on their bodies. Does it endanger a pet goldfish or aquarium fish if you touch it with your fingers?

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS G.O.P. BUDGET PLAN
description: With a pivotal vote on the 1984 budget resolution expected Wednesday, Senate Democrats went on the offensive today, contending that the deficits in the Republican proposal would drain huge amounts of savings from the economy, drive up interest rates and choke off economic recovery.

title: Lottery Official Pleads Not Guilty
description: Reese Palley, a member of the State Lottery Commission, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he falsified documents relating to a state ethics investigation.

title: NEW ENTRIES WORTH CONSIDERING
description: NOT so many years ago, I knew them all. There wasn't a car on the market that I couldn't describe inside out. I purchased my first vehicle, a 1952 Packard, in the halcyon days of high school. Opening the hood, I could literally step inside, tools in one hand, lunch in the other, and spend the better part of a day scrunched up next to that old straight-8 engine.

title: U.S. Reports Concern About Missiles in Asia
description: The State Department said today that the reported continuing buildup of Soviet SS-20 medium-range missiles targeted on Asia ''is a matter of serious concern'' to the United States, the Atlantic alliance and Asian nations.

title: Scientex Chapter 7
description: The Scientex Corporation of Los Angeles said yesterday that it was preparing to file a petition this week for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Earlier, the company announced that it was in default on a $1.9 million loan from lenders in the Far East.

title: Founder of Cetus Starts New Venture
description: Dr. Peter J. Farley, a founder and vice chairman of the Cetus Corporation, announced his resignation yesterday to form a new venture in the health-care market.

title: AGAINST A BLACK CANDIDACY
description: Theidea of entering a black candidate in the Democratic Presidential primaries is being intensely debated in the black community. There is much to commend it, but it is an idea whose time has not yet come.

title: A G.M.A.C. SHELF FILING OF $1.25 BILLION IN NOTES
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $1.25 billion in medium-term notes yesterday.

title: Bridge Loan For Hungary
description: Hungary was granted a shortterm bridging loan through the Bank for International Settlements last month, a spokesman for the bank said today.

title: A MOSCOW SPRING: EASTER EGGS AND WAR RIBBONS
description: Sunday was Orthodox Easter, and in an observance gaining more popularity with every year, tens of thousands of Muscovites flooded the city's cemeteries with flowers, traditional Easter foods and colored eggs.

title: Futures Contract Study
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today began a review of futures contract trading to determine if traders had inflated contract volumes artificially, a commission spokesman said. Among the contracts under study are Eurodollar and Standard & Poor's 500 index futures traded at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, he said. The study resulted from concerns voiced at the commission's April meeting that competition among exchanges could lead to trader inflation of volume figures, the spokesman said.

title: UNITED CANADIAN SHARES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago loss is restated to reflect the translation of the results of certain United States operations into Canadian funds.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JUSTICE POWELL ASSAILS DELAY IN CARRYING OUT EXECUTIONS
description: A Supreme Court Justice said today that unless Congress and the courts could find a speedier way to handle death penalty appeals, the states should abolish capital punishment.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $35,000 from the sales of properties and investments. c-Net loss after a gain of $34,000 from the sales of properties and investments. The revenue figures exclude the sales of properties and investments.

title: Team Exchange
description: A plan to develop an exchange baseball program for 11- and 12-yearold boys in New York City and Acapulco, Mexico, is being sponsored by the Hispanic Society of the New York City Police Department.

title: ATI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Net income including extraordinary tax credits of $122,145 for the quarter and $127,062 for the 6 months.

title: OILERS' OFFENSE TO TEST ISLANDERS
description: The Edmonton Oilers, who have never been in a Stanley Cup final, have an image to dispel and an identity to gain as they begin trying Tuesday night to dethrone the Islanders as the three-time defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: The U.N. Today; May 10, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaints by Nicaragua at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ADVANTAGE, RIGGS
description: That old male chauvinist, Bobby Riggs, earned another Mother's Day victory Sunday when he and his partner, Mal Anderson, defeated Rosie Casals and Wendy Turnbull, 6-7, 3-6, 6-1, 7-6, 8-6, in Houston.

title: INTERVIEW METHODS QUESTIONED IN '60 MINUTES' SUIT
description: A slander suit filed by a California physician against CBS's ''60 Minutes'' and Dan Rather is scheduled to come to trial today in Los Angeles Superior Court amid allegations by the physician's lawyer that Mr. Rather staged interviews and coached interviewees on what to say.

title: A NYLON CORD IS A CONSTITUTIONAL ISSUE
description: Like most village boards, the one here usually deals with issues such as zoning variances and road repaving that keep suburban governments yawning along for hours. But now the five-member board finds itself balancing the Constitution's separation of government and religion with the Old Testament's prohibition against Sabbath-day labor.

title: Accounts
description: * Gentlemen's Quarterly magazine to Chalk Nissen Hanft. * Baccarat Inc., to Young & Rubicam Special Markets.

title: Executive at Coachmen Adds President's Duties
description: Coachmen Industries, makers of recreational vehicles and other products, has named C. Raymond Johnson president and chief operating officer. Mr. Johnsosn, 36, will retain his postion as executive vice president of the recreational vehicles group.

title: Explosions Damage 2 Offices Of U.S. Concerns in Amman
description: Two offices of United States organizations were damaged by explosives in Amman tonight, a Government spokesman said.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook Airbags for Adam Smith

title: Reporter Is Ordered To Testify on Series That Won a Pulitzer
description: Loretta Tofani, a reporter for The Washington Post, was ordered today to testify before a grand jury about a series of articles she wrote on rapes in jail. She was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for her reporting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I always was of the conviction that Heidemann believed in the diaries.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income.

title: HILTON HEAD ISLANDERS SPLIT RACIALLY OVER INCORPORATION VOTE
description: Spanish Wells Road cuts a narrow moss-draped path through miles of untouched wetlands, sandy spans of lo@blolly pines, and more than a century of Southern black culture on this sea island.

title: Bank Board Nominee
description: President Reagan, visiting here today, said he would nominate Donald I. Hovde, Under Secretary of of Housing and Urban Development, as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board until June 1985. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Richard T. Pratt.

title: Gossage Examines Relievers' Problems
description: While the Yankees were traveling through the Midwest last week, Rich Gossage read about the agony of Neil Allen and he understood only too well.

title: Half a Loaf in Lebanon
description: It is not yet Lebanon that's been restored by Secretary of State Shultz's painstaking mediation, only the truth that Syria holds the key to Lebanon's independence. Exposing this truth is helpful to the United States' reputation in the Arab world, and to Israel's in America. But the truth alone will not set the Lebanese free.

title: Suffering Springtime
description: There comes a time in every life when one is tempted to complain like Job: ''Are not my days few? Cease then, and let me alone, that I may take comfort a little.'' For many New Yorkers, that time is right now.

title: How the Rangers Helped the Oilers
description: EDMONTON, Alberta I n drilling the Edmonton Oilers into what they are, Glen Sather used the memory of what the New York Rangers were not. ''I remember losing the Stanley Cup final with the Rangers, it was awful,'' Glen Sather was saying, referring to the 1972 loss to the Boston Bruins in six games. ''I was just a role player, but I remember the personal commitment some of the guys weren't willing to make. We had a good team, but not enough guys cared.''

title: THE DEEP STRAINS IN COMECON
description: When the Soviet Union built a headquarters for Comecon, the trading bloc that links Moscow and its Communist allies, officials selected a prime site by the Moscow River and erected one of the capital's tallest buildings, a 31-story steel-andglass structure that looks out on an unlimited horizon.

title: REAGAN BLAMES 'GREAT SOCIETY' FOR ECONOMIC WOES
description: President Reagan said tonight that food stamps, the minimum wage, Federal urban renewal and the entire array of Great Society programs enacted in the 1960's had destroyed the economy and made Americans poorer than they were 15 years ago.

title: PUBLIC WORKS NEED PERMANENT WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: AID URGED FOR POOR COUNTRIES
description: Western leaders should seek to prevent the ''unraveling'' of the world financial and trading systems by encouraging continued credit for developing countries and arresting protectionism, the Overseas Development Council said today.

title: GALILEO 'HERESIES' STILL UNDER STUDY, POPE SAYS
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the Vatican was still examining the ''heresies'' of Galileo. He gave no hint whether it would eventually reverse its judgment on him.

title: VARIETY, ELEGANCE MARK THE RETURN OF THE SWEATER
description: Sweaters move in and out of fashion with alacrity. Sometimes the focus is on the cozy warmth they provide. At other moments it is thesweater-as-art that draws attention, with artisan knitters developing individual and sometime baroque designs. In the sweater-girl era, starring Lana Turner and Rita Hayworth, the basic appeal of knitted tops was their figure-hugging seductive quality.

title: TWIGGY, IN HER 'ONE AND ONLY' PHASE
description: She had the body of a starvation victim and the face of an angel, and she was world-famous by the time she was 16. She wore three sets of false eyela@shes, chewed her fingernails, slept with a bedful of stuffed animals and was accompanied everywhere by her managerbodyguard-boyfriend.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CABANAS'S WINNING CHIP SHOT
description: PLAYS Alex Yannis

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE city stretched its arms toward summer and rolled over for five m ore minutes' sleep. What else could it do in a week that served up m ore fashion and social events than humans can safely digest?

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
HALIFAX DEVELOPMENTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Addendum
description: * Needham, Harper & Steers/USA has opened an office in Phoenix.

title: Hartford Insurance In Piper Jaffray Pact
description: Piper Jaffray Inc., a regional securities firm with offices in the Middle West, Northwest and Mountain states, and the Hartford Insurance Group said yesterday that they had entered into a long-term agreement under which Piper Jaffray would market life insurance products for Hartford and the insurer would acquire about 25 percent of Piper Jaffray.

title: Chinese Official Praises Rumanian Foreign Policy
description: Hu Yaobang, the Chinese Communist Party leader, praised Rumania today for taking a foreign policy line independent of Moscow, but he avoided making an outright attack on the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. GOALS FOR ECONOMIC TALKS SET FORTH
description: The United States plans to pursue four main goals when the major industrial democracies hold economic talks later this month, according to a classified memorandum prepared by W. Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

title: SCIENCE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $436,000 after taxes resulting from an increase in the value of stock appreciation rights and a reduction in the minimum required holding period prior to exercise of the rights, and foreign tax credits and net operating loss carryforwards of $20,000. c-After foreign tax credits and net operating loss carryforwards of $6,000.

title: OPI LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DIMIS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $48,000. Results include operations of Dimis Microsystems Inc., formerly R & B Computer Systems, since the date of acquisition, Feb. 1, 1982.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Della Femina Selected
description: The First Boston Corporation, which has not had an agency for corporate advertising, has selected Della Femina, Travisano & Partners. Doremus & Company will continue making the tombstone ads. Jerry Della Femina, chairman of the agency and a man knowledgeable about money, will be copywriter and creative supervisor for the investment banking company.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRIEFING
description: How Sweet It Is

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $63,000, or 2 cents a share, from the early extinguishment of debt. Results for the latest first quarter reflect the adoption of LIFO inventory accounting which decreased net income by approximately $137,000.

title: A CALIFORNIA DEVELOPER BIDS TO RE-ENTER 42D ST. PROJECT
description: A California developer who dropped out of the $1 billion Times Square re- development project last year now says that he would like to re-enter the project as sponsor of a proposed 2.4-million square foot merchandise mart.

title: SOVIET ORDERS EMBASSY DEPENDENTS TO LEAVE BEIRUT
description: Wives and children of Soviet diplomats in Lebanon left Beirut unexpectedly today on board a special Aeroflot flight, officials at the Soviet Embassy said.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary net gain of $487,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: NEW YORK STARTS DRIVE TO CUT AUTO ACCIDENTS
description: Alarmed by a rise in injuries of pedestrians and motorists, New York City officials announced plans yesterday for a fourfold increase in the number of police officers assigned to enforce traffic laws at hazardous intersections.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES AID FOR I.M.F.
description: The House Banking Committee, on a voice vote, today approved an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund. Attached to it was a ban on American support for loans to South Africa.

title: AMERICA'S DIM FIRST VIEW OF THE HAITIAN REPULBIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraser Vote Keeps Harrods
description: After months of feuding, Britain's House of Fraser P.L.C. announced today that it had thwarted, temporarily at least, an attempt by its largest shareholder, Lonrho Ltd., the mining conglomerate, to spin off the renowned store, Harrods of Knightsbridge, from the rest of the giant retailer.

title: AAA Utah Bonds
description: A $93 million issue of Aaa-rated Utah general obligation bonds was tentatively priced to yield from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 7.6 percent for bonds due in 1985 by an E.F. Hutton & Company group.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a charge of $887,000 for administration reorganization. c-Includes administration reorganization pre-tax cost of $284,000. The company is listed on the Pacific, Midwest and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: Dam Ruptures in Colorado
description: A small earthen dam broke near here today, unleashing a torrent of water that washed out two private bridges and briefly closed a highway. There were no injuries or major damage, the officials said.

title: MONDALE PROPOSES PLAN TO RESPOND TO CRITIQUE OF U.S. SCHOOLS
description: Walter F. Mondale came to Harvard today to attack President Reagan's response to a Federal commission's report on the plight of American education and to announce the Mondale solution: An $11 billion program of Federal aid with an emphasis on local control.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes tax benefit of $2,027,000. c-Net income The share earnings were restated for 3-for-2 stock split paid June 1982.

title: Advertising; Consultant Is Going to Laurence
description: ALTHOUGH he had not planned it that way, Thomas K. Myers, one-time president of Norman, Craig & Kummel, is heading back into agency work, leaving behind the lucrative and loose field of management consulting.

title: DEMOCRATIC WOMEN SPLIT ON BEST STRATEGY FOR '84
description: A couple of weeks ago, the six declared candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination received a manifesto signed by 170 politically active women warning them to agree on an agenda for issues affecting women or face the possibility of women staying away from the polls in 1984.

title: DRESHER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
