title: UNISEX INSURANCE RATE WILL HURT ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Says Beliefs Can't Preclude Test
description: A state appeals court ruled today that religious beliefs cannot be cited as grounds to avoid blood tests to determine the parentage of children.

title: Official Defends Rights Policy
description: A top Justice Department official said today that it was ''patently absurd'' for civil rights groups to contend that the Reagan Administration has abandoned enforcement of civil rights laws.

title: Mobil Official to Head Alternative Energy Unit
description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday announced the formation of an alternative energy division and the appointment of Jerome F. Trautschold Jr. to be president of it.

title: 500 Protest Probation For 2 Killers in Detroit
description: More than 500 people marched in downtown Detroit today demanding the jailing of two men who were placed on probation for beating a Chinese-American to death with a baseball bat.

title: Comedian's Wife Injured In Helium Balloon Crash
description: Tuanchai (Cookie) Wilson, the wife of the comedian Flip Wilson, was injured today when the helium balloon in which she was riding crashed near the Missouri-Iowa state line, the Highway Patrol said. Mr. Wilson was riding in another balloon and was not injured.

title: NATION'S PSYCHIATRISTS GIVE 'HIGH PRIORITY' TO THE HOMELESS
description: THE growing problem of mentally ill people living in despair on the nation's streets has prompted psychiatrists to re-analyze the current practice of releasing many such patients from mental institutions.

title: New Mexico Bond
description: A $71 million issue of Aa-2-rated Farmington, N.M., pollution control revenue bonds due in 2013 was tentatively priced at 100 with a 9 percent coupon by underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. The bonds are secured by payments from the Southern California Edison Company.

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE BISHOPS' OVERSIGHT
description: The American Roman Catholic bishops' pastoral letter on nuclear weapons, an arresting attempt to deal with a profoundly troublesome moral issue, is based on an anachronistic legal premise.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Shanghai Chitchat

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Astros, at Houston. Ed Lynch seeks his second victory of the season against Bob Knepper as the Mets try to improve their poor road record. (Television -Sports@Channel, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. The Yankees, still struggling to get past the .500 mark, send Shane Rawley (4-1 and a 3.76 earned run average) against Jon Matlack (2-1 and 3.13). (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Basketball Los Angeles Lakers vs. San Antonio Spurs, Western Conference finals, second game, at Inglewood, Calif. The Spurs need a victory to keep the Lakers from taking a commanding two-game lead, and it will be up to Artis Gilmore to contain Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who scored 30 points Sunday. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Edmonton Oilers, Stanley Cup finals, first game, at Edmonton, Alberta, 9:05 P.M. The long-awaited confrontation between the two high-scoring stars, New York's Mike Bossy and Wayne Gretzky. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK-FM, 97.5; 9 P.M.) Other Events Boxing: James Smith vs. Linwood Jones and Woody Clark vs. Conroy Nelson, heavyweights, eight-round co-feature bouts, at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 7:45 P.M. Harness Racing: Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape); Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M.; Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 8 P.M.; Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M. Tennis: Miller-DePhillips Eastern hardcourt championship, women at 1 P.M., men at 3 P.M., at Port Washington Tennis Academy, 100 Harbor Road, Port Washington, L.I. Thoroughbred Racing: Monmouth Park, Oceanport, N.J., 1:30 P.M. Water Polo: Italy vs.

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Analysis
description: Faced with problems of preparing for possible emergencies at two nuclear electric power facilities, Governor Cuomo has responded with a campaign to get the Federal Government to provide more assistance.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA BIDS FOR FLAGSHIP GROUP
description: Sun Banks of Florida, an Orlando-based banking group that is the state's third biggest, said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the Miami-based Flagship Banks group in a cash and stock offer valued at up to $331 million.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $97,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $9,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, said they had increased their stake in Fisher Foods Inc. to 17.9 percent of the common shares outstanding, through open market purchases.

title: TV: CHANNEL 13'S 'FIFTH'
description: AFTER watching a performance of Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July'' on Broadway, a theatergoer was heard to remark, with evident satisfaction, ''Finally, a play play - maybe real plays are coming back.'' It was a pinpointing of Mr. Wilson's strength. Eschewing abstractions, avant-garde experimentation or gimmicky sets, he uses the fairly traditional forms of domestic drama - complete with beginnings, middles and ends - to create his own very distinctive world of special sensibilities. It is an art he has developed with uncommon skill.

title: A RAIL LINE TO ATLANTIC CITY PLANNED
description: Plans are under way to re-establish rail service from Philadelphia to Atlantic City, linking the casino city with communities on Amtrak's Northeast Corridor between Boston and Washington.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS REMAIN DIVIDED ON SALVADOR AID
description: Democrats on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, divided over military aid to El Salvador, were unable to reach a compromise at a 90-minute closed-door meeting today.

title: Champion Driver Sought by F.B.I.
description: John Paul Sr., a two-time winner of the World Endurance Drivers championship, is being sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges stemming from the shooting of a Federal grand jury witness, it was reported Monday.

title: Resorts Debenture
description: A $230 million issue of Resorts International 11 3/8 percent subordinated debentures due April 1, 2013. is expected to be offered at a price of 90.321 to yield 12.625 percent today.

title: Wyoming Loses Lawsuit To Keep Amtrak Route
description: A Federal district court today dismissed a lawsuit filed by the state of Wyoming, which tried to stop Amtrak from bypassing the state in favor of a more scenic passenger rail route through Colorado.

title: Debt Issues
description: * BOC Group's British Oxygen Finance B.V. subsidiary is issuing $100 million of Eurobonds due in 1993, priced at par, with 10 3/4 percent coupons, through Nomura International Ltd.; the issue is guaranteed by the parent company.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SEES NEW YORK CITY VULNERABLE AS ECONOMY PICKS UP
description: The finance and service fields, which have kept New York City's economy healthy, may become points of vulnerability for the city as the nation emerges from the recession, according to a Federal analysis.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MUSIC: BERLIOZ'S 'CELLINI'
description: THE French taste in opera has long run in two opposite and seemingly unreconcilable directions. On one hand, there is the concentration, amounting to obsession, with grandeur, mythic deeds, heroic striving and all that. But, running against this current, there is also a strong affection for a more prosaic kind of musical theater.

title: Bandits Land an Ace
description: Gary Anderson, the versatile runner-receiver from Arkansas, yesterday became the first National Football League first-round draft choice to sign with a United States Football League team, but it was not the New Jersey Generals, who had made him their No.1 draft pick. Anderson, one of three first-round picks of the San Diego Chargers, signed a four-year contract with the Tampa Bay Bandits, who obtained his negotiating rights from the Generals in a trade for a future first-round draft choice.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest periods include income of approximately $675,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,275,000, or 29 cents a share, for the year from incremental U. S. exports and a foreign currency translation loss of approximately $550,000 for the quarter and year.

title: HALEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
28 FOR WALKER
description: In the short life of the New Jersey Generals, there have been more downs than ups and tonight's 22-7 loss to the Birmingham Stallions at Giants Stadium was decidedly on the down side.

title: HYDROMER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Reborn Inside Sports Offering Ad Discounts
description: Norman Jacobs, the president of Century Publishing Company, which he founded in 1969, has been publishing advertising media since then and has never had an advertising sales force. Direct mail advertising was the answer.

COMPUTER LAW FIELD IS BEYOND INFANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 HITS FOR NICHOLS
description: Reid Nichols smacked four hits, including a two-run homer and two doubles, to lead the Boston Red Sox to an 8-2 victory over the California Angels tonight. Bob Stanley pitched six and two-thirds innings of two-hit relief to help the Eastern Division leaders win for the sixth time in the last seven games.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Decision File; Judge Rejects Air Crash Claim
description: On Jan. 13, 1982, when an Air Florida jet crashed into Washington's 14th Street Bridge and sank in the Potomac River, what followed was immediately televised nationally, and some of the victims were seen by friends and families.

title: The Treasury Deserves a Chrysler Profit
description: Should the Government yield its right to profit from the Chrysler Corporation's success? The company argues that the risk in guaranteeing Chrysler loans was not large enough to justify a potential Treasury windfall of $220 million. But an important reason remains to enforce an admittedly tough deal: the need to avoid a precedent.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000 from the sale of property. Share earnings do not reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split declared yesterday.

title: Guerrillas Seize Town From Salvador Troops
description: Guerrillas seized a heavily fortified town in Cabanas Province and overran four small military posts in the rugged hills around it, military sources said today.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $113,042. c-Net loss.

title: VISTA RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 10, 1983
description: International Britons will vote June 9 in a general election, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced. The date is 11 months before the end of her five-year term. Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives are widely expected to win a substantial majority in the new House of Commons. (Page A1, Column 6.) The world's monetary system needs revamping, according to President Francois Mitterrand. The French leader called for a top-level conference to try to reorganize the monetary system and warned that, otherwise, ''there will be no salvation.'' (A1:4.)

title: THEATER HALL OF FAME GETS 10 NEW MEMBERS
description: The gold-carpeted lobby of the Uris Theater was crowded with theater people who gathered yesterday afternoon to honor 10 distinguished members of their community and to reminisce about them.

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $341,000 for the quarter and $561,000 for the 9 months. c-Incluidng a tax credit of $256,000.

title: FORGERIES FACE NEW ARSENAL OF ANTI-HOAX TECHNIQUES
description: IDENTIFYING the age of ink and paper - and thus tracking down forgeries as was apparently done in the case of the purported diaries of Hitler - is an art that has come of age in recent years because of sophisticated new techniques that can detect subtle changes in formulas, according to forensic scientists in and out of government.

title: EXHAUSTS STILL AFFLICT BUS COMMUTERS
description: As the rush hour peaks in the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal every evening, the diesel exhaust from loading buses swirls around 24 glass-and-metal enclosures that were installed two years ago to protect commuters from the fumes.

title: CHRYSLER ANGERS SOME IN CONGRESS
description: Several members of Congress responded angrily today to word that the Chrysler Corporation wants the Government to forgo some or all of the large profit it could make by exercising its right to buy Chrysler common stock.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 10, 1983; International
description: President Franc,ois Mitterrand of France called for a ''new Bretton Woods'' conference to reorganize the world monetary system. He told O.E.C.D ministers meeting in Paris that such a conference would reinforce and stabilize links between the dollar, the yen and European currencies. (Page A1.) Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan warned new debt reschedulings might be needed by third world countries heavily in debt to Western banks and governments. (D5.) The U.S. has four main goals for the Williamsburg, Va., summit meeting, according to a Government memorandum. (D5.)

title: Farm Exports Continue Slide
description: The value of United States farm exports continues to drop from levels a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Baldwin-United
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation has agreed to sell its 460,000 shares of Cincinnati Bell stock to the utility, Cincinnati Bell said. The company has negotiated an extension until July 15 with several lenders to refinance some $682 million in shortterm debt.

title: NORFOLK'S REVITALIZATION SPURRED BY PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP
description: From City Hall, Mayor Vincent Thomas can spot as many as 25 construction cranes working on the waterfront where $500 million in new office buildings, housing units, a trade center and recreational sites are transforming downtown Norfolk.

title: CONSULTANT AND 50'S DEFENSE AIDE
description: Anna Rosenberg Hoffman, one of the most influential women in the country's public affairs for a quarter of a century and an assistant secretary of defense from 1950 to 1953, died of pneumonia yesterday in her Manhattan apartment. She had been suffering from cancer for more than a year. She was was 81 years old and also had a home in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Ally Is First Agency For NFL Properties
description: Ally & Gargano has come up a winner of the account of NFL Properties, the licensing and marketing arm of the National Football League.

title: B.P. Drops Oilfield Bid
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. has decided not to exercise its right to match a bid by the Dorset Group for the British Gas Corporation's Wytch Farm oilfield, Energy Secretary Nigel Lawson told Parliament today.

description: The regents of the Smithsonian Institution today put off until September action on a request to open their meetings to the public and press.

title: Art Panel Backs Plan For Auto-Race Track
description: Landscaping changes necessary to permit a Grand Prix Formula One auto race through Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens were approved unanimously yesterday by the City Art Commission. The commission reviews all such alterations of public land.

title: THE SAME OLD SCANDAL
description: When former Federal prosecutor Thomas Puccio produced his report on Westway last week, as commissioned by Governor Cuomo, advocates of the $4 billion megadevelopment didn't like its conclusions, so they dismissed it as an insignificant ''memorandum'' full of ''unsolicited advice'' that broke ''no new ground.''

description: b-After a charge of $1.20 a share from the writedown of inventory, and a tax credit of $38,000. c-Net income after a tax credit of $80,000.

description: b-Net loss. Corrected from last Thursday's editions.

title: Title Retained
description: Rafael Orono of Venezuela defended his World Boxing Council super flyweight title tonight with a unanimous 12-round decision over Raul Valdez of Mexico. There were no knockdowns.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected Robert E. Keilman a senior vice president.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $12,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Grey's Profits Up 45%
description: Grey Advertising reported Friday that its first-quarter net income, thanks to a change in accounting methods, jumped 45 percent, to $634,000, or $1.12 a share, from $437,000, or 73 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues increased 9.3 percent, to $31.8 million, from $29.1 million.

title: SI HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Feb 27.
CITY BALLET: KYRA NICHOLS
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S ''Afternoon of a Faun'' would seem to be interpretation-proof after so many years of new casts. But Kyra Nichols made it her own on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet presented that Robbins classic.

title: Daily Meetings Begun On Status of A-Plant
description: The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, began a series of daily meetings today with officials of the Consolidated Edison Company and the State Power Authority in an effort to avoid a Government-threatened shutdown of the Indian Point nuclear plants.

INDIANAPOLIS WATER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WISER OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
25 Are Killed in Mexico In Church Explosion
description: Barrels of gunpowder to be used for fireworks at a religious fair exploded in a crowded Roman Catholic church in this town 45 miles southeast of Mexico City, killing 25 people and injuring more than 350, officials said today.

title: OASIS OF LEARNING SPRINGS UP IN JUST A YEAR
description: WHAT was once Benjamin Franklin High School, a hapless institution in East Harlem with one of the city's highest rates of absenteeism and one of its lowest rates of graduation, has been transformed in just one year into a model institution for upgrading education in low-income neighborhoods.

title: Sale of Cavs Approved
description: The National Basketball Association's Board of Governors today approved the sale of the Cleveland franchise and conditionally approved the sale of the Indiana franchise.

title: LEXICON
description: The relentless war on straightforward language waged by Washington bureaucrats and think-tank denizens continues, with a spring offensive on the nuclear warfare front and in budgetmaking. Some usages noted in recent Government reports and papers, or heard in conversation:

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers cut prices on notes and bonds and tried to clear their shelves of unwanted inventory.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Green Book as Catalogue

title: L.M. Ericsson Stock Offering
description: An issue of 3.65 million shares of the L.M. Ericsson Telephone Company was priced for offering today at $62.50 a share through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tracking the Tourists

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THEATER: 'LABOR OPERA' BY BLITZSTEIN IS REVIVED
description: JUST before each performance of ''The Cradle Will Rock'' at the American Place Theater, John Houseman walks to a podium to deliver a 10-minute lecture. We're used to watching Mr. Houseman lecture these days: with his bow tie, crusty demeanor and authoritative voice, he has become, courtesy of television, our foremost unofficial university professor. But the speech he's giving this time is not manufactured rhetoric. What Mr. Houseman reads instead is his own account of how Marc Blitzstein's ''labor opera'' first faced a New York audience almost 46 years ago.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
J. EDGAR BENNETT, EX-CHESEBROUGH EXECUTIVE
description: J. Edgar Bennett, a director and retired vice president of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., manufacturer of cosmetic and health products, was shot to death by a burglar early Saturday at his vacation home on St. Martin, French West Indies. Mr. Bennett, who lived in Greenwich, Conn., was 66 years old.

title: REAGAN CALLS MEETING ON ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan, moving quickly to reach accommodation with key members of Congress, has called a National Security Council meeting Tuesday to decide whether to shift the American negotiating position in the strategic arms talks in Geneva, high-ranking Administration officials disclosed today.

title: IN PRESSURE SPOTS 76ERS RELY ON JONES
description: About 90 minutes before the start of Sunday's game against the Milwaukee Bucks, Julius Erving of the 76ers was guiding his car into a parking spot at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. Not far away, several youngsters, pencils and pads in hand, were talking basketball.

title: SOME DERBY CLOUDS
description: ABC had planned to build its telecast of the 109th Kentucky Derby l ast Saturday on two themes: first, that the Derby is an event that t ranscends horse racing -a slice of Americana - the way that the S uper Bowl is more than just a championship football game and the I ndianapolis 500 more than fast cars traveling in circles. Second, t he producer Chet Forte decided to focus on the horse, Marfa, the r ambunctious gray colt who created controversy during Derby week b ecause of his penchant to run roughshod over other horses in his p revious races.

title: Lawyer Puts Gloves Back On
description: Mike Trainer, the lawyer who guided Sugar Ray Leonard to more than $35 million in earnings, always used to say that when Leonard retired from the ring, so would he. After all, there were a lot of boxing people who would have loved to get even with Trainer for his tough negotiations on behalf of Leonard. They figured that without a superstar attraction, Trainer would quietly retire to his Silver Spring, Md., law practice.

title: CONCERT: BRENDEL IN BEETHOVEN CYCLE
description: IN each generation there are a few musicians who stake out for themselves what may be called, using the term loosely, the intellectual audience. Names such as Artur Schnabel, Joseph Szigeti and Edwin Fischer captured that constituency's votes while other musicians such as Arthur Rubinstein, Jascha Heifetz and Vladimir Horowitz found little favor there. In recent decades, Rudolf Serkin has been a darling of both sorts of audiences, which is a feat roughly comparable to being a hero of both the Blue and the Gray. At the moment, the intellectual public's leading candidate for heroism seems to be Alfred Brendel, who launched a complete cycle of the Beethoven piano sonatas last night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Czechoslovakia Bars Entry Of New York Times Reporter
description: A correspondent for The New York Times was barred from entering Czechoslovakia today for refusing to allow security officials at the Prague airport to inspect his personal address book.

title: Senator's Son Charged
description: Stephen Specter, the 22-year-old son of Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, was arrested Sunday and charged with second-degree burglary, the United States Attorney's office said today.

title: ERROR ADMITTED BY AN INFORMER AT BRINK'S TRIAL
description: A key informant acknowledged under cross-examination yesterday that he had been ''confused'' about some dates and details in his testimony in the Brink's trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid June 21, 1982.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALGAE: MASS EXTINCTION
description: THE earliest known major mass extinction occurred among algae some 650 million years ago, according to evidence reported this week by scientists from the United States and Sweden.

title: DEBATE OVER STOCK SPECIALISTS
description: The need for the stock market specialist once was unquestioned. As recently as the mid-70's, specialists at the New York and American exchanges were the focus of stock trading on the exchange floors.

title: Stokely-Van Camp
description: Esmark Inc. said that it would not participate as an investor in the acquisition of Stokely-Van Camp Inc. by the SVC Acquiring Corporation. SVC is a group led by William Stokely, Stokely-Van Camp's chairman, that is trying to take to company private. Stokely said, however, that Esmark does not plan on disposing of its stock position and intends to vote in favor of the proposed transaction.

title: REGAN SEES DANGER IF THE THIRD WORLD FAILS TO REPAY DEBT
description: United States Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan warned today of ''unpleasant developments'' for the world economy if more third world countries fail to repay their debts to Western banks and governments.

18 Are Hurt in Crash Of a Bus in Brooklyn
description: At least 18 people suffered minor injuries last night when a commuter bus carrying 30 passengers hit a car in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect miscellaneous income and expense.

title: Market Place; A Moratorium On Bank Deals
description: PAUL A. VOLCKER, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has asked Congress to enact legislation temporarily halting all acquisitions of banks and thrift institutions by nonbank companies. He proposed the moratorium to give Congress time to establish policy ''rather than be faced with a fait accompli.''

title: IS THE SITUATION REALLY THAT BLEAK?
description: EDUCATION is front-page news again. Not since the post-Sputnik crash programs to improve the teaching of science and mathematics in the late 1950's or Lyndon Johnson's education-based Great Society legislation of the mid-1960's or the college students' revolt of a little more than a decade ago has education been given as much public attention as in recent weeks.

title: Shrinking Fertility Rate
description: A survey of 17 industrialized countries in both the East and West has found that all but four have fertility rates that are insufficient to maintain their current populations if long continued. Furthermore, the rate is expected to drop below the replacement level in this decade in the four remaining countries: Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Poland and the Soviet Union.

title: C P REHAB CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: ITI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Comings and Goings
description: The Venezuelan Government and its national Olympic Committee reached an agreement yesterday that will permit the IX Pan American Games to take place in Caracas beginning Aug. 14. Guillermo Yepes Boscan, Venezuela's minister of Youth, agreed to recognize the Olympic Committee. His earlier refusal to extend recognition had left the status of the Games in question. ... Jack Kemp, the Republican Representative from Buffalo and former quarterback for the Bills, was named winner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame's Gold Medal. ... While his father, Mario Andretti, was in Indianapolis Sunday preparing for the Indianapolis 500 later this month, Mike Andretti drove his Electrolux Ralt Rt-4 to victory in a 100-mile race in Sears Point, Calif. ... Donald Lizak, who was an assistant to Lou Carnesecca at St. John's last season, was named head basketball coach at Queens College. ... Brad Lesley, a reliever who pitched for the Reds in 28 games last season, has been called up from the Indianapolis farm club. ... The World Boxing Association ruled yesterday that Ray Mancini must present proof that he has incurred the shoulder injury he cited in canceling a title bout May 27 in South Africa with Kenny Bogner.

title: MITTERRAND SEEKS PARLEY TO REVAMP MONETARY SYSTEM
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France called today for a conference ''at the highest level'' that would attempt to reorganize the world monetary system.

title: U.S. Backs Can Concerns
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division tentatively supported motions today by the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company to end 33-year-old court orders entered against them. The court orders, dating from 1950, prevented the two companies from tying the sale or lease of equipment used to close filled cans to the sale of cans themselves.

description: The Beltran Corporation said that its Acton Foodservices Corporation unit had consented on May 6 to a previously reported involuntary position for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Six trade creditors owed $175,000 had filed the action.

description: Western banks working on a credit package of $6.7 billion for Yugoslavia are trying to give the country enough to pay its debts this year as well as something extra to revive its ailing economy, according to Yugoslav officials.

title: A SECOND POST FOR ANDROPOV IS DISCLOSED
description: The Soviet Defense Minister disclosed today that in addition to serving as Communist Party leader, Yuri V. Andropov holds the post of chairman of the Defense Council, a group that is believed to supervise the Soviet armed forces under the overall authority of the ruling Politburo.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results include a $1,700,000 writedown of receivables related to certain charges disallowed by Medicare.

title: PHILADELPHIA NEARS ACCORD IN TRANSIT DISPUTE
description: The transit authority serving Philadelphia commuters reached agreement today with the largest of its striking unions, but the system's 54-day-old walkout will continue until all the unions reach settlements.

title: NEGOTIATORS PLAN TO MEET IN EFFORT TO SETTLE SOME METRO-NORTH ISSUES
description: Union and management negotiators in the still-unsettled contract dispute on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad are scheduled to meet tomorrow to try to resolve secondary matters before the critical question of crew size is placed before a three-member arbitration panel.

title: Israeli Envoy at U.N. Scolds 133 U.S. Jewish Law Students
description: Yehuda Z. Blum, the Israeli delegate to the United Nations, today challenged the accuracy of a letter sent to him by a group of American Jewish law students protesting Israel's invasion of Lebanon and its treatment of Palestinians in the occupied territories.

title: Turkish Publisher Draws a Jail Sentence
description: A martial law court today sentenced Nadir Nadi, publisher of the left-wing daily Cumhuriyet, to 2 months and 20 days in jail on charges of ''provoking the public to violate laws.''

title: Ex-Mayor Seeking Post in Bridgeport
description: Former Mayor John C. Mandanici said today he would seek re-election. Mr. Mandanici, a Democrat, said he had been ''encouraged by many people to run again, not the politicians but the homeowners and the taxpayers.''

title: FEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
description: b-Net income.

title: ADMINISTRATION PRESSES COURT ON TEEN-AGE CONTRACEPTIVE RULE
description: The Reagan Administration asked the United States Court of Appeals today to uphold a new Federal rule that would require certain family planning clinics to notify parents when they prescribe contraceptives for minors.

title: AMERICAN AGGREGATES CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
UNLIKELY TEAM CAPTURES CHESS TITLE
description: When Robert Cotter, a fifth-grade science teacher, tried to organize a chess club at his inner-city school three years ago, none of the students knew a pawn from a king.

title: CANADIAN MANOIR INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SHULTZ IN THE MIDDLE EAST: HOW AN ACCORD EMERGED
description: The draft agreement last week on joint security arrangements between Israel and Lebanon resulted from more than four months of negotiations that reached a turning point in Beirut last Wednesday.

title: Valdez, in Court, Denies Charge
description: A plea of not guilty was entered today on behalf of Julio Valdez, the Boston Red Sox player who is charged with statutory rape of a 14-year-old girl.

title: Bridge: Lipsitz and Silverman Win The Cavendish Invitational
description: Robert Lipsitz of Annandale, Va., and Neil Silverman of New York won the Cavendish invitational pairs Sunday by a substantial margin. Their score was 1,423 international match points, 236 more than that of the runners-up, David Berkowitz of Secaucus, N.J., and Harold Lilie of New York.

title: Chess:; Three Tie for First Place in Marshall Tournament
description: The sixth annual Frank J. Marshall International Tournament at the Chess Center of New York saw three international masters - Eugene Meyer of Woodstock, N.Y., Dimitry Gurevich of the Bronx and Igor Ivanov of Canada - tie for first place, each scoring 8-3.

title: H.M. HORNER, 79, A PIONEER IN AMERICAN FLIGHT INDUSTRY
description: H. M. Horner, a pioneer in the American aviation industry who retired in 1968 as chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: KEG RESTAURANTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Corral for W. 41st St.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $165,000 net of tax write-off in oil and gas operations.

title: Californian Is Killed As Jets Bomb Test Range
description: A 35-year-old man was killed and his father was seriously injured when Marine Corps jets bombed a practice range where they were collecting scrap metal, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. CUTTING SUGAR PURCHASES, NICARAGUA SAYS
description: The United States has reduced the amount of sugar it buys from Nicaragua by 90 percent, the Nicaraguan Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: THREAT TO CABLE TV EXPANSION VOICED
description: New York's long-delayed plan to get cable television systems in the boroughs outside Manhattan has been jeopardized by a proposal to build a satellite communications center on Staten Island, an executive of a cable company said yesterday.

title: ELECTIONS CALLED 11 MONTHS EARLY BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today called a general election for June 9, 11 months before the end of her fiveyear term.

title: MACANDREWS & FORBES GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax charge of $1,928,000 relating to the present value of an employment ntract with the former chairman of Technicolor. c-Includes a nonrecurring pretax gain of $1,325,000, or 48 cents a share, realized on the disposition of the company's investment in Richardson Co. The results for the latest quarter include the operations of Technicolor Inc. which was acquired last December.

title: News Analysis
description: The tentative agreement on security arrangements in Lebanon has been greeted in Israel with something considerably less than enthusiasm.

title: TENSIONS GROW
description: A top official in Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's Government has been strongly criticized by the Soviet Union, and the attack has introduced new uncertainty into Poland's political situation.

title: BROOKLYN GIVES VIEWS OF BUDGET LOUD AND CLEAR
description: The voice of the people was heard yesterday in the deliberations over New York City's budget, and the message was clear: repair our roads, clean our parks, save our schools, put the police back on our streets and don't close our libraries.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Julio Valdez, i nfielder, on the restricted list; recalled M arty Barrett, second baseman, from P awtucket of the International League. CHICAGO (AL) - Reactivated Britt B urns, pitcher, who has been on the dis- a bled list because of a cold in his pitching s houlder; optioned Steve Mura, pitcher, to t he Denver Bears of the American Associ- a tion. CINCINNATI (NL) - Sent Ben Hayes, r elief pitcher, to Indianapolis of the A merican Association; recalled Greg H arris and Brad Lesley, pitchers, from In- d ianapolis; traded Rafael Landestoy, in- f ielder, to Los Angeles for Brett Wise and J ohn Franko, minor league pitchers. CLEVELAND (AL) - Fined Rick Man- n ing, centerfielder, for running the base- l ine too slow and Miguel Dilone, leftfield- e r, for missing a team bus. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Ordered Ed Whit- s on, pitcher, to Las Vegas of the Pacific C oast League for 20 days of rehabilitation. W hitson underwent knee surgery last m onth.

title: Congressman Hurt in Crash
description: Representative Cecil Heftel, Democrat of Hawaii, was recovering today at Walter Reed Army Medical Center from injuries received in a car crash Sunday on a rain-slicked street near the Lincoln Memorial. The 58-year-old lawmaker broke his hip, ankle and nose when his car veered off the street onto a grassy area and hit a tree, an aide said.

title: MORROW'S RETURN TRIBUTE TO SURGERY
description: K en Morrow thought about a lot of things last Wednesday night. He thought about his daughter, Krysten, who will soon spend her first full summer in the world. He thought about the things his wife and daughter will do together. Morrow remembered the golf game that he will soon have the opportunity to improve. He imagined the possibility of a fourth Stanley Cup celebration in his fourth season with the Islanders. He looked forward to his job as an assistant coach during the tryouts for the United States Olympic hockey team at the end of June.

title: MARKET GAINS, BUT DOW IS OFF
description: Stock trading remained heavy and the overall market continued to show strength yesterday, although its three major indexes retreated from the record highs they reached on Friday.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Amoco Italia Sale
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) is negotiating the sale of its Italian subsidiary, Amoco Italia, a company spokesman said.

title: Sears Courting The Investor
description: Robert M. Gardiner has been in the securities business since 1946, when he started as an analyst for A.M. Kidder after leaving the Army. In 1951, he moved over to Reynolds Securities, and has since seen a lot of firms come and go on Wall Street. He himself has been involved in 32 mergers or acquisitions, including the 1978 amalgamation of Reynolds - he was by then its chairman and chief executive - with Dean Witter.

title: CANADA CEMENT LAFARGE LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: People
description: * David T. Michaelson is joining Cadwell Davis Partners Advertising as senior vice president, media director.

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared in February.

title: Jacobs Leads Bid To Buy Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that a group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessman, that already owns 16.3 percent of Kaiser Steel's common stock had offered to buy the company.

title: NEWS COUNCIL CONTRAST
description: To the Editor:

title: TWIN CITY BARGE & TOWING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Prices Are Up For Gasoline
description: Gasoline prices have increased 10.11 cents a gallon since late March, because of the 5-cent-a gallon Federal tax rise and higher charges imposed by oil companies to recover from months of intense competition, according to Dan Lundberg, an industry analyst.

title: CHOMERICS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Net loss.

title: I.R.A. Case Argued
description: After five hours of deliberating, a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn failed to reach a verdict last night in the case of four men charged with plotting to smuggle weapons to the provisional Irish Republican Army. Deliberations will resume today.

title: LOWERING OF PCB'S IN HUMANS IS FOUND
description: The Environmental Protection Agency released today a study indicating that the level of the toxic chemicals known as PCB's in the body tissue of Americans has declined dramatically since 1977.

title: Pogo Tender Suit Counterclaim
description: Sedco Inc. and Northwest Industries jointly announced that they would file a counterclaim in the tender offer litigation begun on April 27 by the Pogo Producing Company in Houston.

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: FURTHER ADVENTURES OF HERO, THE ANDROID
description: ''WARNING!'' he called out in his synthesized voice. ''Warning, intruder. I have summoned the police!'' Hero the robot held his arm high and ominously waved a toy gun back and forth. One of his sonar systems had detected someone entering the office and now he was valiantly attempting to ward off the prowler.

title: Board Won't Bid for Seafirst
description: The Washington State Investment Board today decided against making a bid for the financially troubled Seafirst Corporation, which the BankAmerica Corporation last month agreed to take over.

title: NICARAGUA ATTACKS U.S. AT U.N.
description: Nicaragua told the Security Council today that the Reagan Administration was waging an undeclared war against the Sandinist Government, a charge that the United States quickly denied.

title: KEY INTERNATIONAL FILM DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a provision for depreciation of $10,858. c-Net loss

title: 1. Art for Wearing
description: A young woman from Barcelona named Kima does hand-painted clothing that doesn't look hand-painted at all. The designs are not the usual flowers or faces but strong geometrics reminiscent of the constructivist art movement of the 1920's. She makes scarves, blouses and tuniclike dresses in simple, squared-off shapes, using raw silk, crepe de chine or satin. Her most interesting designs are boldly colored, but she also does some soft pastels with an Oriental feeling. She has a selection of ready-made clothes here and will also accept commissions for custom work. Dresses, like the one shown, range from about $330 to $450. Blouses are $275 to $375; scarves, $55 to $75. Kima works by appointment, which may be made by calling 212-228-5692.

title: EASTERN PACT MAY GIVE PILOTS 21% OF THE AIRLINE
description: The pilots at Eastern Air Lines Inc. could end up with a 21 percent stake in the airline in return for about $100 million in work-rule and benefits concessions, according to a top official of the pilots' union.

title: INTERNATIONAL POWER MACHINES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. The Yankees get another shot at Rick Honeycutt, who beat them on April 29 by allowing only one run in seven innings.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Mary Frances Carpenter lives in a ground-floor window on West 48th Street. Like New York's luckiest hanging plants, she gets sunshine all day long. From the street, there is just her moon face in the window, with its half-moon grin, and the shadowy edges of the chairs and tables inside her railroad flat.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $2,872,000. c-After realized investment losses of $625,000.

title: HOW RESTAURANTS ARE MONITORED FOR FOOD SAFETY
description: NEW YORK CITY has more than 14,000 restaurants, some of which seem to change identities like movie marquees. So it is no small feat for the city's Health Department to keep keep track of them, let alone monitor them for cleanliness. What makes the task even more difficult is that the department has only 17 full-time restaurant inspectors. Albert Simms is one of them.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sixty-one-year-old Tex Winter, who has a career record of 454-333 as a college basketball coach, will become an assistant to Dale Brown at Louisiana State after he resigns at Long Beach State in August. ... John Walker, a 6-foot-6-inch, 270-pound defensive tackle from Nebraska-Omaha who was the Jets' fifth-round draft choice, signed a contract with the club and became its first 1983 draftee to do so. ... Rest just hasn't done the trick, so Dave Cowens, the sidelined Milwaukee Buck, has decided to try surgery to repair the injury to his right knee that has kept him out of action for much of the season. He said he would have the operation as soon as the playoffs ended.

title: COMBINED NETWORK INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective May 6.

title: ARGUING CALL PROVES TO BE BAD DECISION
description: HOUSTON D id the umpire make a bad call? Was Danny Heep, in only his second start at first base this season, largely responsible for costing the Mets a ball game? Would things have turned out differently if Dave Kingman had been playing there instead?

title: UNRELATED APARTMENT SHARERS MAY BE EVICTED
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that landlords have the right to evict unrelated people who are sharing an apartment without the landlord's consent.

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Hammermill Paper Company, a leading maker of writing and printing papers, yesterday named Donald S. Leslie as president. Mr. Leslie, 57, who has been executive vice president, succeeds Albert F. Duval. Mr. Duval, 62, has been president and chief executive and now will be chairman and chief executive.

title: PIONEER STANDARD ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN it comes to classic French dishes, I usually try to be as precise as possible. If I gave a recipe for tournedos Rossini, I would insist that it be made with the fillet of beef Rossini cooked and garnished with foie gras plus truffles and a Madeira sauce. In a recipe for sweetbreads a la financiere, it would be essential that olives, fluted mushrooms and veal dumplings be used in the sauce.

title: Carlton Passes 3,500 Mark
description: Steve Carlton pitched a five-hitter and Tony Perez celebrated his Cincinnati homecoming tonight by tripling in two runs to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 3-1 victory over the Reds.

title: A Jab at Cooney
description: Bert Sugar, the editor and publisher of The Ring magazine, will be the host of an informal party this afternoon at O'Reilly's Restaurant on West 31st Street. But the guest of honor won't be there.

title: Kerr-McGee Chairman
description: D.A. McGee, a 79-year-old geologist and business manager who has retained tight control of the Kerr-McGee Corporation for more than 35 years, announced yesterday that he was stepping down as the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: U.S. SAID TO MOVE TOWARD NEW PLAN ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration moved today toward adoption of a new negotiating position in strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
2 Killed in West Virginia As Coal Mine Collapses
description: Two West Virginia coal miners were killed today when tons of rock fell on them as a mine roof collapsed 2,600 feet into a Logan County mountainside, officials said.

title: Advertising; A Tuneful Shop With 5 'Sammys'
description: THE Dr Pepper and 7-Up jingles, the background music for the Army and Pan Am commercials, the NBC-TV network promotion announcements and scores of other familiar scores connected with advertising can all be traced back to HEA Productions, one of the city's most prestigious suppliers of music for commercials.

title: SENATE DUE TO VOTE ON RISE IN TAXES FOR A LOWER DEFICIT
description: The Senate is expected to vote Wednesday on the politically charged question of how much in tax increases to lock into the Government budget for the fiscal year 1984 for the sake of reducing the deficit.

title: OWNERS OF U.P.I. VOW IMPROVED SERVICE TO EDITORS
description: The owners of United Press International, the nation's second largest news service, faced skeptical and occasionally hostile questioning today from newspaper editors who said they did not know why they should continue to subscribe.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SYSTONETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $5,000. c-Net income after extraordinary credit of $295,000.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON CHICAGO PARKS
description: In what Federal officials hailed as a landmark settlement, the Chicago Park District agreed today to upgrade facilities, services and maintenance in parks serving the city's black and Hispanic areas.

title: CARL A. HILL
description: Carl A. Hill, former dean of Dartmouth College's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration, died Saturday at his home in Kennebunk, Me.

title: BRINK'S DEFENDANT QUESTIONS WITNESS
description: A defendant confronted his chief accuser in a highly unusual cross-examination yesterday in the Brink's trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Cancels Meeting With Reagan
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has canceled a meeting with President Reagan this month and indicated she might not attend the seven-nation economic conference scheduled for Williamsburg, Va., May 28-30.

title: Raymond International
description: Raymond International stockholders, at the annual meeting yesterday, approved amendments to the company charter requiring approval of 80 percent of shareholders for certain business transactions. The engineering and construction concern has been negotiating with Kelso & Company, an investment banking firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts. Raymond, which has six million shares outstanding, has been considering a plan by which its management and employees would buy out the company for $25 a share, or $150 million.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Debt Issues
description: * American Electric Power Co.'s Ohio Power Co. subsidiary filed a shelf registration for up to $130 million of first mortgage bonds, to be sold from time to time, with terms and underwriters determined at the time of sale.

title: REV. RENE LUEDEE
description: The Rev. Rene Luedee, a retired Army chaplain, died of cancer Sunday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in West Haven, Conn. He was 51 years old and had lived in New Haven.

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss

title: US DESIGN CORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRIEFS
description: * Atari Inc., a unit of Warner Communications, said it had formed a joint venture with MCA Inc.'s MCA Video Games Inc. subsidiary to create coin-operated video games, home video games and computer software based on motion pictures, television, and other MCA properties.

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTA, GA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The share earnings and the shares outstanding reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid April 20, 1983.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $39,000 for the quarter and income of $453,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $91,000 for the quarter and income of $127,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock splits declared in September 1982 and March 1983.

title: Value Line Sale Proves Popular
description: A public offering of 1.9 million shares of common stock in Value Line Inc. began yesterday with the stock offered by the underwriters at $17 a share.

title: DYATRON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SANDINISTS CURBED ON U.S. SUGAR SALES
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would deprive Nicaragua of the right to sell most of its sugar crop to the United States. The White House said it was doing so in order to reduce the fiscal resources that are available to the Sandinist Government for ''subversion and extremist violence.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Secret of Model Boats: Setting the Rubber Band

title: Passenger on Eastern Jet Tells of Near Disaster
description: A passenger on the Eastern Airlines plane that nearly ditched in the Atlantic last week says flight attendants were not familiar with emergency procedures, but an airline official discounted this.

title: BECK-ARNLEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MPSI GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REPORTER DENIES HITLER HOAX ROLE
description: The reporter who acquired the bogus Hitler diaries accused his former employer, Stern magazine, today of making him a ''scapegoat'' for its own incompetence, and he denied having kept some of the money paid for the notebooks.

title: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Blast Wins, 8-6, And Gains Finals
description: Dave MacWilliams led Baltimore with three goals and two assists as the Blast defeated the Cleveland Force, 8-6, to capture the Major Indoor Soccer League's Eastern Division championship tonight in the fifth game of their three-of-five-game series.

title: POLITICS PLAYING A PART A CANNES FILM FESTIVAL
description: A Hungarian film director named Zsolt Kezdi-Kovacs spent a good deal of time at a Cannes Film Festival news conference Monday fencing with reporters who pressed him on the political import of his film, ''Forbidden Relations.''

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICY HEADED FOR A DEAD END
description: To the Editor:

title: DIXON, JOSEPH, CRUCIBLE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Line of Succession Set at Northwest
description: The stage for management succession was set yesterday at Northwest Industries, where Ben W. Heineman, the Chicago lawyer and industrialist, has been in charge since he founded the company in 1968.

title: BIO-MEDICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $112,000 for the latest first quarter and $463,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SAN DIEGO BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,500. c-Includes income of $22,847 from discontinued operations.

title: WHEN THE SECRETARY OF STATE'S AWAY
description: Kenneth Willard Dam confesses, quite openly, that he enjoys serving in the shadow of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. If he is unnoticed at restaurants or parties, if his appearance in the inevitable pin-stripe suit in the corridors of the State Department fails to turn a head, Mr. Dam says he is perfectly content about it.

title: NESTLE-LE MUR CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHINA SETS OFFSHORE OIL ACCORD
description: China awarded an offshore oil exploration contract today to a group of Western companies headed by British Petroleum. The contract was the first to result from China's first official round of bidding for oil concessions, in which 33 foreign companies participated last year.

title: QUESTIONABLE IDEA TO SPEED JUSTICE
description: To the Editor: Your attack on lawyer conduct of the examination of prospective jurors (''Wasting the Courts' Precious Time,'' editorial May 3) is unburdened with the facts.

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILL. & EXPLORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S., HELP NIGERIAN DEMOCRACY
description: The next three months are critical to the future of democracy in Africa. Nigeria, a major oil producer, and the world's fourth largest democracy (its 90 million people constitute a quarter of Africa's population) is in the midst of an intense political campaign leading to elections in August. In 1979, the army handed over power to an elected Government with a Constitution based on the American model.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Finish Tour Of Pacific in Familiar Style
description: The New York Precision team's tour of the South Pacific ended here Sunday night just as it had begun six weeks earlier in Auckland, New Zealand: With one deal remaining to be played on Vu-Graph in front of a tense audience, the score was virtually tied.

title: JETS BOOST WAYWARD SATELLITE
description: The space agency edged a $100 million communication satellite 284 miles deeper into space today as it initiated a methodical plan to elevate the craft to a stable orbit 22,300 miles above the earth.

title: SPAIN'S LETHAL COOKING OIL: THE FEAR WON'T FADE
description: Two years ago this month a mysterious disease broke out in Spain, mostly in the Madrid area, spreading panic. It seemed to appear anywhere and everywhere, without a pattern. It would attack some members of a family and spare others, strike down an elderly woman in one house and a young boy in the next.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES $20 MILLION IN AID TO SALVADOR
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved a compromise measure today that would provide an additional $20 million in military aid for El Salvador, $30 million less than was requested by President Reagan.

title: INTERNAL E.P.A. REVIEW CRITICIZES WASTE CLEANUP AS MISMANAGED
description: An internal Environmental Protection Agency report says the agency's hazardous waste programs have been so seriously impeded by mismanagement that they are not adequately protecting the public.

title: French Seeking Loan
description: France has asked the European Economic Community for a loan to help finance its huge balance-of-payments deficit, European monetary officials said today.

title: 'TRASHING' CANDIDATES
description: An interesting paradox of American politics is that every Presidential contender longs to become the front-runner, but this position once achieved becomes so hazardous as to be perceived as a possible liability on the road to nomination and election.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $89,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $32,838 from discontinued operations.

title: 20% Drop Cited In Foster Care
description: The number of city children in foster care has been reduced by 20 percent in the last four years, according to a report released yesterday by the office of City Council President Carol Bellamy.

title: MINT CONDITION
description: In the syndicate, it's the stomach that gave us the big payoff. It was Big Barney's idea to ''go for the gut,'' as he put it. He had a vision of where the money was, Big Barney.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT & TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TV: DOMINGO AND MILNES IN CONCERT
description: THE METROPOLITAN OPERA'S series ''In Concert at the Met'' concludes its second season on public telelvision, tonight at 8 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13, with a performance starring Placido Domingo, tenor; Sherrill Milnes, baritone, and James Levine, conducting the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra. Taped before an enthusiastic audience on Jan. 30, the event is still another sparkling triumph for this series.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $155,000 for the quarter and $315,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $73,000 for the quarter and $115,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from Saturday, April 30.

title: From F.C.C. to Law Firm
description: Joseph R. Fogarty, whose term as a member of the Federal Communications Commission ends in June, will head a new telecommunications department here for a New York law firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges, the firm announced today.

title: CITY MOVES AGAINST BUILDER FOR RENEGING ON PUBLIC MALL
description: The City Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday revoked the certificate of occupancy of a 36-story apartment and office building on the West Side. The board said it had determined that the building's owners had failed to properly complete a covered pedestrian mall.

title: Unfinished Chapter
description: Roger Kahn, the author, has resigned as the president of the Mets' Class A farm club in Columbia, S.C., and given up the ownership interest he acquired in the club just two months ago. Kahn, who wrote ''The Boys of Summer,'' about the old Brooklyn Dodgers, and who had planned another book about his experiences as a minor league owner, gave no reason for his decision to leave the South Atlantic League team.

title: GRAND JURY CRITICIZES THE PRACTICES OF MIAMI AND DADE COUNTY POLICE
description: A Dade County grand jury that has been investigating recent fatal police shootings today sharply criticized the hiring, training and firearms-use procedures for city and county police officers.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Long- and short-term interest rates declined yesterday as traders raised prices slightly in response to announcements by the Federal Reserve and the Treasury that pointed to a reduction soon in the amount of securities in dealer hands.

title: ATI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $122,145 for the quarter and $127,062 for the 6 months.

title: AIDE APPOINTED IN INVESTIGATION OF CONGRESSMAN
description: A special prosecutor was appointed yesterday to investigate allegations that Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn misused state funds in his 1980 Congressional race.

title: Iroquois Brands Gets New Operating Chief
description: Iroquois Brands Ltd. announced yesterday that it had named James P. McCaffrey as president and chief operating officer. Mr. McCaffrey, 49, has been executive vice president for operations. Iroquois, of Greenwich, Conn., is a maker of brand name foods and beverages.

title: CHESTER S. WILSON
description: Chester S. Wilson, Minnesota's Commissioner of Conservation from 1943 to 1955, died Friday in Stillwater.

title: News Analysis
description: Not since 1945, when the Conservatives under Winston Churchill joined battle against Labor under Clement Attlee, have Britain's major political parties fought a general election on platforms as diametrically opposed as the ones they have adopted for the balloting four weeks from Thursday.

title: The Peters Principle
description: New York dinner parties, it is our impression, are considerably less boring than Washington dinner parties, but neither is in its salad days as a social art form. More and more, at dinner parties in both cities, someone seems to look up from the Spode with glazed eyes that say ''What am I doing here?'' Charles Peters recently gave this anguish eloquent expression and the ultimate refinement. In an article in The Washington Post, he offered what might fairly be called the Peters Principle.

title: CON EDISON'S POSITION ON INDIAN POINT
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission last week threatened to shut down the two Indian Point nuclear reactors June 9 unless major improvements were made in plans for dealing with a possible emergency at the plants.

title: TURKISH-ARMENIAN ISSUE: THE COMPLEX TRAGEDY OF 1915
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Lifts Outlay
description: The Exxon Corporation will increase its investment in the construction of a power plant in Hong Kong by $750 million, a company spokesman said today.

title: PCL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: MTS SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CITY BALLET: NEWCOMERS IN MAJOR ROLES
description: RECENT performances by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater featured newcomers in several major roles. Perhaps the most important was Daniel Duell, who portrayed Frantz in ''Coppelia'' on Sunday afternoon. The way Mr. Duell entered with a wide smile and made his mimetic gestures big and broad suggested that he conceived of Frantz as a hearty peasant lad thoroughly pleased with himself and happy to be in love with two pretty girls at once.

title: Detained Afghans End Hunger Strike
description: A weeklong hunger strike by most of the 40 Afghan aliens confined in a Brooklyn detention center ended yesterday at the behest of one of their lawyers and a leader of an organization called the Afghan Community in America, the lawyer reported.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split issued last November.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Mrs. Cuomo on Nutrition

title: UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Niland Is Indicted
description: John Niland, a former all-pro guard for the Dallas Cowboys, was indicted Monday on two charges of cocaine possession. The indictments accuse the 39-year-old Niland of having cocaine in his car on March 3 when he was arrested on a theft charge stemming from a dispute wuth a former female companion, and on April 6 when he was arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to operate an export trading company. The new unit of the bank holding company will offer financing, counter trade and barter transactions. Security Pacific has been authorized to invest $10 million initially in the unit.

title: A WARNING ON ORDERS BY PHONE
description: Many Americans, used to shopping by mail, are turning to telephones to make ordering quicker and easier. But when they do, they are not covered by the same consumer-protection rules that apply to mail orders.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR most women, the birth of a baby is a joyous experience. Having waited and worried for nine months, women expect to be thrilled when the outcome is a live, healthy infant. And, at first, most are thrilled. But for up to two-thirds of new mothers, something unexpected and mystifying happens during the first week after childbirth. For no apparent reason, sadness sets in and the initial elation dissolves in teary confusion that may last for days, weeks or months.

title: Hunger Is the Biggest Error
description: Imagine a store that, no matter how much the customer was owed, gave only 50 cents in change. Such a policy might make it harder for a sales clerk to make a mistake, but only by treating customers unfairly.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have been told that there is a children's dish in America called frumenty or furmenty. It is supposed to be some sort of custard made with sugar and raisins. Are you familiar with it?

title: Moody of Generals Is Lost for Season
description: The New Jersey Generals today lost one of their most important players, Keith Moody, for the rest of the season. The veteran free safety underwent surgery at the College of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark to repair damage to torn cartilage and ligaments in the left knee.

title: Ex-Flight Controller Jailed
description: Gary Green, the first former air traffic controller jailed fob striking against the Government, began serving a 90-day sentence today, The conviction of Mr. Green, who was president of the union local at the Dallas/Fort Worth airport and one of 77 controllers nationwide prosecuted for his role in the August 1981 strike, was upheld by a Federal appeals court last month.

title: New Sony Camera
description: The Sony Corporation said it had developed a video camera that is compatible with its Betamax videotape recorders.

title: DOW GAINS 1.45
description: Stock prices advanced broadly yesterday as small and institutional investors alike stepped up their buying and sent volume over the 100 million mark. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored declining stocks by 1,010 to 675.

title: Eurobonds Steady
description: Dollar bonds closed unchanged today as professional short-covering helped prices rally from small initial declines, dealers said.

title: JERSEY LOTTERY OFFICIAL SUSPENDED
description: Governor Kean said today that he had suspended Reese Palley, a businessman and art dealer, as a member of the New Jersey Lottery Commission. Mr. Palley was indicted April 29 on charges that he tried to thwart inquiry into his activities by an ethics commission.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Gerulaitis Upset In First Round
description: Georges Goven of France upset topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of a $78,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: PROFILE OF COMPUTER BUYERS
description: Who owns what type of home computers? Public opinion polls differ on specifics but are beginning to provide a profile. Following are a few of the polls' findings:

title: MORRISON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for year to March 31.
ALLEGHENY LAND & MINERAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 11, 1983
description: International A buildup of Syrian and P.L.O. forces in Lebanon was reported by the State Department, which expressed concern about the ''persistent threat of renewed hostilities.'' American intelligence officials say that 10,000 Syrian troops have entered Lebanon in the last two months and that Syrian troop strength there now is just under 50,000. (Page A1, Column 6.) George P. Shultz appealed to Moscow to drop its opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement and to use its influence to bring about the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. The Secretary of State spoke to reporters in Paris. (A8:1.)

title: BOXING SAFETY BILL INTRODUCED IN STATE
description: All boxers fighting in New York State would be required to undergo brain scans at least once every three years and to wear thumbless gloves during a bout under legislation introduced today with bipartisan support.

title: TRILON FINANCIAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The latest quarter is Trilon's first full quarter of operations. The company said year-ago figures are those of London Life Insurance Co. on a pro forma basis.

title: Islanders Capture One for the 'Boss'
description: In their dressing room, the Islanders were awaiting tonight's opener of the Stanley Cup final against the Edmonton Oilers when Bryan Trottier spoke up, loud enough for all his teammates to hear.

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP (VANCOUVER) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,136,000 for the latest quarter and $197,000 for the year-ago quarter.

title: Traffic Delayed In Cable Failure
description: The failure of a telephone cable in Queens early yesterday threw traffic lights out of synchronization in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, causing minor traffic delays.

title: ISLANDERS, WITHOUT BOSSY, SHUT OUT OILERS IN OPENER
description: The Islanders showed up for the opener of the Stanley Cup finals tonight without their top goal-scorer, Mike Bossy, who was sidelined with tonsillitis. The Edmonton Oilers showed up with the highest-scoring team in National Hockey League history, but left with their offense grounded.

title: METS LOSE 4-0 LEAD AS ASTROS WIN IN 11
description: For the second night in a row the Mets blew a 4-0 lead in the Astrodome and lost. On Monday, the Houston Astros got five runs in the fifth inning and went on to a 6-4 victory. Tonight the Astros got four in the eighth, then needed a bases-loaded single by Denny Walling in the 11th inning to win, 5-4.

title: NOW to Meet in Florida, Ending 6-Year Boycott
description: The National Organization for Women will end a six-year boycott of Florida over the state's failure to ratify the proposed equal rights amendment when the organization holds its 1984 convention in Miami Beach.

title: NEW ERA IN TORONTO TRADING
description: Led by the Scots pipes and drums of Toronto's Metropolitan Police Band, the city's stockbrokers, in traditional top hat and tails, marched two blocks this week into a new technological era.

title: Apple Computer Japan
description: Apple Computer Inc. will set up its second overseas subsidiary, Apple Computer Japan, in Tokyo next month, a company spokesman said today. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., established its first overseas subsidiary in Australia last year. The Japanese subsidiary is planning $4.4 million in sales in its first year, according to the spokesman.

title: SPURS BEAT LAKERS, TIE SERIES
description: George Gervin scored 32 points for the San Antonio Spurs, who held off the Los Angeles Lakers in the closing minutes tonight to gain a 122-113 victory and tie the Western Conference championship series at 1-1.

title: Usery a Toyota-G.M. Spokesman
description: W.J. Usery Jr., a former Secretary of Labor, announced today that he would serve as a spokesman and labor relations representative for the joint venture of the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation to make small cars in California.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 25.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $728,750, or $1.03 a share. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $95,776, or 14 cents a share.

title: MUSIC: PARNASSUS AND BOULEZ
description: PIERRE BOULEZ'S ''Marteau sans Maitre'' (1955) -one of the major compositions written after World War II - was given a refined and all-too-rare performance by Parnassus in Merkin Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CONCERT: A BELLAK PROGRAM
description: RICHARD BELLAK brought his own music to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. There were piano pieces, chamber music and songs, and in all of them we heard a lot about Mr. Bellak's tastes in other people's music but not very much about his own musical self.

title: News Analysis
description: The French and the Americans, in two days of talks among the West's economic policy makers, have emerged as ideological poles in the debate about how to bring about a global recovery.

title: YOUTH SEIZED IN NEWSBOY SLAYING
description: A friend of the Long Island newsboy slain last March while delivering Sunday newspapers in his neighborhood was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of the 14-year-old boy, the Nassau County police said last night.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INTERIOR DESIGN INDUSTRY STUDYING A MOVE TO QUEENS
description: One of the most ambitious real estate deals in recent history is taking shape in the city. Leaders of the interior design industry - the wholesalers of furniture, fabrics, wall coverings, lighting and carpeting - are talking about joining together and moving to a new location.

title: ALVARADO TO EASE PROMOTION POLICY
description: New York City's new Schools Chancellor said today that he had decided to reverse key aspects of his predecessor's promotion policy and would allow thousands of failing students to enroll in regular high school programs next September.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 11, 1983; International
description: The chief industrial democracies may now safely promote faster economic growth because of gains they have made in curbing inflation, according to the O.E.C.D. ministers meeting in Paris. It was the first time in a decade that the officials had given top priority to reducing unemployment. (Page A1.) In the two days of talks, France and the U.S. took opposite stands on achieving global recovery. (D4.) Two leading American officials, at a special dinner, ended up with guests who were well below their own rank. (D4.)

title: SYRIANS AND P.L.O. INCREASING FORCES BASED IN LEBANON
description: The State Department, expressing concern about the ''persistent threat of renewed hostilities'' in Lebanon, said today that Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization had been building up their forces there.

title: Budget Deficits, Political Defaults
description: Whatever happened to the balanced budget amendment? It's obviously gone, to the burial ground for bad ideas. But whatever happened to the idea of reducing the budget deficit? Judging by the activity, and inactivity, of the President and Congress, this could be a goner too. It's a perilous prospect.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Advanced Systems Inc., Arlington Heights, Ill., has promoted John A. Kirkham to senior vice president.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading 'Tongue-Tied'

title: COSTAIN LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: People
description: * Eugene O'Sullivan, a senior vice president of Young & Rubicam/New York, promoted to director of client services.

title: G.& W. Sells 2 More Stakes
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that it had sold its stake in two companies as part of its continuing strategy of reducing its stock portfolio to lower its debt.

title: PHILIP MORRIS CREDIT reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There were no comparable year- ago results because Philip Morris Credit Corporation was incorporated in February 1982. The company is a subsidiary of Philip Morris Inc. and engages primarily in financing activities for stomers of that company and its subsidiaries.

title: TRANSITRON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Includes a gain of $776,000 from the sale of property. c-Includes a tax credit of $690,000.

title: Article 159006 -- No Title
description: Willem de Kooning's ''Two Women,'' a voluptuous oil-and-charcoal on canvas painted in the mid-1950's, sold last night for $1.2 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by a living artist, an art work by a living American artist or an Abstract Expressionist work. The painting was one of 10 art works that also established new highs for individual artists in a sale at Christie's that totaled $4.4 million, the highest ever for a contemporary art sale.

title: COACHES IN N.B.A. ON SHAKY GROUND
description: An impatience with losing has made the last several weeks a particularly insecure time for National Basketball Association coaches.

title: ISRAELIS CALL PACT A VIRTUAL TREATY
description: Israeli officials are describing the tentative security agreement with Lebanon as tantamount to a peace treaty. In conversations with reporters since the accord was approved in principle by the Cabinet last Friday, officials who have seen the text have portrayed it as a wide-ranging document constituting the second major agreement between Israel and an Arab country.

title: A Black Sprint in 1984?
