description: All the talk and speculation so far about a black candidate in 1984 has focused on two questions - whether Jesse Jackson, the controversial minister and activist from Chicago, should make the run and whether any black candidate would achieve desirable leverage over the eventual Democratic nominee.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: EIGHT TO NINE HOURS OF SLEEP RECEIVES A NOD OF APPROVAL
description: SLEEP. It's something that everybody needs, and according to the experts, seven to eight hours a day is the normal amount. People who require less can often be heard boasting about it - ''I only need four hours of sleep.'' Such a statement is fashionable these days, ranking right up there with ''Perrier, please'' and ''I never watch television.''

title: California Utility Offers $150 Million in Bonds
description: A $150 million issue of Southern California Metropolitan Water Works revenue bonds was offered by Salamon Brothers yesterday. The bonds due in 1985 were priced to yield 5.25 percent, while the longer-term bonds due in 2013 were priced at 100 to yield 8.75 percent and the 8 percent bonds due in 2023 were priced at a discount to par to yield 8.70 percent.

title: AMBASSADOR KIRKPATRICK'S 'SLANDER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Contran's Owner Sued
description: The Government today charged Harold Simmons, a Dallas investor who owns the Contran Corporation, and his associates with illegally using more than $25 million in pension plan assets to finance corporate takeovers.

title: I.R.A. Jury Out
description: A Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn failed to reach a verdict last night after a second day of deliberations in the nine-week trial of four men charged with plotting to smuggle weapons to the provisional Irish Republican Army. The jury will resume its deliberations today.

title: ANTITRUST CHIEF OFFERS GUIDELINES ON RESEARCH
description: William F. Baxter, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, offered business executives specific benchmarks today that should make it easier for them to judge when companies can do joint research without violating the law.

title: SECRET PENTAGON INTELLIGENCE UNIT IS DISCLOSED
description: The Defense Department has set up a special unit for intelligence gathering and covert operations to supplement the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency, according to several officials and others familiar with the new unit and its activities.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Complaint on Leaks

title: Savings Bond Sales Up 37%
description: Sales of United States Savings Bonds totaled $350 million in April, the highest monthly figure in two years and a 37 percent increase over the same month a year earlier, the Government reported today.

title: Economic Scene; Local Fiscal Difficulties
description: THE past few years have been difficult for state and local governments as the recession cut into tax revenues, Federal revenue assistance declined, and the public continued to clamor for more services and lower taxes.

title: Sun Banks Calls Off Its Bid for Flagship
description: Sun Banks Inc. of Orlando called off merger talks with Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami today, just a day after announcing a $331 million bid for Flagship.

title: CONVERTIBLE SCALES
description: AMERICA'S lag in adapting itself to the metric system of weights and measures, which is used in most of rest of the world, has created a market here for kitchen scales that convert weights. The newest of them offer digital readouts that flip from ounces to grams at the push of a button.

title: Chevron Bond Yields Raised
description: A two-part $57.8 million pollution control revenue bond financing on behalf of Chevron U.S.A. Inc. was tentatively priced with a yield of 7.25 percent on bonds with a final maturity in 2001.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MIW INVESTORS OF WASHINGT0N (DC) reports earnings for year to March 31.
CANADIAN GENERAL INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
VIATECH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: John J. Ghezzi Dies in Albany; Ex-New York State Secretary
description: John J. Ghezzi, who served as the Secretary of State under Gov. Malcolm Wilson of New York in 1974, died Monday at his home in Albany. He was 72 years old.

title: Panel Votes Deadline On Arms to Turks
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today narrowly voted to cut off aid to Turkey in 1987 if Turkish troops still occupy Cyprus.

title: William T. H. Jackson, Professor at Columbia
description: Dr. William T.H. Jackson, professor of German, English literature and history at Columbia University for 30 years and a trustee of the Columbia University Press since 1980, died of a heart attack Saturday in Crowborough, England. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Riverside Defeats Soviet by 114-97
description: The Riverside Church Hawks, National Amateur Athletic Union champions for the last four years, defeated the Soviet Union junior national team, 114-97, in basketball last night at St. John's Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: AEG Sees Small Loss
description: AEG-Telefunken A.G. expects a small operating loss in 1983 after losses equivalent to $382 million last year and $176 million in 1981, a company spokesman said today.

title: OAKBROOK CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
description: b-Net income.

title: TENANTS ASK EXCEPTIONS TO KOCH'S EVICTION PLAN
description: Tenants of rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments said at a public hearing yesterday that there should be exceptions to Mayor Koch's proposal to evict rent-regulated tenants who do not pay city income taxes at resident rates.

title: Minoso's Big Day
description: On Sunday at Comiskey Park in Chicago, Minnie joined Nellie and Luke in the pantheon of the White Sox. Saturnino Orestes Arrieta Armas Minoso, who was born 60 years ago in Havana, became the third White Sox player to have his playing number (9) retired.

title: Fairleigh Beats St. Francis, 2-1
description: Leon Matthews hit a one-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning to score Mike Pettigrew and give Fairleigh Dickinson a 2-1 victory today over St. Francis College in the semifinals of the Metropolitan Conference baseball playoffs.

title: SANCHEZ SHOWS LINGERIE FOR ALL SEASONS
description: ADECADE ago Fernando Sanchez showed his first collection of lingerie and at-home clothes during the French ready-to-wear presentations in Paris. A mixture of traditional vamp styles and some modern concepts, it was a smash hit. Soon afterward Mr. Sanchez moved to New York and began producing the clothes here. They helped change the way everyone thought about underwear. It was indeed possible to introduce fresh ideas of dressing into what was coyly referred to as ''intimate apparel.'' One of them was the introduction of strong colors such as red and yellow into what was usually a pale palette of pinks and blues, like baby clothes.

title: S.B. Thomas Moves Its Muffins to Y.& R.
description: Young & Rubicam is getting the Thomas's English Muffins assignment, Nina Henderson, the vice president of product management at S.B. Thomas, confirmed yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: For all the confusing intricacies of the rival budget proposals now before the Senate, much of the maneuvering of the White House and Senate Republican leaders is geared ultimately toward the 1984 election.

title: RON'S BROKEN RECORD
description: President Reagan has been talking recently as if he were back on the old General Electric radio shows peddling washing machines.

title: SUSPENSION STARTS
description: Manager Billy Martin of the Yankees yesterday lost his appeal of a three-game suspension, which took effect last night as the Yankees lost to the Texas Rangers, 4-2, at the Stadium.

title: SLOWER INFLATION LEADS O.E.C.D. TO URGE GROWTH
description: French-American differences pose a barrier to taking unified economic action. News analysis, page D4.

title: Brett Goes 0 for 4, Ending His Streak
description: Julio Franco made three hits, including a three-run double, to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 4-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight. George Brett went 0 for 4, and his 19-game hitting streak ended. Brett had hit in 25 consecutive games since last season.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. The year-ago results reflect an accounting change relating to foreign currency translation.

title: People Express
description: The British Board of Trade has sent a note of dissatisfaction to the United States State Department on the filing by People Express to charge $149 one-way on its proposed service from Newark to London. Ed Stukane, a spokesman for People, which won the right to serve the route from the Civil Aeronautics Board last month, said that the note also said that there would be further review of the filing. While the note could cause problems, he said, the carrier was still optimistic that the fare could be approved.

title: BALLET: A.B.T. PREMIERE
description: ONE has to be grateful for small favors, so the saying goes, and presumably John McFall's ballet, ''Interludes,'' is one of those minor but decent premieres for which American Ballet Theater should be grateful enough.

title: O.& M. Divulges Its 11 Commandments
description: Insiders at Ogilvy & Mather International call it the ''true church,'' William E. Phillips, chief executive, confided at the beginning of the company's annual meeting yesterday.

title: UNITED CANADIAN SHARES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago loss is restated to reflect the translation of the results of certain United States operations into Canadian funds.

title: ATLANTIS RESOURCES INTERATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was formed in July 1982.

title: Schlichter, Rozelle Meet
description: The National Football League's investigation of Art Schlichter continued yesterday when Schlichter, the Baltimore Colt quarterback who is serving as a material witness against four Baltimore-area men charged with gambling activities, met for several hours with Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner. A league spokesman said that the interview was ''just another phase'' of the league's inquiry. The trial of the four men is scheduled to begin June 6 in Columbus, Ohio.

title: O.E.C.D. Cites 0.4% Price Rise
description: Consumer prices in industrialized democracies rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March, twice the February rise, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: REVIVAL ON 42D STREET: NEW AMSTERDAM ROOF
description: Amid a maze of scaffolding, Peter Brook, the celebrated director, other theater luminaries, and state and city officials donned hard hats and sipped champagne yesterday evening on the dusty stage of the New Amsterdam Theater's rooftop theater on 42d Street west of Broadway. The occasion was the announcement of plans for the rebirth of the historic site -another theater reclaimed for Broadway - and the unusual production that will inaugurate it.

title: Article 158478 -- No Title
description: In what may be the largest out-of-court settlement of its kind, MGM Grand Hotels and 41 other defendants have agreed to pay $140 million to settle claims arising out of a 1980 Las Vegas hotel fire that killed 84 people.

title: Careers; New Financial Advisers For Labor's Capitalists
description: SOMETIMES a single question from the floor at a meeting can spotlight a career trend. D. Quinn Mills, professor at the Harvard Business School and a member of the National Commission on Employment Policy, in a recent Harvard Business Review article, described just such an occurrence at the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, whose workers received voting stock in exchange for concessions on wages and rules.

title: Reservists Felled by Fumes
description: Gasses from a malfunctioning coal-fired furnace in an Army barracks sent 48 members of an Illinois reserve unit to hospitals early today, officials said. The reservists, members of the 724th Transportation Company of Peoria, Ill., were overcome apparently either by carbon monoxide or coal gas released by the furnace, said Stan Fitzner, public affairs officer at the base.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results reflect a change in accounting for investment tax credits.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Australian Editor Tells Of Destroying Spy Data
description: A newspaper editor told Australia's High Court today that he had destroyed tens of thousands of secret intelligence papers used as the basis for a report on Australia's spying activities that has embarrassed the Government.

title: Women's Bank Loses Its Chief
description: Judy Hendren Mello, president and chief executive officer of The First Women's Bank, in New York, has resigned, effective last Friday, the bank announced late yesterday.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HENREDON FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
THEATER: 'HAJJ,' A JOURNEY BY MONOLOGUE
description: IN the dim light, the stage at the Public Theater looks as if it had been set with a miniature village of spires, mosques and minarets. Then the lights brighten, ''Hajj'' begins and we realize that we are looking at a tabletop environment, a large dressing room table completely filled with cosmetics. Those ''towers'' are bottles of sprays, creams and lotions. However, in a symbolic way, they represent the architecture of a world, dominated by the play's single character, acted by Ruth Maleczech.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARDY PERENNIAL

title: MUSIC: GLASS'S ENSEMBLE PERFORMS 2 NEW WORKS
description: NOT since 170 years ago, when Rossini was churning out operas on commission, has a composer seemed so busy as Philip Glass. In the midst of his own opera composing, dance and concert-music writing, ensemble touring, rock producing and record making, Mr. Glass found time last night to stop off at Carnegie Hall and offer a sold-out house the first concert performances of all or parts of two recent works.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STRESS FACTOR AND ALCOHOL
description: N eil Allen asked for help the other day and got it. He was referred by his employer, the New York Mets, to an alcoholism treatment center in Manhattan.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THIRD CANADIAN GENERAL INVESTMENT TRUST LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FINDING HOME COMPUTER USES
description: Gary Berger, a concrete salesman from Englewood Cliffs, N.J., purchased a home computer that he uses to keep track of his investments and to learn about computers. While he is happy with his purchase, he said, ''I am somewhat disappointed that there are not more home uses for it.''

title: FEDERAL GRANTS DOWN IN '82, FIRST DROP IN 27 YEARS
description: Federal aid to state and local governments declined in the last fiscal year for the first time in at least 27 years, according to a new Federal study.

title: NBC SCHEDULES NINE NEW PROGRAMS FOR FALL
description: NBC, which has ranked third in the ratings for the last eight years, will offer nine new prime-time shows next fall while retaining such critically praised but low-rated holdovers as ''Cheers,'' ''St. Elsewhere'' and ''Remington Steele.''

title: U.S.F.L. Ratings At Lowest Point
description: The 10th Sunday of the United States Football League's television exposure on ABC three days ago drew the lowest overnight ratings from A.C. Nielsen since the season began in early March.

title: COURT RESTORES ABSCAM CONVICTION OF EX-CONGRESSMAN FROM FLORIDA
description: A Federal appeals court today reinstated the bribery conviction of former Representative Richard Kelly of Florida, ruling that the undercover Abscam operation in which he had been charged did not involve ''intolerable'' tactics.

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Renewed Drive for Cup
description: Despite all apparent odds, and with a final decision expected in 10 days, American soccer officials stepped up their efforts yesterday to gain the 1986 World Cup matches for the United States. In Washington, President Reagan accepted the honorary chairmanship of the committee pressing the nation's case before the Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's international governing body, which is to meet in Stockholm next week to make the site selection.

title: RELTRON CORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 7, 1983.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
5 West Bank Youths Sentenced in Stoning
description: An Israeli military court gave five West Bank Arab youths prison terms of 11 to 13 years today for throwing stones at an Israeli woman in January, resulting in her death two weeks later, an army spokesman said.

title: INTER-CITY GAS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Salvador Troops Take Town Lost on Sunday
description: Government troops retook this embattled town today, ending a guerrilla incursion that killed as many as 220 people, the army and witnesses said.

title: ROBERT F. MERRICK
description: Robert F. Merrick, former chairman of J. Walter Thompson Publicidade Limitada, Brazil, a subsidiary of the JWT Group, the international advertising concern, died last Wednesday at his home in Islamorada, Fla.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would call upon the Soviet Union to take another look and to get on the side of peace in Lebanon.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A8:1.)

title: ORIOLE HOMES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CAJUN COOKING: A TASTE OF THE BAYOU
description: DINNER on the bayou, lunch in a lumberyard. Narrow, winding country roads interlaced with spiderwebs of waterways, superhighways and oil rigs. The land where the Cajuns dwell, in Louisiana west and southwest of New Orleans, is a study in extremes.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS MOTORCYCLE TARIFF, STEEL QUOTAS
description: President Reagan today defended his decision to order a tenfold increase in tariffs for heavyweight motorcycles, insisting that it was not a breach of his free-trade policy but only a temporary protection to help American manufacturers to readjust to Japanese competitors.

title: Accounts
description: * Hansel'n Gretel, Glendale, Queens, to Levy, Flaxman & Associates for its hams and deli products.

title: WINE TALK
description: SAN FRANCISCO WHAT do Ridge, Fetzer, Sebastiani and Beaulieu Vineyards, Robert Mondavi Winery and Baron Philippe de Rothschild have in common? They are all selling wine for under $5 a bottle around here. What's more, they are not alone. Wine prices in Calfornia are tumbling faster than leaves in the fall.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After realized investment losses of $14.5 million. c-After realized investment gains of $11.6 million. The latest quarter income from operations includes gain on the sale of subsidiaries owning the leases of the Churchill and Montcalm Hotels of $45,851,000, or $4.08 a share.

title: NEWLY DISCOVERED UNUSUAL COMET VISIBLE IN NORTH AMERICAN SKIES
description: A bright, fuzzy blob of light moved across the skies of North America last night as a newly discovered comet sped toward the closest encounter with Earth by any such extraterrestrial object in more than two centuries.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split in January 1983.

title: STAGE: THE KARAMAZOVS, JUGGLING AND JOKES MIX
description: THE Flying Karamazov Brothers, while neither Russian nor brothers, are certainly the best jugglers anyone would ever want to see. In their boisterous, good-natured vaudeville act at the newly rejuvenated Ritz Theater, they juggle everything from flaming torches to eggs to razor-sharp sickles. Such feats are not idle monkey business. As one of the fellows explains, ''There's only one end of a sickle one can catch - more than once.''

title: POLISH ANTI-SEMITISM: A CRUCIAL DISTINCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO DEMOCRATS FAIL TO HEAL RIFT
description: Negotiating teams representing Mayor Harold Washington and a group of rebellious aldermen failed to reach a compromise today to end a bitter reorganization fight that has turned recent City Council meetings into finger-waving shouting matches and near fistfights.

title: BISHOPS' ATOMIC ARMS LETTER DIVIDES CATHOLICS AT A FORUM
description: A panel of prominent Catholics, including members of Congress and former Government officialsl expressed sharply different views tonight on the meaning of the pastoral letter on nuclear war recently ratified by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops.

title: SAI GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an accounting adjustment of $241,000.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a net charge of $165,000 from oil and gas operations. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Mrs. Merrick Withdraws
description: T he estranged fourth wife of David Merrick, the Broadway producer, withdrew her bid yesterday to become conservator of his interests. The producer, who is 73 years old, suffered a stroke last February. Mr. Merrick wanted his old friend, Milton Mitofsky, 76, to be his conservator.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The latest quarter figures include the operations of Lane Bryant Inc., acquired in May 1982.

title: REBELS UNDER FIERCE ATTACK IN AFGHANISTAN, ENVOYS SAY
description: Soviet and Afghan Government forces have mounted a major offensive to destroy rebel strongholds just north of Kabul, the Afghan capital, Western diplomats here said today.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Units Seek Press Cards
description: The Voice of America and Radio Free Europe asked a Senate panel today to approve press credentials for their reporters, who they say have trouble gathering information at Congressional hearings.

title: A PARTY THAT WENT AWRY
description: At the Pre Catalan restaurant here tonight, the guest list was not all it might have been. In fact, the vagaries of diplomacy left the American hosts - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Bill Brock, the special trade representative - with dinner companions well below their own rank.

title: Chernenko Back at Work After Illness, Aide Says
description: A spokesman at the office of Konstantin U. Chernenko said today that the 71-year-old party secretary had been released from a hospital and had resumed work for an hour or two a day.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a tax credit of $223,000, or 3 cents a share and the net reflects acquisition of a unit of Damon Corporation in January 1983. c-Net loss

title: DECOM SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
CONWEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago revenues are restated.

title: Stanton to Be Named To Panel on the Arts
description: Frank Stanton, the president of CBS Inc. from 1946 to 1971, will be appointed to the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, the White House announced today.

title: Nuclear Power Plants Alerted on Sabotage
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned utilities with nuclear power plants to look out for possible attempts by disgruntled employees to sabotage key safety equipment.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON RESTORATION OF BRYANT PARK
description: Bryant Park is about to be restored to its former elegance as the backyard of the New York Public Library, library officials said yesterday.

title: WALESA FINDS UNLIKELY ALLIES IN APPEAL
description: The leaders of the old Government-sponsored unions, dissolved in August along with the Solidarity movement, have joined with Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, in a call for a return to open, competitive unions.

title: U.N. Council Puts Off Session on Nicaragua
description: The Security Council put off its session on Nicaragua today until foreign ministers from four Latin American nations, trying to act as mediators, hold talks in Panama on Wednesday.

title: Drama in Brief
description: T here was a certain familiarity in the casts - Christopher Reeve, Fritz Weaver, Marshall Mason, Swoosie Kurtz and others - but not in the program: 11 world premieres of five-minute dramas.

title: N.R.C. AGREES TO TAKE PART IN CUOMO'S SHOREHAM STUDY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission agreed today to participate in a fact-finding panel Governor Cuomo is establishing to advise him on whether he should support the opening of the nuclear power plant at Shoreham on Long Island.

title: James River Signs Pulp Sale Deal
description: The James River Corporation said it had signed an agreement to buy pulp and paper-making operations from the Diamond International Corporation for about $125 million.

title: Mankiewicz Resigns As President of NPR
description: Frank Mankiewicz, the president of National Public Radio, formally announced his resignation today from the financially troubled network.

title: Matuszak Retires
description: John Matuszak, the Los Angeles Raiders' veteran defensive lineman, announced his retirement, saying that back surgery last year had taken too much out of him. ''I felt stronger than ever, but to play Raider football is a step above everything else physically, and it's very important to me to only give the Raiders my best,'' he said.

title: MGIC Is Ordered To Give Notice
description: Thomas P. Fox, the Wisconsin insurance commissioner, has ordered six insurance subsidiaries of the MGIC Investment Corporation of Milwaukee to give 30-day notices before making any new financial arrangements with its parent company, the Baldwin-United Corporation of Cincinnati.

title: RANCHERS PACKING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Hagler Bout Is Put Off
description: Friday night's middleweight title fight between the champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Wilford Scypion has been postponed two weeks because of an inflamed tendon in Hagler's left knee, promoter Bob Arum said late Tuesday night.

title: SHULTZ ASKS SOVIET TO NUDGE SYRIANS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz appealed to the Soviet Union today to drop its opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement and use its influence to bring about the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CORRECTION
description: The television listings yesterday gave an incorrect date for the conclud- ing program of ''Watership Down,'' a two-part animated special on CBS. It will be shown at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WELL, boys and girls, here it is the merry month of May. It's time to be skipping ropes, riding bikes, flying kites, chasing balls and other things gerundive. But before we can do all those things, we must put on our thinking caps and come up with some good excuses for why we did not do our homework.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: STUDY SAYS U.S. LOST $100 MILLION ON COAL SALE
description: The Interior Department's sale of coal leases in the Powder River Basin of Montana and Wyoming last year, the largest Federal coal sale in history, brought the Government $100 million less than fair market value, according to a General Accounting Office report released today.

title: TV: 'LA BELLE EPOQUE'
description: ''LA BELLE EPOQUE'' is a lush documentary about a lush time, 1890 to 1914, ''when the world belonged to fashionable society,'' according to Douglas Fairbanks Jr., the documentary's civilized narrator, and chaos was just around the corner. It will be seen on ARTS, the cable network, at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Metromedia Split
description: Metromedia Inc. declared a 10-for-1 stock split and said that shareholders at its annual meeting in Secaucus, N.J., had approved an increase in authorized common shares to 35 million from 10 million. According to proxy material, the company said the additional shares would be available for financing acquisitions or for distribution of shares in stock dividends or stock splits. Metromedia's stock closed yesterday at $550, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Market Place; Proxy Fights In Spotlight
description: WITH mergers and acquisitions becoming smaller and friendlier lately, the fireworks on Wall Street are now coming from proxy fights. Moreover, more proxy fights are on the way.

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Comparable figures are not availble because the results of Valley Federal's operations as a mutual association were not consolidated with subsidiary operations for Federal Home Loan Bank Board reporting purposes.

title: AMDISCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the quarter and $21,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $45,000 for the quarter and $72,000 for the 6 months.

title: Burmah Cancels Ships
description: The Burmah Oil Company said today that it had agreed to pay $32 million to Universe Tank Ships Inc. of New York for canceling the charters of two very large crude carriers. Burmah had six years left on its contract to charter the vessels.

title: Texas Bond Sale Reflects Rate Drop
description: The recent drop in tax-exempt yields was reflected yesterday in an $86 million offering of Aaa-rated general-obligation bonds of Texas, with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 8.10 percent for bonds due in 2001.

title: DOMAN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $997,000. c-Net loss.

title: JEANTOT'S VICTORY IS ULTIMATE IN SAILING
description: At the start of the BOC Challenge, the first organized singlehanded race round the world, last August, Robin Knox-Johnston, the race chairman, observed that a global voyage was ''the ultimate in sailing and the greatest challenge a person can find to the ability to survive.''

title: WHERE FISHERMEN REVIVE AND EAT (BEEF)
description: ALONG about sundown, beginning in the spring, fishermen who have just ended a day of trout fishing on the Beaverkill River head for a restorative meal at the Antrim Lodge Hotel in the small town of Roscoe, N.Y. The cozy lodge, snuggled into a grove of tall conifers, resembles the big, old, rambling homes with a flower-bedecked front porch that one might see in any small town in America.

title: New Tests for Dailey
description: Quintin Dailey, the basketball player who assaulted a nursing student at the University of San Francisco more than a year ago, has been suffering from severe depression and has entered a Baltimore hospital for a 10-day psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer, Bob Woolf, has disclosed. Woolf said Dailey's depression is a result of the publicity given the assault, which occurred in December 1981, before he joined the Chicago Bulls.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum RateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: 1934. By Alberto Moravia. Translated from the Italian by William Weaver. 297 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.50.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''AN ideal balance between structure and emotion -that's what I'm looking for in music,'' said Jon Hassell, the trumpet-playing composer and theorist of future-primitive music. ''A piece by Phillip Glass might be fulfilling structurally, but a bit lacking emotionally. A rock recording, say by Talking Heads, may have a strong emotional feeling, but structurally it may be just a conventional song form. But a really strong performance by Miles Davis has this exact balance of emotion and structure that I'm talking about.''

title: CONTINENTAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $492,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Music in Bryant Park
description: J ohnny Colon grew up singing, from East Harlem barrio festivals to the High School of Commerce to radio and, from there, to recording stardom and his own big band.

title: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions

title: FIGHT GROWS OVER COTTON DUST RULES
description: The long, emotional struggle over protection of textile workers from byssinosis, or brown lung disease, entered a new round today when a House committee approved a report criticizing the Reagan Administration for attempting to change the regulations that protect those workers from exposure to cotton dust.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Announced that B rian Downing, left fielder, suffered frac- t ured wrist and will be sidelined at least t wo weeks; reactivated Bill Travers, p itcher. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Called up Mark T hurmond, relief pitcher, from Las Vegas f arm club.

title: CHILTON CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
House Minority Leader Ill
description: The House minority leader, Robert H. Michel, was admitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital with abdominal pains today. Mr. Michel, a 60-year-old Republican from Peoria, Ill., was undergoing tests and was listed in satisfactory condition.

title: RECITAL: VINOGRADE IN PIANO PROGRAM
description: PETER VINOGRADE'S piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon moved easily between two widely separated styles - from Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations in the first half to three 20thcentury American pieces after intermission.

title: Hilton Head Voters Approve Incorporation for Resort Isle
description: Voters on this resort island approved incorporation today after a campaign in which opponents of the move said it would raise taxes and wrest undeveloped land from blacks through zoning.

title: QUEBEC TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
L LAURIA & SON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WALKER TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DISTANT CHAMPAGNE
description: To the Editor:

title: RIVAL OF PRETORIA'S RULING PARTY WINS ELECTION TEST
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's main right-wing challenger was returned to the all-white Parliament early today by a commanding margin over the governing National Party in a crucial by-election in the northern Transvaal.

title: Joseph A. Tortelli, 52, Headed Agency for Affirmative Action
description: Joseph A. Tortelli, director of the Westchester County Office of Affirmative Action, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 52 years old.

title: Polaroid Seeks Computer Role
description: Polaroid is moving to combine its traditional instant photography business with the high-technology field of communications and computers, William J. McCune Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said today.

title: 2 Cars Derail On No. 5 Express
description: Two cars of a 10-car, southbound No. 5 express train on the IRT Lexington Line that was carrying 1,500 people derailed at 5:30 P.M. yesterday just north of the Brooklyn Bridge station in Manhattan, the Transit Authority police said.

title: Gulf Oil to Reduce Its '83 Spending
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation will cut 1983 capital and exploration spending by $1.5 billion from its earlier estimate calculated before oil prices began to fall, James Lee, chairman, said at the annual meeting.

title: THEODORE WARD, PLAYWRIGHT WHO FOCUSED ON BLACKS, DIES
description: Theodore Ward, an outstanding playwright of the 1940's whose principal work was done in the Federal Theater, died Sunday in Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago. He was 80 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Buckingham Palace Honors Solzhenitsyn
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today received the 1983 Templeton Prize at Buckingham Palace for contributions to religion.

title: OUT ON THE HUSTINGS AND PREACHING TO THE FAITHFUL
description: Looking ruddy and relaxed, President Reagan was back at the White House today after a restorative weekend at his California ranch and what his aides assessed as a productive trip touching base with friendly groups in Texas, Arizona and Ohio.

title: China Foreign Funds
description: China used $12.6 billion in foreign investment by the end of 1982, the New China News Agency today quoted Wei Yuming, Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, as saying.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR LIGHTING DARK CORNERS
description: EVERY house or apartment has a few dark corners or nooks that would be more attractive with extra lighting. Several light fixtures are specifically designed for such spots when it is not practical to build in additional lighting fixtures.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO SHIFT APPROACH ON ARMS CONTROL
description: President Reagan sent letters to nine members of Congress today promising a new approach to arms control talks on strategic weapons. A key House panel then voted to release funds for the development of the MX missile, which had been frozen by Congress last year.

title: A STICKLEY GRANDSON KEEPS HIS FAMILY HERITAGE ALIVE
description: PETER WILES SR. recalls that his grandfather Gustav Stickley, the master craftsman, taught him that ''if you are doing your absolute best, then for some reason you must be right.''

title: GOTAAS-LARSEN SHIPPING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CONCERT: CAMERIT
description: AT Merkin Hall on Tuesday night, Musica Camerit proved to be an earnest, often impassioned group of chamber players, but that approach suited only some of the repertory.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE CITY
description: A television newscaster disarmed and shot one of three robbers who tried to hold up an East Side restaurant early yesterday, the police said.

title: M.I.S.L. Ignores Team America
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League yesterday turned down a request that it lend players to Team America, the North American Soccer League franchise that is intended to form the nucleus of this country's national team.

title: Stake in Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines pilots probably will get less than a reported 21 percent stake in the airline in exchange for wage and work rule concessions, an offical of the Airline Pilots Association said. August Gorse, chairman of the Master Executive Council of Eastern's Pilots Association, said the figure, which stemmed from a taped message to union members from Richard Heckenberger, chairman of an Eastern Pilot's Council in New York, was ''purely speculative.''

title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: As a father who is grieving the recent death of his only daughter, I wish to compliment Susan Jacoby on her sensitive essay on grief. I cannot overemphasize the importance of the condolence letter.

title: Parking Fines to Go Up Outside Midtown Area
description: The New York City Transportation Department plans to raise the fines for certain parking violations outside midtown Manhattan, effective July 1.

title: Great Western To Buy Aristar
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, a thrift institution holding company, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Aristar Inc. subsidiary of the Canwest Capital Corporation of Canada for about $170 million in cash.

title: MUSICA AETERNA: HORSZOWSKI PIANO
description: THE highlight of Musica Aeterna's Sunday afternoon concert in the Metropolitan Museum was Mieczyslaw Horszowski's performance of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 27 in B-flat major (K. 595). The 90-yearold Mr. Horszowski, who may well be the last surviving pupil of the legendary Theodor Leschetizky, has been performing since 1901.

title: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $10.8 million for the quarter and year on the sale of an investment and a charge of $6 million for the quarter and year for the early retirement plan at Imperial Tobacco. c-After a loss of $4.7 million on the sale of an investment. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in November 1982. The company is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $344,000 for the quarter and $1,232,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after tax benefits of $90,000 for the quarter and $1,434,000 for the 9 months, a pre-tax credit of $2,000,000 for the quarter as a reserve for home furnishings restructuring, and a charge of $13,000 for the 9 months from the reserve.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GREAT OUTDOOR AMERICAN ADVENTURE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: POP SINGER: EEK-A-MOUSE
description: A-MOUSE may be the most mannered singer yet to emerge from Jamaica. He started out as a disk jockey, but his ''toasting'' (spoken passages between and atop records) featured doubletime passages of nonsense syllables, like scat singing.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Baseball Title To Fairleigh
description: John Suarez pitched seven and two-thirds innings of scoreless relief yesterday to help Fairleigh Dickinson defeat C.W. Post, 9-4, at Shea Stadium and win the Met Conference baseball title.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $394,000 for the quarter and $791,000 for the 9 months.

title: STARRETT, L S, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Harlem Savings
description: The Harlem Savings Bank will change its name next Monday to the Apple Bank as part of an effort to increase its share of New York's banking market, the company announced at a press conference.

title: E.P.A. STUDY CITES POSSIBLE PERJURY
description: An investigation within the Environmental Protection Agency has concluded that agency officials may have committed perjury or obstruction of justice in connection with denials that a political ''hit list'' of E.P.A. employees was kept for use in making personnel decisions.

title: ACCOUNTING FIRM REVENUES
description: Arthur Andersen & Company, the nation's biggest accounting firm, reported 1982 revenues of $809 million from United States operations, an industry newsletter said in its May issue.

title: Audit Identifies Fund at L.S.U.
description: Chancellor James Wharton has recommended that a special fund created by fans and used by Louisiana State University's athletic department be brought under the school's control.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
APPEAL BY KLOCKNER DENIED
description: The European Court of Justice has rejected appeals by Klockner-Werke A.G., a West German steel company, against a $2 million fine imposed on it by the European Commission for exceeding production quotas, court officials said today.

title: Uncle Sugar, Redux
description: To compel Fidel Castro to mend his ways, the United States in 1960 ordered a halt to the import of Cuban sugar. But Mr. Castro did not fall penitently to his knees. He played on that swat by Uncle Sugar to rally his people against dollar diplomacy, and to justify his new trade dependence on the Soviet Union. The embargo has continued; so has Mr. Castro's unyielding hostility to a neighbor that once was Cuba's major trading partner.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADERS DELAY SENATE BUDGET ACTION
description: The Senate Republican leadership, unsure of its own voting strength, delayed action today on a 1984 budget resolution supported by President Reagan as the White House said publicly that Mr. Reagan would prefer no Congressional budget to one with major tax increases.

title: BERKLEY, W R, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TELECOM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $159,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $14,372,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ART: A WINSTON CHURCHILL EXHIBITION
description: SIR WINSTON CHURCHILL made no great claims for his paintings, and he might even have been surprised to find them given a place of honor in an exhibition that begins today at the National Academy of Design. Room after room has been filled with his paintings, under the curatorship of his granddaughters Edwina and Celia Sandys. The general effect is undeniably happy, and to a degree that would certainly have delighted him. ''Painting,'' he once said, ''is an activity not violently harmful to man or beast,'' and that was about as far as he would go.

title: SHADOW OVER WHITE HOUSE SECURITY
description: A nervous Secret Service tried to discourage it, but there was no stopping construction of a private office building whose top floors command a clear view of the north side of the White House.

title: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: Visitors to Australia Made Good Use of Wailing Room
description: The most unusual bridge-club building in the world may well be the premises of the South Australian Bridge Association in Adelaide. The building was originally put up as a church for a minor sect, and it provided, in the interests of decorum during the services, a wailing room for infants and emotional adults.

title: SOVIET INTEREST IN IRAN
description: The banning of the pro-Soviet Tudeh (Communist) Party and expulsion of 18 Soviet diplomats from Teheran is a significant setback for the Soviet Union. It should not, however, be mistaken as a boon for the United States - for it does not signal an end to Soviet efforts to penetrate and manipulate the Iranian regime.

title: Shoe Duties Removed
description: Special duties imposed to hold down United States imports of shoes from India, Spain and Brazil were lifted Tuesday by the International Trade Commission. The decision in favor of India revoked duties of 15 percent imposed in 1979; the commission also voted in favor of imports of ''non rubber footwear'' from Brazil and Spain, where the duties, which range up to 14.3 percent for Brazil and 2.5 percent to 3.5 percent for Spain, go back to 1974.

title: Columbia Pictures' Role
description: The Coca-Cola Company expects that its newly acquired Columbia Pictures Industries unit will be able to increase net earnings by an annual rate of about 20 percent over the next five years, Coca-Cola's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, said today at a bankers' presentation here. Mr. Goizueta said Columbia Pictures contributed considerably to Coca-Cola's first-quarter net income of $122.1 million, following the box office success of the films ''Tootsie'' and ''Gandhi.''

title: Refugees and Refoulement
description: There's a hard question to be asked about the thousands of undocumented aliens from Afghanistan or Haiti or El Salvador seeking a haven in the United States: Are they legitimate refugees?

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: GARDEN WORKSHOP
description: You Gotta Have Park Weekend, Central Park Conservatory Garden, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, 212- 722-5497.

title: THE MUSEUM AS COUNTERPOINT TO EDUCATION'S 'BACK TO BASICS'
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Moore-Duran in Garden
description: The title bout betweeen Davey Moore, the World Boxing Association's junior-middleweight champion, and Roberto Duran has been rescheduled for June 16 at Madison Square Garden. It had originally been planned as part of the double card at the Sun City resort in Bophuthatswana. But that card was canceled when Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, the W.B.A.'s lightweight champion, who was to have met Kenny Bogner, suffered a broken collarbone.

title: HERS
description: SOME years ago, while reading the morning paper, I heard a dull thud and looked out the window of my second-floor apartment to see the broken body of a teen-ager who had apparently jumped from a higher floor. Then, a few moments later, came an equqlly terrible sight and sound: a balding, bathrobe-clad man, howling with the anguish of a trapped animal. ''Why?'' he asked the police officer over and over. ''Why couldn't I stop him?'' The man was the boy's father.

title: New Kronenbourg Ad: 'Better, Not Bitter'
description: Kronenbourg beer, with advertising by Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, was available only in New York in the beginning of 1981, in New York and Boston in the beginning of 1982, and now, after an explosion in distribution, is in 24 states.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ACCORDING to Christian Duvernois, its director, the two-month-old Facade Gallery is ''dedicated to exploring four themes: architecture, garden design, interiors and the theater.'' Designed by Walter Chatham, an architect, the modest gallery will present through June 13 a show of early-19th-century watercolors and drawings of furniture and interior views entitled ''Homage to Mario Praz.''

title: ELDERLY TENANTS' BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: NO-COST GESTURE OPEN TO MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 12, 1983
description: International

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid April 28.

title: GERMAN CRITICISM OF U.S. POLICY WANES
description: Criticism of American economic policy is waning in West Germany as the economic summit conference in Williamsburg, Va., approaches.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $1 million for the quarter and 9 months on the extinguishment of debt. c-After a charge of $3.6 million. d-Net income.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: U.S., SOVIET TRADE BASKETS AND SNACKS
description: An hour after his Riverside Church Hawks played the Soviet Union National Junior Team, Coach Ernest Lorch was lugging a box of McDonald's hamburgers back to the hotel where the touring Soviet squad was staying. As he entered the lobby, a few of the Soviet coaches and players were there to greet him, and to pounce on his box of goodies. ''What else could I do?'' Lorch said with a smile, ''They wanted a late-night snack.''

title: UNITED-GUARDIAN INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
GUILFORD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for year to April 3.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company began operations on March 29, 1982.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WESTERN ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $22,700,000 from a change in the method of accounting.

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted for 2 percent stock dividends paid in June and December.

title: ANYTHING FOR A STORY
description: The press says a great deal, as it should, about greed and irresponsibility in politicians. Will it be as tough when some in its own ranks display those same characteristics? That question is posed by the affair of the fake Hitler diaries.

title: Judicial Panel Head Named
description: Governor Cuomo has appointed former Judge Domenick Gabrielli of the Court of Appeals to serve as chairman of the Governor's new state Judicial Screening Committee. The panel, established by executive order in March, is to recommend candidates to fill vacancies on the state's Court of Claims. Mr. Cuomo announced the appointment of Mr. Gabrielli, who retired from the state's highest court on Dec. 31 after having reached the mandatory retirement age of 70, on Wednesday.

title: NOW IT'S OFFICIAL: ATHENS SMOG IS EUROPE'S WORST
description: Athenians have grown increasingly worried about a brown cloud of pollutants they call nefos that hovers over the capital for much of the year.

title: L.I. TEEN-AGER IS ARRAIGNED IN SLAYING OF NEWSPAPER BOY
description: A teen-ager who had been out on bail in a burglary case was arraigned today on charges of murdering a 14-yearold Rockville Centre newspaper boy who lived down the street from him.

title: YANKEES, GUIDRY BEATEN
description: The Yankees, a team whose manager is suspended and whose top catcher and shortstop are sidelined, sank into last place in the American League East last night.

title: Index; International
description: The cloud over Athens: Pollution A2 Israel warns of consequences if Syrians don't pull out A3 Syria's bolstering of forces in Lebanon called a ploy for talks A3 Red Cross criticizes Iran and Iraq over prisoners A4 Around the World A7 U.S. and China sign more accords on technical cooperation A11 French students try to storm the Cannes Film Festival A12 U.S. accuses Soviet of testing two new missiles B9 Government/Politics Chicago Mayor and foes clash again in Council A16 Republican leaders delay Senate budget action A24 E.P.A. investigation cites possibility of perjury on ''hit list'' A24 Study urges replacing city tax incentive plan with expanded one B1 Building chosen by city department is called white elephant B3 Greenhouse-type restaurant planned for Bryant Park B3 Report backs Rickover figures on Navy contractor profits B12 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Q.&A.: Abner J. Mikva B8 Kennedy Center Opera House getting a $2-million facelift B8 Office building poses a question of White House security B8 Health/Science Scientists may have discovered important subatomic particle A13 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of Ascension Day, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. The Home Section Home Embellishing 80's interiors: the elegant art of decoration C1

title: Cosmos Shut Out Sounders
description: Second-half goals by Roberto Cabanas, Vladislav Bogicevic and Giorgio Chinaglia gave the Cosmos a 3-0 victory over the Seattle Sounders tonight.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHIEF OF STAFF OF THE ARMY: JOHN A. WICKMAN JR.
description: In the 101st Airborne Division, one of the Army's elite combat units, troopers who can survive the physical rigors of a special field training course are awarded an ''air assault badge.''

title: TOP COMMERCE AIDE RESIGNS IN INQUIRY ON SATELLITE SALES
description: Guy W. Fiske, the Deputy Secretary of Commerce, has resigned in the middle of an investigation by the Justice Department and the House of Representatives into his activities in the proposed sale of the Government's weather satellites to private industry.

title: Posing Nude Costs Officer Her Job
description: A 25-year-old police officer who posed nude for a magazine while she was a civilian employee of the Police Department three years ago, was discharged yesterday by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire.

title: I.T.T.'s Meeting In London
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation today became the first major American company to hold its annual meeting outside North America. The event, staged in a hall of the new Barbican Center here, drew an estimated 1,000 shareholders.

title: LA LUZ MINES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including an investment gain of $413,309.

title: New Orleans Issue Set to Yield 8.25%
description: A $37 million revenue bond for the Port of New Orleans was tentatively priced yesterday to yield 8.25 percent in 2001, according to Salomon Brothers Inc., the lead underwriter.

title: STUDENT ENTREPRENEURS ARE MAJORING IN PROFITS
description: AFTER the semester ends at Tufts, two sophomores, Ronald Dickerman and Glendon Good, will stay around campus so they can carry on business as usual. They are the owners of D.N.G. Properties, a realestate company they founded last September that recently purchased a 12-unit apartment house two miles from the school. They will spend the summer managing their property and looking for acquisitions to be used for campus housing. Mr. Dickerman projects a $13,000 profit by the end of the year and a long future for the company.

title: Quick & Reilly Offering
description: Quick & Reilly Inc., the nation's second-largest discount brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of two million shares of common stock, half to be sold by the company and half by current shareholders. The New York-based firm said it would use part of its share of the proceeds to acquire companies conducting specialist activities.

title: SCIENTISTS DETECT NEW ATOMIC PART
description: An international team of 126 researchers at CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics near Geneva, appears to have detected the last of the three particles that theorists believe transmit the so-called weak force in subatomic reactions.

title: Progress on South Street
description: The South Street Seaport Museum's ''public profile has been quite low, indeed'' for a year, its president, Christopher J. Lowery, noted. And, at a Preservation League of New York benefit at the Yankee Clipper restaurant, it was easy to see why.

title: Dutch Debate Plans for Trip By Senior Official to Salvador
description: A planned May 27 visit to El Salvador by the Dutch Foreign Minister has created a political uproar centering on United States involvement in Central America.

title: S.I. TELEPORT GRANTED FEE EXEMPTION
description: The Teleport Communications Center, under an agreement reached with the city yesterday, will not have to pay a franchise fee provided it does not offer entertainment services to commercial establishments.

title: AN RX FOR COSTS
description: Americans have the world's best medical care, but persistent double-digit inflation in health care costs threatens to put that care out of the reach of many. Those costs are soaring because the health care financing system provides too little incentive for both consumers and providers to be cost-conscious and rewards those who believe that ''more medicine'' is ''better medicine.''

title: MICHIGAN NUN QUITS ORDER TO KEEP WELFARE POST
description: A Roman Catholic nun who was ordered by her church to resign as director of the Michigan Department of Social Services because of her support for state-financed abortions said today that she had given up her religious vows rather than face expulsion from her order.

title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After net provisions for losses on discontinued operations of $8,350,000 for the quarter and $20,700,000 for the year.

title: Florida Panel Rejects Fund-Raising Change
description: An effort by young Republicans on campus to reduce the funds of student-run public interest research groups at three Florida universities was defeated Tuesday by a Florida House committee.

title: Mr. May Comes Into Bloom
description: In the elegant lobby of the Westin Hotel, only a few feet from the elevators, the silver Stanley Cup glistens atop a glittering display of more than a dozen National Hockey League trophies. As the Islanders go to or from their rooms, they can't help but see, and perhaps be inspired by, the cup that they are hoping to drink champagne out of for a fourth consecutive year. It has become part of the team's heritage and part of the players' lives.

title: STRIPPING WOODS CAN YIELD SURPRISE
description: THE customer was shocked. She had lugged in an old varnished chair to be stripped, and while the one that Samuel Christensen handed back was lovely, she said it wasn't hers. An argument ensued.

title: AMERICAN STATES LEASING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
SHORT TERM RATES EDGE UP
description: A Commerce Department report of rising retail sales in April sparked late selling pressure that pushed up short-term interest rates on government securities.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $66,000 for the latest first quarter and $94,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT BUCKS FOR 2-0 SERIES LEAD
description: Bobby Jones blocked five shots tonight, but the one that hurt the Milwaukee Bucks the most came with 2 minutes 17 seconds left at the Spectrum. It protected a slim Philadelphia advantage, stalled a Bucks' comeback and helped the 76ers go on to an 87-81 victory and a 2-0 lead in the Eastern Conference championship series.

title: Hard to Replace
description: Just about every New York baseball fan knows that when Darryl Strawberry was brought up to the Mets late last week, he displaced Danny Heep in right field.

title: Action on Tower With Mall Halted
description: A temporary restraining order was issued yesterday that prevents the city from enforcing the revocation of a certificate of occupany for a 36-story building on the West Side. The promises of the owner of the building to create a pedestrian mall were found by a city board to have been ignored.

title: Harvester-Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was renegotiating an existing $500 million engine supplier contract with the International Harvester Company, seeking to double output of Harvester's light truck diesel engines starting next year. Harvester sources said that, when the final agreement was reached, the value of the accord would reach nearly $900 million. Harvester is Ford's only supplier of light truck diesel engines.

title: United Brands Sets Sizable Write-Off
description: The United Brands Company said yesterday that it would take a $100 million charge against fiscal third-quarter earnings from the restructuring of its United Fruit Company division. United Fruit is the world's largest importer of bananas, which are sold under the Chiquita label.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared in 1982.

title: CITY FIREFIGHTER AND 22 OTHERS ARE ACCUSED OF DEALING IN DRUGS
description: Twenty-three people - including a city firefighter, a restaurant owner, a former university library employee and a former police officer - have been indicted on charges of conspiring to buy, sell and distribute cocaine and heroin, authorities announced yesterday.

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Sentenced to 8 Years
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, H. Edward Tickel, was sentenced today to eight years in prison on six counts of obstructing justice, tax evasion and dealing in stolen diamonds.

title: The U.N. Today; May 12, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CAE INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for year o March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordiany gain of $477,000. c-Net loss after a special charge of $6,020,000.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $2,100,000 from equity in the net earnings of Chromalloy. c-Includes a gain of $1,400,000 from equity in the net earnings of Chromalloy.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 16.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal Stock Exchanges.

title: Mathematica Deal
description: Mathematica Inc., the computer information systems company, said it was discussing a merger with the subsidiary of an unidentified company that would bring shareholders $27 a share in cash or stock. Mathematica, based in Princeton Junction, N.J., also reported a net loss of $186,000 for its fiscal third quarter, compared with a $321,000 profit, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues dropped to $8.37 million in the quarter, from $8.58 million.

title: On Grief and Mourning
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $748,000 on investments.

title: EXPOS' 3-RUN 11TH DOWNS BRAVES, 8-5
description: Andre Dawson's tie-breaking single triggered a three-run 11th inning that enabled the Montreal Expos to gain an 8-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

title: COLLEGE BOARD LISTS WHAT STUDENTS SHOULD KNOW
description: A report specifying the skills students ought to master in high school to be prepared for higher education was made public yesterday by the College Board, providing educators with a practical guide for reform in response to demands for higher standards.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings are fully diluted and reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 10, 1983.

title: CANADA PERMANENT MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including securities gains of $112,000 for the latest first quarter and $3,439,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Electronics Installation
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Salvador Rebels Raid Plant
description: Left-wing guerrillas firebombed a coffee processing plant in eastern El Salvador Tuesday night, causing $2 million in damage, the police said today.

title: RESCUE CHIEF OPPOSES CHRYSLER BID
description: G. William Miller, who as Treasury Secretary directed the Government's $1.5 billion Federal rescue of the Chrysler Corporation, has written his successor to urge that the Government not release the company from any of its obligations.

title: BALLET: 'SYLVIA' BY A.B.T.
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S ''Sylvia'' Pas de Deux, staged by Andre Eglevsky, after George Balanchine, is delicate fare as grand pas de deux go. There is barely a hint of the usual Soviet-style pyrotechnic flash. The ballet manners are more Gallic here, with the emphasis on inflection. But that look of delicacy is deceptive. The ''Sylvia'' Pas de Deux requires exceptional control and technical virtuosity. And it got them both in a performance by Martine van Hamel and Patrick Bissell on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Dutch Jobless Rise
description: The unemployment rate in the Netherlands increased again to record levels last month, the Social Affairs Ministry said today. At the end of April, 783,200 people were out of work, an increase of 14,000 from the previous month.

title: ALVARADO SETS NEW CENTERS FOR READING
description: The new Schools Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, said yesterday that special centers would be opened in nine New York City high schools next September to help entering ninth graders with very poor reading skills.

title: MOSCOW'S MIDEAST BID
description: Mustering the troops of its defeated client, Syria, and the remnants of P.L.O. forces driven from Beirut, the Soviet Union is now making a determined and dangerous bid to force its way into the politics of the Middle East.

title: S.E.C. IS SAID TO FACE INQUIRY ON ASHLAND ROLE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, under Congressional criticism for its enforcement activities, now faces an inquiry into its failure to follow up on charges of questionable payments by Ashland Oil Inc. to Government officials of Oman, according to Congressional sources and others familiar with the case.

title: Cunard Purchase
description: Trafalgar House Ltd. of London said its Cunard Lines subsidiary had agreed to purchase Norwegian-American Cruises and its two luxury cruise vessels, the Vistafjord and the Sagafjord, for $73 million. The acquisition would increase Cunard's fleet to five major cruise vessels. Cunard said there would be no major changes in Norwegian-American's operations.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $23,364. c-Net loss.

title: PROFITS
description: I.T.T.'s Net Fell 17.5% in Quarter By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

title: Zaire Revisited
description: The 10th anniversary of Muhammad Ali's upset of George Foreman, with which Ali regained the world heavyweight boxing title, will be celebrated in Zaire next year. And Don King, the promoter who arranged the fight, says he has been invited back by Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's President, to stage another main event.

title: Technology; Satellites That Fight Muggers
description: THE use of satellite communications has so far been confined to telephone and television companies and other concerns that use dishshaped antennas at least several feet in diameter.

title: BUILDING LEASED BY CITY IS CALLED WHITE ELEPHANT
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee yesterday characterized as a ''white elephant'' the building in downtown Brooklyn where the city's Finance Department is moving half its employees.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ASHFORD WANTS TO HELP METS
description: The crowd had not come to Shea Stadium last Friday to record the arrival of Tucker Ashford, the 73d third baseman in Met history, but at various moments during the coronation of Darryl Strawberry, the notebooks and microphones stopped by for a visit. ''It didn't bother me,'' Ashford said. ''It was something I had never seen before. I had four televisions and a dozen writers, and people asked me if I was being shunned.''

title: U.S. SEES NEW SOVIET ARMS VIOLATION
description: In two high-level private diplomatic approaches, the United States has accused the Soviet Union of testing two new intercontinental missiles and asked Moscow to explain why this did not violate the 1979 strategic arms agreement, American officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CORP (ITT) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Return of the Falcon
description: It's a sign of spring unseen in the city for 35 years: two pairs of peregrine falcons are incubating their eggs. The nests, on the Throgs Neck and Verrazano Bridges, are invisible from the roadways and are scratched out of gravel on ledges underneath, according to bird watchers.

title: People Express
description: Britain's Trade Department has deferred a decision on whether to allow People Express Airlines to start offering cheap trans-Atlantic flights, according to The Financial Times business newspaper.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STAGE: LERNER MUSICAL 'DANCE A LITTLE CLOSER'
description: ALTHOUGH ''Dance a Little Closer,'' the new musical at the Minskoff, numbs the audience with almost every step, I won't pretend that it didn't get to me. That happened just before the second act, when the able conductor, Peter Howard, led his band in a brief medley of the score. Listening to Charles Strouse's music, as lithely orchestrated by Jonathan Tunick, anyone can plainly hear that it contains some pretty melodies. Remembering some of the Alan Jay Lerner lyrics that accompany them - especially those for the romantic title song - I was reminded of why Mr. Lerner is one of our musical theater's top professionals. It's depressing to watch these men bury their gifts in a huge, extravagant mishmash that obviously took months of hard labor to produce.

title: CONTROVERSY OVER LAVISH STATELY HOME
description: A LIVELY little controversy has broken out over an American's flamboyant redecoration of Sutton Place, the most important survivor of the great Tudor houses built in the years immediately after Cardinal Wolsey started Hampton Court in 1514. Sutton Place is the precursor of such well loved stately homes as Hardwick Hall, Longleat and Burghley.

title: DEBATE BY EDITORS CENTERS ON PHOTO
description: The picture showed a naked woman covering herself with a hand towel as a burly policeman hurried her away from the house where her husband had just killed himself. The question posed to the 50 newspaper editors at a workshop today was whether they would print it.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $270,000 for plant relocation.

title: OLLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $32,232 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $2,104,702 from the sale of assets. c-Includes income of $92,391 from discontinued operations.

title: Ruling Party Set Back In South African Vote
description: The National Party of Prime Minister P.W. Botha suffered an erosion of Afrikaner support in final returns today from by-elections in conservative rural districts of the Transvaal, but managed to save a Cabinet member from defeat by a right-wing challenger.

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SHULTZ SAYS HE IS CONFIDENT SYRIA WILL CONSENT TO LEBANON PULLOUT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told President Reagan today that he was confident Syria would eventually consent to withdraw its troops from Lebanon along with Israel's despite Syria's early opposition to the proposal.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: TO many people masonry surfaces - concrete, stucco, brick, cement block - are like stone, impervious to the elements and almost maintenance-free. However, as many homeowners have long since discovered, this is not true. Masonry materials do crack and chip, and crumbling develops in mortar joints, especially when structural defects allow moisture to enter.

title: 3 Youths and 2 Adults Missing In Flooding of a Texas River
description: Five people, including three children and a counselor, disappeared early today after their campsites were flooded by the rain-swollen Pedernales River.

title: MOSCOW SAYS IT WILL NOT LET SAKHAROV GO ABROAD
description: Western efforts to persuade the Soviet Union to allow Andrei D. Sakharov to emigrate were rejected today with an announcement that the 61-year-old physicist and human rights campaigner had been barred from going abroad because he possessed state secrets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Les Habegger was elevated from assistant coach to general manager of the Seattle SuperSonics, succeeding Zollie Volchok, who is scheduled to retire in July. ... Leon Hess, the Jets' owner, will receive the National Football Foundation's Distinguished American Award at a dinner in December. ... Reggie Collier, the Birmingham Stallion quarterback who missed three games with a knee injury, underwent knee surgery that will keep him out for four more weeks.

title: Polish Priest, 70, Is Jailed
description: The Rev. Stefan Dzierzek, a 70-year-old Jesuit priest in Kalisz, has been sentenced to two months in prison for planning to collect aid for victims of martial law, church sources said today.

title: UNICORP AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes revenue of $174,000 and income of $156,000, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of a small office building.

title: NEW GROUP BACKS HAGLER-SCYPION
description: The world middleweight title fight between Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the champion, and Wilford Scypion was rescheduled today as a 15-round bout to be held on May 27 here and sanctioned by the United States Boxing Association International.

title: BOSSY MAY BE BACK TONIGHT
description: Mike Bossy said today he was feeling better after his attack of tonsillitis and could probably play Thursday night in the second game of the Stanley Cup final round against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: A PEOPLE'S CAFE IS BEING PLANNED FOR BRYANT PARK
description: A conservatory type of restaurant that would seat hundreds of people both indoors and outdoors is under consideration as a key element in the renovation of Bryant Park.

title: PAUL SHERMAN
description: Paul Sherman, an announcer and reporter for WINS radio in New York for 38 years until his retirement two years ago, died Monday at his home in Coconut Creek, Fla.

title: Court Upholds Kean on Budget
description: A state appeals court today unanimously rejected moves by Democratic legislative leaders to limit the Governor Kean's power to change the state budget.

title: THE DAY LILY MEETS A GARDENER'S NEEDS
description: Gardeners are always looking for the perfect plant. It should require little care, bloom with spectacular flowers, grow just about anywhere and last for years and years. The day lily comes close to all those attributes.

title: Ex-Head of Bank Board Takes Merrill Lynch Job
description: Richard T. Pratt, who stepped down last month as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is stepping into a new post at Merrill Lynch.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SAVING THE SOIL: THE DOUBLE-DUG GARDEN
description: THERE are two basic philosophies of the role of soil in growing plants. One of them, as old and well grounded as the human race's first efforts at agriculture, sees the earth as the source of the nutrients that, along with sunlight, air and water, make plant life possible. The other, not nearly as concerned with the ground as such, views it as a conduit by which nourishment is carried from fertilizer sack to plant, with soil contributing little to the process.

title: New Group Picks Salomon Brothers
description: The National Financial American Network, a newly formed organization of 40 savings and loan insitutions and savings banks across the country, announced the selection of Salomon Brothers as the investment banker for the group.

title: Canada Air Traffic Falls
description: Canada's major airlines carried 24 percent fewer passengers in January and February than they did a year earlier, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The airlines - Air Canada, CP Air, Wardair and the major regional carriers - carried 3.04 million passengers, a million fewer than in January-February 1982, Statistics Canada said.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
SEISCOM DELTA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm voting against all military appropriations.'' - Representative George W. Crockett Jr., Democrat of Michigan, explaining his vote against military aid to El Salvador. (A1:5.)

title: Accounts
description: * General Cigar and Tobacco Co. to Young & Rubicam/Chicago for its Silver Creek brand of smokeless tobacco.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Between Golden Fruits & Vegetables and the Yang Yang restaurant on Columbus Avenue near 72d Street, a couple embraced yesterday. They were ensconced on a red velvet Napoleon III love seat outside Only Hearts, a shop selling suction cups with lips painted on, heartshaped lollipops and year-round valentines.

title: RED CROSS CRITICIZES IRAN AND IRAQ
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that both Iran and Iraq had violated international law in their treatment of war prisoners.
