It accused the two countries of ''summary executions of captive soldiers, abandoning of enemy wounded on the battlefield and indiscriminate bombardment of towns and villages.''

title: EMBELLISHING 80'S INTERIORS: THE RETURN OF DECORATION
description: UNTIL several years ago, contemporary designers frequently remodeled older apartments and houses by removing moldings, knocking down walls and eliminating rooms, to open up the interiors for space to ''flow.'' Beauty resided in the spaces' essential simplicity, openness and light. But by the late 1970's, with minimalism pushed to the point of austerity and the interiors of whole buildings dissolved in white paint, there was simply nothing left to take out, nowhere less to go.

title: Senate Shelves I.M.F. Curb
description: The Senate shunted aside today by a vote of 70 to 25 a proposal by Senator John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, to reduce the United States share of an enlargement of the International Monetary Fund to $3.4 billion from the $8.5 billion recommended by the Reagan Administration.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ISRAEL WARNS AGAINST PULLOUT FAILURE
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir told Parliament today that ''Israel will be free to act as it sees fit'' if Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization refuse to withdraw from Lebanon.

title: Isaiah M. Minkoff, Ex-Member Of Group on Jewish Relations
description: Isaiah M. Minkoff, retired executive vice chairman of the National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council, died of cancer Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Minkoff, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 82 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Juror's Duty
description: One expression of disillusionment with New York State's criminal court system is not enough. To serve as a juror is an unforgettable experience. How, one keeps wondering, could a judicial system be so inefficient?

title: PREREQUISITE TO CENTRAL AMERICAN DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Watt Urges Christian Change
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, saying that the United States ''is a hurting nation, a nation that needs help,'' has urged graduates of the Rev. Jerry Falwell's college to be part of a Christian revolution.

title: Bid-Rigging Charges Filed
description: The Justice Department today filed its first criminal charges in a five-state antitrust investigation into bid-rigging on electrical construction.

title: OPERA: 'GIORNO DI REGNO'
description: FEW operas have had such a tragic history as Giuseppe Verdi's ''Giorno di Regno.'' In the years immediately preceding its La Scala premiere in 1840, Verdi's wife and two children died, and the composer himself was very ill throughout the work's gestation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., elected Thomas F. McLarty 3d president of its Arkansas Louisiana Gas Company division.

title: Doctor Joined Schlichter
description: When Art Schlichter spent several hours Tuesday with Pete Rozelle, among those accompanying him was Dr. Robert Custer, a Washington psychiatrist who specializes in the treatment of compulsive gambling, a league source said yesterday.

title: Armco Callback
description: Armco Inc. said 96 laid-off workers would be recalled Sunday to jobs at the steelmaker's Middletown Works.

title: Vice Chairman of ABC Retiring at End of Year
description: Elton H. Rule, the 65-year-old vice chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies, said yesterday that he would retire at the end of the year. He will remain a director of the company.

title: Southland Enters Plea
description: The Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges that it conspired to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the 7-Eleven convenience store chain. The Dallas-based Southland is operator and franchiser of the nationwide chain.

title: People
description: * Gerald Karp has been appointed executive vice president at Nadler & Larimer.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Corrected from Wednesday's editions.

title: NUCORP ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $93,974,000 for the quarter and $300,567,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,904,000 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $12,269,000 for the year. The year ago results have been restated to reflect the change to the successful efforts method of accounting for oil and gas properties and the scontinuance of operations in 1982.

title: POLAND LETS PARTY WEEKLY REBUT SOVIET ATTACK ON MILITARY REGIME
description: The Polish Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has cleared for publication on Thursday a defense of his military rule against criticism from the Soviet Union and from hard-liners within his own Communist Party.

title: MUSIC: 'HARLEM NIGHT SONG'
description: CRAIG HARRIS'S ''Harlem Night Song'' was a lot like one of his trombone solos. As performed by a 16-piece band and five dancers on Sunday afternoon at the Museum of the City of New York, the suite was by turns lyrical and boisterous, smooth and loose.

title: MANAGED PROPERTIES FOR PORT AUTHORITY
description: Robert S. Curtiss, who was in charge of the Port Authority's properties during its postwar expansion and then headed one of New York's oldest realty brokerage and management concerns, died Sunday while on a visit in Seminole, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Farewell to Football
description: John Hannah, regarded as one of the best offensive linemen ever, told the New England Patriots yesterday that he did not want to play football anymore. Hannah, a 32-year-old guard, informed the Patriots of his retirement after complaining about what he views as an inadequate effort by the team's management.

title: A Dated Message Goes on the Air
description: ''Hi, I'm Larry Brown, the coach of the New Jersey Nets,'' Larry Brown said in a public-service announcement seeking donors for a New Jersey blood bank.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RIVALS CLASH AGAIN IN CHICAGO COUNCIL
description: Mayor Harold Washington and a rebellious faction of aldermen opposing him had another stormy City Council session today. It was punctuated by more of the vitriolic exchanges and parlimentary manuevering that have kept the Council at a standstill for the last 10 days.

title: E.E.C. '84 Budget
description: A $25.5 billion 1984 budget for the European Economic Community, which will virtually exhaust funds available to the 10-nation trading bloc, was disclosed today, the community's budget commissioner, Christopher Tugendhat, said.

title: VOYAGE TO BROADWAY BY 'SHOW BOAT' SINGER
description: Lonette McKee plays a part heavy with history in the romantic Broadway revival of the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical ''Show Boat.'' Her most memorable predecessor in the role of Julie was Helen Morgan. Yet Miss McKee is making history of her own with her renditions of ''Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man'' and ''Bill,'' which were described by one critic as ''heart-stopping.''

title: E.P.A. FAULTS TESTS ON 200 PESTICIDES
description: A study by the Environmental Protection Agency has found that two-thirds of all tests conducted by a big private research laboratory to establish the safety of pesticides and herbicides now on the market were scientifically invalid.

title: Product Introductions Up 25% From Last April
description: Just because new product introductions in April did not keep up the heady pace set in March does not mean they did not better last year's mark. The Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News reports that they were up 25 percent from last April's 113 to a solid 140, bringing the year's total to 529, a 36 percent increase from the 390 in the first four months of 1982.

title: NEW YORK STATE SEEKS A SITE IN CITY TO CONSTRUCT HIGH-SECURITY PRISON
description: A search is under way for a site in New York City for a medium- or maximum-security state prison, correction officials said today.

title: U.N. Team Has Theory On West Bank Illnesses
description: A World Health Organization inquiry said today that hydrogen sulphide escaping from school toilets may have started the illnesses of Arab schoolgirls and others in the Israeli-occupied West Bank this spring.

title: Honeywell Layoffs
description: Honeywell Inc. is laying off 100 workers at its residential division because the housing industry has not rebounded as quickly as expected. A spokesman for the electronics and computer manufacturing company, Karen Bachman, said the division, which makes thermostats and other control systems, now will have 1,700 workers on layoff. About 4,000 employees are still on the job.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $2,990,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to the full cost method of accounting and to segregate discontinued minerals exploration and mining operations.

title: POTVIN'S CRUCIAL SAVE
description: The pass from Paul Coffey to Wayne Gretzky was placed perfectly. So precise, in fact, that Gretzky yesterday could almost feel himself this time rapping the puck into the net.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GIRL, 17, ABDUCTED AND RAPED IN QUEENS BY AT LEAST 6 IN VAN
description: A 17-year-old girl walking home with her boyfriend at 2 A.M. yesterday in a quiet residential area of Queens was abducted by at least six men in a van and raped repeatedly during an hourlong drive.

title: SUPPLY SYSTEM'S BONDS ON 3 PLANTS CUT TO BAA 1
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday announced a downgrading to Baa1 from A1 for bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System's nuclear power plants 1, 2 and 3.

title: SYRIA'S BUILDUP CALLED A TACTIC FOR TALKS
description: A flow of well-armed Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas into Lebanon and a significant reinforcement of Syrian forces there, both reported this week by United States officials, are intended to strengthen Syria's position in negotiations on the withdrawal of its troops from Lebanon, American intelligence officials believe,

title: GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $147,000.

title: Aerospatiale Leader
description: The French Government named Jean Martre, senior Defense Ministry arms expert, to succeed Jacques Mitterrand as head of the state-owned Aerospatiale Aircraft Company.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Construction Is Begun On New Bellevue Unit
description: Construction of Bellevue Hospital Center's new psychiatric service facilities began yesterday with a ground-breaking ceremony, hospital officials said.

title: MISSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,092,000 from a realized investment. c-Includes a gain of $124,000, or 1 cent a share, from a realized investment.

title: Plans for BL Ltd.
description: The Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has agreed to sell shares of the stateowned BL Ltd. to the public as soon as possible if it wins reelection in June, the Minister of State for Industry, Norman Lamont, said. The auto maker, formerly called British Leyland, has agreed to dispose of peripheral activities to enable it to concentrate on vehicle manufacture and sales.

title: Tanaka Trial Resumes
description: The trial of Japan's most powerful politician, former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, resumed today after a three-month recess. It began in January 1977. He is charged with taking a $2 million bribe from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the early 1970's to use his influence as Prime Minister to obtain orders for Lockheed's Tristars from All Nippon Airways.

title: SEAVER WINS ON 5-HITTER
description: A five-hit pitching effort by Tom Seaver and a towering two-run homer by Dave Kingman proved to the Mets tonight that, despite their youth movement, they still need some of the old pros to survive.

title: Scientex Failure
description: The Scientex Corporation, a medical research and development company, said it expected file within the next week a petition for Chapter 7 bankruptcy, which would involve liquidation of the company. It said it had informed its major shareholder, Uban International Ltd. of Hong Kong, of its plan.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S LETTER ON ARMS CONTROL POLICY
description: Following is the text of a letter on arms control policy that was sent by President Reagan today to Representative Norman D. Dicks, Democrat of Washington, and eight other members of the House:

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A Tug of War
description: Billy Ray Smith, the all-America linebacker from Arkansas who was the top choice of the San Diego Chargers in the National Football League's college draft last month, is being wooed by the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League. San Diego has already lost one first-round draft choice to the newer league: the Arkansas wide receiver and running back Gary Anderson, who signed with the Tampa Bay Bandits. Unless he thinks he is ''properly compensated,'' said Smith's agent, George Kalafatis, ''Billy Ray is not going to play in the National Football League.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE WARLORD. By Malcolm Bosse. 717 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the previous year include extraordinary credits equal to 25 cents a share.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Great Western Financial Corp., a California savings and loan institution, is issuing $50 million of Eurobonds due in 1998, with an indicated coupon of 7 1/2 to 8 percent, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.; final terms are to be set May 18.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Olajuwon to Stay
description: Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, the University of Houston's sophomore center, said he would stay in college for at least another year, but Ennis Whatley of Alabama and Byron Scott of Arizona State said they would pass up their remaining eligibility to enter the National Basketball Association's draft next month. In interviews published in Houston yesterday, Olajuwon said he had ruled out an immediate move to the pros primarily because his parents, in Nigeria, had urged him to remain in college.

title: MAJOR NATIONS BACK U.S. ON JOINT EFFORT TO FIGHT TRADE BARS
description: Major industrialized allies have accepted a United States initiative for a new approach to world trade protectionism, European monetary officials said today.

title: PILAR RIOJA'S CONCERTS
description: VIRTUALLY all dance forms require dancers to be musically sensitive. But some also literally require them to make a kind of music as they move. One such form is Spanish dance, with its castanets and percussive steps for the feet. Recently, Pilar Rioja, an eloquent dancer, proved to be an equally eloquent one-woman percussion orchestra in her season of solo concerts at Repertorio Espanol's Gramercy Arts Theater. Just as she did during her engagement here last fall, so Miss Rioja again made one aware of the varied steps and sounds of Spanish dance.

title: EVACUATION ISSUE THREATENING NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Nuclear power plants around the country are threatened by the reluctance of many local governments to develop or participate in emergency preparedness plans.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Turkey Season Is Under Way
description: Spring turkey hunting is under way in the Northeast states that offer such sport, and, unless one is devoted to the somewhat esoteric pursuit of woodchucks with high-velocity, flat-shooting, smallcaliber rifles, this is the last opportunity to go afield with gun in hand until fall.

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results are reported in Canadian dollars.

title: 'OLD' GAS DECONTROL MEANS SOARING PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: BARRINGER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $462,000. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $23,000.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $136,635 for the quarter and $301,552 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $117,919 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $204,062 from discontinued operations.

title: MALARTIC HYGRADE GOLD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
STUTTGART MAN NAMED AS HITLER HOAX SOURCE
description: The West German journalist who brought to light the forged Hitler diaries said today that he had acquired them from a dealer in Stuttgart who handles Nazi memorabilia.

title: 37 Reported Slain In Colombian Battles
description: Leftist guerrillas today attacked the police station of the village of Paujil in southwest Colombiaay, killing 4 police officers, pushing to 37 the number of people dead in less than 48 hours of skirmishing.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT INCREASED $2.58 BILLION IN MARCH
description: American consumers, apparently gaining confidence in the economic recovery, took on $2.58 billion more in installment debt in March than they paid off, the Government reported today.

title: DATA PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
RATES FALL ON MONEY ACCOUNTS
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts declined for the sixth consecutive week, both in New York and around the coutnry, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: FRANCE SEEKS $4 BILLION E.E.C. LOAN
description: France will ask its European Common Market partners for a new $4 billion loan to swell its depleted reserves and help defend the franc, which is again under pressure, a Government spokesman announced today.

title: NATIONAL SEA PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
Smith Corona Model
description: Smith Corona produced its last manual typewriter today, ending 77 years of producing manual portable typewriters. Three hundred people employed here are being laid off with the end of manual typewriter production by Smith Corona, a unit of the SCM Corporation.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Vilas Target of Inquiry
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the governing body of the Grand Prix tour, has informed Guillermo Vilas of Argentina that it is conducting an investigation to determine whether he accepted an appearance fee from the Rotterdam Grand Prix event, held in March. Vilas denies he got such a payment. He could be fined as much as $20,000 and suspended from the Grand Prix circuit up to three years.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 12, 1983
description: International

title: 2 to Share Prize In $3 Million Lotto
description: Two Queens people will share last Saturday's $3 million Lotto jackpot, it was announced today. One, Isabel Yannaco, 65 years old, of Whitestone, was waiting to go out for a Mother's Day dinner with her son and two daughters Sunday when she discovered she had picked all six numbers.

title: HOUSE UNIT TIES AID TO SALVADOR TO START OF TALKS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee adopted a compromise measure today that would provide additional military aid to El Salvador on condition that the Salvadoran Government begin talks with the insurgents.

title: LOANS TO FAMILIES IN MORTGAGE PINCH APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved an emergency mortgage assistance bill designed to help 100,000 families facing foreclosures.

title: People Express Adds Atlantic City
description: People Express Airlines said today that it would begin scheduled nonstop service between Newark and Atlantic City on June 1.

title: FRENCH STUDENTS CLASH AGAIN WITH THE POLICE
description: Riot policemen battled hundreds of students who demonstrated in Paris, Cannes and other French cities today to protest the Socialist Government's proposed changes in education.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
OPERA HOUSE GETS FACELIFT FOR $2 MILLION
description: Although it is less than 12 years old, the Opera House at the Kennedy Center has been under such unexpectedly heavy use that it is undergoing a $2 million facelift.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,410,139 from discontinued operations. c-Net income which includes income of $30,149 from discontinued operations.

title: TRIMAC LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: APRIL SALES AT RETAIL ROSE 1.6%
description: Retail sales rose a strong 1.6 percent in April, led for the second consecutive month by a revival in auto sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations.

title: Q&A
description: Q. One wall in my den is covered with dark cork, and another wall is covered with wood paneling and cabinets stained a dark color. I would like to make this room look lighter. What can I use to paint over the cork and wood paneling?

title: PREMIER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income which includes extraordinary tax credits of $354,000 for the quarter and $529,000 for the 6 months.

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DANCE: AILEY PREMIERE
description: BILL T. JONES certainly set the dancers hopping in his ''Fever Swamp,'' which was given its New York premiere by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: Panel Limits New F.B.I. Rules
description: A House committee, concerned about new Federal Bureau of Investigation guidelines that give agents broader authority to infiltrate domestic groups, agreed today to a compromise that allows the bureau to use the regulations temporarily.

title: Norwegian Oil Discovery
description: Norway today announced the discovery of its first offshore oil discovery north of the 62d parallel, but declined to comment on its commercial potential.

title: Advertising; Dealing In Coins And Ads
description: BARRY BLAU runs a direct marketing advertising agency, and that does not make him unique. But he is more than just another run-ofthe-mill upscale Connecticut resident. He also has a direct mail company on the side. And he pursues both occupations in the Constitution State, as it is known to license plate fans.

title: AM General Order
description: The AM General Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation, was awarded a $38 million contract to build 6,400 postal vehicles for the Federal Government, the company announced. AM General is the leading supplier of vehicles to the United States Postal Service. A.M.C. is trying to sell AM General to get needed cash for auto development programs.

title: Braniff-Marriott Deal Called Off
description: A proposed deal between the Braniff International Corporation and the Marriott Corporation has fallen through, Howard D. Putnam, Braniff's chairman, confirmed.

title: ARGUS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Saldi Traded
description: The Dallas Cowboys traded Jay Saldi to the Chicago Bears today for an undisclosed 1984 draft choice.

title: ESTATES AND STUDIES OPENED FOR VISITORS
description: Estates, private homes and artists' studios are open to the public this month. Any proceeds from tours will benefit charities. Private Houses

title: Don't Give Up the Withholding Ship
description: A year ago, Congress adopted a law to establish tax withholding on interest and dividends. The resulting avalanche of constituent mail has demanded repeal, and even Congressmen who believe in the law are saying, ''It's dead, so why fight it?'' That's politics at its weakest.

title: The Ambassador's Wife
description: Contradictions abound. Betty Friedan gave a party Tuesday night in her Lincoln Center apartment for Elizabeth Shannon, author of ''Up in the Park: The Diary of the Wife of the American Ambassador to Ireland.''

title: The Roll-Call
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved a compromise bill to end military aid for El Salvador unless its Government begins talks with insurgents and their political representatives. FOR THE BILL - 36 Democrats - 23 Barnes, Md.

title: VINTAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BUFFTON OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: STUDY ON TAXES URGES REPLACING INCENTIVE PANEL
description: A disputed tax incentive program for developers should be replaced by an expanded one that would guarantee incentives for virtually every commercial and industrial project in New York City, according to a study released yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: O.E.C.D. COMMUNIQUE EXCERPTS
description: Following are excerpts from the final communique of the ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, as contained in the English-language text distributed Tuesday by the 24-nation organization:

title: Small Talk
description: ABC is the television network whose willingness to broadcast the games of the United States Football League for its first two seasons enabled the U.S.F.L. to gain an initial measure of credibility. Has the network also attempted to give the league, whose ratings are dipping, a subtle boost through references to it on one of ABC's popular soap operas? Suspicions might have been aroused by an episode the other day, but an editor for the show denies any such thing.

title: Results Due in 2 Proxy Fights
description: Two large oil companies today will confront dissident shareholders attempting to make major management changes. In Reno, shareholders of the Superior Oil Company are meeting this morning to hear the results of an election on a resolution to end management's policy of resisting takeover offers.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WORLDWIDE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: PUPILS GIVE CUOMO A QUIZ ON GOVERNING
description: Governor Cuomo assured 10-year-old Robert Schreib today that Japanese schoolchildren were not smarter than their American counterparts. But he said that schools ought to ''concentrate a little bit more on the essentials.''

title: BRITAIN'S COMEBACK IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: Britain's commercial setbacks in the fast-developing field of biotechnology had long been more remarkable than its successes. Today, however, the nation's biotechnological companies are hopeful that those days have passed.

title: Australia Scandal Erupts Over Soviet Diplomat
description: A former national secretary of the Australian Labor Party had a relationship with an expelled Soviet diplomat that gave rise to a serious security concern, Prime Minister Robert Hawke told Parliament today.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: RICKOVER ON NAVY CONTRACTS
description: Two years ago Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, a longtime critic of military contractors, charged that the profits of several Navy contractors were excessive. Now a Congressional inquiry has borne out the admiral's figures but has declined to label the profits excessive.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TUCSON ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $697,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $389,000 from discontinued operations.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
HELLER, WALTER E, INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Italy Oil Unit Sold
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has sold its Italian oil refining company, Amoco Italiana, to two Saudi Arabian companies. No financial details were released.

title: Chairman Elected At Eastman Kodak
description: The board of directors of the Eastman Kodak Company elected Colby H. Chandler as the new chairman and chief executive officer yesterday to succeed Walter A. Fallon, who will be 65 years old next month. Mr. Chandler, 57, has been president of the company since 1977.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,334,000 for the latest first quarter and $697,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: LILLIAN D. COLE
description: Lillian D. Cole, administrator of the Powder Coating Institute, a trade association, and a secretary for the GCA Chemical Corporation of Stamford, Conn., died Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.)

title: Comet Passes Earth On Way Toward Sun
description: The comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock came and went yesterday. It made its closest approach to the Earth in the morning and, where skies were clear, was seen last night as a diffuse ball of light speeding away f'r a swing around the Sun in two weeks.

title: Dean Suspended At Passaic College
description: The dean of business affairs at Passaic County Community College was suspended from his $45,000 post on Tuesday after admitting that he took more than $68,000 from two college funds, officials said.

title: TV: MUPPETS IN ROCKIES SING WITH JOHN DENVER
description: THE persistently youthful John Denver joins the Muppets tonight, on ABC at 8 o'clock, in a music special called ''Rocky Mountain Holiday.'' The program was produced by Mr. Denver and Jim Henson, creator of the Muppets, and was taped near Aspen, Colo., the spectacular mountain town that Mr. Denver calls home.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Natural Resources Co. said a subsidiary of its ANR Coal Co. unit had agreed to buy two underground mines and a coal processing plant in Wise County, Va., and other equipment from two subsidiaries of the Duke Power Co. for $22.3 million.

title: Socialists Sign Accord On Austrian Coalition
description: Austria's Socialist and Freedom parties announced agreement today on the first coalition Government in 17 years, amid a furor over the possibility that a former Nazi SS man may become a Parliament leader.

title: P.& G. Said to Buy $15 Million TV Package
description: The big spenders at Procter & Gamble, who are accustomed to setting advertising spending records, have done it again.

title: DOW DROPS 9.96
description: Stock prices staged a moderate retreat yesterday, although some of the depressed oil and gas company issues resisted the decline. Brian M. Greenman, president of Pendrick Reeves Associates Inc., a brokerage firm in Southport, Conn., said that stock prices over the near term ''should continue to ease as investors take more of their profits, as was the case today.''

title: TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: As a psychotherapist I found Susan Jacoby's article, on the need for society to allow the grieving person to grieve, very meaningful. People who have suffered loss through the death of a loved one do indeed need to have an opportunity to express their sadness without being turned off by palliatives from well-intentioned others.

title: Liver Transplant Child Dies in Memphis
description: Thirteen-month-old Brandon Hall, who underwent two liver transplants, died today, a hospital spokesman said. Brandon's mother, Billie Hall of Walnut, Miss., was at his side, according to John Donica, a spokesman for Le Bonheur Children's Medical Center.

title: Washington Public Power
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System, a project sponsored by 88 utilities that is close to default, said today that it had received a $4 million payment from the Babcock & Wilcox Company, a contractor on one of the project's nuclear power plants.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: IS SURVIVAL THE ONLY ABSOLUTE VALUE?
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLUBBY

title: ON LEAVING CAPITOL HILL FOR THE BENCH
description: It was nearly four years ago that Abner J. Mikva moved from the often noisy halls of Congress to the quiet of chambers as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. But the one-time Democratic Representative from Illinois has not forgotten from whence he came. He is a co-author of a recently published political science textbook, ''The American Congress, The First Branch.''

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results reflect extraordinary credits of $161,000 in each 9 monthe period.

title: U.S. AND CHINA SIGN 4 MORE SCIENTIFIC ACCORDS
description: Despite disputes that have cooled China's relationship with the United States, cooperation between the two countries has received new impetus at a session of their joint commission on science and technology that concluded here today.

title: Matuszak Injured
description: John Matuszak, who announced his retirement Tuesday after 10 years in the National Football League, suffered a concussion today when the car he was driving veered off a road and struck a power pole. Joan Cole of Riverside Hospital in North Hollywood said that Matuszak, who is 32 years old, was ''in stable condition and going into intensive care.''

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Cool Welcome

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Kitchen Equipment column and an accompanying picture caption in The Living Section yesterday incorrectly described the abilities of two new digital scales. They display only weight.

title: CBS-TV IS DROPPING ARCHIE BUNKER
description: Archie Bunker, the noisy bigot who articulated the prejudices of a generation of Americans, is being dropped from prime-time television after this season. The cancellation of ''Archie Bunker's Place,'' the successor to the original Bunker program, ''All in the Family,'' was disclosed yesterday when CBS Television announced its evening lineup for next fall. In its two forms, the show ran 13 seasons on network prime time.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WYLY CORP  reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MUSIC: CHAMBER PROJECT
description: THE young chamber players of the Music Project featured - appropriately enough -music by teen-agers at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night. We heard the Sextet in D for strings and piano written by Mendelssohn at the age of 15, then the ''Phantasy'' Quartet for oboe and strings by a 19-year old Benjamin Britten.

title: DETROIT'S NEW PUSH TO UPGRADE QUALITY
description: Against the backdrop of the Buick Motor Division's Factory No.3 here, a noisy, grimy workplace that has been turning out automobile springs since 1918, the flickering display of a modern video display terminal on the shop floor seems strangely out of place.

title: COLONIAL GAS ENERGY SYSTEM reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a credit of $795,000 for an accounting change.

title: Market Place; Penn Central's Tax Bonanza
description: PENN CENTRAL stock has climbed nearly $9 a share in the last two weeks. By the close of trading yesterday, it stood at 33 3/4. When the stock first surged nearly $5 a share one day late last month, the rise was initially attributed to strength among the oil stocks. Among Penn Central's 40 businesses is a big energy group. But before long, it became apparent that the institutions were not buying because of oil developments but because of an announcement that the company itself had made.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EMPIRE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including gains of $413,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $749,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months on the repurchase of debt.

title: Ruling on DeLorean Files Upset
description: A Federal district judge was wrong to seal the files in the cocaine smuggling case of the automobile maker John Z. DeLorean and the court documents should be opened to the public, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: Playboy Cuts Loss in Quarter
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., citing a sluggish economy, has reported a net loss of $4.8 million for the third quarter of its fiscal 1983 year, compared with a $22.6 million loss in the period a year ago.

title: How to Spend Taxes for Jobs
description: When New York City discovered in 1977 how fast it was losing manufacturing jobs, it tried hastily to strengthen its economy by offering real estate tax concessions to new or expanding businesses. Now, reacting to the cry that some of these concessions were unnecessary or too costly, the city is rushing to reshape the rules for granting them.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including realized gains of $1,128,000 for the latest quarter and $41,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SAGE ENERGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $5,906,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago revenue figures are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Upset-Minded
description: No Princeton varsity crew has ever won the championship of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges since the competition began in 1946. The problem has usually been Harvard.

title: Superior Dissidents Claim 'Big' Victory
description: Representatives of Willametta Keck Day claimed victory today at the Superior Oil Company's annual meeting, saying that a majority of the shareholders entitled to vote on Mrs. Day's protakeover proposal had approved the motion.

title: Scypion Agrees to New Date
description: Wilford Scypion agreed today to a 15-round fight against the undisputed middleweight champion, Marvelous Marvin Hagler, on May 27.

title: Nuclear Regulators See A Wide Safety Problem
description: The Duke Power Company plant in Seneca, S.C., is alone among the country's nuclear power plants in adequate procedures to identify what is wrong when a reactor shuts off for safety reasons, officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: OXOCO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
POWER SEEKER FROM CHICAGO: EDWARD R. VRDOLYAK
description: Among an array of sports trophies in Edward R. Vrdolyak's City Hall office is a picture of the Alderman, sweaty and disheveled, shouting at a referee in an annual softball game between aldermen and the City Hall staff. ''I like to win,'' he commented to a visitor as he glanced at the picture.

title: PRAIRIE HUMOR COMES TO THE BIG CITY
description: As a rule, writers are not the most outgoing sort of people. Their idea of a good time is to sit alone and try to complete the sentence ''It was a lot like ... '' before the rent comes due. Yet every so often, writers find it in their hearts and financial interests to break away from the printed page and to rekindle the ancient tradition of storytelling in public, despite the presence of a live audience of total or partial strangers.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $174,000. c-Including a gain of $102,000 on the sale of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $126,000.

title: GREATWEST HOSPITALS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $300,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $34,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the 6 months.

title: ART: HENRY MOORE AT MET IN 60-YEAR PERSPECTIVE
description: THE American art world is basically divided into two kinds of people. There are those who think that Henry Moore is the best thing that ever happened. And there are those who think that he is not an artist at all.

title: Dow Off 5.32 as Volume Falls
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday, for the second consecutive session, in slower trading. Some of the technology and brokerage issues were the poorest performers.

title: A MIRROR IMAGE
description: The dominant talk of Washington these days is about the tremendous infighting within the Administration, which the President seems to ignore. It makes for a surprising mirror image with Paris.

title: U.S.-SYRIAN TALKS BEING CONSIDERED
description: The Reagan Administration is contemplating direct talks with Syria to try to persuade the Damascus Government to participate in the simultaneous pullout of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces from Lebanon, State Department officials said today.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
WITHHOLDING PLAN REJECTED BY PANEL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today voted against requiring corporations and banks to withhold 10 percent from dividend and interest payments for taxes.

title: FAST FOOD OPERATIONS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
'Dance Closer' Ends
description: The musical ''Dance a Little Closer,'' which opened Wednesday night to poor reviews, closed after one performance at the Minskoff Theater.

title: 5 Green Party Leaders Held Briefly in East
description: The East German police seized five leaders of West Germany's antinuclear Green Party today after they crossed into East Berlin to demonstrate against nuclear weapons.

title: George S. Kawata Dead at 61; Adviser to Economic Groups
description: George S. Kawata, an economic management consultant, died April 20 while on a business trip in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: Olajuwon Is Still Unsure
description: Less than 35 hours before the National Basketball Association deadline for underclassmen to apply to its draft and more than 50 minutes after the University of Houston's two most celebrated decision-makers were scheduled to announce their plans, Akeem Abdul Olajuwon and Clyde Drexler decided today only that they did not know what to decide.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Capital Holding Corp. said its shareholders had approved an increase in the number of authorized common shares to 69 million, from 35 million, and in the number of preferred shares to 6 million, from 2 million; Capital said it had no immediate plans for the additional shares.

title: Success and Its Trappings
description: Jeffrey Wisotsky, a 27-year-old Bronx film maker, has ''lived in housing projects all my life.'' His ambition to make a film about them, conceived when he was a student at the David V. Picker Film Institute at City College, has been more than fulfilled.

title: Soviet's Grain Imports
description: The Soviet Union has resumed paying cash for imported grain after financing most purchases last year under short-term credit, United States Government and grain industry officials said today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: FIVE descendants of Winston Churchill, one of whom bore an uncanny resemblance to the late B ritish Prime Minister, turned out Wednesday night for a cocktail p arty celebrating an exhibition of 51 of Sir Winston's paintings.

title: ADAMS DRUG CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MX and Arms Control
description: President Reagan has begun to get what he wanted from the report of the Scowcroft commission - new movement toward development of the MX missile. But the MX still is a long way from being deployed, and Mr. Reagan had to give Congress several important pledges that may yet mean it never will be:

title: FILMTEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $36,557 for the quarter and $40,517 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $43,605 for the quarter and $33,077 for the 6 months.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rutgers Fullback Dies in Hospital
description: A Rutgers University freshman who collapsed during spring football practice last month died today at St. Peter's Medical Center.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA MAKES $420 MILLION LOAN DEAL
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation yesterday announced the execution of a definitive long-term loan agreement with 13 major banks to refinance the remainder of the loans it took out last year in its takeover battle with the Bendix Corporation.

title: AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GUESSING GAME ON L.I.R.R.: WHOSE STATION WILL BE SHUT?
description: Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road - long accustomed to wondering whether the 7:25 A.M. will arrive before the 7:12 - have recently been playing a different kind of guessing game. Some riders refer to it as railroad roulette, and the object is to guess which four stations the L.I.R.R. will eliminate as part of a $146.5 million modernization program.

title: Jet Carrying 248 Is Hijacked To Havana, Returns to Miami
description: A Capitol Air jet carrying 248 people was hijacked to Cuba late Thursday by a woman armed with a flare pistol, officials said.

title: THEATER: SECOND BILL AT THE ONE-ACT PLAY MARATHON
description: IN the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual Marathon of short plays, there is generally at least one outstanding work for every evening of one-acts. In the opening evening this spring, there was Percy Granger's ''The Dolphin Position.'' On the second bill, however, the rewards are limited: one of out of five tiny vignettes by David Mamet and about one-half of Carol K. Mack's ''Postcards.'' The third play, ''Poisoner of the Wells,'' by Brother Jonathan, is an overheated fabrication about the Black Plague.

title: Cavalier Owners Exercise Option
description: George and Gordon Gund, the new owners of the Cleveland Cavaliers, exercised their option today to purchase Nationwide Advertising Service Inc. from the team's former owner Ted Stepien, sources told a Cleveland business newspaper.

title: U.S. JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR TRIAL ON AGENT ORANGE
description: Vietnam veterans who say their medical problems have been caused by Agent Orange won a round here today when a Federal district judge agreed that their suit against several chemical companies that produced the herbicide should go to trial.

title: Kunkel Near Return
description: Three months after undergoing his second cancer operation, Bill Kunkel, the American League umpire, is ready to take up his stance behind the plate once again. ''I'm champing at the bit,'' said the 46-year-old Kunkel, who has been cleared by his doctors to return to work and who has the support of league officials.

title: MOSCOW'S LESS THAN-OMINOUS REASONS FOR DEPLOYING SS-20'S
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY VOTES PENALTY FOR WEARING BULLETPROOF VEST DURING A FELONY
description: A bill that would allow a judge to lengthen the prison term of anyone wearing bulletproof clothing while committing a violent crime received final approval yesterday in the New York State Legislature.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Debt Limit Rise Backed
description: Responding to a Reagan Administration appeal, the House Ways and Means Committee voted today to increase the national debt limit by nearly $100 billion, to almost $1,400 billion.

title: Student, 18, Guilty Of Extortion Plot
description: An 18-year-old college freshman admitted today that he took part in a ''sick joke'' to extort $50,000 from a Princeton couple. Two of his co-defendants pleaded not guilty.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $441,000.

title: BASEMENT BATTLE: SAVING THE NATIONAL AQUARIUM
description: To Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, they are the most comely fish in the world. They're all ''affectionate,'' he said, even the deadly lion fish from the South Pacific that looks more like a turkey with fins. ''And they all have character.''

title: DROP IN MONEY FUNDS EASES
description: Money market mutual fund assets fell $495 million for the week ended Wednesday, by far the smallest drop since fund asset levels began a steady decline 23 weeks ago, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: U.S. Satellite Inc.  Fills Top Position
description: United States Satellite Systems Inc., which has received the green light for its satellite-launching plans, has named J. Roger Moody to be its president and chief executive.

title: 2 Alabama Prayer Laws Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A Federal appeals court today declared two Alabama laws authorizing periods for prayer in public school to be unconstitutional, overturning a lower court that upheld the statutes.

title: MEASURE DRAWS COUNCIL'S FIRE
description: In a rare move, the New York City Council yesterday refused to vote on a measure that had been approved by one of its committees, and instead sent the bill back to the panel.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $17,900,000, or $1.22 a share, of Canadian operations and a gain of $4,300,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of assets.

title: GAF Sees Delay In Certification
description: The GAF Corporation said Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York had indicated he would issue a temporary restraining order prohibiting for 10 days the certification of the shareholders' vote in GAF's election of directors.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Stay Is Extended In Utility Trial
description: The Washington State Supreme Court continued its stay of a complex trial that is expected to determine who is responsible for payment of $7 billion in construction revenue bonds for two terminated nuclear units. The lawsuit was filed by the Chemical Bank of New York, trustee for bondholders.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an unrealized loss of $306,910 on marketable securities.

title: BRANIFF BOARD ACCEPTS PROPOSAL FROM HYATT
description: Braniff International's board of directors agreed in principle last night to a proposal by the Hyatt Corporation that would allow the grounded airline to resume some flight operations. The plan calls for Hyatt to raise $70 million in return for 80 percent of the new airline's stock.

title: 2 Mechanics Suspended In Jetliner's Plunge
description: Two mechanics for Eastern Airlines were suspended without pay for 30 days today as the result of the stalling in flight of all three engines on a Lockheed L-1011 jetliner.

title: HOW TO TAX A PENSION
description: To the Editor:

title: K-TEL INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: BOMBS GO OFF IN QUEENS AND L.I.
description: Bombs exploded outside an armed forces reserve centers in Nassau County and one in Queens late last night and early this morning, the police said.

title: Highway to Big Sur Reopens
description: The storm-battered Coast Highway was reopened today between Carmel and Big Sur, a rugged coastal resort region that had been virtually cut off from the rest of California since February. Dozens of mud slides had isolated Big Sur, a small town built along the narrow edge of spectacular mountains.

title: DETROIT'S NEW LABOR STRATEGY
description: Henry Ford developed the moving assembly line into one of the most bountiful production systems ever known. Here, at the Ford Motor Company's light truck assembly plant, they think they have improved on the founder. They stop the line.

title: Constance Hirt Is Wed To Financial Executive
description: Constance Vickery Hirt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Hirt of Ligonier, Pa., was married yesterday evening in New York to Michael David Erlanger, son of Norman D. Erlanger of New York and the late Olga Jaffe Erlanger. State Supreme Court Justice Leon A. Beerman performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite, 1A East 77th Street.

title: G.M.-Toyota Plan
description: Workers for the General Motors-Toyota joint venture to produce a new compact car in the United States will primarily be drawn from General Motors Corporation employees who were laid off last year, a spokesman for G.M.-Toyota said. The spokesman also said that the United Automobile Workers union was expected to bargain for the aproximately 3,000 workers who will assemble the new cars at a G.M. plant in Fremont, Calif.

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $974,000 and an extraordinary gain of $81,000.

title: Church Group Deplores Policy on Asian Refugees
description: Representatives of American church and humanitarian groups said today that American officials had denied entry to thousands of Indochinese refugees by being too strict in applying guidelines for resettlement in the United States.

title: HOUSE SETS TERMS FOR MONEY TO BUILD A PROTOTYPE REACTOR
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to deny money for the Clinch River Breeder Reactor in Tennessee beyond Sept. 30 unless Congress accepted a plan to share the cost of constructing the reactor with private industry.

title: Belize Leader Sees Reagan
description: Prime Minister George Price of Belize paid a 75-minute visit today to President Reagan at the White House. The two men discussed insurgency in Central America, the economic development needs of the region and Belize's territorial dispute with Guatemala.

title: Worker Is Killed In Camden Blast
description: One man was killed today and three others were injured in an explosion in the Federal Building here. The explosion was apparently caused as fuel fumes in a boiler ignited when a new burner was turned on, officials said.

title: New Keeper, Same Jail
description: Andrei Sakharov is probably the greatest living scientist to be treated as a public enemy in his own country. It was a scandal when he was seized by security police and cruelly banished in 1980 to the closed city of Gorky for the crime of defending human rights.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT OILERS TO TAKE 2-0 LEAD IN SERIES
description: Neatly, and for the most part without controversy, the Islanders pinned a 6-3 loss on the Edmonton Oilers tonight to take a 2-0 lead in the four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup final series.

title: Friday; ROCKLAND COUNTY FAIR
description: Every year for almost a century before World War II, Rockland County held a country fair and exposition. Now, for the first time in 43 years, that practice is resuming. Today through Sunday at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y., there will be events including a 1940's dance contest tonight at 7; a 4-H fair and horse show and an antique-car display, both tomorrow, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; a dog show, same hours Sunday, and a rodeo Sunday at 2. Exhibits on commerce and industry, health, culture and other subjects can be seen and ethnic foods consumed in the Field House. Crafts will be sold, and a farmers market and entertainment are also planned. Directions: (914) 786-3131. Admisision: $2.50 ($2 for over-65's, $1.25 for under-16's). TAP DANCING TO BACH

title: Yanks' Stars Failing in Clutch
description: The Yankees, with the heaviest payroll in sports for names such as Winfield, Guidry, Gossage and Nettles, woke up in last place in the American League East yesterday after another listless batting performance on Wednesday night when they dropped a 3-1 decision to the Texas Rangers.

title: 16 WOMEN OF SONG BRIGHTEN POP SCENE
description: IF springtime is a time for singing, New York is living up to its responsibilities this weekend. Singers of blues and ragtime, singers who use their voices as jazz instruments, singers of Kurt Weill, of Latin American art songs, of the repertories of Bessie Smith and Edith Piaf can all be heard over the next few days and nights in supper clubs, cabarets, college auditoriums and Central Park. In every case these singers are women, a coterie that includes Linda Hopkins, Martha Schlamme, Nancy Wilson, Sheila Jordan, Odetta, Carrie Smith, Janet Lawson and Nacha Guevara.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend effective last December.

title: 2 HURT AS GLASS FALLS FROM HOIST AT TRUMP TOWER
description: Two pedestrians were hurt yesterday, one critically, on Fifth Avenue near 56th Street when a piece of glass fell at about 2 P.M. from a construction hoist at the Trump Tower, the police said.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHRYSLER RETREATS ON WARRANTS
description: The Chrysler Corporation, responding to an outburst of criticism, said today that it was giving up its efforts to keep the Government from profiting on Chrysler stock that it has the right to purchase.

title: Sculpture and Suicide
description: It looked like a suicide to Brooklynites who saw the figure atop Fort Greene Park's 120-foot memorial column. The 88th Precinct switchboard was jammed with calls the morning of May 2, and 75 people were gathered at the tower when a Parks Department employee arrived with keys, to let the police climb up inside.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 5 on the mayoral pri mary in Gary, Ind., incompletely re called previous elections of black mayors. On Nov. 7, 1967 - the same day that Richard Hatcher was elected in Gary - Carl Stokes was elected the first black mayor of Cleveland, a much larger city.

title: A WATERMAN OF A DIFFERENT SORT
description: He wears suits with a European cut, weaves foreign expressions into his conversation, strides comfortably through the capital's most exclusive drawing rooms and smokes a pipe. William W. Warner is a waterman of a different sort.

title: 'BLUE THUNDER,' A HELICOPTER
description: JOHN BADHAM'S ''Blue Thunder,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, comes as close to being a big-screen video game as any movie this year. The popularity of video games being what it is, the movie's future doesn't appear to be in doubt.

title: Economic Scene; The Industrial Policy Issue
description: DOES the economics discipline really know what ails the economy and how to fix it? One sign that economics either may not have all the answers - or that people think it does not - is the attention being paid to proposals for a Federal policy to aid industry. The proposals start from the premise that traditional economics has failed to explain or to solve America's economic problems, and that more attention must be paid to policies that will compensate for weaknesses in America's business and labor institutions.

title: U.S. BACKS BIAS SUIT AGAINST BELL'S LAW FIRM
description: The Justice Department and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have urged the Supreme Court to rule that major law firms may not discriminate on the basis of sex in choosing partners.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
The camera that followed Eartha Kitt.
description: ''ALL BY MYSELF,'' a feature-length musical portrait of Eartha Kitt (at the Film Forum through next Tuesday), is the work of the film maker Christian Blackwood. ''Two years ago, I called Eartha,'' he says, ''and I said, 'I'd just like to follow you around and see what happens.' ''

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHURCH COUNCIL SEES PARADOX IN UNITY
description: The theological difficulties lying in the way of uniting Christian churches came into clearer view this week in a debate among the leaders of the National Council of Churches.

title: APPROVAL OF PACT DELAYED BY BEIRUT
description: A three-hour meeting of President Amin Gemayel's Cabinet ended this evening without the expected formal endorsement of the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement.

title: MOSCOW PREDICTS A MISSILE IMPASSE
description: The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda has rejected the possibility of combining American proposals with aspects of Yuri V. Andropov's latest offer to produce an accord on reducing medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: GIANTS BEAT REDS ON 2-HITTER
description: Mike Krukow pitched six hitless innings before giving way to a pinch hitter, and three San Francisco pitchers settled for a two-hitter and a 4-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Crossing Streets; Signed Off
description: A worm to the Department of Transportation for not doing enough to keep the city's streets well marked. Within living memory, street signs were one of New York's minor glories. They marked all four corners of every intersection. They showed in large letters the name or number of the thoroughfares they faced, and in small characters, neatly set off by a metal molding, the identification of the cross streets.

title: OPERA: 'THE MIKADO,' CHICAGO LYRIC COMPANY
description: Right off, you might have suspected that the Lyric Opera of Chicago's new production of ''The Mikado'' was going to be unusual. During the playing of the overture at last night's premiere, young ladies dressed as Northwest Orient stewardesses stood onstage and in the audience rhythmically miming the familiar airline drill with seat belts, oxygen masks and life vests. Suspicion deepened when the production, having landed in Japan, took us into a corporate boardroom behind which flashed signs advertising Sony, Canon, Toshiba, Fuji and that universal solvent Coca-Cola. The first number, ''If You Want to Know Who We Are,'' was sung by a chorus of executive clones, 20th-century ''gentlemen of Japan'' identically made up in black business suits, black glasses and black toupees.

title: SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $91,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $86,000.

title: DR. LESTER BREIDENBACH
description: Dr. Lester Breidenbach, director emeritus of emergency services and former attending surgeon at New York University Hospital, died of kidney failure Wednesday at the hospital.

title: KEY WITNESS IN BRINK'S TRIAL ASSERTS THAT HE TOLD 'TRUTH'
description: The prosecution's main witness in the Brink's trial completed his testimony yesterday by asserting that he had told ''the truth, as I remember it, to the best of my ability.''

title: COSTLY HARLEM HOUSING PLAN REVIVED
description: A proposed Harlem apartment complex that was cited five years ago as an example of runaway building costs in subsidized low- and moderate-income housing may be on the verge of construction. But it would still be one of the city's most expensive publicly financed housing developments.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: RANGER OIL LTD (CANADA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for year to Jan 30.
POP JAZZ
description: WHEN Marvin Hamlisch appears with a 90-piece orchestra at Queens College on Sunday afternoon, it will be the last local public appearance by the Broadway and Hollywood composer-entertainer for at least a year. The proceeds of the concert will go toward establishing a Marvin Hamlisch scholarship at the college's Aaron Copland School of Music. Mr. Hamlisch, who will be at the piano to play, sing and conduct his music from ''A Chorus Line,'' ''The Sting,'' ''The Way We Were'' and other familiar themes, will also be presented with the Queens College Medal, the institution's highest honor.

title: FORGERY INQUIRY AT BANK IS REPORTED
description: A Federal grand jury has opened an investigation into possible loan forgeries at banks formerly controlled by Jake F. Butcher, the east Tennessee businessman-politician, sources close to the proceeding said.

title: F.B.I. INQUIRY SEEKS TO LEARN HOW TIMES GOT SECRET PAPERS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying to discover how The New York Times obtained a top-secret National Security Council document on Administration strategy for preventing the ''proliferation of Cuba-model states'' in Central America, according to Federal officials.

title: Limit Put on Election Outlays
description: The Federal Election Commission said today that independent political committees could not spend more than $1,000 to support Presidential nominees, and a conservative group declared it would sue to overturn the ruling.

title: Cullinet Project With Anacomp
description: Anacomp Inc. and Cullinet Software said that they would jointly develop a new version of Anacomp's retail banking software, which is currently designed for banks with assets of $1 billion or more.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Found Increasing 4,000, to 473,000
description: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose slightly, to 473,000, in the last week in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Funds and Membership Sought in WNYC Drive
description: Live! From Zabar's! It's ''Morning Music'' over WNYC-AM, 840 on the dial, and FM, 94. The city-owned radio stations begin their ''Springfest'' membership and fund-raising drive tomorrow.

title: PUBLISHING: AUTHORS REBORN AT UNIVERSITY PRESSES
description: SEVERAL years ago Jerre Mangione was suffering from one of the worst fates that can befall an author: all 10 of his books, including his highly praised book about the Federal Writers Project, were out of print and available only from secondhand dealers. But Columbia University Press republished one of his books last year, it recently agreed to republish another next year, and the University of Pennsylania Press has agreed to republish two others. ''I feel as if I'm being reborn,'' the author said recently.

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Nabisco Aide Resigns
description: C. Richard Owens, chief financial officer of Nabisco Brands, has resigned ''to pursue other interests,'' the company announced yesterday. Nabisco Brands said it has not yet named a successor. Nabisco Brands was formed two years ago by a merger between Nabisco and Standard Brands, two large food companies.

title: Live TV of Races Proposed in Bill
description: A bill that would authorize live telecasts of New York horse races into offtrack-betting parlors, race tracks and new betting theaters was introduced in both houses of the State Legislature yesterday.

title: WORLD HEALTH AGENCY CONDEMNS ISRAEL OVER WEST BANK EPIDEMIC
description: The World Health Organization voted 65 to 17 today to condemn Israel over an epidemic in the occupied West Bank this spring.

title: K N ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company was formerly the Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company.

title: A Niche in Arizona
description: When the Yankees asked Dave LaRoche, the left-handed pitcher, to take a pay cut and start the season with their Columbus farm club while awaiting a possible call back to the majors, LaRoche, who had spent much of 1982 shuttling between Columbus and New York, decided he'd had enough of the commuting life. So he quit rather than return to the minor league team.

title: TRANSALTA UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-After a tax credit of $160,000, or 13 cents a share, and a charge of approximately $165,000 for start-up costs for new contract. c-After a tax credit of $82,000, or 7 cents a share. The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: REALTY PANEL SEES NO 'QUICK FIXES' FOR CITY'S GRIM RENTAL PROBLEM
description: The Real Estate Board of New York gave a mandate to its housing committee last year: Study the dimensions of the city's housing troubles and recommend to elected officials a realistic course of action to alleviate the problems over five to ten years.

title: OLD-NEW MIX IN WATER POLO TOURNEY
description: Gianni De Magistris was the goal-scoring star of the powerful Italian water polo team that won the world championship in 1978, finished second in the Olympics in 1976 and finished third in the world championships in 1975.

title: Books Of The Times
description: WHOSE LITTLE BOY ARE YOU? By Heywood Hale Broun. Illustrated. 215 pages. St. Martin's/Marek. $14.95.

title: LEBANESE, IN SYRIA, SEEKS TO PERSUADE ASSAD ON PULLOUT
description: Foreign Minister Elie Salem of Lebanon arrived here tonight in an effort to persuade Syria to drop its objections to the agreement on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon.

title: News Analysis
description: An emerging Congressional consensus on military aid to El Salvador, considered unlikely last winter, may provide more funds than the Reagan Administration could reasonably have expected. It would also tie more strings to the aid than critics had hoped to achieve.

title: Colts Sign Hinton
description: Chris Hinton, who had expressed displeasure with a deal that sent him, a 1983 No.1 draft choice of the Denver Broncos, to the Colts as part of the package for John Elway, the Colts' top choice, signed with Baltimore yesterday. Hinton, an outstanding offensive lineman from Northwestern, said yesterday of the trade, which had upset him when it was made last week: ''It's a business.

title: NORCEN ENERGY RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: First Boston Wins Revenue Bonds
description: First Boston won the competitive bid on $100 million in San Antonio electric and gas system revenue bonds.

title: Advertising; Israel Promoting Tourism
description: THE Israel Ministry of Tourism is more than tripling its advertising budget in the United States from last year, to $2.5 milllion, and may even add another $3 million to lure more American travelers and make up for the European falloff that followed the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: CACHE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Nicklaus Cards 66
description: Jack Nicklaus, helped by a shot that ricocheted off a woman's leg, shot 4-under-par 66 today to gain a share of the lead with Gary Hallberg and Joe Inman after one round of the Colonial National Invitation.

title: AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 22.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings for the latest quarter reflect a 10 percent stock dividend to be paid June 1.

title: 2 OF 5 OFFICERS FOUND GUILTY OF MURDER IN MOTEL BRAWL
description: Two police officers from the nearby city of Everett were convicted of second-degree murder today in a case stemming from a brawl in which a civilian was beaten to death and six others were injured.

title: Morton Gottlieb's 92 investors to get a try at 'Winning.'
description: QUESTION: What do one set, a handful of characters and 92 investors add up to? Answer: A Morton Gottlieb production. Mr. Gottlieb, who has already proved the wisdom of this formula with such hits as ''Sleuth'' and ''Same Time Next Year,'' will apply it to his next presentation, a new play by Bill C. Davis, the author of ''Mass Appeal.''

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U. S . Says P.L.O. Kept Some Fighters in Beirut
description: The State Department knew for more than six months, but did not disclose, that some armed Palestinian fighters remained in West Beirut in violation of the 1982 cease-fire accord, according to letters made public today.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock markets were closed for Ascension Day yesterday in Zurich, Brussels, Frankfurt, Amsterdam, Johannesburg and Paris. Tables for those exchanges do not appear in today's paper.

title: WATT TELLS HOUSE PANEL HE WILL CONTINUE SALE OF COAL LAND LEASES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today he would continue offering large tracts of Federal coal land to industry despite Congressional findings that a recent big sale of leases brought in far less than ''fair market value.''

title: Pepsico Fills Executive Post
description: Pepsico Inc. yesterday announced the promotion of D. Wayne Calloway to executive vice president and chief financial officer. He will replace Herman A. Schaefer, 62 years old, ''who after 25 years has decided to reduce his corporate commitments and pursue other business interests,'' the company said. Mr. Schaefer continues as a director and financial consultant.

title: GEOKINETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Polish Movie Makers Protest Wajda Dismissal
description: The colleagues of Andrzej Wajda, Poland's most distinguished movie maker, have protested his dismissal by the Ministry of Culture, calling it ''absurd'' and ''harmful'' to the nation's cultural life.

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MEDICAL GROUPS AIDING THE UNINSURED JOBLESS
description: Patricia Johnson, who is 41 years old and the divorced mother of one, has been out of work since March, when she lost her job at Western Electric's Norcross, Ga., plant. When she contracted bronchitis she did not go to a doctor because she needed her money for rent and food.

title: Loud Workout Before the Bell
description: With a little help, Mike Weaver, the former heavyweight champion of the World Boxing Association, is making some noise in his effort to regain the title from Michael Dokes, whom he meets a week from today in Las Vegas.

title: MANVILLE BID TO SPIN OFF NON-ASBESTOS ASSETS
description: The Manville Corporation yesterday made public a plan of reorganization that it wants to propose to its creditors - including thousands of claimants with asbestos-related diseases - if the parties involved in the company's bankruptcy negotiations do not reach agreement soon.

title: Officer Is Charged With Assault
description: A 10-year veteran of the New York City Police Department was charged yesterday with misconduct and assaulting a teen-age prisoner, authorities said.

title: LATIN AID: WHERE BILL STANDS
description: Military Aid to El Salvador - For the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the House Foreign Affairs Committee has approved $65 million, and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has approved $76.3 million. Action by the two houses of Congress is still to come.

title: Bridge: Deceptions Are Permitted If the Rules Are Followed
description: A century ago, Harvard's great president, Charles William Eliot, made this comment on a baseball star who had been benched because of low marks: ''He is no loss - why, they boasted of his making a feint to throw a ball in one direction and then throwing it in another.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BANK OF WASHINGTON (DC) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $286,282. The 1982 figures have been restated for discontinued operations and a tax benefit adjustment

title: LEONARD KAPLAN, SHIP PLANNER, DIES
description: Capt. Leonard Kaplan, a retired naval construction officer who supervised the building of some of the Navy's major warships and was later a naval architect in New York City, died of cancer last Thursday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Watchung, N.J.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago net reflects a change in accounting method for foreign currency translation. In the latest quarter a translation loss of $310,000 has not been included in net income but is being reported as an adjustment to equity.

title: LABRADOR MINING & EXPLORATION CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago figures included $2,033,000 in dividends from the Iron Ore Company of Canada. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Cho-liang Lin to Play
description: The violinist Cho-liang Lin will play Mozart, Beethoven, Stravinsky, Falla and Sarasate at the 92d Street Y tomorrow night at 8. Sandra Rivers will be the pianist. Tickets are $9 to $12.50, from the box office, 427-4410, or Chargit, 944-9300.

title: Labor Reappointment
description: President Reagan reappointed Janet L. Norwood today to a four-year term as the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the office that gathers and reports economic statistics, including the unemployment rate and the Consumer Price Index.

title: 'Executions' by Rebels In El Salvador Reported
description: The State Department said early today that Salvadoran guerrillas executed at least 16 of the prisoners they took Sunday when they seized a heavily fortified town in Cabanas Province and overran four small military posts in the hills around it.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ART: THREE SHOWS OPEN NEW BRONX MUSEUM
description: IT'S an odd, but by no means unhappy fate for a deconsecrated synagogue to become an art museum. That's the case with the former Young Israel Synagogue at 1040 Grand Concourse (165th Street) in the Bronx. Built in 1961 and sold by its dwindling congregation to the city last year, it's now the permanent home of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, which has settled in after a dozen years of camping out in the rotunda of the Bronx County Courthouse. And though the building has a way to go before its metamorphosis is complete, Luis Cancel, director of the Bronx Museum, and his staff have already installed three lively shows.

title: I.M.F. Appointment
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that its managing director, Jacques de Larosiere, has been appointed to serve another five-year term.

title: Cafe cuisines, new and classic.
description: THIS week's restaurants have much in common. Both are casual, intimate bistros that are reasonable options in their neighborhoods, and both just miss deserving two-star ratings. Cafe New Amsterdam, on the corner of West Fourth and West 12th Streets, is a handsome and romantic setting with more or less nouvelle cuisine specialties. Some of the house creations are delicious, but many tend to be oversweet, bland and somewhat in the tearoom tradition.

title: Comex Membership Bid
