description: The governors of New York's Commodities Exchange Inc. voted yesterday to create a separate membership category for options traders. Under the plan, which must be approved by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, options members would have floor privileges for the first time in gold options. Separately, the exchange applied for approval to begin trading in aluminum futures.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'The Real Reaganites'

title: Louisiana Land Tallying Votes
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company's proxy fight came to a subdued ending today at the company's annual meeting here, but the outcome will not be announced for a week or more.

title: GTE Telenet
description: The GTE Telenet Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, said today that it planned to distribute Texas Instruments Inc.'s model 707 portable terminal along with its own Telemail electronic mail and Minet medical information services.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXECUTIVES
description: * Cohu Inc., San Diego, has named James M. Brown president and general manager of the electronics division.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES ARE SWIFT UNDER ALVARADO
description: In the 11 days since Anthony J. Alvarado took over as Chancellor, the New York City school system's executive ranks have undergone swift changes. Five top staff members have resigned, four more are expected to resign soon and additional staff shifts are under way.

title: JONES GETS JOB DONE FOR 76ERS
description: In comparison with some of the National Basketball Association's bulkier forwards, Bobby Jones, the Philadelphia 76ers' sixth man, appears to be one of the least likely candidates to block a shot. At 6 feet 9 inches and 205 pounds, Jones looks frail. But the 76ers will carry a 2-0 lead in the Eastern Conference championship into Milwaukee tomorrow afternoon, and Jones is the major reason.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LETTER TO 3 SENATORS
description: Following are excerpts from a letter sent today by President Reagan to three members of the Senate dealing with his proposal to require the United States and the Soviet Union to remove two nuclear weapons for every new one that made. The rest of the letter repeated what the President wrote Wednesday to nine members of the House on arms control.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Seton Hall to Have Reagan as Speaker
description: President Reagan will deliver a commencement address at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., on Saturday, May 21, the White House announced today.

title: PRESIDIO OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated for an accounting change.

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: b-Including tax credits of $196,000 for the quarter and $1,023,000 for the year.

title: Ford's Chairman Expects Sales Rise
description: Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said that he expected a significant improvement in sales of new cars in the near future.

title: DRUNK DRIVERS' OFF-THE-RECORD DEATH TOLL
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Marathon
description: There will be a 10-hour jazz and swing marathon beginning Sunday at 3 P.M. at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, above 113th Street, to benefit WKCR-FM, the Columbia University radio station, 89.9 on the dial. The musicians will include former members of the Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Benny Goodman big bands, as well as such freelance musicians as the pianists Joe Albany and Walter Bishop Jr. and the trombonist Jimmy Knepper. The suggested contribution is $5; more information is available from (212) 280-5223.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Ann's Newstand

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Paper Profits
description: ''I was working at the exchange as a financial research manager,'' recalled Dr. Marcia J. Kramer, now research director of the American Stock Exchange, ''and wanted to simulate the trading-floor situation to get a good feel for how the market ran.''

title: PRISON'S FOOD SHUNNED AFTER AIDS VICTIM'S DEATH
description: Some inmates of the state prison in Auburn, N.Y., are refusing to eat meals or use utensils from the mess hall because they are afraid of contracting a deadly disease that breaks down the body's immunological defenses, prison authorities said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TORREZ SUFFERS HIS FIFTH LOSS
description: Manager George Bamberger said tonight that the Mets' most acute problem in a season of many problems was a lack of coordination: When the pitching was good, the hitting was weak; when the hitting was strong, the pitching was weak.

title: DAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
2 Fund-Raising Events To Be Held in Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn's Prospect Park will be the setting this weekend for two fund-raising events. Tomorrow at 10 A.M., a ''Movin' On-athon'' sponsored by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and Nathan's Famous will start, rain or shine, from the Park Circle entrance, at the merger of Parkside, Coney Island and Fort Hamilton Avenues and Prospect Park Southwest.

title: Cyclist's Goal
description: John Howard is ready to face another challenge. The 35-year-old California native set an American record of 475 miles last year in the Pepsi Challenge 24-Hour Bicycle Marathon in Central Park.

title: WOOLWORTH HAS PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it earned $1 million, or 1 cent a share, in the fiscal first quarter ended April 30. In the corresponding period of 1982, the company had a loss of $16 million.

title: 8 Tiffany Items Believed Stolen
description: Seven Tiffany lampshades and a Tiffany lamp base valued at $120,000 have been reported missing and are believed to have been stolen from the New York Historical Society, at Central Park West and 77th Street, the police and society officials said yesterday.

title: POP: SINGERS OF ROARING 20'S
description: THE examination of ''The Glory Days of Tin Pan Alley,'' which has occupied the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y this season, came to an appropriately slambang conclusion last weekend with an evocation of the Roaring Twenties.

title: RICHARD GERE IN 'BREATHLESS'
description: JESSE LUJACK (Richard Gere), a rootless young petty thief with a broken heart tattooed on his chest, has no past aside from a string of aliases. He has no future, either, except for some fuzzy dreams about going to Mexico, which, though he lives in Los Angeles, seems as far away as Chicago. The only thing all his own is a police record. He lives in a glittery world of neon and plastic, where everything is up for grabs and where everything is disposable, including himself.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I had the chance to tell him what I've heard from the people in Pennsylvania about arms control.

title: Many Runs, No Hits
description: Rita Condon and Madeline Moniz, of New Fairfield (Conn.) High School softball team, and Chris Greco, of nearby Brookfield, all pitched no-hit ball last week although the score may not have indicated it: Brookfield beat New Fairfield, 15-0.

title: CUOMO ATTACKS REAGAN ON ARMS AND AID FOR POOR
description: Governor Cuomo characterized the Reagan Administration's philosophy yesterday as ''make munitions and punish criminals - especially welfare cheats.'' He said this philosophy, coupled with ''acts aimed at undermining the Government of Israel,'' would offer voters in the 1984 Presidential campaign the clearest choice in 50 years.

title: CENTENNIAL MEMENTOS OF A BRIDGE
description: As everyone in New York surely knows by now, this month is the 100th anniversary of the opening of the first bridge linking Brooklyn to Manhattan.

title: D.H. LAWRENCE NOVEL 'SONS AND LOVERS' ON PBS
description: DH. LAWRENCE'S ''Sons and Lovers'' moves into public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' showcase Sunday on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., for a run of seven episodes. Like Lawrence and most of his work, the production is not easy to embrace, even though this was one of his more ''accessible'' novels.

title: Caveat Passing Up Preakness
description: The fastest starter and the fastest finisher among the 3-year-olds are out of the running May 21 for the Preakness Stakes. Strike Gold, the undefeated speedball who was held out of the Derby to be pointed for the Preakness, is going to wait a little longer before running with top company at longer distances. Caveat, who closed like a whirlwind to finish third behind Sunny's Halo in the Derby, is off his feed and scheduled for a long rest.

title: U.S. Confirms It Asked Soviet To Explain New Missile Test
description: Larry Speakes, White House deputy press secretary, confirmed today that the United States had asked the Soviet Union for an explanation of a missile test that appeared to be in violation of the 1979 accord on strategic arms reduction.

title: Seafirst Payout Is Put in Doubt
description: The Seafirst Corporation has been forced to dip into a $1.5 billion ''safety net'' credit line, because some holders of large certificates of deposit are not renewing them, the company's chairman said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issures

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-The company broke even for the latest first quarter including income from discontinued operations of $5,000. c-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $1,000.

title: SHULTZ MISSION SEEN AIDING REAGAN AMONG JEWS
description: For a politically sensitive White House, mending fences with important constituencies as it eyes the 1984 election, the Middle East diplomacy of Secretary of State George P. Shultz over the past two weeks has come as a timely boost.

title: New Study Needed For Grand Prix
description: An environmental-impact study must be made before a Grand Prix race can be held in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens in September, the city's Corporation Counsel, Frederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., said yesterday.

title: ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Salomon Says It's Boycotted
description: Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it had heard ''from various sources'' that it had been placed on the Arab boycott list, despite its past role in a number of financial deals with Arab banks.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $50,519. c-Includes a tax benefit of $16,919.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (CALIF) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday misidentified ownership of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange and incorrectly reported the cost of American Stock Exchange membership. The Cincinnati Exchange is owned by its members. An American Exchange seat last sold for $282,500.

title: U.N. TEAM TO INSPECT IRAN-IRAQ WAR DAMAGE
description: Acting on an Iranian proposal, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that he would send a mission to both Iraq and Iran to examine civilian areas damaged by their war.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEMS (DANISH CO) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JACOBS BID FOR KAISER REJECTED
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said today that its board of directors had rejected as ''inadequate'' an acquisition offer worth more than $255 million that was made by a group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs.

title: SCHOOL VOTING: A LONG COUNT BEGINS
description: In many ways, it seemed like a throwback to the old days - paper ballots, cardboard ballot boxes, candidates and their aides closely watching tally clerks spill the ballots from the boxes and start counting.

title: CONGRESSMAN FEARS FOR NUCLEAR PLANT SECURITY
description: The chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee has warned President Reagan that the national security is seriously threatened by the possibility that terrorists might slip by inadequate security forces to steal nuclear material or blow up Government nuclear production facilities.

title: JOHNSON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WOODS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HEAVY PLAY IN MARKET INDEXES
description: No new investment instruments have attracted so many investors in so short a time as stock-index futures and options. Nor have so many market analysts, brokers, professional and ordinary investors struggled so hard to understand their use.

title: 'NUDO,' FROM ITALY
description: NINO MANFREDI'S ''Nudo di Donna'' isn't the first film to tell the story of a wife who, dismayed by her husband's indifference, masquerades as a sexpot and becomes his glamorous mistress. It may be, however, the first film to present such a tale with this much suffocating fanciness, this many unwarranted allusions to paintings and this sort of mind-boggling attention to interior decoration.

title: HUDSON VALLEY RE-ENACTMENTS OF WARS AND PEACE
description: This is the weekend for nostalgia in the Hudson Valley - draft horses on farm fields, World War I airplanes in mock combat and a Revolutionary War ship sailing up the Hudson River.

title: DEPICTED CALIFORNIA IN DEPRESSION YEARS
description: John Fante, a novelist and Hollywood scenarist who chronicled the saga of a poet growing into professional and personal maturity in Los Angeles in the 1930's, died Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Country House in Woodland Hills. He was 74 years old and had been suffering from diabetes for several years.

title: BALLET: TWO WAYS OF DANCING 'GISELLE'
description: THE great ballet classics may seem fairly standard fare, but they are open to a variety of interpretations. American Ballet Theater presented casts that were poles apart in the matinee and evening performances of ''Giselle,'' the season's first, on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said its preferred ''A'' shareholders had defeated a motion to convert their preferred shares into common shares. The company's chairman, Victor Rice, has previously said the conversion is necessary to strengthen the company's balance sheet because preferred stock is sometimes viewed as debt. Several shareholders at today's meeting complained that the offer was undervalued because of the recent surge in Massey's common shares.

title: CONCERT: MARLBORO ENSEMBLE
description: THE final Music From Marlboro chamber concert of the season Monday night in Alice Tully Hall was atypical in that the performers were all young, with no one older than his early 30's; usually, the Marlboro people have sought to season their youngsters with one or two veterans. But the program was entirely typical in the quality with which we have come to associate the Marlboro brand name.

title: Market Place; Portfolio Sale Lifts G.& W.
description: IN the past three months, Gulf and Western Industries' stock has advanced about $9 a share. At the close yesterday, it stood at 26 5/8. The rise, analysts say, can be attributed in large part to the fact that G.& W. has been steadily selling substantial blocks of its prize stock portfolio. It has been using the money to reduce its huge debt.

title: 2 Watchmakers Plan to Merge
description: Switzerland's two biggest watch manufacturers, both plagued with heavy losses, plan to merge, according to a major shareholder in one of the companies.

title: THEODORE P. DALY
description: Theodore P. Daly, a specialist in maritime law and a former assistant general counsel to the Panama Canal Company, died Wednesday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 7-4
description: Seton Hall's starting right fielder, Pat Pacillo, pitched one and one-third innings of hitless relief and drove in three runs to lead the defending champion Pirates to a 7-4 victory over St. John's yesterday. The game was the second of an opening-round doubleheader of the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey regionals at St. John's.

title: A TV WRISTWATCH IS INTRODUCED BY SEIKO
description: The Seiko Time Corporation introduced its television wristwatch yesterday, the first to be formally offered for retail sale in this country.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Chief Operating Officer Appointed by Sheraton
description: John Kapioltas, who has been overseas with the Sheraton Corporation for more than 20 years, is coming home to be president and chief operating officer at its Boston headquarters.

title: JEWISH 'GENIUS' TELLS OF A CULTURE ENDURING
description: It started with an anecdote about a boy named Moishe growing up in Poland. He had convinced himself that the Jews had no future. ''My idea is that the best way for us is to assimilate,'' Moishe said to Isaac Bashevis Singer when the Nobel Prize-winning Yiddish writer was also a boy. ''Let's become Poles, goyim, not Jews.''

title: FRIDAY, MAY 13, 1983; The Economy
description: Businesses trimmed their inventories 1.1 percent in March, the biggest decline ever recorded, the Commerce Department reported. The reduction, to the lowest level in two years, came as sales increased a brisk 1.8 percent. This sent the inventory-to-sales ratio down to 1.45, also the lowest level in two years. (Page D1.)

title: ANOTHER REFORMER ENTERS THE RING
description: Everybody wants to reform boxing these days. In the wake of the ghastly trilogy of last fall -when Duk Koo Kim was killed, Alexis Arguello was pounded senseless, and Tex Cobb served as a punching bag on national television - there are now more reformers than fighters. And greatly needed, every one.

title: WITH NICARAGUAN REBELS: ROSARIES AND RIFLES
description: In the still of dawn on a road near the northern Nicaraguan town of Ocotal, two dozen well-armed men, women and boys who said they were anti-Sandinist guerrillas took up positions in the foliage.

title: PRAIRIE PRODUCING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The U.N. Today; May 13, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MASSTOR SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CHATHAM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Time for a Reckoning in Argentina
description: When the world notices the Argentine people, it is often to deplore their addiction to myths of national destiny. So let the world now take note of some salutary behavior: a sobered people is seeking the plain truth about the thousands who ''disappeared'' during the last seven years of military rule.

title: A BOULEVARD OF ETHNIC FOODS
description: If ethnic foods make your blood run hot, this should be a feverish weekend along Ninth Avenue. Stoking the flames will be the likes of Adela and Jack Talanga of La Milonga Restaurant at 51st Street, who turn out some of the meanest Argentine meat pies north of Buenos Aires; Sotirios Karamouzis at the International Grocery on 39th Street, who will be roasting stuffed quails, baby lamb and other Greek specialties, and the frying Esposito brothers, Tony, Teddy and Armand, sausage makers extraordinaire.

title: Article 162758 -- No Title
description: Motion-picture rights to the book ''Eleni,'' Nicholas Gage's account of the life and times of his mother, who was tortured and murdered by Communist guerrillas in a remote Greek mountain village after World War II, have been purchased for $850,000. The sum is said to be among the highest paid for a film property in years. Mr. Gage has been signed as co-producer of the film, which is expected to go into production early next year.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
Comings and Goings
description: Bruce Harper, the Jets' running back, has signed a new contract, leaving only two unsigned free-agent veterans, Chuck Ramsey, the punter, and Barry Bennett, a defensive lineman. ... Jay Saldi, the Dallas tight end from White Plains who has complained that he spent too much time on the Cowboys' bench, was traded to the Chicago Bears for an undisclosed draft choice. ... Reggie Theus, unhappy that the Chicago Bulls have refused his request to renegotiate his $300,000-ayear contract, which has three years to run, may ask to be traded. ... Gerald R. Ford and Arnold Palmer are among those who will participate in the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center pro-am golf tournament at the Meadow Brook Club on Long Island on May 27.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss after an after-tax gain of $5,000,000 from the repurchase of debentures for sinking fund requirements and an after-tax loss of $11,000,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in March 1983.

title: SHOREWOOD CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE FREE PRESS IN AFRICA: WALKING A NARROW LINE
description: A case involving a young Kenyan journalist said to have been threatened by the police because of his newsgathering activities illuminates some of the constraints on reporters in this continent, where the press is largely fettered by official controls.

title: 'LA BOUM,' A DOMESTIC FARCE
description: FOR American audiences, to whom French films once represented the ultimate in chic, it's going to be something of a shock to watch a Gallic comedy like Claude Pinoteau's ''Boum'' - one that takes its inspiration less from the great French films of yesteryear than from American television situation comedies. Not that ''La Boum'' isn't entertaining. In its pleasantly predictable way, it is. It's just that a French heroine who keeps a Muppet poster on her bedroom wall or who has the kind of madcap family that might ordinarily be found on a hit television series, seems to be something of a cultural hybrid. Her parents' good-natured philandering is the only recognizably French contribution to the formula.

title: Mary L. Monty Is Wed To Glenn Barry Levine
description: Mary L. Monty, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Monty of Port St. Lucie, Fla., was married yesterday to Glenn Barry Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Levine of Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Albert Sturmer of Scarsdale, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the couple's new home in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: ART: NEO-EXPRESSIONISTS OR NEO-SURREALISTS?
description: DESPITE Shakespeare to the contrary, there's a lot in a name. Cubism, Dada and Pop, for instance, not only sound like the movements they denote, but also describe them admirably. Even Abstract Expressionism, though contested as a label by some of its exponents, is accurate enough, but Neo-Expressionism is another matter. Aside from having the same makeshift ring as Post-Modernism, it's at best a misleading term for the still newish figurative revival.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Crossing Streets; Evening the Odds
description: ''The more fear of the law you put into the motorist's mind,'' Inspector Joseph Scutta of the Police Department's Highway District said recently, ''the less he'll violate the law.''

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NINTH AVE. COOKS UP 10TH FEAST OF NATIONS
description: THE city's biggest and most varied neighborhood block party, the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, celebrates its 10th birthday this weekend, and along with its vast milelong table of ethnic food tastes and smells ranging from Thai curries to Polish kielbasas, the event will make room this year for a few nongastronomic celebrations.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a reduction of $2,640,000 from the costing of inventories under the LIFO method. c-After a reduction of $2,585,000 from the costing of inventories under the LIFO method.

title: CENTRAL MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $10,217 on the disposition of assets.

title: IN SPIRIT OF SPRING: TWO ROMANTIC PARTIES
description: If it's spring and if you're going to give a spring dinner, dance, party or tea - as half of New York seemed intent on doing this week - then you had better keep within the spirit of the season. That means if the centerpieces are made of anything more high-tech than flowers, if the music is not Lester Lanin or a reasonably dreamy facsimile, and if your dress is fire-engine red sequins with hip wings, then you are off on the wrong foot.

title: ROBOTIC VISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divildend in December 1982.

title: Klezmer to Meet Jazz
description: The Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street (212-598-7150), will present ''Klezmer Meets Jazz'' tonight at 11:30, featuring the Kosher Kitschin, a group of klezmer revivalists and jazz players led by the musicologist, violinist, banjoist and guitarist Henry Sapoznik and the clarinetist Andy Statman. The program will explore the side-by-side development in the 1920's, 30's and 40's of two improvising traditions, jazz and Jewish klezmer music, the Eastern European dance music brought to the United States by immigrants. Tickets are $7.50.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary credit of $85,000 and the effect of a change in accounting of $118,000.

title: GUARANTY TRUST CO OF CANADA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PHILHARMONIC: ELGAR WORK
description: THE English critic Sir Donald Francis Tovey considered the ''Falstaff'' Symphonic Study (Op. 68) of his peer, Edward Elgar, to be ''one of the immeasurably great things in music,'' with a power ''identical with Shakespeare's.'' But when Andrew Davis conducted a rare performance of the work at the New York Philharmonic concert on Wednesday night, Sir Donald's usually judicious and acute perceptions seemed as distant from the work in question as Prince Hal was in birth from Falstaff.

title: HARRY R. MCCOMB
description: Harry R. McComb, retired manager of the New York office of Standard Brands, now Nabisco Brands, died Wednesday at Southern Ocean County Hospital in Manahawkin, N.J. He was 72 years old and lived in Barnegat, N.J.

title: Lendl Upset
description: Balazs Taroczy of Hungary upset top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, today and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $250,000 German Open tennis championships.

title: U.S. Exports to China
description: United States exports to China, hurt by sharply declining agricultural sales, dropped 26 percent in the first quarter of 1983, and the United States trade surplus plunged 61 percent from a year ago, the United States Embassy said today. The embassy said exports totaled $668.6 million, compared with $905.2 million in January-March 1982, while imports from China fell from $556.6 million, to $534.3 million. The surplus dropped from $348.6 million, to $134.3 million, the embassy said.

title: INSURERS ASSAILED ON SEX BIAS ISSUE
description: Chairmen of Congressional committees criticized the insurance industry today for reversing its position on proposed legislation to prohibit discrimination by sex in premiums and benefits.

title: ALTEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
description: b-Including a gain on the redemption of debentures of $37,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including gains of $28,000 for the quarter and $341,000 for the 6 months.

title: MX PLAN CLEARS ANOTHER HURDLE BY A 17-11 VOTE
description: The MX missile survived another test vote today as the Senate Appropriations Committee voted to approve the release of $625 million in development funds that Congress blocked last year.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
N.C.A.A. REBUFFED ON TV CONTRACT
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit today upheld a lower-court decision that broke the N.C.A.A.'s exclusive control of football television rights and cleared the way for colleges to negotiate their own television contracts.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ECONOMIC NEWS LIFTS RATES
description: Evidence that the economy is showing increased vigor dampened hopes yesterday that the Federal Reserve would stimulate credit creation soon by cutting its rate on loans to financial institutions. As a result, interest rates rose.

title: TENSOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Concerned at Ouster Of Christians by Saudis
description: The United States has expressed concern to Saudi Arabia over its expulsion of five members of a private Christian group, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: News Summary; Friday, May 13, 1983
description: International

title: N.F.L. in London
description: It won't be official until an escape clause expires on Sunday, but according to officials of the Minnesota Vikings the contract has been signed and it's a virtual certainty that the Vikings will be playing an exhibition game against the St. Louis Cardinals at London's Wembley Stadium on Aug. 6. ''We've told the players to get their passports,'' said the Vikings' general manager, Mike Lynn, in confirming arrangements for what would be the first National Football League game to be played in Europe. London promoters have been pushing for such a preseason game ever since an estimated 4.5 million Britons stayed up until 2:30 A.M. to watch a telecast of this year's Super Bowl.

title: SENATORS REJECT 2 SEPARATE PLANS FOR 1984 BUDGET
description: The Senate today rejected a Government budget for 1984 sponsored by the Republican leadership and backed by President Reagan. The vote was 52 to 48, with 7 Republicans joining 45 Democrats in rejecting the proposal.

title: WHEN TO PUBLICIZE SOVIET ARMS VIOLATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CENTRAL AMERICAN POLICY AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Yields Determined For St. Paul Bonds
description: A $142.9 million bond offering by the City of St. Paul was priced yesterday by Miller & Schroeder Municipals Inc., with yields on the serial issues ranging from 5.75 percent to 9 percent and bond yields ranging from 9.25 percent for the issue due in 2007 priced at par, to 9 percent for the issue due in 2012 priced at a discount.

title: Store Owner Slain
description: The owner of a cigar store at Broadway and 104th Street was shot to death yesterday in a robbery, the police said. The victim was 33-year-old Abdullah Al-Haj Saleh Abdullah, who lived at 1328 West Seventh Street in Brooklyn.

title: PUT THE FED UNDER THE PRESIDENT
description: Debate over whether Paul A. Volcker should be renominated as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board by President Reagan focuses on the wrong questions. The issue should not be Mr. Volcker personally, or his appointment by President Jimmy Carter or even his policy predilections. Rather, the issue should be focused on responsibility for public policy.

title: SIMKINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BIG WEEKEND IN CENTRAL PARK
description: There was once a time when New Yorkers had to travel to Hoboken or Staten Island for outdoor entertainment. And then, in 1858, the city acquired ''that beautiful Arcadia known as the Central Park,'' as a journalist of the time described it. The park was, he continued, ''a magnificent domain containing hundreds of broad acres of hill and valley, cliff and copse, lake and lawn, and miles upon miles of winding drives and winning walks, all radiant in a magic atmosphere of art and taste.''

title: BUOY LATIN DIPLOMACY
description: We are going to have to settle for a great deal less than victory in El Salvador. We would do better to start looking now for alternatives to military solutions in Central America. Perhaps the most promising is a stengthened Latin American initiative to end all external intervention and encourage separate negotiated solutions in each troubled country.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption accompanying the television listings on Wednesday incorrectly identified two scientists. They were Dr. Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, left, and Dr. Joseph Gold.

title: SMITH SEEKING BAN ON LUMLEY
description: On the offensive as always, Billy Smith, the Islanders' goaltender, tonight called for the suspension of Dave Lumley of the Edmonton Oilers following two last-minute skirmishes in the second game of the Stanley Cup final.

title: TWO REPORTED KILLED IN CHILEAN PROTEST
description: Two people were reported killed Wednesday and 200 arrested during a daylong ''national social protest'' called by union leaders against military rule.

title: Foote Cone Net Plunges
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications reported yesterday that its net income dropped 56.9 percent in the first quarter, to $603,000, or 21 cents a share, from $1.4 million, or 50 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues were down four-tenths of 1 percent, to $41.24 million, from $41.4 million.

title: AEICOR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $223,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $26,000.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SURPRISING PROFILE OF A JOURNALIST
description: The typical American journalist is a 32-year-old, white, married man who works for a newspaper and thinks he is middle of the road politically. He is getting paid $19,000 a year, and because of that he thinks he may have to find work in another field, even though he loves his job.

title: SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Article 162052 -- No Title
description: AN art feast valued in excess of $50 million awaits visitors to the exhibitions of Impressionist and 20th-century paintings, drawings and sculpture that are going on view this weekend - and which will be up for bidding next week - at New York's two major art auction houses, Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, and Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. Included are 15 Impressionist paintings collected by Henry O. and Louisine Elder Havemeyer at the turn of the century and not seen publicly in five decades. Also on view are more than a score of important works by Klee, Picasso, Munch, Matisse, Giacometti, Rivera, de Kooning, Kenneth Noland, Jasper Johns, Hans Hofmann, Morris Louis and other 20th-century masters.

title: VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a tax credit of $573,000 and the deduction of a nonrecurring preferred stock dividend of $650,000. c-Net loss.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SYRIANS MAY LEAVE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today on returning from Paris that he was ''very encouraged and optimistic'' about the prospects for withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon. He linked his optimism to talks he had in the French capital with Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister.

title: Regan Looking for a House
description: After living 39 of his nearly 53 years (this Saturday) in Buffalo, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has sold his home there and is house-hunting in northern Westchester County, midway between his Manhattan and Albany offices.

title: Driver Injured In Indy Accident
description: Bob Harkey suffered a broken neck, a broken collarbone, multiple rib and arm fractures and bruised lungs today when his Coyote racer brushed Mike Mosley's car and slammed against the fourth-turn wall during practice for the Indianapolis 500.

title: N.R.C. TO WEIGH LILCO PLAN FOR SHOREHAM EMERGENCIES
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it would consider an emergency evacuation plan proposed by the Long Island Lighting Company for its nuclear power plant in Shoreham, L.I.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corp.

title: INVENTORIES FALL 1.1%, A RECORD
description: Businesses trimmed their inventories 1.1 percent in March, the biggest drop the Government has ever recorded, the Commerce Department said today.

title: JOHN EDWARD HANRAHAN
description: John Edward Hanrahan, a patent lawyer with the American Cyanamid Company for 28 years, died last Saturday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Memorial for Anna Hoffman
description: A memorial service for Anna Rosenberg Hoffman will be held on May 23 at 2:30 P.M. at the Caspary Auditorium of the Rockefeller University, 1230 York Avenue, at 66th Street. Speakers will include former Gov. W. Averell Harriman, David Rockfeller, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner and Gen. Marshall Carter, president of the Marshall Research Foundation.

title: Suspect Charged In Jersey Slaying
description: James J. Koedatich, 34 years old, of Morristown has been charged by a Warren County grand jury with the kidnapping, aggravated sexual assault and murder last December of Dierdre O'Brien, 25, of Mendham Township, Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman announced today.

title: SENATE'S ROLL-CALL ON G.O.P. BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the Senate approved a notion to kill a 1984 budget containing small tax increases and large deficits that was proposed by the Senate's Republican leadership. A vote ''for'' was a vote to reject the budget, while a vote ''against'' was a vote to keep it alive.

title: THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JORY GRAHAM
description: Jory Graham, a columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times who inspired cancer patients with her syndicated column, died Wednesday after an eight-year bout with cancer.

title: INDIANA COMPROMISE ON EXCLUDING EVIDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pan Am and U.S. Accept Responsibility for Crash
description: In a move one lawyer called ''astounding,'' Pan American World Airways and the Government accepted blame today for a jet crash that killed 154 people last year in Kenner, La.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aladdin International Inc., Minneapolis, declared a 3-for-1 stock split, payable May 20.

title: COVETING JOBS, NORTHEAST PORTS WOO NUCLEAR FLEET
description: From their offices on the 68th floor of the World Trade Center, the people who run the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey can look out over the harbor toward the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, where the battleship Iowa was built and from which she steamed away in 1943.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $25,175 from discontinued operations. Year-ago sales have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FACE OF AMERICA

title: COAST MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COALITION URGES MORE ALL-DAY KINDERGARTENS
description: A coalition of parent and civic organizations that monitors the Board of Education's budget called on the city yesterday to increase next year's education budget so that the number of full-day kindergarten classes could be doubled and the size of first-grade classes reduced.

title: West Germany Maintains Lead
description: Hagen Stamm scored with 29 seconds remaining Thursday night, giving the West Germans a 9-8 victory over Italy and allowing them to retain first place in the FINA World Cup water-polo championships. In another fifth-round game, the United States held off the Netherlands, 7-6.

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Police Search Shop Of Hitler Diary Figure
description: Policemen investigating a purported link between a dealer in Nazi souvenirs and the forged Hitler diaries searched the man's shop today but said they found ''nothing significant.''

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Hermon D. Smith Dies at 83; Chairman of Insurance Firm
description: Hermon Dunlap Smith, retired president, chairman and chief executive officer of Marsh & McLennan Inc., the international insurance brokers, and chairman of the Field Foundation of Illinois, died Wednesday at Lake Forest, Ill., Hospital as a result of injuries suffered in a fall at his home in Lake Forest. He was 83 years old.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective last Dec. 30.

title: Georgia Goes On Without Walker
description: It was a shock, at first, to hear Coach Vince Dooley of Georgia say over the phone yesterday that none of his Bulldog players missed Herschel Walker during the recent spring football practice.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Goodyear Plans A New Blimp
description: A bit of Americana and one of the nation's most famous corporate mascots - the Goodyear blimp - will be updated to 20th-century standards, officials of the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation announced.

title: EASED F.B.I. CURBS TOUCH OFF DISPUTE
description: A dispute has developed between the Justice Department and the House Judiciary Committee over new guidelines on inquiries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into groups that try to ''achieve political or social change through violence.''

title: S.E.C. Panel Asks Curb On 'Golden Parachutes'
description: A special panel named by the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended yesterday that stockholders be consulted when a company makes provisions for lucrative severance payments, or ''golden parachutes,'' for its executives.

title: Folk Art as a Lure For High School Students
description: It was an unusual opening at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night - no dinner jackets, no champagne, just several hundred high school students wandering delightedly through the Greek galleries and the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing on the museum's main floor.

title: NBC WILL SHIFT 'MONITOR' IN FALL TO CHALLENGE '60 MINUTES'
description: NBC News is preparing an assault on television's most popular program, CBS's ''60 Minutes,'' next September. At that time, ''Monitor,'' the new NBC magazine program, will move to 7 P.M. on Sundays, the period that ''60 Minutes'' has dominated since 1975.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Comings and Goings
description: Ed Sherod of the Knicks underwent surgery for removal of cartilage from his right knee. ... Tom Heinsohn, the former coach of the Boston Celtics, will talk with the Houston Rockets this weekend about their vacant coaching position. ... Clyde Vaughan, the high-scoring Pitt basketball player, has been barred by the International Olympic Commiteee from competing for the United States in the Pan American Games in August because the English-born star is not expected to become a naturalized citizen until July. Olympic rules require a three-year wait before naturalized citizens can compete in international events. ... Don McMahon, the Indians' pitching coach, was admitted to Lutheran Medical Center in Cleveland yesterday to undergo test related to a heart condition. Team officials said a device McMahon was wearing to monitor his heart apparently revealed a problem.

title: SOVIET WARNED BY WEINBERGER ON THE MIDEAST
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger yesterday warned the Soviet Union and ''any proxies they may have in Syria'' that any aggression by them in the region would be met by ''a retaliatory force.''

title: PRODUCER PRICES FALL 0.1% MORE
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, which measures the prices of goods ready for sale to retailers, dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the Government reported today, continuing the nation's longest trend of falling prices since the 1960's.

title: ROTHKO PAINTINGS VANDALIZED
description: A vandal scratched Z-shaped marks on five paintings by Mark Rothko at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, officials said here today. The paintings, valued at $2 million, are on loan to the museum from the Mark Rothko Foundation in New York.

title: OFFICIALS WARN PUBLIC ON FRAUDS BY PHONE
description: Daniel Gulban doesn't remember how his life savings disappeared. He remembers the smooth voice of a salesman on the telephone. He remembers dreaming of a fortune in oil and silver futures. But to this day, the 81-year-old retired utility worker does not understand how swindlers convinced him to part with $18,000.

title: Post Wins, 5-4
description: Mike Alfano scored on a balk by the starting pitcher, Tim Mirabito, in the 10th inning to give C.W. Post a 5-4 victory over LeMoyne (15-6) in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II Northeast regional tournament today.

title: FACING PRESSURE OFF THE COURT
description: In Wednesday afternoon, three days before the deadline for his decision to remain at the University of Houston or leave for the financial security of professional basketball, Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, the 7-foot sophomore, was walking on campus when he spotted Lee McElroy, the athletic department's academic adviser.

title: Orioles 8, Rangers 1
description: Ken Singleton hit two home runs, and Storm Davis scattered eight hits in seven innings as the Orioles took sole possession of first place in the American League East. The victory put Baltimore one-half game ahead of the Boston Red Sox, whose game in Milwaukee was rained out.

title: ORLANDO SEEKS A HOME FOR GIFT ROCK
description: City officials are looking for an appropriate site to put a 12-ton marble monument recently received from their sister city in Taiwan, but the task is proving troublesome.

title: SYNCOR INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $39,000 for the quarter and $3,639,000 for the 6 months.

title: Your Money; Using a Car For Business
description: A CHANGE in the procedure for calculating automobile deductions made late last year by the Internal Revenue Service could have an important impact on individuals who use a car for business purposes.

title: TANO COR. reports earnings for qtr to April 17.
description: b-Net income.

title: Big Vote for Volcker
description: Big Business likes Paul A. Volcker - enough apparently to give him a near unamimous vote for another fiveyear term as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday on Hudson Valley activities gave an incorrect location for the re-creation of a meeting between George Washington and a British general. It takes place today at 1 P.M. at the DeWint House in Tappan, N.Y., on Oak Tree Road and Livingston Street.

title: DODGER FAN IS CALLED OFF BASE AND THE WALL
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GAF Session Ends
description: The annual meeting of GAF shareholders in New York reconvened for a short time yesterday and was adjourned until May 23, pending a count in the proxy battle for control of the company. The meeting had previously been adjourned until April 28. GAF has asked for more time to determine whether a dissident shareholder, Samuel Heyman, has title to his GAF shares.

title: PARIS CLASHES: BRAWLERS ARE BLAMED
description: The sporadic street skirmishes over the last three weeks that have resulted in dozens of injuries and hundreds of arrests in Paris are increasingly taking on the appearance of clashes between the police and young brawlers known to students here as ''the uncontrollables.''

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about pop singers gave an incorrect date for a concert by Odetta. It is tonight at 8 in Aaron Davis Hall, Convent Avenue and 134th Street.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including gains of $36,000 for the latest first quarter and $3.9 million for the year-ago first quarter on the sale of leaseholds.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COMCAST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
IRAQI SAID TO EXPECT PEACE MOVE
description: Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, was quoted here today as having said he thought the United States would soon move in the United Nations Security Council to seek an end to the Iraqi-Iranian war.

title: NETWORK SECURITY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Irsay After Elway
description: When John Elway, the new quarterback for the Denver Broncos, goes to Baltimore for the Colts' opening home game next fall, he'd better watch out. That's the word from the Colts' owner, Robert Irsay, who traded Elway after the former Stanford star rejected Baltimore.

title: NEW GARDEN CITY HOTEL AIMS FOR CARRIAGE TRADE
description: After the gracious century-old Garden City Hotel was torn down here in 1974, Myron Nelkin, a local developer, gave much thought to building a modern luxury hotel on the same spot that would again be the gathering point for business and society leaders.

title: 3 San Quentin Inmates Killed in Brawls
description: Three prisoners were killed in two outbreaks of fighting Thursday at San Quentin, prison officials said.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 9, 1982 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 14, 1983.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Wife of President Has Spots on Skin Removed
description: Since the removal of a malignant lesion above her lip last winter, Nancy Reagan has had a number of noncancerous spots on her skin removed ''purely as a precaution,'' a White House spokesman said today.

title: A Government That Would Sell the Sky
description: A few weeks ago the Administration announced it was going to sell the nation's four weather satellites to private industry. Instead of presenting a specific case for commercialization, it merely waved the flag of anti-Government ideology. The satellites ''would be better operated by the private sector,'' the White House asserted. ''The private sector is what made America great,'' explained the official in charge of the satellites.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DOW ADVANCES 4.35
description: Stock prices advanced broadly yesterday after a two-day slide, propelled by encouraging Government reports concerning inflation and the economy.

title: NELSON, THOMAS, INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SANITATION SITE IN QUEENS PARK BACKED BY CITY
description: The Board of Estimate agreed yesterday to ask the State Legislature to rezone several acres at one of two sites in Cunningham Park in Queens to make room for a Sanitation Department garage.

title: End the Bilingual Monopoly
description: ''Our political democracy rests on the conviction that each citizen should have the capacity to participate fully in our political life; to read newspapers, magazines, and books ... to express ideas and opinions ... and to vote thoughtfully - all activities that call for literacy in English.''

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. MOVES TO LOOSEN ITS TIES TO PRIBILOF ISLANDERS
description: Meetings scheduled for next week are expected to speed the end of a century-old relationship between the United States Government and the Aleuts who live on the Pribilof Islands, home of the Pacific fur seals. The relationship has been unusual; some call it shameful.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title:
PATENTS;
Type of Algae Produces A Useful Amino Acid
description: A certain type of algae, plants that grow in water, can be used to produce a useful amino acid that serves as medicine. Two patents on the process were granted this week to Richard I. Leavitt of Baton Rouge, La., and assigned to the Ethyl Corporation, Richmond.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sockers Capture M.I.S.L. Opener
description: Julie Veee had two goals and an assist, and Allen Mayer excelled in goal as the San Diego Sockers beat the Baltimore Blast, 6-0, in the opener of the Major Indoor Soccer League's championship series. The second game in the three-of-five series will be played Sunday at the San Diego Sports Arena, where the Sockers have won 17 straight.

title: 3 Injured in Crash Of Plane in Jersey
description: Three Pennsylvania residents were injured today when a small plane crashed near the Somerset Airport here, the police said. The plane crashed about 5 P.M. just short of the airport, a police dispatcher said.

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY & RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bids Made For Miami Thrift Unit
description: The Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association, the insolvent Miami thrift institution seized by Federal regulators on April 6, is almost certain to be acquired by an institution from outside the state.

title: News Analysis
description: The Soviet Union, with its daily fulminations against Secretary of State George P. Shultz's plan for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon, has again cast itself as a spoiler of the American peace initiative for the Middle East.

title: ILLINOIS SAYS WASTE WITH CYANIDE WAS ILLEGALLY STORED NEAR HOMES
description: The State of Illinois has filed a lawsuit charging several companies with illegally storing 16 million pounds of cyanide-contaminated waste at sites throughout Cook County and in Dixon, Ill.

title: Elizabeth Trippe, 79; Active in Social Work
description: Elizabeth Stettinius Trippe, a longtime social-service activist and the widow of Juan Terry Trippe, founder of Pan American World Airways, died Thursday in her Manhattan home after a brief illness. She was 79 years old.

title: COURT RULING APPEARS TO EASE NEWSPAPER BUSINESS MERGERS
description: A Federal appeals court decision has provided new guidelines that are expected to make it easier for a financially troubled newspaper to merge its business operations with a more successful competitor.

title: THE TOOTHBRUSH TEST
description: Judges, like the rest of us, are entitled to have bad days - those times when they are seized by dyspepsia, disgruntlement and other dysfunctions - but the State Court of Appeals had a whopper this week.

title: AN ADULTEROUS LOVE
description: IN THE PALOMAR ARMS, By Hilma Wo litzer. 307 pages. Farrar Straus & Gi roux. $14.95.

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock xchange. The year-ago results have been stated to reflect year-end adjustments.

title: Water-Polo Tie
description: West Germany was held to a 9-9 tie by the Netherlands tonight but retained first place in the FINA Water World Cup water-polo championships.

title: Brcic a Starter
description: David Brcic will start in goal for the Cosmos tomorrow when the North American Soccer League champions play host to the Tulsa Roughnecks. Coach Julio Mazzei said he decided to start Brcic rather than Hubert Birkenmeier, the league's top goalkeeper last season, because of the success Brcic had in the playoffs against Tulsa last year when Birkenmeier was sidelined with a hand injury.

title: U.S. Is Airlifting Equipment For Cruise Missile to England
description: The United States Air Force said today that it had begun airlifting equipment to England for its cruise missile base at Greenham Common.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,611,000 from discontinued operations and an accounting adjustment loss of $285,000.

title: Homeowners Sue In Contamination
description: A couple who moved into a tent in their yard because their home had been contaminated by a termite poison filed suit today seeking $20 million from the makers of the chemical, the distributor and the exterminator who applied it.

title: SUNSHINE-JR. STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 14, 1983
description: International

title: REAGAN EASES TOWARD SHIFT IN STAND ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: President Reagan has moved toward modifying his strategic arms proposal by subscribing to a principle that requires an immediate start on nuclear force reductions as new weapons are introduced, even before a final agreement on a new strategic arms treaty, Administration officials said today.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income after losses of $8,000 for the quarter and $24,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $445,000.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: Mother Wins Suit on TV Star
description: A jury awarded $5.9 million in damages today to a mother who was denied information about her son by the staff of the Phil Donahue show after a television appearance by his father, who abducted him in a custody dispute.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $32,443 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $87,485 from discontinued operations.

title: MAY 1-10 AUTO SALES UP 3.6%
description: The nation's three major auto makers reported today that sales in the first 10 days of May rose 3.6 percent from a strong selling period last year.

title: An Amateur Again
description: A decade after he gave up his amateur status to compete as a professional with the short-lived International Track Association, Jim Ryun, a former holder of the world record in the mile, has been formally reinstated as an amateur by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. The decision comes seven years after Ryun, now 37, retired from competition.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After tax credits of $70,000 for the latest quarter and $69,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: L.I.R.R. SELECTS 5 OF ITS STATIONS FOR ELIMINATION
description: The Long Island Rail Road ended weeks of speculation yesterday when it announced which stations between Hicksville and Ronkonkoma it plans to eliminate as part of the program to electrify a stretch of track now served by self-powered diesel trains.

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results are in U. S. dollars.

title: AN INFORMATION CAPITAL'S VITAL CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: WASTEFUL AND FUTILE 'SEARCH FOR THE TRUTH'
description: To the Editor:

title: Chacon Bout Is On
description: A California appeals court reinstated Sunday's nationally televised match between Bobby Chacon and Cornelius Boza-Edwards in Las Vegas, Nev. Presiding Judge Richard Schauer and Associate Justice Earl Johnson issued a stay of the injunction issued by Superior Court Judge Leon Savitch on Thursday that would have called off the scheduled 12-round non-title bout between Chacon, the World Boxing Council 130-pound champion, and Boza-Edwards, the former champion and current No.1 contender ... The World Boxing Association yesterday granted its lightweight champion, Ray Mancini, another 180 days, until Nov. 13, for a title defense against Kenny Bogner. The fight had been scheduled May 27 but was canceled when Mancini broke his collarbone in a training session in South Africa.

title: HOLLINGER ARGUS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes dividend from the Iron Ore Company of Canada of $6.4 million.

title: British Vote Campaign Gets Off to Angry Start
description: Parliament was dissolved today and the campaign for the June 9 general election officially began with angry statements from two party leaders.

title: BRIEFING
description: Cover Story

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to make it very clear to the Soviets and any proxies they may have in Syria that any aggression by them would be met by a retaliatory force that would make the aggression totally unworthwhile, totally lacking in any hope of gain to the aggressors.'' - Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger. (4:4.)

title: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $433,000. c-Including a credit of $213,000 resulting from a discount taken on the extinguishment of debt and a tax credit of $930,000.

title: 'HIDDEN' CON EDISON TAXES CRITICIZED
description: Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper said yesterday that he would review New York City's use of the Consolidated Edison Company to impose hidden taxes on New Yorkers.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $21,500 for the quarter and $79,100 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $242,200 from discontinued operations. The year-ago results have been restated.

title: REBUFF NOT FINAL, THE LEBANESE SAY
description: Despite Syria's formal rejection of the Israel-Lebanon withdrawal agreement, a senior Lebanese official said today that his Government did not regard the rejection as Syria's last word on the subject, and intended to continue discussions with Damascus.

title: Graniteville Bids On Its Own Stock
description: The Graniteville Company, in an effort to defeat the takeover attempt by Victor Posner's Southeastern Public Service Company, said that it was beginning a tender offer for up to 1.5 million shares of its own common stock at $17.50 a share in cash. The Graniteville, S.C., producer of heavyweight apparel fabrics said that should Southeastern obtain control, its offer would provide a greater number of its own shareholders with the opportunity to sell their stock for cash at the same $17.50-a-share price of the Southeastern offer.

title: ARMS STAND OF BISHOPS PRAISED
description: The National Council of Churches' Governing Board today praised the Roman Catholic bishops' pastoral letter condemning nuclear war.

title: OPERA: 'RAPPACCINI' OPENS
description: The success of Margaret Garwood's opera ''Rappaccini's Daughter,'' which is being given its premiere performances here by the Pennsylvania Opera Theater, is partly due to the impact of the story itself. Hawthorne's tale is so well suited to an operatic treatment that it is surprising, in fact, that it has not been attempted on this scale before.

title: No N.H.L. Review Of Officials' Calls
description: Brian O'Neill, the executive vice president of the National Hockey League, said today that he thinks no further punishment would result, or would be merited, from the slashing and spearing incidents that occurred Thursday night in the final minutes of the second game of the Stanley Cup final series.

title: YANKEES END LOSING STREAK
description: Two teams with lofty preseason expectations continued struggling at Yankee Stadium last night. Except the Yankees struggled a little less and defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-1.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TRANS WESTERN EXPLORATION reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $61,000 and pretax earnings of $3,800,000 representing the proceeds from the brokerage of leases in the Anadarko Basin. The year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: BALLET: NEW PAIRING IN 'GISELLE'
description: ''Giselle,'' that most poignant of ballet's 19th-century classics, worked its magic again on Thursday night when Gelsey Kirkland and Mikhail Baryshnikov took over its leading roles at American Ballet Theater's performance at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: A Threatened Institution: Caraway Seeds on Rye
description: Add caraway-seeded rye bread to the list of endangered staples of New York life, along with the egg cream. The seeds, diners report, have vanished from the rye bread at the Carnegie Deli on Seventh Avenue.

title:
Patents;
Growing Berlinite Crystals
description: A PROCESS for growing the berlinite crystals that are increasingly used in satellite communication systems and for other high-frequency applications has been invented by staff researchers for the Allied Corporation, Morristown, N.J.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus
description: Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus narrowed to $2.02 billion in April from a downward revised $2.03 billion in March, but was well above a $485 million surplus a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column yesterday gave an incorrect date for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center pro-am golf tournament. It is on Tuesday.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $13,612,000 from investments. c-After an investment loss of $1,147,000. The company does not report share earnings because its common stock is privately held. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: STERLING STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
DENVER SELECTED
description: The United States Football League, influenced largely by the city's climate and league-leading attendance, has chosen Denver as the host for the league's first championship game on Sunday, July 17.

title: CANNES, THE FESTIVAL OF FILM DEALS
description: For hundreds of people here, the business of the Cannes Film Festival is business. The festival itself, the score of movies showing every hour, the would-be starlets who disrobe on the beach - these are mere distractions for those who have come here to buy, sell, rent and trade movies.

title: SRC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LET HOMELESS YOUTHS HOLD ON TO HOPE
description: To the Editor:

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Dance Benefit June 8 To Aid Scholarships
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will perform with soloists from the Royal Danish Ballet and the New York City Ballet's Peter Martins in a benefit June 8 in Carnegie Hall.

title: RE-EDUCATING DRIVERS ON THE MEANING OF RED
description: Once upon a time, it was decreed throughout the land that when the traffic light turned yellow, the car should slow down. This was many years ago, when young people said ''sir'' and ''ma'am,'' when subway cars rarely smelled of marijuana, when there was no need to take out a loan to rent an apartment.

title: No Contest Plea Entered In Computer-Theft Case
description: An American businessman pleaded no contest today to charges that he conspired to sell computer secrets stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation to Japanese rival Hitachi Ltd., averting any trial in the controversial espionage case.

title: SAVING SWISS WATCHMAKERS
description: Plans to merge Switzerland's two biggest watchmakers, announced this week, reflect a last-ditch effort by Swiss banks to salvage the remains of an industry whose products were once among the country's most lucrative foreign exchange earners.

title: DEALER IN ROTHKO CASE MUST DONATE $100,000
description: One of the world's best-known art dealers, sentenced by a judge last January to promote art education in New York City public schools, has agreed to donate $100,000 to a scholarship fund and permit students to tour his Manhattan gallery, according to a court order released yesterday.

title: Coca-Cola Names Dr Pepper in Suit
description: The Coca-Cola Company filed suit in Federal court accusing the Dr Pepper Company of copying the patented design of Coca-Cola's new red vending machines.

title: PIRATES TOP METS ON EASLER HIT IN 9TH
description: The Mets took another step backward tonight as they lost their second consecutive game to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: Seton Hall Upset
description: Brian Brady drove in three runs with a bases-loaded double in the bottom of the third inning as New York Tech upset the defending champion, Seton Hall, 5-2, yesterday in the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey Division I Regional playoffs at St. John's in Jamaica, Queens. New York Tech (22-6) remained the only team that has not lost in the double-elimination tournament. Seton Hall and St. John's will play in the opener of a doubleheader today, with the winner advancing to the final against Tech.

title: Turkish Amnesia
description: ''Read Toynbee,'' a Turkish visitor urged, ''read his mea culpa.'' He was protesting a comment in this space on the murder of Turkey's Armenian community in 1915. My visitor insisted I had it all wrong. It was really a civil war within a world war, and talk of genocide was a gross exaggeration that only encourages an ugly band of Armenian terrorists.

title: Man Hit by Glass Is Reported Better
description: A pedestrian critically injured Thursday by a piece of falling glass from the Trump Tower was improving yesterday at Bellevue Hospital.

title: PLACE GAS & OIL CO LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After $12,458 gain on sale of investments. The year-ago results have been restated.

title: Index; International
description: Along the Amazon, barges bustle by backwaters 2 Reagan is said to be modifying his strategic arms proposal 3 Paris street clashes: Young brawlers blamed 3 Skepticism expressed on new Lin Biao book 3 Lebanon says Syria's rejection is not Damascus' final word 4 Around the World 5 Government/Politics U.S. moves to reduce its supervi- sion of Pribilof Islands 7 Official says city imposes taxes on consumers through Con Ed 27 Washington Talk Briefing 8 It's politics and tennis, not poker, in Washington 8 Education/Welfare Coalition urges more full-day kin- dergarten classes 24 Arts/Entertainment Cannes, a festival of film deals 14 The City Ballet gives world pre- miere of ''Glass Pieces'' 14 Kaze-No-Ko, a Tokyo theater group, heading for New York 17 NBC to put ''Monitor'' against ''60 Minutes'' 48 Style Consumer Saturday 12 De Gustibus 12 Officials warn public on frauds by phone 12 Obituaries Shuji Terayama, Japanese au- thor and film maker 10 Sports Pages Yanks beat White Sox, 3-1 19 Pirates down Mets, 2-1 19 Dave Anderson on the tarnished Stanley Cup 20 News Analysis John F. Burns on the Soviet role in the Middle East 4 Nathaniel Sheppard Jr. on the stakes of Chicago politics 7 Features/Notes About New York 1 Saturday News Quiz 16 Going Out Guide 17 Sports People 21 New York Day by Day 26 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Cessna's Navy Contract
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company said today that it had received a $160 million contract from the Navy for its training system, which includes a modified version of its Citation II business jet. The Navy will require 15 aircraft. Delivery of the first is scheduled for Aug. 1, 1984.

title: TOKYO'S KAZE-NO-KO TO PLAY IN NEW YORK
description: As a child, the Japanese theater director Yukio Sekiya liked to play with matches. But instead of lighting fires, he entertained friends by fashioning matches into stick-figures that seemed to come to life.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $24,100,000 from the sale of holdings in Avnet Inc. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,800,000.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: PROGRAMS UNLIMITED reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
UTILITY WARNS OF DEFAULT
description: The builder of two terminated nuclear power plant units in Washington State warned today that it was likely to default on $15.6 million in interest payments due to holders of bonds issued to finance construction of the units.

title: New President of Yugoslavia
description: Mika Spiljak became President of Yugoslavia today, succeeding Petar Stambolic, who ended his one-year term as head of the nine-member collective state presidency.

title: 33 Years on the Bench Honored in a Professorship
description: Judge Edward Weinfeld, 88 years old as of today, has won devotion as well as respect during his 33 years on the bench in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Latin Talks: Opposing Views
description: El Salvador's political and military opposition has called repeatedly since October for ''direct dialogue without prior conditions'' with the Government as the best way to end the threeand-a-half-year-old guerrilla war there.

title: PAGE PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CITIES IN TEXAS WITNESS FLOWERING OF FINE ARTS
description: To attract a following when he first took over the Houston Ballet seven years ago, Ben Stevenson had to program plenty of staid classical ballet to satisfy Houston's decidedly unadventurous audiences. But today the troupe offers many a daring modern piece, like Mr. Stevenson's own creation, ''Zheng Ban Qiao,'' winning critical acclaim here, in New York and in Europe.

title: VIKING FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

PATENTS;
Process Is Devised To Make Nuclear Fuel
description: A method of producing nuclear fuel was patented this week for the Department of Energy, and licenses will be available to interested American companies. The process is chiefly concerned with creation of the pellets that are loaded into the fuel rods.

title: F.B.I. IS SEEKING TERRORIST GROUP FOR 2 BOMBINGS
description: Explosions Thursday night and early yesterday at military reserve centers in Nassau County and in Queens were the work of a terrorist group that is believed responsible for three other bombings since last December, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $208,000 and a credit of $125,000.

title: MRS. ASTOR TURNS PHILANTHROPIC WORK TO LIBRARY
description: Brooke Astor, one of New York City's most active philanthropists for the past quarter-century and a longtime trustee of many of its leading institutions, has resigned from most of the boards on which she has served to devote herself to the New York Public Library.

title: AMERICAN MEDI-DENT reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DON'T MAKE LANGUAGE-MINORITY CHILDREN 'SINK OR SWIM'
description: To the Editor:

title: A GROUP OF LATIN OBSERVERS TO INSPECT COSTA RICA BORDER
description: The Foreign Ministers of Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama agreed today to send civilian observers to Costa Rica to inspect its border with Nicaragua.

title: 20TH CENTURY BEGINS TO INTRUDE ON SLEEPY AMAZON
description: In the small Amazon River town of Parintins, you can exchange goods at the wharf with the traditional itinerant river hucksters known as ''regatoes'' who offer guitars and funeral wreaths and nails and health powders made from the leaves of a local plant. You can also dial New York directly.

title: SALVADOR CHIEFS ARE DISPLEASED OVER AID CURBS
description: Salvadoran political leaders say they are disturbed and bewildered by the discussions in Washington over how much aid their country should receive and what their Government must do to receive any aid at all.

title: TRIBUTE TO CORRUPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MAURICE I. RAPPAPORT
description: Maurice I. Rappaport, a lawyer who had been a Municipal Court justice on Staten Island before his retirement in 1975, died Tuesday in John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla., where he had been living. He was 84 years old.

title: BALLET: WORLD PREMIERE, ROBBINS'S 'GLASS PIECES'
description: ''Glass Pieces,'' with music by Philip Glass and choreography by Jerome Robbins, is unlike any work the New York City Ballet has ever had in its repertory. At its world premiere Thursday night in the State Theater, Mr. Robbins succeeded in taking ballet into a brave new world.

title: GIVENCHY OPENS FALL FUR SHOWINGS
description: Hubert de Givenchy is a leader of the quiet elegance school of dressing, also known as the couture look. The fur collection he designed for Revillon and presented Thursday afternoon in his Madison Avenue boutique was quite in character with its emphasis on the simple luxury of mink, sable, fisher and fox. It was the beginning of more than a week of intensive showings of fur collections for fall and winter.

title: Rule on Comments On Indian Point
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the public had until May 23 to issue written comments on the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income after a loss of $209,000 from tinued operations. Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Northeast Petroleum Industries since the date of acquisition, Feb. 28, 1983.

title: Bridge:; Rally by Berkowitz Team Garners the Cavendish Cup
description: The first Cavendish Cup teams' championship was won in come-frombehind style here early Friday morning by David Berkowitz, Secaucus, N.J.; Harold Lilie and John Solodar of New York; Bart Bramley of Avon, Conn., and Rich Friesner of Austin, Tex. They scored 264 out of a possible 420 victory points in the four-day Swiss teams event played for the benefit of the Children's Cancer Fund of America.

title: U.N. Calls on Turkey To Pull Out of Cyprus
description: The General Assembly called on Turkey today to pull its forces out of Cyprus.

title: HIGH LEVELS OF DIOXIN REPORTED AT A TRAILER PARK IN MISSOURI
description: A trailer park occupied by 28 families has nearly four times the level of dioxin found in the evacuated town of Times Beach, Federal officials announced today.

title: WEDGESTONE REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TOCOM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Violence and the Tarnished Stanley Cup
description: Just when the Stanley Cup final had raised itself to a new level of artistic attraction, hockey tripped over two sticks one swung as if it were a scythe by the goaltender Billy Smith of the Islanders atW ayne Gretzky, the other thrust as if it were a bayonet at Billy S mith by Dave Lumley of the Edmonton Oilers in retaliation.

title: FOUR FOUND GUILTY OF PLOTTING TO SMUGGLE ARMS FOR THE I.R.A.
description: Four men were convicted here yesterday of plotting to smuggle guns, explosives and surface-to-air missiles to the Provisional Irish Republican Army, the outlawed group battling British rule in Northern Ireland.

title: THE ODDS AGAINST GETTING A GOOD STRIPED BASS
description: Although striped bass is one of my favorite fish, I have virtually given up eating it. That was not an easy decision, for this snowy and meaty fish with its delicately sweet flavor lends itself to many wonderful preparations.
