In summer, cold poached bass with herbed mayonnaise and cucumber salad makes an elegantly restorative main course. And it is almost as good when broiled, baked with lemon juice, white wine, onion and parsley, or simmered in an Italian brodetto, a tomato and garlic broth usually accented by steamed clams and mussels.

title: Ryan's Contract Extended 2 Years
description: Nolan Ryan, the career major league strikeout leader with 3,521, signed a two-year extension of his contract with Houston before the game tonight against the Atlanta Braves, Astros' officials announced.

title: WINCORP REALTY GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Wincorp Realty Investments Inc. and Western Harness Racing Inc. have paired capital shares.

title: A Fair View of Executions
description: The futile search for simultaneously fair, humane and expeditious executions continues. But a hint that the futility is dawning on the Supreme Court comes from Justice Lewis Powell. He told southern Federal judges recently that executions were so fraught with tension, delay and last-hour histrionics that if the process couldn't be speeded up, the states should abolish capital punishment.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Megaturn Waits
description: What do you do if you're training an unbeaten 3-year-old colt who's probably ready to take on the best in the land in the Preakness Stakes but acts as if he needs some more seasoning? If you're Richard Nieminski, who has such a colt in Megaturn, you change your mind a lot.

title: CARVING THE GARGOYLES OF A CATHEDRAL
description: In the four years since work resumed on the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, more than 3,300 blocks of Indiana limestone have been cut, each hand-finished with a boasting chisel.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings give retroactive effect to a 1-for-1 stock distribution made on April 26, 1983.

title: News Analysis
description: At the heart of the bitter City Council reorganization battle between Mayor Harold Washington and a group of insurgent Democratic aldermen are the issues of money and power.

title: EXECUTIVES SEE PROFITS UP IN A SPOTTY RECOVERY
description: The chairmen of most of the nation's biggest companies, meeting here for recreation and talks with senior Government officials, said today that they see a spotty recovery for the economy in general but a strong rebound in the area that affects them most - corporate profits.

title: First Jersey Corp.
description: Officers of the First Jersey National Corporation and the Guarantee Bancorp Inc. announced additional terms of the agreement in principle under which First Jersey would acquire Guarantee in a transaction valued at about $37 million. The additonal terms would give Guarantee shareholders, other than those receiving a mandatory cash payment, additional consideration in the form of cash or First Jersey adjustable rate preferred stock, at Guarantee's option, proportinate to the amount by which the average price of First Jersey common stock during the valuation period comes to less than $22 but not less than $19. If the First Jersey common stock average valuation price is less than $19, Guarantee will have the right to withdraw the merger offer.

title: Thais Say Hanoi Sent New Forces to Cambodia
description: Vietnam sent 2,000 more troops into southern Cambodia early this month, the day after it announced a partial troop withdrawal from the country, Thailand's security chief said today.

title: CANADA DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bobby Wadkins Up by 1 on 64-132
description: Bobby Wadkins shot a 6-under-par 64 today and took a one-stroke lead after two rounds of the $400,000 Colonial National Invitation.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NAMING OF DRUGS IS NO EASY TASK
description: Dyazide probably won't kill weeds. Zantac never appeared as an alien invader on ''Star Trek.'' And ''Mylanta!'' is not what Scarlett O'Hara exclaimed when she saw her favorite Georgia city in flames.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New Israeli Army Chief Eases West Bank Policy
description: The new Israeli Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Moshe Levy, has issued new orders on the treatment of Arabs in occupied territories, softening the strong-arm policy of his predecessor, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, army officers said today.

title: FOR NURSERIES, SPRING IS MORE THAN A SEASON
description: For Fred Hicks, springtime is harvest time. While customers pack his store buying seed, fertilizer and garden tools for the spring planting season, Mr. Hicks, president of Hicks Nurseries, Westbury, L.I., reaps the benefits of months of preparation aimed at five or six weekends in April, May and June.

title: E.P.A. STREAMLINES CLEANUP PROGRAM
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today outlined a series of what it described as ''far-reaching changes'' of policy and management practices for its hazardous waste programs.

title: Mixed Reviews
description: Few issues are more hotly debated among Met fans than the question whether Dave Kingman's assets to the team outweigh some fairly obvious liabilities. Kingman continues to hit for power, but is batting only .191, with 23 strikeouts and 31 men left on base. His team has won only 9 of 29 games and is in last place.

title: A WATERGATE BURGLAR IS PARDONED
description: President Reagan pardoned Eugenio R. Martinez for his part in the burglary of the Democratic Party's headquarters in the Watergate building in 1972, an Administration official said today.

title: Everett B. Yelton of Du Pont; Helped in Developing Teflon
description: Everett B. Yelton, a leader in the development of Teflon and other plastics in a career of more than 40 years with E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in West Chester, Pa. He was 64 years old.

title: LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
OPTIMUM HOLDING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT ROSE 2.1% IN APRIL, THE MOST SINCE '75
description: Industrial production jumped 2.1 percent in April, the largest increase in almost eight years, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STANDARD-BRED PACERS & TROTTERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $36,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $86,000.

title: THE NO. 2 GAME: TENNIS EVERYONE?
description: Politics is the big game in Washington, but tennis seems to be running a close second. More and more of the capital's diplomatic and political business is being conducted in whites.

title: Carter's Sister Faces Cancer
description: Ruth Carter Stapleton, the 53-year-old evangelist sister of former President Carter, is shunning conventional treatment in favor of faith, diet and excercise as she battles cancer of the pancreas. ''Due to the nature of my illness, I don't have a choice,'' she said. ''It would be different if I had a different type of cancer that could be cut out or treated with a great chance of healing.''

title: Swiss Prices Up in April
description: Wholesale prices in Switzerland in April rose five-tenths of 1 percent from March and were up two-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The year-to-year increase was up slightly from one-tenth of 1 percent in March.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 14, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Training a Seal To Return to the Sea
description: At the New York Aquarium at Coney Island, a young harbor seal named Rocky has been doing well on her formula, a puree of raw mackerel and herring, heavy cream, antibiotics and vitamin and mineral supplements. She laps up three pounds of it a day.

title: WILSHIRE OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $1,420,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $1,393,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CENTRAL TRUST CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $439,000 on loans and the sale of investments. c-After a loss of $153,000 on loans and the sale of investments and income of $559,000 from equity investment.

title: Herbert Benjamin, 85, Leader Of U.S. Communists in 30's
description: Herbert Benjamin, a leader of the American Communist Party in the 1930's who later broke with the party and became a merchant in Washington, died Tuesday of a heart ailment at the Hebrew Home in Rockville, Md. He was 85 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Lakers Defeat Spurs
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored 26 points, and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 25 tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 113-100 victory over the San Antonio Spurs and a 2-1 lead in their Western Conference championship series.

title: A.B.T. Cast Changes
description: American Ballet Theater has announced that Susan Jaffe will replace Gelsey Kirkland in George Balanchine's ''Bourree Fantasque'' Monday and Tuesday in the Metropolitan Opera House. Clark Tippet will replace Kevin McKenzie in ''Interludes'' on Tuesday.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a charge of $2,000,000 related to changes in distribution and a gain of $1,300,000, or 27 cents a share, from the sale of a broiler business.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PREMIER TRUST CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DOUBT EXPRESSED ON LIN BIAO BOOK
description: Experts are expressing skepticism about a new book, purportedly smuggled out of China, that asserts that Lin Biao, a Chinese Defense Minister, was ordered assassinated by Mao Zedong and that many important aspects of the case have been covered up.

title: FLORIDA BANK MERGER TERMS ARE SET
description: Two of Florida's largest bank holding companies, Sun Banks Inc. and Flagship Bank Inc., today announced a ''mutual understanding'' providing for Orlando-based Sun to acquire Flagship for approximately $334 million in cash and Sun stock.

title: SHUJI TERAYAMA, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES
description: Shuji Terayama, a Japanese avant-garde poet, playwright and film maker, died of nephritis in Tokyo on May 4. He was 47 years old. One of his country's more prolific artists, Mr. Terayama received a number of honors for his plays and other works in Europe and at home. His works were performed only sporadically in the United States, notably Off Broadway.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $109,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: F.C.C. Moves to Repeal Curb on Editorializing
description: The Federal Communications Commission has moved to repeal its rules limiting personal attacks and editorializing on the air, concluding that the rules stifle public debate.

title: S & K PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Strike Gold Wins 4th Straight Race
description: Strike Gold, the brilliantly fast 3-year-old who has been held out of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness because of his inexperience, won his fourth race without a defeat at Aqueduct yesterday with a neck victory over older horses.

title: ROBBERS GET $1.5 MILLION IN GEMS
description: Two men wearing stocking masks rushed up behind a jewel importer as he was opening his office in the diamond district yesterday morning and forced him, at gunpoint, to give them $1.5 million in diamonds, emeralds and rubies from his safe, the police said.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: The year-ago results include the 50 percent pro-rated earnings of the company's affiliate, Welmoore Industries, which are accounted for under the equity method. On Oct. 21, 1982, Welmoore Industries commenced operations as a manufacturer and distributor of commercial food service equipment following the acquisition of the businesses of four subsidiaries of the Sunbeam Corp.

title: A BALM IN AMIDON
description: The Secretary did not undertake a two-week mission to North Dakota; hence there was no reason for him to fly back to Washington and assure the President he was confident of success. For this reason the Secretary did not do so.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $4.2 BILLION
description: Interest rates rose sharply late yesterday after the Federal Reserve announced a much-larger-than-expected $4.2 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended May 4.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or prespective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $90,000 for the 9 months.

title: Drexler Will Turn Pro
description: Clyde Drexler, Houston's star junior forward, decided today to leave the university and declare himself eligible for the National Basketball Association's draft next month. The move came only a day before the N.B.A. deadline for such a decision.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: VW and Insurer File Lawsuit
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. and its insurance company have filed a $2.16 million lawsuit against two manufacturers for damages caused when a cloud of hydrochloric acid drifted over the auto maker's South Charleston, W.Va., stamping plant.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-After a loss of $32,000 from discontinued operations. c-After income of $71,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect sales of certain subsidiaries and other assets.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WATERMAN MARINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Parade in Norfolk, Va., Protests Busing Decision
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson led more than 6,000 demonstrators in a peaceful march through downtown Norfolk today to protest the school board's plan to stop busing elementary school students to achieve integration.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Soviet Activist Gets Visa
description: Sergei Batrovin, a founder of an independent antinuclear group that the authorities have tried to crush, received an exit visa today and plans to leave the Soviet Union with his wife and baby, his friends reported. The 26-year-old Mr. Batrovin, his 25-year-old wife, Natasha, and their 13-month-old daughter will go to Vienna on May 20, the friends said.

title: POLLOCK PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HAT REPAIR: CLEANING, BLOCKING
description: IN the opinion of Ann Albrizio, who has been in business 30 years a s Albrizio Inc., there aren't enough hat cleaners and blockers a round to cope with a demand that is constantly increasing, so she h as set about teaching what until recently was, in her words, ''a l ost art.'' These days, her students at the Fashion Institute of T echnology learn to make, clean and block hats. ''And,'' she says, ' 'they are enthused about the resurgence in hats.''

title: Indy Driver Hurt
description: John Paul Jr., a driver preparing for his first Indianapolis 500, suffered a fractured left ankle today when his Penske PC-10 skidded out of control and hit the concrete wall in the first turn at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Paul, whose right leg was also bruised, underwent surgery at Methodist Hospital to repair the fracture.

title: Transit Officer Wounded
description: A 23-year-old Transit Police officer, Rafael Miranda, was lightly wounded in the leg with his own gun last night during a struggle while issuing summonses to two men and a woman on a southbound No. 2 train on the IRT Seventh Avenue line, the police said. All three people, who were not identified, were arrested.

title: Clevepak Link To Interpace Near
description: The Clevepak Corporation and the Interpace Corporation said their boards had approved an agreement under which Clevepak will acquire Interpace, a building products company, for about $150 million in cash and stock.

title: WOMEN GOT NO 'RAW DEAL' FROM THE G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW U.S. LAW WOULD ALTER RULES ON WESTWAY TRADE-IN
description: Recent Federal legislation has changed the procedures and circumstances for a possible trade-in of funds for the Westway project, according to Reagan Administration officials and lawmakers.

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect the recent sale of most of the properties owned by the company's U.S. subsidiary. The sale is expected to close next month. The company is listed on the Pacific, Boston, Philadelphia, Montreal, and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: FGI INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: TO FULFILL A 35-YEAR MIDEAST PRINCIPLE
description: Today, with Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces taking aim at the Israeli-Lebanese pullout agreement, with President Reagan's peace plan on the shelf, and with a frozen Israeli relationship with Egypt, it's worth looking back to history to note that from the outset - the creation of Israel 35 years ago - the idea of peace and justice for Israel was related to peace and justice for all peoples in the region.

title: U.S. Judge Charles R. Scott; Ruled on Busing and Prisons
description: Federal District Judge Charles R. Scott, known for his rulings in the areas of prison reform and busing to achieve integration in public schools, died Thursday at Memorial Medical Center here. He was 79 years old.

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
CALIFORNIA INDIAN RESERVATION PLAGUED BY VIOLENCE IN 10-YEAR FEUD
description: Fear and tension have gripped residents of the Soboda Indian Reservation in the wake of the latest outbreaks in a 10-year pattern of violence in which five people have been killed, apparently as a result of a complex blood feud.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 10 percent stock dividend payable June 12.

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BLUE CROSS SAYS COST CONTROL CUTS ADMISSIONS TO HOSPITALS
description: The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, which provides health insurance for 80 million Americans, says there has been a steady decline in the rate of hospital admissions for its subscribers in the last 13 years.

title: CLINCH RIVER REACTOR - AX IT
description: Like a vampire that refuses to die, the Clinch River Breeder Reactor project in Tennessee haunts Federal budget meetings with an unworldly survivability. Despite repeated death blows by liberals, environmentalists and, in 1982, even fiscal conservatives, the $6 billion boondoggle continues to elude the budget axe.

title: VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

PATENTS;
Liquid Crystal Display Patent to Go to Timex
description: The Timex Corporation, Middlebury, Conn., has announced that it will be granted patent 4,385,842 on May 31 for a multiplexing liquid crystal display to be used on a conventional watch with hands.

title: TV FOOTBALL RULING STIRS LEGAL DEBATE
description: Lawyers for the National Collegiate Athletic Association emerged from daylong meetings today still undecided on their next move in the legal fight for control of football television rights.

title: Progress on PCB's
description: There was a brighter moment last week for the environmental agency - when it announced that levels of the toxic chemicals known as PCB's in the body tissue of Americans had declined significantly over the last six years. It was reflected glory, however.

title: SIGNS TALK TO BLIND
description: The West 55th Street offices of the Jewish Guild for the Blind now have emergency-door exit signs that speak. The 29 signs, installed in the Guild's building last month, utter the words, ''Fire, this way out,'' in a synthesized but commanding voice, according to John Heimerdinger, executive director of the nonprofit organization.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
FINALLY, CONSUMERS START SPENDING
description: Retail sales rose a hefty 1.6 percent in April, a strong indication the consumer has finally joined the budding recovery. The much-larger-than expected increase was accompanied by an even more heartening revision of consumer spending in the previous month. The Commerce Department, which had originally reported that retail buying gained a mere three-tenths of 1 percent in March, revised that figure sharply higher - to 1.7 percent. With the July 1 tax cut just around corner and consumers showing more willingness to take on installment debt, economists are enthusiastic about the prospects for a spending spree that could lead to a rebuilding of inventories - which fell 1.1 percent in March - and a burst in industrial output.

title: GEM OF A PERFORMANCE ELEVATES A PLAY
description: EVERY production, regardless of how stultifying it might otherwise be, will have something special about it. Sometimes the gem hidden in the rock pile will be a spectacular set, or it might be a clever bit of stage business, or perhaps it will be seen in colorful, graceful costumes. In Bohemia, the Airport Playhouse production of ''Once Again, for the Very First Time,'' the gem is Tony Loverro's performance as a young, unhappy widower.

title: WAS PRESIDENT FROM 1946 TO 1952
description: Miguel Aleman, former President of Mexico and an advocate of industrialization and improvements in agriculture, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Mexico City. He was 79 years old.

title: Shaun Murphy Weds W. P. McGreevey
description: Shaun Elaine Murphy, daughter of Adm. Daniel J. Murphy, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Murphy of Potomac, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to William Paul McGreevey, son of Mrs. James Metzcar of Cincinnati and the late Paul Henry McGreevey.

title: PLEASE DON'T FEED THE GRIZZLIES
description: While traveling through the national parks in the more northerly Rockies, I felt, always, the pervasive, haunting presence of the grizzly. The grizzly is distinguished by its ugly hump, its whitetipped fur and its huge size (it can grow to nine feet and weigh over 1,000 pounds). But despite its bulk and ferocity it is a very much endangered species. Richard L. Knight, director of something called the Inter-Agency Grizzly Bear Study Team, predicted last October that there would be no more grizzlies in Yellowstone National Park ''in 20 to 30 years.'' There are now fewer than 200 and the bear population of other parks is threatened as well.

title: JAZZ
description: Janet Lawson has one of the most interesting emergent jazz voices of the 80's but her vocal skill has not developed overnight. She has been on her way for a long time (she was making Demonstration Records as long ago as 1960), gradually honing her talents and building an instrumental group in which her voice serves as one of the horns.

title: Nuptials for Florence Golden
description: Florence Michele Golden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Golden of Hempstead, L.I., was married there yesterday to Bruce David Pavalow, son of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Pavalow of Syosset, L.I. The Rev. Patrick J. Armshaw performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Loretto Roman Catholic Church. The bride is tax manager for the Wells National Services Corporation, a television equipment rental concern in New York. Mr Pavalow is a senior systems analyst for the Depository Trust Company in New York.

title: HOW TO FOIL AN ENDPLAY
description: It may have been Oscar Wilde, or if not somebody with a similarly sharp wit, who on hearing an acquaintace described as ''modest'' allowed that, ''He has a lot to be modest about.''

title: Manchester City Loses; Is Out of First Division
description: Manchester City, after having played in the First Division of the English Soccer League for 17 years, was relegated to the Second Division for next season after a 1-0 loss to Luton today.

title: JAIL REFORMS MOVING SLOWLY
description: IT has been more than two years since a Federal judge found that overcrowding at the Nassau County Correctional Center was unconstitutional, but the overcrowding continues.

title: Leslie A. Nickel Is Married to Michael Henry Fara
description: Leslie Ann Nickel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Nickel of South Yarmouth, Mass., was married to Michael Henry Fara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Fara of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: SOME SOUTHWEST IN SOUTHHAMPTON
description: THE location of the Southampton Restaurant across from the railroad station would be perfect except that it's in Southampton instead of some sleepy border town in the Southwest. This restaurant, actually a bar and grill, has been serving Mexican food since November in an atmosphere that has nothing whatsoever to do with a stylish resort community. It may not be in a border town, but it looks as though it should be.

title: Gillian M. Gordon Wed To Robert A. Crozier
description: Gillian Margaret Gordon, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Ernest Gordon of Alexandria, Va., and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Ames Crozier, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Crozier of Potomac, Md. The bride's father, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel, of which he is dean emeritus.

title: THEATER: 1-MAN SHOW ABOUT SHAW
description: Wearing purple spats and an itchy-looking Irish tweed suit, Donal Donnelly strides deliberately on stage at the Players Theater and, head-on, tells the audience with self-satisfaction: ''And so I broke loose and became a professional man of genius.''

title: EPITHALAMIUMS
description: Three months ago a young friend asked me to suggest a poem to be read at her wedding. The weeks of searching have gravely damaged my faith in poets. If 1,000 anthologists published collections of love poems there would not have to be a repetition in the lot, but all the good wedding poems in the world could be scribbled on a placard.

title: Garner, 14, Gains Eastern Tennis Final
description: Chris Garner, a 14-year-old junior high school student from Bay Shore, L.I., continued a surprising advance through the Miller DePhillips Eastern hard-court tennis championships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Data Bank; May 15, 1983
ISLANDERS BEAT OILERS, 5-1, AND TAKE 3-0 SERIES LEAD
description: The Islanders played for 40 minutes tonight the way they had played for many of the 80 games of the regular season: They chugged, sputtered and stalled.

title: RED GROOMS DESIGNS 'MUSKETEERS' FOR D'AMBOISE
description: Red Grooms, the artist, and Jacques d'Amboise, one of the stars of the New York City Ballet, worked away with scissors and tape the other day, busily measuring and snipping in Mr. Grooms's studio in lower Manhattan. Assisting them, and fortified with burgers and lemonade, were five boys between the ages of 9 and 15, all of them dancers in the fifth annual ''Event of the Year,'' the benefit gala for Mr. d'Amboise's National Dance Institute that will take place May 23 at the Felt Forum.

title: COUNCIL LOW ON VISIBILITY AND MONEY
description: The National News Council, an independent agency set up in 1972 to monitor press performance, is running out of money, in part, it says, because not enough people know what it does.

title: CONNECTICUT U. BRANCH'S CLOSING RECONSIDERED
description: The University of Connecticut's branch campus in Torrington, targeted for closing because of low enrollment, won a reprieve this week in the State House of Representatives.

title: BUSINESS GROUP SET FOR POLITICAL ACTION
description: OFTEN considered politically timid in the past, the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry is starting a Political Action Committee that has modest goals this year but could become a potent political force on the Island.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pirates at Pittsburgh, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, the Bronx. 2:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 2 P.M.).

title: ARTISTS GRAPPLE WITH NEW REALITIES
description: ''There is a lack of subtlety now, an indifference to what are ultimate concerns, a tendency to improvise rather than think something through clearly. When we started out, there were people like Mondrian, who regarded art as a calling, something that expressed the world of the spirit. People now are quite cynical about that. They have forgotten what art is all about.'' The speaker is Robert Motherwell, the 68-year-old Abstract Expressionist painter who was a leading figure of the first generation of the New York School.

title: A PIONEER DANCE CRITIC
description: MOTION ARRESTED Dance Reviews of H.T. Parker. Edited by Olive Holmes. Illustrated. 325 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $29.95.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Valuable Evenings

title: Lacrosse Final 8 to Be Picked
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's lacrosse tournament committee will announce tomorrow the names of the eight teams from Division I selected to play in the postseason championship tournament.

title: D.H. LAWRENCE COMES TO TV
description: When public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' presents D.H. Lawrence's ''Sons and Lovers,'' beginning tonight at 9 on WNET/ Channel 13, it may surprise some viewers to see the name of Trevor Griffiths credited with the seven-part dramatization. What possible connection could there be between the author of ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' and the ebulliently left-wing British playwright best known for ''Comedians'' and as the co-author, with Warren Beatty, of the film ''Reds''?

title: Lynn Caroline Jackson to Be the Bride Of Charles Deane Urstadt Next Year
description: Comdr. Morse Robert Jackson, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Jackson of Burke, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Caroline Jackson, to Charles Deane Urstadt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Urstadt of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: SHAKERS FAIL TO HALT STADIUM
description: A State Supreme Court justice has refused to halt construction of a new baseball stadium in the Town of Colonie near a cemetery where the founder of the Shaker religious movement is buried.

title: ALBANY HOPES FOR BIG BYTE OF HIGH TECH
description: As he has labored to restructure the state's Urban Development Corporation, William J. Stern, its new chairman and president, has been putting his mouth where his money is. In 1969, with more ideas than dollars, he and three partners started a computer software company in a hotel room at 42d Street and 12th Avenue. Seven years later they sold out for $16 million. Now Mr. Stern, a brief but prosperous retirement behind him, is hoping to bring the largess of high technology to New York State.

title: 5 Killed in California Crash
description: Five people were killed and four were injured today in a head-on crash on the Pacific Coast Highway, the police said.

title: CHINA PRESENTS A PLAY ABOUT ITS VIETNAM WAR
description: A mother asks an old family friend to help get her soldier son transferred from the battlefront. ''I only have one son,'' she pleads over the telephone. ''We have done enough for the revolution.''

title: Barbara Evans to Wed W.C. Paganelli
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Evans of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Spring Evans, to William Charles Paganelli, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles V. Paganelli of Williamsville, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: T.V.A., AT 50, DRAFTING NEW ROLE IN REGION'S FUTURE
description: Fifty years ago, in the first days of the agency that was to remold the Tennessee River Valley, all the cities and towns there were deep in the craw of the Great Depression.

title: HOW TO TOUR THE SITES OF THE REFORMATION
description: When Martin Luther traveled, there was usually trouble afoot. He was walking along a road near Stotternheim in 1505 when a severe thunderstorm drew out of him the vow to become a monk. Five years later he trekked to Rome on business for his Augustinian order of monks and during that trip began questioning the way the Church was dispensing the grace of God. Returning home from the conclave at Worms, where he stood his theological ground before Pope and Emperor, friends ''kidnapped'' the Reformer and spirited him off to the Wartburg Castle for his own protection.

title: GLOSSY BUT DISEMBODIED
description: ''My One and Only,'' the new arrival at the St. James, is indisputably filled with sleek-looking top hats, sleek-looking tails and sleek-looking tap shoes that rap their cleats against the floorboards the whole night long - just as the ads and the newspaper photographs suggest. The only problem with these outfits is that there seems to be no one inside them. They give the impression of having come back from the cleaners all by themselves, like clothes flapping off a washline in an animated cartoon, prepared to go right into the routines that their old creases remember.

title: SOVIET AIDE BACK IN GENEVA FOR MISSILE PARLEY
description: The chief Soviet delegate to the talks on reducing medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe returned from a recess today and said there had been no ''positive change'' in the United States position since the talks began 18 months ago. The talks are scheduled to resume next week.

title: Variable Oil Tariff
description: To the Business Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: After several lean years caused by soaring prices of gasoline, the recreational vehicle industry is thriving again. And it is striving to convince vacationers that its products offer the best - and often the most economical - way to roam leisurely about the countryside while taking along many comforts of home.

title: 5TH AVENUE NIGHT PEOPLE BRING WINDOWS TO LIFE
description: They gather at the cosmetics counter on the first floor of Bergdorf Goodman every Tuesday night. They never speak to one another. They have nothing to say. Yet they are strikingly similar. All wear size 6 dresses and size 7 shoes. And all are tall and thin. One by one they are dressed, their lips are brightened and their cheeks are powdered. And one by one these mannequins are carried to the main bank of windows on 58th Street and Fifth Avenue where they stand, frozen in the latest fashions, until the next Tuesday.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and ususally commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary durint the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: HIGH TECH, LOW HOPES
description: As unemployment remains stuck at the highest level in 40 years - 10.2 percent - everyone from President Reagan to the liberal ''Atari Democrats'' hopes that economic recovery will emerge from expanding service and high-technology industries. But instead of bringing economic salvation, lower paying service and high-tech jobs may be a Trojan horse, bringing continued declines in the quality of American life through polarized incomes, growing poverty and increased class tensions.

title: Fairleigh Captures Met Track
description: The Fairleigh Dickinson team, which has had an erratic spring, pulled itself together to win the 50th Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships at New York Tech today.

title: REPORT URGES NONNUCLEAR BUILDUP BY NATO
description: A group of Western military and civilian arms experts has called on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to spend about $20 billion by 1986 to strengthen its conventional forces to be able to defend Western Europe against any Warsaw Pact attack.

title: Miss Sun and R.J. Smith, Science Writers, Are Wed
description: Marjorie E. Sun and R. Jeffrey Smith, both staff writers for the magazine Science in Washington, were married yesterday by the Rev. John Frederickson at the Gloria Dei Lutheran Church in Rockford, Ill.

title: SUN VALLEY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCHES' COUNCIL STUDYING CHANGES
description: The National Council of Churches, faced with criticism that it is unresponsive to the needs of its members and under pressure to devote more attention to theological concerns, is planning major changes to make it more accountable to its 32 member denominations.

title: Revival for Trans-Am Series
description: The Sports Car Club of America's Trans-Am, the oldest professional road-racing series in the United States, was moribund three years ago. Today, thanks to some timely rule changes and sponsorship help from Budweiser, the Trans-Am is booming. There are more than 40 entries for the second round of the season today at Summit Point, W.Va.

title: SELLING COLLEGES IN A BUYER'S MARKET
description: Since the number of 18-year-olds available in each of the next 17 years is known and immutable, this intensive recruiting is a zero-sum game for the nation. Rather than increasingly expensive throatcutting for a share of a fixed market, educators would be better advised to devote money to increasing their market.

title: ISRAELI DIGS
description: To the Editor:

title: DODGE CITY TIME IN SOCCER
description: IN the old western movies, they used to be called ''hangin' juries'' - councils that assembled with the decision already sticking out of somebody's hip pocket.

title: TOWN MAY FORECLOSE ON MOON CHURCH ESTATE
description: The Town of New Castle plans to begin foreclosure proceedings against the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon for failure to pay $121,000 in property taxes owed since 1980 on a 98-acre estate owned by the church near here.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET;
FIRST NATIONAL SAFEWAY
description: Supermarkets, which cash more checks for individuals than banks do, may be on their way to becoming the money changers of America. About 1,300 automatic teller machines are now in use at American supermarkets and the number is expected to double or triple in five years as more financial institutions cooperate in setting up bank-tosupermarket networks. Three years ago, there were only about 200 such machines. There are another 1,500 machines in supermarkets that verify checks and serve as branch banking facilities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HAZEL RYE By Vera and Bill Cleaver. 178 pp. New York: J.B. Lippincott. $11.50. (Ages 10 to 13) By CAROL BILLMAN

title: PICTURE TAKERS WITH STYLE
description: THE ART OF FRENCH CALOTYPE With a Critical Dictionary of Photographers, 1845-1870. By Andre Jammes and Eugenia Parry Janis. Illustrated. 284 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $75.

title: Belgium Said to Oust Soviet Businessman
description: Belgium has ordered the expulsion of a Soviet businessman for activities incompatible with his function, a phrase usually used for spying, two Flemish newspapers said today.

title: JERSEY REVIEWING RIGHT-TO-DIE CASE
description: A New Jersey appeals panel has begun considering a lower-court order that would have allowed the death of a mentally incompetent, terminally ill woman through the removal of a feeding tube.

title: MAKING A STATEMENT WITH SPRING'S STRAWBERRIES
description: BASKETS of beautiful California strawberries are becoming a regular feature in produce departments these days. And within a few weeks, the harvest of strawberries from local farms will begin. Summer is evidently just around the corner.

title: POP: BILL BOGGS IN KING COLE ROOM
description: In its newest salute to Broadway, the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel is presenting an easygoing program of Rodgers and Hart songs titled ''This Must Be Love.'' Instead of legitimate theatrical voices, the show features Bill Boggs, the popular New York television personality, and the nightclub singer Dana Valery, backed by the pop-jazz trio S.R.O.

title: Diane Bee Weds Roxburgh Rennie
description: Diane Irene Bee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Bee of London and San Francisco, was married yesterday to Roxburgh Rennie, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Rennie of Palm Beach, Fla., and Milwaukee. The Rev. Robert J. Plocki of St. Hilary's Roman Catholic Church in Tiburon, Calif., and the Rev. J.Barton Sarjeant of St. John's Episcopal Church in Ross, Calif., performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady in the Presidio in San Francisco.

title: LABOR GROUPS OPPOSE GOVERNOR'S PLAN ON PLANT CLOSINGS
description: ATTEMPTS to devise legislation dealing with plant closings and relocations have so divided the General Assembly over the years that one can generally tell who supports and opposes the idea by the way they describe the measure.

title: NUCLEAR METHODS PUT TO OTHER USES
description: ''IT'S not a question of whether we're going to do it or not,'' said Garman Harbottle of Setauket, a senior chemist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton. ''It's a question of whether we're going to do it right. I think nuclear waste can be disposed of safely.''

title: Ann Logan Is Married To Legislative Counsel
description: Ann Logan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Logan of Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Lawler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Lawler of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. James Q. Bittner performed the ceremony at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Peapack, N.J.

title: Topics; Sounding Off; Quackery for Cuba
description: The Reagan Administration dearly wants to barrage Cuba with propaganda beamed from Florida by a proposed Radio Marti. Fidel Castro threatens a nasty reprisal: regular jamming of American radio stations.

title: PRIVACY PRESERVED-ALMOST
description: Behind a forbidding wrought-iron fence along a busy thoroughfare in Madrid, all but hidden by clusters of oak and willow, stands the Palace of Liria - a treasure house of great art, a home. Its walls are covered by Titians and Goyas and Rembrandts, its dozens of rooms are chockablock with Gobelin tapestries and rare procelain figurines, yet cheek by jowl with the masterpieces are photographs of family parties and a collection of perfume bottles. Therein lies the palace's special charm, and its challenge.

title: Lower Price For Failure
description: Anthony J. Alvarado made his first marks on the New York City school system last week by erasing some of those left by his predecessor. As part of a reversal of Frank J. Macchiarola's policy against ''social promotions,'' the new Chancellor said he would allow failing pupils to enroll in regular high school classes in the fall.

title: POLITICAL TURMOIL UNSETTLING IN KENYA
description: Kenya, the United States' most prominent ally in East Africa, is embroiled in its deepest political turmoil since last August's coup attempt after assertions by the President that a foreign power is plotting to replace him with a challenger of its own choice.

title: THE BRITISH AND OTHER EUROPEANS
description: THE EUROPEANS By Luigi Barzini. 267 pp. New York. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Death at Graduation Party
description: John Harter, attending a graduation party with classmates of Delaware Hayes High School, was killed Friday night when he fell from the ''Eiffel Tower'' at Kings Island Amusement Park.

title: THE LUXURY OF WILD RICE
description: When the colonists first came to the New World, their early American ''cooks'' had to learn to adapt their methods to accommodate unfamiliar American Indian staples, such as corn and squash and pumpkins, white potatoes, sweet potatoes and peanuts.

title: BILL SEEKS TO AID WORKERS OVER 55
description: IN the past, the term ''vocational education'' applied to those learning a trade, primarily young people who wanted to develop the skills necessary to compete in the job market.

title: GIRLS GET ADVICE ON DEALING WITH TECHNOLOGY
description: Marilu Marcillo talked of becoming an architect. Maritza Ortiz stumbled as she said ''pediatrician.'' Jennifer Weiner wanted to be a psychologist.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE GIFT Imagination and the Erotic Life of Property. By Lewis Hyde. 327 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $17.95. Vintage Books. Paper, $7.95.

title: INDIAN SITE VS. NEW HOMES
description: THE discovery of ''treasures'' in an Indian cemetery has halted work in a section of a Montauk luxury housing development. In a recent presentation to the East Hampton Town Board, Melville King, an archeologist, said he had unearthed remnants of a 17thcentury fort on the crest of Fort Hill and evidence of up to 136 graves containing artifacts of ''national importance.'' The board agreed to deny building permits on three lots of the development until the boundaries of the cemetery had been delineated by a certified archeologist.

title: FOR RIVERDALE, A COALITION OF CO-OPS
description: A NEW association of shareholding residents has been formed in the R iverdale section of the Bronx, where the pace of converting rental a partments into cooperative units has been rapid.

title: MINNEAPOLIS TO MOSCOW
description: A JOURNEY FOR OUR TIMES A Memoir. By Harrison E. Salisbury. Illustrated. 546 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: HOW TO KEEP A PUBLIC ENDLESSLY FASCINATED
description: A few years ago - in the fifth century, A.D., to be exact - a Syrian hermit named Simeon decided he had had enough of life's hurlyburly. He built himself a platform atop a pillar, climbed on it and stayed there for 35 years. During those decades of retreat, Saint Simeon Stylites, as he is now known, must have aroused a ravenous curiosity in the large public that had heard of his feat. I don't know what happened when Simeon eventually came down from his perch, but I suspect that a booking agent was waiting at the foot of the pillar with a tempting offer for a long personal-appearance tour.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Serving One Master

title: A Vote Against Power Sharing
description: By few definitions is South Africa, as Prime Minister P.W. Botha describes it, a ''democracy.'' However, Mr. Botha and others who would like to add a few trappings of true popular rule suffered a setback last week.

title:
WHAT'S NEW AT THE SUPERMARKET;
WATCH THE GOODS, NOT THE CUSTOMER
description: Grocers are beginning to watch the sirloin more carefully than the shoplifters, using a variation on the plastic tags attached to retail merchandise at department stores.

title: CITY FOLK IN THE COUNTRY: THE LAST GREAT INNONCENTS?
description: WE know the fallacy of believing that the country is somehow better than the city, and yet, whenever we're made aware of the fact, we wish it weren't so. After all, the myth of nature is involved: purity, truth, goodness, even deity. We're reminded that the machine invading the garden in the 19th century started it all, with railroads ruining the landscape, but we reinforce the polarity even though we know it is based on exaggeration.

title: COUNTRY LIVING
description: I am practicing to live in the country. It's almost as expensive as skiing. First, you have to acquire a few acres of farmland and a log house with a lot of the chinking missing between the logs, so as to let in the weather.

title: Anne Fox Betrothed to Stewart Cutler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell Stephens Fox of Barrington, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Weldon Fox, to Stewart Lee Cutler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hinchman Cutler Jr. of Morristown, N.J. A July 9 wedding is planned in Providence, R.I.

title: ON ANY STAGE, THE KARAMAZOVS ARE A HANDFUL
description: It's a dirty, dangerous job, this business of being a Flying Karamazov Brother, but somebody's darn well got to do it. There is, for instance, the combustion problem. ''I caught fire once,'' said Randy Nelson, one of the five Karamazovs, on a recent afternoon. For the first time on a Broadway stage, the troupe was about to juggle 15 flaming torches, and the conflagration question was of more than theoretical concern.

title: 38 Japanese-Americans To Get Compensation
description: Thirty-eight Japanese-Americans who lost their state jobs in World War II will receive up to $5,000 each under a reparations bill signed into law Friday by Gov. John Spellman.

title: HONORING FATHERS AND MOTHERS
description: THE WAR OVER THE FAMILY Capturing the Middle Ground. By Brigitte Berger and Peter L. Berger. 252 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $14.95.

title: 'WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY' IN DEBATE ON MX MISSILE
description: Early Wednesday afternoon a group of moderate Congressmen had just received a draft letter from the President, designed to convince them that Mr. Reagan was seriously committed to arms control. In less than an hour, a critical vote on the MX missile was scheduled in a House subcommittee. The White House desperately wanted the letter approved and publicized before then.

title: HARVARD REAFFIRMS PLANS FOR MCKOY SCHOLARSHIPS
description: Despite protests by Jewish and Asian-American students, Harvard University administrators have reaffirmed that a new German-American scholarship program would be named for John J. McCloy.

title: 2 DENIED PARDONS IN WATERGATE CASE
description: President Reagan has denied pardons to Jeb Stuart Magruder and E. Howard Hunt Jr. for their part in the Watergate burglary, Justice Department officials said today.

title: OFF TO THE REGATTA WITH A 36-INCH SLOOP
description: LAST winter Lindsay Hewitt, a Wall Street options trader, happened to pass through Heckscher Park in Huntington and saw a fleet of sailboats racing around the pond, guided by a band of land-bound sailors with transmitters in their hands.

title: Marianne Wolstein Plans To Wed Dr. Gary Neifeld
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Wolstein of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Wolstein, to Dr. Gary Neifeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Neifeld of Springfield, N.J.

title: Madrid's Ritz
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seeks to Recover Park Cleanup Money
description: The Justice Department filed suit Friday to recover the costs of cleaning up or moving an Arizona trailer park built on the site of an old asbestos plant.

title: PSYCHOLOGICAL AND MORAL DILEMMAS
description: EIGHT GREAT HEBREW NOVELS Edited by Alan Lelchuck and Gershon Shaked. With an introduction by Alan Lelchuk. 392 pp. New York: A Meridian Book/New American Library. Paper, $9.95.

title: Rhode Island Strike Barred
description: A Rhode Island judge issued a temporary restraining order today barring a strike planned for Monday by a union representing 10,500 state employees.

title: Irish Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO LOST CHINA?
description: The tactical elements of the Reagan policy in Central America are now clear. The Administration aims to isolate Nicaragua in the region, harassing the Sandinists by covert war and economic pressure; to support the Governments of Guatemala and El Salvador no matter how murderous they are, and to smear as pro-Communist anyone who disagrees with the policy.

title: Hobart and Roanoke Gain Final in Lacrosse
description: Tom Grimaldi, a sophomore attackman, scored five goals and had five assists in leading Hobart College to a 22-7 victory over Ohio Wesleyan in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III lacrosse tournament today.

title: VIOLATIONS AT FOOD SPOTS CITED
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 30 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named nine places that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Islanders Didn't Panic
description: The Islanders don't plan it this way. They would prefer to take decisive leads early in every playoff game. But when things don't go their way, and a big game has dwindled down until precious few minutes remain, the Islanders have an almost uncanny talent for becoming swiftly decisive.

title: A CALL AND A PLAN TO TAKE BEANBALL OUT OF BASEBALL
description: RECENTLY, as I watched a replay of the Yankees' Dave Winfield charging the Detroit Tigers' pitcher Dave Rozema after Rozema had thrown a pitch over his head, I couldn't help but think about a growing trend in baseball: Charge the mound and go after the pitcher.

title: Latest Study on Shoreham Plant May Be the Last
description: When the Nuclear Regulatory Commission threatened to shut the Indian Point power plant in Westchester two weeks ago, some predicted that the line it drew would soon be extended all the way to the nearly completed $3.2 billion reactor at Shoreham, L.I. But last week the commission agreed to participate on a fact-finding panel with state and local representatives to help Governor Cuomo decide whether to support the opening of the Long Island Lighting Company plant.

title: Buffalo Steak
description: To the Editor:

title: Rain Puts Off Indy Time Trial
description: Rain today washed away the first day of time trials for the 67th Indianapolis 500-mile auto race, although the track dried out long enough for some drivers to get in practice. Seven did laps of more than 200 miles an hour.

title: Q&A
description: Question: I would like to take a bicycle trip of about a week's duration through Vermont this summer. I like to travel light and I don't want to carry camping gear; instead I would like to go ''inn to inn.'' 0here can I get information to plan such a trip? -F.B.T., Hamden, Conn.

title: Grand National Saved By Purchase of Aintree
description: A board of trustees purchased the Aintree race track at Liverpool for 3.4 million today and secured the future of the Grand National, the world's most famous steeplechase race.

title: POLAROID TRIES TO GET ITSELF INTO FOCUS
description: THE scene, as recalled by Edwin H. Land, retired patriarch of the Polaroid Corporation, is surrealistic. More than 30 years ago, after achieving the startling advance that made possible the first instant black-and-white photography, Mr. Land summoned his friend and associate, Howard C. Rogers, and told him to sit down ''and think about color.''

title: HOMECOMING IN HOMEWOOD
description: SENT FOR YOU YESTERDAY By John Edgar Wideman. 208 pp. New York: Bard/Avon Books. Paper, $3.50.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BRUSSELS
description: Medieval houses, cobbled streets, acres of unspoiled forests, fine food and one of the world's finest collections of Flemish and Dutch paintings are among the enduring attractions of Brussels. An endless procession of gray, wet days can make off-season travel uncomfortable. But late spring and summer offer enough sunshine to encourage outdoor activities like visits to the Grand Place, one of Europe's noble squares, to Brussels's many outdoor markets and to the acres of beech and chestnut trees in the Bois de la Cambre and the Foret de Soignes. Grand Place

title: Sports for Peace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mary Keepnews to Marry Walter Renz
description: Mrs. Lawrence W. Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Susanne Keepnews, to Walter L. Renz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Renz of Larchmont, N.Y. A July 30 wedding is planned.

title: Debra K. Wolfe Weds Frank M. Babbitt 3d
description: Debra Karen Wolfe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Wolfe of North Hills, L.I., was married yesterday at the Pierre to Frank Madison Babbitt 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Babbitt Jr. of South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: TRADE AND TOKYO
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Bloomsbury
description: To the Editor:

title: TRYING TO AVOID ANOTHER VERSAILLES
description: IN less than two weeks, the leaders of the Western alliance will g ather for a summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va., to try to map out a common economic strategy. Profound differences exist among the a llies - over control of East-West trade, energy policy, government i ntervention in the foreign exchange markets and policies to s tabilize the world banking system - but the discord is not likely t o be visible at the summit talks. For months, elaborate political e fforts have been under way to paper over the problems.

title: Selling Colleges in A Buyer's Market
description: D.C. Denison's article ''Selling Colleges in a Buyer's Market'' (April 10) should be welcomed by all those working on behalf of higher education. Appropriate marketing activities are a legitimate need of American colleges in the highly competitive environment of the next 15 years.

title: Greece to Ask Britain For the Elgin Marbles
description: The Greek Government has decided that it will officially ask Britain to return the Elgin marbles. A Government announcement said the decision was reached Friday night at a Cabinet meeting presided over by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, after a formal proposal from Culture Minister Melina Mercouri.

title: Paul Greenfeder, 58, Is Dead; Headed Times Reference Unit
description: Paul Greenfeder, chief of the editorial reference library of The New York Times, died of a heart ailment Friday night at St. Vincent's Medical Center of Richmond, S.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Castleton Corners, S.I.

title: U.S. JUDGE ALLOWS PRAYER IN SCHOOL
description: The reciting of prayers will be allowed in a public school under a Federal district judge's ruling despite a warning that it would violate Supreme Court decisions.

title: GROUPS SAY CITY UNFAIRLY DROPS WELFARE CASES
description: Two welfare-rights groups are charging that public-assistance benefits for thousands of people are cut off periodically each year because of unfair procedures imposed by New York City's Human Resources Administration.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I HAD a pleasant shock the other day, looking out the kitchen window a t flower beds flamboyant with tulips and primroses. I realized that m y yard had turned the corner between hang-your-head and brag.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN COMPOSERS STAR IN 2 CONCERTS
description: The Bicentennial, it seems, was only the beginning. There has always been a decent amount of attention paid at any given time to contemporary American music. But until recently, we were less aware of our past. Now, programs of American art music from not just the 20th century but the 18th and 19th centuries as well, crop up with regularity on our concert schedules.

title: Boxberger and Miss Bell Win in Paris Marathon
description: Jacky Boxberger of France won the eighth Paris Marathon today in 2 hours 12 minutes 35 seconds, beating Ryszard Marczak of Poland by a minute.

title: Karen Greenspan Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Greenspan of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Barbara Greenspan, to Raymond Seth Cohen, son of Estelle Cohen of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Dr. Mortimer H. Cohen. An October wedding is planned.

title: Hussein Says He Continues To Back Reagan Peace Plan
description: King Hussein of Jordan said tonight that his support for President Reagan's Middle East peace plan remained strong despite his failure to reach an agreement with the Palestinian Liberation Organization on Jordan's role in the peace process.

title: SOVIET BUILDING FISHERY PORT ON NICARAGUA'S PACIFIC COAST
description: This tiny, forgotten Pacific harbor, once a key point on the gold rush route from New York to San Francisco, is about to get a new life as a port of call for Soviet fishing boats.

title: LEBANESE CABINET VOTES TO ACCEPT PACT ON PULLOUT
description: Despite Syrian objections, President Amin Gemayel's Cabinet today unanimously approved the American-sponsored withdrawal agreement with Israel, a Cabinet statement said.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Blacks in the Military

title: Mailbox; Lendl Is Praised For Speaking Up
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AUTO UNION SHARES THE INDUSTRY'S WOES
description: ''We are the vanguard in America,'' Walter P. Reuther told the cheering delegates at the 1947 convention of the United Automobile Workers at Atlantic City, where he consolidiated his power in the union. ''We are the architects of the future.''

title: GARDEN CITY HOTEL RETURNS IN GRAND STYLE
description: THE ISLAND's newest hotel is also its most famous old historic hotel and if that's not confusing enough, it has already opened, although it doesn't officially open until Friday.

title: Lewis's :009.96 2d Fastest 100
description: Carl Lewis won the 100-meter dash in 9.96 seconds at the S&W Modesto Invitational track meet tonight. It was the second fastest time ever.

title: Prison Philosopher
description: As the first philosopher-in-residence of Connecticut's prison system, David G. Lovell received a broad assignment when he was hired last year: to examine the system for 10 months with a philosopher's impartiality and make recommendations.

title: In Chicago, City Hall Is For Fighting
description: Its heyday may be over, but Chicago's old political machine is not quite ready for burial. Last week, Mayor Harold Washington was forced into peace talks with his political enemies on the City Council, who had welcomed him to City Hall with a barrage of contempt.

title: PLANT SHUTDOWNS: THE CITIES FIGHT BACK
description: MAYOR Angelo R. Martinelli of Yonkers doesn't mince words when he describes his dispute with the g iant United Technologies Corporation over a plant shutdown. ''This is a war,'' he insists. ''I'm going after this company, I'm g oing to embarrass them.'' To Mr. Martinelli, the four-term Mayor of New York City's northern n eighbor, the battle pits his city, and its declining industry, a gainst a plundering conglomerate that welshed on a promise. The M ayor is angry because a subsidiary of United Technologies is going t o close a plant that it expanded in 1972 with the help of $13.9 m illion in public financing. Yonkers had put together the aid p ackage, and contributed one-sixth of the funds, in an effort to savel ocal jobs.

title: MORAL ISSUE WITH A BOTTOM LINE
description: WITH legislation now pending in more than 25 states and cities c alling for withdrawal of public funds from companies doing business i n South Africa, church, educational, labor and community groups are l eading the call for United States divestment from South Africa. And t he momentum of their efforts parallels the rapid growth in public o wnership of corporate America.

title: Landlords and 'Family'
description: Had Julia M. Weiss chosen to marry, or adopt, Jack Wertheimer, they could have lived happily ever after in her rent-controlled apartment. Because she didn't, Mrs. Weiss is facing eviction, and so, perhaps, are a lot of New Yorkers who live together without benefit of legal or blood ties.

title: Barbara Jean Lee To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Lee of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean Lee, to Peter John Monahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen T. Monahan of Wilton, Conn.

title: ARAFAT IS REPORTED IN LEBANON
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has returned to Lebanon for the first time since he left Beirut during the Israeli siege last summer, P.L.O. officials said today.

title: DOUBTS RAISED ABOUT ALASKA'S NEW BUSH SCHOOLS
description: Work is about to begin on the last of a series of high schools Alaska has built in the bush at a cost of $132.5 million since 1976, and doubts about the wisdom of the project are being heard in high places.

title: ELEN RIDER PLANS WEDDING
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Graham Salkeld Rider of Manhasset, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Elizabeth Rider, to Jonathan Greenwood Meath, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Anthony Meath of Dublin, N.H. A September wedding is planned. Miss Rider is a program coordinator for CBS Entertainment in New York. Her fiance, an independent television producer, is a former production manager for CBS Cable.

title: Sergei Izotov Dies in Soviet; Was Aircraft Engine Designer
description: Sergei P. Izotov, one of the Soviet Union's leading designers of aircraft engines, died May 6 in Leningrad, according to Soviet newspapers received in New York. He was 65 years old.

title: AT LAST, ITEMIZED FUNERAL COSTS
description: TODAY, the Federal Trade Commission's rule on funeral trade practices becomes law, making this a milestone for consumer activists. Congress has not approved another F.T.C. consumer protection law in eight years, and there were few hopes that this rule, which requires undertakers to itemize prices and refrain from fraud, would be the one to pass.

title: Debra J. Ogilvie Marries
description: Debra Joan Ogilvie, daughter of Joan C. Ogilvie of Syosset, L.I., and the late Donald Douglas Ogilvie, was married yesterday in New York to Robert Lawrence Harding, son of Marcia Lawrence Harding and J. John Harding, both of Providence, R.I. The Rev. John Wade Payne performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church. The bride is an assistant vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Her husband is a vice president of Bankers Trust International in London, where the couple will live.

title: ATLANTA
description: It certainly looked like the Metropolitan Opera. There was James Levine beaming cherubically at the audience and launching into the downbeat. There were the well-worn Robert O'Hearn sets for ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' There was Aage Haugland, who made his Met debut in 1979 as Baron Ochs, repeating his most appealing characterization. There were even the familiar faces of the Met chorus and bit-players.

title: Warming Up For Williamsburg
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan threw a dinner in Paris last week for his opposite numbers from Washington's six biggest industrial allies, but the French, British and West Germans didn't come.

title: Reagan Tries A Little 'Give' On Missiles
description: President Reagan compromised with Congress last week on arms control and the MX missile program, adopting new positions that his aides hope will strengthen his negotiators in Geneva. In a move that revived at least some bipartisan support for the $20 billion MX program in the appropriations committees, Mr. Reagan agreed to a concept known as ''build down'' - scrapping old warheads as new ones are added to the arsenal.

title: Jacques Lacan
description: To the Editor:

title: Temple Crew Wins A Trip to Henley
description: Temple University's unbeaten heavyweight varsity crew capped its intercollegiate racing season today with a 5.5-second victory in the Dad Vail Regatta's featured Conville Cup race.

title: MISS CURTIN WINS 1600
description: Chris Curtin of Mepham High School in Bellmore, L.I., showed today that she was regaining the form that made her one of the leading schoolgirl runners in the country as a sophomore last year.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COIN SCULPTOR DONATES TO ROCHESTER MUSEUM
description: Through the years the Rochester Numismatic Association has been one of the most successful local or regional coin clubs in the nation. Much of its success can be traced to the dedication of a self-effacing sculptor, the late Alphonse A. Kolb.

title: Mixing Business And Displeasure
description: Peking's relations with the Reagan Administration remain prickly but pragmatic. Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang last week reminded visiting Americans that China hoped Washington would remove ''obstacles,'' a code word for weapons sales to Taiwan.

title: BEWARE THE FREE SPIRIT
description: There is nothing more dangerous than a player who has nothing to lose. He can play like a free spirit who need not agonize over a pivotal judgment of strategy.

title: Ryan Pact Extended
description: For a career strikeout leader of a different sort, Nolan Ryan, this was to have been his last season as a pitcher. ''I thought the contract I signed before would be my last,'' said the 36-year-old right-hander after doing what he had not planned on doing - signing a two-year extension to his multimillion-dollar contract with the Houston Astros.

title: THEATER: 'OBEDIENCE SCHOOL' ON TOUR
description: As performance art, Laura Farabough's ''Obedience School'' is more art than performance. It is a graphic environment for a closely compacted study of mechanistic human behavior and the theatrical equivalent of a sculpture show - artfully crafted and as coldly impersonal as alabaster. The play, on tour from California, is at the Performing Garage.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A RHODES scholar from Huntington studying Renaissance drama at Oxford and a graduate student in English at the State University at Stony Brook are the first winners of the Phyllis A. Whitney Writing Award.

title: THE CURRENT BONANZA IN FIRST ISSUES
description: WHEN Trak Auto, a discount auto parts retailer, sold shares in the p ublic market for the first time a few weeks ago, demand was so g reat that its managing underwriter, Prudential-Bache Securities, i ncreased the size of the deal to 1.85 million shares from 1.65 m illion, and increased the offering price to $22 a share from $16.

title: BY THE DAWN'S EARLY LIGHT
description: THERE is something very special about being outside at sunrise. While the rest of the world is still snuggling under its covers, sleeping peacefully, the few early risers share the streets.

title: MOVIE MAKERS WITH THEMES
description: AMERICAN DIRECTORS By Jean-Pierre Coursodon with Pierre Sauvage. Volume One, 456 pp. Volume Two, 424 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. Cloth, $21.95 each. Paper, $11.95 each.

title: AN OUTPOURING OF CONCERTO DISKS
description: Concerto recordings continue to pour out upon the public. Some offer new looks at very familar material. Others explore the fringes of the standard repertory.

title: The Lion Roars
description: The London Times, harrumphing, announced the other day that an auction gallery was a ''national institution'' whose ''survival in its present form matters to Britain.'' What prompted this remarkable statement was a bid by two brash Yanks, Stephen Swid and Marshall Cogan, to take control of financially troubled Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN TRIBECA
description: THERE is something desolate in the streets of Tribeca. They flow l ike gray rivers of cobblestone, their banks lined by warehouses. F ive years ago, cars were so rare that sea birds wheeled inland from t he river, unafraid.

title: FOR SOVIET AUTHORS, THE SWORD IS MIGHTIER THAN THE PEN
description: Leo Tolstoy, Ivan Turgenev and several other successful writers got together in 1859 to start a literary fund to help struggling young writers. Their ''Litfund'' survives, but now its mission, according to a Moscow wag, is to ensure that writers don't write.

title: NEWCOMERS IN NEW YORK
description: THE COFFIN TREE By Wendy Law-Yone. 195 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.OUR HOUSE IN THE LAST WORLD By Oscar Hijuelos. 235 pp. New York: Persea Books. $13.95.

title: HOW TO PREVENT AND REMOVE STAINS ON THE OUTSIDE OF A HOUSE
description: NOTHING detracts more from the appearance of freshly painted white or light-colored houses than unsightly rust streaks or dark stains caused by knots or sap streaks in the wood that ''burn through'' the paint. Sanding and scrubbing generally do not help much (although scrubbing does sometimes lighten the stain - at least temporarily), and painting over these spots with regular outside paint is only a temporary cure. In a short while, the same stains will burn through and be just as noticeable.

title: EAST ENDERS DISAGREE ON OPEN SPACES
description: YEARS ago, when Lee E. Koppelman, the Suffolk County Planning Director, first urged that steps be taken to preserve the open space in Suffolk's five East End towns, he was met with suspicion and hostility from town officials and many local residents.

title: No Headline
description: ''Learning to Say Goodbye'' was one of the most well written, meaningful, sensitive pieces of writing I have ever encountered. ED SUSSMAN, Plainview

title: CORRECTION
description: Incorrect figures were given in a recent article on plans to build Suffolk County's first kosher nursing home. Estimates on the amount of working capital needed for the initial stages before groundbreaking range from $250,000 to $750,000.

title: E.P.A. Finds Some Causes of 'Superfund' Lag
description: Swift cleanups of hazardous wastes was the intent of the ''superfund'' legislation enacted in 1980, with the Federal Government taxing industry to finance the job. Slow response has been the reality, partly because of mismanagement and bickering within the Environmental Protection Agency, according to an internal agency report that was leaked last week by the staff.

title: 'WE MUST GO BEYOND MEASURING MEGATONS'
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS, AFTER LEWELLYN
description: For Safeguard Scientifics Inc., 1982 would have been bad enough without Gary Lewellyn.

title: MUMPHREY 4 FOR 4
description: Even when the Yankees win a game these days, they struggle. Yesterday, in playing the Chicago White Sox, who are struggling even more, the Yankees had a shutout after seven innings and a five-run lead after eight. But it was not until Rich Gossage secured the last out in the ninth inning with two runners on base that the Yankees were safe with an 8-5 victory at the Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: As a sometime writer about Chicago, I offer my praise for Andrew Malcolm's excellent article. His analysis is perceptive, his facts, with some exceptions, are authoritative.

title: Alice Manson Lynn Is Wed
description: Alice Manson Lynn of Lincoln, Mass., widow of David E. Lynn, was married yesterday to William Preston Palmer of Darien, Conn., a senior member of the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood. The Rev. Stephen White performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Lincoln. Mr. Lynn was a former president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Mr. Palmer's first wife died.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
CHECKING OUT RETIREMENT PLAN OPTIONS
description: IF you are a corporate employee, retirement plan options that shelter earned income from Federal income taxes may be more available than you realize. They bear an alphabet-soup array of names and have different rules, with some serving particular needs better than o thers.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Mutabaruka, who is at the Ritz on Thursday, has attracted more attention, and more rave reviews, than any other new reggae artist of the past year. He was featured in the reggae film ''Land of Look Behind'' and was the surprise hit of reggae festivals held in Kingston, Jamaica and in Los Angeles.

title: VOLUNTEER FIREMEN SUE MILFORD FOR JOBS
description: VOLUNTEERS in five Milford fire companies, contending that the City Fire Chief has tried to keep them from fighting fires, have filed a suit against the city in Federal District Court in New Haven.

title: IN WEST HARTFORD, A SYMBOLIC DOMAIN
description: STRIPS of brown molding will soon be stapled to a number of utility poles whose wires form an unbroken ring around the northeast corner of West Hartford.

title: ASSAD: ODD MAN OUT?
description: CALL it what you will an expanded armistice agreement, a technical security arrangement or a virtual peace treaty - the Lebanon-Israel withdrawal accord has one meaning that no one will dispute. Egypt is no longer alone; a second Arab state is withdrawing from the confrontation with Israel.

title: Peking Gives Defector a Job
description: Li Dawei, an army pilot who defected from Taiwan in a light plane last month, has been appointed deputy head of a Chinese Air Force flying school, the Peking radio reported.

title: AUGUST WEDDING FOR SHELIA CASEY
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul Casey of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Pinkham Casey, to Kevin Richard McManus of Washington. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. McManus of Marblehead, where the couple plans a late August wedding.

title: WILLIAM L. SCHULTZ
description: William L. Schultz, a wildlife painter and sculptor whose painted woodcarvings of birds are on display at the Smithsonian Institution, died of leukemia Friday. He was 57 years old. Mr. Schultz, born in Milwaukee, joined the staff at the Milwaukee Public Museum in 1947. He resigned in 1973 to devote full time to carving and painting wildlife.

title: LAYMAN IN CHARGE OF CATHOLIC RELIEF
description: After a yearlong search, Catholic Relief Services has appointed a career diplomat as its executive director, the first layman to head the 40-year-old foreign-aid agency.

title: THE ISRAELI ARMY SIGNS A POLITICAL TRUCE
description: Israel's army is going through something of a catharsis after the war in Lebanon and the massacre in Beirut's Palestinian refugee camps. The high pitch of crisis has brought a sweeping change of leadership and a pragmatic calm that holds some promise of restoring the army as Israel's most unifying institution, above the divisive politics of the day.

title: A PRIZE HOSTELRY IN UTAH
description: Each afternoon, crisp linen cloths are folded over tables in the lobby of the Hotel Utah, and tea and cakes are offered from rolling trays. For the most part, the guests who come for this afternoon ritual are vintage Salt Lake City residents, well-scrubbed families and proper church folk, who talk quietly, even reverentially, amid the almost palatial grandeur of the hotel's lobby.

title: Stallions Defeat Express
description: Bob Lane passed for three touchdowns and set up two others as the Birmingham Stallions defeated the Los Angeles Express, 35-20, in a United States Football League game tonight.

title: The Rich Visions of Cynthia Ozick
description: Cynthia Ozick is a gifted and versatile writer, remarkable in her craft and passionate in her style (''The Rich Visions of Cynthia Ozick,'' by Eve Ottenberg, April 10).

title: Rebel Invasion Halted, Nicaragua Announces
description: Two groups of 250 rebels each invaded Nicaragua early today from Honduras but were repelled by Nicaraguan troops in a major battle in northern Zelaya Province, the Defense Ministry said.

title: YACHT RACE TO AID ANTIDRUGS FUNDS
description: Sailing is a natural high. At least, that's what sailors contend. Now some intend to prove it. Some Long Island sailors have gotten together to create the Sag Harbor Cup Race Against Drug Abuse, an event that couples a new yacht race with the fight against narcotics.

title: CAUTIOUS HOPE FOR A WORKING TRUCE
