description: MERCUTIO, in ''Romeo and Juliet,'' described his wound as ''not so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church door; but 'tis enough, 'twill serve.'' Similarly, t he rift between organized labor and the Reagan Administration isn't so deep as to be unhealable nor so wide as to be unbreachable, but ''twill serve'' both parties as a serious hindrance as each strives to carry out its respective responsibilities.

title: O'Neill's Plan on Runaway Firms
description: Can Connecticut make it hard for industry to move out without discouraging it from moving in? Gov. William A. O'Neill doesn't think so. Last week he unveiled a plan to help workers who lose their jobs when plants relocate but promised to veto any measure requiring companies to give advance notice before they can move.

title:
CAMERA;
WHEN A METER FAILS, TRY THE RULE OF F/16
description: When camera batteries konk out at home, replacements are usually handy. But batteries often have a way of giving up at the most inconvenient times, either during a vacation out in the boondocks or at a Sunday party when all the stores are closed.

title: Lisa Palfy Wed To Joseph Kohn
description: Lisa Palfy, daughter of Maria G. Palfy of Old Bridge, N.J., and Zoltan G. Palfy of South River, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph C. Kohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Kohn of Philadelphia and Devon, Pa. Judge Dolores K. Sloviter of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Devon.

title: Nancy Newman, Chef, Weds Bruce L. Hager
description: Nancy Ann Newman, daughter of Elizabeth Newman Sweet of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Harry Martin Newman of Seattle, was married in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday to Bruce Linton Hager, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eric Hill Hager of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John Andrew, rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Dr. Charles Pinckney Deal, uncle of the bride.

title: BRITISH MILLS, VICTORIAN STYLE
description: In today's high-tech world of bauds and bytes, chips and bits, it is easy to forget a distant, yet equally revolutionary era when the tools of transformation were spinning mules and flying shuttles, carding engines and fulling stocks.

title: Coffee Concern Is Sued Over $34 Million Fraud
description: Eight banks have filed a suit charging a Colombian coffee company with defrauding them of up to $34 million. Five other banks filed a separate suit Thursday against the company, which was said to have defrauded banks of up to $80 million.

title: Inquiry Confirms Rickover's Math
description: For years, critics of the military-industrial establishment, especially the military part, have had a powerful ally in Adm. Hyman G. Rickover and his blasts against profiteering.

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor:

title: Original Designs In Folk Art
description: I was very pleased to see a picture of an original hand-painted egg by Stephanie Kostecki Costanzo in the May 1 ''Letters to the Long Island Editor.'' Upon reading the accompanying letter by Dorothy Lukaszuk in reaction to a recent enlightening article entitled ''Decorating Eggs: A Folk Art Updated'' (April 3), I was quite dismayed; she should have her facts straight.

title: IN THE RUSH TO SELL HITLER, PUBLICATIONS SOLD READERS SHORT
description: When the West German Government announced just over a week ago that 60 volumes purporting to be ''Hitler's diaries'' were crude fakes, the only people who seemed surprised were the journalists in Germany, England and the United States who had paid for the documents or had splashed their contents all over their news pages. The editors and reporters and their history experts were left to explain why they had been so far behind most readers in rejecting a clumsy replay of a ''Big Lie.''

title: Koch Names Press Aide To Film, Theater Post
description: Patricia R. Scott, a deputy press secretary for Mayor Koch since 1981, has been appointed by the Mayor to head the city's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. The office tries to encourage film, television and theater production in the city.

title: SUPPLIER OF HITLER FORGERIES GIVES UP
description: The man who supplied the bogus Hitler diaries to a journalist at Stern magazine turned himself over to the police today and denied that he had forged the notebooks, his lawyer said.

title: SCOTS JOIN CITY IN CELEBRATING SUNNY DAY AND CENTRAL PARK
description: With the sound of bagpipes and military drums rising through the trees, Mary Garner-Smith of Inverness, Scotland, said Central Park reminded her of home.

title: No Headline
description: HALFWAY up the slopes of the Northlands Coliseum in Edmonton, dozens of blue-and-orange banners decorate the arena. One reads: ''And On The Eighth Day God Created Gretzky.'' Across the ice from where 41-year-old Peter Pocklington sits as the Oilers' owner, another banner proclaims: ''Peter Puck - The Man Who Would Be King.'' Peter Puck is one of Edmonton's nicknames for the owner of its National Hockey League franchise. Peter Pocketbook is another. But by any name or nickname, Peter Pocklington is perhaps the most complex club owner in sports.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
AN ERA OF MASTERWORKS CREATED FOR THE MEDIA
description: There is an interesting idea in the handsome selection of photographs on view at the Downtown Branch of the Whitney Museum at Federal Hall National Memorial, 26 Wall Street, through June 3. Entitled ''Phototypes: The Development of Photography in New York City,'' the exhibition includes 102 works intended to show the development of photography from the earliest days to the present and, up to a point it does this very nicely.

title: BEWARE THE WELL-INTENTIONED
description: SHOULD the United States and other Western nations pursue a policy o f disinvestment in South Africa? The answer depends on who you ask. A merican liberals, and other well-meaning people, from the safety a nd comfort of their high-rise apartments, say yes. Their reasoning i s that disinvestment will weaken the South African economy and f orce the Government to change its position on apartheid. I am sure d isinvestors sleep better after taking a moral stance against trade w ith the devil.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Alternatives for Authors

title: GRADUATION TIME AT COLLEGES THROUGHOUT STATE
description: ON the day after she finished her last exam, Michelle Caraveto was at the University of Hartford's television studio, editing a videotape that she could use as part of her resume.

title: HANDCRAFTED WARE ATTRACTIVE TO BRIDES
description: WITH an invitational group show based on the theme ''Art for Eating,'' The Elements Gallery has found a timely way of utilizing its exhibition space.

title: ATHLETIC ENERGY FOR ACADEMIC POWER
description: IN order to drive home the significance of academic success for my athletes, early last season I read to them an article about a new eligibility rule for Los Angeles students participating in interscholastic sports. The rule would prevent any student from playing in sports if he or she didn't maintain at least a C grade average.

title: SOUTH AMERICA HANDBOOK
description: Cover your toes at night in Latin America to foil vampire bats, which carry rabies. Keep an eye out for cattle rustlers on the Inca road in northern Peru. When traveling on buses in Colombia and Ecuador, be wary of strangers offering candy, drinks or cigarettes, which may be drugged to make it easier to strip you of your possesions. Continue taking antimalarial tablets for six weeks after a tropical holiday, for thousands of people who neglect to do so develop malaria afterward and some die.

title: CONCERT: FAURE, STRAVINSKY BY COLLEGE CHORALE
description: The Collegiate Chorale marked two major events in the life of man at Carnegie Hall Friday night - marriage and death. The music was ''Les Noces'' by Stravinsky and the Faure Requiem; and though these pieces stood in stylistic opposition to one another, crosscurrents of irony ran between the two.

title: ISRAELI DIGS
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHERN EUROPE SOCIALISTS MOVING LEFT ON ARMS ISSUES
description: A major move leftward on basic East-West security issues is taking place in northern Europe. Interviews with leaders of the region's Socialist parties show they are now softening positions they have held for years and posing questions on nuclear policy that represent potential divisions within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: No Headline
description: I want to thank Barbra Wagner Williams for her poignantly graphic account of the losses and anger in her life that accrued from 10 years of unresolved mourning. It was a powerful statement, affirming the work we do at the Bereavement Center of the Family Service Association of Nassau County.Her story is proof that time alone does not heal, as people so often say. Without going through the mourning process, the mere passage of time is meaningless. Essentially, one continues to remain behind the closed door of the hospital, at the bedside of the dying person, or looking at the coffin.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WOODBRIDGE SHOW OFFERS VARIETY
description: GATHERED in one of Connecticut's most attractive settings for an outdoor show, 125 exhibitors from all of the New England states, along with colleagues from New York and Pennsylvania, will stage the 10th annual Woodbridge Antiques Festival Saturday.

title: Day Louise Pessoni Weds G.B. Ketcham, Consultant
description: Day Louise Pessoni, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Pessoni of Middletown, Conn., was married yesterday in Glastonbury, Conn., to George Bonbright Ketcham, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I. The Rev. Victor S. Ross Jr., performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Adair Brown Is Married
description: Adair Ann Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald David Brown of Rye, N.Y., and Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Dean Walter Rowland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Rowland of New Rochelle, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., with the Rev. George Zabriskie 2d and Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg officiating.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: SELECTED POEMS. By Galway Kinnell. (Houghton Mifflin, $6.95.) Winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize for poetry and co-winner of the 1983 American Book Award in that category, this rich collection includes poems from every phase of Galway Kinnell's career. Our critic, Morris Dickstein, called it more than a good introduction to Mr. Kinnell's work. It is, he said, ''a full-scale dossier for those who consider him, at 55, one of the true master poets of his generation ... There are few others writing today in whose work we feel so strongly the full human presence.''

title: Elizabeth Gregg Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Gregg to Christian William Wolf has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John N. Gregg of St. Davids, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Wolf is a son of Phyllis Sargent Wolf of Wheeling, W. Va. A fall wedding is planned.

title: CHAPIN INSPIRES STUDENT'S TRIBUTE
description: ALTHOUGH they had met casually one or two times, David Miller didn't really get to know Harry Chapin until after the entertainer's death. But now, after spending more than a year immersed in the minute details of Mr. Chapin's life and career for a documentary, ''The Story of a Life,'' Mr. Miller feels he knows his subject well - so well that he has embarked upon a one-man crusade to remind Long Islanders who Harry Chapin was and, more important, what he stood for.

title: CUOMO OFFERS 1984 PARTY THEME BASED ON DIFFERENCE WITH G.O.P.
description: Governor Cuomo of New York told national leaders of the Democratic Party here today that to win the 1984 Presidential election the Democrats needed to stress their ''fundamental and crucial'' differences with the Republicans.

title: AMERICAN BOTTLES ON THE AMERICAN BLOCK
description: While out for a Sunday drive with their three children 24 years ago, Edmund and Jayne Blaske stopped at an antiques shop 50 miles west of their home in Battle Creek, Mich., and purchased for $15 a sunburst-embellished green whisky flask that their daughter Patricia admired.

title:
IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES;
PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Like a photographic Mondrian or Albers, Denny Moers produces elegant near-abstractions out of almost nothing. His usual motif is minimal - a circular staircase, a bit of frescoed wall, the corner of a room - and he frames it in such a way as to reduce it to little more than a harmonious arrangement of lines and tones.

title: DELAWARE TOWN LOOKS TO ROLE AS BANKING CENTER
description: This is the Hub of Delaware, says a sign on U.S. 13, just before a turnoff leading past the Harrington News Stand and Restaurant, across the Conrail tracks and around the corner to Commerce Street and Dr. Robert H. Smith's dental office, Burton's Sport Shop and J.Edward Taylor's hardware store.

title: Saundra Williams Marries a Banker
description: Saundra Clarke Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael D. Williams of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married in Manhattan yesterday to W. Don Cornwell, son of Lelia Allen of Tacoma, Wash., and the late Felton Cornwell. The Rev. Dr. Moran Weston performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist.

title: FILLING A HUNGER FOR THE WILD
description: Having an instant ago, in terms of his time on Earth, removed himself with marvelous and terrifying ingenuity from total intimacy with the world of wind and tides, forest and stream, it is small wonder that man has a need to return, however briefly, to that habitat.

title: 60% Assessments
description: To the Editor:

title: August Wedding For Miss Riorden
description: Mr. and Mrs. Shane E. Riorden of Williamstown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Haviland Riorden, to John A. Guffey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guffey of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is to be in August.

title: Anne Davidson, Insurance Executive, Marries David Robert Hardy, Lawyer
description: Anne Treat Davidson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Wetmore Davidson Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., and Milwaukee, was married yesterday to David Robert Hardy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hardy of Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, assisted by Canon Robert S.S. Whitman of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Pittsfield, Mass.

title: Weinberger Warning to Soviet On 'Force' Is Clarified by Aide
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's stern warning to the Soviet Union of a ''retaliatory force'' against Syrian-based aggression in the Middle East was a warning that Israel would do the retaliating, an Administration official said today.

title: CAREY OFFERS PLAN TO CONTROL FEDERAL DEFICITS
description: In his first major address since leaving office, former Gov. Hugh L. Carey yesterday offered a plan to deal with the Federal deficit through a combination of long-term borrowing and sharp limits on the Federal debt ceiling.

title: Journeying Into the Past
description: When it comes to long journeys, next week marks the beginning of a regularly scheduled trip 45 million centuries into the past. The site is Watkins Glen State Park, at the intersection of Routes 414 and 14 in upstate New York, where private enterprise and a public preserve have joined to create a new sound-and-light show called Timespell.

title: AGENCY ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION TO CENTER ON BUILDING TRADES
description: A Federal agency charged with enforcing affirmative-action programs has agreed to improve its procedures in order to increase the number of women and members of minority groups in federally assisted construction projects in New York City.

title: Flooding in Indonesia
description: Flood waters inundated the main plant of the Conoco Oil Company in Irian Jaya on Wednesday, forcing a complete evacuation of workers, the official Antara press agency said today. No casualties were reported, but damage to the plant was substantial, the agency said.

title: PATTERNS AND SPINNING ARE ONLY PART OF IT
description: About a decade ago, Laura Dean staked out a bit of choreographic territory for herself and, since then, she has become known for dances involving constantly changing, but always clearly defined, patterns and extended passages of spinning.

title: Leslie Clark, Nurse, Weds Thomas L. Wittenberg
description: Leslie Anne Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Burrel Clark of Plantation, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas Lester Wittenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Wittenberg of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Walsh performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Chapel at Louisiana State University.

title: Birthday for the Appalachian Trail
description: MORE than 1,000 hikers - serious and casual - from across the nation are expected to take part in the 60th anniversary celebration of the creation of the Appalachian Trail's first section. The Trail, which extends for more than 2,000 miles from Mt. Katahdin in Maine to Springer Mountain in Georgia, is probably the world's best-known foot path.

title: CONVERSIONS IN REGION COUNTER THE NATIONAL TREND
description: AROUND the country, the conversion of rental to tenant-owned housingi s a shadow of its former self. The Advance Mortgage Corporation of D etroit, which did a national survey last month, says that c onversions in 17 markets dropped to 11,000 units last year in an u ninterrupted decline from a high of 84,000 in 1979.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
BROWSER'S GUIDE TO BOGOTA
description: The very mention of Colombia tends to conjure images of coffee or emeralds in the traveler's mind. Certainly either are readily available there. Coffee of excellent quality is easy to find and makes a welcome present back home. In the towns it costs around $1.70 a kilo (2.2 pounds) but it can also be purchased at the last minute at airports for a slightly higher price. Emeralds are quite another story, although they sometimes appear to be as much in evidence as coffee, albeit costlier.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ABKHAZIAN MARK TWAIN
description: SANDRO OF CHEGEM By Fazil Iskander. Translated by Susan Brownsberger. 368 pp. New York: An Ardis Book/Vintage Books. Paper, $9.95.

title: Toward Higher Higher Education
description: Though billed as a how-to on preparing for college, recommendations released by the College Board last week could have been a new definition of a liberal arts education. Students, the board said, should have ''the ability to distinguish between scientific evidence and personal opinion by inquiry and questioning,'' ''the skills to gather scientific information through laboratory, field and library work,'' and ''an understanding of the unifying concepts of the life and physical sciences.''

title: PARENTS SIGN UP CHILDREN FOR FRESH AIR
description: It was a hazy spring afternoon, humid enough to remind people how sticky summer can be. Teen-agers talked on the stoops that line some of the streets in Harlem, and some older men gathered outside stores. Most of the neighborhood children were still in school.

title: Comsat Dealings Under a Cloud
description: Communications Satellite Corporation is a potential buyer of the Goverment's weather satellites. Guy W. Fiske, until last week the Deputy Secretary of Commerce, had been deeply involved in the debate over whether the agency should sell the satellites.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A PRESCIENT NOVEL ABOUT NAZISM
description: In the 50 years since Adolf Hitler seized the reins of power in Germany, no single historical or fictional work has more tellingly or insightfully depicted the relentless disintegration of German humanism, the insidious manner in which Nazism began to permeate the fabric of German society, and the first inexorable steps toward what Hitler came to call ''the final solution to the Jewish question'', than Lion Feuchtwanger's novel ''The Oppermanns.''

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Good sopranos are a rarity in any age; good sopranos who excel in contemporary music rarer still. Margaret Ahrens is both. On Thursday evening, Miss Ahrens presented a varied and invigorating program of 20th-century material at the Abraham Goodman House, with Paul Alan Levi at the piano. Miss Ahrens is a distinctive artist with a fresh, flexible voice; she communicates even the most challenging material with taste and intelligence.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WENDY GARB TO WED IN JUNE
description: Dr and Mrs Allan E Garb of Cos Cob, Conn, have announced the engagement of their duaghter, Wendy Alison Garb, to Michael Gregory Doremus, son of Mr and Mrs Burton T Doremus of Bridgeton, N J .

title: Trade and Tokyo
description: To the Business Editor:

title: VISITOR'S GUIDE TO THE ROCKIES
description: The national parks offer a broad range of accommodations and services, from hotels and motels to raft trips, hikes and horseback riding. Some parks have elaborate hotels, others only campsites. Rates for the better hotels range from $50 to $200 a night for two. There are dozens of hotels and motels around the parks.

title: DEBATING PERSPECTIVES AND PRIORITIES IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Question. What are the basic troubles of Central America?

title: Double Defeat On School Prayer
description: At least a dozen states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, have tried to circumvent Supreme Court objections and clear a path for prayer in public schools by calling for ''moments of silence'' or ''voluntary'' meditation. Silent moments, proponents argue, compromise no one's beliefs since anyone can think of anything at those times.

title: NATION'S HOSPICE MOVEMENT WORRIES ABOUT ITS OWN LIFE
description: The hospice movement won a major victory last year when Congress voted to provide Medicare reimbursement for the medical, social and psychological services that hospice care provides to the terminally ill. That implied financial security is being shaken by the Reagan Administration, which has proposed Medicare payment rates that, hospice operators say, would make it hard to function.

title: Patricia Joan Coughlin Wed
description: Patricia Joan Coughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Coughlin of Huntington Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to William Gillespie Caffray, son of Mrs. James Lincoln Fee of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert George Caffray of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. John Olofson Jr. performed the Protestant ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich. The bride is fashion director of Nigel French Enterprises in New York. Mr. Caffray is a general partner of Conklin, Cahill & Company, also in New York.

title: ENGINEERING THE BIRTH OF CATTLE
description: PEERING through a microscope at the embryo impaled on the blade of his micromanipulator - a $25,000 machine that scales down surgical dexterity to a fraction of a millimeter - Timothy J. Williams announced: ''This is my 618th egg whacking.''

title: Constance Davis Wed To David Cederholm
description: Constance Hopkins Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Nelson Davis of Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday in New York to David Tither Cederholm, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustave D. Cederholm of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: FIREARMS ON CAMPUES DEBATED
description: LAST year, a woman was robbed and then pistol-whipped in a parking garage at the State University at Stony Brook. Although several university police officers heard her screaming, they could not assist her.

title: UPGRADING A WAREHOUSE AND A FACTORY
description: The New York Telephone Company is among many companies going west - to the West Side of Manhattan, that is, in search of an alternative to the high rents and limited space of midtown office towers.

title: CANADIAN BROADCASTERS WIN AWARDS BUT NOT BIG AUDIENCES
description: Al Capone spoke for many Americans when he remarked, ''I don't even know what street Canada is on.'' For Canadians, such neighborly ignorance is unthinkable. More than three-quarters of them are clustered within 100 miles of the United States border reading predominantly American publications, buying mostly American products and watching American television -lots of American television..

title: Gelato
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Pan Am Set To Settle in Air Crash
description: Pan American Airways and the Federal Government, facing lawsuits of more than $3 billion in connection with the crash of a Boeing 727 jetliner that killed 154 people, will not contest liability for the accident and will pay any judgment rendered by a court.

title: THE TRIALS OF A MISSISIPPI LAWYER
description: WHAT KIND OF BLACK man are you?'' The question, asked by a black woman, stung me. She had been a defendant in a case in my home state of Mississippi. I had been arguing for a young white boy's right to be educated, in what had been an all-black school, against a black teacher's relentless bigotry. It seemed inevitable that I should help plead the child's case. My whole life led me to make that choice, arguing for the principle of law over race.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Green, an assistant basketball coach at Tulane, has been named head coach at Fairleigh Dickinson, replacing J. Donald Feeley, who was dismissed after he led the school to its best record (17-12) in 24 years but pursued such an aggressive recruiting policy that many of his players flunked out of college. ... Tommy Kramer, the Viking quarterback, has signed a two-year extension of his contract that will reportedly bring him $350,000 a year when the extension begins at the end of his present five-year contract in 1985. ... Another quarterback, Jack Thompson, says he and the Cincinnati Bengals have worked out a contract and he will report to the team's minicamp. Thompson sat out the 1982 season after the strike, saying he should have been paid because he voted against the strike. ... Don McMahon, a Cleveland Indians pitching coach, was hospitalized with a heart ailment and the Indians have called up Chuck Estrada, their pitching coach at Charleston, W.Va., of the Class AAA International League. ... Champagne Tony Lema, the golf professional who was killed in a plane crash in 1966, has been honored by having a new golf course named after him along the shoreline of the San Leandro Marina at San Francisco. ... The drunken driving trial of Tom Cousineau, the Cleveland Browns' linebacker, ended in a hung jury in Rocky River, Ohio, and the city will decide by Tuesday whether to try him again.

title: BUFFALO STEAK
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT U.S. STAKES?
description: The Reagan Administration should not proclaim loudly that United States vital interests and credibility are at risk in Central America unless it is fully prepared to act. Before our honor is committed, Americans should know to whom it is being pledged. Most important, the Administration needs to decide what it is committed to opposing. Is it determined above all to fight leftist ideology or to contain Soviet power?

title: Miss McCabe Is Betrothed To an Artist
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert Emmet McCabe of Englewood, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Wyllys McCabe, to George Windsor Sherwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Holman Sherwood of Southport, Conn.

title: Elizabeth Rice Betrothed
description: Mrs. Richard Jay Wilcox of Summit, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Wood Rice, to Bruce Scott Wilson, son of Mrs. Harold Weeks of Aurora, N.Y., and Bruce Simpson Wilson of Dallas. The wedding is planned for August. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Garrison R. Rice.

title: Hallowed Mark Falls
description: Back in 1933 when Winfield Whipple set an Arkansas high school record by making a 24-foot long jump, great things were predicted of him and he started training for the Olympics. But, as his relatives recalled yesterday, before the Arkadelphia youth could make it to the Olympic Games, he died of bone cancer, a disease that developed following a jumping injury.

title: Provincetown
description: To the Editor: How nostalgic, how true was the Gregory Katz article ''What's Doing in Provincetown'' (Travel, May 1). We have saved our fall vacation time for P-Town for the last eight - soon nine - years and we are quite well-acquainted with it. (Also we love it).

title: BACKPACKING IN THE BACK COUNTRY
description: The reddish-orange of first light hangs on the tip of the steelgray peak above. The glassy surface of Mokawanis Lake is obscured by a low-lying mist that will dissipate as the sun moves higher into the sky and warms this quiet basin. But at dawn, even in July, the mornings in the high country of Glacier National Park are cool. I cast a handful of ground coffee into a pot of water just beginning to boil on my portable backpack stove.

title: SHULTZ DOESN'T TAKE A DAMASCUS NO FOR AN ANSWER
description: SYRIA last week tried its worst to wreck the Israeli-Lebanese accord on troop withdrawal and bilateral relations worked out by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. But yesterday, the Lebanese Cabinet approved the treaty and sent it to Parliament. Israel was expected to sign this week.

title:
ART;
SHOW ENCOMPASSES THE POSSIBILITIES AND PITFALLS OF SCULPTURE
description: IN celebration of its 65th anniversary, the American Society of Contemporary Artists has mounted an exhibition of works by 11 of its sculptor members at the North Shore Sculpture Center in Great Neck. The group, founded in 1917, was originally known as the Brooklyn Society of Artists, but 20 years ago the name was changed to allow expanded membership.

title: Grammar Phone
description: It started as an experiment last September, a hot line that anyone puzzled about a point of grammar could phone for advice. The questioner simply dialed REWRITE in New York City. Newspapers, radio and TV spread the word, and soon the hot line, manned by 16 volunteers at York College, was awash in publicity.

title: WELL-BEING
description: SUMMER IS THE SEASON, MORE THAN OTHERS, that mingles physical exuberance with physical exhaustion. It is also the season that puts the highest premium on physical appearance, since we show more of ourselves. The same hot sun and humid temperatures that propel us in droves to beaches, weekend retreats and picnics in the country can drain us of energy, heighten irritability and actually impair health. It is all too easy to forget at this time of year that physical and mental well-being is an integral part of a productive, fulfilling life.

title: 'THE QUESTION PURE MORALISTS HAVE TO FACE'
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHINESE PUZZLE MISSING SOME PIECES
description: THE CONSPIRACY AND DEATH OF LIN BIAO By Yao Ming-le. With an introduction by Stanley Karnow. Illustrated. 231 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: 5 TIE FOR LEAD AT 206 OVER SOGGY COURSE
description: Bobby Wadkins struggled through a bizarre combination of spring- and autumn-like weather today and his four-over-par 74 left him in a five-way tie for the lead after three rounds of the $400,000 Colonial National Invitation.

title: CHILEANS SEIZE 1,000 AT 2 SHANTYTOWNS
description: Troops carrying submachine guns seized about 1,000 people in predawn raids in two shantytowns in the southern part of the city today and carted them off to soccer stadiums and police stations.

title: Polly Vail Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vail of Bedford, N.Y., and Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Blair Vail, to Mark Lawson Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Walsh of Baltimore and Dunlewy, Ireland. The wedding is to be Oct. 1.

title: Laura Jacobs Engaged To Lloyd C. Blankfein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Jacobs of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laura Susan Jacobs, to Lloyd Craig Blankfein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Blankfein of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The wedding is to be June 19.

title: Ruttman Gets Pole Spot For Mason-Dixon 500
description: A day after his father's death from a heart attack, Joe Ruttman won the pole position today for Sunday's Mason-Dixon 500 Grand National stock-car race in a record time of 139.616 miles per hour.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME WORDS OF CAUTION ON PESTICIDES
description: MAY is the month when the browns and beiges of winter finally disappear. Barren branches once again take on a mantle of green and, as if by magic, flowers appear everywhere. It is a time to enjoy the garden, yet, as any experienced gardener knows, it is also the time when many things can go wrong and much work must be done.

title: IN THE LAND OF MARTIN LUTHER
description: Five hundred years ago on Nov. 11, St. Martin's Day, a young copper miner's wife gave birth to a son. The following morning he was baptized Martin. The family name was Luther. This centenary year will be a good time to visit the places connected with the Great Reformer - the composer of ''A Might Fortress Is Our God,'' the man who said ''God reformed the church while I drank Wittenberg beer'' and further emphasized the blunt realities of life by complaining that in Rome they thought that Germans had to pay attention when a cardinal broke wind.

title: Water Polo Gold To Soviet Union
description: Georgi Mshvenieradze scored a goal with 33 seconds to go in the deciding game of the III FINA Cup world water polo championships to give the Soviet Union a 6-5 victory over West Germany today. The gold medal marked the Soviet Union's third consecutive world championship and left West Germany with the silver.

title: Miss Slevin Plans A Jersey Wedding To E.H. Melhado
description: Mrs. Robert F. Slevin of Fair Haven, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Loretta C. Slevin, to Edmund H. Melhado, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Melhado of Dorset, Vt., formerly of Rumson, N.J.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF MASSAGE
description: GOOD MASSAGE is a potent tonic for mind and body. It can help relieve tension, stress and strain; temporarily aid blood circulation; make joints more supple, and act as a natural tranquilizer to induce pleasurable sedation. Medically, when performed by a physician or physical therapist, it can ease the pain of backaches, arthritis, bursitis, whiplash, sciatica and migraines. Massage, as a passive form of exercise, is also a valuable substitute for those who are incapable of activity.

title: Correction
description: ''In Africa Even the Flies Are Happy: Selected Poems 1964-1977'' by Breyten Breytenbach, from which a poem was excerpted May 1, is published in the United States by Riverrun Press. The book is available at $11.95 in cloth and $7.95 in paper from Flatiron Book Distributors, 175 Fifth Avenue, New York City 10010.

title: STARS VS. BLITZ TESTS U.S.F.L.
description: In Philadelphia this afternoon, the most successful team in the United States Football League, the Stars, play the Chicago Blitz, George Allen's outfit that is tied for first place in the Central Division. It looms as the best game of the weekend for the U.S.F.L. and another test at the box office.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Decides on Early Election
description: In the British political system, a Prime Minister can call an election any time within the five-year parliamentary term. Last week, Margaret Thatcher, who was elected in 1979, decided the time was right to go to the country for a new majority.

title: BRCIC'S PATIENCE IS REWARDED
description: In his five years as a backup goalkeeper for the Cosmos, David Brcic has been used primarily in emergencies or late-season games that did not mean much. But when Brcic starts in goal Sunday against the Tulsa Roughnecks at Giants Stadium, it will be the the first time that he has been given a starting role so early in the season.

title: SECOND OPINIONS ON MEDICAL EXAMINERS
description: Frank Sandola died of ''natural causes,'' the investigator from the New York City Medical Examiner's Office officially concluded. For a while, it seemed a reasonable diagnosis. The 42-year-old manager of two New York City health clubs had been found slumped over a table in his Manhattan apartment, a piece of meat lodged in his throat.

title: NEW YORK PRISON POPULATION HITS A RECORD 30,000
description: For the first time in New York's history, the number of inmates in the state's prisons exceeded 30,000 last week. At the aging state prison in Ossining, there were only 12 empty beds one day recently. At Attica, 2,193 inmates were living in a facility designed to hold 1,758.

title:
LEISURE;
SEEDLINGS IN A PLASTIC BAG WILL GROW JUST ABOUT ANYWHERE
description: Though container gardening has been around for some time, now there's a difference - the container is a bag. Gardeners are finding that soilless planting mixes bagged in large quantities of 16 to 40 quarts can be transformed into portable planters.

title: TOWN'S MERCHANTS FEAR 'NO SWIMMING' MEANS NO BUSINESS
description: THERE will be no swimming or fishing this summer at Black Rock State Park. For James and Peter Petruzzi, brothers and owners of the Black Rock Restaurant on Route 6 in Thomaston, a few hundred yards from the entrance to the 443-acre park, that could mean ruin.

title: Basketball Player Dies
description: Bruce Lee, a reserve forward on the University of Oklahoma basketball team, died today of complications after a routine tonsillectomy, hospital officials said. Margaret Barett, a nursing supervisor at Deaconess Hospital, said that the cause of death had not been determined, but that Lee, 21 years old, had died after the operation, not during it.

title: WHAT'S THE BOTTOM LINE ON THIRD WORLD DEBT?
description: When President Reagan and leaders of six other industrial nations examine economic issues over the Memorial Day weekend, they will take at least a glance at the troubles of third world countries, whose debt of more than $600 billion menaces the banking system of the industrial world. French President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada, moreover, are likely to press their colleagues at the Williamsburg, Va. summit to make some gesture towards the developing world. At a minimum, this might mean renewal of the unfulfilled pledge at last year's economic meeting in Versailles to launch ''global negotiations'' that the third world hopes will bring it a large-scale transfer of resources.

title: 'A STATEMENT THEY DID NOT IN FACT MAKE'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ARTIST IN POLITICS
description: REFLECTIONS OF A NONPOLITICAL MAN By Thomas Mann. Translated, with an introduction, by Walter D. Morris. 435 pp. New York: Frederick Ungar Publishing Co. $29.50.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ALL'S FAIRS
description: A fair is a fair is a fair, and today the spring fair circuit comes alive with enough varied seasonal festivals to keep Long Islanders hopping. For example, the Huntington Historical Society is holding ''Sheep to Shawl,'' and from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Powell-Jarvis House, 434 Park Avenue, visitors can see old-time craft demonstrations (including sheep shearing), hear Early American music and play old-fashioned games. The admission is $1, or 50 cents for children under 12.

title: Suellen Wilson, Jeffrey Wheeler Exchange Vows
description: Suellen Todd Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric J. Wilson Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., and West Stockbridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Weston Wheeler of Boca Raton, Fla., son of Joan Weston Wheeler and Thomas B. Wheeler Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Miner and the Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Saviour's Episcopal Church in Old Greenwich.

title: PINE BARRENS FACE NEW TEST
description: PHASE ONE of a development plan that Brookhaven Town officials said would safeguard 85,000 acres of environmentally sensitive land by diverting industrial growth into other areas of the town will be aired at a public hearing at the Brookhaven Town Board meeting tomorrow.

title: A CUSTOMER'S RIGHTS
description: ''THE customer is always right.'' That saying was often heard in the years when I was growing up. We did not totally believe it even then.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation Comfort

title: DONNISH WEST GERMAN TRIES TO RALLY SOCIALISTS
description: The 120-year-old Social Democratic Party of Germany is in an unenviable predicament. It lost not only the March 6 election but also the consolation prize of being the sole opposition party in Parliament - a role it must now share with an upstart, the antinuclear Greens.

title: Yanquiology
description: What are the damn Yanquis trying to tell us? You might well ask if you were an embattled Salvadoran democrat.

title: A STYLISH SUCCESS AND A HIGH-TONED FAILURE
description: NBC might seem these days to be trapped between the programming high road, with series such as ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''Cheers,'' and the exploitative low road, with violent concoctions like ''The A-Team.'' But in fact, the network is beginning to look strongest in the crucial middle ground of its schedule, most notably with a stylish private-eye series entitled ''Remington Steele.'' Currently shown on Tuesdays at 9 P.M., immediately following ''The A-Team,'' this MTM Enterprises production is frequently witty and it features what surely must be the most attractive couple on television's entertainment menu.

title: Hearing It From a Marine
description: According to William Safire, he expended considerable effort in chasing down what I meant by the word ''obtuse'' in my letter concerning incidents involving Israeli Defense Forces and my Marines serving in Lebanon (''Tell It to the Marines,'' On Language, April 17). I accept his criticism of my use of the word.

title: Gail Swirsky, Teacher, Marries in Connecticut
description: Gail Katherine Swirsky, daughter of Jeanne Feinn Swirsky of Waterbury, Conn., and Joseph Carl Swirsky of Woodbridge, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Philipp Joseph Franz Beaufays, son of Mrs. Josef Beaufays of Vienna and Cape Town and the late Dr. Josef Beaufays. Justice of the Peace Eugene Kaplan of Waterbury performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: NEW YORK IN RACE TO KEEP STRAVINSKY ARCHIVE
description: The clock is ticking in an international race to decide who will gain ownership of Igor Stravinsky's manuscripts, correspondence and memorabilia - an archive maintained by the late Russian-American composer that covers 60 years of musical, dance and literary history.

title: Bank Meeting Ends
description: The African Development Bank ended its annual meeting here today expressing hope that the admission of industrial nations would bring funds to alleviate the continent's economic difficulties.

title: CARDINALS DOWN EXPOS IN 11TH
description: Tom Herr hit a bases-loaded single with two out in the bottom of the 11th inning today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: REAGAN LAUDS SMALL BUSINESS
description: President Reagan, praising entrepreneurs as the ''forgotten heroes'' of America, said today that small businesses would help steer the nation toward economic recovery.

title: DINING AT ITS BEST IN HARTFORD
description: EVEN the name of Hartford's newest and most dazzling restaurant seems inspired: L'Americain. While French, the name plays up the restaurant's nouvelle American cuisine.

title: THE MILLIONAIRE OR THE DIRT FARMER?
description: OUT OF CANAAN By Keith A. Rice. 184 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95.

title: BRINK'S TESTIMONY EXAMINING ESCAPE
description: Testimony in the Brink's trial has turned to Joanne Chesimard, a Black Liberation Army leader who escaped from a New Jersey prison while serving a life sentence for the murder of a state trooper.

title: Postal Rivalry
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Bogota Ends Curfew and Ban On Liquor in Area of Clashes
description: The Colombian Government lifted a curfew and ban on liquor sales today in the jungle district of Caqueta, where 40 people died this week in clashes between the army and guerrillas.

title: Robin A. Brearton Married To Paul Curtis, an Actuary
description: Robin Abigail Brearton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Brearton of Killingworth, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Stephen Curtis, son of Dr. Emerson C. Curtis of Eureka, Utah, and the late Jacqueline Bardsley Curtis. The Rev. Marjean Bailey performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Andover, Mass.

title: TWO VIEWS OF ENGLISH GARDENS
description: EVERY country has its gardeners, but none, surely, in such abundance as England. A gardening show on British television was reported recently to have a year's backlog of questions sent in by its audience. Still, the national obsession with roses and glads, rockeries and trellises may not be as innocent as it seems. The British class system reigns over flowers as it does humans, and it was not so long ago that those aspiring to the upper classes would not give house room to house plants, lest they be suspected of owning no land.

title: PHILADELPHIA AVOIDS THOSE CODE WORDS
description: With only two days left before the mayoral primaries, the polls show that a substantial number of voters still haven't chosen between either of the two Democratic candidates.

title: COUNTRY PINE TAKES WITHERS
description: The Withers Stakes was a thrilling race for those watching the finish line at Aqueduct yesterday but a discouraging one for those looking ahead to the Preakness next Saturday. Country Pine won a three-way photo from I Enclose and Megaturn, but the winner finished eighth to Sunny's Halo in last week's Kentucky Derby and will not try him again in Baltimore.

title: Alicia M. Bradford Is Wed In a Connecticut Ceremony
description: Alicia Merriman Bradford, daughter of Elsa H. Bradford of Meriden, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to D. Alan Scribner 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Scribner of Glens Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Scott Sanders performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Cheshire, Conn.

title: More Cells In New York?
description: It is notoriously hard to find a place to live in New York City, but it is even harder to find a place for the notorious. Nevertheless, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, Commissioner of the State Department of Correctional Services, said last week that a search was under way for a site for a new medium- or maximum-security prison.

title: METS' ALLEN AND OROSCO STOP PIRATES, 6-2
description: The Mets' 6-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight was notable for several reasons, but primarily for the performance of the pitcher Neil Allen, who made his first major league start in four years after 208 consecutive relief appearances.

title: NINTH GRADE IS SPECIAL
description: IN Westport this fall, ninth graders will leave the junior high schools forever as they become part of a high school that now will include grades 9 through 12. Their exit is part of a trend back to the four-year high school.

title: On the Death Of a Parent
description: As one who within the past month lost a revered mother, I cannot relate to the feelings Barbra Wagner Williams expressed in her article ''Learning to Say Goodbye'' (Opinion Page, April 17).

title: Sneaky, but Not 'Intolerable'
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly, whom the Government's busy Abscam cameras captured stuffing $25,000 into his pockets, insisted that he had been framed. A Federal district judge agreed, tossing out his 1981 bribery-conspiracy conviction.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is inconceivable that the Arab position should be the cause of extending the duration of the Israeli occupation or allowing attempts at partition and subversion to emerge.'' - President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. (1:4.)

title: Taryn N. Emmons to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Emmons of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Taryn Niles Emmons, to John Halstead Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Freeman of Rumson, N.J. Miss Emmons is an account executive for the Shaw-Walker Furniture Company in New York, where her fiance is a freelance photographer.

title: YALE MEDICAL ART
description: The Yale Medical Library says it is the first to install a new method of cataloging, preserving and making accessible valuable museum collections.

title: Reena Raggi, D. W. Denton Are Married
description: Reena Raggi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Raggi of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to David William Denton, son of Mrs. Lyle McCallum of Great Falls, Mont., and the late Eugene Denton. The Rev. David McBriar performed the ceremony at St. Stephen of Hungary Roman Catholic Church.

title: SYRIAN VOWS TO UNDERMINE LEBANON-ISRAEL ACCORD
description: A ranking Syrian official said today that if the provisional accord on troop withdrawal between Israel and Lebanon was signed Syria would leave its troops in Lebanon for the foreseeable future and would ''do all we can to foil the agreement.''

title: Misfortune Continues to Follow Chacon
description: Bobby Chacon said he was ready again ''to fall off the deep end.'' On Thursday, the World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion learned that his fight Sunday with Cornelius Boza-Edwards, for which he was to be paid $450,000, had been called off by a Los Angeles County court at the request of the promoter Don King.

title: Ellen F. Hartwell, William L. Blais To Marry June 25
description: Ellen French Hartwell, director of group sales for the Metropolitan Theater Corporation in Los Angeles, and William Lee Blais, a management consultant with Arthur Young & Company in Los Angeles, plan to marry June 25.

title: PORT WINE'S ENGLISH ACCENT
description: Rob Roy Buckingham, a former editor of The New York Times News Service, has lived in Portugal for the last year. He collaborated on this article with Peter Webb, a former senior editor of Newsweek.Around noon every Wednesday, the automobiles sweep up to the gracious Palladian-style building near the waterfront of Oporto, Portugal, 175 miles northeast of Lisbon. The passengers, casually dressed in tweed sport jackets, talk in the cultivated accents of England's prestigious public schools. They saunter through the vast hallway, where sedan chairs were parked in the 18th century, and ascend the massive granite staircase that leads to the reading room and dining room.

title: MACY'S PROFITS BY GOING ITS OWN WAY
description: I N the mid-1960's, several ambitious young men, prodded by a demanding senior executive, developed a turn-around strategy for a decaying old department store in downtown Newark. The plan defied customary retailing methods, but in just a few years it brought about a stunning reversal in the fortunes of L. Bamberger & Company, and by 1970 it had become the most profitable division in R. H. Macy's retailing empire.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: LESSONS ON WAR AND PEACE
description: FROM Chicago, the 265 bishops of the Roman Catholic Church said their goodbyes last week and fanned out to their respective dioceses with a pastoral letter on nuclear arms that appeared certain to change the direction of the church's social ministry.

title: Scheveningen
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN-AMERICANS COMING INTO THEIR OWN
description: HERE ARE A NUMBER OF ways to assess the quiet yet spectacular rise of Italian-Americans in the United States today, but one of the best perspectives is from the 57th-floor windows of the Governor's New York City office in the World Trade Center. The view takes in Ellis Island, twin symbol of opportunity and pain to countless immigrants, and, beyond, the flat and colorless industrial precincts of Jersey City.

title: MEN SEEK AID ON FAMILY PROBLEMS
description: ''WHEN my problems began to interfere with my getting through the day, I knew I needed help,'' a 17-year-old student said. ''I saw no reason to hold on to a macho image, pretending I could handle it all alone.''

title: The Scourge of a New Disease
description: Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome is a strange and deadly new disease. Five hundred people have already died, half of them in New York City, and the epidemic is still gathering pace. Assuredly frightening, the disease has caused too much alarm among some groups at risk. But it also has caused too little in the Federal Government.

title: Castle
description: To the Editor:

title: RICHARD FOREMAN REMAINS PROVOCATIVE
description: Richard Foreman, the avant-garde director and playwright, has come a long way since 1968, when he opened his theater in a fourth-floor loft on lower Broadway. In the intervening 15 years he has produced approximately 20 of his own plays for his company, the Ontological-Hysteric Theater. For the last two years, Mr. Foreman has been in residence at the Public Theater, where the latest Ontological-Hysteric production, ''Egyptology (My Head Was a Sledge Hammer),'' opens this week. He has also created several musical theater pieces with the composer Stanley Silverman, including ''Dr. Selavy's Magic Theater,'' which had a long Off Broadway run, and ''Madame Adare,'' which was performed two years ago by the New York City Opera. And his unorthodox stagings of classic plays have been seen on such prestigious stages as the Vivian Beaumont at Lincoln Center, the Guthrie in Minneapolis, and the Paris Opera.

title: 'OAKLAHOMA!' IS STILL A LOVEABLE MUSICAL
description: NO matter when we saw ''Oklahoma!'' for the first time, or how many musicals we have seen since, this production will somehow symbolize our very first. The Darien Dinner Theater recaptures and, for some, creates the innocent aura of being initiated into a new world of wonder.

title: WINDSURFING RUNS INTO CHOPPY WATERS
description: ALTHOUGH Bruce Tait and Jerome Toy, owners of the Sag Harbor Sail and Pedal Company, have been renting windsurfers from their shop a few hundred feet from the beach adjacent to the wharf in Sag Harbor for the last three years, and they say the majority of village residents want their business to stay where it is, the village trustees recently voted unanimously not to allow the business to use the beach for windsurfing.

title: LONDON
description: A week or two ago there was opened at the Tate Gallery in London a most remarkable exhibition. Its full title is ''The Essential Cubism: Braque, Picasso & Their Friends, 1907-20.'' Organized by Douglas Cooper and Gary Tinterow, it consists of 232 paintings, papiers colles, drawings, sculptures and prints. By turns dense and luminous, monumental and alive with a darting mischief, the work in question adds up to a quite exceptional display. No one who cares for 20thcentury art and can get to London -whether by air, steamship or rowboat - should miss it.

title: Irsay Reprimanded
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, has reprimanded Robert Irsay, the owner of the Baltimore Colts, for asserting that his team would ''get'' John Elway, the Stanford quarterback who was drafted by the Colts, then spurned them and was traded to the Denver Broncos. According to an N.F.L. spokesman, after Rozelle told Irsay that he did not ''condone those kinds of remarks,'' Irsay said that all he had eant by his comments was that the Colts had signed some young defensive players who would be more aggressive toward all quarterbacks.

title: Pact Reached At Aqueduct
description: Agreement was reached early yesterday morning on a new contract offer that could end a 25-day strike by maintenance workers at Aqueduct.

title: THE MAN WHO IS TAKING THE LABOR MOVEMENT TO TASK
description: THE problem with the labor movement, Anthony Mazzocchi said the o ther day, ''is that it can't accommodate dissent.'' And for Mr. M azzocchi, a rebellious 56-year-old labor leader, that failing has h it close to home: Not only has it stripped the labor movement of i ts vigor and importance, but it also has thrust him from the fulcrumo f power in the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union into its f ringes.

title: ONE WOMAN'S CHOICE
description: The writer of this article requested anonymity. A Fantasy

title: 17 GROUPS AWAIT AID FOR HOMELESS
description: None of the 17 community groups promised grants by the state five months ago to house the homeless have received any money.

title: AN ATHLETE LEARNS SPORTS IS NOT ENOUGH
description: AFTER four years of playing basketball at the University of Connecticut, Michael McKay had accumulated a 14.3 shooting average per game and a reputation as a potential professional player.

title: WIDE ANTIMISSILE DRIVE URGED
description: European antiwar activists today called for general strikes, blockades, plebiscites and large-scale campaigns of civil disobedience to try to stop the planned NATO deployment of new United States nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: ROAD TO THE BUDGET MEANDERS THROUGH A POLITICAL MINEFIELD
description: In 1981 and 1982, Capitol Hill's budget debate was by and large dominated by spending -how much could be cut without unduly harming the poor and the re-election chances of members of Congress.

title: PROBLEMS OF MEXICO CITY: WARNING TO THIRD WORLD
description: Fed by the emissions of 2.4 million vehicles and 35,000 factories, by the smoke from burning garbage dumps and the dust thrown up by a dry lake bed, a huge blanket of brownish smog covers Mexico City most days. The stories spawned by the city's pollution are graphic - the 11,000 tons of waste material pumped into the atmosphere daily, the doctors who come from all over the world to study new respiratory diseases, the canary that was left in a cage on a downtown street corner and was dead within an hour.

title: THE BRITISH AND OTHER EUROPEANS
description: THE CHANGING ANATOMY OF BRITAIN By Anthony Sampson. 476 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Living Together Is Suddenly Risky
description: Consenting adults also need a consenting building owner if they want to share a New York City apartment. So ruled the State Court of Appeals last week in permitting the eviction of unrelated people living together without benefit of landlord.

title: FREE FENCE PAINT
description: Though the wrought- and cast-iron railings and fences that grace many of the city's landmarked churches, schools and libraries are protected by law and may not be removed or altered without permission, they still are vulnerable to the ravages of time and weather. In an effort to preserve these iron adornments, the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission is giving away 620 gallons of rust-inhibitive black paint to designated landmarks that are operated as non-profit institutions.

title: FAMILY WINS $122,000 FOR A CONTAMINATED WELL
description: When Marjorie Luecke moved into an 18thcentury Bucks County farmhouse in 1977 she thought it was the home of her dreams. But Mrs. Luecke says she and her two daughters almost immediately began to suffer mysterious symptoms.

title: Pamela Singer Shields Is Married in Delaware
description: Pamela Singer Shields, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson T. Shields 3d of Greenville, Del., was married there yesterday to Emile Pragoff 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pragoff Jr. of Hockessin, Del. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, by the Rev. Adam Lewis and the Rev. John Scobell.

title: KISSINGER AT 60
description: Henry Kissinger will be 60 this month, which is surprising, since he seems to have been an elder statesman ever since he was 40.

title: William M. Hickey, 76; Ex-United Corp. Head
description: William Mace Hickey, former president and chairman of the board of the United Corporation, a securities investment company, died yesterday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: LA PESA: TOAST OF THE TRATTORIAS
description: Certainly there are still disagreements about osso buco, Milan's savory contribution to the long Italian catalogue of veal dishes: The debate continues to simmer about whether to eat the risotto Milanese before the osso buco or with it, for example; or whether home-cooked osso buco is always preferable to the restaurant variety; or whether any innkeeper can prepare the hearty dish as well as any Milanese mamma.

title: Still No Exit For Sakharov
description: Andrei D. Sakharov knows too much for Moscow's good. Or so officials claimed last week in denying the physicist and human rights activist a chance to emigrate.

title: RESEARCHING AT THE CHECKOUT
description: Laser scanners are turning supermarkets into research laboratories. Five years ago barely 200 stores had the scanners, but today there are an estimated 8,000 and the number is growing as scanners become more advanced and their prices fall. Their increased number is causing an explosion in shopper information, which is beginning to change grocery retailing and manufacturing practices.

title: Notes on Chicago
description: As much as I enjoyed Andrew Malcolm's portrait of the city of Chicago, I was disturbed by his statement that ''two schools of jazz originated in Chicago, and blues clubs flourished, but real musical renown came with the symphony ...'' (''Chicago!'' April 10).

title: Women's Game Called Inferior
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Correction
description: The Sports People column on May 1 incorrectly described Ira Davis and Josh Culbreath. Neither ever won an Olympic gold medal.

title: CALIFORNIA COASTAL REPORT
description: Hugging the edge of one of America's most breathtaking shorelines, California's Route 1, one of the nation's busiest tourist byways, is broken in many places this spring. The worst storms to hit the state in decades, perhaps in a century, chiseled and sliced and eroded the highway until much of it plunged into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Recent Sales
description: Denville $177,000 *2*21 Mabro Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old *2*colonial; central vacuum, deck; taxes $2,400. Glen Rock $175,000 *2*31 Birchwood Road, 5-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; beamed living room, country *2*kitchen; taxes $2,900. Mahwah $117,000 *2*84 Oweno Road, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old *2*colonial; wrap-around porch, crescent driveway; *2*taxes $1,646. Sparta $70,000 *2*5 Birch Parkway, 2-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*35-year-old cottage; close to Lake Mohawk, *2*fireplace; taxes $1,490. Upper Montclair $107,500 *2*60 Normal Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old *2*colonial; finished basement, fireplace; *2*taxes $3,312. West Orange $88,200 *2*29 Bradley Terrace, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old *2*colonial; natural woodwork, new carpeting; *2*taxes $2,113. OTHER AREAS Albertson, L.I. $88,500 *2*5 Meadow Drive, 5-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*30-year-old Cape Cod; new roof, full basement; *2*taxes $2,300. New Fairfield, Conn. $74,500 *2*Lake Drive South, 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*28-year-old log ranch; lake community, *2*100-by 100-foot lot; taxes $918. Yonkers, N.Y. $133,000 *2*1 Clare Terrace, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*43-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; new roof, *2*walk to station and stores, 52- by 100-foot lot; *2*taxes $2,373.

title: HANDLING CLAIMS ON PROPERTIES
description: THE threat of a lien on your home or the discovery of a lien on property you are about to buy can be a scary proposition. Many people fear that once a creditor has secured a lien, it will become tough to sell that property - in financial terms, akin to discovering termites in the woodwork. This is, indeed, true, but the dangers and problems are lessened if the right responses are made by the house or apartment owner.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ON FILM, AS SEEN BY NADINE GORDIMER
description: JOHANNESBURG Nadine Gordimer, South Africa's foremost novelist by any serious literary reckoning, was not bowled over when a producer of educational television films from Munich appeared on her doorstep in a sedate white neighborhood with a proposition for putting some of her short stories on film. Earnest visitors from the west, with a sudden urge to get involved in the intense morality play that is everyday reality here, show up occasionally in Miss Gordimer's fiction and more frequently in her life; typically the impulse that brings them expires with their visas.

title: THE PROJECT THAT TRANSFORMED A BRONX NEIGHBORHOOD
description: AMID the South Bronx's glut of high-rise housing projects and b urned-out tenements, a cluster of low-rise, award-winning buildings s tands out in an area generally devoid of personality.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 15, 1983
description: International

title: TRADITION BOUND ALLEN-STEVENSON SCHOOL MARKS CENTENNIAL
description: The Allen-Stevenson School, which began when a young man just out of Harvard College accepted a job teaching the two sons of a wealthy family in the attic of their Fifth Avenue brownstone, will celebrate its centennial at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel next Wednesday night.

title: Chemical Clue In Anorexia
description: In still another study that suggests an interaction between psychology and biochemistry, researchers at the National Institute of Mental Health have found that young women suffering from anorexia nervosa had elevated levels of the hormone called vasopressin. Anorexia, a disorder in which women become obsessed with weight loss, has been considered strictly behavioral.

title: Warsaw Newspaper Warns Catholic Church
description: The editor of a Warsaw newspaper warned the Roman Catholic Church today against applying double standards in its actions.

title: CANADA
description: I was walking down an antiseptically tidy street in downtown Ottawa when I became aware of a knot of some 20 pedestrians waiting on the curb. The light was red, but there were no cars in sight. No policemen, either. It was a narrow little street. The rain was fairly heavy and unpleasant. But still the small crowd waited patiently - rather stupidly, I thought - until the light changed.

title: FORMER LAB WORKER QUERIED ON ALTERED DATA
description: Defense attorneys for four former laboratory officials being tried here on charges of falsifying data in cancer and toxicity studies have sought to portray the Government's chief witness as an embittered employee who stole boxloads of data to cover his own wrongdoings.

title: ARGUENDO
description: William Zinsser has written a book, ''Writing with a Word Processor,'' which arguably gives the most helpful and humane treatment of the subject and is surely the most stylish book produced so far on that intimidating machine. I put it that way because, in recent correspondence, he added a postscript: ''By the way, what the hell does arguably mean?''

title: TWO WAYS TO HANDLE GROWTH: RIGHT AND WRONG
description: THIS is a tale about two villages and how they grew. One managed it with grace and good sense, and the other did not. The first is still a fine place to live with beauty, diversity and a feeling of community. The second - well, here is what happened.

title: PLANS FOR TRUMAN CENTENNIAL STIR FRIENDS' REMEMBRANCES
description: It was supposed to be a businesslike meeting to announce plans to observe the centennial of Harry S. Truman's birth, but it quickly became an occasion for fond recollections by his associates.

title: Safeguarding the Hudson
description: A small band of fisherman and river enthusiasts was on hand today when a 25-foot boat was ceremoniously lowered into the Hudson River to mark the beginning of a new project to help keep the river free of pollution and serve as a floating research station.

title: ARE VIDEO GAMES ABOUT TO ZAP THE ACTION MOVIE?
description: More and more these days one attends to the mayhem within an action movie with impatience, as if watching other people play video games, which, when the history of entertainment is written, may turn out to be the breakthrough of our era. Old-fashioned movies can't easily compete with the wizardry that, for a small price, allows anyone to be the hero of his own action epic.

title: Durango
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE nonprofit New Haven Food Co-op, struggling for the past year to stay in business, has closed and has filed for a reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws. But its operators are attempting to salvage the store, according to Joseph Ballow, co-op general manager, who said that it was ''hard to say'' whether the effort would be successful.

title: Interest on Escrow
description: Question: My home mortgage has a clause requiring that the monthly payments include an amount to be held by the bank in escrow for property taxes and insurance bills. I understand that New York State law requires that the bank pay interest on the escrow funds. Does this requirement apply to mortgages that predate the law? If this is the case, what rate is specified? ... K.E.W., Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: MAJORCA: GEORGE SAND WAS RIGHT
description: ''I f European civilization could arrive at the point of doing away with customs officers and revenue guards, those manifestations of mistrust and national antipathies, if communication by steamer could be organized direct from our country to those parts,'' wrote the French novelist George Sand in 1839, ''Majorca could very soon compete with Switzerland. The day will come no doubt when those seeking rest, and even beautiful women, will be able to go to Palma with no greater fatigue and trouble than that with which they now go to Geneva.''

title: FINLAND IMPORTS MUSICAL EXCITEMENT
description: As those who attended the recent Finnish National Opera productiions of Joonas Kokkonen's ''Last Temptations'' and Aulis Sallinen's ''Red Line'' at Lincoln Center may have already discovered, there is some exciting new music emanating from Finland. Mr. Kokkonen and Mr. Sallinen are only the most outstanding of several worthy contemporary Finnish composers, among them Einojuhani Rautavaara, Paavo Heininen, Erkki Salmenhaara and Kalevi Aho. Definitive recordings of ''The Last Temptations,'' ''The Red Line'' and Mr. Sallinen's earlier opera, ''The Horseman,'' are now available in the United States from Polygram Special Imports, 137 West 55th Street, New York, N.Y., 10019.

title: Susan E. Mitrani Is Married to Fred David Knapp
description: Susan Ellen Mitrani, daughter of Paula Mitrani Lustbader of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Harold P. Mitrani of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Fred David Knapp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Knapp of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: DON KING'S CONTROL GROWS
description: THE Brooklyn Bridge is 100 years old and Don King continues to sell it. In the fast-talking world of wise guys and pugs, this 51-year-old salesman supreme has methodically fast-talked and muscled his way to the largest share of the multimillion-dollar boxing business.

title: HOMES ON A LEASE-PURCHASE PLAN
description: MANY families that could afford regular monthly mortgage payments e nd up renting instead of buying because they cannot save enough m oney to make the down payment required by most banks.

title: ART
description: Alexander Hollweg is an English artist whose activity is not easily defined. For years he made sculptures that were in effect landscape paintings that just happened to bulge into the third dimension.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT BUCKS BY 104-96
description: For all of his other great talents, Moses Malone of the Philadelphia 76ers is also proving to be an accurate forecaster. Nearly two weeks ago when he was asked how his team would fare in the playoffs, he said, ''Four, four and four.''

title: TOMORROW'S PLANTS ON 7 COUNTY PLOTS
description: FOR most people, getting ready for the gardening season means hauling out the tools and a quick trip to the garden shop for seeds and fertilizer. But John Scarchuk of Coventry has to plan his garden 5, 10, sometimes even 15 years in advance.

title: Bad Ink Between Moscow, Warsaw
description: The Polish Government found itself in an ideologial squeeze last week as prodding from the Soviet Union appeared to encourage a renewed push by hard-liners at home. Faced with Moscow's sternest criticism since the imposition of martial law 17 months ago, Warsaw was forced to defend itself in the midst of heightened nervousness over the visit next month of Pope John Paul II.

title: Woman's Trial Put Off In Killing of Her Father
description: The Utah Supreme Court has postponed the trial of Frances Bernice Schreuder, a New Yorker accused of ordering the 1978 killing of her father by her son.

title: Spain's Socialists Come Out Ahead
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's right-wing opposition had insisted that last weekend's local elections would be a test of voter confidence in Spain's five-month-old Socialist Government. If so, Mr. Gonzalez had little to worry about.

title: IN HARTFORD, A PARADE OF PAINTINGS
description: ONE of America's best-known historical paintings, ''The Declaration of Independence'' by John Trumbull, will be carried in a stately procession up Hartford's Main Street from the Wadsworth Atheneum to the Old State House Thursday at noon.

title: TANAKA: STILL ON TRIAL-AND STILL POWERFUL
description: The Lockheed bribery trial has been running for more than six years now, an enduring drama with former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka as its central character.

title: Milestone for Jackson
description: It was one of those milestones that baseball is forever celebrating, but Reggie Jackson, the California Angels' outfielder and designated hitter, wasn't in a celebrating mood after reaching the milestone in a game against the Minnesota Twins Friday night. He had just struck out for the 2,000th time in his major league career, the first player ever to do so.

title: Robin Woodard Wed in Houston
description: The marriage of Robin Lorraine Woodard, an assistant vice president of Scudder Fund Distributors in New York, to Joseph Peter Bergmeyer, a vice president of the Schroder Leasing Company in New York, took place at the First Congregational Church in Houston yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Tucker, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Declan Bailey, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Wedding in June For Leslie Fritz
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Fritz of Milwaukee and Ephraim, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Hayes Fritz, to Richard N. Doyle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle of Saddle River, N.J. The wedding is to be June 18.

title: Olajuwon Decides He Won't Turn Pro
description: Akeem Olajuwon, the 7-foot center who led the University of Houston into the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball final, said today that he would return to the school for his junior year rather than turn professional.

title: Steamboating
description: To the Editor: The article ''Steamboating in Ontario'' (Travel, March 27) brought back many memories. My first trip on the Segwun (then the Nipissing) was in July 1900 at the age of 10 months.

title: A 12-DAY PLUNGE INTO 5 NATIONAL PARKS
description: Pale blond, the size of a mountain lion and with a lion's shanks, but with the neck and head of a ram, the lone, elegant bighorn was seated regally on a narrow ledge that rose steeply along the side of a canyon road. It was munching grass amid Indian paintbrush and other alpine flora and its huge, liquid brown eyes seemed to mirror all the wisdom of nature. Having gazed, spellbound, at this mythical beast from less than six yards' distance, I would not have been surprised to encounter, at the road's next bend, a unicorn.

title: TECH BEATS ST. JOHN'S IN FINAL
description: Jim Dalton and Al Ashkinazy hit run-producing singles in the seventh inning yesterday as New York Tech defeated St. John's, 2-1, in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey baseball playoffs at Redmen Field in Jamaica, Queens.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME WORDS OF CAUTION ON PESTICIDES
description: MAY is the month when the browns and beiges of winter finally disappear. Barren branches once again take on a mantle of green and, as if by magic, flowers appear everywhere. It is a time to enjoy the garden, yet, as any experienced gardener knows, it is also the time when many things can go wrong and much work must be done.

title: Coast Bomber Sentenced
description: John Rico, 30 years old, has been sentenced to 10 years in Federal prison for planting a bomb in the House of Iran restaurant in Beverly Hills June 10, 1980. On Wednesday Federal District Judge Laughlin Waters ordered that the Federal sentence be served after Mr. Rico finishes a six-year state term in a case involving explosives. A friend said Mr. Rico bombed the restaurant to express his feelings of the taking of American hostages in Iran in 1980.

title: Rebecca Alice Bodell and John Hsu Are Married
description: Rebecca Alice Bodell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Ronald Bodell Jr. of Warwick Neck, R.I., was married yesterday to John Hsu of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jabin Hsu of Shanghai and Hong Kong. The Rev. Kenneth R. Franklin performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Warwick, R.I.

title: U.S. Reports Cracking Six-State Drug Ring
description: Federal agents arrested 13 people and were hunting for 12 more who were reported to be involved in a ring that ran a marijuana operation in six states, the United States Attorney said Friday.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE MARKS THE GROWTH OF PHYSICAL FITNESS IN THE NATION
description: The United States Postal Service seems to be making 1983 the year for causes. A new 20-cent commemorative for Physical Fitness has just been issued, less than three weeks after a commemorative for Volunteerism.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Administration Ousts Expert In American Indian Education
description: One of the Government's top experts on Indian education has been dismissed in what critics say is a campaign by the Reagan Administration to eliminate a program providing assistance to American Indian schoolchildren.

title: IS THIS THE BEST KIND OF PUBLIC ART?
description: No one can accuse the world of neglecting the artist Christo, that master manipulator of landscape and the media. In fact, it's probably safe to say that since the late 1960's, when he began his bold-scale outdoor operations - wrapping a mile of Australian coastline to create a mysterious new cliffscape, bridging the gap between two Colorado peaks with a shimmering orange curtain, snaking a nylon ''fence'' some 24 miles over hill and dale to the sea in northern California - no other creator in the fine arts has commanded so much public attention, not all of it positive, to be sure. He and his current ''Surrounded Islands'' spectacular - opened in Miami May 4 and ending on Wednesday - have been given prime exposure by networks and newspapers around the globe, right up there with such headline stories as Hitler's diaries, the Israel-Lebanon draft agreement and the nuclear arms freeze.

title: BIAS: BLAMING THE VICTIMS
description: LEADERSHIP in the public schools of Long Island is still monopolized by men.
