Women have been fighting for equality the last 20 years, yet sex discrimination continues to permeate the primary stronghold of education where women hold few administrative positions as well as unequal salaries.

title: Australia to Study Effects of Agent Orange
description: The Government today announced an inquiry into Vietnam veterans' claims that exposure to chemical defoliants such as Agent Orange damaged their health.

title: AGENCY CRITICIZED ON AIRPORT NOISE
description: The Town of Hempstead's Presiding Supervisor says the Port Authority has not been aggressive enough in seeking Federal funds that could be used for noise abatement in schools around Kennedy International Airport.

title: SCOTTISH ISLES
description: To the Editor:

title: 200 Cheer as Grocery Collapses Into Ground
description: A supermarket built over an abandoned coal mine sank into shifting ground and broke apart Friday as about 200 spectators cheered.

title: 'FIRST STEP TOWARD NUCLEAR WEAPONS REDUCTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Jays Turn In 1-Hitter
description: Luis Leal and Roy Lee Jackson combined on a one-hitter, and Willie Upshaw hit a two-run triple to highlight a six-run fourth inning today and carry the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Panamanian Reported Ready to Quit Key Post
description: Brig. Gen. Ruben Dario Paredes, head of the national guard, was quoted as saying today that he would give up his post before making a trip to Washington next month.

title: RUTGERS' EAGLETON POLL STARTS TO PHASE OUT ITS OPERATIONS
description: The Eagleton Poll of Rutgers University, which has reported New Jerseyans' opinions of candidates, elected officials, gambling and chemical wastes since 1971, is preparing to go out of business.

title: Future Events; All Week Long
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Galaxy of Stars

title: Stonehenge Defaced By Soccer Followers
description: Vandals sprayed soccer slogans in blue paint today on five of the ancient monoliths at Stonehenge.

title: Turkey Calls U.N. Vote On Cyprus Unbalanced
description: Turkey said today that a United Nations call for the withdrawal of foreign troops from Cyprus was unbalanced.

title: Defending P.S. 40
description: To the Editor:

title: Supporting Genius
description: Two years ago the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in Chicago began searching for ''exceptionally talented'' people so it might offer them up to $60,000 a year for the next five years, no strings and no taxes attached.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 9 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 6 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high-school set. 3 3 6 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 4 4 7 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 5 5 7 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 6 7 4 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 7 6 7 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.) London bankers gamble on the ability of a horse breeder to produce a star race horse. 8 8 10 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh.

title: BEQUEST IN RICH COAST AREA STALLED: TOO FEW NEEDY
description: When a Marin County widow, Beryl H. Buck, died in 1975, she left $7 million in a charitable trust fund to ''care for the needy in Marin.'' But in Marin County, whose residents' average income is among the highest in the United States, there are apparently not enough poor people for charities to spend their money on.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen E. Turton Is Married to Stephen E. Porter
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Ellen Eugenia Turton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Turton of Orlando, Fla., formerly of Southport, was married to Stephen Earle Porter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Porter of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: AUDIO WITH A SWISS TOUCH
description: It has been said of the Swiss that, over the last 500 years, they have changed from mercenary soldiers into mercenary bankers. This capsule of Helvetic history skips other favorite occupations. Aside from their fruitful engagement with chocolate and cheese, the Swiss have been among the world's best mechanics and engineers for more than a century, as witness their watches, mountain railways, cannon, and machine tools.

title: GREENWICH
description: PERIODIC drinking of alcoholic beverages ''is almost universal'' by seniors in five high schools in this generally wealthy town, with almost four out of 10 seniors reporting that they get drunk at least once a week, according to a survey of 4,355 students in seventh through 12th grades in 10 private and public schools.

title: FOR EMPTY NESTERS, THE ADULT VILLAGE
description: TWO middle-aged couples, arms linked, lounge in a huge hot tub. Another couple embrace after a game of tennis. Others chat over a game of pool. Everyone is smiling.

title: Spanish King Visiting Brazil
description: King Juan Carlos and Queen Sophia of Spain arrived in this historic colonial city today at the start of a six-day visit to Brazil. They were scheduled to go sightseeing before flying Monday to Brasilia for meetings with President Joao Figueiredo.

title: EGYPT URGES ARAB NATIONS TO BACK THE ACCORD ON TROOP WITHDRAWALS
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt urged Arab nations today ''not to be thrifty in their support'' of an accord for the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon.

title: DAVID BOWIE TAKES ON THE CHALLENGE OF BEING HIMSELF
description: Since his last foray into rock and roll in 1980, David Bowie has become known for his acting - on stage in ''The Elephant Man,'' on television in Bertolt Brecht's ''Baal,'' and on screen in a host of forgettable films. His most memorable roles, however, have always been connnected to his music. Whether as a means of distancing himself from his own creations, or of making musical dilletantism more respectable, Mr. Bowie routinely interposes another persona between himself and his work.

title: INDIAN POINT AND SHOREHAM PROBLEMS INTERTWINE
description: AT Lake Success and Valley Stream, three 115-kilovolt cables stretch from the Long Island Lighting Company's electric grid into the system of the Consolidated Edison Company, and at almost every moment of every day the companies are feeding power to each other. The two utilities have maintained this underground connection for years, but in the last few days they have added a link that may be far more significant; both are now struggling with recalcitrant counties that threaten to shut their most valuable assets, nuclear reactors.

title: 'THE COST OF THIS MORALITY IS CIVILIZATION ITSELF'
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Melinda Hevner Is Married
description: Melinda Verel Hevner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon L. Hevner of Park Ridge, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Ernest Canty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Canty of Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. George W. Kaslow Jr. performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church.

title: A NEW DANCE, A NEW PARTNERSHIP
description: At the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow night, American Ballet Theater will present the first New York performance of ''Estuary,'' a new ballet by the American choreographer Lynne Taylor-Corbett. ''Estuary'' is Miss Taylor-Corbett's second commission from American Ballet Theater and the first ballet ever created especially for Martine van Hamel and Patrick Bissell. Discussing their collaboration recently, the choreographer and dancers seemed pleased with the results.

title: Dioxin Trial To Proceed
description: The progress of a lawsuit filed by Vietnam veterans against the chemical companies that produced Agent Orange, a Federal judge noted early on, would turn on whether the companies had withheld information from the Government about the dangers of the herbicide. Last week, the judge, George C. Pratt Jr., ruled that the preliminary evidence showed Washington hadn't been fully informed and that the suit should go to trial.

title: THEATER: FRANK LANGELLA IN 'PASSION'
description: IT really is true: There are no tired stories - only tired writers. In ''Passion,'' at the Longacre, the English playwright Peter Nichols takes one of the oldest tales in the book - a middle-aged husband has an affair with a younger woman - and, with virtuoso writing and unsparing honesty, rocks the foundations of an audience's complacency. The gripping, recognizable world in this play is a barren contemporary landscape where husbands and wives can divorce easily, but where passion and suffering form an unholy union that no one can tear asunder. It's the most savage view of marriage yet from the author of ''A Day in the Death of Joe Egg'' and ''Forget-Me-Not Lane.''

title: THE MEMORY OF HITLER
description: In a way, it's a shame that the hoax of the Hitler diaries was so quickly exposed and that the central question discussed is the greedy and arrogant motive for perpetrating it.

title: LAKERS WIN FOR 3-1 EDGE
description: Magic Johnson scored 31 points and contributed 17 assists today as the Los Angeles Lakers fought off a fourth-quarter rally and beat the San Antonio Spurs, 129-121. The victory gave the Lakers a 3-1 lead in the Western Conference final of the National Basketball Association.

title: Noah Wins Final, Beating Higueras
description: Yannick Noah of France won the last 11 games of the match to defeat Jose Higueras of Spain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, 6-0, today in the final of the $250,000 German Open tennis tournament.

title: 3 Die in New Delhi Accident
description: Thousands of cylinders filled with cooking gas burst into flames at a bottling plant here today, killing 3 people and injuring 30 others, the police said.

title: BULLETPROOFED ASSAILANT OF GUN CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: 28 Peruvian Guerrillas Are Reported Killed
description: Twenty-eight guerrillas have been killed by Government security forces in clashes in the last few days, according to the police.

title: More Credibility Is Aim Of Power System Chief
description: The appointment Friday of Donald Mazur, 49, as managing director of the Washington Public Power Supply System's financially troubled nuclear construction program is expected to pave the way for a smooth management transition.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Fancy Footwork; Cycles of Menace
description: The most irresponsible drivers on New York streets are the bicyclists who ignore red lights, blindside motorists, ride the wrong way on one-way streets and, whistles blowing, threaten pedestrians. The offenders are not only annoying, they break skulls and legs.

title: Arias Takes Final
description: Jimmy Arias of the United States defeated Francesco Cancellotti of Italy, 6-4, 6-3, today to win the $88,500 Florence International tournament.

title: EDUCATION: PROLONGED 'AGONY' IS NO SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Gretzky Lives A Nightmare
description: FOR Wayne Gretzky, it is 3 in the morning, when the bad dreams come out to play. He is always off balance; strange objects strike him from every angle; he can no longer perform the task that always seemed simple for him: putting a puck in a net.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Have any players beside Sal Maglie played for the old New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers and for the New York Yankees?

title: CORRECTION
description: In New York Day by Day on Saturday, the age of Judge Edward Weinfeld of United States District Court was given incorrectly. He is 82.

title: NOISE CURBS ON JETS THREATEN CHARTERS
description: Noise restrictions scheduled to go into effect at New York metropolitan airports in July have set off a chain reaction in the charter industry that may result in higher air fares and may put financial pressure on charter tour operators and charter airlines.

title: 'REACHING OUT'
description: PATRICIA RUSSELL has written, directed, helped finance and starred in ''Reaching Out,'' a film that opens today at the Embassy 72d Street theater for reasons that probably only Patricia Russell would understand. This badly dated period piece recalls the early 70's at their dingiest, as a not very sympathetic young woman wanders through New York in search of companionship and self-expression.

title: Pam Shriver Wins
description: Pam Shriver of the United States defeated Tracy Austin, 6-2, 6-2, today to win the women's title in the $200,000 Gunze invitation tournament. Jun Kamiwazumi beat the Australian John Newcombe, 6-3, 7-5, in the men's final.

title: Middle West Earthquake Is Felt in Four States
description: A minor earthquake rumbled through the Middle West early today, rattling windows and shaking some residents awake in four states.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Tigers at Detroit, 7:35 P.M. This is the Yankees' first stop on a nine-game, 10-day road trip to three cities.

title: FIREFIGHTERS IN MILFORD FEUD WITH VOLUNTEERS
description: Life was a good deal less confusing here when the firefighters basically fought fires. But lately the city's 216 firefighters - half of them paid city employees, half volunteers - have been busier battling one another in the bitter ouster of the volunteers.

title: Jockey Is Killed In Spill at Phoenix
description: A veteran jockey died in surgery today from internal injuries he suffered when he was trampled by two horses after a fall during the third race at Turf Paradise. Nels Petersen, 44 years old, died at John C. Lincoln Hospital.

title: Six Challenged Ads Changed or Dropped
description: In six of the 11 challenges to national advertising assertions resolved in April by the industry's self-regulatory apparatus, the books were closed when the advertisers either changed the assertions or for one reason or another stopped the advertising.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ORIOLES, 2-1, ON 4-HITTER
description: Bucky Dent singled home the deciding run in the second inning yesterday as the Texas Rangers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2-1, in Arlington, Tex., behind the four-hit pitching of Danny Darwin and strong relief by Odell Jones.

title: Required Reading; Rehnquist on Judges
description: From a speech by Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court, delivered at Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, March 11, 1983: What are the attributes that make a good judge? The ability to write clearly is obviously a very important one, but just as obviously it is not the only one. Especially with respect to the office of Chief Justice, the ability to keep eight prima donnas on some sort of a leash, given the very limited authority over his colleagues which the Chief Justice possesses, is important; it must be done largely by conciliation, persuasion and the development of consensus within the Court as a body.

title: STERN'S PARENT, AFTER THE HOAX
description: Stern magazine, its publisher, Gruner & Jahr, and the parent, the Bertelsmann group, are all trying to assess the business damage from Stern's publication of bogus Hitler diaries.

title: Johns Hopkins No.1 in Lacrosse
description: Johns Hopkins was named the top Division I team in the country today in the final weekly poll of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Coaches Association.

title: Beloved Herring Maven Is Returning to Solow
description: One of the favorite characters in advertising for those who were still listening to radio from 1964 to 1969 was the Beloved Herring Maven, who was created by Martin Solow, then head of Solow/Weston.

title: STATE POWER AUTHORITY PLANS ISSUE
description: A New York State Power Authority $590 million bond issue dominates this week's new-issue financing. The corporate schedule is light, and the Treasury's financing is limited to a reduced auction of Treasury bills until Congress votes to raise the debt ceiling.

title: VIOLENT UNDERCURRENT MARKS SOME FILMS AT CANNES FESTIVAL
description: A powerful undercurrent of violence marks many films that are being shown in and around this year's Cannes Film Festival. The violence depicted is usually undertaken by individuals for their own inscrutable ends and not by groups whose misdeeds are more easily explained away.

title: Judy Lynn Stein Marries
description: Judy Lynn Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stein of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Andrew D. Lipschitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Lipschitz, also of New Rochelle.

title: CARLTON BEATS CUBS FOR SIXTH VICTORY
description: Steve Carlton got his sixth victory of the season when the Phillies beat the Cubs, 5-3, in 10 innings at Chicago yesterday, but he fell one short of Walter Johnson's career strikeout total, recently surpassed by Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros.

title: Heinsohn Meets On Rockets' Job
description: Tom Heinsohn, who guided the Boston Celtics to two world championships, met today with Ray Patterson, the Houston Rockets' general manager, to discuss the team's vacant coaching job.

title: NEW LEADER STEERS BLACK BAPTIST CHURCH INTO ACTIVIST COURSE
description: The president of the National Baptist Convention, the country's largest black denomination, says his church has abandoned the staunchly conservative stance its top officials held in his predecessor's 30-year tenure.

title: MUSIC: HOROWITZ RECITAL AT METROPOLITAN OPERA
description: VLADIMIR HOROWITZ long ago reached the plateau, achieved by only a handful of musicians in any generation, at which his every appearance in public qualifies as an Event. So, the Metropolitan Opera House was awash in celebrities last night for his piano recital. Musicians could be seen on every side, of course, but the turnout also included the fashionable audience that always wants to be on hand whenever anything out of the ordinary is going on. The Met was the place to be on this night, and no mistake.

title: Residents of Dioxin Site Sign Up for Housing Aid
description: Residents of a highly contaminated mobile home park signed up for temporary housing assistance today, but many said that despite the dioxin, they would stay in their homes for now.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide on Wednesday gave an incorrect minimum for the show at Michael's Pub. It is $10.

title: Cuts Urged at Cockerill
description: Cockerill-Sambre, the ailing Belgian steel company, must trim 8,000 people from its work force of 22,200 and get $2.1 billion in new financing to avoid a Government bailout, according to a Government-appointed expert.

title: West Bank Demonstrations Leave 3 Palestinians Injured
description: An Israeli Army spokesman said today that three Palestinians were injured in Nablus during demonstrations in the occupied West Bank.

title: FOR DEAF CHILDREN, SPECIAL CLASSES IN SELF-DEFENSE
description: ''What is crime?'' Kerry O'Brien, a social worker with the Victim Services Agency, asked the students gathered for a special assembly at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf.

title: PANEL IN SENATE SAYS F.B.I. WITHHELD DATA ON DONOVAN
description: A Senate committee has concluded that officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ''misled'' the committee in 1981 and 1982 by withholding information that might have cast doubt on the fitness of Raymond J. Donovan to be Secretary of Labor.

title: The Scandal in Chemical Testing
description: There is an appalling rent in the safety net that protects the public from hazardous chemicals. New compounds must be tested by law, but what if those hired to do the testing cut corners and fabricate the results? According to a Government study released during a trial now under way in Chicago, 15 percent of all the pesticides on the market have been certified safe on the basis of one or more tests now thought to be invalid.

title: U.S. PUSH IN WORLD MARKET URGED
description: Leaders of 16 major universities and corporations called on President Reagan yesterday to put the full weight of the White House behind a new national program to restore the nation's ability to compete with other industrial nations.

title: 8 GERMANS FREED FOR LIBYANS
description: Two Libyans who had been accused of torturing a compatriot here were sent home today in exchange for the return of eight West Germans who had been arrested in Libya.

title: Soviet Body May Add To Andropov's Roles
description: The Soviet Union announced today that the Supreme Soviet, the country's nominal Parliament, would meet in regular summer session on June 16. The announcement appeared to add weight to reports that the session will be used to install a successor to Leonid I. Brezhnev as head of state.

title: GRAND TRUNK EXPANSION PLAN
description: If the Interstate Commerce Commission approves the reorganization plans of the bankrupt Milwaukee Road, the Grand Trunk Corporation, a subsidiary of the Canadian National Railway Company, will accomplish a westward push from here into the heartland of the United States that it first began contemplating more than a century ago.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*8.86 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*11.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: JAZZ PIANO: MISS MCPARTLAND
description: THE most jazz-oriented of the major composers for Broadway and Hollywood musicals during the 20's, 30's and 40's was, without a doubt, Harold Arlen. There will be votes for George Gershwin, but Gershwin's music was less jazz than ''jazzy,'' that descriptive term of the 20's that identified music that was still anchored in ragtime.

title: Miss Hendel Weds Steve Zelson, Lawyer
description: Shelley Hendel, a psychiatric social worker at the Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens, was married yesterday to Steve Zelson, a patent lawyer. Rabbi Carl Astor performed the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue in New London, Conn., where the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Myron Hendel, reside.

title: COLONIAL TO COLBERT
description: Jim Colbert defeated Fuzzy Zoeller on the sixth hole of a sudden-death playoff today and won the Colonial National Invitation golf tournament.

title: Helena Deutsch Is Married
description: The marriage of Helena Leah Deutsch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Deutsch of New Haven, to Marvin Joseph Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Goldstein of Woodmere, L.I., took place yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetsky and Rabbi Albert Feldman performed the ceremony. The bride is a speech pathologist at the Shield Institute in New York. Her husband is an associate with the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan.

title: COOLER SUBWAYS AND BUSES SEEN FOR THE SUMMER
description: The president of the New York City Transit Authority says passengers on subway lines and buses can expect a cooler ride this summer than last.

title: RCA's Global In Paging Tie
description: The RCA Corporation's Global Communications unit and the PageAmerica Group Inc., a New York-based paging company, will establish a joint venture to develop a worldwide paging and personal communications service. The service is to be formally announced at a news conference today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has appointed Pieter J. Schiller president of its recently acquired Instrumentation Laboratory Inc. in Lexington, Mass.

title: CARING FOR MENTALLY ILL CHILDREN
description: ''THE most difficult thing for me is loving my son - and yet knowing he wants to kill me,'' said a mother who lives in Brooklyn and who preferred not to be named. ''I'm afraid my son will kill me if he goes off his medication.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Reaction at Stanford

title: EASTERN DETENTE?
description: What is the truth behind recent rumors of a so-called Chinese-Soviet detente? In the last few years, there has been a modest revival of contacts between the Soviet Union and China in the scientific, cultural and economic realms. In fact, however, there is no real evidence to support Russian leaks to American visitors about ''substantial detente'' with China. According to Chinese officials, Moscow is trying to play its own ''China card,'' and real rapprochement between the two countries is nowhere in sight.

title: IN HONG KONG, SOME BEGIN LOOKING FOR THE EXITS
description: The normally starched police inspectors of this British colony, an unlikely source of trouble, set nerves jangling in recent days.

title: China's Party Chief Ends Visit to Yugoslavia
description: China and Yugoslavia today publicly reaffirmed the independence of their ruling Communist parties at the end of a five-day visit by the Chinese party leader, Hu Yaobang.

title: Compton to Prepare Campaign for Skyline
description: Among Ma Bell's competitors for the lucrative long-distance telephone business is Skyline Service, now available in 13 markets and hoping to be in 20 by the end of the year.

title: D'AMATO OFF TO FAST START IN RAISING FUNDS FOR 1986 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato boarded a private jet the other day and flew to Syracuse for a cocktail party to raise money for his 1986 re-election campaign. About 70 guests mingled with the Senator and became members of his Senate Club by pledging to give $200 a year.

title: TO GET A SUMMER JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Analysis
description: The appeal by President Francois Mitterrand of France for a highlevel Bretton Woods-like conference to lay the basis for a more stable international monetary system comes at a time of continuing problems for the French economy as well as instability for its currency. While many economists agree that something needs to be done to reform the international monetary system, few agree on what reforms should be enacted or whether they would work.

title: Bridge: Lovely Mauritius Is Scene Of an Important Tourney
description: Teams from many countries in or near the Indian Ocean are converging on this beautiful island, hoping to take a step toward the world championship. When the zonal tournament beginning Monday ends on May 22 the winners will qualify for the Bermuda Bowl in Stockholm in September.

title: Kaufman Sees Leveling Off of Interest Rates
description: Henry Kaufman, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said today that the steep decline in interest rates over the last year had ended and that rates would fluctuate by up to one percentage point for the foreseeable future.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STATECRAFT AS SOULCRAFT. What Government Does. By George F. Will. 186 Pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: BRANIFF URGES CREDITORS TO APPROVE HYATT PLAN
description: Executives of Braniff International are pushing to persuade secured creditors to go along with a $70 million proposal by the Hyatt Corporation to restart part of the airline.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: PROPOSAL FOR RESTAURANT IN BRYANT PARK DISPUTED
description: In 1960, one of the fiercest battles in New York City park history was touched off when Parks Commissioner Robert Moses announced that Huntington Hartford had donated $500,000 to build a sidewalk cafe in Central Park across from the Plaza Hotel.

title: Advertising; Kimberly Back With F.C.& B.
description: Clark Corporation agency for 52 years when it lost the business in 1975, is back on the paper company's agency roster once again. Campbell-Mithun/Minneapolis has also joined the list and Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, already an agency, has gotten additional assignments.

title: BALLET: CYNTHIA GREGORY IN 'GISELLE'
description: AS usual, this time of year brings an avalanche of debuts and cast changes in dance. At American Ballet Theater on Saturday night, these included Ross Stretton's New York debut as Albrecht, partnering Cynthia Gregory in her first ''Giselle'' of the season. Earlier in the week, Valentina Kozlova and Leonid Kozlov, the new Russian recruits to the New York City Ballet, were seen in George Balanchine's ''Symphony in C.''

title: Market Place
description: ONLY eight months ago, the Martin Marietta Corporation, one of the nation's major defense suppliers, was in dire condition. Today, Wall Street analysts are recommending the stock and Marietta is moving up. At the close of trading last Friday, its stock was priced at 55, up from 47 at the end of March.

title: Indy Time Trials Rained Out Again
description: Qualifying time trials for the Indianapolis 500 auto race were again postponed by rain today, completing the weekend washout and putting pressure on the second weekend schedule. The elimination of the weekend reduced the time available to drivers attempting to qualify for the May 29 race.

title: Rodolfo Gucci Is Dead at 71; Brother in Leather Goods Firm
description: Rodolfo Gucci, one of the owners of the leather goods firm that bears the family name, has died. He was 71 years old.

title: Mementos Stolen From Former Colt
description: An estimated $2,100 worth of electronic equipment and jewelry, including the gold ring and watch from the Baltimore Colts' world championship years of 1958 and 1959, were stolen from the home of Lenny Moore, the former Colt running back and flanker.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about the Cathedral of St. John the Divine misidentified the Very Rev. James Parks Morton. He is dean of the cathedral.

title: Practical Patronage
description: Summertime means sun and warmth to most of us. But to a politician, it can also mean the glow of bestowing several hundred jobs and favors.

title: N.H.L. GENEROUS IN TROPHIES
description: The Stanley Cup, which has been around since 1893, is one of the best-known trophies in sports, but it takes a dedicated fan to name the National Hockey League's 15 other trophies.

title: BULLETPROOFED ASSAILANT OF GUN CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: College Fraternity's Initiation Reported to Include Branding
description: A fraternity is reportedly branding its pledges on the arm as a part of hazing at West Georgia College. ''We don't condone it,'' said Maurice Townsend, president of the college.

title: McNulty Captures Yonkers Marathon
description: John McNulty, a 25-year-old Rutgers University graduate, outclassed a field of 298 runners today in winning the 47th annual Yonkers Marathon in 2 hours 24 minutes 22 seconds.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 16, 1983
description: International

title: Pakistani Official in China
description: Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan of Pakistan arrived on a two-day visit to Peking today and went straight into talks on Afghanistan with his Chinese counterpart, Wu Xueqian, the New China News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Hong Kong, gave no details of the talks. Mr. Yaqub Khan is on his way to New York for consultations with members of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Taiwan Cuts Ties to Lesotho, Objecting to Peking Relations
description: Taiwan broke diplomatic relations with Lesotho today to protest the southern African kingdom's announcement that it established official ties with China, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: SMITH STILL BEDAZZLING OILERS
description: No one knows how to beat them. If anything, all that anyone knows by now is how not to beat the Islanders. ''Look,'' said Glen Sather, the coach of the Edmonton Oilers, ''this is a great hockey team. You're not going to upset the champions of the last three years with mirrors. It doesn't work that way.''

title: Lisa Ehrich Weds Robert Bernstein
description: Lisa Ehrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ehrich of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Robert Charles Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bernstein of Margate, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff of Temple Emanu-El in Westfield performed the ceremony at Windows on the World. Jill Spasser, a cantorial student at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York, assisted.

title: PENTAGON STUDIES 'MIDGETMAN' BASING
description: On the warning of a nuclear attack, a group of low-slung, box-shaped vehicles would disperse from a Western military base, carrying the small intercontinental ballistic missile sometimes called Midgetman.

title: Finnish Bank Chief Out
description: Ahti K. Karjalainen, governor of the Bank of Finland, has been relieved of his duties, effective immediately, a statement from the office of the Finnish President, Mauno Koivisto, said on Friday.

title: Cuba Labor Chief Denies Death Sentences on 5
description: The head of Cuba's trades unions has denied reports that five people were sentenced to death for attempting to organize a trades union in Cuba on the lines of Poland's banned Solidarity movement.

title: PRODIGY LEARNS IN 6-2, 6-1 LOSS
description: When the tennis match was over and Chris Garner, 14 years old, had lost to 32-year-old John James, all of his friends and family who were watching still thought it had been a worthwhile afternoon.

title: Yank Scene; At 'Opener'
description: NEARLY five weeks into the baseball season, yesterday turned out to be the Yankees' opening day. In the first intramural incident of Billy Martin's third term, the manager, acting with George Steinbrenner's approval, threw out the first sportswriter. Then the Yankees lost to the Chicago White Sox, 7-3, in weather as murky as the machinations by the manager and the owner in trying to lift this struggling team off its treadmill to oblivion.

title: AUSTRALIAN ASKS CAMBODIA PEACE FORCE
description: Deputy Prime Minister Lionel E. Bowen proposed today that Australian and Japanese troops form a peacekeeping force in Cambodia to allow the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces.

title: CITY BALLET: DEBUTS IN ROLES
description: THE New York City Ballet unveiled fine performance after fine performance on Friday at the New York State Theater, in a program studded with role debuts.

title: TWO SIDES APPROVE THE FINAL WORDING OF LEBANESE PACT
description: Israeli and Lebanese negotiators completed work today on the text of their security agreement, a spokesman for the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced. He said the accord was ready to sign.

title: JAVELIN RECORD OF 327-2 SET
description: Tom Petranoff, whose previous best competitive javelin-throw mark was 296 feet 8 inches, unleashed a throw of 327-2 today and bettered the world record by nearly 10 feet. He also broke the American record by almost 13 feet.

title: Ava Swartz Is Married
description: The marriage of Ava Carroll Swartz, a research associate for the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in New York, to Stephen Laurence Isaacs, assistant director of the Center for Population and Family Health, took place yesterday at Darech Amuno Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbis William Berman and Dennis Math performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Esther Swartz of San Francisco and the late Morris J. Swartz. Mr. Isaacs, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is also an associate professor of public health at Columbia University. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Isaacs, live in Rye, N.Y.

title: HOUSTON'S PLAN FOR RAIL SYSTEM MEETS OPPOSITION
description: Resistance is mounting here against an 18.5-mile, $2.1 billion rail system the County Metropolitan Transit Authority wants as the first phase of a widespread upgrading of mass transit in the Houston area, ultimately to reach into four counties.

title: The U.N. Today; May 16, 1983; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: I.B.M. DEFENSE IN DISCRIMINATION SUIT OPENS TODAY
description: Defense lawyers are to open their case Monday in a Federal suit charging the International Business Machines Corporation with discriminating against its black professional and managerial employees.

title: 3 FOR CHINAGLIA
description: Giorgio Chinaglia has a history of success against the Tulsa Roughnecks. Today's encounter at Giants Stadium was the 18th between the two teams and Chinaglia went through his usual jump-and-dance routine that follows a goal three times.

title: Akroyd to Utilize Cohn For Expansion in U.S.
description: Timothy F. Jones is joint chairman of Akroyd & Smithers, one of the major firms on the London Stock Exchange. Akroyd & Smithers last week completed the purchase of Cohn, Delaire & Kaufman Inc., a Wall Street firm, and is planning expansion here.

title: The Economy
description: Many big companies say they will not rehire workers let go during the recession - regardless of the strength of the recovery. Leaders of the nation's biggest corporations, winding up a three-day meeting of the Business Council, say they also see wrenching changes in store for the nation's work force, especially for younger workers. (Page A1.)

title: Assad Affirms Support Of Beirut Foes of Pact
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with Lebanese political leaders opposed to the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal accord and said they had his full support, the state-run Syrian radio said.

title: Qatar Gas Price Rise
description: Qatar has notified Japanese importers that it has raised its official price of both types of liquefied petroleum gas to $280 a ton, effective last Tuesday, in line with the increase recently announced by Saudi Arabia, according to industry sources. The previous prices were $260 a ton for propane gas and $270 for butane gas, they said. Japan imported 255,000 tons of liquefied petroleum gas from Qatar in 1982.

title: Manhattan Theater Benefit
description: The 11th benefit dinner and show for the Manhattan Theater Club will be held on May 23 at 7 P.M. at the Waldorf Astoria, Park Avenue and 50th Street.

title: CRUELTY IN LABS
description: In a single year, 64 million animals in the United States and 200 million worldwide are used as research subjects in laboratory experiments. In this country, their numbers include 400,000 dogs, 200,000 cats, 33,000 primates, thousands of pigs, calves, sheep, horses and rabbits and millions of rats and mice. Many experiments are frivolous and waste taxpayers' money. Many could be conducted with micro-organisms, computer simulations or other surrogate subjects. But the paramount fact is that many experiments inflict severe pain on animals and are morally objectionable.

title: Connors Winner
description: Jimmy Connors won an eight-player round robin today with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Roscoe Tanner. The first prize was $32,000.

title: THE FLUID STYLE OF ROD CAREW: IN TOTAL CONTROL AT BAT
description: ROD CAREW at bat tickles the fancy, unless, naturally, one is sitting in the foe's dugout, or facing him from the pitcher's mound. The California Angels' first baseman, one of the most remarkable and successful hitters of the last three decades, is off to perhaps the best start of any batter in baseball history. Carew was hitting nearly .500 - .500! - after his first 100 times up this season.

title: SPORTFISHING FOR PROFIT
description: IT is obvious that the urge to compete formally with others of their kind lurks in most American anglers. A few doddering relics of another time - this writer among them - still cling to the notion that fishing is one of the few endeavors in which the abrasiveness of the marketplace may be escaped, but the continuing proliferation of fishing contests demonstrates that this attitude has waned.

title: PIPELINE ACT TO CUT GAS COSTS
description: In a series of abrupt, unilateral moves to reduce the prices they pay to natural gas producers, the nation's major gas pipeline companies appear to have put an end, at least temporarily, to the rapid escalation in gas prices over the last two years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He was always saying 'I want my family to have a better living.'

title: 19 GRUMMAN BUSES RETURNED FOR REPAIR OF CRACKS
description: Nineteen Grumman Flxible buses have been sent back to the manufacturer for repairs after cracks developed around the rear doors, officials of the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
WATCHING THE DISCOUNT RATE
description: Despite the $4.2 billion bulge in the nation's basic money supply that was announced last week, analysts believe the Federal Reserve will have room to relax its monetary policy if M-1 grows at a slower pace than expected in this week's report.

title: The Joys of Walking
description: When he was a freshman in high school, Gary Yanker spent the year in a small town in West Germany's Black Forest, living among people who didn't own cars and didn't seem to know what they were missing.

title: HITACHI-F.B.I. TAPES ARE RELEASED
description: Tapes of a Federal Bureau of Investigation ''sting'' operation in California last year show that two executives of Japan's Hitachi Ltd. knew they were dealing in stolen goods when they offered to purchase I.B.M. computer components from agents posing as consultants.

title: The Off-Campus Housing Muddle
description: New York State's highest court ruled recently that apartments owned by nonprofit institutions like universities and hospitals are not subject to rent regulation. That judgment is good news for institutions that want to use their residential property to house staff and students who are reluctant to come to New York City unless they are sure of a place to live.

title: Judicial Requirements
description: Thirty black and Hispanic lawyers had a lot of questions for the Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary at a meeting arranged by City Councilman Frederick E. Samuel of Manhattan last week at the City Bar Association. But the central one was: What criteria are used to determine who is qualified to sit on the Criminal and Family Courts?

title: Michele Helena Guez Weds An Executive of a Hospital
description: At the Fort Lee (N.J.) Jewish Community Center yesterday Michele Helena Guez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ange Guez of New York, was married to Carl Allen Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Horowitz, also of New York. Rabbi Irving Spielman officiated.

title: Anesthesiologist Loses Job on Drug Charges
description: La PORTE, Ind., May 15 (AP) - An anesthesiologist was dismissed after La Porte Hospital officials determined he had taken drugs during an operation and learned that his license had been suspended in California, Texas and New Jersey because of drug abuse.

title: IN JERSEY, PITCHMEN PROVE GIFT OF GAB STILL WORKS
description: The science of selling has become complicated, with marketing experts mapping strategy, computers targeting tastes and copywriters spinning songs of appeal. And yet, even in a sophisticated age, the person with a gifted mouth endures.

title: Freddie Mac Sets Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will announce today the offering of $1 billion of guaranteed mortgage certificates that will be priced and sold by an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation and Salomon Brothers.

title: State Workers' Strike Averted in Rhode Island
description: The state and its largest public employees' union reached a tentative contract agreement today, averting a statewide strike by 10,500 workers that had been planned for midnight.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's $150 million issue of floating-rate notes due in 1998 was priced at 99 7/8, with an initial rate of 9.15 percent, through Salomon Brothers.

title: NEW SCRIPT FOR PREAKNESS
description: When a horse wins the Kentucky Derby as easily and authoritatively as Sunny's Halo did nine days ago, the Preakness at first looks like a bore. Why should the horses who couldn't catch the winner at Churchill Downs, or some newcomers who weren't good enough even to run in the Derby, do any better at Pimlico in the second leg of the Triple Crown?

title: TRANSCRIPT EXCERPT
description: The following is an unedited excerpt, taken from the Federal Bureau of Investigation transcript of last year's computer theft investigation, from a conversation that occurs on Jan. 20, 1982, one day before two Hitachi executives are arrested. In the conversation, Richard A. Callahan and Alan J. Garretson, F.B.I. agents, are questioning Isao Ohnishi and Kenji Hayashi, Hitachi executives, on why the Japanese company needs to buy stolen International Business Machines technology:

title: NOTED HARLEM PHOTOGRAPHER IS DEAD
description: James Van Der Zee, the photographer whose pictures chronicled the life of Harlem for half a century, died yesterday at the age of 96. Though he began his Harlem career when he was in his 20's, he did not receive public acclaim until he was 82 years old, when his photographs were featured in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: The Avenue of Food, For A Weekend
description: At any given moment on Ninth Avenue yesterday, large numbers of people weren't eating anything. But most of them, of course, had just had been, or soon would be.

title: IS IT BIPARTISANSHIP OR IS IT SYMBIOSIS?
description: Bipartisanship is the official buzzword at the White House for President Reagan's current dealings with Congress on the MX missile and Central America. Symbiosis might be a more accurate description, by the accounts of some participants.

title: MRS. LEE A. IACOCCA
description: Mary Iacocca, who was a receptionist for the Ford Motor Company when she met her husband, Lee A. Iacocca, died today in Beaumont Hospital after a long series of illnesses. Mrs. Iacocca, who was 52 years old, suffered for decades from heart problems and diabetes and had suffered a stroke.

title: 'FISHBOWL' TASK: DECIDING HOW TO DISPOSE OF NUCLEAR WASTE
description: He is tucked away in the back of the Energy Department's massive Forrestal Building, a career civil servant in a job so delicate that he scarcely dares open his mouth for fear of compromising, at the outset, a vital Government program that won't reach its main goal until 1998.

title: Doner Wins Sedgefield
description: W.B. Doner & Company in Baltimore, which for two years has been handling co-op advertising for Blue Bell's Wrangler Men's division, has now been assigned the regular advertising account of the Sedgefield Sportswear Company division, which makes branded jeans and ''casual bottoms'' for males of all ages and young girls and junior misses. Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner of New York, one of the Bloom Companies, previously did the ads.

title: F.C.&B. British Pact
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, already the eighth-largest agency in Britain, has reached an agreement to acquire a majority interest in Garratt Baulcombe Associates, a 23-year-old shop with $23 million in billings and offices in Nottingham and Manchester, England. The question is, in Robin Hood country, do agencies get a 15 percent commission or take 20?

title: ASSEMBLY TRYING FOR 2D TIME TO REORGANIZE P.S.C.
description: For the second year in a row, the State Assembly has passed legislation to reorganize the state agency that regulates utilities and the rates they charge. The measure's sponsor says his bill is intended to give the consumer more say in the regulation process.

title: Pepsico Executive Joining Chart House
description: Donald N. Smith has carved an enviable record in his 17 years in the restaurant business at the McDonald Corporation, Pillsbury's Burger King and at Pepsico Inc. Now he is moving to Chart House Inc. to work some of his management magic.

title: Commodities; Pricing Of Index Futures
description: HOW well does the price of a futures contract relate to the actual value of the underlying goods in the cash market? This relationship, called a basis, has long been the most important tool used by traders in the futures and cash markets. But it has become a mystifying problem in the new market for stock index futures.

title: ALLEN ENCOURAGED BY HIS STARTING EFFORT
description: To Neil Allen, the problems that recently raised questions about his future as a major league pitcher now seem ''like years behind me.''

title: Arafat Urges P.L.O. to Wage War Against Israel and U.S.
description: Yasir Arafat, trying to rally his forces against the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement, called today on the Palestine Liberation Organization to wage war against Israel and the United States.

title: Estimate Pared On Steel Use
description: The International Iron and Steel Institute says that total steel consumption in the non-Communist world in 1983 is likely to be 6.2 percent less than its earlier predictions because of the unexpectedly severe recession in the closing months of last year.

title: PUBLIC RADIO MAY HAVE TO CUT BUDGET FOR NEWS
description: National Public Radio, which has become identified over the last decade with its smoothly fashioned news broadcasts, has fallen upon hard financial times that threaten the programs as they are now known.

title: BOSS'S DAUGHTER TAKES FIRM COMMAND OF EAGLES
description: LEONARD TOSE of Philadelphia and Julia Farber of Cherry Hill, N.J., were married May 5 - the fourth marriage for him, the second for her. They spent the next two days honeymooning aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 on a ''Voyage to Nowhere.'' ''It was wonderful,'' said the third member of the wedding party, Susan Tose Fletcher, looking as tanned and refreshed as her father. ''I was their chaperone.''

title: A Couple of Rivals
description: When Ed Sprague, the owner of the Stockton Ports in the California League, follows his Class A baseball team to nearby Lodi for games against the Lodi Dodgers, Sprague's wife, Michele, is always right there blowing the whistle and ringing the cowbell.

title: EX-SOLDIERS PAY TRIBUTE TO DR. KING
description: The veterans of war stepped out onto Fifth Avenue yesterday to honor the preacher of nonviolence. And when the annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Parade reached the reviewing stand at 69th Street, a chorus of ''We Shall Overcome'' mingled with martial airs being played a few blocks away and the members of the 369th Veterans' Association talked of the parallels between their struggles and those of Dr. King.

title: Muge Gocek Married to Charles R. Hammerslough
description: Fatma Muge Gocek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Muzaffer Gocek of Istanbul, Turkey, was married yesterday to Charles Rohr Hammerslough, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Hammerslough of Weston, Conn. Justice of the Peace Glen Leet performed the ceremony at Cobb's Mill Inn in Weston.

title: North Korean Delegation In Japan for Conference
description: Japan, in a move indicating a thaw in relations with North Korea, has permitted an official delegation from Pyongyang to come to Tokyo for the first time to attend an international conference, official sources said today.

title: News Analysis
description: For the second time in four years, a Middle East accord has been worked out by the United States, but unlike what happened after the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, Washington appears this time to be on the side of an Arab majority favoring the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal agreement.

title: FINNISH CHIEF IN THE SHADOW OF A LEGEND
description: For most Finns, Urho Kekkonen, who was President for 25 years, is now a historical figure. But to his successor, Mauno Koivisto, he often looms as an unseen competitor.

title: YANK PITCHERS BATTERED IN 7-3 SETBACK
description: When the Chicago White Sox signed Floyd Bannister as a free agent five months ago, they gave him $4.79 million for five years. When they signed Marc Hill as a free agent two years ago, they gave him $100,000 for one year. The wealthy pitcher and the journeyman catcher combined their talents yesterday and led the slumping White Sox to a 7-3 victory over the Yankees.

title: A New Career
description: It seems only a few yesterdays ago that a small, but hard-running back by the name of Bobby Hammond was making headlines at Bayside High School in Queens. Perhaps the memory seems fresh because his 1,400 yards rushing in a season still stands as a school mark.

title: Washington Watch; Cruise Ships, U.S. Style
description: A FLORIDA builder and financier, Robert L. Lambert, believes he has a new recipe for business success. First, buy two Cunard liners with help from investor syndicates. Next, hire as Washington counsel the son of the Speaker of the House. Then, persuade Congress to pass a private bill authorizing American-flag registration. And, finally, sign up droves of East Coast, Great Lakes and West Coast passengers for cruises between American ports such as New York and Charleston, S.C. Foreign-flag cruise ships are barred by law from these routes, which represent a new dimension to the cruise business, a growth industry.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OASES

title: Leonard E. Read Dies; Free-Market Advocate
description: Leonard Edward Read, founder and president of the Foundation for Economic Education, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: TIME FOR AN ALL-AMERICAN HEALTH PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worm and the Apple; Fancy Footwork; Brooklyn Moss
description: From a distance, it looks like Spanish moss. Since it grows most profusely in Brooklyn, call it Brooklyn moss. But instead of dangling from stately live oaks, it festoons the arching masts that support the borough's traffic lights.

title: Cyclists Rally in Maine
description: Hundreds of motorcyclists thundered through this quiet capital to the Statehouse Saturday to protest a proposed law requiring helmets. The Legislature, unable to agree on a bill to re-enact a helmet law, has appointed a bipartisan conference committee. The Legislature has rejected repeated attempts to pass a helmet law since one was repealed in the late 1970's.

title: U.S. ENVOY AT GENEVA TALKS CALLS FOR FLEXIBILITY BY SOVIET
description: The United States negotiator at the talks on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles said today that an accord ''should be possible'' if the Soviet Union showed some flexibility.

title: Computerland Selects J.W.T.
description: The Computerland Corporation, a chain of franchised retail stores specializing in personal computers, has selected J. Walter Thompson, San Francisco, as agency for its account, which could run to $10 million in billings.

title: Panther Linebacker Praised
description: Chuck Fairbanks, the coach of the New Jersey Generals, often makes reference to ''the dominant player,'' meaning one whose skills can change the outcome of a game. Herschel Walker can be a dominant player for the Generals, but Fairbanks has no others.

title: TV: SOUND OF MOTOWN CELEBRATED
description: FROM the Grammy Awards to Grand Ole Opry galas, music specials on television are fairly rigid affairs - a long list of name performers drenched in hit recordings or sentimental nostalgia. Two new productions this week stick closely to the familiar formula. One is pleasant. The other - as the ultimate superlative in current slang would have it - is death.

title: Chacon Beats Boza-Edwards
description: ''Boy, what a fight!'' exclaimed Bobby Chacon. ''Wish I could've seen it.'' Chacon was too busy today scoring a 12-round unanimous decision over Cornelius Boza-Edwards in what surely will be regarded as one of the best fights of the year. It was a 12-round slugfest with four knockdowns - three by Chacon, including a final one in the last round to punctuate his domination.

title: FORMIDABLE MISSILES PUT IN PLACE AT RUSSIAN BASES IN WESTERN SYRIA
description: Outside this industrial town in western Syria, known to the ancients as Emesa, the Soviet Union has installed a constellation of SAM-5 antiaircraft missiles - a formidable weapon that the Syrians hope will change the balance of power in the Middle East.

title: Ally & Gargano Gets Kloss Projector TV Sets
description: Ally & Gargano, already the agency for MCI Communications, a Skyline competitor, is taking another step into the world of high tech.

title: EGYPT SPRING: FAST GETAWAY TO THE OASIS
description: Deep in the recesses of this lush farmland, Abdul el-Bossa, a teacher, took his leisure today surrounded by friends and members of his family who picnicked under a large mango tree in this tiny village in the Faiyum oasis about 65 miles southwest of Cairo.

title: New Yuspeh Shop
description: Sonya Yuspeh, 55 years old, newly elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association, will be leaving J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., where she is senior vice president and researach head, to open her own advertising and marketing research shop at 2211 Broadway. ''I'll continue to do what I do, but I'll be doing it for myself,'' she said.

title: HIGHWAY DEATHS AT A 20-YEAR LOW
description: Deaths on the highways and in nearly all other areas of transportation dropped in 1982 to the lowest levels in 20 years, according to preliminary figures released today by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: PHILADELPHIA RIVALS CALL TURNOUT VITAL IN PRIMARY
description: The last day of the final weekend of the long Mayoral primary campaign dawned wet and dreary today, but glimpses of the sun gave good weather omens to both major candidates of the dominant Democratic Party.

title: KEAN ASKS GRADUATES NOT TO BE SELF-CENTERED
description: Governor Kean urged 1,500 graduates at Fairleigh Dickinson University here today to be a ''they'' rather than a ''me'' generation, and to set a good example for future graduates to follow.

title: Mr. Watt Shoots the Other Foot
description: The progress of nations may be hard to measure, but one sure milestone on the path from barbarity is the separation of church and state. Interior Secretary James Watt finds the principle as difficult to grasp as most other rules for maintaining civility in politics.

title: APARTMENT SHARERS FRET OVER LEASE RULING
description: In the wake of a ruling last week by New York State's highest court, a middle-aged Greenwich Village couple found themselves poring over a legal document long buried in a filing cabinet - the lease to her apartment. The lease, like most in the city, limited occupancy of the apartment to the person who signed it, in this case the woman, and to members of her immediate family.

title: Jackson Says Black Bid For President Could Win
description: A black Presidential candidate has ''a real chance of winning,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today at the opening of a black voter registration drive.

title: FLORIDA'S BANK-MERGER SPREE
description: This time a decade ago, when the economy was hot and few people knew what the term ''oil embargo'' meant, there was a flurry of merger activity across Flordia within its blossoming banking industry.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SALVADOR DEATH SQUADS STRIKE AGAIN
description: The Salvadoran Government has released more than 50 of the country's 700 political prisoners since the beginning of the year. Last Sunday the bodies of two of those freed were picked up with six others by the International Committee of the Red Cross on a road three miles north of the capital.

title: CHURCH IN NEW YORK VOTES TO SELL JERSEY TENEMENTS
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church has voted to sell more than 100 rundown apartment buildings it owns in three New Jersey cities, after a yearlong controversy over the church's management of the properties.

title: CHINA JAILS A HONG KONG EDITOR AS A SPY FOR U.S.
description: China disclosed today that it had jailed a Hong Hong newspaper editor for 10 years on charges of spying for the United States.

title: TO PAY PAUL
description: At the most recent meeting of the ''graybeards,'' or ''wise men'' - the outside economists who advise President Reagan on economic policy - a special guest was Paul Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: EDUCATION: PROLONGED 'AGONY' IS NO SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: ROSBERG CAPTURES MONACO GRAND PRIX
description: Keke Rosberg of Finland, using dry road tires on rainslicked streets, won the Monaco Grand Prix today. The victory was only the second in Grand Prix competition for Rosberg, the defending world champion, and the sweeter for his having lost an appeal this week against disqualification from second place in the season opener in Brazil.

title: BUCKS TOP 76ERS, TRAIL SERIES, 3-1
description: After 13 seasons in the National Basketball Association, five knee operations and countless frustrations, Bob Lanier today showed a sellout crowd of 11,052 fans and the Philadelphia 76ers just how badly he wants his first championship ring.

title: McPherson Stars In City U. Meet
description: Peter McPherson of Medgar Evers took the 100-meter dash in 11.1 seconds and the 200 in 22.2, then anchored his team to victory in the 400 relay in the City University men's track and field championships yesterday at Downing Stadium in Randalls Island.

title: AN IMMIGRANT AND HIS DREAM DIE IN A HOLDUP ON BROADWAY
description: His dream was to bring his family from Jordan, to put his brother through engineering school and eventually to educate his sons. When he landed at Kennedy International Airport six years ago, he had only a few hundred dollars and the belief that hard work would pay.

title: A Reunion For 'Communicators'
description: Could Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia have imagined in 1935, when he established the High School of Music and Art, how many of its graduates would wind up in ''communications''?

title: FRASER BIDS ADIEU AS HEAD OF U.A.W.
description: An era in the American labor movement will come to an end Thursday when Douglas A. Fraser retires as president of the United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America.

title: 6 Hurt on Park Avenue As Car and Cab Collide
description: Six people were injured, one seriously, when a car collided with a taxicab yesterday, ran up on the sidewalk and struck three pedestrians at 37th Street and Park Avenue, the police reported.

title: GATO DEL SOL A WINNER
description: Gato del Sol, the 1982 Kentucky Derby winner, made his first start since finishing fifth in the Travers Stakes at Saratoga last Aug. 21, winning an allowance race by 2 1/2 lengths today.

title: MUSIC: ST. CECILIA CHORUS AT CARNEGIE
description: THE ST. CECILIA CHORUS and Orchestra, conducted by David Randolph, presented a well-meaning but undistinguished performance of Mozart's Requiem in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night.

title: Miss Weinstein and Dr. Stephen W. Kress Marry
description: Evelyn Weinstein, an ornithologist and freelance photographer, was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen W. Kress, a biologist and a research associate at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology in Ithaca, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Shaw of New York performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Weinstein of Norwalk, Conn.

title: Kay Sherman Married to Iver Bernstein
description: Kay Sherman, an associate with the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, was married at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday to Iver Bernstein, a doctoral candidate in history at Yale University. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Lawrence Raphael, assisted by the bride's grandfather, Rabbi Leib Silverberg, and Cantor Eleazer Schulman.

title: Stars Defeat Triumph on Late Score
description: Chuck Fusina ran 17 yards on a bootleg for the go-ahead touchdown with 5 minutes 46 seconds left in the game to lift the Stars to a 31-24 victory today over the Chicago Blitz.

title: SOUTH AFRICA 'HOMELAND': A SUCCESS OF SORTS
description: Anyone looking for a success story to illustrate the efforts of South Africa's white theorists to resolve the country's racial conflicts sooner or later focuses on seven scattered fragments of real estate known as Bophuthatswana.

title: Iran Reports Crushing Attack by Iraqis
description: Iran said today that it had crushed an Iraqi attack on the border near Qasr-i-Shirin, killing or wounding hundreds of enemy soldiers.

title: HOLLYWOOD FORECAST: BEST SUMMER AT BOX OFFICE
description: Summer begins early in Hollywood. The 16 glorious weeks when movie theaters are expected to sell well over $1 billion worth of tickets started last Friday with the release of ''Blue Thunder'' and ''Breathless.''

title: Rikers Island Guard Slain in Coney Island
description: A New York City correction officer, apparently on his way to work on Rikers Island, was shot and killed early yesterday on a ramp of the Coney Island Boardwalk, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: After his initial success in negotiating a budget on time, Governor Cuomo and his staff have been slow to come to grips with the remaining issues before the State Legislature this session, according to many of the legislators and senior legislative staff members who deal with the Governor's office.

title: Roger Gray, a Student, Wed to Miriam David
description: Miriam David, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Arthur David of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Roger Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Gray of Spring Valley, N.Y. The bride's father, a chaplain of the Nassau County Police Department, performed the ceremony at Hampshire House.

title: WAGE PRICE CONTROL BY ANOTHER NAME
description: To the Editor:

title: EDITOR ROLE WAS USEFUL TO 2 SIDES
description: Lo Chengxun, whose 10-year sentence as an American spy was disclosed in Peking yesterday, was one of several Chinese or Hong Kong journalists and officials who have informal license from the Chinese Government to maintain contacts and exchanges with foreigners in Hong Kong.

title: Last Stroke Gives Harvard Row Title
description: Harvard regained rowing supremacy on the last stroke on Lake Quinsigamond today, winning the Worcester Bowl in the Eastern Sprint Rowing Association championships for varsity heavyweight eights.

title: GREEK BID TO COMMON MARKET
description: Two years after Greece became the European Economic Community's 10th member, the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou is asking the community's partners for huge sums of money as an incentive not to quit the organization, despite Mr. Papandreou's campaign promise to pull out.

title: THE POWER OF A FEINT IN THE RING
description: Edwards's defense he had spotted, just what moves had set up the straight right hand to the chin.

title: Jockey, 19, Dies
description: Val Tonks, a 19-year-old jockey, died today of injuries suffered during a quarter-horse race last Thursday at Los Alamitos Race Course, a track spokesman said. He had undergone brain surgery at Los Alamitos General Hospital after the accident when his mount, Alota Dream, hit the inside rail and threw the jockey into the infield.

title: FACTORY OPERATION UP TO 71.1% OF CAPACITY
description: Manufacturers, starting up long-idle production lines, operated their factories at 71.1 percent of capacity last month, the highest rate in more than a year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Limiting the Medicaid Credit Card
description: A Medicaid card is the medical equivalent of MasterCard: it guarantees payment to any doctor, hospital or clinic willing to accept it. New York health officials believe limiting its range might control medical costs and improve care, but their plan for such an experiment in East Harlem has aroused opposition. While skepticism is understandable, the idea is worth testing.

title: COSMOS UNLIKELY TO GET HELP
description: The Cosmos lack depth and can use another international star to attract more fans, but Nesuhi Ertegun, the board chairman, says the soccer team will not spend so freely for players as it did in the past.

title: CANADIAN SCHOOLS IMMERSE THE STUDENTS IN FRENCH
description: Every school-day morning Sarah Wright, who is 9 years old, and her brother, David, who is 7, leave their Englishspeaking home here to go to a public school where they spend the next six hours learning, thinking and talking in French.

title: U.S. HELP FOR PRIVATE ROCKETS
description: The White House announced today that the Federal Government would encourage private industry to build and operate expendable rockets in competition with the Government's space shuttle.

title: OPPONENTS OF MX HOPE TO BAR FUNDS
description: Opponents of the MX missile said today that they were starting a nationwide lobbying and letter-writing campaign to try to block Congressional financing for the new weapon.

title: Reagan News Session To Be Broadcast Live
description: President Reagan's news conference, scheduled for tonight at 8 P.M. Eastern time, will be televised live by CBS, NBC, ABC and the Cable News Network.

title: NEW TRIAL SOUGHT IN ATLANTA KILLINGS
description: Attorneys for Wayne B. Williams, who was convicted of two murders last year in the Atlanta child killing case, argued before the Georgia Supreme Court today that his conviction should be set aside and a new trial should be granted.

title: CBS CONCENTRATES ON PLAYOFFS
description: A t a time when there is speculation about the saturation of sports on over-the-air and cable television, the contract between CBS and the National Basketball Association appears to be based on the premise that less is better.

title: Dresser Loses $10.1 Million
description: Dresser Industries today reported a $10.1 million net loss for its second fiscal quarter ended April 30, in contrast to earnings of $63 million, or 80 cents a share, for the same quarter of the 1982 fiscal year.

title: Defense in CBS Trial To Call Lone Witness
description: The defense in the multiple-murder trial of Donald Nash will call a single witness today as its entire case. Mr. Nash's lawyer, Lawrence Hochheiser, said the witness would be a physican who is to testify about Mr. Nash's sight. Mr. Hochheiser, in an interview, said that because Mr. Nash was blind in his right eye and had limited vision in his left, he would have been unable to commit the slayings.

title: MONEY FUNDS FIGHTING BACK
description: When banks were permitted to offer their own money market accounts in December, the nation's mutual funds warned that the extraordinarily high introductory rates offered by most banks to draw depositors away from the funds would not last forever.

title: Advertising; Wendy's Plans New Campaigns
description: YESTERDAY in Columbus, Ohio, Wendy's International began serving and advertising a breakfast menu. Its first. Wendy's, based next door to Columbus in Dublin, hopes to help the gross sales of its individual units catch up a wee bit with those of McDonald's.

title: HOSTAGES AT L.I. SCHOOL ARE FREED, AND GUNMAN THEN KILLS HIMSELF
description: A teacher's aide dismissed recently after a fight with a student returned to a Long Island school yesterday wearing military fatigues and carrying a rifle, shot the youth and the principal and took 18 students hostage.

title: TV: GAME SHOWS AND THE GOOD THINGS IN LIFE
description: GAME shows are a television perennial, hanging in there no matter how tastes change, and at the moment dominating the programming on weekday mornings. Between 9 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. there are now 12 game shows, most of them based on the principle that it is better to have the good things of life than to be without them. Money, in fact, is almost incidental on most game shows; it is a trash compactor, say, or microwave oven that counts.

title: The MX Bargain Is a Snare
description: Congress is buying a dangerous deal if it unblocks funds for the MX missile in return for President Reagan's vague promises about new arms control and weapons policies.

title: GUIDRY WINS ON 3-HITTER
description: A relaxed Ron Guidry, rearing back and throwing almost nothing but fastballs in the final five innings, produced a 7-0 shutout over the Tigers tonight as the Yankees began a nine-game trip.

title: Electric Rate Rises Allowed
description: Rules to let electricity producers increase their wholesale rates an average 3.5 percent this year were approved today by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: OILERS MAY START FUHR AS GOALTENDER FOR GAME 4
description: From Denis Potvin's point of view, ''for the Oilers to beat us four straight games would be virtually impossible.'' With Potvin's Islanders leading the Stanley Cup final series by three games to none, that is what the Edmonton Oilers would have to do to stop the Islanders from winning their fourth straight championship. But the Islanders hope to prevent the Oilers from winning even one game, so that Long Island fans at the Nassau Coliseum for Game 4 tonight can see their team hoist the Stanley Cup in a victory skate once again.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 17, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices plummeted as concern spread about the outlook on interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 15.77 points, to 1,202.98. On the overall market, declines outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1. Analysts cited Friday's report of a recent surge in the basic money supply, which could prevent the Federal Reserve Board from encouraging lower interest rates. (Page D1.) Yields on long-term bonds rose sharply and prices fell, while in the short-term market Treasury bill yields rose very slightly. The Treasury auctioned $7.4 billion in three- and six-month bills instead of the $12.4 billion usually sold each Monday. (D13.) The dollar rose to a new high of 7.4138 against the French franc in U.S. trading. Gold prices declined $2.50 an ounce, to $438, in New York. (D18.) Prices of Treasury bond and bill futures fell sharply. (D18.)

title: POLISH YOUTH DETAINED IN WARSAW REPORTED DEAD OF INTERNAL INJURIES
description: The son of a woman who aids the families of jailed Solidarity activists died of internal injuries over the weekend after being taken into police custody and beaten in the Old Town section of Warsaw, Roman Catholic Church sources and family friends reported.

title: CUOMO ASKS U.S. HEARINGS ON NUCLEAR EVACUATION
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday formally requested Congressional hearings to develop Federal legislation that would make clear the roles of the Federal, state and local governments in nuclear power plant emergencies.

title: Long Term for 18-Year-Old
description: A young man was sentenced today to serve up to 25 years in prison for the jailhouse slaying of Christopher Peterman, a 17-year-old who had been jailed in a traffic case. The defendant, Randall McKeown, who turned 18 years old three weeks ago, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the torture slaying of Mr. Peterman, who had been jailed for failing to pay $73 in fines.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Picketing a Manor

title: Philadelphia Jury Finds 5 Ex-Policemen Guilty
description: Five former Philadelphia policemen were convicted today of conspiring to take bribes to allow prostitution, gambling and illegal liquor sales to flourish in bars and massage parlors.

title: U.S. AND LAOS SAID TO DISCUSS MOVES TO IMPROVE RELATIONS
description: The United States and the Communist Government of Laos, after years of tense relations, have quietly begun discussions aimed at upgrading their diplomatic missions and gaining closer ties, Administration officials said today.

title: ACCIDENT BY DEFINITION
description: Last July, less than 10 months ago, a 31-year-old man, Warren Levenberg, was killed on a Madison Avenue sidewalk when a crane being dismantled atop a skyscraper office building nearing completion suddenly crashed on the roof and spewed granite and glass to the street below.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THIS is supposed to be the slow time for fashion, but last week was a nything but slow. At Mercedes Kellogg's lunch for Helene Hayes, a n ew French designer who makes a John Singer Sargent sort of gown, t here was the news that Diana Vreeland will present her first c ollection of sheets for Wamsutta tomorrow. The three different p atterns are known as Diana's Poppies, Diana's Plaid and Diana's L ace. The sheets are not all cotton, so for $18.50 one can have a t win size sheet with Mrs. Vreeland's stamp of approval. Sheets, Mrs. V .? She has always wanted to do this and always wanted to make a k illing at it. Now's her chance.

title: Klecko Says Knee Is Healed
description: The thing that hurt most, Joe Klecko said, was that some people insisted he would never play football again.

title: Petro-Canada In Oil Sands Deal
description: Petro-Canada said it and B.P. Resources Canada would build a 7,000-barrel-a-day oil sands plant at Wolf Lake, Alberta.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Comings and Goings He had said that, at 30, he was ''too old'' to play on European clay courts. But now Jimmy Connors, last year's Wimbledon and United States Open champion, has changed his mind.

title: Eastern Air Concessions
description: Eastern Airlines said its employee council had outlined a deferred-salary program for noncontract employees, calling for them to invest 3.5 percent of their salaries in an investment bonus agreement and 6.5 percent in convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Emslie Back on Job
description: He has been dismissed twice by the International League and, according to the Major League Umpires Association, has been denied a job in the major leagues because of discrimination. Now Bill Emslie will be umpiring again.

title: Text of agreement, page A12.
description: The Lebanese-Israeli security agreement, which is to be signed in both countries Tuesday, places strict and detailed limits on the deployment of Lebanese military personnel and weapons in southern Lebanon.

title: Japanese Steel Output
description: Japan's production of crude steel in April fell 9.3 percent, to 7.967 million metric tons, from the same month a year ago, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today.

title: PARENTS WARY OF SUPPRESSING SEXUALITY IN CHILDREN
description: FIFTEEN or twenty years ago parents had few conflicts about how to deal with the sexuality of their preadolescent children: Unquestionably it was to be discouraged. Even the most enlightened parents continued to maintain a cautiously repressive attitude toward the free expression of childhood sexuality.

title: Books Of The Times
description: HERE TO GET MY BABY OUT OF JAIL. By Louise Shivers. 136 pages. Random House. $11.95. FALSE PREMISES. By Winthrop Knowl- ton. 215 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: Alumax-Howmet
description: Alumax Inc., which is half owned by Amax Inc., said it had agreed to acquire the Howmet Aluminum Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann of France. It did not state the price. Alumax and Howmet jointly own two aluminum reduction plants.

title: HARVARD'S RUSSIAN STUDY UNIT STARTS A $5 MILLION CAMPAIGN
description: Harvard University announced the start today of a $5 million drive to upgrade its 35-year-old Russian Research Center, one of the nation's major institutes sponsoring teaching and research on the Soviet Union.

title: Peking Finds Security Lax in Plane Hijacking
description: Shen Tu, director general of China's national airline, said today that inadequate airport security had allowed six hijackers to bring two handguns aboard the first plane ever to be hijacked out of China. He demanded that they be returned from South Korea to face trial.

title: SHULTZ IS UNLIKELY TO GO BACK TO TALKS ON LEBANON FOR NOW
