description: A senior State Department official said today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz was inclined to stay away from the Middle East for now and let the Arabs take the lead in negotiating over Lebanon.

title: N.F.L. Rebuffed
description: United States District Court Judge Harry Pregerson today denied the National Football League's request that he overturn the verdict requiring the league to pay nearly $49 million in damages to the Los Angeles Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: North Dakota Bonds Are Tentatively Priced
description: A tentative pricing for $152 million of North Dakota student loan revenue bonds was set yesterday by the underwriter, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Rated A+ by Standard and Poor's and A by Moody's, the serial bonds due in 1987 were priced at par to yield 7.25 percent, with those due in 1996 priced at par to yield 9 percent.

title: CITY BALLET: SOME NEW FACES IN OLD BALANCHINE FAVORITES
description: THE New York City Ballet offered exciting typecasting Sunday night in the New York State Theater, when Gen Horiuchi took on George Balanchine's ''Tarantella.'' Mr. Horiuchi is a technical whiz kid and he danced the ballet's high-spirited, nonstop technical display to the hilt. He spun out multiple turns, flung jumps and taut beats, all executed with care and fearless abandon, shaking his tambourine all the while.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Building and Equipment Corp., St. Louis, has elected Carl J. Weis, president, to the additional position of chief executive officer.

title: A 6-1 UNDERDOG WITH BIG PUNCH
description: Life still bothers Tim Witherspoon, who took up boxing to work off anger and frustration against heavy bags, and who challenges Larry Holmes for the heavyweight championship here Friday night.

title: Sumitomo Certificate
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said today that it would establish a $400 million, five-year certificate of deposit facility with a syndicate of 16 banks led by Citicorp International. The agreement will be at an interest rate of 0.25 percent below the London interbank offered rate, with certificate of deposit terms of three or six months.

title: JUDGE REVERSES PUNITIVE DAMAGES AGAINST GROUCHO MARX COMPANION
description: A Superior Court judge today reversed a jury's award of $250,000 in punitive damages against Erin Leslie Fleming, Groucho Marx's longtime companion, and granted her a new trial if the Bank of America does not accept the reduced award.

title: WITHDRAWAL
description: Following is the official text of the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal agreement with its annex, appendix and agreed minutes, as made available today by Lebanese officials:

title: First New Political Party Is Formed in Turkey
description: A group of retired military officers, former Government officials and businessmen today announced the formation of Turkey's first new political party since military rule began three years ago.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Combined International Corp. filed a shelf registration statement covering up to $125 million of debt securities.

title: 3 YEARS LATER, MOST CUBANS OF BOATLIFT ADJUSTING TO U.S.
description: It began as a small-boat exodus of several thousand Cubans who were welcomed here as refugees from the Castro Government. As the number of refugees swelled, many Americans became increasingly upset as the Cuban Government labeled those sailing to southern Florida from the port of Mariel misfits and outcasts.

title: SERVICE FOR TURNER CATLEDGE
description: A memorial service for Turner Catledge, former executive editor of The New York Times, will be held June 28 at 11 A.M. in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Catledge died on April 27 at his home in New Orleans, where he had lived since his retirement from The Times in 1970.

title: CHANCELLOR SAYS HE WILL WEIGH ADDITIONAL CUTS
description: Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado said yesterday that he would consider making administrative cuts in the school budget for next year, in exchange for more city funds for new programs.

title: 1,970 SEE METS HALT PIRATES
description: Before a crowd of 1,970, the smallest in the 13-year history of Three Rivers Stadium, the Mets unleashed their biggest offense of the season tonight, defeating the Pirates by 11-4.

title: THE RATTLESNAKE, OF ALL THINGS, IS ENDANGERED
description: THE timber rattlesnake, a denizen of the woods and lower mountains of eastern North America, is not the most huggable creature on earth. But cuddly or not, next month the handsomely mottled brown, black and yellow reptile, scientifically known as Crotalus horridus, will be put under the protection of New York State's threatened species law.

title: OAKLAND CITES EMINENT DOMAIN IN EFFORT TO REGAIN FOOTBALL TEAM
description: The City of Oakland began an unusual legal effort today to prove that, because of the importance to a city of having a professional sports team, it may use eminent domain legal procedures to seize a privately owned sports franchise.

title: The Man Behind The Stanley Cup
description: With the Islanders taking a 3-0 lead in games into tonight's Stanley Cup championship playoff game at Nassau Coliseum, Lefty Reid knows exactly what he must do. The curator of the Hockey Hall of Fame is in charge of the trophy that is emblematic of supremacy in the National Hockey League, and he must tend to it until either the Islanders or the Edmonton Oilers claim it with their fourth victory,

title: South African Invitation
description: Dr. Danie Craven, the president of the South African Rugby Board, has invited 80 to 90 overseas rugby writers at a cost of $446,000 to an ''international media congress'' in South Africa in August.

title: THE BILLY MARTIN CASE, CONTINUED
description: T he Yankees are foundering, and Billy Martin is flailing. On Sunday morning, the manager berated a New York Post sportswriter, Henry Hecht, for an article he had done about Martin. This came the day after Martin had returned from a three-day suspension for abusing an umpire.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OF LISTENING TO AMBASSADOR KIRKPATRICK AND HONORING HER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW E.E.C. FINANCIAL RULES
description: Many European and foreign-owned corporations operating in the European Economic Community's 10 member countries are to be gradually forced to present a clearer picture of their financial affairs under new rules adopted today. The rules require them to publish consolidated annual financial statements.

title: Peterson to Share Lehman Chief's Job
description: Peter G. Peterson, completing his 10th year as chairman of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., gave away half of one of his titles yesterday.

title: GEMAYEL URGES SHULTZ TO ASSIST IN SYRIAN TALKS
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon said today Secretary of State George P. Shultz should return to the Middle East as soon as possible to help his country negotiate a withdrawal of Syrian forces.

title: Strike Halts Burials in Paris
description: Burials in the main cemeteries of Paris were suspended today as gravediggers and pallbearers staged a one-day strike over working conditions, city officials said. The officials said 110 of the 140 gravediggers employed by the city and 46 of the 96 pallbearers stopped work.

title: Grand Met Raises Profit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that its earnings more than doubled in the six months ended March 31 from the same period a year earlier.

title: THE DREAM OF RACING ON SUNBEAMS
description: WHERE ships of a future day may sail, there is no air smacking of salt. There is no air at all. But a ''breeze'' does blow, a gentle force. Imperceptible though it may seem, nothing to flutter the pennant on a tall mast, this force may someday send ships scudding through interplanetary space.

title: MURPHY IS CONFIDENT, AT LAST
description: D ale Murphy remembered the happy beginning of another season, and the disappointing way that his successful start concluded. Murphy was a catcher and first baseman for the Atlanta Braves in 1979. He was 23 years old and full of power and promise. There was just this one problem: His throwing arm.

title: Bridge: Defenders Win, Then Find Others Scored Even Better
description: The bridge organizers of China, like its players, are rapidly becoming more sophisticated. In the early stages of their five years of activity they concentrated on head-to-head team contests, which are relatively straightforward. However, the recent Shanghai international tournament included an event called the ''Textile Pairs.''

title: Market Place; A Closer Look At TV Sector
description: THE hiring freeze at CBS's broadcasting division, announced last Friday, has touched off a reassessment by institutional investors that was reflected in yesterday's weak market performance by the whole broadcasting sector.

title: SUNNY'S HALO IS IMPRESSIVE IN WORKOUT
description: It was a raw and rainy dawn at Pimlico Race Course today until Sunny's Halo stepped onto the track and lighted up the place like a flare. The official clocker's report will say that the Kentucky Derby winner went seven furlongs in 1 minute 24 seconds. But anyone who was there will say that Sunny's Halo's victory at Churchill Downs clearly was no fluke and that he may be on the verge of proving that he is a great horse.

title: Wall St. Journal Editor
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that Norman Pearlstine will become managing editor of The Wall Street Journal on Sept. 1. Mr. Pearlstine, 40 years old, will succeed Laurence G. O'Donnell, 47, who will become an associate editor of The Journal and other Dow Jones publications, the company said. Mr. Pearlstine will be in charge of all day-to-day news gathering and reporting operations. Currently editor and publisher of The Wall Street Journal/Europe, which began publication in January, he had previously been the national news editor for The Journal's United States edition. Before joining The Journal he was an executive editor at Forbes magazine.

title: Sunlamp Damage
description: Overexposure to sunlight and artificial sources of ultraviolet light have long been linked to an increased risk of developing skin cancers, including the often fatal melanomas. Damage to the genetic material of skin cells and a failure of the cells to properly repair that damage has been cited as the likely mechanism involved.

title: 'All's Well' Closes
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company's ''All's Well That Ends Well'' closed after the matinee Sunday at the Martin Beck Theater. The play, directed by Trevor Nunn, ran for 38 performances and 11 previews.

title: PANTHERS' RALLY TOPS GENERALS
description: Although Herschel Walker made a significant contribution, the New Jersey Generals lost again tonight when their defense could not protect a 14-point lead in the second half. The Michigan Panthers scored four touchdowns in that half to win by 31-24 before a crowd of 32,282 in the Silverdome.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New School in an Old One

title: Democrats Ask Court to Bar Unlimited Gifts to President
description: The Democratic Party today asked a Federal district court to block two independent groups, the National Conservative Political Action Committee and the Fund for a Conservative Majority, from going ahead with their plans to make unlimited expenditures on behalf of President Reagan if he runs for re-election next year.

title: 'CATS' LEADS IN TONY RACE, WITH 11 NOMINATIONS
description: ''Cats,'' the British musical that was the only solid box-office hit of the New York theater season, leads this year's nominations for the American Theater Wing's Antoinette Perry Awards, known as the Tonys, which are Broadway's equivalent of Hollywood's Academy Awards. ''Cats'' has received 11 nominations, including one for best musical. Close behind is ''My One and Only,'' with nine nominations.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A MAN'S MAN

title: A Familiar Acquisition For Clevepak Executive
description: Charles H. Moore Jr. joined the Clevepak Corporation from the Interpace Corporation in 1981. And now, Interpace is joining Clevepak.

title: A STOP SIGN FOR BANKS-FOR NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A page 1 caption Saturday on the final phase of reinstallation for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Egyptian collection incorrectly described the exhibition history of objects to be displayed. The statue of Queen Hatshepsut was on loan in Richmond between 1948 and 1961. The coffin of a court official is believed never to have been displayed before in the United States.

title: O'ROURKE CITES PROGRESS ON PLAN FOR INDIAN POINT
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, announced today that ''substantial progress'' had been made in efforts to avert a Federal shutdown of the two nuclear plants at Indian Point because of flaws in the emergency preparedness plan.

title: Salomon Brothers Sets CATS Issue
description: Solomon Brothers said yesterday that it had begun offering a new series of Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, or CATS, with a total par value of $2.2 billion.

title: Trading Halted In Biscayne Stock
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in an unusual move, today halted over-the-counter trading of stock in the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami. It has been in receivership since April 6.

title: GENDER AS AN INSURANCE ISSUE FACES SHOWDOWN IN CONGRESS
description: Six months ago, legislation to remove sex distinctions from insurance rates and benefits glided through a Senate committee on a voice vote. A month ago, a major insurance trade group decided it was ''politically untenable'' to advocate sex discrimination in setting rates. And just a week ago, women's and civil rights groups were negotiating a compromise with the industry to minimize the plan's cost.

title: THIS ISLE, SCEPTER'D
description: The parliamentary election June 9 will be Margaret Thatcher's election. It has been called by her, it is about her and it will be won by her.

title: WASTEFUL ABATEMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Post for Fraser

title: Challenge to Britain
description: Al Franken, the chairman of the Kinney invitation track meet at Berkeley, Calif., on June 12, has offered a $25,000 prize to the winner of the one-mile run, provided one of Britain's stars in the event - Sebastian Coe, Steve Ovett or Steve Cram - decides to compete in the race. The idea underlines a challenge from Steve Scott, the top miler in the United States, to the British runners to oppose him on American soil. Coe holds the world record of 3 minutes 47:33 seconds and Scott has the second best time, 3:47:69.

title: DOW FALLS 15.77 TO 1,202.98
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday as growing concern over the interest rate outlook unsettled the market. The Dow Jones industrial average was down almost 21.96 points at 3 P.M., its low for the day. It closed off 15.77 points, at 1,202.98, after a late rally erased some of the earlier losses. The late recovery was attributed mostly to bargain hunting.

title: PENNEY REGISTERS 11.5% GAIN
description: The J.C. Penney Company, citing improved profit margins and lower interest expense, reported yesterday that net income increased 11.5 percent in the first fiscal quarter. Sales edged up 1.7 percent.

title: Q&A
description: Q The moon rotates on its axis at a rate equal to its revolution around the earth, so we always see the same side of the moon. Is this a coincidence, or the result of the mechanics governing the interaction of the earth and moon?

title: Comsat Satellite For Use by NBC
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said that a subsidiary and the RCA Corporation's NBC network had agreed to establish a satellite communications system that NBC would use to distribute programming to affiliated stations. NBC will begin to use the system next January for 24 stations.

title: Berbick Waits
description: Trevor Berbick has become boxing's version of the designated hitter, or perhaps, the designated catcher. The Canadian heavyweight is in training for a fight Friday for which he is not scheduled.

title: Chilean Company Sues Union Chiefs After Strike
description: Chilean union leaders face court action for calling an illegal general strike that turned into a protest against the Government, the state-owned copper company said today.

title: RCA Terminals
description: The RCA Corporation introduced four computer terminals for business, professional and hobby use.

title: Vadnais a Free Agent
description: In his 17-season National Hockey League career, Carol Vadnais has played 1,087 games with six teams -Montreal, Oakland, California, Boston, the Rangers and the New Jersey Devils. Yesterday, the 37-year-old defenseman became a free agent when the Devils decided not to pick up his option. Vadnais, who was claimed in the waiver draft from the Rangers last October, scored two goals and was credited with seven assists in 51 games with New Jersey during the 1982-83 season. ''I'll talk to some people about playing somewhere next year,'' said Vadnais.

title: AM Pension Plan
description: AM International Inc. said it would end a comprehensive retirement plan and replace it with one funded by future profits.

title: BEGIN SAID TO INSIST ON POST FOR GENERAL CRITICIZED ON MASSACRE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to have overruled Defense Minister Moshe Arens by insisting on a key appointment for a general who was severely criticized by the state commission that investigated the Beirut massacre.

title: AS ONE COMET RECEDES, A SECOND IS EXAMINED
description: AS comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock recedes from its close encounter with the earth on May 11, new calculations are showing that another comet will pass within about six million miles on June 12. This is twice the distance of the earlier comet but still unusually close.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, struggling to escape from last place in the Eastern Division, send their stopper, Tom Seaver, against Tim Lollar.

title: SIBERIAN CRANE THREATENED BY ANCIENT FORM OF HUNTING IN PAKISTAN
description: IN a remote valley in northern Pakistan, tribesmen perform a colorful spring hunting rite: the hurling of weighted cords into the air to snare migrating cranes as they fly overhead.

title: STILL ON THE STUMP, ON THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp stood before the Florida Conservative Union, his voice rising in the short-fire rhythms of a television preacher, his hands clenching the lectern.

title: Indy Driver Hurt
description: Pete Halsmer, a veteran of two Indianapolis 500 races, was reported in satisfactory condition at Methodist Hospital today after crashing into the first-turn wall during practice at the Motor Speedway. His injuries were a partly collapsed left lung, a puncture wound on his left leg and bruised heels. Halsmer, the third driver injured in practice, lost control of his car while speeding out of the first turn on the 2 1/2-mile oval.

title: People
description: * John Sheedy has joined Symon & Hilliard Inc. as president.

title: Chernenko Is Again Absent From a Gathering in Kremlin
description: Yuri V. Andropov and other members of the Politburo gathered today to meet with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola, but the ailing Konstantin U. Chernenko did not appear.

title: CRISS BOLSTERS BUCKS
description: When Charlie Criss entered the locker room of the Milwaukee Bucks two hours before they would win the fourth game of the Eastern Conference final series here on Sunday, he wondered if anyone would notice.

title: Reagan Curbs on Trips To Cuba Ruled Invalid
description: Regulations issued by the Reagan Administration restricting travel by Americans to Cuba are invalid, the First Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: Gulf Coast Waste Bonds Selling Well
description: A $65 million Aaa-rated bond issue for the Gulf Coast Waste Disposal Authority sold well yesterday, the first day of the offering, according to the underwriter, Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

title: JAPAN'S TRADE MINISTRY DRAWS PRAISE AND IRE
description: Much of the reason for the shining success of Japan's industrial policy can be found within the walls of two drab brick buildings in the Kasumigaseki district here. They serve as the headquarters of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

title: SOFTWARE: 'FIRST IDEA PROCESSOR'
description: LONG have I railed against the incomprehensible verbiage that passes for instructions - or documentation, as it's known in computerese - accompanying most hardware and software. It almost seems as if somehow, now that we have word processors, there's no longer any need for the words themselves to make sense. One begins to gain the impression that they are there merely to be stirred together and canned like so much alphabet soup.

title: PRESS IS A TARGET OF MARCOS DECREE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos issued a secret decree in 1981 calling for the death penalty for publishers who take part in ''sustained propaganda assaults'' on the Government, it was learned today.

title: Zimbabwe Telephones
description: The European Investment Bank has awarded Zimbabwe a $13.5 million loan to modernize the country's telecommunications network, the national press agency, Ziana, reported today.

title: Unilever Net Declines 22.4%
description: Unilever said today that its profits declined 22.4 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, but that its Lever Brothers operations in North America posted an operating profit after three years of losses.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS UTILITY RULES OF U.S.
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a set of Federal regulations intended to force utility companies to cooperate in the development of alternative, competing sources of energy.

title: OIL SEAL ERROR IN JET DRIVE WAS NOT EASTERN'S FIRST
description: The maintenance mistake that caused the nearly disastrous shutdown of all three engines of an Eastern Airlines jumbo jet May 5 had previously led to shutdowns of one engine on four or five similar planes in the airline's fleet, according to evidence presented at a public hearing today.

title: Argentina, at Request of U.S., Seizes Former Bolivian Aide
description: A former Bolivian Interior Minister was arrested today in connection with a United States request for his extradition on drug charges, the official Argentine press agency Telam reported.

title: INQUIRY INTO E.P.A. NEARS GRAND JURY
description: Justice Department officials say a grand jury will be impaneled ''very soon'' to investigate the possibility that two former officials of the Environmental Protection Agency committed perjury in testimony before House committees.

title: SECRET CURB BY CONGRESS ON COVERT AID IS DISCLOSED
description: Congress a year ago secretly restricted the use of covert money for Nicaraguan rebels to supporting operations to intercept shipments of arms to insurgents in El Salvador, according to a report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence made public today.

title: 5 Named to Broadcast Board
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate five people to be members of the Board for International Broadcasting. They are: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O.; Malcolm Forbes Jr., president of Forbes magazine; Former Republican Representative Clair W. Burgener of California; Arch L. Madsen, president of the Bonneville International Corporation, and James Michener, the author. The board administers Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe.

title: NEW SPIDER FOUND IN PANAMA FOREST
description: RESEARCHERS at the American Museum of Natural History have discovered a spider that lives on the floor of tropical forests and has strange physical features that set it far apart others of the spider world.

title: BRAZILIAN AID PACKAGE DISCUSSED BY BANKERS
description: Representatives of the commercial banks coordinating Brazil's multibillion-dollar rescue package met in New York yesterday to consider ways to make up a $1.5 billion shortfall in their aid program.

title: REGIME'S CANDIDATE LOSSES IN HAITI VOTE
description: HAITIEN, Haiti, May 16 (AP) - Free municipal elections, the first in 26 years of Duvalier family rule, were held in two-thirds of Haiti on Sunday, and unofficial returns today showed that the Government-backed candidate had lost in the country's second-largest city.

title: U.S.I.A. Hiring Dispute Leads Weinberger's Son to Resign
description: The son of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and the No. 2 man at the United States Information Agency both resigned from the agency today in the midst of a dispute over agency hiring of Reagan Administration relatives.

title: COURT SAYS 1-MAN RULE AFFECTS ESTIMATE BOARD
description: A Federal appeals court, reversing a lower court, ruled yesterday that the selection process for the New York City Board of Estimate must conform to the United States Constitution's principle of one man, one vote.

title: Accounts
description: * The Automotive Service Equipment division of the FMC Corporation, to Lewis, Gilman & Kynett Inc., Philadelphia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I heard a shot about 1 o'clock. We were told that when the bells ring to change classes, not to move.

title: I.O.C. Is Insisting On Drug Controls
description: The International Olympic Committee today told organizers of the next year's Games in Los Angeles that they must enforce the committee's new drug controls.

title: Stern's Owners Rebuff Demands by the Staff
description: The company that controls Stern magazine today rejected demands by the staff that the management be dismissed for publication of the forged Hitler diaries, a member of the editorial staff said.

title: NAPLES THEATER TROUPE POISED FOR LA MAMA DEBUT
description: For Tomas Arana, opening night of ''Tango Glaciale'' at La Mama, E.T.C., today will be a homecoming as well as a very big night. For the rest of Falso Movimento, the small and youthful Neapolitan experimental theater troupe, it will just be a very big night, perhaps the biggest of their lives.

title: Chrysler Board Backs Payment
description: The Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board approved the auto maker's proposal to pay off about $400 million in federally guaranteed loans, Chrysler said.

title: BY BEENE AND BISANG, LIGHTWEIGHT LUXURY IN FURS
description: ''The oldest fur looks the most modern,'' said Geoffrey Beene before the opening of his fur collection for the HBA Fur Corporation yesterday at the Parsons Fashion Center.

title: Packaging the Arts; Charlotte Curtis; Quid pro quo: Culture's latest path to funds.
description: APROFESSIONAL promoter, according to William Goldstein, who is one, makes money by putting events in need of financial backing together with those who have the dollars to produce mutually beneficial crowds, publicity, excitement and sales of the backer's product. In an earlier age, this sort of entrepreneur staged prize fights. More recently, promoters have reaped profits plastering corporate names on golf, tennis and other sports contests.

title: JUSTICES AVOID A DECISION IN BOSTON CIVIL RIGHTS CASE
description: The Supreme Court today ordered dismissed as moot a civil rights case involving layoffs on the Boston police and fire departments. By its action, the Court avoided deciding the difficult question of whether judges may supersede ordinary lasthired, first-fired seniority provisions to protect the jobs of recently hired black employees.

title: Treasury Aide Is Nominated
description: Thomas J. Healey, an executive at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., has been selected to become the new assistant secretary for domestic finance, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Pensions or Productivity?
description: The Ford Motor Company had long been losing money on its Sheffield, Ala., plant. But last year, when Ford gave its Sheffield workers the choice of (a) taking a big pay cut (b) buying the plant from the company or (c) closing the plant, the auto workers voted for unemployment.

title: RUSSIANS' STRATEGY ON TRADE
description: The Soviet Union is pursuing a mixed strategy toward East-West trade, seeking to expand it while at the same time warning of retaliation against American efforts to impose restraints, an interview with a senior Soviet trade official suggests.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Touring in a Bed

title: SENATORS REPORT PROFITS FROM SPEECHES AND STOCKS
description: The financial disclosure forms of the six senators from the New York metropolitan area were filed today, revealing estimates of their personal wealth and outside earnings.

title: Mark Syers, 30, Actor; Was Magaldi in 'Evita'
description: Mark Syers, an actor and singer best known for a leading role in the Broadway hit musical ''Evita,'' and another man were killed Sunday night when their cars collided on a wet highway in Hopewell Township, N.J. Mr. Syers was 30 years old and lived in Washington's Crossing, N.J.

title: New Astronauts Sought
description: NASA announced today it will be looking for astronauts - six pilots and six mission specialists - later this year.

title: Braniff Plan Is Discussed
description: Top executives of Braniff International met with the company's secured creditors in New York yesterday and outlined a $70 million plan, approved by the airline's directors last week, to restart the carrier.

title: COURT AGREES TO DEFINE U.S. ROLE IN LEASING OF OFFSHORE OIL TRACTS
description: The Supreme Court entered a major environmental controversy today and agreed to define the Federal Government's environmental obligations in the leasing of offshore tracts for oil and gas exploration.

title: THE ILLEGITIMATE OFFSPRING OF RENT CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: LEXICON
description: It sounds like one of those awful concoctions of alphabet soup encountered in the Army - USJCIRPTE (pronounced use-jay-KRIP-tee).

title: BRIEFING
description: Milk and Cookies

title: REVERSING A DEAD END FOR YOUTHS
description: The young men rose late and drifted into Hamilton Park, where they sat on park benches and, seeing no future, talked of the past. They seemed old. Late in the afternoon a few roused themselves for a basketball game, one in which most tried to score on the impossibly long shot.

title: Brief Comeback
description: Ahmad Rashad, who spent 10 years as an outstanding wide receiver in the National Football League before becoming a sports commentator for NBC this year, is proud of his athletic talents. Last week in Adelaide, Australia, while covering the women's world power-lifting championships, he found an opportunity to test his skills in a sport similar to American football, but one that has some major differences.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A New Arena
description: Henry A. Kissinger has been active campaigning in recent weeks on behalf of the United States, which is trying to hold the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament.

title: KENYAN OFFICIAL DENIES PLOTTING
description: Charles Njonjo, Kenya's Minister for Constitutional Affairs, today denied veiled accusations by fellow politicians that he was being groomed by an unidentified foreign power to oust President Daniel arap Moi.

title: SECRETS THAT SERVE AS A STATUS SYMBOL
description: To the Editor:

title: WRONG ARGUMENT FOR OPPOSING METRICS
description: To the Editor:

title: A FOCUS IS PUT ON RESULTS
description: THE College Board, the organization best known as the sponsor of the Scholastic Aptitude Tests, is adding its muscle to the growing movement that seeks to improve elementary and secondary education by having schools and colleges work together more closely to achieve mutual goals.

title: LEGISLATION SEEKS FIXED JAIL TERMS
description: Governor Cuomo and two key legislators have agreed on the main elements of legislation that would establish fixed sentences for most crimes instead of relying on judges' discretion.

title: Federal Data Is Rejected In Discrimination Suit
description: The Government's discrimination suit against the International Business Machines Corporation was given a setback today when a judge refused to admit statistical data as evidence.

title: Football and the Law
description: Spokesmen for the National Collegiate Athletic Association said they still were undecided on their next move in the legal wrangling over television rights to college football games. But ultimately, says Dr. Joab Thomas, president of the University of Alabama, the issue will be decided by the United States Supreme Court.

title: NICARAGUA SEEMS TO EASE U.N. STAND
description: Nicaragua appeared ready today to accept a Security Council resolution on outside support of a rebellion within its borders far milder than the version that it originally proposed.

title: Warner Amex Cable Cuts 57 More Positions
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc., which lost $47 million last year, announced yesterday that it was eliminating 57 jobs, mainly in marketing and personnel.

title: Island Reported Melting
description: After more than 36 years of wandering in the Arctic Ocean, Fletcher's Ice Island, used for a quarter of a century as a research station, appears destined to melt. The ''island'' - a flat slab of glacial ice almost as large as Manhattan - is no longer occupied and for half a year, until this month, its whereabouts had been unknown.

title: Article 170918 -- No Title
description: The European Economic Community today authorized a $3.7 billion loan to France to help it with a severe balance-of-payments problem.

title: Marietta to Acquire Mathematica Inc.
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire all the outstanding stock of Mathematica Inc. for $30.8 million in cash and securities.

title: The U.N. Today; May 17, 1983; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ROGER J. TRAYNOR, CALIFORNIA JUSTICE
description: Roger J. Traynor, a legal scholar who served for 30 years on a California Supreme Court reknowned for its activism, died Saturday in San Francisco, it was announced yesterday. He was 83 years old and had had cancer for several years.

title: SHORT GOWNS SHINE FOR NIGHT
description: Short dresses with an effervescent glow provide a fresh slant on dressing for festive evenings, and the style is a recurring theme in the fall and winter collections. The dresses slither easily over the body in uncomplicated shapes. Often they are brief enough to show the knees, so fancy stockings and pretty shoes are the most necessary accompaniments.

title: BBDO Discusses Loss Of the Camel Account
description: Bruce Crawford, chief executive of BBDO International, told the New York Securities Analysts yesterday that if worse came to worst, the greatest harm that could befall his worldwide agency organization as a result of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco moving the Camel brand from his organization to Ogilvy & Mather, would be a per-share earnings drop of 10 cents to 15 cents in the second half of this year.

title: REAGAN DENOUNCES LAWMAKERS URGING INCREASE IN TAXES
description: The President will hold a televised news conference at 8 P.M. today.

title: DEBT, NOT DOMINOES
description: While President Reagan tries to rouse the nation against the threat of falling dominoes that he perceives in Central America, he is not talking about what may well be a more serious hemispheric problem - the mountains of external debt towering over Mexico ($85 to $90 billion), Brazil ($85 to $90 billion), Argentina ($35 to $40 billion), Venezuela ($25 to $35 billion) and Chile ($15 to $20 billion).

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 17, 1983
description: International The Lebanese-Israeli accord, which is to be signed by both countries today, places strict and detailed limits on the deployment of Lebanese military personnel and weapons in southern Lebanon. Only two Lebanese Army brigades with a total of 8,682 soldiers may be stationed there with the equipment the troops normally carry. No antiaircraft or ground-to-sea missiles and no military radar that can search Israeli territory will be allowed. (Page A1, Column 4.) George P. Shultz was urged to return to the Middle East as soon as possible to help Lebanon negotiate a withdrawal of Syrian forces. The appeal to the Secretary of State was made by President Amin Gemayel during an interview in Beirut. (A1:5.)

title: Pill Is Linked To a Cancer
description: Prolonged use of birth control pills may increase the risk of contracting a form of skin cancer, according to a study by Dr. Elizabeth Holly, an epidemiologist at the University of California here.

title: Palestinians Stone Israelis
description: Palestinian youths stoned Israeli vehicles and threw bottles at security forces today during scattered protests in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, security officials said. The Palestinians said they were protesting the wounding Sunday of a Palestinian who was shot in the thigh when he escaped from a military vehicle during demonstrations.

title: I.B.M. INTRODUCES COMPUTER TO REPLACE SYSTEM 34 MODEL
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new medium-sized general purpose computer today as an eventual replacement for its existing System/34 model.

title: GRAND JURY IN ALABAMA CLEARS 2 WHITE OFFICERS OF KILLING 2 BLACKS
description: A grand jury, meeting in the Henry County Courthouse 24 miles south here, today cleared two white Eufaula police officers in the fatal shooting of two blacks, Hampton and Anthony Russaw.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
BOND PRICES DIP ON RATE FEARS
description: Yields on long-term bonds rose sharply yesterday as investors sold securities in fear that interest rates might rise further. Dealers slashed prices in hopes of attracting buyers.

title: FRANCE HARDENS VIEW ON U.S.
description: The tone and tactics of the French Government are hardening into positions that make more likely a confrontation with the United States at the economic summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va., over the Memorial Day weekend.

title: JUDGE ORDERS JERSEY TO RESUME CHECKING ALL AUTOS EVERY YEAR
description: A Federal judge ruled today that New Jersey's ''odd-even'' system of motor vehicle inspection, which reduced inspections from once a year to once every two years, violated the Federal Clean Air Act. He ordered the state to resume annual inspections.

title: EXPERT ON METALS
description: Dr. John Chipman, an internationally recognized metals expert and former head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's department of metallurgy, died Saturday at his home in Winchester, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Arabs Seek U.N. Meeting
description: The Arab countries called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to resume debate on what was termed the situation in the occupied territories, a reference to the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Jasim Jamal, the chief delegate of Qatar and current chairman of the Arab group, submitted the request. A United Nations spokesman said he did not know when the 15-nation Council would act on it.

title: SCIENTISTS FROM RUSSIA: WHO ARE THEY?
description: MOST Soviet scientists sent to the United States on exchange visits are either ''ideologically reliable'' bureaucrats with no real scientific credentials or spies bent on stealing technological secrets, according to Michael Taksar, a Soviet mathematician who emigrated in 1977 and is now an assistant professor of operations research at Stanford University.

title: REBELS WIN COURT DECISION IN CHICAGO COUNCIL DISPUTE
description: A circuit judge ruled today that a group of dissident aldermen acted legally in approving a City Council reorganization plan that excludes allies of Mayor Harold Washington from the chairmanship of important Council committees and greatly reduces the Mayor's control over business before the legislative body.

title: VOTE MX, VOTE PERIL
description: Congress is moving rapidly to approve the MX missile in a carefully manipulated spirit of bipartisanship. This course is both dangerous and irresponsible. The deployment of the MX would seriously increase the risk of accidental or unintentional nuclear war for both superpowers. Last month, the Scowcroft commission reached the eminently sensible conclusion that stability should be our primary objective in nuclear weapons policy but, in total contradiction of this good sense, recommended going ahead with the MX. It is difficult to imagine a measure that would contribute more profoundly to nuclear instability.

title: EXPERTS TESTIFY AIDS EPIDEMIC STRIKES THE CITY
description: A deadly syndrome that ravages the body's natural defenses against disease has reached epidemic proportions among homosexuals and intravenous drug users in New York City, medical experts told a legislative hearing yesterday in Manhattan.

title: FOR FRIGHTENED FAMILIES, A VIGIL IN THE CHILLY RAIN
description: ''It's a horrible, terrible feeling. I feel like he's shot two, he's got nothing to lose,'' said Eric Guandar, two of whose children were held hostage at the Brentwood East Junior High School today.

title: LANG WARMS TO U.S. FILM MAKERS
description: Jack Lang, the head of the French cultural ministry whose statements criticizing American cultural dominance have aroused anger in the American film industry and elsewhere, held a conciliatory lunch here last weekend for the heads of America's largest studios.

title: OF LISTENING TO AMBASSADOR KIRKPATRICK AND HONORING HER
description: To the Editor:

title: DISCOURAGEMENT PERVADES THE CAMPUSES OF ITALY
description: ROME WHILE university students in Paris are battling the police, their counterparts in Rome are apathetic and resigned. They have, at least for the time being, sworn off violence, but they appear also to have abandoned hope for reform of the system through political action.

title: DISCOMFORT AND MIXED SIGNALS ON THE DEATH PENALTY
description: When it comes to the death penalty, the Supreme Court appears more and more uneasy in its role as the court of last resort.

title: New Appeal Is Rejected In Italy's Bulgarian Case
description: A magistrate has rejected a new appeal to release a Bulgarian held in connection with the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, judicial sources said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Life After Legal Aid

title: Parody Planned On Playboy Magazine
description: A parody is a laughing matter, but a $13,500 tab for an advertising page is no joke. Which is one way of saying that some of the same gang that must have profited nicely from earlier parody publications entitled Not The New York Times and Off The Wall Street Journal have now decided to get down to the basics with Playbore, from the girlie area that is so ripe for parody and one taken on by the masterful wits of The Harvard Lampoon staff in 1966 when they did their Playboy spoof.

title: U.S.F.L. Grows
description: Commissioner Chet Simmons of the United States Football League announced today that the league's 14th franchise would begin play in San Diego next March.

title: I.R.S.'S LITHOGRAPH CHALLENGE
description: During the late 1970's, wealthy taxpayers and their accountants started expanding the boundaries of tax-shelter law. Millions in deductions were claimed for the purchase of such exotica as the master plates for lithographs, or the right to reproduce an image on wallpaper and tablecloths.

title: BOND AND BILL FUTURES DECLINE ON RATE FEARS
description: Prices of Treasury bond and bill futures fell sharply yesterday as a report last Friday of another unexpected surge in the basic money supply renewed fears of a rebound in interest rates.

title: 17 Injured by Tornadoes In Georgia and Alabama
description: By The Associated Press Tornadoes touched down in several communities in southern Georgia and Alabama yesterday, wrecking homes, leaving thousands without power and injuring 17 people.

title: MUSIC: HOROWITZ RECITAL
description: VLADIMIR HOROWITZ long ago reached the plateau, achieved by only a handful of musicians in any generation, at which his every appearance in public qualifies as an Event. So, the Metropolitan Opera House was awash in celebrities Sunday night for his piano recital. Musicians could be seen on every side, of course, but the turnout also included the fashionable audience that always wants to be on hand whenever anything out of the ordinary is going on. The Met was the place to be on this night, and no mistake.

title: FORMER COUNSEL TO THE A.C.L.U.
description: Osmond K. Fraenkel, a former general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, died of a heart attack yesterday on the way to work. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SEARS SAYS IT MAY PUSH PLAN TO BUY THRIFT UNITS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, in line with its goal of becoming one of the nation's largest financial services companies, told shareholders yesterday that it was considering acquiring more savings and loan institutions to build ''a nationwide deposit base.''

title: Chess: 5 Finish in First-Place Tie In New York Open Event
description: The grandmasters Lev Alburt of New York, Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., and Anthony Miles of Britain tied with the international masters Sergey Kudrin of Stamford, Conn., and Kamran Shirazi of Los Angeles for first place in the power-packed New York Open Tournament.

title: Business and the Law; Defining Insider Trades
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission was not pleased when it learned how Thomas C. Reed's 48-hour investment in $3,125 of Amax options yielded more than $427,000. Mr. Reed bought his call options March 4, 1981, the day before the company's board - on which Mr. Reed's father sat - announced a proposed $4 billion takeover by the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: A.G. Edwards
description: A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc., a St. Louis brokerage, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Hammerbeck & Company of Portand, Ore.

title: STUDY OF LOVE CANAL FINDS NO DIRECT LINK TO GENETIC DISEASES
description: Residents and former residents at the Love Canal toxic-waste site in Niagara Falls, N.Y., are no more likely to have suffered chromosomal damage than residents elsewhere in the city, a Government study concluded today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: year association with Motown Records at the beginning of the 1980's, has returned to this country in style. Last night, he began a six-night run at Radio City Music Hall, and during the next two months he will be touring the rest of America, for the first time since 1976. ''Midnight Love,'' his first album for Columbia, has been on the pop charts for 26 weeks, and ''Sexual Healing,'' the controversial single from that album, was one of the biggest hits of Mr. Gaye's career.

title: Magazine Publishers Pick D'Arcy/New York
description: After a competition involving six agencies, each of which developed speculative campaigns, the board of the Magazine Publishers Association has selected D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York as its agency.

title: Thatcher Trip Curtailed
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in the midst of a general election campaign, will make an abbreviated appearance at the Western economic meeting in Williamsburg, Va., at the end of May, her office said today. Mrs. Thatcher's travel plans were thrown into doubt after she called an election for June 9. Government sources said they knew of no precedent for a Prime Minister to be out of the country during a campaign.

title: PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $410,000 from sale of the company's minority interest in Fres-co System U.S.A. and a bad debt recovery of $226,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $5,000.

title: ISLANDERS MAKE IT FOUR, THE HARD WAY
description: Four championships in four years. That's what the Islanders accomplished last night in the Stanley Cup final. And by doing so, the Islanders emerged as one of history's most elite sports organizations. High society was once known as the Four Hundred, but the Islanders now have created an even more exclusive Four among all the major league franchises in the most prominent American professional team sports - baseball, football, basketball and hockey.

title: Texas Oil and Gas
description: The Texas Oil and Gas Corporation, Dallas, announced it had agreed to acquire interests of the Hadson Petroleum Corporation and its limited partners in 128 producing gas wells and about 52,000 undeveloped leasehold acres for $26.7 million. All the properties are in the Arkoma Basin of western Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bacteria in Soy Products

title: CHAMBER: NASH ENSEMBLE
description: THE Nash Ensemble of London is not well known in this country. The group toured here in 1981, but its records seem largely confined to British labels with limited circulation abroad. The ensemble's first concert here Monday in Alice Tully Hall was poorly attended, but its third and final New York appearance, set for Saturday evening, again in Tully Hall, deserves the attention of all chamber-music lovers.

title: AARON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid May 31.

title: INTEGRATED ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PROTESTERS AT BEGIN'S DOOR ARE UNMOVED BY PULLOUT ACCORD
description: For the last 22 days, during an intense period of work on the Israeli-Lebanese agreement, a group of young people protesting against the presence of Israeli troops in Lebanon has maintained a vigil outside Prime Minister Menachem Begin's house.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding adjusted to reflect aggregate stock dividends paid through March 4, 1983.

title: Sunny's Halo Improved
description: The ringworm rash that had been spreading over Sunny's Halo's flanks and threatened his status for the Preakness here Saturday began to recede today, and the Kentucky Derby winner is now almost certain to run in the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE is a troublesome kind of exclusivity about fine wine, a tendency to be patronizing and elitist when describing bottles no one else will ever taste.

title: GAC LIQUIDATING TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: STATE'S INVESTIGATION FINDS NO ILLEGAL ACTS BY DORMITORY PANEL
description: The State Commission of Investigation said today that it had found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing on the part of Dormitory Authority officials who lost nearly $20 million in state money because of investments with a Wall Street concern that later filed for bankruptcy.

title: GEORGIA BONDED FIBERS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $172,000 for the quarter and $264,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $43,000.

title: CABLE NETWORK PLAN TO OFFER EDUCATIONL SHOW TO DOCTORS
description: Cable Health Network, a year-old cable television service, plans to begin a weekly two-hour educational program for physicians on June 29, Dr. Art Ulene, the network's chairman, said at a news conference yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: GLOUCESTERSHIRE CELEBRATES RETURN OF THE EEL TO THE SEVEN
description: Every spring, the people who live along the River Severn, which runs through Gloucestershire to the sea at Bristol, look forward to the elver rush, as high spring tides sweep millions of these young eels far upstream.

title: STRAWBERRY'S 3-RUN HOMER PACES METS
description: With the old Tom Seaver pitching and the new Darryl Strawberry hitting and fielding, the Mets defeated the San Diego Padres last night at Shea Stadium, 6-4.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WHEN Polly Bergen was a youngster in the Bluegrass Country of Tennessee, she despised her given name. ''There were no other Pollys around except a lot of cows who were called that,'' she said. ''I used to dream that I had a twin sister, that her name was Polly and my name was Pamela. That seemed a terribly acceptable name to me; all the rich kids were named Pamela.''

title: UNIVERSAL CIGAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a net gain of $125,196, or 9 cents a share, on the sale of securities.

title: Market Place; Thrift Industry And Its Stocks
description: WASHINGTON A YEAR ago, few stock groups had a dimmer future than did those of the nation's troubled savings and loan industry. But thanks largely to the sharp decline in interest rates and new legislation that permits the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to inject capital into institutions that are running out of reserves, the outlook for the industry is much brighter now,

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the equity method of accounting for investment in the Penn Central Corporation.

title: Mitterrand Assails U.S. Deficit
description: President Francois Mitterrand asserted today that the United States was making Europe pay the bill for its budget deficit. As a result, he said, Europe should press the Americans on the issue at the economic summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va., at the end of the month.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $107,578 from discontinued operations.

title: VIOLA: RIVKA GOLANI-ERDESZ
description: IT takes a substantial personality to raise the viola from its subservient, often clumsy, role in the orchestra to a solo status. Rivka Golani-Erdesz's recital at the 92d Street Y Sunday never quite avoided her instrument's unwieldiness of tone, but she did bring to it the requisite generosity of spirit.

title: Injunction Delays GAF Certification
description: A Federal judge issued a temporary injunction that delays for at least 14 days the certification of the election of some dissident directors to the board of the GAF Corporation.

title: Peruvian Forces Kill 30 In Clash With Guerrillas
description: Security forces killed 30 suspected Maoist guerrillas in a clash on Sunday near Cussi in the Andes, a communique said today.

title: WHO SPEAKS FOR AMERICA?
description: The Secretaries of State and Defense spoke in public the other day about the problem of getting Syrian troops out of Lebanon, each in a different way.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: ESTEBAN'S MEXICAN FOOD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Anna Leskaya Asch, Russian-Born Soprano
description: Anna Leskaya Asch, a Russian-born soprano who sang the title role in the 1935 American premiere of Dimitri Shostakovich's ''Lady Macbeth of Mzensk,'' died in New York May 9. She was 87 years old and had lived here since 1927.

title: HUDSON BAY MINING & SMELTING CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting with respect to the capitalization of interest costs on major capital projects.

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Egypt Urges All Sides To Respect Agreement
description: Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali called on ''foreign parties'' today to respect the withdrawal agreement signed by Israel and Lebanon.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on March 8, 1983.

title: GALA EVENING OF DANCE HONORS AGNES DE MILLE
description: Representatives of the worlds of theater, dance and music paid tribute to one of the most distinguished American choreographers Monday night when the Friends of the Theater and Music Collection of the Museum of the City of New York presented a gala honoring Agnes de Mille at the Shubert Theater.

title: KEMP'S HOME RUN IN 11TH IS DECISIVE
description: Steve Kemp said that when he went to bat in the 11th inning against the Detroit Tigers tonight, he was thinking: ''If I don't hit a home run now, we might have to play another inning. Anything can happen.''

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on May 7 about oil exploration attributed to the wrong Phillips Petroleum official a remark about the ''investment climate most attractive'' for exploration projects. The speaker was Edward Morse, director of international affairs for Phillips.

title: PACIFIC EXPRESS HOLDING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $123,000. Since the company did not begin operating jet airline service until Jan. 27, 1982, the earlier year results represent only two months of full operation.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COSTA RICANS ARRIVE IN NICARAGUA FOR BORDER TALKS
description: A high-level delegation of Costa Rican officials has arrived here for talks with the Nicaraguan Government on border problems.

title: Honda Unit Moves
description: Needham, Harper & Steers/New York has become agency for the Honda Dealers Association Metro New York Group, which bills more than $1.5 million. For the past year the dealers were served by Lois, Pitts, Gershon, which created the ''Help me, Honda'' TV campaign.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will not support a budget resolution that raises taxes while we're coming out of a recession.

title: Orioles Win 2; Flanagan Hurt
description: Leo Hernandez and Rick Dempsey hit consecutive homers in the second inning, and Mike Boddicker, a rookie, pitched a five-hitter in the second game to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-0 triumph and a sweep of their doubleheader with the Chicago White Sox.

title: JEFFERSON CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,085 for the latest year and $261,914 for the previous year.

title: House roll-call vote, page D5.
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to repeal the withholding of taxes from dividends and interest payments.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 28.
description: b-After a tax credit of $130,000.

title: Technology Unit Picks Texas Site
description: The city of Austin, Tex., has beaten 56 other municipal contestants in the competition to become home to a major new research enterprise headed by Bobby R. Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, it was announced today.

title: WHY JERSEY IS LEANING TO EXECUTIONS BY INJECTION
description: In a small room in a complex of buildings not far from the State Capitol, five people have been working for several weeks to fashion New Jersey's details of death.

title: MX SURVIVES A TEST IN HOUSE AFTER LOBBYING BY PRESIDENT
description: After President Reagan lobbied lawmakers with last-minute phone calls, the MX missile narrowly survived another test vote in Congress today and headed for a showdown on the floor of the House and Senate.

title: SUNRISE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (LAKE WORTH, FLA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICAN DROUGHT, BLACKS ARE HARDEST HIT
description: Older farmers who remember a devastating drought in 1933 say the one that is now gripping southern Africa is certainly worse. A South African Cabinet minister insisted it was the worst in two centuries.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Vote on Lavelle Case Today
description: The House of Representatives has scheduled a vote tomorrow on a contempt-of-Congress citation against a former official of the Environmental Protection Agency, Rita M. Lavelle. She was cited by the House Energy and Commerce Committee for failing to testify after receiving a subpeona. Miss Lavelle was formerly in charge of the toxic waste cleanup program.

title: DEFENSE IN CBS DEATHS CALLS STATE'S CASE CIRCUMSTANTIAL
description: On the basis of a telephone call, lack of a positive identification and poor eyesight, a jury in Manhattan was urged yesterday to acquit Donald Nash of charges he was a hired gunman who killed five people.

title: FOR 7,300 AT COLUMBIA, A DAY FULL OF BALLOONS AND DIPLOMAS
description: There was stately music and lusty cheering; confetti and balloons filled the air and, here and there in the sea of gowns and tassels, champagne corks popped. In afternoon ceremonies, more than 7,300 people, including a distinguished 80-year-old philosopher who got his bachelor's degree after a 60-year delay, received degrees yesterday at Columbia University's 229th commencement.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 18, 1983
description: International A confidential U.S.-Israeli accord was signed in Washington and Jerusalem, according to Israeli and Reagan Administration officials. The agreement, they said, recognizes that despite the Israeli-Lebanese security accord, Israel has the right to retaliate against terrorist attacks from Lebanon and that Israel may delay withdrawing its forces from Lebanon until the forces of Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization also withdraw. (Page A1, Column 1.) An Israeli-Lebanese agreement was signed in ceremonies in both countries. The security agreement is designed to lead to a withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and a continuing Israeli involvement in policing southern Lebanon. (A16:1-4.)

title: News Analysis
description: For all its historic significance and for all the smiles and handshakes of the negotiators, the signing of the Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement seems to have been cause for little real rejoicing in either Israel or Lebanon.

title: MEMBERS OF HOUSE DISCLOSE HOLDINGS AND INCOME
description: Financial disclosure forms filed by members of the House today show that of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Representative Stewart B. McKinney is probably the wealthiest.

title: REAGAN CALLS FOR MEDAL FOR LEADERS IN THE ARTS
description: President Reagan called today for the establishment of a national medal to honor both the creators and sponsors of art.

title: Florida Bank Victory
description: Florida bankers won a significant victory today in their battle to keep New York banks out of the state.

title: HART SEEKS TO STRESS IDEAS IN A CAMPAIGN OF 'CATTLE SHOWS'
description: When the Democratic Presidential candidates appear as a group, it is easy to spot Senator Gary Hart of Colorado. He is the one who looks as if he would rather be somewhere else.

title: Tennis Players To Stress Age
description: On a rainy day at Wimbledon in the summer of 1981, Billie Jean King and Rosie Casals were chatting in the dressing room when Miss Casals mentioned an idea.

title: Topics; Benchmarks; Hopeful Jobless
description: President Reagan complains that faulty statistics do not properly depict the improving job market. He's understandably frustrated that the official unemployment rate still hangs high even as employment rises.

title: Much of Philippines Stricken by Drought
description: A severe drought has spread over all but the northernmost parts of the Philippines, causing heavy losses for a quarter of the nation's two million farmers.

title: Brewers in Court Case
description: A Texas A&M athlete denied yesterday that alumni and assistant coaches gave him a car, credit cards and a $200 weekly stipend during his last year in high school. That charge was made by Dan Duquette, a Milwaukee Brewer personnel official, in Federal Court in Houston, where the Brewers were seeking an injunction that would bar the athlete, Kevin Murray, a former star quarterback at North Dallas High, from playing football for the Aggies.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Mike Torrez is struggling along at 1-5, with defeats in his last three decisions, and is trying to fight off relegation to the bullpen. He gets the start against Dave Dravecky, who is looking for his seventh victory. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. Dave Righetti, off to a start reminiscent of his rookie-of-the-year season in 1981, goes for victory No. 6. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball 76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks, Eastern Conference final, fifth game, at Philadelphia. The Bucks, led by Bob Lanier, rallied Sunday to deal Philadelphia its first playoff defeat in eight games. Still, the 76ers are up, 3-1, and need one victory to reach the league final. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. San Antonio Spurs, Western Conference final, fifth game, at Inglewood, Calif. Los Angeles goes for the clincher. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M.) Boxing LeRoy Haley, champion, vs. Bruce Curry, World Boxing Council's junior-welterweight title bout, at Las Vegas, Nev. This is the third title defense for the 27-year-old Haley. Curry, the North American Boxing Federation's champion, is rated sixth by the W.B.C. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Other Events Golf: Long Island Open, at the Huntington (L.I.) Country Club, 7:30 A.M. Harness Racing: Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, midnight, tape); Yonkers Raceway, 8 P.M.; Monticello (N.Y.) Raceway, 8 P.M.; Freehold (N.J.) Raceway, 1 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing: Belmont Park, 1 P.M. The $50,000-added Roseben Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at 6 furlongs, is the opening-day feature.

title: Fragrances at B.B.D.O.
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn may have lost the R.J. Reynolds Camel account to McCann-Erickson, but it has won something more pleasant scentwise - two fragrances from Jacqueline Cochran: L'Air du Temps and Pierre Cardin. Jacqueline Cochran is a subsidiary of the American Cyanamid Company, which already has its Pine-Sol Household Cleaner and other products at B.B.D.O. The two scents were previously at Sacks, Rosen; the billings reportedly run about $6 million.

title: MOSCOW ON THE HUDSON
description: The biggest difficulty about living in Manhattan nowadays is finding a place to do it. Remember how Americans used to laugh about housing conditions in Moscow - four generations plus house guests crammed into a one-bedroom apartment? We felt superior about that and said it demonstrated the failure of Communism.

title: Japan's Auto Union Chief Pledges to Help U.A.W.
description: The president of the Japan Automobile Workers' Unions pledged today to assist the United Automobile Workers in the United States in organizing workers in Japanese automobile plants in this country.

title: STATE SOCIETIES SPECIALIZE IN FLAVOR
description: It was not a typical Washington soiree. There were no elegantly clad guests sampling equally elegant canapes. The plates were paper, the forks and glasses were plastic and most of the guests showed up in jeans and colorful T-shirts inscribed SLOPS: Society for Lovers of Pit-Cooked Swine.

title: BIRDSBORO COR. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $268,000 for the latest first quarter and $212,000 for the year-ago first quarter from equity in earnings of affiliates.

title: INTERIOR DEPT. AIDS OIL GROUP IN WILDLIFE STUDY
description: The Interior Department, currently reviewing its rules on oil and gas leasing in wildlife refuges, is helping an oil industry trade association to conduct a survey on how compatible drilling operations are with the protection of wildlife.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EMPHASIS ON PSYCHOLOGY AT A LUXURY HOTEL IN CITY
description: Most operators of urban hotels have wrongly valued operational efficiency over the psychological comfort of their guests, says Rene E. Hatt, a Swiss-born hotelier who is renovating the former Gotham Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street into the Nova-Park Gotham Hotel, New York.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes a $1.5 million gain from the sale of property.

title: DAYTON-HUDSON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $953,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $5,263,000 and a net gain of about $2.5 million on the sale of six jewelry companies.

title: ZALE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. The results for the latest year reflect a charge of $10.6 million for the settlement of the tax examination for fiscal years 1970-1975. Year-ago results are restated.

title: TV: THREE-PART SERIES ON BLACKS IN THE MILITARY
description: WILLIAM MILES, a film maker and documentarian, has spent the greater part of the last decade illuminating the role of black people in the history of this country.

title: BALLET: A NEW WORK BY MISS TAYLOR-CORBETT
description: CORBETT scored such a popular success last year with ''Great Galloping Gottschalk,'' the first ballet she choreographed for American Ballet Theater, that the management, very naturally, asked her to create still another work for the company.

title: HORIZONS RESEARCH reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $147,504.

title: Technology Issues Lead Market Higher
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in more active trading after Monday's selloff, with some of the technology issues posting the best gains.

title: WALTON IS OPTIMISTIC ON OUTLOOK FOR JETS
description: With not even a scrimmage under his cap, Joe Walton of the Jets has already had a quick introduction to some of the concerns of a professional head coach.

title: 'BEAR' BRADY DOWNS A CHINATOWN FEAST
description: BETWEEN receiving an honorary doctorate at Wilmington College in Delaware on Sunday and a father-of-the-year award from a retail group in New York yesterday, James S. Brady, the White House Press Secretary, found time to do what he likes best: eat.

title: Hometown Help
description: Although he gained 4,442 yards in his four-year football career at Lawrence College in Appleton, Wis., and for the last three seasons led National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III schools in rushing, Scott Reppert attracted no interest in the recent National Football League college draft.

title: JET MAINTENANCE WORRIES OFFICIAL
description: The head of the National Transportation Safety Board said today that he was ''disturbed'' about the possible inadequacy of steps being taken to prevent more maintenance errors like those that nearly caused an Eastern Airlines jumbo jet to ditch in the Atlantic on May 5.

title: EDUCOM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect payment of a 5 percent stock dividend in March 1983.

title: QUANTUM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Included a tax credit of $814,000.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results are restated.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The Justice Department reached an agreement today to require the Indiana prison system to assign women as guards inside men's minimum- and medium-security institutions.

title: Lockheed Shares
description: Despite record quarterly earnings recently, the Lockheed Corporation said it did not plan to resume cash dividends. Roy A. Anderson, chairman of the California-based aircraft and aerospace company, told the annual meeting that an improved debt-to-equity ratio was bringing the company ''closer to a situation where we can again consider dividends on the common.'' Its last dividend, 30 cents a share, was paid in December 1969.

title: OUR COUNTRY'S ENDANGERED PUBLIC ESTATE
description: To the Editor:

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued business of $34,000. c-After a loss from discontinued business of $75,000.

title: Soviet Dissident on Trial
description: Leonid Borodin, a dissident, went on trial here today on charges of anti-Soviet propaganda, the press agency Tass said.

title: Spectator Roles
description: When Spectacular Bid won the Preakness Stakes in 1979 at Pimlico, it was one of the most popular victories ever at the Maryland track. It wasn't just that Spectacular Bid was 1-to-10, the shortest price in Preakness history, but that his trainer, Buddy Delp, and his jockey, Ronnie Franklin, were both locals who made their daily living at Pimlico.

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,675,000 from investment income. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $500,000 and income of $147,000 from investments.

title: EX-INTELLIGENCE DIRECTOR DISPUTES CENSORSHIP OF HIS BOOK ON C.I.A.
description: Adm. Stansfield Turner, who as Director of Central Intelligence prosecuted a former C.I.A. agent for refusing to clear his book with the agency, is disputing C.I.A. censors over his own book on intelligence.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 24.
description: b-Net loss.

title: DEMOCRATIC WOMEN UNITED FOR '84
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In May 1979, Police Officer Anthony J. Abruzzo Jr. was dispatched to a fire on Main Street in Flushing, Queens. In the course of crowd control, he found himself repeatedly warning a young woman with hair to her waist and enormous doe eyes to stay back at a safe distance on the other side of the street. Officer Abruzzo soon went from giving the young woman orders to asking her questions. He found out that her name was Barbara and that she worked in a furniture store on the street. A few days later, he came back to look for her.

title: 4 RETAILERS POST STRONG GAINS
description: Four of the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported sharp increased earnings in their first quarter as a result of improved sales, higher margins and better internal controls.

title: Stronger U.S.  Bayer Units
description: Bayer A.G. expects its United States operations to contribute strongly to world group profits in 1983 after costing it about $78 million last year, the managing board chairman, Herbert Gruenewald, said today.

title: DEBATE RAGES ON DMSO DESPITE ITS USERS' CLAIMS
description: AS with many other unproved substances with seemingly miraculous properties, DMSO has been dubbed alternately a panacea and a snake oil. The drug has also attracted a considerable cult following, enormous journalistic attention and highly profitable sales for unapproved uses.

title: SYRIANS BLOCK ROADS TO BEIRUT
description: Syria reacted to the signing of the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal accord here today by blocking roads linking Beirut with the rest of the Arab world, security officials and travelers said.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,815,000 for the quarter and $24,582,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,513,000 for the quarter and $3,207,000 for the 9 months.

title: HAMILTON BROTHERS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results include a pretax gain of $8.1 million from the sale of assets.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MARCOS TO RELAX SECRET '81 DECREE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he planned to relax a 1981 decree imposing the death penalty for a wide range of offenses, including organizing anti-Government demonstrations.

title: Officer Shot in Subway At Lexington and 59th
description: A transit police officer was shot with his own gun yesterday evening in a fight on a platform of the subway station at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue with a man who had been smoking on a train, authorities said.

title: HERCULES IN LINK WITH MONTEDISON
description: Montedison, an Italian chemical company that is one of the world's largest, and Hercules Inc., a major American chemical company, announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement for a joint venture that would combine the bulk of their plastic resins businesses.

title: HOLMES, NOW 33, PLANS TO KEEP PUNCHING
description: Diane Holmes celebrated her birthday the other day and her husband, the heavyweight champion, laughed and asked, ''How does it feel to be 30?''

title: DMG INC. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $57,000.

title: 1,300 Florida Seniors Are Denied Diplomas
description: Florida announced today that it would deny diplomas to 1,300 high school seniors who failed a functional literacy test. A judge refused to interfere with the state's decision, and his ruling was appealed.

title: China Loan for Oilfield
description: An oil, gas and chemicals base in China's large Zhongyuan oilfield will be developed with the help of a $108 million loan from the World Bank, according to the Economic Information Journal. The loan, for 20 years with a 5-year grace period and interest at 10.97 percent, will be used largely to import equipment and technology, it said.

title: Pacific Power
description: The Pacific Power and Light Company announced it will take an $81 million write-down in the second quarter, equivalent to about $1.50 a share, on its investments in three nuclear power plants that have caused problems. Despite this, the Portland, Ore., company said earnings would be high enough to cover the $2.16 a share annual dividend.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I live in a state of some confusion when I read various recipes and they refer to grated foods. To choose but one example, I have a recipe that calls for one cup of grated walnuts. Does this mean one cup of whole walnuts, grated? Or does it mean one cup of nuts that have already been grated?

title: AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $537,754 for the quarter and $955,010 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $945,700 for the quarter and $1,195,800 for the 9 months.

title: GREECE ASKS BALKAN ARMS PARLEY
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece has called on the leaders of the other Balkan nations to participate in talks leading to a Balkan zone free of nuclear arms.

title: FIRST SINCE 1981
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. reported today that it returned to profitability in the first quarter; it was the troubled Canadian energy company's first profit since the fourth quarter of 1981.
