title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $79,263 for the quarter and $42,659 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $853,297 from discontinued operations.

title: EXETER OIL CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,330,000 from change in accounting principle.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CARHART PHOTO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: It's Nice to Be Able to Ask What Can Ever Go Wrong
description: A rich man can afford to worry about unlikely contingencies - a nuclear war, for example, or a repetition of the 1929 stock market crash. A poor man has more immediate pressing problems. And it is the same at the bridge table - a rich declarer who seems to have plenty of assets for the purposes of making his contract can afford to ask himself: What can go wrong?

title: Polaroid Recorder
description: The Polaroid Corporation will begin shipments later this year of a desktop computer image recorder, for use with personal and small business computers. Called Palette and priced around $1,300, the new system can produce 35-millimeter color slides, 3 1/4-by-4 1/4-inch instant Polaroid color prints and colored copies from monochrome display computers.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: APRIL STARTS IN HOUSING OFF BY 8%
description: The pace of the nation's housing recovery slowed a bit more in April with new housing starts falling 8 percent from the March level, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.49 million units, the Government reported today.

title: ALA MOANA HAWAII PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1.2 million on the sale of property.

title: 1883: APPETITES AND FARE WERE ROBUST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- By Meryle Evans Meryle Evans, a social historian, is coordinating producer of Channel 13's ''My New York: Walt Whitman and Friends.''

title: Austrian Chancellor Resigns; His Deputy to Form Coalition
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky formally stepped down today in favor of his deputy, Fred Sinowatz. Mr. Kreisky announced he would resign as Chancellor after the Socialists lost their majority in Parliament on April 24.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: EX-AIDE SEEMED 'OVERQUALIFIED'
description: When he was hired by the Brentwood Union Free School District last December, Robert O. Wickes underwent the standard screening for potential, non-teaching employees in the district and was an ''excellent candidate for the job,'' a spokesman for the district said yesterday.

title: Topics; Benchmarks; Chief Justice Traynor
description: It was aptly said that Roger Traynor was one of the finest jurists who never sat on the United States Supreme Court. His 30 years on California's highest court proved that Washington is not the only place to influence American law.

title: Upper Volta Announces A Government Purge
description: President Jean-Baptiste Ouedraogo of Upper Volta announced a Government purge today, and Agence France-Presse said tanks surrounded the home of Prime Minister Thomas Sankara.

title: Chad Reports Heavy Fighting With Ex-President's Forces
description: Chad military sources today reported heavy fighting around the strategic northern town of Faya-Largeau but said Government troops controlled the area.

title: HOW JAPAN GUIDES INDUSTRIES
description: The rapid strides made by Japan in computers and semiconductors are generally viewed as the best recent examples of the payoff from the Japanese brand of industrial policy. The Japanese approach emphasizes cooperation between business and Government. While the teamwork that characterizes Japanese industrial policy has accomplished much in the rising high-technology field, perhaps its biggest achievement has been in maintaining an unemployment rate of less than 3 percent, the lowest of any major developed country.

title: SENATE UNANIMOUSLY BACKS RUCKELSHAUS AS E.P.A. CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate today unanimously confirmed William D. Ruckelshaus as head of the Environmental Protection Agency with a charge to restore public confidence in the agency.

title: ADVERTISING
description: The Paddington Corporation, best known for its J.& B. Scotch and Bailey's Original Irish Cream Liqueur, announced yesterday that it would enter the ''white goods'' arena (that's where gin and vodka are) with a product called Malibu (which is neither). Made of rum, neutral grain spirits, coconut and other flavors, it is 56 proof; to be called rum it must be 80 proof.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Tosco Officials Shifted
description: The Tosco Corporation said today that its president and chief executive officer, Morton M. Winston, had relinquished those posts to take the title of chairman and consultant to the company's directors.

title: ISLANDERS SWEEP TO FOURTH STANLEY CUP IN ROW
description: Quickly and efficiently, the Islanders swept to their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Edmonton Oilers and moved into the National Hockey League record book next to the Montreal Canadiens.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Anglo Group Promotion
description: Graham Boustred is to take over the chairmanship of the Anglo American Industrial Corporation, Gavin Relly, the current chairman, announced today. Mr. Boustred is an executive director of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. and chairman of the Anglo American Coal Corporation and the Highveld Steel and Vanadium Corporation. Mr. Relly, who is also chairman of the Anglo American Corporation, said he wanted to free himself for other positions in the group.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES NORTHWEST INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
RUSSIANS WILL TALK ON GRAIN
description: The Soviet Union, after hesitating more than a month, has accepted President Reagan's offer to negotiate a new longterm grain purchase agreement, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: COOKERY, SEEN BY SAUL BELLOW
description: CHICAGO THE Nobel laureate for literature in 1976, winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 1975 and the holder of three National Book Awards, Saul Bellow recently elaborated not on the state of the novel or the role of the writer in society but on his interest in eating and cooking and his penchant for scrubbing pots and kitchen sinks until they are free of grease. ''Never, never use steel wool,'' he warned. ''It leaves little threads of steel in the pots.''

title: SPACE WEAPONS: ANDROPOV AND THE AMERICAN PETITIONERS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
MISSILES A MAJOR ISSUE IN BRITISH VOTE
description: Every day, thousands of members of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament knock on doors in all parts of Britain, urging voters to support candidates in the June 9 general election who are committed to immediate British nuclear disarmament.

title: SERVICE FRACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
San Francisco Board Backs Antismoking Plan
description: The Board of Supervisors has approved a tough antismoking ordinance, which bans cigarette smoking in many workplaces and authorizes fines of up to $500 a day for employers if they fail to comply.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an investment gain of $1,000 and a gain of $208,000 on the sale of an investee. c-Net loss.

title: BMW Car Plant
description: Contracts covering land purchase for the planned Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. car plant here have been signed, according to the Regensburg City Council. The company, known as BMW, plans to invest about $488 million to $546 million over 10 years in the Regensburg plant, which will eventually provide 3,500 jobs. Production at the plant is expected to begin in the fall of 1986, the company said.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
KENNAN CRITICIAL OF U.S. POLICY
description: In a rare public appearance, former Ambassador George F. Kennan said today that Soviet-American relations were in a ''dreadful and dangerous'' state that had ''unfailing characteristics of a march toward war.''

title: KENYA'S PRESIDENT CALLS EARLY ELECTIONS
description: President Daniel arap Moi, who has accused an unidentified Cabinet minister of plotting against him with the aid of a foreign country, called today for a general election in September.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
7 STORIES BY NADINE GORDIMER
description: THE opening today at the Film Forum of ''The Gordimer Stories,'' the collective title for a series of seven short films based on stories by South Africa's Nadine Gordimer, is something more of a literary event than an occasion of cinema. This is not to underrate the imagination of the films, which, based on the two that I've seen, is first-rate, but to emphasize that what is being served in this program is a quality of mind that is most completely and gracefully revealed in Miss Gordimer's prose.

title: Ground Is Broken For New Rail Yard
description: Ground was broken yesterday for an $11 million rail yard in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. The ceremony at the 33-acre complex was attended by Mayor Koch, Borough President Howard Golden and other officials.

title:
DISCOVERIES;
1. Keeping the Sun Off
description: A combination sun visor and scarf is a becoming item to protect the eyes from the glare of the sun at the beach, on the tennis court, on the golfing green and even on a city street. The visor comes in lilac, blue or smoky gray, the scarf in a wide range of solid colors, stripes and prints. The Sunbandana, as it is called, is $10 on the balcony at Bloomingdale's.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $765,896 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Gretzky Finds Value in Loss
description: After being limited to no goals and four assists in the Stanley Cup final series, Wayne Gretzky nevertheless tried to make the best of the experience tonight.

title: Nurses Plus
description: Nurse practitioners are nurses with additional education that qualifies them to perform routine diagnoses and treatments. Working in collaboration with doctors, they are capable of taking over large areas of everyday medicine.

title: EVERGOOD PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A GERMAN MAGAZINE NAMES 4 AS SOVIET SPIES
description: A West German magazine quoted Western intelligence agents today as having identified four Soviet diplomats here as spies who were ''high security risks.''

title: INVERNESS PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: AUCTION PRICE OF A CASSATT IS $1.1 MILLION
description: Mary Cassatt's ''Reading le Figaro,'' an 1883 portrait of her mother, sold for $1.1 million last night at Christie's to a buyer who was not identified, the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist.

title: Roberts & Porter
description: Roberts & Porter Inc. of Des Plaines, Ill., which on Monday reported a loss of $1.6 million for the first quarter, said it had filed a petition to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. The company, which manufactures printing inks, chemicals and graphics arts supplies and equipment, said outstanding debt totaled about $34 million, and its unencumbered assets totaled about $34.6 million.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GOODE IS NOMINATED IN PHILADELPHIA VOTE, TURNING BACK RIZZO
description: W.Wilson Goode, a sharecropper's son, defeated former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo in a primary race last night, becoming the first black mayoral nominee of the city's dominant Democratic Party.

title: Texas Airport Bonds Will Pay 6.75% and Up
description: A $76.3 million revenue refunding bond for the San Antonio airport was priced at par yesterday. Proceeds will be used to pay off a maturing bond issue and to finance additional construction.

title: JUDGE WILL HOLD CONTEMPT TRIAL ON THE WESTWAY
description: A Federal judge decided yesterday to hold a contempt-of-court trial to determine if Government agencies had violated his orders to study how the Westway project would affect fish in the Hudson River.

title: Advertising; Interpublic To Acquire Dailey
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies, a holding company of advertising agencies and the largest of its kind, is to acquire Dailey & Associates, the Los Angeles agency closely identified with the election victories of President Reagan and President Nixon.

title: RIPLEY, SMITHSONIAN HEAD, TO RETIRE
description: S. Dillon Ripley, who has headed the Smithsonian Institution during a nearly 20-year period of growth in which it has become one of the pre-eminent cultural organizations in the world, announced today that he would retire next year.

title: REAGAN STRESSES TOTAL OPPOSITION TO RAISING TAXES
description: President Reagan, vowing to ''draw the line'' against Congressional pressure, said tonight he would veto any new tax legislation while the national economy was moving into a recovery.

title: DR. MARTHA PATE, EX-COLLEGE HEAD
description: Dr. Martha B. Lucas Pate, a former president of Sweet Briar College, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 70 years old and lived in West Redding, Conn.

title: BLIZZARD STARTLES MOUNTAIN STATES
description: A spring blizzard swept across parts of Wyoming and Colorado today, temporarily knocking out electrical power to thousands of homes and dumping up to a foot of snow in some areas.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: RECIPES FOR ECONOMIC CONFERENCE IN WILLIAMSBURG
description: Chicken and Sausage Gumbo 1 chicken, 2 1/2 pounds, cut into serving pieces Salt to taste if desired 1 teaspoon finely ground black pepper 1 1/4 teaspoons finely ground white pepper 1 teaspoon powdered mustard 1 1/2 teaspoons cayenne pepper 1 1/2 teaspoons paprika 1 teaspoon granulated garlic 1 teaspoon file powder, optional 1 1/2 cups flour 2 1/2 cups corn, peanut or vegetable oil 3/4 cup finely chopped onion 3/4 cup finely chopped celery 3/4 cup finely chopped green pepper 9 cups rich chicken broth 1 3/4 cups chopped or thinly sliced smoked sausage such as kielbasa (see note) 1 bay leaf 1 teaspoon finely minced fresh garlic 2 cups cooked rice.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Summer Project
description: Frank Layden, the coach and general manager of the Utah Jazz, has a special summer project. He and his staff have designed a six-day-aweek program that includes weight training, running and fundamental basketball skills for Mark Eaton, a center who averaged 4.3 points and 5.7 rebounds as a rookie this season.

title: AMERICAN PACESETTER reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Betty Chamberlain, 75; Started Artists'; Center
description: Betty Chamberlain, the founder and director of the Art Information Center, died of a stroke Saturday in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 75 years old.

title: Mel Wright, 55, Was Pitcher And Coach in Major Leagues
description: Mel Wright, who spent 32 years in professional baseball and was the Montreal Expos' bullpen coach this year, died in Houston's Methodist Hospital Monday night. He was 55 years old.

title: Economic Scene; Debtor-Nation Rescue Costs
description: AFTER frenzied negotiations to put together multibillion-dollar rescue packages last year, officials at international lending institutions and commercial banks are beginning to see the results. These programs are intended to ease the huge debt burdens borne by Mexico, Brazil and Argentina, which together hold one-third of the developing world's $600 billion public and private debt.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income.

title: Election Delays E.E.C. Meeting
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany announced today that the next semiannual meeting of leaders of European Economic Community countries, scheduled for Stuttgart June 6-7, was being put off to June 17-19 because of the British elections on June 9.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nominee Under Fire

title: GULF ARABS TRYING TO END WAR AND OIL SPILL
description: Two Persian Gulf officials said to be carrying a peace plan arrived in Iraq tonight from Iran in an effort to persuade the warring countries to cap Iranian oil wells polluting the Persian Gulf.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EDUCATOR AND A LABOR CONSULTANT
description: Marion Dickerman, an educator and labor consultant and a longtime friend and associate of Eleanor Roosevelt, died Monday at Crosslands, a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 93 years old and had lived in New Canaan, Conn., until moving to Crosslands.

title: MOVIE: TRILOGY ON A LIFE
description: ''The Bill Douglas Trilogy'' was shown as part of the ''British Film Now'' series in 1980 at the Paramount Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby that appeared in The New York Times of Sept. 23, 1980. The film opened yesterday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: A Protest Over Fur
description: T he fur flew unexpectedly at the three-day Fur Expo, which ends today at the New York Statler Hotel. As some 50 protesters, animal lovers who deplore fur-wearing and fur-trapping, demonstrated outside the Statler Monday evening, 2 went inside, took over the microphone -after the Fur Expo fashion show and before the banquet - and made a statement.

title: CENTURY OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., said it had transferred its Prestolite automotive products division to the Automotive Group acquired in its merger with Bendix Corp.

title: ORNATE FOOD MOLDS
description: IN an era when simplicity in food preparation and presentation is the vogue, ornate food molds such as those pictured here may seem antiquated. Granted, they have roots centuries deep - ancient Greeks and Romans molded breads into religious icons - but they still have a place when you want to impart a sense of whimsy or elegance to meals. And with summer just around the bend, they are particularly suitable for cold buffets.

title: RULING ON CITY PANEL WORRIES OFFICIALS
description: New York City officials remained undecided yesterday over what to do about a ruling by a Federal appeals court that the makeup of the city's Board of Estimate must conform to the United States Constitution's principle of one man, one vote.

title: Acquisition by CBS
description: CBS Inc., whose magazine division already owns the five-year-old American Photographer, has acquired from Ziff-Davis ''certain assets, including the subscription list,'' of Camera Arts magazine, which was founded in 1981 and now has a circulation of 150,000, two-thirds of which is by subscription. After its final edition in July, Camera Arts will be combined with the older magazine in CBS Publications.

title: OUR COUNTRY'S ENDANGERED PUBLIC ESTATE
description: To the Editor: Steve H. Hanke calls attention to some serious political and economic problems which plague the management of federally owned commercial timberlands. As a long-time student of these issues, I should like to note that he has merely identified the tip of a sizable iceberg.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: Changing Faces
description: E ighteen feet long, 14 feet wide and 2 feet high, the white plywood sculpture is for people to sit on. It was originally called ''The Pope's Plateau'' and the sitting area was a portrait of Pope John Paul II.

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. to Sell Missiles to Japan
description: The Pentagon informed Congress today that it planned to sell 24 Harpoon antiship missiles to Japan for about $26 million. The missiles will be installed on three new destroyers now being built in Japan, the Pentagon said in a statement.

title: Computers in Medicine
description: Medical Market Communications, which already has a journal called Computers in Medical Practice, will come out in September with a six-a-year magazine called Computers in Medicine. The main difference between the two is that the former is a single-sponsor publication and the latter will be for all interested advertisers. The new publication will go free to 50,000 physicians in ''high prescribing'' specialties: office-based internists and family physicians no older that 45, and all cardiologists. Medical Market is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: Blast Tops Sockers
description: The Baltimore Blast defeated the San Diego Sockers, 4-3, at Civic Center tonight after shutout defeats in the first two games of the Major Indoor Soccer League championship series.
Interest rates declined slightly yesterday as bond prices traded in a narrow and choppy pattern. Dealers reported scant buying interest from investors.

title: A New Foundation
description: A merican Telephone and Telegraph Company made well over $60 million in a real-estate sale of several properties yesterday and will use the money to finance what will be one of the nation's largest corporate-sponsored philanthropies.

title: THOMAS A. HANSBURY
description: Thomas A. Hansbury, former executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Merrick Corporation of Roseland, N.J., maker of industrial weighing equipment, died of a stroke Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Rights Group Assails Chile
description: Amnesty International accused the Chilean police today of widespread torture of political prisoners, and called on the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet to set up a ''full, open and independent inquiry.'' The human rights group said Chile's secret police systematically torture political prisoners.

title: OLSON FARMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRAZILIAN BEAT

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 18, 1983; The Economy
description: The House voted overwhelmingly to repeal tax withholding from dividend and interest payments, despite the strong opposition of both President Reagan and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. The margin -382 to 41 - indicated there is sufficient support in the House to override any Reagan veto. The Senate has passed a separate bill that would postpone withholding but retain some tax enforcement provisions. The two measures will now go to conference. (Page A1.)

title: HIGHER BUDGET FORESEEN FOR ADVANCED MISSILES
description: The Defense Department's senior technical official, Richard D. DeLauer, said today that the Administration planned to spend far more in the next three years for President Reagan's advanced missile defense than officials had previously indicated.

title: 360 COURT OFFICERS MAY LOSE JOBS OVER TEST SCORES
description: About 360 court officers who handle security and clerical duties in New York City face dismissal because of their performance on a Civil Service examination given last year, court officials said yesterday.

title: Careers; Lawyers In Pursuit Of Jobs
description: ARE there too many lawyers? The official publication of the American Bar Association estimates the number of lawyers in the United States at 600,000. And every year more than 30,000 new ones graduate from law school, pass the bar exams and want work.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: b-Net income.

title: ISRAEL AND LEBANON SIGN AGREEMENT AT 2 CEREMONIES
description: Israel and Lebanon signed a security agreement today that is intended to lead to the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and continuing Israeli involvement in policing the country's southern region.

title: ISRAEL AND THE U.S. SIGN AN AGREEMENT ON LEBANON RAIDS
description: The United States signed a confidential agreement with Israel today recognizing that despite the accord with Lebanon Israel had the right of self-defense to retaliate against attacks by ''terrorists'' in Lebanon.

title: Helen M. Whitman, 68, Dead; A Designer of Herb Gardens
description: Helen M. Whitman, a grower and designer of herb gardens, died Saturday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 68 years old and lived in Salem Center, N.Y.

title: A Judgment Call
description: Hank Peters, the general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, filed a complaint with the American League office against an umpire, Ken Kaiser, suggesting that Kaiser's judgment had been clouded because of a feud with Baltimore's first baseman, Eddie Murray. ''It appears a personality conflict has developed, which causes me to question how objective a person can be,'' said Peters, who lodged the complaint after a couple of disputed calls by Kaiser during Sunday's Orioles-Rangers game in Baltimore.

title: FLAWED U.S. APPROACH IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PANEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $430,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. The charge was for administrative expenses related to bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Paul J. Barnes, 64, an Actor; 'Man of a Thousand Voices'
description: Paul J. Barnes, an actor known as ''the man of a thousand voices,'' died Monday afternoon in Sherman Hospital here. He was 64 years old.

title: Aleksander Hertz, Author, 87; Studied Sociology of Theater
description: Aleksander Hertz, a sociologist in Poland before World War II and the author of books and many articles after his arrival in the United States in 1940, died Monday in Boulevard Hospital in Queens after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived in Queens.

title: 6th Suspect Seized In Rape in Queens
description: A sixth suspect was arrested yesterday in the abduction and rape last Wednesday of a 17-year-old girl in Queens Village. The police said the suspect, Wilson Gayton, 19, surrendered to detectives at the 112th Precinct. Mr. Gayton lives at 141-28 181st Street in Springfield Gardens, Queens.

title: INTELLIGENCE UNITS IN CONGRESS AT ODDS ON COVERT LATIN AID
description: The House and Senate intelligence committees are in sharp conflict over Congress's role in curbing covert aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, members of both committeees indicated today.

title: DYNAMIC HOMES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BIOCHEM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $175,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.6 million and a tax credit of $4.8 million. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $600,000 and a tax credit of $2.7 million.

title: The Budget Paralysis
description: A budget sets priorities and ratifies hard choices. When budgetwriting fails, politics fails, and the Senate's current paralysis amounts to a doubly dangerous failure.

title: POPE MAY MEET WALESA ON HIS TRIP TO POLAND
description: The Vatican made public the official schedule today for Pope John Paul II's trip to Poland next month, and Vatican sources said the Pope might meet with Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity union, which is now banned.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income The year-ago figures were restated.

title: BOMAINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $181,000. c-Net loss.

title: KANSANS PROTEST BROADCASTS OF HATE
description: Nellie Babbs, a blunt-speaking woman, and her husband, Charlie, believe they are God's watchmen, keepers of a ''trumpet of warning'' that was given them to sound when they see ''the enemy coming.''

title: TO CUT THE DEFICIT
description: The following is adapted from a message from six founding members of the Bipartisan Budget Appeal to the Senate, which is debating budget resolutions. The six are W. Michael Blumenthal, John B. Connally, C. Douglas Dillon, Henry H. Fowler and William E. Simon, all former Treasury Secretaries, and Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce.

title: Suzuki Reports Rise of 20.5%
description: The Suzuki Motor Company, citing a sharply reduced corporate tax load, said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 20.5 percent despite a 1.7 percent sales decline.

title: WHAT DRIVES UP THE COST OF NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: To the Editor: In his April 29 Op-Ed article, Herbert J.C. Kouts blames the breathtaking rise in the cost of constructing nuclear power plants on ''delays caused by activists and confusion in regulation.'' He cites the Shoreham nuclear plant, which, after $3 billion, is still a long way from producing a kilowatt-hour.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 27.
Spanish Bankruptcy
description: The Banco de los Pirineos, in temporary receivership since 1981, filed for bankruptcy before a Barcelona court, legal sources said today.

title: British Output Declines
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted output in all industries fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in March from February, according to provisional data released today by the Central Statistical Office. The drop in output in all industries compares with a 1 percent rise in February.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
21 Are Charged With Fraud
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted 21 people believed to have been involved in what the Government labeled one of the largest investment swindles in the nation's history.

title: Seth A. Hubbard, 80, Is Dead; Suffolk Planning Board Chief
description: Seth A. Hubbard, chairman of the Suffolk County Planning Commission, died Monday at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Riverhead.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Arizona Hospital Issue Priced at Par
description: A $62.7 million bond issue of the Maricopa Industrial Development Authority of Arizona for the Scottsdale Memorial Hopsital was priced yesterday at par by E.F. Hutton & Company Inc.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DESPITE my often-stated preference for pork in almost any form, the cut of meat that I consider the best for a serious meal is rack of lamb. And, indeed, it is one of the easiest foods to prepare.

title: Boat People, Launched
description: Stand next to Marjorie Russell, a sewing teacher in Portland, Ore., and you see one reason for the Senate to pass the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration bill today. She teaches in the old brick Neighborhood House, where refugees from Hitler once learned English and table tennis. Now it's a center for Indochinese refugees, where shy Laotian and Hmong women bend over sewing machines, spinning out knee pads for loggers.

title: POLYCAST TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
3 ASTHMA INHALERS TAKEN OFF SHELVES
description: The two manufacturers of an inhaler drug for asthmatics have agreed to withdraw it from nonprescription sale in the wake of complaints from medical experts that the drug might result in death if used excessively.

title: JERSEY SENTENCES FIRST PERSON TO DEATH IN 12 YEARS
description: A 44-year-old twice-convicted murderer today became the the first person in New Jersey in 12 years to be sentenced to death.

title: CAN FIXED RATES STAGE COMEBACK?
description: It was billed as a ''Pre-Williamsburg Monetary Conference,'' but the eyes of most of the participants were on a different town, Bretton Woods, N.H., where in 1944 the postwar monetary system was born.

title: Nurses End Strike At S.I. Hospital
description: Nurses returned to work at Staten Island Hospital yesterday with a new three-year contract, ending a two-week walkout.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS RESUME TALKS ON MEDIUM-RANGE NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed negotiations today, after a seven-week recess, on a reduction of intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 23.
description: Year-ago results reflect a gain of $141,700 from the redemption of $499,000 of the company's subordinated debentures at a discount of approximately 30 percent.

title: Canadair Chief Resigns
description: Frederick R. Kearns has resigned as president and chief executive of Canadair Ltd. after a career that began in 1949 at the nowtroubled Canadian plane manufacturer.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SPAR AEROSPACE PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SMITH GETS THE LAST WORD
description: Billy Smith finally got rewarded tonight for what he does best - defending the Islanders' goal from the toughest challenges that National Hockey League teams can throw at him. The Islanders' goaltender won the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player of the 1983 Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Sent Rick Mahler, p itcher, to Richmond farm club and re- c alled Donnie Moore, relief pitcher, from R ichmond. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Ewing Kauff- m an, owner, sold 49 percent of team to A vron Fogelman, Memphis real estate d eveloper, with option to buy the remain- i ng 51 percent. METS (NL) - Activated Bob Bailor, in- f ielder, and optioned Wally Backman, in- f ielder, to Tidewater. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Activated Gary T empleton, shortstop, and optioned Floyd C hiffer, pitcher, to Las Vegas. SEATTLE (AL) - Called up Ricky Nel- s on, outfielder, from Salt Lake City; d esignated for assignment Rod Allen of S alt Lake City; optioned Jim Maler, first b aseman, to Salt Lake City. YANKEES (AL) - Placed Butch Wyne- g ar, catcher on 15-day disabled list and c alled up Juan Epino, catcher, from Co- l umbus.

title: U.S. Is Disappointed Over Argentine Report
description: The State Department expressed disappointment today that Argentina had failed to issue a complete account of the fate of the thousands of people who disappeared in the 1970's.

title: One Killed in Beirut Protest
description: One person died and 10 others were wounded in a clash between Lebanese Army troops and Shiite Moslems protesting the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal accord, official sources said.

title: POP: A SINGER AND ACTRESS, MISS GUEVARA
description: NACHA GUEVARA, the Argentine singer who first appeared in New York four years ago, presents herself in the early stages of her performance at the Top of the Gate, where she opened Sunday night, as a polished and versatile satirist, singing songs whose humor ranges from sly to black.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: European Talks Delayed
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that a meeting of the Common Market planned in Stuttgart for June 6 and 7 had been postponed until after the British elections on June 9. He said it would now be held June 17 to 19. Speaking to reporters after talks with President Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Kohl said he had made the decision after consulting with other Western European leaders.

title: Inquiry on Complaint
description: The affirmative-action office at Washington State plans to investigate a complaint that school officials weakened the role of women in college athletics by hiring a man, Harold Rhodes, to coach the women's basketball team. The complaint was made by Patti Gora, chairman of the college's commission on the status of women, who said that Sam Jankovich, the athletic director, had ''engineered'' the hiring of Rhodes through an unrepresentative search committee. Jankovich denied the charge.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Pogo Shares Tendered
description: The Pogo Producing Company, the embattled Houston-based energy company, said that 4.5 million shares of its own stock had been tendered to it by the offer's May 11 deadline.

title: SOVIET SAID TO PUT GARRISON IN AN AFGHAN CITY
description: Western diplomats said today that, for the first time since the Soviet Union intervened in Afghanistan at the end of 1979, a Soviet garrison had been established in northwest Afghanistan near the Iranian border.

title: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Oppenheimer Chooses Top Official of New Unit
description: Oppenheimer & Company, the investment firm, has set up a new subsidiary to expand its leveraged-buyout activities and has chosen a corporate executive, rather than a Wall Street man, to head it.

title: First Award by Fund To Fight Corruption
description: W hen Mario Montuoro, a Bronx construction worker forced from his job as a union official, won $2.5 million in the New York State Lottery last year, he vowed to use part of the money to assist unionists fighting corruption.

title: Bach to Coach Warriors
description: John Bach, a longtime college coach who spent the last four years as an assistant with the Golden State Warriors, was named yesterday the National Basketball Association club's head coach. He replaces Al Attles, who retired at the end of the season to become general manager.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The results for the third quarter include nonrecurring gains from the sale of property and the favorable settlement of a patent infringement suit and the quarters results also include costs associated with the move of a division from California to Connecticut.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt A PRIVATE VIEW. By Irene Mayer Selz- nick. 284 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Roll-Call Vote in House
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 382 to 41 by which the House of Representatives voted today to repeal the withholding of income taxes from dividends and interest payments. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for repeal. Voting ''yes'' were 225 Democrats and 157 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 32 Democrats and 9 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Er@dreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, xxx; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, no.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Katherine Zoric, 32 years old, of 2021 Woodbine Street in Ridgewood, Queens, was gardening in her backyard when she was shot with a pellet gun shortly after noon yesterday. Stephen Schoeffow, 15, of nearby 20-22 Palmetto Street, was arrested and charged with assault, reckless endangerment and possession of a weapon. Mrs. Zoric was treated at Wyckoff Hospital, where she was listed in good condition. ... A gypsy cab driven by Theodore Gardner, 58, struck and killed two pedestrians at White Plains Road near East Tremont Street in the Bronx shortly before midnight Monday.

title: 'SCTV' MOVES TO CABLE
description: ''SCTV Network,'' the Emmy-award-winning comedy series that NBC dropped from its late-night schedule last month, has been picked up by Home Box Office.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CARMA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MICHAEL B. RUSKIN
description: Michael B. Ruskin, an owner of the Chinese Chance restaurant at 1 University Place in Greenwich Village, died in his sleep Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
FAFCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Commission Is Named On Australia's Security
description: The Government appointed a commission today to inquire into the security services after the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat on charges of spying.

title: CURIOSITY LEADS TO A RECORD
description: On a bright spring day in 1977, a 19-year-old baseball player had finished practice and was walking across a field at Palomar Community College in San Marcos, north of San Diego, when he saw a javelin flying.

title: Eastern's Lenders Back Finance Plan
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. announced that at a meeting yesterday its key lenders agreed to a financial recovery plan calling for Eastern employees to grant about $200 million in wage and productivity concessions.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AFTER climbing out of the wreckage of his first marriage, a man we know rented an apartment in a large and impersonal building on West 96th Street. He was known to the staff as 9D. In the laundry room one night, 9D saw a woman smiling at him. He smiled back, then began furiously mating his socks, stalling for time until he could come up with a snappy conversational opener. By the time he came up with one the woman was gone.

title: Ohio Agency Yield Is 5.75% to 9.75%
description: A tentative price was set yesterday for $109 million of Ohio Building Authority refunding revenue bonds by the underwriter, the First Boston Corporation.

title: Van Der Zee Memorial Is Set
description: A memorial service for the photographer James Van Der Zee will be conducted tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Mr Van Der Zee, who photographed Harlem residents for more than half a century, died Sunday at the age of 96.

title: THEATER: 'EGYPTOLOGY' BY RICHARD FOREMAN
description: ENTERING the Public Theater's Other Stage to see Richard Foreman's ''Egyptology (My Head Was a Sledgehammer),'' you may think you've wandered into an old-fashioned tunnel-of-horrors ride in a 1950's amusement park.

title: DOME CANADA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
American Symphony Plans Nine Concerts
description: The American Symphony Orchestra's 1983-4 season at Carnegie Hall will extend from Oct. 16 to May 6, with all nine concerts on Sunday afternoons.

title: ALIEN BILL'S AMNESTY PLAN SURVIVES SENATE TEST
description: The Senate, moving toward a final vote on a comprehensive immigration bill, today rejected a proposal to strip the bill of provisions granting legal status to several million illegal aliens.

title: MANVILLE AND CREDITORS HEAD TOWARD NEW PLAN
description: After nine months of negotiations, the Manville Corporation and its creditors are moving toward agreement on a reorganization plan that differs substantially from the proposal Manville outlined in court last week.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of Vladimir Horowitz's recital Sunday evening, printed in some late editions Monday and reprinted in all copies yesterday, incorrectly described his inclusion of Schumann's ''Carnaval'' in his public programs. He incorporated it only recently.

title: 5,000 U.S. Troops Scheduled For War Games in Caribbean
description: Nearly 5,000 United States troops along with cargo planes and jet fighters will take part in two-week military exercises in the Caribbean starting May 31, the Pentagon announced today.

title: LAST HOSTAGE RECOUNTS THE VIOLENT END OF SIEGE AT L.I. SCHOOL
description: The last hostage held by a former teacher's aide in a junior high school classroom here Monday said today that he and the man sang Army songs and talked quietly about war movies, hockey and their grandmothers. Then the gunman lifted his .22-caliber rifle to his head and shot himself.

title: Guilty Plea In Tax Fraud
description: The former president of a defunct company that sold solar panels has pleaded guilty to fraud charges. Ronald Farnsworth, former head of Major Dynamics Inc., pleaded guilty Monday in United States District Court to charges of conspiracy to defraud the Government and of aiding and abetting the preparation and filing of a false income tax return.

title: CONSULTANT TO LEAD BALDWIN
description: Victor H. Palmieri, who played a key role in bringing Penn Central back from bankruptcy, was named president and chief executive officer yesterday of another troubled company, the Baldwin-United Corporation.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Brock Hotel Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $25 million of subordinated debentures, to be offered through Offerman & Co.

title: The U.N. Today; May 18, 1983; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REAGAN'S LATINS
description: The Reagan Administration now says it will support dialogue and negotiations in Central America. Assurances to that effect are being given to the Congress and Richard Stone has been appointed negotiator. One can hope this reflects a basic change of course rather than a tactical shift to assuage Congressional concern. So far, however, the signs are not encouraaging. Certainly, there was nothing in the President's speech before the joint session of Congress on April 27 to suggest he intends to call off the ''secret'' war against Nicaragua and negotiate seriously with the Sandinist Government.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In another draft debacle for the Baltimore Colts, George Achica, a middle guard from Southern Calfifornia who had been the club's thirdround draft choice, signed with the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League. ... The Internal Revenue Service has filed a $70,000 lien against Darryl Dawkins, charging that the Net center owes the Government that much in unpaid taxes for 1981 and accrued interest and penalties. ... The co-owners of the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., Ralph A. Miller 3d and Raymond C. Daikler, filed suit Monday against Terry Bradshaw and his agents, charging that the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback pulled out of a lead role in a production of the musical ''Damn Yankees'' from April 19 to May 15. . . . Saying he was tired of hearing people ask him about his contract status, Kent Hrbek, runner-up as American League rookie of the year last year, signed with the Minnesota Twins for 1983.

title: BTR Increases Bid for Tilling
description: BTR raised its bid today for Thomas Tilling to 11 BTR shares for 20 Tilling shares, or the equivalent of about $3.38 cash a share, from 10 BTR shares for 21 Tilling shares, or the equivalent of about $2.78 cash a share.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALL-AMERICAN MENUS FOR THE ECONOMIC SUMMIT
description: THE economic summit meeting scheduled for Memorial Day weekend in Williamsburg, Va., will be, among other things, a remarkable occasion for American cooking. The representatives of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, West Germany and the United States who attend will be served special menus, comprising dishes made from American ingredients and American inspiration.

title: GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STV ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes federal income tax benefit from carry-forward losses of $111,000 for the quarter and $243,000 for the six months.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert J. Carlson was named president of the United Technologies Corporation yesterday after his major competitor dropped out of the running.

title: Denver Mayor Loses To Ex-State Legislator
description: Mayor William H. McNichols Jr. lost today's mayoral vote to Frederic Pena, 36 years old, a former state legislator. Mr. McNichols, who is 73, conceded defeat barely two hours after the polls closed, with about 43 percent of the precincts reporting. Frederico Pena, 36, a former state legislator, had 42 percent of the vote, and Dale Tooley, 49, a former district attorney who had lost twice before to Mr. McNichols, had 29 percent. Mr. McNichols was running third, with 18 percent of the vote.

title: THE ANNUAL PARTY
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. T he New York Islanders staged a party Tuesday night that showed why they are the best sports team in North America, why they have won four straight Stanley Cups.

title: FORTHCOMING TOURS OF HOMES IN REGION
description: Listed below are some forthcoming tours of homes, apartments and offices in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Connecticut and on Long Island. All tours are open to the public, and proceeds will benefit charities and civic groups.

title: ALBANY LEGISLATORS AGREE TO DELAY BOTTLE LAW UNTIL SEPTEMBER
description: Negotiators in the Legislature have agreed in principle to delay the imposition of a nickel deposit on beer and soft-drink containers sold in New York State.

title: DEFENDANT IN CBS KILLINGS IS DESCRIBED AS 'AMORAL'
description: Describing Donald Nash as an ''amoral automaton'' who was responsible for the murders of five people, a prosecutor yesterday asked a jury in Manhattan to bring back a ''cold, hard'' verdict of guilty against Mr. Nash.

description: b-Net loss. c-Including a tax credit of $239,998.

title: RECITAL: FRANK, BY SAMUEL MARDER
description: born violinist, was not always a compelling player at his recital in Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon. But if his interpretations lacked grandeur and expanse, they were also clearly the work of an accomplished technician and an intelligent musician.

title: BILL TO AID UTILITY GAINS IN WASHINGTON STATE
description: A compromise bill that would allow the Washington Public Power Supply System to insulate each of its nuclear power projects from the financial woes of the others was approved by the Senate Energy Committee today and sent to the Senate floor.

title: Florida Test of Seniors On Literacy Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld Florida's functional literacy test, allowing the state to withhold diplomas from about 1,300 seniors who failed the examination.

title: ALEM PARAIBA, Brazil
description: CANDINHA SILVEIRA had three things in mind when she and her husband, Joaquim, set out to buy their country place. ''I wanted an old house,'' she said, ''I wanted it on a hill and I wanted a waterfall nearby.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The first duty of a sovereign nation is to control its borders, and we don't.'' - Senator Alan K. Simpson, sponsor of immigration bill. (A1:6.)

title: Venezuela Cuts Oil Goal
description: Venezuela has reduced its 1988 production target in the Orinoco basin, a source of very heavy crude oil, to 135,000 barrels a day, from 240,000, Nelson Vasquez, a director of Petroleos de Venezuela, said today. Mr. Vasquez told a congressional hearing that the $5 billion Cerro Negro project in the Orinoco basin, designed to produce 125,000 barrels a day of synthetic crude by 1988, had been scaled down to 35,000 barrels. But a Petroven subsidiary is to continue with plans to produce 100,000 barrels a day of blended crude.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PLYWOOD is a useful and versatile building material that is extremely popular for cabinets and furniture. However, it does have one drawback: The exposed end grain is very difficult to paint or finish properly.

description: To the Editor:

title: Volcker Calm On Currency
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he is not convinced that the American dollar is too strong in relation to other major currencies. But he is not willing, he added, to ''make that statement too forcefully.''

title: Mount St. Helens Area Becomes a Monument
description: Officials today declared 110,000 acres of the slopes and surrounding area of Mount St. Helens a national monument. The declaration came on the third anniversary of the volcanic eruption that reshaped the peak and killed 59 people.

title: CREDITORS SAID TO BALK AT BRANIFF PLAN
description: Braniff International's secured creditors decided at a meeting on Monday to reject the latest offer made by Hyatt International to put some of Braniff's planes back into service, but the creditors left the door open for future discussion with Hyatt, a lawyer who was at the meeting said yesterday.

title: UNITED STATES PLAYING CARD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Comparable year-ago results were not provided. The company acquired its playing card business in the second quarter of 1982.

title: NAVY TRAINS TO BATTLE SOVIET SUBMARINES IN ARCTIC
description: Adm. James D. Watkins, the Chief of Naval Operations, disclosed today that United States submarines had begun extensive training under the Arctic ice to be ready in wartime to attack Soviet submarines armed with ballistic missiles that have increased operations there.

title: A POLITICAL ACTION COMMITTEE AT 35
description: The National Committee for an Effective Congress marks its 35th anniversary this week the same way it began: by tilting at what it considers the radical right in American politics.

title: GRAY COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Cuba Offers 300 Scholarships To Students in the Caribbean
description: Cuba has offered 300 university scholarships to students from the Caribbean, the official newspaper Granma said today.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Tenneco Is Sued By Superior Oil
description: The Superior Oil Company said it had filed a suit charging Tenneco Inc. with breach of contract in five natural gas sales agreements. Superior said it had asked for a declaratory judgment that the ''take-or-pay'' obligation be binding on Tenneco.

title: REALTY-TAX RISE ISN'T NECESSARY, SADOWSKY SAYS
description: The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee said yesterday that an increase in real-estate taxes, as Mayor Koch has proposed, would not be necessary to balance the budget for the fiscal year 1984.

title: Advertising; Ted Chin Plays by The Rules
description: THE small agencies struggling for a foothold are so hungry and eager for clients that they will bend the traditional rules. Or at least that is what the so-called smart money thinks.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, will be given an extension on his five-year contract that expires after the 1984 season, according to Dan Galbreath, the club's president. ... Bill Walsh, the coach of the San Francisco 49ers, is being replaced as general manager by John McVay, who had been administrative vice president, but Walsh has been named president by Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., the owner who relinquished the title to become chairman of the board. ... John Ebersole, former linebacker with the New York Jets, won one of the two Republican nominations for the Blair (Pa.) County Commission in Tuesday's primary. ...Don McMahon, Cleveland Indian pitching coach, will have a triple-bypass heart operation today and will remain hospitalized at least 10 days.

title: ELECTRONIC THEATRE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: If Defense Pauses to Study A Position, It May Pay Off
description: The line of least resistance is usually right for the defense against a suit contract: trying not to give away tricks; leading toward the declarer's sure tricks; making him ruff in his hand.

title: NATURA ENERGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Silky, in Space
description: For a generation, space travel has conjured up images of strength: rumbling roars, dazzling flashes, hissing clouds ... words like thrust and throw-weight, warp drive and surge power. The whole enterprise is sometimes called the conquest of space.

title: CHOICE AND CARE OF A BLANKET CHEST
description: Blanket chests, simple in construction and design, are still much in demand. While they may not be as plentiful as they once were, their numbers are such that a careful eye while choosing one will result in a chest that needs the least amount of repair or restoration when it gets home.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP (CITY OF INDUSTRY, CALIF reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $252,000 for the quarter and $379,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: 'Motown 25' Was Seen By 47 Million Viewers
description: ''Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever,'' the two-hour taped celebration of the black-owned record company's 25th anniversary that was broadcast on NBC Monday night, was seen by 47 million persons, an NBC spokesman said.

title: STAGE: NEGRO ENSEMBLE, 'MANHATTAN MADE ME'
description: It's a real surprise to go to the Negro Ensemble Company, where plays have not tended to be airy of late, and find a comedy of manners whose characters listen to Rodgers and Hart, sip Scotch before a glittering New York skyline and read Town and Country magazine. But perhaps one should expect the unexpected from the evening's playwright, Gus Edwards, whose last N.E.C. effort, ''Weep Not for Me,'' found wacky comedy in the blighted, impoverished precincts of the South Bronx.

title: 2 ALLIES' MISSILES
description: Yuri V. Andropov has made it clear that he wants to limit British and French nuclear missile forces, as well as ours, in exchange for reducing his SS-20's facing Europe. The Administration rejects the idea, repeating instead French and British platitudes about how their forces are ''national,'' or ''strategic'' or ''minimal'' - and thus untouchable.

title: TORY VOW: 'BRITAIN STRONG AND FREE'
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher opened her campaign for re-election today, unveiling a Conservative Party program that she promised would improve living standards and ''insure that Britain remains a steadfast ally in an uncertain world.''

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $178,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 9 months.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $186,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $8,000 and an extraordinary credit of $214,000. d-After an extraordinary credit of $400,000. e-After income from discontinued operations of $41,000 and extraordinary credit of $444,000.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Flanagan Is Sidelined
description: Mike Flanagan, the Oriole left-hander who has won his first six decisions this season, will be lost to the club for 8 to 10 weeks as a result of the knee injury he suffered in a freakish accident during Baltimore's 7-2 victory over Chicago Tuesday night in the first game of a doubleheader. After retiring the game's leadoff batter, Flanagan twisted his left knee when he apparently caught his spikes on the mound while attempting to field a grounder by Tony Bernazard.

title: BUSH HAILS COAST GUARD DRUG SEIZURES
description: Vice President Bush, speaking today at the 102d graduation of the Coast Guard Academy, praised the Coast Guard today for a ''stupendous job in helping stanch the flow of drugs into our country.''

title: STYLE AND DURABILITY UNDERFOOT: WOOD, TILE, VINYL OR CARPET?
description: EARLY in this century the decorator Elsie de Wolfe had no problem recommending flooring materials for a New York town house. Marble made the most elegant floor for a foyer, she advised, and for the main rooms, dark, highly polished wood was proper.

title: MOTHER IN PHIL DONAHUE CASE FINDS BOY AND FATHER IN TULSA
description: A three-year nationally publicized search for a boy taken from his mother's custody by his father ended yesterday when the woman regained custody of her child in Tulsa, Okla.

title: COURTING HISPANIC VOTERS NOW A REAGAN PRIORITY
description: Discouraged by its failure to attract black voters, the Republican Party is making an effort to reverse its slippage with another ethnic group that is viewed by party strategists as an awakening giant in American politics, the nation's 14.6 million Hispanic Americans.

title: ARTS MEDALS PRESENTED
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday presented two major awards, its Gold Medal in Fiction and Gold Medal in Sculpture, to the novelist Bernard Malamud and the sculptor Louise Nevelson at the organization's annual ceremonial on Audubon Terrace in Manhattan.

title: 3 Die in L.I. Crash
description: The driver and two passengers were killed early yesterday when their car ran off the road and struck a tree on West Shore Road in Mill Neck, L.I.

title: ELEGANT FURS FOR FALL: SQUIRREL TO SABLE
description: PERRY ELLIS deserves a fur toque for imaginative designs that include the tiny sheared-beaver jackets with flaring backs that echo a major theme of his ready-to-wear collection. Oscar de la Renta embroidered some of his furs as ebulliently as he embellished some of his evening clothes, and Bill Blass produced the perfect sable coat.

title: Market Place; A Confidence At Parker Pen
description: STOCK market interest in Parker Pen is responding to favorable earnings projections from the company and a strong buy recommendation from Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. On Tuesday the stock advanced 1 7/8, to 17 3/4, on the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday it rose to 18, after touching 18 5/8.

title: GRUMMAN PLANE HALT DISCUSSED
description: Senior Navy officials have discussed a longrange plan to interrupt production of F-14 Tomcat fighters and A-6 Intruder attack aircraft, according to Navy, industry and Congressional officials. The planes are made by the Grumman Corporation on Long Island.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The share earnings for the latest third quarter do not reflect the additional 1.1 million shares of the company's common stock it sold in an initial public offering in early May.

title: STAGE: KAZE-NO-KO, A TROUPE FOR CHILDREN
description: NO-KO, or Children of the Wind, is a Japanese theater troupe for children that aims delightfully to reach the child in all of us. With a final performance tonight in the Asia House, the group is apt to proclaim again its faith in youthful innocence.

title: CONTEMPT FOR LAW
description: One value that a conservative Administration might be expected to bring to Washington is respect for law. The legal tradition is itself conservative, after all, with its emphasis on process and precedent. And conservative politicians, including Ronald Reagan, have often charged liberals with turning law to their own ends instead of taking statutes as legislatures write them.

title: RESEARCH TRACES AIDS IN 6 OF 7 FEMALE PARTNERS
description: A study of seven female sexual partners of men with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, suggests that the disease may be sexually transmitted between heterosexual men and women, according to its authors.

title: Curry Tops Haley For W.B.C. Title
description: Bruce Curry, whose 21-year-old brother Donald won the World Boxing Association welterweight title earlier this year, tonight defeated Leroy Haley by a unanimous decision for the World Boxing Council junior welterweight title. The Currys, according to the Ring record book, are the first brothers in boxing history to hold world titles simultaneously.

title: Epton Drops Sun-Times Plan
description: Bernard Epton, who blamed the news media for his loss in the Chicago mayoral election last month, has taken himself out of consideration as a purchaser of The Chicago Sun-Times, the newspaper said today. Mr. Epton said in a letter that some potential investors were reluctant. Field Enterprises, which owns the paper, announced April 15 it would be up for sale as part of a plan to dissolve Field Enterprises.

title: ALDEN ELECTRONIC & IMPULSE RECORDING EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for year to March 26.
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Sanitation Union Backs Truck Pact
description: The union that represents New York City's sanitation workers yesterday approved the Sanitation Department's plan to put two-man teams on garbage trucks that now use three men.

title: STOP PENALIZING THE POOR
description: Liberal and conservative critics who charge that the Administration is unfair need only point to welfare policy to prove their case. That policy goes against the grain of bipartisan belief in the work ethic. It violates the principle that sacrifices required by the Government should not fall most heavily on those who can least afford them.

title: AUTO UNION CONVENTION CHOOSES BIEBER AS CHIEF
description: Owen F. Bieber was elected without opposition today as the sixth president of the United Automobile Workers by 2,500 delegates attending the union's convention here.

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE ON ALIEN MEASURE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved a major overhaul of the nation's immigration laws:

title: RESOURCES PENSION SHARES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The U.N. Today; May 19, 1983; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Concern Over Weather Raises Sugar Prices
description: World sugar futures prices continued to rise yesterday, reaching their highest level since mid-July 1982. At the close on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange spot July world sugar futures were up 0.18 cent a pound, to 10.18 cents, while the more active October delivery advanced 0.21 cent, to 10.84 cents.

title: New York Power Bond To Yield 6.5% to 9.37%
description: The largest municipal bond issue of the week, a $590 million New York State Power Authority refunding bond, was priced at par yesterday by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Technology; Low-Dosage Herbicide
description: HERBICIDES are often given brand names that sound appropriately merciless: Smite, Spike and Stomp, for example. But E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company recently began marketing a herbicide for cereal crops that appears unique not only in the gentleness of its name - Glean - but also in its chemistry, mode of action, dosage and apparent safety.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $453,276 for the quarter and year.

title: News Analysis
description: With deliberate public toughness in the last two days, President Reagan has signaled that he will give no further ground for the sake of compromise on the 1984 budget and that he is ready to use his veto to battle Congress on individual tax and appropriations bills later this year.

title: M/A-Com Deals
description: M/A-Com Inc. of Burlington, Mass., said it had received three contracts totaling more than $48 million for its electronics equipment from the Internal Revenue Service, the Argo Communications Corporation and Time Inc.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute for a First Lady

title: U.S. URGED TO SEEK BAN ON WEAPONS IN SPACE
description: A group of scientists, retired military officers and several senators urged today that negotiations be opened with the Soviet Union on a treaty banning the testing and use of weapons in space.

title: Louisiana Judge Backs Black Blood Law
description: A Louisiana law that states anyone with more than ''one thirty-second Negro blood'' is black was upheld today by a state judge.

title: Dotson Loses One-Hitter
description: Dan Ford of Baltimore broke up a no-hit bid by Chicago's Richard Dotson with a one-out homer in the eighth inning tonight.

title: WATSCO INC. reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
OFFICIALS SAY INDIAN PT. PROBLEMS CAN'T BE SOLVED BY JUNE DEADLINE
description: Federal and state officials said yesterday that the problems with the emergency plans for the Indian Point nuclear power plants could not be solved by the June 9 deadline set by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Female Umpire
description: Perry Barber, a 27-year-old New Yorker whose introduction to baseball came through reading the works of Ring Lardner and Roger Angell, is hoping to become a major-league umpire. Miss Barber also is a songwriter and vocalist, who has recorded ''Baseball'' and ''The Umpire Stands Alone,'' songs that have been played at Shea Stadium and other National League parks.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net income including a gain of $1.9 million, or 21 cents a share, on the sale of capital assets.

title: House Votes to Raise Debt Limit $99 Billion
description: The House of Representatives agreed today to increase the Government's borrowing authority, due to expire this month, to nearly $1.4 million million, insuring an uninterrupted flow of Government checks.

title: Harvard Drops Grading Plan
description: The faculty of Harvard Law School voted today to postpone indefinitely or reverse two recently adopted changes in grading policy. The changes prompted two days of demonstrations by more than 500 of the school's 1,500 students.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 19, 1983
description: International Syria rebuffed President Reagan, rejecting his appeal to withdraw its forces from Lebanon and announcing it would not receive an American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, to discuss the issue. The Syrians also hinted they might close their entire border with Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 3.) Margaret Thatcher opened her drive for re-election as Prime Minister, announcing a Conservative Party program that she pledged would improve living standards and enhance Britain's stability. The program calls for further curbs on the power of trade unions and the removal of one layer of local government. (A3:1-3.)

title: ROPER CORP. reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes gains of $443,000 from discontinued operations and $1,424,000 from the sale of business.

title: Head of Showa Venture At Diamond Shamrock
description: Allan J. Tomlinson, president and chief operating officer of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, is stepping down to lead a Diamond Shamrock venture with Showa Denko of Japan.

title: MEDICAL CLOUDS AT PREAKNESS
description: The second leg of this year's Triple Crown may be remembered as the Prescription Preakness, as various medical problems today compromised the prospects of Sunny's Halo, Desert Wine and Marfa, the three favorites.

title: NOBEL INSURANCE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for 15 percent stock dividend paid March 31, 1983.

title: 3 U.S. Yachts Detained At a Port in Nicaragua
description: A Nicaraguan patrol boat escorted three American yachts to port after a storm nearly beached them during a trip to Costa Rica. One of the captains said today that they would soon be on their way.

title: P & O Takeover
description: Shares in the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, which owns the liner Canberra, gained 15 percent, to $2.93, on the London stock market amid speculation about a possible takeover bid by Trafalgar House, owners of the rival Cunard passenger line.

title: Maurice E. Day, Animator, 90; Drew Deer for Movie 'Bambi'
description: Maurice E. (Jake) Day, one of the first and best-known animators at Disney Studios, who used Maine deer as his models for ''Bambi,'' died after a long illness Sunday at his home. He was 90 years old.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
MIZEL PETRO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Dam Dealing
description: Who should operate Merwin Dam? That apparently local question about a hydropower project on Federal land in the state of Washington raises an important national issue about billions of dollars worth of property belonging to all Americans.

title: GROWING THE PLANTS FOR THE POTPOURRI
description: FOR a fragrant summer and a bountiful harvest of leaves that can be used for potpourri, grow species with scented foliage. A goodly number require minimal space and will do nicely in a flowerpot on a sunny windowsill or with other plants in a large container on balcony, terrace or patio.

title: From Notoriety To Landmarks?
description: The Tweed Courthouse and a police station house known as Fort Apache are being considered for designation as New York City landmarks. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission said yesterday that both would be considered for the designation at a public hearing on June 14.

title: 2 WIN DERWENT AWARDS
description: Dana Ivey, who is appearing in Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' and John Malkovich, who was in Sam Shepard's ''True West,'' have been named winners of the 39th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, which are presented to ''the most promising male and female actors on the metropolitan scene'' during the last theatrical season.

title: FORMER E.P.A. AIDE CITED FOR CONTEMPT BY THE HOUSE, 413-0
description: The House of Representatives voted today to cite Rita M. Lavelle, former head of toxic waste programs for the Environmental Protection Agency, for contempt of Congress for failing to comply with a subpoena to testify before a House subcommittee.

title: TIERCO GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: Debt Issues
description: * Fair Lanes Inc. filed for an offering of $25.7 million of subordinated exchangeable debentures due in 1998, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.; the debentures are exchangeable at an unspecified date for common shares of Brunswick Corp.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Boost for Literacy

title: LATIN WOES HURTING MIAMI
description: Economic downturns in Latin American countries are causing serious financial trouble for many businesses here. Latin tourist traffic to southern Florida, once a reliable hedge against domestic recessions, is in a slump and it is unclear when an upturn may occur. Foreign investment in real estate in the area has dropped and is expected to decline further. Two international banking agencies have announced plans to close as financial transactions have diminished; others have reduced staff and hours.

title: MICROSEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
Little-Bank Debt Role Criticized
description: Big city bankers said today that smaller regional banks were fleeing their international lending responsibilities and warned that if the trend continued it could touch off a world financial crisis.

title: VOTERS REJECT PLAN TO PUMP THE DELAWARE
description: Officials of suburban Bucks County are searching for ways to follow the voters' mandate Tuesday to withdraw from the $54 million Point Pleasant Water Diversion Project.

title: RONCO TELEPRODUCTS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income which includes a United Kingdom tax credit of $751,000.

title: MARXIST-LENINISTS' SOLE AIM IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FACES LIKELY WHEN ISLANDERS TRY TO PROLONG CUP REIGN
description: Until Tuesday night, the Montreal Canadiens were the only team in history to win the Stanley Cup, the silver emblem of the National Hockey League championship, more than three times in a row.

title: Addenda
description: * Jean Anderson & Associates, a newly formed research firm at 875 North Michigan Avenue in Chicago.

title: NO CURE SHOULD BE WORSE THAN THE PEST
description: ARECORD spring rainfall. Damp, cool nights. Few sunny days. These are the makings of a host of plant problems - fungus diseases, crown rot and slugs, for example. As a result, gardeners face a rough beginning to the growing year.

title: BIG RISES BY MACY'S, FEDERATED
description: R.H. Macy & Company and Federated Department Stores Inc., continuing the trend of improved earnings among the nation's leading retail chains, yesterday announced sharply higher results for their latest fiscal quarters.

title: Air Force Said to Make Bleak Missile Analysis
description: An Air Force official said today that a new study submitted to the Senate Armed Services Committee estimates that as few as 1 percent of American land-based missiles might survive a Soviet first strike.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income includes tax credit of $268,000.

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET
description: THE New York City Ballet is known for the catholicity of its musical taste, and on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater it offered a sampling of the kinds of music its choreographers have favored over the years.

title: At Least Salvage Some Revenue
description: Tax withholding on interest and dividends died Wednesday. It would have been the most effective and efficient means of collecting billions from tax chiselers, but millions of letters, instigated by the bankers, convinced Congress otherwise. So be it. But the underlying issue remains: how to collect those evaded taxes. Withholding may be dead, but with any care Congress can still make the chiselers pay something.

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SCHOOL BOARD ELECTIONS POINT TO A RISE IN VOTERS
description: In what was considered one of the most significant of 32 school board elections in New York City on May 3, followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. failed to win any seats in an Upper West Side district as the count neared completion.

title: CON MEN USE AN OLD GAME TO GET FUNDS
description: One recent morning, an elderly woman who lives on the East Side received a telephone call from a man who identified himself as a special detective. It was the beginning of a swindle.

title: Labor Talk
description: ''Collective Bargaining in the Arena of Professional Sports'' was among topics discussed yesterday at the Labor-Management Seminars of the American Arbitration Association conference at the New York Hilton. The speakers had been involved in the recent player strikes in professional baseball and football: Donald Fehr, the general counsel for the Major League Baseball Players Association, and Jack Donlan, the executive director of the National Football League Management Council.

title: College Player Backed by Judge
