description: A Federal judge refused to bar a Dallas athlete from playing football for Texas A&M because he signed a baseball contract with the Milwaukee Brewers last year.

title: New Role for Reagan Adviser
description: President Reagan said today that he had appointed Robert Michael Kimmitt, general counsel of the National Security Council, to be its executive secretary.

title: TUSCANS HOPE TO LEND PIERO MADONNA TO MET
description: If the owners had their way, visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York would soon be seeing one of the most admired and least known paintings of the early Italian Renaissance, the ''Madonna del Parto'' by Piero della Francesca.

title: CONCERT: ORMANDY
description: GIVEN the brevity of the seasons that most music directors actually spend with most major symphony orchestras, and the short contracts that bind them to their posts, the 46-year-long relationship between Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra is remarkable. And in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, that relationship was evident in the music.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: EACH era has its preferred decorative objects that, on a table or shelf, become small environmental adjectives -ceramic figurines, primitive masks or Oriental vases, for example, that are the visual modifiers of a home.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Queens, 8 P.M. Scott Holman of the Mets, looking for his first victory of the season, will oppose Eric Show in the major league game that follows a special regular-season Class A Carolina League preliminary game. Starting at 4:30 P.M., the Mets' Lynchburg farm team plays the Padres' Salem team. Dwight Gooden, the Mets' No.1 pick in the draft last June, is the Lynchburg starter. He is 3-2 with 65 strikeouts in 35 innings. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8 P.M.). College: E.C.A.C. New York-New Jersey Metro Division III championship at Kean College, Union, N.J., 3 P.M. Boxing Sean Mannion vs. In-Chul Baek, 10 rounds, junior middleweights, at Resorts International Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 8 P.M. The undefeated Baek, a South Korean, has won all 26 of his fights by knockout and is ranked second in the W.B.A. behind Tony Ayala. Mannion is 26-9-1 with 9 knockouts and is ranked No.8 by the W.B.A. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.).

title: LAKERS DEFEATED
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, lost an opportunity to retain their Western Conference title tonight, losing to the San Antonio Spurs, 117-112, before a sellout crowd at the Forum.

title: Nicholas A. Leitner, 88, Dies; Ex-Price Waterhouse Partner
description: Nicholas A. Leitner, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse, the accounting concern, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and had lived for many years in Summit, N.J.

title: Eastern Offer Is Confirmed
description: Eastern Airlines employees could own a 5 percent to 20 percent interest in the company if they approve a securitiesfor-salary swap, Frank Borman, Eastern's chairman, said here today. He also confirmed union reports that airline employees would nominate two of the carrier's directors.

title: MUNICIPALS: COUPON'S DEMISE
description: The municipal bond market - in some ways the most archaic securities market in the country despite its rapid growth and popularity among individual investors - will take a big step into the modern era on July 1, when all new issues must be sold in registered rather than bearer form.

title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for year to April 2.
LILCO TO TRAIN 1,300 OF ITS STAFF FOR EMERGENCY AT SHOREHAM
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it would train 1,300 of its employees to substitute for Suffolk County personnel in case of an emergency evacuation of the 10-mile area around the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: BILLINGS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DAMASCUS REJECTS APPEAL BY REAGAN TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: Syria today rejected an appeal by President Reagan to withdraw its forces from Lebanon and said that it would not receive an American special envoy to discuss the subject.

title: MACY (R.H.) & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ADMINISTRATION 'CAN LIVE WITH' SALVADOR DIALOGUE
description: Administration officials said today that Congressional proposals for a dialogue between the Salvadoran Government and Salvadoran guerrillas were ''something we can live with.''

title: SWITCHCO INC. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A STUDY QUESTIONS GAINS BY ISRAELIS
description: The International Institute for Strategic Studies has concluded that Israel's gains through the invasion of Lebanon may prove to be less than at first expected.

title: MILITARY IN ARGENTINA IS ACCUSED OF KILLING 2 LEFT-WING PERONISTS
description: Argentine political leaders and human rights activists charged today that military authorities assassinated two left-wing Peronists over the weekend in an attempt to intimidate the opposition.

title: RESEARCHER DREW SUSPICION AT EMORY
description: A report by the Emory University School of Medicine indicates that some officials there may have been aware as early as 1978 that a young doctor who was detected cheating three years later on an experiment at the Harvard Medical School was guilty of scientific fraud.

title: NORTH CAROLINA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (ALBERM reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
KEE EXPLORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting.

title: 7 Music Series Planned By the 92d Street Y
description: The 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, will offer seven music series during the 1983-84 season. They consist of a Distinguished Artist recital series, the Y Chamber Symphony, Chamber Music at the Y, the Y Chamber Symphony Goes Baroque, Master Singers at the Y, Ransom Wilson's Solisti New York and the Group for Contemporary Music.

title: Youth Convicted In Bronx Slaying
description: A 19-year-old Bronx youth was convicted yesterday of shooting another youth to death during a fight that started because of a stare.

title: G.O.P. MOVES BIG-DEFICIT BUDGET FOR ANOTHER VOTE ON SENATE FLOOR
description: Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee today approved and sent to the Senate floor a proposed Government budget for 1984 with large deficits and only minor tax increases, which are believed to be acceptable to President Reagan.

title: CABLE OFFERS OFFERS BOXING
description: A new pay-per-view television venture, Reserved Seat Video Productions, will make its national debut tomorrow with a four-bout championship boxing special from Las Vegas.

title: L.I. Lawyer Accepted Stolen Articles as Fee
description: Sydney Chase, a well-known Long Island criminal lawyer, admitted today in Nassau County Court that he accepted two electric typewriters as part of his fee for representing a burglary suspect.

title: Klan Member Is Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a professed member of the Ku Klux Klan for trying to intimidate an Asian couple by burning a cross outside their home in Tennessee. The indictment was returned Tuesday in Federal District Court in Chattanooga, Tenn., against John W. Thacker and was announced by the Justice Department here.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP 0.8%
description: Americans' personal income jumped eighttenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest gain since last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THRIFTIMART INC. reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
MARTIN PROCESSING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: DOWNS AND UPS IN THE U.S. POVERTY CURVE
description: To the Editor:

title: DARK HORSE TOPS DENVER CANDIDATES
description: William H. McNichols Jr., the 73-year-old incumbent Mayor of Denver, will be only a spectator next month when voters go to the polls to choose between two younger candidates to replace him.

title: L.I. School Opens 2 Days After Siege
description: Brentwood East Junior High School reopened today with counselors to deal with students' feelings about the shootings and hostage-taking there two days ago.

title: A Jockey Comes 'Home'
description: Declan Murphy has been coming to Belmont Park for five years, since he was 12 years old. But yesterday he got a new view of the gracious old track in Elmont, L.I., on the opening day of its 60-day springsummer meeting.

title: Cox to Acquire Detroit Station
description: Cox Communications, which already operates six television stations, said that it had agreed to buy television station WKBD-TV in Detroit for $70 million in cash from Field Enterprises.

title: EXPORT TRIAL STYMIED BY DEPARTURE
description: The trial of a British subject charged with violating the ban on shipping American-produced high-technology equipment to Eastern Europe has been thrown into uncertainty by his departure from this country.

title: SENATE APPROVES IMMIGRATION BILL WITH HIRING CURB
description: The Senate today passed a comprehensive immigration bill that would outlaw the hiring of illegal aliens and offer amnesty to more than a million people now in the country illegally.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $196,000 from discontinued operations and income of $756,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuation of coal operations and the accounting change.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PARANOIA IN PARIS
description: ''My right has been rolled up; my left has been driven back; my center has been smashed,'' Marshal Foch was reported to have said to Marshal Joffre at one of the battles of the Marne, adding: ''Excellent! I shall attack.''

title: CONTROLLED FOODS reports earnings for 12 wks to March 27.
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., has named Jack Lewis, president, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: Dhaka University Reopened
description: Dhaka University reopened today, 92 days after it was closed during student protests, but no classes were held because of a boycott. Students were not expected to return until next Tuesday while activists conduct a campaign seeking support for demands for a judicial inquiry into a Feb. 14 police shooting on the campus, an official accounting of those killed and wounded and the restoration of democracy in Bangladesh.

title: WROTE GUIDES ON TRAVEL IN EUROPE
description: Temple Hornaday Fielding, whose travel books charted the way to Europe for millions of American tourists, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Palma, Majorca. He was 69 years old.

title: Ingersoll-Rand
description: Ingersoll-Rand, which manufactures air compressors and other industrial machinery, will close its foundry for a week, laying off 135 employees, because of slumping orders, company officials said.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
BRIEFING
description: Wrong Number

title: Bechtel and Parsons Get New Presidents
description: Two worldwide engineering and construction companies based in California announced yesterday that they had selected new presidents. At the Bechtel organization in San Francisco, Alden P. Yates was elected to the post vacated last July by George P. Shultz when he became Secretary of State.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE VALUED 'STEP' IN EVER MORE FAMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS ON CASSETTES: NOW, A GOOD LISTEN
description: IF you want to negotiate midtown traffic and read ''War and Peace'' at the same time, now you can. Recorded versions of books, in both abridged and full-length form, are increasingly available on cassette tapes.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
BOND PRICES FINISH DAY MIXED
description: Bond prices were mixed and interest rates unchanged to slightly lower yesterday as some buying interest arose at the lower price levels.

title: Cribbs Eyes U.S.F.L.
description: The official announcement won't be made until today, but Dr. Jerry Argovitz, the retired dentist and players' agent who is being awarded a United States Football League expansion franchise for Houston, already has his eye on a top prospect - Joe Cribbs, a star Buffalo Bills running back and an Argovitz client who is flying in for the announcement ceremony. ''We'll be talking about Joe's future,'' said Argovitz, noting that Cribbs, who has a year to go on his Buffalo contract, could be available for U.S.F.L. duty next spring.

title: ENGLISH, THE LANGUAGE, RECONQUERING POLYGLOT INDIA
description: After three decades of often bitter squabbling over what the national language of this country of many languages should be, it appears that English is winning.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was formed in January.

title: Blunt-Hann-Sersen
description: Three people out of Thomas G. Ferguson Associates have started their own specialty ad agency in the health-care field. They have called it Blunt-Hann-Sersen and opened its doors in Hackensack, N.J. The reason for the agency name is Karen L. Blunt, 40, Dwayne G. Hann, 36, and Donald F. Sersen, 34. Miss Blunt will be chief executive and copy director. Mr. Hann is the account type and is also the president, and Mr. Sersen is executive vice president and creative director.

title: School Fire Routs 2,000 in Brooklyn
description: A fire broke out in a pile of gym mats at a Brooklyn high school yesterday, forcing officials to evacuate more than 2,000 students. Fire officials said the origin of the blaze was suspicious.

title: Upper Volta's President Arrests Prime Minister
description: Prime Minister Thomas Sankara of Upper Volta and several Cabinet members have been arrested on suspicion of plotting against the President, French officials said today.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 19, 1983; The Economy
description: Personal income rose 0.8 percent in April, the biggest gain since July, the Commerce Department reported. It said consumer spending rose even faster than income - by 1 percent. The gains in both categories mean that companies are likely to continue recent increases in production and hiring, according to analysts. (Page D1.)

title: New Computer From Timex
description: The Timex Corporation announced a successor to its highly popular Sinclair 1000 home computer, and said the new machine would have eight times more memory capacity than its predecessor.

title: SPECTRO INDUS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $529,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on April 19 about resumption of service on the Metro-North rail line incorrectly described the circumstances under which a conductor, Frank Cosgrove, was quoted. Although interviewed near a card game, he was not a player.

title: Richardson's Future
description: Bill Blair, the Nets' interim coach, did not confirm reports yesterday that Michael Ray Richardson, the team's guard, had checked into a New Jersey hospital for treatment of a drug problem. But Blair said he was pleased that Richardson had apparently decided to get treatment for a problem he had repeatedly denied despite persistent reports since he joined the Nets earlier this year. ''If it's true, then it's great,'' said Blair, whose sentiments were echoed by Nets players and others close to Richardson.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS EXPANDS SYSTEM OF TELLER MACHINES
description: In an effort to capture a larger share of the credit card market, American Express is expanding its automatic teller machine service to more regions of the country, as well as to nonbanking locations. In the process, it is drawing criticism from bankers, who say American Express is encroaching on their territory.

title: PRIMA ENERGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes gain of $233,000 from sale of assets.

title: 2 Face Charges On Cocaine Ring
description: A Colombian lawyer and a former member of that nation's consulate in Hamburg, West Germany, were arrested yesterday in what officials said was a ''high level'' international cocaine trafficking conspiracy.

title: LONGTIME IRISH OFFICIAL
description: Frank Aiken, Irish Republican Army chief of staff in 1923-25 and later a prominent Irish statesman, died today of pneumonia. He was 85 years old.

title: JAPANESE TO RESUME BIG PROJECT IN IRAN
description: After months of negotiation, a Japanese consortium led by Mitsui & Company has reached an agreement to resume construction on a $4 billion petrochemical complex in southern Iran. Work on the trouble-plagued project has been stalled since September 1980, shortly after the war between Iran and Iraq began.

title: POLAND ASSERTS WALESA IS NO LONGER FIT FOR ANY ROLE IN PUBLIC LIFE
description: The Polish authorities today published their most vitriolic attack against Lech Walesa, saying he was no longer fit to play any role in public life.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Bert Jones to Retire
description: Bert Jones, one of the premier quarterbacks in the National Football League during a 10-year career with Baltimore and Los Angeles, is retiring from football. Jones, in an interview today with The Ruston Daily Leader, the newspaper in his native town, said that a serious neck injury sustained last season is forcing him to quit.

title: TVI ENERGY reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: MOSPORT PARK reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Giants Stadium Pecking Order
description: There is heavy traffic this week at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands. The Giants' football team is conducting a minicamp for all 103 of its players, and being the senior tenant has first choice as to hours and facilities.

title: Nigeria Bid To I.M.F.
description: Nigeria, its economy hard-hit by the international oversupply of oil and the sharp decline in energy prices, has requested aid from the International Monetary Fund, monetary officials said today.

title: SPURRING STOCKBROKERS TO LEAVE NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Mel Wright, 55, Was Pitcher And Coach in Major Leagues
description: Mel Wright, who spent 32 years in professional baseball and was the Montreal Expos' bullpen coach this year, died in Houston's Methodist Hospital Monday night. He was 55 years old.

title: Leveille Pay at Issue
description: Since he suffered a crippling cerebral hemorrhage between periods of a game in Vancouver last Oct.23, Normand Leveille, the Boston Bruins' wing, has not been paid by the Bruins because of a question over the cause of the affliction, a lawyer for his family said yesterday. Under his contract, Leveille would be entitled to continued compensation only if the injury was hockey-related, according to the lawyer, Neil F. Abbott, who said that to prove the hemorrhage was caused by his play, Leveille, who is paralyzed on his right side and cannot speak, may have to go to court. Harry Sinden, the Bruins' general manager, could not be reached yesterday, but in talking with The Boston Herald he acknowledged the issue and said, ''We're trying to handle this in a way that will be of utmost benefit to Normand.''

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Stocks Up, but Dow Is Off 2.23
description: Stock prices in the overall market made a moderate advance yesterday although late selling pressure erased all of the day's sizable gains in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: 3 Sri Lankans Killed In Election Violence
description: The Government declared a national emergency today after two people were killed and three others injured in national and local elections.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the year-ago 6 months are for the period from Nov. 7, 1981, when the company went public, through March 31, 1982.

title: SANITATION MAN FROM THE BRONX CONTRACTS AIDS
description: A New York City sanitation worker has contracted what appears to be Acquired Immune Defeciency Syndrome, the City Health Commisioner said yesterday. But the Commissioner, Dr. David J. Sencer, said the case was not evidence AIDS was a threat to the general population.

title: SIBONEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOME BEAT
description: HER real profession is that of a photographer's stylist. That's how D ebrah Donahue, above, started poking around in antiques stores and f lea markets, collecting children's antiques - books and plates and c hairs and quilts and pull-toys and rag dolls.

title: Sakharov Said to Accept Norwegian Invitation
description: Norway said today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist now in internal exile in the Soviet Union, had accepted an invitation to settle in the country.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have dark wood kitchen cabinets that seem to be coated with grease, dirt and grime. We would like to clean them without damaging the finish. I have tried a commercial furniture cleaner and this didn't seem to help much. Do you have any suggestions?

title: Storms Kill 31 in India
description: Freak storms in northern India in the last four days have killed at least 31 people and damaged crops and property, the Press Trust of India news agency said today. The storms struck at harvest time in the key wheat-growing states of Punjab, Haryana and Uttar Pradesh.

title: SERVICO INC. reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: People
description: * Richard E. Hodges, chairman of Liller Neal Inc., Atlanta, has also been named chief executive officer.

title: REGENCY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BANK CONFEREES SEEK GLOBAL DEBT SOLUTION
description: In a fairy-tale atmosphere of palaces and kings, the world's leading commercial and central bankers are trying to create a new wonderland - one in which the banks' need to get repaid would mesh with the economic, social and political needs of the debtburdened third world. It appears to some people that the hopes are stronger than the chances of success.

title: Phone Plan Objections
description: The United States has raised objections to a Belgian project for manufacturing telephone equipment in China because of the transfer of technology involved, a Belgian Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The project calls for the Bell Telephone Manufacturing Company, a Belgian affiliate of the American I.T.T. Corporation, to sell China 100,000 digital telephone lines and later to set up a joint venture with the Chinese post office to build a factory in Shanghai to produce 300,000 lines a year.

title: Jersey State Prison Shows Death Row
description: A new death row at Trenton State Prison was shown today, and one cell has already been assigned. State corrections officials showed the new block of cells one day after Thomas E. Ramseur, a 44-year-old convicted murderer from Irvington, became the first person sentenced to death in 12 years.

title: F.B.I. WANTS TO TALK TO MOYNIHAN AIDE FACING DRUG CHARGES
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation wants to interview a Senate Intelligence Committee staff aide who was arrested here Monday night for possession of heroin, the aide's attorney said today.

title: PENINSULA RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RUMANIA PLANS TO END TAX ON EMIGRANTS
description: Rumania has informed the United States that to avoid losing normal tariff treatment in this country, it intends to stop imposing a tax on potential emigrants, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Court Upholds Obscenity Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a lower-court ruling that certain pornographic items seized by the Government, including the movie ''Deep Throat,'' may be ''unpleasant, uncouth and undeniably pornographic,'' but cannot be legally confiscated as obscene in New York City.

title: WHY CUSTODY GOES MOSTLY TO MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUP RUNNETH OVER
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. T hey were all there, standing in the bright lights, surrounded by cameras, ready for a sip. Armand and Lucille Potvin stood on a platform in the Islander dressing room, while Denis, the youngest of their three sons, provided directions for the proper way to position the Stanley Cup to take a drink. After they drank together, Armand Potvin placed an index finger in the cup, collected a drop of what was left inside, and held his finger in the air to show everyone how good it tasted.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
DECORATIVE COVER-UPS
description: IF high tech is not for you, you might consider covers that have been designed to disguise, without limiting the function of, two important home safety items.

title: SSP INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28 1.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Changes at Burmah Oil, Executive and Fiscal
description: When John Newcombe Maltby takes over the chairmanship of Burmah Oil P.L.C. early next month, business at the British oil company will be a good deal more brisk than when his predecessor, Sir Alistair Down, took control in January 1975.

title: PRESS GROUP ASSAILS SOUTH AFRICA
description: The annual general assembly of the International Press Institute approved resolutions today that condemn ''continued harassment and persecution'' of the press in South Africa and express concern about the press situation in some Latin American countries.

title: GLENN LEADS MONDALE AS VOTE-GETTER IN GALLUP POLL
description: A new Gallup Poll projects Senator John Glenn as a stronger vote-getter than former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in a general election race against President Reagan.

title: Tonelli In Court After Celebration
description: John Tonelli, the Islander wing, pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of speeding and paid a $45 fine, after having been charged with driving while impaired with alcohol following the team's celebration of its fourth consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDS ARGENTINA IN BID TO EXTRADITE ASSASSIN
description: The Justice Department is cooperating with efforts by Argentina to extradite Michael Vernon Townley, an American who was convicted of assassinating a Chilean exile here in 1976. Mr. Townley is wanted by Argentina for killing a Chilean there in 1974.

title: A PATIENT, LOW-KEY AUTO UNION LEADER
description: The ascent of Owen Bieber to the presidency of the United Automobile Workers is a good example of how it is possible to win while playing by the rules.

title: France Recalls Envoy And Criticizes Chile
description: France today recalled its Ambassador from Chile, calling Gen. Augusto Pinochet a ''curse on his people'' and accusing the Government of human rights violations after demonstrations against it.

title: STANDARD LOGIC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-Including tax recoveries of $33,200 for the quarter and $126,200 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax recovery of $5,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: STANDARD METALS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Preservationists Honored

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,287,000 for the quarter and $594,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,248,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,592,000.

title: SANITAS SERVICES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of 000 for the quarter and $2,374,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $278,000 for the quarter and $752,000 for the 9 months.

title: TV: STORY OF A FAMILY IN NAZI ERA
description: BEING quietly slipped into Channel 13's schedule, tonight at 10 o'clock, ''The Oppermanns'' may very well be the most fascinating television production of the year.

title: U.S. Says Milwaukee Police Discriminate in Promotions
description: The Justice Department charged today that the assignment and promotion practices of the Milwaukee Police Department discriminated against black officers.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE VALUED 'STEP' IN EVER MORE FAMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: RARE CHAPLIN CUTS
description: A LOT of rare and wonderful material is contained within the three 52-minute segments of Thames Television's ''Unknown Chaplin,'' the Charlie Chaplin documentary screened here yesterday at the Museum of Broadcasting, where it will be shown again June 21. It says something about the curious relationship between theatrical films and television that this material should be presented to us under the auspices of a television company.

title: DISPUTE DELAYS NICARAGUA DEBATE BY HOUSE PANEL
description: A dispute over whether to hold an open or closed debate on a proposal to end covert aid to the Nicaraguan rebels led the House Foreign Affairs Committee to delay consideration of the measure today.

title: OPERA: 'NERONE' BY BOITO
description: ARRIGO BOITO is one of music's fascinating marginal characters. He provided Verdi with the great librettos for ''Otello'' and ''Falstaff,'' and Ponchielli with the rather less distinguished ''La Gioconda.'' Boito was also a composer, and one of his two operas, ''Mefistofle,'' is still heard regularly throughout the world.

title: Books Of The Times
description: CROSSROADS OF MODERN WARFARE: Sixteen 20th-Century Battles That Shaped Contemporary History. By Drew Middleton. 320 pages. Doubleday. $17.95.

title: 76ERS WIN AND GAIN FINAL
description: For the fourth time in seven years, the Philadelphia 76ers will go searching for the elusive National Basketball Association championship.

title: TRANS-NATL LEASING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CRAWFORD ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results include a gain of about $500,000 for the quarter and 9 months from insurance proceeds on a drilling rig destroyed by fire.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Breakers' Lament
description: ''Of course we're disappointed,'' said Bob Caporale, the president of the Boston Breakers, when attendance figures announced by the United State Football League showed that the team's home average of 10,507 was by far the lowest in the new 12-team league. ''We're hoping for much better crowds at our remaining games against Philadelphia, Chicago, Tampa Bay and New Jersey.

title: Chairman of NBC Sees Improvement
description: NBC, the third-place network, is financially healthy and moving up in the program ratings, Grant Tinker, NBC's chairman, told an audience of affiliate station owners and managers.

title: CHANCELLOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a writedown of resource properties of $6,150,000.

title: Rate Level On Money Accounts
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts are showing signs of stabilizing after six weeks of decline, The Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: NEW TACTIC USED TO FIGHT JUNKED CARS
description: They are parked - one last time -on city streets. They are hidden behind bushes. They are even stashed in vacant buildings. Every day, about 180 cars are abandoned by their owners and become wards of the New York City Sanitation Department.

title: Technology Today Gets a New Publisher
description: Gerald G. Hotchkiss, 52, for 10 years the publisher of Psychology Today magazine, on Monday will begin a new job as publisher of Technology Today magazine, one of the Goldhirsh Group publications.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Clamming Coming Back to Monmouth
description: After a 20-year absence, hard-shell clamming will resume in coastal waters near this Monmouth County borough June 1, the head of the State Bureau of Shellfisheries said today.

title: A 'KING'S RANSOM' IT'S NOT, GEM WINNER SAYS
description: The Metropolitan Opera's raffle catalogue described it as a gem ''fit for a king's ransom or a museum's desire'' and worth $60,000. But Ann Cicchelli, who won the unusual yellow sapphire, said she could not find anyone who would give her more than $7,000 for it.

title: Albuquerque Issue
description: A $109.7 million Albuquerque, N.M., general obligation refunding bond was priced yesterday at par to yield 5.75 percent in 1984 and 8.80 percent in 1998.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After cumulative effect on prior years of change in method of determining impairment related to proved oil and gas properties of $702,000. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the latest year include a gain of $3.3 million on the retirement of debt.

title: Hewlett Posts 16% Rise in Net
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, citing strength in domestic orders, reported yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter increased 16 percent, while revenues advanced 12.5 percent.

title: LOUISIANA FESTIVAL OF MUSIC AND FOOD
description: AMERICA is full of folk and craft festivals. Every weekend when the weather is warm, people stream onto the grounds of some regional fair featuring local and touring musical performers and craftsmen. But few such festivals can hope to equal the diversity and focus of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, which wound up its 14th year at the New Orleans Fair Grounds Race Track earlier this month.

title: TORK INC. reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: STAGE: 'FROZEN ASSETS,' AT ENSEMBLE
description: ABORSTAL boy is on the run in Barrie Keeffe's ''Frozen Assets,'' a hard-bitten but heavy-handed British play in an American production at the New York Theater Ensemble. Mr. Keeffe is the author of the play ''Gimme Shelter'' and the screenplay for ''The Long Good Friday.'' ''Frozen Assets'' shares an urban geography but not a tautness with those other works.

title: JAPAN TRADE RELAXATION
description: In a concession to Japan's trading partners, the Parliament today approved legislation to ease import regulations. The bill amends 16 laws on import certification and standards, and the legislative approval fulfills a promise by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that the Government would reduce nontariff trade barriers.

title: SOTHEBY AUCTION SETS RECORD OF $37 MILLION
description: More than $37 million in Impressionist and modern art was sold last night at an auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet. The total set a world record for art auctions.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday misidentified the man standing nearest the novelist James A. Michener at a White House awards ceremony. He was the painter Frank Stella.

title: Revere Descendant Dies
description: Anna Revere, great-great-granddaughter of Paul Revere, died Sunday at her home in Chestnut Hill. She was 83 years old. Her survivors include her sister, Margaret A. Revere, three nephews and a niece.

title: NASA STUDY BACKS SPACE SHUTTLE RIDES FOR PRIVATE CITIZENS
description: A special study group recommended today that space travel be opened to private citizens and that the first ones to fly should be writers, broadcasters, artists, poets and educators.

title: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock split in May 1983 and a 25 percent stock split in September 1982.

title: U.S. AND TAIWAN: DIPLOMATIC DANCE CONTINUES
description: The American non-Embassy is a plain, cream-colored building just off a boulevard lined with small shops and rain trees. The embassy was in another part of town, but that was before the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 1979 and gave formal recognition to mainland China.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TAFT BROADCASTING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Michigan Bonds' Top Yield Is 9.82%
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said that only about $30 million of the $114.1 million hospital revenue bond offering of the Regents of the University of Michigan remained unsold by late yesterday.

title: CONVENTURES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-The company reported a revenue deficit of $174,115 after deducting a loss of $3,337,441 on the sale of investments. c-Net loss.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRIEFS
description: * Ivan F. Boesky Corp. disclosed that an investors group it leads had sold 317,800 shares of the Interpace Corp. on May 13 on the open market for between $33.75 and $33.88 a share; Boesky said it now owns 20,000 shares, or five tenths of 1 percent of Interpace's common.

title: Ton of Frozen Shrimp Stolen
description: More than a ton of stuffed shrimp, valued at nearly $10,000, was stolen from a truck early today as the sleeping drivers waited for the storage facility to open. The frozen specialty shrimp were taken before 6 A.M. from a truck parked in front of Booth Cold Storage on the city's North Side, the police said.

title: Paraguay Port Emergency
description: The port at Asuncion, Paraguay's capital, was declared in a state of emergency after the rising waters of the Paraguay River reached the level of its dock. The National Ports and Navigation Office said in a statement Tuesday that work was partly halted at the port because the waters had flooded electrical installations supplying power to the cranes.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: JAPANESE FURNITURE
description: 100 Years of Folk Furniture: Tansu

title: HERS
description: IS nothing sacred? In 1983, no one is surprised by the dissection of yet another less-than-exemplary private life led by a famous politician, pediatrician, poet, theologian or (let it never be said that honest reporters are reluctant to air their own dirty linen!) journalist. But I have always held staunchly to the belief that baseball players are one group of American heroes who have remained true blue, brave, thrifty, clean and reverent. Now, baseball wives are begining to speak up about their difficult lives with the boys of summer - and it seems clear that ''boys'' is the operative word.

title: NORTH CANADIAN OILS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
description: The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in April 1982 and a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1982.

title: TOXIC DUMPING IN CITY LANDFILLS CITED IN A STUDY
description: A research group said yesterday that it had documented the legally authorized dumping of ''massive quantities'' of hazardous chemical wastes in city landfills intended for garbage. It called for an immediate cleanup program and expanded health tests of nearby residents.

title: Pan Am Terminal
description: Pan American World Airways, saying that its financial condition had improved, reported it had ended discussions with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey about the sale of its terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
STRAWBERRY'S HIT LIFTS MET STREAK TO 4
description: The Mets ran their winning streak to four games last night when they defeated the San Diego Padres, 2-1. And for the second straight night, the winning hit was delivered by the rookie Darryl Strawberry.

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOUSE DRUG STUDY FAULTS POLICE ROLE
description: A House inquiry has found that no members of the House were implicated by a drug investigation undertaken by the Capitol Police Force, according to a report released today. At the same time, the report was highly critical of the conduct of the police.

title: UNA CORP. reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CONNECTICUT SENATE BACKS INTERSTATE BANKING BILL
description: The State Senate, by a 29 to 7 vote, today approved legislation that would open Connecticut's borders to interstate banking with the other New England states, but not with New York.

title: GOODE CONSOLIDATES POWER AFTER PHILADELPHIA PRIMARY
description: As political experts here sifted the results of Tuesday's election, W. Wilson Goode moved quickly today to consolidate the commanding position his victory in the Democratic mayoral primary provided for a race next fall. He seeks to become the first black Mayor of the city where, more than two centuries ago, a nation was born.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PLANT INDUS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $541,000 from discontinued operations and a $1,974,000 loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a $58,000 loss on discontinued operations. The loss on disposal of discontinued operations includes a provision of $518,000 in 1983 for operating losses during the phase-out period. The 1983 results reflect a loss of $473,000 relating to provisions for the discounting of notes receivables and potential litigation losses.

title: RESEARCHERS SEE NATO THREAT FROM WITHIN
description: The International Institute for Strategic Studies said today that the unity of the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance was threatened by internal disputes over military and economic policies.

title: Islander Victory Parade Sunday
description: A victory parade for the Islanders is scheduled to begin at 3 P.M. Sunday in Uniondale, L.I. A club spokesman said the parade would follow the same route as last year, beginning on Oak Street, near the Hofstra University campus, and continuing past Nassau Coliseum to Eisenhower Park.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $4,955.

title: AMQUEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for year to Jan 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,661,000 and an extraordinary credit of $1.2 million. c-Net loss including income of $359,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
YANKEES TRIUMPH, PASS .500
description: Billy Martin took a phone call in his clubhouse office from someone named Bob shortly before the Yankees faced the Detroit Tigers tonight. Bob apparently was giving advice.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Schumer Seeking To Bar Prosecutor
description: The lawyer for Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn moved yesterday to bar the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate his client.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE Third Street Music School Settlement is one of those lucky charities with not one but two f und-raising parties. This season's first, run by the Junior C ommittee, was held Tuesday night at Joanna. More than 250 of New Y ork's most attractive young people dressed up for a Swiss-accented d inner, a showing of expensive jewels by Eric Bertrand, the Swiss j eweler who underwrote the evening, and dancing till all hours in ther estaurant's downstairs room.

title: U.S. AND NICARAGUA CLASH AT U.N.
description: The United States and Nicaragua clashed at the United Nations today immediately after they voted together in the Seucrity Council to urge four Latin nations to intensify their peacemaking efforts in Central America.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 20, 1983
description: International One of the biggest protests in Warsaw since martial law was imposed 17 months ago occurred as about 20,000 Poles attended the funeral and marched for nearly two hours to the burial of a 19-year-old youth who died after being detained by the police. The signature of the outlawed union Solidarity was fastened to the front of the coffin. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) Rifts among Western leaders may mark the economic summit conference in Williamsburg, Va., on May 28-30, Reagan Administration aides fear. They have sought to assure a harmonious meeting, but there are major differences between Washington and Europe, including France's charge that American budget deficits and high interest rates are damaging the world economy. (A1:4.)

title: CUOMO NOW PLANNING TO REPLACE CHAIRMAN OF STATE'S PAROLE BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo will replace the chairman of the State Parole Board, administration officials said today. The Governor has chosen Marion L. Borum, a deputy commissioner in the Correction Department, to replace Edward R. Hammock, the officials said.

title: Swedish Prices Rise
description: Sweden's consumer price index rose in April by eight-tenths of 1 percent from March and was 8.5 percent higher than in April 1982, Statistics Sweden said today.

title: DRUG AGENTS SEIZE WRITER, EARL AND 14 OTHERS
description: A writer, a British earl and 14 others were arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a group that conspired to import millions of dollars worth of heroin and cocaine into the United States.

title: Arbour Rests Up
description: Al Arbour, the coach of the four-time champion Islanders, was not with his team yesterday for its informal ''family day'' picturetaking session at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. Instead, the coach was home under doctor's orders, suffering from the flu and exhaustion.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Pitching In
description: Wayne Gross is a versatile athlete who has played third base, first base or catcher for the Oakland A's this year while batting .275 with three homers. But on Wednesday he was called upon to expand his act.

title: TORO CO reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-Net loss c-Including an extraordinary gain of $466,000.

title: City's art policeman.
description: ''ART has always been an integral part of my life,'' Detective Robert Volpe said the other day. ''I grew up in the street and loved the freedom. But I also graduated from the High School of Art and Design. I have been a curator as well as a painter. It's sort of strange how the art and the adventure came together.''

title: SPURS RUIN SCRIPT FOR LAKERS
description: The setting was perfect. With the National Basketball Association's defending-champion Los Angeles Lakers holding a three-games-to-one lead in this Western Conference final, it was only natural that the Lakers would reward their hometown fans Wednesday with a display of the dazzling speed and quickness that led them to their advantage, thus finishing the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Economic Scene; Strong Dollar's Global Effect
description: WASHINGTON ONE lends only to the rich, or so a popular saying goes in France. The implicit irony is seen by many to apply to an increasingly contested privilege that the United States has under the present monetary system.

title: Warriors' Bach Gets Late Start
description: ''I'm going into a challenging situation, a new and beautiful world,'' John Bach said yesterday. ''I wish I had made the transition 20 years ago.''

title: DOW FALLS 12.19, TO UNDER 1,200
description: The stock market registered a broad loss yesterday in less active trading as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.19 points, to 1,191.37.

title: Lindner Chairman Of Penn Central
description: Carl H. Lindner, a Cincinnati-based financier who has built a reputation for shrewd investment decisions, yesterday was named chairman of the Penn Central Corporation.

title: Debt Issues
description: * BankAmerica Realty Investors filed for an offering of $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

title: Santa Fe Lobbyist Charged
description: The Justice Department today filed criminal charges against a Washington lobbyist for the Santa Fe International Corporation, accusing him of illegally tipping a friend that the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation would acquire Santa Fe.

title: CUOMO GIVES UP GOAL ON SHARING MEDICAID COSTS
description: Governor Cuomo has abandoned efforts to win approval for a five-year state assumption of the Medicaid costs of local governments because of opposition in the State Senate.

title: ECONOMY UP 2.5% IN 1ST QUARTER
description: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the first quarter this year, slower than originally estimated, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Early Report on Mercury In Tennessee Disclosed
description: Two brothers who took unauthorized samples from a creek in 1981 spurred the Government to make a study that showed heavy concentrations of mercury near a nuclear weapons parts plant, one of the brothers asserts.

title: TIME WILL SPIN OFF FOREST UNIT
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would spin off its large forest products business to concentrate on publishing and video operations.

title: Friday; TWYLA THARP ON L.I.
description: The dance company of the innovative choreographer Twyla Tharp will make its only appearance in the New York area this season at 8:30 tonight in the C.W. Post Concert Theater in Greenvale, L.I. On the program are ''Sue's Leg,'' danced to the music of Fats Waller; ''The Fugue,'' which has no music (footsteps create polyphony); ''Short Stories II'' and ''Assorted Quartets.'' Tickets are $12.50 and $15. The campus is about an hour from Midtown Manhattan. Directions and reservations: (516) 922-0061. A MIME OF MASKS

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 23.
Mission's Chief To Step Down
description: E. Richard De Rosa, president and chief executive of the Mission Insurance Group of Los Angeles, said yesterday that he would resign by Jan. 31.

title: SUDDENLY, HUNGARY POLICED THE SAMIZDAT 'BOUTIQUE'
description: By Western standards, the Hungarian Government is generally considered the most liberal in Eastern Europe, in part because of its pragmatic economic policies, but mainly because it has been willing to tolerate some degree of internal dissent. Dependent on the International Monetary Fund and Western banks, Hungary's leaders are eager to maintain its good reputation in the West. Yet in recent months, the Government has behaved uncharacteristically in a series of actions aimed at intimidating its ''democratic opposition.''

title: Topics; Jobs Undone, Well Done; Rare Bird
description: S. Dillon Ripley's decision to retire next year at 71 will remove a rare bird from the Washington scene. As boss of the Smithsonian Institution, this gifted ornithologist brought a most needed addition to the vast Mall between the Capitol and the Washington Monument: people.

title: YIELDS UP ON U.S. SECURITIES
description: Jitters over an expected large rise in the basic money supply sparked late selling in the Government securities market yesterday as anxious dealers unloaded inventories, pushing down prices and raising yields.

title: MAKING CITY'S SUBWAY CARS IN JAPAN
description: Garbed in a tan army-style helmet, khaki work suit and white safety spats, Yukio Okada strides among the workers - a front-line warrior in New York City's multibillion-dollar effort to refurbish its subway system.

title: CHANNEL 13 DEFICIT CUT BY $3 MILLION
description: A cutback of more than 50 staff members and reductions in administrative expenses, coupled with increased revenues, have enabled WNET/Channel 13, the New York metropolitan area's major public television station, to reduce its deficit of more than $6 million to $3 million over the past six months.

title: New York Power Issue Repriced to Lift Yield
description: A $590 million bond issue by the New York State Power Authority, the largest municipal issue of the week, was repriced yesterday to give higher yields and to attract buying. The move reflected the bearish tone of the credit markets.

title: The Duvalls and a movie with Gypsies.
description: GAIL YOUNGS met Robert Duvall, to whom she's now married, when she was a fledgling actress and he was playing in ''American Buffalo'' on Broadway with her brother, John Savage.

title: ART
description: ''Holbein at the Court of Henry VIII,'' at the Morgan Library through July 30, is primarily a loan show of 70 portrait drawings by Holbein from the Royal Library in Windsor Castle. As such, it will be irresistible to anyone who cares for superfine drawing or for a definitive account of the English face in some of its more archetypal forms. These were people who loved to be drawn, and who knew that they were sitting for a man of exceptional powers.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 20, 1983; The Economy
description: The economy grew at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter, more slowly than forecast, the Commerce Department said. But the shortfall resulted from a sharper-than-expected decline in inventories, economists said, so it does not change the outlook for stronger second-quarter growth. Also, first-period corporate profits soared 12.6 percent, the biggest such gain in five years. (Page D1.)

title: Ups and Downs
description: O nce among the most popular pastimes in America, yo-yoing is in a slump. At the peak, yo-yo sales reached $15 million in 1971 but dropped to $5 million last year.

title: HYSTER CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Funds' Assets Drop Again
description: Money market mutual fund assets dropped $721 million for the week ended Wednesday, to $170.4 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Preakness Stakes Field; POST PROB.  NO. POS.  HORSE JOCKEY TRAINER ODDS 2 1 Play Fellow Jean Crugeut Harvey L. Vanier 8-1 3 2 High Honors Miguel Rivera Lou Rondinello 15-1 1 3 a-Deputed Donnie Miller J. William Boniface 15-1 Testamony 4 4 Chas Conerly Kenny Skinner Mervin Marks 15-1 5 5 Bet Big Roger Velez Hubert Hine 15-1 6 6 Marfa Jorge Velasquez D. Wayne Lukas 4-1 7 7 Desert Wine Chris McCarron Jerry Fanning 7-2 8 8 Paris Prince Terry Lipham Laz Barerra 15-1 1a 9 a-Parfaltement Herb McCualey J. William Boniface 15-1 9 10 Common Sense Jack Penney Dennis Manning 20-1 10 11 Sunny's Halo Eddie Delahoussaye Davis Cross 2-1
description: a-coupled. Post positions and numbers differ because of entries and mutuel field.

title: Base, and Bases, in Manila
description: An old dilemma seems likely to intrude again into Washington's tricky relations with the Philippines. President Marcos is an authoritarian ally, unashamedly highhanded. He has just been discovered to have composed a secret decree in 1981 that threatened death to those who ''scurrilously libel'' him. The offensiveness of this remnant of martial law is not much lessened by assurances that, since the decree was never published, it will not be enforced.

title: Death by Injection Approved
description: The Nevada Senate gave final approval Wednesday to a bill that would change the method of execution in the state from the gas chamber to lethal injection. The bill is now before Gov. Richard H. Bryan.

title: MUSIC
description: New York's classical music is most often thought of in terms of its grandest institutions: the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the panoply of visiting orchestras, instrumentalists and singers that traipses through our midtown concert halls week after week. But our music is just as much a matter of variety and breadth: every weekend one can find a positively disorienting array of exotic but genuinely interesting musical events out on the geographical and stylistic margins. Here are some of them for this weekend:

title: MOSCOW, DAMASCUS AND THE ROAD TO PEACE
description: The Kremlin's response to Secretary of State George P. Shultz's request ''to take another look'' and to ''get on the side of peace in Lebanon'' is predictable. It is a definite and unqualfied nyet. The Russians are neither philanthropists nor fools. They have no incentives to endorse an agreement worked out by Washington without Moscow's participation. The last thing the Politburo wants today is to help Ronald Reagan achieve a diplomatic victory in the Middle East.

title: Rockets Win Sampson
description: The Houston Rockets beat the Indiana Pacers yesterday in a coin toss for the first choice in the college draft June 28, and General Manager Ray

title: Citicorp's Plans
description: Citicorp officials said that plans to buy a South Dakota bank will enable the bank holding company to establish an insurance concern.

title: JAMES C. WALKER
description: James C. Walker, chairman of Warnaco Inc., an apparel company, died of kidney disease Tuesday at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Greenwich, N.Y.

title: NLI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect a change in accounting for the company's investment in Amalgamated Sugar Co.

title: Everywhere, Readers
description: A ndre Kertesz's lifelong fascination with readers reading is reflected in an exhibition opening today at, appropriately, the New York Public Library. In the second-floor gallery of the Central Research Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, the show, spanning seven decades, runs through July 2, Mr. Kertesz's 89th birthday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DULUTH. By Gore Vidal. 214 pages. Ran- dom House. $13.95.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JAZZ/CABARET
description: New life, new promise, new excitement - all the usual accompaniments of spring - have turned up at just the appropriate time in New York's cabarets and jazz clubs.

title: HERBERT ROSENBERG, LAWYER WHO SERVED IN CITY WATER POSTS
description: Herbert M. Rosenberg, a lawyer, financier and former New York City official, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: An Injury Forces Jones to Retire
description: Bert Jones, whose powerful throwing arm made him one of the top quarterbacks in the National Football League, tearfully announced his retirement today, saying doctors had warned him that he risked paralysis if he continued playing.

title: ROSE'S STORES reports earnings for qtr to April 28.
Hyatt to Seek Plan for Braniff
description: Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of Hyatt International, will meet with a select group of Braniff International creditors here today and urge them to come up with a proposal to restart the airline, a source involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: 4 NUNS AND BISHOP END SUIT OVER JOBS
description: Four nuns dismissed from their parochial school jobs said today that they were dropping a suit against the Diocese of Manchester in exchange for new jobs and the clearing of their names.

title: Teamster Leader in Michigan To Head 13-State Conference
description: The teamster union's new president, Jackie Presser, has selected Robert Holmes, an international vice president of the union, to head the 13-state Central Conference of Teamsters.

title: Bridge: Precision Team in Pacific Had Many a Close Finish
description: Short exhibition matches of 24 boards or so can be expected to produce close results, and therefore drama for the spectators, but the recent Precision tour of the South Pacific had more than its share. Four matches out of 10 hinged on the last deal, with the margin at that point being two or fewer international match points.

title: Mary Lou Burg, Former Aide To National Democratic Party
description: Mary Lou Burg, a former vice chairman and deputy chairman of the Democratic Party, died after suffering a stroke here Monday. She was 53 years old.

title: VERNON JORDAN'S NEW CAREER HAS TRACES OF THE OLD
description: Now that he is doing well, Vernon Jordan still tries to do a little good. After 22 years as a civil rights activist, the last 10 as president of the National Urban League in New York, Mr. Jordan in 1981 became a partner in the Washington office of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, an influential Dallas law firm that has 110 lawyers on four floors of a downtown office building here.

title: Blast Wins, 7-6, Forcing 5th Game
description: Joey Fink scored his second goal of the game one minute into overtime to give the Baltimore Blast a 7-6 victory over the San Diego Sockers and force a decisive fifth game in Major Indoor Soccer League finals.

title: Getting There
description: The Upper Montclair Country Club is situated in Clifton, N.J., at the intersection of the Garden State Parkway and Route 3. From midtown Manhattan, it can be reached by taking the Lincoln Tunnel and traveling 12 miles on Route 3 to the club.

title: TEXT OF COUNCIL'S RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of a resolution on the situation in Nicaragua adopted by the Security Council today by a vote of 15 to 0:

title: 'Non Pasquale' will present Donizetti in Central Park.
description: ''NON PASQUALE,'' a new pop opera, will follow ''Richard III'' as the Shakespeare Festival's second production in Central Park this summer. ''Non Pasquale''? ''That's because it's not 'Don Pasquale,' '' says Wilford Leach, who will direct the production.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Some of the most remarkable social documents of the 1940's were photographed not in the interest of justice and equality, as one might expect, but as promotional material for a multinational corporation. Commissioned by Standard Oil Company of New Jersey from 1943 to 1950, these pictures are brought to light for the first time in years in an eye-opening exhibition at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street.

title: SCREEN
description: In ''Tender Mercies,'' at the Guild Theater and Quad 1, Bruce Beresford, the Australian director who made ''Breaker Morant,'' has turned out the kind of American film people usually mean when they ask why Hollywood doesn't make movies the way they used to. ''Tender Mercies'' isn't an old-fashioned movie at all, but the way it regards middle-American life, without either ridicule or condescension, makes it appear to be a throwback to simpler times. It is a beautifully accomplished, sophisticated movie about comparatively simple folk, including a has-been country-and-western singer (Robert Duvall), his new young wife (Tess Harper) and his small stepson (Allan Hubbard). The fine screenplay is by Horton Foote.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Hagler Bout Sanctioned
description: Abandoning their insisistence on a 12-round limit, the two major boxing organizations have agreed to sanction a 15-round championship bout between the middleweight champion, Marvelous Marvin Hagler, and Wilford Scypion in Providence, R.I., next Friday, but the move may have come too late to win a major role in the bout for the two groups, the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association. In accepting certification by the two groups, Bob Arum, the bout's promoter, agreed to pay sanctioning fees to each of them, but he said he could not abrograte previous agreements giving the the month-old United States Boxing Association International and the Rhode Island Racing and Athletics Commission the right to name the officials and supervise the bout under U.S.B.A. International rules.

title: CONCERT: BRONX GROUP
description: THE Bronx Arts Ensemble left its home ground Monday night for a concert of chamber music in Manhattan's Abraham Goodman House. The group plays concerts throughout the Bronx every season, and this year it has been celebrating its 10th year of life in the community.

title: De Laurentiis Buys Film Rights to 'Marie'
description: Motion picture rights to Peter Maas's ''Marie,'' the true story of a woman who challenged a ruthless political machine in Tennessee, have been purchased by Dino Di Laurentiis for $650,000. Mr. Di Laurentiis previously produced ''Serpico,'' Mr. Maas's 1973 book about police corruption that has sold more than 3 million copies.

title: REAGAN TO TELL CONGRESS OF PLANS TO RELEASE JET FIGHTERS FOR ISRAEL
description: President Reagan said today that he would notify Congress ''in a day or two'' that he wants to go ahead with the sale to Israel of 75 F-16 fighter jets that he held up after the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last June.

title: Red Miller Dismissed
description: He was popular with the fans, he was popular with his players and he was popular with his fellow coaches, but Red Miller, the head coach of the Denver Gold, was never popular with the club's owner, Ron Blanding. And yesterday, after four straight losses, a 4-7 record and weeks of acrimony, Miller was dismissed, making him the first coach to lose his job since the United States Football League began its first season in March.

title: GEORGE MERNS
description: George Merns, founder and board chairman of Merns Inc., a retail clothing company, died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital following a stroke.

title: STAMFORD TO GET A NEW RAIL STOP UNDER U.S. PLAN
description: Ground breaking will take place here Friday for a new $50 million railroad station, one of the largest construction projects in a $2.19 billion revitalization effort along the Boston-Washington rail corridor.

title: Injuries Force Nilsson to Quit
description: Ulf Nilsson used to go to work at night, on ice skates, under the glaring lights of Madison Square Garden and many other hockey arenas. Now he works days, wearing a jacket and tie, and he commutes to his job each morning on a train from Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Volcker's View On High Rates
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, indicated today that the Federal Reserve system might tolerate higher interest rates because it appeared that an economic recovery had begun in the United States.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Award to Philanthropist
description: I n recognition of the millions he has given the World Health Organization's blindness prevention programs, Ryoichi Sasakawa, the flamboyant Japanese businessman, was scheduled to be given the Helen Keller International Award last night at the Pierre Hotel.

title: PRESIDENT AND LAWMAKERS MIX SMILES AND BARBS
description: Jim Wright, the House Democratic leader, offered President Reagan some unsolicited advice at the White House today, telling him to turn off his ''spigot'' of denunciations of the Congressional budget process if he wanted to encourage bipartisanship on foreign policy.

title: DESERT WINE'S STATUS STILL QUESTIONABLE
description: Thirteen colts were entered today for the 108th Preakness Stakes here Saturday, but Desert Wine, the second choice on the morning line, remained a questionable starter after his owners were rebuffed in an attempt to convince the Pimlico stewards to permit the colt to run with medication.

title: CONCERT: THE AMERICAN CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: THE American Chamber Orchestra is youthful and sometimes amateurish sounding, but under its talented conductor, Charles Barker, at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night, it was also capable of sensitive music making. Mr. Barker's strengths were evident in Telemann's Don Quixote Suite and Haydn's Cello Concerto in C. Each gesture was precisely defined; the music was shaped with intelligence and understanding. The soloist in the Haydn work, Peter Wyrick, shared Mr. Barker's talents and taste for fervent lyricism.

title: TALKS ARE CUT OFF ON A BASE IN EGYPT
description: Administration officials said today that the United States and Egypt had broken off talks for an agreement that would have permitted the United States to improve an Egyptian military base for use by American rapid deployment forces.

title: Market Place; Home Appliance Issues: Earnings Progress Seen
description: HOME appliance stocks typically move inversely to interest rates. And since rates have been falling, appliance stocks have been rising. Moreover, appliance makers have been automating their operations, thus keeping labor costs down so that, after a certain point, small increases in sales mean large increases in profits.

title: Alexander Cuts Pay And 400 Positions
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a major insurance brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had undertaken a program of layoffs and salary cuts to trim expenses. John A. Bogardus, chairman and chief executive officer, said at the annual meeting yesterday in New York that the reductions would save the company ''millions of dollars,'' but he did not give further details.

title: SUPRADUR MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $401,000 for the latest quarter and $138,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Dioxin Waste Found In Northern France
description: Forty-one containers of dioxincontaminated waste that had been the object of an international search were found in a northern French village today, the Justice Ministry announced.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The net in the latest quarter and year include gain of $594,000 on sale of interest in oil and gas property.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a charge of $69 million for the quarter and 6 months for operational restructuring costs, a loss of $6 million for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations and a gain of $54,136,000 for the 6 months from the acceptance of an exchange offer by certain debenture holders. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $28,864,000 for the quarter and $40,676,000 for the 6 months.

title: New Mexico Bond Is Priced at Par
description: A $109.9 million Farmington, N.M., power revenue refunding bond was priced at par today by the lead underwriter, Boettcher & Company in Denver.

title: AN EVENING OF TITLE FIGHTS
description: The first live heavyweight title doubleheader in history, an obscenity in the minds of most boxing purists, will take place here Friday night with what the local bettors believe are two mismatches.

title: BEFORE START-UP
description: To the Editor:

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
STAGE
description: The quest for the offbeat in theater can send audiences scurrying in multimedia directions. This weekend, for example, there is an attempt at combining television and live performance: Laura Farabough's ''Obedience School'' at the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street (966-3651).

title: POLITICAL USE OF TOXIC CLEANUP CHARGED BY DINGELL
description: A House subcommittee today released material indicating that an official of the Environmental Protection Agency had discussed with White House aides ways the Reagan Administration could take political credit for cleaning up toxic waste.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
AFTER A SUICIDE, PARENTS TALK OF FEARS
description: On Saturday night, Cathy Ann Petruso, a 17-year-old high school senior, had a brief quarrel with her boyfriend at a drive-in movie in Danbury, Conn. She left the car and went to the restroom. A few minutes later, she was found dead, hanged by her own belt.

title: Mikan Is Cleared
description: A judge dismissed a complaint against the former basketball great George Mikan after an hour of questioning yesterday about why Mikan had failed to pay a $20,000 nursing home bill for care of his mother.

title: PUBLISHING: QUESTIONS ABOUT LITERARY AUCTIONS
description: THE literary agent for a book that appeared briefly on The New York Times best seller list has been accused of misrepresenting the price that was bid for the book when it was first put up for auction. The agent, in turn, says that the controversy is the result of a misunderstanding.

title: OFFICER IS GIANT PROSPECT
description: Phil McConkey is a football player of a different stripe, the kind that naval lieutenants wear on their sleeves. For the next month, he will continue to be an officer and a gentleman as defined by the Navy.

title: Greece Assails a Threat For New State in Cyprus
description: Greece expressed concern today to the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council over a threat by the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, to create an independent state in northern Cyprus, Government officials said.

title: Required Reading; Notion of Deterrence
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, speaking on the concept of deterrence before the Arms Control and Disarmament Panbel of the House Armed Services Committee, May 12, 1983:

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1 million for the quarter and $2 million for the 6 months.

title: AMY ALCOTT LOOKING BEYOND $1 MILLION
description: If Amy Alcott finishes sixth or better this weekend in the L.P.G.A's $125,000 Chrysler-Plymouth Classic at the Upper Montclair Country Club, she will become the sixth female golfer to earn $1 million in her career.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $537,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $4,285,000 for the quarter and $5,436,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $1,556,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago figures have been restated.

title: BALLET: 'EPISODES' REVIVED
description: THE re-entry of George Balanchine's ''Episodes'' into the New York City Ballet repertory after an absence of four years is cause for rejoicing. Performed on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, it is a major work of 20th-century ballet - provocative in its astringency, strikingly beautiful, and a revelation of its Webern score.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Neil Allen tries for his second straight victory, after beating Pittsburgh last Saturday in his first start since 1979.

title: Ellen Berland Sachar Wed To Bud H. Gibbs, a Lawyer
description: Ellen Berland Sachar, a vice president of Goldman Sachs & Company, was married yesterday to Bud H. Gibbs, a New York lawyer. Rabbi Seth Bernstein of Temple Rodeph Sholom performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Vote on final passage, page A12.
description: The Senate voted 50 to 49 late tonight to adopt a 1984 budget with tax increases opposed by President Reagan as too large.

title: AT EASE IN HIS REFUGE IN SPAIN, TOP BELGIAN FASCIST EXTOLS PAST
description: Leon Degrelle is living very well these days and at first glance one might take him for a retired businessman, one of the thousands who come down from northern Europe for the easy life in the Spanish sun.

title: THOMAS B. TIGHE
description: Thomas B. Tighe, editor emeritus of The Asbury Park (N.J.) Press, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Neptune City.

title: 29 ARRESTED IN SOCIAL SECURITY INQUIRY
description: Twenty-nine people were arrested yesterday on charges of fraudulently cashing nearly half a million dollars worth of Social Security checks made out to dead relatives and friends. Federal officals said the charges stemmed from a continuing investigation that had uncovered losses of $30.4 million in New York City.

title: Barry Harris Program
description: The jazz pianist Barry Harris will lead his annual large-ensemble program Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Beacon Theater (874-1718). There will be an orchestra, chorus, tap dancers and jazz musicians, including the pianist Chris Anderson and the violinist Bruce Hinkson. Tickets are $8 and $10.

title: State Commission Admonishes Judge
description: An acting Supreme Court justice was admonished yesterday for his conduct as a Civil Court judge by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: THE CUBAN PRETEXT
description: Debate in the United Nations Security Council next week will dramatize the fact that two years of the Reagan Administration's cozy relations with South Africa have left independence for Namibia - mandated by the U.N. in l976 - further than ever from realization.

title: LED NATIONAL GUARD IN JERSEY
description: Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, a former Army artillery officer who headed the New Jersey National Guard and the state's Department of Defense for 15 years until his retirement in 1970, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Trenton. He was 74 years old.

title: 20,000 MARCH TO WARSAW FUNERAL OF YOUTH WHO DIED AFTER ARREST
description: About 20,000 Poles went to the funeral today of a young man who died after being in police custody. It was one of the largest demonstrations in the capital since martial law was imposed 17 months ago.

title: CANADA PROPOSES A SECURITY AGENCY
description: The Canadian Government has introduced legislation to set up a clandestine intelligence service with broad authority to intercept mail, install recording devices and surreptitiously break into homes or offices.

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Rutherford Out of Indy
description: Johnny Rutherford, the three-time Indy 500 champion, is out of this year's race.

title: INDIA SAID TO BE ON VERGE OF $1.8 BILLION ARMS DEAL WITH U.S.
description: India has quietly expressed interest in buying machine guns, mobile howitzers and C-130 aircraft in a potential $1 billion sale of arms from the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Of the two groups of stock index futures traders who have been selling the market short in recent weeks, those who counted on the blue chips to lead the decline have made large profits from those who thought the secondary issues would show the larger losses.

title: POWERS OF BAKER ERODING IN SENATE
description: Last Friday morning Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, requested a meeting with James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff. His message was that Senate Republicans wanted President Reagan to be more flexible in his budget demands.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
BID TO RAISE RIKERS JAIL LIMITS DENIED
