description: A Federal judge has denied New York City's bid to raise the population limit for its jails on Rikers Island. Three months ago, city officials told the judge, Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court in Manhattan, that unless some relief were granted, they might have to release some inmates to accommodate newly arrested people.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM IN AN OLD FILE STIRS A COLLEGE
description: A tent is stretched across a gracious lawn among a cluster of low, handsome buildings at Sarah Lawrence College as the 54-year-old school here prepares for commencement next week.

title: Driver Indicted In 34th St. Death
description: An ex-convict was indicted yesterday on charges of killing a New Jersey woman and injuring 26 other people when his car went out of control and crashed into a store on West 34th Street last month, authorities said.

title: Shortened Season
description: Nancy Lopez, who has accumulated $81,448 while winning twice on the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tour this year, does not plan to compete during the final five months of 1983. She and her husband, Ray Knight, are expecting their first child in mid-November.

title: Salvador Army Officer Said to Admit Killings
description: A secret United States Government cablegram suggests that a Salvadoran Army officer admitted he planned the assassination in 1980 of Archbishop Oscar Romero of San Salvador and the killings of two American labor experts a year later, a newspaper reported today.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON THE BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved a 1984 budget outline with tax increases President Reagan opposes: FOR THE PLAN - 50 Republicans - 21 Andrews, N.D.; Boschwitz, Minn. Chaffee, R.I. Cochran, Miss.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every death is painful, but this one is especially brutal. It will not be forgotten.''

title: What Is a Commencement But a Beginning?
description: Y esterday's commencement at the Lincoln Center campus of Fordham University was for 17 graduates, all women and all over 60. They had been among 200 students in Fordham's College at Sixty program, designed to attract people back to school.

title: BEYOND THE PUNISHMENT OF DRUNK DRIVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Rev. Dr. Brian Duffy Is Dead; Ex-President of Siena College
description: The Rev. Dr. Brian F. Duffy, a Franciscan priest who was president of the order's Siena College from 1964 to 1970, died Wednesday at his home in Loudonville, N.Y., of complications after a stroke. He was 66 years old.

title: Kaiser Steel Talks End
description: Negotiations to sell the Kaiser Steel Corporation, of Fontana, Calif., to a group headed by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor, have ended, Kaiser said yesterday.

title: BOY'S RETURN ADDS TWIST TO TV CASE
description: The recovery of a child who the police say was abducted by his father three and a half years ago has added an element of irony to a nationally publicized case that cast journalistic principles against the mother's search for her son.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. TO KEEP ORDER TO INSTALL DUST CONTROLS AT TEXTILE MILLS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a rebuff to its own budget office, reversed itself today and decided that it would continue to require textile companies to develop engineering controls to protect workers against inhalation of cotton dust.

title: BLOCK SAYS U.S. MUST SLASH COST OF FARM AID
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block warned today that unless new farm programs were developed to reduce the staggering costs of grain and dairy surpluses the public might soon refuse to sustain them.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ROBERT KRAFT, WITHOUT 'GLITTER,' IS AT THE BALLROOM
description: ''A DUKE ELLINGTON quote I love is that 'every problem creates an opportunity,' '' Robert Kraft said the other day. The 28-year-old pop-jazz composer, saloon singer and pianist who is playing an openended engagement at the Ballroom has reason to be philosophical. His recording career, which has produced three albums, stalled recently when the singer and his label, RCA, parted company. And his original musical, ''Metropolitan Serenade,'' which Hal Prince optioned for Broadway three years ago, remains unproduced for lack of a book writer.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The net in the 1982 period reflects a $4,953,000 accounting adjustment.

title: MOVIE RECOUNTS TIMERMAN ORDEAL
description: ON Sunday at 9 P.M., NBC is offering ''Jacobo Timerman: Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number,'' a television movie based on a book by Mr. Timerman. He is the distinguished journalist who was expelled from Argentina in September 1979 after his newspaper, La Opinion, had embarrassed the military regime with questions about the disappearance of citizens in the political opposition. The network is to be congratulated for tackling such a project. It deals with unsettling present-day realities and is not likely to be appreciated in certain domestic political circles bent on wooing Argentine friendship.

title: U.S. FEARS DISCORD WITH MAJOR ECONOMIC ALLIES AT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's efforts to assure a harmonious economic summit conference at Williamsburg, Va., over the Memorial Day weekend, aides are worried that the meeting may be marked by sharp disagreements.

title: The Sense Of Service
description: President Reagan called himself ''Johnnie One-Note'' on reducing the Federal Government's role in domestic affairs, and especially education.

title: 'BRIGHTON BEACH' HONORED BY CRITICS
description: Neil Simon's ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' was named best new play of the 1982-83 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. David Hare's ''Plenty'' was voted the best foreign play, and ''Little Shop of Horrors'' was selected as best musical.

title: DANCE
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will play host to one of the dance season's most unusual events on Sunday at 2 P.M. when Normadien Gibson, a dancer in the Chuck Davis Dance Company and N'Goma Woolbright, the troupe's stage manager and lighting designer, will be married on stage by a minister as part of the academy's annual Dance Africa Festival. Mr. Davis will stage the ceremony.

title: Soviet Envoy Quoted On Afghan Withdrawal
description: The Soviet Ambassador to Afghanistan said in an interview published today that the Kabul Government was willing to set a timetable for the total withdrawal of Soviet troops provided it had international guarantees against intervention from across its borders.

title: INSURANCE LOBBYING DRIVE DRAWS IRE FROM 'FOLKS IN THE BOONDOCKS'
description: Inspired by the remarkably successful campaign waged by banks against legislation that requires the withholding of taxes on interest and dividends, a group of insurance companies has organized what is in at least one way an even more aggressive lobbying drive to preserve sex-based distinctions in insurance.

title: The U.N. Today; May 20, 1983; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10 A.M.

title: One Man, One Vote - and One City
description: For a time, it looked as though New York City would be spared the chaos that might result if its unusual Board of Estimate were subject to the one-man, one-vote rule. A Federal district court said the rule did not apply because the board is administrative, not legislative. Not good enough, a Federal appeals court now says; the distinction won't wash because the board performs general governmental duties. But that needn't mean chaos.

title: INDIAN PT. REPORT SAYS ARMY COULD PLAY ROLE
description: New York's Health Commissioner suggests that cadets or regular Army troops from the United States Military Academy could be used to help remove residents around the Indian Point nuclear power plants in case of an accident there.

title: FORD'S HOMER TOPS JAYS
description: For the second straight night, a home run by Dan Ford in the eighth inning gave the Orioles a victory. Wednesday, Ford's homer - it was Baltimore's only hit - with one out beat the Chicago White Sox and Rich Dotson, 1-0. Tonight, Ford hit a two-run homer with two out to beat the Toronto Blue Jays and Mike Morgan, 2-1.

title: SHORT INTEREST SETS MARK ON BIG BOARD AND AMEX
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 4.1 percent, or 6.1 million shares, in the month ended last Friday, to a record 153.7 million shares. The previous high of 147.6 million shares was set last month. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 103.6 million shares.

title: Penn Central Plans Hotel Sale
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had agreed to sell the 915-room Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Florida to VMS Realty Partners Inc. for $100 million. VMS is a Chicago-based company with a real estate portfolio approaching $1 billion, Penn Central said.

title: GERMAN LEARJET, COCKPIT EMPTY, IS THOUGHT TO CRASH IN THE ATLANTIC
description: A West German executive jet veered 1,600 miles off course Wednesday on a training flight from Vienna and, with no one at the controls, was believed to have crashed into the Atlantic 200 miles south of Iceland.

title: POP: MARVIN GAYE SINGS
description: MARVIN GAYE complained that his hair looked messy and predicted that the critics would advise him to get in better shape during the first of six shows at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday. He did seem easily winded during the course of his frequently strenuous 90-minute show, but that was hardly surprising; Mr. Gaye hasn't toured America, or performed much anywhere, in more than five years.

title: 7 SOCIALIST NATIONS BID U.S. CUT DEFICIT
description: Seven Socialist governments, meeting here to propose plans for economic growth, asserted today that reducing the United States budget deficit was an ''indispensable condition'' for a sustained international recovery.

title: L.I. Youth Denies Slaying Newsboy
description: A 17-year-old youth pleaded not guilty today to charges that he murdered a Rockville Centre newsboy.

title: SAFETY OF LIFTING AIR TRAFFIC LIMITS QUESTIONED
description: The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday called for a slowdown in the timetable for ending air traffic restrictions caused by the 1981 strike by Federal air traffic controllers, warning that safety could otherwise be jeopardized.

title: MIAMI'S COMMUNITY OF REPUBLICAN CUBANS AWAITS REAGAN WITH EXCITEMENT
description: President Reagan's plans to visit here Friday, pursuing his efforts to appeal to Hispanic voters, have stirred enthusiasm through much of the Cuban community, with many expecting tough talk about an issue that dominates Cuban life here: Fidel Castro.

title: WARSAW, IND., WRESTS ITS DOWNTOWN FROM PIGEONS
description: The view from Bob Goley's bank office window was a common sight in many Middle Western small towns: the village square, the old county courthouse, the crumbling sidewalks, the decaying century-old brick building whose broken windows made flyways for scores of pigeons.

title: Operating Chief Named At California Thrift Unit
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association, which recently became a publicly traded company, yesterday announced the election of George P. Rutland as president and chief operating officer.

title: MARTIN MAKES ANOTHER RETURN
description: Another series opener in another town where Billy Martin has managed looms for the Yankees. But this weekend against the Oakland A's is special. This is where they've named a Little League park for Martin. It is close to where he was raised and lives. And it is where he was dismissed last year.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE current engagement of Jonah Jones, the master of the muted trumpet, at Jimmy Weston's, where his quintet is playing, had its roots at the Embers, the legendary 52d Street jazz club of the 1950's more than a quarter of a century ago.

title: STREAK ENDS AT 4
description: Darryl Strawberry hit another home run last night, his third in four games, but it wasn't enough to keep the Mets from losing to the San Diego Padres, 3-2, and ending their winning streak at four games.

title: Cam Fella Wins
description: Cam Fella, harness horse of the year in 1982, surpassed $1 million in earnings when he won the second leg of the World Cup Pacing Series at the Meadowlands tonight.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
RAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New York Is Resuming Competitive Bond Sales
description: New York City yesterday announced plans to sell $100 million of bonds next Wednesday, in what will be the its first competitive bond auction since February 1975.

title: Army Officer Resigns
description: Brig. Gen. Peter Dawkins, the West Point halfback who won the Heisman Trophy in 1958, announced that he was retiring from the Army on Aug. 1. In a statement issued at the Pentagon, where he has been deputy director of strategy, plans and policy for the Army's deputy chief of staff for operations, Dawkins gave no reason for his surprise move and said he had not decided on his future activities. Since he was appointed brigadier on June 1, 1981, the 45-year-old Dawkins had been the nation's youngest general on active duty.

title: New York-Bound Jet Hijacked to Cuba
description: A man who said he wanted to see his wife and family and claimed he had a bomb forced a New York-bound Eastern Airlines jet to fly to Cuba today in the third hijacking of a United States airliner to Havana in 19 days.

title: Driver Is Charged In I-80 Bus Crash
description: A bus driver who was injured with all 22 passengers when his vehicle skidded off Interstate 80 on Monday has been charged with speeding, police said.

title: Topics; Jobs Undone, Well Done; Belatedly Moot
description: ''The most important thing we do,'' Justice Brandeis once said of the Supreme Court, ''is not doing.'' For a tribunal with such power and discretion, choosing the right cases and issues - and avoiding the wrong ones - can be as important as the decisions themselves.

title: FRAUD SUIT CITES GENERAL DYNAMICS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, a major military contractor and shipbuilding company, was accused yesterday of indirect participation in a conspiracy to extract $4.5 million in kickbacks from a subcontractor. It denied the charge.

title: ART: ISAMU NOGUCHI AND HIS WORLD OF STONE
description: IF nature hadn't invented stone, Isamu Noguchi might have, so in touch does he seem with its dense essence. To be of Japanese blood is to have stone in the family, so to speak, and the 78-year-old sculptor has always worked with it, mostly in landscape arrangements and monumental structures. ''The whole world is made of stone. It is our fundament,'' he has written. ''When I tap it, I get an echo of that which we are.''

title: THE BAUERS, DAREDEVILS OF THE BIG TOP
description: The four Fearless Bauers, whose daredevilry atop 70-foot poles without a net is a high point of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, live up to their billing. They cannot, they say, recall ever being scared of heights. However, they can experience a qualm if, as Joe Bauer put it, ''maybe you slip a little up there.''

title: Advertising; Dim View Of Profit Margins
description: Last year was a pretty good one for agencies to increase their billings, but it was the worst in a decade for profit margins. And, to spread the gloom a little further, the agency heads predicting a bad year outnumber those who see an improvement.

title: THE SOTHEBY AUCTION: WHAT THE RECORDS MEAN
description: THE $37.4 million art auction of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby Parke Bernet Wednesday night did more than establish a monetary record for an art sale anywhere in the world. It also indicated to many collectors and dealers that New York has replaced London as the world center of the art market and that the recession in art sales may be over.

title: Group Is Suing 92 In Nassau G.O.P.
description: A class-action suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn seeking to recover $4.5 million from 92 Nassau County Republicans it said had received kickbacks in an insurance fraud scheme.

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-earlier quarter and year include a net gain of $1,250,000 from the recovery of loans.

title: PRINCETON'S SMALL WORLD OF BIG WRITERS
description: Princeton has had a certain popular association with things literary ever since F. Scott Fitzgerald praised the New Jersey town this side of paradise for its ''lazy beauty'' in the 20's, and John O'Hara motored around the place exhibiting his JOH-1 license plates. But rarely has Princeton had such an interesting community of writers in residence. Well, pretty much in residence; they do tend to travel a lot.

title: PORTABLE COMPUTER'S PROMISE
description: Manny A. Fernandez beamed with delight at the crowds gathered in his company's booth at the National Computer Conference here. For an unknown company that was not even listed in the exhibit guide, the Gavilan Computer Corporation was drawing crowds that would have done I.B.M. proud.

title: ORDER ON TRUCKS BY U.S. DEFIED BY CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that the Federal Government had demanded that Connecticut end its ban on double-trailer trucks, but that the state would not back down.

title: Met 'Kids' Play at Shea
description: The Mets, who like to boast about ''the kids'' in their farm system, imported an entire team of them yesterday from the Class A Carolina League and had them play a game in Shea Stadium before the senior Mets played the San Diego Padres.

title: WHAT SOME PAY TO TALK WITH A POLICY MAKER
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: ZUBIN MEHTA does not put much stock in ceremony when it comes to pulling down the curtain on the New York Philharmonic's seasons. One year, for instance, the music director closed out the schedule with Ravel's ''Bolero,'' possibly in hopes of winning a rating of ''10'' from the audience.

title: An Adviser To Reagan Is Cleared; Teller's Stock Was at Issue
description: The White House said today that no evidence of impropriety had been uncovered in the fact that Edward Teller, the physicist, had stock holdings in Helionetics Inc., a laser and space weapon research company, at the same time he served as a part-time Administration adviser on space weaponry.

title: Benefit Concert
description: The International Committee for the Desaparecidos will present a benefit concert Sunday at 4:30 P.M. at Washington Irving High School Auditorium, 40 Irving Place at 16th Street.

title: Audit Criticizes U.D.C.  On Legal Consultants
description: The state's Urban Development Corporation and its subsidiary, the Mortgage Loan Enforcement and Administration Corporation, paid too much for outside legal consultants, according to an audit released today by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: ALI FOGS HOLMES'S VIEW
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. S uddenly, his voice dropped almost to a whisper, as if he were talking about a loved one who had aged quickly, sadly. And he was. Larry Holmes was talking about having seen Muhammad Ali here this week.

title: An East Side flavor of Mediterranean.
description: THE combination of an attractive and intimate setting, a gracious staff, and well-prepared food that has an engaging homemade quality adds up to some very pleasant dinners at Andree's Mediterranean Cuisine on 74th Street between First and Second Avenues. On Monday nights, these premises function as a cooking school run by Andree Abramoff, a native of Cairo who specializes in Middle Eastern food supplemented by dishes from France, Spain and other parts of North Africa.

title: 4 GROUPS SUING E.P.A. FOR RELEASE OF FUNDS TO CLEAN UP THE HUDSON
description: Four environmental groups sued the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday to force the release of $20 million sought by New York State to help clean up the Hudson River.

title: F.C.C. Upholds MCI Award
description: The Federal Communications Commission has upheld a nearly $1 million damage award that the MCI Communications Corporation won in 1981 against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: ART: THE SCULPTURE OF WILLEM DE KOONING
description: ANYONE who wants to answer the question ''What has the third dimension done for de Kooning ?'' has only to go along to the Xavier Fourcade Gallery at 36 East 75th Street, where ''Willem de Kooning: The Complete Sculptures'' can be seen through June 30. The visitors who go on to examine the monumental ''Seated Woman'' of 1969-81 by de Kooning that can now be seen in front of the Seagram Building on Park Avenue will have all the evidence.

title: Mariners 1, Angels 0
description: SEATTLE (UPI) - Julio Cruz scored on a suicide squeeze bunt by Jamie Allen in the eighth inning for Seattle.

title: BALLET: 'BAYADERE' AT A.B.T.
description: ''LA BAYADERE'' returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House and, with its lavish designs by Pier Luigi Samaritani, it remains one of the most spectacular productions in all American ballet.

title: Smith of Islanders Is Proud of Trophy
description: The Conn Smythe Trophy was belly-high on Billy Smith - clutched in his hands, goaltender and award facing the cameras.

title: JAPANESE FILM AWARDED TOP PRIZE AT CANNES
description: The jury of the 36th Cannes International Film Festival today gave its highest award, the Golden Palm, to ''The Ballad of Narayama,'' a film by the Japanese director Shohei Imamura that portrays the customs through which the people of a primitive Japanese village dealt with aging and death.

title: POP/ROCK
description: Wilson Pickett - the Wicked Pickett to soul fans - is a powerfullooking, man with a voice that sounds capable of shearing steel. Stylistic changes that periodically revamp pop-music sensibilities have not been kind to him, for while young English rockers are falling all over themselves to sound soulful, the black audience that was always Mr. Pickett's prime constituency now favors more fluid and mellifluous vocal stylists. But that doesn't keep Mr. Pickett from raising the rafters. He's at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue at 15th Street (989-9505), tomorrow at 1 A.M. Admission is $5 before 11 P.M., $10 after.

title: A G.I. IN LUTHER'S TOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: 34 TOWN HOUSES IN CONDOMINIUM ON MANHASSET BAY
description: For many years Manhasset Bay has been renowned as one of the finest natural harbors on the East Coast. Its deep protected waters have attracted several yacht clubs, and hundreds of boat owners tie up at the bay's 1,800 slips.

title: KANGAROOS ARE BEING KILLED, LEGALLY AND ILLEGALLY, BY THE MILLIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'ASIAN SHADE,' TWO SOLDIERS ON LEAVE
description: TWO young men, buddies in a small Southern community, are home on leave before being shipped to Vietnam, and they are eagerly trying to have a high-spirited holiday. The situation is familiar, but the play, Larry Ketron's ''Asian Shade'' (at the WPA Theater), has the buoyancy of youth, and the actors - most of them new faces - inhabit the landscape as if they are natives.

title: WHITHER THE STRAVINSKY ARCHIVE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Principled Pardons
description: President Reagan defined some sound principles in explaining his pardon for a convicted Watergate burglar. Eugene Martinez, he said, was a first offender.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Billy Ray Smith, the Arkansas linebacker who was the San Diego Chargers' top draft pick, has signed a multi-year contract with the club, ending speculation that he might accept an offer from the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League. ... Birmingham Stallions officials plan to keep the rights to Joe Cribbs, the running back, even though his agent, Jerry Argovitz, wants to build his new U.S.F.L. franchise around the Buffalo Bills star. ... Don McMahon, a pitching coach for the Cleveland Indians, was listed in stable condition after open heart surgery.

title: Man on E. 88th St.  Dies in Stabbing
description: A 22-year-old aspiring interior designer was fatally stabbed at about 3 A.M. yesterday outside the basement entrance to a building at 229 East 88th Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

title: Apartheid Foe Is Fined $27,000 in Church Fraud
description: The former general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, an opponent of apartheid, was fined $27,000 and given a suspended 10-year prison sentence in Supreme Court here today for defrauding the church group of more than $358,000.

title: DEATH OF A NO-HITTER
description: O ver the first seven innings, 27 Baltimore Orioles went to bat against Richard Dotson of the Chicago White Sox Wednesday night. Nineteen were retired routinely, seven walked and another hit into a double play. Going into the eighth inning of a scoreless game, no Oriole had managed a hit against the White Sox right-hander, and Dan Ford, the Baltimore right-fielder, had struck out twice and walked.

title: N.C.A.A. Seeks New TV Hearing
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said today that it would seek a rehearing before the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in an effort to retain control of football television rights.

title: PORT AGENCY OFFICIAL SUGGESTS INVESTMENT OUT OF MANHATTAN
description: The future economic health of the metropolitan region depends largely on new investment in the outer boroughs of New York City and in nearby communities in New Jersey, Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the executive director of the Port Authority, said yesterday.

title: Watt Avoids Protesters At Arizona Ceremony
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, sidestepping irate environmentalists at ceremonies celebrating the 20th birthday of Lake Powell, today hailed American leaders who have braved ''the abuse of public opinion'' so people could have a better way of life.

title: MAJOR COFFEE DEALER, SUED OVER BIG DEBT, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: A coffee importer who borrowed nearly $120 million from two dozen American and foreign banks in the past six months filed yesterday for personal and corporate bankruptcy.

title: Content Bill On Autos Advances
description: One of last year's most contentious pieces of legislation, an unsuccessful bill aimed at requiring both foreign and domestic auto makers to use a large percentage of American parts and labor in cars they sell in the United States, made its first advance today toward passage by the new Congress.

title: U.S. Says Tapes Show DeLorean Drug Deals
description: John Z. DeLorean once offered to invest in both Asian heroin and Colombian cocaine and said it was ''tragic'' that the deal fell through, according to Government documents released today in the automaker's drug trafficking case.

title: BUDDHISM, ONCE CRUSHED, BLOOMS AGAIN IN TIBET
description: Bands of pilgrims bearing fruit jars filled with yak butter trudge to the old monasteries, and then spoon it into the flickering lamps that illuminate the great Buddhas. The pilgrims press their foreheads to the relics and sip holy water poured from a teapot by a monk in a rust-red robe.

title: Champion-F.T.C.
description: An administrative law judge has dismissed an antitrust complaint about the Champion Spark Plug Company's acquisition of the Anderson Company, according to the Federal Trade Commission. The F.T.C. had filed the complaint. Champion bought Anderson, the nation's largest replacement windshield-wiper manufacturer, in 1978 for $38.1 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: Even Kermit the Frog

title: REGULATING LASIX: A PATCHWORK OF RULES
description: BALTIMORE The brouhaha over which Preakness horses will be allowed to run tomorrow with furosemide coursing through their veins may have given occasional racing fans a horrifying picture of why so many horses need the drug. Furosemide, better known under the trade name Lasix, is a diuretic that lessens bleeding from a horse's lungs.

title: LEBANON, DESPITE SYRIAN REBUFF, SEEKS DIRECT TALKS ON WITHDRAWAL
description: Despite strong rebuffs from Syria, Lebanon is still trying to start direct negotiations with Damascus in an effort to overcome Syria's denunciation of the Lebanese-Israeli troop withdrawal agreement, which was signed Tuesday.

title: South Jersey Gas Granted Rate Rise
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today granted South Jersey Gas Company a 4.7 percent rate increase that will raise an average customer's monthly bill $3 to $7.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER NARROWS LOSS IN PERIOD
description: The International Harvester Company, struggling to avoid bankruptcy, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the second fiscal quarter to $159.1 million, from $201.1 million a year earlier.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Rodolfo Gucci on Monday incorrectly identified his late father, who founded the Gucci fashion concern. He was Guccio Gucci.

title: MUSIC: SYMPHONIC BAND
description: JUST a few years ago, Marshall McLuhan was predicting the imminent advent of a ''global village'' in which every corner of the planet was to be connected instantaneously by electronic communications. As a result, he theorized, everyone would know what everybody else was doing, all the time.

title: SHULTZ SUGGESTS ISRAEL-SALVADOR ANALOGY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, arguing for continued military aid for El Salvador, today suggested an analogy with Israel. He told representatives favoring a negotiated accord in El Salvador that Middle East peace talks could never succeed if Israel were ''unarmed, weak or unsupported.''

title: EMERGENCY PLANNERS' VETO OVER NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Co. has appointed Dr. Carl W. Ehmann vice president, dermatology research and development at its Pharmaceutical Research and Development division.

title: Judge Bars Razing Of Synagogue
description: The demolition of the Mount Neboh Synagogue, a city landmark, was temporarily stopped yesterday by a court order from a State Supreme Court judge barring the owner from altering the structure before a hearing can be held Monday.

title: A.H. Belo to Buy Two G.E. Stations
description: The A.H. Belo Corporation, Dallas, announced that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy radio stations KOA-FM and KOAQ-FM - both in Denver - from the General Electric Broadcasting Company, a unit of the General Electric Company, for $22 million. Belo, which publishes The Dallas Morning News and seven community papers in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, currently owns two radio stations in Dallas and several television stations.

title: Canadian Prices
description: Canada's consumer prices last month were unchanged from March and 6.6 percent above April 1982, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The annual comparison represents the smallest year-to-year increase since January 1977, the agency said. Gasoline prices declined sharply, offsetting increases for electricity, tobacco, housing and furnishings.

title: CUOMO APPOINTS 21 TO NEW PANEL ON FISCAL AND ECONOMIC PRIORITIES
description: Governor Cuomo announced the creation of a State Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities yesterday and appointed 21 members - ''the best and brightest minds and experience we could find in this state.''

title: ROZELLE SUSPENDS SCHLICHTER FOR BETS
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League suspended Art Schlichter indefinitely yesterday because the 23-year-old quarterback had gambled on N.F.L. games and other sporting events.

title: ENTERPRISE OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 30.
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $629,330 for the quarter and 6 months due to the early settlement of long- term employment contracts and the writeoff of furniture and fixtures associated with moving of the corporate headquarters from Los Angeles to Houston. c-The company said that due to the acquisition of R.H. Gow Inc. in October 1982 comparable year-ago results are not meaningful.

title: Ukrainian Street Fair
description: A Ukrainian street fair with music, food and crafts will be held this weekend, rain or shine, on Seventh Street, between Second and Third Avenues. The fair, the seventh sponsored by St. George's Ukrainian Church, will feature continuous entertainment and traditional crafts such as psanky (colored eggs) and embroidered goods. Hours are 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. today and 1 to 11 P.M. tomorrow.

title: New York Day by Day
description: With a Spanish Accent

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $430,000 for the quarter and 6 months and an extraordinary gain of $5,752,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of surplus land. c-Net loss.

title: GREAT WEST STEEL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Mexico Is Chosen As World Cup Host
description: Soccer's world governing body awarded the 1986 World Cup tournament to Mexico today, bringing a barrage of criticism from the United States and Canada.

title: JERSEY G.O.P. HAILS REAGAN VISIT TODAY
description: President Reagan's decision to speak at the commencement exercises at Seton Hall University on Saturday is being viewed by New Jersey Republican leaders as a sign the President recognizes the importance of the state to his re-election, should he decide to seek a second term next year.

title: CANADA PERMANENT INCOME reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Money Supply Up $7 Billion; Sharp Jump Causes Rise In Bond Rates
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported a $7 billion increase in the nation's money supply for the week ended May 11, far above the $4 billion rise that many analysts had predicted.

title: Occidental Seeking Canada-Cities Unit
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that its 80 percent owned Canadian unit had agreed to acquire Canada-Cities Service Ltd. for about $295 million (United States).

title: The Region; Biegenwald Denies Camden Slaying
description: Richard F. Biegenwald, a convicted murderer linked to five deaths since his parole two years ago, pleaded not guilty today to the one killing with which he has formally been charged.

title: News Analysis
description: Two years into Socialism, the French have begun to discuss the idea that their economic difficulties are whittling away at the country's place in world affairs.

title: STEINBRENNER AID TO F.B.I. INDICTED
description: George M. Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, made the facilities and personnel of his shipbuilding company available to the Government in a national security matter in the 1970's, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,749,000 for the quarter and $7,410,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $4,103,000 for the quarter and $7,527,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago results restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: New York Day by Day
description: The Legendary Race To Govern S.I.

title: UNDERWRITING BY BANKS TO BE TOPIC OF HEARING
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the securities business said today that he opposes a proposal by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to allow statechartered banks to underwrite corporate securities.

title:
Patents;
Method of Measuring Occupants of Spacecraft
description: A method of determining changes in the sizes of the arms and legs of occupants of spacecraft was patented this week for NASA. Pramode K. Bhagat and Vic C. Wu of a research laboratory at the University of Kentucky in Lexington got patent 4,383,533 under a contract with NASA.

title: The City; Jury to Receive CBS Case Monday
description: The jury is scheduled to begin deliberations Monday in the trial of Donald Nash, who is accused of slaying a Federal witness and three CBS employees who tried to come to her aid.

title: FURS AVIZOU'S WAY, FROM RABBIT TO FOX
description: Halfway into this season's fur showings, when audiences could be expected to be somewhat blase about yet another mink coat, Revillon celebrated its 260th anniversary. Nothing was spared: luncheon at the Pierre for 500 behatted retail customers, store buyers and press; Peter Duchin and his band, and special effects a Broadway show might have envied. And, of course, there were the furs themselves: 110 styles designed by Jean-Paul Avizou, who threw out ideas by the handful.

title: ARGENTINA ACCUSES PERONIST FACTION OF REBEL TIES
description: The Argentine military Government accused the major leftist faction of the Peronist party today of working closely with exiled leftist Montonero guerrillas.

title: FEMINIST PHILANTHROPY COMES INTO ITS OWN
description: In the last decade a small but growing number of foundations have been established by and for women, to redress what many women perceive as years of philanthropic neglect of projects relevant to them.

title: LACKAWANNA BLUES
description: Governor Cuomo, who has kept a diary since 1972, on April 29 visited Lackawanna, N.Y. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced in December that it would lay off 7,300 of its 8,600 employees and end basic steelmaking at its plant there. Here are excerpts from Mr. Cuomo's diary entry of April 30.

title: 2 NUNS STABBED TO DEATH IN JERUSALEM
description: Two nuns - a mother and her daughter - were found stabbed to death today at a convent of the Russian Orthodox Church in Jerusalem, and the Israeli authorities ordered a special inquiry into the slayings.

title:
Patents;
Acting Head Serving At the Patent Office
description: Gerald J. Mossinghoff, who headed the Commerce Department's Patent and Trademark Office as commissioner since 1981, has now been made Acting Deputy Secretary of Commerce, succeeding Guy W. Fiske, who resigned. In the absence of Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who is in China, Mr. Mossinghoff is also Acting Secretary of Commerce.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Gunman Kills Girl in Oregon
description: A 7-year-old girl was killed and her mother, sister and brother were wounded by a man who flagged down their car and opened fire after demanding the car, the police said today.

title:
Patents;
Automatic Telephone Silencer
description: WASHINGTON ACONNECTICUT patent attorney got one of his own this week, for an automatic telephone silencer. It can be set to stop the telephone from ringing during sleeping hours or through any other period when quiet is desired.

title: WESTGROWTH PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: 4 MORE OFFICIALS RESIGN FROM E.P.A.
description: Four top officials of the Environmental Protection Agency submitted their resignations today, reportedly at the request of the agency's new Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including income of $39,087,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: VIDEO-GAMING CENTRAL AMERICA
description: In his speech before the joint session of Congress on Central America, President Reagan presented a fact that most Americans would like to forget: We will spend some $6 billion worth of quarters on video games this year.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STABILIZED APARTMENTS SHOW AN INCREASE OF 2.6% IN COSTS
description: The costs of operating rent-stabilized apartment buildings in New York increased by 2.6 percent last year, the second-lowest rise in the 15-year history of the system, according to a study presented yesterday to the Rent Guidelines Board.

title: BEWARE THE MOVIE MUNCHERS
description: Being a movie fan from way back, I went off last week to see Paul Newman in ''The Verdict,'' only to wind up with chow mein in my hair, soda pop on my skirt and popcorn in my shoes.

title: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Indian Militants
description: A Federal district judge dismissed all charges against Dennis Banks and other American Indian Movement leaders today in a seven-and-a-half-year-old firearms and explosives case.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $902,000 for the latest first quarter and $61,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: CITY ACTS TO BLOCK TUDOR CITY SURVEY
description: A major New York City developer has begun sending city legal forms to residents of Tudor City asking who is occupying each apartment and requesting notarized answers. The city announced yesterday that it would seek an injunction to block the mailings.

title: ACCIDENTS DELAY TRAFFIC IN TUNNELS TO MANHATTAN
description: Accidents caused delays through much of the day yesterday in the Lincoln Tunnel and blocked traffic in the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for more than an hour during the morning rush, authorities said.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAMBLER MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $240,000.

title: CONDUITS-AMHERST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago sales includes sales of a discontinued division.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know, they say there are only two places where Communism works: in heaven where they don't need it, and in hell where they've already got it.'' - President Reagan. (1:6.)

title: Greece Protests to U.S.  Over Airspace Violations
description: Greece delivered a strong protest to the United States today against what it called violations by American and Turkish aircraft over the Aegean.

title: Medical Students End Strike
description: France's 35,000 medical students voted today to end a three-month strike after the Government agreed to amend medical education provisions of a bill changing the university system. Other students scheduled more demonstrations for next Tuesday.

title: Salazar Denies Offer of Payment
description: Alberto Salazar has denied published reports quoting him as saying that prominent officials of The Athletics Congress offered him $60,000 if he would run in the Los Angeles Marathon this year, the congress announced today.

title: The Region; 2 Youths Sentenced In Jersey Drowning
description: Two Hopatcong, N.J., teen-agers were sentenced today to seven years in prison for the drowning death of a boy they had prevented from climbing out of Lake Hopatcong.

title: PHILIP FRADKIN, 61, MUSICAL DIRECTOR
description: Philip Fradkin, musical director of ''42d Street,'' the Broadway musical, was struck and killed by a hit-and-run motorist early yesterday morning while trying to get a taxicab at 11th Avenue and 57th Street in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SUMMIT OILFIELD SERVICES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: WHEN HUNTER AND PARK AVE. WERE YOUNG
description: To the Editor: In chiding government for ''selecting notoriously prime land for operations it could conduct on less valuable sites'' ('' Tax Exemptions Can Be Prudent,'' editorial May 5), you cited the location of Hunter College on Park Avenue as a ''venerable but obvious example.'' Venerable, yes; obvious example, absolutely not. v. hen the Normal School (Hunter's precursor) moved to 68th Street and Park Avenue more than a century ago, Park Avenue was not prime urban real estate but a semi-rural backwater.

title: UNICORP CANADA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including special gains of $1,060,000 for the latest first quarter and $9 million for the year-ago first quarter on the sale of investment in First Union Real Estate Investments. Year-ago results have been restated to include operations of San Francisco Real Estate Investors on a consolidated basis.

title: CADILLAC FAIRVIEW CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
DOKES RETAINS TITLE; WITHERSPOON SUFFERS FIRST LOSS
description: Tim Witherspoon, a 25-year-old former South Philadelphia High School football player who went into boxing to work out his anger and frustrations on a heavy bag, tonight came close to one of the great upsets in the sport.

title: 16 KILLED, 190 HURT IN PRETORIA BLAST AT MILITARY OFFICE
description: A car bomb exploded today outside the headquarters of the South African Air Force in Pretoria, killing at least 16 people and wounding more than 190.

title: DOKES RETAINS TITLE; DRAW FOILS WEAVER IN REMATCH
description: Michael Dokes, who needed only 63 seconds to win the title, had to struggle through 15 rounds of Mike Weaver's solid punching in their rematch tonight to gain a draw and retain the World Boxing Association heavyweight title.

title: Scouting; Ryan Is Unfazed
description: When the New York Jets drafted the quarterback Ken O'Brien on the first round of last month's National Football League draft, Pat Ryan, the backup for Richard Todd since 1978, said he wasn't worried.

title: TWO CENTS TOO MANY FOR A PACK OF CIGARETTES
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, MAY 21, 1983; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve reported a $7 billion increase in the money supply for the week ended May 11, far above the $4 billion predicted by analysts. As a result, bond prices fell sharply, bringing their total decline over the last two weeks to about five points, and yields rose, by more than 0.2 percent in the case of three-month Treasury bills. Some experts predicted the Fed would tighten bank reserves in a bid to check the money supply's growth. (Page 37.)

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Sports People; Clerc Disqualified
description: Jose-Luis Clerc, the Argentine tennis star, has been disqualified from the Italian Open, a Grand Prix tournament in Rome, after he stalked off the court during a doubles match Thursday. The incident, which occurred when Clerc disagreed with a line call, caused an immediate default of the doubles match and led officials to disqualify Clerc, the second-seeded player, from the singles.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WALTER REUTHER'S GHOST
description: The shadow of Walter Reuther still hovers over the United Automobile Workers 13 years after he died in an airplane crash. His 24 years as president of the union, his success at the bargaining table and his forceful personality left an impression on many union members that has been transformed by memory into something approaching deification.

title: French Arms Plan Adopted
description: The National Assembly today adopted a five-year, $112 billion defense program by a vote of 330 to 152.

title: BRASCADE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Sports People; Lights for Cubs?
description: After almost half a century of night baseball, the Chicago Cubs have apparently decided that the phenomenon may not be a passing fad. According to the club's general manager, Dallas Green, Wrigley Field, the last holdout in the major leagues, may get lights as early as next year - but only if the club's prospects improve. ''We're going to have to make a case to the owners that this club is ready to contend before lights could be put in,'' said Green as engineers began making a feasibility study of the stadium to see if lights could be installed.

title: ASTRONOMERS FIND RAPIDLY THROBBING PULSAR
description: A pulsar throbbing 163 times a second has been discovered between the constellations Vulpecula, the Little Fox, and Cygnus, the Swan. It is the second of these perplexing, high-speed pulsars to be found.

title: Talks Continue On Braniff Plan
description: Negotiations to get Braniff International flying again under new management continued yesterday in deep secrecy. The airline went into bankruptcy proceedings a year ago with $1 billion in debts.

title: UNITED SISCOE MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,986,000. c-Net loss after a $3,825,000 loss from discontinued coal operations of an affiliate.

title: Letter: On Chemical Testing; How Toxicology Labs Should Function
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; Youth Jobless Rate Rises to 32% in City
description: The unemployment rate for 16- to 19-year-olds in New York City was 32.5 percent for the first quarter of 1983, compared with 25.3 percent a year earlier, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The national teen-age jobless rate edged up from 23.5 percent to 24.6 percent over the same period, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner.

title: Going Out Guide
description: BRIDGE WALK

title: A. & P.'S WORKER-MANAGERS
description: At each of the Super Fresh supermarkets that have been opening here at a rate of one a week since last July, workers earn about 20 percent less than their counterparts at competing supermarkets. In return, however, they have a hand in store management, and they may get to divide up about 1 percent of a store's gross sales.

title: The Region; June 1 Deadline Set In Jersey Car Tests
description: A Federal judge today ordered New Jersey to resume the auto-emissions testing of all registered automobiles by June 1.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: Founder of Scientology Files Legal Declaration
description: A Superior Court judge said today that he was ''convinced'' that L. Ron Hubbard, a science fiction writer and founder of the Church of Scientology, was alive despite claims that he was dead or mentally incompetent.

title: 'SPACEHUNTER,' ADVENTURES IN 3-D
description: ''Spacehunter,'' which opened yesterday at Loews State and other theaters, has attracted more experienced personnel than most 3-D movies do. And, unlike most films of its genre, it attempts to do more than send bats and snakes and yo-yos hurtling from the screen. It attempts so much that it will probably remind you of at least a dozen other pirate, gladiator, horror and science-fiction stories, because its own plot is none too distinctive and is seriously overcrowded.

title: 3 MANUFACTURERS IGNORED UNFAVORABLE SAFETY TEST OF CHEMICAL
description: Three manufacturers seeking Federal approval of a swimming pool disinfectant deliberately ignored a study of the chemical in which test animals died of kidney stones, according to a report by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: BRIEFING
description: Free but Sharp Advice

title: The Region; Waitress's Killing Denied by Suspect
description: A 34-year-old Morristown handyman, a convicted murderer, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he murdered Deirdre O'Brien, a 25-year-old waitress, and dumped her body along Interstate 80 in Warren County last December.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Net income after loss on discontinued operations. c-After loss on discontinued operaMtions.

title: Pope Begins Visit to Milan
description: Amid driving rain and heavy security, Pope John Paul II today began the first papal visit to Milan since Pope Martin V came here in 1418.

title: ALLEN HURLS 6-HITTER TO DOWN DODGERS
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers strutted into Shea Stadium last night with the best record in the major leagues and slunk away looking like the worst team in the majors.

title: Sports People; Berry in for Berry
description: After a month-long search for a successor to Bob Berry, the Montreal Canadiens' coach who was demoted to a scouting position after the team failed to get past the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, the club's new general manager, Serge Savard, has finally found his man - Bob Berry. ''After analyzing the Canadiens' play last season,'' Savard said, ''I became confident that Bob Berry was a very competent coach and the best man for our club this season.'' In addition to Berry's reappointment, Savard announced the signing of Jacques Lemaire and Jacques Laperriere, former Canadiens, as assistant coaches.

title: Changes at Volvo
description: AB Volvo said that its chairman, Anders Wall, would resign his post, effective Sept.1. Pehr Gyllenhammar, president and chief executive officer, would take over as chairman, while Mr. Wall would remain on the board as one of the vice chairmen. Mr. Gyllenhammar will leave the post of managing director of AB Volvo and be replaced by Hakan Frisinger.

title: Quackery in Chile
description: When Chile was booming, some thought it a good advertisement for authoritarianism-cum-monetarism. The authoritarianism survives: troops swarmed through a Santiago shantytown in typical fashion last week and seized 1,000 alleged troublemakers. But there is no more talk about economic miracles. The country is sinking, and a regime that took credit for a boom now tries to duck the blame for bust.

title: JAMES STEWART, AT 75, GETS HERO'S WELCOME
description: James Stewart celebrated his 75th birthday today with his wife, Gloria, and hundreds of friends and fans at a party in the town where the lanky star was born. His father was the owner of a hardware store here.

title: PRESIDENT ATTACKS CRITICS OF HIS PLAN FOR LATIN AMERICA
description: President Reagan, saying there were dangers in a ''Soviet-Cuban-Nicaraguan axis,'' warned Congressional critics of his Latin-American policy today that they risked leaving the hemisphere ''immobilized by fear or apathy.''

title: CORRIDA OILS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ST LAWRENCE CEMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CMI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Dow Drops by 1.35; Week's Fall Is 28.73
description: The stock market ended its worst week in more than six months yesterday with a small decline in slower trading. At the conclusion of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.35 points, to 1,190.02. For the week, the average, which is made up of 30 leading issues, tumbled 28.73 points; it was the largest weekly drop in the blue-chip indicator since the five days ended Oct. 29, when it declined by 39.74 points.

title: Estimates On G.N.P.
description: The estimates released Thursday by the Commerce Department on the gross national product for the first quarter of 1983 were as follows, with all dollar figures in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates: CURRENT DOLLARS Last Pct. Quarter Chg. Gross National Product $3,170.9 +8.3 Consumption 2,054.2 +4.7 Business Investment 338.1 -0.4 Inventory change -37.3 Housing 120.5 +99.4 Net exports 19.0 Government 676.4 - 0.2 Memo: Final sales* 3,208.2 + 6.7 1972 DOLLARS Gross National Product $1,486.2 + 2.5 Consumption 973.1 + 2.6 Business Investment 163.1 + 5.6 Inventory change -16.1 Housing 49.7 +79.6 Net exports 23.5 Government 292.9 - 8.5 Memo: Final sales* 1,502.3 + 0.9 Memo: G.N.P. price delfator + 5.7 Memo: Fixed-weight price index + 3.2 * G.N.P. less inventory change. n.a. Not applicable Source: Commerce Department

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a dance review in Weekend yesterday omitted a sentence in describing the Wednesday performance of George Balanchine's ''Episodes'' by the New York City Ballet. Referring to the ballet's closing section, it should have read, ''To applaud seemed an intrusion, so eloquently did Maria Calegari and Adam Luders dance it.''

title: Bank Waives Marx Damages
description: The Bank of America agreed today to waive $250,000 in punitive damages it won from Erin Fleming, Groucho Marx's companion, rather than face a possible retrial of its battle with her over the comedian's estate. A judge said she must still pay $221,000.

title: DICKERMAN HOLLISTER
description: Dickerman Hollister, a retired partner in the New York City law firm of Choate, Regan, Davis & Hollister, died Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut following a stroke. He was a resident of Greenwich and was 72 years old.

title: CHINESE, IN RARE TREAT, DEVOUR NEWS OF HIJACKING
description: Readers of People's Daily, accustomed to a diet of communiques, statistics and ideological exhortations, may have been jolted this month by the rare appearance of a story about a real event.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
POLICE INQUIRY FINDS OFFICERS AT FAULT IN A SUSPECT'S DEATH
description: Five white police officers have been found guilty by the Milwaukee Fire and Police Commission of breaking police department rules by failing to give first aid to a 22-year-old black who died after he was subdued when he was arrested.

title: Bridge:; Quarterfinal Play Today In Grand National Teams
description: The Grand National team championship continues today at the New York Hilton Hotel with eight teams squaring off in head-to-head quarterfinal matches. After two full days of play this weekend, two teams will qualify for the District 24 final, to be played June 5.

title: Voodoo Education
description: Frances Vazquez is pleased and honored that President Reagan, at his news conference this week, cited Morris High School in the south Bronx as an example of a public school whose downward slide had been turned around by ''leadership'' and a ''return to the basics'' - all of which, he said, can be done ''without money.''

title: HOWARD HAUSMAN, EX-CONNECTICUT AIDE AND HEAD OF G.O.P.
description: Howard E. Hausman, a former Republican state chairman in Connecticut and former chairman of the State Public Utilities Commission, died of a heart attack Thursday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in New Britain and Madison, Conn.

title: AUTOMATED MEDICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $25,000.

title: HORNBECK OFFSHORE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $81,000 for the quarter and $211,000 for the year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Air France Proposal
description: Air France today proposed a capital restructuring to cover part of its loss last year of 791.8 million francs, the current equivalent of $106.6 million. The Governmentowned airline proposed paying 818.1 million francs of debt by cutting the nominal value of each of its shares to 22 francs from 40, thereby reducing its capital to 999.9 million francs from 1,818 million. Fresh capital totaling 737 million francs, through the issue of 33.5 million shares at 22 francs each, is planned mainly by converting Government loans into shares.

title: No Piecemeal Conrail Sale
description: The United States Railway Association made the official determination today that Conrail is profitable, clearing the way for a sale of the 15,000-mile Northeast-Middle Western railroad in one piece to private enterprise.

title: REDFERN FOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for a change in accounting.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines said it planned to start service between London and Newark on May 26, subject to the British Government's approval. The company said it would charge $149 one way and $439 ''premium class.'' It said it would fly five round trips a week between Newark and Gatwick airports.

title: Carlton Passes Johnson Mark
description: The San Diego Padres defeated the Philadelphia Phillies and Steve Carlton, 5-0, tonight, but Carlton passed Walter Johnson's strikeout total.

title: AVANTI'S LUXURY CAR: GAMBLE PAYING OFF
description: Though Stephen Blake says he went into ''hock up to his eyebrows'' to acquire the Avanti Motor Corporation last October, his gamble seems to be paying off. After an expansion, the company is beginning to meet demand for the American luxury car.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 28. 1. Don King promoted the first heavyweight boxing title doubleheader in history. At stake were the heavyweight titles of the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DIGITECH LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JACOBS GROUP STARTS BID TO OUST KAISER BOARD
description: An investor group led by Irwin L. Jacobs began a proxy campaign today to replace directors of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, a day after the company broke off talks on a takeover offer from the Minneapolis-based group.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET BOMBS CIVILIANS IN AFGHANSTAN
description: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of killing hundreds and probably thousands of Afghan civilians through a series of bombing raids in Afghanistan in recent weeks.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ed Lynch gets the start for the Mets, providing them something of a bonus. Not only has Lynch been pitching well, but he also has 3 hits in 10 times at bat and has driven in 3 runs. That's a big change from 1982, when he failed to get a hit in his last 37 times at the plate. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. Billy Martin's return is expected to attract 40,000 fans for an afternoon game. (Television - Sports@Channel, 4 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.) Royals vs. Chicago White Sox, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Golf Chrysler-Plymouth Charity Classic, second round, at the Upper Montclair Country Club, Clifton, N.J., 8 A.M. Amy Alcott is trying to become the sixth L.P.G.A. player to reach $1 million in career earnings.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S SPEECH ON THREAT TO LATIN AMERICA
description: Following is the advance text of President Reagan's speech today in Miami to an audience of Cuban-Americans, as made available by the White House:

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Angola Leader Leaves Soviet
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola ended a five-day tour of the Soviet Union today and joined the Kremlin in praising the Cuban military forces in his country. Both countries rejected United States and South African efforts to link a Cuban troop pullout to granting independence to South-West Africa.

title: U.S. SEES QUESTIONS FOR 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Questions raised in criminal and civil investigations have led the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's staff to conclude that it can no longer vouch for the ability and integrity of the operators of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column yesterday incorrectly described George Mikan's involvement in a complaint by Will County authorities in Illinois. According to the authorities, a nursing-home bill for care of Mr. Mikan's mother is owed by his brother Ed. George Mikan was involved only because the county sought information from family members about any assets that might be used to pay the bill.

title: Waste Company
description: Waste Management Inc. said at its annual meeting that it expected 1983 to be a record year but that second-quarter earnings would be below expectations of analysts, who had been forecasting earnings of 65 to 75 cents a share, up from 61 cents a share in the second quarter of 1982.

title: N.A.A.C.P. OFFICIALS SAY DIRECTOR HAS BEEN INDEFINITELY SUSPENDED
description: Benjamin L. Hooks has been indefinitely suspended as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People by the organization's chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, members of the association's board said yesterday.

title: OF TENANTS, LIVE-IN FRIENDS AND LANDLORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $50,921 from discontinued operations.

title: GAINED BASKETBALL HALL OF FAME
description: Clair Bee, one of the most acclaimed college basketball coaches of his time, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Cleveland at the age of 87. Mr. Bee earned fame as the Long Island University coach during a time when college basketball grew from a sport played before a handful of people in school gymnasiums to the capacity crowds of more than 18,000 at Madison Square Garden.

title: 50 IN CONGRESS TRY BAGELS AND KOCH
description: ''New York is the greatest city in the world,'' Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said yesterday. ''If America didn't have a New York, it would have to create one.''

title: Tilling the Toilers
description: Since this seems to be the season for abusing the American school system, let's put aside the nonsense about its producing too many academic nincompoops and go immediately to its betrayal of American youth.

title: NEW TERRITORY FOR EXPLORER IN FICTION
description: Having focused on Africa, where he lived as a boy, in his critically praised novels ''A Good Man in Africa'' and ''An Ice-Cream War,'' William Boyd has started exploring a new territory for his next novel.

title: Books of the Times
description: LETTERS OF ARCHIBALD MacLEISH, 1907-82. Edited by R.H. Winnick. 471 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $20.

title: WIFE OF SAKHAROV SAYS HE'S IN PERIL
description: Yelena G. Bonner held a sidewalk news conference today to warn that her husband, Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, would die unless the Soviet authorities relented and allowed him to return to Moscow for urgent medical treatment.

title: Madrid Court Overturns SS Officer's Extradition
description: An appeals court has overturned a court ruling that granted an extradition request for a 62-year-old former Dutch SS officer.

title: BLACK MINISTER STALLING INQUIRY, THE POLICE SAY
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that a department investigation into allegations that a black Baptist minister had been beaten by two white police officers who reputedly made abusive remarks about his race and religion had been ''stymied'' by the minister's refusal to cooperate.

title: Page Beats Snipes on Decision
description: In a World Boxing Council heavyweight bout, Greg Page, its top-ranked contender, was awarded a unanimous 12-round decision tonight over Renaldo Snipes, the No. 2-rated contender.

title: Holier Than Himself
description: President Reagan is a tax-cutter, and to hear him talk about it there's none better. He pushed through a mammoth three-year tax cut within months of taking office and would prefer that you forget the rest of his tax record. Now, he says, the ''deficit doctors'' in Congress are ''getting ready to operate on your wallet.'' Strong stuff, and it doesn't hurt his standing with the voters one little bit. But in fact, Mr. Reagan is also a tax-raiser; indeed, he has to be. That makes his new tough anti-tax line both misleading and unwise.

title: Sports People; 'Statesman' Perkins
description: Not every football coach gets a chance to address a joint session of a state legislature, but then, not every coach is in charge of a program like the one at Alabama, a state university.

title: G.M. Chairman Sees Big Profit
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation said that he anticipates the corporation will report a profit of more than $2 billion in 1983.

title: 'Waiting for Spring' - and a Family
description: Bruce is 15, and wants to work for a computer company ... Yvette is 11, doesn't like school, but does like boys ... Michael is almost 4 but cannot talk ... Nicqua, 4, is severely retarded ... Martin, 3, wears scars of physical abuse ... Shavine, 11, offers a line of a poem she wrote: ''Waiting for spring is an impossible thing.''

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U.S. IS CONDEMNED OVER SALVADORANS
description: The United States' refusal to grant political asylum and temporary residential status to Salvadorans has stirred a wave of letters and protests from members of Congress and church groups, who say the lives of many of the Salvadorans would be in danger if they returned home.

title: BY SALLY BEDELL
description: NBC News will conduct an extensive research study to determine why its 31-year-old ''Today'' show, once the dominant morning program, has slipped steadily in the ratings over the last year. Among the many factors being tested will be the popularity of the show's anchors, Bryant Gumbel and Jane Pauley.

title: MUSIC: SPECULUM GROUP
description: Though the music played by Speculum Musicae at Symphony Space on Wednesday night was quite varied, the overall impression was of lyricism - a songful exuberance tempered in many pieces with something resembling introspection and nostalgia.

title: SOVIET JOURNAL PRINTS A CRITICISM BY POLES OF WARSAW REGIME
description: New indications appeared today of Soviet dissatisfaction with the policies of the Polish Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss. Sales figures exclude sales of leased departments.

title: Cities Service Co.  Backed in Oil Suit
description: A Federal judge has given the Cities Service Company a first-round victory in its $3 billion breach-ofcontract suit against the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: PALMIERI'S LATEST 'ADVENTURE'
description: Victor Palmieri and his cadre of management and financial specialists spent eight years helping to bring Penn Central out of bankruptcy; today the one-time railroad is a thriving diversified corporation with $800 million in assets.

title: U.S. Soldier Killed in Sinai
description: A United States soldier was killed and another was injured when their water truck overturned on a road in Egyptian Sinai, the Multinational Force and Observers announced today. The peacekeeping force said Spec. 4 Junior E. Hudgins, 23 years old, of Anniston, Ala., was killed and a second soldier, whose identity was not released, was hurt in the accident Thursday afternoon.

title: Latino Festival to Open With Farce About Alien
description: ''Green Card Blues,'' a farce about the experiences of an illegal alien, will open the 1983 Spring Festival of the Latino Playwrights of Henry Street Settlement Monday.

title: OUTSIDER JOINS HALLMARK AS A SENIOR EXECUTIVE
description: Hallmark Cards Inc., in a surprise move, today named Irvine O. Hockaday Jr., president and chief executive of Kansas City Southern Industries, as executive vice president. The appointment appears to put Mr. Hockaday, who is 44 years old, in line for the presidency of the privately held company, which has not brought outsiders into high-level management positions before.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: News Analysis
description: The European Economic Community has failed in at least one of its major objectives: to shield the economies of its member nations from the effects of economic fluctuations in the United States.

title: Scouting; To the Point
description: The fact that the Cosmos won a game by the score of 5-2 last week got Coach Julio Mazzei talking about the oft-heard criticism that soccer is too low-scoring a sport.

title: Index; International
description: Notes on China: Hijacking is big news 2 Argentine military accuses leftwing Peronists of rebel ties 3 Sakharov's wife says he is in danger of dying of a heart ailment 3 Two Russian Orthodox nuns are stabbed to death in Jerusalem 3 Around the World 5 U.S. criticized over refusal to grant asylum to Salvadorans 5 Government/Politics U.S. and Catholic group plan alien amnesty program 9 Reagan Seton Hall visit today linked to re-election bid 26 50 members of House of Representatives tour New York City 27 Washington Talk Briefing 10 Working profile: Edward C. Schmults 10 General Around the Nation 8 James Stewart, at 75, gets hometown birthday party 8 Reporter's Notebook: At the Auto Workers convention 12 Coast Guard drops its case against skipper of the Karen E 26 Minister is said to hamper investigation of brutality charge 27 News Analysis John Vinocur on France's declining fortunes 5 Robert A. Bennett on ties that bind Common Market to U.S. 37 PARADE TOMORROW The Solidarity Sunday March for Soviet Jewry begins at noon tomorrow, moving down Fifth Avenue from 64th Street to 47th, then east to First Avenue, where a rally will start about 1 P.M. in Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. Arts/Entertainment Spoleto Festival U.S.A., opens seventh season 29 New territory for William Boyd, explorer in fiction 29 ''Letters of Archibald MacLeish, 1907-82'' is reviewed 30 Edward Duke's one-man show, ''Jeeves Takes Charge'' 30 ''Bill Cosby - 'Himself,' '' film of performances, opens 31 NBC News to study drop in ratings of its ''Today'' program 48 Style Consumer Saturday 7 Feminist philanthropy comes into its own 7 Fur Avizou's way, from rabbit to fox 7 De Gustibus 7 Health/Science Government rejects plan to repair defective X-ray scanners 8 Three firms ignored unfavorable safety tests of chemical 8 Obituaries Clair Bee, former L.I.U. basketball coach 21 Philip Fradkin, musical director of ''42d Street'' 21 Howard Hausman, former Re- publican leader of Connecticut 21 Sports Pages Holmes takes split decision from Witherspoon to keep title 33 Dokes draws with Weaver and retains W.B.A. crown 33 Rozelle suspends Schlichter indefinitely for gambling 33 Mexico is awarded the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament 33 Judge overrules commission on use of drug in Preakness 33 George Vecsey on the Alibi Breakfast at Pimlico 34 Lakers beat Spurs, 101-100, to gain N.B.A. final 35 Mets top Dodgers, 4-0 35 Nettles declines chance for a rest at third base 35 Features/Notes New York Day by Day 26 About New York 27 Saturday News Quiz 28 Going Out Guide 31 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp. said it expects 17 to 19 percent earnings growth in 1983, and for each of the next several years.

title: A'S SCORE 3 IN FIRST, TOP YANKEES BY 8-4
description: The Yankees' three-game winning streak ended tonight against the A's in a noisy ''Billy's Back'' atmosphere. Oakland defeated the Yankees, 8-4, before 38,007, the A's largest crowd of the season. Billy Martin, who was dismissed last season after three years as manager of the A's, was greeted with a noisy ovation when he entered the dugout from the field entrance before the game. He remained there until the eighth inning when he was met again by cheers when he removed Rudy May, the fourth of five Yankee pitchers.

title: NEW YORK BLUE CROSS RAISES RATES OF 5 MILLION SUBSCRIBERS 16 TO 21%
description: Monthly rate increases of 16.5 to 21.8 percent for more than four million individual and small-group subscribers of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York and 730,000 elderly Medicare subscribers have been approved by the State Insurance Superintendent, his department said yesterday.

title: LATIN ENVOY NOMINEE SAYS U.S. CAN'T IMPOSE ACCORD
description: President Reagan's choice to serve as special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, told a Senate committee today that the United States would try to bring opposing groups in the region to the bargaining table but ''cannot impose'' a settlement or act as a negotiator.

title: Tandem Driver Cleared By a Connecticut Judge
description: Charges against the first trucker to be cited under Connecticut's ban on tandem-trailer trucks were dismissed today.

title: Lower British Inflation
description: Britain's annual rate of inflation fell to a 15-year low of 4 percent in April, down from 4.6 percent in March, the Employment Department said today. The rate was the lowest since April 1968.

title: Sports of the Times; PREAKNESS WORDS AND DEEDS
description: BALTIMORE T his afternoon the horses will be paraded in front of the public for the 108th running of the Preakness Stakes. Yesterday it was the humans' turn. It is called the Alibi Breakfast.

title: About New York; ONCE UPON A STORYTELLING CONTEST
description: The best moment in the Sixth Annual Citywide Storytelling Festival came when the winners were announced. The worst moment came when the winners were announced, too.

title: PETRO-SUN INTERATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BILINGUAL PATH TO GOOD MENTAL HEALTH
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Day by Day
description: U.N. Blood Bank, Model for the World

title: AN UNSETTLING START FOR GOLF CO-LEADER
description: Chris Johnson, a 25-year-old professional golfer from Arizona, discovered at 8 o'clock this morning that her 1983 silver Mazda sports car was missing from the parking lot of her hotel in Hasbrouck Heights.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW JOBS DEVELOPING IN OLD INDUSTRIAL AREAS
description: For decades the Youngstown area was at the center of the American steel industry. Furnaces and finishing mills lined the Mahoning River for 25 miles and were the bulwark of the economies of such communities as Warren, Niles, McDonald, Girard, Struthers and Youngstown.

title: SPOLETO FESTIVAL U.S.A. OPENS SEVENTH SEASON
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. opened its seventh season here this afternoon, the start of a 17-day event that will feature three operas, including Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' directed by the British film maker Ken Russell, five dance companies, three theater groups and the Pittsburgh Symphony.

title: U.S. AND A CATHOLIC GROUP SET ALIEN AMNESTY PROGRAM
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service, with the help of the United States Catholic Conference, has made extensive plans for a nationwide amnesty program in which illegal aliens could apply for legal status.

title: Cadillac Fairview Sale
description: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation, one of Canada's largest real estate developers, said it had accepted offers for about 62 percent of the $1.9 billion of assets it put up for sale on Feb.28, 1982. The Toronto-based company said the gross proceeds of the sale would be $1.5 billion and the net proceeds would be between $25 million and $50 million. Fairview also reported that its net income in the year ended last Feb.28 fell 51.5 percent, to $12.6 million.

title: FALL IN MEXICAN OUTPUT
description: The austerity program that Mexico adopted to help pay its foreign debts could result in a 2 percent to 5 percent decline in the nation's economy this year, Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog said yesterday.

title: Scouting; Richardson Pact To Be Discussed
