description: The attorney for Michael Ray Richardson of the Nets said yesterday that in July he would seek an extension of his client's contract. Pat Healy said that Richardson, a former all-star guard, has two years remaining on a contract that had been renegotiated with the Golden State Warriors last October, after Richardson was traded from the Knicks.

title: OF TENANTS, LIVE IN FRIENDS AND LANDLORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: MILWAUKEE (AL) - Sent Pete Ladd, p itcher, to Vancouver (AAA); removed J erry Augustine, pitcher, from the dis- a bled list. MONTREAL (NL) - Activated B rad Mills, third baseman, from the 1 5-day supplemental disabled list; d esignated Tim Blackwell, catcher, on a ssignment.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a gain of $6.7 million from the sale of real property and an extraordinary gain of $11.5 million from debt restructuring. c-Including a gain of $9.5 million from the sale of real property and an extraordinary gain of $16.7 million from debt restructuring.

title: Thais Expel Russian Envoy
description: A Russian trade official was expelled from Thailand today after being found with what the police said were secret documents on troop positions along the Thai-Cambodian border. The envoy, Viktor Barychev, 47 years old, was a trade official at the Soviet Embassy in Bangkok.

title: Your Money; A New Fund In Mortgages
description: AMUTUAL fund that indirectly invests in conventional home mortgages i s the latest offering among a spate of new business activities of o pen-end investment companies.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MICC INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago figures were restated.

title: Israelis Dismiss Arab Official In West Bank Illness Dispute
description: The Director of Public Health Services on the West Bank, Dr. Hussein Obeid, said today that he had been dismissed from his job because he disagreed with Israeli officials about the causes of a recent wave of illness in the occupied territories.

title: Aide Says Bonn Will Refuse If U.S. Seeks More Reservists
description: West Germany will refuse an expected request by the United States for 80,000 more reservists to support American forces here, Defense Minister Manfred Worner was quoted as saying today.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $44,500 for the quarter and $128,100 for the year.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Robert Bidner, Painter, 53; Bates Agency Art Director
description: Robert Bidner, American realist painter and art director of the Ted Bates advertising agency, died Monday in Brooklyn of a stroke.

title: SHEILA B. MEROLLA WED TO FRANK FIORAMONTI
description: Sheila Brody Merolla, a social worker at the Herbrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Frank R. Fioramonti, assistant attorney general in charge, legislative bureau, New York State Department of Law. Civil Court Judge Kristin Booth Glen perfrmed the ceremony at the bridegroom's office at the World Trade Center.

title: News Analysis
description: The Senate vote for a budget resolution Thursday night marked the emergence of a centrist, bipartisan coalition that is no longer willing to follow President Reagan's lead on fiscal matters.

title: The Region; 7 Are Sentenced In Submarine Case
description: Seven people were sentenced today to jail terms ranging from two months to one year for damaging a nuclear-powered submarine last fall.

title: LAKERS ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: The defending-champion Los Angeles Lakers won the right tonight to face the Philadelphia 76ers in the championship round for the second straight season by defeating the San Antonio Spurs, 101-100, to capture the Western Conference title.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: IT used to be that, with the exception of sentimental favorites, m ost men felt they could afford to toss away their soiled, frayed or d ingy neckties. But with the average price of these accessories n udging the $25 mark, any effort to have neckwear cleaned and r epaired seems more than ever to be money well spent.

title: COURT RULING CLEARS USE OF LASIX IN PREAKNESS
description: A circuit court judge overruled the Maryland Racing Commission today and cleared the way for Desert Wine and Marfa, the second and third choices in Saturday's Preakness Stakes, to run with the benefit of a medication the commission had ruled they could not use.

title: Concert Artists Guild Picks Audition Winners
description: The Concert Artists Guild, which presents young musicians in their New York debuts at Carnegie Recital Hall, has announced the winners of its 32d annual auditions. They are the Beacon Brass Quintet; Helen Campo, flutist; Stephen Drury, pianist; the Ensemble Chanterelle; Thomas Gallant, oboist; John Harle, saxophonist; Mary Ann Hart, mezzo-soprano; Linda Kobler, cellist, and Timothy Landauer, cellist.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Thurs- day incorrectly listed the size of the outflow from New York State savings banks in April. It was $486 million.

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $207,000 for the quarter and $1,350,000 for the year and a gain of $14,968,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of stock in subsidiaries. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $453,000 for the quarter and $1,784,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to segregate operations discontinued during fiscal 1983.

title: New Territory for Explorer in Fiction
description: Having focused on Africa, where he lived as a boy, in his critically praised novels ''A Good Man in Africa'' and ''An Ice-Cream War,'' William Boyd has started exploring a new territory for his next novel.

title: U.S. REJECTS PLAN TO REPAIR DEFECTS IN X-RAY SCANNERS
description: The Food and Drug Administration has given a manufacturer of advanced X-ray machines three weeks to prepare a new plan to fix what the Government says is a defect that sometimes causes the units to emit ''unnecessary and possibly hazardous amounts'' of radiation.

title: Ford Closes Coast Plant, Idling 2,386 Workers
description: The Ford Motor Company's last assembly plant on the West Coast, a sprawling factory where 4 1/2 million vehicles were built, closed today, leaving at least 900 workers looking for jobs.

title: GAZ METROPOLITAN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: Laurence H. Burd Dead at 68; Former Washington Reporter
description: Laurence H. Burd, a former Washington correspondent for The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times and a retired computer analyst for the Federal Reserve Board, died of cardiopulmonary arrest today at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 68 years old.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: After 16 years with the Rangers as a player and assistant coach, Walter Tkaczuk announced that he is retiring to return to his businesses in Ontario. ... Vincent White, a Stanford running back and wide receiver who had been the Jets' sixth-round draft choice, has signed with the Denver Gold of the United States Football League. ... Deborah Sgroi, a student at Ulster County Community College, has become the first recipient of the Red Smith Memorial Scholarship, named for The New York Times columnist who died last year. The scholarship, established at the college by Catskill Canoes, a Kingston, N.Y., company, is to be given annually to a communications media arts major who plans a career in journalism.

title: WHITE HOUSE CRITICIZES SENATE'S 1984 BUDGET
description: The White House today criticized as ''off target'' the Senate's newly passed bipartisan budget for 1984, which calls for tax increases President Reagan considers too high.

title: THE TALK ON CAMPUS: WAR, PEACE, TANNING
description: This is the season of summation on the college campuses. It is the time of mortarboards and final examinations and family station wagons lurching down the Interstate, carrying the children back home.

title: Manila Activists Call For Gandhian Protests
description: Four human rights advocates called today for nonviolent protests in the style of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an effort to force President Ferdinand E. Marcos to relinquish powers to decree capital punishment and indefinite detention for people said to be seditious or subversive.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Operating loss. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $144,895. d-Net loss.

title: Satellite Is Lifted 506 Miles Farther Toward Proper Orbit
description: A communication satellite that is in the wrong orbit was lifted 506 miles higher Thursday in a firing of rockets that lasted nearly three hours.

title: JUSTICE AIDE MAKES MARK AS MEDIATOR
description: There are Democrats on Capitol Hill who are reluctant to say all they think about Edward C. Schmults, the No. 2 official in President Reagan's Justice Department.

title: New York Day by Day
description: The Classical Side Of the Grammy Awards

title: JONES-HOSPLEX SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: James Van Der Zee Services Are Held at Trinity Cemetery
description: The body of James Van Der Zee, the photographer, was entombed yesterday in a crypt at Trinity Cemetery and Mausoleums, at Broadway and 155th Street, the morning after funeral services in Riverside Church.

title: CROWN LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,616,000 for the latest first quarter and a gain of $27,159,000 for the year-ago first quarter from foreign currency translations and other items.

title: CAMEL OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALEKSANDR ZHIROV, SKIER, 24, KILLED IN AUTOMOBILE MISHAP
description: Aleksandr Zhirov, at one time considered the best Alpine skier in the Soviet Union, died today of injuries suffered in an automobile accident, the press agency Tass reported.

title: HOWDEN, D H, & CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title:
Patents;
A Nut That Locks Itself to a Bolt
description: A nut that locks itself to a bolt was patented this week by Richard L. Reynolds, an engineer in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. The inventor, who was granted patent 4,383,787, says the device, trademarked Pac-Nut, has undergone development in the automotive industry and is scheduled to be used on 1984 Ford front-wheel-drive cars. He predicts it will eliminate any adjustment of nut tension in the axles.

title: DURABLES ORDERS RISE 2.4%
description: Orders to American factories for durable goods rose a strong 2.4 percent in April, climbing above the $80 billion level for only the third time in 18 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Brooklyn Boy Dies Of Self-Inflicted Shot
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy who shot himself in the head in what the police believe was a game of Russian roulette died yesterday, authorities said.

title: BONN AIDE BIDS U.S. CUT DEFICITS
description: Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg of West Germany, while critical of Washington's failure to reduce its huge budget deficits, says the Bonn Government does not share the French view that American fiscal and monetary policy is responsible for many of Europe's economic troubles.

title: Arizona Football Put on Probation
description: The University of Arizona's football program has been placed on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for two years, during which the team will be banned from postseason bowl games and television appearances.

title: STAGE: BERTIE AND JEEVES
description: You must have your man run over and purchase a pair for ''Jeeves Takes Charge,'' the one-man (it really seems like many more) show in The Space at City Center. If you have a man, that is, in the way that Bertie Wooster had Jeeves, the nonpareil gentleman's gentleman, the sort that they do not make them like anymore.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON) reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U.S. LIFTS EMBARGO ON SALE OF 75 F-16 FIGHTERS TO ISRAEL
description: President Reagan today formally lifted the yearlong ban on the sale of 75 F-16 jet fighters to Israel. Later, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a group of American Jews that President Reagan would soon invite Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to Washington for talks on future diplomatic steps in the Middle East.

title: CANADA'S AUTO INDUSTRY SEEKS NEW CONTENT LAW
description: Canada's auto industry is asking Parliament for legislation that would require Japanese auto makers to produce domestically some parts for the cars they sell in this country.

title: BILL COSBY'S HIGHLIGHTS
description: ''Bill Cosby - 'Himself,' '' produced, written and directed by Bill Cosby, is a concert film recording the highlights of four performances given by Mr. Cosby at Toronto's Hamilton Place Performing Arts Center in May 1981.

title: Rockwell Contract
description: The Air Force announced that the Rockwell International Corporation will produce 28 Navstar Global Positioning System Block II satellites over a five-year period in a contract valued at $1.2 billion. The navigation system is part of the Administration's $180 billion effort to upgrade the command, control, communications and intelligence network used by the nation's strategic nuclear forces.

title: ABUNDANT NATURAL GAS AWAITING DEVELOPMENT
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Computer Retrieval Of Related Expressions
description: As a computer aid in the preparation of text, two Maryland employees of International Business Machines Corporation have invented a new method of retrieving, from an enormous stored vocabulary, various expressions related to a given subject, including synonyms and antonyms.

title: GREAT EASTERN ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Herald Tribune Plant
description: The International Herald Tribune said today that it planned to open a printing operation near The Hague in October to serve readers in northern Europe. The plant will be the sixth for the daily, which is published in Paris and printed in Paris, London, Zurich, Hong Kong and Singapore. Lee W. Huebner, the newspaper's publisher, said the paper was exploring other printing possibilities in southern Europe and the Middle East.

title: ALL-AROUND BAD POLICY
description: To the Editor: You deserve credit for your criticism of the bilingual establishment in your editorial of May 14. But the letter on the subject published the same day (''Don't Make Language-Minority Children 'Swim or Sink' '') suggests how hard it will be to effect a rational policy in this matter.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CONCERT: ELLY AMELING
description: Elly Ameling's evening of lieder at the 92d Street Y Thursday was a triumph of thoughtful detail. She sang Schumann's ''Frauenliebe und Leben,'' three of his other songs and 12 lieder by Brahms.

title: Scouting; A Silent Moment
description: A few moments before the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park on May 29, a moment of silence will be requested while a wreath is placed on a gravesite at the foot of the grandstand flagpole. Timely Writer never ran in the Peter Pan, but the race is for 3-year-olds, and that is how old Timely Writer was when he was buried in the Belmont infield last October.

title: Martin Is Reprimanded
description: Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, has sent Billy Martin a sharp letter of reprimand as a result of an incident in the Yankee clubhouse last Sunday in which Martin ordered a reporter to stay out of the manager's office and told the Yankee players not to talk to him.

title: DUNES HOTELS & CASINOS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $2.2 million.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Margareta Akermark, Headed Art Museum's Film Program
description: Margareta Akermark, the former director of the circulating film program of the Museum of Modern Art, died Wednesday in New York City of a stroke. She was 69 years old.

title: DOMINIQUE A. BROWNING MARRIES NICHOLAS LEMANN
description: Dominique Alice Browning, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis deLoach Browning of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday at Waveney Park in New Canaan, Conn., to Nicholas Berthelot Lemann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Berthelot Lemann of New Orleans.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 21, 1983
description: International More U.S. aid for Latin America was the theme of a speech by President Reagan to an audience of Cuban expatriates in Miami. He was also addressing Congressional critics of his Latin American policy. He said there were dangers in a ''Soviet-Cuban-Nicaraguan axis'' and warned his critics that they risked leaving the hemisphere ''immobilized by fear or apathy.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) A car bomb blast in Pretoria killed at least 16 people and injured more than 190. The explosion occurred during the evening rush hour outside the headquarters of the South African Air Force. The Minister of Law and Order, Louis Le Grange, said he had no doubt that black guerrillas of the outlawed African National Congress were reponsible. (1:4.)

title: YARDNEY ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 10.
Armco Backed On Arch Patent
description: A Federal appeals court agreed with Armco Inc. that the Republic Steel Corporation violated its patent rights on a steel arch device. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld Armco in its contention that its ''Fisher'' patent on an oversized, long-span corrugated steel arch is valid.

title: KEEP AIR CLEAN HERE
description: Means are at hand to give New York City residents cheaper electricity without significantly sacrificing clean air. To prevent the loss of that opportunity, New Yorkers ought to make their voices heard.

title: EXECUTIVE OF UTILITY TAKES A MOVIE ROLE
description: ''MICHAEL O'BRIEN, you have committed the crimes of an adult but the law protects you ...''

title: ILLUSIONS ROLL ON
description: Is El Salvador just Vietnam closer to home? Clearly not. Vietnam was always part of another world. Its social structure, its customs, its language and religion were too mysterious and impenetrable for us. It was either somebody else's colony (France's), or somebody else's sphere of influence (China's).

title: LES GRANDS BALLETS DANCE TO MANY STEPS
description: ''This is a thinking company,'' James Kudelka declares proudly. He is praising the enthusiasm and adaptability of the 40-member Montreal-based Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, the troupe with which he has happily cast his lot - as dancer and choreographer - for the last two seasons.

title: South Africa
description: To the Business Editor: As a South African, I take strong exception to the article by Walter E. Williams on disinvesting from South Africa (''Beware the Well-Intentioned,'' May 15). For the last two years I have worked with legislators from all around the country, helping to get divestment laws enacted. The three South Africans Mr. Williams uses to justify his arguments against divestment are the very people the white minority Government uses when it lobbies against divestment legislation.

title: JAZZ
description: Of all the legendary settings for jazz in New York, the most colorful was the Savoy Ballroom on Lenox Avenue between 140th and 141st Streets. All the great bands of the 20's and 30's and 40's played there, usually two at time in ''Battles of the Bands,'' although there were battle royals with four bands and even six in one night. By the 1930's the Savoy had become as celebrated for its dancing as for its bands and, in recognition of this, it became known as ''The Home of Happy Feet.'' Because of the fast footwork by its regulars as they flashed through the Lindy Hop, Peckin', Truckin' and the Suzy Q, it was also called ''The Track.''

title: Gold Beauty Scores
description: Gold Beauty, champion sprinter of 1982, edged previously undefeated Platinum Belle by 2 3/4 lengths today to win the $33,575 Regret Handicap for fillies and mares at Monmouth Park.

title: Hydroplane Racers Seek Greater Safety
description: Unlimited hydroplane racing is without question a high-risk sport. The light boats are the fastest afloat, propelled by massive airplane engines to speeds approaching 200 miles an hour. Yet, after the death of Bill Muncey and Dean Chenoweth, the sport's foremost drivers, within a year of each other, some wondered whether the risk justified the rewards.

title: A FULL MENU AND DAILY SPECIALTIES
description: OVER a period of several years, the Chalet in Roslyn seemed to be developing a kitchen capable of distinction in a provincial French style. Recently, however, although the charm of the place has not diminished, there has been a falling off in terms of the care and consistency with which the food is prepared. At the same time, the wine list has become more sophisticated under the direction of the restaurant's manager, a man of particular expertise. The result is usually a dinner that is extremely pleasant in most respects, if less than thrilling.

title: Wendy Frances Conway Marries John R. Schmidt
description: Wendy Frances Conway, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mark Conway of West Hartford, Conn., and John Reed Schmidt, son of Benno C. Schmidt of New York and Mrs. Benjamin Darby Orgain of Beaumont, Tex., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the couple's home in Millbrook, N.Y., by Acting Justice Rena K. Uviller of the State Supreme Court.

title: D.M. Rubenstein Wed To Alice Nicole Rogoff
description: Alice Nicole Rogoff, managing director of the Washington merchant banking firm of G. William Miller & Company, was married yesterday to David Mark Rubenstein, a partner in the Washington law firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge. Rabbi David Saperstein performed the ceremony at Protocol House in Washington.

title: MEMORIAL DAY FILM SALUTES EAST END
description: AT the beginning of the 14-minute film ''Memorial Day,'' an elderly man raises the American flag. Then the parade passes by the firehouse, the John Drew Theater and other familiar sites on East Hampton's Main Street.

title: NEW LOOK AT OLD IDEAS
description: The photographer who tires of traditonal methods used in making images, can derive satisfaction by trying various offbeat techniques. One idea is taking photographs without a lens.

title: Katherine Proctor Is Wed to Dr. John MacIlwaine
description: Katherine Lynn Proctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Allen Proctor Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Richmond, was married yesterday to Dr. John Courtenay MacIlwaine, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Andrew MacIlwaine of Waynesboro, Va. The Rev. Douglass Ray performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: FIRE STATION RAISES PUBLIC DEBATE CROSS ON MOUNT KISCO
description: A 10-FOOT cross that stands atop a firehouse was the major issue at last Monday's meeting of the Mount Kisco Village Board. The cross, erected on the Green Street firehouse by volunteer firemen in 1959, is outlined in blue lights that are turned on each year during the Christmas season.

title: Together Again At The E.P.A.
description: Banking on an old broom sweeping clean, the Senate last week unanimously confirmed William D. Ruckelshaus as head of the Environmental Protection Agency. Mr.Ruckelshaus had guided the agency through its formative years, beginning in 1970, as the first administrator. He must now steer it through a messy reformation amid Congressional investigations into whether the agency has been protecting industry at the public's expense.

title: AND STILL CHAMPION, OF SORTS
description: IF the two boxers had fought in a street somewhere and now were on display, a latecomer surely would be able to identify the winner. One was unmarked and unafraid, his face glowing as he said, ''I had fun, I know I can beat him.'' The other was uncertain and unconvincing, his face glum and his right eye puffed as he said, ''Maybe I'm going down a little bit, a couple of fights ago he couldn't have worn my socks.'' But the fight had been in a ring, not a street.

title: Overnight, U.S. Roads Are Safer
description: Highway death statistics for 1982 were out last week and down to their lowest point in the last 20 years -43,990. That is 11 percent lower than the 1981 figure, and thus the largest year-to-year drop since the oil embargo helped push drivers off the roads in 1973.

title: June A.Haselton Married in Texas To T.G. Stephens
description: June Ann Haselton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Haselton of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Gage Stephens, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joe Bill Stephens of Bangs, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Leighton K. Farrell performed the ceremony at the Highland Park United Methodist Church in Dallas.

title: Theater; GEORGE STREET IS BACK TO OFF-BROADWAY
description: FOR THE third time in its nine-season history, the George Street Playhouse has infused a play with a New York afterlife. This time, however, the trip from New Brunswick to Off-Broadway was expeditious, direct and, for Eric Krebs, the producing director, a personal statement.

title: New Killings Stir Argentina
description: Among the 25,000 Argentines who took to the streets of Buenos Aires last week to protest thousands of unexplained disappearances and deaths in an anti-leftist military campaign in the late 1970's, some may have felt familiar foreboding. The Government declared that the left was on the rise again and announced that two left-wing Peronists had been killed in a ''shootout'' with police.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
A COMEBACK TRY AT FOX
description: IN 1977, ''Star Wars'' came to the nation's screens, and the Force was with it. The Force was with ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' too, in 1980. And when ''Return of the Jedi'' opens this Wednesday at 800 movie theaters across the country, completing the trilogy that has accounted for nearly $1 billion in ticket sales so far, it will almost inevitably be the movie of the summer of '83. ''We expect it to be the biggest of the three,'' said Alan Hirschfield, the chairman and chief executive since mid-1981 of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, ''Jedi's'' distributor.

title: If you're thinking of living in: Yorkville
description: FROM a neighborhood that in 1900 was second in the world only to Berlin in the number of German residents, the area of the Upper East Side known as Yorkville has been transformed into a mostly upscale community that is more silk stocking than lederhosen.

title: ANTINUCLEAR GROUP VARIES ITS APPROACH
description: WHEN Dr. Helen Caldicott, the renowned antinuclear advocate, addressed the New Canaan Coalition for Nuclear Arms Control last week, she received a standing ovation before she said a word.

title: K.G.B. SUPPRESSING A DISSIDENT GROUP
description: Since the middle of last week a Leningrad courtroom has been the scene of a treason trial that appears to represent the most determined effort yet to suppress the so-called Solzhenitsyn Fund, a semiclandestine group that has aided thousands of Soviet political prisoners and their families over the last decade.

title: MOSQUITOES ARE PLENTIFUL, BUT KEEP CALM
description: MOSQUITOES are abundant ''because of the unusually heavy rain this spring,'' according to Dr. Theodore G. Andreadis, research entomologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
THE SEARCH FOR MOROCCO'S BEST BASTILLA
description: Composed of a flaky pastry dough called warka surrounding a filling of chicken or pigeon meat, butter almonds, lemony eggs, spices and sugar, bastilla, when properly made, is considered one of the great dishes of the world. It may come in as many versions as its name, which is printed variously as b'stilla, bastilla, bastia, pastila, bisteyya, bistaylao and pastella (the latter name found most often on menus designated for Americans).

title: THE CLASSROOM BEHIND THE CAMERA School
description: EVERY weekday morning, a group of high school students rushes into the Mildred E. Strang Middle School in Yorktown with television on the mind.

title: Environews
description: THE New Jersey Coalition for Alternatives to Pesticides has been searching in vain for a commercial laboratory that will perform blood tests on those accidentally sprayed in the war on gypsy moths. The spraying began last week.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S LABOR VOTERS HAVE DOUBTS
description: Ron Smith gazed into the plate glass windows of a store displaying Japanese computer terminals, killing time until the hour he was to pick up his wife from her part-time job at a local box factory.

title: A SMALL PUBLISHER REFLECTS ON VENTURE
description: TO start a new business at a time when many established ones are failing requires a combination of determination and naivete, said Heike Fenton, who began Transnational Publishers in Dobbs Ferry 14 months ago. ''Looking back now, I think that maybe I had more guts than knowledge of what would be required,'' she said. ''I started out thinking I could get going with about $10,000. I had some savings and asked my husband: 'Can we do it? Can I give up my job?' But he didn't have any idea of what we were getting into, and neither did I.''

title: HARVARD ADOPTS GUIDELINES ON SPONSORED RESEARCH
description: Harvard University's faculty of arts and sciences has adopted a comprehensive set of rules to limit the ability of commercial companies to influence research they sponsor on the campus.

title: First Test for Death Penalty
description: Having weighed the evidence and found the defendant guilty, an Essex County jury considered the crime and found the maximum penalty warranted. Thus, Thomas E. Ramseur, a 44-year-old twice-convicted murderer, last week became the first person in New Jersey in a dozen years to face the death penalty and the first to test the state's new capital punishment statute.

title: REAGAN REPORTED PLANNING TO NAME 4 TO RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan plans to replace four of the six members of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, commission members and their aides reported today.

title: WHEN OLD AGE COMES TOO SOON
description: MY father stepped into old age reluctantly, with one foot still firmly embedded in his youth. His mind refused to accept what his body had already learned to live with, and that is what made the transformation so painful.

title: CONSUMER RATES
MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) International intrigue and secret negotiations between England and Russia on the eve of World War I: fiction. 2 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $3.95.) A Korean War widow makes it as a career woman, a celebrity and a mother: fiction. 2 MY SWEET AUDRINA, by V.C. Andrews. (Pocket, $3.95.) A young girl entrapped by the fears of her overprotective family: fiction. 4 TRULY TASTELESS JOKES, by Blanche Knott. (Ballantine, $2.25.) Humor. 5 THE CIRCLE, by Stve Shagan. (Bantam, $3.95.) A novel of crooked politicians and big-time gangsters. 6 SO SPEAKS THE HEART, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $3.95.) A beautiful noblewoman falls into the hands of a powerful knight: fiction. 7 ONCE MORE MIRANDA, by Jennifer Wilde. and ends as a famous novelist: fiction.

title: THE FAMILIAL RELATIONSHIP OF THE PRO SPORTS TEAM
description: ''We are family'' chanted Willie Stargell and the Pittsburgh Pirates as they marched to the 1979 World Series championship. Indeed they were a family. And the family feeling is what gave the team the spark needed for victory.

title: Goode Does Well Enough On Primary Day
description: Frank L. Rizzo's nice-guy imitation might have won him a few friends, but it wasn't enough to swing an election. Philadelphia Democrats last week instead picked W. Wilson Goode in their party primary, by about 7 percentage points, and if elected in November, Mr. Goode would be the city's first black mayor.

title: REGENTS WEIGH STIFFER COURSE REQUIREMENTS
description: New York State students would be required to learn a foreign language and take more math, science and computer courses under a major change in the curriculum being considered by the state's Board of Regents.

title: 'THE DOGS ARE THE SMART ONES'
description: ALTHOUGH the Long Island hunting season was little more than a memory, a secluded section of South Haven Park along the Carmans River on a recent Saturday morning was alive with the barking of dogs, the strident commands of their masters and the abrupt reports of gunfire. Four dozen hunters and their dogs had ventured to the Brookhaven parkland for the off-season rigors of a field trial.

title: ROBOT STARS AT COMMENCEMENT
description: As graduating students around the country listened to prominent leaders warning them about the challenges of tomorrow, the graduating class of Anne Arundel Community College in suburban Maryland met the future today and heard it invite them to accept it and use it well.

title: TINY TOWN'S PLAN FOR NUCLEAR ESCAPE
description: Most of the 6,000 residents of this peaceful Tidewater community have their own water wells. The town fathers see no need for such urban affectations as street curbs. A modern sewer system remains but a gleaming ditch in the eye of some engineer.

title: Headliners; Oriental Import
description: The heirs of one of organized labor's most bitter opponents and one of its most fervent champions have found a harmony that might have shocked their progenitors.

title: A FOREIGN POLICY FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: The foreign policy for Democrats presented by Harry McPherson and Richard Holbrooke, otherwise excellent, ducks two important issues: arms-control negotiations and international trade policy. Both are vital to the nation's welfare and will be widely debated in the 1984 election campaign.

title: Mary C. Ciccaglione Weds
description: Mary Carmela Ciccaglione, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Ciccaglione of Mount Union, Pa., was married yesterday to James Todd Manacher, son of Joan Manacher of Encino, Calif., and Jay Manacher of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Gift Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Baldrige Arrives in China
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige arrived in Peking today for talks with Chinese officials on trade relations.

title: A Choice in Haiti, for Once
description: Cap Haitien voters last week took full advantage of Haiti's first free municipal elections since the Duvalier family came to power 26 years ago, rejecting a regime-backed mayoral candidate. A new leaf? Not exactly.

title: STAGE: WOMEN'S COLLAGE
description: Claire Luckham's ''Fish Riding Bikes'' is a quiet contrast to the English playwright's last New York venture, the violent wrestling comedy, ''Teaneck Tanzi: the Venus Flytrap.'' The stage at the Interart Theater is set as if it were a conversation pit. One by one, eight actresses rise from the audience and gently deliver monologues about subjects from first sexual experience through contraception, pregnancy and lesbianism.

title: A SUMMER OF MUSIC IS ABOUT TO BEGIN
description: ALTHOUGH summer is nearly upon us, and the formal concert season is ending, there will be no lack of musical activity in the coming months. Hardly a day will pass, it seems, without a performance, indoors or out, of opera, symphonic or chamber music, bluegrass, jazz or pop.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: SAN VICENTE BLEEDS FROM EL SALVADOR'S WAR WOUNDS
description: SAN VICENTE province occupies a skewed triangle in the middle of El Salvador, its broad top bordering the northern province of Cabanas and its narrow tip running less than four miles along the Pacific Coast. Three years ago, it was among El Salvador's more prosperous regions. Most of the workers among its 70,000 people had jobs in the sugar fields or in the stores supported by the large farming industry. Today, many of the towns are nearly deserted and all are bullet-scarred. And many of the once hard-working people just sit and wait for the Red Cross to drop off the corn and beans they used to grow for themselves.

title:
Gardening;
WHEN SHADE BECOMES THE PERFECT LIGHT
description: GARDENS have a way of starting out sunny and becoming shady. It begins with a new house and a new planting. The trees are small and cast very little shadow. The owner may actually feel that they will never grow sufficiently to provide him with the cool comforts of shade during his lifetime.

title: Miss Lyons, A Teacher, Is Engaged
description: Dr. Kathleen Hausmann Lyons of Litchfield, Conn., and Dr. William B. Lyons of Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Mary Lyons, to John James Wallace, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward F. Wallace Jr., also of Litchfield.

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN'S ARTFUL SHOP DESIGNS
description: Shop signs are the flags of commerce beckoning shoppers to venture further so that they will browse and buy. The best shop signs throughout history and everywhere in the world have always been masterworks of design simplicity - in the images chosen and the way they are rendered.

title: 1941 CABLES BOASTED OF JAPANESE-AMERICAN SPYING
description: Before interning 120,000 Japanese-American citizens and alien residents in World War II, President Roosevelt and some of his top advisers may have seen decoded Japanese diplomatic cables boasting that ethnic Japanese had been ''utilized'' for espionage, according to a former intelligence official.

title: GAP BETWEEN SEXES IN VOTING SEEN AS OUTLASTING RECESSION
description: Economic concerns were critical to the tendency of women to vote Democratic in greater proportions than men in the 1982 elections, but the ''gender gap'' will not be ended by an improving economy, two pairs of academic researchers argued here today.

title: IMPORTS ASSAILED BY GARMENT WORKERS' HEAD
description: The future of the apparel industry in the United States and the jobs of thousands of garment workers are in jeopardy unless the flood of foreign imports is limited, according to Sol C. Chaikin, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: THE CASTE SYSTEM RETURNS TO THE SKIES
description: In a frenzy of price-cutting passion last year, a few airlines were forced to drop the price of first-class flight so low that almost all business travelers were enjoying a free drink and special attention. But with the economy bouncing back, aviation's caste system is making a comeback, much to the airlines' relief.

title: ART
description: The notion of the Grand Tour went out with the grand tourist - the person who could leave for Europe, stay where he liked for as long as he wanted, hire a valet, a chef and a dragoman and generally carry on as if the natives had nothing better to do than to pander to his whims. They don't make tourists like that any more, and Europe isn't like that any more, either.

title: THE LONG-RUN SUCCESS OF KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR
description: GAME chaos pervaded the locker room of pro basketball's world c hampions, the Los Angeles Lakers, one recent evening. With this b ackdrop, the ageless one, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, sat quietly between t he gold, metal walls of his dressing stall.

title: BOUQUET OF ORCHIDS
description: More than 1,000 varieties of the 35,000 species of orchids registered worldwide will be on view in the Greater New York Orchid Society Show to be held at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx Thursday through next Sunday.

title: Letters; Aspen Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: TOPICS
description: MY garden is full of ''stupid'' tulips, which couldn't read the label on their packaging that clearly stated ''late May, early June.'' I'm getting married in two weeks, feeling happier than ever in my life, and trying to rejoice with the buds and blooms that make May the merriest month (and the reason for our wedding date).

title: Adelaide Herkert and William R. Harris Jr. Marry
description: Adelaide Macaulay Herkert, daughter of Henrietta Voorhees Herkert of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Carl John Herkert of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Rees Harris Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Salisbury, Conn. The Rev. William Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford; he was assisted by the Rev. Jack Silvey Miller of the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Home Clinic; BEGIN NOW TO AVOID LAWN MOWER BREAKDOWNS THIS SUMMER
description: LIKE an automobile, a power lawn mower needs periodic maintenance to keep it operating properly, and to keep it from breaking down in the middle of the season when it gets its heaviest use (and when local service shops are loaded with work so that long delays are a strong likelihood).

title: FABI OF ITALY GAINS INDY POLE
description: Teo Fabi, a veteran road-racer from Italy, put on a stunning performance today as he broke the one- and four-lap records at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway and became only the second rookie in history to win the pole position for the Indianapolis 500.

title: Alice B. Chrystie and Peter H. Wyman Exchange Their Vows in Short Hills
description: Alice Belknap Chrystie, a doctoral student in educational psychology at Columbia University, and Peter Hunt Wyman, a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David B. Earnest, rector of the church, and the Rev. Halliwell L. Duell, great-uncle of the bride.

title: Glenn to Lead Parade
description: The organizers of the Minneapolis Aquatennial parade have chosen Senator John Glenn of Ohio as grand marshal over his fellow Democratic Presidential contender Walter F. Mondale, who is a native son. Ken Walstad, a parade official, said that Senator Glenn, the first American astronaut to orbit the earth, was chosen because the July 20 torch-light parade celebrates the 25th anniversary of space flight.

title: Self-Employed
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Stacie S. Canan Is Wed
description: Stacie Sara Canan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Clinton Canan of Wichita Falls, Tex., was married in State College, Pa., yesterday to Charles Arthur Koch, son of Mrs. O. Charles Koch of Upper Montclair, N.J., and the late Mr. Koch. The Rev. Andrew Campbell performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Eisenhower Chapel at Pennsylvania State University. The bride, who graduated from Penn State, is a doctoral candidate in organic chemistry at the University of Illinois. Mr. Koch, who holds a bachelor's degree from the University of Massachusetts and a master's from Rutgers University, expects to receive a doctorate in analytical chemistry from Penn State on May 29.

title: For the Democrats
description: Richard Holbrooke and Harry McPherson were right on the mark with their article, ''A Foreign Policy for the Democrats'' (April 10). As a new Democratic member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, I was very pleased to read their solid suggestions in The New York Times Magazine. MEL LEVINE, (Democrat of Califonia) House of Representatives, Washington

title: NASSAU REP MAKES 'BUS STOP' A DELIGHT
description: THE Kansas-born playwright William Inge wrote about the heart and heartland of America. His plays, from ''Picnic'' to ''Come Back Little Sheba'' to ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs,'' have been gentle dramas delineating the longing, loneliness and love in the day-to-day existence of ordinary people.

title: AFTER A LONG SLIDE, HOPE FOR JAMAICA
description: AT the corner of Guy R. Brewer Boulevard and Jamaica Avenue in Queens stands a vacant seven-story building that for 69 years housed Gertz's department store. Despite plans for converting the building's 200,000 square feet of selling space into a discount mall, it has stood gated and empty since Gertz shut its doors in 1980.

title: Trainer in Spotlight
description: For someone whose horses have won more stakes races and earned more money than those of any other trainer in thoroughbred racing history, Charlie Whittingham hardly needs another honor. But the 70-year-old Whittingham will be getting one today when Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., honors him as the track's career leading trainer.

title: Anita Heppenheimer Married to Artist
description: The marriage of Anita R. Heppenheimer of New York, a photographer of fine arts, to Hilary Halsted Holmes, also of New York, a portrait and landscape painter, took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: SAN FRANCISCO SEEKS TO COMBAT FEAR OF AIDS
description: Growing alarm over 236 diagnosed cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has prompted the city's Finance Committee to urge the Mayor to spend $2.1 million on research on the disease and on community education.

title: French Dance Troupes To Make Debut in U.S.
description: Five French modern-dance companies will make their American debuts at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., from July 11 to July 16.

title: MAKING OF A COMPROMISE COULD BE LONG AND NASTY
description: Shortly after his election to the Senate in 1980, Slade Gorton opted for membership on two porkbarrel committees - Commerce, and Environment and Public Works.

title: Long, Former Jet, Is Happy in U.S.F.L.
description: Kevin Long hopes to be remembered today, remembered as a former New York player for the Jets who always did the best he could. Long will be the starting fullback for the Chicago Blitz in their game against the New Jersey Generals at Giants Stadium. Should any extra recognition come from the fans, he says he would be pleased because he always liked New York and loved the Jets. He was with them for five seasons, 1977-1981, and two were notable.

title: Carol J. Wilson Is Wed in Capital
description: Carol Jane Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J.Robert Wilson of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Kenneth Rone Baldwin, son of Mrs. F.Hunter Creech of Yorktown, Va. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: The New Point Men: From Bechtel to Wriston; TWO DOZEN OF THE NATION'S TOP BUSINESS LEADERS NOW WHISPERING IN WASHINGTON'S EAR
description: IN the 70's, a small group of top corporate executives were the point men in Washington for the nation's diverse business community. Leaders like Irving Shapiro of Du Pont, John deButts of A.T.& T, and Reginald Jones, of General Electric, were familiar faces in the corridors of Congress and farther down Pennsylvania Avenue at the White House. Their views on such matters as trade policy, civil service reform, consumer protection and antitrust were familiar and important to policy makers, Democrat or Republican.

title: Headliners; Bowing to Master James
description: If McGraw-Hill Book Company science editors got a warm feeling from a first-grader's recent letter, it wasn't because they were touched.

title: Comings and Goings
description: There will be two Players in the Westchester Classic golf tournament next month - Gary Player, the 47-year-old veteran, and his son, Wayne, 21, who turned pro last November. ... Johnny Rutherford, who broke his right ankle and left foot in a crash during practice for the Indianapolis 500, will be out at least eight weeks, according to his doctor. ... Sara Simeoni, the Olympic high-jump champion, is running for Parliament in Italy.

title: CITY BALLET: 'COPPELIA'
description: ''Coppelia'' came to vivid new life Thursday at the New York State Theater when the New York City Ballet presented a number of role debuts in the George Balanchine-Alexandra Danilova classic.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Leniency for Boy With Gun
description: The Dade County school board has agreed to waive automatic expulsion for an 8-year-old third grader who took a loaded pistol to school.

title: 25 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 25 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named six that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for failing to do so.

title: Toney's Shooting Turns Tide for 76ers
description: The essence of Andrew Toney's game, a blend of power and grace, is to score on a few jump shots and to lure opponents into playing a tight defense, then wiggle past them for layups.

title: ENMITY, TORMENT, ADVERSITY
description: VOICES A Life of Frank O'Connor. By James Matthews. Illustrated. 450 pp. New York: Atheneum. $25. ''AN Irish writer without contention is a freak of nature,'' Frank O'Connor wrote of himself toward the midpoint of his career, before his writings had been officially censored in Ireland but well after he had already become, in his biographer's words, ''an abrasive and self-appointed voice of the cultural conscience.''

title: Sex Education In the Schools
description: The development of sex education in many Long Island schools (''Schools Vary in Sex Education,'' April 24) should help more and more teen-agers to live and love in more rewarding ways with fewer bad consequences.

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; TIME, SPACE AND NEW JERSEY RAILROADS
description: MANY years ago, Albert Einstein formulated the General Theory of Relativity. One of the interesting effects that his theory predicted was time dilation, a phenomenon that has been experimentally confirmed.

title: Art; JERSEY CITY: A NEWCOMER'S PERSPECTIVE
description: TO BE an immigrant is to be born again, and that's no metaphor. After rebirth, of course, there's re-education, which means mastering not just a new language, but also the technology of daily life.

title: Living Near Shoreham Without Fear
description: It seems that the Opinion Page debate on the Shoreham issue is between ''untutored laymen'' and ''utility investors.'' Since I am neither a utility investor or totally untutored, I feel it is my turn.

title: Kimberly Sue Towler Wed To Dr. Jerome V. Vaccaro
description: Kimberly Sue Towler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oscar A. Towler Jr. of Aiken, S.C., was married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Dr. Jerome V. Vaccaro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Vaccaro of Brooklyn. The Rev. Elizabeth Alcaide of the Community Church of New York performed the ceremony.

title: LAWYERS' CLIENTS GET $233,000
description: In its first year of operation, New York's Clients' Security Fund handed out 281 awards to people who were cheated by their lawyers - 279 for complaints involving one former attorney.

title: KOREA ZONE BLAMED FOR UNREST
description: A senior officer of the United Nations Command said today that the Demilitarized Zone dividing South and North Korea was a primary source of tension.

title: WOMEN SEE GAIN AS PILOTS
description: AS THE big Lockheed C-141B rose from the runway at McGuire Air Force Base here, climbing into the night sky and out over the Atlantic, the fact that the flight was making military history was secondary in the pilot's mind.

title: Carol Nelson Marries Laurance Read
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Carol Ann Nelson, a registered architect specializing in the restoration and redesign of historic buildings, was married to Laurance Alan Read, a vice president of the Stride Rite Corporation, a shoe manufacturer in Cambridge. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lewis Mills, assisted by the Rev. William McLennan.

title: Politics; DEMOCRATIC PARTY REJECTS ITS OBITUARY
description: EACH May, reporters who cover the state government hold a gridiron dinner at which they put on a show that genially - if sometimes not so gently - needles public figures and institutions. Nothing that is said, or sung, at the dinner is ever reported.

title: TEXAS SCHOOL PRINCIPAL, CONTRADICTING REAGAN, SAYS FEDERAL AID WAS CRUCIAL
description: Three years ago a Federal district judge here ordered that busing be used to desegregate Austin's public schools. That order, combined with $368,000 in special Federal aid, has transformed the Johnston High School from a decaying slum school into an institution that has gained national attention for educational excellence.

title: BANDITS WIELDING PLASTIC
description: WHEN Robert Benkowski, a Chase Manhattan vice president for credit card investigation, established a ''buy operation'' to break up a counterfeit credit card ring in New York City last year, one of his undercover agents approached a merchant with some cards that were clearly counterfeit. The merchant refused to accept them for purchases. ''But I can take you across the street,'' he offered. ''My brother will take all the cards you have.''

title: NEW YORK ISN'T CONNECTICUT, SO JUDGE BACKS SMUT RULING
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that some ''hard-core pornography'' could not be seized in Manhattan because the material did not offend the community standards there, but one judge said things would be very different in his home state of Connecticut.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Liquidation Prices On Other-Age Items

title: GOOD BUT INCONSISTANT CHINESE
description: OUR experiences at the new Chinese restaurant in Norwalk, Mandarin East, point up the vagaries of dining out. The first evening, our dinner was a series of pleasant surprises. Unusual Sichuan dishes - sauteed spicy string beans (crunchy and cidery), beef with ginger root (tantalizingly aromatic), and sha-cha lamb (pleasingly hot with a mix of straw mushrooms, broccoli and flower-shaped carrot slices) - were well seasoned, freshly made and thoroughly delectable.

title: Poland Bars Amnesty For the Pope's Visit
description: The Government stressed today that it would not grant the Roman Catholic Church's request that political prisoners be granted amnesty before the visit of Pope John Paul II next month.

title: BALLET: TWO A.B.T. CASTS APPEAR IN 'LA BAYADERE'
description: Three years after it was first staged for American Ballet Theater, Natalia Makarova's full-evening production of ''La Bayadere'' has reaped the advantages of certain improvements - a terser, more persuasive approach to the acting and a more generalized excellence in the dancing.

title: SYRIA ATTACKS REAGAN OVER SALE OF F-16'S TO ISRAEL
description: The state-run Damascus radio said today that the Reagan Administration had revealed its true anti-Arab stand with its decision to lift a ban on the sale of F-16 fighters to Israel.

title: A Harder Line On Youth Crime
description: Despite doubts about his qualifications, the Senate last week confirmed Alfred S. Regnery, a firm believer in not sparing the rod, as the head of the Justice Department's Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention.

title: AS MTM GOES, SO GOES QUALTIY IN TV PROGRAMMING
description: They drank wine dispensed by blood pumps from a make-believe operating room, and they danced in the shadow of a 10-foot-high painted kitten clad in a green surgical mask and gown. Gathered on a Hollywood sound stage one evening in late March, the cast and crew of ''St. Elsewhere,'' the NBC series about an urban hospital, were celebrating their first prime-time season together. Their festive mood was tinged with anxiety, however. Given the show's anemic ratings, there seemed little reason to believe that ''St. Elsewhere'' would survive.

title: Kathy Lynn Smith to Wed Joseph N. Gayda Jr. in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Layton F. Smith of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathy Lynn Smith, to Joseph N. Gayda Jr., son of Mr. Gayda of Redington Shores, Fla., and Jeanette Gayda of Northbrook, Ill. A June 23 wedding is planned.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Big Brother Of the North
description: Ready or not, Canada's year-old Constitution seems headed for a series of severe tests. The Government last week proposed a new secret intelligence agency with broad authority to bug, break in and read people's mail, among other things.

title: Charboneau, in Minors, Penalized for Gestures
description: Joe Charboneau, the American League's rookie of the year in 1980 with Cleveland, was fined $200 today and suspended without pay for a week by the Indians' Class AA farm team, the Buffalo Bisons, for making derisive gestures to fans.

title: STEALTHY DESTRUCTION FROM THE SKY
description: THERE is growing concern in New Jersey and other Northeastern states about the damage that acid rain is causing to both nature and man.

title: AGRICULTURAL POLICIES' CHRONIC QUANDARY
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT HUNGRY ENOUGH
description: LOOK AT ME By Anita Brookner. 192 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95. FRANCES HINTON, the heroine of Anita Brookner's second novel, works in the reference library of a London medical research institute that investigates human behavior. She is in charge of the pictorial material and spends her days clipping representations of melancholia and madness through the ages. Her parents are dead, and she lives alone, except for an elderly maid, in a large furnished flat. The decor would do for a 1930's cocotte - ''terrible cut-glass mirrors with bevelled edges hanging from chains over tiled fireplaces, shaggy off-white fitted carpets, zig-zag patterned rugs, nests of walnut tables, semicircular armchairs upholstered in pale creaking hide.'' The Hintons never got around to changing anything; neither has their daughter. Frances is as incapable of impressing her personality upon a room as she is of turning into the life of the party. Still, she would love to be the latter: ''Look at me, look at me'' is her continual, silent plea.

title: AN INVITING 'BRIGADOON'
description: REFLECTING upon ''Brigadoon'' right after having survived Alan Jay Lerner's recent Broadway bomb, ''Dance a Little Closer,'' reaffirms the former - a musical about a miracle - as a miracle indeed.

title: 20 Killed in Peru In Guerrilla Attack
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked the police headquarters in Ayacucho during a blackout Friday night, and at least 20 people were killed and 20 wounded, military sources said.

title: Woman Begins Sentence For Harboring Spy
description: The woman convicted of harboring the escaped spy Christoper Boyce surrendered to Federal marshals Friday to begin serving a five-year sentence.

title: BASKETBALL BECOMES 'WAY OF LIFE' FOR COUPLE WHO COACH
description: ''FOR some people, like Janice and myself, basketball is not a sport, not a part-time job,'' said Joseph L. Verdi of Long Beach. ''It's a way of life.''

title: THE FLAVORS OF MEXICO
description: Cooking may not be everyone's notion of a vacation. Yet, a cooking course on foreign soil, with an expert instructor at the helm, can provide insights into the customs and traditions of a people and open doors that otherwise would be closed to the average visitor.

title: In New Jersey; PRESERVATION GAINS IN PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON, so proper and reserved in most matters, is passionate a bout its land. Zoning changes and land use issues generate enormous interest among residents and battles can be waged whenever a historic site or open space is threatened by development.

title: DEBATE REKINDLED ON GARBAGE PLANT
description: THE Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority is seeking bids to restart the garbage-to-energy plant in Bridgeport, but it may be too late for some of the nine Fairfield County towns involved in the long-stalled project. Several are so dissatisfied that they are considering creating an independent recycling center.

title: FIGHTING HIS OWN SIDE
description: WAR TOYS By Hampton Howard. 252 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $14.95. WATCHDOGS By John Weisman. 274 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.75.

title: ADULT EDUCATION IS INCREASING
description: ALTHOUGH public-school enrollment in New Jersey has declined by 17 percent in the last decade, attendance at adult learning centers in the same period has increased by 319 percent. Today, about 670,000 adults take courses in more than 200 centers across the state.

title: Vindication for Umpire
description: Four years ago, his outspoken support of the major league umpires' strike set in motion a series of events that Bill Emslie believes cost him a sure promotion to the majors and his job as a minor league umpire. On Friday he was back at work in the International League after having been rehired by the league's president, Harold Cooper, who dismissed him after last season on the ground that the majors had no interest in him.

title: Haiti Invalidates Two Election Results
description: Interior Minister Roger Lafontant said today that election results in the towns of Petit-Goave and St.-Raphael were fraudulent.

title: Look at Me
description: FRANCES HINTON, the heroine of Anita Brookner's second novel, works in the reference library of a London medical research institute that investigates human behavior. She is in charge of the pictorial material and spends her days clipping representations of melancholia and madness through the ages. Her parents are dead, and she lives alone, except for an elderly maid, in a large furnished flat. The decor would do for a 1930's cocotte - ''terrible cut-glass mirrors with bevelled edges hanging from chains over tiled fireplaces, shaggy off-white fitted carpets, zig-zag patterned rugs, nests of walnut tables, semicircular armchairs upholstered in pale creaking hide.'' The Hintons never got around to changing anything; neither has their daughter. Frances is as incapable of impressing her personality upon a room as she is of turning into the life of the party. Still, she would love to be the latter: ''Look at me, look at me'' is her continual, silent plea.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE LAST ENEMY By Richard Hillary. 184 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $10.95.In the summer of 1940 Richard Hillary, a young Royal Air Force pilot fresh out of Oxford, was shot down in his Spitfire over the English Channel. His hands and face were horribly burned, but he lived to write the tale, an understated story of heroism coupled with a moving account of how he reluctantly developed an affection for suffering humanity. The work came out in 1942 under the title ''Falling Through Space,'' after which Hillary went back to war. He was killed in combat on Jan. 7, 1943.

title: O'NEILL SIGNS BILL LIMITING COST TO CONSUMERS OF NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Legislation imposing a $3.54 billion limit on the cost that electricity consumers would have to assume in the building of the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant was signed this week by Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: Zahringer Advances In Travis Golf
description: George Zahringer, the current Metropolitan and Long Island amateur champion, reached the semifinals of the Walter J. Travis tournament here today by winning two rounds of match play at the Garden City Golf Club.

title: HOW HOSTAGE TEAM PASSED THE TEST
description: ''OUR role is to calm down a situation, to buy time,'' said Capt. Robert Dormer, head of the Suffolk County Police Department hostage team. ''Police by nature are action-type people, and they want to resolve a situation as soon as possible so they can be ready to move on to the next job.

title: VERMONT U. HONORS MCCARTHY ERA VICTIM IT OUSTED
description: Yesterday morning, in a sunny football field in the hills off Lake Champlain, the president of the University of Vermont called the name of Prof. Alex B. Novikoff, of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

title: HE MADE A REVOLUTION
description: CHOREOGRAPHY BY GEORGE BALANCHINE A Catalogue of Works. 407 pp. New York: The Eakins Press Foundation. $75. IT'S no accident that the ballet explosion in this country coincided with the work of George Balanchine, especially after the New York City Ballet was established in 1948. Balanchine produced an enormous body of work of prodigious originality and amazing stature. And since dance, alone among the performing arts, cannot separate the creative artist from the interpretive artist, Balanchine invented a new kind of dancer for his ballets: fast, mobile, energetic, conspicuous and distinctly American. Together, dances and dancers make up the New York City Ballet, perhaps the most important performing arts institution since the Globe Theater in Shakespeare's time.

title: NOT FOR THE POOREST
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILEAN RULES OUT EARLY DEMOCRACY
description: President Augusto Pinochet has ruled out a speedy return to democracy in Chile in a speech that followed violent demonstrations against his military Government last week.

title: Battles Are Reported In Eastern El Salvador
description: Leftist guerrillas ambushed two military convoys early today, setting off battles on an eastern road, military sources reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Never again, never again are our people going to be doing all the bleeding, never again.'' - Oliver Tambo, leader of the African National Congress of South Africa. (1:4.)

title: Pay-Later Fever In Connecticut
description: Connecticut lawmakers have yet to agree on raising enough revenue, but that didn't deter them last week from turning to the far more pleasant task of spending it. The Legislature's Appropriations Committee approved $3.62 billion in outlays for the fiscal year beginning July 1, $43.5 million more than Gov. William A. O'Neill requested and 11.6 percent more than the state will spend this year.

title: Ellen Leblang Is Wed To David D.Petrocci
description: Ellen Kim Leblang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Leblang of Greenwich, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to David D. Petrocci, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Petrocci of Syracuse. The Rev. David Ourisman, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel.

title: SENATORS LIST MORE OUTSIDE INCOME FOR 1982
description: Senators, who are paid more than five times the average salary in the United States, sharply increased their outside earnings from speechmaking last year, according to financial disclosure forms.

title: France's Prost Has Pole For Belgian Grand Prix
description: Alain Prost of France retained the pole position he had taken provisionally in the early qualifying when rain prevented any improvement of speed today in the final timed trials for Sunday's Belgian Grand Prix.

title: JOHNSON-TONEY MATCHUP MAY BE KEY TO TITLE ROUND
description: The statistics of the six-game Western Conference championship series between the Los Angeles Lakers and the San Antonio Spurs, which ended with a 101-100 Laker victory Friday night, were spread out yesterday before Coach Billy Cunningham of the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: In Nasty Fix
description: One perk of high-level Government service has come to be a shot at making big bucks on a book. However, Adm.

title: Data Bank; May 22, 1983
YANKEES HOLD OFF A'S, 1-0
description: In unexpected, dramatic and sometimes chilling ways, the Yankees continued today to play winning baseball on a potentially pivotal road trip.

title: A NEW LOOK TO GROWING OLD: STAYING ALIVE
description: ALTHOUGH older adults always have been able to provide a few outstanding people who could perform at competitive physical levels, there has generally been indifference toward being physically active after 50.

title: Malta
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANS TO RENOVATE A MILL RAISE HOPES
description: THE purchase and proposed renovation of a 19th-century textile mill in the town of Thompson by a development company has created hopes of an economic upturn in the northeastern corner of the state.

title: Food; FROM LITTLE POTS OF HERBS, LARGE WONDERS GROW
description: AT this time of year, small pots for fresh herbs start to appear in the market. Basil and tarragon are now readily available to be grown on windowsills or transplanted outdoors. These herbs do wonders for chicken, veal or fish, or they can be mixed into spring salads.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ROME
description: Church and state, each in its own way, are making this a special summer for visiting Rome. For Roman Catholics, this is the Holy Year of the Redemption, a jubilee for pilgrimages to the See of St. Peter, a year of special events that make a stay in Rome even more rewarding than in other years. For visitors of all faiths or none, the city of Rome is planning a rich program of cultural events of many kinds, a festival of recent vintage called the Roman Summer. And, without special arrangements on anyone's part, there is the perennial festival of being in a great city aglow in architectural beauty, alive with one of the most energetic and good-natured of urban populations - a feast for all the senses, this season or any other. Holy Year Events

title: ARIAS, 18, REACHES ITALIAN TENNIS FINAL
description: Jimmy Arias, the 18-year-old American, defeated Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland, 6-2, 7-6, today and reached the final of the Italian Open tennis championships against Jose Higueras of Spain.

title: Miss Eglin, Legal Aide, Is Married
description: Cintra Emlen Eglin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wilson Eglin of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married there yesterday to Wayne Clifford Willcox, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jonas Clifford Willcox of Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Edith Memorial Chapel of the Lawrenceville School, where the bride's father is dean of students.

title: IT'S ANCHORS AWEIGH, FINALLY
description: CARL CALDWELL'S new 22-foot Aquasport patrol boat puttered up the narrow Byram River on a recent day at the legal speed of five miles an hour. But although the skies were cloudless and the temperatures in the 70's, there was a noticeable absence of other craft along the waterway.

title: WHERE DID THE STARS GO?
description: WHEN astronomers plan for an observatory, they usually seek an isolated spot, preferably a mountaintop, far from the dimming effect of city lights on the heavens.

title: HAGERTY TOPS HAMMER MARK
description: Declan Hagerty of Boston University topped his meet-record distance to win the hammer throw for the third straight year at the IC4A outdoor track and field championships today.

title: Leslie Butcher Is Bride Of Angus Littlejohn Jr.
description: The marriage of Leslie Wright Butcher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Calhoun Butcher of Westhampton Beach, L.I., to Angus Chisholm Littlejohn Jr. of Norwalk, Conn., took place yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Littlejohn of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Zdenek F. Bednar performed the ceremony in the Wilton, Conn., Congregational Church.

title: THE SIREN'S STORY
description: LORELEI TWO My Life With Conrad Aiken. By Clarissa M. Lorenz. 231 pp. Athens, Ga.: The University of Georgia Press. $19.95.LORELEI TWO was the name Conrad Aiken gave the second of his three wives in his autobiographical memoir ''Ushant.'' The other wives were Lorelei One and Lorelei Three. What he began in ''Ushant'' as an obscure account of himself as a kind of Ulysses threatened by sirens and shipwreck, has become in this volume an explicit story of an actual disaster, that of his second marriage as told by Lorelei Two. One sees that the nickname was not as playful and teasing as it first appears.

title: LETTERS HAIL STATUE OF LIBERTY'S LASTING INSPIRATION
description: In 1913, Helen Gaynor arrived in America for the first time. She was 5 years old and had sailed from Poland in a cargo ship with her sister and mother. Their farm had been confiscated and war threatened to overrun the country.

title: WATT STILL BACKED BY MANY IN ROCKIES
description: Although Interior Secretary James G. Watt's policies on land and water use have their greatest effect in the Rockies, he retains considerable support in this often conservative region while still the subject of much debate.

title: FRESH AIR FUND BEGAN IN SMALL TOWN
description: In 1877 Charlotte Buchanan was 6 years old and, by all accounts, very sick. The crowded and dirty conditions on DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn, where she lived with her parents and 12 brothers and sisters, only made her many illnesses worse.

title: PERPETUAL EMOTION
description: THE MADNESS OF A SEDUCED WOMAN By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. 578 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $16.95. THE literature of obsessive love is ancient and endlessly compelling. We nourish our imaginations with the stories of Tristan and Isolde, Cathy and Heathcliff. Susan Fromberg Schaeffer's ''Madness of a Seduced Woman'' is an enormous, engrossing feast for those who hunger for the fiction of extreme emotion. Based on actual turn of the century events, it is the story of a beautiful young woman who commits murder out of both love and self-revulsion.

title: Braves Win, 4-1, on Murphy Triple in 8th
description: Dale Murphy hit a bases-loaded triple in the eighth inning to snap a 1-1 tie and give the Atlanta Braves a 4-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: GUERRILLA CHIEF WARNS PRETORIA OF NEW ATTACKS
description: The leader of the African National Congress of South Africa said tonight that a car bomb attack in Pretoria on Friday signaled ''an escalation'' and a tactical change in his organization's struggle against white minority rule.

title: BOMBING CIVILIANS: THE WORLD WAR II LESSON
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SONS OF DIVORCE
description: JAMIE WAS 14 AND HIS SISTER, LAURA, was 12 when their parents told them they were getting a divorce. The announcement caught both children totally by surprise. They knew their parents had dissimilar personalities, but they had never heard them fight. They were a close-knit family, and often took trips together, rafting in Colorado one year, touring Spain another. So this announcement seemed catastrophic. ''I felt like I'd been hit by a steamroller,'' says Jamie, now 15. ''The world was coming apart. That's all I knew.''

title: Headliners; Crowning Touch
description: The architectural work of Ieoh Ming Pei hasn't exactly left him short of cash or credibility, but a little more of either never hurts.

title: PHYSICISTS PUSH HUNT FOR ELUSIVE PARTICLE
description: OBJECTS millions of times smaller, but incalculably more important, than a mote of dust may be floating around in the universe. They are magnetic monopoles, fundamental particles that scientists have been trying to find for 50 years.

title: TRAP HEARING STARTS DISPUTE
description: ASSEMBLYMAN D. Bennett Mazur, Democrat of Fort Lee, has charged that state wildlife officials, to support fur trappers and the continued legalization of steel leghold traps, gave false and misleading testimony at a recent legislative hearing.

title: CORRECTION
description: The 'Votes in Congress' table in last Sunday's Times incompletely described the May 12 Senate vote on a White House-backed budget resolution.

title: A LATIN AMERICAN VISION COMES TO THE NEW YORK STAGE
description: While the Latin American novel has surely arrived, most Latin American plays are still waiting for their passports. Works for theater have been turned out by some of the most eminent Latin American writers, including Mexico's Carlos Fuentes and Argentina's Manuel Puig. But these are rarely seen by English-speaking audiences in New York, where theater from abroad is most likely to be stamped ''Made in London.'' But on Wednesday, at the INTAR Hispanic American Theater, New York will see the English-language premiere of ''The Senorita from Tacna'' by Mario Vargas Llosa, the Peruvian novelist and one of last year's Nobel Prize nominees who is also one of the most eminent writers to have come from the Spanish-speaking world. The play's five-week run is part of an effort by INTAR, a theater on 42d Street's Theater Row devoted to the work of Latin American and Hispanic American writers, to offer one notable Latin American play each season.

title: Seeking Donations
description: Another View If Eileen Charbonneau wishes to dance, sing, make rice pudding or write a novel, that is certainly her privilege. But when she resolves to ''ask for money gracefully'' from local merchants for her own pet charities, as she recounts in her article (Opinion Page, May 1), she exceeds privilege and achieves chutzpah.

title: ARGENTINA FARMERS DEBATE THE 70'S REBELLION
description: Hundreds of sugar-cane growers converged on this small northwestern town by horse-drawn carriage on a recent Saturday to buy supplies and talk crops and politics over red wine.

title: A FOREIGN POLICY FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: It is difficult to devise a foreign policy that would satisfy our desire for peace as well as our equally strong desire to support democratic values and human rights, and Richard Holbrooke and Harry McPherson should be commended for their attempt to do so. But they could strengthen their policy, I believe, by making human rights not merely one ''of the ingredients of a foreign policy based on national interest'' but its cornerstone.

title: ANOTHER INSTRUMENTALIST TAKES UP THE BATON
description: ''I think of my role up there on the podium as akin to that of a great movie director - which is, to work with an extraordinarily talented group of people, and to help them to be seen in the best possible light,'' Ransom Wilson was saying. Mr. Wilson, who is best known as a flutist, is also one of the more recent additions to the growing ranks of instrumental soloists who have taken up the baton.

title: BLASTING NASTY NAZIS
description: ROGUE JUSTICE By Geoffrey Household. 198 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $14.50.OPERATION LILA By Marvin H. Albert. 000 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.25.THE HITLER DIARIES By Richard Hugo. 279 pp. New York: Morrow and Company. $00.00.

title: Cosmos Beat Roughnecks, 2-1
description: Giorgio Chinaglia scored his 11th goal of the season early in the second half tonight to lead the Cosmos to a 2-1 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 22, 1983
description: International

title: Correction
description: ''The Great Evolution Mystery'' by Gordon Rattray Taylor, reviewed May 15, is a Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book published by Harper & Row.

title: COMPUTERS AS HOTEL AMENITIES
