description: Taking a portable computer on business trips might seem convenient at first, but some executives are beginning to wonder if it's worth the trouble. At 25 to 30 pounds, most ''portables'' weigh more than a medium-sized television set. And stories are already making the rounds about executives who pass through airport metal detectors, only to discover later that the floppy computer disk on which they stored a 70-page report was wiped clean by the detector's magnetic field.

title: GENTLY WITH GANGSTERS
description: A people that suffered torture and murder at the hands of a dictatorship is told by its government that nothing will be done about that bloody record: no investigation, no justice. World leaders express outrage at the decision. The U.S. State Department, after thinking about it for two weeks, issues a brief statement of ''disappointment.''

title: LESSONS OF POLITICS; Well-Schooled Voters
description: Nine members of the so-called National Democratic Policy Committee, an organization inspired and led by Lyndon LaRouche Jr., entered the New York school board election in District 6, covering Inwood, Washington Heights and upper Harlem. The threat of their candidacies helped bring 14,000 voters to the polls, 6,000 more than three years ago.

title: DISPUTE SNAGS RENOVATION OF HARLEM BROWNSTONES
description: An unexpected historic-preservation dispute has thrown into doubt New York City's timetable for renovating a number of abandoned Harlem brownstones that were sold a year ago to neighborhood residents.

title: WHY 'SKY BURIALS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill Ellen Cowan Will Wed June 19
description: Jill Ellen Cowan, who is with the polling unit of ABC-TV News in New York, and Dan Eliot Wiener, a member of the class of '84 at the Boston University School of Medicine, plan to be married June 19 in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of Hebrew Congregations of America, is to perform the ceremony in the Rose Garden at the Old Westbury Gardens.

title: Coast School District Declares Insolvency
description: Officials of the San Jose Unified School District, one of the state's largest, with 32,000 students, have voted to declare that the district is insolvent.

title: STATE SENATE ACTS TO TOUGHEN PENALTY FOR ILLEGAL SHELLFISHING
description: The State Senate moved against illegal clammers this week by passing a measure that would raise fines for illegal shellfishing and use the extra money to increase the policing of Long Island waters.

title: THE WRONG TIME TO DRAIN CHRYSLER
description: To the Editor:

title: Unions, Management and Politics; RIGHT AND A WRONG COURSE FOR LABOR
description: DEEPLY concerned with the long-term ability of America's manufacturing sector to compete with its foreign counterparts, management and labor are casting about for solutions that will salvage both profitability and jobs.

title: LOWER EAST SIDE FAMILY SHELTER OFFERS COUNSELING
description: Bonnie Oglensky, a social worker, remembered the 21-year-old woman with six children and no husband. Last year, when the woman lived in an apartment at the Urban Family Center, a Manhattan shelter for homeless people, she was spending so much time trying to control the children that she could not keep her apartment clean.

title: TAINTED TOOTH POLISH FOUND IN NEWARK WAREHOUSE
description: More than half of a slightly contaminated batch of tooth polish that its manufacturer said it had ordered destroyed was later found in a Newark warehouse with pesticides and other chemicals, prompting investigations by Federal and state agencies.

title: Postings; GRIEVANCE GUIDE
description: Homeowners throughout New York have always had the right to take their tax assessors to court when they felt their property assessments were miscalculated, excessive, unequal or otherwise unfair. But in 1981 the Legislature simplified the process and lowered legal costs by establishing a Small Claims Assessment Review, a local board whose members have a knowledge of property values in the assessing area.

title: INDIANS RETURN TO A SPIRITUAL HOME
description: LONG ago, before Henry Hudson and the Dutch, before the English who created the entity called Westchester, they were here: the Kichtawanks, the Sinsinks, the Rechgawawamks, the Wiechquaeskecks and other bands of coastal Indians who spoke a common Algonquian dialect and referred to themselves as the Lenape, the common people. By the time of the American Revolution, the majority of them had left. But there existed among them a tradition that one day they would return to the Hudson, to the place where the water was never still.

title: Mary Lewis Shaw Marries Jeffrey M. Kaplan, Lawyer
description: Mary Lewis Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ellsworth Shaw of Tucson, Ariz., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Matthew Kaplan, son of Doris Willens Kaplan of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Milton L. Kaplan. City Court Justice Bram Goldman of Tucson performed the ceremony at the Shaw home.

title: Hilary M. Walker Engaged to Marry Insurance Broker
description: Mrs. John Hone Bartol and Alexander David Walker Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Magnus Walker, to Winchester Fitch Hotchkiss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hotchkiss of Bernardsville, N.J.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HAPPY BIRTHDAY, ISLIP
description: In Suffolk, tercentenaries come in twos this year. Not only is the county marking its 300th birthday, but the hamlet of Islip is celebrating, too. And today's the day that the anniversary hoopla reaches its peak - with a historical exhibition from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Tercentenary Museum, 521 Main Street; a concert by the Long Island Banjo Society at 1 P.M., Town Hall, Main Street; the arrival of the Tercentenary train bearing dignitaries at the Long Island Rail Road station at 1:15 P.M.; bell ringing by area churches at 1:30 P.M. and, finally, what the hamlet fathers call a ''colossal parade'' along Brentwood Road starting at 2 P.M. The parade ends at Town Hall with a re-enactment of the 1683 purchase of what is now Islip from the Secatogue Indians. A marathon Saturday morning completes the week's festivities. For information about the race, call 581-6766.

title: A String Quartet and Clarinetist Are Among Recitalists
description: The Orion String Quartet consists of the violinists Sandra Goldberg and Ruth Herring, the violist Ann Roggen and the cellist Julie Charland. Although the four young artists show talent, the quartet is currently less than the sum of its parts, and their New York debut on May 14 at Carnegie Recital Hall may have been premature.

title: Gen'l Practitioner Wins
description: Gen'l Practitioner sprinted to a 5-length lead turning for home and held on for a 1 3/4-length triumph in the $212,000 Illinois Derby today at Sportsman's Park.

title: UNITY A MAJOR GOAL FOR STATE'S INDIANS
description: AFTER 16 months without a coordinator, the Connecticut Indian Affairs Council again has filled the position. Financing cutbacks in 1982 led the state's Department of Environmental Protection to let the job stay vacant.

title: S.A. Roth Weds Jean A. Demaree
description: Jean Armstrong Demaree, an assistant editor at House & Garden magazine, and Stephen Anthony Roth, a vice president in the mortgage securities department of Salomon Brothers, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Stephen Rodgers performed the ceremony.

title: Boros Manages A's With Aid of Science
description: Steve Boros keeps a computer upstairs, good books on the shelf and a mitt on his desk. He has been able to keep the three in motion - although sometimes they collide - while he serves as rookie manager of the Oakland A's, the team he inherited from Billy Martin.

title: Sutherland Sets Record
description: Bill Sutherland, competing for the New York Athletic Club, set a Tom Black Classic record in the hammer throw Friday night with a throw of 224 feet 2 inches in opening-day competition.

title: Cleaner Air, Angrier Drivers
description: When New Jersey switched in August from annual to biennial inspections of auto emissions, environmentalists got angry. Now it may be drivers' turn.

title: EXPERIMENTS IN 'RHYTHMIC FORM' BASED ON COLOR HARMONY
description: IN the years just prior to World War I, when Paris was the undisputed center of the art world, two young Americans were among the small but energetic group of avant-garde painters whose theories and experiments radically altered the course of Western art. Morgan Russell and Stanton MacDonald-Wright, working together in Paris from 1911 to 1914, developed an esthetic system based on principles of color harmonies equivalent, they believed, to tonal values in music.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION

title: WHO TESTS THE PRODUCT-TESTING LABS?
description: Scandal has cast a cold light on the nation's 300 contract laboratories - the scientific gatekeepers whose tests help determine whether new drugs and chemical products can be marketed.

title: Manchester, Brighton Tie in English Cup Final
description: Manchester United and Brighton played to a 2-2 overtime tie in the English Cup final before 100,000 soccer fans at Wembley Stadium today.

title: PARIS BARS A FLIGHT BY SHUTTLE OVER SEINE
description: France refused special permission today for the American space shuttle Enterprise to make a demonstration flight over Paris on its current tour of Western Europe. The British, Belgian, West German and Dutch Governments have all invited the craft to fly over their capitals.

title: Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN AN INFANT DIES, WHO WILL HELP?
description: FEW families cope well with the death of a baby. When the cause of death is Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, or SIDS, the grief can be even more intense, say those who counsel such families.

title: NEAR PLAYLAND, 'TEX-MEX' DISHES
description: WITH the approaching warm weather signaling, among other things, the reopening of Rye's Playland, it is of interest to note that during the last year Alamo, a restaurant serving ''Tex-Mex'' food, has opened just south of Playland Parkway. Dishes such as steak, burgers and ribs done on a char-broiler appear on the menu, along with those that, in these parts, pass for Mexican. And as in other places in the county that offer this type of cuisine, the efforts of Alamo's kitchen lacked consistency. The kitchen produced some dishes of such startingly disparate quality that it is difficult to believe that the hand turning out luscious pollo al cilantro - luxuriously thick, juicy chicken cutlet of exceptionally fine flavor and texture, sprinkled with fragrant cilantro (or coriander) leaves - is also responsible for using mucid avocado in guacamole and preparing enchiladas like papyrus.

title: LAWFUL GLOBAL FINALE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITNEY NORTH SEYMOUR SR., LED BAR GROUP
description: Whitney North Seymour Sr., a prominent New York trial lawyer for more than half a century, a member of the Administration of President Herbert Hoover and the 84th president of the American Bar Association, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mother to Keep Baby
description: A surrogate mother has decided to keep her baby after reaching an agreement with the child's father and his wife. Ronda Price made her decision after meeting last Sunday with the father and his wife. According to the original agreement, Mrs. Price was to have received $10,000 plus expenses not covered by insurance.

title: ROLE PLAYER
description: BOOKER T. WASHINGTON The Wizard of Tuskegee, 1901-1915. By Louis R. Harlan. Illustrated. 548 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30. THE last two decades of Booker T. Washington's life, 1895 through 1915, coincided with the worst period for black Americans since Emancipation. The great majority of them remained in the rural South as sharecroppers, with increasing numbers sliding over the edge into peonage, another type of involuntary servitude. Those were the years when the rights extended blacks during the Civil War and Reconstruction were withdrawn, when most freedmen were disfranchised, when segregation was legally, rigidly and universally established and when lynching and race riots set records. A shrill chorus of white supremacy denied blacks human status in the South, and the North generally joined in or acquiesced.

title: Postings; HELPING NEWARK TURN THE CORNER
description: The third component of the Prudential Insurance Company of America's long-term Gateway Center project is now rising in downtown Newark. Scheduled for completion early in 1984, the 18-story Gateway Three, at 100 Mulberry Street, joins the existing and interconnected Gateway One, a 28-story tenanted office building and Gateway Two, an 838,000-square-foot facility Prudential leases to Western Electric.

title: CRIME
description: In the 1940's Lillian de la Torre wrote a mystery in which the detective was Dr. Samuel Johnson, and a good case could be made for the Great Cham of Literature's acting in such a capacity. The eternally inquisitive, highly intelligent Charles Dickens also would make a fine fictional detective, but nobody ever has gotten around to him. Even Jane Austen could conceivably be passed off as a sort of Miss Marple.

title:
JOURNEYS THROUGH WALES;
THE LITTLE WORLD OF ABERGAVENNY
description: Take a map and run a finger down the border between Wales and England. A little over three-quarters of the way down, on the Welsh side, you come to Abergavenny, ringed by its mountains - Sugar Loaf, Deri, Skerrid, Blorenge. To the northwest are the Black Mountains, to the west the Brecon Beacons, and to the east, over on the English side of the border, the Wye Valley. Population 9,000 - a nice size - and on Tuesdays most of it seems to be out in town: ladies holding leisurely conversations at the baker's and gents in the pubs, which stay open all day because Tuesday, after all, is Market Day. This is when the town's vitality is most apparent; though the hill farms are small and nowhere in Britain is free of unemployment, this is a lively and prosperous center that tolerates tourists kindly but does not depend on them. (Abergavenny's official guidebook is anxious to assure its readers that it has the latest thing in shopping for everyone; and indeed there are supermarkets and gift shops and a Woolworth's and an astonishing number of shoe shops.)

title: A LONDON SUCCESS STORY
description: N the 1960's, Mary Quant and Biba were the ''in'' shops that women wanted to visit on a trip to London. In the 1970's, Browns took over South Molton Street, introducing a new (for London) concept of cluster shopping with a street full of shops packed with designer merchandise from Paris, Milan and New York. Now, in the 1980's, Joseph is the retail operation to watch.

title: CLUBS FOR NEWCOMERS CHANGE
description: WHEN Marguerite Sargeant, a Greenwich resident, saw that local employment agencies were not helping her reenter the job market last year, she turned instead to contacts made at her local Newcomers Club, a group she had joined upon arriving in town several years before. She also listed the administrative experience gained as the membership chairman on her resume.

title: ON THE COUCH IN THE CAPITAL
description: Washington has the deserved reputation of being a hard-working, early-rising town, and among the earliest risers are some of the approximately 1,200 psychiatrists in the metropolitan area who minister to the powerful and famous before their official working days begin.

title: NEW MANEUVERS REFLECT PRESSURE OVER SHOREHAM
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company's tremendous financial stake in its nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant was underscored last week by developments that centered on who would pay for the plant if it never opened, whether county personnel were necessary to evacuate Suffolk residents in case of a nuclear emergency and how involved state officials would be in trying to settle the dispute.

title: Harsh Words for Nicaragua Policy
description: The House Intelligence Committee, which said it had been trying for a year to curb the Administration's covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, last week shifted its focus from persuasion to condemnation. In a report immediately disputed by its Republican minority, the committee said the Central Intelligence Agency operation in Nicaragua was ''counterproductive'' to United States interests in the region, did not cut off arms supplies to Salvadoran guerrillas and cost ''innocent lives.''

title:
TV VIEW;
A SEARINGLY HONEST 'SONS AND LOVERS'
description: At New York's Museum of Broadcasting a week or so ago, Jeremy Isaacs, the head of the new, and already beleaguered, fourth television channel in Britain, was complaining that American audiences were not really given much of a chance to see the British drama productions that cope with pressing contemporary problems. American programming interests, he said, prefer to import ''costume dramas'' that keep unpleasant realities at a safe remove. The lushly aristocratic ''Brideshead Revisited'' or the nostalgia-drenched soap opera ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' get selected over more gritty productions that are usually presented as single plays. But in making his point, which has some validity, Mr. Isaacs was unfair, no doubt unintentionally, to the book adaptations he dismisses as costume dramas. The mini-series fare on a showcase such as ''Masterpiece Theater'' can frequently pack a relevancy wallop for modern audiences. Witness ''Sons and Lovers,'' the current multi-part offering that is being broadcast Sunday evenings at 9 on Channel 13.

title: HOW TO REVIVE THE LIBERAL ARTS AND HUMANITIES
description: I WANT you to join me in a new evangelical mission - for the liberal a rts. The liberal arts professor, which I once was, has felt h istorically that his only mission of the liberal arts is to turn outm ajors. Now, what's happened nationally and what creates the anger a nd frustration among liberal arts faculty members is that all of a s udden the humanists and social scientists cannot turn out majors, b ecause the student demand for such fields has dissolved in favor of m ore direct and immediate career prepartion.

title: Spy Stories and Vile Racism
description: What do the former Director of Central Intelligence and the operators of a country music station in Dodge City have in common? They both want the Government to stop censoring their work.

title: LIFE INSURANCE NEEDS: IGNORE THE RULES
description: YOU should carry life insurance equal to seven times your annual income. For years that has been one of the verities of middle-class economic life, ranking with the conventional wisdom about having a will and keeping receipts.

title: About Books
description: LOOK behind the sparkling array of festivities honoring the centennial of the Brooklyn Bridge, which opened on May 24, 1883, to recognize two remarkable figures - John A. Roebling and his eldest son, Washington A., both the kinds of personalitites we would be incredulous of if encountered in fiction.

title: CAMDEN GETS GRANT FOR A TERMINAL
description: THIS troubled city on the Delaware River has received $14 million in Federal and state funds for a transportation terminal that it hopes will stimulate downtown renewal.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: EXILED IN AMERICA

title: COMMUNISTS FACING A TEST IN INDIAN VOTE
description: By the side of a country road in the flat, green ricelands south of here, in one of the poorest, most crowded and least developed parts of rural India, there is a little hut of bamboo and thatch that serves as a chicken-feed store, with a small tea shop attached.

title: A Debate: Revamp the Board of Estimate?; ANOTHER ARM OF CITY HALL GETS TWISTED BY THE COURTS
description: NEW YORK CITY'S governmental branches have been called many things, but none so troubling as the term now in vogue - unconstitutional. First, Federal Judge Edward R. Neaher ruled that the at-large system of representation in the Council violated the constitutional provision of one-man, one-vote because each borough had two at-large seats despite populations ranging from Brooklyn's 2.2 million to Staten Island's 350,000. Then a Federal appeals panel ruled last week that the Board of Estimate, which approves all financial matters, must conform with the same principle because its members were selected by popular election and it ''performs general governmental functions.'' The panel did not say that the board violated the provision; it sent the case back to Judge Neaher, who had initially decided that the rule did not apply, with instructions to determine whether population disparities deviated too far for equal representation on that body, too. That is the contention of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which filed the suit. Richard Emery, staff counsel for the organization, has suggested increasing by various amounts the votes held by citywide officials and all the boroughs save Staten Island. That would be fairer for all New Yorkers, he argued, especially black and Hispanic residents not now represented on the board. But Anthony R. Gaeta, the Staten Island Borough President, has resisted any solution that would effectively reduce his power and, he contends, shortchange his borough. Though officials haven't decided the city's next move, Mr. Gaeta, for one, is ready to fight. Mr. Emery and Mr. Gaeta were asked last week to elaborate on their positions.

title: Diane Bennett, Editor, Is Bride of Marc Levy
description: Diane Elizabeth Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Bennett of Stanhope, N.J., was married yesterday in Woodstock, Vt., to Marc Aaron Levy, son of Joan Heller Leahy of Dallas and Rene I. Levy of Boyd, Tex. The Rev. Russell Bletzer performed the ceremony at the North Unitarian-Universalist Church.

title: 5,000 in West Germany Protest SS Reunion
description: Some people in a crowd of about 5,000 threw tear gas and fireworks at the police today during a protest against a reunion of veterans of two of Hitler's SS regiments.

title: KEN RUSSELL SHAPES A NEW 'BUTTERFLY'
description: Ken Russell, the controversial British film maker, has consistently exposed the seamy side of the world's artistic icons while simultaneously celebrating their genius in movies such as ''Women in Love,'' ''Mahler'' and ''The Music Lovers.'' Recently he has turned his hand to opera directing, with predictably offbeat - some would say outrageous - results. His latest effort, a highly provocative staging of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Spoleto Festival, U.S.A., in Charleston, S.C., is unlikely to change his reputation for gleeful irreverence. The production opened the festival this past Friday and will be repeated Wednesday, Friday and next Sunday.

title: Pieces of a Plan For Indian Point Fall Into Place
description: Officials have been burning the midnight oil to keep the nuclear power flowing from Indian Point, and last week they seemed to be making progress. After meetings with bus companies, drivers' unions and the operators of the reactors - Consolidated Edison and the New York Power Authority - Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'- Rourke announced an agreement on emergency planning. He said the unions would support a two-hour course in ''radiation emergency response procedures,'' the utilities, in addition to paying for the course and the time of the drivers taking it, would lease 1,000 buses and begin a $242,000 study of local roads, and Albany would furnish 1,000 dosimeters and a supply of potassium iodide, a drug that reduces the effects of radiation. None of this, of course, guarantees that 500 drivers would be available to transport those of the nearly 300,000 people living within 10 miles of the Buchanan complex who, in the event of an emergency, couldn't get out by themselves, but Mr. O'Rourke said he was confident ''we'll get the volunteers.'' Just in case, Dr. David Axelrod, the New York State Health Commissioner, suggested in a report to Governor Cuomo at week's end that cadets or army troops from West Point be pressed into service. It was widely agreed that all of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's concerns about Indian Point would not be resolved by the June 9 deadline, but state and local officials said they thought the agency might be satisfied with their efforts thus far.

title: MR. REAGAN IS BIG MAN ON CAMPUS
description: Small red and white azalea bushes popped up on the campus of Seton Hall University here this week. It was more than the normal pregraduation face lift, because it was not going to be a normal graduation. President Reagan was coming to address the university's 126th graduating class today.

title: New Jersey Guide; AN AIRBORNE BENEFIT
description: A lot of hot air will be blowing in Bedminster next Sunday, and a lot of people will get high - all for a good cause. Malcolm Forbes's much-publicized chateau-in-the-sky balloon will carry guests aloft - at $25 each - during ''A Day in the Country,'' a benefit for the Matheny School for children with cerebral palsy. And 14 balloonists will race in the day's featured event.

title: THE CHAMPION THAT TRIED AND SAT ON THE BENCH
description: WHEN I was growing up, I wanted to be a professional basketball player in the winter, a professional football player in the fall, and a professional baseball player in the summer.

title: OPERA: 'ZOROASTRE,' BY BOSTON GROUP
description: This is the 300th anniversary of Jean-Philippe Rameau's birth, and while this greatest of French Baroque composers may not now be played with the frequency he deserves, he need fear nothing in comparison with the grandest masters of Western music.

title: ARMY REALIGNING JOBS AT PICATINNY
description: REORGANIZATION plans under way at the Army Armament Research and Development Command will modernize facilities, realign manpower and consolidate assets to expedite the development and fielding of weapons, according to military and management officials.

title: LAGOS, OIL BOOM FADING, SCARRED BY VAST GROWTH
description: In the catalogue of African capitals, there are many that seem to be frail places, products of colonialism's brief interlude that the traveler might visit and leave without passion or scars. Lagos is not one of them.

title: CONGRESSMAN TRIES TO PREVENT CALIFORNIA APPOINTMENT OF FOE
description: Representative Mervyn M. Dymally, Democrat of California, has resurrected a five-year-old political scandal by recommending that the State Senate reject Michael Franchetti's appointment as California's Director of Finance.

title: SOME HITS AND MISSES FOR THE AILEY TROUPE
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, which closes at the City Center today with two performances, reminds us on its program cover that it is about to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Mr. Ailey founded the company in 1958, and the official 25th-anniversary season begins next fall with a national tour and a silver-anniversary gala in New York that kicks off the troupe's City Center engagement from Nov. 30 through Dec. 18.

title: LINER'S DEBUT DELAYED, BARGAINS IN BRAZIL; Maiden Voyage Of Cruise Ship Is Postponed
description: Not only do the best laid plans of mice and men go astray; so do the plans of cruise lines. Holland-America Cruises has announced that the new pride of its fleet, the Nieuw Amsterdam, will not be keeping its early schedule of voyages.

title: ENGLISH TAILORING: TRES CHIC
description: There's Brooker and there's Barnes, there's a Harper, and a Hobbes, an Old England, and an Auld Reekie, plus a Scott & Bruce, not to mention Hilditch & Key or Ted Lengley. All the English-sounding names belong to men's clothing stores in Paris and they confess to enormous admiration for British masculine elegance. The names also suggest a bit of an inferiority complex because when the Anglo-Saxon consonants run out, the Italian vowels start. Cifonelli, Cristiani, and Smalto are among the best custom tailors in Paris. The names and the suggestion of foreign allegiance leave a lot of logical people thinking that London, Milan, and Rome are better places for men's clothing than Paris.

title: Ronald Jordan Is Married To Elizabeth M. Catalano
description: Elizabeth Margaret Catalano, an international broker for Guy Carpenter & Company, and Ronald Jordan, an options analyst for the American Stock Exchange, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Interfaith Chapel of Long Island University, C.W. Post Center, in Greenvale, L.I., by the Rev. Anthony Stanganelli, a Roman Catholic priest,and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz.

title: A WHALER PUT IN SHAPE FOR HER LAST TRIP
description: SOMETIME this summer the whaling ship Charles W. Morgan will make one more voyage in her remarkable 141-year history. This one will last only hours, a blink of an eye compared with her other voyages, some as long as five years.

title: Mary Pommerich Wed To Stephen J. Conway
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church yesterday, Mary Young Pommerich and Stephen Joseph Conway were married by the Rev. Thomas Splain.

title: 'SEAVIEW' AUTHOR WINS PEN/FAULKNER AWARD
description: Toby Olson, a poet and novelist, has been named winner of the 1983 PEN/ Faulkner Award for Fiction. The $5,000 prize is given annually for the book the judges deem the most distinguished novel or shortstory collection published by an American writer in the previous calendar year. Mr. Olson won for ''Seaview,'' a novel published by New Directions.

title: SALLY HORNOR IS BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Hornor of Osterville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Graham Hornor, to Thomas Joseph Caperna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Caperna of Brooklyn.

title: 3 CHORAL GROUPS IN CONCERT TODAY
description: LOVERS of choral music have three enticing reasons to go to church today, starting at 4 P.M. when the Connecticut Chamber Choir presents an ambitious Americana concert at Bridgeport's Salem Lutheran.

title: Article 182212 -- No Title
description: More than $67 million was paid in a 12-day series of sales of Impressionist and 20th-century artworks at Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's, an all-time high for such a series of art auctions anywhere in the world. The series ended yesterday.

title: A BUDGET BATTLE THAT ECHOES FAR AND WIDE
description: IN a favorite new jab at his critics, President Reagan observes sarcastically these days that his economic program is working so well, Democrats are no longer calling it ''Reaganomics.''

title: Looking Back at Beirut
description: It's been a year since the Israelis invaded Lebanon, and there they sit, just south of the U.S. Marines. Having humiliated Syria and the Soviet Union on the way in, they now depend on Syria and the Soviet Union to let them out.

title: THE PRIVATE HAS BEEN TAKEN OUT OF 'PRIVATE LIVES'
description: Whenever the ballroom orchestra sends a tune tinkling up toward the adjoining balcony suites occupied by Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor in the current desecration of Noel Coward's ''Private Lives,'' the tune is Mr. Coward's own ''I'll See You Again.'' This gives Mr. Burton the opportunity to observe to Miss Taylor that the orchestra has ''a remarkably small repertoire.'' And that, of course, is Mr. Coward's little joke. What is no joke at all is the fact that Miss Taylor's repertoire is even smaller, giving rise to about as much audience merriment as would be suitable for a public hanging.

title: A SCHOOL DISTRICT WEIGHS ITS PRIORITIES
description: IT has been a ritual of spring in the Southbury-Middlebury School District for the past seven years. Through petition, citizens have forced school officials to hold a referendum to decide the education budget for the next school year. On May 4 of this year, the proposed budget was defeated and last Wednesday a pared-down version was approved.

title: PIONEER FARM LABOR ACT IS IMPERILED IN CALIFORNIA
description: California's pioneering farm labor law, hailed by former Gov. Edmund J. Brown Jr. as his greatest personal triumph, is under the strongest attack since its enactment in 1975.

title: WARY TAIWAN KEEPS TIGHT REIN ON FREE EXPRESSION
description: Incidents of Government interference with magazines or books are a constant reminder that there are always limits to free expression here, despite a considerable loosening of restrictions over the last decade by the ruling Nationalist Party.

title: THE THREE SELVES OF CYNTHIA OZICK
description: ART & ARDOR By Cynthia Ozick. 306 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ME ME ME ME ME Not a Novel. By M.E. Kerr. 212 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. (Ages 12 and Up) When Marijane Meaker, who writes under the name of M.E. Kerr, was growing up in a small upstate New York town, her mother missed no opportunity to warn her that ''there isn't a female comedian alive who's happy.'' Fortunately, she never paid her mother the slightest attention. She went right on being funny and, after establishing her career as a writer with a series of suspense novels under the pseudonym Vin Packer, she proceeded, as M.E. Kerr, to produce nine highly successful young adult novels about the heartbreaking comedy of American adolescence.

title: Whitfield Hits 16th
description: Terry Whitfield's two-run homer backed Masayuki Matsunuma's two-hit pitching today as the Seibu Lions beat the Nankai Hawks, 3-0, for their eighth straight Japanese League baseball victory. The homer was the 16th of the season for Whitfield, a former major leaguer.

title: 'OKLAHOMA' IS STILL A LOVABLE MUSICAL
description: NO matter when we saw ''Oklahoma!'' for the first time, or how many musicals we have seen since, this production will somehow symbolize our very first. The Darien Dinner Theater recaptures and, for some, creates the innocent aura of being initiated into a new world of wonder.

title: N.A.A.C.P. DIRECTOR'S SUSPENSION BRINGS SHOCK AND ANGER IN GROUP
description: The suspension of Benjamin L. Hooks as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has sent waves of shock and anger through the organization, members of the association's board and branch officials said yesterday.

title: Galen S. Martin Wed
description: Galen Spaulding Martin, daughter of Mrs. John Stuart Evans of Winnetka, Ill., and Charles Robert Martin of Chicago, was married yesterday to Theodore Oliver Dale Mott, son of Mrs. George Sherman Mott 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Mott. The Rev. Frank M. McClain performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka.

title: Dr. Patricia L. Arnold Weds Donald A. Buss
description: Dr. Patricia Lynn Arnold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Arnold of Kinderhook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Anderson Buss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Buss of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. Patricia Youngdahl performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Third Presbyterian Church in Rochester.

title: A MOVEABLE FEAST OF COOKING SCHOOLS
description: The cooking school vacation may be the most delicious form of the quest for self-development. There is nothing new about schools that train young people to be professional chefs, but schools that offer short courses pertaining more to pleasure than to professionalism are proliferating.

title: Marjorie Gifford Phillips Marries Thomas J. Elliott
description: Marjorie Gifford Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gifford Phillips of New York, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest to Thomas Joseph Elliott, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Elliott of Wilbur by the Sea, Fla. The Rev. Stephen Rodgers performed the ceremony.

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: AFGHANISTAN DENIES ACCUSATIONS BY U.S. OF CIVILIAN BOMBING
description: The official Kabul radio denied today charges by the United States that Soviet bombing has killed hundreds and probably thousands of civilians in Afghanistan in recent weeks.

title: JUST WHAT ARE THE MOTIVES FOR THIS IRREVENENT 'MIKADO'?
description: In the main hall of a school that I once passed through there stood a lifesize copy of the Discus Thrower, forever poised to fling his saucer into the admissions office. With the persistence and ingenuity of youth, student provocateurs would periodically find ways to drag the crouching Grecian figure into the modern world. Anyone arriving early of a morning might find a football helmet on the statue's head, or perhaps a colorful sweatband. Another time, poor old Discobolus would be clutching a slide rule, or maybe wearing an athletic supporter. It was pure sophomoric humor, but even blase seniors were amused, and probably a few of the younger teachers, too. It helped downtrodden youth build solidarity against the ruling elders.

title: Crafts; THE GIVE AND TAKE OF POTTING
description: ''THE pot makes a move and you make a move,'' Bennett Bean told an audience of collectors at the opening of his current show in a SoHo gallery.

title: It's Time to Turn To River Banks
description: Much attention has been paid these past months to interest rates on investments. Decisions must be made: Convert a six-month certificate into a money-market fund? Buy municipal bonds or tax-free securities? Invest in stocks?

title: D.C. Cronin Wed To Virginia Tippit
description: Virginia Mayo Tippit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Carlisle Tippit of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Orlando, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel Charles Cronin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hester Cronin of Moreland Hills, Ohio. The ceremony was performed at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John Andersen, and the the Rev. Martha Shiverick of Columbus, Ohio, a former classmate of the bride at the Laurel School in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMB THROWN IN MILAN WHERE POPE WILL SAY MASS
description: A young man hurled a gasoline bomb today at an open-air stand where Pope John Paul II is scheduled to celebrate mass on Sunday, burning wooden seats, carpeting and a temporary altar on the stand, the police said.

title: STAMFORD SHOW IN ITS 10TH YEAR
description: WITH 100 exhibitors from throughout the Eastern Seaboard to help celebrate its 10th year, the Stamford Antiques Show again will be held at Yacht Haven June 3, 4 and 5. The widely varied exhibit and sale has something for an equally varied group of visitors - a gamut that runs from early furniture and paintings to estate jewelry and other small collectibles.

title: Five Guards Assaulted By Inmates at Auburn
description: Five correction officers were assaulted and injured today by inmates in the gymnasium of the maximum-security Auburn Correctional Facility, officials said.

title: Elizabeth Pollock Married
description: Elizabeth Pollock, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Pollock of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to David Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Womack Harrison Jr. of Longview, Tex. The Rev. Ross B. Baxter performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Michael's Church. Mrs. Harrison is a restoration consultant on Victorian interior decoration and her husband an architect with John Burgee, Architects with Philip Johnson, New York.

title: Martin Forgives Rowdy Fan
description: Martin was feeling magnanimous even before the game. He said he had decided to take no action against the fan who was removed from Friday's game for throwing marshmallows at him.

title: 13 AMERICAN ARTISTS
description: An exhibition that Dorothy Mayhall, the Aldrich Museum's director, believes is ''the most historically important'' the museum has ever presented, opens today and runs through next Sept. 11.

title: BATTERED HOLMES TO CONSIDER RETIRING
description: Larry Holmes removed the wet towel from his face this morning and asked, ''You want to see my eye?'' The right eye was blackened shut and now the heavyweight champion of the world was slipping questions a lot better than he slipped Tim Witherspoon's punches Friday night.

title: SMOKE BILL PASSES
description: ''IT'S a toe in the door for nonsmokers' rights,'' observed State Representative Paul Gionfriddo, Democrat of Middletown. Mr. Gionfriddo was commenting on the General Assembly's approval last week of a bill requiring employers with 50 or more workers to adopt a policy concerning smoking in the work place and post the policy prominently.

title: Handley Captures Final In Houston Bowling
description: Bob Handley rolled strikes on seven of his first eight shots today and defeated Ray Shackelford, 248-204, in the $100,000 Houston Open.

title: Sports of The Times; Commuting To Work
description: IN these shaky times, a colt named Deputed Testamony struck a blow for the comforts of home and the value of family life when he stayed as long as possible near his loved ones yesterday and then went to work and got the job done.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Celebrating a Bridge

title: LESSONS OF POLITICS; Buzzwords
description: A new publication, International Portfolio, describes itself as ''a sound view of foreign affairs.'' This is meant literally. A sample first issue contains two tape cassettes, on which experts chat about nuclear war, the global economic crisis, the third world and British-American relations.

title: THE VIRGINIA SUMMIT
description: There are no ''great expectations'' here about this year's summit meeting of the industrial nations at Williamsburg, Va., over the Memorial Day weekend.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about college lacrosse incorrectly described the University of Virginia's past performance in the national tournament. Virginia won the championship in 1972.

title:
Dining Out;
ROCKLAND: FRENCH AND ITALIAN FARE
description: LA CAPANNINA INN, which is just over the state line in the Rockland County community of Spring Valley, N.Y., is housed in an old building that dates from the early 18th century. The inn was originally owned by a Dutchman, Abraham Garret Haring, but since the 1930's it has functioned as a restaurant under various proprietors.

title: A Screen Show By Any Other Name
description: Is the term ''movie'' an expression of endearment, or can it be a patronizing putdown? To Harold Steinberg (''When It's a Movie, Not a Film,'' April 17), to say ''movies'' is to express love. To say ''film'' or ''cinema,'' on the other hand, is to band oneself as esoteric or elitist.

title: METS ARE PLANNING MORE STARTS FOR ALLEN
description: The bullpen, Neil Allen says, is where ''I found myself. That's where I got my name. That's where I found success. That's where I'd like to return.''

title: A CHINA HAND
description: It might be slightly unfair to characterize chess as an activity for introverts and therefore appropriate as the national game of the Soviet Union. But bridge is without doubt a game for sociable extroverts, which may explain why it is well on the way to becoming the national game of the People's Republic of China.

title: A TOUCH OF THE IRISH POET ON L.I.
description: HE is most unusual: a poet whose books sell, who can be read and enjoyed by the casual reader but whose technical virtuosity meets the demands of academic critics; a provincial Irishman whose universality appeals to readers of all nationalities; a world traveler who, in his mind at least, is never far from home.

title: Bandits Defeat Invaders
description: Mike Kelley, making his first pro start, passed for 307 yards and 2 touchdowns tonight to lead the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 29-9 victory over the Oakland Invaders in the United States Football League. Kelley, who started at quarterback because of injuries to John Reaves and Jimmy Jordan, completed 21 of 40 passes. His touchdown passes were for 21 yards to Eric Truvillion and 16 yards to Willie Gillespie.

title: William Henderson 3d; Foreign-Affairs Expert
description: Dr. William Henderson 3d, who had served as an associate executive director of the Council on Foreign Relations and was manager of international government relations for the Mobil Oil Corporation, died of cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: IN PRAISE OF EARLY MUSIC
description: ONE HUNDRED years ago, music, like science and social justice, rode a confident tide of progress. How much greater would Mozart have been, sighed our great grandfathers, had he possessed the modern accoutrements of a Wagner or a Brahms - the flexibility of horns with valves, the cutting power of metal strings. Progress was real in that optimistic age: Art - like steam turbines - could be made better. The past was an admirable, but technologically primitive, prelude to better things.

title: WILDLIFE AGENCIES CAUTION ON RABIES
description: WHEN 10-year-old Alex Dyer of Croton awoke at 3:30 A.M. and sleepily informed his parents that there was a raccoon prowling around his room, his father patiently sent him back to bed. Unable to sleep, James Dyer went down for coffee and found the garbage overturned. At that moment he heard discordant piano notes coming from the next room and discovered there was, indeed, a raccoon in the house.

title: Paul Robeson
description: To the Editor:

title: Magee Hickey Wed to S.R. Salembier
description: Magee Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Hickey of New York, was married yesterday to S. Richolson Salembier, son of Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mary Lathrop Salembier. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDALS HONOR THE PRESIDENTS OF IRELAND
description: The presidents of Ireland are honored on a new set of gold and silver medals designed and produced by the Dublin jeweler, Thomas Gear. The medals are said to represent the first tribute fashioned either by the Irish government or a private minter.

title: MISS FARWIG, A ROOKIE, TIED FOR LEAD AT 141 IN NEW JERSEY
description: Stephanie Farwig, who is currently the leading candidate for Ladies Professional Golf Association 1983 rookie of the year, strengthened her claim to that honor today when she joined Amy Alcott and Donna White in a tie for the lead after two rounds of the $125,000 Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

title:
Antiques;
WHALING MEMORABILIA IN PRINCETON
description: FOR MANY people, collecting is an enjoyable pastime. For others, like Barbara Johnson, it has been a fulltime passion. Over the last two decades, Mrs. Johnson has amassed at her home here one of the country's great assemblages of whaling memorabilia and paraphernalia, a collection that ranges from anvil to anchor, from scrimshaw to jawbone, from print to painting and from doll to figurehead.

title: L.I.R.R. HAS ITS SIGNALS STRAIGHT AT LAST
description: Thirteen years after Nelson Rockefeller promised to turn the nation's busiest commuter line into the nation's best, the Long Island Rail Road finally seems to be getting somewhere. Ontime performance is the highest since the 1960's, ridership is rising, trains are cleaner and the railroad is poised to begin a $146.5 million electrification project that would trim the longest commutes by roughly 20 percent.

title:
Gardening;
WHEN SHADE BECOMES THE PERFECT LIGHT
description: GARDENS have a way of starting out sunny and becoming shady. It begins with a new house and a new planting. The trees are small and cast very little shadow. The owner may actually feel that they will never grow sufficiently to provide him with the cool comforts of shade during his lifetime.

title: Deadlier Tactics Against Pretoria
description: South African officials were quick to blame black guerrillas last week for an explosion that killed at least 17 people and wounded 188 at the headquarters of the country's air force and prisons in Pretoria. Police Minister Louis Le Grange held the banned African National Congress responsible for exploding a bomb in a parked car during rush hour.

title: TAX DEBATE SET AS PANEL ADOPTS A SPENDING PLAN
description: CONNECTICUT'S General Assembly found itself last week in the same shape as the family household that has pretty well decided what to buy next year, without figuring out how to pay for it.

title: Future Events; In and Out of Town
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Period Setting May 25 - Scenic Hudson Inc. celebrates its 20th anniversary with ''A Night of Wine and Roses'' at Lyndhurst, a Greek Revival mansion overlooking the Hudson River in Tarrytown, N.Y. Black-tie party starts with cocktails on the veranda, followed by dining and dancing in a big white tent and winds up with a fireworks display. Proceeds will enable the nonprofit organization to continue its work of preserving and enhancing the natural resources of the Hudson Valley. Anne Sidamon-Eristoff and John R. Petty are cochairmen. Benefactor tickets, $500, include transportation from the city by limousine; patron tickets, $200, include bus transportation. From 212-874-2390.

title: Postings; HOUSING FOR AGED
description: When the Federal Housing Administration's Section 8 program expired last year, so did plans for several rent-subsidy projects under consideration in the New York area.

title: DEPUTED TESTAMONY WINS PREAKNESS AND PAYS $31
description: Good spellers and serious horseplayers both received a jolt today when a colt misnamed Deputed Testamony scored a 2 3/4-length victory in the 108th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course and Sunny's Halo finished sixth as the 11-to-10 favorite.

title: AT AUTO BUREAUS, NEW STAFF TRAINS AS LINES LENGTHEN
description: ROBERT J. MARCHIONNI had been standing in line at the Motor Vehicles Bureau for nearly an hour trying to register a car he had recently purchased, only to be told that his certificate of ownership was not acceptable.

title: Amherst
description: To the Editor:

title: A BUILDING BOOM TURNS SOUR
description: A GLUT of unleased office space in Danbury has put a damper on the economic boom that followed Union Carbide's move to the city in 1980, and on developers' plans to build 18 new office buildings there. City officials and commercial real-estate agents say that as much as half of the more than 432,000 square feet of office space in 12 buildings built since 1977 is vacant, and no work has begun on the 18 proposed new offices totaling some 820,000 square feet.

title: JEFFERSON HIGH'S HUNTER WINS 400 IN 47.22
description: Roger Hunter admits that he hates to run the 400 meters and considers the 200 his best race. But Mark Mendez, his coach at Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn, insists that Hunter's future is in the 400.

title: MUSIC
description: Music on the Upper West Side spans well past Lincoln Center. This week there will be several intriguing concerts taking place around Columbia University, in the Morningside Heights neighborhood.

title: CAPTURING THE ESSENCE OF WALES
description: What follows is a highly selective list of hotels, restaurants and attractions in a few cities and tourist areas in Wales. Unless otherwise noted, summer hours, in effect from now through September, are from 9:30 or 10 to 6 or 7 daily for most attractions. Many events are free or require only a nominal admission fee.

title: Lawyer Is Found Guilty In Munitions Smuggling
description: A California lawyer has been convicted of conspiring with the former intelligence agent Edwin P. Wilson to smuggle 20 tons of plastic explosives to Libya six years ago.

title: A Roundtable: America's Agenda at the Williamsburg Economic Summit; IS GLOBAL RECOVERY POSSIBLE WITHOUT BAD SIDE EFFECTS?
description: The participants

title: Love Canal Tests Prove Negative
description: Though there is perhaps no better symbol of the hazards of toxic wastes than the contamination of the Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., the actual risks to those who lived there have been difficult to pin down. Last week, a Federal study of chromosomal damage concluded that there was ''no increase in abnormalities'' among 46 current or former Love Canal residents compared to a control group living about a mile away.

title: HEALTH-CARE GUIDE AIMED AT CONSUMER
description: A NURSE who believes that consumers often lack the information they need to choose doctors, dentists and hospitals has published the first in a projected series of directories covering medical services in New Jersey.

title: Fighting Fire Ants
description: The sting of the fire ant not only is painful; it has killed babies and livestock. So for two decades, 13 Southern states battled the ant with Mirex and other deadly chemicals.

title: PORTABLE CLASSROOM SOLVES A PROBLEM
description: FACED with high construction costs and voter fear of overbuilding, a few school districts on the Island that are still growing - all in Suffolk County -are looking for alternative ways to house their students.

title: Abigail F. Rowe Becomes a Bride
description: Abigail Fuller Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ackley Rowe of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to David De Witt Clinton Oswald, son of Audrey Clinton Oswald of Newport, R.I., and Frank G. Oswald Jr. of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church.

title: STIEB WINS 5TH IN A ROW
description: Dave Stieb silenced Baltimore's bats with a four-hitter, and Alfredo Griffin drove in two runs today, leading the Toronto Blue Jays to a 6-0 victory over the Orioles.

title: A Student Speaks On Busing
description: In response to Lee A. Daniels's article ''In Defense of Busing'' (April 17), I can tell you my story and thoughts as a student involved in early efforts at integration in Grand Rapids, Mich., 1969-73.

title: IMMIGRATION REFORM IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: If Congress passes a comprehensive immigration bill this year, it may say as much about the vitality of the legislative process as about the severity of the nation's problem with illegal aliens.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH AMERICA'S LAW SCHOOLS
description: TO ALL OUTWARD APPEARANCES, Stanford Law School is an institution flushed with success. Its campus, the lavish, Mexican-modern Crown Quadrangle, is among the most elegant around. Its faculty includes some of the nation's most highly respected legal scholars and perhaps the most promising collection of younger law professors; together they teach 525 of the brightest law students in the country. In recent years, Stanford has broken into the almost impenetrable inner circle of leading American law schools.

title: STUDENTS HOLD A RALLY AGAINST NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The clouds threatened rain, and the weather kept the turnout smaller than the organizers had wanted. But the spirit of the 500 people at yesterday's Students for Peace disarmament rally in the Bronx did not darken with the skies.

title: Marianne Suters Weds John Varley in Atlanta
description: Marianne Leigh Suters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett T. Suters of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to John J. Varley of Baltimore, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Varley of Bound Brook, N.J. The Rev. William M. Steinbrook Jr. performed the ceremony in the Covenant Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Daniel Stack, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: DOCUMENTS WITH AN AIR OF THEATER
description: Much recent photography bears a striking resemblance to publicity stills taken on the sets of plays, movies and television shows. Like publicity stills, such pictures suggest a narrative situation without actually supplying any real narrative, and they are distanced from the real world by the artifice of their construction. Most are as elaborately and transparently illusionistic as a soapopera interior; the characters who appear in them seem to inhabit the soap-opera realm as well.

title: THE NEW FACE OF BUSINESS LEADERSHIP
description: IN the first few days of the Reagan Administration, business came to town - ferried to the inauguration, in part, by an air force of some 400 corporate jets. They traveled by limousine, threw lavish parties and generally made their presence felt in numbers that Washington had not seen in recent years.

title: PERILS CONFRONT THE YOUNG LIONS OF JAZZ
description: Last summer at the Kool Jazz Festival, 17 young and not-so-young musicians who have been acclaimed by the critics and by their fellow musicians as among the brightest hopes for jazz in the 1980's performed in various combinations in a concert that billed them as the Young Lions of Jazz. Though it was a bit formal and stuffy, as such events usually are, the concert did include some superb performances, which can now be heard on a double-album ''The Young Lions'' (Elektra-Musician).

title: RAIL BUFFS REVIVE PAST IN PRESS FOR FUTURE
description: NEARLY 24 years have elapsed since the end of passenger-train service on the West Shore Railroad between this city and points northward along the Hudson.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CITY SEEN FROM A TO Z Written and illustrated by Rachel Isadora. 32 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $8. (Ages 3 to 6) The city scoured in this alphabet book is the artist's native New York.

title: UNDER THE 1983 CHIC, MOVIES STILL LEER AT WOMEN
description: With more of James Bond, Superman and ''Star Wars'' just over the horizon, and with remakes of everything from ''Unfaithfully Yours'' to ''Where the Boys Are'' on their way, it doesn't look as though movies are currently offering anything different. Sometimes it even seems an act of faith merely to keep on watching the same old formula films, hoping for something - anything - that's a little bit new.

title: A Wider Risk Of AIDS Feared
description: It first seemed that the new and often deadly disease called AIDS was limited to a few groups - homosexual men, intravenous drug users, Haitians, and hemophiliacs and others who receive blood transfusions. A study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, however, suggests the disease may also be transmitted between heterosexual men and women, possibly through sexual contact.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: IT HAS been described as the largest example of a Victorian-style wooden structure along the Hudson River, and when the trustees of Nyack (N.Y.) College in Rockland County were told that 80-year-old Simpson Hall, a dormitory, would have to be condemned because it was a potential firetrap, they took the hard way out. (The school, just over the state line, is said to be the oldest Bible college in the country.)

title: Tass Accuses Reagan On Speech to Cubans
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, accused President Reagan today of making crude attacks on Cuba and the Soviet Union in a speech in Miami Friday in which Mr. Reagan called the Havana Government a fascist regime.

title: TROUBLING WEAKNESSES CLOUD NEW YORK'S ECONOMIC FUTURE
description: Despite the sudden and sharp improvement in New York City's budget prospects for the coming fiscal year, the outlook for the city's economy is clouded by a mixture of good and bad signals, according to city officials and industry representatives.

title: Headliners; Nutty but Nice?
description: Erin Leslie Fleming and Groucho Marx had something less than an idyllic relationship during the last few of their many years together.

title: WILD, BLUE YONDER CAN BE CALM, TOO
description: ON BOARD Air-Evac Flight 40639 near the coast of North Africa, the sun rose slowly, casting a lazy haze over the purple clouds below. The flight commander, 29-year-old Capt. Giuliana Sangiorgio of Sergeantsville, took her eyes off a bank of instruments to glance at the skyline.

title: Q&A
description: Question: We are planning a trip to Nova Scotia in July. Where can I obtain information on special events and attractions along the route through New England? - E.F., Valley Stream, N.Y.

title: Some Further Thoughts On Disrespect
description: For too long, these have been times of general anomie whose symptoms are epidemic, manifesting themselves in society's discourtesy, direspect and contempt for one another and, basically, itself.

title: MEMORIES OF WAFFLES
description: ANY of the dishes that appear on this page reflect a nostalgia of our childhoods - mine in the American South, Pierre's in French Burgundy. Waffles are no exception. I recall in vivid detail the electric waffle irons that were plugged in - sometimes in the dining room, sometimes in the kitchen - in the mornings of my early youth and watching that pale batter as it was poured on the grill, emerging minutes later crisp and golden brown to be served with any of a number of homemade jams and jellies along with country sausage or home-cured ham. (Even as a child I had a loathing for maple syrup, one of my few food prejudices.)

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AS usual, Adele Rubins wasn't listening. The doctors tried to explain to her that people being treated for leukemia should not show up every night at rehearsals of ''Funny Girl.''

title: 2 Trying to Be Oldest To Climb Mt. Everest
description: Two Americans in their 50's climbed today toward the summit of Mount Everest in an attempt to become the oldest climbers to conquer the world's highest mountain.

title: CURB THE HALTING
description: You think synonymy is a waste of time? You think all this fiddling with semantics is an arcane and abstract diversion, far from the applied science of life?

title: FRENCH FARMERS STIR SPANISH WRATH
description: Bands of French farmers have been stopping Spanish trucks in southern France in recent days and spilling agricultural produce onto the roads, producing headlines in the Spanish press and outrage in Spanish hearts.

title:
STAMPS;
A HALF-CENTURY MARK FOR THE NEW DEAL'S T.V.A.
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, one of the world's most ambitious undertakings to harness the forces of nature for the benefit of mankind, has just turned 50 years old. Its half-century is being marked by a new 20-cent commemorative.

title: IN DARKNESS, FOUR MILES OF POETRY
description: AT the end of a cool May evening, the kind on which only the heartiest souls might appear in shirtsleeves, a coterie of men and women assembled on a Connecticut hilltop and peered off to the west.

title: A DRAW COULD BE THE PRUDENT COURSE
description: When you need only a draw but obtain a clear advantage in the game, do you just offer the draw or do you extract every last pound of flesh?

title: COMPROMISE SAVES MOBILE HEALTH UNITS
description: JOINT action by state and Federal officials has salvaged a lifesaving emergency-care system that had been threatened with extinction.

title:
Gardening;
WHEN SHADE BECOMES THE PERFECT LIGHT
description: GARDENS have a way of starting out sunny and becoming shady. It begins with a new house and a new planting. The trees are small and cast very little shadow. The owner may actually feel that they will never grow sufficiently to provide him with the cool comforts of shade during his lifetime.

title: CHAMPIONS OF 1933 ROW AGAIN
description: CARRYING a letter of encouragement from President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the high hopes of their coach and headmaster, the Rev. Frederick H. Sill, eight young men brought to Kent School 50 years ago its first victory in England's historic Royal Regatta at Henley.

title: STRIKING A MOOD
description: DESPITE their insistently singular devotion to function and clean lines, most designers of modern interiors, whether consciously or inadvertently, tend to create signature moods: pervasive atmospheres that transcend function and distinguish their work from that of their colleagues. And generally, when such a designer is chosen, the client is attracted by an instantly recognizable style, not by an exceptional skill at space planning.

title:
JOURNEYS THROUGH WALES;
AN ANCESTRAL LAND DISCOVERED
description: ''Plentyn Cymreig ydwi, a plant Cymreig oedd fy rhieni.'' Which is Welsh for ''A child of Wales am I, as my ancestors were too.'' My mother used to advise me never to talk about myself in front of strangers. But when the subject is Wales, I have to: Wales and I are bound together. And since I'm not talking face to face, but on paper, perhaps my mother would forgive me.

title: STALIN'S DAUGHTER LIVING IN BRITISH UNIVERSITY TOWN
description: More than 15 years after her defection to the West, Stalin's daughter, Svetlana, has settled in this university town northeast of London with her 11-year-old daughter, Olga.

title: Pigeon Express
description: What is the fastest and cheapest way to get copies of engineering designs up a mountain? After weighing alternatives, the Lockheed Missile and Space Company put pigeons on the payroll in December 1981.

title: OFFICE DIRECTORIES COMING ON LINE
description: AVISITOR entering the lobby of a skyscraper office building usually has to scrutinize a glass-paneled directory to find out where he is going. A lot of time can be wasted this way, especially when the directory covers an entire lobby wall and lists many tenants twice - once under their own names and once under the name of their companies.

title: AS LEBANON POWDER KEG, BEKAA HAS EVERYTHING
description: ''It's southern Lebanon all over again,'' a senior Lebanese political analyst said. ''The cast of characters pitted against each other are the same. It is the focus of attention and tension - the next flashpoint for a Syrian-Israeli war, if it comes to that.''

title: IN MIDDLESEX, YOUNG PEOPLE CAN AFFORD A NEW HOME
description: THE philosophy that Kevork Hovnanian brings to home building in New Jersey went on view yesterday when selling started at the ''preliminary grand opening'' of a new subdivision called Society Hill at East Brunswick. But model houses were nowhere in sight.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE CORPSES WERE DUMMIES, BUT AREN'T THEY ALWAYS
description: NO doubt about it, a heinous crime had been committed at the Tarantula Arms Motel. There was Big Louie, folded into the refrigerator, bleeding all over the cheese and eggs. And there was his sweetie, Bella Donna, lying lifeless on the sofa, a blue ruffled boa wrapped around her neck.

title: CITY TO OPEN A DOWNTOWN OFFICE FOR CASHING EMPLOYEE PAYCHECKS
description: New York City is planning to enter the check-cashing business - not because it wants to, but because it must if 77,000 city workers are to continue receiving paychecks.

title: Leslie Stephen
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: STAMFORD and Greenwich have joined towns around the state and nation in offering an electronic emergency-aid system to elderly or disabled people. The units, 100 of which are in use in Fairfield County now, consist of a permanently installed box with a telephone line connected to a response station, and a portable device the size of a cigarette pack that the person may carry up to 200 feet from the base unit.

title: Over 1,200 Join March In Salute to the Military
description: The blare of brass mixed with the muffled sounds of tanks, mortar carriers and howitzers on Fifth Avenue yesterday as more than 1,200 military men and women marched in the annual Armed Forces Day Parade.

title: HOW THE EAR PLAYS TRICKS
description: Engineers would have you believe - and often they believe it themselves - that they are always in possession of exact knowledge. They like to see themselves as the valiant knights of the age of science, blazing the straight and true path of technical progress by the light of pure reason.

title: MRS. THATCHER OWES A BIG CAMPAIGN DEBT TO FLABBY FOES
description: While checking the history books the other day, David Watt of the Royal Institute of International Affairs made an intriguing discovery: British voters have not once in this century given to any government what Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is seeking in next month's general election - a clear mandate to carry on for a second full term with the same leader who won the preceding election.

title: CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE: HOW IT ORIGINATES
description: A CONNECTICUT man married to a domineering woman he does not love is now serving time in the high-security prison in Somers for sexually abusing his wife's daughter from a previous marriage.

title: ADAPTING TO HARD TIMES
description: LOCAL government can survive! Strong words indeed from an official of a city that found itself on the brink of bankruptcy in 1975. Yet, in an ironic way, the hard times that Long Beach has endured have proved to be an asset in the present economic environment.

title: Carole Conover Is Wed To Frank Slusser Jr.
description: Carole Ann Conover, a public-relations executive in New York, was married yesterday to Frank Willard Slusser Jr., a reporter for United Press International. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony in the chapel of Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: COLD SPRING'S WATER AT ISSUE
description: NICK ANDEIC, his wife and two children know that a bubbling spring in Cold Spring Harbor has been declared a health hazard by the Suffolk County Department of Health and the Town of Huntington, but they fill their pitchers with the clear, cool water every week anyway.

title: SOLID EVIDENCE OF PATRONAGE IN 2 SHOWS
description: ART galleries in New York City may take the initiative in showing new artists but they will also follow a museum's suit in exhibitions. Either way, the two groups remain conscious of each other and though it doesn't necessarily guarantee superlative shows or new geniuses, the relationship contributes to the city's supremacy as an art capital.

title: HIRSHHORN BEQUEST ADDS TO COLLECTION
description: During his lifetime, Joseph Hirshhorn, the modern-art patron, stocked the museum here that bears his name with thousands of objects. At the same time he filled his two houses here with artworks, and he got to a point at which he also had to lease a warehouse on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Feud at the Top In N.A.A.C.P.
description: Like many civil rights organizations, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the oldest and largest of such groups, has in recent years been steadily losing membership and divided about its sense of purpose. And, like many organizations that are foundering, the N.A.A.C.P. has turned increasingly to internal bickering.

title: CUOMO AIDES SEEK COHALAN OPPONENT
description: THE Cuomo administration has joined in the Suffolk County Democratic chairman's search for a candidate to oppose County Executive Peter F. Cohalan this fall.

title:
ON THE BOOKSHELF;
ANATOMY OF A SUMMIT CONFERENCE
description: Economic Summitry, by George de Menil and Anthony M. Solomon. Council on Foreign Relations, New York. paperback. $8.95.Next weekend, amid great international fanfare, the leaders of the seven major industrial powers in the Western alliance will gather in Williamsburg, Va., for their ninth annual economic summit meeting. Inevitably, all the pomp, circumstance and cost - to say nothing of the clearly limited prospects for substantive accomplishment at the gathering - have raised the question: Is all of this really worthwhile?

title: A GARDEN HOME FOR TINY ALPINES
description: True alpine plants grow in the mountains high above timberline. There they hug the earth for shelter from winds and burst into bloom each spring. Baked by the sun, their roots are bathed in a trickle of cool water.

title:
Gardening;
WHEN SHADE BECOMES THE PERFECT LIGHT
description: GARDENS have a way of starting out sunny and becoming shady. It begins with a new house and a new planting. The trees are small and cast very little shadow. The owner may actually feel that they will never grow sufficiently to provide him with the cool comforts of shade during his lifetime.

title: 3 Breeds Granted Registry by A.K.C.
description: After a decade, the barks of three breeds finally have been heard at 51 Madison Avenue, home of the American Kennel Club. The organization's board of directors has authorized the addition of the Portuguese water dog, the Pharaoh hound and the Tibetan spaniel for registry into its stud book, starting Aug. 1. Next Jan. 1, the three breeds will become eligible to compete for breed, group and best-inshow awards as well as championships.

title: Glen Cove Affair
description: The cold war between Glen Cove, L.I., and the Soviet Union broke out just a year ago, and in no time the two sides were fighting about the beaches.

title: SPECIALS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: WITH fewer than a dozen major supermarkets to serve the city's 320,000 residents, officials were concerned when they heard that still another store was plannning to close.

title: Inside the Divided Mind
description: As a psychotherapist in the process of completing a successful treatment of a patient with a multiple-personalitylike illness, I read Ellen Hale's stimulating article ''Inside the Divided Mind'' (April 17) with particular interest. Though most therapists treat few true ''multiples,'' we do see a number of patients who, like mine, can be correctly diagnosed in the borderline-psychotic range, but who employ multiplelike defenses. These are patients whose early traumas were so severe that they created personality fragments which became ''keepers'' of the thoughts, feelings and memories associated with the experiences. These patients differ from multiples in that the fragments do not necessarily ''grow up'' with the patient. Rather, they emerge, to the surprise of the patient and therapist, in the course of treatment, as the memory of the trauma for which they were created becomes accessible to the patient's ego. The fragment looks and acts as it did when it was first created - often like an enraged or suicidal young child - as if emerging from a kind of psychological cryogenesis. Consequently, this development can be erroneously confused with transference psychosis, a severe regression of the patient in response to the therapist, usually to be avoided. On the contrary, the emergence of individual personality fragments in treatment is good and should be welcomed, though, of course, dealt with cautiously, since it signals the beginning of a systematic, though unconscious attempt by the patient to achieve fusion. In each successive working-through, there is a moment of risktaking when the fragment first needs to trust the rest of the personality, believing that though there was great danger once, it is now safe to give up its split-off existence.
Size: 22 to 26 inches. Color: Pure white with black bill and legs; conspicuous yellow feet.

title: PATIENTS, DOCTORS NEED 'PARTNERSHIP' ON MALPRACTICE
description: IN the last few years, in these pages and elsewhere, we have been bombarded by propaganda from the medical establishment concerning malpractice. The main thrust of their whining is that physicians in all specialties are paying too much in malpractice insurance premiums because of excessive awards to generally litigious patients who are egged on by avaricious lawyers eager to prey on them on a contingency basis. Their solution is to pass laws that will dramatically limit awards so their insurance rates can be reduced to reasonable amounts. This is analogous to solving our crime problems by giving shorter or no sentences to lawbreakers. To reduce crime, we must stop criminal behavior, which has been unsuccessfully attempted since the beginning of civilization. To reduce malpractice costs is easier. We need only reduce malpractice.

title: PROPOSED HOSPITAL FEE IS ASSAILED
description: A new state regulatory fee levied on New York's health-care industry ''flies in the face'' of Federal efforts to help ease New York hospitals' deteriorating finances and should be disapproved, the regional Federal health administrator has recommended.

title: Poland Creates A Young Martyr Of Resistance
description: Next to the massed red carnations and Solidarity streamers, the sign on the young man's grave read ''another Polish victim.'' But this was a very special victim. Twenty thousand Warsaw students, workers, intellectuals and Roman Catholic Church activists gave the ''V'' sign of resistance to military rule as they marched behind the coffin of 19-year-old Grzegorz Przymek, who died last weekend after a beating by police.

title: THE TOURIST AS TARGET
description: To Roberta Sydorko, a vacation should be ''a time of relaxation and excitement -not having to look over your shoulder every minute to see if you are being stalked.''

title: Mary McDermott Wed To Ernesto M. Nassau
description: Mary Elizabeth McDermott, daughter of Mrs. Thomas H. Connell of Westport, Conn., and the late John R. McDermott, was married yesterday to Ernesto Manuel Nassau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Helmut Nassau of Mexico City. Justice of the Peace John Minor Williams of Westport performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, who is an editor of The Hour in Norwalk.

title: Barbara J. Cook, an Aide to First Lady, Will Marry James P. Fabiani in July
description: Barbara J. Cook, deputy press secretary to Nancy Reagan, plans to be married in July to James P. Fabiani, a senior associate in the government-relations firm of Schlossberg-Cassidy & Associates in Washington.

title: Arizona Criticizes Curbs
description: The University of Arizona ''is disappointed in the severity of the penalties'' imposed on its football program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the president of the college, Henry Koffler, said today.

title: Adventure Series
description: To the Editor:

title: Quay Brown Becomes Bride
description: Quay Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Q. Brown of Charlestown, R.I., was married there yesterday to Mark Allen Sternburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. John Sternburg of Norwalk, Conn.

title: THE CHANGING FACE OF MUNICIPAL DEBT
description: THE municipal bond market, which has grown to a $430 billion colossus using old-fashioned bearer bonds, will more closely resemble other debt markets after June 30, when Federal law requires new bonds to be issued in registered form.

title: Q and A; The Employer as Landlord
description: Question: The building in which I rent an apartment is owned by a hospital, which is also my employer. The hospital, as my landlord, did not provide me with a lease for my apartment and asked that I pay an ''occupancy fee'' each month. I have been subject to annual rent and fuel-cost increments that have almost doubled my rent. Am I entitled to a lease? Is there an agency where I can seek help? ... K.K.R., Manhattan

title: Miss Demetz Wed To M.M. Posever
description: The Dwight Chapel at Yale University was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne-Marie Demetz, daughter of Peter Demetz and Hana Demetz-Rosskam, both of New Haven, and Michael Maguet Posever, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix C. Posever of Whittier, Calif. The Rev. Hans Frei of Yale performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER

title: AUSTRALIAN ROCKS ARE OLDEST FOUND
description: Geologists working in the mountains of Western Australia have discovered grains of rock that are 4.1 billion to 4.2 billion years old, by far the oldest ever found on the earth.

title: SOCIALISM AS MANHOOD
description: EUGENE V.DEBS Citizen and Socialist. By Nick Salvatore.Illustrated. 437 pp. Chicago: University of Illinois Press. $24.95. BECAUSE Eugene V. Debs has long personified American socialism in the popular imagination, each successive group which laid claim to that heritage has refashioned the legend of Debs in its own image.
