The Bancroft Prize-winning biography by the Cornell historian Nick Salvatore differs from all of its predecessors in two important respects: Its unswerving determination to be true to the documentary record of Debs's career, and its persuasive analysis of aspects of 19th-century American culture which Debs drew upon for his own ideas and through which he communicated with his own generation.

title: Mrs. Gandhi on Election Trip
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today began an election tour of the Himalayan border state of Jammu and Kashmir, where one person has been killed and more than 100 injured in political clashes in the last two days. The state election is June 5.

title: Kentucky Mission
description: The Kentucky Commerce Department said last year that businesses in its state hoped to increase their trade with South Africa, a move that many states viewed with restraint because of that country's apartheid policy.

title: FENDING OFF VIOLENCE
description: SELECTED POEMS By John Montague. 189 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Wake Forest University Press/ University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95..JOHN MONTAGUE is very much the Irish poet. He has all the credentials: His middle name is Patrick, he was educated at St. Patrick's College, Armagh, he teaches in Cork, he edited ''The Book of Irish Verse,'' and he was born in Brooklyn. Fortunately, he is skeptical about the indomitable Irish. It is because his poems find love hard - whether it is the love of Ireland or of individuals - that they do find love.

title: INSIDE ELSEWHERE
description: THE CITADEL OF THE AUTARCH Volume Four of ''The Book of the New Sun.'' By Gene Wolfe. 317 pp. New York: Timescape Books/ Simon & Schuster. $15.95. THE EYE OF THE HERON By Ursula K. Le Guin. 179 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. THE VOID CAPTAIN'S TALE By Norman Spinrad. 250 pp. New York: Timescape Books/ Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: DIGGER PHELPS ON COACHING, BASKETBALL AND EDUCATION
description: This article is an edited excerpt from a radio transcript of a question-and-answer session that Richard (Digger) Phelps, the Notre Dame basketball coach, had with the National Press Club earlier this month.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE ASIATICS. By Frederic Prokosch. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.25.) The ordinary canons of criticism seem ''hopelessly inadequate'' for a book as well written as this one, L.H. Titterton said in his 1935 review of a novel many writers praised. The tale of a young American who makes his way across Asia from Beirut to the China Sea, it is filled with color, movement, complex personalities, accidents and adventures that display varied aspects of the Asian mind and spirit. ''Passage after passage,'' Mr. Titterton declared, ''seems to express some truth that we have many times, in a stumbling way, attempted to state.''

title: Kate McMahon To Wed Aug. 20
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Horace McMahon of Rowayton, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Katherine Mara McMahon, to Stuart Barnard Upson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Upson of Darien, Conn. The wedding is to be on Aug. 20.

title: THINKING SMALL IN HOUSTON
description: S prawling Houston, the most supremely Texan of Texas towns, seems an odd place to convince people that small is better. Bigness is held a virtue in itself, and by Houston standards the fellow who builds a better mousetrap is usually the one who sets out to catch a moose.

title: A FOREIGN POLICY FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: The centrist Presidents the authors admire led our soldiers through more than a decade of jungle warfare, and their centrist predecessors were responsible for their share of mischief of a similar nature - in Iran, Nicaragua and Guatemala, to name a few. These are not merely mistakes, they do spring from fundamentals of policy. It is entirely possible that without a radical reconsideration of the fundamentals, a ''responsible'' centrist will preside over another war in Central America. DAVE DENISON, Chicago

title: THE ROEBLINGS: A STATE LINK TO HISTORY
description: ALTHOUGH the Brooklyn Bridge, which will be 100 years old on Tuesday, physically connects Manhattan and Brooklyn, it has strong links to New Jersey as well, and one of the strongest is the Roebling family, which built the span.

title: WROTE 'CIVILISATION' TV SERIES
description: Kenneth Clark, art historian, museum director, author and narrator of the television series ''Civilisation'' and for many years a preeminent figure in British cultural life, died yesterday in a nursing home in Hythe, England, after a short illness. He was 79 years old.

title: A TOUGH TIME FOR SIBERIAN MINING
description: FROM a bluff a few miles outside this new Siberian town, a visitor can see giant power shovels clawing at jagged piles of rock at the face of a man-made canyon.

title: ABC Sports Role In Climb Defined
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Noshing at the Summit
description: Forty-five years ago, George VI and his wife, Elizabeth, came to lunch with Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt at Hyde Park. ''I had corralled two friends to cook hot dogs on an outdoor fireplace,'' Mrs. Roosevelt wrote, ''and we had smoked turkey which Their Majesties had not tasted before, several kinds of ham cured in different ways from different parts of the United States, salads, baked beans and a strawberry shortcake with strawberries from Henry Morgenthau's farm in Dutchess County.''

title: ECOLOGY PROGRAM PLANNED FOR CHILDREN
description: SOMETHING new will be offered to children in the county this summer - an ecology program specially designed to keep youngsters probing many facets of nature they usually are not exposed to.

title: RUTHERFORD WOMAN FIGHTS FOR M.I.A.'S
description: CONVINCED that United States officials have been covering up the retention of American servicemen in Indochina, Josephine McAtarian is fighting to open up the issue and bring the men home.

title: Helen L. Orth, a Lawyer, Marries Henry A. Cross
description: Helen Louise Orth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bruce Orth of Moorestown, N.J., was married there yesterday to Henry Andrew Cross, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H.A. Cross of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Frederick Missel performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: TRAPPING CONTROVERSY TAKES NEW TURN
description: UNTIL now, the animal-trapping controversy in New Jersey has focused on both the need for trapping to control wildlife population and disease and the possibility of damaging domestic animals and nongame birds.

title: AMHERST
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chicago, No Letup
description: The plans of Chicago's recently inaugurated Mayor to change things at City Hall were first sidetracked by his political enemies. They might be derailed altogether if a court decision last week is allowed to stand.

title: THE DAY THE BARBIE DOLLS LEFT HOME
description: LAST week my daughter parted with her Barbie dolls. As I was leaving the house, she handed me that little pink trunk with Barbie's name on it that I knew so well.

title: Correction
description: In the article ''Privacy Preserved - Almost'' (Travel, May 15) about touring the Palace of Liria, the home of the Dutchess of Alba in Madrid, the address to which prospective visitors may write for reservations was omitted because of a production error.

title: Aftermath of An Abduction
description: News reports had spread the story of Willow Lynne Cramlet and her search for her son Eland, abducted by his father three and a half years earlier. Some Tulsa, Okla., residents thought the description fit a boy they knew as ''Jeff'' and they said as much to Miss Cramlet last week. Mother and son are now together at her home in Arvada, Colo., after Miss Cramlet, aided by Tulsa police, came and collected him.

title: A VISION OF THE WOUNDED GENIUS
description: THE PORTABLE EDMUND WILSON Edited, with an Introduction and Notes, by Lewis M. Dabney. 647 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $18.75. Penguin Books, Paper, $6.95. THE FORTIES From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period. By Edmund Wilson. Edited, with an Introduction, by Leon Edel. Illustrated. 369 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: ERIC HOFFER, DOCKWORKER-AUTHOR WHO LOOKED INTO LIFE, DIES AT 80
description: Eric Hoffer, an itinerant farm worker who became a longshoreman and whose musing on life, power and social order turned him into a celebrated author-philosopher, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: INSIDE THE DIVIDED MIND
description: It was interesting to read that work is being done to help patients with multiple-personality disorder that concurrently throws light on the nature of consciousness itself. But Ellen Hale's provocative discussion did not satisfy me on one point: What kind of research is being done on the violent mind? Has any work been done with the parents of patients with multiple-personality disorder? The real mental disorder is not so much the divided mind, but rather the mind of a man who would continually rape his daughter throughout her childhood or of a mother who could comply with such cruelty. Now that multiple personality is gaining ''new credence'' in the psychiatric world, let's hope that doctors will move on to conquer the disorders that cause this manifestation in the first place, however difficult that task may be. ELIZABETH FOSTER, Monsey, N.Y.

title: THE NEXT WAVE RIDES A NEW TIDE
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music is planning a major reorganization of its avant-garde series, Next Wave, and will receive major new funding for nationwide tours of its performances during the next three years.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: CUTE LITTLE THINGS, BUT NOT IN THE HOUSE
description: SOME things go bump in the dawn. Actually, they clatter, and this last rainy April, they have clattered a lot. Just what was doing a claw dance on top of the air-conditioner we weren't sure, but it sounded as though the entire inside of the machine was being rearranged.

title: Lebanon, Israel Sign Pact - and Hope for the Best
description: Despite a barrage of threats from Syria and timid silence from most other Arab countries, Lebanon last week signed the American-mediated troop withdrawal agreement with Israel. The Lebanese Parliament, meeting behind closed doors under heavy security, unanimously endorsed the accord. In Israel, the Labor opposition underlined its objections to the conduct of the war by abstaining in the Knesset's 57-to-6 vote of approval.

title: CONCERT: ENGLISH ORGAN MUSIC
description: Now that the Metropolitan Museum has acquired and restored an 1830 Thomas Appleton organ and installed it imposingly on a balcony of the Equestrian Court, the instrument is being used to shed light upon a kind of music that is virtually unknown here nowadays. This is music composed for English organs from the 17th through the 19th centuries.

title: WESTBETH RACES FORECLOSURE DEADLINE
description: COUNTLESS handbills and posters clutter the cork bulletin boards near the mailboxes at Westbeth, the artists' rental housing complex in West Greenwich Village. But amid the colorful cluster, a block of black print on white paper stands out.

title: FURS AND CLOTHES: ARTFUL PAIRINGS
description: John Anthony provided a perfectly rational explanation for the fact that most fashion designers inevitably show their fur collections on models wearing pants.

title: LIVING WITH FEAR FOR 38 YEARS ALOFT
description: FRANK COMPOSTO stood on the East River pier, casting a curious glance up at ''his'' bridge and listening to the drone of traffic - like a giant swarm of bees - overhead.

title: AFRICAN DEMOCRACY HAS A LIFE OF ITS OWN
description: When Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi called early elections last week, some bewildered outsiders wondered about the purpose of a vote that would offer only one party and, probably, only one presidential candidate.

title: James P. Jenkins Wed to Nevitt Nugent
description: Nevitt Nugent, an artist and interior designer in private practice in New York, was married yesterday to James P. Jenkins, a vice president of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. The Rev. Randall Lee Saxon performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: Charles Miesmer Wed to Miss Cole
description: Lindsey Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dodd Cole of Pomfret, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles Reeve Miesmer, son of Audrey Rueger of Sarasota, Fla., and Charles William Miesmer of New York. The Rev. James Birdsall performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Clark Memorial Chapel at the Pomfret School.

title: Ruth Johnson Weds John R. Stevenson
description: The marriage of Ruth Carter Johnson of Fort Worth, Tex., and John R. Stevenson, chairman and senior partner of the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, took place yesterday in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Fort Worth. Msgr. Vincent Wolf, assisted by the Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: OPERA: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'
description: Singing may be the most important element in opera, but it is certainly not the only one, and productions can falter seriously when other factors are given exceedingly short shrift. The Opera Ensemble of New York has run into bad luck on this account with its current production of Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' at the Lillie Blake School Theater, which is to run through tonight.

title: NATO WAR GAMES ARE FIRST IN TURKEY ALONG SOVIET BORDER
description: NATO's Southeastern Command is preparing for the first multinational deterrent and combat exercises in eastern Turkey, bordering on the Soviet Union, which are to be held early next month.

title: CULTIVATING CULTURE IN PARIS
description: After a decade of dol-drums, Paris is in the midst of a New Yorkinspired campaign to turn it into a ''fun city'' again: rock concerts in the subway, ballets in the Gare Montparnasse, chamber music in the parks for the first time in years. And there are now two Paris marathons, one on foot and one on roller skates.

title: EX-BEATTY AIDE MADE RECORDINGS AS EVIDENCE
description: A woman who worked for former State Senator Vander L. Beatty in his unsuccessful race for Congress in 1982 secretly recorded her conversations with him to help gather evidence of possible election fraud against him, court documents show.

title: Focus on Targets
description: The 12-member Federal Open Market Committee, which sets the course of monetary policy, will gather at the Federal Reserve Tuesday for a regular session and a special spring review of the 1983 monetary targets that were set in February.

title: CONSORTUIM AIDED
description: THE Suffolk County Consortium, representing 12 communities, recently received the second-largest amount of community-development block-grant funds to an urban county administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York regional office. Only Nassau received more, and those disbursements were reported earlier.

title: HOW A CONTROVERSIAL JOURNALIST'S STORY WAS BROUGHT TO TV
description: ''Iam not a political person,'' Linda Yellen said, sipping a glass of white wine and speaking, as is her style, with deliberation, calmly measuring her words. Hers is the understated manner that somehow expresses modesty and conviction at the same time. ''I don't understand politics in the sense of what is happening currently,'' she went on. ''I'm interested in politics on the human level, in what happens to people.''

title: Gerald Galvin 3d Betrothed To Susan Hussian, a Nurse
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent P. Hussian Jr. of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Hussian, to Gerald Galvin 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Galvin Jr. of Forest Hills Gardens.

title: REGGAE: MUTABARUKA
description: ''I am not a singer,'' said the Jamaican poet Mutabaruka from the stage of the Ritz on Thursday. ''But people get bored when they hear too much talking.''

title: SALVADOR PARALLELS VIETNAM. THIS TIME, LET'S WIN
description: El Salvador's parallels to Vietnam are so startlingly exact that the Administration is foolish to deny them. If President Reagan sensibly acknowledged them, and Congress stops obliging the left, for whom might makes right, this time we might win.

title: Salesman Is Shot in Holdup At Store on Park Ave. South
description: A 23-year-old Queens man was shot in the face yesterday during a holdup at the Park Avenue South furniture store where he is a salesman, the police said.

title: A.C. Brown Weds Elizabeth Gonzalez
description: Elizabeth Gonzalez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Gonzalez of Miami Lakes, Fla., formerly of Havana, was married yesterday to Andrew Clemmer Brown of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ray Francis Brown. The Rev. James A. Carpenter, the bridegroom's foster father and professor of theology and subdean of the General Theological Seminary in New York, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the seminary's Chapel of the Good Shepherd.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: TOMORROW afternoon will almost certainly represent the last chance for county residents to speak out on the proposed redistricting plan for the Board of Legislators. Minor adjustments have been made, and speakers will be addressing what appears to be the final version.

title: Kathryn A. Abele Marries J.P. Devine Jr., Executive
description: Kathryn Ann Abele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Abele of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday in St. Agnes Cathedral to John P. Devine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Devine of Bellmore, L.I. The Rev. Thomas F. Sinnott of Riverhead, L.I., performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: THE LOVE OF NATURE: MORE DISSENT
description: I would like to respond to Howard Schneider's ''A Few Dissenting Thoughts on the Love of Nature.'' Although I am involved with environmental causes and am a volunteer at the Bronx Zoo, which includes giving free educational tours to the general public, I am not ''harbor(ing) decidedly unfriendly attitudes toward the public (I'm) supposedly working in behalf of.''

title: RIDING THE RAILS A LA J.P.MORGAN
description: When DeWitt Chapple, president of Chapple Leasing Inc. of Middletown, Ohio, goes on a business trip, he takes the train. But when Mr. Chapple sees America on Amtrak, he sees it through the windows of his own private railroad car.

title: JAPAN
description: To the Editor:

title: SLOWER START FOR THE RECOVERY
description: Off to a weak start: The economy grew more slowly in the first quarter than forecast, the Commerce Department said. The estimate had been for growth of 3.1 percent in the gross national product, but the revision came in at 2.5 percent. The shortfall, however, was attributed to a sharper-than-expected decline in inventories, and the first-quarter performance isn't changing the outlook for strong second-quarter growth.

title: Jennifer W. Salinger Marries William W. Duffy 2d
description: Jennifer Wilson Salinger, daughter of Mrs. Herman Salinger of Durham, N.C., and the late Dr. Salinger, was married in Alexandria, Va., yesterday to William Walton Duffy 2d, son of Mary O. Duffy of Providence, R.I., and the late Robert C. Duffy. The Rev. Mark S. Anschutz performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: MORE THAN ONE KIND OF ARMS RACE WORRIES BRITISH
description: Mention police and guns in the same breath and most British citizens summon up a vision of what they politely call the ''American illness.'' They are fed bloody television images of real or fictional American police in action, and they are appalled by even a hint that British police should be routinely outfitted with sidearms. Yet, firearms are entering the urban equation here as more and more police officers are being armed to counter the growing use of lethal force by criminals.

title: DUMBARTON OAKS SHOWS OFF ITS RARE COINS; WASHINGTON
description: One of the more distinguished exhibitions of the year consists of exactly 12 Byzantine icons. Such are the dimensions of the show that if you happen to sneeze when you come into the room you may well walk right past it. But this, if ever, is a case in which small is beautiful.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Bon Voyage

title: AT LAST, A WELCOME PUBLIC SPACE FOR MANHATTAN
description: It is tempting to say that there has not been a first-class public open space created in Manhattan since Central Park. It would not be true, of course - there is Paley Park, and the promenade over the East River Drive at Carl Schurz Park, and the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art. But the list of decent open spaces is short - so short that it seems reasonable to wonder if we know far less than we once did about how to make civilized and comfortable outdoor places. It is certainly no exaggeration to say that most of the parks, plazas, promenades and squares that have been built in the last few years have been urbanistic catastrophes - harsh, unwelcoming spaces that seem to have been designed more with the intent of keeping people out than inviting them in.

title: Wulff Designs a New Flyfishing Line
description: AT an age when many men have drifted into a twilight of inactivity, Lee Wulff, whom many consider the most accomplished all-round fly fisherman in the world, continues to drive himself as he drives a long cast into half a gale sweeping down a broad salmon river.

title: STEPPING OUT FROM THE SHADOWS
description: A PRIVATE VIEW By Irene Mayer Selznick. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. ONCE upon a time - and even today in certain quarters - young ladies ''came out'' by arriving at balls in white dresses, signaling their arrival as marriageable adults. Nowadays women ''come out'' in a far different and more encompassing way, and at almost any point during their adult lives. There is nothing more exciting than the ''debut'' of a middle-aged or older woman who takes stock of her life and says, ''I'm responsible.''

title: DON'T SUBJECT THE FED TO PRESIDENTIAL CONTROLS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 DEMOCRATS FAVORED IN SPECIAL ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS
description: Two Democratic district leaders are favored to win Assembly seats in special elections in predominantly Democratic districts in the Bronx and Queens on Tuesday.

title: MOZART CONCERT ARIAS BESTOW MANY REWARDS
description: Mozart wrote 35 independent arias, to be used by singers for performance in concert, as substitutes for existing arias in operas by himself or other composers or as added inserts in such operas. Sixteen are available on two independent, highly rewarding disks recently released by London Records. They were recorded two years ago in the Sofiensaal in Vienna with Christopher Raeburn as producer and Gyorgy Fischer conducting the Vienna Chamber Orchestra. For one album the soprano is Kiri Te Kanawa (OS 26661); for the other the soprano is Edita Gruberova (OS 26662). Since the repertory on the two disks does not overlap and the artists do not differ much in quality, you would do well to get them both.

title: Louis-Schmeling And a Shoelace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Gallup Reports Glenn Cutting Mondale Lead
description: A new Gallup Poll shows that Walter F. Mondale is still leading in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination but that Senator John Glenn of Ohio has narrowed the former Vice President's lead since the last Gallup survey.

title: Deirdre Clancy Is Married
description: Deirdre Osgood Clancy, daughter of Patricia Hendren Clancy of New York and the late James Scott Clancy, was married yesterday to John Jay Feeney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Feeney of Albany.

title: Francesca Stanfill Marries Peter Tufo
description: Francesca Stanfill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Stanfill of Los Angeles, and Peter Tufo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gustave F. Tufo of Chicago, were married in Southampton, L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church.

title: ON ARMS CONTROL, THE RISING PRESSURE IS MAINLY POLITICAL
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union have been maneuvering vigorously on nuclear arms control without making appreciable progress. In the process, the two sets of talks in Geneva, on medium-range and intercontinental-range forces, are coming to bear the full burden of Soviet-American relations - perhaps too much weight to make headway now or perhaps so much that real movement will become politically irresistible later.

title: CELEBRITIES JOIN TOURISM CAMPAIGN
description: BOTTOM the burro and Quack the duck will make their television debuts this summer, with their owner, the actress June Havoc, in a series of commercials promoting tourism in Connecticut. Filming of the spots began last week in Wilton at Cannon Crossing, the 19thcentury village that has been restored by Miss Havoc.

title: WOMEN'S WORK
description: With the recent announcement of the PEN awards for fiction, this year's literary laurel-giving season comes to an end. And at the risk of sounding chauvinist, I'd like to point out that the most notable aspect of the season was a near sweep of the various prizes by women.

title: Lewis Hine's Last Legacy
description: It was during my years of graduate study that I discovered the photographic beauty celebrated in Lewis Hine's work (''Lewis Hine's Last Legacy,'' by Judith Mara Gutman, April 17). Social-work policy classes are notoriously dull.

title: JAZZ: JANET LAWSON, SINGER
description: The format of the ''Five Ladies of Jazz'' series, which combined an interview by John Gruen, the host, and a concert performance, worked more to the advantage of Janet Lawson than to any of her four predecessors. Miss Lawson concluded the series n Monday evening in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: LABOR'S KISS OF DEATH
description: There is an opportunity for one of the Democratic contenders for President to seize the initiative in the current campaign for the nomination. Although at first it might seem crazy, the candidate with the imagination and courage to declare that he won't seek organized labor's endorsement could propel himself to the nomination and the White House.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: The principal subscription series of the Brooklyn Philharmonic under the conductor Lukas Foss at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next season will run from Nov. 4 to May 6. There will be six programs, with each program given three times. Soloists will be Peter Serkin, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Andre-Michel Schub and Eugene Fodor.

title: A Statement To American Management; STOP THE OPPRESSION OF SHAREHOLDERS
description: AMERICA is blessed with great natural resources, the most stable political system in the world, a well-educated and generally industrious labor force and a sound currency. Yet, American industry finds it increasingly difficult to compete and productivity lags well behind that of foreign competition. American management blames this on many factors, especially labor. However, management should note that when armies do battle and the better-equipped force loses, the fault lies not with the soldiers, but with the generals.

title: COPING WITH UNWANTED HAIR
description: Hot weather and revealing summer clothes pose a troublesome cosmetic problem for many women: how to banish superfluous hair. Legs and underarms are most often the areas in need of attention, but women are also often bothered by downy growth on the upper lip, chin and torso.

title: MEN OUGHT TO SHARE A STITCH IN TIME
description: MOST women, I suppose, would have had a spare half-slip of the right length, and others would have headed for the sewing basket and repaired the thing outright.

title: COLLEGES BESTOW HONORS
description: AN 84-year-old Japanese philanthropist, an American woman who inspired the wartime song ''Rosie the Riveter'' and an Auschwitz survivor are among this year's recipients of honorary degrees at Long Island colleges.

title: CAN ROSIE THE RIVETER SPEAK TO A NEW GENERATION?
description: The earliest moviemakers came to Hollywood for the weather, but this winter some of their descendants must have wondered if the westward migration had been worthwhile. Southern California was pelted with two months of steady rain, and the storms snarled the plans of the Warner Bros. production team preparing ''Swing Shift,'' a new comedy-drama starring Goldie Hawn and directed by Jonathan Demme. A crucial outdoor scene had to be postponed several times, and the elaborate set built near the Santa Monica Pier was almost destroyed before ever being used.

title: DORM CLOSING ENDS AN ERA
description: IN its heyday, the student-run Rogers Hall at the University of Connecticut at Storrs brought vegetarianism to college dining halls and faculty participation to student life. But when Rogers shut down for the summer last Wednesday, the student group that ran the dormitory for nine years closed down for good.

title: IRANIAN SAYS IRAQIS ARE USING EXOCET MISSILES
description: A senior Iranian official said today that Iraqi forces had used French-built Exocet missiles to attack Iranian oil wells in the Persian Gulf.

title: DEATH-ROW TENANCY COULD LAST YEARS
description: ALTHOUGH Thomas E. Ramseur, the first person in more than a decade to face the death penalty in New Jersey, will be sentenced on June 17, months - and perhaps years - will pass before he can be put to death.

title: STUDENTS DISPLACED BY ASBESTOS THREAT ADJUST TO NEW HALLS
description: SOME of the eighth graders unexpectedly finishing the school year at Roosevelt High School here complain about going to the gymnasium in street clothes because there is no locker room in which to change.

title: INTO THE MINES: NOT PRETTY, BUT REAL
description: Beams from our headlamps bounce off the black coal-mine walls like fluttery, ghostlike creatures, their shafts of light filtered by a fine dust rising from the floor of the passageway. Overhead, handhewn timbers that were hammered into place more than a half century ago seem to strain under the weight of all of South Wales. Our guide pauses and a string of 13 bobbing headlamps, all that is visible in the darkness, comes to a halt behind him like a swarm of fireflies on a moonless night.

title: Mother of Missing Producer Offers $1 Million as Ransom
description: The mother of Roy Alexander Radin, a Southampton, Long Island, movie and theatrical producer who disappeared in Hollywood on his way to a business meeting on May 13, is offering $1 million for his safe return, a private investigator said.

title: THE JET-LAG DIET
description: Can you fly from New York to San Francisco and arrive with your body and brain already set to Pacific time? What about New York to Honolulu or Tokyo or, to change directions, Paris or Nairobi?

title: REAGAN ASSAILING IRAN OVER BAHAIS
description: President Reagan will issue a statement Sunday night saying the United States is ''alarmed and dismayed'' at the persecution of Bahais in Iran and urging the Iranian Government to halt the planned execution of a group of prominent Bahais, White House officials said today.

title: Teatime
description: To the Editor:

title: LAMU ISLAND: THE SLOW PACE IS CATCHING
description: The pace slows here to a halt. The traveler might arrive, eager and anxious, shutter finger ready on the camera, seeking historic ruins and local craftsmen and a smattering of atmosphere. And then the island will take over, the urgencies will ease, disappear, suddenly seem beyond comprehension. The day will be punctuated by small things the occasional light aircraft, the passing of a dhow, the ebb and flow of the tide. The evenings have no more on their agenda than watching the moon rise over distant mangrove swamps. After a while the visitor will trade Western clothes for a wraparound cloth called a khanga, or kikoyi, the island inevitably, will win.

title: Postings; AIR SHAFT NO MORE
description: The Alwyn Court, an apartment building at 58th Street and Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, has long been known for the splendor of its elaborately carved French Renaissance facade. But the interior court of this landmark structure was, until recently, nothing more than a dreary, energy-sapping air shaft.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH its $2.5 million budget is in for some hefty cuts, things may be looking up a bit for the Suffolk County Drug Abuse Council. The agency, which is slated to receive some $200,000 less in government aid next year, will benefit from a new annual yacht race that will make its debut off the waters of Sag Harbor next month.

title: STAGE: SIMON'S 'PROMISES' REVIVED
description: The combination of Neil Simon's one-joke book and Burt Bacharach's highly stylized music, whose choppy, repetitious phrasing creates the effect of one-note songs, makes ''Promises, Promises'' a very thin and fragile vehicle.

title: NEWARK GETS CENTER FOR STUDY OF 'CRIB DEATH'
description: WITHOUT a warning or a whimper, more than 200 seemingly healthy babies die in their sleep in New Jersey every year. Parents or sitters find them lifeless in their carriages or cribs. Autopsies do not reveal hidden birth defects or evidence of disease, choking or external suffocation.

title: Degree for Sampson
description: His grade average was only C-plus and he had to pass up lucrative employment offers to stay the course, but Ralph Sampson, who is scheduled to receive his degree today from the University of Virginia, says it was all worth while. ''The money will always be there,'' he said.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TEMPERING By Gloria Skurzynski. 178 pp. New York: Clarion Books. $10.95. (Ages 11 and Up)Tempering means mingling in due proportion; it is the heating and quenching that toughens steel and, in this novel, matures Karl Kerner. Karl is the son of an Irish immigrant mother and a secondgeneration German steelworker in Canaan, Pa., (the fictional counterpart of Duquesne, where the author Gloria Skurzynski grew up). ''The Tempering'' is the story of his 15th year, during which he decides whether to quit school and work in the steel mills - where, his adored teacher tells his class, boys are sacrificed to the blast furnaces as children of ancient Canaan were sacrificed to the firegod Baal.

title: HARD OF HEARING
description: I woke up deaf in the right ear one morning, waited a few weeks for the problem to clear up and, when it didn't, went uptown to Manhattan's mink belt to see a doctor. There at Madison Avenue and 57th Street where coffee and toast can cost you $7.50, a panhandler struck on my deaf side.

title: The Love of Nature: More Dissent Eureka!
description: Howard Schneider is sure he's on to something: the human mind as amorphous blob, tugged this way and that by those hidden manipulators! (''A Few Dissenting Thoughts on the Love of Nature,'' Opinion Page, April 24.)

title: Steeler Coach Ailing
description: Chuck Noll, coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, has been hospitalized with a back ailment.

title: Talking: Private Wells; WHY TESTS FOR TOXINS ARE NEEDED
description: IN the old days, when a person owned a suburban or country home s erved by a private on-site well, the icy-fresh water that flowed f rom the tap was a source of pride. Often superior in taste and a ppearance to chlorinated and cloudy municipal water, it was a cclaimed as one of the delights of living on the property.

title: Deborah Dietzer Wed to Vance Polley, Seminarian
description: Deborah Ayers Dietzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Walter Dietzer of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Vance E. Polley, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Max E. Polley of Davidson, N.C. The Rev. Robert Miner performed the ceremony at St. Saviour's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Harry L. Holfelder of Bridgeton, N.J., and the bridegroom's father.

title: CHARACTER AS CULTURE
description: RUTH BENEDICT Patterns of a Life. By Judith Schachter Modell. Illustrated. 355 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $25. LIKE her mentor Franz Boas (whose co-worker she became) and her student Margaret Mead (who became her co-worker), Ruth Fulton Benedict (1887-1948) was one of the few anthropologists who mattered outside the discipline. With Boas and Mead, Benedict was a major architect of modern cultural determinism in anthropology, which sees the distinguishing psychological traits of various human groups as the result of differing cultural milieus rather than as a reflection of differences in heredity and phsyical makeup.

title: CATS' EYES OFFER CLUE TO VISION DISORDERS
description: BEFORE the 1970's, if a child was born with visual problems, the odds were that ophthalmologists would have waited to see if the condition corrected itself over time. Also, they thought that ''waiting'' had little to do with the success of surgery, even up to five years following the impairment.

title: New Jerseyans
description: OLD LABOR leaders don't fade away - they just keep on working, like Sol Stetin of Paterson. His career began 50 years ago, when he was 23 years old, in a Paterson dye shop.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS U.S. SCHOOL AID IN JERSEY SPEECH
description: President Reagan declared today that parents and local governments should be given greater control over schools and that teachers should be paid and promoted ''on the basis of their merit and competence.''

title: Colbert and Pooley Share Lead at 136
description: Jim Colbert, who broke a three-year victory drought last weekend, converted a lucky break into a 67 today that tied him with Don Pooley for the lead in the second round of the rain-shortened Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: L.I. MAN IS ORDERED DEPORTED FOR CONCENTRATION CAMP ROLE
description: A 63-year-old Long Island man who was stripped of his United States citizenship because he commanded a Nazi concentration camp during World War II has been ordered deported by a judge for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Anne Spitz Is Married
description: Anne Bellin Spitz, daughter of S. James Spitz Jr. of New York and Mrs. Parks Spitz of Pensacola, Fla., was married yesterday to Edmund James Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund James Brown of Mineola, L.I.

title: ROBARDS-AN ACTOR AT THE PEAK OF HIS ART
description: The hamster is loose. The cat's on the roof. Jason Robards is home. Childrens' drawings adorn the refrigerator, a mower drones across the Connecticut lawn. ''I've always wanted to be part of a family,'' says the 60-year-old actor, strolling in the warm spring sunshine. After a long stretch of stormy weather, it had seemed a long time coming.

title: Cuba Player Tells Of Fixed Games
description: Barbaro Garbey, an outfielder for the Evansville Triplets of the American Association, has acknowledged that he and some Cuban teammates were paid to fix games in Havana in 1978.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY LOSING OFFICER TO PROLINK
description: Erik T. Ringkjob, one of the original employees of the Storage Technology Corporation when it was formed 13 years ago, will leave to become president and chief executive officer of a new officeautomation enterprise called the Prolink Corporation, based in Boulder, Colo. It is a private company formed with venture capital.

title: CLOSING OF STORE ENDING AN ERA IN BOOK HUNTING
description: Amid mounds of clutter and dust, one of the last of the bargain bookstores that made up New York's famous Book Row in Greenwich Village is closing.

title: Ukrainian Chorus Sings And Accompanies Itself
description: There are two differences between the Ukrainian Bandurist Chorus and other Russian choral groups that have toured the United States. The musical one is that the group accompanies itself on some 20 banduras, Ukrainian folk instruments.

title: 23 REPORTED DEAD IN LEBANON BATTLE
description: Twenty-three people were reported killed and as many as 100 others kidnapped in outbreaks today between Druse and Christian factions in the Shuf Mountains south of Beirut.

title: SUMMIT TALKS TEST EVEN BLASE WILLIAMSBURG
description: The Japanese have been dissuaded from bringing mopeds and golf carts. President Francois Mitterrand of France, as requested, will be served no cream sauces and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain will be given an extra bedroom for her security detail, instead of the dressing room that was offered.

title: COURANT TRIES TO MULTIPLY USES OF MATH
description: Dr. Charles S. Peskin is a physiologist with a professional interest in the design of artificial heart valves. He used to do much of his work in laboratories with live animals, but these days he is constructing computer simulations of the heart at New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.

title: WHY DOCTORS USE MODERN TECHNOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: Cup of Good Cheer
description: Like a giant nickel-plated hockey puck skidding across the ice and ricocheting off the boards, the Stanley Cup has been making the rounds of triumph, bumping into surprised and delighted fans and serving up the nectar of victory throughout the New York metropolitan area.

title: F.T.C. Ends Gallo Ban
description: The Federal Trade Commision has vacated a 1976 consent order against the E.& J. Gallo Winery that had been aimed at preventing the nation's leading wine maker from engaging in anticompetitive relationships with its dealers. Gallo, in an announcement Friday, said the F.T.C. found that conditions in the wine market ''make it unlikely that competitive injury would result'' if the order was set aside. Gallo had asked the F.T.C. in September to set aside the order, arguing that the structure of the wine market had changed, reducing its dominance.

title: Frederick N. Goodrich, A Retired Trust Official
description: Frederick Norman Goodrich, retired executive vice president and chief economist of the United States Trust Company, died Saturday night at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 74 years old.

title: AN UMPIRE'S SON GETS READY FOR BIG LEAGUES
description: WHEN the time comes, and there is no one in the household who doubts it will, Jeff Kunkel can think of it as a return trip to the major leagues. He was a young boy the first time a baseball brat - and American League ball parks were his summer playground. Whether it was in New York, Baltimore, Boston or Anaheim, his pockets would be lined with change for frequent trips to the concession stands and he felt as if all the empty seats were reserved for him.

title: Hobart Retains Lacrosse Title
description: Led by Guy and Marc Van Arsdale, Hobart College beat Roanoke, 13-9, today to win its fourth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III lacrosse title.

title: Arnaud Dumond Plays Guitar and Lute Recital
description: Arnaud Dumond, a French performer on the guitar and lute, offered music for both instruments at CAMI Hall Friday night. The program ranged back 350 years to John Dowland and forward to Maurice Ohana's sterner 20th-century style.

title: Foreign Affairs; NOW HISPANIC POWER
description: Mexico's economic tailspin has brought a spate of distress on the U.S. side, where people have become heavily dependent on border-crossing business. But this is the Sun Belt, and basically there is a good deal of optimism for an expansive future.

title: A SOMALI'S MISCONCEIVED CRITIQUE OF SOMALIA
description: To the Editor:

title: CREDIT SUISSE HOLDS COURSE AMID SHIFTS
description: A management shift brought on at Credit Suisse by a retirement will not mean any change in the business strategy of Switzerland's thirdlargest bank, Robert A. Jeker said of his succession to the post of chief executive officer at the age of 47.

title: SNIPER KILLS WOMAN AND WOUNDS MAN AT A NEW HAVEN CHARITY FAIR
description: A 29-year-old woman working at an arts and crafts fair in New Haven was shot and killed yesterday afternoon when a sniper firing from a nearby house sprayed a crowd of festival-goers with bullets, the police reported. One other person, a man, was slightly wounded.

title: Eclectic Services
description: A red velvet umbrella, gold-fringed and topped like a tiny temple, was carried in the liturgical procession at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights yesterday. A gift to the church from a group of Syriac Christians from India, it set the ecumenical tone for a Pentecost service that included Jewish, Moslem, Hindu and Buddhist prayers and chanting.

title: Books in the Computer Age
description: Second graders from Public School 11 in Chelsea and from the Bank Street Children's School on West 112th Street were among this year's jurors for Bank Street College of Education's annual Irma Simonton Black Award for children's literature.

title: 3 U.S. Amateurs Win in Boxing
description: Three American amateur world champions - Steve McCrory, Floyd Favors and Mark Breland - won their bouts today in the Amateur Boxing World Championship Challenge Matches.

title: C.I.A. IS REPORTED TO PREDICT OUSTER OF THE SANDINISTS
description: The Director of Central Intelligence and another senior Administration official have predicted that Americansupported Nicaraguan rebels have a good chance of overthrowing the Sandinist Government by the end of the year, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: VIKING 1 STAYS SILENT ON MARS
description: The Viking 1 lander, its power supply apparently exhausted, sat silent on Mars today after scientists failed to contact the spacecraft.

title: Howard Levin, Physician, And Stacy Pollack Marry
description: Stacy Pollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Pollack of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Howard Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Levin of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Alvin M. @Poplack at the North Woodmere (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: WIDE CHOICE FOR HUNGRY CELEBRATORS
description: There is nothing like a celebration to work up an appetite, and if there is any one frustration that tomorrow's merrymakers can expect to confront in their pursuit of nourishment, it is choice.

title: Advertising; In Search Of Public Approval
description: Unlike most new chairmen of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Paul C. Harper Jr. does not bring with him a cause that he would like the association to get behind. The one he is inheriting suits him just fine.

title: Satellite TV Speeds Service
description: The Satellite Television Corporation, a division of the Communications Satellite Corporation, plans to introduce satellite broadcasting of television programs directly to homes next year, well in advance of its original plan to offer such a service in 1986.

title: The Region; 3 Are Arrested At Anti-Klan Rally
description: Three anti-Ku Klux Klan demonstrators were arrested today in a clash between the police and more than 50 protesters at a shopping mall.

title: News Analysis
description: If Congress approves all of President Reagan's program to modernize nuclear striking forces, the result will be a dramatic increase in the size and especially the power of the nation's nuclear arsenal, according to a Congressional staff study and other analyses.

title: Egypt Will Build Red Sea Base Without Any Help From U.S.
description: Egypt will finance the construction of a key military installation on the Red Sea without United States aid, Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali said today.

title: EMBELLISHED COURTHOUSE IS REGAINING ITS SPLENDOR
description: ''Justice'' was crumbling. ''Peace'' was falling apart. So were ''Moses'' and ''Louis IX'' and ''Solon.'' Marble chunks of the courthouse statues were dropping to the street. Inside, a stained-glass panel fell out of the domed ceiling while court was in session.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A MAN OF HONOR. The Autobiography of Joseph Bonanno. With Sergio Lalli. 416 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Five More Countries to Join Central America Peace Effort
description: Panama's Foreign Minister said Saturday that leaders from five more countries would join this week's meeting of the Contadora Group, four Central American nations pushing for peace in the region.

title: BIGGEST FIREWORKS SHOW PLANNED AT BRIDGE
description: The Grucci family has produced some huge fireworks displays in recent years: President Reagan's inaugural celebration, the World's Fair in Knoxville, Tenn., and the International Fireworks Competition in Monte Carlo, which they won in 1979.

title: MCENROE HEALTHY FOR OPEN
description: Under the flowering chestnut trees at Roland Garros Stadium, 256 tennis players today completed their preparation for the French Open, the first of the 1983 grand-slam tournaments.

title: ZAHRINGER WINNER IN TRAVIS GOLF
description: George Zahringer added a replica of the Schenectady putter to his collection of golf trophies today by winning the Walter J. Travis Invitation tournament at the Garden City Golf Club.

title: Essay; LE COMMUNIQUE JOINT
description: Fearful of premature disagreement, the seven nations gathering for an economic summit at Williamsburg, Va., have forbidden their ''sherpas'' to draft a joint communique. However, the following nondocument indicates that some surreptitious drafting is under way.

title: HEARINGS PLANNED ON DRUG AGENCY NOMINEE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee plans to hold a hearing on the nomination of Francis M. Mullen Jr. to be head of the Drug Enforcement Administration amid new questions about the legality of his service as Acting Administrator for the last 22 months.

title: GOVERNOR'S INTERVENTION ALTERS KENTUCKY RACE
description: Three Democratic hopefuls are frantically whipping toward Tuesday's gubernatorial primary with no clear leader, no dominant issue and a passel of undecided voters watching from the rail.

title: RULE CHANGE SPLITS OIL TANKER OWNERS
description: Owners of oil tankers that operate solely between ports in the United States have begun a campaign against an Administration proposal that would increase the number and size of tankers eligible to compete in the domestic market, especially in the $1.3 billion a year Alaska oil trade.

title: Funseth Romps
description: Rod Funseth, leading from start to finish, posted a nine-stroke victory today in the first $150,000 Hall of Fame tournament on the senior PGA Tour.

title: News Analysis
description: Until the car-bomb explosion Friday in the heart of Pretoria, the occasional death of a bystander from underground violence nearly always seemed to result from miscalculation.

title: New Chief for Meldrum
description: Meldrum & Fewsmith Inc. in Cleveland announced that its president, Terrence G.E. Parmelee Sr., 37 years old, has been elected chief executive officer, succeeding Arthur E. Earley, 60, who resigned. Mr. Earley will continue as chairman.

title: The War on Discrimination
description: With some advice from B'nai B'rith's Anti-Defamation League, founded in 1913, the Sons of Italy set up a Commission for Social Justice four years ago. On occasion the two groups have joined to fight discrimination against other ethnic communities as well as their own.

title: Delaware Women Win in Lacrosse
description: Karen Emas scored two goals and assisted on three others as she led Delaware to a 10-7 upset over topseeded Temple in the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's lacrosse championship today.

title: Market Place; Power Bonds And Pitfalls
description: TEN years ago, when the Washington Public Power Supply System began selling bonds to the public, its nickname, Whoops, had no meaning except as shorthand for its initials, W.P.P.S.S. Now, more than $8 billion later, the nickname has become an embarrassment.

title: Briefing
description: To Paris on Wings

title: The Worm and the Apple; Rip-Offs; Threatening Calls
description: ''We'd like you to contribute to our fund for widows and orphans of police slain in the line of duty. We know you'll want to help.

title: DISTINGUISHED TOURISTS, FROM LAFAYETTE ON
description: In 1824 Marquis de Lafayette, the French hero of the American Revolution, swept into the Virginia city of Williamsburg to be showered with gifts by well-wishers. Williamsburg remains the landmark to which the Federal Government shuttles its visitors from abroad. It is to Washington what Versailles is to Paris; it is officialdom's Disneyland, an attraction for foreign visitors of distinction.

title: Envoy Addresses Graduates
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States representative to the United Nations, told 155 graduates of Bethany College Saturday that their biggest challenge would be a smooth transition from youth to maturity. Mrs. Kirkpatrick, who has been heckled in other college appearances, received a warm reception at Bethany and the crowd of several hundred gave her a standing ovation as she approached the podium to give a nonpolitical speech.

title: 76ERS TAKE A 1-0 LEAD OVER LAKERS
description: Among the capacity crowd of 18,482 at the Spectrum here today was a group of fans dressed in the biblical garb of Moses, staff and all - a tribute to the Philadelphia 76ers' center Moses Malone. And near the end of the 113-107 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association championship series, a makeshift banner appeared in the stands. ''Moses Parts the Lakers,'' it said.

title: WHAT AN I.R.S. AMNESTY CANNOT DO
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * The corporate advertising account of the Grand Union Company, Elmwood Park, N.J., to Grulich-Koenig Advertising of Miami, which is opening a New York office.

title: Advice From the Pulpit
description: Yesterday morning's service at the Abyssinian Baptist Church on West 138th Street was a celebration of the church's tradition in general and, in particular, of two former pastors, the late Rev. Adam Clayton Powell and the late Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the former Congressman.

title: Risk of Cervical Cancer Is Linked to Smoking
description: Young women who smoke run 17 times the risk of developing cervical cancer than nonsmokers, according to a University of Utah study.

title: Commencement Day, a Time for Parting Words and Rejoicing; MISS STREEP URGES CLASS OF '83 TO TRY FOR EXCELLENCE
description: The Academy Award-winning actress Meryl Streep returned to the rolling, green campus of Vassar College today to deliver the commencement address to the 119th graduating class.

title: Ani Kavafian, a Violinist, Wed to Bernard Mindich
description: Ani Kavafian, daughter of Mrs. Ara Zerounian of Royal Oak, Mich., and the late Yenovk Kavafian, was married yesterday to Bernard Mindich, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Saul Mindich of Miami.

title: DIME SAVINGS PUSHES LOANS
description: Although most New York savings institutions have viewed commercial lending with trepidation, the Dime Savings Bank has run counter to this trend by aggressively pursuing small and medium-size businesses as loan customers.

title: Prost, in Renault, Winner in Belgium
description: Alain Prost of France, driving a Renault turbo, won the shortened Belgian Formula One Grand Prix today and took the lead in the 1983 world-championship drivers' standing.

title: YANKS GET TWO RUNS IN 9TH INNING TO DEFEAT A'S, 4-2
description: In the confusion of a wonderfully wacky ninth inning, the Yankees emerged with a 4-2 victory over the A's today, as Rick Cerone, of all people, scored Graig Nettles, of all people, with the decisive run.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Luck of the Irish
description: Barry McGuigan of Clones, County Monaghan, Ireland, knows he is good and believes he has proved it in his small corner of the world. Now he wants to prove it to himself and the world at large.

title: ISRAELI DOCTORS STRIKE TO SUPPORT DEMAND FOR A WAGE INCREASE
description: Government-employed doctors refused to report for work at hospitals today in a move to back their threemonth-old demand for higher pay.

title: THRIFT UNITS: CAUTIOUS RIVALS
description: Last November, when thrift institutions were granted new powers allowing them to make commercial loans, some analysts predicted that a price war would break out with their traditional rivals, the small commercial banks.

title: BRAVES WIN IN 11TH FOR SWEEP OF CARDS
description: A throwing error by Mike Ramsey, the substitute shortstop, with two out in the 11th inning allowed Brett Butler to score from second base today, giving the Atlanta Braves a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and a sweep of their threegame series.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RUSSIAN BEAT

title: ARAFAT REPORTED MOVING TO CRUSH A MUTINY IN P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat was reported today to have moved to put out a smoldering rebellion among Palestine Liberation Organization commanders in eastern Lebanon.

title: CITIES TURN TO PRIVATE GROUPS TO ADMINISTER LOCAL SERVICES
description: The neighborhood groups that used to demand better services from city halls around the nation are now providing those services themselves.

title: Timken Ban Nearing End
description: The Justice Department has tentatively agreed to end a 33-year-old court order barring the Timken Company from dividing markets with its British and French subsidiaries.

title: OPERA: NEW 'BUTTERFLY'
description: Perhaps because he lacked Ken Russell's feverish imagination, Puccini never wrote an opera called ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Nagasaki.'' Too bad, because the production of ''Madama Butterfly'' that Mr. Russell concocted to open the seventh season of the Spoleto U.S.A. Festival would fit such an opera beautifully. Mr. Russell, the British director who left his mark in films and television with a string of bizarre productions, has now turned his mind to opera. The premiere of this bawdy-house ''Butterfly'' here on Friday night represented his his first American effort in a new career.

title: ARIAS BEATS HIGUERAS IN FINAL
description: Jimmy Arias scored his biggest tournament success today when he upset top-seeded Jose Higueras of Spain, 6-2, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4, to win the $375,000 Italian Open tennis championships.

title: Phils Deal Monge
description: The Philadelphia Phillies traded Sid Monge, a left-handed relief pitcher, to the San Diego Padres today for Joe Lefebvre, an outfielder who can also play third base and catch. Lefebvre, who is 27 years old, has appeared in 18 games and has a .250 batting average with one run batted in in 20 times at bat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams-Russell Co., Waltham, Mass., has named W.C. Goetter president of its Microwave Products subsidiary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you can live with the devil, then Vassar has not sunk its teeth into you'' - Meryl Streep at Vassar's commencement. (B2:2.)

title: Ronna G. Klingenberg Weds J.L. Lichtenberg
description: The marriage of Ronna Glaser Klingenberg, director of issues management with the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Newark, to James Lester Lichtenberg, a senior vice president of Hill & Knowlton Inc., a public relations-public affairs agency, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at La Belle Epoque.

title: ORIOLES BLANKED BY JAYS
description: The Orioles have lost two of their starting pitchers, Jim Palmer and Mike Flanagan, to injuries, and yesterday Baltimore failed to get adequate replacement from one of the pitchers the team is counting on to fill in.

title: MACHISMO MURDER CASE: WOMEN BITTER IN BRAZIL
description: The exoneration last week of a systems analyst who killed his wife because she wanted to separate from him to see another man has drawn national attention to a Brazilian legal precept that accepts such a reaction as a ''legitimate defense of honor.''

title: CONCERT: Y ENSEMBLE
description: GOUNOD and Puccini are not usually associated with orchestral music, yet two works by these operatically renowned composers framed an intriguing program presented by Gerard Schwarz, conducting the 92d Street Y Chamber Symphony on Saturday night.

title: Commencement Day, a Time for Parting Words and Rejoicing; GRADUATES HAILED AS 'BETTER ROUNDED PEOPLE'
description: The University of Connecticut held its 100th commencement today, and Charles and Augustus Storrs would probably have been surprised by it all.

title: GEORGE MASON U. CAPTURES IC4A TITLE
description: Mike Scudieri captured the last event, the triple jump, enabling George Mason University to beat out Maryland and Villanova for top team honors at the IC4A outdoor track and field championships today.

title: OPERA: CHINESE TROUPE
description: CHINA'S Hunan Flower Drum Opera is paying a series of calls on New York, Washington and Philadelphia this month, and Saturday afternoon at Pace University, next to Chinatown, the company performed ''The Tale of the Woodcutter and the Golden Toad.'' The earthy directness of this troupe evidently seems to have rescued it from the fate of other scheduled cultural exchanges between the United States and China. Diplomatic frictions have caused most to be canceled recently, but this tour's ''people-to-people'' quality is said have redeemed it in the eyes of Chinese officials.

title: Irish Folk-Rock Band, The Moving Hearts
description: Although the Moving Hearts have not yet released an album in the United States, the Irish folk-rock band made a triumphant American debut Saturday at the Savoy. The sextet, a four-piece rock band plus a saxophonist and a uileann pipes (Irish bagpipes) and whistle player, interspersed rock songs with instrumentals based on jigs and reels.

title: Commencement Day, a Time for Parting Words and Rejoicing; ROHATYN CALLS FOR NATION TO ADOPT 'SERIOUS PURPOSE'
description: Felix G. Rohatyn told the 2,400 graduates at Fordham University's 138th annual commencement yesterday at the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx, that ''we must once again become a serious nation with a serious purpose.''

title: PARADES, FIREWORKS AND MUSIC TO MARK DAY
description: The Brooklyn Bridge, one of the city's best-loved landmarks, will be 100 years old tomorrow, and a big birthday party is planned. A parade of 18,000 will cross the grand old bridge on foot, on horse, in carriages, on floats, in historic buses, by horse-drawn ambulance and horse-drawn pumper, in a Model T Ford and even atop a small elephant. They will march 10 abreast, fifing, drumming, tooting, piping, twirling and stepping smartly in joyful celebration of the anniversary.

title: INFORMATION CAPITAL, BARRING AN EXODUS
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMENCEMENT DAY, A TIME FOR PARTING WORDS AND REJOICING
description: In a commencement address today at the State University of New York at Albany, Dr. John Brademas, the president of New York University, accused the Reagan Administration of a ''fundamental attack'' on Federal programs to aid education.

title: OUTDOORS: THE FASCINATION OF WHAT IS DIFFICULT
description: OUR project was deceptively simple: to catch the Delaware River's shad on fly rods. There is nothing startling about such an endeavor. Long before the advent of easily mastered spinning gear, which permits casting the small lures that shad like, anglers were catching shad on flies. But they were a tiny band compared to the hoards that today work shad waters with light monofilament line and the marvelously effective shad dart, a little lead headed jig with a bit of hair or bucktail attached.

title: FRENCH SEEK ONE VOICE FOR WILLIAMSBURG
description: President Francois Mitterrand has called in most of the major opposition political leaders to Elysee Palace for consultations this week in what appears to be an effort to make a show of French unity before the start of the Williamsburg, Va., economic meeting Saturday.

title: Miss Rogers Wed To Mark Golodetz
description: Nancy Fulton Rogers, daughter of Margaret Henderson Rogers of Longport, N.J., and New York and the late Dr. Robert Clayton Rogers, was married yesterday to Timothy Mark Golodetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Golodetz of Kingston, Surrey, England. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
description: International

title: Midcourse Corrections for Schools
description: To increase pressure for achievement, the former Chancellor of New York City's schools, Frank Macchiarola, began the controversial ''gates'' program that denies promotion to students who fail reading and math tests after the fourth and seventh grades. While most students have risen to the challenge, the program left a troubling legacy: more than 16,000 who could not pass the standardized tests even after repeating the seventh grade more than once. For them, the gates became frustration rather than education.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart accompanying an article on portable computers in Business Day Friday incorrectly reported the weight of the Gavilan computer and misstated the units of measurement for the internal memory of computers.

title: Around the World; Pope, in Milan, Champions Workers
description: Pope John Paul II told Italy's leading industrialists today that inflation and recession must not obstruct the fight against unemployment and called for greater worker participation in the management of companies.

title: Gasoline Prices Up 10%
description: Gasoline prices have risen more than 10 percent since mid-March, with the entire increase going to refiners and taxes, according to a survey released today. Dan Lundberg, an industry analyst, said his survey of 17,000 service stations found the average price for all grades of gasoline was $1.229 a gallon on May 20, up 12.7 cents from $1.102 in mid-March. Of the increase, more than 7.1 cents reflected higher wholesale prices, 5 cents came from a rise in Federal taxes and the rest stemmed from higher state taxes.

title: QUEENS REDEVELOPMENT IN BUREAUCRATIC TANGLE
description: The most noticeable feature in the nondescript Queens neighborhood of Hunters Point is a 38-foot-high neon Pepsi-Cola sign that stares across the East River at the United Nations.

title: Around the Nation; Refugees Replace Aliens After Food Plant Raid
description: Immigration and Naturalization Service agents who removed 14 illegal aliens from a food plant here arranged for legal refugees to take their places in an effort to keep other undocumented workers from getting the jobs. The 14 were arrested at the Ozuna Mexican Food Products plant Thursday.

title: DANCE: NEW YORK CITY BALLET PERFORMS TWO BY BALANCHINE
description: THE New York City Ballet offered a nicely balanced mix of the new and old on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, with a program that included a debut in George Balanchine's ''Tarantella'' and the re-entry into the season's repertory of his ''The Four Temperaments.''

title: Executive Pay Off a Bit
description: Although many top executives took pay cuts last year because of the recession, the reductions were much less than the decline in corporate earnings, according to a report published today. U.S. News and World Report said the average pay of the heads of leading corporations was $365,000 last year, down 2.7 percent from 1981, while profits after taxes plummeted 22.4 percent. Twenty-nine of the 916 executives surveyed made more than $1 million a year, three more than in the previous year.

title: SEAVER IS ROUTED BY DODGERS
description: Bob Welch outhit, outpitched and outclassed Tom Seaver yesterday as the Los Angeles Dodgers restored some orderliness to their play in a 5-0 victory over the Mets.

title: Sampson Hailed At Graduation
description: Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch center who had spurned lucrative offers to play in the National Basketball Association so he could complete his college education, was graduated today from the University of Virginia.

title: Rebecca L. Rozen Is Wed to George S. Blumenthal
description: Rebecca L. Rozen, daughter of Freda Rozen Brown of Andover, Mass., and Morton D. Rozen of Merrimac, Mass., was married yesterday to George S. Blumenthal of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Blumenthal. The Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein and the Rev. A. Lopes Cardozo performed the ceremony at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Congregation Shearith Israel in Manhattan.

title: THOUSANDS IN MARCH ON 5TH AVE. SUPPORT JEWS IN SOVIET UNION
description: Near the front of a long procession down Fifth Avenue yesterday, a band of students from the Frisch School in Paramus, N.J. - dressed symbolically in striped prison garb - carried placards demanding freedom for Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Relationships; REACTING TO BOORISH MANNERS
description: DID you see him? Did you see her? Did you see that? Talking throughout the performance. Barging aheadi n the checkout line. Smoking during the meal. Redialing a number w ith five people waiting to use the telephone. He ought to be a shamed. She ought to be ashamed. Someone should say something!

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: POLAND'S HARD LIFE FINDS MORE WOMEN CHOOSING ABORTION
description: The stand of the Roman Catholic Church on abortion in this devoutly religious country, as elsewhere in the world, is quite clear: it is not permissible. But many estimates by Polish experts find that the abortion rate in Poland is now higher than the country's birthrate.

title: Rhonda Ann Grossman Weds Robert H. Silver
description: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Teaneck, N.J., yesterday Rhonda Ann Grossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bernard Grossman of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married to Robert H. Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Silver of Greensboro, N.C. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Simon Glustrom, assisted by Rabbi Kenneth Berger.

title: Susan Fink Marries
description: Susan Ann Fink, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Arthur Fink of Scotch Plains, N.J., and James Alan Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Alan Singer of New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Rabbi Lynne Landsberg of the Central Synagogue performed the ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a banking research consultant with McKinsey & Company, a New York management consulting firm. Mr. Singer is a vice president of Salomon Brothers Inc., New York investment bankers.

title: Nuclear Chicken
description: New York has become the testing ground for the Federal edict that all nuclear power plants shall have emergency evacuation plans, prepared by state and local authorities. The price of this distinction is that the state now stands on the brink of losing three nuclear plants, a forfeit that could impose a heavy burden on consumers and businesses merely to eliminate an unlikely and manageable hazard.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Rip-Offs; Post Neglect
description: New Yorkers routinely treat lampposts as free billboards. Though past-ing up promotion for a stoop sale or community theater is illegal, the only deterrent seems to be reluctance to obliterate someone else's fresh offer of a reward for a lost cat.

title: Firestone Gains Last Indy Spot
description: A combination of new-found speed and some good luck made Dennis Firestone the only driver to crack the record-setting lineup for the 67th Indianapolis 500 in the rainshortened final session of time trials today.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Outlay
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the Government-owned chemical maker, plans to spend 500 million francs, or the equivalent of about $67 million, to make an advanced polyester film used in the video cassette industry, a spokesman said Friday. The outlay, which represents almost a quarter of the company's investment budget for 1983, will be used to modernize a plant at Saint-Maurice-de-Beynost and to increase film production to 24,000 tons a year from 14,000. The film, terphane, is also used in packing and graphic arts.

title: 76ERS PAY FIRST INSTALLMENT ON OLD DEBT
description: THE Philadelphia 76ers began the awesome task of trying to repay all those promissory notes to their fans yesterday. They opened the cashier's window in the first game of the National Basketball Association final round, banking on their new collateral, Moses Malone, and their established gold bullion, Julius Erving, for a 113-107 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: INDUSTRY AND GOVERNMENT EFFORTS FOR NUCLEAR POWER DRAW SCRUTINY
description: In an intensified national effort, the Government and the electric power industry are engaging in separate but overlapping campaigns to persuade the American people that nuclear energy is economical and safe.

title: Bridge:; Top-Seeded Squad; Loses In Grand National Tourney
description: The top-seeded team in the District 24 Grand National Teams event was eliminated in the quarterfinal round Saturday at the New York Hilton. In a contest that was close all the way, the top seed, the squad headed by Michael Becker, was defeated by 10 international match points by the team of Augie Boehm, Saul Bronstein, Michael Engel and George Tornay.

title: An Intelsat 5 Launched
description: The sixth Intelsat 5 satellite, capable of handling 12,000 telephone calls and two television programs, was launched Friday.

title: MIAMIANS SEE POLICE TRIALS AS TEST OF RACIAL TRUCE
description: Four trials of police officers charged with killing black men are likely to test the fragile racial peace here, Miamians believe. The first trial will start Monday, with the others unfolding throughout the summer.

title: THIS TIME MARYLAND KEEPS THE TROPHY
description: It was getting close to midnight Saturday when William Boniface walked out of the yellow and white tent after a lavish post-Preakness party. It was a party that Boniface and his family would have attended regardless of what happened in the mud and rain at Pimlico Race Course six hours earlier, but now it was an evening he would savor forever. He cradled a silver trophy in his arms and shook his head as he stared at it.

title: Commencement Day, a Time for Parting Words and Rejoicing; UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT EXHORTS GRADUATES TO USE FULL TALENTS
description: Addressing graduates at St. John's University's 113th commencement yesterday, the Very Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, president of the school, told the students they were blessed with great talents and abilities and that the community, the nation and the world needs what they can offer.

title: Jersey Atom Plant Back in Operation
description: The Salem I nuclear plant, dormant for nearly eight months, is generating electric power again, its operator said today.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: PEETE RALLIES FROM 7 BEHIND TO WIN BY 2
description: Calvin Peete, who was distracted by a gum infection and shot a 75 Saturday, came from seven strokes behind today and scored a two-stroke victory in the Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Around the Nation; Los Angeles County To Seek Wage Cuts
description: Los Angeles County, battling a projected budget deficit of $100 million, will ask 60,000 employees to take wage cuts of 3 percent in the coming fiscal year.

title: Washington Watch; Japan's Looser Customs Rules
description: THE United States trade representative, Bill Brock, says he finds something to cheer about in new import procedures just voted by the Japanese Parliament. According to Mr. Brock, the new legislation, which liberalizes customs procedures for imports into Japan, is the most significant development in American-Japanese relations in the last four years.

title: PAT BRADLEY'S 66-212 TAKES JERSEY GOLF
description: Pat Bradley shot a seven-under-par 66, a women's course record for the Upper Montclair Country Club, and charged from five shots back in the final round today to win the eighth annual Chrysler-Plymouth Classic by one stroke over a rookie, Stephanie Farwig.

title: DeJohnette Quintet, Special Edition
description: Flexibility is the byword of Jack DeJohnette's Special Edition, which played last weekend at Swing Plaza. In fact, the quintet - Mr. DeJohnette on drums or piano, Rufus Reid on bass and David Murray, J.D. Parran and Howard Johnson on saxophones and clarinets - can sound like a different group for every tune.

title: END OF A CAREER: FINNISH POLITICIAN AND RUMORS OF ALCOHOLISM
description: The once outstanding career of a former Finnish Prime Minister has ended with presidential announcements dismissing him as governor of the Bank of Finland and co-chairman of the Finnish-Soviet Economic Commission.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a race like the Indianapolis 500, the leading driver is only a few feet ahead of the second-place auto as the final lap begins. The yellow light comes on and the yellow flag is waved because of a mishap on the other side of the track. Must the drivers hold their positions even though it looks as if the second-place car is about to make a move to take the lead?

title: Kornhauser Appointed
description: Spectravideo Inc. of New York, which makes home computers, has appointed Kornhauser & Calene as its agency for consumer advertising. The company had previously handled all its advertising in-house, and will continue to handle its own software and trade promotion. Ad expenditures for 1983 are expected to reach $8 million, a good part of which will be used to promote its recently introduced SV 318 home computer, which is priced under $300.

title: GOLDWATER 'GOOFED' IN MISSING LAST VOTE ON BUDGET MEASURE
description: As the Senate jockeyed back and forth last week toward passage of a 1984 budget resolution that called for an increase in taxes, Senator Barry Goldwater sided steadfastly with the White House in opposition. But when the final vote came just before midnight Thursday, the conservative Arizona Republican was absent from the chamber and the measure passed, 50 to 49.

title: Around the World; Fierce Rioting Flares In Londonderry Streets
description: Bands of youths hurled hundreds of gasoline bombs at policemen in the Roman Catholic district of Bogside today in rioting that included a brief exchange of gunfire, the police said.

title: UNSUNG PLAYERS IN PLAYOFF SPOTLIGHT
description: The reporters huddling in the back right corner of the Philadelphia 76ers' locker room this afternoon were a familiar sight. Julius Erving dresses in that area and entertains a crush of reporters after almost every home game.

title: 'Work or Die'
description: Katherine McKinstry worked for 20 years as a waitress until, at the age of 53, she began to suffer from arthritis, spinal disease and severe depression. In December 1981 she put a gun to her head and killed herself. Her case is especially interesting because the note she left was addressed not to a resented or beloved relative, but to the Federal Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Put Off Expressly
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Schlichter's 'Problem'
description: THE man was a pit boss at a Las Vegas casino. He made what Frank Hall called ''real good money'' but he kept gambling it away. ''His wife used to tell me,'' Frank Hall, the manager of the Churchill Downs sports and racing book, was saying, ''that if he went broke and didn't have any money to bet, he'd lay in bed and cry. He'd rather lose a bet than not be able to bet. Now that's a compulsive gambler. I don't think there are too many people like that, but there are some.''

title: Alaska Pipeline Expense Cited
