description: Alaska's abundant supplies of natural gas would be better left in the ground for the rest of the decade because the high cost of completing a pipeline to transport it to southern markets makes it uncompetitive, according to a Government study.

title: Around the World; Actions, Not Words, Peking Tells American
description: China said today that the United States must demonstrate action and not merely good will if it hopes to tap the ''great potential'' in economic relations with China.

title: Quality, Not Quantity
description: When Tyrone Bogues's name is spotted on a list of top high school basketball players recruited by major colleges, the first impression is that the listing must be a misprint.

title: ROTTERDAM BUSY BUT TROUBLED
description: The freighter was called the Waterberg, out of South Africa with 2,400 containers on board. She moored recently in the Prinses Margriethaven here, at the 2-mile-long Europe Container Terminus piers, which handle about one million containers a year.

title: PERSIAN GULF INDUSTRIALIZATION
description: Ever since the first big run-up in oil prices in 1973, the Persian Gulf oil-producing countries have been trying to wring more profit out of their oil and gas reserves by diversifying into related fields such as chemicals and fertilizer or by setting up heavy industries such as aluminum and steel, which need abundant cheap energy.

title: RAILROADS URGE HIGHER TRUCK TAXES
description: The railroad industry has begun a campaign to prod several states into raising their taxes on heavy trucks, an increase that would be added to the higher Federal taxes approved by Congress in January.

title: CHIPS ARE NO BARGAIN
description: As the Scowcroft commission's recommendations move toward a vote in Congress, the phrase ''bargaining chip'' is often used in support of the MX. We would do well to stop using this vague expression in thinking about arms control negotiations. That won't be easy, because it is tempting for officials to argue that the weapons they are developing can be used to persuade Moscow to agree to arms limitations.

title: Boston Bank Acquisition
description: The First National Bank of Boston announced yesterday that it would purchase the mortgage banking business of Stockton, Whatley, Davin & Company, a subsidiary of the Phillips Petroleum Company, for $120 million in cash.

title: AMERICA, BE WARM TO ISRAEL
description: Will Secretary of State George P. Shultz be able to build on his progress in the Middle East, or will the Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization buildup in Lebanon produce another confrontation? The answer may depend on whether the Administration learns from recent experience or whether it returns to mistaken assumptions.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM'S HEAD IS FIRST EMPIRE'S CHIEF
description: The First Empire State Corporation, a bank holding company based in Buffalo, has named Robert G. Wilmers chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Restore Capitol Facade, Not Extend It
description: A Senate subcommittee approved a plan Friday to restore the crumbling West Front of the Capitol, the building's last original sandstone wall, setting the stage for another in a 130-year-old series of Congressional battles over the building.

title: CANNES OVER, FILMS FACE THE PUBLIC
description: At 8 A.M. Friday, barely four hours after the last party on the last day of the 36th Cannes Internattional Film Festival came to an end, workers were already tearing down the gigantic, glittery billboards in front of the Carlton Hotel. The remnants of what had taken a year to plan and pay for would be cleared away in a matter of days.

title: ROGER VASSELAIS
description: Roger Vasselais, retired senior partner of the investment concern of Reynolds & Company, died of a heart attack Saturday while taking part in field trials for Labrador retrievers in Manorville, L.I. Mr. Vasselais was 81 years old and lived in Remsenburg, L.I.

title: Joni Mintz, Paralegal, Wed To Alan S. Cohen, Lawyer
description: Joni Ellen Mintz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Mintz of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Stuart Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Cohen of Fort Lee, N.J., and North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Peter E. Kasdan, assisted by Cantor Mikhail Manevich, performed the ceremony at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: SOUTH AFRICA JETS BOMB MOZAMBIQUE
description: South African Air Force planes bombed offices of the African National Congress early today in the Mozambican capital of Maputo, according to an announcement by Defense Minister Magnus Malan.

title: Holmes Triumphs
description: Greg Holmes of Utah defeated Fredrik Pahlett of Minnesota, 6-3, 6-2, today to capture the N.C.A.A. men's singles tennis championship.

title: Seyna Jo Bruskin Weds Subba Rao Seethamsetty
description: Seyna Jo Bruskin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Bruskin of New York, was married in White Plains yesterday to Subba Rao V. Seethamsetty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vengal Rao Seethamsetty of Visakhapatnam, India. Cantor Frederick Herman performed the ceremony at the Westchester, a hotel.

title: Commodities; Bond Puts Become Profitable
description: TREASURY bond options traders who held apparently worthless puts on the June bond futures contract were handsomely rewarded last Friday. So too were others who were buying puts on the June bond option up to the moment it expired at 1 P.M. in New York.

title: Some New Issues May Be Postponed
description: Given the rise in interest rates last week and the stubbornly high rate of money supply growth, underwriters of corporate and tax-free bonds scheduled for this week may postpone issues if market conditions do not improve.

title: Air France Proposal
description: Air France has proposed a capital restructuring to cover part of its loss last year of 791.8 million francs, the current equivalent of $106.6 million. The Governmentowned airline on Friday proposed paying 818.1 million francs of debt by cutting the nominal value of each of its shares to 22 francs from 40, thereby reducing its capital to 999.9 million francs from 1,818 million. Fresh capital totaling 737 million francs, through the issue of 33.5 million shares at 22 francs each, is planned mainly by converting Government loans into shares.

title: STAGE: 'WINTERPLAY,' SET IN CALIFORNIA
description: PERHAPS no one can say with authority what a ''typical'' American family is anymore, but it seems that everyone can still define a typical upper-middle-class suburban Californian family. Such families are all unhappy and all alike. Dad is inevitably a slick professional man who drinks too much (but very quietly) and philanders. Mom is a chipper but bored housewife who may some day find herself. The children often include a psychiatric basket case, an automobile fanatic and an out-of-the-closet homosexual. They all live in an antiseptic glass house and are so tolerant of one another's mostly anomic behavior that you - and they - could die.

title: MATCH MADE BY COMPUTER IN ADOPTIONS
description: Gilbert needed a mother. Beverlie Blackwell wanted a child. He has delayed motor development. She said she could love a child who was not perfect.

title: NEW TROUBLE SEEN FOR SEARLE
description: At the annual meeting of G.D. Searle & Company in early May, Donald H. Rumsfeld, president and chief executive officer, showed a rare moment of self-doubt when a disgruntled stockholder timidly asked why Searle had not raised the 13-cent quarterly dividend during Mr. Rumsfeld's six-year tenure.

title: HOW PARAMOUNT 'SEVEN' FARED AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: In the spring of 1981, under the pressure of movie budgets that were spinning out of control and an expected strike by Hollywood directors, Paramount rushed six low-budget movies into production and made an arrangement to help finance a seventh.

title: Nina Jeanne Sauro Is Wed To Dr. W. S. Maginnis 3d
description: Nina Jeanne Sauro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Sauro of Kendall Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. William Stuart Maginnis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maginnis Jr., of Fullerton, Calif. The Rev. John Heinsohn peformed the ceremony at the Kingston (N.J.) Presbyterian Church, assisted by Brian Boughter, a seminarian at Princeton Theological Seminary.

title: Reds 4, Cubs 3
description: Gary Redus hit a home run and scored twice to support the four-hit, 10-strikeout pitching of Mario Soto (6-2) and pace Cincinnati.

title: Dr.Nancy Post Wed in Raleigh
description: Dr. Nancy Post, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour C. Post of New York and Truro, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Schecter of Raleigh, N.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schecter of Arlington, Va. Rabbi Jerry Leibler performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Expos 2, Giants 0
description: Charlie Lea scattered five hits over eight innings, and Montreal took advantage of five errors. Lea (3-1) struck out three but walked six, including the first two batters in the ninth, and Jeff Reardon came on to get the last three outs for his third save.

title: MONDAY, MAY 23, 1983
description: Companies

title: Bank Planning Shift to Stock
description: The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, the nation's largest mutual savings bank, plans to convert to stock ownership. The plan must be approved by Pennsylvania's Department of Banking.

title: QUIET MOVEMENT AIDS FAMILIES IN CRISIS
description: It may have a particularly enigmatic title and a sweeping mission, but family support, its proponents contend, is an increasingly significant movement that may well alter the way society helps the American family.

title: The Thouvenel Quartet, From Midland, Texas
description: Although a young ensemble, the Thouvenel String Quartet has garnered a reputation that extends far beyond the boundaries of its native Midland, Tex. Thursday evening, the quartet, which consists of the violinists Eugene Purdue and Edmund Stein, the violist Sally Chisholm and the cellist Jeffrey Levenson, presented a varied program in Carnegie Recital Hall consisting of music by Mozart, Schubert and Milton Babbitt.

title: SCIENTIST SEES AIR OF 'LUNACY' IN NUCLEAR WEAPONS BUILDUP
description: Squinting as the the bright sun shone on the rows of black-robed graduates at the State University here, the scientist Lewis Thomas warned today that politicians' ''obsession with stockpiling nuclear armaments has at the core aspects of what we would call lunacy.''

title: BOY, 8, IS KILLED IN GANG CROSSFIRE
description: An 8-year-old boy returning home from a family gathering with his mother and grandmother was fatally shot late Saturday night when he was caught in the crossfire of a gang battle on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: Around the World; Polish Labor Groups Start to Register
description: The Polish authorities, pressing ahead with plans to replace the banned Solidarity trade union, have registered the first national federation under a new union system started in January.

title: ILL-CHOSEN APPROACH TO RISING HEALTH COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: A CASE OF POLLUTION
description: THIS evening's WNET/13 schedule looks at the emotional subjects of pollution and taxes. ''In Our Water,'' packaged as part of the ''Frontline'' series, begins at 8 with a look at one notorious case of hazardous-waste dumping in New Jersey. Later, at 10:30, ''Tax Is a Three-Letter Word'' features Milton Friedman, the economist, arguing in favor of the proposed constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, an amendment he helped write.

title: DIAMOND SEEKING NATOMAS
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation announced yesterday a $700 million cash tender offer for a controlling stock interest in the Natomas Company. Both companies are oil and natural gas producers, with Diamond Shamrock engaged mostly in domestic operations and Natomas in the Far East, particularly Indonesia.

title: DEMOCRATS OF 'MAINSTREAM' REGROUP TO TRY AGAIN
description: It occurred without fanfare, in a tiny meeting room in an austere hotel just off Capitol Hill. A handful of men and women, briefcases in hand, swept in and helped themselves to ham sandwiches and white wine. An hour and a half later, the Coalition for a Democratic Majority, one of the forces that tried to persuade the Democrats to take stronger stands on national security issues in the 1970's, had been brought back to life.

title: STARS WIN 8TH IN ROW
description: The running back Kelvin Bryant rushed for 106 yards and two touchdowns as the Philadelphia Stars beat the Arizona Wranglers, 24-7, tonight for their eighth straight United States Football League victory.

title: FEDERAL PLAN FOR GHOST TOWN: SAVE HOUSES BY SELLING THEM
description: Before the Government repealed the Silver Act in 1907, several thousand people and 27 saloons flourished here in a booming gold and silver mining town.

title: Opponents of Arms Activity In Cambridge Move for Vote
description: Advocates of eliminating nuclear weapons activity in Cambridge said Saturday they had gathered enough signatures to put the question on the November ballot.

title: Art Directors Bestow Awards
description: When it came to awards for advertising, Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein did the best at the annual presentations of the Art Directors Club held Friday night aboard the carrier Intrepid at Manhattan's pier 86.

title: Beth Herr Wins
description: Beth Herr, a Southern California freshman who was 1 point from defeat, recovered today to win the singles title of the N.C.A.A. women's tennis championships. She beat Clemson's Gigi Fernandez, 3-6, 6-2, 7-6, in a 2 1/2-hour final.

title: A LEBANESE OFFICIAL IS OPTIMISTIC SYRIA WILL NEGOTIATE PULLOUT
description: Foreign Minister Elie Salem of Lebanon said today that Syria would probably negotiate on troop withdrawals from Lebanon soon despite its initial rejection of an Israeli-Lebanese accord.

title: STILLS OF CAPITAL'S MOVERS AND SHAKERS
description: At 7:30 o'clock last Monday morning, George Bush walked into Michael Evans's town house in a quiet northwest Washington neighborhood and went upstairs.

title: Around the Nation; E.P.A. Says Cyanide Has Spread to 3 States
description: Environmental Protection Agency officials say their investigation of a suburban company accused of illegally dumping tons of cyanide-tainted photographic film waste has spread to three other states.

title: Sandra McCardell Weds Raul Arcenas
description: The marriage of Sandra Beth McCardell and Raul Rodriguez Arcenas, graduates of the University of Chicago M.B.A. program, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Archie Richard McCardell, parents of the bride, in Fairfield, Conn. Judge T.F. Gilroy Daly of the United States District Court performed the ceremony.

title: BLITZ TOP GENERALS IN OVERTIME, 19-13
description: The New Jersey Generals' game against the Chicago Blitz today was a re-run before a crowd of 33,812, the second lowest attendance of six home games.

title: LABORITE STRESSING ISSUES, NOT IMAGE
description: The television interviewer had reminded Michael Foot an hour before that this part of England, East Anglia, is covered with military installations, but the 69-year-old Labor Party leader was in no mood to tone down his message to suit the area.
A spirited tug of war is likely to develop at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting tomorrow as monetarists battle to regain control of Fed policy.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: News Analysis
description: The City of New York, effectively barred last week by a Federal judge from increasing its jail population beyond 10,200 inmates, now has two choices: build more jails or have fewer inmates.

title: NATOMAS STOCK CLIMBS ON BID FROM DIAMOND
description: The Natomas Company was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, following the surprise offer by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation Sunday to pay about $1.4 billion in cash and stock for the West Coast energy company.

title: BERGER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 28.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $125,700. c-Net income.

title: Blue Jays Win, 4-0, on 3d Shutout in Row
description: The Toronto Blue Jays tied club records for consecutive shutouts with their third and for home runs in a game with four in a 4-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

title: PIZZA VENTURES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-Includes charge of $433,000 relating to merger costs.

title: BRIEFING
description: Saturday Afternoon Live

title: NEW BRUNSWICK SCIENTIFIC CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES PLC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a pretax credit of $3.2 million from the settlement of claims.

title: Addendum
description: * Country Living magazine increasing its circulation rate base 6.6 percent, to 800,000, from 750,000, and its advertising rates by the same percent, effective with the July issue.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $365,000. c-Net loss. The year-ago revenue figure is restated to conform to 1983 presentation.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a net realized gain of $13,600,000 on investments. c-After a net realized loss of $1,100,000 on investments. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: U.S.F.L.  Mulls Shift On Signing
description: Commissioner Chet Simmons of the United States Football League told Congress today that the league was considering changes to its rules, making them more flexible toward the signing of undergraduates with collegiate eligibility remaining.

title: Bill on Check Clearing Passed by State Senate
description: Banks in New York State would be required to clear checks quickly under a bill passed unanimously today by the Senate and sent to Governor Cuomo.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LIFE AND DEATH IN TIBET: THE PAST CLINGS FIERCELY
description: A large yellowish bird of prey glided down on powerful wings and landed a distrustful distance from a solitary horseman who was leading his laden pack ponies along the twisting mountain road.

title: TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect fiscal 1982 year-end audit adjustments.

title: Abercrombie President Leaves After Shake-Up
description: The revitalized Abercrombie & Fitch, the famous old sporting goods retailer whose name, trademarks and charge accounts were acquired by Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. of Houston in 1978, has just come through a shake-up. Jerry L. Nanna, Abercrombie's president, and Terry Smith, store operations vice president, have both resigned and the heads of Oshman's say that they will now directly take over daily operations and planning.

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
S.& P. Lowers Lilco's Rating Again
description: For the second time this year, the Standard and Poor's Corporation has downgraded the bonds of the Long Island Lighting Company because of uncertainty over the future of the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago figures were restated to reflect acquisition of Compu-Psych Inc. in February 1983.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
'SYLPHIDE,' AN END AND A BEGINNING FOR ERIK BRUHN
description: Erik Bruhn's new production of ''La Sylphide,'' which is to be unveiled tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House in the American Ballet Theater's major gala of the season, marks a new phase in the great Danish dancer's career.

title: More Time for Manville Plan
description: The Manville Corporation, which went to a bankruptcy court last August to seek protection from thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits, yesterday was given 30 more days to come up with a reorganization plan.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the latest first quarter include a nonrecurring pretax gain of $1,237,000 on securities transactions.

title: SOUTH AFRICA JETS RAID MOZAMBIQUE IN REPLY TO REBELS
description: South Africa said today that its planes staged an early morning raid on installations and residences of the African National Congress in the Mozambican capital of Maputo.

title: A Helper in Need of Help
description: When the poor in Harlem have needed an advocate, Florence Rice has been likely to be called. Now, however, she is seeking the help of others to save her 20-year-old Harlem Consumer Education Council.

title: WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
VENEZUELA SEEKS I.M.F. HELP
description: Venezuela's Finance Minister, Arturo Sosa, said today that he would apply for loans from the International Monetary Fund next week to help his country's debtburdened economy. Speaking to reporters after a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mr. Sosa said, ''Using the fund has always been part of the plan.''

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $56,951 for the quarter and $166,058 for the 9 months. On April 18, the company said its shareholders voted to change its name from Anaerobic Energy Systems to Sun Coast Plastics Inc.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS AWAITS LONDON RIGHTS
description: People Express began to sell low-cost tickets today for flights between London and Newark, despite uncertainty whether the British Government would grant the necessary permits.

title: VALENZUELA DEFEATS PHILS ON 4-HITTER, 2-0
description: Fernando Valenzuela pitched a fourhitter for his third shutout of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored a 2-0 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: RAISING THE QUESTION OF FEDERAL 'INTERFERENCE'
description: SUPPORTERS of education may cheer the fact that a reporter asked, and President Reagan answered, a question about the schools during his televised news conference last week. Education's return to the limelight on that exalted level may confirm predictions by some observers that education would play an important role in the next Presidential election campaign.

title: COATS: NEW LINES IN CLOTH
description: It appeared for a while, when every woman seemed to be snuggling into a down coat as if it were a feather bed, that the standard tailored winter coat was an endangered species.

title: PAULIN, H, & CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The Roeblings' Bridge, and Era
description: In another time and what would seem another world, on a day when two young men were walking on the moon, a very old woman on Long Island would tell reporters that the public excitement over the feat was not so much compared with what she had seen ''on the day they opened the Brooklyn Bridge.'' - David McCullough, ''The Great Bridge''

title: 1st Amendment Cases Not for Juries Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: ON WINGS OF NEW TECHNOLOGY, DIRIGIBLE TRIES A COMEBACK
description: FOR Frederick D. Ferguson, a 33-year-old Canadian industrial designer, the production of lighter-than-air sky hoists capable of moving huge loads is an idea whose time is overdue.

title: Hamilton Sells Stake
description: The Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its equity position in the Gulf Energy and Development Corporation to the Penn Central Corporation for $22.3 million in cash. Hamilton Brothers owns all of Gulf Energy's outstanding convertible preferred stock and warrants to a purchase of common stock. On a fully converted and exercised basis, its position represent 24.3 percent of Gulf Energy's common stock.

title: CORSICAN REBELS SET OFF 43 BOMBS IN POLITICAL WARNING TO MITTERRAND
description: Corsican separatists blasted banks, a police station, homes and businesses in 43 separate bomb attacks on the Mediterranean island early today, the police said.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Four Years Later
description: An agent's defamation-of-character lawsuit filed in 1979 against Ted Turner, the owner of the Braves, is going to court this week in Atlanta. The plaintiff is Bucky Woy, who says that Turner caused ''irreparable damage'' to his reputation by declaring that Woy was ''guilty of manslaughter'' in the death of Bill Lucas, the Braves' general manager.

title: Topics Learning and Labor; Women's Work
description: More and more, women are taking jobs that once were almost exclusively male. Two decades ago, for instance, only two of every 100 lawyers were women.

title: A Saigon Premier of 60's Among 'Boat People'
description: A Prime Minister of South Vietnam was among a boatload of refugees that has arrived in Singapore, a senior United Nations refugee official said today.

title: More Layoffs At Atari Inc.
description: Atari Inc. plans to lay off 225 workers Friday in another round of cost-cutting at the computer and video-game maker.

title: PREGNANCY WITH FROZEN EMBRYO IS SUCCESSFUL AT 14TH WEEK
description: MICE, rats, rabbits, cattle and sheep have all been raised from embryos that had been frozen and stored for future use, sometimes for as long as eight years before being thawed and implanted in foster mothers for gestation and birth.

title: UNILEVER NV reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Ex-Jet Is Accused Of Manslaughter
description: A former professional football player and his partner in two sand mining companies have been indicted on manslaughter charges in the death of an employee, officials said today.

title: UNILEVER GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ROLE IN PANAMA OF U.S. MILITARY CAUSING STRAINS
description: United States relations with Panama have been strained in recent months by increased American use of bases in Panama for a variety of military missions in Central America, according to American and Panamanian officials.

title: THEFTS OF CAR STEREOS TURN MUSIC INTO HEADACHES
description: Something is missing in George Larkin's life. For two weeks, commuting had bordered on the exhilarating, breezing to work from New Jersey across the upper deck of the George Washington Bridge in his snappy new European car, with the spiffy stereo system blaring Puccini or Michael Jackson. All that is lost now. There is a hole where his Blaupunkt used to be.

title: 3 Gang Members Held In the Killing of Boy, 8
description: Three members of a Brooklyn gang were arrested yesterday in the fatal shooting late Saturday of an 8-year-old boy who was standing on a Sunset Park street corner with his mother and was struck by a stray bullet apparently intended for members of a rival gang.

title: FLORIDA LITERACY TEST SNAGS DIPLOMAS
description: For most of the 491 seniors at Sarasota High School, these are sunny days of anticipation. The talk on this palm-@ and eucalyptus-studded campus is of Saturday night's gala senior prom and the graduation ceremony set for June 4.

title: Lightning Kills 8 in Austria
description: Lightning struck a group of hikers today, killing eight people and injuring nine, a police spokesman reported. The hikers were resting under two trees.

title: MRS. RUCKELSHAUS SAID TO RETAIN JOB
description: President Reagan has dropped his Administration's earlier plan to replace Jill S. Ruckelshaus as a member of the United States Civil Rights Commission, a White House official said today.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 24.
description: The results for the latest fourth quarter reflect the acquisition of Dixie-Northern sector of the American Can Co. in July 1982.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Ambush Convoy Carrying Journalists
description: A military convoy escorting about a dozen foreign correspondents from a Government-sponsored trip near the northern battle zone was ambushed by rebels, officials reported today.

title: DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
ROCK: DAVE EDMUNDS
description: DAVE EDMUNDS, the Welsh singer, guitarist and songwriter, has established himself as a rock-and-roll classicist of the most orthodox sort, with a performing repertory that runs from Chuck Berry to Elvis Costello. And at Roseland on Wednesday, Mr. Edmunds and his quartet played an impeccable concert that defined this very specific idea of rock-and roll-purity.

title: LESSON OF COALINGA: CALIFORNIA SEEMS IN STILL GREATER PERIL
description: THE rumbling from California's Coalinga earthquake May 2 has stopped but serious scientific reverberations continue. They now indicate to geologists that the state is in even worse seismological condition than had been thought.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Boston, Philadelphia, Pacific, Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: P.L.O. UNIT ASKS SYRIAN BLOCKADE OF LEBANON
description: A Palestinian leader with good ties to Damascus called on Syria today to impose an economic blockade on Lebanon to undermine its security agreement with Israel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's the great bridge. You should see it at night, the stone towers with all the lights on.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AT INDIANAPOLIS: LIFE ON THE FRINGE
description: Having failed yet again to qualify for the Indianapolis 500-mile race, and having little desire to watch others drive when he cannot, Larry Cannon will spend Sunday afternoon here, at home, tending to chores long neglected and listening to the race on his radio.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TENSION BELIEVED TO BRING TIES TO LOW POINT
description: Soviet-American relations have reached one of the lowest points in a generation as the two nations trade recriminations over the Middle East, Central America, Afghanistan and missile deployments in Europe, according to many Government and academic specialists.

title: A BAFFLING EPIDEMIC
description: Although the news media and some segments of organized medicine were slow to recognize the seriousness of the illness, that lethargy seems over and we are now being flooded with reports and warnings about the new disease the mystery of whose origin is reflected in its cryptic name - Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, or AIDS.

title: PACESETTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
EMOTIONS FOUND TO INFLUENCE NEARLY EVERY HUMAN AILMENT
description: The care of tuberculosis depends more on what the patient has in his head than what he has in his chest. - Sir William Osler (1849-1919), the father of modern medicine.

description: b-After a net loss of $2,526,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After net losses of $11,691,000 for the quarter and $14,809,000 for the 9 months on discontinued operations and the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $2,084,000 for the 9 months.

title: Democratic Head Assails Bid By G.O.P. to Disrupt Telethon
description: Charles Manatt, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today accused the Republican Party of returning to ''the 'dirty tricks' of another era'' by devising a plan to disrupt next weekend's fund-raising telethon by jamming the telephone lines.

description: b-Including tax credits of $1,691,000 for the quarter and $2,148,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $573,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: North Sea Oil Gain
description: The British Petroleum Company P.L.C. and four other partners in the North Sea Buchan field have recovered their share of the $300 million development costs after two years of production, according to a B.P. statement today.

title: Bridge: Pakistan Gains the Right To Play in Bermuda Bowl
description: At the end of zonal championship final play here today, Pakistan had defeated India by 175 international match points and thus qualified for the Bermuda Bowl, to be played in Stockholm in September.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $262,000. c-Net loss.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 2-for-1 split payable June 15.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: OPTIMISM BUDS IN THE MIDWEST
description: It's been a long time coming, but the Middle West, where the industrial heartland meets the nation's bread basket, is at last sprouting a promising economic recovery.

title: India Asks U.N. for Deadline For Namibia's Independence
description: India urged the Security Council today to set a deadline for the independence of South-West Africa and to impose a trade embargo on South Africa if it is not met.

title: PURCELL CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
An Unhappy Pirate
description: John Candelaria says that although he's ''not suggesting a trade,'' he wouldn't mind one from the Pirates. Candelaria, a left-handed pitcher, first made his unhappiness known last week when he excoriated Pittsburgh fans who had booed him for not running out a bobbled groundball against Cincinnati.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: SAMOAN LEADER DECLARES: 'BOTH ANTHROPOLOGISTS ARE WRONG'
description: PRIME Minister Tofilau Eti of Western Samoa wants his Government to take a hand in the current international controversy among Western anthropologists over sexual practices in those balmy South Pacific islands.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Guyana Expelling 2 In the U.S. Embassy
description: Guyana has ordered two United States Embassy officials out of the country for interfering in its domestic affairs, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: The Robot at Commencement
description: The commencement message at a community college near Washington last week was that humans would have to learn to work with computers. What gave this amiable message its special interest is that it came from a chrome and fiberglass machine named Robot Redford.

title: BUDGET IS UNCERTAIN
description: As Congress tries to complete action this week on several major bills before the Memorial Day recess, prospects for approval of the MX missile seem to be improving, but serious divisions remain on Capitol Hill over economic policy.

title: CONCERT: THE MONTREAL UNDER DUTOIT
description: THE Montreal Symphony's program at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night spoke in a very loud, very clear voice. Charles Dutoit led the orchestra in three emphatic pieces - Berlioz's ''Le Corsaire'' Overture, Act II of the Saint-Saens opera, ''Samson et Dalila,'' and finally Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.''
When First Lieut. Paul Byron Whipkey, a 26-year-old pilot and company commander, disappeared from Fort Ord, Calif., on July 10, 1958, the Army listed him as absent without leave.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TIME SPANS

title: Some Conrail Rates Cut
description: Conrail said today that it had reduced rail-motor rates for iron and steel shipments from 30 steel mill locations to the Detroit and Philadelphia metropolitan areas. Conrail said the new rates for bars, billets, blooms, ingots, slabs, sheet or strip steel are about 10 to 17 percent cheaper than those charged by truck companies between the same points, and are a part of continuing effort to compete with all truck service.

title: New Moses Goal
description: Edwin Moses surprised a track writers luncheon in Los Angeles yesterday by saying that he would like to set a world record in the 800 meters before the 1984 Olympics.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Chrysler Debt Ratings Are Raised by S.& P.
description: The Chrysler Corporation's and the Chrysler Financial Corporation's senior debt ratings were raised to B from CCC by S.& P. yesterday.

title: Sweet Deals in the Orchard
description: ''Oranges are not an essential food. People don't need oranges. They can take vitamins.'' So said an official of the Agriculture Department two years ago in defense of the Government-enforced destruction of 40 percent of California's navel orange crop. And in that spirit, indifferent to the needs of consumers, the department goes merrily on championing farm interests. Its parochial view, however, is finally being challenged by conservatives in the Reagan Administration who care more about the efficiency of American agriculture than the profits of farmers.

title: A 25% PAY CUT FOR TRAINEES ON THE POLICE FORCE IS URGED
description: The chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee proposed yesterday that the pay of rookie police officers be cut by 25 percent during the five months they are trained at the Police Academy.

title: STUDENTS QUERY REAGAN ON PRAYER AND BUDGET CUTS
description: President Reagan, saying ancient Greece and Rome declined when they began to ''abandon their gods,'' today asserted that the Supreme Court ban on organized school prayer had ''diminished the importance of religion, and thus morality,'' among Americans, particularly young people.

title: ROBERTS & PORTER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TO JUDGE A PLEA FOR ASYLUM FAIRLY AND SPEEDILY
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 10 AFRO-AMERICAN COMPANIES
description: NORMADIEN GIBSON and N'Goma Woolbright got married Sunday afternoon. It wasn't just the average catered affair. The ceremony began with drum incantations to the earth and sky and chanting processionals down the aisles of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the wedding occurred. The bride and two women friends were veiled, lest any witches in the audience search her out with an evil spell. And after the brief onstage ceremony, with its ritual tasting of mango, bitters, salt, pepper, maize, water and honey, the bride and groom were entertained by 10 Afro-American dance companies.

title: SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $992,903 for the quarter and $929,724 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a loss of $68,176 for the quarter and income of $46,893 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Occidental Alters Its Pension Plans
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had restructured its employee pension plans, adding that the change would increase reportable profits by more than $100 million.

title: A Double Eagle To Remember
description: Bob Gilder stood alone at a golf tee in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday and drove half a dozen balls at a pin about 250 yards away. He was trying to duplicate the shot of his life - a doubleeagle 2 on the par-5 18th hole at the Westchester Country Club in last year's Westchester Classic.

title: WON NOBEL PRIZE IN MEDICINE
description: Dr. Albert Claude, a founder of modern cell biology who never graduated from high school and who went on to win a Nobel Prize in medicine, died Sunday night in Belgium. He was 84 years old.

title: EX-JERSEY ENVIRONMENT AIDE IS INDICTED IN WASTE DUMPING
description: A former Deputy Attorney General in charge of environmental cases in New Jersey was indicted today on charges he and others illegally dumped millions of gallons of untreated hazardous waste into New Jersey waters.

title: VETERANS' LOBBIES RETAIN TAX STATUS
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Federal Government's preferential tax treatment of organizations that lobby for veterans.

title: THEATER: 'JACQUES BREL'
description: TO celebrate the 15th anniversary of the original presentation of ''Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,'' which opened at the Village Gate in 1968 and ran there for more than four years, a new production of this collection of the Belgian composer's songs in English adaptations by Eric Blau and Mort Shuman has opened at First City Theater. This anniversary production, staged by Mr. Blau, has very direct roots to the original because First City is a cabaret theater newly opened by Art d'Lugoff, who also owns the Village Gate.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REV. FREDERICK BURGESS
description: The Rev. Frederick Burgess, former rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy at 26 West 84th Street in Manhattan, died Saturday at the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 93 years old and until recently had lived in West Redding, Conn.

title: 3d Arbiter Picked In Rail Dispute
description: Robert L. Stutz, an arbitrator and former professor of Industrial Administration at the University of Connecticut, was selected yesterday as the third and neutral member of the three-member arbitration panel in the dispute between the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the United Transportation Union.

title: DECEPTION DEFEATS GENERALS
description: ''Given the circumstances, there wasn't much we could do,'' said John Joyce, the inside linebacker for the Generals. ''I thought it was an excellent call.''

title: TWIN FAIR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $42,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Japan Loans To China
description: Japan has made $1 billion in loans to China under a five-year agreement signed in 1979, the New China News Agency said today.

title: New York Sheraton Sold
description: The New York Sheraton Hotel, New York's fifth largest, has been sold to VMS Realty, a real estate concern based in Chicago, for $60 million, VMS said. The 32-story, 1,450-room hotel, on Seventh Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets, was owned by the Sheraton Corporation, a unit of the ITT Corporation.

title: SEARCH NATIONAL RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The company said that it changed its fiscal year-end to Feb. 28 from May 31 and therefore the company's 1983 fiscal year results are based on 9 months compared with a full year of operations for fiscal 1982. Before the change, the year ended on May 31.

title: WESTGROWTH PETROLEUMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation's Control Data Ltd. subsidiary said it had acquired 40 percent of Systime P.L.C., the largest shareholding in the company, following completion of Systime's financial restructuring.

title: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. The year-ago results are restated.

title: DOW RISES BY 10.54, TO 1,200.56
description: The stock market staged a dramatic comeback yesterday, finishing higher after being down sharply in early trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 leading stocks, did much better than the general market. It closed with a rise of 10.54 points, to 1,200.56, after being off almost 13 points at 10:30 A.M.

title: SWIRLING OBJECT LABELED POSSIBLE DISTANT PLANET
description: A swirling, gaseous object discovered near a young star 450 light years from Earth may be the first planet ever seen outside our solar system, an astronomer said today.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Operating earnings c-Net income.

title: POMP AND HUMOR BLEND AS YALE GRADUATES 3,013
description: On the lawn of the Old Campus, surrounded by the century-old dormitories to which many came here as freshmen, 3,013 students graduated today in the 282d commencement of Yale University.

title: RANCHERS EXPLORATION & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SEISDATA SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Comings and Goings
description: Art Howe, the infielder for the Houston Astros, has been scheduled for elbow and ankle surgery Wednesday at Houston's Methodist Hospital, the team announced yesterday. ... Only hours after they traded the reliever Sid Monge to the San Diego Padres for Joe Lefebvre on Sunday, the Philadelphia Phillies sought to fill the vacancy in the bullpen, acquiring Willie Hernandez from the Cubs. To get him, the Phillies gave up Dick Ruthven, the veteran starter, and Bill Johnson, a pitcher from the minor leagues. ... Larry Pleau, former director of hockey operations for the Hartford Whalers, was appointed assistant general manager. ... For the third consecutive season, Wayne Gretzky was voted the N.H.L.'s player of the year in balloting among players conducted by The Sporting News. ... Providence College awarded an honorary doctorate in physical education to Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox.

title: MORTALITY DIFFERENCES SUBJECT TO CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: BUS DRIVERS TAKE A COURSE ON NUCLEAR RADIATION
description: The half-hour film on nuclear radiation began this morning with a musical flourish and an orange sun rising in a mist.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. The year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: WINDSOR INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated to include the operations of subsidiaries acquired in November.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Cameron Iron Works filed a shelf registration for an offering of up to $100 million of debt securities.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TOWNER PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ed Lynch, rained out of a start on Saturday night, tries to keep the recently revitalized Mets on the right path against Mike Krukow.

title: ZIMBABWE TRIES 6 OFFICERS AS SABOTEURS
description: Six high-ranking officers of the Zimbabwe Air Force went on trial here today accused of aiding South African saboteurs in blowing up 13 warplanes at a base in the center of the country last July.

title: Cunningham & Walsh Plans to Acquire Reiser
description: Cunningham & Walsh, one of the agencies owned by the publicly held Mickelberry Corporation, has reached an agreement to acquire Reiser Williams deYong, an eight-year-old business-to-business advertising agency with offices in Irvine and Santa Clara, Calif., and about $20 million in billings.

title: PRECISION FILM & VIDEO reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $43,000. The 1982 figures have been restated to include nonrecurring expenses of $118,000 and have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid August 1982.

title: UNILEVER PLC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Luncheon in the Park
description: Midtown got a couple of new open-air lunch spots yesterday when the Bryant Park and Lowell Fountain Cafes served their first meals. They provide oases of white wire-mesh tables and chairs in the park behind the public library on Fifth Avenue below 42d Street.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-Net loss. Revenue figures have been reclassified.

title: Insurance to Rise On All Jersey Cars
description: Insurance rates will rise next week by $19 or $33 a year for all private automobiles in New Jersey because no legislative action is scheduled on a measure that could stop the increases, the Insurance Department said today.

title: Caterpillar Jobs Added and Lost
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that it was recalling about 2,000 workers but that it was also laying off 1,450 other employees. Most of the recalls and layoffs will take effect June 6.

title: LEGAL AID SOCIETY SEEKS TO CUT APPEALS BACKLOG
description: The Criminal Appeals Bureau of the Legal Aid Society in the city, citing an ''explosion'' in the number of cases it receives, says it can now take as long as three years to file its appeals, and it has asked for help.

title: GENESEE COMPUTER CENTER reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: VIDEO GAME SPECIALISTS COME TO HARVARD TO PRAISE PAC-MAN, NOT TO BURY ; HIM
description: Pac-Man's beeping bite may be good, not bad, for children, a series of psychologists, teachers and computer designers said today at a conference on video games and learning at Harvard University.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COURT AVOIDS BRANIFF BANKRUPTCY RULING
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear a challenge by American Airlines to a Federal bankruptcy court's jurisdiction over the reorganization of the bankrupt Braniff International Corporation.

title: PIPER HYDRO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE IMAGINATIVE PATH TO DESIGNING GAMES
description: THERE probably isn't anyone who has played video games for any length of time who hasn't thought of designing a better one. But designing video games is an arcane art the secrets of whose craftsmanship reside within the very machine code of the computer itself, not only requiring consummate programming skills but forcing the creator to deal with the computer's capabilities on its own terms, in the most elementary particles of binary language, the zeroes and ones. It's an intellectual feat equivalent to batting .400.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated.

title: HYATT'S SWEETENER ON BRANIFF DEAL
description: Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of Hyatt International, will meet with a small group of secured creditors in Chicago today in an effort to win their agreement for a sweetened proposal to put 30 of Braniff's planes back into service.

title: SUMMIT THUNDER
description: There is a very real possibility that the Williamsburg, Va., summit meeting will set the stage for a full-scale clash between the Americans and the French - and there is a case to be made that such an outcome might be useful.

title: PASTORS SEE RACISM IN CHURCH
description: A group of United Methodist ministers in New York charged yesterday that officials of the denomination suppressed a report that the ministers said gave evidence of ''institutional racism'' within the 10-million-member church.

title: CONCERN OVER AIDS GROWS INTERNATIONALLY
description: THE problem of AIDS is growing internationally, but not yet with the frightening speed seen in this country. In many parts of the world there is anxiety, bafflement, a sense that something has to be done - although no one knows what - about this fatal disease whose full name is Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and whose cause is still unknown.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
OMEGA HYDROCARBONS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
URBAN RENEWAL: LESSON IN FAILURE
description: It was to be a model of urban renewal. On two square blocks in a poor neighborhood of Brooklyn, city officials and private developers planned to build a complex of 391 apartments. The Federal Government announced it would provide $16 million in rent subsidies.

title: News Analysis
description: Overlooked in the noisy, drawn-out Congressional debate over the 1984 budget is the fact that the Government's 1983 spending is running $40 billion or so above the ceiling of $769.8 billion that Congress adopted a year ago.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The U.N. Today; May 24, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meeting of donors to the program of humanitarian assistance for the Kampuchean people - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

Foreign Markets Closed
description: Markets had holiday closings yesterday in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and West Germany. Canadian markets were closed for Victoria Day.

title: Technology Magazines Are Said to Show Gains
description: With yesterday's arrival of Gerald G. Hotchkiss in the New York office of the Goldhirsh Group to begin his duties as publisher of Technology Illustrated, interest is heightened in just how the group's two new magazines - Technology Illustrated and High Technology - are doing.

title: ISLAND TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
US TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: J. SEWARD JOHNSON, A LONGTIME DIRECTOR OF FAMILY COMPANY
description: J. Seward Johnson, a director of Johnson & Johnson from 1921 to 1971 and an internationally known yachtsman half a century ago, died yesterday at his home in Fort Pierce, Fla. He was 87 years old and also lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Bids at Pogo Stand
description: A Federal District judge in Houston denied motions for preliminary injunctions against the competing offers for Pogo Producing Company shares by Pogo itself and by Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc. jointly.

title: Hutzler Chief Executive
description: Angelo R. Arena, vice chairman of the Batus retail division of Batus Inc., will become president and chief executive officer of the Hutzler Brothers' department store chain, Baltimore, on June 1. Mr. Arena, 54, and Edward McCormick Blair, Chicago investment banker, will become substantial investors in the eight-store chain, according to Hutzler Brothers.

title: Theatrical Adaptations
description: The party turned into a toast to the host when the American Theater Wing held its 10th annual Tony-Time Dinner and entertainment at Sardi's Sunday night.

title: Norwest Weighs Eurobond Issue
description: The Norwest Corporation tentatively plans to make its debut as a borrower in the Eurobond market this year with an issue of about $50 million, David Jarvis, executive vice president and chief financial officer, said today.

title: PENNEY, JC, CO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a loss of $3 million from discontinued operations.

title: ESPN STRUGGLING, BUT MAKING AN IMPACT
description: From the time the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network became a staple of cable-television systems across the country in September 1979, some executives of the major over-the-air networks have minimized its importance as a potential force in acquiring major sports events. Even for the hard-core fan, watching ESPN meant settling for selected college football games on a delayed basis, learning to love soccer and finding the rodeo fascinating. All of this repeated over and over.

title: EX-LAWMAKERS HAIL OLD FOES AT REUNION OF HOUSE ALUMNI
description: It took Les Arends nearly half a century to get there, but he finally made it to the Speaker's chair today. The former House Republican whip, still spry at the age of 87, was tapped by a onetime Democratic opponent, Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., to preside over the annual spring meeting of Former Members of Congress, a fast-growing alumni association.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STANFORD LIBERALS QUESTION SCHOOL'S TIE TO HOOVER INSTITUTION
description: The Stanford University campus here has been gripped for a month by a dispute between some faculty members and students on one side and, on the other, research scholars associated with the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace.

title: BROCK CASTS OFF GARVEY'S SHADOW
description: T he examination of Greg Brock received a new piece of evidence last Wednesday night. The beginning of his career as the first baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers had already been judged more than acceptable, even considering the demanding nature of the Dodger clientele and the emotional circumstances of his arrival. The names of Brock and Steve Garvey, his predecessor, which were first entwined last summer, are now together near the top of the National League home-run leaders.

title: MSI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed on Jan. 7, 1983.

title: Dow Resin Prices Rise
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that it was raising its prices for low-density polyethylene resins and linear low-density polyethylene resins by 6.5 cents a pound, effective June 20.

title: WMI EQUITY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $583,100 for the quarter and $652,800 for the year. c-Net loss. d-Including a gain of $172,300 on the sale of real OLDINGS INC (AMEX) Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 39,937,000 43,731,000 Net inc 2,391,000 4,206,000 Share earns .25 .41 Shares outst 9,483,420 10,178,398

title: Bullish View On Futures
description: John Barkshire is chairman of Mercantile House Holdings, a Londonbased financial services company, and the London International Financial Futures Exchange, which started business last autumn. Although the exchange has floundered in its early months, Mr. Barkshire says that futures exchanges are poised for huge growth, and ought to be compared with the Eurodollar market in 1966 on the eve of its explosive growth.

title: Johnson of 76ers Hospitalized
description: Clemon Johnson, the Philadelphia 76ers' reserve center, was hospitalized today with an acute urinary-tract infection.

title: First Union Corp.
description: The First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said its board had agreed in principle to the acquisition of Piedmont Bank.

title: E & B MARINE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
description: b-Net income.

title: A 'ONE-WAY PASSPORT' OUT OF POLAND
description: Peter J. Mroczyk, who left Warsaw only six weeks ago, arrived in Washington the other day with plane fare from his brother in Detroit. At night, after wandering the halls of Congress and visiting officials at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., he returned to the home of a friend and thought, quite suddenly, of his wife struggling to learn English in London.

title: Cedeno Suspended
description: Cesar Cedeno balked at being assigned a coach seat instead of one in first class for the Reds' flight Sunday back to Cincinnati from Chicago and tore up his ticket. Last night, the Reds fined the outfielder $100 for missing the flight and suspended him without pay for three days for ''misconduct.''

title: U.S. Requires Watch On Welfare Children
description: The Government issued final regulations today that require closer supervision of children in the welfare system and are designed to help keep the children with their families.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
BILL RATES HIGHEST 7 WEEKS
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday and yields fell as dealers bought securities to cover earlier sales of issues they did not own, a common credit market practice known as short covering.

title: RALPH SAMPSON'S PROUDEST DAY
description: Rain was falling steadily on Mr. Jefferson's Lawn in the center of the campus, or Grounds, of the University of Virginia Sunday morning. Rain dripped from the thick leaves of the ash and maple trees that line the Lawn, and the rain darkened the columns of the nearby buildings and obliterated the view of the Blue Ridge Mountains in the distance. The rain fell steadily on the colorful umbrellas of the spectators alongside the wide greensward, and it beat on the 4,000 or so empty metal folding chairs that had been placed on the Lawn and were facing a canopied platform.

title: Moscow Radio (Oops!) Calls Soviet 'Invaders'
description: The Moscow radio made an uncharacteristic contribution to the annals of broadcasting blunders today with three newscasts describing Soviet troops in Afghanistan as ''invaders'' and ''occupants'' who endangered the country's security.

title: GOULD INC. TO SELL BATTERY OPERATIONS
description: Gould Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its lead-acid battery operation to a group of investors organized by Allen & Company. Gould said the battery business had provided weaker sales and earnings growth than its advanced technology operations.

title: REGAN IS 'CONCERNED' ON MONEY SUPPLY JUMP
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he was ''concerned'' about the $7 billion increase in the nation's money supply in the latest reporting week, but that the Administration ''won't worry'' unless the increase becomes ''pronounced'' in coming weeks.

title: RESEARCH THAT CAN'T DO WITHOUT ANIMALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes for Eagles
description: As was expected, the shakeup in the front office of the Philadelphia Eagles has resulted in the dismissal of General Manager Jim Murray, who had been on the team's staff for 14 years. Leonard Tose, the owner, said that he and his daughter, Susan Fletcher, would take over Murray's duties.

title: Baby Strollers to Be Fixed
description: About 49,000 E-Z Roller baby strollers will be voluntarily repaired by the manufacturer because of the possibility that infants' fingers could become entrapped in their metal hinges, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. The manufacturer, Graco Children's Products Inc. of Elverson, Pa., said the strollers had been involved in four incidents in which children placed their fingers in the main metal folding hinge on the sides of the stroller while it was being unfolded for use. The company is providing free plastic hinge guard kits to owners of the strollers, which include Models 6620 and 6020.

title: UMC ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
SPAIN PROPOSES GAS LINE FROM ALGERIA
description: Spain has formally proposed the construction of a $10 billion pipeline system for natural gas that would link Algeria and Nigeria to Western Europe under the Strait of Gibraltar.

title: THE REAL STAR WARS
description: Not content with its earthbound military buildup and a nuclear ''modernization'' program to expand the American strategic arsenal from 9,000 to 14,000 warheads, the Reagan Administration seems bent on extending the arms race into outer space with costly and dangerous anti-satellite weapons (ASAT's).

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MACHINES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-The company reported that it had no sales income for the year-ago first quarter.

title: TO SCIENCE TIMES
description: In her article ''Parents Wary of Suppressing Sexuality in Children'' (May 17) Marie Winn raised an important point. Today's parents are confused about the best way to deal with their children's sexuality. Unfortunately, however, Miss Winn did not deal with the key issue - the message imparted to children about the goodness of their bodies, the wholesomeness of their natural curiosity and the health and desirability of responsible sexual expression that is appropriate to the child's developmental level.

title: LAKER HOPES HINGE ON MCADOO RETURN
description: Bob McAdoo's mournful eyes still search for the ball, but in a new way. Once the star of the show, McAdoo is now the Los Angeles Lakers' most important extra. When the 36-year-old Kareem Abdul-Jabbar needs a rest, McAdoo replaces him at center, and when the Lakers' need his offense, McAdoo plays the power forward in place of Kurt Rambis.

title: OFFERING PUBLIC SCHOOL TO 3- AND 4-YEAR-OLDS
description: EACH morning at 9:25, almost 45 minutes after the start of the normal school day, a gray van pulls up to Red Bank Primary School, near the shore of the Navesink River, and discharges its 16 passengers, all 3-year-olds. These children are among the few of their age enrolled in a public school anywhere in the country.

title: M.I.S.L. Title to Sockers
description: The San Diego Sockers defeated the Baltimore Blast, 3-1, tonight to capture the championship of the Major Indoor Soccer League. The Sockers won the deciding game of the three-of five series before a sellout crowd of 12,948 at the San Diego Sports Arena.

title: ACS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TO JUDGE A PLEA FOR ASYLUM FAIRLY AND SPEEDILY
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Cross, Out of Money, Plans Emergency Drive
description: The American Red Cross said today that its disaster relief fund was empty, and it has started a fund-raising drive to keep operating until the end of June.

title: Topics; Learning and Labor From the Waterfront
description: Eric Hoffer, who died last weekend at 80, was as wonderfully American as the country he celebrated. He was a true unbeliever, who judged ideas with the practical severity of a mechanic.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The firm is privately owned and does not report share earnings.

title: PENNEY, J C, FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
NIGERIA REPORTED IN DEBT AGREEMENT
description: Nigerian officials and representatives of American and European banks have tentatively agreed on a plan for rescheduling part of Nigeria's sizable short-term debt, banking sources said yesterday.

title: EAST RIVER FLOTILLA TO SAIL IN A WATERBORNE TRIBUTE
description: Mariners see bridges as the enemy, obstructing waterways and making navigation difficult and sometimes treacherous. And Grover Sanschagrin, who worked on tugboats on the East River for more than half his 62 years, is no exception - except when it comes to the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Market Place; Investors' Fear Of Labor Party
description: WITH just two and a half weeks left before Britain's June 9 general election, the City of London - the country's financial community - is growing steadily more confident that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the Conservative Party will stay in power. Prices on the London Stock Exchange have risen, the pound has been strong and bond prices have been steady for the last week as jitters about a possible Labor Party victory have receded.

title: Changes at Stan Kovics And Earl Newsom
description: Stan Kovics Advertising, with about $5 million in billings, has closed down and reopened as Kovics & Ciociola, reflecting the new partnership of Mr. Kovics and Mel Ciociola, who is also a copywriter. He previously worked at Young & Rubicam; N.W.Ayer; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, and Cunningham & Walsh, to name most. Mr. Kovics has passed through the doors of Doyle Dane Bernbach; Campbell-Ewald, New York; Van Brunt, and Griswold-Eshleman, and has had his own place for 10 years.

title: CITY SAVINGS BANK LOSSES CUT
description: Most New York City's savings banks reported a sharp narrowing of losses in the first quarter, while some of the 30 institutions moved back into the black, the New York State Banking Department disclosed yesterday.

title: Carling Chairman Quits
description: Canada's former energy minister, Alastair Gillespie, resigned yesterday as chairman of Carling O'Keefe Ltd., one of Canada's largest brewers. In a statement, he cited the adverse publicity caused by his involvement in a coal liquefaction project in Nova Scotia.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include the 50 percent pro-rated earnings of the company's affiliate, Welmoore Industries, which are accounted for under the equity method. On Oct. 21, 1982 Welmoore Industries commenced operations as a manufacturer and distributor of commercial food service equipment following the acquisition of the businesses of four subsidiaries of the Sunbeam Corp. Corrected from Saturday's editions.

title: Court Upholds Claim by UNC
description: The UNC Resources Company said a court in New Mexico had ruled that the company was covered by an insurance policy for the collapse of a structure at a uranium mill in Church Rock, N.M., in 1979.

title: SUMMIT SUN
description: The stakes are large and the opportunities great at the Williamsburg, Va., economic summit conference this weekend. Worldwide economic recovery, more open arrangements for international trade, a less vulnerable monetary system - all these are on the agenda. There are two potential dangers.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RATLIFF DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. The year-ago results were restated to reflect a change to full cost accounting.

title: Cold Snap Hits Soviet Grain
description: A dramatic drop in temperatures and heavy snowfalls have hit northern Kazakhstan, one of the Soviet Union's prime grain-growing areas, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Prudential-Bache Sells Citizen Bonds
description: Prudential-Bache Securities said it had begun a program of marketing its so-called Citizen Bonds, which are tax-exempt municipal securities in denominations of $1,000.

title: The World Trade Prison?
description: In Albany yesterday, State Senator William T. Smith introduced a bill that would direct the state to study the feasibility of converting the World Trade Center or other metropolitan-area buildings into a maximum-@security prison.

title: IMPORTER FOUND GUILTY OF 'LAUNDERING' DRUG MONEY
description: A businessman from Colombia was convicted yesterday in Manhattan of laundering more than $150 million in cash in what the Government called the largest operation to disguise the profits of narcotics trafficking uncovered in the New York metropolitan area.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago earnings figure is adjusted to reflect tax law changes reflecting premiums on annuity products.

title: CREDIT AID TO COFFEE IMPORTER
description: A syndicate led by the Shawmut Boston International Banking Corporation is providing an $8 million line of credit to rescue the General Coffee Corporation, part of the corporate network of a Colombian importer, Alberto Duque Rodriquez.

title: WORK BROADENED ROSSINI'S APPEAL
description: ''Tancredi,'' which Rossini wrote at 21, was the 10th of his 39 works for the stage and the one that established his reputation outside Italy. Venice heard the premiere in 1813.

title: L.I.R.R. UNION AND THE M.T.A. AGREE ON A PACT
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the union representing conductors and trainmen on the Long Island Rail Road announced last night that they had agreed on a new three-year contract that could open the way for pacts with other unions and avert a walkout in August.

title: TV Conflict
description: Professional golf and the National Basketball Association bumped heads on Sunday over the television facilities of CBS Sports, and the N.B.A. came away angry.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
ORROX CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
SERVED WITH TIMES IN PARIS SINCE 40'S
description: Josette Lazar, who represented Sunday sections of The New York Times in Paris for three decades, died this morning after a long illness. She was 62 years old.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend declared on May 6, 1983.

title: Floods Hit Eastern Australia
description: Torrential rains flooded areas of eastern Australia today that until last month were suffering from one of the worst droughts of the century. Roads were cut, several towns were isolated and crops were damaged after three days of heavy rain over central and southwestern Queensland and northwestern New South Wales.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rex Gosden, a Songwriter; Known for His Country Music
description: Rex Gosden, a writer of country-music songs, died of a heart attack early today.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
VERNA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: REGIONAL BROKERS: ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: A few years ago, Advest Inc., a Hartford-based brokerage house, had to make a choice. The firm, then privately owned, needed fresh capital. Its options were to accept a takeover by a well-capitalized financial organization, thus exchanging independence for security, or to try to raise the money by selling public shares.

title: CONNORS WINS EASILY IN PARIS
description: Jimmy Connors, the No.1-seeded player, and Mats Wilander, the defending champion, advanced easily today in openinground action at the French Open tennis championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an erroneous police report, an article in late editions of Metropolitan Report on May 16 about the collision of a taxicab and a private car misidentified Charles and Jean McDermott. They were pedestrians injured in the accident.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I am thinking of buying a device advertised as driving away rodents and insects with ''ultrasonics,'' or high-frequency sound. Is there any scientific evidence that such devices work?

title: An Appreciation
description: Few things in New York last for 100 years, and fewer still mean as much at the end of a century in this city as they did at the beginning. But the Brooklyn Bridge seems only to grow in importance. It no longer seems as daring an act of engineering as it did in the 19th century, or as overwhelming a presence on the skyline, but on its 100th birthday today it remains as potent, and as beloved, an icon as New York City has. It has always been something apart from other bridges. It was, of course, the first great bridge, the first roadway anywhere in the world to leap across so much water. But now that bigger suspension bridges are commonplace, the Brooklyn Bridge still holds sway over our imaginations.

title: MONDALE, IN HIS 7TH RACE, IS THE 'PROUD' POLITICIAN
description: At times, this seventh election campaign of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's political career appears to be taking a prematurely heavy toll.

title: NATIONAL KINNEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a provision for loss on the disposition of discontinued operations of $5,050,000.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 24, 1983
description: Markets

title: Stallions Win In Overtime, 23-20
description: Scott Norwood kicked a 46-yard field goal 4 minutes 32 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Birmingham Stallions a 23-20 victory that snapped the Michigan Panthers' six-game winning streak.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ASTREX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. DENIES REPORT HE PREDICTED OUSTER OF SANDINISTS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, denied yesterday that he had predicted that rebels had a good chance of overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government by the end of this year.

title: People
description: * Janet B. Keeler and Howard Stoner elected senior vice presidents of N.W. Ayer Inc.

title: OBIE AWARDS PRESENTED
description: The Circle Repertory Company, its artistic director, Marshall W. Mason, and its leading resident playwright, Lanford Wilson, won an Obie Award last night for ''sustained achievement'' in the theater. The award, which carries a $1,000 cash prize, was made at the 28th annual Village Voice Obie ceremony honoring achievement in the Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theater.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Year-ago results for the quarter and fiscal year have been restated to reflect acquisitions made during the year and accounted for as poolings of interests.

title: 167 PERUVIAN REBELS AND PEASANTS SAID TO DIE IN A WEEK OF FIGHTING
description: The military said today that 167 rebels and peasants and 2 police officers were killed in a week of fighting in central Peru, and President Fernando Belaunde Terry suggested that he might send a special antiguerrilla squad into the battle zone.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BARTLEBY IN MANHATTAN. And Other Essays. By Elizabeth Hardwick. 292 pages. Random House. $15.95.

title: Accelerator Ready to Go
description: Next weekend, if all goes well, protons will begin circulating through what was designed to be the world's most powerful atom smasher. The machine, at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Illinois, is known as the Supersaver or Tevatron.

title: STAR-FILLED BENEFIT HONORS STRASBERG
description: Leading actors from Broadway and Hollywood last night staged a tribute at Lincoln Center to honor the memory of Lee Strasberg, the teacher-director who helped to turn many of them into stars.

title: Chess: Spassky Takes First Place In the Linares Tournament
description: Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, a 46-year-old former world champion, triumphed in the all-grandmaster Linares International Tournament in Spain with a 6 1/2-3 1/2 score.

title: Tickets for Jazz Festival Go on Sale
description: Tickets for the Kool Jazz Festival New York are now on sale. The festival, which will feature more than 1,000 entertainers in 50 concerts, will run from June 24 to July 3.

title: Farewell, Oblivion?
description: Those who sometimes forget what they did the night before under the influence of alcohol may someday be offered, if they want it, a drug to prevent alcoholic memory blackout.

title: PRINCIPLE FOR OUR SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: ROSSINI FESTIVAL PRESENTS 'TANCREDI'
description: THE serious operas of Rossini have long been regarded as the aberrations of a natural clown who wanted to play Hamlet. However, every now and then Rossini fanciers make an effort to revive interest in works such as ''Tancredi,'' which Carnegie Hall presented triumphally in a concert version on Sunday night as part of a Gala Rossini Opera Festival.

title: ZAHN STOPS YANKEES
description: The California Angels punched some timely hits tonight - including two by Rod Carew that pushed his average to .450 - and toppled the Yankees by 3-0.

title: The Party Of the Week; A state dinner of sorts to mark Kissinger's 60th birthday.
description: HENRY KISSINGER may have been as devious a Secretary of State as his many and substantial critics charge, but Manhattan's rich and powerful, never ones to probe too deeply, are beyond the fray. Since he and his wife Nancy took up residence here in 1977, virtually everybody who is anybody has eagerly accepted his frequent dinner invitations, delighted in his company, pursued him socially and feted him to a fare-thee-well.

title: METS TOP GIANTS ON RUN IN 8TH
description: When Jesse Orosco entered the Mets' game with San Francisco in the eighth inning last night, he brought with him a 0.72 earned run average. When Darryl Strawberry stepped to the plate in the other half of the eighth inning, he had a .170 batting average.

title: Keeping Order in a Cab
description: Besides three ''No Smoking'' signs (''Driver Allergic''), taxicab No. 3C17 has two others that read: ''Please do not kiss in the taxi. Por favor no se besen en el taxi. Thank.''
