description: THIS evening at 8, CBS is offering another of those entertainment packages that trail a long list of star names. This one is called ''Movie Blockbusters: The 15 Greatest Hits of All Time.''

title: Japan Lacks Evidence In Soviet Spy Case
description: Japan said today that an official inquiry failed to back charges that a Soviet K.G.B. agent had recruited Japanese politicians and reporters and planted a mole in the Foreign Ministry, giving Moscow regular access to highly sensitive information.

description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a pooling acquisition in December 1982 and for a 100 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

A New Chairman At ACF Industries
description: When Ivan A. Burns became president and chief operating officer of ACF Industries in November 1981, he set certain goals for the company's six divisions. These goals are gradually being met, he said, as the diversified industrial company emerges from the worst of the economic slump.

title: 30 Hurt in Unrest At Clinton Prison
description: Fifteen guards and 15 inmates were slightly injured in a disturbance at the Clinton Correctional Facility here today. Guards fired warning shots to control inmates.

description: b-Net loss.

title: DANCE: MARYLAND THEATER TROUPE
description: TECHNICAL precision and sharpness of attack were prominent among the virtues of the Maryland Dance Theater, which appeared Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. The company is a professional modern-dance group in residence at the University of Maryland in College Park, Md., and it made a striking impression because of its consistently high energy level and fondness for choreographic turbulence.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Tests Offered in Blast That Emitted Toxins
description: People exposed to toxic chemicals from an underground transformer explosion were given an opportunity today to be tested for contamination, even though a doctor warned there was no medical treatment for such exposure.

title: REAGAN AIDE ASKS CONSENSUS ON NURSING HOME INSPECTION
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that it would not relax Federal rules for the inspection of nursing homes until consumer groups and the nursing home industry had reached a ''consensus'' on the issue.

title: N.Y. Tech Opens Against Maine
description: New York Tech was paired with Maine in the Northeast Regional playoffs for the 37th National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I baseball championships today.

title: SLATER STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Includes $925,000 in proceeds from fire insurance received by the Joslyn Stainless Steels division for the quarter and year and a writeoff of $612,000 of Slater's share of idle machinery and equipment at Interprovincial Steel & Pipe Corp for the quarter. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Chinese Loan Funds Sought
description: The World Bank needs a significant increase in its funds to meet any loan requests from China, the bank's president, A.W. Clausen, said at a news conference today.

title: WHEN ENVIRONMENTALISTS OVERSTATE THEIR CASE
description: To the Editor:

description: Three pressing matters, including the installation of a new Management Council executive committee, await the owners of the 28 National Football League teams Wednesday, when they begin two days of meetings in Wesley Chapel, Fla., north of Tampa.

description: AFTER the national introduction of Benson & Hedges 100's Deluxe Ultra Lights by Philip Morris last July, marketing/advertising teams at the client and at Wells, Rich, Greene, one of its agencies, were ready to do it again.

description: A subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation introduced a system that permits a bank to link up with almost any brand of personal computer. The subsidiary, Periphonics, said a voice-response technology is integrated into the system.

SOLAR MICRO INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
TODAY
description: Tens of thousands of New York City residents and out-of-town New York City buffs will flock into lower Manhattan and Brooklyn this morning and onto the banks of the East River tonight to pay joyful homage to the Brooklyn Bridge, which is 100 years old today.

Miss Mercouri in London To Discuss Elgin Marbles
description: Melina Mercouri, the Greek Minister of Culture, brought her campaign for the recovery of the 2,400-year-old Elgin marbles to Britain today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ivan F. Boesky Corp. announced that an investors group it leads had increased its stake in Sierra Research Corp. to 9.5 percent of the stock outstanding through open market purchases in May.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: NOT only does the city never sleep; it never seems to take off its t ie. Indeed, the only person who refused to wear a tie last week was P erry Ellis, who arrived without one at the opening of his first s heet collection for Martex, even though the event had all the t rappings of a momentous occasion. Martex published a leather-bound c atalogue of the new sheets. Guests had to duck huge trays of food, a nd photographers. And Mr. Ellis walked in surrounded by what looked l ike a phalanx of linebackers.

title: Soviet Woman Sets Discus Mark
description: Galina Savinkova of the Soviet Union set a world record in the women's discus throw with a distance of 240 feet 4 inches, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $45,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHORAL MUSIC: EAST EUROPEAN
description: EVERY so often musicians who perform as amateurs can offer us gifts that professionals cannot. The New Amsterdam Singers invested their program of East European choral music at the Abraham Goodman House Sunday night with just such a fresh directness.

title: NATIONAL ENERGY CAPITAL reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: b-The company had no comparable year-ago results. It is in a development stage, having been spun off by Cogenic Energy Systems in September 1982.

description: b-Net income.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is privately owned and does not report share earnings.

title: 3 Plead Guilty In Schlicter Case
description: Three Maryland men charged in the gambling case involving Art Schlichter of the Baltimore Colts today changed their pleas to guilty in a plea bargain arrangement.

title: Nuclear Agency Staff Ends Backing of Plant
description: An aide to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that the agency's staff had withdrawn support for the utility that operates the Three Mile Island nuclear plant because of questions about managerial competence and records.

title: FROM ONE KIND OF ARMY TO ANOTHER
description: Andrew Eiva did not want the Mujahadeen guerrillas fighting the Russians in Afghanistan to suffer the same fate as the friends and relatives of his parents in Lithuania after World War II. To him, this meant only enough American covert support for ''freedom fighters'' to satisfy American political concerns, only enough for the liberation movement to die slowly, and in the end, not even that.

title: Tallmadge L. Boyd, Executive Of the Allied Maintenance Co.
description: Tallmadge L. Boyd, vice president of the Allied Maintenance Corporation and a former airline executive, died Saturday after openheart surgery at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: Khachaturian Tribute Five Years After Death
description: The Armenian composer Aram Khachaturian died five years ago; Sunday afternoon, some of his admirers held a fitting commemorative concert at St. Vartan's Cathedral.

title: Bridge: Solodar and Glubok Teams Gain Grand National Final
description: Teams led by John Solodar and Brian Glubok of New York won the semifinals of the District 24 Grand National Teams event at the New York Hilton Hotel last Sunday. They will meet for the title on June 4.

title: Car Emission Tests
description: A Federal judge today denied a Kean administration request for a delay of the June 1 deadline for resumption of annual automobile emissions tests given at state-run inspection stations.

title: LABOR CHIEF FEARS 'LOST GENERATION'
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that unless the economy quickly doubled its current rate of growth, this country would have a permanent ''lost generation'' of workers who would never find jobs comparable to those they lost in the current recession.

title: AUTO SALES AT BIG 3 OFF 5.4% IN MID-MAY
description: The Big Three domestic car manufacturers reported today that sales for the mid-May period were off 5.4 percent from a strong selling period last year.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U.S. Rejects Lumber Charge
description: The Government has rejected a charge by the United States lumber industry that Canada has given its companies unfair subsidies to sell in the American market, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: CASABLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Richmond Hill Savings Appoints a President
description: Eugene J. Callan, former head of the New York Bank for Savings, is now at the president's desk at the Richmond Hill Savings Bank. Mr. Callan, who is 62, was president and chief executive of the New York Bank for Savings when it ran into trouble and Federal regulators merged it early last year with the Buffalo Savings Bank, now known as Goldome. As is usual in such cases, Mr. Callan was forced to resign.

title: MINERALS ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: TRAFALGAR SEEKS P & O WITH A $452 MILLION BID
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C., the real estate and construction company that owns the Cunard Line, bid more than $450 million today for control of the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company, one of the world's oldest and best-known shipping companies.

title: THE CITY
description: Six people were injured Monday night, one critically, when a Holmes security van mounted a sidewalk, struck them and then crashed into the window of a bagel shop at 228 Prospect Park West in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: STAGE: SOUTH AFRICA TALES
description: IN its atmosphere and its generosity of spirit, ''The Day, the Night,'' a musical collage conceived, directed and composed by Welcome Msomi, is like a postscript to ''Poppie Nongena.'' That feeling is heightened by the fact that both works are presentations of the Music Theater Group/Lenox Arts Center. The brevity and the apparent incompleteness of the piece should not distract us from its musicality and sense of purpose. On its own terms, as more of a cantata than a musical play, ''The Day, the Night'' makes a moving statement.

title: HISPANIC LEADERS URGED TO 'STAND BY' ALVARADO
description: About 450 leaders of the New York Hispanic community, many of them education and civic officials, were urged yesterday to give their support to Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado.

title: Developer Curbed On Tenant Notices
description: New York City yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order to prevent a major developer from continuing to send formal notices to residents at Tudor City demanding to know who lived in their apartments.

title: Teacher in Aliases Cases Announces a Retirement
description: Lawyers for Paul Arthur Crafton, the George Washington University professor who has been charged with using aliases to teach simultaneously at two Pennsylvania colleges, have notified the university that he intends to retire, a spokesman for the university said yesterday.

title: AIDS: A SCENARIO THAT MIGHT SPELL HOPE
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: * Grace Geothermal Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $115 million of subordinated debentures due in 2003, to be underwritten by Merrill Lynch and others. The debentures will be redeemable at the option of the company.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $6,810,000 on the sale of shares of Denison Mines.

title: GRATERS AND SKEWERS
description: AS any cheese lover knows, there is no comparison between freshly grated Parmesan or Romano and the dry, bottled versions. All cheese retains its flavor and texture better when whole, and the only way to get maximum effect when sprinkling it over pasta or other foods is to grate it as you need it.

title: REPORT TELLS OF '46 WARNING ON ATOMIC TESTS
description: The safety chief at the first postwar atomic bomb test warned in 1946 that the health of 42,000 American servicemen could be jeopardized by fallout, according to a report presented at a Congressional hearing today.

title: CHURCHILL KOHLMAN
description: Churchill Kohlman, a composer who wrote Johnnie Ray's 1950's hit, ''Cry,'' has died of a heart attack.

title: FROM A PIZZA BY LAND TO FILLET OF BEEF BY SEA
description: Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine publisher, organized a boating party to get a good view of the fireworks. Robert L. Hess, the president of Brooklyn College, looked out at the borough - and the bridge - of his heart from a 60th-floor soiree in Manhattan. William R. Everdell, a Brooklyn historian, decided to celebrate by sending out for pizza.

title: Taking Food Abroad
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Soviet Imprisons Head Of Solzhenitsyn Fund
description: A Leningrad court today sentenced the local manager of the Solzhenitsyn Fund, an organization that assists political prisoners and their families, to a two-year jail term followed by three years in exile.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ALABAMA LEGISLATURE HEARS JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson preached from the well of the Alabama House of Representatives today, sending up thanks and exhortations from the cradle of the Confederacy.

title: Sorg Receives Bid
description: The Sorg Paper Company said it had received an offer to be acquired but it did not identify its suitor.

title: LEVITZ FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bank Stock For Employees
description: The Republic Bank of Clearwater, Fla., a seven-branch bank in upper Pinellas County, said it would distribute $1 million of stock to its employees over a 10-year period, thus becoming what it said is the first bank in the United States to be wholly owned by its employees, officers and directors.

title: A SAMPLING OF HOT-WEATHER COMFORTS
description: IT may be hard to believe, but the summer season really starts this weekend. Beach and country houses are officially opened, guest lists are being drawn up, the barbecue grill is being cleaned, and parties and entertaining are on many minds.

title: SERVED AS CHAPLAIN AT WEST POINT
description: Rabbi Avraham Soltes, Jewish chaplain at the United States Military Academy in West Point, an author and a leading figure in Jewish cultural affairs, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan after an illness of several months. He was 66 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J., and Stockbridge, Mass.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CAPTAIN CRAB'S TAKE-AWAY reports earnings for qtr to Feb 27.
Levitz Elects Chairman
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation announced yesterday that Robert M. Elliott, formerly president and chief executive officer, had been elected to the position of chairman and chief executive officer, and that George H. Bradley, 50 years old, formerly an executive vice president, would replace Mr. Elliott as president. Mr. Elliott, who is 60, succeeds Ralph Levitz, 70, who retired as chairman last month.

title: T. Bayles Minuse, 78, Is Dead; Ex-Suffolk Water Agency Chief
description: T. Bayles Minuse, a former chairman of the Suffolk County Water Authority and former executive secretary of the Stony Brook (L.I.) Community Fund, died Friday at his home in Stony Brook. He was 78 years old.

title: Plant-Closing Bill Gains in Hartford
description: The State House of Representatives today approved compromise legislation sought by Gov. William A. O'Neill to assist Connecticut workers who lose their jobs in factory closings or relocations.

title: TOYS R US reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
COSTS UP BY 1.1% IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Increases in the costs of shelter, airline fares and gasoline helped push up the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area by 1.1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported yesterday. It was the sharpest rise since last October.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STORING UNPROCESSED PRODUCTS TO HOLD FLAVOR AND AROMA
description: DUSTY-COLORED whole grains and flours, barrels of dried beans with foreign names, deep amber-tinted oils pressed from a variety of nuts and seeds. Foods such as these now fill the shelves of natural food stores, specialty shops and even many supermarkets. Heightened desire for improved nutrition and a predilection for the new-style American cooking have in recent years given foods with minimal or no processing a broader appeal.

title: 2 BOLD HEADS OF SEMINARIES LEAVING POSTS
description: Two seminary presidents, each of whom has left a vivid personal imprint on his institution, are stepping down after writing celebrated but distinctly different chapters in theological education.

title: RANGERS ADDING NEW PLAYERS
description: News conferences to introduce newly signed players are a routine part of sports. But today, when two of the best players in Sweden and an all-America goaltender from Michigan State are presented as the newest Rangers, the announcement will mean something more to Ranger management.

title: CAPITOL'S WEST FRONT: TO PRESERVE OR EXTEND?
description: It is not really true that extending the West Front of the United States Capitol would be an architectural travesty, as historic preservationists have contended in what is clearly this city's longest-running battle of esthetics. The Capitol has been pushed and pulled and altered and expanded for most of its life, and there is not necessarily any reason, given all of the changes it has been subjected to for nearly two centuries, why it should be frozen in time now.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to April 30.
Girl, 15, Is Indicted For Arson-Murder
description: A 15-year-old girl accused of setting fire to her parents' home because her mother ordered her to go to school was indicted yesterday for arson and the murder of a 16-month-old girl who died in the fire.

title: JUSTICES OVERTURN JAILING OF MAN WHO WAS TOO POOR TO PAY A FINE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that it is unconstitutional for a state to send a convicted defendant to jail simply because he is too poor to pay a fine.

title: Workers' Purchase Of Dan River Gains
description: Stockholders of Dan River Inc. voted today to sell the textile company to its employees and management rather than risk takeover by Carl Icahn, a New York investor.

title: AT POINT-TO-POINT RACES, ELEGANT PICNIC DISHES
description: RMINDA du PONT served caviar, tenderloin of beef salad and marinated mushrooms with Dom Perignon from the trunk of a brown Rolls-Royce. Blair Both had a cold three-layered mousse of tomatoes, chicken and sorrel along with cream of asparagus soup. She kept them cool in the shade of a 1934 Buick - complete with rumble seat - that had belonged to Louise du Pont Crowninshield. Susan Fraley and several friends wore straw garden-party hats and served their cooperative tailgate picnic on a table covered with a Madeira cutwork cloth.

title: Fasting Seoul Dissident Is Removed to Hospital
description: The opposition leader Kim Young-sam, who began a hunger strike a week ago demanding a democratic form of government in South Korea, was forcibly removed from his home today and taken to a hospital.

title: LIGHT TO READ BY
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Chinaglia Interested In Bid to Buy Lazio
description: Giorgio Chinaglia said yesterday that five Italian-American businessmen from New Jersey had asked him to help them in an attempt to acquire Lazio, the Rome-based soccer team that Chinaglia left in 1976 to join the Cosmos.

title: Israeli Cabinet Survives Vote
description: The Government defeated a Parliamentary motion of no confidence today, 59 to 53 with one abstention. The motion was presented after it was announced that inflation in April was 13.3 percent, the highest one-month rate in Israel's history. The Government coalition has a majority in Parliament.

title: Marietta Plans To Sell Shares
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation disclosed yesterday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would sell in a secondary offering up to 1.9 million shares of common stock held in its Treasury and use the money raised to acquire a similar number of shares held by the Allied Corporation. The transaction would reduce Allied's stake in Martin Marietta to about 20 percent.

title: Excerpts from opinions, page A22.
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 1, that racially discriminatory private schools are ineligible for Federal tax exemptions.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $558,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: Morton Coach of Gold
description: Calling it an ''excellent opportunity,'' Craig Morton, the former Denver Bronco quarterback, accepted yesterday the job of coaching the Denver Gold of the United States Football League.

title: AN OLD BRIDGE'S BIRTHDAY IS A HOMETOWN CARNIVAL
description: With an unabashed outpouring of affection, New York celebrated the 100th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday. It had been billed as a great day in the history of the city, and that is exactly what it turned out to be. In the morning, thousands of pedestrians, horse-drawn carriages and marching bands - filling the air with martial music - paraded across the stately bridge under summerlike skies.

title: Strauss and Berlioz At St. John Cathedral
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine has been offering a series known as ''Music for a Great Space,'' and on Sunday afternoon close to 150 choristers, instrumentalists and vocal soloists gathered to sing Richard Strauss's ''Deutsche Motette'' and Berlioz's Te Deum.

title: Stoltz Leads Dodge Golf
description: John Stoltz, assistant pro at the host Rockaway River Country Club, shot a five-under-par 67 today to take the first-round lead in the 20th annual Dodge Open.

title: Writer Loses a Round In Lawsuit Over 'E.T.'
description: A writer who alleges that ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial'' was plagiarized from a play she wrote has lost the first round in a $750-million lawsuit.

title: House Passes Bill to Extend Counseling Plan for Veterans
description: The House voted Monday to extend through September 1987 the Government program that provides psychological counseling to Vietnam veterans at 136 centers nationwide.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss.

title: To Sleep, Perchance ...
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government has a fundamental, overriding interest in eradicating racial discrimination in education, discrimination that prevailed with official approval for the first 165 years of this nation's history.'' - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. (A22:6.)

title: Dr. Edward Tolstoi, 86, A Specialist in Diabetes
description: Dr. Edward Tolstoi, a specialist in diabetes and an associate professor at Cornell Medical College, died Sunday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Afghan Blunder Is Attributed To Radio Moscow Announcer
description: A spokesman for Radio Moscow said today that a ''personal mistake'' by an announcer, Vladimir Danchev, led to three newscasts Monday on Radio Moscow's English-language service in which Soviet troops in Afghanistan were described as invaders and occupants threatening the country's security.

title: Doubleday Tale Debunked Again
description: To most people interested in the origins of baseball, the idea that Abner Doubleday invented the sport in Cooperstown, N.Y., in 1839 is generally regarded as legend or myth. Baseball scholars have often challenged the Doubleday theory and generally advanced the idea that the creator of the game was Alexander Cartwright whose diagram of the diamond and original rules were created in 1845 and now rest in the National Baseball Museum in Cooperstown.

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
MUSIC: INXS, 6 FROM SYDNEY
description: THE so-called Australian invasion of the American music scene has produced pop that places more of a premium on aural slickness than on lyrical content. INXS, the Sydney-based sextet that made its local debut at the Ritz on Saturday, is no exception.

title: SPRIGHTLY WINES FOR SUMMER FARE
description: NE day in the future some chronicler of our epoch will pin down the exact day when white wine overtook martinis at some of the better bars and hotels. A pivotal date if there ever was one, it marks the point in time when white wine moved up from its picnic-on-the-lawn image to a full-fledged succorer of shattered egos, bruised ids and thwarted ambitions. Most white-wine drinkers, whether at the ''21'' Club or in their own backyards, think of it as just that: white wine. Occasionally, someone will tell the waiter, ''I'd like a glass of chablis,'' but for the most part, no one other than the experienced enthusiast ever differentiates among the hundreds of different white wines on the market. It is ordered like a martini, with only an occasional inquiry as to exactly what is in the glass. But there is a great deal going on in the white-wine field, and it helps to know what's happening. To begin with, there is plenty of it around, thanks mostly to the Italians. What's more, a lot of it is pretty good. Not great, but good. About a decade ago, an unsung genius in the Italian wine business decided that it was time to find out what people wanted - as opposed to the time-honored French way: ''This is what we do; take it or leave it.'' The Italians threw out centuries of tradition - they had always made heavy, overoxidized white wines - and came up with new, fresh, lively wines that anyone could drink.

title: New Voting Map In Westchester
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators approved new district lines Monday night to reflect a population shift from south to north reflected in the 1980 Census. It was the second such effort for the Republican-controlled board, whose 1981 proposal was vetoed by the Democratic County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, who is now the Lieutenant Governor.

title: Dismissed Coach Sues
description: Richard Bell, who was dismissed as South Carolina's football coach last December after working one year of a four-year contract, has filed suit against the university seeking payment of the remaining $150,000 due under the contract as well as other damages. In the suit, filed May 13 in United States District Court in Columbia, Bell charged that the school's athletic director, Bob Marcum, who was also named as a defendant, had devised a scheme to force Bell into breaking his contract by ordering Bell to drop four assistant coaches.

title: State Treasuries Found at Low
description: Despite signs that a national economic recovery is gaining momentum, state treasuries will end this fiscal year at a low, the National Governors Association said Monday.

title: Panel Votes Debt Ceiling Rise
description: The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to increase the national debt by nearly $99 billion, enough to let the Government pay its bills through the end of September.

title: PANTRY PRIDE SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for 12 wks to May 7.
description: b-After income of $153,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $2.6 million. c-After loss of $3.1 million from discontinued operations and tax credit of $2.3 million. d-After income of $153,000 from discontinued operations, tax credit of $5.4 million and a gain of $1.3 million from debt reduction. e-After loss of $3.9 million from discontinued operations, tax credit of $5.9 million and gain of $2 million from debt reduction.

title: Irish Police End Search For Missing Racehorse
description: The police have called off their search for the racehorse Shergar, concluding that the masked gunmen who abducted the stallion in February killed it when they did not receive a ransom.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Greenmarket Reopening
description: The 1983 Greenmarket season officially opens this Saturday at Union Square. While cold weather will probably delay some fruit and vegetables at the markets, June shoppers can expect to find strawberries, sugar snap peas, asparagus, spinach, cherries, summer squash and rhubarb, plus a wonderful variety of herbs. Fresh eggs as well as smoked meats, fish, cheese, bread and pastry and flowers will also be offered.

title: G.M. PATENT PENALTY IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a patent infringement award against the General Motors Corporation, ruling unanimously that the lower courts correctly ordered the automobile maker to pay $11 million in ''prejudgment interest'' to a company whose patent it infringed during the 1950's.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HEALTH CHIEF CALLS AIDS BATTLE 'NO. 1 PRIORITY'
description: The Government's top health official said today that the investigation of acquired immune deficiency syndrome had become ''the No. 1 priority'' of the United States Public Health Service.

title: Choices Asked On Fed Chief
description: The Reagan Administration has been asking the chief executive officers of the nation's largest banks to recommend individuals who might succeed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Volcker's term as chairman expires in August.

title: Tax-Exempt Hate, Undone
description: President Reagan and the lawyers he has put in charge of protecting civil rights should stand ashamed. Racial hatred is not tax-exempt, the Supreme Court ruled yesterday by a lopsided vote. Only this Administration - and one dissenting justice - ever doubted it.

title: THE MILLSTONE OF MRS. THATCHER'S GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TASTING NOUVELLE CUISINE, CHICAGO STYLE
description: ANYONE interested in an object lesson in what nouvelle cuisine should and should not be can get one by visiting two of Chicago's more fashionable and popular restaurants, Le Perroquet and Ambria, as I did two weeks ago.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ASHLAND HINTS AT 1981 OUSTER
description: Ashland Oil Inc., in an internal report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, indicated that Orin Atkins might have retired under pressure as chairman in September 1981 because of questions raised within the company about payments to officials of Oman to secure crude oil supplies.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CUBA DISPUTES REAGAN ON DRUGS
description: Cuba's official Communist Party newspaper, Granma, harshly criticized President Reagan today and denied charges he made last week that there was ''strong evidence'' of Cuban involvement in the illicit drug trade that flows through Miami.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $13,576,000 from the sale of shares of Denison Mines.

title: Soup Kitchen Clients Increase
description: The number of people served at soup kitchens and similar emergency food programs in the United States grew dramatically last year, the Center of Budget and Policy Priorities reported today.

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: SIMPLIFIED VOIR DIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A READER recently asked how to prepare truite au bleu, or blue trout, of a sort he had had in Switzerland. The trout was curled and served with the skin on and a hollandaise sauce on the side.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in some editions of The Living Section on April 27, accompanying an article on bottled water, specified an incorrect amount of sodium for Artesia Pure Sparkling Texas Mineral Water. It contains two milligrams in eight ounces.

title: Turner Posts A Profit Again
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. today reported earnings of $2 million, or 10 cents a share, for the first quarter, its third straight quarterly profit.

title: BISHOPS IN PLEA AGAINST SMUT
description: Nearly 100 Roman Catholic bishops have written to President Reagan in the last month to ask that a Federal coordinator be named to monitor enforcement of obscenity laws, according to officials of Morality in Media, an interfaith organization concerned with pornography.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 28.

title: FILM: LUCAS RETURNS WITH 'THE JEDI'
description: WILL Han Solo ever fly again or is he forever doomed to remain a wall decoration in the pleasure palace of Jabba the Hutt? Does Princess Leia do her own hair or does she pay someone to make it look that way? Who, or perhaps what, is Salacious Crumb? When will Luke Skywalker become a true Jedi knight? Where does Yoda do his shopping? Will Darth Vader sacrifice his only begotten son so that evil might triumph? And, speaking of Vader, when he takes off his mask, what is underneath? James Earl Jones? David Prowse? A cantaloupe?

title: A FAST-LANE U.A.W.
description: When Owen Bieber took over from Douglas A. Fraser as president of the United Auto Workers last week, one of the nation's most prestigious unions officially entered a new era. Not only is Mr. Bieber the first U.A.W. president in the union's history with no direct link to the legendary Walter Reuther, but Mr. Bieber has come into office as the union faces an entirely new set of conditions and challenges.

title: Insider Case Guilty Plea
description: John Nugent, a former Washington lobbyist, pleaded guilty today to criminal charges that he illegally passed on ''insider information'' about the 1981 merger of the Santa Fe International Corporation and the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation. But he continues to state that he did not know his actions were illegal. The guilty plea was part of an agreement Mr. Nugent made with the Justice Department to cooperate in the investigation.

title: Fire at the Meadowlands
description: More than 300 people were evacuated from the Meadowlands Race Track tonight and the 10-race card was canceled when a fire was discovered in a storage closet on the clubhouse level, officials said. No injuries were reported.

title: DeBartolos' Lawyer Suggests Accord; Discussions Are Rejected
description: A possible conflict of interests involving Edward DeBartolo Jr. and his father, who own franchises in rival football leagues, could be eliminated if certain rules were agreed upon by the commissioners of the two leagues, the lawyer for the DeBartolos said today.

title: Devils Look Abroad
description: Vladislav Horsky, a Czechoslavak hockey authority, recently spent five months in the United States conducting clinics and coaching seminars for the Amateur Hockey Association. The New Jersey Devils, who finished last season with the third-worst record in the National Hockey League, think he can help them, too.

title: Turkish Court Sentences 35 Kurds to Death
description: A military court in southeast Turkey ruled today on 572 people accused of trying to topple the Government to establish a separate Kurdish state, sentencing 35 of them to death.

title: REYNOLDS PLANNING A 25-CIGARETTE PACK
description: In a departure from traditional cigarette packaging in the United States, R.J. Reynolds Industries introduced a new cigarette yesterday and said it would be sold in packs of 25 instead of the usual 20.

title: Albany Bill Would Aid Purchasers of New Cars
description: Negotiators have reached agreement on a bill that would increase the protection of buyers of new cars in the state against the purchase of defective vehicles.

title: California Bond Has 9% Top Yield
description: The largest competitive municipal bond issue bid yesterday was won by the Bank of America. The issue, made up of various purpose general obligation bonds, will raise $155 million for the State of California.

title: GUARDIAN DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $167,340 for the latest first quarter and $163,750 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Gasoline Up 9 in 8 Weeks
description: Gasoline prices have climbed 9 cents a gallon in the last eight weeks, spurred on by the new Federal gasoline tax, but they remain 13 cents below the peak reached two years ago, the American Automobile Association reported today.

title: CITIBANK'S EXPERT ON LATIN CRISES
description: Like many executives, William R. Rhodes likes to take a run around the reservoir in Central Park when time permits. But since last summer, Mr. Rhodes has not had much free time. And the word ''workout'' has taken on an entirely different meaning.

title: REAGAN BACKS BETTER EMERGENCY LINKS WITH SOVIET
description: President Reagan, saying he was seeking to reduce the possibility of ''unintended war,'' endorsed a series of proposals today for improving emergency communications with the Soviet Union, including direct transmissions between the nations' military generals.

title: Clausen to See China Officials
description: A.W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, arrived today in Peking for talks that could lead to an increase in lending to China, if the bank can raise the money.

title: FINE JAPANESE ART OF MAKING FAKE FOOD
description: IN Japan many restaurants put fake food in their windows, where it serves as a sort of visual menu. Every time Yoshiko Ebihara, a SoHo gallery owner, went to Tokyo, she found herself buying examples of the incredibly realistic fakes.

title: MARCHI WARNS S.I. ON EFFECTS OF CHANGE IN ESTIMATE BOARD
description: State Senator John J. Marchi, a Republican from Staten Island, suggested today that the people of his borough should reconsider their relationship with the City of New York if legal challenges succeed in overturning the structure of the Board of Estimate.

title: E.F. Hutton Names Director of Buyouts
description: The business of leveraged buyouts is apparently growing, and Wall Street is gearing up to get its share. The E.F. Hutton Group yesterday named Robert P. Jensen, former chairman and president of GK Technologies, as chairman and chief executive of a new unit, to be called E.F. Hutton LBO Inc. The move follows the establishment of a similar unit last week at Oppenheimer & Company.

title: GREENWOOD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Hewlett-Packard Has 3 New Models
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced three new models of HP 3000, its principal business computer line, which provide performance improvements.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: DOUBLE ASTERISKS AND PARKING TICKETS
description: Three women on the State Department's official list of diplomats have double asterisks next to their names, which means, among other things, that they have to pay their parking tickets.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's problems with Congress over Central America policy have worsened in recent weeks because of confusion over the Government's justification for supporting insurgents in Nicaragua.

title: Jersey County's Bonds To Yield 6.5% to 9.75%
description: One of the largest tax-free issues scheduled for this week was priced yesterday by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The $201 million Ocean County Utilities Authority waste water revenue bond, series 1983, was priced with yields ranging from 6.5 percent in 1986 to 9.75 percent in 2014.

title: TUITION TAX CREDIT BACKED BY PANEL
description: With strong backing from President Reagan, the Senate Finance Committee today approved legislation that would permit parents of students in private elementary and secondary schools to deduct a portion of the tuition costs from their Federal income taxes.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Conoco Inc. has promoted Samuel Schwartz to executive vice president-administrative.

title: FLEXIBILITY ON INTEREST TAX ISSUE
description: The Senate Finance Committee is considering a plan to repeal the withholding of taxes from interest and dividend payments rather than postponing it, as the Senate originally voted to do.

title: JUMP IS TIED TO GASOLINE TAX RISE
description: Higher prices for gasoline, housing and food helped raise the Consumer Price Index six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase since last July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Eurobonds Rise Slightly
description: Dollar Eurobond prices rose slightly today in quiet trading ahead of the Association of International Bond Dealers meeting, which starts Wednesday. Dealers said that trading was likely to remain light until after the bond dealers' meeting, which ends Friday, and the Monday bank holiday in Britain. The new $75 million I.C.I. 8 7/8 percent 1991 issue with equity warrants was initially priced at 99 1/2 to 100 1/4.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Aid for Indonesia
description: The World Bank has suggested that Indonesia needs to borrow $15 billion over the next three years to help cover a drop in overseas earnings caused by the international recession and falling oil income, the bank said. In a report circulated today to Western countries that provide aid to Jakarta, the bank said Indonesia must borrow to help reduce a deficit in its current account while maintaining domestic employment.

title: Calder Is Closed In Drug Protest
description: Calder Race Course was closed indefinitely today because trainers protesting a new ban on medication refused to enter their horses.

title: PROTESTERS AND POLICE SKIRMISH IN PARIS
description: New demonstrations by about 12,000 students against the Socialist Government's university bill filled the streets of the Left Bank today and then degenerated into skirmishes between the police and several hundred roving street fighters.

title: Harvey Gaylord, Ex-President Of Bell Aerospace, Dies at 78
description: Harvey Gaylord, who had been president of the Bell Aerospace Corporation and an executive vice president of Textron Inc., died Friday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospitals in New London, Conn. He was a resident of Niantic, Conn., and was 78 years old.

title: REAGAN AND THE FUTURE
description: In trying to decide whether he should seek a second four-year term in the White House, President Reagan faces a situation that did not exist in the campaign of 1980.

title: Phibro-Salomon
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc. declared a 2-for-1 stock split and increased the quarterly cash dividend on the presplit shares to 27 cents, from 23 1/2 cents. The dividend will be 13 1/2 cents a share after the split. Both the dividend and the split shares will be distributed June 30 to shareholders of record on June 20.

title: MUTINY DISMISSED BY ARAFAT AS A BIT OF QADDAFI'S MISCHIEF
description: Yasir Arafat sat smiling tonight under a photograph of himself surrounded by equally jovial commanders of the Yarmouk brigade.

title: DAMAGE IN MOZAMBIQUE RAID LOOKS SURPRISINGLY LIGHT
description: In both scope and impact, South Africa's reprisal raid here Monday does not seem to equal the act it purported to avenge.

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINION AND DISSENT ON TAX STATUS OF SCHOOLS
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that racially discriminatory private schools are not entitled to tax-exempt status. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger delivered the opinion of the Court. From the Opinion By Chief Justice Burger

title: SIGMA MINES (QUEBEC) LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a $1,799,000 gain on sale of Denison Mines shares.

title: THEATER: BLACK UNIT OF LONDON
description: AS part of the Britain Salutes New York Festival, the Black Theater Cooperative of London has brought over Charlie Hanson's original production of Mustapha Matura's ''Welcome Home Jacko'' for a limited engagement through this weekend at the Quaigh Theater. While the British cast gives the work a needed authenticity, the play is a minor example of the author's writing.

title: Light to Read By
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FOR SCHOOL STAR, RUNNING IS HER LIFE
description: For all her playfulness and humor, Angela Williams, regarded as one of the finest female high school sprinters in America, has the razor-sharp instincts of a world-class competitor.

title: JOAN RIVERS SOUGHT FOR 'TONIGHT' ROLE
description: In an effort to improve the ratings on ''The Tonight Show,'' NBC is talking to Joan Rivers, the comedian, about becoming the program's permanent ''guest host'' on Monday nights and during Johnny Carson's vacations.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Zamir Chorale Offers Memorial of a Horror
description: Theodor Adorno's oft-quoted comment about the barbarities of writing poetry after Auschwitz might be applied to music as well. How can the experiences of the Jews during World War II ever be adequately treated in sound?

title: Art All Over Town
description: Suddenly, Wilson Brandao is seeing copies of his painting, ''Hispanic Woman,'' all over Spanish-speaking New York. A reproduction of the 33-year-old Panamanian-born artist's 45-inch by 69-inch work is on the cover of the new Paginas Amarillas, the New York Telephone's Yellow Pages for the Hispanic community.

title: Missing in Brooklyn
description: Amid the swirl of campaigns for upcoming student government elections, copies of The Kingsman at Brooklyn College vanished last week from distribution points on campus. The issue included a story charging incumbent officers with padding expenses.

title: Homeless Upheld On Bad Housing
description: Families who live in city-run emergency shelters cannot be evicted when they refuse to move into substandard apartments offered by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: D'AMBOISE SHOW A BENEFIT FOR DANCE
description: Mary Tyler Moore played Charlemagne, smartly clad in New York City Police Department blues, with real uniformed police officers as her valiant knights. Judy Collins sang a song by Jacques Brel, Lorin Hollander played the piano and Martin Charnin donated two original songs and served as a narrator.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
NASH CONVICTED OF KILLING 4 IN PARKING LOT ON PIER
description: Donald Nash, whom the prosecution described as a hired assassin, was convicted yesterday of murdering a Federal witness and three CBS employees in a Hudson River parking lot last year.

title: Wrong Missile, Wrong Chip
description: The same Congress that has been piously urging a nuclear weapons freeze now seems ready to vote for the MX, a powerful new missile that promises to accelerate the arms race. Why?

title: KENTUCKIANS VOTE IN PRIMARY RACES FOR GOVERNOR
description: State Senator Jim Bunning, a former major league pitcher, won the Republican gubernatorial nomination tonight, and it appeared that he would face either Lieut. Gov. Martha Layne Collins or Mayor Harvey Sloane of Louisville in the November general election.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida System Inc., a Miami-based airline, said it had recalled 40 flight attendents, effective June 1, to meet increased summer demand.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 28.
Comings and Goings
description: Don Curry, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, has broken his hand while training in Rome, forcing the indefinite postponement of his title defense against Thomas Stafford that had been scheduled for Monte Carlo on June 11.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE ON DEPLOYMENT PLAN FOR MX MISSILE
description: Following is the 239-to-186 roll-call vote by which the House agreed today to spend $625 million for development and testing of the MX missile. A yes vote is for development of the missile. Voting yes were 91 Democrats and 148 Republicans. Voting no were 168 Democrats and 18 Republicans. An xxx denotes members not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes.

title: Brae Plans Sale
description: Brae Corporation of San Francisco said it had agreed to sell for about $120 million a portfolio of 7,100 leased signs of its 85 percent owned American Sign and Indicator unit.

title: Former U.S. Aide Joins Unit of Paine Webber
description: Roger W. Mehle, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, has returned to Wall Street. Mr. Mehle, 41, has joined Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, the investment banking unit of Paine Webber Inc., as executive vice president and managing director.

title: House roll-call, page A18.
description: The House of Representatives today approved President Reagan's plan to base 100 MX missiles in existing shelters under the plains of Wyoming and Nebraska. The vote, a major victory for the President, was 239 to 186.

title: EUROPEANS' IMPERILING EUROPE
description: Many of the Western Europeans who are protesting the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's plan to install American intermediate-range nuclear missiles in their countries later this year have a larger aim than simply preventing the deployment of 572 Pershing 2 and ground-launched cruise missiles. They see blocking these weapons as a first step toward removal of the thousands of other nuclear weapons that are now in place in Europe and, ultimately, to the dissolution of both great military blocs, NATO and the Warsaw Pact. This ultimate goal can be partly achieved. It would be the most important change in international politics since the end of World War II. But it would likely have consequences that are the opposite of what the antinuclear-weapons movements are seeking. The wish to escape from the control of the two superpowers and regain the freedom of maneuver in foreign policy that Europe lost in 1945 is understandable. The aspiration to independence is universal. No country will feel wholly comfortable while its fate rests in the hands of others. Some countries have no choice in the matter. In the European case, however, the wish can be partly fulfilled. The Soviet bloc is not about to dissolve, not as long as the Communist Party of the Soviet Union has the power to prevent its dissolution - power that it islikely to have for a very long time. The Western alliance, however, is voluntary. It is not immune to change, including the sort of change sometimes advocated by the European antinuclear-weapons movements.

title: AT AN ITALIAN FEAST, PARALLEL WINES
description: ''This is not meant as a comparison,'' explained Dr. Lucio Caputo, former director of the Italian Trade Commission, who helped organize a six-course black-tie dinner at the Rainbow Room on Monday at which Italian and California wines were poured side by side.

title: STAGE: VOODOO RITUALS
description: NOMINALLY, this is an enlightened age, but to many people the word ''voodoo'' still conjures lurid Hollywood visions of pounding drums and things that go bump in the night. More properly, voodoo is a colloquial modification of vodun, the name given by the Fon people of Dahomey to an African religion that has put down deep roots in Haiti and elsewhere in the Caribbean since the years of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.

title: DEMOCRATS WIN 2 SPECIAL RACES FOR LEGISLATURE
description: Two Democratic district leaders, one in Queens and the other in the Bronx, won easy victories yesterday in special elections to fill vacant seats in the State Assembly.

title: Olympic Security Aide Hired
description: Col. Charles Beckwith of the Army, retired, has been hired as a special Defense Department consultant to study security for the 1984 Olympic games in Los Angeles, a White House spokesman said today. Colonel Beckwith, one of the most decorated soldiers in the Vietnam War, led an unsuccessful mission to rescue American hostages in Iran in 1980.

title: Murky Outlook For City's Budget
description: The city's budgetary horizon is not as unclouded as many would like to believe, according to Deputy Mayor Nathan Leventhal. He told an audience of Upper East Side residents Monday night that a number of issues had yet to be resolved.

title: Northwest, Sedco Extend Pogo Offer
description: Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc., the two companies seeking to acquire control of Pogo Producing Inc., the Houston-based energy company, said they had extended their tender offer to buy Pogo shares at $25 through midnight next Tuesday.

title: DEERE REPORTS DEFICIT; LITTON OFF 24%
description: Deere & Company, hard hit by the worldwide recession and the severely depressed demand for farm and industrial equipment, yesterday reported a loss of $11.3 million in the second fiscal quarter of 1983, contrasted to earnings of $3 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: CUT IN CARS ANGERS L.I.R.R. SMOKERS
description: John Parenti, a usually well-mannered, middle-aged accountant, is so angry about a reduction of smoking cars on the Long Island Rail Road that he has taken to acting ornery.

title: STATE WILL BUY ERIE JAIL AND CONVERT IT TO PRISON
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that the state would buy the 700-bed Erie County Jail and turn it into a maximumsecurity prison as part of his effort to relieve overcrowding in the state prison system.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTO ALBUM

title: AND HIS MOUTH SO PRIM
description: It has been a sweet May for T.S. Eliot. Last week he was nominated for two Tony Awards, the prizes given for excellence in the Broadway theater.

title: American Express
description: The American Express Company said it had agreed to buy the Ayco Corporation, a personal financial counseling firm based in Albany. Ayco, which is privately owned, has 8 regional offices across the country, employs 200 and counsels executives in 100 of the largest industrial companies. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Students Gain Better Grasp of the Law
description: Lisa Haynes came away from the experience with an understanding that ''there's more to being a lawyer than the Perry Mason type that appears on the TV screen.''

title: LETTER-WRITING DRIVE BACKS CLEMENCY BID BY MARGIOTTA
description: Nassau County Republicans are mounting a letter-writing campaign to gain clemency from President Reagan for Joseph M. Margiotta, who is scheduled to begin a two-year prison sentence next Wednesday.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for year to April 30.
HIGH LAND-TAX PLAN DOING WHAT IT SHOULD
description: To the Editor:

title: DEB SHOPS, THE reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
WEDNESDAY, MAY 25, 1983
description: The Economy

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Advertising; Another Salvo from Seven-Up
description: THE Seven-Up Company, which not only increased its market share, but also started an industry trend with its ''no caffeine'' advertising campaign last year, will next add to consumer and competitor concern with a ''no artificial colors'' and ''no artificial flavors'' campaign.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LAST LION. WINSTON SPENCER CHURCHILL. Visions of Glory. 1874- 1932. By William Manchester. 973 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $25.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: BOB JONES, IN SERMON, ASSAILS SUPREME COURT
description: The Rev. Bob Jones 3d chose as his sermon topic today the United States Supreme Court. The Court, in an 8-to-1 decision, upheld the Government's right to deny tax-exempt status to Bob Jones University because of its racially discriminatory policies. Mr. Jones, president of the Greenville, S.C., university, learned of the decision shortly before addressing students at their mandatory daily chapel meeting.

title: Head of D.D.B. Sees Turnaround This Year
description: At the annual meeting yesterday of Doyle Dane Bernbach International, Neil R. Austrian, president and chief executive, said that the worldwide company should stage an impressive turnaround in 1983.

title: A CONCERTO TO THE BEAT OF THE CITY
description: It was the Brooklyn Bridge in music. Beneath the Roeblings' stone towers, an orchestra played into the night, offering a vigorous serenade to the skyscrapers of Manhattan and the town houses of Brooklyn Heights. The orchestra was the Brooklyn Philharmonic; Paul Dunkel was conducting, and the composer, Tobias Picker, was at the piano.

title: Real Estate; Store Rent Control Is Debated
description: DO the sharp rent increases for stores, which have dismayed many owners of small businesses in New York City in the last two years, threaten to deprive some residential neighborhoods of commercial and retail services? And does that threat warrant the imposition of a rent-regulatory system?

title: Decision Delayed
description: Bill Fusco, the athletic director at the University of San Francisco, said there would be no decision on whether the school will resume varsity basketball competition until after a trustees meeting June 10. Citing the need to preserve its academic integrity, the university dropped the program last July after a series of embarrassing incidents: accusations that some players had been paid for summer work they did not perform, and the assault by a former player, Quintin Dailey, now with the Chicago Bulls, on a student nurse. A university task force has recommended that basketball be reinstated for the 1984-85 season.

title:
Economic Scene;
Bank/Broker Deregulation
description: DEREGULATION is rapidly transforming the face of the American financial system. Lines of separation between banking, insurance and the securities business - some traditional, some enacted in the Depression - have become almost indistinguishable.

title: Amoco Oil Accord
description: Amoco Oil Co. , a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said it had agreed in principle to sell its fertilizer and pesticide division to the Scoular Company, a closely held operator of about 60 grain and fertilizer facilities owned mostly by employee managers.

title: Cuomo Keeps Up Fight For Medicaid Takeover
description: Governor Cuomo, who said last week that his plan for a long-term takeover of most local Medicaid costs was dead because of opposition in the State Senate, said today he would continue to fight for the Medicaid takeover.

title: Review: 'The Last Lion. Winston Spencer Churchill'
description: Given his heroic posture and his heightened rhetoric, Winston Churchill seems, 18 years after his death, a kind of mythic figure. His life is so huge, so resonant with achievements, failures and contradictions, that the prospective biographer is faced, from the very start, with a host of daunting problems.

title: U.S. Promises Navajos Help In Conserving Soil and Water
description: The Government agreed Monday to help the Navajo Indians with soil and water conservation programs on some reservation land.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: CONSTIPATION is probably the most worried about but least talked about common health problem. For the overwhelming majority of sufferers it is really not a health problem at all, at least not until they succumb to some of its more hazardous treatments.

title: Bolivia Orders Arrest Of Former President
description: Bolivia's civilian Government ordered the arrest today of former President Luis Garcia Meza and 29 members of his military regime on charges of ''corruption and economic crimes.''

title: CONCERT: TAFELMUSIK GROUP
description: TAFELMUSIK, the ensemble-in-residence at Greenwich Village's Provincetown Playhouse, played music from the Baroque and the 20th century Monday night. Jean Kopperud, clarinet, and Evan Paris, violin, were also there, and the music ranged from Quantz, Telemann and Vivaldi in the 18th century, to Manuel de Falla's Concerto for Harpsichord and Five Instruments written a generation ago, to David Olan's new ''Fantasy'' - a piece commissioned by Tafelmusik.

title: SQUARE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE ROEBLINGS ENJOY A FAMILY REUNION
description: It seemed only fitting that the descendants of the man who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, John A. Roebling, had the best seats in the house, and possibly the best food in town last night, while they watched the fireworks that capped the daylong celebration of the bridge's 100th birthday. Some of those descendants had come more than 5,000 miles for the party under the bridge.

title: Health Insurance for Jobless Is Approved by House Panel
description: Legislation to set up a Federal-state health insurance program for the unemployed was approved today by the House Energy and Commerce Committee and sent to the House.

title: Badische Furnishings Choses Cadwell Davis
description: Cadwell Davis Partners/Advertising, which is part of Compton Communications, has been tapped to do advertising for the Home Furnishing Group of the Badische Corporation of Williamsburg, Va.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: NEWWAVE rock has finally achieved the commercial breakthrough that its most ardent supporters have been anticipating since the mid-1970's, but it hasn't followed the scenario that those original supporters had in mind.

title: SUMMIT FOCUS PUT ON GROWTH
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that planning for economic growth would be the first priority at the economic summit conference this weekend at Williamsburg, Va.

title: BLUES SUE N.H.L. IN ANTITRUST ACTION
description: The Ralston Purina Company filed a Federal antitrust suit today against the National Hockey League, which last week rejected the company's effort to sell the St. Louis Blues to a group of Canadian investors who wanted to move the team to Saskatchewan.

title: Elusive Match
description: When the three-hour television special honoring Bob Hope's 80th birthday was in the planning stages many months ago, it was decided that because he had been a boxer (under the name Packy East) as a youngster in Cleveland, a segment on boxing should be included.

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: YANKS LOSE IN 10TH AFTER GAMBLE ERROR
description: The Yankees lost, 7-6, in the 10th inning to the California Angels tonight when Oscar Gamble, in a rare start in right field, dropped a fly ball for an error that allowed the tying run to score, then reached but couldn't hold the game-winning hit.

title: Quake at Paso Robles, Calif.
description: A moderate earthquake awakened rural San Luis Obispo County residents early today but caused no damage or injuries, the authorities said.

title: CITY OR BOROUGH, DODGERS OR NO DODGERS, BROOKLYN IS BROOKLYN
description: In front of a house on Lafayette Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant stands a magnolia tree as big as a brownstone, its broad leaves as glossy as if each had been individually oiled. It is a magnolia grandiflora, and it usually grows nowhere north of the Mason-Dixon line.

title: Military Analysis
description: Israeli military sources say their Defense Forces high command is increasingly concerned over the recent reinforcement of the Syrian Army and

title: THEATER: 'TANGO' BY FALSO MOVIMENTO
description: PERFORMERS, posed like statuary before a slide projection of Roman pillars, suddenly jerk into motion and become disco dancers. A man tangos with a vacuum cleaner that resembles a robot out of ''Star Wars.'' Cardboard cutouts of cars float from the sky into a David Hockney swimming pool.

title: S. PAUL BOOCHEVER
description: S. Paul Boochever, chairman of the board of Jeanne Bouchever Inc. of Essex, Conn., manufacturers of women's accessories and apparel, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: OIL LEASING IN A FAMILIAR PITCH
description: As the slump in energy markets has deepened in the past couple of years, the nation's leading oil companies have reduced spending for exploration and production. But on Wednesday, they are expected to put frugality aside for a day and bid furiously at a Federal auction of oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: ALTIUS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
VORNADO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After tax credits of $700,000 for the latest quarter and $625,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Careers; Humanities Majors and Commerce
description: THE corporate connection with humanities departments of colleges and universities is growing dramatically. In November 1982, the University of Maryland's division of arts and humanities invited a dozen corporate executives to help set up a program to prepare humanities majors for work in the business world.

title: THE REGION
description: Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of Schenectady, said today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was jeopardizing the economy of New York State by insisting on ''totally unrealistic regulations'' for nuclear power plants.

title: Lucas Returns With the 'Jedi'
description: Will Han Solo ever fly again or is he forever doomed to remain a wall decoration in the pleasure palace of Jabba the Hutt? Does Princess Leia do her own hair or does she pay someone to make it look that way? Who, or perhaps what, is Salacious Crumb? When will Luke Skywalker become a true Jedi knight? Where does Yoda do his shopping? Will Darth Vader sacrifice his only begotten son so that evil might triumph? And, speaking of Vader, when he takes off his mask, what is underneath? James Earl Jones? David Prowse? A cantaloupe?

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
2 FOR KINGMAN
description: No, George Bamberger said before the game last night, he would not bench Dave Kingman. ''Sure, I'm going to stay with him,'' the Mets' manager said. ''I have confidence he'll come out of it. If I take him out, he can't come out of it. Home-run hitters can give you a quick three runs.''

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 25, 1983
description: International

title: Letter: On Libel Cases No Reason Not to Trust Jury Judgments
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Saudi Confers in Syria On Accord in Lebanon
description: A special Saudi envoy met today with President Hafez al-Assad, reportedly to try to soften Syria's opposition to the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement.

title: What to Preserve in Harlem
description: The New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Preservation is suffering a spell of bureaucratic tunnel vision. Adhering strictly to guidelines that have no practical relevance, it would withhold approval of an innovative renewal project in Harlem.

title: N.W. Ayer Is Assigned All Beatrice Candies
description: Beatrice Foods has consolidated all of its candy brands into a newly formed unit called Beatrice Confections, which will be based in St. Louis.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TRIUMPHS BY 6-1, 6-1
description: Martina Navratilova began defense of her French Open women's title today in the same confident fashion that she has played all year: she beat Mary Lou Piatek, 6-1, 6-1. Vitas Gerulaitis began his quest for the men's title with little confidence because of the tennis balls being used and was beaten by Hans Simonsson of Sweden, 6-4, 6-4, 2-6, 6-1.

title: AN AMERICAN CHALLENGE TO BEAUJOLAIS
description: IN a popularity contest among American wine grapes, the lowly gamay could be described as somewhat of a wallflower, passed over by judges who are attracted to its more glamorous cousins, cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay, zinfandel and pinot noir. Its pleasant but retiring personality has earned it a reputation as ''nice'' and ''presentable,'' the type you would be happy to take home to your parents but certainly not the first one you would look up for a big night on the town.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Illinois Judge Extends Guards on Cyanide Sites
description: Ten northern Illinois sites containing cyanide-contaminated film chips still pose a danger to the public, a judge said Monday as he extended an order to keep guards stationed at the sites.

title: HOUSE LEADERS CRITICIZE VOTE TO LIMIT SENATORS' EARNINGS
description: House Democratic leaders today assailed as a breach of faith a House committee proposal to limit senators' outside earnings to $18,200, or 30 percent of their salary.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: THE MILLSTONE OF MRS. THATCHER'S GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Pepsico Takeover Of Philippine Unit
description: Pepsico Inc. is being permitted to take over operations of its financially troubled subsidiary, the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of the Philippines, the Philippine Board of Investments said in Manila.

title: CANADIAN CORPORATE MANAGEMENT CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Market Place
description: ''I LET other people worry about the market,'' Peter Lynch said yesterday. ''I worry about what stocks to buy.'' This approach has paid off handsomely for the 39-year-old portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund in Boston.

title: HOUSE DATA SEEM TO DISPUTE EX-COMMERCE AIDE ON SATELLITE POLICY
description: The Justice Department has been given excerpts from notes that appear to contradict the assertion of a former Reagan Administration official that he was not actively seeking a job with a private corporation while working for a change in Government policy that benefited the corporation.

title: EDITORS' NOTES
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectfies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual erros.

title: Steve Rose Presenting Songs of Irving Berlin
description: Because Irving Berlin reached his 95th birthday on May 11, Steve Ross is devoting an hour of his Wednesday through Saturday sessions in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel during the month of May to the songs of Mr. Berlin. It is a conjunction that points up some special talents of both Mr. Ross and Mr. Berlin.

title: Splendid View and Party, Well Almost
description: As a painter of trompe l'oeil murals, Richard Haas has given New Yorkers a lot of stunning views that weren't really there. Then he sent out 200 invitations to a real one - the Brooklyn Bridge celebration from his 11th-floor loft studio at Fulton Ferry Landing, just south of the bridge's Brooklyn end.

title: Another Leak Disclosed At Stringfellow Dump
description: A state official says he forgot to tell the local authorities right away that contaminated water began seeping from the Stringfellow Acid Pits toxic dump last week.

title: JACKSON SEARCHES FOR A SWING AT 37
description: At his locker before batting practice, Reggie Jackson fingered several of his brown bats. Finally he gripped one and quickly halfswung it.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
HIGH LAND-TAX PLAN DOING WHAT IS SHOULD
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in late editions of Business Day yesterday, listing leading regional brokers, carried misnumbered footnotes that failed to apply to the companies cited. A corrected version appears today on page D2.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE Mystery Bus, an M3, rolls down Fifth Avenue electronically blinking an arcane message. People at bus stops blink back at the message: MEMORY CHIP II ... MEMORY CHIP II ... MEMORY CHIP II.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I recently read a book about feasting in Scotland and came across a dish named inky pinky. Can such a dish actually exist?

title: BLACKS SEEN TO APPLAUD BOMB ATTACK IN PRETORIA
description: In virtually all their pronouncements on Friday's car bomb explosion in Pretoria, South African officials have emphasized the black casualties, apparently in the belief that sympathy among blacks for the outlawed African National Congress would give way to revulsion over the brutality of an urban bombing.

title: PATIENT'S RIGHT TO REFUSE DRUGS UPHELD
description: In a decision believed to be the first of its kind in the United States, patients confined involuntarily in state mental hospitals have won the right to refuse drugs that are routinely and often forcibly used to treat them for psychosis.

title: Stone Clears Senate Hurdle
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to recommend confirmation of Richard Stone as President Reagan's speacial envoy for Central America. Senate action was expected later this week.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $341,000 for the quarter and $964,000 for the 9 months.

title: SHULTZ TO CONFER WITH NAMIBIA REBEL LEADER
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet with Sam Nujoma, the head of the South-West Africa insurgent movement, and representatives of key black African countries in New York on Thursday.

title: TROUBLED DRUSE AREA IS CALM BUT SHELLS FALL OUTSIDE BEIRUT
description: An uneasy calm existed in Lebanon's troubled Shuf Mountain area today after a late-night exchange of hostages between Druse and Phalangist Christians.

In a mood that reflected some confidence that the Federal Reserve has not tightened monetary policy, the credit markets posted modestly higher prices and marginally lower interest rates in steady but light trading yesterday.

title: U.S.F.L. Request For Lease Denied
description: The San Diego Stadium Authority voted today, 5 to 3, to deny a lease request from a new United States Football League franchise that had hoped to play next spring at Jack Murphy Stadium.

title: PERILOUS 'FREE ELECTIONS' IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AN AFGHAN REBEL AND SOVIET REPORTEDLY AGREE TO A TRUCE
description: A Western diplomat reported today that a guerrilla leader in Afghanistan had agreed to a truce with Soviet forces in a northern valley, where farming had been hampered by three years of continual fighting.

title: UNIONS PRESS DRIVE TO ENLIST HIGH-TECHNOLOGY WORKERS
description: Organized labor, faced with declining membership from a loss of jobs in the heavy industries that have long given it strength, is trying once again to unionize workers in the nation's high technology electronics industries.

title: French-Iraqi Accord
description: France has agreed with Iraq, its biggest arms client, on ways to repay outstanding Iraqi debts, estimated at around $2 billion, the French Government said today.

title: GENERAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $74,192. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $244,699.

title: GREAT AMERICAN RESOURCES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,700. c-Net loss.

title: Rivalry Renewed
description: Louisville and Kentucky, who have not played each other in a regular-season basketball game since 1922, will meet Nov. 26. The game will be played in Lexington and will be the first in a four-year series, according to The Washington Post.

title: CHAIRMAN OF N.A.A.C.P. SAYS SHE IS 'UNAWARE' OF MEETING
description: Margaret Bush Wilson, chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that she was ''unaware of any constitutionally called meeting'' planned by other members of the board to discuss her suspension of Benjamin L. Hooks as executive director of the organization last week.

title: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SUPERIOR OIL LOSES PROXY VOTE
description: The Superior Oil Company said yesterday that it had lost a proxy fight waged by its founder's daughter to force the company to consider takeover bids. The move was expected to generate renewed interest in Superior, whose current worth is nearly $5 billion.

title: HITLER 'DIARY' POSTSCRIPT: THE SCANDAL STALKS STERN
description: The scandal over the fake Hitler diaries has produced an upheaval and an identity crisis at Stern magazine that has spread into the tightly interlocked world of Hamburg's liberal journalistic community.

title: Phils Blanked 3d Time in Row
description: Alejandro Pena pitched a four-hitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Philadelphia, 3-0, tonight, extending the Phillies' scoreless string to 35 innings and their losing streak to four games.

title: CELTICS UP FOR SALE IN RIFT WITH ARENA
description: Harry Mangurian put the Boston Celtics up for sale today, citing strained relations with the owners of Boston Garden, where the team plays home games.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a charge of $4.4 million from nonrecurring costs of restructuring various segments of the company. c-Including a gain of $1,077,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of a textile division.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $387,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The results for the latest periods reflect a provision for losses of $737,000 primarily due to the company's BRT Realty Trust subsidiary's financial reorganization plan.

title: BLUE JAY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A Pennsylvania Issue Is Priced
description: An $85 million Commonwealth of Pennsylvania capital improvement general obligation issue was won in competitive bidding by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Nothing Proved
description: Through his first 34 games this season, Rod Carew of the California Angels batted .450 with 63 hits in 140 times at bat. Does the 37-year-old first baseman with a .331 career average have a realistic hope of becoming major league baseball's first batter in 42 years to top the .400 mark?
