title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for 9 mos to March 31.
description: The results for Mutual Real Estate Investment Trust were carried incorrectly in the Thursday, May 19, editions as for the three months ended March 31.

title: LUCAS RETURNS WITH 'THE JEDI'
description: WILL Han Solo ever fly again or is he forever doomed to remain a wall decoration in the pleasure palace of Jabba the Hutt? Does Princess Leia do her own hair or does she pay someone to make it look that way? Who, or perhaps what, is Salacious Crumb? When will Luke Skywalker become a true Jedi knight? Where does Yoda do his shopping? Will Darth Vader sacrifice his only begotten son so that evil might triumph? And, speaking of Vader, when he takes off his mask, what is underneath? James Earl Jones? David Prowse? A cantaloupe?

title: Providence, R.I., Mayor Indicted in Kidnapping
description: Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. was indicted today on charges that he kidnapped, beat and threatened to kill a contractor whom he reportedly suspected of having an affair with the Mayor's estranged wife.

title: Computer Ball
description: Doug Melvin, the Yankees' batting practice pitcher, got to the park in Anaheim early yesterday. He needed to work out a few bugs, on his computer.

title: 7 Black Officers Found To Be Dismissed Illegally
description: City officials in Columbus, Ga., had no right to dismiss seven black police officers who cut the American flag off their uniforms in a protest in 1971, a Federal appeals court ruled Monday.

title: COMPANY RECALLS SMOKE DETECTORS
description: The Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission today announced the recall of more than 770,000 residential smoke detectors that may sound alarms when manually tested but may not go off in the presence of smoke.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Neil Allen, who has found new life as a starter, goes for his third straight victory.

title: The U.N. Today; May 25, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: BRIEFING
description: Civil Rights Appointment

title: LIBERAL IN BRITAIN FIGHTS AGAINST TIDE
description: It was not a good weekend for the new alliance of the Liberals and the Social Democrats, the ''third force'' that only a year ago seemed on the verge of fulfilling its bold pledge to ''break the mold'' of British politics.

title: Constance Winchell Of Columbia Library
description: Constance Mabel Winchell, a former head reference librarian for Columbia University and author of a compilation of reference books, died Monday at her home in New Paltz, N.Y. She was 86 years old.

title: Mullin on U.S. Team
description: Chris Mullin, St. John's standout basketball guard, is 1 of 12 top college basketball players who have been named to the United States team for the Pan American Games in Venezuela in August. Mullin, the Big East Conference's player of the year, was one of four sophomores selected by the team's coach, Jack Hartman of Kansas State, after five days of trials in Colorado Springs.

title: KAPOK TREE INNS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 10.
18.48 GAIN LIFTS DOW TO 1,219.04
description: Stock prices soared yesterday in accelerated trading, apparently propelled by a belief that interest rates would continue to decline despite the recent increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: U.S. WINNER AT CANNES STILL HOPING FOR A BREAK
description: The only American movie to win a prize at the Cannes Film Festival this year was an eight-minute short about an hysterical maitre d'hotel.

title: Hong Kong Dollar Falls
description: The Hong Kong dollar hit a new low on foreign exchanges today and stocks fell heavily for a second day in a fresh bout of pessimism over the colony's future. At the end of trading, the Hong Kong dollar was worth only 14.09 cents (United States), well below its previous low of 14.21 cents (United States) last Thursday. Much of Hong Kong is due to revert to China when 19thcentury leases expire in 1997, and its markets have shown sporadic bouts of nervousness since an inconclusive visit to Peking by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain last year.

title: REAGAN CHOOSES 3 FOR RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan today replaced three members of the United States Civil Rights Commission who have been critical of his Administration with appointees who insisted they had been guaranteed full independence by the White House.

title: CLIMBERS EXPUNGE CLIFF SIGN CRITICAL OF WATT
description: After two park employees failed in an attempt, two expert climbers were sent up a sandstone cliff in Zion National Park on Tuesday to remove a sign critical of Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: AM Reports Profit in Quarter
description: AM International Inc., operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws since April 1982, yesterday reported a profit for its third quarter, ended April 30, of $3.2 million, or 31 cents a share. It was the company's second consecutive quarterly profit.

title: Lloyds Bank Curbs Loans
description: Lloyds Bank International Ltd. plans to limit growth in its lending this year, a spokesman for the parent company, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., said today.

title: Judge in Illinois Orders Cleanup of Cyanide Sites
description: A Cook County Circuit judge today ordered several companies to pay for the cleanup of 16 million pounds of cyanide contaminated waste at sites throughout Cook County and in Dixon, Ill.

title: Third California Condor Hatched in Captivity
description: A California condor was hatched in captivity today and the chick appeared to be healthy and normal, San Diego Zoo officials said.

title: Early Start for Fans
description: When the Jedi returned, the fans were waiting. The newest sequel to ''Star Wars,'' opening yesterday at three Manhattan theaters, brought out extra police details.

title: Satanism in Iran
description: The Devil, it is reliably reported, can quote Scripture. So can Iranian judges. Asked to explain why 22 adherents of the Bahai faith had to die, a religious judge in Shiraz said it would fulfill a prayer of Noah, as recorded in the Koran: ''And Noah said, Lord, leave not one single family of infidels on the earth; for if thou leave them they will beguile thy servants and beget only sinners and infidels.''

title: VICTORIAN DETAILS FOR RENOVATIONS
description: IN 1969, when Victorian houses were not in the mainstream of fashion, a definition of gingerbread, the carved architectural detailing often found on 19th-century American houses, appeared thus in The American Heritage Dictionary: ''Any superfluous or tasteless embellishment, especially in architecture.''

title: ABDUL-JABBAR TOP FREE AGENT
description: Twenty-four hours after the end of the pro basketball playoffs, there could be a telephone conversation in which Tom Collins, the agent for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, tells a general manager something like this:

title: Soviet Cool to Hot Line Plan
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today dismissed President Reagan's proposals to improve the hot line between Washington and Moscow as an attempt to divert attention from the MX missile issue.

title: HOUSE PANEL ON AGING ASSAILS DRAFT RULES ON HOSPICE COSTS
description: Members of Congress from both parties criticized the Reagan Administration today for drafting rules that would reduce the value of a new Medicare benefit for the terminally ill to about 60 percent of the level envisioned by Congress.

title: Cable Service to Offer Ticket-Purchase Plan
description: A new cable television service that will enable viewers to select seats for plays and sports events from seating plans displayed on the television screen is scheduled to begin operation next month in Denver.

title: Medical Care Issue Yields 8% to 9 3/4%
description: Merrill Lynch priced a $108 million bond issue for the New York State Medical Care facility finance agency yesterday at yields ranging from 8 percent to 9.75 percent.

title: Burden of Debt
description: Art Schlichter, the suspended Baltimore Colts' quarterback, may have run up far more in gambling-related debts than the almost $400,000 in losses that had been reported in court papers. Schlichter's lawyer, John J. Chester, said last night that the debts actually exceeded $750,000.

title: DANCE: ERIK BRUHN'S 'SYLPHIDE' AT BALLET THEATER
description: ERIK BRUHN has staged a new, even surprisingly grandiose, production of August Bournonville's famous 19th-century Romantic ballet ''La Sylphide'' that is bound to be as controversial as it is already thrilling. It is one of the biggest challenges to preconceived ideas that a ballet classic has offered in a long while and is, in its strangely stupifying way, a complete success.

title: CABARET: JENIFER LEWIS
description: A MONTH LONG series of performances by Jenifer Lewis that had been scheduled at Don't Tell Mama, the West 46th Street cabaret, was interrupted last week when Bette Midler asked Miss Lewis to become one of her Harlettes during a current tour. Miss Lewis immediately took off for the hinterlands but it is doubtful that she will be a Harlette for long.

title: AMENDED WITHHOLDING REPEAL GAINS
description: The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to repeal tax withholding on interest and dividends, but voted to attach to the repeal bill a package of unrelated measures, including President Reagan's Caribbean Basin Initiative and a trade reciprocity bill.

title: U.S. Steel Defends Plan
description: The United States Steel Corporation might have to close its Fairless, Pa., plant as early as 1986 unless it makes a controversial deal to import British steel, David Roderick, the company chairman, said yesterday.

title: Turf Speculation
description: Among the guests at the Epsom Derby next Wednesday will be a New Yorker with a strange name and rather thin credentials for England's most prestigious horse race. It's Slewpy, the son of Seattle Slew who was not considered good enough to run in the Kentucky Derby earlier this month, but is boarding a jet Sunday morning that will take him to Epsom.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: LANDSCAPE DESIGN
description: ''Abstraction as a Formative Process in Landscape Design,'' Architec- tural League, 457 Madison Avenue (50th Street), 212-753-1722.

title: KING IDRIS, OUSTED IN '69 BY QADDAFI, DIES IN CAIRO
description: Qaddafi and other army officers overthrew him in 1969, died today in a Cairo hospital. He was 93 years old.

title: CONCERT: SOLISTI NEW YORK
description: IN a recent interview, Ransom Wilson said it was Mozart's Symphony No. 29 in A that inspired him - a flute virtuoso - to take up conducting. If the concert he led at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night gave a reliable indication of his leadership skills, it was an inspiration for which he should be grateful.

title: A BLAZING NILE STEAMBOAT SINKS, LEAVING 48 DEAD AND 254 MISSING
description: A Nile River steamer and two towed barges carrying 627 people caught fire and sank today in a lake behind the Aswan Dam. At least 48 people died, and 254 others were reported missing. The police said 325 people had been rescued.

title: Advertising; Bulgari Looks to Public TV
description: THE expansion-minded Bulgari brothers, whose grandfather founded the Rome-based jewelry operation that caters to the upscale all over, have some specific growth plans for the United States, where currently their only shop is cozily ensconced just off the lobby of the Pierre Hotel.

title: Insurance Exchange
description: The New York Insurance Exchange reported yesterday that premium volume of its underwriting syndicates in the first quarter of 1983 climbed 82.3 percent, to $57.8 million, from $31.7 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: TENNESSEE BANK BIDS ARE SOUGHT
description: Federal banking regulators today invited bids for at least five Tennessee banks shaken in the collapse earlier this year of a state banking and finance empire headed by two brothers, Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Newburgh Losing Its City Manager
description: Gary Bloomquist, the City Manager here for two and a half years, resigned today, citing ''personal reasons.''

title: Meadowlands Reopens Tonight
description: The 10-race harness card at Meadowlands Race Track was canceled for a second straight night as the arson squad of the state police began investigating Tuesday night's fire in a kitchen storage pantry. Spokesmen for the track said it would reopen Thursday with admission, programs and parking free of charge.

title: SENATE VOTES 51-42, TO ADD $99 BILLION TO U.S. DEBT CEILING
description: The Senate voted today to increase the national debt limit by nearly $99 billion, enough money to keep the Government running until Sept. 30, and sent the measure to President Reagan for his expected signature.

title: Dayton-Hudson Split
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation's management will recommend a 2-for-1 stock split to the board next month, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, William A. Andres, told the annual meeting today.

title: Youth Lost, 2 Rescued As a Boat Tips Off S.I.
description: A youth in a rowboat that capsized yesterday off Staten Island was missing and presumed drowned, the police said.

title: Mammoth Skull in Alaska
description: The well-preserved skull and tusks of a mammoth that died 15,000 years ago have been discovered near an Alaskan gold mine. ''This is a very significant find,'' said Robert Thorson, an expert on glacial and geological science.

title: Penzoil Increases Its Stake in Pogo
description: The Pennzoil Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had raised its stake to 1,469,000 shares, or 5.8 percent, of the common stock of the Pogo Producing Company, the Houston energy company. Pennzoil also said it intends to increase its holdings in Pogo, but added that it had no intention of seeking control of the company.

title: COURT DECISION DUE ON SUPPLY SYSTEM
description: A State Superior Court judge is scheduled to issue a decision Friday on how long he plans to restrain Chemical Bank of New York from declaring in default the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: MCENROE FINED, BUT ADVANCES
description: John McEnroe earned his first victory and first fine of the French Open today in a contentious five-set match against Ben Testerman, a 21-year-old American ranked 84th in the world.

title: Money Accounts Gain
description: After several weeks of decline, interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts edged upward nationwide last week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: AUTHOR AND EXPERT ON FREUD; United Press International
description: Dr. Hendrik M. Ruitenbeek, a scholar on Freud and author who was among the first psychoanalysts to advocate equal rights for homosexuals, died yesterday after a brief illness, his family said. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Walesa Says Gdansk Police Have Summoned Him Again
description: Lech Walesa has been summoned to appear at the Gdansk police headquarters after work Friday, the leader of the outlawed Solidarity trade union said.

title: MUSIC: LOVE DUETS AND SONGS
description: A SELECTION of 17th- and 18th-century duets and songs about that most popular of subjects, love, was offered at Merkin Hall on Tuesday afternoon, titled, appropriately enough, ''Duetti Amorosi.'' The soprano Kristine Ciesinski and the countertenor Rodney Hardesty engaged in sweet, winsome, cynical and affectionate duets, bringing taste and conviction to everything they sang.

title: ORGANIZED UNITS BLAMED FOR PARIS BRAWL
description: A leading police official today accused ''organized and determined groups'' of being behind the new round of street fighting that broke out Tuesday as students continued their demonstrations against the Government's proposed changes in the university system.

title: DANIEL W. HORGAN, AN EX-CARTER AIDE
description: Daniel W. Horgan, a former executive director of the Democratic National Committee and a longtime political organizer in New Jersey, died of a heart attack yesterday while working at a party campaign office in West New York, N.J. He was 52 years old and lived in Kendall Park.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CENTER

title: New Jazz Trio
description: Gerald Bagley, a real-estate developer and member of the Utah Jazz advisory board, and his son Thomas have purchased 50 percent of the National Basketball Association club. Sam Battistone, president of the Jazz, will retain the other 50 percent of the club that finished 30-52 last season and reportedly lost $2 million a year for the 1980-82 seasons.

title: PICKING BEST PLANTS FOR RENTAL HOMES
description: THE Memorial Day weekend, when troops of urbanites head once again for their summer resort rentals, proves that summer is a state of mind rather than a matter of meteorology. After nine winter months in the city, it is high time to get out of town and into the country splendors they have longed for. Still, as they survey the current late-spring barrenness in which they propose to spend their summer weekends, they see rather less than the stuff of dreams. Empty expanses of deck and porch greet the eye with all the cheer of the Gobi desert. Unplanted borders and ratty patches bring T.S. Eliot unbidden to the lips: ''That is not what I had in mind at all.''

title: U.S. BIDS CUBA TAKE SEVERAL THOUSAND OF ITS EXILES BACK
description: The United States has asked Cuba to take back as many as several thousand of the 125,000 Cubans who came to this country as part of the boatlift from the port of Mariel in 1980, the State Department said today.

title: THE OLDER BROTHER OF BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: AS New Yorkers congratulate themselves on the centennial of the Brooklyn Bridge, people in this city would like them to remember that a handful of Ohio River Valley businessmen, as attuned to the westward march of empire as any Walt Whitman rhapsodizing on the Brooklyn shore, showed them the way.

title: Thrift Unit Rests Its Case
description: Lawyers for the insolvent Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association rested their case against the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today with an expert witness testifying that tapes of bank board meetings contained unexplained gaps.

title: Siebert Opens Branch in Bank
description: In a new twist in the growing relationships between banks and discount-brokerage firms, Muriel Siebert & Company has opened a branch in the First Women's Bank. It is the first time a discount brokerage firm has opened an actual branch in a commercial bank.

title: Books Of The Times
description: STREETBIRD. By Janwillem van de Wetering. 286 pages. Putnam's. $13.95. BANSHEE. By Margaret Millar. 202 pages. Morrow. $10.95.

title: DANCE: CANADIANS AT CITY CENTER
description: LES GRANDS BALLETS CANADIENS from Montreal, now celebrating its 25th anniversary, returned Wednesday night to the City Center for the second year in a row with a program that showed the company as appealing and as slightly confused in its esthetic as ever.

title: ROLL CALL IN SENATE ON MONEY FOR MX
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today approved $625 million in development and testing funds for the MX missile. FOR THE MX - 59 Republicans - 47 Abdnor, S.D. Baker, Tenn.

title: TV: NEWS SPOOF ON HBO
description: Popping up on the Home Box Office schedule several times a month is a half-hour program called ''Not Necessarily the News.'' Inspired by, or cribbed from, Britain's ''Not the Nine O'Clock News,'' the show offers a frenetically paced collection of comedy segments, many of them using ''fractured film footage'' of current news events. The result, a sort of speeded-up ''Laugh-In,'' is inevitably uneven, but there are enough on-target routines to merit further encouragement.

title: A RECORD-BREAKER AT THE INDY TRIALS
description: There was nothing to do. With all the things that happened during the first month Teo Fabi had spent at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, it was remarkable that yesterday, four days before the annual 500-mile race and one day before the final day of track testing, he had nothing to do.

title: REAGAN PLANS AMIBITIOUS ROLE AS SUMMIT HOST
description: Even before the discussions begin at the seven-nation economic summit conference this weekend, President Reagan has given the gathering his personal stamp, taking on an unusually ambitious role as host, chairman, moderator, note-taker and reporter on the proceedings.

title: PENTAGON CURBING TALKS WITH PRESS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger is limiting attendance by senior Pentagon officials at breakfasts with reporters after policy differences were aired at two such meetings.

title: NOTE OF CAUTION FOR THE TRAVELER: DETOURS AHEAD
description: The rebuilding of highways and bridges in the New York area is being stepped up this year, bringing mixed news for the motorist this Memorial Day weekend.

title: Generals Switch Kickers
description: The New Jersey Generals switched field-goal kickers today. They dropped Dave Jacobs, who had been with the team since the United States Football League season began last March 6, and signed David Betz, who has never performed in a professional game.

title: CUOMO SUGGESTS WAY TO CORRECT INDIAN PT. PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday proposed using state employees and several hundred utility workers in the evacuation plans for the two Indian Point nuclear reactors. The Governor offered the proposal in an effort to satisfy Federal concerns about emergency procedures there.

title: Team America Tied by Dynamo
description: Viktor Sokor scored on a penalty kick with just over three minutes remaining to lift the Dynamo Minsk soccer team into a 2-2 tie with Team America tonight.

title: I.M.F. SEEN DELAYING LATEST LOANS TO BRAZIL
description: The International Monetary Fund has decided to postpone for at least a month the distribution of some $411 million in loans to Brazil because of doubts that the country is complying with an economic austerity program required by the I.M.F., monetary sources reported yesterday.

title: BALLADS: A DEBUT BY MISS MCBROOM
description: AMANDA McBROOM, the Texas-born singer and songwriter, who is making her New York debut at Freddy's Supper Club, is known primarily as the composer of Bette Midler's hit, ''The Rose.'' That song, it turns out, is no fluke.

title: BRIEFING
description: How Best to Brief

title: News Analysis
description: The House and the Senate, in separate versions of the budget resolution, have endorsed the idea of a new Federal program to provide health care for unemployed people.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Our old house in New England, which we use only in the warmer months, has a full-height cellar with a dirt floor. The walls are made of fieldstone that is not mortared, and these are topped with blocks of granite on which the sills rest. There are only three windows for ventilation, and opening more windows through the granite blocks would seem to be a formidable task. The cellar is often damp, and in wet spring weather it exudes this dampness into the groundfloor rooms. What can you suggest to alleviate this problem?

title: Officer Kills Man
description: A police officer shot and killed a man yesterday on East 79th Street after the man slashed at an officer with a 10-inch hunting knife, the police said.

title: Debt Issues
description: * IC Industries' subsidiary, IC Industries Finance Corp. N.V., priced a $100 million issue of 8 7/8 percent guaranteed notes due in 1991, with warrants, at par, through Orion Royal Bank, London.

title: Mistrial Is Declared by Judge In South Carolina Sheriff Case
description: A mistrial was declared tonight in the misconduct trial of suspended Williamsburg County Sheriff Theodore McFarlin, who was the first black man to become a South Carolina sheriff since Reconstruction.

title: Bernice Judis Is Dead at 83; Headed Radio Station WNEW
description: Bernice Judis, a former general manager of radio station WNEW, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at the North Beach Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 83 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

title: New Koch Appointment
description: Mayor Koch is expected to announce today that Rosemary Ginty will be promoted to Director of the Office of Intergovernmental Relations, according to city aides.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: It Sure Didn't Look Like Times Square
description: Mortarboards and academic robes turned Times Square into an unlikely scene yesterday. Parsons School of Design, with headquarters on lower Fifth Avenue, held its 87th commencement at Town Hall, on West 43d Street.

title: HOUSE GETS A PLAN ON COVERT ACTIONS
description: Democratic members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee are considering a proposal to create a commission that would set guidelines for, and approve or disapprove, all covert intelligence activities by the United States Government.

title: GREAT LAKES GOVERNORS PREPARE TO ACT IN UNISON
description: The governors of the Great Lakes industrial states, saying they were tired of having their economic problems ignored, formed a united front today to advance the region's interests.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 26, 1983
description: International

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America announced that it had developed three aluminum alloys that it said could reduce the weight of a large commercial airliner by as much as six tons, thus reducing fuel consumption by as much as 220,000 gallons a year.

title: Bridge: 2 New York Women Find Spot on 'Real' Swiss Team
description: For two New York women to play on a Swiss team is an everyday occurrence, but for them to play on a ''real'' Swiss team - that is, one based in Switzerland - is unusual indeed.

title: SENATE BY 59 TO 39, VOTES $625 MILLION FOR TESTING MX
description: The Senate today gave final approval to a resolution endorsing President Reagan's plan to base 100 MX missiles in existing shelters and releasing $625 million for development of the huge new weapon.

title: REDUCE 'CORPORATE WELFARE'
description: Because the budget battle again pits fiscal against social responsibility and guns against butter, legislators favoring adequate social spending find themselves boxed into anti-defense or budget-busting positions. But Congress can escape this trap by cutting funds from an area conspicuously absent from the budget debate: corporate welfare.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS CUT SQUAD LIMIT TO 45
description: The National Football League's owners voted today to return to a squad limit of 45 players next season, a decision that effectively eliminates 112 jobs.

title: Cosmos Halt Zungul and Win 5th in Row
description: The Cosmos neutralized the Golden Bay Earthquakes and Steve Zungul at Giants Stadium tonight. And while the defense stymied Golden Bay, the Cosmos attacked with crispness and accuracy throughout and recorded a 5-1 victory, their their fifth in a row and sixth in eight games.

title: American Can
description: The American Can Company, the diversified packaging and financial services company, said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the American General Capital Corporation of Houston, and its subsidiaries.

title: BRITISH LABORITES SPLIT ON MISSILES
description: Already trailing badly in the opinion polls, the opposition Labor Party has been further damaged, with only two weeks of campaigning left until the general election on June 9, by the inability of its leaders to agree on what defense policies they favor.

title: Tuition to Rise $300 At State U. This Fall
description: The State University's board of trustees voted today to increase the annual undergraduate tuition for state residents by $300, to $1,350.

title: CONCERT: SIX PREMIERES
description: THE New York Quintet, which consists of William Moersch on marimba, Keith Underwood on flute, James McElwaine on clarinet, Dennis Masuzzo on bass and Jonathan Haas on a multitude of percussion instruments, is clearly not a typical ensemble. Therefore, it is not surprising that most of their material must be specifically tailored to their idiosyncratic blend of instruments.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
EASY STORAGE SPACE
description: WHEN you need sturdy, inexpensive storage space in an attic, basement or garage two versatile systems will fill the bill. Steel City's heavy-duty storage components enable you to build shelves in the attic, under stairs or suspended from the ceiling over appliances.

title: OF PROSPECTIVE JURORS AND THE LAWYERS WHO QUESTION THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: A late rally enabled stock prices yesterday to score their third consecutive advance in one of the heaviest trading sessions this year.

title: Gould Battery Sale: Chief Seen Staying
description: Stanley N. Gaines, president and chief executive of Gould Inc.'s lead-acid battery operations, is expected to become the top management man if a plan goes through to sell the company to a group of investors.

title: Player Comforts
description: Cesar Cedeno of the Reds found the idea of flying coach class on a commercial team flight from Cincinnati to Chicago so distasteful on Sunday that he tore up his airplane ticket, missed the flight and was assessed a $100 fine and a three-day suspension by his team.

title: THE COURT SAYS NO
description: It is a long time since an Administration has suffered such a defeat in the Supreme Court. The 8-to-1 decision that racist private schools are ineligible for tax exemptions was worse than an embarrassment for President Reagan and his lawyers. It was a humiliation.

title: METS COMMIT 5 ERRORS IN LOSS
description: The Mets, renowned for their talent for self-destruction, outdid themselves yesterday in Shea Stadium as they suffered a 7-6 loss to the San Francisco Giants.

title: JOHN FINISHES SWEEP OF YANKS, 7-1
description: The Yankee lineup was shaken up again tonight in an attempt by Manager Billy Martin to get some runs, but it didn't help as New York ended its road trip with a 7-1 loss to the Angels and Tommy John. California swept the three-game series.

title: Texaco Files Suit Against Tenneco
description: Texaco Inc. said it had sued Tenneco Inc. for more than $100 million in a Louisiana state court seeking enforcement of provisions of 33 gas-sales contracts.

title: The Rumblings in South Africa
description: South Africa can segregate its races, but it cannot segregate itself from the violence its policies breed. This is the meaning of last weekend's terror bombing in Pretoria, which claimed 17 lives, white and black, and left 217 wounded. Bombs beget bombs, and South Africa has compounded a gruesome deed by loosing its warplanes against Mozambique, insisting that its targets are guerrilla installations.

title: Virginia Tech Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today that Virginia Polytechnic of Blacksburg, Va., had been placed on a one-year probation without sanctions for recruiting violations in its football program.

title: REAGAN NOW BACKS INCREASE IN AID FOR ISRAEL
description: The Reagan Administration has switched positions and told Congress that it will now support Congressional efforts to increase military and economic grants to Israel by some $400 million, State Department officials said today.

title: STUDY TELLS CITY AIDING INDUSTRY HELPS SAVE JOBS
description: To retain dwindling industrial jobs in the boroughs outside Manhattan, the city should mount a major effort to assist manufacturers in finding building space and in obtaining more money for development, a nonprofit research organization said yesterday.

title: NPR BOARD VOTES ON CUTS
description: The board of directors of National Public Radio approved a budget reduction plan today that will force the lay off of nearly one-fifth of the staff and require major cutbacks in programming.

title: 2 ON THRUWAY PANEL ARE ASKED BY CUOMO TO RESIGN FROM JOBS
description: Governor Cuomo has asked for the resignation of two Democratic members of the State Thruway Authority who were fund-raisers for former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, aides to Mr. Cuomo said yesterday. Both of the authority members rejected the suggestion.

title: Briton Worried By U.S. Deficit
description: Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, today joined the chorus of European leaders expressing concern about high interest rates and the United States budget deficit.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Interest rates rose slightly in late trading yesterday as credit market participants worried about increasing the inventory of securities at a time when investor demand has shrunk.

title: KOCH CRTITICIZES A CABLE TV BILL BEFORE CONGRESS
description: Mayor Koch warned a House subcommittee today that if Congress adopted legislation deregulating cable television, New York City would have to substantially rewrite its agreements on nearly completed cable television franchises.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., has promoted Thomas H. Quinn to corporate vice president in charge of the Home Health Care business.

title: IF THE U.S. IS LEFT WITHOUT BASIC STEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Quanex Refinancing
description: The Quanex Corporation, which makes steel products, said yesterday it had signed an interim refinancing agreement with its lenders covering $170.8 million of debt.

title: 20,000 Cambodian Refugees Leave Thai Haven for Home
description: About 20,000 Cambodian refugees who fled to Thailand after a major Vietnamese dry-season offensive in western Cambodia three months ago have returned home, Thai and United Nations relief workers said today.

title: Sharp Fall Seen In Oil Drilling
description: The Hughes Tool Company, an oil service and supply concern, said today that it had doubled its estimate of this year's decline in oil and gas drilling in the United States.

title: Amtrak Is Increasing Fares
description: Amtrak announced today that fares on its passenger trains would be increased by an average of slightly less than 3 percent on June 1. Amtrak said the increase would not apply to advance purchases of All Aboard America tickets.

title: Patriots Get Eason
description: Tony Eason, the quarterback from Illinois who was the 15th player chosen in the National Football League's draft last month has agreed to a four-year, $2.3 million contract with the New England Patriots. Eason had also been sought by the United States Football League and the Montreal Concordes of the Canadian Football League. That competition, along with the rich pact signed recently by John Elway with the Denver Broncos, inflated the value of Eason's contract by about $1 million, said his agent, Leigh Steinberg.

title: June 14 'Lucia' to Open Opera Season in Parks
description: The Metropolitan Opera will open its 17th season of parks concerts with a performance of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' June 14 on Central Park's Great Lawn. This eight-performance series will include four performances of ''Lucia'' and four of Puccini's ''Boheme.

title: 7TH GRADERS AS INTERIOR DESIGNERS
description: ''WHEN Dana first heard we'd be studying interior design,'' said Ruth Lessuck, a seventh-grade teacher at Manhattan's Academy of Environmental Sciences, ''she thought it meant playing with colors and furniture for 10 weeks, and that it would be boring. But she learned that interior design is more than putting a sofa in front of a window, that it also means interior architecture. She has liked it and is now thinking of becoming an interior designer.''

title: LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR TOPS CLOSE KENTUCKY PRIMARY
description: Lieut. Gov. Martha Layne Collins, seeking to become Kentucky's first woman Governor, narrowly won the Democratic primary Tuesday to set up a campaign against the Republican nominee, Jim Bunning, a State Senator who is a former major league baseball pitcher.

title: U.S.-FRANCE CURRENCY DISPUTE
description: When the leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies gather in the Capitol Building in Colonial Williamsburg this weekend, they will be meeting not far from Yorktown, Va., where George Washington - with powerful assistance from the French - won his decisive victory in the Revolution.

title: No Gain for Legislator
description: Ernie Chambers, a Nebraska State Senator, showed up at the legislative hall in Lincoln Tuesday wearing a University of Nebraska helmet and jersey and carrying a football under his arm. The uniform, he said, was intended to dramatize his bill that would require Nebraska to pay football players as state employees.

title: Continental Executive To Head Micronesia Air
description: George A. Warde, who has headed two big airlines, now plans to head a small one - Micronesia Airlines in the Pacific. Mr. Warde, who is 61, is currently vice chairman of Continental Air Lines. Micronesia Airlines is operated by Continental and the United Micronesia Development Association. Aloha Airlines has a 10 percent interest.

title: Man, 36, Arrested In Wife's Murder
description: An unemployed auto-body repairman was arrested today and charged withkilling his estranged wife, the Nassau County police said.

title: AN 'UNELECTED MEMBER' OF THE SENATE
description: ''Senators Only'' said the sign in front of the Capitol subway, but David Brody was waved aboard by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, whom he thanked for signing a resolution opposing the sale of advanced weaponry to Jordan.

title: DOCTORS IN ISRAEL OBEY WORK ORDER
description: About a third of Israel's 8,500 doctors returned to work today on Government orders but their strike, which resulted in an almost complete walkout of doctors at the beginning of the week, showed few signs of resolution.

title: E.P.A. RESCINDS REPORT OF AIDE'S RESIGNATION
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced the resignation of one of its top officials today, then reversed itself hours later and said the official, Sonia Crow, a regional administrator, had not resigned.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball 76ers vs. Los Angeles Lakers, championship final, second game, at Philadelphia. The 76ers lead by one game to none against the defending N.B.A. champions, who are hoping that Bob McAdoo is sufficiently improved from his thigh injury to help against Moses Malone.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An offer of a reported $250,000 a year and a chance to coach Ralph Sampson were apparently not enough for the former Boston Celtic coach, Tommy Heinsohn. He turned down the offer from the Houston Rockets. ... Jim Eisenreich, the Twins' outfielder who has been sidelined since April with the nervous disorder that forced him to miss most of last season, has asked to be placed on the voluntary retirement list. ... After 30 years of coaching basketball at the college and professional level, Bill van Breda Kolff has found a new challenge: as a high school coach in Picayune, Miss. Officials of Picayune Memorial High School said the 60-year-old van Breda Kolff, a resident of nearby Bay St. Louis, had been hired to replace Lowrey Robinson, who resigned after last season.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN 'REFORM'
description: THERE IS change in the air in South Africa. Officials now speak easily about reform and only rarely about racial separation and supremacy. But the change is peculiarly South African, for it promises new and more elaborate forms of racial domination and yet more widespread black resistance. It promises, in fact, yet more incidents like the one Friday in which a car bomb planted by the African National Congress killed 18 people and injured almost 200 in downtown Pretoria.

title: 3-WEEK POLITICAL CRISIS IN CHICAGO STILL AT IMPASSE
description: Three weeks after the start of its new session, the City Council remains deadlocked in a bitter dispute over reorganization that has kept Council business at a standstill. It has also begun to rekindle the racial divisiveness that surrounded the April mayoral election.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 26, 1983; The Economy
description: Oil companies bid a record $3.47 billion for exploration rights on 656 Federal tracts in the Gulf of Mexico. The previous record, $2.7 billion, was set in 1980 on 147 tracts. The response by industry to the offering was hailed by Interior Secretary James G. Watt. (Page D1.)

title: New Options Pause Sought
description: The Securities Industry Association is asking securities exchanges to postpone introduction of new options products until early next year to give brokers and investors time to digest the flood of recently unveiled options.

title: Japanese Group In a Trade Plea
description: Keidanren, the Japanese Federation of Economic Organizations, called on the Government today to open the domestic market further to imported products to prevent trade friction from spreading to political and social areas.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A LOOSE, cracked or rotted fence post may not be high on the priority list when it comes to outdoor chores around the house, but the longer it is ignored the more likely the condition will worsen. Eventually a major rebuilding project, even the replacement of sections of fence, will be required.

title: MUSIC: JAZZ IN U.S.S.R.
description: A RECENTLY published history of jazz in the Soviet Union, ''Red and Hot: The Fate of Jazz in the Soviet Union'' by Frederick Starr, inspired a program of jazz by Soviet emigres and visitors from the U.S.S.R. on Monday evening at the Public Theater.

title: Vulnerability of Children
description: ''Parents must be aware that their children are vulnerable - that is the hard lesson we've learned.'' That is the message Stan Patz conveyed yesterday as parents gathered to mark National Missing Chilrden's Day.

title: Sydney Box, Movie Producer And Author of One-Act Plays
description: Sydney Box, author of more than 50 one-act plays and producer of more than 100 films, including ''The Seventh Veil,'' an Academy Award winner, died today at Royal Perth Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Redskin Reported Indicted for Drugs
description: A Washington Redskins player, Clarence Harmon, has been indicted by a Texarkana, Tex., grand jury on a first-degree felony charge of possession of cocaine, according to a published report.

title: Woodbridge Plans A Medical Center
description: A vacant 3.3-acre site on Route 35 in Woodbridge will be the site for a new $2.5 million emergency medical center and clinic, according to township and hospital officials.

title: FORD AND REUTHER KIN REVIVE OLD DETROIT MANSION FOR SECT
description: Buried deep in a neighborhood on Detroit's crumbling near East Side, almost to the mouth of the Detroit River, a cream-colored stucco mansion built by the automobile magnate Lawrence Fisher, a cruel reminder of the once-unlimited wealth of this city, was recently brought back to its original 1920's splendor.

title: Hamburg Defeats Juventus for Cup
description: SV Hamburg won the European Champions Cup today when a goal by Felix Magath in the eighth minute stood up for a 1-0 victory over Juventus in the new Olympic stadium before 80,000 soccer fans.

title: U.S. SETS ASIDE $6 MILLION FOR SALVADOR VOTING
description: The Reagan Administration plans to spend $6 million to $8 million to underwrite El Salvador's costs of holding presidential elections later this year, an Administration official said today.

title: Atlantic Air Talks Pressed
description: Representatives of America's State Department and Britain's Trade Department continued negotiations in London late last night on whether to let People Express begin flights to London for a one-way fare of $149.

title: TAKING THE PATH TO LEARNING
description: Kevin Ross, 24 years old and with four years of college behind him, was graduated tonight from the eighth grade of Chicago's Westside Preparatory School.

title: Russian Who Slipped Up Is Off the Air
description: Vladimir Danchev, an English-language newscaster for the Moscow radio who in two days of broadcasts described Soviet troops in Afghanistan as ''invaders,'' has not been heard from since Tuesday, when he told his housekeeper he was ''going for a walk,'' a Western reporter here said.

title: CARVING OUT NEW LIVING SPACES FROM TWO VINTAGE TOWN HOUSES
description: A COUPLE and a bachelor, looking for more living space in Manhattan, found similar solutions to the same problem. They bought brownstones, renovated them and created simple, large and airy living spaces. The renovations in both instances included complete gutting of the interiors, so the owners' triumphs were expensive ones. ''In an old house you're not sure what is really going on until you look under the surface,'' the bachelor, who is a doctor, said.

title: Legal Aid Society Loses Backlog Plea
description: A request by the Legal Aid Society in New York City to be relieved of accepting appeals cases for the next 18 months in order to deal with a mounting backlog was denied yesterday by two appeals justices.

title: WEINBERGER TELLS ARMY CADETS THEY STAND TALL
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger spoke to graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy today of a new national mood, one that he said would enable those who entered without the encourgement of their peers to graduate with the ''respect and envy of all Americans.''

title: Weinberger Europe-Bound
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will leave on Sunday for an eight-day trip to West Germany, Belgium and Norway, the Pentagon said today.

title: Yonkers Bonanza
description: When a fire forced the cancellation of harness racing at the Meadowlands Race Track in East Rutherford, N.J., on Tuesday night, several thousand fans apparently found an alternative. They took their betting dollars across the Hudson River to Yonkers Raceway.

title: WAYS OF CLEANING FURNITURE BRASSES
description: There may be no ordinary do-it-yourself chore where more results are apparent for less effort than in the face lifting of brass hardware on furniture.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, Air Controller
description: A fare of just $149 to fly from Newark to London? Travelers accustomed to paying $400 or $500 think of that as incredible. But People Express says it can provide no-frills flights across the Atlantic for less than half the regular coach fare, and still make a profit. The only thing stopping the innovative little airline is the British Government, which seems more interested in protecting its state-owned airline than in serving thrifty travelers.

title: GEORGE H. DONER
description: George H. Doner, general counsel, vice president and secretary of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, died Monday after surgery at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: Martin Named in Scuffle
description: A man who described himself as a fan of Billy Martin told police today that Martin had punched him in a bar early this morning, and that one of Martin's assistant coaches, identified as Dom Scala, had pummeled him.

title: U.S. OFFERING CITY PART OF FT. TOTTEN
description: The Federal Government has announced that it will give New York City 11 acres of property at historic Fort Totten in Queens. But if the city wants the remaining 32 acres of surplus fort property, it will have to buy them, the Government says.

title: FINANCE NEW ISSUES;
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. won the bidding to underwrite a $115 million issue of prior-lien revenue bonds for the City of Houston water system.

title: OFFICER IS FOUND GUILTY OF HITTING CUFFED PRISONER
description: A 38-year-old police officer was has been convicted of seconddegree assault for striking a handcuffed prisoner on the head with his nightstick in a Brooklyn station house.

title: NEW PARTS RAISE HOPE OF CUTTING DELAY FOR CENTER
description: Four companies have manufactured satisfactory replacements for defective structural components that have delayed construction of New York City's new Convention Center, officials of the center said yesterday.

title: Nigerian Debt Talks Hit Snags
description: Efforts to agree on a package to reschedule a portion of Nigeria's short-term debt burden bogged down today in a meeting here of European lenders.

title: Fetchick Shares Lead
description: Mike Fetchick, who at 60 is the oldest player in the 20th annual Dodge Open, shot a 4-under-par 68 today and moved into a tie for the lead at 139 with John Stoltz at the Rockaway River Country Club. Stoltz, the opening-round leader with a 67, had a par 72 for the 6,600-yard layout.

title: MORE SPACE FOR THE VICTORIA & ALBERT MUSEUM
description: Every time you turn your back in London, someone seems to have hatched, if not a completely new museum, then a new museum within an older one.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review Monday of Jack DeJohnette's Special Edition incorrectly identified a band member. The saxophone section included David Murray, Howard Johnson and John Purcell.

title: IRAQ PROPOSES ACCORD WITH IRAN TO BAN ATTACKS ON CIVILIANS
description: Iraq said today that it was ready to sign an agreement with Iran under United Nations auspices to ban attacks on border cities and civilian areas even if the war continues elsewhere.

title: CITIBANK, UNDER PRESSURE, ENDING LIMIT ON ACCESS TO TELLERS
description: Citibank said yesterday that it was abandoning a policy that prohibited most customers with less than $5,000 in their bank accounts from being served by tellers at certain branches.

title: Lionel to Sell Stake
description: The Lionel Corporation, which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since February 1982, said it had agreed to sell its 82 percent interest in Dale Electronics to the Acme-Cleveland Corporation for $43 million.

title: Cub Manager Penalized
description: Lee Elia, the Chicago Cubs' manager, who was ejected from a game against the Cincinnati Reds on Saturday after he slapped away an umpire's hand during an argument at home plate, has been fined an undisclosed amount and given a one-game suspension by the National League's president, Charles S. Feeney. Elia has appealed the suspension and will remain in the Cubs' dugout until Feeney hears the appeal next month.

title: CORRECTION
description: A roll-call listing from The Associated Press yesterday incorrectly reported the vote of Representative Claudine Schneider, Republican of Rhode Island, on funds for development of the MX missile. She voted no.

title: THE SEARCH FOR HERPES DRUGS
description: The United States pharmaceutical industry has mounted a huge effort to find treatments and possibly a cure for genital herpes, a venereal disease afflicting millions of Americans and spreading rapidly.

title: HERS
description: THE women's movement came along just in time for those of us in our 30's and 40's. For our mothers, now in their 50's and 60's, it came along too late - too late, at any rate, for most of them to take advantage of the new opportunities opening up to their daughters. However, a positive side effect of feminism, one rarely credited to the movement, has been its breach of a long, forbidding silence between mothers and daughters.

title: WHEN AND HOW TO STOP RACIST BROADCASTS
description: To the Editor:

title: VANCE AND BRZEZINSKI: FEUDING CHAPTER BY CHAPTER
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski and Cyrus R. Vance, whose personal and policy disputes were an open secret while they served as President Carter's chief foreign policy advisers, have revived their feud in a pair of candid memoirs that are fueling the gossip circuits among Washington's foreign affairs specialists.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUNDS TO RESTORE CAPITOL FACADE
description: Reversing its stand of previous years, the House voted overwhelmingly today to restore the central West Front of the Capitol rather than build an extension.

title: OF PROSPECTIVE JURORS AND THE LAWYERS WHO QUESTION THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION
description: The New Jersey Lottery Commission voted today to dismiss its advertising agency because of reputed business dealings between the agency's president and Commissioner Reese Palley before the latter was suspended.

title: Market Place; Speculators Back in Force
description: RECORD highs yesterday in the American Stock Exchange market-value index and the Nasdaq composite index clearly suggest that stock speculation by smaller investors is on the increase.

title: American Safety Razor Aiming at Men Again
description: The American Safety Razor Company, which has been putting its advertising efforts behind equipment for women in recent years, is returning to its interest in the razor-buying habits of menfolk and will be once again pushing its Personna line, which has not been advertised since about 1975.

title: African News Agency Sends Its First Article
description: The Pan African News Agency went into operation today, capping four years of work by African nations to set up a news service.

title: OIL LEASE BIDS IN GULF SET RECORD
description: Seventy-eight oil companies bid a record $3.47 billion today for the right to explore for oil and natural gas on tracts leased from the Federal Government in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: HATE-MONGERING TEACHER TESTS CANADA'S PATIENCE
description: If they believed what they were taught, high school students in this little speck of a town about 120 miles north of Calgary would think that the world is governed by an international Jewish conspiracy and that the Nazi horror never happened.

title: Dumping of Sludge In Ocean Assessed
description: Municipalities dumping sewage sludge in the ocean should use a site 106 miles off the Maryland-Delaware coast rather than a site 12 miles off New York City and northern New Jersey, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. Sergeant Sentenced In Athens Car Mishap
description: An American master sergeant was sentenced in absentia today to three years' imprisonment by an Athens court for injuring a Greek base employee last November as the sergeant tried to enter the United States air base in Athens.

title: Doctor Weighs His 'Junk Mail'
description: Dr. Roger A. Breslow, who has been practicing internal medicine in Utica, N.Y., these past 20 years, undertook a bit of advertising research for the full year of 1982. He saved his professional mail, which he unsportingly calls ''junk mail.''

title: HITLER FRAUD STIRS DEBATE ON LITERARY AGENTS' ROLE
description: Weeks before the story of the purported Hitler diaries became front-page news in America, the West German weekly magazine Stern asked a New York literary agent to sell the magazine and syndicate rights to an excerpt from the diaries.

title: Editor of Monitor Is Named
description: Katherine W. Fanning, editor and publisher of The Anchorage Daily News, was named today to be editor of The Christian Science Monitor. The newspaper's board of directors also promoted Earl W. Foell from editor to editor in chief and said he would write a regular column for the 75-year-old newspaper, which circulates daily throughout North America and weekly overseas. Mrs. Fanning, whose Alaskan paper won a Pulitzer Prize in 1976, will direct a staff of more than 150 journalists.

title: U.S.-CHINA INVESTMENT TALKS
description: The United States will open negotiations in Peking next Wednesday on a treaty establishing rules for settling disputes, repatriating earnings and other activities related to investments between the two countries.

title: Don't Bail Out Whoops
description: ''Whoops'' is what people call the Washington Public Power Supply System, and not only because that's abbreviated W.P.P.S.S. This consortium of municipal electric utilities in the Pacific Northwest is on the verge of defaulting on $2.25 billion in debts, creating a bankruptcy that could rock the national bond markets. Whoops wants someone else - preferably Federal taxpayers - to pick up the tab for two nuclear plants, partly built and recently abandoned.

title: GEORGE S. STEPHENSON
description: George Storer Stephenson, retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, died of cancer Tuesday in the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 79 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: SOME BOOKS THAT PROVIDE ORIGINAL VIEWS AND PARTICULARS
description: Reprints of Victorian architectural books that give exact specifications and details of the originals are often helpful in renovating a period house. A selection from the offerings of several publishers follows.

title: HOME BEAT
description: ACCORDING to Rudi Stern, standing at right, the moving force behind Let There Be Neon, a neon lighting gallery in SoHo, the new collection of lamps that he developed with Dan Chelsea, far right, explores the combination of neon with other light sources. ''We wanted to see if there was compatability between neon, which is considered decorative, and halogen, incandescent or fluorescent lighting, which is thought of as more functional,'' Mr. Stern said.

title: CONCERT POMERIUM MUSICES PERFORMS JOSQUIN
description: THE Pomerium Musices concert Tuesday night at the Abraham Goodman House was actually a big concert followed by a separate little concert, and each was noteworthy in its own way.

title: A Newcomer Is Named President of Pantasote
description: Pantasote Inc., where changes at the top have been few, brought a new face into its management yesterday. Edmund H. Damon, who joined Pantasote's board last December, was named president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Henry H. Wyman, who has been with Pantasote 40 years and president for 23. Mr. Wyman, 64, becomes chairman and in turn succeeds James H. Goss, 75, who has reached the company's mandatory retirement age for directors. Mr. Goss, who had been chairman since 1973, will be chairman emeritus.

title: Phone Service Subsidy Plan
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, said today that concerns about rising telephone bills had prompted him to introduce legislation to continue some form of subsidization of local phone charges after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company divests itself of its local phone companies.

title: Nicaraguan Loan Talks
description: A committee of Nicaragua's chief foreign bank creditors will meet early next month to discuss a Nicaraguan request to reschedule more than $100 million in loans falling due soon, West German banking sources said today.

title: New Kodak Film
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has introduced an instant color film that produces prints that can be peeled off their stiff backing for easier storage and handling. The Kodamatic Trimprint film, scheduled to be available in September, will have a list price of $10.95 for 10 exposures, the same as Kodak's conventional instant color film, the company said.

title: Braves Get 7 Straight Walks
description: Craig McMurtry, a rookie, tossed a threehitter and the Atlanta Braves received seven straight walks in the third inning to tie a 74-year-old major-league record tonight in posting a 6-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: DOZENS ARE SWEPT TO SEA BY WAVE AFTER QUAKE HITS NORTHERN JAPAN
description: A major earthquake struck northern Japan this morning, causing a huge sea wave that swept dozens of people, including elementary schoolchildren, into the Sea of Japan.

title: New State Bottle Law Deferred Till Sept. 12
description: The Legislature voted today to delay until September key provisions of the state law requiring a 5-cent deposit on beer and soda containers sold in New York State.

title: LEBANON
description: An Israeli military spokesman said today that Syrian fighter planes had fired two air-to-air missiles at Israeli reconnaissance planes flying over Lebanon but had missed. The incident was the first aerial encounter since the war last summer.

title: Victory Is Claimed By Louisiana Land
description: The management of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company said today that it had won a proxy battle allowing it to retain control of the New Orleans-based oil concern.

title: CRAFT WORKSHOPS BEGINNING IN JUNE
description: The following craft workshops and classes will be offered in New York beginning next month. Woodworking

title: Staying Young
description: It was billed as ''Age in Action,'' an outdoor festival for the elderly at Lincoln Center yesterday.

title: BOLD FASHIONS BY THE JAPANESE ARE SUCCESSFUL IN CITY'S STORES
description: JENNIFER RUGAVICH stood in front of a three-sided mirror at Bloomingdale's, gazed at three images of her dancer's body wearing a Rei Kawakubo black coat, then jumped and watched all three jump back. ''Good God!'' she said, en pointe. ''I look like a pregnant tent!''

title: U.S. ADVISERS IN SALVADOR: A DELICATE MISSION
description: Every morning at military headquarters the Chief of Staff sits down with his officers in a room ringed with large maps to discuss war strategy. Four United States Army officers are at the same table.

title: Suggestions on Improving the Games
description: The race-track clock was stuck at 24 minutes to post time. I was convinced of it. I looked up, I looked down, I took a sip of coffee, I glanced at the newspaper, and it was still 24 minutes to post time.

title: Peruvian Army Sent Out As Civil Guards Strike
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry ordered a three-day state of emergency in Lima and the adjoining port of Callao today because of a strike by paramilitary civil guards.

title: 'A BLUEPRINT FOR MASS MISERY'
description: To the Editor:

title: ORCHIDS ON DISPLAY IN BOTANICAL GARDEN
description: Nearly 3,500 orchids are on display at the New York Botanical Garden, in an effulgence of color, shape and texture. This is the second year for the show, which is becoming known among orchid growers as a major one. It will continue through Sunday.

title: DISCOVERY OF MERCURY CONTAMINATION PROMPTS DISPUTE IN OAK RIDGE, TENN.
description: ''It's a miracle city,'' said Mayor Alvin K. Bissell. ''It's an aberration,'' said Steve Gough. It is not surprising that the two men hold contrasting views of this town, which was started from scratch in 1943 and run for many years by the Federal Government as a weapons research and parts production facility. Partly as a result of Mr. Gough's suspicions and his surreptitious tests, Mr. Bissell's ''miracle city'' in the Cumberland foothills has become the center of a controversy over huge mercury spills.

title: Japan's Car Output Off
description: Japan produced 938,495 vehicles in April, down seven-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. Association officials attributed the decline to slower sales both in Japan and abroad.

title: 2 Bodies Back Bill To Reopen Calder
description: The Florida House and Senate approved today different versions of an emergency bill that would get Calder Race Course in Miami back in business. The passage came as Calder's betting windows, which usually collect $800,000 daily, stood empty as a result of a protest by trainers, who were refusing to enter their horses.

title: 100th Birthday: A Glance Back
description: It was the Day After and time to clean up - and tally up. The litter along the Brooklyn Bridge Parade route and in the nighttime celebration areas came to 105 tons.

title: POP VOCALIST: VIC DAMONE
description: VIC DAMONE poses a problem for himself by allowing his musical director and pianist, Norman Geller, and the three other musicians who back him at Marty's - Don DeMarco, guitar, Jim DiGuilio, bass, and Joe Cocuzzo, drums - to have a number to themselves before he makes his entrance.

title: Funds to Repair Sandy Hook Road
description: About $700,000 to repair a wave-ravaged Sandy Hook, N.J., road through the Gateway National Recreation Area was included in the 1983 supplemental appropriations bill approved this evening by the House of the Representatives.

title: Strike Shuts Louvre And Jeu de Paume
description: Guards went on strike today at the Louvre and Jeu de Paume, forcing authorities to close the two art museums. The guards stopped work to support colleagues from French overseas departments and territories who are protesting the Government's costcutting decision to stop paying living allowances and for workers' flights home.

title: U.S. IS CONSIDERING QUARANTINE ON TEXAS CATTLE
description: Unless the Texas Legislature moves quickly to control a contagious cattle disease that causes cows to abort their unborn calves, the Federal Government plans to impose a quarantine on the shipment of Texas cattle out of state.

title: THEATER: 'THE OXCART,' BY PUERTO RICAN TROUPE
description: FIFTEEN years ago the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater began its life with a production of Rene Marques's ''The Oxcart'' (La Carreta). Since then, under the leadership of its founder, Miriam Colon Edgar, the company has become one of the city's theatrical adornments. For its final production of the current season, the troupe is presenting a revival of Mr. Marques's play. Although the work retains its place as a social and historical document, its dramatic impact has lessened.

title: Clippers Deny Interest in Albeck
description: Scratch Stan Albeck from the list of prospects to coach the San Diego Clippers of the National Basketball Association. A Clippers official said yesterday that they will introduce their head coach next Wednesday, and that Albeck, the San Antonio coach, who is reported to be at the top of the Nets' list of candidates, will not be the choice.

title: Daring A's Squeeze In Deciding Run
description: Since Steve Boros began his career as a major league manager this season he has learned that words of T.S. Eliot, studied while he was earning a bachelor's degree in literature at the University of Michigan, are not necessarily so. Boros has found that Eliot's words - ''Indeed, there will be time to wonder 'Do I dare?' and 'Do I dare?' '' - has no application to baseball.

title: Coke Settles Suit
description: The Coca-Cola Company, which had filed suit to prevent Procter & Gamble from acquiring the stock of the Coca-Cola Bottling Mideast Inc. franchise in Kentucky for $62 million, announced it had settled the suit and approved P.& G. as the owner of the bottling company's stock under terms that ''permit a constructive future working relationship.''

title: Technology; Video/Phone Conferences
description: REMEMBER the Picturephone? Something like it is on the way back. The Picturephone, with which one could see as well as hear the person at the other end of the line, was a big hit at the 1964 World's Fair and a big flop in the marketplace. Since then, a somewhat similar idea has reappeared in the guise of ''video teleconferencing,'' in which people in one city gather in a special room and have televised meetings with people in other cities.

title: Armco Ends Talks
description: Armco Inc. said it had ended discussions with the Arch Mineral Corporation of St. Louis for the sale of substantially all of Armco's West Virginia coal properties. Armco said the original letter of intent called for an Arch subsidiary to purchase 640 million tons of metallurgical and steam coal reserves, together with operating facilities, for about $320 million. Armco said it would explore a joint venture of its coal properties with one or more parties.

title: Accounts
description: * Institutional Investor magazine to Bloom & Gelb Inc.

title: POLICE SUSPEND 5 FACING CHARGES OF ILLEGAL PAYOFF
description: Five police officers assigned to the 10th Precinct in Manhattan have been suspended on charges that they accepted part of an illegal payoff from their radio-car partner, the Police Department said yesterday. Three were accused of taking $25 each, and two of taking $37.50 apiece.

title: Kohl Cautions Moscow On How to Ease Strains
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, addressing a convention of the Christian Democratic Party, warned the Soviet Union today that progress toward better ties with Bonn could only come in exchange for ''more humanity and less confrontation.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Police Blotter
description: An unidentified man plunged to his death from the center of the of the top level of the George Washington Bridge shortly after 11 A.M. yesterday. The body was recovered by a private boat. ... Ronald Wert, a 25-year-old off-duty police officer, shot himself in the chest shortly after 12:30 A.M. yesterday while a fellow officer was trying to talk him out of jumping off a seventh-floor ledge of a Pace University building in lower Manhattan.

title: BILLY SMITH AND HEDBERG PLAN TO BE BACK
description: Carol Vadnais returned to the Rangers yesterday, as an assistant coach, and Anders Hedberg said he planned to return as a player. And across town, the Islander goalie Billy Smith said he was sure he would return to play with the Stanley Cup champions.

title: DEPUTY CHIEF OF U.S. MILITARY UNIT IS SHOT AND KILLED IN SAN SALVADOR
description: The deputy commander of the United States Military Group in El Salvador was shot and killed here today. The officer, Cmdr. Albert A. Schaufelberger of the Navy, was shot four times in the head outside the University of Central America, according to Col. John A. Cash, the defense attache.

title: Askew Urges Labor to Delay Endorsement of Candidates
description: Reubin Askew, a former Governor of Florida who is one of six announced candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, told members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council today that their plan to endorse a candidate before the primaries could be ''counterproductive.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The MX debate would have provided a veritable gold mine for Orwell, were he here with us today, poised on the edge of the abyss.

title: WHEN AND HOW TO STOP RACIST BROADCASTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Resales At 2-Year High
description: Resales of existing houses inched up 1.5 percent during April, hitting their highest level in more than two years, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: BEWARE BANANA SKINS
description: The Conservatives of Britain have an audacious strategy to pulverize the far left and thereby reshape the political landscape. If they succeed, the election here on June 9 will be a warning to America's Democrats not to flirt with head-in-the-sand ultraliberals in U.S. elections in 1984.

title: Vanet Advertising Gets Jersey Lottery Account
description: Vanet Advertising of Union, N.J., and New York is the new agency for the New Jersey Lottery, which will be spending $5 million on advertising over the next two years. The previous agency was Keyes-Martin in Springfield. Seven agencies were in the running, including one each in New York and Philadelphia.

title: The U.N. Today; May 26, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: FIRE OFFICIALS BATTLE TRAFFIC ON THE STREETS OF MANHATTAN
description: It has never been more difficult for fire trucks to get through Manhattan traffic, and that has led to increased property losses and perhaps one recent death, fire officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANIES THAT OFFER MAIL-ORDER COPIES
description: Here is a sampling of companies that specialize in mail-order reproductions of Victorian architectural details. For a more comprehensive listing see the Old-House Catalog, available by sending $11.95 to The Old-House Journal, 69A Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217. Millwork Ornaments Cumberland Woodcraft Company, Drawer 609, Carlisle, Pa. 17013; 717-243-0063.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS SEEN AS HELPING BUDGET CONFEREES
description: The improving economy is likely to mean extra billions of dollars in prospective revenue for the 1984 fiscal year, easing the task of House-Senate conferees when they try to write a Congressional budget resolution next month, according to staff aides.

title: A HANDGUN MEASURE LOST TO 'BIG BUCKS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Settlement in Hughes Estate
description: The estate of Howard Hughes has settled with Terry Moore, the actress who contended she was married to the reclusive millionaire and thus was due consideration from his estate, spokesmen for both sides say. The amount of the settlement was not disclosed. Miss Moore, who is 54 years old, said the amount was ''not more than eight figures,'' but Wayne Fisher, attorney for two Hughes heirs, said it was ''substantially less than eight figures.''

title: OF PROSPECTIVE JURORS AND THE LAWYERS WHO QUESTION THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Blues and Fluke Are Plentiful
description: 1 Margate, N.J.: Small bluefish, 2 to 5 pounds, plentiful offshore five miles; fluke fishing excellent in interior waters. Barnegat, N.J.: Plenty of good-sized summer flounder in Barnegat Bay. Party boats will begin offshore trips this weekend. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Flounder plentiful in bay waters. A few small bluefish off shore. 2 Sea Bright N.J.: A short while ago, anglers began catching blackfish, some weighing 5 pounds and more, all along the shore from Sea Bright to Long Branch. Small bluefish are in Sandy Hook Bay and a few larger ones have been taken farther off shore by bottom fishermen. Sheepshead Bay, N.Y.: Small bluefish being taken by deep jigging near Ambrose Light Tower; party boats are doing well on fluke and sea bass, and flounder are still about. Freeport, L.I.: Some large mackerel continue to be caught off shore; blackfishing over wrecks is good; a few large bluefish have showed up off shore and smaller ones are inshore. Big fluke and flounder are being caught in and around Jones Inlet. Captree State Park, L.I.: Good-sized fluke are in Fire Island Inlet; small bluefish have arrived. 3 Mastic Beach, L.I.: Small weakfish have appeared; flounder are still around and fluke fishing is good. Blue crabs are plentiful and area experts predict a splendid year for them. Montauk, L.I.: Small bluefish are in Gardiners Bay; mackerel are scarce in the bay but are still being caught off shore. Flounder continue to be taken and the first angler-caught porgies and sea bass of the year have been goodsized.

title: 'JEDI' SETS SALES RECORDS ON FIRST DAY'S SHOWING
description: More than one-and-a-half million people saw Lucasfilm's ''Return of the Jedi'' Wednesday, as the third movie in George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' trilogy apparently set box-office records across the country.

title: Saudi Oil Production
description: Saudi Arabia's crude oil production has for some time ranged between 4 million and 5 million barrels a day, Ahmad Abdullatif, deputy governor of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, said here today.

title: Energy Unit Mounts Nuclear Safety Drive
description: The United States Committee for Energy Awareness is a Washingtonbased organization founded after the Three Mile Island accident and it is going to mount a major television campaign to persuade the American people that nuclear energy is economical and safe.

title: GEORGE BRUNS
description: George Bruns, director of music for Walt Disney Productions, died Monday of a heart attack in a Portland hospital.

title: Productivity Rises 8.3%
description: The productivity of American factory workers rose 8.3 percent in the first quarter, an even stronger advance in productivity than originally reported last month, the Labor Department said today.

title: Advertising; A New Gift, By Phone: Liquor
description: IF long-distance gift giving of flowers and candy can easily be accomplished, why not alcoholic beverages? Well, there are the different laws in each state that could cause difficulty. But they can be accommodated, as a venture by John D. Angleman shows. His company, 800 Spirits of Hackensack, N.J., is finally going into test market in Washington, just in time for Father's Day.

title: RUTGERS TO STIFFEN STANDARDS IN MATH AND ENGLISH
description: Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University, told graduates today that incoming students would henceforth be required to show specified competence in mathematics and English.

title: Ski Area Accused Of Wrongdoing
description: The State Commission of Investigation said today that it had documented ''marked evidence of wrongdoing'' by operators of the Vernon Valley-Great Gorge ski resort and recommended that the state revoke the lease the resort holds on the property.

title: Loss Widens at Renault
description: France's state-owned Renault auto company said yesterday that it had lost 1.28 billion francs, or about $173.2 million, last year, nearly twice its 675 million franc loss in 1981.

title: Not Even Symbolism on Civil Rights
description: All the dither about the United States Commission on Civil Rights makes it sound like a powerful giant. It's not. It's a fact-finding agency, more terrier than behemoth - alert and useful, but more bark than bite. It's important most of all as a symbol of devotion to minority progress.

title: DAGARS OF DELHI, A TRADITION LIVES ON
description: Compared with the Dagars of New Delhi, J.S. Bach and his family were a flash in the pan. The Dagar family, whose current scions Zahiruddin and Faiyazuddin are performing tonight at the Alternative Museum in TriBeCa, had a 100-year head start on the Bachs.

title: INDIAN PT. UNIT SAYS RISK DOESN'T JUSTIFY CLOSING
description: The president of the New York Power Authority said today that the risk posed by the Indian Point nuclear plants in Westchester County was so small that the reactors should be allowed to operate despite questions about emergency planning.

title: NEW BOMB BLAST IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A bomb blew up under a parked car here during lunch hour today, causing damage but no casualties.

title: WHEN DEFENSE PLANNERS' SOLE TRUMP IS NUCLEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: PEERLESS RUG LTD reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: 10 People Injured In 2-Car Accident
description: Ten people, seven of them children, were injured at 8:20 A.M. yesterday in an auto accident in the Inwood section of Manhattan, according to the police, who said one of the drivers was drunk.

title: ART: THOUGHTS OF SPRING AND GRAND TOUR VIEWS
description: THIS is the season of spring migrations, human and other. At no time is the thought of Venice and Rome more seductive, or the pull of the great 18th-century view painters more widely felt. An exhibition called ''Views From the Grand Tour'' is well timed, therefore, and Colnaghi's, at 26 East 80th Street, is out to stir the vagrant imagination with an exhibition of 18th-century views of Italy by Canaletto, Guardi, Marieschi and others. (It can be seen through June 30, by the way.)

title: Ballard's Plan for Blues
description: Harold Ballard, the owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, said he would propose that the National Hockey League buy and operate the St. Louis Blues as a way of resolving a lawsuit against the league for blocking the transfer of the Blues to Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. ''I am going to suggest that we buy the club,'' said Ballard, who led the league's move to block the sale of the Blues to a group of Canadian investors by the Ralston Purina Company.

title: For Holiday Weather
description: News of weather conditions for the Memorial Day weekend anywhere in the world may be obtained by calling the Channel 2 Holiday Hotline at 955-9300. The service will be in operation daily from 8 A.M. to 9 P.M. through Monday. It is headed by Irving Gikovsky, the station's weatherman.

title: SUMMIT CHALLENGE
