description: When the leaders of the industrialized democracies meet at Williamsburg, Va., this weekend, their agenda should include a discussion of the economic problems of the non-OPEC developing countries. They should agree on a course of action to address those problems, which are of direct interest to the United States and the other industrialized countries.

title: New Claims by Jobless For Benefits Off 30,000
description: About 453,000 Americans filed first-time claims for unemployment benefits in mid-May, the lowest level since September 1981, the Labor Department said today.

title: SOVIET CREWS WALK OFF U.S. EMBASSY JOB
description: Efforts to check the walls of the new United States Embassy here for electronic listening devices have precipitated a walkout by Soviet construction crews, bringing the $120 million project to a halt.

title: McCormick Plan
description: The McCormick Oil and Gas Company said it intended to submit to its shareholders a plan of reorganization that would result in its liquidation. The company said that after liquidation substantially all of its oil and natural gas properties and related liabilities would be transferred to a newly organized limited partnership, and shareholders would receive interests in the partnership. McCormick said the partnership interests would be publicly traded.

title: Soviet Broadcaster Ousted
description: Soviet sources said today that Vladimir Danchev, the Radio Moscow news announcer who twice in six days described Soviet troops in Afghanistan as an occupying force, had been dismissed and was under investigation. They said Mr. Danchev, 35 years old, opposed the Soviet role in the Afghan war and hoped by his action to increase pressure for the troops to be withdrawn.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE cool, lithe strains of modern Latvian jazz wafted through the Public Theater on Lafayette Street Monday evening, shortly before a party for hundreds of Soviet musicians and fans, as well as A merican devotees of Soviet jazz. They broke black bread and shared g enerous portions of vodka and caviar.

title: G & H STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Charge Reinstated Against Fiumara
description: A state appeals court today reinstated an indictment that charged Tino Fiumara, a reputed organized-crime leader, with conspiring to control the garbage industry in nine counties in northern New Jersey.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ohio Road Bonds Yield 5.5% to 7.9%
description: A $50 million State of Ohio Highway Obligation Bond issue was priced by Bankers Trust yesterday to offer yields ranging from 5.5 percent to 7.9 percent.

title: CONDOMINIUM EFFORT STARTED BY DEVELOPER AT PARK WEST VILLAGE
description: A major developer in New York City has begun efforts to convert to condominiums part of the Park West Village development on the Upper West Side. The apartment complex was originally built as a slumclearance project for moderate-income families.

title: Article 194189 -- No Title
description: Caesars World Inc., citing the impact of a provision for additional reserves of about $15 million for certain past-due casino account receivables, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $14.3 million in the third fiscal quarter ended April 30.

title: Jury Acquits Policeman In Miami Black's Slaying
description: A Metro Dade County police officer was found not guilty tonight of killing a county corrections officer last October. A six-member all-white jury deliberated 90 minutes before acquitting Officer Thomas Pellechio, who is white, of manslaughter in connection with the death of Ernest Kirkland, who is black.

title: FILM: LOSEY'S 'TROUT'
description: ''The Trout'' was shown at the New York Film Festival in 1982 at Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin that appeared in The New York Times on Nov. 1, 1982. The film opens today at the Baronet Theater, Third Avenue at 59th Street.

title: Inspections to End On the New Haven
description: Time-consuming wheel inspections of commuter trains between New Haven and New York will be halted Tuesday, officials said today.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $21,000 for the latest quarter and $609,000 for the year-ago period. Year-ago figures were restated for the discontinuance of the Metal Alloying and Extruding business.

title: MUSIC: NEW TO THE CITY
description: CONCEPTUALLY, the ''Music New to New York'' concert Wednesday night at the Abraham Goodman House was a complete mess. Musically, things went much better. And when it comes to concerts, music counts for more.

title: MONGOLIA REPORTEDLY OUSTS THOUSANDS OF CHINESE
description: Thousands of Chinese are reportedly being expelled from Mongolia after refusing orders from the pro-Soviet Government there to move to the Gobi Desert or leave the country.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE piano is the only musical instrument that genuinely approximates an orchestra. Its player commands a broad range of dynamics and textures, enjoying more harmonic choices than players of other instruments, up to 10 notes at a time. Classical composers have systematically explored the piano's resources, but they also had the option of writing for full orchestra. Most American vernacular musicians have not had that choice. In jazz, blues, Latin and other vernacular idioms, the piano is the only orchestra available. And it is an orchestra if the right player is at the keyboard.

title: HARNISCHFEGER COR. reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
REDUCING LAWYERS FEES
description: The wallets of public-interest lawyers may soon start growing thinner. In its decision in Hensley v. Eckerhart last week, the United States Supreme Court signaled how far judges should go to encourage lawyers to bring lawsuits. It ruled that when a court orders losers to pay the attorneys' fees of winners, the extent of a plaintiff's success is a crucial factor in determining the amount of the award. As a result, the hours spent on unsuccessful claims will be excluded when a fee award is set.

title: NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO'S SADDEST STORY IS ITS OWN
description: The most recent assignment for Scott Simon, a correspondent for National Public Radio, has been the melancholy one of reporting on the finanical crisis at National Public Radio.

title: PUPILS CONTINUE ABOVE AVERAGE IN EXAM SCORES
description: Children in New York City's public schools are continuing to perform above national norms on reading and mathematics tests, according to statistics released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Turks Are Said to Move 20 Miles Onto Iraqi Soil
description: Two brigades of Turkish troops advanced about 20 miles into Iraqi territory today across the border between the two countries, official sources here said.

title: Nigerian Debt Proposal
description: Nigeria's creditor banks will be asked to approve by June 3 a plan to convert about $1.5 billion of Nigeria's debt arrears into a three-year loan, Barclays Bank International said today.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: 1982 figures were restated.

title: New Medical Center Wins Approval
description: ''They have a holistic component in this with no urging from me at all - they've seen the light,'' William J. Stern, head of the State Urban Development Corporation, said with a smile yesterday.

title: BIFLYX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a gain from sale of assets of $217,127.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Movie Lines and the G.N.P.
description: There's a quiet experiment under way in New York that might make all America grateful, and doubly so. It seems to show that moviegoing can be made civilized again. It may also be helping to end the recession.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Burlington Northern Inc.'s $50 million issue of equipment trust certificates was priced at par, yielding 9.65 percent to 11.30 percent at maturities from 1984 to 1998, through Salomon Brothers Inc.; each maturity includes about $3.3 million of securities. The certificates are rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service, and AA by Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: HURRICANE PREDICTIONS WILL ADD PROBABILITIES
description: During periods of hurricane danger this year, the National Weather Service will issue the mathematical probability of a storm striking a given area, officials of the service said in New York yesterday.

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
THE BALLET: TWO CASTS IN 'SYLPHIDE'
description: SCENICALLY, American Ballet Theater's new production of August Bournonville's ''La Sylphide'' may be unusually, even unnecessarily, elaborate. But dramatically, this revival supervised by Erik Bruhn is simplicity itself. The conflict between good and evil is compellingly presented and the production is free of some of the extraneous details in staging and the blatant reorchestration of Hermann von Lovenskjold's score that marred Mr. Bruhn's last production of this Danish classic.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joan Benoit, the world-record holder in the women's marathon, has withdrawn from the 11th annual L'eggs Mini 10-kilometer race in Central Park on Saturday, leaving Grete Waitz, the four-time champion, without a serious challenger. ... Seve Ballesteros, the 1982 Masters champion who plays most of his golf in Europe, has entered next month's Westchester Classic. ... Mancil Davis, the golf professional at the Woodlands Inn and Country Club in Houston, got a hole-in-one yesterday. The ace, on the club's west course, was the 44th for Davis, who holds the professional record for holes-in-one. ... Gerry Cooney, who has been troubled by a painful swollen knuckle on his left hand, was told by doctors that the condition was not serious and would not affect his June 18 bout with Philip Brown. ... Turner Gill, Nebraska's quarterback, said he would stay in school for his senior year rather than play professional baseball. ... Jaime Garza and Bobby Berna will fight for the vacant World Boxing Council superbantamweight title in Los Angeles on June 15. ... Dave Taylor, a right wing for the Los Angeles Kings, will have surgery Saturday to repair a broken bone in his right wrist. He broke it last October but reinjured it last month while playing for Team Canada.

title: STAGE: 'FOOL FOR LOVE,' SAM SHEPARD WESTERN
description: NO one knows better than Sam Shepard that the true American West is gone forever, but there may be no writer alive more gifted at reinventing it out of pure literary air. Like so many Shepard plays, ''Fool for Love,'' at the Circle Repertory Company, is a western for our time. We watch a pair of figurative gunslingers fight to the finish - not with bullets, but with piercing words that give ballast to the weight of a nation's buried dreams.

title: MEDICAL OFFICE 'PHONY,' RATHER TELLS COAST JURY
description: Dan Rather testified today that when he went to a California medical clinic three years ago with cameras rolling to investigate insurance fraud for ''60 Minutes,'' there wasn't a doubt in his mind it was Dr. Carl A. Galloway's office and ''phony from one end to the other.''

title: A big week in Americana.
description: AMERICAN art valued at $10 million will be up for bidding next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet in what the auction house calls one of the most important and diverse sales of American painting ever. The auction is one of four sales of Americana next week at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips, three concentrating on art, and one on period furniture and the decorative arts.

title: Sikorsky to Pay $6 Million in Suit
description: Sikorsky Aircraft has ended a legal battle with New York Airways, agreeing in an out-of-court settlement to pay the bankrupt commuter airline $6 million compensation for two fatal helicopter crashes in the late 1970's.

title: Ernest Saunders, an Engineer And a Writer on Black History
description: Ernest Saunders, an engineer who founded the Connecticut Afro-American Historical Society and wrote books on black history, died Tuesday at his home in New Haven. He was 82 years old.

title: CONCEPT RESOURCES reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a special gain of $139,000.

title: Pratt & Whitney To Trim 2,200 Jobs
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft said today that it was cutting its work force by about 2,200 employees. The maker of jet engines said about 1,800 workers would be laid off June 3.

title: STEEL LEADERS ASSAIL U.S. STEEL PLAN
description: The annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, normally a chummy spring rite for hundreds of the nation's top steel executives, will be remembered this year for its undertone of fractiousness.

title: Friday; CALVIN HAMPTON FAREWELL
description: Calvin Hampton will give the last of a 13-year-series of free midnight concerts at Calvary Church, Park Avenue South and 21st Street, tonight. Mr. Hampton, who has been Calvary's choir director for 20 years, is ending his affiliation with the church to concentrate on composing and concertizing. One of his specialties is transposing orchestral works for the organ. In tonight's concert, he will play his version of Moussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' - written originally for piano. Also on his program is Mozart's F minor Fantasy. A BROADWAY REOPENING

title: HOLMES, D H, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Net income figures include gain on sale of property of $111,000 for the latest quarter and $62,000 for the year- ago period. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid June 1.

title: Required Reading; Selling the Bridge
description: Colloquy in the House between Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx, and Representative Harold L. Volkmer, Democrat of Missouri, before passage of a resolution to designate May 24 Brooklyn Bridge Day, April 26, 1983:

title: SIERRA PACIFIC POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The earnings for both year-ago periods have been restated as the result of an order issued by the Public Service Commission of Nevada.

title: NURSE INDICTED IN DEATH OF BABY NEAR SAN ANTONIO
description: A licensed vocational nurse has been indicted in Kerr County on two counts of murder in connection with the death of a 15-month-old girl last year.

title: UNITOG CO reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
ART: BROOKLYN BRIDGE UNVEILS ITS OWN GALLERY
description: TALK about alternative spaces! The 100th birthday of the Brooklyn Bridge has brought about the most dazzling of them all, an exhibition and performance area that is part of the bridge itself. Known as the anchorage, it's the massive masonry structure in whose piers the cables are fastened on the Brooklyn shore of the span.

title: 'BIG BIRD' ON GREAT WALL
description: THE award for most charming offering of the weekend has to go to ''Big Bird in China,'' a 90-minute special on Channel 4 Sunday at 7 P.M. Big Bird is the eight-foot-tall ''Sesame Street'' character who looks like a flustered and somewhat goofy barnyard character, but is really the world's biggest child - loving, trusting, gentle and unfailingly thoughtful. On this outing, co-sponsored by China Central Television and a United States production company, Big Bird and some of Jim Henson's other Muppets get to visit China.

title: Kay Gable, 65, Is Dead; Mother of Film Star's Son
description: Kay Gable, widow of the movie star Clark Gable and mother of his only son, died late Wednesday following a lengthy illness.

title: A COURT BRANCH IN WHITE PLAINS GIVEN APPROVAL
description: Congressional action has cleared the way for creation of a branch of Federal District Court in the center of this Westchester County city, Federal and city officials said today.

title: JAZZ: SAM RIVERS QUARTET
description: THE Sam Rivers Quartet that is appearing through Saturday at Sweet Basil shares a few habits with Mr. Rivers's previous small groups. Like them, it plays long, uninterrupted, eclectic sets - about 75 minutes in its opener on Tuesday - in which Mr. Rivers moves from tenor saxophone to soprano saxophone to piano to flute.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Chrysler Said to Hire Hertz Marketing Expert
description: Bennett E. Bidwell gave up selling Ford cars for a while to try the rental business with Hertz. Now he is going back to selling cars, according to industry sources, but with the Chrysler Corporation, not the Ford Motor Company.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
A Master's Touch
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the N.B.A., was credited yesterday with having headed off a possible referee's strike during the playoffs by resolving several union-management disputes in a five-and-a-half-hour meeting with union reprentatives on Wednesdsay. ''There was a serious chance that if O'Brien had not stepped in, there would have been a work stoppage for the rest of the playoffs,'' said Richie Phillips, general counsel for the National Association of Basketball Referees.

title: 7-Elevens to Get Banking Machines
description: Automatic banking machines will be installed at about 200 7-Eleven stores in Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware under terms of an agreement announced between Girard Services Inc. and the Southland Corporation of Dallas, which owns 7-Eleven stores.

title: TOBACCO GROWERS FEAR LAW AND MARKET CHANGE
description: For as long as anyone in Wolfe County remembers, the two sure things in life have been that the Red River rises in the spring and the tobacco crop pays the debts in the fall.

title: New Home for Rare Books
description: The tea-table cloth is pristinely white but plastic. The chairs are modern, red and white striped. But the White Rabbit is there and Alice in pictures hangs on the walls.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 27, 1983
description: International

title: DIVERS FIND OLD SHIP INTACT IN THE ARCTIC
description: Divers reached a 19th-century shipwreck 340 feet beneath the Arctic Ocean ice last month and one said today that the vessel ''looked like you could sail it away.''

title: Rags of the Rich, Rags of the Poor
description: ''At Bloomie's, the rich can get dressed up just like the poor,'' shouted Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore, who works with a Union Theological Seminary soup kitchen and a shelter for the homeless, as he led a handful of demonstrators outside Bloomingdale's yesterday.

title: ADVERTISING
description: An increasing number of people say they are not subscribing to cable television because they do not want their children exposed to some of the programming, according to a survey by Benton & Bowles. Some 33 percent of the 4,000 people on a consumer panel who do not have cable gave that reason for not having it, compared with 25 percent two years ago.

title: Tractor Deal By Mitsubishi
description: The Mitsubishi Agricultural Machinery Company said it had agreed in principle to a request from the International Harvester Company for supplies of 30- to 40-horsepower small farm tractors for sale in North America.

title: E.P.A. Coast Official Resigns After Meeting
description: Sonia Crow, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency's San Francisco regional office, resigned late today after two days of confusion over her status, the agency said.

title: Toll Is Now 194 In Nile Sinking
description: Egyptian officials said today that at least 194 people were known dead in a fire on a Nile River steamer in southern Egypt, and that there was ''little or no hope'' that 108 missing people would be found alive.

title: Heep's Father Dies
description: Danny Heep, the leading hitter on the Mets at .313, did not accompany the team to San Diego for the weekend series with the Padres. Instead, he flew home to San Antonio for the funeral of his father, Jake Heep, who died during the night of a heart attack at the age of 60. The Mets said Heep might not rejoin them until Monday in San Francisco.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES MOVES TO CONTROL RATE OF EXCHANGE
description: President Reagan, indirectly rebuffing President Francois Mitterrand's proposal for stabilizing exchange rates, said today that the answer to the instability lies in general economic recovery and in conquering inflation.

title: 43 KILLED, 59 LOST IN JAPAN SEA WAVE
description: At least 43 people were killed and 59 were missing and presumed dead today after earthquake-induced waves pummeled a long stretch of Japan's western coast.

title: N.A.A.C.P. DIRECTOR IS REINSTATED AFTER PRESSURE BY BOARD MEMBERS
description: The chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People reinstated Benjamin L. Hooks as executive director yesterday, eight days after she suspended him.

title: MANNESMANN IN TALKS ON SOVIET COAL PROJECT
description: Mannesmann A.G., a maker of steel products, said today that it was holding talks with the Soviet Union on the sale of strip-mining and coal-processing equipment to develop huge reserves in southern Siberia.

title: Bridge: Eastern Regional to Begin; At New York Hilton Today
description: The country's oldest tournament, the Eastern Regional Championships, begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel. The schedule is: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; newcomers' pairs, 8 P.M.; speedball Swiss teams, midnight. Tomorrow - Newcomers' pairs, 1 P.M.; Goldman pairs, two flights, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; newcomers' pairs 7 P.M.; speedball Swiss teams, midnight. Sunday - Newcomers' pairs, 1 P.M.; Goldman pairs final and Flight B Swiss teams, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; newcomers' Swiss teams, 7 P.M.; speedball Swiss teams, midnight. Monday - Reisinger knockout teams, two flights, 12:30 P.M. and 6:30 P.M., continuing through Saturday.

title: Economic Scene; The Global Stock Boom
description: LAST August, Mexico said it could not meet its debt payments and Wall Street promptly took off into the wild blue yonder. Nine months later, stock exchanges the world over are roaring heavenward, some chalking up their sharpest gains in a generation. Why are they booming? And how long will it last?

title: THE CHINA SYNDROME
description: A dreadfully familiar game is being played again just below the surface of this politically minded town. In the 1950's, when Senator Joe McCarthy was making the headlines, it was called ''Who lost China?''

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 31.
CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the quarter and $176,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary credit of $85,000 for the quarter and a tax loss carryforward credit of $936,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $109,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary gain of $934,000 for the quarter and a tax loss carryforward credit of $2,267,000.

title: JOHN P. BLAIR, FOUNDER OF COMPANY WITH VARIED INTERESTS, DIES AT 83
description: John P. Blair, founder and honorary chairman emeritus of John Blair & Company, the nationwide advertising, communications and printing conglomerate, died Wednesday at Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Naples and Linville, N.C.

title: Freeze Advocates Kept From Parade
description: The Pound Ridge People for a Nuclear Weapons Freeze have been told that they will not be allowed to march in the Memorial Day Parade on Monday in this town of 4,500.

title: SUMMIT OF TOASTS FOR KISSINGER AT 60
description: Harvard's genial Guido G. Goldman finally gave his eagerly anticipated and much discussed big party in honor of Henry Kissinger's 60th birthday at the Pierre Hotel last night, and a gala it was with a cake, singing, dancing, formal toasts and hugs for the brilliant if controversial former Secretary of State.

title: STEINBRENNER BACKS MARTIN ON INCIDENT
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, last night defended his manager's version of a barroom incident Wednesday morning in Anaheim, Calif., that led to a complaint from a 27-yearold Californian to the police that Martin had hit him in the jaw.

title: WARMER WATERS ARE AWAITED
description: From Cape May, N.J., to Cape Cod, Mass., those who depend on recreational anglers for their livelihood are cursing the cold, wet, nasty spring. The unusual weather has delayed the arrival of some species, such as bluefish. Even when fish are about, anglers have been scarce.

title: Van Breda Kolff In a New Arena
description: Calvin Triplett, the athletic director at Picayune (Miss.) Memorial High School, received a phone call about a month ago from a man who asked if the school was looking for a basketball coach.

title: WHEN INDY HAD CARS BUILT FOR TWO
description: Duke Nalon remembered the year before his first Indianapolis 500. It was 1937, the year Jimmy Snyder set a onelap qualifying record with a speed of 130.492 miles an hour. The record had jumped more than 5 m.p.h., the biggest jump since 1923. ''I thought, '130 miles an hour. I don't know if I want to race here or not,' '' Nalon said.

title: West Side Thai, East Side French.
description: THE theater district, long considered a wasteland by lovers of good food, is starting to offer brighter prospects for pleasant, moderate-price meals. One welcome addition is the Siam Grill on Ninth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets, an offshoot of Bangkok Cuisine on Eighth Avenue. This six-month-old restaurant is small and more trimly attractive than most Thai restaurants, and its young staff is gracious, efficient and accommodating.

title: CUBS DEFEAT BRAVES, 5-1
description: Bill Buckner had a two-run double, and Jay Johnstone slugged a homer as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-1, tonight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BancTexas Group Inc., Dallas, announced that Edward C. Nash Jr., chairman, was assuming the additional post of president, following the resignation of Michael Doman.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,762,000.

title: TriBeCa Walking Tour
description: TriBeCa, the triangle below Canal Street, will be explored in a walking tour Sunday at 11 A.M., sponsored by the 92d Street Y. The area is rich with art galleries, artists' lofts and cast-iron and historic structures, among them the Woolworth Building, Federal houses and the A.T. Stewart Building. The tour goes on rain or shine and begins at the triangle at Hudson and Chamber Streets and West Broadway; it costs $6.50 and lasts till about 4 P.M. The number for reservations or further information is 427-6000, extension 179.

title: FIRST MIDWEST CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: MASTERS AND JOHNSON DEFEND PIONEER SEX THERAPY RESEARCH
description: Dr. William Masters and Virginia Johnson publicly defended their sex therapy research yesterday against criticisms that have provoked heated debate in the field for the last several years.

title: Superior Oil Tally
description: The Superior Oil Company said 55.7 million shares had been voted in favor of the stockholder proposal by Willametta Keck Day that would require that certain above-market offers for at least 45 percent of Superior's shares be submitted to a committee of three outside directors. The motion was opposed by Superior's management, and 45.9 million shares were voted against the resolution. About 25.8 million of the 127.4 million outstanding shares were not voted, the company said in announcing the final official count.

title: AFTER 23 SENIORS IN GRADUATE IN EAGLE MOUNTAIN, THE TOWN WILL ALSO PASS AWAY
description: Like thousands of high school seniors, the members of the class of 1983 at Eagle Mountain High School will have mixed emotions when they receive their diplomas Friday night.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There comes a time in the life of every man and any city when change is appropriate.

title: CFS CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 16.
description: Year-ago figures include gains of $162,000 for the quarter and $249,000 for the 6 months on the sale of an affiliate.

title: BRINGING UP A CHILD NOW COSTS $80,000
description: A Department of Agriculture report says it would cost about $12,000 more to raise a child born in 1982 to the age of 18 than it would to raise one to that age who was born in 1980.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company went public earlier this month--year-earlier results for both the quarter and 6 months are calculated on a pro forma basis.

title: KEVIN WHITE BARS 5TH RACE FOR THE MAYORALITY IN BOSTON
description: Kevin H. White, Mayor of Boston for 16 years and long one of the nation's most influential local politicians, announced tonight that he will not run for a fifth term this fall.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
76ERS SET BACK LAKERS TO TAKE 2-0 LEAD IN FINAL
description: When the Philadelphia 76ers' dressing room doors were opened tonight after their 103-93 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers at the Spectrum, Earl Cureton sat where Moses Malone usually sits. And the 76ers' third-string center was answering the questions usually reserved for Malone.

title: CURB THOSE WHO GIVE BICYCLING A BAD NAME
description: To the Editor:

title: SIMPSONS-SEARS LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 4.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: SCYPION UNDERDOG TO ALL BUT TRAINER
description: The meat and potatoes have sometimes been lost in the steamy alphabet soup of international boxing politics. But when Marvelous Marvin Hagler challenges the World Boxing Council and World Boxing Association here Friday night, he will also be defending his undisputed middleweight championship against Wilford Scypion.

title: KEAN PLANS PRISON ON A NETWORK SITE
description: Governor Kean presented plans yesterday to build a state prison for 1,000 inmates on a vacant plot north of Newark International Airport. Appearing with Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson in Newark's City Hall, Mr. Kean described the $100 million prison as a major part of his yearold plan to ease severe overcrowding in the state's medium- and maximum-security prisons.

title: FIRST GOAL AN UNHAPPY EXPERIENCE
description: Andranik Eskandarian, the best defender on the Cosmos, has always been kidded by his teammates because he has never scored a goal in his five years with the North American Soccer League team. The scoring drought came to an end, sort of, Wednesday night at Giants Stadium, as the Cosmos were defeating the Golden Bay Earthquakes, 5-1.

title: Band on the Run
description: Ten amateur women distance runners, including a 42-year-old mother of three, jogged through a heavy rain in Central Park early yesterday as they prepared for a relay of more than 2,200 miles that will end on June 23 in Colorado Springs.

title: John Jay Wins
description: Tom Weeden drove in four runs with a double and three singles today to lead John Jay College to a 17-5 victory over Queens College in the championship game of the City University Conference. The Bloodhounds, who collected 24 hits, finished the season at 18-9. Sean Gargin, a freshman right-hander, limited the Knights to eight hits.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA DIG IN ACROSS A QUIET FRONT
description: The Israeli and Syrian Armies, facing each other across the ravines and plains of eastern Lebanon, are busy fortifying their positions by strengthening earthworks, reinforcing bunkers and building access roads.

title: Stanford Faculty Seeks Study of Hoover Unit
description: The Academic Senate of Stanford University voted today to urge the university's president, Donald Kennedy, to consult with the board of trustees ''with a view to appointing a committee to explore and reassess'' the university's relations with the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace.

title: G.O.P. Endorses Race by Martinelli
description: Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli has won endorsement for re-election at a Republican convention here. Mr. Martinelli got 242 votes to 108 for Carl J. Calvi, a Westchester County Legislator, at the meeting Wednesday night. Mr. Calvi, who has the endorsement of the Conservative Party, would not say if he planned to challenge Mr. Martinelli in a primary. Some dissident Republicans had been upset over Mr. Martinelli's endorsement of an increase in a tax on water frontage and the Mayor's proposed budget.

title: REAGAN SAYS KILLING WILL NOT CHANGE U.S. POLICY
description: President Reagan suggested today that the killing of an American naval officer in El Salvador Wednesday night was an act of terror, but said the Administration's policies toward that nation would not change.

title: Manchester Wins
description: Manchester United defeated Brighton, 4-0, in the English Cup final tonight. The game was a rematch of last Saturday's 2-2 tie. Bryan Robson had 2 goals.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Friday on the profits of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group incorrectly reported the results for Shell Oil, the United States subsidiary. Shell Oil earned $246 million in the first quarter of 1983, down from $345 million a year earlier.

title: 'HEADS OR TAILS'
description: PHILIPPE NOIRET, who was so fine in Bertrand Tavernier's ''Coup de Torchon,'' and Michel Serrault, best known in this country for his performances as Zaza in the two ''Cage aux Folles'' movies, appear to be making the most of a not great provincial meal in Robert Enrico's ''Heads or Tails'' (Pile ou Face), the French film that opens today at the Embassy 72d Street 1.

title: CONDOMINIUM STATUS NEXT AT PARC VENDOME COMPLEX
description: In the 1920's Otto Kahn, the financier and arts patron, owned land west of Eighth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets. He offered the property at cost as a new home for the Metropolitan Opera Company, but the offer was rejected.

title: CHILDREN'S WORLD INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PLANS TO REOPEN APOLLO REVIVED BY U.D.C. AID
description: A plan to convert Harlem's shuttered Apollo Theater into a cable television studio and performance center was revived yesterday after the state's Urban Development Corporation voted to invest at least $2.5 million.

title: CORATOMIC INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Scientific Satellite Lofted
description: A European Space Agency scientific satellite carrying equipment to study X-ray sources in space was launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base today. The European X-Ray Observatory Satellite was sent aloft aboard a Delta rocket of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It had been scheduled for launching aboard the European Ariane craft in November, but delays forced the European Space Agency to switch to the Delta rocket in February.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: 1982 share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 18, 1983.

title: Bottler Murdered In Queens Home
description: The president of a Brooklyn soda company was shot to death in his Woodhaven home yesterday morning, the police said.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Kaiser Resumes Takeover Talks
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced today that it had asked the New York Stock Exchange to delay trading in its common stock while it resumed takeover talks with a group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier who holds 16.3 percent of its stock.

title: Calder to Reopen
description: Gov. Bob Graham signed emergency legislation today designed to reopen Calder Race Course in Miami.

title: Less Gas From Mexico
description: Exports of natural gas to the United States have been reduced, and the price has been cut, the state monopoly Petroleos Mexicanos said yesterday. Border Gas, a consortium of American importers, has decided to buy 180 million cubic feet a day, down from 300 million. Pemex and Border Gas agreed to lower the price to $4.40 a million British thermal units from $4.94.

title: OUSTED ARGENTINE SINGER WHO YEARNS TO SETTLE IN
description: NACHA GUEVARA, the Argentine singer and actress whose solo show ''Nacha'' opened at the Top of the Gate last week, is hoping for a long run. ''A very long run,'' she said with a wistful smile the other day. ''I would like to stay in one place.''

title: NETS STALLED IN PURSUING ALBECK
description: The San Antonio Spurs, trying to keep Coach Stan Albeck from being hired away by the Nets, went into a Bexar County court in Texas yesterday and obtained a temporary injunction that prevents New Jersey from negotiating with him.

title: OPTION VALUE LINE IS DROPPED
description: The Kansas City Board of Trade is phasing out its market in options based on its Value Line futures contract. These options are the latest casualty of the rapid expansion in stock index futures and options since February 1982, when the Kansas City Board introduced Value Line futures, the first such trading vehicle.

title: Stocks Off Slightly On Profit Taking
description: Stock prices fell modestly yesterday on profit taking and a weakness in the technology sector. Volume declined. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 5.52 points, to 1,223.49. In the previous three sessions, the widely followed average climbed almost 40 points, mainly on the conviction that interest rates would drop despite huge advances in the nation's money supply figures in recent weeks.

title: Arguello's Complaint
description: Alexis Arguello said the World Boxing Association had refused to rank him among the top 10 contenders in the junior-welterweight division unless he agreed to a series of deals he considered improper.

title: Dome Petroleum
description: The Dome Shareholders Protection Committee, which was set up last year to work for more favorable refinancing arrangements than those negotiated by Dome Petroleum Ltd., said it was seriously considering disbanding because of Dome's improved operations and the ''relaxed attitude'' by Dome's creditors.

title: Ex-Stix Broker Is Convicted
description: A former stockbroker who looted a St. Louis brokerage firm of some $16 million has been convicted by a Federal jury in Alton, Ill., on a charge of obstructing justice.

title: BRIEFING
description: Protest From Australia

title: OLDER COLLEGIANS MAKE UP FOR LOST TIME
description: For 70-year-old Ilse Kaim, who graduated from New York University this spring, a degree in urban studies was something she had wanted as a young student in Germany. ''Mr. Hitler prevented me from getting it,'' she said. For Patricia Abramson, 63, who worked for 15 years to earn her bachelor's degree in art history from Columbia University, the time was spent ''for me - for me alone.''

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income after a loss from disconinued operations of $164,000 for the quarter and $848,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,900,000. The nine months loss is after a credit of $2.7 million representing a gain from sale of bonds and $1.9 million from sale of property.

title: VATICAN IS SILENT ON DETAILS
description: Pope John Paul II today received a Bulgarian Government delegation headed by a Deputy Foreign Minister, Luben Gotsev. A Bulgarian Embassy spokesman, Vassil S. Dimitrov, described the 50-minute private audience as ''sincere and open.''

title: MUSEUMS OPEN FOR HOLIDAY
description: Many of the museums in the city will be closed on Monday, but they will follow their usual weekend schedule. Here are some that will be open on Memorial Day: American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street (873-4225).

title: HENRY AARON TAKES A SWING
description: Ever since the baseball owners voted to replace Bowie Kuhn as commissioner, only one candidate has officially come forth. He is Henry Aaron, the leading home-run hitter of all time and now the vice president of player development for the Atlanta Braves.

title: HAWAII BONDS PRICED TO YIELD 6.50% TO 9.35%
description: The Bankers Trust Company yesterday priced a $75 million general obligation bond issue for the State of Hawaii at yields ranging from 6.50 percent to 9.35 percent.

title: UNION DEMANDING ISOLATION OF INMATES WITH AIDS
description: The head of the union representing the state's prison guards today demanded that the state isolate prisoners suffering from Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and that all correction officers who guard such prisoners be given special training and protective clothing.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PUBLISHING: TIME OUT FOR WRITERS' CONFERENCES
description: ADDRESSING a University of Colorado writers' conference in 1935, Thomas Wolfe said: ''Of all the people here in this audience, I am the last, the worst, the least prepared to tell anyone how to write a story in such a way that it will sell to anything, no matter what.'' Whereupon he proceeded to deliver 74 typewritten pages of observations about the writer's craft.

title: BIG TEST FOR PRINCESS ROONEY
description: The pursuit of racing's less gaudy triple crowns begins this weekend at Belmont Park. Tomorrow, Princess Roooney will try to win her 11th race without a defeat in the Acorn, the first leg of the New York filly triple crown for 3-year-olds. She has been running up her record against inferior fillies and meets top company for the first time tomorrow. Ski Goggle, Stark Drama and Far Flying are the best of her eight opponents in the one-mile Acorn and all look capable of dethroning the Princess, who is 4 to 5 on the morning line.

title: SHULTZ CALLS TRADE KEY TO RECOVERY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said yesterday that an expansion of world trade, particularly between industrialized and developing countries, was crucial to global economic recovery for the rest of the 1980's.

title: IF THE MX IS NEAR, POLITICS OF '84 CAN'T BE FAR AWAY
description: While Congress was debating the MX missile Monday, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado was delivering a speech to the New Hampshire Council on World Affairs. He told his audience in that critical primary state that his pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination was ''ultimately based'' on his opposition to President Reagan's arms buildup in general and the MX in particular.

title: Sybron Plans Sale Of Its Taylor Line
description: The Sybron Corporation, Rochester, announced it had agreed to sell its Taylor line of industrial instrumentation and controls to Combustion Engineering Inc. for $80 million in cash, and said it would take a one-time, after-tax charge of $30 million, or $3.11 a share, in the second quarter.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 27, 1983
description: The Summit

title: Iran Rebuffs Iraq On Sparing Civilians
description: Iran responded negatively today to a proposal by Iraq that the two countries agree to stop shelling each other's towns and villages. It said the suggestion constituted a confession that Iraq had been bombarding civilians.

title: PAKISTANIS TELL U.S. OF SOVIET HINT ON AFGHANISTAN
description: Pakistani officials have told the Reagan Administration that there have been ''signs'' the Soviet Union would withdraw from Afghanistan if the Government could be replaced by one that was friendly to the Russians but not necessarily under Soviet control.

title: Derailment Slows West Side IRT
description: A southbound IRT subway train derailed as it left the Times Square station yesterday afternoon, touching off a smoky fire that forced the evacuation of the train and a shutdown of power on the West Side line.

title: Business Deans Named
description: Two business schools yesterday announced the appointment of new deans. The Graduate School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley has appointed Raymond E. Miles and the Colgate Darden School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia has picked John W. Rosenblum.

title: FILM: MARRIAGE IN BRAZIL
description: ''They Don't Wear Black Tie'' was shown in the 1982 ''New Directors/ New Films'' series at the Festival Theater. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin that appeared in The New York Times of April 18, 1982. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio I, Broadway at 66th Street.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
Market Place; Regional Banks: Modest Multiples
description: AT a time when many stocks are selling at lofty price-earnings ratios, Thomas H. Hanley, who heads bank stock research at Salomon Brothers, suggests the purchase of five issues that trade at modest multiples.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: 31st Site With Dioxin Is Found in Missouri
description: Dioxin has been found on the property of a landscape gardening concern in St. Louis County, bringing to 31 the number of confirmed dioxin sites in Missouri.

title: A French Nuclear Test Reported in Pacific
description: France set off a 70-kiloton nuclear test explosion, much larger than any previous known French test, at Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific, Foreign Minister Bill Hayden announced in Parliament today.

title: Quintet at Guggenheim
description: The Boehm Quintette will give a concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Guggenheim Museum featuring the premiere of a piano-and-wind quintet by Tobias Picker, which was commissioned by the group.

title: Gertrude Goldworm, 85, Dies; Headed Sportswear Company
description: Gertrude Goldworm, the co-owner of Goldworm Sportswear in Manhattan and the recipient of many fashion awards, died Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BLACKS AND 1984
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's evangelistic address to the Alabama Legislature only happened to be delivered on the same day the Supreme Court ruled against the Reagan Administration's effort to award tax exemptions to racially segregated private schools. The coincidence nevertheless served to emphasize the vital - perhaps determinative - role blacks could play in the 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a special charge of $1.5 million. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MARIE: A True Story. By Peter Maas. 420 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: Fabi Posts Top Test Speed
description: Teo Fabi, who will start at the pole position in his first Indianapolis 500, posted the top speed of 201.795 miles an hour Thursday in carburetion testing, the final workout before Sunday's race. The Italian racer was at least a mile an hour faster than any other driver. Fabi's four-lap average of 207.395 m.p.h. last Saturday earned him the pole at the 2 1/2 mile circuit.

title: PAGURIAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Scali Head Reaffirms Link With Ogilvy
description: In response to queries yesterday, Marvin Sloves, chairman of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a wholly owned subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather International since 1977, said that while he had been negotiating for some time with the parent company to get some S.M.S. equity back in the hands of its executives he has no interest in being totally independent of the parent, and indeed has been assured by Ogilvy management that it plans a continuing ownership position.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The latest quarter includes provision of about $300,000 for estimated future losses on jobs in progress compared to loss of $123,000 for discontinued real estate operations in year-ago period.

title: Tylenol Figure Guilty In Credit Card Fraud
description: James W. Lewis, who is accused of extortion in the tainted Tylenol poisonings, was convicted today in a separate case on six counts of credit card fraud.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MONY's New Chief Was at Equitable
description: The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York has reached out of its ranks to choose a new chairman and chief executive. The company said yesterday that it had named James A. Attwood to the posts. He succeeds James E. Devitt, who retires Aug.1. Mr. Attwood, 55 years old, is senior executive vice president and chief investment officer at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: GETTING THE JUMP ON SUMMER OUTDOORS
description: AFTER hardly any spring, summer arrives today - if not on the calendar, then at least by custom. To greet the season ushered in by the Memorial Day holiday, New Yorkers and their neighbors have a wide choice of outdoor things to do this weekend.

title: TU INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-The results for the year-ago quarter are not comparable since the company became public in December 1982.

title: Earlier Trading in U.S. Issues
description: Traders in Treasury securities soon may be opening for business earlier to accommodate investors based in Europe and the Middle East. RMJ Securities, a broker of Treasury securities, initiated the move by recently informing the three dozen largest dealers in Treasury securities that it intended to adopt a 7 A.M. opening beginning June 1.

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: The share earnings are per American Depositary Receipt. Translation from pounds sterling into dollar is at the rate of $1.48 to the pound, the approximate rate on April 1.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S INTERVIEW ON MEETING
description: President Reagan was interviewed today by correspondents from Canada, West Germany, France, Britain, Japan and Italy. Following are excerpts from the White House transcript. Concern Over Deficits

title: 'A Marriage in Movies,' a true story.
description: A FILM series called ''A Marriage in Movies'' has been running at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, where it continues through June 17. It is a tribute to Hideko Takamine (for more than 50 years the most popular actress in Japan) and to her husband, the writerdirector, Zenzo Matsuyama.

title: WHERE TO DINE ON YOUR HOLIDAY WEEKEND EXCURSION
description: Merely getting into the car for a weekend outing is enough to make some people hungry. But even if you're not one of those, it is a good idea to plan where to eat before setting off on an excursion to areas surrounding New York City.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LATIN MARXISM
description: To the Editor:

title: TANNETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,295,000 for the quarter and $2,347,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $51,000. d-After net from discontinued operations of $157,000.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
S.E.C. Rule On Fees
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed yesterday that investment advisers handling the accounts of ''financially sophisticated'' investors, those with portfolios of $150,000 or more, be allowed to claim a portion of any client's capital gain as their fee.

title: PRESIDENT DRAWS HEAVY CRITICISM OVER HIS CHOICES FOR RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan is being criticized by civil rights groups and members of Congress after replacing three members of the United States Civil Rights Commission with conservative appointees who agree with his opposition to racial quotas and school busing.

title: AUTOMOTIVE HARDWARE LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
8 DEMOCRATS BACK LATIN INITIATIVE
description: A delegation of Democrats opposed to the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America met today with Mexico's Foreign Minister and gave their backing to a peace initiative being promoted by Mexico and three other regional governments.

title: Bar Hours Upheld In Westchester
description: The Westchester County Alcoholic Beverage Control Board decided today to let the county's 1,300 bars, restaurants and hotels continue to serve liquor until 4 A.M.

title: The U.N. Today; May 27, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CRENSHAW AND WADKINS LEAD BY TWO
description: Ben Crenshaw has apparently recovered from his worst year on the PGA Tour. In 1982, he finished 83d on the money list, never came close to winning a tournament and finally had to take time off to collect his thoughts and regain his swing.

title: GAS SERVICE CO reports earnings for year to April 30.
To Gracious, Vapid Williamsburg
description: The Reagan Administration has taken great care that this weekend's economic summit conference in Williamsburg not be ''another Versailles.'' Last year's gathering there was a model of how bad such an event can be - inconclusive, disputatious and, in the end, damaging to relations among the seven industrial powers. But prearranged harmony isn't much better. The world wants leadership.

title: LOUISE WEISS, A FRENCH FEMINIST AND PACIFIST
description: Louise Weiss, a French feminist who was the oldest member of the European Parliament, died yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 90 years old.

title: Bell Replaces Financial Aide
description: Robert E. Allen, 48 years old, has been named an executive vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and will become its chief financial officer effective July 1, the company said yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * New Jersey Devils of the National Hockey League to Gianettino & Meredith Advertising, Mountainside, N.J.

title: AUTHOR OF 14 BOOKS HAD BEEN REPORTER
description: Zelda F. Popkin, a novelist who had published 14 books, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Silver Spring, Md. She was 84 years old.

title: ON PATROL DOWN AMAZON: CHALLENGES FOR THE BOLD
description: The blast of the horn and the roiling water to stern meant that the naval river patrol ship Raposo Tavares, its 67 crew members and a pet monkey were off on another Amazon mission.

title: RATES RISE AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: Interest rates rose and prices weakened for the second consecutive day as concern over additional Treasury borrowing, growth of the money supply and the uncertain direction of Federal Reserve policy continued to plague the credit markets.

title: POLICE TO USE CHECKPOINTS IN MOVE TO CATCH DRUNKEN DRIVERS IN CITY
description: The New York Police Department will begin stopping cars tonight at unannounced checkpoints throughout the city in a search for drunken drivers.

title: U.S. PLANS TO TRAIN SALVADOR SOLDIERS AT HONDURAN BASE
description: The Reagan Administration has gained approval from Honduras to triple the number of United States military advisers there and open a training base there for Salvadoran soldiers, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title: The Bottom Line
description: Tom Heinsohn, the former Celtic coach, said he had turned down an offer to coach the Houston Rockets because he had been led to expect a salary ''commensurate with that of the top-paid coach,'' in the National Basketball Association and that the Rockets' ultimate offer of a base salary of $200,000 didn't measure up to his expectations. Although Hubie Brown of the Knicks is believed to be the highest-paid N.B.A. coach with a reported base pay of $300,000, Heinsohn said he would probably have accepted a $250,000 offer from the Rockets. Houston's interest in signing a coach of Heinsohn's stature had apparently waned since the club won the coin toss that assures it of drafting Ralph Sampson, the Virginia star.

title: Money Funds Shrink Slightly
description: In the smallest decline since asset levels began shrinking in December, money market mutual fund assets dropped by only $125 million last week, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $120,000 for the latest quarter and $57,000 for year-ago period.

title: McEnroe Advances Despite Outbursts
description: John McEnroe continued to struggle against opponents and behave cantankerously toward spectators and officials today as he moved into the third round of the French Open with a 6-3, 7-6, 6-3 victory over Alberto Tous.

title: GALANOS'S FURS END SHOW
description: James Galanos brought down the curtain on the season's fur showings with an extensive and expensive collection - 120 pieces valued at more than $3 million at retail prices. It was as full of glitter and glamour as anything he has ever attempted in cloth. The designer tossed out Russian pelts, such as sables, silver foxes, broadtail and lynx - some with price tags in six figures - until the audience of customers and store buyers gasped.

title: 10 EMPLOYEES OF STATE HOSPITAL ON S.I. ARE ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Ten employees at the state hospital at Willowbrook on Staten Island have been arrested and charged with selling cocaine, heroin and other drugs while on duty, the police said yesterday.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a gain of $449,010 from the sale of real estate. c-Includes gains from real estate of $2,720 for the quarter and $20,149 for the 6 months.

title: 8 YEARS OF TALK ON ECONOMICS
description: The ninth economic summit conference is being convened in Williamsburg, Va., this weekend in an atmosphere strikingly different from that in which the previous eight sessions were held.

title: LEAP YEAR TO CREATE $35 MILLION PROBLEM FOR THE CITY'S BUDGET
description: Throwing blame around for New York City's budget problems is an old game, but city officials have found a new suspect - leap year. They say it is responsible for a $35 million hole in the next budget.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 24.
THE EXCLUSIONARY RULE'S MANY UNDESERVING BENEFICIARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Deletes Barb at Japan
description: The Reagan Administration today removed material criticizing Japan for protectionist trade policies from an official press kit prepared for the economic summit meeting this weekend.

title: CURB THOSE WHO GIVE BICYCLING A BAD NAME
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTAGON BREAKFASTS QUESTIONED
description: The Defense Department's chief spokesman, Henry E. Catto Jr., said in response to questions by reporters today that ''It was perhaps an error on my part'' to have recommended to Defense Seccretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Pentago's senior officials no longer meet for breakfasts with the press. He said he might reconsider his suggestion.

title: PEOPLE STARTS $149 FLIGHTS
description: People Express Airlines Inc. started its much-publicized air service to London late yesterday, offering one-way tickets at $149, the lowest trans-Atlantic fare since Freddie Laker's Skytrain service in the late 1970's.

title: Letting Capitalism Land in London
description: Cheers for Margaret Thatcher. Britain's Conservative Prime Minister has chosen competition over protectionism after all. People Express, the upstart little airline from Newark, has won permission to fly travelers to London for just $149.

title: GENERALS TRADE SCOTT TO BLITZ
description: Bobby Scott, who had started at quarterback in all 12 of the New Jersey Generals'games, was traded yesterday to the Chicago Blitz for an offensive lineman, Kari Yli-Renko, and a future draft choice.

title: 'TOUGH ENOUGH,' PROVING IT BY BOXING
description: A CONTEST mentality is peculiarly apparent in ''Tough Enough,'' a very dull boxing movie with no other distinguishing features. The film begins with a wet-T-shirt contest in a country and western bar, and it quickly moves on to something called the Toughman competition, which combines elements of ''Rocky'' and ''Let's Make a Deal.'' Aspiring Toughmen are summoned into a boxing arena two at a time (''Come on down!'' cries an announcer in game-show tones). They slug it out, and then the winner fights another winner, until only the two toughest Toughmen remain. When one of these is victorious, he raises his arms and bounces up and down to a recognizably ''Rocky''- like theme. He also wins a big cash prize.

title: U.S. ENVOY SAYS SALVADOR KILLING LOOKS POLITICAL
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that in ''all probability'' the slaying of the deputy commander of the United States Military Group in El Salvador was a ''political act.''

title: Butcher's Bank Seeks Extension
description: Directors of the City and County Bank of Knox County met to draft a message to Tennessee Banking Commissioner Billy Adams asking for 30 more days to raise the cash they need to keep the bank open, a bank spokesman said.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees open a 13-game home stand with Ron Guidry on the mound.

title: Unlike 'Zorba,' Quinn is suddenly playing coy.
description: AFTER a long career of playing bold, lusty characters, Anthony Quinn is suddenly trying to be coy. He wants people to believe that he has not yet made up his mind about coming to New York in the revival of the musical ''Zorba,'' which is now playing in Los Angeles. But there is every reason to believe that, barring something unimaginable, ''Zorba'' will open on Broadway in October. The producers, Fran and Barry Weissler and Kenneth-Mark Productions, have already made a tentative deal for a theater, now occupied by a longrunning musical that is winding down.

title: Unmistakable Message
description: ''Wife Wanted: New or Used,'' read the fifth-story sign painted on a Seventh Avenue building near Penn Station. ''I'm a charismatic yet humble 30-year-old libertine who feels that honest work is a sin against my nature; seeking kindred spirit, 20-40, of exceptional brains and beauty, fully able to appreciate the truly enchanting creature that I am.''

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL UNDERGOING INQUIRY ON FALSE DATA
description: The National Institutes of Health, which chided the Harvard Medical School earlier this year over its supervision of a young physician accused of forging data, is also investigating the Emory University School of Medicine's overseeing of the same doctor's work.

title: Patient Yankee
description: Bobby Murcer has come to bat only 5 times for the Yankees this season and his only hit was a double on April 10 against Toronto. But the 37-year-old outfielder says he is willing to sit patiently on the bench and wait for his turn to perform.

title: 2 SEANTORS IN HOT DISCUSSION ON EQUAL RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: Two Senators engaged in a heated exchange at a hearing today over the legal effects of the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution, which would outlaw discrimination based on sex.

title: Article 193687 -- No Title
description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation releasing $625 million for further development of the MX missile.

title: RED SOX WIN, 7-2
description: Carl Yastrzemski hit his first home run of the season, the 443d of his career, and Dwight Evans and Jim Rice also hit homers tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 7-2.

title: CYRUS C. HUNGERFORD
description: Cyrus C. (Cy) Hungerford, a cartoonist with Pittsburgh's morning newspapers more than 70 years, died Wednesday night in nearby Wexford.

title: CASEY ASKS PANEL: WHO SAID 'THE C.I.A. LIES'?
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, has written to members of the House intelligence committee demanding to know who told a reporter that ''the C.I.A. lies to us anyway.''

title: Road to Recovery
description: As a player Keith Moody's football career may have come to an end, but as a coach it has not yet begun. Moody, the New Jersey Generals' free safety, suffered a knee injury in the game against Birmingham on May 9 when he made a driving tackle to force Earl Gant, the Stallions' running back, out of bounds.

title: Ryotaro Azuma Is Dead at 90; A Former Governor of Tokyo
description: Ryotaro Azuma, former Governor of Tokyo and president of the Japan Red Cross, died of pneumonia today, the Juntendo Hospital said. He was 90 years old.

title: RADIO-TV EXPANSION APPROVED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved a national expansion in radio and television service, including a new allotment of 1,000 FM radio stations and a technology for delivering up to five channels of movie and sports programs to residential subscribers by microwave.

title: TWO SETS OF MISSILES THAT DON'T COMPARE
description: To the Editor:

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $224,000.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PARIS AIR SHOW: BITTER RIVALRY
description: Biting winds, fierce competition and the surprise withdrawal of three major United States manufacturers marked today's opening of the 35th Paris International Air Show, where 900 aeronautical companies are fighting for shares of the world's tight aircraft market.

title: Required Reading; Whose Deficits?
description: Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, in remarks to the House of Representatives, May 18: Mr. Speaker, I am 44 years old. I know I look younger. But for all but two years of my life, this House has been controlled by the Democrat Party. Yet, today, we hear them ranting and raving about the President of the United States, a Republican President, being in control of the deficits that we face.

title: Around the World; I.L.O. to Study Charges Against Polish Rulers
description: The International Labor Organization decided today to set up a commission of inquiry to examine charges that the Polish Government is flouting its treaty commitments to guarantee trade union freedoms.

title: DRIVER HELD AS DRUNK
description: A police officer was seriously injured yesterday evening when a truck driver, who was later charged with driving while intoxicated, rammed the rear of the officer's unmarked car on Rockaway Boulevard in Queens, the police said.

title: COURT BATTLE OVER BOOK: VIKING AND A GOVERNOR
description: Viking Press and Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota are suing each other, thus setting up a legal dispute that booksellers say may have important implications for publishing.

title:
PATENTS;
Water-Based Paint From Aerosol Container
description: Two New Jersey businessmen have patented water-based paint compositions that can be sprayed from aerosol containers.

title: THE ULTIMATE QUIZ
description: Now, a multiple-choice nuclear war scholastic achievement test.

title: EX-OFFICIAL OF E.P.A. INDICTED OVER DISPUTE WITH CONGRESS
description: Rita M. Lavelle, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste cleanup program, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury for contempt of Congress.

title: LIFE PRISON TERMS GIVEN 2 POLICEMEN
description: Two police officers were sentenced today to life prison terms and a third got a sentence of six years to 10 years for convictions growing out of a motel brawl that left one man dead.

title: RECITAL: BORIS LVOV, PIANIST
description: Boris Lvov, a Soviet emigre pianist who settled in Israel in 1973 and joined the piano faculty of the Rubin Academy in Jerusalem, made his first New York appearance in Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night playing Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata (Op. 106), Scriabin's Sonata No. 6, Balakirev's ''Islamey'' and shorter pieces by Miaskovsky and Liadov.

title: Catch of the Day
description: Robert Parks, a 23-year-old auto-body shop owner from Monticello, N.Y., who likes to fish for trout, went off in pursuit of American shad for the first time two weeks ago, and he made a significant catch. Accompanied by friends on the Delaware River at Barryville, N.Y., in Sullivan County, he pulled in a 26-inch shad that weighed 7 pounds 14 ounces, a record for New York State.

title: NAKASONE BACKS REAGAN ON ARMS
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan called on the Western powers today to give the Reagan Administration united backing for its arms and arms control policies and voiced hope for a Soviet-American summit meeting ''at the earliest possible date.''

title: The Talk of St.-Denis
description: DENIS, Reunion - John Boot, a figure created by Evelyn Waugh in his novel ''Scoop,'' once cabled his editors from a far-flung place to announce that nothing much was happening. He then went on to chronicle unrest, upheaval and the outbreak of bubonic plague.

title: U.S. SAYS CUBA IS FOSTERING CENTRAL AMERICA SUBVERSION
description: The Reagan Administration charged today that Cuba was expanding its ''political-military activism'' in Central America and that Cubans, Nicaraguans and guerrillas from El Salvador were jointly planning terrorism in the region.

title: SALVADOR KILLING IS CLAIMED BY LEFT
description: A leftist guerrilla group said today that it was responsible for the killing of a United States military officer here Wednesday, calling it a ''patriotic operation,'' and warned against the ''useless sacrifice of American soldiers.''

title: News Analysis
description: Syrian officials and Western diplomats here believe there is no likelihood that President Hafez al-Assad will accept the Israeli-Lebanese security agreement and withdraw his troops from Lebanon.

title: Odd-Even Checks Of Cars Extended
description: A Federal appeals court today permitted the Kean administration to continue its odd-even system of automobile inspections until July 1.

title: Jordanians Seized On Heroin Charge
description: Three Jordanian Army sky marshals were charged yesterday with trying to smuggle an estimated $10 million worth of pure heroin through Kennedy International Airport in plastic bags taped to their bodies, the United States Customs Service announced.

title: Books of The Times; Joe McCarthy's World
description: A CONSPIRACY SO IMMENSE. The World of Joe McCarthy. By David M. Oshinsky. Illustrated. 597 pages. Free Press. $19.95.

title: ARENS SAYS ISRAEL WILL RESIST A WAR
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens said today that Israel would resist being drawn into battle with Syria. ''They will certainly not scare us,'' Mr. Arens said in a speech in Tel Aviv. ''We will not be dragged into any hostilities. We will not lose our nerve.'' He added: ''We can sit quietly, watch events and reach a correct assessment. We cannot be provoked.''

title: Around the World; The Turks Explain Their Foray Into Iraq
description: Turkish troops crossed the southeastern border into Iraq to capture ''aggressors who posed a threat to security and peace in the area,'' the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: MIDEAST PEACE HURDLE THAT DRAWS LITTLE IRE
description: To the Editor:

title: FITCH, IN SURPRISE, QUITS THE CELTICS
description: The Boston Celtics were shaken today by their second major setback in four days when Bill Fitch announced that he was resigning after four years as coach.

title: OF, BY AND FOR ALL THE PEOPLE OF NEW YORK CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Point's Reluctant Savior
description: The pieces seem at last in place to prevent the threatened shutdown of the two nuclear plants at Indian Point. Governor Cuomo, a reluctant Lochinvar, has ambled forward at the eleventh hour to save the two plants from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's ax.

title: U.S. AGREES TO KEEP DATA ON TOXIC WASTE VICTIMS
description: The Reagan Administration, under the pressure of a Federal suit, has agreed to carry out the requirements of a 1980 law and establish an agency to maintain a national registry of victims of poisons seeping from toxic waste dumps.

title: FUGITIVE PUERTO RICAN TERRORIST ARRESTED IN MEXICO
description: A Puerto Rican terrorist who escaped from a hospital prison ward in New York City in 1979 was recaptured in Mexico Thursday, lawenforcement officials in New York said yesterday. Two people were killed and three wounded in gun battles with the Mexican Federal police after the capture, the officials said.

title: L.I. COLLEGE ACTS TO SHUT OPEN DOOR
description: In 1968, the State University of New York's College at Old Westbury opened for classes as an experimental institution with an open-door policy that allowed anyone with a high school diploma to enroll. Now, 15 years and 3,000 graduates later, the college has moved to abolish the open-admissions policy.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS BUDGET STRATEGY ON EVE OF ECONOMIC TALKS
description: President Reagan arrived here today for the economic summit conference after insisting that his strategy for dealing with continuing high budget deficits would not aggravate world economic problems.

title: No Headline
description: Jimmy Albus of Piping Rock survived a bogey 6 on the final hole this morning to complete a final round of four-under-par 68 and win the 20th annual Dodge Open with a 72-hole total of 279 at the Rockaway River Country Club.

title: Ryotaro Azuma Is Dead at 90; A Former Governor of Tokyo
description: Ryotaro Azuma, former Governor of Tokyo and president of the Japan Red Cross, died of pneumonia on Thursday, the Juntendo Hospital said. He was 90 years old.

title: DR. ARTHUR DEGRAFF, EDUCATOR AND CARDIOLOGIST, DEAD AT 83
description: Dr. Arthur C. DeGraff, a cardiologist, educator and president of the Committee for the Promotion of Medical Research Inc., died Wednesday at Hartford Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Newtown, Conn., and Warm Mineral Springs, Fla.

title: Chicago's Mayor Seals Truce With Dissidents
description: Mayor Harold Washington and the City Council have reached their first agreement in a three-week-old feud by approving a plan for allocating $147 million of Federal community development funds.

title: U.S. CAUTIONS SYRIA LEBANON BUILDUP IS THREAT TO PEACE
description: The United States cautioned Syria today that its latest military buildup in Lebanon and along the Syrian-Lebanese border was threatening ''the uneasy peace'' in the area.

title: 28 Missing Off Philippines
description: Rescue ships searched for 28 missing passengers and crewmen today who were aboard a coastal freighter that capsized and sank in rough seas off the northern Philippines. A Philippine Coast Guard spokesman said the ship, the Rommel, sank Tuesday off the Babuyan Islands, 300 miles northwest of Manila.

title: 84 AT PUBLIC RADIO GET LAYOFF NOTICES
description: A new management team for National Public Radio today laid off 84 employees, including three reporters, in the latest program reductions aimed at keeping the financially troubled network alive.

title: DANCE: LES GRANDS BALLETS CANADIENS
description: Admirably eclectic as ever, Montreal's Les Grands Ballets Canadiens presented another varied program Thursday night at the City Center. The most interesting items were a beloved old ballet in the Classical manner and a new Expressionist work. However, despite their stylistic differences, these ballets were curiously similar in the way they treated their implied themes.

title: MCENROE TIRADE UNDER INQUIRY
description: While Chris Evert Lloyd and Yannick Noah were advancing to the fourth round of the French Open today, two of their more obstreperous peers faced the possibility of fines for their behavior in matches earlier in the week.

title: Warner Sees Wider Deficit
description: Steven J. Ross, chairman and chief executive of Warner Communications Inc., disclosed to the company's annual meeting here that Warner expected to show a larger deficit in the second quarter than the $18.9 million loss it recorded in the first three months of this year.

title: SOVIET WARNS NATO OVER MISSILE PLANS
description: The Soviet Union warned today that the scheduled deployment of new American missiles in Europe would bring inevitable countermeasures, possibly including the stationing of new nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe.

title: REAGAN IS REPLACING TOP OFFICIAL ON LATIN POLICY AT THE STATE DEPT.
description: The White House is replacing Thomas O. Enders as the State Department's senior official dealing with Latin America. Langhorne A. Motley, a longtime Republican Party politician who is now Ambassador to Brazil, will be nominated to succeed Mr. Enders as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 29.

title: Terror In Tudor City
description: Tudor City - that attractive park-enhanced enclave of tall brick buildings on the East Side in the low 40's -used to be considered a nice place to live, safe and green and secure from the terrible things happening on the mean streets outside. But no more.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Is Seeking Recall Of 431,000 '79 Cars
description: The Government wants 431,000 Ford and Mercury cars recalled for repairs after numerous complaints of brakes locking, officials disclosed today.

title: Harvester to Call Workers Back
description: More than 700 of the 1,300 International Harvester workers still on layoff in Springfield will be called back by mid-July, says Bill Greenhill, the company's manager of corporate communications.

title: WITH WHITE'S WITHDRAWAL, BOSTON FACED WIDE-OPEN MAYORAL RACE
description: With the dramatic exit Thursday of Mayor Kevin H. White from the fall mayoralty election, any one of four or five candidates could win, political experts here believe, making it the most wide-open race since Mr. White was first elected in 1967.

title: SHAMROCK IS STILL GOING ITS OWN WAY
description: As a troubled chemicals producer a decade ago, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation rewrote its strategic plan. By selling its chemicals businesses and investing in a variety of energy operations, Diamond Shamrock set out to become an integrated energy company.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. If his blister is better, Dave Righetti will go after his seventh victory, against Chris Codiroli, a rookie who has a record of 4-2. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres, at San Diego. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 10 P.M.) Blue Jays vs. Boston Red Sox, at Toronto. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Dodgers vs. San Francisco Giants, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Lacrosse Johns Hopkins vs. Syracuse, National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I championship game, at Rutgers Stadium, Piscataway, N.J., 2 P.M. This is Johns Hopkins's sixth appearance in the title game, and Syracuse's first.

title: SHARPER QUARREL IS SEEN
description: The French franc sank to a new low against the United States dollar today on the eve of the economic summit conference.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Sister Betty Nickels is a short, sturdy woman who sometimes talks like a social worker and sometimes talks like a street kid. She doesn't have much money, and she doesn't have much privacy.
