title: CONNECTICUT IS SUED BY U.S. FOR ITS BAN ON LARGE TRUCKS
description: The Federal Government filed suit today to overturn Connecticut's ban on double-trailer trucks. The civil action, filed in Federal District Court here by the Justice Department for the United States Department of Transportation, was viewed by state officials as an important test case of a state's power to police its highways.

title: Markets Closed Monday
description: All American stock and commodity markets will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Banks and government offices will also be closed. The weekly Treasury bill auction is scheduled for Tuesday.

title: HEAD OF REALTY CONCERN DISMISSED AFTER 11 DAYS
description: William D. Foote, president and chief operating officer of Institutional Investors Trust, a real estate company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, has been dismissed after 11 days on the job.

title: DEFUSING THE TENSION
description: The chill - if not the cold war -that succeeded the detente of the early 1970's has paralyzed progress in arms negotiations. The danger of blundering into a world confrontation seems to many greater today than at any time since the Cuban missile crisis. It is increasingly urgent, then, to consider steps to repair damaged superpower relations - including a reaffirmation of the SALT II treaty and reconsideration of the measure that formally links East-West trade to Soviet emigration policy.

title: De Gustibus; IF FOOD IS TO HAVE ZEST, DINERS MUST BE COMPATIBLE
description: What with computerized personality profiles, biorhythms, astrological forecasts and the insights provided by psychoanalysis, much advice is available for judging the compatibility of prospective mates or the suitability of applicants for schools and business organizations. For all that data, one is offered little guidance in selecting eating companions, a choice that can account for the success or failure of a meal. Those who take eating seriously might consider developing application forms that would be filled out by prospective companions so that unpleasant experiences could be avoided. No Automatic Assurance

title: DETROIT BATTLE: THE COST GAP
description: To help reduce the cost gap between Japanese and American automobiles, Detroit is scrambling to automate its factories, increase quality and improve labor relations.

title: Summit Meeting
description: President Reagan arrived in Williamsburg, Va., for the ninth in a series of economic summit conferences. Before leaving Washington he insisted that his strategy for dealing with big budget deficits won't aggravate world economic problems. He predicted that the three-day meeting will be marked by a spirit of ''realistic optimism'' and that there will be no ''confrontational'' incidents. (Page 1.)

title: Creighton Responds
description: Robert J. Gerraughty, Creighton's vice president for administration, says that Kevin Ross, who has accused the university of failing to teach him to read or write while he played basketball there, has ''persisted in telling half-truths, taking things out of context and lying outright.'' Ross left the university in 1982 after a knee injury had ended his hopes for a career in professional basketball.

title: PADRES DEFEAT METS, 4-0 AFTER YANKS, A'S BRAWL
description: The Mets, who got only two hits for Tom Seaver last Sunday, got two more for him tonight. And, after pitching no-hit ball for five innings, Seaver finally yielded four runs during one horrendous inning and suffered a 4-0 loss to the San Diego Padres.

title: U.S. DEPICTS ALLIES AS WARY ON SOVIET
description: The Reagan Administration appears to have achieved a more cautious attitude among the Western allies toward trade with the Soviet Union. But many experts are unsure whether this achievement will produce concrete change or prove worth the strain it has caused to the Atlantic alliance.

title: Your Money; Health Plans: A Rule Change
description: ONE of the lesser-known provisions of the 1982 tax law dramatically changes the way that medical insurance will be offered to workers between the ages of 65 and 70.

title: June Dance Benefit to Aid Scholarships
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will perform with soloists from the Royal Danish Ballet and the New York City Ballet's Peter Martins in a gala benefit June 8 in Carnegie Hall. Proceeds from the evening, which includes a dinner-dance aboard the Intrepid, will be used to establish an exchange scholarship program for American and Danish performing-arts students.

title: Briefing
description: A Lure for Tourists

title: DEFEND VALUES, SARAH LAWRENCE TOLD
description: E.L. Doctorow told Sarah Lawrence College graduates today that the hydrogen bomb presented ''a most unprecedented condition for living'' in which ''more and more we are showing signs of becoming unnerved by it.''

title: CYRUS C. HUNGERFORD
description: Cyrus C. (Cy) Hungerford, a cartoonist with Pittsburgh's morning newspapers more than 70 years, died Wednesday in nearby Wexford.

title:
PATENTS;
Check-Dispensing Terminal for Stores
description: Employees of the NCR Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, have invented a check-dispensing terminal that can be used in stores by purchasers who want to draw on their bank accounts for payment.

title: Kolff Medical Files for Offering
description: Kolff Medical Inc., the Salt Lake City-based company that developed the world's first permanent artificial heart, the Jarvik-7, announced that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares of common stock. Kolff said the stock, which would be priced between $15 and $17 a share, would be offered in early July through underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin and J.C. Bradford & Company.

title: Letter: On Institutional Housing Protect Non-Campus Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH LOBBY SENATE ON EXPORT ACT
description: The British Government, in an unusual lobbying effort, has called on the Senate to strike a provision of an East-West trade bill that extends the reach of American laws to foreign countries.

title: SAN CLEMENTE EAGER FOR NIXON LIBRARY
description: The Presidential library of Richard M. Nixon is to be built here on a beautiful seaside bluff, adjacent to where this town's waste disposal ponds used to be and overlooking a row of ocean-front mobile homes.

title: Sturgis S. Wilson, 77, Leader Of Pharmaceutical Company
description: Sturgis S. Wilson, retired president of Schieffelin & Company, a pharmaceutical and wine and liquor concern of New York City, died of a heart attack Thursday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: PRETORIA SLOWS TRAFFIC TO LESOTHO IN A RETALIATORY MOVE OVER REBELS
description: By slowing down traffic at its main border post with landlocked Lesotho, South Africa showed today that its arsenal of retaliatory measures against neighboring nations that harbor personnel of the underground African National Congress includes economic as well as military weapons.

title: Salem Nuclear Plant Back at Full Capacity
description: The Salem 1 nuclear plant resumed generating at full capacity today for the first time in eight months, a spokesman for the plant's operator said.

title: Horowitz Bound for Japan
description: Vladimir Horowitz will be playing in Japan for the first time on June 11 and June 16 in Tokyo's NHK Hall.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages yesterday gave an incorrect title for a country-and-western record with Bobby Murcer as the lead singer. It is ''Skoal Dippin' Man.''

title: MUSIC: SUMMER BACH OPENER
description: St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University is offering a Summer Bach Series that in the space of three summers will encompass Bach's complete works for the organ. This year's series of recitals began Thursday night with a recital by George Stauffer, who directs the chapel's musical activities.

title: NORTHWEST UTILITY HALTS ANOTHER NUCLEAR PROJECT
description: The executive board of the Washington Public Power Supply System voted today to halt construction on yet another of its nuclear projects if financing cannot be raised within a month. The action leaves the system with only one remaining project out of the five originally scheduled under a $24 billion program construction program.

title:
PATENTS;
Electrical Connections For a Computer Lab
description: For several years, Edwin Z. Gabriel has been working on computer laboratories that could be used by educational institutions.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. They are characters in the movie ''Return of the Jedi,'' which grossed higher box-office returns on its opening day in Hollywood than the previous single-day record set in 1982 by ''Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan.''

title: AUTOMATION SEEN BY EXPERTS AS A JOB-SAVER FOR INDUSTRIES
description: Robots and other automated manufacturing systems, often portrayed as a dire threat to workers in America's depressed manufacturing industries, would actually save more jobs than they destroy, experts from industry, labor and economics told a scientific conference today.

title: Honor for Miss von Stade
description: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade will receive an honorary doctor of music degree from the Mannes College of Music at commencement exercises next Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. at the school, 157 East 74th Street. Miss von Stade, a member of the Metropolitan Opera, graduated from the school in 1969 and became a trustee in 1979.

title:
PATENTS;
Robot That Follows Painting Instructions
description: A robot that can follow stored instructions in such operations as painting was patented this week for Tokico Ltd., a manufacturer in Kawasaki, Japan.

title: G.M. Faces Recall
description: Howard Kehrl, the General Motors Corporation vice chairman, said that the possible recall of 5.3 million 1978-1980 model midsize A-cars, could cost the company $125 million. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is considering ordering a recall for fear the axles might fall off.

title: A FEEBLE CASE AGAINST THE DEATH PENALTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Tennessee Blast Kills 11 At Fireworks Factory
description: An explosion destroyed an illegal fireworks factory today, killing at least 11 people and hurling bodies through the roofs of nearby buildings.

title: Sandinists Prolonging Curbs
description: The Sandinist Government extended a state of national emergency today for a year. It said the move was needed to counter covert action by the Central Intelligence Agency. The state of emergency, in effect since July 26, 1982, suspends freedom of expression, travel and the press.

title: LITTLE AL UNSER: TO THE AUTO BORN
description: INDIANAPOLIS U ncle Bobby doesn't race here anymore. He retired after his third Indianapolis 500 victory. Uncle Jerry exists only in the memories of the family. He died at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in May 1959, nearly three years before Little Al Unser was born. Dad, Al Unser Sr., is still making left turns and chasing checkered flags. He will start in the seventh position on Sunday, on the inside of the third row.

title: GERMAN SAID TO ADMIT WRITING HITLER DIARIES
description: Konrad Kujau, a Stuttgart dealer in Nazi memorabilia, has confessed to forging the Hitler diaries, a West German prosecutor said today.

title: Life Terms Given In Death of Officer
description: Two Newark men have been sentenced to life terms for a bank robbery in which a Newark police officer was killed. Judge Felix A. Martino of Essex County Superior Court imposed consecutive sentences Thursday on the two, Willie Lee Lawson, 29 years old, and Robert Cooper, 45, both members of the New World of Islam, a militant sect.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve said yesterday that the nation's basic money supply measure rose $2.1 billion in the week ended May 18. The increase was slightly larger than expected and drove up interest rates in late afternoon trading.

title: JUDGE CLEARS F.B.I. OF NEGLIGENCE IN SLAYING OF RIGHTS WORKER
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a $2 million negligence suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation by the children of Viola Gregg Liuzzo, the civil rights worker murdered in Alabama in 1965 by members of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: ARTS GROUP SHAPES WORLD CULTURAL VIEW FOR U.S.
description: Arts International, a Washington-based nonprofit cultural organization, is in the business of answering questions.

title: Boehm Unit to Play
description: The Boehm Quintette will give a concert tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the Guggenheim Museum, featuring the premiere of a piano and wind quintet by Tobias Picker, which was commissioned by the group.

title: FIVE BANKS CLOSED IN TENNESSEE
description: Tennessee and Federal banking regulators yesterday shut five banks controlled by the brothers Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. and, in a deal worked out earlier this week in Washington, sold them.

title:
Patents;
Magnetic Bacteria Particles
description: WASHINGTON ANEW HAMPSHIRE microbiologist who discoverd magnetic bacteria in 1974 believes they can be put to useful purposes. He was granted a patent this week for the development of a pure culture of such bacteria and the recovery of magnetic particles for employment in recording and other devices.

title: Jewish Choral Concert
description: The American Jewish Choral Festival, featuring nine choirs under the direction of Matthew Lazar, will offer a concert in the Abraham Goodman House tomorrow night at 8 o'clock and will conduct workshops Monday from 10:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. The Monday events will be in the Hebrew Arts School, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Ex-Senate Aide Admits Guilt
description: Eric M. Breindel, a former aide to the Senate Intelligence Committee, pleaded guilty Thursday in Federal District Court to possession of heroin. Mr. Breindel, 27 years old, who quit his post after he was arrested two weeks ago, agreed to be questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Agency, and the District of Columbia police, and to a search of his office and safe in the Dirksen Senate Office Building. Sentencing was tentatively set for July 15.

title: Around the World; Peru Holds U.S. Jet For 9 Hours
description: An Eastern Airlines Tristar L-111 jet was held for nine hours here today while its pilot was questioned for taking pictures of nearby military installations, police sources said.

title: COUNCIL'S LEADERS PROPOSE TO ADD $112 MILLION TO 1984 CITY BUDGET
description: City Council leaders yesterday proposed additions to the city's budget for the next fiscal year that would give more money to education, police, fire, sanitation, parks and numerous other agencies.

title: 'SCANDAL IN CHEMICAL TESTING': WHAT HAS HAPPENED SINCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock Film Festival
description: An early-morning festival of rock films begins tonight at midnight in the Eighth Street Playhouse, 52 West Eighth Street, with ''Pink Floyd the Wall.'' ''Led Zeppelin, the Song Remains the Same,'' follows at 2 A.M., and ''Woodstock'' completes the cycle at 4:30 A.M. Admission for all films is $7 ($4 after 4 A.M.).

title: RATHER TESTIFIES ABOUT SIGNATURE OF PHYSICIAN
description: Dan Rather acknowledged in testimony today that after he had made two attempts to reach a doctor who was linked to insurance fraud in a ''60 Minutes'' broadcast, no further efforts were made to reach the man before the show was broadcast more than three weeks later.

title: Going Out Guide
description: MOVIES

title: Around the Nation; Two Mud Slides Force Utah Canyon Evacuation
description: Homeowners in a canyon above Salt Lake City were ordered to evacuate today after two mud slides blocked the canyon top as masses of snow melted in Utah's mountains in temperatures up to the 80's and 90's.

title: 15 Writers Win Prizes Of Arts Institute
description: Fifteen writers have been awarded prizes by the American Academy-Institute of Arts and Letters. Eight of them have been awarded $5,000 each ''to honor and encourage them in their creative work.''

title: END OF AT-LARGE SEATS ON COUNCIL IS ENDORSED
description: New York City's Charter Revision Commission said yesterday that it would recommend the abolishment of the 10 at-large City Council posts and the formation of an independent panel to redraw the Council's election districts.

title: Panel to Study Rise In Pay for Officials
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he and other top city officials deserved a raise, and he named a commission to study the issue. Mr. Koch selected Richard R. Shinn, former chief executive officer and board chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, to head the five-member group. Mr. Shinn served in a similar capacity on a 1979 panel that recommended raises for city officials.

title: Bridge: What May Appear Sloppy Could Actually Be a Trap
description: In many situations in bridge, as in life, something slightly odd happens. Most of the time the oddity will be trivial and meaningless. But occasionally it will have an unexpected impact.

title: Simon Says No
description: William Simon, a former Treasury Secretary and a man often mentioned as the successor to Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, says he is not interested in the job. In an interview with USA Today, Simon reported that he had canceled a meeting scheduled for yesterday with Bud Selig, who is heading the search committee to find a replacement for Kuhn. His primary responsibility, Simon said, will continue to be his presidency of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: MRS. THATCHER SEES THE FUTURE AND SAYS IT WORKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited the future today, the future that she promises her policies will create for Britain, and concluded that it worked.

title: News Analysis
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which must decide soon whether to shut on grounds of faulty emergency planning the two nuclear power plants operating at Indian Point, heard both extremes of the argument this week -that all the problems had been solved, and that the difficulties of evacuation would always defy solution.

title: DIPLOMAT WITH A DIRECT STYLE: LANGHORNE ANTHONY MOTLEY
description: One of the delicacies of Brazilian political life this year has been how to deal with Leonel Brizola, the new Socialist Governor of the state of Rio de Janeiro. Mr. Brizola was a principal target of the coup that brought the military to power, and he spent 15 years in exile before returning to win last November's election.

title: HELMS DEFENDS ASKING TREASURY CHIEF'S HELP
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, asked Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan for help in a tobacco case that the Senator said could help his 1984 re-election effort, but he said he never asked Mr. Regan ''to make an improper decision.''

title: UNFERTILIZED HUMAN EGG BEGINS DEVELOPMENT
description: Scientists have experimentally created an eight-cell human embryo from an egg that was not fertilized, the British science journal Nature reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sounds From the Hills Of New Guinea

title: NEW FLAIR FOR LARGE AND SMALL SIZES
description: If most fashion designers had their way, all women would be at least 5 feet 8 and as slender as willow wands. It would help, too, if their ages were permanently frozen in their 20's. But reality isn't like that. Women come in shapes and sizes far from the designing ideal and those who do not fit the mold find shopping frustrating.

title: No Headline
description: Kathy Young shot a 4-under-par 68 and moved into the second-round lead of the $150,000 Corning Classic. Miss Young, with a total of 139, tied the record for the front nine of the Corning Country Club course by shooting a 31.

title: THEATER: MIME IN ORBIT IN 'INCLINED TO AGREE'
description: For Daniel Stein's ''Inclined to Agree,'' the apron of the stage at the Dance Theater Workshop is scalloped with a decolletage of small building blocks, resting on a long curved ribbon. After a moodsetting prelude -no movement and a humming musical background - with the audience sitting in hushed anticipation, watching the scenery as if it were a museum installation, a single block is toppled off stage. On cue, the entire line of blocks falls, one by one. Then the ribbon is pulled off stage in one brisk movement.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum RateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PROFILES OF THE SEVEN LEADERS AT WILLIAMSBURG
description: Ronald Reagan ... 72 ... President of the United States since 1981 ... Host and moderator for the summit discussions ... Must defend charges, much like those leveled last year, that U.S. budget deficits and high interest rates are damaging the world economy ... Skeptical of plan by President Mitterrand to set up new structure to stabilize international currency exchange rates ... Has tried to establish understanding with allies on trade with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries ... Has vowed to veto any new tax increases ... Maintains that his economic policies are bearing fruit ... Idealistic, staunchly conservative. JAPAN Yasuhiro Nakasone ... 65 ... Elected Japan's Prime Minister last year ... Conservative veteran of mainstream Japanese politics ... Has moved to liberalize trade laws to open up the Japanese market, but the U.S. and others remain skeptical, criticizing Japan's low yen and high trade surplus ... Faces Japan's highest unemployment rate in 30 years ... Favors reduction in government spending to trim budget deficits ... His Liberal Democratic Party won sweeping victories in nationwide local elections last April ... A maverick personality with a direct manner and exceptional public speaking abilities, in English as well as Japanese. WEST GERMANY Helmut Kohl ... 53 ... West German Chancellor since Oc@tober ... A conservative Christian Democrat ... Faces an unemployment level hovering at 10 percent, near post-war record levels ... But has remained optimistic, as the rate of inflation has slowed, and investment levels have increased ... In foreign policy, has stressed continuity with the Government of former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, and an improvement of relations with the Unites States ... Expects the summit meeting to deal primarily with unemployment and the international debt crisis ... Regarded as genial but uninspiring ... Speaks no foreign languages.

title: The Beauty Of Belmont
description: T he first time I saw a horse running without a New York City policeman on his back was at the 1963 Dutchess County Fair. The fair was only 90 miles from the city, but to a child of Manhattan this annual celebration of farm life seemed as alien and exotic as China.

title: 48% RISE ASKED BY LILCO TO PAY SHOREHAM COSTS
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today asked for a 45 percent rate increase to cover the cost of opening its Shoreham nuclear power plant and operating it through 1987.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: The Agriculture Department announced today that talks with the Soviet Union on a new long-term grain supply agreement would be held in London next Thursday.

title: Woman Abducts An Infant on L.I.
description: A 17-month-old girl was taken from her stroller inside a Suffolk County shop yesterday afternoon. The authorities said they were looking for a heavyset woman in her 30's or 40's with a ''disheveled appearence'' who apparently drove off with the child in a brown hatchback.

title: STEINBRENNER IN A DISPUTE AFTER YANKS, A'S BRAWL
description: The Yankees defeated the Oakland A's, 4-2, last night on a threerun home run by Graig Nettles against Mike Norris in the seventh inning. However, it was a pitch that Norris threw to Dave Winfield in the first inning that resulted in a fight, Winfield's ejection, three formal statements and a promise of disciplinary action against George Steinbrenner by Lee MacPhail, the American League president.

title: FIRM FINDS REWARD IN A GRIM SPECIALTY
description: It was July 1981, and Roger L. McCarthy had just received a horrifying telephone call: Two suspended walkways at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City, Mo., had collapsed, killing 114 people. The caller, a lawyer for the architectural firm that had designed the walkways, needed to know why.

title: Cubans Without a Country
description: Back in 1980, Fidel Castro had a problem. Humiliated by an exodus of 125,000 Cubans from Mariel, he opened his jails and dumped several thousand criminals into the United States. Now the United States has a problem. It wants Cuba to take back convicted felons ineligible for residency here and unwanted elsewhere. But it refuses to talk with Cuba about anything else.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Syrian buildup of forces into Lebanon and along the Syrian-Lebanon border can lead only to increased tensions in an already volatile area and could threaten the uneasy peace that now prevails in Lebanon.'' - The State Department. (1:6.)

title: CORRECTION
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday misidentified the seller of a version of Augustus Saint-Gaudens's ''Victory.'' It is an unidentified Pennsylvania academy.

title: Road and Track
description: Calumet Farm in Lexington, Ky., one of the most successful stables in the history of American thoroughbred racing, did not have an entry in either the Kentucky Derby or the Preakness Stakes this year. But tomorrow Calumet will have a great rooting interest in two races.

title: German Exports Fall
description: A slump in West German exports caused the country's trade surplus to contract sharply in April, according to statistics released today, lessening the likelihood of an export-led revival of the economy later this year.

title: Around the World; Argentine Ex-President Freed From Army Camp
description: Former President Leopoldo Galtieri has been freed from detention at an army camp on the outskirts of Buenos Aires, the press agency Noticias Argentinas said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Canine Campaigners

title: GRAND JURY FOREMAN ACCUSED OF EXTORTING BRIBE FROM WITNESS
description: The foreman of a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with seeking to extort more than $6,000 in bribes from witnesses before the panel and with accepting $300 as the first installment.

title: Dow Off 7.35, to 1,216.14; Gain for Week 26.12
description: The stock market closed out a strong week yesterday with moderate losses in less active trading, The main casualties were some of the recently strong transportation, technology and blue-chip issues that fell sharply as investors cashed in some of their recent gains.

title: Study of Sex Selection Gains
description: Techniques being developed for farm animals may ultimately allow humans to choose the sex of their children, possibly leading to the birth of many more sons than daughters, researchers said today. Although there have been assertions that it is already possible to choose the sex of children, there is no scientific evidence to back them up, according to researchers at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: Bean Takes Lead by 2 Strokes; Shoots 67 in Memorial; Crenshaw 2nd
description: Andy Bean's caddie, Wayne Beck, presented Bean with an old putter last Sunday, one that Beck had used for years. The caddie suggested to Bean that he might feel more comfortable with the change because the putter Bean had been using had not been dropping many putts recently.

title: Consumer Saturday; APPRAISERS WILL HOLD FREE CLINIC
description: DETERMINING the value or cost of such personal possessions as j ewelry, art objects, antiques and other collectibles can be a d ifficult task, not only because of fluctuating market demand and v olatile prices of precious metals and gems but also because one c annot ordinarily do comparison shopping on such items.

title: MERGER TALKS CITED BY MARYLAND CUP
description: The Maryland Cup Corporation, a leading manufacturer and distributor of a wide range of paper and plastic food service products based in Owings Mills, Md., reported yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger discussions with another corporation, but that terms had not been settled upon, nor had they been submitted to Maryland Cup's board.

title: HOOKS CASE: A NEW FOCUS
description: The reinstatement of Benjamin L. Hooks as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has eased some tensions within the civil rights organization. But some of its board members say the underlying issue has brought into sharp focus the need for changes in the way the group has functioned.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 28, 1983
description: International The United States cautioned Syria that its latest military buildup in Lebanon and along the Syrian-Lebanese border was threatening ''the uneasy peace'' in the area. The statement followed several days of diplomatic messages between the United States, Israel and Syria. (Page 1, Column 6.) Israel would resist a war with Syria, Defense Minister Moshe Arens said in a speech in Tel Aviv. In a pledge of firm restraint, Mr. Arens said, ''We cannot be provoked.'' (5:1.)

title: 2 Charged in Ohio Murder
description: Murder and robbery charges were filed Thursday against two Cleveland men in the murder in 1980 of Stella Walsh, a former Olympic track star. One suspect, Ricky Clark, 24 years old, was in custody, and the second, Donald Cassidy, 21, remained at large. Miss Walsh, a native of Poland, won a gold medal in the 1932 Olympics.

title: Offensive Shift For Notre Dame?
description: Mal Moore, the longtime offensive coordinator with the Alabama football team, was hired for the same position at Notre Dame last winter, and ever since then there has been speculation that the Irish would change their offense from the power I to a wishbone or some form of the option offense.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Street-Corner Hero

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about tobacco allotments incorrectly identified a farmer inspecting a crop. He was Scott McGuire.

title: Flyer Changes
description: In a major restructuring of their front office, the Philadelphia Flyers have added the duties of general manager to those of coach for Bob McCammon and have signed him to a multiyear contract for both roles. McCammon had been considering an offer from the Pittsburgh Penguins, who were looking for someone to replace their general manager, Baz Bastien, who was killed in a car crash two months ago.

title: Reese Granted Parole
description: The Florida Parole Commission has decided to free Don Reese, the former Miami Dolphin defensive lineman, from prison on June 21, five months after he began serving his sentence. Reese was on probation from a term for cocaine dealing when he acknowledged in a widely publicized magazine article last June that he had continued to use the drug.

title: TAUGHT ENGINEERING AND ART AT COLUMBIA
description: Frank H. Lee, professor emeritus of engineering graphics at Columbia University and the originator of a program for a combined liberal arts and engineering education, died Thursday following a stroke at his home in Roslyn, L.I. He was 82 years old.

title: JACOBS GROUP AGREES TO BUY KAISER
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest steel producer, said yesterday it had accepted in principle a sweetened takeover offer from an investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis financier.

title: Requiem for an Adviser
description: Memorial Day will have a poignant meaning for the family of Albert A. Schaufelberger 3d, U.S.N., the first American adviser to die in El Salvador. He was sent to that country to help save it from the savagery that claimed him. Who were his executioners? A distraught United States official had this first response: ''It could have been from the left, it could have been from the right; you never know here.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE ADMINISTRATION PAPER ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Following are excerpts from ''Background Paper: Central America,'' a white paper made public today by the State and Defense Departments: Castro's Strategy

title: U.N. HEAD URGES HELP FOR POOR
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has urged President Reagan and the six other heads of state who will attend this weekend's economic summit meeting at Williamsburg, Va., to provide more aid to the third world and to develop more trade with it.

title: Schlichter Treated on L.I.
description: The treatment center where Art Schlichter is undergoing therapy for compulsive gambling is South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, L.I. The Baltimore Colt quarterback was suspended indefinitely by the National Football League last week for having bet on N.F.L. games and other sports events.

title: ALIBI FOR SPEEDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTISTS VS. THE LORDS OF THE LOFTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 1984 Arrives Early
description: After a brief flirtation with common sense, Congress reverted to the higher wisdom of absurdity this week and voted to slow down the arms race by accelerating the arms race.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: One Man's Crusade

title: Mortgage Agency To Get New Head
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday nominated the director of his gubernatorial campaign, William Haddad, chairman of the State Mortgage Agency.

title: Around the Nation; Woman Denied Custody Of Son Hidden by U.S.
description: A Federal district judge here has refused to grant a Kansas City woman custody of her 13-year-old son, who has been in hiding with his father for more than four years under the Federal Witness Protection Program.

title: Iran Indemnity Accord
description: The Iranian Government has paid Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles $17 million as indemnification for the French oil company's share in the Iranian oil consortium that was dissolved after the Iranian revolution of 1979, a spokesman for the company said today. The settlement comes four months after Iran paid Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, another French oil company, $333 million for debts incurred before the revolution.

title: Maryland Eases Rules on Lasix
description: A week after a judge allowed Desert Wine and Marfa to use Lasix in the Preakness Stakes, the State Racing Commission's thoroughbred board has agreed to relax its restrictions on the use of the drug.

title: APRIL TRADE GAP WIDER DESPITE OIL PRICE DROP
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened to $4.6 billion in April even though the price of imported oil dropped to the lowest level in more than three years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: QUEENS PUPILS RELIVE 'COLLEGE BOWL'
description: Erik Dina knew that G.I. stands for Goverment issue. Satip Ghosh knew that the duck-billed platypus, mammal though it is, lays eggs. Laurie Meinberg knew that Renoir and Degas were Impressionists. Nobody knew that the mutineers from the Bounty landed on Pitcairn Island, or that Georges Bizet composed ''Carmen,'' but that was all right.

title: HAGLER SCORES KNOCKOUT
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, proving he was still the undisputed middlweight champion no matter what the World Boxing Council, World Boxing Association or Kenny Weldon said, tonight stopped Wilford Scypion in the fourth round with another brilliant performance.

title: Deputed Testamony in Outside Post
description: Deputed Testamony, the upset winner of the Preakness Stakes, drew the outside post in a field of 12 yesterday for the $200,000-added Pennsylvania Derby at Keystone Race Track on Monday.

title: REFORM JAIL SENTENCING
description: New York State's method of sentencing convicted criminals frequently produces widely disparate prison terms for the same crime. A completely different, more equitable system is needed.

title: BOY FIGHTING RETURN TO SOVIET LOSES ILLINOIS APPEALS RULING
description: Fifteen-year-old Walter Polovchak, who ran away from home rather than go back to the Soviet Union with his family, can be returned to his parents' custody if they come to the United States to get him, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Jessica A. Swigert Wed in Carolina
description: Jessica Anne Swigert of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Jarvis Swigert of Lehigh, Fla., was married yesterday to Welles Murphey Jr., also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphey of Casey Key, Fla., and Shelter Island, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Robert Kencheloe of the First Presbyterian Church at Hilton Head Island, S.C., performed the ceremony on the South Beach there.

title: PHYSICIAN FIANCE OF DR. FLASCHEN
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stewart S. Flaschen of New Caanan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Sheryl Lynn Flaschen, to Dr. George Harrison Talbot, son of Mrs. Harrison Talbot of St. Davids, Pa., and the late Dr. L. James Talbot of New York. The wedding is to be in July.

title: E.P.A. HEAD SEEKS UNIT TO SET POLICY ON HEALTH
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the Reagan Administration should consider creating a national commission to find ''some universal way'' to measure health risks and assess how much it was willing to pay to reduce those risks.

title: LIVERPOOL'S SOCIALIST BUDGET RUNS INTO THE RED
description: Soon after the Labor Party took control of the City Council here in municipal elections May 5, the councilors voted to strip the ceremonial office of Lord Mayor of its pomp and regalia, selling its Rolls-Royce, open carriage and two Gelderland horses.

title: Major News in Summary; Syria Lets Fly With Missiles And Mutineers
description: Syria last week pursued its spoiler's role against the recently signed Israeli-Lebanese accord.

title: The Nation in Summary; Dismissed E.P.A. Aide Is Indicted
description: The controversy that has so farbrought the resignations of a baker's dozen of President Reagan's high appointees to the Environmental Protection Agency last week produced its first indictment, that of Rita Lavelle. the former head of the agency's toxic waste cleanup program. The charge, denied again after the indictment, is that she ''wilfully'' refused to testify before a House subcommittee investigating allegations of political manipulation of the $1.6 billion cleanup ''superfund.''

title: HE REMODELED THE COSMOS
description: KEPLER, By John Banville. 195 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95.

title: VALENZUELA STOPS GIANTS ON 2 HITS, 5-0
description: Fernando Valenzuela, who gave up only two hits, pitched his second straight shutout to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-0 victory today over the San Francisco Giants.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article about Citicorp in The Times Magazine today, in a reference on page 18, incorrectly states the amount of Citicorp's dollar-denominated loans to Brazil. It is $4.3 billion. The article also refers to a Citicorp policy of sending customers with low deposits to banking machines rather than to tellers; after it was printed, the company announced that it was dropping the practice.

title: Cynthia Kamford Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Austin Kamford of West Hempstead, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Diane Kamford, to Robert Charles Marino of Elizabeth and Toms River, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gaspar Marino of Elizabeth. An October wedding is planned. The future bride is a nurse at the Upjohn Corporation in Hicksville, L.I. Her fiance is a merchandising manager for the Wakefern-ShopRite Corporation in Elizabeth.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; How It Was At Bikini
description: On July 25, 1946, a 23-kiloton atomic bomb exploded beneath the lagoon of Bikini Island. A million-ton column of radioactive water rose 6,000 feet into the air, then rained down upon the fleet of ''target'' ships assembled for the test.

title: THE FRESH AIR FUND SEEKS COUNTY HOSTS
description: FOR 20 minutes last week, Elba Melendez was 9 years old again, reliving her dream come true - of leaving the streets of Spanish Harlem and riding horseback in the country, of swapping stories late at night with a new friend or simply taking long walks where the air is clear and trees are seemingly everywhere.

title: WHERE PRICE AND MUSIC BLEND
description: By far the most popular price bracket for loudspeakers lies between $100 and $200 and, except for those specializing in the upper fringes of audio, nearly every manufacturer fields an entry in this class. As a result, the choice is ample and varied.

title: TRACING THE THREAD OF ISLAMIC JEWELRY
description: Jewelry, one of the most revealing of art forms, tells us how people view themselves and what they value in their world. The design and materials used throughout history in crafting rings, necklaces, bracelets, belts, hair ornaments, earrings and brooches speak volumes about the men, women and children who wore them and the society in which they lived. Whatever dominates in a civilization - religion, worldly wealth, intellectual or human concerns - is reflected in these baubles. And so are the personal idiosyncracies of the artisans who crafted them.

title:
Gardening;
CARING FOR AN OLD FRIEND, THE TOMATO
description: OF all the plants in the garden, tomatoes are undoubtedly the most widely planted. A survey conducted by the National Association for Gardening indicated that 94 percent of all American gardeners grow these delicious, nutritious fruits.

title:
The World in Summary;
FAint Echoes Of Paris '68
description: In Paris last week, clubs and stones and broken bones may have evoked memories of student riots 15 years ago, but no real comparisons. In their sixth week of street demonstrations against proposed university reforms, the students of the 1980's couldn't muster the numbers, the fervor or the unity that enabled their predecessors to nearly topple the French Government in 1968.

title: N.H.L. TO WEIGH PLAN TO BUY BLUES AND KEEP CLUB IN ST. LOUIS
description: The wrangling over the future of the St. Louis Blues hockey franchise has spilled over into legal territory that could put the team in limbo for next season.

title: ARMS FIRST TOPIC AS LEADERS GATHER FOR SUMMIT TALKS
description: With a display of Colonial pageantry, President Reagan opened the summit conference of major industrial democracies today and held an extensive dinner discussion with the allies on arms negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: THREATENED BY APOCALYPSE
description: THE BIRTH OF THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF ANTARCTICA, By John Calvin Batchelor. 403 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $16.95.

title: CELLISTS DISPLAY THEIR ELEGANT MASTERY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: Support for Ryan From History
description: To the Sports Editor: In his letter (May 8) Dan Wallack complained that Walter Johnson achieved his strikeout record when the major leagues had only 16 teams instead of the present 26, and thus Nolan Ryan's strikeout record has been achieved against a large number of inferior players who would not have been in the majors in Johnson's time.

title: BANK LOAN CHANGES VOTED BY NEW YORK LEGISLATURE
description: Banks could no longer penalize borrowers who pay back loans early, but would be allowed for the first time to offer variable-rate installment loans, under a bill sent to the Governor this week by the State Legislature.

title: FRESH AIR CHILDREN THRIVE IN COUNTRY
description: Van Riley stood in front of his second-grade class and spoke of last summer. Eight-year-old Van told the 32 other students in class 2-451 at Public School 36 in Harlem and his teacher, Leona Cameron, about the two weeks he had spent as a Fresh Air Fund child.

title: What's Doing In Calgary
description: based writer and broadcaster for nine years. By ROBERT D.BOTT

title: ARMY FINDS WELDING GAS BROUGHT HOSPITAL DEATHS
description: FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., May 28 (AP) - A tank resembling an oxygen container but faintly labeled ''argon,'' a gas used in welding, was examined by investigators today after the deaths of two patients who breathed the gas at the Army hospital here.

title: Westchester Guide; AIRPORT CELEBRATION
description: A portion of the County Airport will be turned over to the public from 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. next Sunday when the Air National Guard hangars are cleared to house a circus, musical revue, band concert and a display of antique and contemporary aircraft -all free, in celebration of Westchester County's Tricentennial.

title: Elizabeth Powers Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Helen Whitecotton Powers of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Francis C. Powers of New York and Honolulu of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Radley Powers, to Isaac Hallowell Clothier 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clothier 4th of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: WORK ON ROUTE 9
description: ASTATE transportation official said last week that his agency was studying improvements to a portion of Route 9, a major north-south route along the Hudson River, between the villages of Ossining and North Tarrytown.

title:
Gardening;
CARING FOR AN OLD FRIEND, THE TOMATO
description: OF all the plants in the garden, tomatoes are undoubtedly the most widely planted. A survey conducted by the National Association for Gardening indicated that 94 percent of all American gardeners grow these delicious, nutritious fruits.

title: Around the World; Authorities in Gdansk Question Walesa Again
description: Lech Walesa, a founder of the Solidarity labor union, was summoned to Gdansk police headquarters today for the second consecutive day.

title: SLEUTHS TRACING THE HISTORY OF THEIR HOUSES
description: IT was five years ago, Susan Rudolph of Rye recalled, when she sat alone in the dusty archives of the Columbia School of Architecture, rummaging through box after box of papers, drawings and photographs. The cartons contained uncatalogued materials from the office of a renowned church architect, Hobart B. Upjohn, the man who designed Mrs. Rudolph's two-story Tudor house on Clark Lane.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about the Ken Russell production of ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., in last Sunday's Arts and Leisure section, the singer in the role of Lieutenant Pinkerton was erroneously identified in both the text and a caption. His name is Barry McCauley.

title: No Headline
description: College Need Not Stay in Bridgeport It's unfortunate that your excellent article on the problems regarding the relocation of Housatonic Community College (''College in Bridgeport Seeks a New Home,'' May 1) failed to deal with several major factors that affect the relocation.

title: Reagan to Fill Justice Post
description: President Reagan said Thursday that he would nominate Stephen S. Trott, the United States Attorney in Los Angeles, to head the criminal division in the Justice Department. Mr. Trott, 43 years old, would succeed D. Lowell Jensen as Assistant Attorney General.

title: TWO COINS BESPECK HUNTINGTON'S PAST
description: ABOUT 10 years ago, while searching for historical artifacts at a North Shore site, Arthur Moyano of Smithtown heard the kind of frenzied electronic humming that is music to any coin collector.

title:
ART;
16 ARTISTS' EXPLORATIONS OF WHAT REALISM CAN BE
description: WE hear a great deal about the revival of recognizable imagery in art, and this, presumably, has inspired the Hempstead Harbor Artists Gallery in Glen Cove to assemble -with partial funding from the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development - a small contemporary survey called ''Aspects of Realism.''

title: 'FIDDLER' RETURNS AS AN OLD FRIEND
description: SET in 1905 in Czarist Russia, ''Fiddler on the Roof'' focuses on Tevye the dairyman, his family and the trials and tribulations of life in the Jewish ghetto of the tiny town of Anatevka. Since its opening on Broadway in 1964, the musical, with music by Jerry Bock, lyrics by Sheldon Harnick and book by Joseph Stein, has successfully sung and danced its way across the world's stages. It is ensconced through June 25 at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, where it is as welcome as weekend sunshine.

title: Million-to-1 Shot
description: A 34-year-old psychiatrist in Oceanside, L.I., Dr. Edgar Frenkel, was facing death from bone-marrow cancer. The possible cure was a marrow transplant from a healthy donor, but a rare combination of antigens in the doctor's blood made the odds of finding a perfect match a million to one.

title: EXILED FROM WISDOM
description: PILGERMANN, By Russell Hoban. 240 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95.

title: No Headline
description: The Votes in Congress table May 15, and a correction last Sunday, gave an incorrect vote by Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of the Bronx and Manhattan, on a housing assistance bill. He voted yes.

title: HOMOSEXUALS FIND A NEED TO REASSESS
description: ''EVEN if you think about cheating - this, you die from, so you really do watch what you're doing,'' said Jerry, a 47-year-old computer programmer who has had a seven-year relationship with his male lover.

title: THE FORCE IS WITH THEM, BUT THE MAGIC IS GONE
description: Riding an M-104 bus up Broadway last week, I overheard two young men, both in their late teens, discussing the imminent release of ''Return of the Jedi,'' the third installment of George Lucas's initial ''Star Wars'' trilogy. Their excitement was real, you might say palpable, until one fellow suddenly turned pensive. He was disoriented. If he had been five years younger, he would have cried. ''What happened in the second one?'' he said. ''I don't remember it too well. I only saw it once.''

title: Careful Shopper
description: Prices to Cotton To At Cottontails

title: Best of Three
description: Squeezing through the same sort of party primary vote split that ended up giving Chicago its first black Mayor, Lieut. Gov. Martha Layne Collins of Kentucky moved into position to become that state's first woman Governor last week. Pitted against two more liberal candidates who split nearly 414,000 votes between them, Mrs. Collins won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination with little more than 220,000 votes, beating her closest rival by a scant 3,500. Kentucky being heavily Democratic, Mrs. Collins is expected to go on to the Statehouse in November.

title: FOSTER CARE INVESTIGATIONS SET
description: JERSEY CITY THE plight of a mother fighting for the return of her 7-year-old son, who, she contends, was physically abused in two foster homes, has prompted one Assemblyman to seek increased legal help for indigent parents battling state agencies and another to seek an investigation of the state's Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: AFTER A DECADE, A PEOPLE PLAZA
description: IN the annals of Manhattan's skyscraper architecture, the 1960's m ight be referred to as the age of the plaza and the 1970's as the e ra of the atrium.

title: VETERAN FIGHTING DENIAL OF BENEFITS
description: A disabled winner of the Medal of Honor, denied Social Security benefits because he was deemed capable of a full day's work, has appealed the case.

title: Lucie Wing Meyer, Boutique Manager, And Joseph Kenneally 3d Have Bridal
description: In St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday, Lucie Wing Meyer, daughter of Mrs. Henry H. Bard of Locust Valley and the late S. Willets Meyer, was married to Joseph Thomas Kenneally 3d, son of Mr. Kenneally Jr. and Patricia Steele Kenneally, both of Houston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. Lawrence Costello, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PRIMARIES: MORE THAN A PRELUDE
description: TRENTON ENROLLED Democrats and Republicans will go to the polls June 7 to select candidates for 120 seats in the Legislature - 40 in the Senate and 80 in the Assembly - and although many incumbents are running for renomination without opposition, there are several heated contests.

title: VIOLENCE-PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE-HAUNTS ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's political future is hostage to a dilemma for which there is no evident answer - how to account for thousands of Argentines who disappeared in the 1970's and still return the country to democracy. After seven years of military rule, the Government of President Reynaldo B. Bignone has promised to hold elections in October and to step down in January. But the military demands a guarantee that it will not be drawn into the investigation of more than 6,000 people estimated to have disappeared in the military's antiterrorist campaign. The guarantee has not been made a specific condition for elections, but the threat of current or future coups needs little reminder in this coup-ridden country.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: OUSTING ENDERS, PRESIDENT SIGNALS A TOUGHER COMMITMENT
description: As Air Force One ferried President Reagan to the Williamsburg summit last week, Secretary of State George P. Shultz walked to the back of the plane to tell reporters that Thomas O. Enders, the career diplomat who had handled the State Department's Latin American policy for two years, was being replaced. He would be succeeded by Langhorne A. Motley, a Republican, currently Ambassador to Brazil. Mr. Shultz treated the change as ''routine.'' It was anything but.

title:
About Westchester;
A GUN ON ONE HIP, A STETHOSCOPE ON THE OTHER
description: POLICE officer Andy Kelleher of Greenburgh wears a little medal indicating he is a marksmanship expert, but his coordination is put to the test with more than a pistol. Officer Kelleher is also known to be especially skilled at starting an intravenous line, finding a vein in an arm whose veins appear to be spent and inserting a needle into it.

title: TORRINGTON TURNS OUT TO HONOR ITS 'NEW' THEATER
description: COLORED Cadillac roadster, vintage 1932, was parked outside the Warner Theater in Torrington a week ago. Men and women in tuxedos and long gowns, and others in blue jeans and tailored suits mingled on the sidewalk and in the lobby as the beam from a large rotating spotlight drew even more people to Main Street.

title: Saving on Energy
description: When East Windsor Township, N.J., put up a new municipal building last year, it wasn't interested in flashy looks; some people thought the finished work resembled a Mayan ruin.

title: The Region in Summary; Trying to Make Prisons Pay Off
description: Jails aren't very welcome in many communities. So when Governor Kean and Governor Cuomo traveled last week to Newark and Erie County, respectively - both of which are beset by high unemployment - and announced plans for prisons, each was careful to emphasize a beneficial byproduct: jobs.

title: Miss Ross, Boston Banker, And Paul Cusack Are Wed
description: Susan Gillespie Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Ross of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Edward Cusack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence X. Cusack of Manhasset, L.I. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by Msgr. William Noe Field at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Practical Traveler; TOURISTS AND TROPICAL DISEASES
description: As summer nears, health officials are focusing attention on malaria and other tropical diseases in an effort to coax travelers to take appropriate measures to avoid them. Special emphasis is placed on malaria because in some areas of the world it is becoming increasingly resistant to chloroquine, a drug that has long been depended on to prevent it.

title: NEW JERSEY PINELANDS PRESERVATION WORKS SO WELL IT HURTS
description: Three years ago a New Jersey commission set out to limit development in the 1,700 square miles of Pinelands, preserve the area's unique ecology and conserve the 17 trillion gallons of drinkable water that are beneath its wooded surface. Now there are indications it may be doing its job too well.

title: Steelers Sign Rivera
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers have signed their No.1 draft selection, Gabriel Rivera, who appears destined to replace the retired Joe Greene at defensive tackle.

title: ROLE OF PHYSICIAN ASSISTANTS QUERIED
description: UPON entering St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn recently for a triple coronary bypass operation, Murray Draluck of Bayside was met by Lynnbey Cook, a physician assistant, who recorded Mr. Draluck's medical history and performed a physical examination. Mr. Cook then outlined the surgical procedure to his patient and explained that his assistance to the surgeon would include his performing part of the operation.

title: Amy Cuddy Plans Sept. 17 Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cuddy of Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Clarke Cuddy, to Eric Eugene Stevens, son of Mr and Mrs. Earl E. Stevens of Cumberland, R.I. A Sept. 17 wedding is planned.

title: Rose M. Cubbon Is Wed in Oil City
description: Rose Marie Cubbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Cubbon of Oil City, Pa., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Dwight Leeper 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leeper Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Camden, Me. The Rev. Arnold Rhodes performed the ceremony at the Trinity Methodist Church in Oil City.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The nation's inflation rate rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest increase in consumer prices since last July. But analysts pointed to an increase of 5 cents a gallon in the Federal gasoline tax as a major reason for the increase, rather than any revival of inflationary pressures. The increase - termed ''a one-month blip'' by one private analyst - was twice the average monthly advance for the period from September 1981 through March, and amounted to an annual inflation rate of 7.2 percent. But the rise was actually less than some had predicted. Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that excluding energy costs, the annual rate of inflation for the month would have been 4.7 percent.

title: Astros 9, Cardinals 2
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Jose Cruz hit a two-run pinch double in Houston's four-run fifth inning, and Dickie Thon drove home two runs and scored two.

title: BRIEF ENCOUNTER AT BEDFORD HILLS
description: YESTERDAY I went to prison. They admitted me through the high wire fence, through the security area, guarded by men in uniforms, through the razor-wire-topped inner fence. I was searched with the aid of a metal-detector and then my hand was stamped with a mark, visible only under ultraviolet light. Although I knew that I was arriving as an invited guest, coming to view an innovative new addition to the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, I was actually nervous as I was going through this admission procedure. I couldn't help hoping that the stamp, which in many ways was the only thing that distinguished me from those women who were not visitors, would remain visible to the light, that a rub of a sleeve or of a bracelet would not remove this passport to freedom from my wrist.

title: IT'S CHE SERA, SERA IN COPING WITH ITALY
description: Two words you must know for travel in Italy: ''sciopero'' (''strike'') and ''chiuso'' (''closed''). A few examples gathered from recent trip will show you what I mean. But first it should be noted that coping with strikes and unexpected closures rationally and patiently, rather than in anger, can make the difference between a happy trip and sheer frustration.

title: Dr. John R. Johnson, 82, Dies; Professor Emeritus at Cornell
description: Dr. John R. Johnson, Todd Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at Cornell University, died of emphysema Wednesday at his home in Townshend, Vt. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S. AGENCY FAULTS INDIAN PT. REPORT
description: The General Accounting Office and the operators of the Indian Point nuclear reactors in Westchester County have disagreed on the method of assessing the risk of a serious accident at the plants.

title: A QUEENS LANDLORD HONORS TENANTS
description: IT is rare in New York City for a landlord to give a party for his t enants and rarer still for tenants to say nice things about their l andlord. But that's what happened this month at the Atlas Terminals i n Glendale, Queens.

title: U.S. REBUKES SOVIET FOR NUCLEAR WEAPONS THREAT
description: The United States, reacting sharply to a Soviet threat to deploy medium-range nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe, asserted today that Moscow was seeking to achieve ''military superiority and thus global hegemony'' with its tactics.

title: SCOTLAND WITH SPIRIT
description: ISRAEL SHENKER, who lives in Perthshire, Scotland, is the author of ''In the Footsteps of Boswell and Johnson'' (Houghton Mifflin). By ISRAEL SHENKER

title: A SAFETY-DEPOSIT TWIST
description: The safety-deposit vaults of commercial banks have been among the most secure places for personal valuables, but until the recent development of the 24-hour vault, accessibility to property in the vaults was limited to banking hours.

title: TYROLEAN NATIONALISM PRESSED IN ITALIAN VOTE
description: ''I, too, feel Austrian,'' said the president of the northern Italian province of Bolzano, known in German as the autonomous province of Bozen-Sudtirol. ''Even today, Austria is our fatherland and Italy our state. I don't feel Italian.''

title: THE U.S. WORLD CUP BID HAD SOME SERIOUS FAILINGS
description: WHAT an impressive scene it was that day last June in Madrid's Bernabeu Stadium as the national anthems of England and West Germany were played before a World Cup soccer match between those countries.

title: OFFICIALS AND THE LEGAL AID SOCIETY TO DISCUSS APPEALS CASES BACKLOG
description: Talks involving the Legal Aid Society, New York City officials and officials of the legal community will be held this week in hopes of finding a way to clear the society's mounting backlog of appeals cases.

title: G.G. Hogan Wed To Bonnie Hunt
description: Bonnie Heather Hunt, daughter of Dr. Donald C. Hunt and Elizabeth A. Hunt, both of Middlebury, Vt., was married there yesterday to Gregory Gilson Hogan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert F. Hogan of Woodbridge, Conn., and Quechee Lakes, Vt. The Rev. David Andrews, assisted by the Rev. James Mattison, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Middlebury Congregational Church.

title: BLACK WRITERS AND PRODUCERS ARE WIDENING THEIR FOCUS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Lacayo is a freelance writer specializing in the arts. BY RICHARD LACAYO

title: RISE IN MORTGAGE RATES FOUND TO AFFECT LANDLORDS SEVERELY
description: Increased interest rates and other changes in the financing of mortgages since the mid-1970's ''have drastically affected'' many owners of rent-stabilized buildings, a study conducted for the New York City Rent Guidelines Board has determined.

title: IN COMMONS, WOMEN FACE MALE BASTION
description: Helen Liddell is one of the most precocious figures in British public life. At the age of 32, she has already been active in politics for 16 years, and she has served as the chief professional organizer of the Labor Party in Scotland for more than six of those. She is highly esteemed by her peers.

title: HAYDN'S CHAMBER MUSIC HAS ITS DAY
description: We can never have too many Haydn recordings, and three recent ones - all devoted to his chamber music -have their individual messages to convey. The Orlando String Quartet offers two quartets from Opus 76 and the Tokyo Quartet two more from Opus 20. Stylistically, these two recordings stand at opposite poles, but both serve Haydn in their separate ways.

title: U.S. Said to Shift Burdens
description: The Reagan Administration wants to exploit the seven-nation Williamsburg economic summit meeting to solve economic problems of the United States at the expense of its allies, Tass said today. The Soviet press agency said that because the West was plagued by economic problems and high unemployment, ''the United States seeks to shift the consequences of the crisis on its partners.''

title: Mimi Hazen Wed in Rye
description: The marriage of Mimi Suzanne Hazen, an assistant treasurer with the cash management sales and consulting group of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, to Kevin Francis Burke, a vice president in the world corporate department at Bankers Trust, took place at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph P. Bishop, assisted by the Rev. Gerald F. Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TEEN ARTS FESTIVAL EXPECTS THOUSANDS
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK ''THERE'S a sense of excitement in the air that almost defies description,'' said Barbara F. Russo of New Brunswick. ''And where do you begin to count the number of lives that will be touched and enhanced from the experience?''

title: David Graham in 2-Shot Lead
description: David Graham, who won the United States Open in June of 1981 and then didn't win another golf tournament for 23 months, made a strong move today to win his second PGA Tour event this month when he took a two-shot lead after three rounds of the eighth annual Memorial Tournament.

title: HAGLER, AT THE TOP, WEIGHS RETIREMENT
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler was still sleeping on his retirement late this morning, a rather unpleasant dream for the world of boxing.

title: Gordon Beats Berbick On Unanimous Decision
description: S.T. Gordon, the World Boxing Council cruiserweight champion, scored a unanimous 10-round decision over the heavyweight Trevor Berbick today in a lackluster nontitle fight.

title: O'ROURKE VENTURES INTO WRITER'S CIRCLE
description: BY day, and often by night, he toils as a county civil servant. But in the early hours, when his time is his own, he sits alone in the second-floor study of his Yonkers home and writes, one more Westchester author in search of a publisher.

title: THE NEW EUROPEAN PAINTERS
description: Two questions: Should the title of John Russell's article have been ''The New Male European Painters''? Aren't there any female painters qualified to be included in ''The New European Painters''? DONALD M. KIRSCHENBAUM Brooklyn, N.Y. John Russell replies:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
UPDATE ON THE DESIGN OF THE OLYMPIC MEDALS
description: Improvements in the design of the 1984 Olympic coins by the United States Treasury are intended to stimulate sales. Proceeds are earmarked to help staging of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles and finance athlete training.

title: Reading and Writing; THE WAR OF THE MEMOIRS
description: History, which used to be written by the victors, is these days in the charge of former officials prominent enough to command advances from publishers and prestigious enough to get around Government rules that keep lesser colleagues from using privileged documents. The memoirs that spring forth after an Administration's demise like flowers or weeds around a grave represent final pleas to posterity and present problems for scholars who will have to prune truth from the self-protective thickets.

title: Shultz Shows Cohorts How to Win in Tennis
description: Some of the President's aides found time to play tennis in the morning sunshine today before the heads of government began arriving.

title: PUBLIC UTILITY FIGHTS FOR PRIVATE DAM
description: A public utility and a private one are competing for the right to generate electricity from a dam 30 miles north of here, reopening a quarrel that has gone on in this area for three-quarters of a century.

title: ARE THESE SPLIT EGO TRIPS REALLY NECESSARY?
description: It's been a bad week for good old-fashioned lust. Lust, I would say, has been taking the shellacking of its life. Unbridled sensuality - sensuality uncorrupted by affection - is proving sheer hell to actor Bob Gunton, who's playing the troubled hero of Peter Nichols's springtime message from London called ''Passion.'' Mr. Gunton makes his living restoring modern paintings, and sometimes defends what he admits is a rather limited line of work by making pontifical speeches about helping to ''keep the darkness at bay.'' Stuffy fellow, as his author means him to be.

title:
The World in Summary;
PEru Reassessing Guerrilla War
description: The Sendero Luminoso guerrillas in central Peru call themselves ''a new type of Marxist-Leninist-Maoist party.'' Last week, in the latest of a series of sorties into Lima, the guerrillas blew up power pylons, blacking out the capital, and set off bombs near the American Embassy and the presidential palace.

title: VOTE SET ON TEACHER SENIORITY
description: TRENTON APOLICY that recognizes experience, not certification, as the determining factor in teacher seniority rights is expected to be voted on Wednesday by the State Board of Education. Recommended by Dr. Saul Cooperman, the state's Commissioner of Education, the proposed revisions mandate that senority rights in secondary education be acquired by actual instructional experience in a subject.

title: ROBBINS THINKS BIG ABOUT DANCES
description: With the death of George Balanchine, Jerome Robbins is surely the most distinguished choreographer associated with an American ballet company. Mr. Robbins, who joined the New York City Ballet in 1949, is now, along with Peter Martins, one of City Ballet's two ballet masters in chief.

title: Liberace and Tabloid Sued
description: Scott Thorson, who says he was the lover of the pianist Liberace, filed a $18 million libel suit against the entertainer and a supermarket tabloid in Superior Court Friday, saying he was falsely characterized in an article. He also named as defendants his half-brother, Wayne Johnson, said to have been interviewed for the article in Globe Dec. 7, 1982, and the author, Mike Snow. Mr. Thorson said Mr. Liberace ''masterminded'' the article. Mr. Liberace said he had nothing to do with it.

title: Mark Thompson, Lawyer, Wed to Lauren J. Cardullo
description: Lauren J. Cardullo, daughter of Dr. Hugo M. Cardullo and Dr. June Moore Cardullo of Pompton Plains, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church to Mark J. Thompson, son of Mrs. J.Leonard Thompson of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Thompson. The bridegroom's uncle, Msgr.

title: Miss Solender Weds Dr. W.E. Katzin
description: Katherine Solender, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Solender of Dallas, was married yesterday to Dr. William Effron Katzin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Katzin of Litchfield, Conn. Municipal Court Judge Frank O'Bell performed the ceremony at the College Club of Cleveland in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: AFTER 100 YEARS, BROOKLYN IS STILL SOLD ON ITS BRIDGE
description: THERE are bridges that are longer and taller and maybe even more beautiful - though surely not many are more beautiful - but if the Brooklyn Bridge has relinquished its records over the years, time has failed to diminish its stature. When it turned 100 last week, more than two million New Yorkers turned out. Only the Dodgers were missing.

title: Ronald Siena Married To May Laura Morris
description: May Laura Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Morris of Pottstown, Pa., and Ronald J. Siena, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Siena of Maplewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Morrises' farm by the Rev. Joseph Laird, an Episcopal priest.

title: LANDMARK GUIDE NOW OFFERED FREE
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission is having a sale of sorts. It has marked down its 1979 booklet, ''A Guide to New York City Landmarks,'' from the original price of $1 to just 60 cents for anyone who wants to be sent a copy by mail.

title: 150 Evacuated in Fairbanks As Parked Truck Leaks Acid
description: Hydrochloric acid began leaking from a parked tanker truck, causing a white cloud of gas to rise today and forcing at least 150 people to evacuate their homes near downtown Fairbanks.

title: THE ART OF AGING
description: SISTER AGE, By M.F.K. Fisher. 245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Floating Money
description: To the Business Editor: National money is just a financial commodity (''Have Currencies Floated Too Long?'' May 8). There is no reason why it should not fluctuate in value relative to other national monies in response to supply and demand.

title: TALKING TO ANIMALS IS HIS CAREER
description: ''WHAT I do for a living,'' said Warren Eckstein of Oceanside, ''is talk to animals.'' To put it more formally, the 34-year-old Mr. Eckstein is an ''animal behaviorist or pet therapist.'' He said, ''We travel all over the country working out behavioral problems people have with their pets.''

title:
CAMERA;
THE HIGHS AND LOWS OF A FREELANCER'S CAREER
By Sy Barlowe; NATURE WATCH; FAIRY-RING MUSHROOM; Marasmius oreades
description: Size: To three inches across cap. Color: Variable; commonly pale buff but ranging from red through dull brown to whitish.

title: Fortune Teller Upset; Jersey Cup to Jamuga
description: Jamuga, a lightly raced colt, upset the highly favored Fortune Teller in a heat and went on to win the final of the Jersey Cup pace tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: Dealers and Croupiers Picket Bally's Casino
description: Casino workers set up picket lines around Bally's Park Place at the start of the Memorial Day weekend today in the city's first strike by dealers and croupiers.

title: F.C.C. TO INVESTIGATE INFLUENCE OF ALIENS OVER 7 TV STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission has ordered a full investigation into allegations that the nation's only full-time Spanish-language television network is improperly controlled by a Mexican company.

title: No Headline
description: The Human Side Of Technology In your April 17 article ''Fast Race to Attract Technology,'' there was little mention of the human side of the technology equation. Perhaps one of the lures that Connecticut can use to bring high-technology business to the state is the willingness and ability to address the ''human technology'' issues.

title: Nancy Cook Is Married To Newsman
description: Nancy Ann Cook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton R. Cook of Kenilworth, Ill., was married in New York yesterday to Jerome A. Nachman, son of Dorothy Tuminello of Pittsburgh and Fred Nachman of Brooklyn. Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: WHAT! PAY ROOM AND BOARD?
description: WHEN my 16-year-old son came home and announced that he had got a job in a restaurant, I think I went a little berserk with joy. Imagine, someone was actually going to pay him. It boggled the mind.

title: Ann Marie Derry and Cameron A. Thompson Wed
description: Ann Marie Derry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Derry of San Marino, Calif., was married yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., to Cameron Acheson Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred D. Thompson of New York. The Rev. Michael Holmes of St. Edmund's Episcopal Church in San Marino performed the ceremony in the gardens of the Huntington-Sheraton Hotel.

title: The Region in Summary; The End of the At-Large Era
description: At-large members of New York's City Council will soon be living up to their name. Michael I. Sovern, chairman of a commission revising the City Charter, said last week the panel had decided to recommend that the borough-wide seats be scrapped.

title: A COMPREHENSIVE SHOW OF TIFFANY LAMPS OPENS
description: The most comprehensive exhibition ever held of the lamps and shades of Louis Comfort Tiffany, 133 pieces from the collection of Dr. Egon Neustadt, opened Friday, not without its share of controversy, at the New-York Historical Society, Central Park West and 76th Street, where it will run through Sept. 15.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about law schools in The Times Magazine last Sunday omitted a line on page 21 at the middle of column 2. The sentence should have read, ''Indeed, many students seem to expect little from the roughly $40,000 they invest in a Stanford education, regarding the money more as a licensing fee than as an educational expense.''

title: PRESCRIPTION DRUG ADS: DIRECT DOSE TO CONSUMERS
description: ''My daughter thought I was too much trouble at home,'' reads the caption on an advertisement showing a forlorn older woman sitting in a nursing home.

title: Maine and Harvard Win In Playoffs in Baseball
description: Top-seeded Maine defeated New York Tech, 8-2, and Harvard beat Temple, 2-1, today in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional baseball playoffs.

title: BEHIND A MASK OF SAMENESS, AMERICA'S FACE IS CHANGING
description: THE homogenization of America has been under way for a long time. Airports, freeways, housing projects and shopping malls often look the same in Maine as in California, and once pronounced regional flavors have been fading as travel has increased and the industrial North has lost population to the South and West. Social change - the increase in divorce, smaller families, distrust of Government - is evident in the deep South as in the Northwest.

title: TEACHER, 71, WANTS JOB BACK
description: SCHOOL teacher in Branford has sued the local school board for refusing to renew his teaching contract, contending that the state's mandatory retirement law is unconstitutional.

title: JERSEY, IN CONSOLIDATION MOVE, PLANS 3 BUILDINGS FOR TRENTON
description: The State of New Jersey, in a move designed to consolidate state divisions, will build three large office buildings downtown.

title: THE PROD THAT FAILED
RESIDENT TROOPERS COME INTO SCRUTINY
description: CONNECTICUT'S resident state trooper system is under intense scrutiny for the first time since it was established more than 35 years ago.

title: Limiting the Break
description: To the Business Editor: In recommending a $500 cap on the July 1 individual tax cut (''But Let's Limit the Break,'' May 8), Lawrence Chimerine argues that the $8 billion in revenue so gained would trim the Federal deficit, reduce Federal borrowing, and thus help bring down interest rates.

title: JUDGE BARS AGE LIMIT FOR WELFARE
description: A Federal district judge has struck down a key element of Pennsylvania's new welfare laws, ruling that the state unconstitutionally limited benefits for recipients 18 to 45 years old.

title: DANCE: NEW ENSEMBLE
description: The George White Ensemble, a new dance company, came to the Marymount Manhattan Theater on Friday night. Directed by George White Jr., the group contains some competent dancers. Nevertheless, its debut engagement seemed premature because, although the dancing was bright, the choreography was foggy. And it did not help matters that the program began 20 minutes late.

title: POETRY AND ITS AVATARS ARE ALIVE AND DWELLING AMONG US
description: class writers who have read their work at Pace University in Pleasantville and at Westchester Community College over the last few months. These poets are not mere amateurs, they are the superstars of an accomplished and accomplishing art form - an unobstrusive form that now seems encouraged to dwell among us.

title: 9 Latin Nations Send Officials To Panama for Talks on Area
description: Foreign Ministers of eight Latin American countries and the Deputy Foreign Minister of Costa Rica arrived here today for a meeting to try to ease tension between Honduras and Nicaragua and foster peace in Central America.
