title: ROAD TO CASINOS A JACKPOT FOR JERSEY'S EXPRESSWAY AUTHORITY
description: The Atlantic City casino industry, five years old this weekend, has brought so much traffic to the Atlantic City Expressway that the New Jersey Expressway Authority expects to pay off its bonds 18 years early.

title: Travel Advisory; Is There Life After Skiing?  Ask Vermont
description: What happens to a ski resort when the zephyrs of spring banish the snows? Does it vanish like Brigadoon till Old Man Winter howls down out of the Arctic once more to turn breath to smoke, to frost the pines and whiten trails with fresh, deep cover?

title: CUOMO IS PROVING A TOUGH BEAT TO COVER
description: As the lights dimmed at the annual production of the Legislative Correspondents Association last weekend, four harddrinking reporters were seen busy at a pressroom poker table, more interested in the cards than the gubernatorial campaign they were covering. ''I'm working on a hot lead,'' says one of them when an editor phones. ''It's going to be Koch all the way.''

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: ART Yes, that cascade of blue streamers, topped by orange stars and a moon, coursing down the white marble facade of 2 Columbus Circle (headquarters of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs) is part of an art show. Tim Watkins did it, from blue reflective sheeting, and it's aptly titled, ''Starry Night by the Waterfall.''

title: ONLY PASTA, BUT NOT ITALIAN
description: PASTAPOT in Glen Cove is the realization of a concept that has every reason for success. A restaurant that serves only pasta dishes - dominated by but not limited to the Italian repertory - in pleasantly comfortable surroundings has to have universal appeal these days, especially when entrees range from $3.95 to $9.95, with half of them at $5.95.

title: THE PHILARMONIC LOOKS AT COMTEMPORARY MUSIC
description: In recent years, thoughtful lovers of the symphony orchestra have had constant occasion to question whether their beloved old musical machine could still function efficiently in the modern age. Leonard Bernstein, when he was music director of the New York Philharmonic, used to worry publicly that the orchestra had become an anachronism. Before his appointment as Mr. Bernstein's successor, Pierre Boulez was on record speculating that opera houses and their attendant symphony orchestras might best be blown up.

title: The Nation in Summary; 'New Horizons' In Boston Politics
description: Boston Mayor Kevin H. White, known for his political savvy and flair for the dramatic, displayed both last week with the announcement that he would not seek a fifth term. Though he could have been a formidable early favorite had he chosen to run, his lead might have been difficult to maintain with Federal investigators snapping at his heels.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Susan Bliss and Peter M. Soule Married in Maine
description: Susan Dwight Bliss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Bliss Jr. of South Freeport, Me., was married yesterday at the Old Meeting House in Yarmouth, Me., to Peter Martin Soule, son of Mrs. Lawrence D. Chapman of Falmouth Foreside, Me., and the late Frank H. Soule. The Rev. Glenn E. Rainsley, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Legalizing a Loft
description: Question: My commercial lease was signed with the stipulation that an amendment to the certificate of occupancy for the building that would legalize my loft was pending. How do I find out if it was granted? Will I receive a residential lease and come under rent stabilization? ... R.S.B., Manhattan. Answer: Suzanne O'Keefe, executive director of the New York City Loft Board, suggests that you go to the Department of Buildings, 20th floor, Municipal Building, One Centre Street, to see the certificate of occupancy or check to see if an alteration application has been filed in an effort to amend the certificate.

title: WHEN AN ARTIST CHANGES STYLE
description: The question of change in an artist's work is an intriguing one. For some, who've struggled to find a concept, a way of approaching that concept and an individual voice in which to express it, change comes hard. Others see change as a challenge, and make it the very substance of their art. At one extreme is Josef Albers, content to spend more than 30 years exploring color in an unvarying format of two-dimensional nested squares; at the other is the protean Picasso, who shifted styles and mediums from moment to moment. But what is change to an artist, anyway? For one, it can simply mean a shift in the pressure of brush strokes from one abstract canvas to another; for the next it may mean a deep revision of style or theme. Should change always be regarded as development? Does a significant change in an artist's work render the earlier work less valid - or, as in the case of Giorgio de Chirico, who renounced his powerful ''metaphysical'' paintings for a flabby new style after World War I, is the new insignificant when judged by the standards of the old?

title: PRESIDENT TO REPLACE HINTON AS U.S. ENVOY TO EL SALVADOR
description: President Reagan has decided to replace Deane R. Hinton as Ambassador to El Salvador, Administration officials said today.

title: CABARET: TORONTO SINGER
description: For the last 20 years, Amanda Ambrose has dropped into New York from time to time to sing and play the piano, only to leave again, lately to Toronto, where she lives, where she has reared five children and where she is busy with interests outside of show business. For her current brief visit, she appeared at Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, through yesterday, seated behind a piano and singing in a manner that still retains a strong touch of early gospel influence.

title: MOSCOW'S FACADE ON WAR AND PEACE CRACKS A BIT
description: Twice in recent days the facade of unanimity on matters of war and peace that the Soviet authorities try so hard to maintain has cracked.

title: ALL-SUITE HOTEL TO RISE IN EDISON
description: Among the fastest-rising trends in the accommodations industry is the all-suites hotel. The concept, which apparently started in the Southwest more than a decade ago, has recently taken root in the East.

title: Generals Gambling On Erratic Knapple
description: Jeff Knapple is expected to start at quarterback for the New Jersey Generals today in their game at Washington against the Federals. He is the team's untried successor to Bobby Scott, who had started all 12 previous games for New Jersey before being traded to the Chicago Blitz Thursday for an offensive lineman, Kari Yli-Renko, and a future draft choice.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE This has been a year without Twyla Tharp for most New Yorkers, with no city season for her company. But American Ballet Theater has come to the rescue with a new ballet, ''Once Upon a Time,'' which will receive its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday.

title:
The World in Summary;
MOngolia Isn't Home Anymore
description: Life in Mongolia isn't to everyone's liking, but thousands of Chinese call it home - or did until recently. Western travelers reported last week that as many as 8,000 people holding Chinese passports had been ordered to leave the country by August.

title: A 20TH-CENTURY BATTLE ARRAY
description: CROSSROADS OF MODERN WARFARE, By Drew Middleton. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: STUDY ASKS TIGHTER HIGH SCHOOL CURRICULUMS
description: America's high schools cannot be seriously improved without totally revamping them, shifting emphasis from ''dutiful attendance'' to mastery of subject matter, according to a report cosponsored by the National Association of Secondary Schools and the National Association of Independent Schools.

title: Around the Nation; Reagan to Meet Leader Of Teacher Association
description: President Reagan has agreed to meet with the head of a national teachers' group that was angered by his call to establish merit pay for public school teachers.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend. A time for remembrance, family gatherings, picnics, shopping sales and the start of the pop music season. Pop music in this context has nothing to do with electronic tunes vying with one another on the deejay charts. It is the most traditional pop music in the world - the outpouring of music made by nonprofessionals, mostly youngsters in school bands. We are used to seeing the high-gloss college bands, and even high-school ensembles that catch the television eye at major sports events, but there are heaven only knows how many more whose passion and love is the equal, although the gloss may not be as shiny.

title:
The World in Summary;
AFter Bombs, Insult and Injury In Mozambique
description: Mozambique turned the other cheek last week as South African planes rocketed suspected bases of African National Congress guerrillas in the capital at Maputo. South Africa said the raid was a reprisal for the May 20 explosion at South African Air Force headquarters in Pretoria. Minimizing the incident, Mozambique officials said six people had been killed in the retaliatory raid; South Africa insisted the correct figure was 64. Later in the week, another bomb exploded in the South African city of Bloemfontein; no one was hurt. Pretoria slowed traffic at the nearby border with Lesotho, an economically dependent, landlocked country.

title: J.G. Monroe Wed To Claire S. Lamb
description: Claire Stuart Lamb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Lamb Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., and John Gordon Monroe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Monroe Jr. of Bakersfield, Calif., were married yesterday. The Rev. Stephen G. Geckeler performed the ceremony at the Westside Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood.

title: WHAT THE GUGGENHEIM HAS ON ITS SHOPPING LIST
description: You don't have to look back any farther than the Havemeyer sale of 10 days ago at Sotheby's to realize all over again to what an extent American museums depend on the major individual collector. If Mrs. Havemeyer had not been a friend of Mary Cassatt 100 years ago, the Andre Meyer Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum would look very different today.

title: Glenda A. Nelson to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Luther S. Nelson of Amarillo, Tex., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Glenda Ann Nelson, to Theodore Courtney Rogers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers of New York and Houston.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Reinstated J oe Morgan, second baseman, from the d isabled list; designated Bobby Molinaro, o utfielder, for assignment. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Recalled B rad Wellman, infielder, from Phoenix of t he Pacific Coast League to replace Duane K uiper, second baseman, who was placed o n the 15-day disabled list after suffering a f ractured collarbone in Friday night's g ame against Los Angeles. BASKETBALL DENVER (NBA) - Signed Doug Moe, c oach, and Carl Scheer, general manager, t o new contracts. FOOTBALL GREEN BAY (NFC) - Signed Carlton B riscoe, defensive back from McNeese S tate, Byron Williams, wide receiver from T exas-Arlington, and John Harvey, line- b acker from U.C.L.A, all 1983 draft c hoices, and two free agents: Pat Dean a nd Jim Ettari, nose tackles..

title: A FRESH AIR FAMILY REJOICES
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP FOR Doug and Karin Clark, a stroll through their backyard in this Mercer County community is like leafing through a family scrapbook. There is the pool that Victor flopped into before he knew how to swim, the picnic area where Andrea could not eat because she was so terrified of the bugs and the basketball court where James showed Mr. Clark how to shoot.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Giving Odds On Hurricanes
description: Hurricane forecasting is never a sure bet, much as coastal towns battening down for the high winds and towering waves would like it to be. But meteorologists can offer odds on a hurricane hitting a given area, and will do so during the next hurricane season, according to the National Weather Service last week.

title: 'Panic' in Suffolk: Another View
description: I must take exception to the protestations of Alastair Anderson in '' 'Panic' in Suffolk? That's an Insult'' (Opinion Page, May 8). No one ever accused Suffolk County residents, or East Enders in particular, of having the potential of being a ''hysterical mob,'' nor have Suffolk residents been ''maligned and scorned'' or ''badmouthed.''

title: Lewis Loses in 100
description: Carl Lewis was upset by Ron Brown in the 100 meters but came back to win the 200 today in the Bruce Jenner Classic track and field meet.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE MARKS SHURZ'S MULTIFACED CAREER
description: The United States is continuing the ''Germanic year'' in American stamps. This Friday there will be a 4-cent definitive for German-born Carl Schurz, a man of many achievements who is being added to the Great Americans Series.

title: HILTON CASTS VOTE FOR ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY AFTER hesitating more than four years, the Hilton Hotels Corporation has decided that Atlantic City is the best place to build a hotel-casino.

title: Indy 500 Blends Old and New
description: Round and round they will go Sunday afternoon for the 67th time at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. The basic goal - 200 times around a 2.5-mile oval -remains as firm as the concrete wall that separates the crowd from the track and the fates of the fortunate racers from the less fortunate. But everything else can change as easily as the weather of central Indiana.

title: MORE U.S. ADVISERS ASKED IN SALVADOR
description: United States military officers with experience in El Salvador say they believe the task of training that country's army cannot be done with the 55 American advisers now available for the job.

title: Soares Is Named as Premier Of Portugal for a Third Time
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes designated the Socialist Party leader, Mario Soares, as Prime Minister on Friday and asked him to form a new coalition Government to end a 23-week political impasse.

title: ON THE ARCHITECTURAL FRONTIER
description: WHEN, in 1901, the famous and flamboyant actor John Drew decided to build a house on the ocean in East Hampton, he called in the architect James Brown Lord, whose elaborate design raised some eyebrows among the community's more sober residents, who tended to equate the ''fancy'' with the immoral.

title: The Region in Summary
description: Governor Cuomo readied a makeshift cavalry last week to rescue Rockland County from itself, Indian Point from shutdown by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and millions of consumers from higher electric bills. Faced with an N.R.C. order to improve evacuation plans and the county's refusal to help, the Governor proposed that several hundred state employees and utility workers stand in for Rockland firefighters, police officers and ambulance drivers in the event of an emergency across the river at the Westchester reactors.

title: DEMOCRATS HONOR POSILLIPO'S 30 YEARS
description: IT was only appropriate that the Rye Town Hilton was the setting last weekend for the county Democratic dinner honoring Anthony (Chappie) Posillipo, who is retiring after 30 years as Supervisor of the town of Rye. He had been largely responsible for bringing the hotel to Rye a decade earlier.

title: Concerts at New Whitney
description: A series of free concerts begins June 15 at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue at 42d Street. Starting at 5:30 P.M., the S.E.M. Ensemble will present a program of American music by composers such as Philip Glass, John Gibson, John Cage and Phill Niblock.

title: Home Clinic; THE ART AND SCIENCE OF KEEPING WATER OUT OF THE BASEMENT
description: ONE of the most common causes of water in the basement is poor drainage of surface water around the outside of the house. The ground should slope away from the house on all sides so that in a heavy rain, water tends to run away from the foundation walls, not collect in pools next to them. If water seeps down next to the basement walls, it increases the underground water pressure, helping to force the water in through tiny cracks or porous sections, or to force it in through the joints where walls and floor meet on the inside.

title: Around the Nation; Infant Death Syndrome Is Linked to Brain Defect
description: Sudden infant death syndrome, the leading cause of death in babies 2 weeks to a year old, may be caused by immature brain stems that cannot properly control sleep and breathing, scientists say.

title: CHILDREN LEARN ABOUT ALCOHOLISM
description: ON a recent Tuesday afternoon in Bridgeport, 10 youngsters ages 6 to 9 were constructing masks out of paper bags. Almost all drew happy, smiling faces, the kinds of faces the youngsters said they like to show the outside world. When asked to write inside the bag the word that best described what feelings they were hiding, ''scared'' and ''mad'' were the most common responses.

title: Reagan Says the Third World Won't Be Forgotten at Parley
description: President Reagan said today that he had received letters from several third world leaders and that the economic summit conference here would keep in mind the problems of the world's poorest nations.

title: Television Week
description: Open Communication Each year, ABC presents their choice of an outstanding work from the New Drama for Televison Project, a feature of the National Playwrights' Conference held at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. This year's selection is Phil Penningroth's ''Ghost Dancing,'' which will be telecast Monday at 9 P.M. For this televized version, Dorothy McGuire stars as a widowed farmer who dynamites a reservoir in a battle over a precious water supply.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE RELUCTANT PATRON The United States Government and the Arts, 1943-1965. By Gary O. Larson. Illustrated. 314 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $12.95.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE Newark-based Office of Recycling, an arm of the state's Department of Energy, is trying to persuade businesses that push paper to push it a little farther into recycling programs. The results can be profitable.

title: STOP, LOOK AND WORRY
description: ''IF I had herpes, I would die,'' said Virginia, a 45-year-old divorcee. ''As far as I'm concerned, herpes - socially -is like leprosy used to be. People just consider it a filthy disease.''

title: No Headline
description: Writing 'Romances' Is Hard Work Thanks to Kitty Florey's article (''Writer's Guilt and the Lure of a Word Processor, '' April 17), I now realize that I have been missing out on the true benefits of the system I installed several months ago.

title:
Gardening;
CARING FOR AN OLD FRIEND, THE TOMATO
description: OF all the plants in the garden, tomatoes are undoubtedly the most widely planted. A survey conducted by the National Association for Gardening indicated that 94 percent of all American gardeners grow these delicious, nutritious fruits.

title: The Nation in Summary; Splicing Budgets Will Require Steady Hands
description: ''This will be a difficult conference, extremely difficult,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. His reference was to the task members of the House and Senate will begin next week, trying to fit the two chambers' different designs for the 1984 Federal budget into a single blueprint that will not set the White House to sharpening its red vetoing pencils.

title: Dining Out; GOOD VALUE IN AN INFORMAL SETTING
description: AS though running a popular bakery, gourmet takeout and culinary supply shop, a catering business and a cooking school were not enough full-time jobs, Ann Howard of Farmington has now opened a restaurant.

title: Torrey a Lesson For Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor: Wouldn't it be wonderful if Bill Torrey would take George Steinbrenner to lunch? Think of what the man who would be king could learn from the man who has built a true professional sports dynasty:

title:
DINING OUT;
EAST RUTHERFORD: A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: THE brothers Daniel and David Mangone are the third generation of their family to run Jerry's, the popular East Rutherford steakhouse that specializes in hearty Italian-American fare.

title: BUTCHERS DESCRIBE 'SLICE OF LIFE'
description: ''TO tell you the truth, I hate it,'' conceded John Seebach. ''If anyone said to me I'd be a butcher for 32 years, I wouldn't have believed it. But it's a living, it's steady.''

title: TELLER AND 10 OTHERS RECEIVE SCIENCE MEDAL FROM REAGAN
description: President Reagan has presented the nation's highest scientific honor to Edward Teller, a pioneer nuclear scientist who was instrumental in developing the hydrogen bomb, and to 10 other scientists and engineers.

title: Sally Squires Wed To Writer-Editor
description: Sally Squires, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark B. Squires of Sparta, N.J., was married in Washington yesterday to John L. Wilhelm Jr., son of Mrs. Wilhelm of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Mr. Wilhelm. The Rev. Edward L. Lee Jr. performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, Georgetown.

title: THE MX'S BLEAK PROSPECTS AS A BARGAINING CHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET: JOHN WALLOWITCH
description: John Wallowitch, looking owlishly elegant as he sits at the piano in the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, peers through his glasses and sings songs of his own devising that create a constantly changing personality.

title: RENTAL APARTMENTS: HAVES AND HAVE-NOTS
description: LIKE successful big-game hunters, apartment-seekers who land the t rophy of rentable space at an affordable price in New York City are c oming away from their experience with tales to tell. As the spring h unting season wears on, the tales suggest at least two conclusions:

title: Sarah E. Cogan, Lawyer, Marries
description: Sarah Edwards Cogan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Cogan of New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Hayward Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold M. Evans of Chatham Township, N.J. The Rev. E. Page Rogers performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Farmington, Conn.

title: CAN ZONING SAVE OPEN SPACE?
description: THE Town of Southold and the City of Glen Cove have more in common than their waterfronts and venerable ages. Both are looking at ''upzoning'' as a way to preserve their greenbelts.

title: NO MASS EVICTIONS FORESEEN
description: THOUSANDS of tenants who have permitted friends, lovers or roommatest o move in with them without notifying their landlords have been w ondering about their status since the New York State Court of A ppeals affirmed three weeks ago that landlords may evict unrelated p eople who share an apartment without their consent.

title: ISADORE J. SILVERMAN
description: Isadore J. Silverman, former president of the W.F. Schrafft & Sons Corporation and a lawyer in Boston, died of a heart attack Friday night in the Mount Auburn hospital in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Wurzburg
description: To the Editor: Olivier Bernier's article, ''Wurzburg: A Rococo Jewel Box'' (Travel, March 27) vividly reviews the architectural glories of that city. It is well to remember that some of the splendors that he describes, exist today because of the dramatic action taken by a few United States Army men during World War II.

title: AIDS AND HERPES FORMENTING FEARS
description: THE emergence of new sexually transmitted diseases and the resurgence of old ones have given rise, health officials say, to an outbreak of fears and fallacies, particularly about AIDS -acquired immune deficiency syndrome - and herpes.

title: Dr. Sumers Is Married To Dr. Ricks
description: Dr. Anne Eva Ricks, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. David F. Ricks of Cincinnati, formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Elliott Harold Sumers, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Sumers of Roslyn, L.I. Mayor Thomas B. Brush of Cincinnati performed the ceremony at the University of Cincinnati Foundation House.

title: Around the World; Seoul Dissident Says He'll Continue His Fast
description: The dissident leader Kim Young Sam said at a hospital today that he would continue a hunger strike he began 10 days ago to demand restoration of full democracy in South Korea.

title: MX MEANS INSECURITY
description: The MX has been sold to Congress as a boon to nuclear arms control negotiations. This is more than wishful thinking - it is destructive self-deception. The fact is that the MX would seriously weaken our negotiating position at the strategic arms reduction talks and might well undercut one of our most important nuclear arms agreements, the Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 29, 1983
description: International A discussion of the nuclear arms talks with the Soviet Union was the first issue as the meeting of leaders of the major industrial democracies in Williamsburg, Va., got under way. The meeting is officially devoted to economic topics, but Reagan Administration officials said that the give-and-take on arms at last night's dinner meeting could prove to be among the productive moments of the weekend of meetings. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Three Pianists And a Lyric Tenor Give First Recitals
description: When the pianist Chiharu Nakai concluded her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night with Liszt's Sonata in B minor, the impressive results were, to a certain extent, unexpected. Earlier in the recital, the Japanese-born musician, who has studied in her native land and with Beveridge Webster at Juilliard, displayed a penchant for proper but episodic interpretations. And her preference in repertory for the Romantic epic and the Impressionist image required much more. Such works as Scriabin's Sonata No. 5 and Schumann's Fantasy were lacking in structure and drive. A broadly shaped phrase would end and another gesture would begin, at times stiffly. Miss Nakai's technique, while more than adequate, also stiffened in the face of some of Schumann's and Debussy's demands.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe DiMaggio received an honorary degree at the commencement of Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass., Friday. ... Todd Blackledge, the quarterback who led Penn State to the top ranking last fall, received the Eric A. Walker Award at his commencement ''for enhancing the public esteem and renown of the university.'' ... A judge has issued an arrest warrant for John Thompson, the reserve tight end of the Green Bay Packers after he failed to appear on misdemeanor charges. ... A county court judge in England has ruled that Joe Bugner, the English boxer, will face a two-month jail sentence on his return home from the United States unless he pays his former wife, Gale, $22,260 in the next 28 days. ... Juan Lapointe will defend his World Boxing Council featherweight title against undefeated Johnny De La Rosa on June 25 in San Juan, P.R. ... Ray Floyd, the second leading money winner on the PGA Tour in 1981 and 1982, has announced he will play in the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic next week. ... Wojtek Fibak, Poland's top tennis player, said in Paris that he saw no reason why he should not return home to visit his family despite his stand against martial law. Fibak, who was banned by his hometown club earlier this week, has not been in Poland since the declaration of martial law in December 1981.

title: SINGLE MALTS: LOOKING AND TASTING
description: The following selective guide includes information on distilleries on and off Scotland's official Whisky Trail, as well as nearby accommodations. It also describes some notable bars in various parts of Scotland where a selection of single-malt (unblended) whiskies may be tasted, and a section pointing the way for seekers of good single malts in London. The Trail The official Whisky Trail is 70 miles long, and signposts point the way. Visitors should allow at least an hour for each of the five malt whisky distilleries - Glenfiddich, Glenlivet, Glenfarclas, Tamdhu and Strathisla. Among other distilleries, not on the official trail, but open to visitors: Glendronach, at Forgue near Huntly, by appointment (Forgue 046682-202); Glengarioch, Old Meldrum, by appointment (Old Meldrum 06512-2706); and Glen Grant, Rothes, Monday to Friday, 10 to 4. Distilleries are usually closed on principal holidays and sometimes for cleaning, so check first with the local tourist information center. Visitor facilities are increasing numerically and developing professionally year by year. For a complete list, write to the Scotch Whisky Association, 17 Half Moon Street, London W1. Distilleries Glenfiddich, Dufftown, Banffshire (tel. 0340-20373), has two reception centers, one giving an audiovisual presentation in a 50-seat theater, from where visitors are taken on a tour of the distillery (founded 1806). Afterward they reach the second reception center where they are given a taste, and can visit a gift shop and examine a small exhibition of local history and whisky making. Open all year, Monday to Friday 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Glenlivet, Glenlivet, Banffshire (08073-427), offers guided tours from Easter through October, Monday through Friday, 10 to 4.

title: SOME PROTECTIONISM
description: ''Should we have free trade or protection?'' is not an honest question.

title: Major News in Summary; Moderates Claim MX as Their Chip
description: One of the influential moderates who last week voted to give President Reagan money for the MX intercontinental missile that Congress only five months ago withheld explained the reversal this way. He saw, he said, a ''window of opportunity'' through which the President could be pushed to a more flexible stance on arms control. As others viewed it, especially some holdout Democratic liberals who saw a big election issue vanishing, Mr. Reagan jumped - at the chance to shut the political window of vulnerablity opened by public perceptions of his bellicosity, and get the missile too.

title: Atlantic Salmon Back in Lake Ontario
description: AFTER a century's hiatus, Atlantic salmon, perhaps the world's most highly-regarded food and game fish, are back in Lake Ontario. Unlike the two Pacific salmons, the coho and chinook, which were introduced into the lake in recent years and are now providing a spectacular sport fishery, the Atlantics were once there in great numbers.

title: Pamela Woodworth Marries Christopher Maxwell
description: Pamela Cheyney Woodworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newell B. Woodworth of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to C. Christopher Maxwell, son of Sarah Headly Maxwell and Peter Maxwell, both of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed at the Quaker Meeting House.

title: BOARD OF N.A.A.C.P. CALLS FOR RESIGNATION OF UNIT'S CHAIRMAN
description: A majority of board members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday for the resignation of the association's chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, and voted to curb her powers sharply.

title: Ballesteros Shares Lead
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain shot a 71 today to keep a part of a one-stroke lead in the $140,000 British Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: Art; PAST AND PRESENT FUTURISTS
description: AS editor of the short-lived British publication ''Blast,'' Wyndham Lewis would not have approved of its cover being used to illustrate a review of Italian Futurism, a survey of which is at the Yale University Art Gallery through June 26.

title: A ROCK SINGER TAKES OFF AS A MOVIE STAR
description: What would induce an actor to age on-camera from a lissome 30-year-old fashion plate to a decrepit, several-hundred-year-old relic? The same thing, apparently, that would lead him to play a British soldier confined to a Japanese prisoner of war camp, or to reappear in an 11-year-old rock and roll incarnation as Ziggy Stardust, since David Bowie is doing all three.

title: 2 Fights to Be Shown on TV
description: ABC Sports will televise tapes of the two heavyweight title fights held May 20 in Las Vegas, Nev. The W.B.A. bout between Michael Weaver and Michael Dokes will be shown next Saturday at 5 P.M., and the W.B.C. meeting between Larry Holmes and Tim Witherspoon will be televised one week later at 5.

title: Tubingen
description: To the Editor: I was interested in reading James M. Markham's choice of Tubingen, Germany, as one of the choice ''Summer Places Around the World'' (Travel, April 10) since 12 years ago my boyfriend and I toured Europe for three months and visited Tubingen. v. e were so enthralled with the place that we established the required six-weeks' residency and we were married there in a civil ceremony in the Rathaus (city hall) with an assemblage of some 20 friends we had made while there.

title: Ski Goggle Winner In Acorn
description: With every one of her 10 victories without a defeat, Princess Rooney's reputation had grown to epic proportions - except among those who watched her closely. She was winning without authority, struggling to overcome weak fields. It was only a matter of time before she met her match, and it happened yesterday in the Acorn Stakes at Belmont Park.

title:
Business Forum;
WHY FREE MARKETS AND BANKS DON'T MIX
description: FINANCIAL crises in recent years attest to a growing interdependencya nd vulnerability within the financial services industry. The p roblems that faced Bache and Paine Webber in 1980, Drysdale, L ombard-Wall and Penn Square in 1982 and the international banks t oday with respect to their loans to third world countries, i llustrate the point. They are examples of how, with increasing f requency, the difficulties of a single financial institution t hreaten to set off a chain reaction, extending well beyond those c ompanies immediately involved.

title: NASSAU EXPECTS GAIN IN FINANCES DESPITE DROP IN BOND RATING
description: NASSAU COUNTY is having to pay more to borrow money these days because of its continuing budget deficit, despite the promise of additional revenue from the penny sales tax increase scheduled to go into effect July 1.

title:
Gardening;
CARING FOR AN OLD FRIEND, THE TOMATO
description: OF all the plants in the garden, tomatoes are undoubtedly the most widely planted. A survey conducted by the National Association for Gardening indicated that 94 percent of all American gardeners grow these delicious, nutritious fruits.

title: TEACHING: TOO MUCH TO DO, TOO LITTLE TIME
description: IN THE weeks since the National Commission on Excellence in Education warned in a report to the nation that American educational foundations were being ''eroded by a rising tide of mediocrity,'' newspaper columns have been filled with calls for reforms.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE U.S.S. Nautilus, the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, was granted a new honor last week as Governor O'Neill signed into law a bill naming the vessel Connecticut's official state ship.

title: BOXING-SAFETY BILL TERMED FIRST STEP
description: BOXING law in New York State may soon undergo its first major revision since Jack Dempsey ruled the canvas, but one boxing-safety expert contends that the proposed legislation does not go far enough in protecting the sport's participants.

title: Earnhardt Wins Race
description: Dale Earnhardt, the runner-up here the last two years, won the $125,375 Nascar Mello Yello 300 Late Model Sportsman race today at Charlotte Motor Speedway. Earnhardt's Pontiac took the lead on the 136th lap and stretched the margin to 3 seconds by the end of the race. He averaged 117.724 miles an hour.

title: No Headline
description: Recalling The Blue Ribbon It was a pleasure to read Frank J. Prial's evocative reminiscence of a very special place: the old Blue Ribbon Restaurant, on West 44th Street (''A Refreshing Mix,'' Home Entertaining, May 1.) I'm sure his article struck a responsive chord in many who frequented the place.

title: A BAEDEKER TO BANKS AND BOUTIQUES IN EUROPE
description: AT the headquarters of the Midland Bank in London, an officer of the bank steered a visitor through ane laborate buffet lunch. When the guest selected lamb for his main c ourse, rather than beef, the banker reacted with surprise. ''I d idn't think Americans ate lamb,'' he said.

title: The Region in Summary; Lilco Goes for Broke
description: Just when, or whether, the Long Island Lighting Company will be able to open its nuclear plant at Shoreham is far from clear. But last week the utility said even the best possible case - an April 1984 start-up -would be none too good for its customers.

title: 3 Peace Activists in Florida Get One-Year Jail Sentences
description: Three activists opposed to the arms race were sentenced Thursday to one year in jail on charges growing out of their stretching a steel cable across the entrance to a General Electric nuclear weapon plant.

title: ALL THAT GLITTERS ISN'T ALWAYS GOLD
description: TWO towns, two shows: In Plainfield, the Tweed Gallery, 112 East Front Street, is having one of its round-ups under the title ''All that Glitters'' (through June 18); in Princeton, there is a solo exhibition by Donald Localio at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art, 8 Chambers Street (through June 16).

title: Patricia Reilly Married To Stuart S. Morrison
description: Patricia Mary Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Reilly of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stuart Scott Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Morrison of New Orleans. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Around the World; Flooding in France Forces 1,000 to Flee
description: Floodwaters from the Meurthe River forced the evacuation of more than 1,000 people from Nancy during the night, officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: Budget 'Streamlining' At Adelphi Adelphi's president, Timothy Costello, was quoted in a recent article (''At Colleges, a Season of Changes,'' May 8) as stating, ''The secretaries gave us back money and it's likely the faculty will, too. It's not wizardry.

title: Miss Brown Wed To A.J.P. Seiler
description: Cynthia Clarke Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wellington Brown Jr. of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Douglas Edward Seiler, son of Arthur John Paul Seiler of Haverford, Pa., and Helena, Mont., and the late Jeanne Watson Seiler of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Fay Lincoln Gemmell performed the Methodist ceremony at the Keene (N.H.) University Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Nina Gray-Cullen.

title: INSURANCE BETS ROOTED IN DISCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title:
Business Forum;
AVOID THE URGE TO DO TOO LITTLE
description: WITH so much diplomatic and media attention now focused on W illiamsburg, it is perhaps useful to reflect on the effectiveness oft he summit process and its role in managing the world economy.

title: Future Events; Galas Around Town
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Citizens of the Future June 1 - Usually a play area, the rooftop at the Harbor Center, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, takes on an aura of elegance for a gala dinner-dance with entertainment by Rose Murphy, a jazz singer, and the Back Street Flyers from the Big Apple Circus. Robin Duke is chairman of the party, which is to benefit Boys Harbor/The Harbor for Girls and Boys, a camp and educational facility for underprivileged children founded in 1937 by her brother-in-law, Anthony Drexel Duke. Tickets, $250, from 427-2244. School Treat June 2 - A gala evening arranged by the Neighborhood Committee for the Asphalt Green at the Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, offers cocktails at 6:30 P.M., buffet supper at 7 and dancing from 9 to midnight. There will also be a silent auction. Proceeds will go to the Asphalt Green Sports and Arts Center, soon to be completed at the former municipal asphalt plant at Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and 90th Street. Tickets, $50, from 288-1281.

title: Voodoo Arms Control
description: The people who brought you the biggest tax cut ever as an exercise in revenue raising now present: the biggest American missile ever as an exercise in arms control.

title: Headliners; Boat Personage
description: Despite his status as a former Prime Minister of South Vietnam, Nguyen Van Loc apparently didn't make the ''A'' list for evacuation after the fall of Saigon. Mr. Loc, now 62 years old, has finally made it out of Vietnam after 13 unsuccessful attempts, officials at the Singapore office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said last week. Mr. Loc, who was Prime Minister for seven months in 1967-68, told the U.N. officials that he and 32 other ''boat people'' had been picked up by a French cargo ship off the coast of southern Vietnam.

title: WILL WILLIAMSBURG STOP SLIPPAGE AT THE SUMMIT?
description: ''Nations touch at their summits,'' Walter Bagehot, the English constitutional historian, wrote a century ago. He meant contacts at the highest level can galvanize governments and bureaucracies into action.

title: CHOICE FOR RENT BOARD HALTED
description: THE nomination of Louis Bataille to the Rent Guidelines Board has been halted, following the discovery that Mr. Bataille wrote a newspaper article six months ago suggesting that rent stabilization be abolished.

title: Television Week
description: Big Bird's Flight The first television co-production between the Children's Television Workshop and China Central Television completed its filming this past December. NBC will broadcast the results, a 90-minute special, ''Big Bird in China,'' on Sunday at 7 P.M. In China, it will be broadcast on the national network.

title: SELF-ASSERTION: SOMETIMES IT TAKES A WHILE TO GET THERE
description: AFTER more than three decades of subordinating herself to the whims and dictates of those closest to her, a woman I know contends she is making definite progress in asserting herself. An abridged description of her uphill battle for self-determination follows:

title: COMMUNITIES FACING MOUNT LAUREL SUITS
description: IN THE four months since the Mount Laurel II decision, at least four New Jersey municipalities have been sued under the State Supreme Court's landmark housing ruling, while others have struggled to comply with its guidelines.

title: The Nation in Summary; Industrial States Huddle Together
description: Starting with his inaugural address, Ronald Reagan has promoted a ''new federalism,'' in which Federal responsibilities would devolve to the states. So far, his Administration's policies have produced a new regionalism, in which states have banded together to fight Washington - and each other.

title: Clarifying Rules
description: To the Business Editor: Thomas C. Hayes states (''Good Buys in the Thrift Business,'' May 8) that state-chartered Florida S.& L.'s have considerable advantages relative to federally chartered S.& L.'s in Florida because, in part, the state-chartered institutions are permitted to invest as much as half of their total assets outside of mortgages, whereas Federal thrifts are subject to a 5 percent ceiling on such investments.

title: VACATION TIP: TAKE NO KIDS
description: MY parents believed in truth, justice and vacations without children. Once a year, I was placed in the custody of a friend or relative and they went off to have whatever fun they could possibly have without me.

title: MILOS FOREMAN TAKES HIS CAMERAS AND AMADEUS TO PRAGUE
description: ROME Milos Forman, who was curtly dismissed from Czechoslovakia's stateowned Barrandov Film Studios 12 years ago when the government was purging the country's artistic and intellectual life of those who - to most of the world - represented Czechoslovakia's best, is back at Barrandov making a movie.

title: NORWALK GARDENERS REGAIN A COMMUNITY PLOT
description: TWO years after a group of Norwalk residents lost their community garden in favor of a city bus garage, the gardeners have been granted use of city-owned land on which to cultivate both vegetables and friendship.

title: Milton Wins, 248 to 177, In Pro Bowling Event
description: Tom Milton threw strikes on 9 of 12 rolls today and won the $100,000 Denver Open, defeating Steve Cook, 248-177. Milton, 27, from St. Petersburg, Fla., posted his third victory of the year on the Professional Bowlers' Association tour.

title: CITY'S POLICE STOP 13,000 VEHICLES IN CRACKDOWN ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: The New York City police stopped more than 13,000 vehicles Friday night and last night to begin a new crackdown on drunken drivers. Twenty-nine people were arrested Friday night and yesterday morning on charges of driving while under the influence of excessive amounts of alcohol, and one was taken into custody on a charge of driving under the influence of drugs.

title: SCHOOL THANKING FULBRIGHT FOR GRANTS
description: The University of Scranton will pay tribute to J.W. Fulbright on Sunday, but it will also be celebrating itself. While presenting a degree of Doctor of Humane Letters to the former Democratic Senator from Arkansas, the small Jesuit university in the core of this depressed old hard-coal city will also underscore its success with a program that Mr. Fulbright considers ''by far the most significant'' achievement of his 32 years in Congress.

title: No Headline
description: Higher Education's New Economics I disagree with some of the views expressed in Edward B. Fiske's article ''Higher Education's New Economics'' (May 1). The assumption that private colleges provide a better education is not only snobbish - it's inaccurate! I am also tired of the attitude that higher education is a right, not a privilege, and should be provided by Government if other resources fail.

title: REAGAN'S FRIEND AT THE BANK BOARD
description: WASHINGTON WHEN White House aides leave their jobs, they usually get a send-off luncheon at a local restaurant and some farewell cards. But when Edwin J. Gray left last August to return to private industry, President Reagan and Vice President Bush were the co-hosts at his farewell party in the packed Roosevelt Room, across from the Oval Office. Edwin Meese 3d, James A. Baker 3d and Michael K. Deaver, the trio who run White House day-to-day operations, were there to raise a champagne toast, and the gifts included a set of glasses engraved with the Presidential seal. Even before the party began, the President slipped Mr. Gray a handwritten note, saying he felt a ''great sense of loss'' at Mr. Gray's departure for California. He also asked Mr. Gray to send a hug for him to the two teen-aged Gray daughters.

title: AWARD-WINNING POET FACES LIFE AS IT IS
description: NORWICH WHEN he was trying to promote one of his books of poetry, Leo Connellan sent a copy to Nelson Algren, the novelist. Some months later, supporting himself as a chemicals salesman, Mr. Connellan found himself in Hackensack, N.J., where Mr. Algren then lived. The two met.

title: HEDGING BETS THROUGH INDEX OPTIONS
description: CHANCES are that the same investors who spend money to insure their h omes, autos and other personal property seldom think of buying i nsurance on their investment portfolios.

title: NEW YORK MAPLE SYRUP CROP IS DOWN 27 PERCENT FROM '82
description: New York State's crop of maple syrup, the first crop of the new farm year, dropped 27 percent from last year because of early warm weather, according to a report by the State Crop Reporting Service here.

title: Children's Books
description: HUGO AND THE SPACE DOG Written and illustrated by Lee Lorenz. Unpaged. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By JANICE PRINDLE

title: A COLD STATE LEARNS THAT THE BEST ENERGY IS ENERGY SAVED
description: A quarter of a century ago, as the people and the industries of New England were abandoning the bulky and dirty business of stoking their furnaces with high sulfur coal, switching instead to the fluid ease of fuel oil - and some to natural gas - a wise man gave this piece of advice to a young graduate student at Yale from Lowell, Mass. He should write his doctoral dissertation on deregulation of the price of natural gas, because the issue was so complex and politically charged that Congress would never resolve it, and the young man's expertise would grow more valuable with the passing years.

title: CONSIDER BLUEBERRIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Theodore James Jr. is author of ''The Gourmet Garden.'' BY THEODORE JAMES Jr.

title: THE BASEBALL SLUMP AND HOW TO SHAKE IT
description: NOTHING was going right at the plate for Dave Concepcion, the s hortstop for the Cincinnati Reds. He was in what is known as a s lump, a mysterious malady that is physical or mental or both and t hat at one time or another affects everyone who plays baseball - ande ven those who don't.

title: Marxism And the Masked Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in Egypt Destroys Sugar
description: A fire in a warehouse in the southern city of Kom Ombo destroyed $6 million worth of refined sugar, the police said. No one was injured.

title: FIGHTING THE BOLD STROKE AND THE QUICK FIX
description: HARD CHOICES, Four Critical Years in America's Foreign Policy. By Cyrus Vance. 320 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95

title:
JONATHAN MILLER BIDS FAREWELLL TO THE STAGE;
CAMBRIDGE, Mass.
description: ''After an affair of 25 years, I'm leaving my mistress to return to my wife.'' This is how Jonathan Miller -physician and comedian, director and producer, author and actor - explains his decision to bid farewell to the theater and devote himself full time to neuropathology. His triumphs span virtually every arena of performance art from comic revue to Shakespeare to grand opera, and his television adaptation of ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' not yet seen in America, was hailed by many as the most successful visualization of Lewis Carroll's classic.

title: 2 GUILTY IN DEATHS OF 2 U.S. MARSHALS
description: The son of Gordon Kahl, a fugitive tax protester, and another man were found guilty today on two counts of second-degree murder in connection with the deaths of two Federal marshals.

title: INSIDE CITICORP
description: Standing TALL IN HIS CORNER OFFICE, looking down on Park Avenue from the 15th floor, Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, offered this comment on his 13 years in the job: ''Whether you think it's good or bad, we've changed the environment.'' It was a large claim, modestly stated, and it was indisputable. When Wriston joined First National City Bank, Citicorp's predecessor, he recalled, ''I sat at a rolltop desk and waited for customers.'' Back then, in 1946, most bankers were careful, stodgy types who provided safe harbors for their depositors' money and served as exemplars of American thrift and probity. Today, the major banks take big risks in search of big profits and hawk their wares unashamedly. They are run by ambitious, aggressive businessmen. And more than any man, the Citicorp chairman - an unabashed apostle of laissez-faire capitalism - is responsible for that change.

title: WAR TENSION STAYS HIGH IN LEBANON
description: The level of tension in Lebanon remained high today as reports continued to circulate that the Syrians and the Israelis have been fortifying their positions for another possible confrontation on Lebanese soil. But officials indicated that so far, the warfare has been more psychological than real.

title: Two-Base Award For Hit Batter
description: To the Sports Editor: Art Shamsky's suggestion (''A Call and a Plan to Take Beanball Out of Baseball,'' The New York Times, May 15), to penalize the pitcher who hits a batter - is a start in the right direction, even though it would be expensive and difficult to administer.

title: AUTO RACING FANS HAVE BIG WEEKEND
description: The Indianapolis 500 today casts a long shadow in the motor sports world and it is easy to miss the other events on this weekend's racing calendar. In Charlotte, N.C. the stock car racers are contesting the World 600, the longest race on the Winston Cup circuit, and tomorrow in Lime Rock, Conn., the Northeast's biggest sports car race of the season will be held.

title: MEDICAL CENTER ADVISED
description: JERSEY CITY THE financially stricken Jersey City Medical Center should consider reducing its size by about 100 beds and allow itself to be rebuilt and reorganzied as a private nonprofit hospital, a consultant has recommended.

title: Around the Nation; Nationwide Recall Issued For a Lens Solution
description: A nationwide distributor of contact lens solutions has issued a recall of ''every product it has on the market place'' because of possible bacteria contamination.

title: OBSERVING A MEMORIAL DAY FOR THE PLANET
description: ANOTHER Memorial Day. Another time when many decent, well-meaning, caring people resurrect the symbols and images that revere the dead, those who died amid the terror of war. There have been many wars and many deaths, so many now that speeches and parades, high-flying flags and the rainbows of wreaths become mechanical tributes, somewhat hollow gestures that are powerless to stir our minds and hearts.

title: Orioles Are Victors; Leonard Is Injured
description: Scott McGregor pitched a two-hitter, and Eddie Murray slammed a home run to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 1-0 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: Food; ASPARAGUS: ABUNDANT, DEWY FRESH AND LOW-PRICED
description: FRESH asparagus is abundant in the market now. The distinctive green stalks - the budding shoots of the plant asparagus officinalis - are most readily available at this time of year. The advantages are twofold. Good supply means the vegetable will be delivered frequently and thus be properly dewy fresh and moist. It also contributes to lower prices.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA AND THE U.S. INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: 38 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 38 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: NICHOLAS F. BRADY, appointed by Governor Kean last year as caretaker after the resignation of Harrison A. Williams Jr., says that he really enjoyed being a United States Senator, but has no intention of going into politics.

title: FOR NEW HOPE PLAZA, A NEW LOOK
description: A few years ago, after 1500 Boston Road in the South Bronx was abandoned by its owner, tenants started a drive to buy the apartment building from the city. As an expression of their determination to stay in the area, the occupants named the building The Last Hope.

title: Nancy Young Marries Paul B. Ford Jr.
description: Nancy Young, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Young of South Orange, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Paul B. Ford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford of Pine Orchard, Conn., and Eustis, Fla. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: PROUST BEFORE HE BUILT HIS MONUMENT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Weightman is the author of ''The Concept of the Avant-Garde.'' MARCEL PROUST Selected Letters (1880-1903). Edited by Philip Kolb. Translated by Ralph Manheim. Illustrated. 376 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $19.95. By JOHN WEIGHTMAN

title: WHAT HIGH TECHNOLOGY DEMANDS OF CAPITALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Marian Ruggles Bride Of William Wenck Jr.
description: Marian Gould Ruggles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Ruggles Jr. of Dallas, Pa., was married yesterday to William Aristee Wenck Jr., son of Mrs. Wenck of New Orleans and the late Mr. Wenck.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CITING data collected as part of a computerized, well-monitoring project near the town's landfill on Horse Block Road, the Brookhaven Town Board recently authorized borrowing of $900,000 to pay for the installation of water mains to serve about 150 homes immediately southeast of the landfill.

title: Crime
description: Peter Fox, a British writer, is a relative newcomer to the game, but his mysteries up to now have been impressive for their stylistic deftness and, often, raw force. THE TRAIL OF THE REAPER (St. Martin's, $11.95) continues to show his versatility. It is a traditional mystery, about a lunatic busily engaged in knocking off celebrities, but there is nothing traditional about the author's skillful characterizations and wicked wit.

title: BALLET: INTERPRETING 'LA SYLPHIDE'
description: American Ballet Theater's new production of ''La Sylphide'' may be rather draftily unintimate. Performances on Thursday and Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House proved, however, that Erik Bruhn's staging of the Bournonville classic can call forth very different personal interpretations.

title: JOINT VENTURE: HOMAGE TO 19 ARTISTS
description: SOUTH ORANGE THE Whichcraft Studio-Gallery here is playing host for an exhibition of works by 19 artists who won craft fellowships from the State Council on the Arts from 1981 through 1983.

title: BROOKLYN FEDERAL GRAND JURY SUBPOENAS F.A.A. EMPLOYEES
description: Several employees of the Federal Aviation Administration in the New York region have been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury looking into activities related to the agency, a spokesman for the F.A.A. said yesterday.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Microwave TV Service Cleared
description: The cable television industry raised no storm, not even a mild gust of protest when the Federal Communications Commission considered, and last week approved, a multichannel microwave subscription service for television viewers. Using relatively unsophisticated technology, microwave subscribers will eventually be able to receive up to five channels of movies, news, sports and other video material.

title: No Headline
description: Samoanization Of the West I spent four years as a physician in Western Samoa, at the same time as the anthropologist Derek Freeman (''Samoa: A Paradise Lost?'' by Richard Bernstein, April 24). In fact, he and I shared bachelor digs. While I agree with Richard Bernstein that the impact of Western civilization on the Samoans has been overwhelming, a reverse cultural development - call it ''the Samoanization of the West'' - is even more striking.

title: Nurse Denies Guilt in Death
description: A nurse pleaded not guilty to murder Friday in the death of a 15-month-old girl who reportedly was one of eight children injected with a muscle-relaxant drug at a doctor's office. The nurse, Genene J. Turk, who was indicted by her maiden name, Genene Jones, was returned to jail under $225,000 bail after arraignment before Judge V. Murry Jordan of 198th District Court. Mrs. Turk, 32 years old, is charged with murder in the death of Chelsea Ann McClellan of Kerrville, Tex.

title: FIREMEN'S SAFETY PLAN SOUGHT
description: THE recent rejection of the state employee safety plan, covering firefighters and others, focuses attention on the lack of mandatory standards for volunteer fire companies' protective equipment.

title: About Books and Authors
description: The Expert Confounded

title: Katharine Rudkin and Jeffrey Allsopp, Harvard Students, Marry in Southport
description: Katharine Rudkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Rudkin of Southport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Forester Allsopp, son of Mrs. Peter Bonfield Allsopp of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Mr. Allsopp. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen Chinlund at the Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: VIETNAM EX-PREMIER TELLS HOW HE ESCAPED
description: A former South Vietnamese Prime Minister, now a refugee awaiting resettlement, says he had to abandon his wife and child as he fled his homeland in a flimsy wooden craft under cover of dark.

title: FOSSILS ARE CALLED OLDEST IN AMERICAS
description: Fossils of the earliest land animals known to have inhabited the Americas, the remarkably well-preserved remains of a mite and some spiderlike creatures and centipedes, have been found in upstate New York, scientists disclosed today. The animals lived 380 million years ago.

title: A FILM FOR THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: JANICE O'BRIEN of New Fairfield remembers the summers in her childhood she spent playing with a girl from Brooklyn, N.Y. Those happy times occurred when Mrs. O'Brien's aunt invited the girl to spend two weeks each year at her home in New Jersey, through the Friendly Town program of the Fresh Air Fund.

title: 38 Crewmen on Nile Steamer Face Charges of Negligence
description: The police said today that a Nile steamer that sank in flames Wednesday had no functioning fire extinguishers and that 38 crewmen would be charged with negligence.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They looked like they might have died yesterday.'' - Dr. William A. Shear of Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, speaking of 380-million-year-old fossils. (24:3.)

title: WHY THE TONYS DON'T PLEASE EVERYONE
description: Tony Award fever can cause euphoria or depression. It can lead to interfamilial envy, when one member of a cast is nominated but not another. When the envelopes are opened and the winners are announced next Sunday at the Uris Theater, some otherwise sensible people may turn into dithering idiots, reciting long laundry lists of all those who have passed through their lives.

title: CHAMBER GROUPS GET A BOOST
description: Eight contemporary chamber ensembles recently joined forces to create the New York Consortium for New Music. Early this spring, responding to an invitation from the woodwind player Virgil Blackwell, representatives from Continuum, the Group for Contemporary Music, the Da Capo Chamber Players, Musical Elements, the New Music Consort, the New York New Music Ensemble, Parnassus and Speculum Musicae met to discuss the state of new music. These organizations program 20thcentury music exclusively. Collectively, they have made over 50 recordings, commissioned 155 new works, and given nearly 300 world premieres. But all were faced with the fiscal problems confronting many performing arts organizations: inflation, a shortage of federal and state funds, and increasing difficulties in obtaining private grants.

title: ABDUCTED 17-MONTH-OLD L.I. GIRL IS RETURNED
description: A 17-month-old girl who was abducted from a Long Island mall while her mother was shopping has been reunited with her parents after frantic and painstaking work by more than 70 law-enforcement agents.

title: STATE'S J-51 AUCTION TO MOLD FUTURE OF GUT REHABILITATION
description: CONSTRUCTION men are at work these days renovating a handful of dilapidated brownstones along the pleasant side streets off DeKalb Avenue in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. They are creating modern rental apartments that middle-income New Yorkers will be able to afford.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Immune Disease Given Priority
description: The mysterious and deadly illness known as AIDS has long been a concern among homosexuals, whose numbers it apparently strikes most often. Last week it became ''the No.1 priority'' of the United States Public Health Service.

title: TORONTO PRESSES BABY DEATHS INQUIRY
description: The newspaper headlines here refer to it as the ''sick kids case,'' a reference that has come to be widely and immediately recognized throughout Canada as the muddled and unresolved investigation into the suspicious deaths nearly three years ago of as many as 28 infants at the city's Hospital for Sick Children.

title: A SILVER LINING DESPITE THE CLOUDS
description: PHIL TROMBINO, the enthusiastic head coach of Iona College's baseball team, a member of the Metro Atlantic Conference, looked into the sky on a recent Sunday morning as his team was about to start its last two games of the season - a doubleheader - and smiled. The sun was coming out from behind some rapidly moving cumulus clouds.

title: FRENCH BRING A DARKER VIEW OF WORLD ECONOMIC HEALTH
description: French officials came to the economic summit meeting here today reluctant to underwrite what they suggest is the Reagan Administration's overly optimistic view that the world is recovering from recession.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Indianapolis 500. Among the five rookies in this year's race is Al Unser Jr., whose father and uncle, Bobby, have won this race three times apiece. Al Sr. is also in the race. Teo Fabi of Italy, another rookie, has the pole position. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M., tape).

title: Around the World; 6 Nkomo Supporters Detained in Zimbabwe
description: Six supporters of Joshua Nkomo who were cleared of treason charges last month have been ordered held indefinitely.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE SUBDUED ELEGANCE OF MORVEN
description: PRINCETON THE early history of Morven, for many years the state's Executive Mansion, is a fascinating chronicle of the Revolutionary War period. Gov. Brendan T. Byrne and his family were the last to occupy Morven, which has yielded to Drumthwacket, also in Princeton, as the Executive Mansion. However, Governor Kean has chosen not to live in Drumthwacket, opting instead for his home in Livingston.

title:
The World in Summary;
BId to Send Back Cubans
description: Some members of Congress have called on the Administration to open discussions with Cuba to try to smooth over their sharp differences in Central America. Last week, an official contact was made but it was only to call on Havana to take back several thousand Cuban criminals and other undesirables who came to the United States in the 1980 boatlift.

title: SCHOOL GIVEN A NEW ALLURE FOR SUMMER
description: Summer school is so unpopular among city students who need the extra instruction, according to the Schools Chancellor, that he has decided to revamp the program by offering more interesting courses and extending the school day.

title: EXTRADITION OF TERRORIST FROM MEXICO TO BE SOUGHT
description: Federal and New York City law-enforcement authorities said yesterday that they planned shortly to begin extradition proceedings in Mexico for the return of a long-sought Puerto Rican terrorist captured there last week.

title: ERVING IS KEEPING THINGS IN PERSEPECTIVE
description: THE feeling was there, just as he expected it would be. It was a fluttering in the pit of his stomach, a gentle gnawing, reflecting the anticipation, the anxiety and the nervousness of the unusual moment.

title: AFRICANS ASK U.N. TO ACT ON NAMIBIA
description: A long line of African foreign ministers and diplomats came to the Security Council this week to condemn South Africa and its control over South-West Africa.

title:
Art;
7 ARTISTS' GOOD MANNERS
description: ON-HUDSON THESE days, when the visual and emotional excesses of neoexpressionism seem to be everywhere, it comes as something of a relief to encounter an exhibition as modest and quiet as ''Grass Roots'' at The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson. Selected by a jury, the show includes the work of seven artists from the county, all of them women, and it will be on view through July 1.

title: UTILITY SEEKS MONEY AND GETS A SCOLDING
description: A SMALL family-owned utility on the Connecticut-Rhode Island border has been told that it cannot make its customers pay for such expenses as a $400 ceramic basset hound, Valentine's Day candy, perfume or golfing fees.

title: OPERATING FOR PROFIT AT HOSPITAL CORP.
description: WALTERBORO, S.C., is a poor, sleepy, rural community of 6,100 peoples et about 50 miles from Charleston. It was named for the Walters b rothers, who migrated there in the late 1700's to escape the m osquitoes farther south. Getting sick, though, was what modern day inhabitants dreaded most. That meant checking into the red-brick building over on Lemacks Street - the Colleton Regional Hospital, the only hospital in the county.

title: CUTS IN DRIVER EDUCATION STIR DEBATE
description: DESPITE studies showing that students who complete driver education are safer on the road, more and more school districts on the Island are eliminating or modifying the course, a trend that troubles state officials and local educators as well.

title: Truman Home Cited As U.S. Historic Site
description: President Reagan has signed legislation designating the Harry S. Truman home in Independence, Mo., a national historic site in the centennial year of the 33d President's birth.

title: Saxton Team Wins
description: Tom Hamilton and Jon Saxton of Greenwich captured the 12th annual Wilson Cup with a better-ball total of 131 Friday at the Scarsdale Golf Club in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: THEATER: 'GAY DIVORCE'
description: Fifty years ago, when the world was coping, or not coping, with such distractions as the rise of Hitler and the Great Depression, comedies that frothed were providing diversions into merriment for the masses. Among these was the then-new ''Gay Divorce,'' a sort of bedroom musical by Cole Porter and a trio of book-men. The one memorable feature of it, as you can see in its current revival at the Goodspeed Opera House, in East Haddam, Conn., is the great Porter tune ''Night and Day.''

title:
TV VIEW;
TAKING SOME POINTERS FROM THE BRITISH
description: The ''art of film'' has become a commonplace commodity in the auditoriums of many of the nation's museums. And television productions have sometimes been allowed to wriggle into that category, especially when they take a form as lofty as, for example, the last major projects, all made for Italian television, of Roberto Rossellini. But New York's Museum of Broadcasting, in operation for several years, is devoted exclusively to television and is increasingly active in preserving and displaying the outstanding accomplishments of the medium. Recent ''exhibitions'' have covered everything from the comedy of Sid Caesar to contemporary German television. The latter pointedly reminded film purists that much of the work of the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder, a current idol, was produced for television.

title: MCENROE IS FINED $3,000
description: Martina Navratilova's 1983 unbeaten streak ended today when 17-year-old Kathy Horvath upset the defending champion, 6-4, 0-6, 6-3, in the fourth round of the French Open tennis championships.

title: THE NEW ROMANCE WITH TONALITY
description: There is still a lot of good music waiting to be written in C major. ARNOLD SCHOENBERG (circa 1945).

title: A Clarification
description: An article last week about John A. Roebling, the engineer who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, and his family and industrial complex in and around Trenton was unclear about the companies.

title:
Business Forum;
PUTTING TOMORROW'S SUMMITS ON HOLD
description: SUMMIT conferences are risky business. They can demonstrate common purpose, when there is a consensus on w hat needs to be done. But if the timing is wrong, they can also h ighlight differences and undermine confidence in leadership. They s hould be convened with caution and only when warranted.

title: Deborah Gutoff Marries John Gault Jr.
description: Deborah Lynne Gutoff, daughter of Simone Firestone Gutoff of Westport, Conn., and Reuben Gutoff of Bridgehampton, L.I., and New York, was married yesterday to John Edward Gault Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gault of Chicago. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Metro Changes Rejected
description: Athletic directors of the Metro Conference rejected a 45-second shot clock and 3-point play for league basketball games in the 1983-84 season on the final day of meetings today.

title: Jane Winans to Wed July 30
description: Jane Phillips Winans, Washington office manager for Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, and Thomas Francis McKim, an associate in the law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in Washington, plan to be married July 30. Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Winans of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. William I. McKim of New Castle, Pa. Miss Winans graduated from Kenyon College. Her fiance is an alumnus of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago Law School.

title: HEAVY BAGGAGE
description: nation summit meets primarily to discuss economic issues, but each government leader has politics primarily on his mind. That is natural because nowadays the economy is the central political question in each of the countries concerned.

title: Tylenol Hunt
description: Seven people were dead because someone had laced Tylenol capsules with cyanide and put them back on the shelves of stores, and the crime hunt that followed in Chicago was one of the largest in history. Week after week more than 100 Federal, state and local agents, directed by the Illinois Attorney General, tracked hundreds of leads.

title: 'OLD COMPLAINTS' REGARDING MARCOS
description: To the Editor:

title: RECALLING THE BLUE RIBBON
description: Frank J. Prial finds mixing beer and lemonade to make a drink called panache to be peculiar, French and working-class. If, on the other hand, you mix beer and lemonade across the British Channel, you come up with a drink called shandy which is commonplace, British to the core, middle- or upper-class and definitely not working-class.

title: NEW SAFEGUARD FOR REMODELING A HOME
description: HOMEOWNERS usually protect themselves from dishonest contractors t hrough their vigilance during construction and, if need be, the f iling of bothersome and expensive lawsuits to make sure the job is c ompleted satisfactorily.

title: U.S. WARNS SOVIET
description: The Syrian military command announced today that its armed forces had ended their spring maneuvers and ''have now returned to their normal situation and status.''

title: Headliners; This Time She Means It
description: If those who play guessing games ever form a league, some Environmental Protection Agency veterans doubtless will turn pro.

title: THE HOUSE THAT KEYNES BUILT
description: WHEN I was asked some years ago whether Keynes was dead, I had to reply: ''Yes, Keynes is dead. And so are Newton and Darwin.'' My point was that John Maynard Keynes had become part of history. Of course, most people born 100 years ago are already part of history, especially those who have been dead for almost four decades.

title: Connecticut Guide; FILM BREAKTHROUGH
description: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' was looked upon as a breakthrough in film-making when Max Reinhardt produced it in 1935, and it is still cherished as a magical interpretation of William Shakespeare's comedy. The film, directed by William Dieterle, will be screened at 2 P.M. Saturday in the Ferguson Library, 96 Broad Street, Stamford.

title: Barbara Vande Wiele Marries Brian Buckley
description: Barbara Margaret Vande Wiele, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Laurent Vande Wiele of Alpine, N.J., and Brian Langford Buckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Ross Buckley of Vienna, Va., were married yesterday. The Rev. Jack M. McKelvey performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: Westchester Journal
description: WHEN it is the off-season for trotting at Yonkers Raceway all sorts of things take place there. The yearly Westchester County Fair, to be held July 7 through 17, is an example. And this year, for the first time, there will be a trade show of heavy-construction equipment, supplies and services on June 23, 24 and 25.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 11 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 8 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high-school set. 3 3 8 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 4 5 5 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 5 4 9 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 6 6 6 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 7 8 3 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 8 9 9 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.)

title: No Headline
description: The New European Painters I found John Russell's comparison of Georg Baselitz to a 16thcentury Hans Holbein monk to be apt and also thought-provoking (''The New European Painters,'' April 24). There is perhaps another comparison to be made - viz. the resemblance of Georg Baselitz, Francesco Clemente and Sandro Chia to the three shepherds of the Portinari Altarpiece painted by Hugo van der Goes, in 1476. H.W. Janson, in his ''History of Art,'' speaks of ''the striking contrast between the frantic excitement of the shepherds and the ritual solemnity of all other figures,'' and notes that the artist has depicted a ''wide-eyed directness never attempted before.'' CHRISTINE H. MERKL

title: ANTIQUE BANKING LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BRIDGE RULE ENFORCEMENT
description: THIS summer will be the first that the Federal law redefining the Coast Guard's duties with regard to bridges over navigable waterways will be in effect. Gary Kassof, a civilian supervisor with the Coast Guard, said that the change means that the Coast Guard itself will prosecute violations of the rules governing the operation of the bridges.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. **Comparable data unavailable because method of computing homeownership costs has changed. *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Avergaes) New York Week of May 23 Week of May 16 Week of Nov. 22 Conventional 12.70 12.68 14.04 Rollovers 12.64 12.66 14.34 Adjustable Rate 11.35 11.44 13.57 *4*Source: HSH Associates New Jersey Conventional 12.72 12.68 13.78 Rollovers 12.33 11.36 13.87 Adjustable Rate 11.47 11.54 13.24 *4*Source: HSH Associates Connecticut Conventional 11.16 12.71 14.02 Rollovers 12.62 12.25 13.08 Adjustable Rate 12.25 11.17 12.88 *4*Source: The Millard Group Inc. CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 13.60 13.60 15.33 Rollovers 12.94 12.94 15.17 Adjustable Rate 11.96 11.97 14.00 *4*Source: HSH Associates

title: Shopper's World; WHERE POTTERY IS A TRADITION
description: LINDA JEFFRIES is a writer who lives in Cambridge, Mass. BY LINDA JEFFRIES

title: East Side Holdup Man Slain by Retired Officer
description: A retired New York City police sergeant walking from his Upper East Side apartment to a store early yesterday shot and killed one of two men who tried to steal a gold neck chain and other belongings from him, the police said.

title: All-Star Invitations
description: Bill Terry is the only surviving member of the 1933 All-Star Game who has not accepted an invitation to participate in activities revolving around the 50th anniversary of the game, set for July 6 at Chicago's Comiskey Park, site of the first game. The activities will include an Old-Timers All-Star game to be played July 5.

title: THE 1,001 DELIGHTS OF ANDALUSIA
description: R.W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times. BY R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: Mailbox; Faults Are Found With Ivan Lendl
