description: To the Sports Editor: I find it hard to believe that a reader would praise the good sportsmanship of Ivan Lendl (Mailbox, May 15) in view of his conduct at the recent Tournament of Champions.

title: Cadets Suffer in 'Hell Week'
description: Air Force officials confirmed today that 136 Air Force Academy freshmen cadets were treated and 13 hospitalized briefly this week after annual ''hell week'' activities. The officials said most were suffering from dehydration, caused by a combination of rigorous exercise, 82-degree heat and a lunch of tacos and sour cream.

title: Rosemary McKenna Wed To Lawrence W. Ward Jr.
description: Rosemary Patricia McKenna, daughter of Gerald P. McKenna of Natick, Mass., and the late Rose M. McKenna, was married yesterday to Lawrence William Ward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward of Cincinnati. The Rev. Edward L. Gallagher performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Natick.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE COLOR PURPLE. By Alice Walker. (Pocket/ Washington Square, $5.95.) Winner of an American Book Award and a Pulitzer Prize, ''The Color Purple'' is a ''consummately well-written'' epistolary novel that centers on Celie, a poor, barely literate Southern black woman who struggles to escape the brutality and degradation of her treatment by men. Our reviewer, Mel Watkins, noted that Alice Walker is a lavishly gifted writer whose narrative style in this story ''forces intimate identification with the heroine'' and that the book brings many themes from the author's earlier work into sharper focus.

title: Kumi Sato Is the Bride Of Donald P. Kanak Jr.
description: Kumi Sato, daughter of Mrs. Taeko Matsuda Sato of Tokyo and the late Keiichiro Sato, was married yesterday in New York to Donald P. Kanak Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kanak of Elkin, N.C. The Rev. Robert Nunn performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: English at Erasmus
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Some Questions From East Meadow Once again the people of East Meadow have been deceived by county officials. Over the last 20 years, civic leaders in the community have repeatedly urged that the community add to its tax base by using the prison farm at the corner of Carman Avenue and Salisbury Drive as a high-technology center. The reaction of the county officials has always been the same and has stressed the need for the farm to continue and to provide produce for the hospital and prison.

title: NORTHPORT
description: WHEN it was founded in 1656 on land purchased from the Matinecock I ndians, the Village of Northport was known as Cowharbor. The name isr evived each year on Cowharbor Day, the last Sunday in September, w hen thousands of visitors pour in, a good many of them in running s hoes to compete in a 6.5-mile race.

title: HOW STORES COPE AFTER FIRES
description: THE day after a fire gutted the Valentine Flower and Plant Purveyors shop in Yonkers, George Kanganis, its owner, set up a temporary office and contacted his relatives who operate their own flower shops in the New York City area. With their help, he was able to fill outstanding orders and, by the following week, the Valentine florist shop had established a temporary headquarters in a vacant store 100 feet from its original site.

title: KARPOV ADDS ANOTHER FEATHER
description: It's standard snobbery for a world champion not to participate in his national championship. Isn't it superfluous to show he can dominate the home crowd after he has defeated the world's best?

title: Music; JUNE IS BUSTING OUT IN SONG
description: THE first week of June is traditionally a slow time in the music world - the spring season is over and the summer concerts haven't started yet - but a number of unusual programs next weekend are well worth noting.

title: Abroad at Home; FRUITS OF VICTORY
description: A year ago this week Israeli forces entered Lebanon. As the anniversary approaches, various analysts are giving their estimates of what Israel gained and lost in its longest war. But the accounts commonly leave out what should be a critical element in the costbenefit analysis: the fact that Prime Minister Begin had a hidden agenda in the war.

title: THE SOUTH, IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: Cultural symbols, in their own temples, are harmless signs and songs of celebration or solace. Displayed in someone else's temple, however, they carry an explosive charge of such power that they may destroy the possibility of mutual understanding.

title: NUCLEAR MISSILES: WARNING SYSTEM AND THE QUESTION OF WHEN TO FIRE
description: If the Soviet Union ever fired nuclear missiles at the United States, seconds after the rocket engines ignited bells would ring and lights would flash in warning centers deep inside this mountain.

title: Around the Nation; Warrant Issued in Blast At Tennessee Factory
description: The authorities issued a nationwide warrant today for the owner of a bait farm that they charge was the front for an illegal explosives factory. Eleven workers were killed in a series of earthshaking blasts at the factory Friday.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Recent Sales
SUMMER JOB OUTLOOK DIMMER
description: WHEN the high schools in Merrick and Baldwin, in Riverhead and Huntington, close their doors on June 24, about 173,000 teen-agers will be through with their books for the summer. Many of them will be seeking jobs, something not so easy to come by these days.

title: 40 SHARE $1 MILLION IN ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION AID
description: As the hearing child of deaf parents, Lou Ann Walker learned to use sign language before she could speak. And as she grew up in Indiana, she became adept as a communicator between the deaf and the world of sound, working in hospitals, the courts and wherever she was asked to help the deaf.

title: SYRIA'S BID IS BACKED BY STRONG CARDS
description: Five years ago, Syria and most of the Arab world stridently denounced the Camp David agreement that brought peace between Egypt and Israel. But Arab rhetoric and a half-hearted diplomatic and economic boycott of Egypt finally accomplished very little.

title: SIKORSKY TO PAY NEW YORK AIRWAYS $6 MILLION
description: An agreement by Sikorsky Aircraft to pay $6 million in damages to New York Airways for two helicopter accidents has provided an upbeat postscript to the often-unhappy story of the airline's operations, which ended in 1979.

title: Carolyn Gibbons Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. George B. Gibbons Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Gibbons, to Samuel F. Abernathy, son of Jane Dunn Abernathy of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Samuel Abernathy.

title: Japanese Trade
description: To the Business Editor: Yoshi Tsurumi tells us that there is no mystery to Japan's success (''Japanese Competition Can Be Healthy,'' May 1). If American industries think of long-term growth and refuse to sacrifice that for short-term profits, as Mr. Tsurumi describes the United States semiconductor industry doing by cutting back on planned investment during a recession to keep their profits looking healthy only to find itself way behind Japan when the recession lifted, then this country will be well on its way back to number one. CARYL CALLAHAN

title: Shelter Game
description: New York City was seeking to shelter hundreds of homeless people last year. Donald J. Trump, the realty developer, had a suggestion: put some in 10 vacant apartments in his building at 100 Central Park South.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Closing Chapters On Hitler Scam
description: What some had thought possessed the dimensions of world history degenerated last week into an above-average police blotter item. Gerd Heidemann, the reporter who got Stern magazine to pay $4.3 million for 60 volumes he claimed were Hitler's diaries, was arrested by West German police under suspicion of fraud.

title: HACKENSACK
description: FINDINGS in the death of Henry J. Reed Jr., a New York State corrections officer who died after a brief scuffle with two Bergen County Police Department officers, will be presented to a county grand jury that is scheduled to convene on June 10.

title: A SINGER ACTRESS, AN ACTRESS SINGER
description: ''I'M KATHRYN McATEER. I pay $250 a month for my apartment on Beekman Place, and you don't,'' announces the actress, who was born and raised in Fair Lawn.

title: Too Vague About Fixed Sentences
description: Commit a serious crime in New York and the judge will sentence you to an indefinite term - say, 5 to 15 years. How long you actually serve is decided by the parole board. The system results in different punishments for similar offenses and leaves the public confused. It also leaves too much power with parole boards, whose proceedings are remote from the public.

title: THERE ARE PLEASURES AND PERILS IN HIRING GARDEN HELP
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Carla Wallach has written many books on gardening. By CARLA WALLACH

title: DRAWING ON THE EQUITY IN YOUR HOME
description: AGROWING number of financial institutions now are making an offer t hat many families may find hard to resist: With a special credit c ard or checkbook, they can spend some of the wealth they have i nvested in their home. They can pay for a vacation, a summer home, e ven an evening out on the town, using the house as collateral. And t hey pay interest only on the funds used.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: HELP STILL NEEDED
description: THE bipartisan National Commission on Social Security Reform met for months to deliberate and formulate a plan to ''Save Social Security.'' In order to give support to social programs, the collective thinking in Washington is to raise taxes and cut programs. It is no surprise, then, that those who think this way would select a commission which would think that way.

title: Headliners; Terrorist Recaptured
description: William Morales, who has been on the run since he shimmied down a makeshift rope to escape from a Bellevue Hospital prison ward four years ago, stumbled last week. Mr. Morales, a leader of the terrorist Puerto Rican independence group, F.A.L.N., and its chief bomb builder, was captured after a gun battle with police in Puebla, Mexico. He escaped while being treated for injuries suffered in an accidental explosion - he lost both hands and an eye. He faces a total of 99 years in prison for New York and Federal convictions on weapons and explosives charges.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: OPERA New York's smaller opera companies can be counted on to fill the repertory gaps left open by our two major troupes. An example is the Bel Canto Opera, which regularly presents well-received productions of operas one is not likely to encounter at the Metropolitan Opera House or the New York State Theater.

title: Bangladesh Babies at Risk
description: Bangladesh has the world's highest infant mortality rate, with more than two of every five babies dying within 28 days of birth, Health Minister Shamsul Huq said Friday. He told a pediatricians' seminar that many babies died because of inadequate postnatal care that led to respiratory and other infections.

title: Washington; FREEDOM FROM THE PRESS
description: The Williamsburg summit meeting has not had a very good press, but the fault lies partly with the press itself. The leaders of the industrialized nations didn't invite over 3,000 reporters; they had nothing more in mind than a quiet talk and a stroll in the gardens, but they landed in a circus.

title: ERASTUS CORNING 2D, ALBANY MAYOR SINCE '42, DIES
description: Erastus Corning 2d, who was first elected Mayor of Albany long before many of the capital's present voters were born, died in University Hospital in Boston yesterday of cardio-pulmonary failure. Mr. Corning, who was 73 years old, had served longer than any other big-city mayor in the country.

title: Coaches Are Keys To Academics
description: To the Sports Editor: Finally. Sheldon Silver, in his (''Athletic Energy for Academic Power,'' The New York Times, May 15) presented an attempt at a personal, practical, real solution to the student-athlete dilemma that has gained so much attention in recent years.

title: THROUGH THE EYES OF LORD KEYNES
description: A WARNING OF WAR

title:
Antiques;
ACCESSORIES SHARE RIDGEFIELD SPOTLIGHT
description: TODAY, when an outdoor fair can be found somewhere in Connecticut almost every summer weekend, young collectors may have difficulty imagining the time when flea markets did not exist. One of the pioneer outdoor antiques shows, the Ridgefield Flea Market, the fifth such event organized, will mark its 23d anniversary Saturday.

title: SYMMETRY IS QUITE NICE BUT EVEN NICER WHEN IT BREAKS
description: As Pasteur remarked, chance discovery favors the prepared mind. Yet even expected discoveries are gratefully received by scientists, if only because they confirm their faith in the rational order of nature.

title: HOW ABOUT THE BASSET HORN?
description: When George Bernard Shaw persuaded a London paper in 1888 to let him contribute a column of music criticism, he looked around for a suitable pen name. It happened to be a time when critics often wrote anonymously, a judicious idea. ''I had to invent a fantastic personality with something like a foreign title,'' he wrote later. ''I thought of Count di Luna (a character in Verdi's 'Trovatore'), but finally changed it for Corno di Bassetto, as it sounded like a foreign title and nobody knew what a corno di bassetto was.'' It was and still is, in fact, a melancholy-toned member of the clarinet family known in English as the basset horn. Shaw himself didn't know what a corno di bassetto was, as he gladly confessed: ''If I had ever heard a note of it in 1888 I should not have selected it for a character which I intended to be sparkling. The devil himself could not make a basset horn sparkle.''

title: A 1950'S SALUTE IN A 19TH-CENTURY SETTING
description: TARRYTOWN'S venerable Music Hall, an officially declared 19thcentury landmark where chamber-music concerts and classical plays usually take place, will shake, rattle and roll from Thursday evening through Sunday afternoon. That's when the newly formed Theater League of Westchester will present four performances of ''How Sweet It Was - A Salute to the Fifties.'' The creation of Harve Brosten, the producer, and Barry Harmon, the writer, this is a more or less chronological re-creation of the songs and styles of a decade where simplistic sentiments segued into raucous rock.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
A ROSE TINTED VIEW OF AMERICA IN THE 1940'S
description: There is a friendly, easy look about the photographs of American life in the 1940's on view at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through July 3. Entitled ''Roy Stryker: U.S.A., 1943-50,'' the exhibition consists of nearly 200 photographs taken under the direction of Mr. Stryker for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, photographs that were once widely reproduced in newspapers, magazines and books. Though most of these photographs have been out of circulation for years, they will bring back memories to older viewers, and even younger viewers will catch a glimpse of a vanished America - or perhaps one should say of a fictitious America that did not exist even when the photographs were taken.

title: MY ENCOUNTERS WITH THE TRULY GREAT
description: VOICES A Memoir. By Frederic Prokosch. 343 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Sports of the Times; Pain and Glory For the Lakers
description: The competitor in him was clawing at his composure. Pat Riley was annoyed at his players, annoyed at the referees, annoyed at trailing the Philadelphia 76ers, 2-0, in the National Basketball Association championship series. Some coaches would have been growling and snarling. But the Lakers' coach had a grip on himself as well as the situation. When asked if he planned to make adjustments in the defending champions for today's third game in Los Angeles, he dictated a message to his team.

title: IS THERE A NEED FOR BASEBALL'S ANTITRUST EXEMPTION?
description: professional baseball.

title: Sunday Observer; THAT'S STYLE!
description: Here is a 69-cent sink stopper fresh from the store. It is a flat, circular white object, approximately five inches in diameter, and seems to be made of rubber, but could be made of plastic, I suppose, since almost everything is these days.

title: Nuptials Planned For Miss Griffin
description: Mr. and Mrs. John T. Griffin of Oyster Harbors, Mass., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elisabeth Griffin, to Robert Alexander Montgomery 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Montgomery of New York and Stonington, Conn.

title: JERSEY UTILITIES AID NEEDY THOUSANDS
description: New Jersey utilities have set up programs to contribute money to help needy customers pay their monthly bills, officials said.

title: OH? NOT EVEN AN ACRE
description: SELLING one's home can be a wrenching experience, I am told. Friends and neighbors who visit under the guise of sharing your joy at the job promotion precipitating the move quickly reveal their true purpose, patting your collective family head in sympathy as you prepare to be torn from the finest community in the free world.

title: Khomeini Assails U.S.  Over Appeal on Bahais
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, has criticized President Reagan for supporting members of the Bahai faith in Iran, who he said were agents for foreign powers, the state-run Teheran radio said today.

title: HOW A RECORDING PIONEER CREATED A TREASURY OF FOLK MUSIC
description: When Moses Asch was a young man, in the 1920's, his father, the novelist Sholem Asch, sent him to Europe to study. ''I was the only American in a university in Koblenz,'' he recalled recently, ''with Russians, Hollanders, and so on, and they would have song fests. When it came my turn, they'd say, 'You people had Indians walking your streets when our people were making our songs. You have no folk music.' ''

title: JAPANESE TRADE
description: To the Business Editor: Business analysts recognize that the factors which enable certain foreign producers to succeed in the U.S. market may not be identical to the factors which hinder the efforts of American sellers in foreign markets. The fundamental question is rather the identification and implementation of the reforms that American industry needs to make during the coming years in order to make and keep the major sectors of our economy competitive, both in the U.S. and in foreign markets. ROBERT G. VAMBERY, Ph.D Academy of International Business City University of New York New York, May 4

title: C.H.S.A.A. 1,600 WON BY DORANS
description: Dave Dorans won the 1,600-meter run at the 57th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. But that is not the whole story.

title: Syracuse Wins Lacrosse Title
description: Syracuse overcame a seven-goal deficit, scored nine straight goals during an eight-minute span of the second half and stunned Johns Hopkins, 17-16, today to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship at Rutgers Stadium.

title: CAIRO IS CRUMBLING UNDER THE BURDEN OF ITS PEOPLE
description: In the center of a traffic circle near Cairo's main railway station, a huge serene statue of Ramses II is encased in scaffolding as technicians try to halt its decomposition.

title: WRITERS IN PLACE AND WRITERS IN MOTION
description: MISSISSIPPI WRITERS TALKING, By John Griffin Jones. Illustrated. Volume One, 190 pp. Volume Two, 228 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. Cloth, $15 each. Paper, $8.95 each. BLACK WOMEN WRITERS AT WORK Edited by Claudia Tate. 213 pp. New York: Continuum. $14.95.

title: Correspondent's Choice; QUISLINGS AND PATRIOTS
description: BARNABY J. FEDER is a Times correspondent based in London. BY BARNABY J.FEDER

title: Christopher Doherty Wed To Donna Marie McGuirk
description: Donna Marie McGuirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. McGuirk of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Alexander Doherty, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Doherty of Scranton, Pa.

title: Female Sports Are Not Inferior
description: To the Sports Editor: How can William D. Warner (Mailbox, May 15) dare to say he holds professional sports ''very dear'' when he means he holds men's sports very dear? The idea that someone with such limited, one-sided vision still exists more than 10 years after the inception of the women's movement amazes and depresses me.

title: LILCO ACCUSED OF IMPEDING SHOREHAM INQUIRY
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission has charged the Long Island Lighting Company with impeding the panel's investigation of cost overruns at the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Nina Simone and Judy Mowatt come from different cultures and different generations, but they have a great deal in common, more than one might think. Although Miss Simone grew up in North Carolina in the 1940's, and Miss Mowatt reached maturity in Jamaica in the 1960's, both are black women.

title: PATTY SHEEHAN LEADS
description: Patty Sheehan, getting birdies on three of four holes in one stretch, took a one-stroke lead after the third round of the $150,000 Corning Classic golf tournament today.

title: WATER POLLUTION LINKED TO SOIL TYPE
description: FARMERS and soil experts are grappling to find ways to end groundwater contamination caused by agricultural chemicals on the East End, where prime soils still abound in what is the Island's last remaining farm belt.

title: THE CASE FOR CONSUMERISM
description: Today, an abundance of evidence suggests that President Reagan, by stimulating consumer reaction, has done for the consumer movement of the 1980's what the consumer advocate Ralph Nader did two decades earlier, though neither is likely to cherish the comparison. Recently, a House Appropriations subcommittee added $5 million to the 1984 budget of the Federal Trade Commission, allowing it to keep its regional offices open and strong. The House Energy and Commerce Committee roundly defeated a bid from advertisers that hoped to prevent the F.T.C. from challenging advertisements directed at young children, while passing a resolution directing the agency to begin a series of studies of the insurance industry.

title: A Costly Collision
description: Duane Kuiper, the second baseman of the San Francisco Giants, suffered a fractured collarbone in a collision with Mike Marshall of the Dodgers near second base in a game in Los Angeles Friday night. Kuiper, 175 pounds, was racing for a pop fly over the mound with two out in the second inning and Marshall, a 6-foot-5-inch, 225-pounder, was running from first to second base when the collision occurred.

title: Kathleen Fanning Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Fanning of Marlborough, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Ellen Fanning, to Dr. David J. Stuchiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Stuchiner of New York.

title: Nonpolitical Mann?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Rote Weds Michael M. Starr
description: Clarice Margaret Constance Rote, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rote of Greenwich, Conn., and Sante Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Michael Morrill Starr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Parrish Starr of Bernardsville, N.J., and Mill Reef, Antigua. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at the St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: THE ART OF FINE-TUNING A RECORDING
description: Several thousand new phonograph albums are released in the United States each year, then sent out to fight for space in the nation's record racks. While only one in five will make money, all of them are the products of hope, of dreams and of a good deal of work and advance planning - not the least in the recording process itself, which is sometimes just as complex and delicate as the composition and preparation of the music. In that respect, ''Guitars on the Go,'' a recent release on the RCA label by Los Indios Tabajaras, is a typical album. But in several important aspects the album is atypical - most notably in that in an age of tenuous loyalties, Los Indios Tabajaras and its recording company, RCA have been together for 26 years.

title: MCDERMOTT: RIDING OUT THE SLUMP
description: NEW ORLEANS BACK in the swamp country, alongside Bayou Boeuf, the sounds of the wetlands have been replaced by the clanging of giant chunks of steel coming together. There, in an 1,100-acre fabrication yard 90 miles southwest of New Orleans, McDermott International Inc., the world's leading builder of offshore oil production platforms, puts together awesome steel edifices, some as tall as the Eiffel Tower and able to house as many as 60 oil wells.

title: MEMORIAL DAY EVENTS
description: With the customary parades and tributes, Long Islanders will mark Memorial Day this weekend. At Eisenhower Park, for instance, the United Veterans' Organization of Nassau will honor the war dead today at 10 A.M. in the county's annual Memorial Day ceremony at the Veterans' Memorial adjacent to parking field seven of the East Meadow facility.

title: The Nation in Summary; Liuzzo-F.B.I. Suit Rejected
description: Federal District Judge Charles W. Joiner did more last week than reject the $2 million negligence suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation brought by the children of Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a white civil rights worker murdered in Alabama in 1965. His opinion took a giant step toward rehabilitating Gary Thomas Rowe, the F.B.I. informant riding in the car from which the shots that killed Mrs. Liuzzo were fired.

title: Tip-Off Pairing
description: Houston, which lost to North Carolina State, 54-52, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship game April 4, will get another chance to play the Wolfpack, Nov. 19 in the fifth annual Hall of Fame Tip-Off Classic here. The game is considered the official opener of the college basketball season.

title: Deborah S. Price To Marry in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart E. Price Jr. of Pittsburgh have made known the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Stuart Price, to John Harrison Wright 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wright Jr. of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: THE 3 LIVES OF A WEDDING DRESS
description: When Deborah Gutoff was married to John Gault Jr. yesterday at the Harmonie Club, her silk veil was something old - her mother's. And her Chantilly lace dress was something new - it was made for her by Jeanne Atkinson. But it was also something old because it was refashioned from her sister's wedding dress, which had been redesigned from their mother's wedding dress.

title: Israelis Report an Arab Plot To Poison a Village's Water
description: The police say they have uncovered a plot by Israeli Arabs to poison the water in a Jewish village in Galilee. Five people have been arrested.

title: SALISBURY'S BAND: A 55-YEAR TRADITION
description: WITH three sharp blasts of the bandmaster's whistle, the musicians burst into a rousing John Philip Sousa march. The room could barely contain the noise of blaring brass, crashing cymbals and pounding drums, and a few observers smiled and placed their hands protectively over their ears.

title: Miss Leggett Has Nuptials
description: Clarissa Weld Leggett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Leggett of Washington, Va., was married there yesterday to Peter Solmssen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt A. Solmssen of Philadelphia. The Rev. Jennings W. Hobson 3d performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: DRIVE ON SEA DUMPING PUSHED
description: OVER the last year, at least 25,000 signatures have been collected on petitions opposing ocean dumping off the New Jersey coast, leading anti-ocean dumping groups to surmise that greater public concern has been generated.

title: A PARIS RITUAL TO SAVOR
description: Even for travelers who aren't particularly passionate about food, a tour of the markets of Paris offers both a glimpse of an immensely important French ritual and a look at the fabric of contemporary French society. The visitor who likes to start the day early might take a stroll through the Parc Monceau and then head straight for Rue Poncelet, the lively, open-air street market a few blocks away. Marketing is best in the morning, when the vegetable man is goodtempered, the crowds thin, the produce at its peak.

title: Optic Researcher
description: To the Business Editor: I am reasonably certain that the mysterious name ''Rowland'' in the Rowland Institute of Science is in honor of Prof. Henry A. Rowland (''Edwin Land: Still Searching, at 74,'' May 15).

title: TIME TO EXPLORE THE STATE'S BACKYARD
description: the state for all seasons, with its sailable coast, skiworthy hills, cultured cities and colonial villages - has been busily rediscovering its own infinite variety. As one of the more fruitful byproducts of the high cost of transportation, many Connecticut vacationers have begun exploring the nooks, crannies and diversions offered within a stone's throw of home, instead of taking off for alien parts.

title: Food; AS AMERICAN AS...CLAMS
description: It could be that our addiction to clams stems from the fact that we inhabit one of the great clam regions of America, eastern Long Island. On the other hand, we have savored with equal relish the fine clams of the West Coast, notably the butter clams that we have eaten both on the half shell and steamed, mariniere-style. Although clams are not universally found in all native waters, they are, in our minds, one of the most American of foods. In his estimable book, ''American Food'' (Vintage Books, 1981), Evan Jones notes that clam hash originated on the stoves of transplanted Easterners who immigrated to the West and were so disheartened to find themselves without corned beef that they replaced it with local clams, which they then turned into hash. Mr. Jones also speaks of the sentiment involved in a series of lines from a poem, ''The Old Settler'': ''I laugh at the world and its shams/ As I think of my pleasant condition/ surrounded by acres of clams.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE BOOK BUSINESS
description: Starting Saturday, the 83-year-old American Booksellers' Association- with its 4,756 members - will gather in Dallas with hundreds of e ditors and publishers for the group's four-day annual convention. A ssociation officials say they expect a more upbeat mood than p revailed at the last get-together.

title: Northeast Recovery
description: The economic recovery is coming to New England, but not as fast as it's coming to the rest of the country. A new forecast by the New England Economic Project predicts that the region's rate of employment growth will lag behind the nation's as a whole this year and next. One of the drags in 1983 will be the slow rebound in capital spending, which means little growth in the vaunted hightechnology industries. Data General, the computer company, is projecting no job growth this year and its president, Edson D. de Castro, says candidly that he is disappointed in its lower order figures for April.

title: THE DICTATOR'S DOWNFALL
description: THE EMPEROR, Downfall of an Autocrat. By Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by William R. Brand and Katarzyna Mroczkowska-Brand. 164 pp. San Diego & New York: A Helen & Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: LuAnne P. Piazza Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Piazza of Clifton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, LuAnne Patricia Piazza, to Robert Douglas Carl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Carl of Villanova, Pa.

title: EVANGELICALS HAIL DEBATE OVER ARMS
description: Evangelical Christians met here to debate the nuclear arms race at their first national conference on the issue, ending here today.

title: AT THE WATER'S EDGE: CHILDHOOD REVISITED
description: IT'S a late spring afternoon in Port Jefferson Harbor, and children sit along the edge of the pier fishing. The children come in all shapes, colors and sizes. A little girl, perhaps 3, waddles about, a salty pretzel in her mouth, eyes aglaze, her world apparently awhirl with light, color, noise, confusion.

title: Major News in Summary; On Bias, Court Is Loud and Clear
description: ''We will obey the law'' was President Reagan's only comment last week when the Supreme Court held that racially discriminatory private schools are ineligible for Federal tax exemptions. It was a laconic admission of defeat for an Administration that had tried what its recent predecessors had not considered - giving tax breaks to racially biased schools. The Court's 8-to-1 vote and trenchant opinion seemed a strikingly unequivocal signal that the Administration had gone far out on a political limb.

title: Joseph Donovan Married To Janet Treat St. Goar
description: Janet Treat St. Goar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter St. Goar of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday in Chestnut Hill, Mass., to Joseph Donovan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Donovan of Brackney, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the First Church (Unitarian) by Msgr.

title: PADRES DEFEAT METS, 5-4
description: The Mets tried a lot of things tonight to break the spell of San Diego, where they have lost 19 of 23 games in four years. They benched half the regular lineup; they loaded the batting order with nine right-handers; they even used Darryl Strawberry as a pinch-hitter.

title: RIVAL PARADES IN L.I. VILLAGE TO MEMORIALIZE FALLEN
description: In wartime they marched together, carried the flag together, grumbled about C rations together and fought together. Monday, because they cannot agree on how to honor their buddies who died in the nation's service, the local Veterans of Foreign Wars and American Legionnaires will march in separate Memorial Day parades.

title: TROTTING AROUND STRATFORD
description: SHAKESPEARE'S DOG, By Leon Rooke. 161 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95.

title: Miss Rutherford, Student, Marries Dr. S.B. Dowton
description: Polly Wanton Rutherford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Woodson Rutherford of New Canaan, Conn.; Siesta Key, Fla., and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Bruce Dowton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Dowton of Dubbo, New South Wales, Australia.

title: PERTH AMBOY IS 300
description: Perth Amboy is celebrating its 300th anniversary, and the Navy is helping out. It is welcoming visitors aboard the U.S.S. Boulder, a 565-foot LST (landing ship-tank) that will be docked at the Outerbridge Terminal on State Street today and tomorrow.

title: PANELS ARE IN PLACE TO SCREEN JUDGES
description: MONTH-OLD vacancy on Westchester's Family Court may soon be filled, now that a new series of judicial screening panels established by Governor Cuomo are complete.

title: CUBANS' LAWYERS QUESTION DEPORTATION PLANS
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal that Cuba take back some of the refugees who came to this country in 1980 is drawing criticism from lawyers who have been working to protect the Cubans' rights.

title: Up to 60 Indians Die in Crash
description: A bus carrying 100 people plunged into a gorge when its brakes failed Friday night in Madhya Pradesh state, and 60 people were feared dead, the United News of India news service reported.

title: Barbara G. Biddle and Ens. Charles Swicker Marry
description: Barbara Gayle Biddle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Kirk Biddle of South Dartmouth, Mass., and Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to Ens. Charles Clayton Swicker of the Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kerwin Swicker of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Edward O. Miller Jr., assistant rector of Trinity Church, Boston, performed the ceremony in the Road Congregational Church in Stonington.

title: I.B.M.: A PERVASIVE PRESENCE
description: ''IT seems like every time you turn around, I.B.M. is moving into a new building,'' a retired International Business Machines executive said recently. That is the way it seems to many others, including those who oppose new corporate buildings, such as the residents objecting to the one I.B.M. is proposing to build in New Castle, and those who favor them, such as Mount Pleasant's Supervisor, Michael Rovello, who welcomes a new building the corporation plans to put up in Thornwood.

title: Barbara J. Moore Marries
description: Barbara J. Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Moore of Martinsville, N.J., and Thomas Mark Chamberlain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Chamberlain of Waterville, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Florian Gall performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bound Brook, N.J. The bride is a pharmacist in Charleston, S.C. Her husband is studying for a doctorate in family practice and pharmacy at the School of Medicine of the University of South Carolina.

title: No Headline
description: The Worm and the Apple Public Discomfort

title: A TALENT FOR THE 80'S
description: Early in each decade the tournament bridge world finds itself having to take notice of a chip off the old block. In the early sixties the chip was Jim Jacoby of Dallas, who represented the United States for the first time in the 1963 world championships. He went on to win two world team titles and to develop a record of success matching that of his father, Oswald Jacoby, one of the all-time great players, who is still competing at the age of 80.

title: MEDIATING, NOT SUING, OVER THE ENVIRONMENT
description: Citizens of Laytonsville in affluent Montgomery County, Md., were adamant. They would not have a county garbage dump within their town limits. It would be a noisome eyesore and worse, it might contaminate the groundwater that supplied their drinking water.

title: Dining Out; TASTEFUL GOOD LOOKS IN SCARSDALE
description: THOSE who admired the elegantly appointed Frog Prince Proper should not be too disappointed with Chase Landing, the premises' new occupant. The tasteful decor remains, although some of the dramatic impact of stark, gorgeous simplicity has been lost with the addition not only of floral prints, attractive but cluttery, but also of tables. Dining tables, for instance, now fill half the space of the once-soigne entry room. We recommend refusing a table in this room, where the management's convenience overrides that of the diner. The real difficulty is that Chase Landing does not take reservations for dinner.

title:
Paperback Talk;
Permission to Play
description: ''Huh?'' ''Can this be serious?'' ''Well, how about that!'' Translated into the vernacular from assorted body language (raised eyebrows, furrowed foreheads, surprised smiles), that's what prepublication readers had to say about a spate of books coming out now.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Sheri Mitnick Married
description: The marriage of Sheri Gail Mitnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Mitnick of Lake Success, L.I., to Harlan Richard Halper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Halper of New York, took place yesterday at Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: Data Bank May 29, 1983 THE ECONOMY Gross National Product I Q'83 IV Q'82 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $3,170.9 $3,108.2 $2,995.5 Real G.N.P. title: Q and A
description: Question:I am planning to live in Europe for a year or more, and would like to know whether it is economically feasible to ship my car there. -M.C., Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Answer:Before considering shipping, you should determine that your car can be serviced where you plan to live in Europe, and discuss insurance coverage with your agent. (The American Automobile Association offers a foreign insurance policy to members and nonmembers; coverage for a sedan valued at $10,000 could cost about $1,100 for a year.)

title: Katherine Putnam Weds T.G. Delaney
description: Katherine Elizabeth Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lowell Putnam of Springfield and Chilmark, Mass., was married yesterday to Timothy George Delaney, son of Mrs. George Phillip Delaney of Washington and the late Mr. Delaney. The Rev. George Almeida, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Fahy of Washington, performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: On Language; FEELING EXPANSIVE
description: ''This morning, Mr. George Herman was questioning our F.B.I. director on 'Meet the Press,' '' writes Dr. Abraham Nathan of Brooklyn. ''A statement was made and Mr. Herman requested him to dilate upon that statement. He obviously meant expand - or is this a new meaning for dilate?''

title: HIGHER EDUCATION'S NEW ECONOMICS
description: I do not feel that it is elitist ranting to say that when two people are applying for a job, the one who can state that he attended Harvard will have an advantage over the one who says he went to CUNY.

title: STATUE TO HONOR MEN WHO FREED NAZIS' PRISONERS
description: I have tried to forget everything, but I can still remember this: My tank was the first one into the camp. The Jews and others were all trying to love us up. They were filthy, full of lice and looked diseased. Captain Aldredge ordered us back into our tanks. There were Germans outside in the woods, so we went and fought them.

title: Strong Mast Vital in Riding a Big Wave
description: With more sailors competing in offshore races, there are more incidents of yachts capsizing or rolling through 360 degrees. A study has revealed significant new information on what causes a yacht to capsize.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
FOOD FOR THOUGHT HAS NO CALORIES
description: IN A WORLD where we are all exhorted to eat thin, there is an extravagant gratification in reading cookbooks that describe how the French pour soup over their bread so that they never forget to enjoy the luxury of being able to take pleasure in simple things.

title: MRS. AUDAIN UPSETS MRS. WAITZ IN RACE
description: For different reasons and with varying results, 6,511 women ranging in age from 6 to 72 gathered in Central Park yesterday morning to test their running proficiency in the L'eggs Mini Marathon.

title: Television Week
description: Honoring the Office ''President and Mrs. Reagan are the easiest laughs you ever saw,'' Joseph Cates was saying the other day. He was referring to the Reagans as members of an audience, and most specifically during ''The President's Command Performance,'' a benefit for Ford's Theater in Washington.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Mental Patients Get Their Say In California
description: The drugs used to treat serious mental illness can also incur harrowing side effects including body tremors, contortions and stupor. It is the dark side of institutional therapy and in lawsuits nationwide many patients are refusing to accept it. Efforts to reach agreements in New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts are pending in Federal appeals courts. But one major settlement is in and affirms a right to refuse drugs by patients confined involuntarily to California's mental hospitals.

title: Music; CONCERT BENEFITS ENVIRONMENT
description: IF you love fine music and the outdoors, you can enjoy - and help - them both this Friday by attending the Picnic in the Park, a joint benefit for the New Haven Symphony and the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, a nonprofit public-interest group dedicated to preserving natural resources.

title: INQUIRY IN BROOKLYN
description: New York City's Board of Elections last week completed its unofficial count of the May 3 community school board elections. The board also announced that District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn was investigating possible ''ballot stuffing'' in six Brooklyn districts.

title: Miss Badenhausen Weds D.P. Holmes
description: Marguerite Metcalfe Badenhausen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Badenhausen of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Donald Philip Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Holmes of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. John Corr performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR THE last three years, tenants at 30 Walnut Street, Newark, an apartment house in the City Hall area, have been battling to save their five-story, 37-apartment building.

title: Salt and the Diet
description: To the Business Editor: ''Hitting a Snag in the Salt Wars,'' by Ronald Schwartz (April 24), creates a completely erroneous impression as to the attitude of the food processing industry, and the position of this organization, on the issue of sodium in the diet.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Atomic Power's Big New Promo
description: The old slogan - ''It pays to advertise'' - still applies. Hoping to breathe life into the comatose nuclear energy business, the Government and the electric power industry have launched campaigns to persuade the public that the atom is a wonderful thing to plug into.

title: A PASSIONATE COMMITMENT TO EXPERIENCE?
description: A STROLL WITH WILLIAM JAMES, By Jacques Barzun. 344 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: MARJORIE B. LESTER
description: Marjorie B. Lester, who was appointed by President Eisenhower to the White House Conference on Aging in 1958, died Thursday at the age of 101. Mrs. Lester, a lawyer, was the second woman appointed to the Kentucky bar.

title: VARIETY FORMAT SET FOR THE JOHN DREW
description: IN an attempt to revive the John Drew Theater, Guild Hall is going to a new, variety format this summer, ''Festival of the Arts '83.'' Theater, traditionally the mainstay of the house, will be on the boards for only four weeks, with two Broadway-bound comedies: Ellis Rabb's version of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' and ''Grotesque Lovesongs,'' a new work that will mark the producer Saint Subber's return to the New York theater after 20 years.

title: HELD MAYOR'S POST IN 1962-72
description: James H.J. Tate, the Mayor of Philadelphia from 1962 to 1972, died Friday at Shore Memorial Hospital, in Somers Point, N.J., apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived in Longport, N.J.

title: REAGAN'S WOUNDS ON RIGHTS FREQUENTLY SEEM SELF-INFLICTED
description: At his latest news conference, President Reagan said that people underestimated his commitment to civil rights because they had the wrong ''perception'' of his policies. ''A pretty good hatchet job has been done on us, and a great many people sincerely and honestly believe something that just is not true,'' the President said.

title: GENE TRIGGER IS HOTLY SOUGHT CLUE TO PUZZLE OF LIFE
description: All animals, from frogs to rodents to elephants to humans, begin as single fertilized eggs. Then, during the species' alloted days or months of gestation, the single fertilized cell differentiates into a vast, close-knit community, a myriad of different specialized cells all functioning in harmony.

title: A DIFFERENT APPROACH TO SCHOOLING
description: THE shortage of mathematics and science teachers gravely jeopardizes our national security, we are warned in report after report.

title: Shen-Huey Lee Weds Biologist
description: Shen-Huey Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shui-Chin Lee of Taipei, Taiwan, was married yesterday to Dr. San You Wang, son of Prof. Hao Wang of New York and Mrs. Yenking Kan Wang of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. Paul Szto of the Queens Christian Reformed Church in Jamaica, Queens, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother in Newton, Mass.

title: UTILITY AGENCY, WITH NO BUDGET, MAKING SLOW START
description: WHITE PLAINS AUTHORIZED by the voters in March 1982, the county's Public Utility Agency is still in the throes of organization - its mission to bring low-cost hydroelectric power to the county barely started.

title: RIGHETTI STOPS A'S FOR 7TH, 5-2
description: With George Steinbrenner quiet, except for his new ban on candy and pastry in the clubhouse, the Yankees beat the Oakland A's, 5-2, last night in a fight-free and statement-free baseball game.

title: Susan Murphy Weds Jeffrey Jacobs in Washington
description: Susan Elizabeth Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lee Murphy of Orchard Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Weller Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Jacobs of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. William L. George performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: IN LONG ISLAND'S BARRENS, EVERY LITTLE BIT HELPS
description: LONG ISLAND has Pinelands, too, and while there is no commission to protect them, Suffolk County has been quietly stockpiling acreage, discouraging development and persuading landowners to donate parcels. As in New Jersey, more is at stake than land. The Island depends on underground reserves for its water, so preserving the Pinelands means preserving the supply.

title: UNSUNG THEATRICAL TALENTS TAPPED
description: UNTIL last year, Raymond J. Flores, a playwright from Glen Cove whose works have been performed at the Henry Street Settlement House, the New York Ensemble Theater and the Latino Drama Unit of Joseph Papp's Public Theater, had never seen one of them mounted in suburbia.

title: Fire Danger Causes Moscow To Restrict Visits to Forests
description: Residents of Moscow have been forbidden to go to certain forested areas around the capital because a long, dry spell has greatly increased the risk of forest fires, local papers reported today.

title: RECALLING THE BLUE RIBBON
description: A Frenchman may very well mix Guinness stout with champagne, but the tradition is English and is everywhere to be found on Boxing Day in England. The drink is called black velvet. MARK LEWIS

title: Television Week
description: A Stepping Stone ''Northern Lights,'' which won the award as the best First Feature at the Cannes Film Festival in 1979, was broadcast on Channel 13 last year as part of the ''American Playhouse'' series. It subsequently won the ''Neil Simon Award for outstanding television drama scriptwriting.''

title: BRAZIL GATHERS ARCHIVE ON ITS PAINTER, PORTINARI
description: The late Candido Portinari is considered here to be the greatest artist Brazil has ever produced, yet all but a few of his 4,000 paintings are out of public view. They have become dispersed in private collections in so many places that his biographer compared their fate to that of Brazil's 18th-century revolutionary hero Tiradentes, whose body was dismembered and strewn along a 300-mile turnpike.

title: OUTDOORS: MORE ANGLERS DISCOVER THE BLACK BASS
description: ALTHOUGH there are impassioned trout and salmon anglers who regard the black basses with apathy, the smallmouth and largemouth, particularly the former in the Northeast, have long been cherished by many sport fishermen. The ranks of black bass devotees swell each year; various bass-angling contests, sometimes involving considerable cash or merchandise prizes, have been a substantial factor in this.

title: 76ERS DEFEAT LAKERS, 111-94, FOR 3-0 LEAD
description: After their loss in the first game of this championship series, the Los Angeles Lakers blamed fatigue. Then in the wake of their defeat in the second game, they blamed the officiating. Now, there are no excuses.

title: EVEN 'SIMPLE' PROBLEMS REQUIRE A DOCTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox 8, Rangers 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Vance Law, Ron Kittle and Carlton Fisk hit homers for Chicago.

title: FOE RELIES ON FOE IN SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: In the view of Mozambique and other black-ruled African nations in this region, white-ruled South Africa is a focus of evil, a government that preys on its neighbors' frailties.

title: Volcano Erupts in Iceland
description: A volcano erupted today under the thick ice mass of the Vatnajokull glacier in southeast Iceland, raising fears of flooding from the Skeidhara River, which runs south from the glacier.

title: A HIGH SCHOOL TRACK STAR SAYS 'NO' TO RECRUITERS
description: JIM BUSH has been coaching track for 32 years, the last 19 at U.C.L.A. He has had his share of outstanding runners, he said, from the thickly muscled sprinters to wispy milers and long-legged hurdlers, but that hasn't lessened his enthusiasm for a chance to coach still one more. And early last winter, when Bush received a telephone call from a teen-ager named Clinton Davis, he thought the opportunity was presenting itself again.

title: Sara J. Schechner Weds Joel Genuth
description: Sara Jane Schechner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Schechner of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Joel Genuth, son of Dr. and Mrs. Saul M. Genuth of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro, assisted by Cantor Henry Rosenblum, performed the ceremony in the Schechner Chapel at Oheb Shalom Synagogue.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player in a college basketball game throws a pass that strikes a defensive player on the head, then goes through the basket. Is this a field goal for the offensive team? If so, which player gets credit for the 2 points?

title: CULLING A BOUNDLESS KANGAROO POPULATION IS STRICTLY REGULATED
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Air at the Bridge
description: A British acting troupe will be suspended 50 feet in the air for ''Drunken Madness/Invertebrate Living,'' a performance piece, Wednesday and June 8 at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage, Cadman Plaza West at Front Street, Brooklyn.

title: Miss Sheehan Wins With Record 63
description: Patty Sheehan shot a record 9-under par 63 today to win the $150,000 Corning Classic by eight strokes. Miss Sheehan exceeded the previous best of 66 for the Corning Country Club course that was attained by seven women, including herself. Her 72-hole total of 272 also broke the previous best of 280, which she shared with Sandra Spuzich.

title: '83 COLLEGE GRADUATES FACING BLEAKEST JOB MARKET IN 2 DECADES
description: This spring's college graduates are facing one of the bleakest job markets in at least two decades, despite the upturn in the economy, according to college placement officers and Government analysts.

title: JOHN BULL'S OTHER ISLAND: NEW YORK
description: Which Britain "salutes New York"? That is the question raised by the British arts festival that began in April and will continue here and there in all five boroughs until November. For my taste, there have been rather too many dukes and diplomats doing the saluting.

title: GOVERNOR LOSES ROUND IN HALTING OIL WINDFALL CHECKS FOR ALASKANS
description: All of Alaska's 450,000 residents are eligible for another government check this year under a program started in 1982 to give them a share of the state's oil wealth, key legislators say.

title: TAPPING YOUNGSTERS AS SUMMER VOLUNTEERS
description: As summer approaches, New York City's museums, libraries, zoos and botanical gardens are reaching out for the helping hands of vacationing college and high-school students to do everything from delivering books to the homebound to walking domesticated animals at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Dome Mine Chief Quits; Split Cited
description: Malcolm A. Taschereau, a prominent figure in the Canadian gold mining industry, has resigned as president and chief executive officer of the Dome Mines Group following an apparent split over policy with the company's board.

title: Economic Analysis
description: After four years of disappointing crops, starting in 1979, Soviet farm production appears to be heading upward. The grain crop is expected to total 200 million tons this year, with about 60 million tons of winter wheat and 140 million tons of spring wheat. That would mean an increase of 11 percent over 1982 and 25 percent over 1981. But it would still be 18.5 percent below 1978, when Soviet grain output reached 237.4 million tons.

title: Convenient Culprits
description: ONLY a few baseball umpires have truly had an identity. Bill Klem, Tom Connolly, Cal Hubbard, Jocko Conlan, Babe Pinelli, Al Barlick, Tom Gorman and Nestor Chylak come to mind. But even they preferred to blend into the background of a ball game. Umpires want to be invisible. If, after a game, you have to stop and think who the umpires were, they must have done a good job. But even when debates develop, the umpires can do a good job, too. That's what the umpires' most persistent publicist, George Steinbrenner, doesn't seem to understand.

title: Around the Nation; Chicago Mayor Endorses Unionist for Congress
description: Harold Washington has endorsed a black union leader for the Congressional seat he vacated when he became Mayor. Mr. Washington, Chicago's first black Mayor, made the endorsement in a speech to the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists, which represents 67 unions in 27 states. He said he would support the group's vice president, Charles Hayes, 64 years old, who is also the director of Region 12 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union.

title: MARJORIE B. LESTER
description: Marjorie B. Lester, who was appointed by President Eisenhower to the White House Conference on Aging in 1958, died Thursday at the age of 101. Mrs. Lester, a lawyer, was the second woman appointed to the Kentucky bar.

title: Whose Little Chip Goes to Market
description: As smokestack industries decline, they must be replaced by such growth industries as computers, telecommunications and robotics. These high technologies depend for their working parts on the silicon chips produced by the semiconductor industry. But that industry, born and nurtured in the United States, is now locked in a brutal struggle with its Japanese competitors. Should it fare poorly, Japan would take a major step toward leadership in the bedrock technology of the knowledge-intensive industries.

title: Ellen Radish Marries Seth Zarny in Queens
description: At Temple Torah of Little Neck, Queens, yesterday, Ellen Radish, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Radish of Douglaston, Queens, was married to Seth Zarny, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zarny of Farmingdale, L.I. Rabbi Morton L. Gordon performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE POLISH HEART OF FRANCE, CONCERN FOR A CULTURE
description: This town is in France, not Poland. But you might guess otherwise. Consider the mantelpiece in Boleslaw Natakek's neat, modern row house here. It holds a picture of Mr. Natanek with Pope John Paul II; a miniature sewing machine presented to him by Lech Walesa, head of the Solidarity union movement in Poland, and an icon to Our Lady of Czestochowa.

title: News Analysis
description: Four years ago when the leaders of the seven advanced industrial nations gathered in Tokyo, the power of the oil producing countries of the Persian Gulf and North Africa was so much on their minds that it seemed as if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was an uninvited guest at their dinner table.

title: RAILWAY STRIKE SAID TO HAMPER COOLING OF CARS
description: The strike against the Metro-North commuter rail lines earlier this year has set back hopes for air-conditioning improvements on the railroad's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven lines this summer, according to the president of the railroad.

title: STUDENT PRAYER CLUB MEETS AT PENNSYLVANIA SCHOOL
description: With a quiet sense of satisfaction, a modest cluster of students met at their high school here Thursday for a prayer session.

title: RECITAL: MEXICAN VIOLIN MUSIC
description: It was billed as a centennial tribute to Manuel M. Ponce, but Saturday evening's program at Carnegie Recital Hall by the violinist Thruston Johnson and the pianist John Forconi offered a broad sweep of 20th-century Mexican music.

title: MELVIN E. KARNS
description: Melvin E. Karns, a former vice president in charge of patents and licensing for the RCA Corporation, died last Thursday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Mets Finally Win
description: The Mets finally escaped from their four-game losing streak today, and even eased their four-year slump in San Diego, when Ed Lynch and Jesse Orosco pitched them to a 3-2 victory over the Padres.

title: U.S. CHALLENGED ON ASSURANCE THAT ITS RECOVERY AIDS WORLD
description: Leaders at the economic summit meeting challenged today President Reagan's assurances that economic recovery in the United States was enough to bring prosperity to the rest of the world.

title: Lisa Stone, a Health Aide, Is Married to Scott Cantor
description: At the Orange (Conn.) Synagogue Center yesterday, Lisa Ellen Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Stone of Cincinnati, was married to Scott Brian Cantor, son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Cantor of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Roy Walter of Congregation Emanu El in Houston performed the ceremony.

title: Performing-Arts School Offering Four Programs
description: Dance students at the High School of the Performing Arts will present four graduation performances Thursday through Saturday in Norman Thomas Auditorium, 111 East 33d Street.

title: Braves 6, Cubs 2
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Rick Camp combined with Terry Forster on an eighthitter, and Bob Horner doubled home two runs in a four-run first inning.

title: REAGAN CIVIL RIGHTS POLICIES ARE DEFENDED AND CRITICIZED
description: President Reagan's top civil rights enforcement officer said today that racism was at the root of affirmative action programs, but a black leader charged that the Administration ''acts as if the white male is the minority.''

title: 5,000 BICYCLISTS BEGIN CENTRAL PARK MARATHON
description: Undaunted by a steady rain, the defending champion John Howard led 5,000 cyclists from the tristate area through the starting line in Central Park to open the 12th annual Pepsi Challenge 24-Hour Bicycle Marathon today.

title: Books of the Times
description: OFF BALANCE: The Real World of Ballet. By Suzanne Gordon. 216 pages. Pantheon. $15.95.

title: Sports World Specials; Missed Opportunity
description: In his rookie season in the big leagues, Doug Sisk already leads the Mets in phone calls - the kind the manager makes to the bullpen, telling his relievers to warm up. But, while Sisk appreciates the confidence of George Bamberger, he doubts that he will ever get a phone call like the one in 1976, inviting him to try out for the Olympics in another specialty: shooting a .22-caliber rifle.

title: SEPARATISTS BLAMED
description: A series of bombs exploded in public buildings in the French Caribbean territories of Guadeloupe, French Guiana and Martinique Saturday night and early today, killing one person and causing extensive property damage.

title: BASF'S ROLE IN COMPUTERS
description: In the 1920's German chemists experimented with magnetic iron powders to improve the compressibility of synthetic gasoline. At the same time they produced the first polyvinyl chloride films. Later these advances yielded the first magnetic recording tapes.

title: Drunk, Driving and Male
description: ''Get drunken drivers off the roads and get them off now,'' said the President of the United States. ''People who drive while drunk should go to jail,'' echoed the Mayor of New York. ''You have to assume that late at night every set of headlights coming at you is being aimed by someone stone drunk,'' reported an Indiana state trooper.

title: 2 GUILTY IN DEATHS OF 2 U.S MARSHALS
description: The son of Gordon Kahl, a fugitive tax protester, and another man were found guilty Saturday on two counts of second-degree murder in connection with the deaths of two Federal marshals.

title: Tass Assails American Intent
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused the the United States today of using the Williamsburg economic summit meeting to seek support from its allies for its ''aggressive'' foreign policy.

title: Going Out Guide
description: GARDENS

title: ARTHUR R. KENNEDY
description: Arthur R. Kennedy, a former vice president of Sea-Land Services Inc., the shipping concern, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 84 years old.

title: Required Reading; 'For Good Behavior'
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, in the Congressional Record, May 11, 1983: Someone asked me the other day, ''Are you sorry you have announced that you're not going to run for re-election?'' I said, ''No. Not only am I not sorry, but I'm now actively engaged in negotiations to try to gain time off for good behavior.'' 'Thank You'

title: The City; 15 More Drivers Seized as Drunken
description: Fifteen people were arrested and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol Saturday night and early yesterday in the citywide crackdown on drunken drivers, the police said.

title: Track Title Goes To Maria Regina
description: Maria Regina, led by Youree Spence's two victories, captured the team title yesterday in the annual Metropolitan Catholic High Schools girls' outdoor track and field championships at St. John's University. The school from Uniondale, L.I., scored 65 points. St. Francis Prep, the defending champion, was second with 55.

title: Carew Up to .453; Jackson Hits Homer
description: Reggie Jackson, who came to the plate hitting .174, belted a two-run homer with one out in the ninth inning to give the California Angels their seventh consecutive victory, 6-4, over the Indians.

title: The City; Police in Brooklyn Kill Attack Suspect
description: A police officer fatally shot a man yesterday who attacked a brother and sister from Massachusetts as they stood in a Brooklyn telephone booth calling home to say they had arrived safely in New York, the police said.

title: Around the World; 90 Are Reported Hurt In Kashmir Brawling
description: At least 90 people were injured today in political clashes in the north Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, which holds local elections on June 5, the Press Trust of India, a news agency, reported.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Air, Reconstituted Trio, Plays at Lush Life
description: The wide-open encyclopedic music of Air and of the Art Ensemble of Chicago helped revitalize jazz in the 1970's. Over this weekend at Lush Life, the two groups overlapped, as Air replaced its drummer for the last decade, Steve McCall, with Don Moye of the Art Ensemble.

title: News Analysis
description: Although Democrats far outnumber Republicans on the House Foreign Affairs committee and could easily prevail on most issues, including aid to Central America, they have spent a considerable amount of time searching for bipartisan compromises.

title: Topics; Test Questions
description: Slam Dunk Scores

title: Walker Sets Mark in Victory
description: Herschel Walker rushed for 194 yards, a United States Football League record for a game, but the New Jersey Generals needed a 50-yard field goal on the last play today to beat the Washington Federals, 32-29.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS' MARKET
description: With the good and bad news now out from college admissions offices, high school and college counselors are looking back at the patterns of this past admissions year. They are talking mostly about money. They are talking about the cost of a college education and the importance in the admissions process of a family's ability to pay. They are concerned.

title: TV: 'PEANUTS' IN FRANCE AND ENVIRONMENT DRAMA
description: The animated versions of the ''Peanuts'' comic strip take a different turn this evening, on Channel 2 at 8, with a new installment titled ''What Have We Learned, Charlie Brown?'' Introduced by Charles M. Schulz, creator of the ''Peanuts'' gang, this show is keyed to Memorial Day. Charlie Brown, pasting photos in an album, reminisces about an exchange-student trip to France that included a detour to the beaches of Normandy and the monuments of Flanders Field. Mr. Schulz announces that it is ''a show of which I am especially proud.''

title: MondaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. Giants at San Francisco, 3:05 P.M. The Mets make their second stop on a 14-day road trip (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 3 P.M.). Yankees vs. A's at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Oakland wraps up its four-game visit. (Television -Sports@Channel, 2 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.).

title: Music Noted in Brief; Jay Hoggard Leads Quintet in Village
description: When the vibraphonist Jay Hoggard isn't playing African-inspired rhythm pieces or working on a complex fusion of modern jazz and classical music, he finds time to make overtly commercial pop-jazz records. He has just released one, ''Love Survives,'' so for the occasion he brought a pop-jazz quintet to Seventh Avenue South.

title: MRS. LLOYD, CONNORS, LENDL IN ROUND OF 8
description: There is a hint of irritation in Chris Evert Lloyd's voice as she describes the people who have approached her in the last 24 hours to say that this is now her tournament, that she is suddenly favored to win her fifth French Open tennis title because of Martina Navratilova's elimination on Saturday.

title: A Fifth Suspect Is Arrested In Killing of Boy in Brooklyn
description: A fifth suspect was arrested yesterday and charged in the shooting death of an 8-year-old boy waiting to go home from a birthday party, the police said.

title: 4,400 AT CORNELL EXHORTED TO CONTINUE FRIENDSHIPS
description: More than 4,400 students at Cornell University received degrees during the 115th commencement here today, and Cornell's president, Dr. Frank H.T. Rhodes, urged the graduates to ''cherish and nurture'' the friendships they had made.

title: Leslie Gruss, a Physician, Is Bride of Michael Rosen
description: Dr. Leslie Gruss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Gruss of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Rosen of Rutland, Vt. Rabbis Sol Goldberg and Nancy Fuchs-Kreimer officiated at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt.

title: SELLING TO JAPANESE INDUSTRY
description: Certain types of foreign products fare much better in Japan than others. Those most likely to win out are well-known brands that give a consumer the cachet of membership in the international community.

title: OPEN WINDOWS WILL BE OPTION FOR COMMUTERS
description: After nearly two years of negotiations, commuters on the Metro-North rail lines are about to get what many had said they wanted: trains with windows that can be opened.

title: THE CHICAGO SUN-TIMES WAITS FOR A NEW OWNER
description: Sometime before next April 13, Marshall Field 5th and his half brother, Frederick W. Field, will find out the worth of the newspaper they own, The Chicago Sun-Times.

title: LEWIS PROMOTES HIMSELF AS WELL AS THE FIGHTERS
description: THE fight promoter Ronald (Butch) Lewis is in his office on West 57th Street, surrounded by boxing mementoes and framed photos. In a gray suit, with a white-collared pink shirt and matching striped tie and pocket hanky, the former used-car salesman chainsmokes cigarettes while he takes phone calls and handles a variety of business matters.

title: Polish Court Decrees Death For Radio Free Europe Aide
description: A Polish military court issued a death sentence in absentia Saturday for Zdzislaw Najder, the director of the Polish section of Radio Free Europe.

title: Hundreds March in Wyoming Against Stationing of the MX
description: Hundreds of demonstrators, led by a Presidential candidate and a retired admiral, gathered today to protest the proposed deployment of 100 nuclear-tipped MX missiles underground in Wyoming and Nebraska.

title: Phillies 5, Expos 2
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Bo Diaz hit a two-run homer, and Mike Schmidt got a home run with the bases empty.

title: 7 SUMMIT LEADERS PRESS THE RUSSIANS ON NUCLEAR TALKS
description: The leaders of the seven nations at the economic summit meeting called on the Soviet Union tonight to negotiate constructively on reducing nuclear weapons and warned that any attempt to divide the West would fail.

title: TWO ULSTER PARTIES VIE FOR THE CATHOLICS' VOTE
description: The two contending parties that favor Ulster's merger with the rest of Ireland are providing Northern Ireland with its main interest in the British general election campaign.

title: INSURANCE DEPT. REVIEWING ITS AWARDING OF LEGAL FEES
description: The new Superintendent of the State Insurance Department, James P. Corcoran, is reviewing the department's practice of awarding millions of dollars in legal fees to law firms. Some of the firms that received the fees have powerful members of the New York State Senate and Assembly as partners.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Speculation on Les and Bess

title: SEASON OF BUSY LIVING OPENS AT SHORE RESORTS
description: When Byron Chalfant Jr. was a child growing up in the summer resort of Beach Haven, N.J., Memorial Day weekend would always take him by surprise, but it never went unnoticed.

title: Concerts at New Whitney
description: A series of free concerts begins June 15 at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue at 42d Street. Starting at 5:30 P.M., the S.E.M. Ensemble will present a program of American music by such composers as Philip Glass, John Gibson, John Cage and Phill Niblock. Future concerts at the new museum will feature the New York Grand Opera Singers (June 23 at 12:30 P.M.); Hanne Tierney (June 28 and 30 at 6 P.M.) and Bill and Mary Buchen (July 7 at 12:30 P.M.).

title: Washington Watch; A Democratic Economic Rift
description: WASHINGTON ASTATEMENT on economic policy signed last week by 148 House Democrats highlights a schism within the party between traditional, government-minded liberals and a newer breed that looks more to entrepreneurship.

title: New York Day by Day
description: The Call of the Wild

title: Sports World Specials; Whirlwind Tour
description: Team America, which has been doing fairly well in its first season in the North American Soccer League, may have hit on an unusual formula for success - playing a backbreaking schedule with a minimum of rest and a maximum of jet lag.

title: Breakers Top Stars
description: Frank Lockett grabbed Johnnie Walton's 14-yard touchdown pass after it was tipped by his teammate, Charlie Smith, on the last play to cap a second-half comeback and lift the Boston Breakers to a 21-17 victory over the Philadelphia Stars.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Almi Group has appointed William Paul Nolan executive vice president-legal.

title: Blue Jays 6, Red Sox 1
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Lloyd Moseby hit two homers and drove in three runs to back Jim Gott's three-hitter. The game, which had been scheduled as the opener of a doubleheader, was called by rain in the seventh inning.

title: Foreign Affairs; WHAT USE IS A SUMMIT?
description: With all the hoopla, people have been asking whether there's any point to these seven-nation summits. There are easier ways to run a circus.

title: Ballesteros Leads
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain shot a 3-under-par 67 today for a 207 and a one-stroke lead after three rounds over Brian Waites of Britain in the $144,000 Sun Alliance British Professional Golfers Association championship.

title: PEPSICO, AN EMBATTLED GIANT
description: By all appearances, Pepsico Inc. is a company on the defensive. After years of earnings growth, profits at the nation's secondlargest soft drink bottler - after the Coca-Cola Company - fell 25 percent in 1982 and 42 percent in the first quarter of 1983. Fraud uncovered in its international bottling division in 1982 cost Pepsico millions of dollars and substantial embarrassment. Earlier this month, the company lost two top executives, each of whom was considered among the best in his field.

title: GRIM ALTERNATIVE TO ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LIE DETECTORS: QUESTIONS ANEW ON THEIR ACCURACY
description: The lie detector appears destined for wider use in Washington at a time when its ability to distinguish truth from falsity remains a matter of sharp dispute among scientists and Government officials.

title: PANEL OF EXPERTS DISPUTES GLOOMY OUTLOOK FOR 2000
description: The world is getting better and better, not worse, a panel of experts assembled by the conservative Heritage Foundation contended at a scientific conference here today.

title: Around the World; Uruguayans Break Off Talks on Elections
description: Uruguay's military rulers have broken off talks with civilian politicians and hinted that elections planned for next year might be delayed.

title: EXECUTIVE ETIQUETTE BY LETITIA BALDRIGE
description: You arrive early at a restaurant for a business lunch to which you've been invited by a fellow executive. Do you take a table? If you take a table, should you order a drink? And if your host never arrives, what do you do?

title: Office of Chairman Created at Upjohn
description: The Upjohn Company, a major pharmaceuticals and health-care concern based in Kalamazoo, Mich., has announced a reorganization of top management to prepare for the coming retirement of two executives.

title: ENTERPRISES RUN BY WOMEN WIDEN CUSTOMER BASE
description: When the Feminist Press was created in 1970, its main goal was to provide educational material for teachers and students of feminist studies. Now it is broadening its consumer base by publishing general interest books, such as fiction by female authors, in addition to classroom texts.

title: Bridge: Berkowitz and Sartorius Retain Regional Pair Title
description: Successful defense of a regional pair title is rare in New York, but it happened Friday at the Sheraton Centre Hotel on the first day of the Eastern Championships. David Berkowitz of Secaucus, N.J., and Bob Sartorius of Cedar Grove, N.J., repeated their 1982 victory and stretched to four a string of victories that includes the regional open pairs and the North Jersey knockout team title.

title: Invaders 20, Express 10
description: Raymond Chester fumbled on the 2-yard line after a 36-yard pass reception in the third quarter, but recovered the ball in the end zone for a touchdown to spark the victory. Despite 6-7 records, the teams were tied for first in the Pacific Division.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Microtonal Festival Gives Church Concert
description: The American Festival of Microtonal Music, under the direction of Johnny Reinhard, gave its ninth concert at Christ and St. Stephen's Church last Thursday night, presenting a stimulating, if uneven, survey of esoteric tunings.

title: EX-DODGERS JOIN IN GOING HOME AGAIN
description: Howard Golden, the Borough President of Brooklyn, stood yesterday in an elegantly restored room of Borough Hall and for a moment reflected on what history had done.

title: Around the Nation; N.A.A.C.P. Chairman Won't Discuss Quitting
description: The chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that she would not even discuss a request that she resign until after a special meeting of the association's board in June.

title: FACING THE EMOTIONAL ANGUISH OF AIDS
description: The tragic medical consequences of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, known as AIDS, have been measured in the 558 known deaths caused by the disease. But for the living victims, AIDS has profound psychological consequences that are only beginning to be understood.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Screenings and Art

title: WORDS OF EXPERIENCE SEND THE CLASS OF '83 ON A MISSION OF CHANGE
description: This is the time of commencement exercises at colleges and universities around the country. Following are some commencement addresses.
