title: C.I.A. IS NEARER PACT ON RELEASE OF CERTAIN FILES
description: Lawyers for the Central Intelligence Agency and the American Civil Liberties Union say they may be close to agreement on a formula for amending the Freedom of Information Act to exempt numerous files relating to the agency's clandestine operations.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 30, 1983
description: International The Soviet Union was urged to negotiate constructively on reducing nuclear weapons by the leaders of the seven industrialized democracies at their meeting in Williamsburg, Va. But they warned that any attempt to divide the West would fail. The statement, backed by all the seven nations, followed daylong discussions on its wording, taking up unexpected portions of the leaders' agenda. It left an impression of divisions at a conference intended to express economic solidarity and converging views. (Page 1, Column 6.) Control of six Syrian supply depots near Damascus was seized by rebel Palestinians Saturday as a mutiny spread within Yasir Arafat's Al Fatah organization. The opposing sides in the dispute gave differing accounts of the takeover of the six gasoline, food and truck centers. The pro-Arafat Palestinian press agency said ''alien armed elements'' had seized the depots, but a rebel spokesman said that their commanders had simply taken them over. (1:2.)

title: IN DEFENSE OF JAPAN'S POLICIES
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's visit to the United States offers an occasion to re-examine the distressing American misperception that Japan's market is closed to American exports. The fact is that in every formal and measurable respect. the Japanese market is as open and as accessible as that of any other advanced industrial economy, including the United States. But until this misperception is dispelled, dispassionate and reasonable discussion of our economic relations will continue to be difficult.

title: JACKSON SADLY SIZES UP FLOOD DAMAGE
description: When Todd Pyles finally reached his house by boat Friday, he found four pet peacocks sitting on the roof and a foot and a half of muddy river water lapping the walls of the rooms inside.

title: Spanish Premier Attacks U.S.  On Its Central America Policy
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain sharply criticized United States policy in Central America in an interview published today, on the eve of his first official visit to the region.

title: Martha Starkweather Wed to Roger W. Altreuter
description: Martha Merry Starkweather, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Oliver Starkweather of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married in the First Congregational Church there yesterday to Roger White Altreuter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal Kenneth Altreuter of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herman F. Reissig performed the ceremony.

title: Business People; Cruise-Vessel Operator Recruits New President
description: Arie van Tol, a 61-year-old Dutchman who spent 25 years at the Holland-America Line in various executive capacities, has been named president and chief executive officer of Scandinavian World Cruises, a major cruise-ship operator.

title: Irwin Wins Memorial by 1 on Chip Shot
description: The eighth annual Memorial Tournament was decided today at the par-3 16th hole, where Hale Irwin sank a 25-foot birdie chip from the fringe and David Graham, the leader for 15 of the final 18 holes, took a double-bogey 5.

title: STATEN ISLAND MILER AIMING AT THE TOP
description: To Charles Marsala's way of thinking, only one obstacle stands between him and the top spot among New York State's prep milers. But that one obstacle is no minor one: Marsala, an 18-year-old senior from New Dorp High School on Staten Island and already one of the state's leading runners, knows that only a victory over Mike Stahr of Carmel (N.Y.) High School, who is also the nation's No.1 prep miler, can assure him the No.1 rating in the state.

title: Sports World Specials; Sunken Dream
description: Jack O'Donnell says he knew his idea of starting a free agent football camp for college seniors overlooked by the pros was in trouble when he ran an ad for his enterprise in a Boston newspaper at about the same time the paper ran an article saying such camps were ''a new rip-off sweeping the country.''

title: REAGAN SAID TO FEEL LATIN POLICY WAS MANAGED POORLY BY ENDERS
description: President Reagan removed Thomas O. Enders as the chief State Department officer on Latin American affairs because of frustration that Administration policies were being poorly managed and badly promoted in Congress, Administration officials said today.

title: Index; International
description: In the Polish heart of France, concern for a culture 2 Pope John Paul II announces pil- grimage to Lourdes 2 Bombs explode in Paris and three French Caribbean territories 2 Around the World 4 Mozambique maintains uneasy ties with South Africa 4 Government/Politics Democrats fear Reagan could turn tax bills against them 7 Washington Talk Polygraph use rising despite doubts as to accuracy 5 Required Reading 5 Briefing 5 Health/Science Scientific panel challenges gloomy predictions for 2000 7 MEMORIAL DAY Parade - Begins 9:30 A.M. at 72d Street and West End Avenue, moves east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to the Soldiers' and Sailor's Monument at 89th Street for a wreath-laying ceremony. Parking - Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: ROCK: HARDY KINKS RETURN
description: The fact that rock music is rooted in a tradition of perpetual rebellion insures that only the hardiest can survive changes in fashion to become institutions. But the Kinks, led by the brilliantly eccentric songwriter, singer and rhythm guitarist Ray Davies, have become just that. They are beloved by a generation that wasn't even born when the group helped lead the British invasion in the mid-1960's. At the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Friday, the quintet ranged through nearly 20 years of material, almost all of which the audience knew by heart. The only period not covered was the mid-1970's, when the group recorded several ambitious rock operettas.

title: Roberts Is Winner Driving a Honda
description: Kenny Roberts of the United States, riding a Honda, won the 500cc race today in the sixth leg of the motorcycle street world championships.

title: L.I. CRAFT ARE BLESSED FOR NEW SEASON
description: The fleet and the waters here should be safe for another year. The Rev. John Drab and Rabbi David Greenberg gave them their blessing.

title: DANCE: DIVERSIFYING AT BALLET THEATER
description: American Ballet Theater is renewing its reputation as a living museum of dance this season with a wide-ranging collection of ballets of every genre. On Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, for instance, the company presented a delectable romp by Sir Frederick Ashton, a glittering George Balanchine work and pas de deux by two newer and very different choreographers, Peter Anastos and Jiri Kylian.

title: Beth Morris Is Wed in Roslyn Heights
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I., yesterday Rhoda Beth Morris and Marc Jeffrey Eichenholtz, graduates of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, were married by Rabbi Loel Weiss, assisted by Cantor Lee Schwartz.

title: MUSIC: THE BOEHM QUINTETTE
description: The four 20th-century compositions played by the Boehm Quintette at the Guggenheim Museum yesterday afternoon were written over a period of 40 years, but they shared a common perspective. From Ingolf Dahl's ''Allegro and Arioso'' (1942) to the premiere of Tobias Picker's Serenade for Piano and Wind Quintet, these works grew out of an American musical tradition from the 1930's - a tradition that invoked American popular song and jazz and evoked the eclecticism and energy of urban life.

title: MOZAMBICAN CABINET IS SHUFFLED
description: President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique has taken over the leadership of the Defense Ministry in a Cabinet shuffle, according to an official communique.

title: TEST OF TIME
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESBYTERIANS HAIL MESSAGE OF CATHOLIC BISHOPS ON WAR
description: A Roman Catholic message against nuclear arms was preached from a Presbyterian pulpit yesterday in Brooklyn. The pastor called the message ''a warm and loving document to shake us all up.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They loved the gumbo.'' - Michael K. Deaver on Williamsburg summit dining. (1:6.)

title: 7 UNIONS ON L.I.R.R. IN ACCORD
description: Seven more unions have reached tentative settlements with the Long Island Rail Road, the mediator in the dispute announced yesterday. The move reduced the possibility of a strike against the railroad this summer.

title: POPE PLANS A VISIT TO LOURDES
description: Pope John Paul II announced today that he planned to make a pilgrimage to the shrine of Lourdes on Aug. 15. John Paul had planned to visit the shrine of Our Lady of Lourdes, at the foot of the Pyrenees in southwestern France, in July 1981, but the trip was canceled after the Pope was seriously wounded in an assassination attempt in St. Peter's square in May of that year.

title: Yankees Set Back A's, 5-0
description: Rain fell throughout the Yankees' 5-0 victory over Oakland yesterday, but to three Yankees with no guarantee of regular work, the sun was shining all day.

title: SUMMIT TEXT ON ARMS POLICY
description: Following is the text of a statement read by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today on behalf of the seven industrial nations meeting here:

title: Drugs Seized by Pakistan
description: Pakistani customs agents have seized about four tons of hashish and opium waiting to be smuggled into Europe, officials said today.

title: Cardinals 7, Astros 3
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Jamie Quirk drove in four runs with a three-run homer and a single.

title: Roberta Goodman Is Wed
description: Roberta S. Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton Goodman of Brooklyn, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Peter Samberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Samberg of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Melvin Burg performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue. The bride is an associate with the New York law firm of Gordon & Silber. Mr. Samberg is an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn.

title: Debra Wassman Married in Larchmont
description: Debra Irene Wassman and Jonathan Trumbull Lanman Jr., who are architects in New York, were married yesterday at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Martin performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Robert Wassman of Larchmont. Mr. Lanman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lanman of Bethesda, Md.

title: Dr. Gilbert Voyat Dies at 43; A Professor at City College
description: Dr. Gilbert E. Voyat, professor of psychology at City College and director of a research project with autistic children, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 43 years old.

title: Sandinists Curb Currency
description: The Sandinist Government put new restrictions on the outflow and inflow of local and foreign currency today to counter increased United States ''political, military and economic aggression against Nicaragua,'' a Government statement announced. The restrictions, which do not apply to foreign tourists in Nicaragua, will ban the carrying of more than $500 in cash, traveler's checks or money orders.

title: Porsche Team First
description: The team of Jochen Mass of West Germany and Jacky Ickx of Belgium won the 1,000-kilometer world endurance auto championship today.

title: CULLING A BOUNDLESS KANGAROO POPULATION IS STRICTLY REGULATED
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO SETS OF ARMS TALKS THAT CAN BECOME ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: THE FIXX PLAYS AT THE RITZ
description: Stylish rock videos have helped the Fixx, the English group that appeared at the Ritz on Friday and Saturday, to establish a foothold in this country. And in their weekend appearances, the group performed with a coordination that was well matched to a fashionconscious visual image in which Cy Curin, the Fixx's lead singer and chief focus, struck poses that were projected in shadows on a rear screen.

title: HEROIC FRENCH VILLAGE SALUTED FOR AID TO JEWS
description: The French village of Le Chambon-sur-Lignon, where residents helped thousands of Jews escape from Nazi persecution during World War II, was honored yesterday at commencement exercises of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.

title: Drug Treatment for Howe
description: Steve Howe, the star relief pitcher of the Los Angeles Dodgers who was thought to have overcome a drug and alcohol problem over the winter, has been readmitted to a drug rehabilitation center at his request, the club said today.

title: Giants Defeat Dodgers
description: Max Venable lined a two-out, bases-loaded single in the ninth inning today to break a 4-4 tie and send the San Francisco Giants to a 6-4 victory over Los Angeles.

title: Business Digest; MONDAY, MAY 30, 1983; The Williamsburg Summit
description: President Reagan was challenged by leaders of other industrial nations on his assurances that economic recovery in the United States was enough to bring prosperity to the rest of the world. They insisted that their economies would remain in the doldrums unless American interest rates and budget deficits were cut. (Page 38.)

title: Essay; AND NOW ECOBOWL IX
description: The shine on the black shoes of the honor guard receiving the leaders of the industrial world was unbelievable. How could leather, asked a former Pfc., take such a high gloss?

title: Royals 4, Orioles 0
description: Pat Sheridan, a rookie, hit his second home run of the season in support of the seven-hit pitching of Paul Splittorf and Dan Quisenberry. Sheridan hit a 2-0 pitch from the losing pitcher, Dennis Martinez (3-9), into the water display behind the right-field fence in the first inning.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Insights of Einstein

title: Youths With Gasoline Bombs Battle With the Ulster Police
description: Gangs of youths throwing gasoline bombs clashed with the police in running battles on the streets of Londonderry early today, the police said.

title: Council Chief Sworn In As Corning's Successor
description: Thomas M. Whalen 3d, president of the city's Common Council, was sworn in today as the successor to Mayor Erastus Corning 2d.

title: Books: True Crime
description: MURDER STORY. By Lester Velie. 289 pages. Macmillan. $15.95.

title: Maine and Temple Gain in N.C.A.A.
description: Brad Colton and Bill Reynolds each had three hits and two runs batted in as Maine beat Harvard today, 6-2, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast regional baseball playoffs.

title: Around the Nation; Man Beaten to Death At Second US Festival
description: A man was beaten to death and 44 people were seriously injured today at a festival of rock music and technology that drew 300,000 people in its second day.

title: Death on Duty
description: Though the United States is not at war this Memorial Day, 20 countries are, and Americans are serving in official capacities in most of them. Casualties are part of the job. Last week, Lieut. Comdr. Albert Schaufelberger was assassinated in El Salvador. Last month, a bomb blast at the American Embassy in Beirut took the lives of 16 Foreign Service officers and Marine guards.

title: Around the World; Russian Says U.S. Tries To Torpedo Afghan Talks
description: The Soviet Ambassador in Pakistan has accused the United States of trying to torpedo the United Nations-sponsored peace talks on Afghanistan, which resume in Geneva next month.

title: Pirates 8, Reds 5
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Bill Madlock singled to tie the game and scored the winning run on Richie Hebner's bunt single in the seventh inning.

title: STEVENS BLAZING A TRAIL IN PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: For the last nine months 80 freshmen at the Stevens Institute of Technology here have been pioneers, the first college students in the country to be required to buy @microcomputers and to use them in their course work.

title: GEMOYEL, AT MOSLEM RALLY, APPEALS FOR LEBANESE UNITY
description: President Amin Gemayel, a Christian, made an unusual visit to a mainly Moslem rally in West Beirut today to plead for Lebanese unity and defend his recent troop withdrawal agreement with Israel.

title: Mariners 6, Brewers 4
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Ricky Nelson's tie-breaking homer triggered a five-run sixth inning as Seattle won its fourth straight. Matt Young (6-3) scattered six hits through seven and two-thirds innings as he won his fourth straight.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: All United States stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. All banks and government offices are also closed, as are many businesses. The Treasury's weekly bill auction is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: 6 SUPPLY CENTERS IN DAMASCUS TAKEN BY REBELS IN P.L.O.
description: Five rebel junior officers in Al Fatah have reportedly seized control of six supply depots near Damascus from officers loyal to Yasir Arafat.

title: Suspension Lifted For Reds' Cedeno
description: The Cincinnati Reds said today that the three-day suspension without pay imposed on the outfielder Cesar Cedeno last week had been eliminated.

title: Neal L. Wolkoff Is Married to Janet Lynn Armuth
description: The marriage of Janet Lynn Armuth, an associate with the New York law firm of Dolgenos Bergen & Newman, to Neal Lawrence Wolkoff, a lawyer for the New York Mercantile Exchange, took place in Millburn, N.J., yesterday. Rabbi Victor Mirelman, assisted by Cantor Joshua O. Steele, performed the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Israel.

title: Julie K. Merson Married to Dr. Jay Pivor, a Dentist
description: Julie Karen Merson, daughter of Gail E. Merson of Ridgewood, N.J., and Ronald A. Merson of New City, N.Y., was married in Rochester yesterday to Dr. Jay Pivor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Pivor of East Meadow, L.I. Rabbi Shami Kantor performed the ceremony in the chapel at Temple Beth El.

title: DAVIS IS HAPPIEST AT MIDFIELD
description: Ricky Davis draws raves from everyone around the Cosmos these days. But Coach Julio Mazzei is more qualified than anyone to talk about Davis, because he has watched his development since Davis joined the Cosmos in 1977 as a 19-year-old.

title: Remembering The Dodgers
description: BARBARA LABINE went home last week, back home to Brooklyn. She had never been there before, but as soon as she felt Brooklyn Dodger fans of all ages reaching out to her and her husband, Clem, she knew she was home.

title: A Bad Weekend For Lysander
description: It has not been a good weekend for Rick Lysander. The Twins reliever, who lost both ends of a doubleheader Friday night, lost again today when he surrendered an eighth inning home run to the Tigers' Kirk Gibson.

title: Sports World Specials; Ultimate Challenge
description: When Verlen Kruger, a 60-year-old retired plumber from East Lansing, Mich., and his son-in-law, Steve Landick, were planning their ''Ultimate Canoe Challenge,'' a 28,000-mile, three-and-a-halfyear paddle-and-portage trip through the waterways of North America, they didn't realize just how ultimate the challenge was going to be.

title: SNEVA TAKES INDIANAPOLIS 500, WITH AL UNSER SR. 2D
description: As if there were not enough obstacles for Tom Sneva to pass on the way to his first Indianapolis 500 championship in his 10th attempt, there was one last surprise in his path with first place at stake and fewer than 25 laps to go this afternoon.

title: Fairleigh's Aden Wins And Loses
description: Jama Aden of Fairleigh Dickinson was far from happy as he left Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday afternoon, even though he had turned in gold- and silver-medal performances in the open division of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress track and field championships.

title: Block Island Race Won by Nirvana
description: Marvin Green's 81-foot maxi sloop Nirvana was first to finish as she set a course record in The Storm Trysail Club's 38th annual Block Island Race that started off Larchmont Friday.

title: DEMOCRATS SAY 'JAMMING' BY G.O.P. HURT TELETHON
description: The national chairman of the Democratic Party said today that pledges from the party's 17-hour telethon were in ''the $20 million range,'' but he charged that Republicans had badly hurt the money-raising effort with ''jamming'' phone calls.

title: Dailey Treated For Drug Abuse
description: Quintin Dailey, the guard for the Chicago Bulls who has been undergoing therapy for emotional problems at a Baltimore hospital, is also being treated there for drug abuse, according to a report today in The Chicago Sun-Times.

title: Iran Reported to Be Seeking Closer Relations With West
description: Iran has recently been making diplomatic moves seeking closer ties with the West, West German Government sources said today.

title: Briefing
description: Civil Rights Complaint

title: REAGAN MAY FIGHT ANY NEW TAX BILL
description: Although the Reagan Administration officially still supports enactment this year of taxes to take effect in 1985, some Administration officials say privately that President Reagan really wants no tax bill at all.

title: Bonnett Winner In 600
description: Neil Bonnett captured his second consecutive Nascar World 600 auto race today. Driving a Chevrolet, he took the $488,010 event after two leaders had been involved in an accident late in the race at the Charlotte Motor Speedway.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A SERMON TO LEADERS
description: The Bible provides the first of the required scripts to make sense of this weekend's economic summit conference as something more than a nostalgic trip by democracy down Colonial lanes.

title: OPERA: SPOLETO REVIVES 'CLEOPATRA' BY BARBER
description: For 17 years, Samuel Barber's ''Antony and Cleopatra'' has been trying to crawl from beneath the elephantine weight of its original production. It was the grand new American opera chosen to open America's grand new Metropolitan Opera House in 1966, and the near fiasco that attended those first performances has colored Barber's reputation as an operatic composer ever since.

title: Relationships; FRIENDSHIP BY LETTER: A LASTING TIE
description: THEY are a dwindling band, an anachronism, those people who nurture f riends through the mail with regular, descriptive, contemplative l etters. But they say they are rewarded by relationships imbued with s pecial qualities when, avoiding the easy communication of the t elephone, they put their thoughts on paper.

title: South African Is Said to Seek Asylum From Mozambicans
description: An officer of the South African military has asked for political asylum in Mozambique, the official Mozambique press agency reported today.

title: P & O'S BATTLE OF TRAFALGAR
description: When Trafalgar House announced its long-expected bid to take over the Peninsular & Oriental Steamship Navigation Company last week, wags in London's financial community could not resist calling it ''another Battle of Trafalgar.''

title: TOOL ORDER DROP CITED FOR APRIL
description: The machine tool industry remained in a deep recession in April, beset by low orders, continuing pressure from imports and a falling backlog of orders, even though some of its major customers, such as the auto industry, are showing signs of recovery.

title: A MOTHER'S CHOICES IN NURSING A BABY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 World Records Reported by Tass
description: Yuri Dumchev, in the discus throw, and Lyudmila Baranova, in the 10,000-meter run, set world records today, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Pamela Chassin and J.B. Zelman, Physicians, Wed
description: Dr. Pamela Sue Chassin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jameson L. Chassin of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jared Bruce Zelman, son of Mrs. Julius Zelman of Laguna Hills, Calif., and the late Dr. Zelman. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Chassin home in Westhampton Beach.

title: Business People; Levitz Furniture Chief Adds Chairman's Title
description: Robert M. Elliott, named chairman of the Levitz Furniture Corporation last Tuesday, took the helm of a much different company than the one he joined as president and chief executive officer nine years ago.

title: SLEW O' GOLD WINS IN PETER PAN BY 12
description: Anyone who saw the Peter Pan Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park probably has a strong opinion on who is the horse to beat in the Belmont Stakes June 11. Slew o' Gold, who showed flashes of championship form all spring, finally put it all together with a 12-length victory in the Peter Pan.

title: Lightning Damages Plane
description: Lightning made a hole in the nose of an United Airlines 727 airliner carrying 77 passengers shortly after the plane took off here today, but it landed safely minutes later, officials said.

title: SSC&B U.S.A. Gets New Chief Executive
description: Kenneth L. Robbins, 47-year-old vice chairman and chief operating officer of SSC&B U.S.A., a unit of SSC&B-Lintas Worldwide, has been appointed chief executive officer. He succeeds William V. Weithas, 54, who remains chairman of SSC&B-Lintas Worldwide.

title: Bid by Heinsohn
description: Tommy Heinsohn wouldn't mind returning as coach of the Boston Celtics.

title: STAR CHOICE, $36, WINS METROPOLITAN
description: When John Veitch was replaced as the trainer for Calumet Farm last fall, he practically had to start his career over from scratch. Even after five years of successes with great horses like Alydar, Davona Dale and Before Dawn, Veitch had to begin putting together a public stable one horse at a time. He did not expect to be winning any major races for a while.

title: 5 More Are Arrested As Drunken Drivers
description: Five people were arrested and charged with driving while intoxicated or impaired by alcohol Sunday night and early yesterday in the citywide crackdown on drunken drivers, the police said. The crackdown continued last night.

title: LATVIAN MEMBER OF POLITBURO
description: The Soviet Union today announced the death of the oldest member of the ruling Politburo, Arvid Y. Pelshe, who was 84 years old and the only present leader to have participated in the 1917 Revolution.

title: Tilling Executive Turns Attention to Divestiture
description: Thomas Tilling P.L.C. is fighting to fend off a takeover bid from BTR P.L.C., another British conglomerate. The energy and industrial equipment company is far more accustomed to being acquirer than target, and Sir Patrick Meaney, Tilling's managing director, says the switch has created ''a strange and not very pleasant situation.''

title: Business and the Law; British-U.S.  Antitrust Rift
description: THE first $149 People Express flight from New York to London last week seemed to fly in the wake of Freddie Laker's Skytrain service, not only because of their low fares, but because both encountered the same international law problems.

title: Lime Rock Race To Tullius Team
description: Bob Tullius and Bill Adam jumped from the No.3 position and, taking advantage of a series of competitors' mishaps, drove their Jaguar XJR-5 to victory today in the Camel GT's Coca Cola 500 at Lime Rock Park.

title: BAYLOR'S VIEW: NOT A YANKEE YET
description: H e has been wearing his pin-striped uniform with the interlocked ''NY'' on the chest for nearly two months, but Don Baylor wisely doesn't consider himself a Yankee yet.

title: Books: Rating Authors
description: WRITERS IN AMERICA: THE FOUR SEASONS OF SUCCESS. By Budd Schulberg. 224 pages. Stein & Day. $16.95.

title: TEXT CIRCULATED WEEKS AGO
description: For weeks, Reagan Administration officials have insisted that at this summit conference, unlike others, there would be no final declaration drafted in advance. This time, they said, the communique would be written entirely at the talks.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1983; The Williamsburg Summit
description: The economic summit ended on a hopeful note, with the seven world leaders ''now clearly seeing signs of recovery.'' Without being specific, the final communique called for steps to reduce inflation, interest rates and budget deficits. In a tradeoff, the leaders agreed to the possibility of a conference on monetary changes, a French goal, and said budget deficits should be cut through lower expenditures, the Reagan view. (Page A1.)

title: SEXOLOGY STRUGGLING TO ESTABLISH ITSELF AMID WIDE HOSTILITY
description: Sexologists are struggling to enhance the scientific credibility and public acceptance of their research at a time when sexual studies and sex education in this country are under increasing attack.

title: Fumes Kill 3 Asleep in Car
description: Three men who had been drinking pulled to the side of the road to sleep and were found dead Sunday afternoon, apparently victims of carbon monoxide from the car's idling engine, the police said. The victims were identified as Douglas Wayne Kern, 26, of Knoxville, Tenn., and Norton, Va., and Lawrence Edgar Thacker, 22, and Edwin Lee Reeves, 25, both of Norton.

title: BRIEFING
description: Wiretapping Up

title: WEEKEND IN PARIS: THERE ARE JUNKETS AND JUNKETS
description: On this Memorial Day, there were probably more members of the United States Congress in France than in Washington. That often happens this time of year because this is the weekend of the Paris International Air Show. According to the official lists, there were at least 33 Senators and House members in France for this, the 35th show, at which aircraft manufacturers try to sell their wares, and often entertain lawmakers and prospective customers.

title: News Analysis
description: After three days of negotiations at the ninth annual economic summit conference, a profound gridlock over economic policy is apparent.

title: HOLIDAY PATROL:: WATCHING THE MAD RUSH
description: The officers who patrol the highways here know well that there are four holidays more ominous than all the rest - Memorial Day, the Fourth of July, Labor Day and the Christmas-New Year's period.

title: U.N. Says Haddad Men Killed a Fijian Soldier
description: A Fijian soldier in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon was killed during a gunbattle with members of Maj. Saad Haddad's Israeli-backed militia, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: TUCSON'S 24-HOUR PROJECT TO AID VICTIMS OF CRIME IS DRAWING NATIONAL ATTENTION
description: Last October, as 1,500 women and men marched to ''take back the night'' from rapists, 7-year-old Cathy Fritz said she was going next door to visit a girlfriend.

title: Addenda
description: * Working Woman magazine increases its circulation rate base 4.5 percent, to 575,000, with the July issue.

title: The Calendar
description: Tuesday

title: LEPROSY DECLINES IN CHINA BUT REMAINS FEARED
description: HAIKOU, China THE frail old woman sitting in the sun here in the capital of Hainan province hoisted the cuff of her black silk pajamas to display a welded steel tube that extended from her knee down into one faded brown canvas shoe. Her left leg had been amputated years ago after gangrene rotted it.

title: Chrysler Waits On Bond Issue
description: The Chrysler Corporation is waiting for interest rates to decline further before entering the bond market to begin repaying federally guaranteed loans, according to a company official.

title: TRAYNOR'S OTHER JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-SS Officer Confesses To Massacre in France
description: A former Nazi SS officer admitted at his trial today to rounding up French villagers and gunning them down before razing their village.

title: HOW LEADERS FARED ON POLITICAL AGENDA
description: None of the participants at the annual economic summit conferences ever admits to being a loser afterward, but the range of satisfaction with the conference outcomes varies greatly - and always in relation to the domestic political goals the individual leaders bring with them.

title: NEW YORK, JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT LEGISLATORS FACE KEY ISSUES
description: More than 300 bills have been passed by the Legislature and signed into law by Governor Kean during the two-year session that began in January 1982. However, many of the more difficult problems found to exist 18 months ago still await solution.

title: A Vice President Quits at Woolworth
description: Allan L. Pennington has resigned as executive vice president for marketing at the F.W. Woolworth Company. Joseph Carroll, Woolworth's vice president for public affairs, responding to trade reports, confirmed Mr. Pennington's resignation.

title: Letter: On Health Cost Reform; Medicaid Could Bankrupt Counties
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SOLO. An American Dreamer in Europe: 1933-34. By Wright Morris. 196 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Commodities; Index Said To Portend Price Rise
description: LAST week, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices moved firmly above the level of a year earlier. To many economists who watch the index it means that the 30-month slide in basic commodities prices has ended.

title: NICE GUYS GO TO JAIL
description: Everybody says that Joseph Margiotta is a wonderful guy - and there's no evidence to dispute this - so I think we should now all join in the current campaign for clemency to persuade the White House to spare him the two years in Federal prison for mail fraud and extortion that he is due to start serving tomorrow. That is, I think we should grant him his clemency just as soon as he pays back the money he owes us -$678,000 to be exact.

title: NEW YORK, JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT LEGISLATORS FACE KEY ISSUES
description: The New York State Legislature is returning to Albany Monday to confront some of the most politically charged issues of the 206th session: unemployment and Medicaid, rent control and stabilization, roads and pensions.

title: E.R. Dudley Jr.  And Miss Lopez Marry in Queens
description: Georgette Adrienne Lopez, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George A. Lopez of East Elmhurst, Queens, was married in the Episcopal Church of the Resurrection there yesterday to Edward Richard Dudley Jr., son of Justice and Mrs. Dudley of New York. Canon Kenneth E. MacDonald performed the ceremony.

title: Auburn Prison Inmate Stabbed During a Fight
description: An inmate of the Auburn Correctional Facility was stabbed and two other prisoners received minor injuries in a fight Sunday, the latest in a series of disturbances at the upstate maximum-security prison this month.

title: A HUMANE LOOK A BILINGUAL SCHOOLING
description: WHEN the Twentieth Century Fund recently urged that Federal money ''now going to bilingual programs be used to teach non-Englishspeaking children how to speak, read and write English,'' it reignited a smoldering old controversy. The recommendation implied that bilingual education has failed to promote fluency in English, and it underscored its criticism by calling it ''a grave error'' not to recognize ''the primacy of English.''

title: Why Poles but Not Salvadorans?
description: This is a story about a case of bureaucratic doubletalk, which is harmless, and a double standard, which is not. The doubletalk is ''extended voluntary departure,'' which means giving visitors to this country a port in a sudden storm. The double standard is that the United States gives such refuge to people from most of the world, but not to people from El Salvador. Why not?

title: AMERICAN PREREQUISITES FOR AN INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: Denise Dobyns Marries
description: Denise Dobyns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Dobyns of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Honig of Long Valley, N.J., son of Ann Honig of Elizabeth, N.J., and the late Jules Honig.

title: TV NETWORKS MAY END FULL CONVENTION COVERAGE
description: Gavel-to-gavel network television coverage of Presidential conventions may be a thing of the past. Representatives of all three major networks say they will cover what is essential, but probably not everything that takes place during the Democratic and Republican National Conventions next year.

title: SEOUL ENDS DISSIDENT'S DETENTION
description: The Government decided today to end the detention of a former opposition leader who has been on hunger strike for 13 days demanding the establishment of democratic rule and other changes.

title: Study Ties I.Q. Scores To Stress
description: Children who are under emotional or physical stress score 13 percent lower on intelligence tests than youngsters who are functioning virtually worry-free, two researchers say.

title: Carmel's Stahr Wins in 4:06.3
description: Mike Stahr of Carmel, N.Y., with the fastest mile by an American schoolboy this year, triumphed in the Eastern States track and field championships at Randalls Island yesterday. Stahr's time, 4 minutes 6.3 seconds, was also a record for the meet and a New York State public high school mark.

title: Military Analysis
description: The United States appears to be winning the race with Soviet antiaircraft defenses with its effort to produce Stealth bombers and cruise missiles virtually undetectable by radar.

title: PRETORIA AND LESOTHO TO HOLD TALKS ABOUT BORDER SEARCHES
description: The Foreign Ministers of South Africa and Lesotho will meet later this week to discuss the situation at border posts between the two countries, it was announced today.

title: CRAFTSMEN EXPRESS THEIR ART IN CLOTHES
description: ''I'm an artist who uses fabrics and dyes instead of canvas and paint, an artist who makes clothes,'' said Marian Clayden of Los Gatos, Calif.

title: FIGHTING FIRES IS NOT FOR MEN ONLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Elia Shoves Cameraman
description: A month ago, after Manager Lee Elia of the Cubs lashed out at the fans and the press, Dallas Green, the general manager, said Elia had almost lost his job and would be subject to day-by-day review. Yesterday, Elia strained the limits Green had set for him when he shoved a television cameraman following a 9-7 loss to Houston in Chicago, but again the manager emerged with his job. ''I heard both sides of the story, and I feel satisfied that the incident is over,'' Green said in a statement read by Cubs spokesman Bob Ibach.

title: C.I.A. SEES STAGNATION IN SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union's rigidly centralized economy is likely to muddle through the 1980's at a low growth rate but without danger of collapse, according to a Central Intelligence Agency analysis released today.

title: Natomas May Fight Takeover
description: Directors of the Natomas Company, scheduled to meet today in San Francisco, are expected to rebuff the Diamond Shamrock Corporation's $1.4 billion takeover offer for the West Coast energy company.

title: ASSOCIATION'S HEAD LOOKS BACK AS HE LEAVES
description: Ten years ago this month, Terry E. Herndon became executive director of the National Education Association at the age of 33. This week, still young enough to try a new career, he is leaving the organization to try his hand at other fields. In an interview in his office, just a few blocks from the White House, Mr. Herndon reflected on the changes he helped bring about in the organization, which serves as a professional society and union for 1.7 million educators, and on some of the problems still facing the nation's public schools.

title: MCDONNELL GETS SPAIN JET CONTRACT
description: After months of indecision over awarding the largest military contract to an outside supplier in Spanish history, the Government has decided to go ahead with the purchase of F-18A fighter planes from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez announced today.

title: Olympic Hockey Role For Fallon McElligott
description: Have you ever heard of a United States Olympic team or any segment thereof retaining an ad agency? You have now. Fallon McElligott Rice of Minneapolis is saying it is the agency for the United States Olympic hockey team, although the fact is that such a team will not even be picked until January.

title: COSTA RICANS SEEK BORDER OBSERVERS
description: Costa Rica asked the Foreign ministers of four Latin American countries today to establish a permanent observer team to monitor its border with Nicaragua.

title: MUSIC: PYLON AT THE RITZ
description: Like the more popular B-52's, who also hail from Athens, Ga., the rock quartet Pylon makes quirky dance rock that refers to 1960's television culture. Songs like ''Beep'' and ''No Clocks'' translate the surf music underpinnings from all-but-forgotten television themes into a bouncy, deliberately silly rock style that is made contemporary by carefully placed guitar dissonances and zany sound effects.

title: STAGE: 'FEN,' NEW WORK BY CARYL CHURCHILL
description: ''Fen,'' the new Caryl Churchill play at the Public, could well be called ''Bottom Girls.'' As the author's ''Top Girls'' told of Marlene, a self-made businesswoman who sells out her provincial working-class roots and humanity for corporate success in London, so the new one examines the less privileged sisters such top girls leave behind. The characters of ''Fen'' are downtrodden farmworkers in the Fens of East Anglia. Marlene would dismissively claim that these women deserve their fate because they're too ''lazy and stupid'' to claw their way up the economic ladder as she did. But in Miss Churchill's view, it's the Marlenes of contemporary England who callously keep the benighted poor in their lowly place.

title: OVERTIME HOURS OF CITY WORKERS
description: City employees worked fewer hours of overtime last year than in 1981, as more city agencies began cracking down on overtime abuse, according to a report issued yesterday by city officials.

title: WIDOWS IN CONVENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LONGER LIVES SEEN AS THREAT TO NATION'S BUDGET
description: Life expectancy in the United States is increasing so dramatically that taxpayers in coming years may have to come up with billions of additional dollars to support the aged, various experts told the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

title: SETH TOBIAS
description: Seth Tobias, executive vice president of Rosenfeld Sirowitz & Lawson, a Manhattan advertising agency, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE OTHER TALKS
description: A senior Administration official, taking a break from diplomatese, chose the word ''boring'' to describe the performance of French President Francois Mitterrand at the leaders' final working dinner.

title: TV'S WATCHING YOU
description: In ''1984,'' George Orwell writes, ''With the development of television, and the technical advance which made it possible to receive and transmit simultaneously on the same instrument, private life came to an end...'' Orwell's vision is coming true. Two-way cable television is a reality, with the mixed potential of convenience, economy and large-scale invasion of personal privacy.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All United States stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. Banks and government offices were also closed, as were many businesses.

title: ANGELS' STREAK ENDS AT SEVEN
description: Broderick Perkins's pinch-hit single with the bases loaded in the ninth inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 6-5 victory over California tonight and snapped the Angels' seven-game winning streak.

title: Next Time, Yell 'Fore!'
description: There was another unusual accident report from Britain, this one involving two amateur golfers who forgot to yell ''Fore!'' while chasing a would-be car thief.

title: 2 From Stix Sentenced
description: Two men convicted in a $16 million fraud at the now-defunct Stix & Company brokerage firm have been sentenced to prison and fined.

title: Dollar and Pound Up Sharply
description: The dollar and the pound rose sharply today on foreign exchange markets. The dollar reached record highs against the French franc and the lira.

title: PLAN FOR MESHING ECONOMICS IS BOLSTERED
description: Leaders of the industrialized world acted today to strengthen a little-known international mechanism intended to bring their economies into closer mesh.

title: Setback for Cooney
description: Gerry Cooney, the often-injured heavyweight contender, has had to withdraw from his scheduled June 18 comeback fight against Phillip Brown because of an injury to a knuckle on his left hand. For Cooney, it was another in a long line of postponements because of injuries.

title: Michele Falkow Is Married to Lewis R. Steinberg
description: Michele Falkow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Falkow of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Lewis R. Steinberg, son of Shirley Steinberg Sobel of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Alfred Steinberg. Rabbi Simon Glostrom of the Fair Lawn Jewish Center performed the ceremony at the Center for Inter-American Relations.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1983
description: International Greater unity in economic policies and more consultations to deal with erratic currency exchange rates that have battered West European economies were pledged by the leaders of the major industrial democracies. The seven Government leaders, ending their three-day summit conference in Williamsburg, Va., also said that further steps were needed to reduce trade barriers, narrow budget deficits and lower both inflation and interest rates. (Page A1, Cols. 4-6.) The P.L.O. leadership warned that its forces would strike back if any rebels in Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla group, tried to seize any of its installations in Lebanon. But a senior aide to Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., said the organization ''will not use arms against anyone in Damascus,'' where six Fatah supply depots have been seized. (A1:3.)

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Comserv Corp., Minneapolis, has elected Richard Daly chairman and Ted Priem as president.

title: IRISH LEADERS SEEK BLUEPRINT FOR REUNION
description: Nationalist leaders from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland met today to discuss the delicate task of designing a political framework for Irish unity.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
description: The recent violence between South Africa and its exiled opposition group, the African National Congress, represents a clear escalation of the fight against apartheid. It is not, however, a product of ''international terrorism,'' ''Soviet adventurism'' or any of the other ominous specters South Africa's leaders have tried to raise by waving the bloody shirt. Rather, it marks the predictable next step in a nationalist revolution that the South African regime itself has consistently prodded toward violence.

title: Economic Plan for Mexico
description: Mexico presented a four-point plan today intended to cut its reliance on borrowed money and reduce inflation and unemployment through increased productivity.

title: MORE VACATIONS PLANNED AS ECONOMY PICKS UP
description: There are strong signs of an end to the inhospitable economic period that caused many an American to put a freeze on major summer vacation trips, most travel industry specialists say.

title: STEEL TOWN WARY OF BRITISH
description: When it opened in 1951 on a bend in the Delaware River 30 miles north of Philadelphia, the United States Steel Corporation's Fairless Works created some 7,400 jobs, drawing thousands from depressed coal mining towns in upstate Pennsylvania and elsewhere. Many towns grew in its shadow, among them Levittown, Pa., whose 17,300 look-alike homes make up the world's largest, and most studied, planned suburban community.

title: MENTAL HEALTH PLANS COST COMPANIES LITTLE; Why the Deer Flags Its Tail
description: When a white-tailed deer is surprised in the wild by humans or animal predators it usually goes bounding off into the woods with its tail erect like a white semaphore. Wildlife scientists have long wondered exactly what effect this conspicuous display has on other deer or on an attacking predator, and have proposed several theories to explain the behavior called ''tail flagging.''

title: TEXT OF WILLIAMSBURG DECLARATION ON ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: Following is the text of the Williamsburg Declaration on Economic Recovery, issued today at the close of the ninth annual economic summit conference:

title: Bulletproof Vest Saves Officer
description: A Briarcliff Manor police officer was shot at this morning by the occupants of a car he stopped for a traffic violation, but he was not seriously injured because he was wearing a bulletproof vest, authorities said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: View From the Top

title: Supply System's Chief Joins Nuclear Company
description: Robert L. Ferguson, departing chief of the Washington Public Power Supply System, has a new job lined up for the fall. Mr. Ferguson, whose resignation for health reasons becomes effective Friday, will start Sept. 1 as chairman of U.N.C. Nuclear Industries, three miles from his supply system headquarters in Richland, Wash.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
GROWING CONCERN OVER RATES
description: "May is going to stand out in retrospect as the benchmark month - the month in which the whole psychology of the market changed," said Scott Winningham, economist at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a research firm that specializes in fixed-income securities. Indeed, in early May interest rates were at their lowest levels this month, and analysts were predicting they were heading lower.

title: Turkish Troops Reported To Battle Iraqi Kurds
description: Iraqi Kurdish rebels said today that an advance by the Turkish Army into Iraq trapped between 20,000 and 30,000 Kurdish civilians in remote border areas.

title: MUSIC: LOEB, ON CLARINET, PLAYS BRAHMS
description: The clarinetist Fred Loeb plays with intelligence and musicality. His Sunday evening concert at Symphony Space made for a nourishing experience.

title: People
description: * John Eighmey has been named a senior vice president of Young & Rubicam USA.

title: MENTAL HEALTH PLANS COST COMPANIES LITTLE
description: EMPLOYERS or insurance companies would face only a small increase in costs if they offered full mental health coverage to participants in health care plans, a group of Rand Corporation researchers have reported.

title: HOWARD, ON BICYCLE, SETS 24-HOUR MARK
description: Having fought driving rains, broken glass along the Central Park course and shadowy mirages in the dark, John Howard established a world 24-hour distance record of 514 miles yesterday in the Pepsi Challenge Bicycle Marathon.

title: Dr. Avram Kisselgoff, Ex-Economist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Avram Kisselgoff, former chief economist of the Allied Chemical Corporation, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Driver Is Killed
description: Todd Noffsinger, the youngest of three racing brothers, died Sunday night as a result of a three-car crash in the California Racing Association's sprint-car feature at Ascot Park. The 20-year-old driver was apparently unbuckling his seat belt after his car had come to rest, when it clipped a vehicle that had spun in front of him. A third car then knocked him from his car.

title: N.Y.U. to Play 26 Basketball Games
description: A little more than three months after New York University announced the revival of its varsity basketball program, which had been dormant since 1971, the Violets are making steady progress toward competing next season as a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III team.

title: WORDS AND NUMBERS COMBINED IN A PROGRAM
description: NUMERIC nomenclature abounds in the personal computing field. With such labels as ACS 8000-10, TRS-80, VX128 and TI 99/4A in the vanguard of technology, one can't help but wonder what is to come for us mere mortals. After all, the Middle Ages, wherein arose the custom of adopting surnames because just one name was deemed too imprecise, are relatively recent in the span of man's history; and not very long ago, I was nearly denied a rental car in Las Vegas because, adhering to the original intent of Congress that the Social Security number not be used for identification purposes, I objected to the appendage of my number to my name as further proof of my identity.

title: Quilting Problem
description: Jeanetta Holder of Plainfield, Ind., celebrated her birthday yesterday, the day she came to the Indianapolis Motor Speedway for her annual presentation. Mrs. Holder has followed the race for 30 years, and since 1976, she has made a large quilt for the winning driver and his family. On Monday, she learned that Indianapolis controversies are not limited to the competitors.

title: Lucille F. Schoettle Weds Carlo Novi
description: Lucille Ford Schoettle, daughter of Mrs. Curt Buhler of New York and the late Ferdinand Paul Schoettle of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Carlo Alessandro Novi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Giancarlo Novi of Mexico City and San Diego. The Rev. Julian Nagy of the Hungarian First Reformed Church performed the ceremony at the rooftop pavilion at Manhattan House, an apartment complex.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MASTER HAND

title: Medal of Honor Winner Says He Doesn't Want Charity Aid
description: A Vietnam War hero who has been denied Social Security disability pay said today that White House aides had told him President Reagan wanted to help him through private aid groups, but he declared, ''I don't want charity.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Closing on 'Swing Street'

title: Canadian Winner At Somerville
description: Steve Bauer, a Canadian, set an American record for 50 kilometers today in winning the 40th annual Tour of Somerville bicycle race.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''I T used to be so emotional,'' said Harriet Cain, one of the editors of Mademoiselle, as she rode the elevator down to street level after selecting, with a group of the city's leading fashion editors, this year's Coty Award winners at the Plaza Hotel. ''Vogue would end up hating Bazaar. Bazaar would hate everyone. And by the end, we'd all hate each other. It was so much fun.'' She sighed, and the doors of the elevator exhaled and opened.

title: EX-MILITARY COMMANDER OF NATO
description: Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, a key officer on the Eisenhower staff in World War II who became the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Supreme Military Commander from 1953 to 1956, died of pneumonia at 6 A.M. yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, the Defense Department said. He was 84 years old.

title: YANKS COMPLETE 4-GAME SWEEP
description: Amid the Yankees' most productive offensive display of the season, their cleanup batter was asked to bunt twice yesterday, a highly unusual practice. But Don Baylor executed both bunts perfectly, and the second produced a run in the six-run rally in the eighth inning that vaulted the Yankees to a 10-5 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: FILM: OPHULS'S 'LIEBELEI' OPENS AT PUBLIC THEATER
description: ''Liebelei'' was shown as part of the 12th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center in 1974. Following are excerpts from a review by Nora Sayre that appeared in The New York Times of Sept. 30, 1974. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: STUDY OF PRODUCTIVITY IMPLIES A DIM FUTURE
description: It takes two musician-hours to play a Mozart quartet. This is exactly the same as was required two centuries ago when the work was written. The modern technological era has brought higher and higher productivity to many fields, but live concerts are one activity where virtually no such growth could be achieved.

title: INDY COULD USE LIVE COVERAGE
description: T he delayed telecast of the Indianapolis 500 Sunday night was another reason why the race should be televised live. For the first two and a half hours of the three-hour show, ABC tried a variety of production techniques to pump interest and excitement into a race that was relatively safe and uneventful and where many viewers already knew the outcome.

title: 2 FOR CHINAGLIA
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who thrives on foreign teams, especially those from his native Italy, scored two goals today as the Cosmos beat Fiorentina, 4-1, in the opening game of the fourth annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup.

title: 'Too Much Too Soon'
description: Hepatitis helped cause a double-stress foot fracture, which might be a medical record of sorts.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees, swept by the Angels on the West Coast last week, seek to reverse the result at home, with Shane Rawley facing Bill Travers in the first game of the series.

title: HOW CARNEGIE HALL HAS EVOLVED INTO A 'BUSINESS'
description: A would-be donor once decided to give Carnegie Hall a huge organ, the installation of which would have required breaking into the walls of the venerable hall. Isaac Stern, president of Carnegie Hall, happened to be on tour when the offer was made and accepted.

title: 4 Killed in Crash Of Plane on L.I.
description: A single-engine plane carrying four people crashed a quarter mile short of a runway at Republic Airport on Long Island yesterday morning, killing all aboard.

title: End of Frustration Is Looming for 76ers
description: They are about as different as two good friends can be. One is quiet and reserved to the point, even he will admit, of being almost dull. The other is open and talkative, a willing participant in almost any conversation.

title: SOCCER FIGURES CRITICIZE PELE
description: The Brazilian soccer star Pele, universally recognized as the greatest player the game has ever seen and long an idol in his own country, has become the target of unaccustomed personal attacks here from two major sports figures.

title: A.M.C. Price Rise
description: The American Motors Corporation said it had raised the price of certain Renault Alliance models by about $100, or 1.2 percent. The two-door L model rose to $6,220 and the DL went up to $6,855. The four-door DL increased to $7,105 and the Limited model climbed to $7,670.

title: TOWN BATTLES MEMORIAL DAY APATHY
description: One day about two weeks ago, Mike Colalillo heard that somebody had toppled the 27-foot flagpole at the War Memorial here. He could believe it -vandals had stolen 20 flags from the memorial over the years - but it angered him nonetheless.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have strengthened our resolve to deal cooperatively with continuing problems so as to promote a sound and sustainable recovery, bringing new jobs and a better life for the people of our own countries and of the world.'' - From the Williamsburg Declaration on Economic Recovery. (A1:6.)

title: Chess: Seirawan Takes First Place In the Lugano Tournament
description: Yasser Seirawan, a Seattle grandmaster, won the eigth Lugano International Open Tournament in Switzerland with a 7 1/2-1 1/2 score.

title: Vietnamese Refugee, 17, Leads Pensacola Class
description: A Vietnamese refugee who spoke no English when she came to the United States eight years ago is now the valedictorian of her high school's senior class with a perfect 4.0 grade average.

title: SENDING ANTS INTO ORBIT PUTS 2 SCHOOLS IN CAMDEN ON CLOUD 9
description: Some morning soon, it's going to be Code Red in the ant colony. There will be a huge explosion of liquid hydrogen and oxygen and solid fuel beneath the unsuspecting ants, hurtling them 180 miles into the air and flinging them around and around the earth at 17,500 miles an hour. Gravity will be lost. What will happen to the them biologically and to their sophisticated social structure, no one knows - which is why they are being sent into space.

title: Homage To America
description: The Indianapolis 500, the track announcer did not hesitate to claim, is ''the world's greatest sporting event.'' The usual crowd of better than 350,000 people, Archbishop Edward P. O'Marra informed Heaven in his invocation, is ''the largest annual human gathering'' in the United States.

title: DAVID OWEN FIGHTING FOR POLITICAL LIFE
description: The young man told David Owen that he was worried about the Labor Party's winning the general election because ''they're so weak on the Falklands and on defense.'' He said he guessed that he would have to vote Conservative.

title: Sneva's Triumph Is Made Official
description: Tom Sneva's first victory in the Indianapolis 500 became official this morning when the United States Auto Club announced its standing for Sunday's race.

title: Britons Raid Irish Homes
description: British troops today raided the homes of 20 campaign workers for Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's legal political wing, and the police briefly detained Martin McGuinness, a Sinn Fein candidate for Parliament, for flying the Irish Republic's flag from his car as he campaigned.

title: LABOR UNIONS TROUBLED BY DROP IN MEMBERS
description: Many of the nation's labor unions, including some that provided much of the labor movement's strength for decades, are incurring large membership losses.

title: U.S. and Manila Ready To Sign Pact on Bases
description: The United States and the Philippines will sign a new multimillion-dollar, five-year agreement governing the use of two of America's largest overseas military bases, it was announced today.

title: FREIGHT TRAFFIC THAT CAN'T DO WITHOUT RAILS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. UNION AWAITS TOYOTA
description: For most of the 20 years that the General Motors Corporation's sprawling car and truck assembly plant operated here along the southeastern rim of San Francisco Bay, it was important to this community's economy - but not all-important.

title: Light Offering of New Issues Likely
description: The bearish mood caused by the $2.1 billion jump in the basic money supply, coupled with the increased number of Treasury auctions, will probably keep the calendar of new corporate and municipal issues light this week.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Education, to the 6th Degree

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Biblical Botany

title: Susan Bolotin, Editor, Wed to John Rothman
description: Susan Bolotin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Bolotin of Sharon, Pa., was married yesterday to John Mahr Rothman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Rothman of Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ronne Friedman at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: Union Ends Strike At Jersey Casino
description: Striking dealers and croupiers returned to their jobs at Bally's Park Place here today, ending the nation's first such walkout, management officials said.

title: ROBOT TO HELP HANDICAPPED
description: A one-armed robot that responds to voice commands has been developed to prepare meals and perform other household chores for quadriplegics and elderly people crippled by arthritis, a researcher said today.

title: Landon Gets Pins in Hip After a Fall at His Home
description: Alf M. Landon, former Republican Presidential candidate, emerged from hip surgery today in good condition, but was placed in intensive care for 24 hours, a hospital official said.

title: Census Bureau Reports Drop in Voter Turnout
description: The Census Bureau reports that voter interest has been slipping steadily in recent years. One of the smallest national turnouts in decades was recorded in the 1980 election when 53.2 percent of those old enough to vote took part in the contest in which Ronald Reagan was elected President.

title: Advertising; Retailers' Search for An Identity
description: LIKE the producers of packaged goods, soap and toothpaste some years ago, the nation's department stores today are plagued by a lack of distinction and a failure to project their identity to the public.

title: F.A.A. CALLS FOR IMPROVED FLIGHT DATA DEVICES
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Lynn Helms, has taken steps to require improved flight data recorders on as many as 2,000 standard-width airliners operated in this country.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS' WISH FOR PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: RACIAL ISSUES RAISED IN ROBBERY CASE
description: The old road sign heralding this town as the home of ''The Blackest Land - The Whitest People'' has been gone for 16 years. A sprawling research center for E-Systems, a leading military and electronics contractor, has helped erode the isolation of what is now a town of 25,000 people 55 miles northeast of Dallas.

title: OFFICIAL WHO OVERSAW WORK ON CONVENTION CENTER QUITS
description: The official in charge of overseeing work on New York City's Convention Center and other major construction projects for the state's Urban Development Corporation has resigned, the agency's chairman said yesterday.

title: Music Festival Crowd Becomes Rowdy at End
description: A ''wild'' crowd hurled rocks and bottles and tore down fences early today at the US Festival in another outbreak of the sporadic violence that has left one person dead. A security guard suffered a fractured skull in a fight with other guards, officials at the outdoor concert said.

title: MUSIC: 200 SINGERS IN JEWISH FESTIVAL
description: At the end of the American Jewish Choral Festival concert in Merkin Hall Sunday night, the audience stood and joined more than 200 singers from 7 Jewish choruses from Washington, Philadelphia, Connecticut, New York, Long Island and Boston in singing ''Hatikva'' - the Israeli national anthem.

title: ONE KILLED AS A NEVADA MUD SLIDE FLOODS LAKES AND DESTROYS HOMES
description: A waterlogged mountain gave way today and sent a 15-foot wall of water and mud barreling through a recreational area crowded with Memorial Day picnickers, killing at least one person and injuring several people.

title: GAIN SEEN IN NATURAL GAS DECONTROL
description: Signs are developing that there may be action on an ambitious plan that the Reagan Administration presented to Congress in March to completely remove wellhead price controls on natural gas.

title: Oerter Keeps Up
description: At the age of 46, Al Oerter still follows competition in the discus throw carefully. He has good reason. The man who won four gold medals in that event in Olympic Games competition from 1956 to 1968 will attempt to qualify for the United States team next year in Los Angeles.

title: The U.N. Today; May 31, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ARE CLEVER ANIMALS ACTUALLY THINKING?
description: HOLDING a small feather in the tip of its bill, the heron patrols the edge of the brook, scanning the shallow water. Suddenly it freezes and focuses its attention on a small area of the stream. Then it deliberately drops the feather on that spot. A small fish rises to the feather lure and, in a flash, the heron strikes, catches the minnow and gulps it down.

title: News Analysis
description: The conference on European security and cooperation, a diplomatic game of chess between East and West that has gone on for more than two and a half years, seems to be entering its end game. Yet it remains unclear whether the players can avoid a stalemate.

title: Barnard Student Is a Suicide
description: A 21-year-old Barnard College student, Carolyn Belle Oscar, committed suicide yesterday by jumping from the eighth-floor terrace of her dormitory at 620 West 116th Street, the police said. They said that the woman, who had been suffering from depression, leaped from the building at 1 P.M.

title: Skip the Debt Limit Dance
description: A minor reform: Let's abolish the annual dance of the debt ceiling. Politicians delight in nailing each other for voting to raise the debt, we know, but they always eventually have to, to keep the Government functioning. The hours and ink thus consumed would be better used dealing with the deficits.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a misunderstanding of information provided by the National Institutes of Health, an article Friday on Emory University incorrectly listed the amount of aid the institutes gave in 1979 to the Clinical Research Facility at Emory's School of Medicine. It was $721,014.

title: IS A WORM LINKED TO PREGNANCY AILMENT?  NEW STUDY DOUBTS IT
description: ANEWLY published report from Britain rebuts an earlier claim made by researchers in Illinois that a common and often fatal disease called toxemia of pregnancy is caused by a tiny worm.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: No Headline
description: Charlotte Curtis Very Social New York Week

title: 3 Aluminum Companies Sign Pacts With Unions
description: The nation's three biggest aluminum companies have signed a new contract with the United Steelworkers of America providing 25,900 workers with no more pay but a 3.6 percent increase in benefits, a union spokesman said today.

title: IMMIGRATION LAW SHOULDN'T KEEP FAMILIES APART
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK, JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT LEGISLATORS FACE KEY ISSUES
description: Connecticut's General Assembly must adjourn by June 8, according to the State Constitution, and legislative leaders say they are determined to meet that goal - even if it takes all summer.

title: Massey Reports Deficit
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian heavy-equipment maker, has reported a loss of $17.9 million for its first quarter, ended April 30, compared with a $25.7 million loss a year before. Revenues dropped 27.7 percent, to $403.3 million.

title: Muscle and Teeth for Fair Housing
description: Though Federal law has prohibited it since 1968, much housing discrimination persists. What's the best way to strengthen the law?

title: Second Thoughts
description: The Cleveland Browns may lose a second-round draft choice, Ron Brown, a wide receiver from Arizona State.

title: JOHN WILLIAMS, OLE MISS HEAD IN DESEGREGATION CRISIS IN '62
description: John Davis Williams, the chancellor of the University of Mississippi when it went through its desegregation crisis in 1962, died at his home in Oxford, Miss., Sunday after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Q&A
description: How close to a color television set is it safe to sit? A.

title: Bridge: Cohen and Bergen Capture Goldman by Wide Margin
description: Age and youth were involved in one of the world's most famous bridge events - the Goldman pairs - which ended Sunday night at the Sheraton Centre Hotel in New York.

title: OLD MECHANIC WINS THE 500 ONCE MORE
description: INDIANAPOLIS T he morning after one of his greatest moments, there was still another race for George Bignotti to prepare for. He would hear many more congratulations, and there would be many pictures to smile for and a victory dinner to attend. But there were also endorsements to discuss, and one of his cars had a broken windshield that had to be replaced in time for a race in less than two weeks, and a quick paint job had to be done on the nose of the car that Tom Sneva drove into Victory Lane on Sunday.

title: GIANTS ROUT ALLEN
description: Neil Allen's brief career as a starting pitcher ended today after he lasted less than five innings while the Mets were being shut out for the third time in the last eight games.

title: VANDALS DO THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS OF DAMAGE TO SCHOOL IN BROOKLYN
description: Vandals broke into a Brooklyn elementary school over the weekend, and smashed plumbing, smeared paint on walls and stole thousands of dollars worth of typewriters, electronic equipment and food, school officials said.

title: Earth's Chills and Fevers
description: Elmar Reiter, a scientist at Colorado State University in Fort Collins, has been recording the temperature of the earth in 60 different spots in the United States for the past several years. He is testing a Chinese theory that when the temperature of the soil in any area is higher than normal in the winter, the following summer will be wetter than normal.

title: MacNamara, Clapp Works for Royal Silk
description: For its fifth piece of new business of 1983, MacNamara, Clapp & Klein has signed with Royal Silk, for which it will be doing ''a dramatic new television effort.''

title: GAS RATIONING COUPONS POSE DISPOSAL PROBLEM
description: For months now, Ronald L. Winkler has been absorbed by a problem whose solution appears so simple and yet is so elusive that one wonders how the Government manages to successfully tackle anything as difficult as, say, writing its paychecks.

title: MISS AUSTIN IS UPSET BY BRITON
description: The first visit to the French Open by a member of the British royal family coincided today with one the country's finest victories here, Jo Durie's 6-1, 4-6, 6-0 quarterfinal upset of Tracy Austin.

title: ARTIFICIAL VACCINE: A POWERFUL MEDICAL PROMISE
description: In recent laboratory experiments, scientists have tested vaccines that are totally artificial for protection against the viruses of such diseases as hepatitis, polio and the widespread infection of animals called foot and mouth disease. Experts now believe such synthetic products may have a revolutionary effect on the use of vaccines in public health.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Campaigns In a Turbulent Kashmir
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi opened a three-day campaign tour today in the northern Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, where an estimated 1,000 people were injured in clashes on Sunday, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: 'S.&P. 500' Unit Trust
description: A unit trust composed of stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was approved Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The units will go on sale Tuesday.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE DECLARATION
description: 1 THE FRAMEWORK: The policy goals of the seven leaders meeting in Williamsburg will be low inflation and interest rates, and more investment and jobs, especially for the young.

title: IN WEST BANK, HUMILIATION AS AN ISRAELI WEAPON
description: Occupied West Bank - One night in April, after a stone was thrown at an Israeli patrol in this nationalistic Arab town, Pvt. Arthur Kutcher of the Israeli Army Reserves was assigned to help guard a detail of Israeli border policemen who administered punishment.

title: Nuptials for Eve R. Cohen
description: Eve Rebecca Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of Brooklyn, and Jeffrey Bruce Hausler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Hausler of Parlin, N.J., were married yesterday in the garden of the Renaissance Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I., by Rabbi Arnold Marrans.

title: THE OLD FISHIN' HOLE IS A CHEMISTRY SET
description: I'd like to invite William D. Ruckelshaus, the new head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to come fishing with me. Unfortunately, if he accepted, he might be risking his life. Let me tell you what I mean.

title: IRT DERAILMENT LAID TO FLANGES ON OLD WHEELS
description: The subway derailment that sent hundreds fleeing from a smoky Times Square station last Thursday afternoon occurred on a stretch of track that had been repaired that morning, according to a preliminary report by the Transit Authority.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (AL) - Recalled Keith C reel, pitcher, from Omaha of the Ameri- c an Association. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Placed Steve H owe, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list.

title: P.L.O. AIDE WARNS REBELS ON SEIZING BASES IN LEBANON
description: A senior aide to Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that its forces would ''fiercely strike back'' if any rebels in Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group, sought to seize any of its installations in Lebanon.

title: THE SOVIET 500,000
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS HONOR THEIR WAR DEAD
description: Early yesterday, William Tyler walked outside the balloon store he owns on Metropolitan Avenue in Queens and tied American-flag balloons to some parking meters, in honor of the Forest Hills Memorial Day Parade.

title: Volkswagen Results
description: Volkswagen posted a loss of $40 million on auto operations for the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $22 million a year earlier. It cited depressed sales in the United States and in much of Europe.

title: A CLUE TO THE DECLINE OF ROME
description: A chemical analysis of skeletons of Romans killed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79 indicates that, although they were generally healthy and well-nourished people, some of them may have suffered chronic lead poisoning, an American archeologist reported here today.

title: Ballesteros Wins British P.G.A.
description: Severiano Ballesteros shot a 1-over-par 71 for 278 and a 2-stroke victory in the British P.G.A. golf championship today.

title: Text of declaration, page D14.
description: Leaders of the major industrial democracies, ending their three-day summit conference on a hopeful note, declared today that ''we now clearly see signs of recovery.''

title: Market Place; Still No Letup In Bull Market
description: LAST August, when the budding rally in stock prices was only two sessions old and investors kept wondering if it was genuine, Albert M. Wojnilower of the First Boston Corporation forecast sharp declines ahead for interest rates. A day later, Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers weighed in with similar views and the bull market in equities, armed with the welcome opinions of Wall Street's two most prominent economists, was off and sprinting.

title: NANCY RYAN HOLMES
description: Nancy Ryan Holmes, a featured actress in Broadway comedies of the late 1920's and 30's, died May 23 in Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital after a long illness.
